It didn't look like fun. On the way up, at a pullout above the treeline, we stopped for a breakfast of muffins and coffee, and took pictures of the great view of Maui, with Molokai and Lanai across the channel.  I'll attach a couple pictures if Wen ever finds the roll of film and gets it developed!  While we were enjoying the view, we were passed by many other guided cycling groups on their way downhill.  They'd all got up at 2am, driven to the top and watched the sunrise before heading downhill after daylight.  Standing in the cold and dark at 10,000' for 4 hours before the ride made me very glad we chose the day tour instead of the sunrise tour.  We continued up the mountain and entered the gates of the National Park.  The road continues up for another 10 miles to the crater overlook and visitor center.  If you do a self-guided tour, you must start outside the park boundary.  Only guided tours can ride within the park. After taking in the spectacular view of the crater and dodging the Japanese tourists, we put on our gear and got our bikes.  Most of the people in our group of 12 or so hadn't been on a bike in a couple months (if then).  We wore dirt bike helmets, a jacket and gloves, all provided by the tour company.  The bikes are specially made for this route.  They are modified 1-speed beach cruisers that weigh about 45 lbs and have drum brakes on both front an rear wheels.  Very stable at speed, with big wide seats.  Bob pointed out that these bikes were much more stable and safe on the downhill run than your average lightweight road bike.  A couple turns around the parking lot, then we were ready to go.   Bob put us in order, with the lightest (and cutest) rider right behind him (Wendy), and successively heavier riders following, with the biggest guy at the end.  We were given instructions to keep our position in the order, and keep constant spacing behind the rider ahead of us.  Bob also explained a few hand signals, and what we would do to let following vehicles pass us.  The van followed behind us as a SAG, communicating with Bob via radio, and blocking overtaking traffic.  Then we took off down the mountain.  Whoa!  It was steep, and we picked up speed fast.  About 3 miles down there is a sharp left.  Bob called a halt, lined us up again and showed us the cliff below the turn.  The Park Service has every group stop at this turn because too many riders didn't negotiate the turn at speed and went airborne off the cliff.  It was a nice break, where we all caught our breath, relaxed a little, and got ready for the rest of the trip.  We were very lucky with the weather.  Sometimes the summit is wreathed in clouds, so you are rolling down in cold and fog, but for our trip, it was clear, sunny and warm.  Then we were off again, screaming downhill on switchback after switchback.  The map of the route is at http://tinyurl.com/7a5hf We stopped for lunch at the Sunrise Protea Flower Farm in Kula.  We'd done the first 20 miles in less than an hour.  Lunch was provided, and you had your choice of sandwiches or salads, all good.  They had a wide variety of Proteas growing in the garden.  They are big, strange, showy flowers. http://www.sunriseprotea.com/  After lunch, we headed on downhill.   Six miles later, just outside the town of Makawao, we had to stop, load the bikes in the trailer and jump in the van for a detour through the town.  There was some road construction, but I think it was also because the townspeople don't like all the bike tourists.  At this point, the flakey Aussie realized he'd left his fanny pack with wallet, money and camera at the lunch stop.  Bob called them, and his pack had been found and was in safekeeping.  Since we had to drive back up there, we all voted to repeat the ride down from there, so it turned out OK.   The drive up seemed to take a lot longer than the ride down! On the outskirts of Makawao, we remounted our bikes and headed down Baldwin Ave for the last leg of the trip.  We rode through the small town of Paia and turned left onto the Hana Highway.  A little further on was our last stop, at a beach park.  We all walked out to the beach to take a few pictures, then got back in the van for the ride back to the office.  From there they drove us back to our condo, arriving about 4pm. This is a fun ride, with great views, and you don't have to be a cyclist to enjoy it - I don't think I had to pedal more than a few times in the whole trip.  I liked the convenience of the hotel pick up and delivery, and that breakfast and lunch were included, as were all the clothing and equipment, including bikes.  I hope you have a great time, too. 
There are lots of intriguing routes in the DC area - check http://bikewashington.org - but I'd promised myself when I did the "W&ODCO" route last year that I would do the Mount Vernon Trail.  Wendy is a new cyclist, and, although she's enthusiastic and athletic, she hadn't had much time to practice.  A couple weeks before this trip we had coasted 40+ miles down Haleakala in Maui, but that hardly counts as practice.   The Mount Vernon Trail starts on Theodore Roosevelt Island in DC, crosses over to Arlington, VA and then follows the Virginia bank of the Potomac past National Airport and "Olde Town" Alexandria to Mount Vernon 18 miles away.  I didn't think Wen could handle a 36-mile round trip, so I decided to start in Alexandria.  We'd briefly toured there last year and it looked much more historic and quaint than Arlington and Rosslyn. On Monday we drove from Baltimore via a sightseeing stop at Annapolis, MD to Alexandria, VA where we checked into the Travelodge.  It turned out to be a nice motel across the street from a "Trader Joe's" and within walking distance of old town.  We walked down to Big Wheel Bikes to see what rentals they had, and arrange for tomorrow's trip. Tuesday morning we were up late - the shop didn't open till 11am.  Stopped at the taqueria across the street for breakfast burritos, then drove to the bike shop.  I found that the trail is paved all the way, so we picked out bikes with skinny tires.  The shop is 1 block away from the trail, so we were out of there and on our way by 11:40am.  A map of our route is at http://tinyurl.com/7k7sw It was a sunny day with temperatures in the 80's.  I was dismayed that I'd left my sunscreen behind and worried about getting sunburned.  But not a chance, the trail goes through the woods and is shaded for most of the way.   We stopped for a water break at a park just south of Alexandria, where we had a chat with a runner who was also taking a break.  It's a small world.  He has a son in Kula, Maui, which we'd just visited two weeks before, and he is planning to come out to my town of Scottsdale, AZ for the "Rock and Roll Marathon" in January. Although the trail stays close to the shore of the river, and thus is fairly flat, Mount Vernon is aptly named.  GW put his house on the top of a hill    with a magnificent view to the north overlooking the Potomac.     As we made the winding climb for the last couple miles to the house, I realized that I hadn't rented a lock with the bikes.  Once again, I was worried about nothing.  The main gate is familiar with this problem, and has a stock of bike locks that they'll rent you for a dollar.  We paid our entrance fees, locked up the bikes, and went on a tour of the grounds.  There are warning signs up that they reserve the right to search your bags, but they didn't bother to check my backpack. We got some stares from the other tourists as we were decked out in our bike shorts and jerseys.    We spent a couple hours in the grounds and took the tour through the house.  It was a Tuesday afternoon and luckily for us, there were no lines.  On the tour I learned two interesting things: the house is made of wood, painted and grooved to look like stone, and George Washington died of asphyxiation due to swelling of his throat in a short, acute illness.  If they'd known to do a tracheotomy, he "would be alive today";)   The pear trees in the garden were loaded with pears, but I couldn't find the cherry tree he'd cut down.  On our way out we stopped for a drink at the new snack bar and browsed the gift shop.  I was looking to buy a jar of cherry jam from the tree George chopped down, but they didn't have any.  Sounds to me like a great marketing opportunity missed. After we turned in our rented bike lock, we headed for home.  When we stopped to take some photos, Wendy remarked that the ride home was a lot easier than the ride there.       For one thing, the first couple miles were downhill, and on the return, we were familiar with the route.   Before long, we were back at the bike shop to return the bikes.  I told the shopkeeper that it had been perfect weather for the ride, and the only problem was that the route was too short.  He told me we could have extended the round trip by 6 miles by continuing to George Washington's Gristmill three miles West of Mount Vernon http://www.dcr.virginia.gov/parks/georgewa.htm.  Oh, well, something for next time.    Resource: "Mount Vernon Trail, George Washington Memorial Parkway" in Bicycle Touring 
I wound up starting out just before sunrise, I wanted to get some miles in before the traffic got hairy. Temp was 54 degrees with a light fog. It felt COLD! The entire ride was done against a headwind varying between 10 and 15 mph. As the day progressed, the clouds and light fog burned off into a glorious sunny afternoon with 69 degrees as a high. I hit the wall about the 90 mile point and was getting pretty discouraged, but decided to continue after the wife reminded me I didn't have to do this if I didn't want to, that it was fine if I quit (Man, I hate it when she uses that word, it's a spur in the ol' side if ya know what I mean! ) I ran through a couple of really nice towns (Townships?) around the west side of North Manchester. One was called Ijamsville, and the other was Lakewood. The Lakewood FD was out and offered me water and Gatorade, nice guy's! I was using primarily liquid nutrition this ride and my sugars held up really well! I did get close to bonking, and that's why I was a bit discouraged. I pushed a bit too hard, I think, but still made it. This was a new high mileage day for me. It feels great, and I'm still feeling pretty trashed, but recovering well. Hydration went well and I hit Syracuse hungry as a bear! All evening and most of today, I've been nibbling and drinking fluids. MY average speed was 14.52 MPH. Not bad for an old middleaged fart! http://xs306.xs.to/xs306/06370/ridepic.jpg.xs.jpg http://xs306.xs.to/xs306/06385/SpandexButt.jpg.xs.jpg Click on the links to get the images as I can't seem to get them uploaded! Can't find the upload option! The link in the title bar is a larger version of the frontal shot, taken at the 135 mile point in the ride. They are hosted at http://xs.to/
Yesterday was a soaker.  The red cliffs around Moab sprang rust colored waterfalls all around.  Rivers ran where before I had seen only desert.  The ground was soaked. If this keeps up, Canyonlands National Park will merge with Grand Canyon and Arches will erode to a pile of red gravel. Overhead was gray to black just before sunrise but the full moon looked through a wide clearing in the western sky. Would I even go on this ride? Moab Century Tour is a charity event benefiting the Lance Armstrong Foundation held each October in Moab, Utah.  Of the three ride venues, I had chosen the 65 mile route up into the LaSal Mountains.  This route gains about a thousand feet in the first 21 miles and then turns viscious with 'The Big Nasty', a 7 mile stretch that climbs another 3000 plus.      I had tried this route two years earlier on my Tour Easy, a long wheelbase recumbent bicycle.  It whipped my tail.  I walked the early steeper grades and eventually opted to take the SAG wagon to the summit.  This time, I brought my Greenspeed recumbent trike.  If my Tour Easy performs like a Bentley, the trike is my Hum V.   Knowing I would not be speedy, I had considered starting on the route before the mass start at 8:00 AM.  It is a ride, not a race, so early starts are okay.  That is why I was up before the sun that morning.  But, the dark skies delayed the morning light and I did not consider it safe to ride without lights until about 7:45.  Riding past the starting point, I decided to fall in with the rest of the riders at the mass start.  Following the usual opening comments and introduction of dignitaries, the ride started officially at about 8:10.  I should have gone early.  Pedaling my low-slung trike at wheel and leg level, I worked my way to the street.  The pack followed a police escort up Main Street to downtown where it turned off east and spread out a little.  I read the grade as a steady 2 to 4 percent on my GPS but without reliable vertical and horizontal references, it looked level.  Another recumbent cycle, a white Tour Easy Gold Rush, passed me like it was on auxiliary power.  I did not see it again.  The sun remained behind the clouds lingering over the mountains but the rest of the sky was definitely clearing. The first of the aid stations consisted of water cans and Porta-Potties.  I waited in line about ten minutes with other cyclists anxious to off-load their morning coffee.  On the road again, the first steep grade came into view winding up the side of a bluff (cliff).  This piece made a pedestrian of me the last time I was here. Swinging around a right angle turn, I dropped the trike into its absolute granny gear and slid into turtle mode.  Speed dropped to 2 miles per hour but I was pedaling, not walking.  It was about one half mile of 15 percent grade called 'The Little Nasty.'  Regular bikes passed me, the riders huffing above my low-riding trike.  I smiled.  I was not huffing.  I was slow but not breathless.   The second aid station was atop that grade.  While I rehydrated and wolfed down a cookie and fruit, I saw some riders starting down the hill I just climbed, heading back to Moab.  Others queued to bus to the summit with their bikes in the SAG trailer.  The cycle traffic was much thinner as the next leg began.  A mile or two of 4 to 6 percent slope preceded the start of Big Nasty proper.  Rounding a corner, I saw the road ahead slicing up the side of the mountain, a long constant 14 to 15 percent grade.  Back into turtle mode now.  Several people were walking their bikes; others were doing an uphill slalom from one road edge to another, trading distance for slope.  Everybody was pretty quiet.    The Big Nasty continues like that with short interludes of 5 to 6 percent grades that looked like downhill by comparison and made me want to coast.  After about 4 miles, the way became rolling for about a mile before the next aid station at 8000 feet.   This station had plenty of water and food but only four cyclists in attendance.  The pack had thinned out and I was near the back, if not dead last.  Volunteers were packing up and getting ready to move out.  With a quick cup of water, I remounted.   There followed about a mile and a half of downhill.  I had not heard the whizzing of my brake disk rotors for a long time.  It sounded good.    What goes down must climb back up another long 15 percent grade back to 8000 feet and a longer rolling ascent to the summit at 8300 feet.  Twenty-eight road miles in about 5 hours. Add to that, four fifths of a mile in vertical elevation gain.   The summit aid station overlooked Castle Valley, a broad expanse marked by a number of red rock spires like the battlements of a castle.  It is a beautiful place and were it not for the proximity of Arches and Canyonlands National Parks, this valley would, in all likelihood be designated a national reserve of some sort.  But this part of Utah has an embarrassment of natural beauty so, Castle Valley remains and overlooked treasure on a byway.   Clouds gathered over the nearby peaks while the sun warmed the valley below.  Eight thousand feet of elevation chilled the air.  Bundled in a fleece vest and wind jacket, I made for the valley floor.  The road, while paved, was rough and marked with sharp switchbacks.  Pumping the brakes I leaned into turns as one must do on a trike.  It was a fairly solitary decent.  A van with volunteers and equipment from the previous, now closed, aid station passed me.  Along a straight and gentle decline in the lower valley, a woman cyclist passed me pumping and breathing hard.  My cyclocomputer read 32 miles per hour and I was just coasting.  Heavy recumbents are always faster than ordinary bikes on the downhill.  I let her go, luxuriating in my gravity assisted descent.  The road out of Castle Valley T-bones into the highway that parallels the Colorado River.  Five hours to climb The Big Nasty; one hour back down.  After a pause to shed some high altitude insulation, I fell in with riders who were finishing the century course.   The Colorado River, swollen with runoff, looked more like mudflow than a river.  Despite this, the way was gorgeous, winding along the river's edge with sheer, red rock cliffs rising to 500 feet on each side.  But, I was tired and contemplating the 20 mile ride back to town (the last 5 miles in Moab traffic) I settled into survivor mode and could not appropriately appreciate the beauty around me.  A car pulled along side me.  Through the window, my wife called, 'Are you all right.'  I signaled, 'Yes,' but she pulled off to the side of the road a little way ahead.  Stopping behind her I got off the trike experiencing a new sensation - muscle soreness.  I have been weak and spent from tough rides before but never sore.   Leaning on my arms above her open window, I announced, 'I am very able to finish this ride.'   'I know you are,' she replied.   I went on, 'But you are a sight for sore eyes.'   Without a trace of guilt or disappointment, I loaded the trike into our Outback.   The Big Nasty is one of those challenges that I wanted to surmount.  It is done.  I cannot imagine what would induce me to do it again.  But, you never know. 
                                                   >>> Part 2 of this page 
My "Bike Rides Around Sydney" book features a Hornsby-Gosford ride along the old Pacific Highway, which has long been supplanted by the Sydney-Newcastle Freeway. The in-laws live in Newcastle, and on our infrequent visits we pass by the signs on the freeway saying "Bicycles - Take Old Pacific Highway" scenic route. The "Bike Rides" book labels the route as "difficult", which had been intimidating me a little, but after riding the Sydney-to-the-Gong ride a few weekends ago without trouble, I decided I was up to it.      I set out from home at about 8:30 on Friday morning - the last day of my week off. A fine day, not too windy, not too warm, a step up from the previous day, which had been an unseasonably cool 10 degrees C and littered with showers.  I live near the airport, about 10kms from Sydney's Central Station, where I catch the train out to Hornsby to start the ride: on an all-stations service, it's about an hour's journey. I buy my ticket just after 9am, neatly avoiding having to purchase a peak hour half-fare ticket for my bike.    By 10am, I'm at Hornsby Station and ready to go: down Jersey Street, avoiding the witches hats (most of Sydney's roads seem to be under construction at the moment - end of year budget to be spent?), and thence onto the Highway. The first part of the journey follows the train line, past Mount Kuring-gai Station, and a wide bike path means no need to play in traffic.  Suburban houses and shops, P platers with no sense of direction, and a completely random sight. A white horse, standing on the footpath outside someone's home.    Just before Cowan, the multi-lane road turns into the new Freeway, taking most of the traffic with it, and I follow the old Highway to the left.  Little do I realise that the junction has a guardian. I hear the whoosh and flutter of wings just behind my head, and the angry screech of a territorial magpie, and feel my muscles tense in anticipation of impact. Fortunately it doesn't come. The next few hundred metres are punctuated with these swooping attacks, but I think he's more interested in driving off the intruder than inflicting any injury; I remain untouched. It does make me anxious, though: what if the entire route is going to be like this? That could make for a very long day, and I can't count on getting off unscathed every time. As it turns out, though, this is an isolated incident. A few kilometres further on, I stop at a cafe to get an iceblock. I've been cycling for about an hour, and though I'm still perfectly comfortable, I figure taking a little break is probably still a sensible option. I buy myself a Frosty Fruit (mmm, tropical ice goodness), and sit down in the shade to eat it. Shortly thereafter, another cyclist arrives from the north on a road bike and wanders in to buy himself an icypole. He says hi, and we talk about the ride to Gosford, which he seems to have done quite frequently: he recommends turning off the highway at Brisbane Water and riding on to Woy Woy Station as a more scenic option than braving downtown Gosford. He's also familiar with the magpie guardian I'd encountered down the road: he says that the bird has been menacing that section of road for years, and they've spoken to the ranger about it. Apparently magpies have a hierarchy, and it's the job of the alpha male to do all the diving and swooping; take the alpha away, and a new one will take its place. Magpies as hydras, who knew? Onwards and upwards! The book had mentioned wide shoulders, but in many places the encroaching leaf litter from the surrounding bushland has overtaken all but a few inches of asphalt on the left side of the white line. In other places, the shoulder is broken and cracked, or riddled with seams. It seems best to ride to the left of the lane, where the road surface is halfway decent. Then downwards... The highway snakes back and forth as it descends the mountain, which makes it very popular with motorcyclists. There's a motorbike passing me every few minutes. I'm coasting down the hills without much in the way of pedalling, which I'd say would make me lazy except that I know I'm going to pay for it on the way up the other side.    More workmen: they're working on the road surface on the north side of the Peats Ferry Bridge, and the traffic is down to a single lane. Unlike the cars, who have to wait for the lollipop man to point the "Slow" sign their way, I can just cycle along the pathway on the left hand side of the bridge and out the other side.    There are workers on the footpath on the other side, and they wave me to a halt, worried that I won't stop for them. They're wearing hi-vis clothing and helmets - I can't imagine that they'd think I hadn't seen them. I hop back onto the road shoulder, and continue northwards.    I stop for lunch at a service station that no longer serves petrol, at a place called Peats Island. There are picnic tables beside it, and I buy myself a bottle of Dare iced coffee and a Vegemite sandwich and go sit down at one of the tables to eat. The ducks I'd noticed lounging in the shade now approach me with purpose: clearly they've discovered the picnic ground is an easy source of food.      The female duck has a lot in common with my beagle: a little nose - or in this case, beak - appears from under the table like a periscope and demands food. I have a lot of experience in resisting this sort of mealtime begging, and no food is forthcoming. The duck, again very much like the beagle, settles down under the table to sulk. And fish for crumbs.    The other inhabitant of the picnic ground is a rainbow lorikeet, also used to humans as lunchtime providers. It hops onto the table and noses around my helmet and gloves, which are sitting before me. It's not quite bold enough to hop onto my hand, but it's literally right at my fingertips. It doesn't get any sandwich either. From here on to Mt White is 10kms, uphill. I drop into a good hill-climbing gear (though my chain is rattling; it needs some TLC) and plug away. It's not hard, as long as I remember to let the bike do the work and not my muscles - "mechanical advantage doesn't get tired, dimwit!" - just time-consuming.     I switch my bike computer from the clock mode to the odometer so I can watch the metres tick by. Slow and steady. A roadie on a Specialized whizzes by; I am hillslug, hear me roar. It flattens out and I find a patch of shoulder wide enough to pull over, take a drink, stamp my feet a few times. My hands and feet are doing nicely, though: no pins and needles, no hotfoot. I have a muesli bar, and I'm still chewing when I hop back into the saddle. A motorcyclist zooms past, and waves to me. I'm too slow to wave back: he's already out of sight.      I reach the Road Warriors Cafe, which seems to be where all these motorcyclists have been heading. There's at least a dozen parked out the front, while their riders sit and enjoy a coffee. I consider getting a latte, but I'm not sure my stomach would thank me for it at this point. I get a bottle of cold water from the fridge, top up my bottles, inhale the rest.    There are some middle-aged folks sitting in the shade near the bike racks, with their small dogs. Two of them are white and fluffies, and one is a dachshund type of some description. They're not motorcyclists; perhaps they're on their way somewhere else? One of the fluffies is being cuddled and lavished with attention. The others are romping, albeit lazily, under the table. I'm about to hop back on my bike again and be on my way, when I catch sight of the flowers at the side of the road. I stop to take some photographs: they're too pretty to pass up.      From the cafe to the T-junction at Calga takes no time at all. The highway turns right and then right again; a truck driver stops to wave me on through at the intersection.    And now it's downhill to Mooney Mooney Creek. Strangely, the only photo I have of this portion of road is taken on an uphill slope. But really, who wants to stop for photos when they can be cruising down this winding road?    I flash by the Mooney Mooney Creek sign and am halfway across the bridge before I think to stop. The book has warned me that there's another big climb coming - I'll soon be looking down at the freeway that I can see above and to my left. I wheel my bike back to the sign for a photo.      The uphills continue to be, if not effortless, strangely easy. I think perhaps that tell-tale word "difficult" was psyching me out more than I knew. I haven't even needed to resort to my old faithful hill-climbing chant: I think I can, I think I can. Or perhaps I'm just fitter than I used to be.    I pass the Australian Reptile Park, but no more Old Sydney Town. We used to come out here for school excursions, way back when. It feels a lot drier along this stretch of road than earlier in the trip: microclimate? imagination? or am I becoming dehydrated? I chug down half a bottle of water, just in case it's the latter. Travelling through Somersby Industrial Park would be incredibly unscenic, if it weren't for the same yellow flowers I saw at Road Warriors Cafe, here growing in ridiculous profusion along both sides of the road. It's probably a weed, and the locals despair of it, but it's gorgeous. As I descend towards Gosford - down a twisting winding road with hairpin bends and no shoulder to speak of - the flowers are brilliant yellow around me. If I have to bail out suddenly, at least they'll make for a soft landing. No chance for a photo here! On the last few bends the flowers give way to gum trees and gravel, and then I'm spat out near the sign for West Gosford. Looking back, the last hundred metres of the road - all that's visible - look innocuous.    From here it's all mundane. I cheat along the footpath for a hundred metres to where the bus lane starts, then coast on past the Gosford Racecourse, Henry Kendall High School, and down an absurdly steep street to Gosford station.    It's a twenty minute wait for the train, and then I'm on my way home.
Success! I caught the bus right in time that ran me out to The Brecksville VA hospital. I rested up on the bus after my high speed dash to downtown, unloaded, my gear, and headed out for Silver Springs Lake Park in Stow Ohio. The sun came out of it's hiding, and finally reached around 68 degrees with a nice cool breeze. I headed out toward Boston Mills Ski Resort Area via Snowville to Riverview roads. Had some hot soup at pine picnic area next to boston mills ski resort before continuing on to Peninsula Ohio. Somewhere along the way my oversized water bottle had fallen out of it's cage!  Arrived in downtown Peninsula without a problem, and a local bike shop sold me a water bottle, and let me fill it with some fresh spring water they had their at the store.  I continued up route 303 east a huge hill to the Summit County Bike n Hike entrance, the red blazes glowing in the sun, it was a picture perfect day for a bike ride, just perfect. The trail was real smooth, nicely paved , and covered with leaves.  The trail had very little traffic on it making it really peaceful. On occasion you'd see a smiling jogger, cyclist, or walker greeting you everyone was soaking up the great weather.  The bike trail lead me right to the  Silver Springs Park in Stow ohio. I roamed around this really well kept city owned park for a bit then continued on to the campgrounds further down the trail.  Rolled up this driveway entrance to the park less than a mile from the trail to see a lake, these little cottages each with their own names. A saw a deer beside one of them from the parking lot when I heard a snap, a sound I was all too familiar with (a broken spoke).  Wouldn't you know I forgot something pretty important when I rushed to pack up and get out - fibre fix spokes. The sun was half way down, and I knew I would be running out of daylight soon. I'm fortunate that my brakes have a quick release so I could ride with the rear brake open preventing this really wobbly rim from rubbing the brake on my return ride home.  I wobbled down the trail just as fast as I could, I didn't feel the wobble as bad at a high speed. It was getting late, and now the deers were starting to come out, they stood next to the trail many times, sometimes you'd hear them but not see them. I feared one of them jumping out in front of me like one time before.  I was really pushing it, and my legs started cramping from over doing things so I slowed down, stopped rested and got out some energy bars to eat along the way. I didn't want to take any chances bonking on the way back. I finally arrived at brandywine falls a halfway home point. I found that occasionally walking the bike helped relieve my leg pain by using different muscles.  I continued wobbling up until I reached the end of the trail at Alexander Rd. also known as Pleasant Valley Road. It leads to the Cuyahoga Valley National Park, and towpath. The tow path runs pretty much parrelel to the path I took but has a much rougher surface to ride than the Hike n Bike path . The towpath has alot more shade to offer in the hot summer months than the hike n bike which is a converted railway trail that runs under high voltage lines, and is pretty much wide open. I arrived in Independence, stopped in a local Pizza shop and ordered a huge meatball sub, and had a feast. The valuable lesson I learned is Be Prepared for emergency repairs, Leave yourself enough time, and always try to plan things in advance.                       
I felt great an hour ago. But riding hard without enough fuel in the belly or water to keep you going is like running on empty. I could imagine the headlines, 'Man found babbling out his mind and near death!'; well may be my imagination is in overdrive or not really all there in the first place.  After all, it was only going to be a short ride. Well it would be short by ambulance to the hospital with a drip hanging out my arm. Isn't that what they do with elite athlete's who hit the dreaded wall after the bonk!  Well I was no athlete with back up support crew ready to treat first-aid on me. So what could I do? Looking like a crazed zombie, I made my way to the nearest farm house and knocked on the door. It was only then I notice the salivating Blue-Heeler. 'Oh, he won't bite, he always greets that way. Come in the Billy's on', he waved. I hadn't spoken a word; a warm drink already had my name on it. The tea went down smoother then a cappuccino might have. I usually baulk at drinking liquid tar, but the spring water it was brewed from sweetened the taste. Jack was a true bushy, an old timer sleeper cutter. Silver hair accentuating his deep features. He mumbled something and with that, an elderly woman appeared with a tray of scones. Nellie was the image of a rough diamond, dressed in a flannel shirt and moleskins. 'I really didn't expect this kind of help and hospitality'. Now Nellie was showing me her cast cooking pots while Jack told stories of cutting sleepers by hand tools and experiences they shared on the track cutting and cooking in the bush. Even Jack's hands told a story - of skin cracking working out in shrub during cool winters and freezing rain under the cover of a canvas swag. My high-tech camping gears from the city stores worked fine, but by comparison, lack any real character. And yet we shared our time in the bush away from hassles of town.     I thanked Jack and his wife Nellie for rescuing a weary traveller and for their country charm as I turned to the bicycle resting on the rustic fence surrounding the homestead. And as I rode down the dusty drive back to the road I heard Nellie cry 'Call again, when passing this way!'. Later I recounted, how running on empty can sometimes lead you to find unusual refueling stops. And come away with more than refreshment, but hope for the soul. YOUR WORLD IS A TRULY AMAZING PLACE. ALL YOU HAVE TO DO IS STOP LONG ENOUGH TO NOTICE IT! AND IN DOING SO, MAY RESTORE THE SOUL.   
As the tides are govern by the moon. It is not so surprising that we too may be affected by the lunar forces. As the moon becomes full, the stranger the loss of reality some people have. Then add heat, and pretty soon severe mental derangement afflicts cyclists to believe that cycling after dark would be cooler.  The bitumen melting should have been a warning sign, and the lingering heat of late afternoon should have been a forewarning that the haze in the distance had blinded our sense of reality. But touring cyclist have a obsession with cycling and it's related pleasures. Even though the days had been hot, really hot, the need to get out into the bush camping made us choose a night ride, with near full moon to provide enough light to cycle by. Leaving just before sunset, would allow us to check the equipment is tied to the bikes, and get along the  busier section of road before dark. Within minutes of setting off from the driveway, I was questioning the shower I had before leaving to meet the friend, Ms R.U. Crazi, I was cycling with. The moon and heat must have given both my friend and I nocturnal delusions as the temperature didn't drop after dark. In fact, it was just as hot. Who's idea was this. Were we true lunatics? Most of our friends and family would have had both of us certified if allowed. Perhaps the heat had already melted our minds the days before. The ride was not to be all that long, but we forgot about the temperature slowing us down. We were in the oven on high heat, every little bit of moisture was being drawn from us. And we were drinking non-stop trying not to become dehydrated. Sweat was running off us, and our perspiration could have easily broken the drought. It was 10:30pm when the bikes were laid down at the Reedy Creek campsite. Next was to set up the tents and have a cup of coffee before hitting the sack. Not long after climbing into my tent, I wondered if someone would find me in the coming days cooked in a pressure cooker inside the tent. But a sight breeze kept me from becoming a well done roast. The next morning was very different from the night before. But knowing it would quickly heat up once the sun was up. Ms R.U Crazi and I broke camp early to ride back to town, only to face an uphill climb for 6 kilometres. As we know most up hills are followed by downhills and this one did not disappoint with the reward of cool air rushing past on our descent. The ride to town was only stopped when having just ridden past the town sign and stopping for a drink of water, the rear tyre went flat when ready to push on. A quick change of tube saw us on our way and looking forward to a cold drink and cool shower. 
  The drought's Broken! Or is it just Sweat? Here I am sitting beside the track, and unable to even find a shadow to cool my head. The  bull-dust covering me is as thick as a wedding cake's icing, only not as nice. It' has been nearly a year since the idea first came to me to cycle along desert tracks to small outback communities, encouraged by early outback missionaries who travelled the roads less travelled to care for those in isolated places.  To most Australians anything vaguely rural is 'the bush'. At some indeterminate point 'the bush becomes 'the OUTBACK'. The Outback, for many is beyond the furthest fence, and government outpost. It's the never-never, where flies fly backwards to keep the sand out of their eyes. My journey began as I rode my heavy laden bicycle to the railway station at close to midnight, to await the arrival of the 'Indian Pacific'. The Indian Pacific was a silvery sleek, shiny as a new nickel, humming with the sense of impending adventure. It was the prefect machine to propel me into the outback for the start of my adventure.  I arrived at Broken Hill just after sunrise at eight in the morning and stepped blinking from the train with the bike from the luggage car. It was cooler today than the record of forty-eight degrees C, that's hot, too darn hot.          After breakfast I headed down to the local police station to let them know of my plan to ride to White Cliffs via the road to Mutawintji National Park. They could see that this crazy man had done his home work, knowing that people die in the desert, I told them that if I wasn't in Wilcannia in five days time, that they better come looking for me. 'In a few hours you will be in the real outback where people who don't take precautions do die, even those who do have come to grief' said the young officer behind the counter. And with that they wished me well. He was right. In the few kilometres from the town limits the black-top gave way to a hard earthen road full of potholes, ruts and cement hard corrugations, as jarring as riding over railway sleepers.     Through a landscape empty and brilliantly warm in winter. Past low saltbush and spiky spinifex, the odd turpentine bush and weary looking eucalypt. Here and there along the roadside were the corpses of kangaroos and the occasional basking goanna. Goodness knows how many living things survive in the heat out here in summer. There are creekbeds out there that haven't seen water in fifteen years. The supreme emptiness of this land, the galling uselessness of such a mass of land, was something that took the country's European settlers a long time to adjust to. Several of the earliest explorers were so convicted they would encounter mighty river systems, or an inland sea that they took boats with them. Reading accounts of early forays, it is clear that the first explorers were often ludicrously out of their depths. In expedition after expedition the leaders seemed willfully, almost comically, unable to provision themselves sensibly. It was into this tradition of haplessness that Burke and Wills improvidently stepped in 1860. They are far and away the most famous of Australian explorers, which is perhaps a little curious since their   expedition accomplished almost nothing, cost a fortune and ended in tragedy.    Even today, the emptiness of so much of Australia is  startling. The landscape I was now cycling through was officially only 'semi-desert', but it was barren an expanse as I had ever seen. Every now or then, there be a lonely mailbox and a track leading to an unseen sheep or cattle station.     Once today a convoy of modern day explorers pasted in a four-wheel drive in a hell-for-leather fashion, spraying me in gravelly bits and a coating of fine red bull-dust. Pretty soon after leaving the National Park three days out of Broken Hill, I soon found the outback, the track by now had become sand, and now was nearly two foot deep. Dragging a bicycle in these conditions is harder enough, but add a trailer with the supplies to survive in this wilderness, and I was a broken man. By now I had drunk nearly half of my 12 litres of water. In fact the sweat running down my face into my eyes, could have easily broken the drought. With the stories of failed explorers still ringing in my ear I turned back to the safety of the National Park where there was drinking water and communications with the outside world. Unlike the early explorers, I was lucky to be rescued from the hardship with a ride back to the Hill by a couple who must have felt sorry for a dust encrusted rider, and weary looking. Travelling over the road that took me two and a half days to cover had me back in Broken Hill. Where I looked forward to a running shower to wash the sun baked crust from my body. After a restful night I awoke early to the news of a tailwind to the east. So after down a mix-grill fit for the hardiest of explorers I headed east towards Wilcannia before heading north to While Cliffs once again.     Seeing it today, it is hard to think that Wilcannia was once a mighty river port, loading bales of wool onto paddle steamers bound for Adelaide.     Now a near ghost town the river is almost dry due to the drought and the irrigation upstream. Once the town boomed with the sound of steam whistles, today the local Aboriginals are all that remain. A 109km north of the river town of Wilcannia, is the mining town of White Cliffs. Upon seeing it, it all but impossible to believe that White Cliffs, a small blotch of habitation under a hard clear sky, was once a boom town, with a populations of nearly 4,500, a hospital, a   newspaper, a library, and a busy core of general stores, hotels, restaurants, brothels and gaming houses. Today White Cliffs consists of a pub, a launderette, an opal shop, and a grocery/caf/petrol station. The permanent population is about eighty. They exist in a relentless world of heat and dust. And if you were looking for people with the tolerance and fortitude to colonize Mars this would be the place to look.    Because of the heat, most people living underground in the side of the two bleached hills from which the town takes it's name. The rooms are very nice and quite   normal except for the walls and ceilings were cave-like and windowless as I was to find out as my host Bruce showed me to my room in his house.    I don't know how much you would have to give me to persuade me to settle in White Cliffs-- something like a few million. Later I was about to asked Bruce and his wife Helen what possesses them to stay in this godforsaken outpost where even a run to the supermarket means a six-hour round trip over a rutted dirt road, but before I could speak a remarkable thing happened Kangaroos hopped into the foreground and began grazing as the sun lowered in the western skies. The sky was glowing pinks, deep purples, careless banners of crimson-- all on a scale that you could not imagine, for there was no high-rise to block the view between us and the far horizon.   I asked him what brought him to White Cliffs. 'I worked on the Flying Doc's radio's, and did a bit of mining and just never really left', he said. 'It was a lot more remote back then. Took us eight or more hours from Broken Hill, the roads were that bad, especially the way you tried to come by the National Park. Now you can do it in three hours from Broken Hill on the all weather road, but back then the roads were rough as guts every inch of the way', he said. 'Yeah it was a different world' Bruce went on to say musingly. Still is, I thought, a throw back to   another time when men were men and a spirit of discovery was a way of life. 
I'm by no means an expert at this quite yet, just do it for pleasure, and as a long term goal, to get my legs in better shape to be able to do some long distance touring!   #1 on the map:.New Haymarket Memorial at Desplaines and Randolph. Previously only a small bronze placket Designated by Richard M. Daley, in 1992 on the sidewalk demarked the site of the speakers' wagon and the historic significance of the site, which read: "A decade of strife between labor and industry culminated here in a confrontation that resulted in the tragic death of both workers and policemen. On May 4, 1886, spectators at a labor rally had gathered around the mouth of' Crane's Alley. A contingent of police approaching on Des Plaines Street were met by a bomb thrown from just south of the alley it landed on the west side of Desplaines, most likely thrown from the vestibule of a building on the Northeast corner of Randolph and Desplaines. The resultant trial of eight activists gained worldwide attention for the labor movement, and initiated the tradition of "May Day" labor rallies. In 2004 the city installed the current monument by sculptor Mary Brogger, of a fifteen-foot speakers' wagon echoing the wagon on which the labor leaders stood on to address the crowds.        Just to the north of the monument, on Lake Street was Zepfs Hall home to the Lumbershovers' Union that had asked Albert Spies to speak to its members at the McConnick Reaper Plant on May 3, 1886. When the bomb exploded in the crowd, Albert and Lucy Parsons were in the first floor tavern of Zepfs Hall with their children and their friend Lizzie Holmes.                We rode south on Desplaines, right past the former location of the police station in 1886,  the site of the 3rd District Police station 19 South -120 North Des Plaines Street. The location of the station from which the police were sent in to Haymarket Square to disperse the labor rally on the evening of May 4, 1886. The detail of police who marched in the front line that night were killed when the infamous Haymarket bomb, hurled from a nearby vestibule, exploded within their midst. The repercussions of the Haymarket incident galvanized the labor movement worldwide resulting in the gradual acceptance of the eight-hour workday.  The identity of the bomb thrower has never been determined.   Then west on Madison, past some of the more colorful parts in Chicago's history, referred to as 'Stripper's Row.'  In the I950s, this area of Madison Street was home to numerous adult clubs and known as Stripper's Row. Some of the club names and locations were: Haymarket Halsted and Madison; Academy Halsted and Madison; Star & Garter 915 Madison; Music Box 932 Madison; So Ho 1124 Madison; Flamingo 1359 Madison; E1 Mocambo 1519 Madison. Then south, through the very nice campus of the University of Illinois at Chicago.  The construction of the university itself caused some consternation because it displaced much of the Maxwell Street Market, a famous flee market on the near south side.  You can ride outside the campus and still smell, and buy, the Maxwell Street Polish Sausage sandwiches.  A minor calamity going south on Halstead!  I got lost, which isn't that unusual.  We ran into a bunch of traffic - both cars and cyclists.  The group got commingled with the other cyclists and a couple of blocks later I realized I didn't recognize anybody.  So I quickly checked the map, realized my error.  I went back to 16th street but didn't see anybody so from that point on I just followed the map. Which created a dilemma: was I ahead of the group, or behind?  Do I speed ahead, or wait?  It would be unusual for me to be ahead of anybody, so I sauntered down the street hoping all would catch up.  After a while, they didn't.  So I sped ahead. Actually, the map the Rick Bak, the organizer, has prepared was pretty good, and the route was well chosen.  There were few turns so it was easy to follow.  At once point, near Ogden, Oakley, and Roosevelt Road I stopped and waited and had a good view of points east - to see if I could see a large group.  We had one rat-bike high rider so I thought that might be easy to spot.  After a while, I decided to press on and probably catch up at the cemetery or else wait there. Someplace along Roosevelt (which has a nice bike lane most of the way) I stopped behind a fence for a little relief, and saw the pack coming up behind me!  So I climbed out from behind the fence and joined up with them again.  By this time the group had shrunk to about 15 or so.  Some of the vehicles were really meant for the 20-mile trip through the city to the cemetery out in Forest Park.                    Just recently, a Chicago Park was named after her, the first park in Chicago named after a woman. Lucy Ella Gonzales Parsons (1853  1942) Park, 4712 W. Belmont Ave., is named after the labor reformer and womens rights activist who organized the Working Womens Union No. 1 in 1878, the only women workers union in Chicago at the time.  The last time I did this ride, a couple of years ago, there were several members of the IWW, the Industrial Workers of the World, or 'wobblies' at the monument.  This year we may have gone on the wrong Sunday - nobody from that group was there, unfortunately.  But we still had Al Schorsch with us and his banjo and songs.    I wimped out and took the Blue Line rapid transit from the end of the line, which is only a couple of blocks north of the cemetery. About a 25 mile ride.  Something to look forward to next year. A lot of the history in here was scanned, cut, and pasted from material provided for the ride by Brian Dartmund who acted as our narrator and explainer along the route.    A short history of the Haymarket Ride In 2002 Chicago area artists Brian Dortmund, and Michael Piazza collaborated and initiated the ride as a part of Michael Piazza's project "The Eight Hour Action Series."  Michael designed The Eight Hour Action Series to be an open movement allowing collaborations; this is something he did with so much of his work. Brian Dortmund's objective in the creation of the Ride was to find a way to connect different groups I.e.,   Cyclists, History Buffs, Labor Activists, and Anarchists (who never follow the map we create, but end up meeting us at Forest Home Cemetery) in this communal event.  Brian approached Michael with the Haymarket Ride project, and he worked with him teaching a great deal about the history of the movement, his heroes, the martyrs, and the sites. Every year new parts of the rich history are revealed and we owe this all to Michael's efforts. Rick Bak has worked with Michael and Brian since 2004 and as a group they would ride the routes, plan the maps, and discuss new parts of the historical framework we would uncover. The historical text used on this journal is from the handouts Brian wrote and compile to hand out at the ride. Like the ride, the information grows each year and we learn more and do our best to circulate it so people can find these places and remember the events.

 We started off bright and early from my house (Aaron) around 7:45. We immediately realized we had our work cut out for us. We were heading SW towards Eureka, and there was a strong wind heading NE. I felt as if I were like Lewis and Alex was like Clark and we had come upon the mighty Pacific Ocean. We came to know Woodford County as "The Land of Beautiful Wildflowers and Shoulderless Roads"    Crossing over I-39 we ran into our uncle Bob. It was good to see a familiar face. Once we reached Eureka we went to the major tourist hot spot, the courthouse where we found a cool looking tank.   About 2 min later we were at Grandpa and Grandma's house. I ride a 2005 Specialized Rockhopper Comp, with a Burley D'lite in tow. The Burley is great for carting my daughter around town, but when it comes to touring I think that its simply to big. There is way to much room in the Burley and I found myself trying to fill it up. I am thinking that a BOB trailer is the way to go. The reason that I say this, is the BOB will limit the amount of space and it is not as wide. With the Burley on narrow shoulders I was really fighting the rumble strips on the road. By the time that I got to the camp ground, I was over heated and it took the rest of the afternoon to cool down.    The camp ground was nice. Really clean restrooms, with running water. The one thing that I have to say is that the RV's with "Rent Me" on the back scare me. The RV that I speak of shows up at the camp ground about 8:30 p.m. and they drive around the camp ground 3 times before they find a spot. One thing that I need to tell you is that the camp ground only has 3 spots of RV hook-ups, and they are marked. Also let me add that when the RV showed up, there was only me and the ground keeper there. I think that 3 kids poured out of the RV screaming and then there is about an hour of the adults trying to figure out how to hook the RV up. Childrens hangers are everywhere, I counted 8 in a 17 mile stretch.             
The mindset and experience of self-sufficient, self-contained, unsupported or whatever terminology you prefer for this type of touring deserves to bask in its own limelight.  So, I was surprised when told by Adventure Cycling staff upon my founding the UBTS (a society/club based solely on this type of touring) that they knew of no other such club in the country.  Amazing; no other organization in the US or North America (as far as they know) that's been formed to bring self-sufficient tourers together.  This is was an idea I had years ago and after getting the ball rolling, I immediately realized that it's time had surely come. In short notice, the Utah Bicycle Touring Society has become a fantastic social experience for about 25 people who use their bikes in this fashion, and we've just gotten started.   We do little more than get together every other month during Utah's riding season.  We open and close the season with a casual dinner where we can talk about touring plans for the year, watch trip slide shows and so on.  The other three times we come together are unique touring outings.  A weekend and campsite is picked and tourers ride in from wherever they wish, bringing their tent, food, stove and whatever else they choose want for the weekend.  Hey, if you're a self-sufficient tourer, this has to sound a lot better than car camping.  If you're new to touring, what better way to get your feet wet?   Come on people, where's the ABTS, CBTS, DBTS, FBTS and so on?  We have no club dues, no president, no meetings and no real month to month operating costs.  Start a blog and let the news spread by word of mouth and whatever other means available.  Move the ride to locations around your state if need be and sit back and watch as the tourers materialize from all corners of your community.  Self-contained tours within your state among these new riding friends will automatically come to fruition.  How could you not want this?  As it says on the UBTS homepage, "Wouldn't it be great to have a social network of every self-sufficient tourer in your state?  Why yes, yes it would."   So, this tour journal is of our tour to the year's second UBTS Rendezvous at Rock Cliff Nature Preserve.  There are many nice routes leading to this wonderful campground.  We had to drive close enough for a relatively short ride so we could get back the next day in time to pick our boarded Border Collie up at the kennel.  We would have left him there for an extra day but we just got back from Alaska and figure he's been away from home enough.  A short tour into the gathering but at least we're able to go. Our chosen route this time was from Wanship Utah.  It's a small dot on the map (if there at all) that's right off of I-84.  It's a beautiful place in a southwestern kinda way.  There's a cafe at the interstate offramp and a trail head for the rail trail that runs from Coalville to Park City.  We'll be taking the rail trail to SR 248 to Kamas then SR 32 on to Rock Cliff.    Here we've made it to our starting point. Some front racks are a real pain when it comes to loading the bike on a car's roof rack.  The Tubus Tara isn't that bad as it can be disconnected from the lower mounting point, swung up and secured with velcro (or something) and left on the bike.  Above is a shot of such an arrangement.  That's velcro around the brake bosses holding the rack up for transport. After about 15-20 minutes in the parking lot, we were on our way.  The rail trail isn't paved but we were both on very wide tires.  I've ridden this trail in the past using my cyclocross bike and 700x32c Schwalbe Marathon XRs.  It was fun but my personal preference would be for at least 35c tires for the surface.  Rail trail grades are usually very shallow and this is one is no exception but we were climbing.  It was also into the wind for us.  Along this stretch of I-84 you normally have either a headwind or tailwind because it's between the mountains.  Otherwise, what a beautiful day.  Blue skies and not too hot.  This year, Utah saw it's hottest month ever on record.  We were lucky not to be riding in 100+ degrees.    There are a few cattle ranches along the trail and the Weber River runs here too.  We'd be passing through an number of stock gates.  Today marked the second day we've had on the trail where we had to negotiate with cows.  The first time was a few months ago before our tour of Alaska and we weren't successful then.  They wouldn't move and there was no way to get around them.  This time, after about 5 minutes of acting up they mooooved on.      SR 248 has a nice shoulder but had some glass and debris in it.  Not a problem for proper touring tires.  It's a pretty ride but there's a lot of new development going on here.  That said, this is a popular cycling route and we saw over a dozen roadies getting their rides in.  It's not flat in this part of the state so the hills are gonna have to come sometime. : ) Though it wasn't 100+ degrees, we were still feeling the heat.  We couldn't show up at Rock Cliff early because the campground was closed for the annual Jordanelle Triathlon. Rock Cliff was going to be closed for the night but the Park Managers were nice enough to allow the UBTS entry after 3:30PM.  This had been coordinated far in advance. SR 248 intersects SR32/SR35 in Kamas and at this intersection is a convenient store.  We stopped in here for a cold V8 drink to replace some of what we'd burned along the warm roadside.  A right turn here and we were on a two mile stretch before making the final turn that would take us to the park entrance.  This two mile bit of this route has no shoulder and can be somewhat busy on the weekend with recreationalists.  Our "Take-a-Look" mirrors make riding on shoulder less roads much easier to deal with though and it was only two miles.      So two miles down the road from the Kamas intersection, SR 35 continues forward but SR 32 takes a 90 degree turn and we turned right.  Just a few tenths of a mile and we'd be there at the entrance to Rock Cliff Nature Preserve.   We made it to the fee station pretty close to 3:30PM and were told that no one else had ridden in yet.  With that, we rode on to the Nature Center where we'd find the Park Ranger I'd made our arrangements through.  After talking to her for a little while, we paid for our campsite and walked down to the campground. Our choice of 52 tent sites.  Aside from bathrooms/showers and a pavilion, 52 tent sites is all that's here.  No RV sites, no car camping sites... just tents.  This is a rarity in Utah unless you're talking about small primitive campgrounds.  Only 28.49 miles - 11.48 Ave Speed - 38.7 mph Max    Ahh, such a nice relaxing place, just off the beaten path.    I started setting the tent up while Nancy went off for her shower.  I wasn't that far along before tourers started coming in.      Word spreads relatively slowly among the touring populous so it stands to reason that every time we have our gatherings, they'll be long time tourers that have just joined in on the fun.  Rob here has toured from Utah to Arctic Circle AK and back as well as some other big ones.  He covered the 60-70 miles from his home in Sandy Utah to the campground and was lucky enough to have a tailwind for most of it.  Luck dawg! More and more came in, all having great rides and for a couple of folks it was their first self-sufficient tour.    6ish PM and we all started gathering at the pavilion to whip up our dinners.  Aside from the riding, this is what it's all about.  Stories and other fun around the campsite.    After dinner folks were having a great time catching up or covering the ground you normally do after meeting new friends.  At 9PM I broke in to give everyone a chance to hear about our Denali adventure and answer questions about it.  Afterwards, I worked up the nerve to sing two little songs I'd written and performed at the last campsite on the Denali Highway.  This night however, my voice and memory needed some warming up.  I botched the first number badly and I was lucky no one brought any rotten tomatoes along.  The second song was much better but my voice was still off.  Ahhh well, it's free lighthearted entertainment and laughs were the goal in the first place.  More on the songs in our Alaska journal when I get around to it. After I finished, Peter and Lorraine told us all about their recent 17 days on the Lewis & Clark.  Followed by Lou and Julie talking about their 1,200 mile tour around Wisconsin that's kicking off in September.   Before we started off for our campsites I let everyone know that come the end of October, we'll be closing the year out with a UBTS dinner where I'll plan to show a 25 minute DVD slide show of our Alaska tour.  Yikes!  I'd better get to making that thing then. : ) On our way back to the campsites Lou mentioned that on the last gathering here they'd discovered a raccoon paw print on one of their panniers in the morning.  I'd never seen such an animal here in the past and we'd never had food issues at Rock Cliff.  However, as Nancy was putting the food away in the BOB Trailer bag I asked her if she wanted to do something else with it since we'd heard about raccoons.  Nahhh, I'm putting it all in this bag and it's ziplocked....... 0150 I'm brought out my sleep by rattle, clank, swish, click & clack and such.  Out of the tent to find this...    Hmmmm.  That's not how we left that.  In the darkness we gathered up our remaining food bits and hauled them off to the shower facilities where they'd be safe for the night and hopefully leave our campsite quiet.  This worked real well except for a little noise the visitors made at 4AM to find the cupboards empty.  Lesson learned.  Better to spend 10 minutes, 10 minutes past your bedtime than 10 minutes in the middle of your sleep cycle.  : )    Last night I was saddened to learn that the villains had made off with most of our breakfast.  Come morning I was pleasantly surprised to see that they hadn't carried it very far.  We were able to reclaim a couple of rations that hadn't been compromised.  Picky little varmints.     Morning gatherings confirmed that Lou and Julie also had uninvited guests in the middle of the night.  They fixed the problem by bringing the food into their vestibule.  Folks, don't do that in bear country please.  Having been in Grizzly country and repeatedly schooled on food storage rights and wrongs, I doubt I'll ever have food inside our tent.  For the raccoons pleasure I'll be hanging our food at Rock Cliff or more likely using our bear vault just for the sake of getting more mileage out of that $70 spent.    Show links to this Hide links to this      It's been a while since I've had this bike on any long tours.  I'd spun it up for use in AK but at that last minute took my Rocky Mountain Sherpa.  The Thorn Nomad was born to handle nasty roads like the Denali Highway and I'd gone the further step of having the legendary Peter White build it a pair of insanely strong wheels utilizing Velocity Cliffhanger rims.  They wait to be put to a real test.     Kathy opened up the Nature Center at 9 so we waited there and said goodbye for the year though we'll continue talking over the land line.     The weather was wonderful once again.  On the road at 10AM.  Right out of the gate that 10% hits you (shown above) but it's short.  We stopped for an OJ at the convenient store before hooking a left onto SR 248.  Before we were rolling again a six pack of roadies spun into the parking lot looking for morning snacks.  We chatted with them and answered a volley of questions about the defective reasoning behind our choice to *load* a bicycle rather than drilling holes in it for weight saving purposes.  They apparently had one friend afflicted with a plight similar to ours and thus I passed UBTS data on. Talk to the roadies.  Talk to the RVers.  Talk to the motorcyclists.  Talk to the townspeople.  Talk to them all.  For every 10 times you spend 10 minutes with someone answering the "Where are you going on that thing?" type questions, there's gotta be one that starts thinking...  "Hmmm, bicycle touring." 29.16 miles - 12.40 Ave Speed - 38.2 mph Max Tailwinds!
   After making it to the base, the main gate was a sight for sore eyes as many drivers here do not acknowledge a cyclist as a human, but as a hood ornament.    Riding a recumbent here is like wearing an elephant on your head, everyone sees you coming and the first question is "are you handicapped?"          Well, I knew it couldn't be all easy, the wind picked up and it became a bit more laborious in getting across the base. But I was bound and determined to finish this trip. Enjoy the pics!      In closing I would like to point out a few little lessons learned. I will very soon go shopping for cycling shoes, My running shoes are going to be the death of me. Personally speaking, I enjoy riding and challenge anyone to actually enjoy it and not to think of it as a chore. Fitness is good but fun fitness is even better. Take time to stop and enjoy the world around you. Join me for some fun in Southern Maryland sometime!
