After some rides around Cannes, Juan-les-Pins and Antibes, today I'm starting from N98 road, just east of downtown Nice.    Turning on Mont Boron road, this is a gentle ascent to the top of the hill where, after turning around the Plateau du Mont Boron, I make a stop at the belvedere, enjoying the view towards the Baie des Anges. Going downhill by Chemin de la Borne which offers a view on Villefranche-sur-Mer and Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat peninsula, I reach N98 again.      After cycling through Villefranche's Marina and old streets, I take the beach road, Promenade des Marinires. The crossing of the peninsula is done while cycling on streets shaded by the pines, almost deserted. Everywhere there are  opulent estates, actually one can't see the houses hidden by high fences. This place is among the richest of the Cte-D'Azur. At the southern tip, there is an access to the pedestrian trail that circles the peninsula. I walk a while on it with the bike, but there are more and more stone steps, so I come back. It would be a nice hike : sharp rocks along the coast, blue sky and deep blue sea ! I keep it for another time.    Cycling through the village of Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat, I stop at the marina to take some pictures. I love this coast !        Leaving the village by the seaside promenade, I come back on N98 road (called the Basse Corniche) in Beaulieu-sur-Mer. I'm crossing Eze and, farther, having no light on the bike, instead of going through the highway's tunnel, I take the ancient road on the cliff. Greater view too ! Soon I am arriving in Cap-d'Ail and stop at the bakery to buy some pastries and bread. Now that the sun is lower, it's time to get back at full speed to Nice.  This last day of 2006 has been such a beautiful day ! 
   The trail has a very gentle feel about it with hardly any hills which makes it the perfect day out for people who are not massively bike fit, Heidi had only ever ridden 50km in a day thus far and she was already starting to really enjoy herself with the easy pace and great scenery.    Passing through old railway station's was a nice touch, many of them had been converted into nice picnic areas and were very well maintained which is nice to see.We also spotted alot of live stock and wildlife, namely cows, sheep, lama's even a few emu's plus I also spotted a small snake and a few rabbits, really great stuff plus riding next to wineries is also a great feeling      The K's slowly started to roll on and before we knew it we were almost at warburton, about 10km out Heidi was suffering from a slowly deflating tire, so rather than fix it just now we decided to pump and ride, then when it was almost flat pump again, this got us into Warburton were we proceeded to grab a bite to eat, it was pie and chips for Heidi and a chicken sandwhich with chips for me.    After fixing the flat and having a sit by the river which was very pleasant it was time to head off home, another 45km of really nice riding lay in front of us and I couldn't wait, Heidi was starting to complain about a sore neck so we took it easy and really enjoyed the ride my website is www.cyclingaddict.com enjoy     
The thought for this trip began in the summer of 2000. My plan was to do a cross country bike trip starting in Yorktown, VA and ending in Astoria, OR.  This trip was an Adventure Cycling Cross Country Tour.  There were 13 members on that tour.  The trip started in Yorktown, VA which is the starting point on the east coast for the Tran-American Bike Trail.  Over the next 18 days we biked any where from 32 miles per day to 80 miles per day.  The Trans-American route takes you through the heart of VA. While the biking was a lot of fun, the accommodations in route for sleeping and eating left a lot to be desired.  There were times when we went 3 days before showering.  Out of the 18 days I was on the tour, we knew where we were going to sleep before we got there about 1/2 the time.  In at least one case, we even arrived at where we were supposed to stay and found that we had moved to another location, just what you want to hear when you've already ridden 75 miles that day. 18 days later we arrived in Berea, KY on the western edge of the Appalachian Mountains.  In Berea I made the decision to terminate my participation in the tour. Let me say at this point, Adventure Cycling is a great organization that all bicyclists should belong to.  They do good work for the cycling world.  Every tour has a leader with there own style.  I just got a bad tour.  I would like to make it clear at this point that the people in this tour were not the reason I terminated.  We had 7 people from Holland and the rest were from all over America and they were great people.  I have stayed in touch with most of them including the Europeans.  I would ride with any of them anywhere again but not with Adventure Cycling. Shortly after returning home in June of 2000 my brother-in-law called me and asked if I would be interested in continuing the Tran-American tour in the summer of 2001 but organizing it ourselves.  I told him I would think about it but we needed at least 3 or 4 people. We both agreed to think about it for a few months and communicate by email. We thought about it for about one week and both decided we would love to do it.  We agreed to use a sag wagon which would take a lot of the weight off the bikes and be much easier going up the mountains.  Around the end of the year (2000), I found out that my Nephew in Portland, Or. would go with us.  Now we had three but it would be better if we had 4.  With 4 people we could ride for 3 days and drive the sag wagon for 1 day in rotation.  Doing it this way means we would not have to take any rest days. In an effort to get one more rider, I put an add on Adventure Cycling Web Site which is available free of charge for members. Over the next three months I had about 30 inquires. In March I got a call from Jerry from Ill. who was very interested and made a commitment right away, now we had 4. With all 4  riders in place, the planning of the actual trip could start.  Travel logistics would be a problem.  Walt lives in Georgia and I live in Connecticut and Jerry lives in Ill.  The three of us have to get to Portland, OR. where Jeff lives.  The plan is I will pick up Walt then go northwest to Ill. and pick up Jerry.  We will then head for Portland to pick up Jeff and on to Astoria.  In order to start the biking on June 1st, I will have to leave Connecticut on May 25th. The current date is March 22, 2001.  We have about 2 months to get ready for the trip.  All of us are trying to get into biking shape over the next 7 weeks.  Weather has been a problem and is not looking real good.  In order to stay in shape, I will have to run (not my favorite activity) every other day until the weather improves. The Current date is May 16th, one week until the great adventure begins.  As you might expect, there have been a few changes.  Walt from Georgia has now decided to drive himself across country and deliver a no longer needed Geo Tracker to his daughter in Eugene, OR.  Robert from Connecticut does not now have to go to Atlanta to pick up Walt (I'm disappointed).  I am still leaving on the 25th but I will make a stop in Mooresville Ind. to see my sister before moving on to Ill. to pick up Jerry.  A pleasant change in plans for me.
The weather in Florida has been great for riding the bike.  Since January I have been riding the bike at least 3 times per week and of late 4 or 5 times.  My wife has been back in Connecticut for a month but I stayed in Florida just so I could continue training for the big ride. In addition to riding, I run (jog) several time a week.  Now I will be heading back up north to much colder weather so running will become a larger part of my training at least until the weather warms up.  I'm sure that Walt and Jerry and Jeff are also trying to get into shape in their own way.  At this point we are less than two months away from the start of the ride and much remains to be done.  At some point in this journal I will provide an equipment list for riding with a sag wagon.  I can't do that yet because this will be my first ride with a sag wagon. Also a big and important event in the preparation for the trip is a drivers license for my young nephew Jeff (age 24).  You might ask why does Jeff not already have a drivers license and the answer would be, I don't know.  At some point in this journal creation I will ask him and then both you and I will know. Over the next two months bikes will be tuned and made ready for the big ride.  More details will be provided about the types of bike being used at a later section of this journal.  Also, as soon as I figure out how, I will add pictures of the 4 riders in this adventure.  Some of the things that still have to be done are, add a 2" hitch to the sag wagon (1995 Chevrolet. Blazer), decide if I need to add a roof rack carrier to handle the gear for 4 people.  We will be using a Thule 4 bike hitch for the bikes. Next update will be from Connecticut (getting out my long johns) Well I've been home for 10 days and not one day has been good for riding the bike.  In order to not loose the conditioning gained in Florida, I'm running every other day which is not my favorite activity.  I'm sure that Walt is having better luck with the weather in Georgia, but from what I hear from Jerry in ILL., his weather is like mine (Connecticut).  Busy preparing my bike, a Cannondale T2000 and Jeff's bike a Nishiki Pueblo for the trip. Things that need to be done to a bike in preparation for a trip like this are many: A. Check all brake and shifter cables (replace if worn) B. New tires added (if needed) C. Brakes adjusted and new pads added D. Bearings front and rear re-packed with grease E. Spokes checked for tightness (wheels should be true,no wobbles) F. Rear rack added to bikes G. Clean the entire drive train and lube H. Clean the bike and check that all nuts and bolts are tight I. Add a new drive chain (if worn) J. Ride the bike and make sure the gears all go up and down smooth. I'm sure I will add to this list as we progress over the next 7 weeks. The date is April 19th and the weather in Connecticut is still not good for riding a bicycle.  We are making good progress however toward getting ready for our big adventure.   The 1995 Chevrolet Blazer is now ready for the trip, new brakes, new thermostat, new fan belt, and the replacement of an idler arm (a component in the front suspension),and four new shocks.  All of this is an effort to make sure my Chevrolet with 100,000 miles on it does not give us trouble on the trip.  Also, the hitch and receiver for carrying the bicycles are installed.  Using a Hitch and Receiver is a great way to carry bicycles because it allows entry into the rear of the vehicle without removing the bicycles. All the work on the bicycles is complete (at least for Jeff and I).  Now the job of deciding what to bring on the trip as far as tools, clothing, cooking gear, camping gear, rain gear, warm weather gear, etc,.  I'm sure all of us will be thinking about what to bring right up to the departure date.  We did decide to use a car top carrier on the trip so we would have more room for some extras. Departure is now 0-35 days and closing.   I am happy to report that Jeff, my young nephew who lives in Portland Oregon has a drivers license.  I mentioned earlier in this text that Jeff was 24 years old with no license and his presence on the trip depended on his getting one, he did and all 4 members are now ready to go. The weather has warmed up in Connecticut and training rides are going well.  Yesterday it was 90 degrees (to much to soon).  I did a 30 mile hilly ride which was a little to much in that kind of heat.  May is bicycle month but don't forget it is also May Flies Month and Mosquito month, they ate me alive yesterday while I was trying to fix a flat.  TAKE YOUR BUG SPRAY WITH YOU WHEN YOU RIDE. Yesterday I began to pack every thing that I will need for the trip.  As with any trip, I have much to much stuff and I haven't even packed clothing yet, oh well.  The good part is, packing made me feel like its almost here.  That's not true with 20 days to go but it feels good anyway.  I can't believe I got all this stuff on my bicycle for last years tour. When the trip actually begins, I will make daily entries when a computer is available.  There will be a daily entry for all 46 days eventually.  Pictures will have to be added when we return home in July. As of Friday May 25, my part of the adventure will begin.  At that time I will go to Daily entries along with "from where to where plus mileage".  The first 5 days will be driving across America and that will be an adventure in itself.  I will spend a day in Mooresville Ind. visiting with my sister then on to pick up Jerry near Carbondale Ill.  From Jerry's place we will drive straight to Portland Oregon via I-70, I-80, and then I-84 to Portland.  The estimate is that we will arrive in Portland some time in the afternoon or evening on the 30th of May.  We will then pick up Jeff and go on the Astoria where we will stay for two nights in a motel getting ready for departure on the bikes. Please don't forget to sign the guess book while you are here.
The weather in Astoria on the 30th and 31st was beautiful, sunny and  warm all day, both days. In the morning on the 31th we decided to take a short ride to the bike shop to take care of a couple of problems. When we got there the shop  did not open until 10 am so we decided to ride to Fort Clatsop which is  where Lewis and Clark wintered in 1806.  The ride to the Fort was great with sunny and warm weather.  The ride to Fort Clatsop used part of the  Trans-American bike trail so it was an opportunity of us to ride a little  of the bike trail and check out the condition of our bikes after the long ride on the back of the car.  Over all we rode more than 27 miles getting to and from the Fort. It was great, the weather was great.    When we got back to Astoria the bike shop was open, we took care of a  problem with Jeff's bike and spent the rest of the day enjoying Astoria and the warn sunny weather.  We were all very excited about the next  morning which was the official start of our trip. At first we noticed it was extremely difficult to get all four bike on the  "four bike rack".  We solved that by going to Fred Meyers and purchasing  a cheap single bike rack which we hung off the rear of the vehicle between the  four bike rack and the vehicle.  It worked well.  We knew we had a lot of stuff so we decided to do a practice run on getting  everything in, on, or hanging from the car.  We filled three parking spaces with all the equipment each of us brought.  Then we attempted to get it all in or on the car.  We managed to load the car with NO spare room, however,the car was so loaded we couldn't get at anything, including our biking clothes for the next day.  Faced with the car being so stuffed with gear, none of us were very happy about the prospects of getting our gear in and out.   THAT'S THE GOOD NEWS NOW THE BAD NEWS On the morning of June 1st it was raining very hard with high winds and  cold.  No way could we ride in that kind of weather.  So we talked and  decided to use the vehicle and go ahead and travel to Newport where friends of Jerry's lived.  The weather forecast was for several days of bad weather so even though Newport was 4 days into our trip by bike it was only a half day by car. The thinking was as long as we left the coast from Florence, we  would still be going from coast to coast so it was not important that we  ride to Florence by bike.    Being worried about getting at our gear, on the way to Newport, we spotted  a "U Haul" dealer.  They had a trailer just the right size for our vehicle which would take our bikes and most of our gear and make life on the road  so much easier.  We rented it and will drop it off in Georgia and now everyone is happy, specially Bob. We spent the evening in Newport getting a great tour of the area by Jerry's friends which included a fine "all you can eat" meal which pleased Jeff to no end, at a place with a good view of the ocean.  Dave and Mary outdid them  selves with a very good breakfast the following morning, after providing us  with good sleeping quarters for the night.  Our thanks go out to Dave and Mary for their hospitality! GUESS WHAT? Its raining again for the second day of our bike trip.  To our advantage it's supported to be our 5 day, but getting back into the car again is not making any of us very happy.  We will be ready to ride today hoping the weather  improves at some point during the day.  We are spending some additional time  with Dave and Mary hoping to wait out the rain. Stay tuned for the wonderful adventures of "Walt, Robert, Jerry, and Jeff".
  The weather on day 2 was still not good, however when we were ready to leave Newport it cleared enough to ride the bikes.  All 4 of us dipped our rear wheels in the Pacific Ocean at South Beach State Park just outside of Newport.  Dipping the bike was not easy since the parking lot and the beach was quite a walk over soft sand.  We carried our bike to avoid getting sand all over them.    The riders for the day then took off for Florence while the sag driver waited for about 30 minutes before taking off.   After 15 miles the sky opened up again and we were drenched and had to stop riding again.  We all piled into the car and drove on to Florence and got a motel and it was still raining.      
   We checked into a motel in Eugene in mid afternoon and found we had a problem with Jeff's bike.  Since it was Sunday only one of three bike shops was open.  We called the bike shop and rushed over to get the bike repaired. The female mechanic was very good at fixing bicycles and also very cute; Jeff was in love. In the evening we had diner with Wendy and Richard at a very nice restaurant brew pub.  We had a great time talking with Wendy and Richard about the lousy weather in Oregon among other things.
  What a great day! Bright and sunny and a pleasant temperature.  We started the ride beyond the city center on deserted back roads which were wonderful.  After 22 miles the back roads connected with highway 126.  The connection was far enough beyond the city to have minor traffic.  We had a great ride with a slightly up hill grade all the way to McKenzie Bridge.   The weather continued to be sunny and wonderful for the whole ride causing us to take our first camp site.  The was part of a hot springs resort complete with a lodge and cabins.  We set up our tents with some comedy because it was our first time camping.  We did laundry, went into the spa, and showered.  As we set around our camp site we noticed the clouds moving in.  The rain started while we were preparing our evening meal and did not stop for the next two days; Oregon's Weather Sucks!
   We decided to hang around for the day because we wanted to try to ride McKenzie Pass the next day if the rain stopped. We decided to check out McKenzie Pass by car since it was going to be the hardest ride yet.  The temperature when we started up the mountain was 49 degrees and dropped to 37 degrees at the top.  Jeff and Walt saw snow when they climbed to the top of the observatory.  Our decision not to ride today was a very wise one. We spent the day exploring the area and stayed at a motel in Bend because it was cheaper than Sisters.    
   From McKenzie Bridge to the top of the McKenzie Pass is 23 miles.  The first 7 miles are not very steep but the next 11 miles are "wing dingers".  Nothing but switch backs all the way.  After mile 18 the last stretch is easier.  The ride up the mountain was a four hour uphill bike ride the likes of which we had never experienced before.  The 15 miles down hill to Sisters was wonderful and welcome by all.  We all came to the conclusion that the west bounders had it easy.    The Cell Phone does not work in this area so no call home tonight. We are going out to party tonight!
   We are camping tonight at Ochoco Lake County Park.  The best campsite yet by far.  Beautiful lake with a nice view from our site.    Tonight we feasted on hot dogs, hot sausage and baked beans.  What a great meal!  If you remember the movie Mel Brookes did called "Blazing Saddles" then you know what it was like around our site later that evening. Fortunately there was not many other campers.   
     Tonight we camped in Mitchell's City Park.  Mitchell is a very friendly little town out in the middle of nowhere.  We were all set to go out to dinner when we found Mitchell had a power outage which lasted several hours.  So Bob made his famous Chili which was a replay of last nights "Blazing Saddles".  It was quite good.  While here, we visited the John Day Fossil Beds National Monument.  The fact that the area was at one time a tropical jungle fascinated everyone. We camped with John and Briar from New Zealand whom we met first at Ochoco Lake the night before.  They are a husband and wife traveling from Vancouver, BC. to Nova Scotia using the Trans-American bike route.  Two very delightful people.   
   Then we had a 33 miles downhill ride of our lives to Dayville.  We felt so good after the downhill we decided to go on to Mt Vernon for the evening where we stayed at Clyde Holliday State Park.  It seems the State campgrounds in Oregon are very nice and always have showers.    We found a laundromat in Mt Vernon which allowed us to have clean clothes again. We have observed that Jerry really misses Annalee because he is always misplacing little things and asking us to help him find them.
  It was a 47 degree day with the threat of rain when we got up this morning.  It pays to ride early.  It was level from Mt Vernon to Prairie City but then from there to Dixie Pass was very steep.  We managed to complete the ride before the rains came and complete the downhill to Austin Junction.  Because of the rain we took rooms at Sag's Motel for the night which was back in Prairie City.  Sag's was the only motel around and caters to construction crews so it was a little different than we were used to although we did sleep well.   
   Again today we started in 47 degree weather and rode with the threat of rain all day.  After the two passes totaling 20 miles of climbing it was a beautiful downhill of 31 miles to Baker City. It was a great ride except for the cold and rain in our faces.  Again because of the cold and rain we decided to take a motel.  Jerry is delighted because he has a bathtub. All riders are getting better at doing the passes now that we have done about 6.  We will continue to improve as we ride more.  Look out Rocky Mountains here we come.    
  41 degrees this morning but we do have some sun.  As we left Baker City we passed the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center which we had visited last night.  What an impressive view from their large windows of remains of the Oregon Trail.   After we passed the Interpretive Center we encounter high cross winds which gave Jeff more trouble than the rest of the riders because of their increased bulk vs Jeff.  Within several hours the cross wind turned to a tail wind and we had a great ride that followed the Powder River.    However, at one point Walt saw white caps on a farmers pond so we were glad they were tail winds.  It was a great downhill ride until we reached Richland where we had to climb a short but steep hill to get to our destination of Halfway. We camped in a barn yard (shades of last years ride) although it had showers.  The cow munching on grass near the fence and the visiting dog during the night made for interrupted sleep.  Diner at the local bowling alley was a highlight of our evening.
  Who says the 13th is bad luck, its June 13th and we have the first nice day in as many.  First 34 miles was easy riding mostly downhill to Oxbow and Brownlee Dams.  Hells Canyon is a beautiful ride.  We rode along the Canyon for about 9 miles.  At Brownlee Dam we ran into the local sheriff who thought we were out of our minds.  He was a very pleasant man.  We also crossed into Idaho at Brownlee Dam.  Then we began a 13 miles climb up Brownlee Creek to 4125 feet.  After 7 passes they all seem the same.  At the summit we coasted without having to pedal a stroke unless we wanted to. We have began to see a lot of animals, fox, deer, cows, horses and many birds. We stayed at the Frontier Hotel and Campgrounds which had showers and a Laundry which we all needed.  Dinners out here are so cheap we don't have to cook unless we want to.  Top of the menu is $9.00.    
   We rode mainly uphill today.  It was 48 miles most of which was not hard until the last part which started at Council.  We had two uphill rides which came at the end of the day making it a pain because we were tired.  The last 5 miles was downhill to New Meadows which is at about 4000 feet.     We stayed at Zim's campground and saw the remains of a burned out $75 to $100k motor home which burned just before we arrived.  The owners returned from taking their grandkids fishing only to find nothing left of their motor home.  The family just sit down and cried.  One of the residents had videotaped the fire and showed us a replay on his camcorder.  What a tragedy.    
  Today was a long day but almost all downhill except for a couple of small hills at the very end of the day.  In Riggins we ran into another deputy sheriff who also thought we were nuts.  He too was very pleasant.  When we ask him if we could ride on the side walks in Riggins, his reply was we have no rules in Idaho just don't hurt anyone.  The police and sheriffs are your friends when you are riding bikes in the middle of no where. We rode along the Little Salmon River through some of the most dramatic countryside we have ever seen.  The Little Salmon River became the Salmon River complete with white water rafting.  It must have been trout season because there were hundreds of people fishing along the highway.    We arrived at White Bird to find no room at the Inn because of the annual rodeo.  We loaded up the bikes and drove to Grangeville to get a room.  At this very moment we are using the computer of Ken, our motel owner, who kindly let us update our journal from his home computer.  Stay tuned.
   After the hill it was on to Grangeville again where we gathered up the trailer and then rode on to Kooskia through some very beautiful countryside.  The ride was all downhill so the second half of the day was easy riding.  We camped along the Clear Water River but unfortunately they were selling fire works next to the campground so it was a noisy night but we slept anyway.
  #We are still following the Clear Water River and beginning to see lots of fishing as well as white water rafting.  When we reached Lowell the river became the Lochsa which means rough waters.  We traveled 20 miles beyond Lowell and then placed the bikes in the trailer and returned to Lowell where we stayed at the Three Rivers Campground.    It was a pleasant downhill day with good weather and all the riders enjoyed it.  The countryside gets more beautiful every day.  We are all impressed with Idaho so far.  Diner was at a restaurant overlooking the Lochsa River, what a view.     
  The trip from Lowell to Powell was an all day climb to the base of Lolo Pass.  The ride continued through beautiful country and could have been the subject of a good jig saw puzzle.  Not to hard a ride but as usual it ended with a heart breaker uphill.  We don't mind the uphills but not at the end of the day. We all stayed in a cabin at the Lochsa Lodge.  It had 4 beds including Jeff's which was hung from the ceiling.  We had another evening of "Blazing Saddles" because Dixon had some beer with his dinner.  In spite of all this we got along very well and did not loose any sleep.  We started to call Bob "Mr. Magoo" because he never has his glasses on when he reads the map and we end up with some really strange mileage estimates.   
   At Lolo Pass we crossed into Montana our third state on this bike trip.  This is the Pass that Lewis and Clark had so much trouble with during their expedition.  Had it not been for the Nez Perce Indians, their expedition would have ended here.  Jerry enjoyed all the posted Lewis and Clark camp sites along the way.  Walt enjoyed Fort Fizzle.    We had less trouble than Lewis and Clark crossing Lolo Pass.  After the first 13 miles the ride was all down but with a strong head wind so it was not an absolute joy.  We arrived in Missoula around 4pm on the bike lane of a large busy highway which we were not over joyed with.  We are staying in a KOA Campground and had dinner at an all you can eat restaurant.  If everyone ate like we did at the restaurant it would go out of business.
Jerry found new tent poles to replace the broken ones that he had been repairing with tape as he would have done it on the farm.  None of us thought that he would ever find them. Jeff bought two new science fiction books so he wouldn't have to go to sleep with the old timers at 7pm. Walt also bought another book and got a new battery for his camera.   We all did our laundry, updated the web site and visited Adventure Cycling Headquarters.  After 19 days of riding our bikes all need attention so that is the last chore of today, cleaning and adjusting the bikes.
  The route today was flat with no hills to speak of.  The group made the run to Hamilton by 1pm.  From Lola to Florence Rt. 93 was under heavy construction.  Fortunately there was a new bike path the whole 9 miles to our turn off in Florence. Finding a campground was not easy.  We ended up 8 miles south of Hamilton at a family campground.  Now we will have to back track to Hamilton in the morning to start the bike ride.    We had our first flat tire today, Jeff's rear tire picked up a piece of glass.  We fixed it in 20 minutes and were on our way. We were going to be treated to Bob's famous Chili tonight but there is no picnic table so we are going to find a cheap restaurant. Walt has put his Kudos (energy bars) under lock and key.  At the beginning of the trip Walt bought plenty of Kudos and offered to share with everyone.  We all took advantage of his offer and depleted his stock.  Since no one replaced them, Walt went out and bought some more and has hidden them from the rest of us.  Not fair! (More than fair says Walt!)
Route 93 continues to be very busy between Hamilton and Darby.  These small towns are feeder towns serving the entire Bitterroot Valley.  There's a steady stream of traffic coming into and leaving each of these towns. Sula turns out to be a KOA Campground, gas station, and cafe.  The KOA was unsuitable for tents.  After checking out two other Cabin/Campsites (one of which offered to put the four of us up in a cabin for $160 which put Jerry and Bob into a state of shock) we decided to return to Darby and took a normal motel for the night.  This part of the Bitterroot Valley was hit hard by the forest fires last summer.  Some 70 homes were burned.  The fires were finally put out when winter arrived.  The route we are traveling was closed to traffic during August last summer.  Interestingly enough Morrell Mushrooms only grow the first year after a forest fire.  There are a multitude of mushroom pickers sharing the lodging facilities with us.  If they can pick a hundred pounds of mushrooms they can make $300 a day.    
At noon today we finished the first half of our 45 day ride.  23 days of riding bikes is a long time.  We expect to make Pueblo without any trouble by July 15th. The ride from the pass to Wisdom was 26 miles of mostly downhill through forest and mountain streams then into a big flat valley (Big Hole Valley).  We are still on the route that Lewis and Clark took.    Our biggest problem today was Mosquitoes.  We encounter a cloud of them when we stopped at the Big Hole Monument.  They were so bad we thought they were going to carry both the bikers and the car away.  We broke out the Off but it was not much help so we had to keep riding without stopping until we got to Wisdom and escaped into a restaurant for lunch.  After lunch we made an 18 mile nonstop ride to Jackson to escape being eaten alive.  A breeze came up and blew them away while we were in Jackson. We stayed the night at the Jackson Hotsprings Lodge in a two room cabin with 4 beds for $27 each.  It was one of the best places we stayed.  The meal was the first meal up to Walt's eastern standards.
   We stayed at a KOA Campground which had plenty of shade and to our surprise we ran into our friends from New Zealand.  John and Briar had caught up to us because we took a day off in Missoula.  It was good to see them again. We were going to cook but the winds were too great so we ate Pizza at Poppa T's in Dillon.  We enjoyed it very much and nothing was left when we finished.  The high winds we experienced last evening help keep the Mosquitoes at bay. We took the car and did a tour of Dillon which is the home of Western Montana University.  It was a pretty little college town with a beautiful campus.
  The first 20 miles today was wonderful.  We rode it in about 1 1/2 hours.  Then we turned right at Twin Bridges onto a different highway and had a head wind and an uphill stretch which challenged us all.  The slow going took the strength out of all of us and we decided to have an early lunch in Sheridan. After lunch we continued on to Alder and to our surprise we had a tail wind all the way.  We are camping at a nice KOA and Bob is finally getting to make his famous Chili again tonight.  Blazing Saddles revisited. We are all looking forward to Yellowstone Park which will come in three more days.
Virginia City is an exact reproduction of the original city from the gold rush days.  It is now a tourist attractions with all the appearances of a gold rush western town. Tonight we are sleeping at the Madison River Lodge.  What a great place and reasonable too.  Jeff Bob and Walt shared a cabin with three beds and a video player and watched the Verdict with Paul Newman.  Great flick. The big event for today was the MOLD Jeff and Bob found growing in the bottom of their water bottles.  It took bleach to get it out.  The bottles had turned black with mold.  God knows how long it was there.     
   The ride from Cameron along highway 287 was beautiful.  We followed the river  through the Madison River Canyon Earth Quake area.  In 1959 there was an earth quake which caused a mountain side to fall into the Madison River.  The results was a lake formed where there was no lake before.  19 people were killed and the Madison river was blocked causing the backed up water to form a lake.  The Corp. of Engineers cut a spillway from the lake to the other side of the slide releasing some of the water.    After Quake Lake we rode along Hebgen Lake which is one of the water storage areas for Montana.  One of the prettiest rides we have had. This afternoon we did go visit old faithful and were lucky because we did not have to wait too long to see it erupt.  We found the Golden Eagle passes that both Bob and Jerry have very useful; they got us all into the Park free. West Yellowstone is a tourist trap with all the trimmings.  We are staying at  a KOA 6 miles west of West Yellowstone which is a nice campground but very busy and a lot of kids and adults making noise until 11pm.  We will be glad to be on the road again. 
  We did the upper loop of Yellowstone today by car.  We saw the upper and lower falls and Mammoth Hot Springs (which are almost dry).  Our animal list is now as follows: Buffalo, Elk, Moose, Deer, Coyote, Bear, Trumpeter Swan and lots of tourist type animals.    The fire damage to the park is extensive.  Everywhere we went the trees were gone and very small new trees were growing.  An advantage was you get a better view of the Park as you drive but at times it was depressing.      Tomorrow we are back on the road and glad of it.
   We crossed two passes inside Yellowstone, Craig Pass at 8261 and an unnamed pass at 8391.  We also crossed the Continental Divide two times.  Both passes were the highest yet.  We are all a little concerned about the thin air as we approach 9000 ft.     
  Today we crossed Togwotee Pass at 9658 ft.  This pass is the second highest pass on the Trans-American Bike Trail.  The climb started and continued for 17 miles.  The altitude did not effect us as much as we thought it would.  I guess we are in pretty good shape at this point in our ride.  It took less than 3 hours to climb and no one had any trouble.  We are back in the high desert again.  The temp was 94 degrees in the afternoon. After the pass we had a 29 mile downhill ride into Dubois with a tail wind.  We left Moran Junction at 8:30am and were in Dubois by 1pm.  Along the way we saw the Budweiser Clydedales as they passed us in their trailers.  They then corralled outside of Dubios.  The locals we asked thought they were filming another commercial. We camped at the Circle Up Campground.  It was somewhat shaded from the 94 degree temp.  The campsite has showers and laundry.  All the things we need to stay clean.  We have been able to camp at places that have showers for the most part.  An absolute necessity.    
  For the second day in a row we are starting our ride with a tail wind.  Tail winds are next to food in order of importance to bikers.  Two in a row is a blessing. Our ride today has been through tree less terrain.  The rock formations changed as we rode.  There were some really pretty colors as we traveled on.  It was 95 degrees today and there was no shade at all not even a tree.  We tried to ride on schedule and did but the heat still got to us.   We spent the evening in Lander.  It really was an attractive city with pretty homes and a lovely canyon park.  They are having their annual rodeo event which starts tomorrow. Again we are glad we are getting out of town.
  Boy it got hot again today.  Another 95 degree day with no shade at all anywhere in route.  We got out on schedule and were finished by 1pm.  Sweetwater Station is the headquarters for the Shoshone Indians but had no sleeping facilities. We planned to stay in Jeffery City where there was one motel.  The best thing that happened was taking Jeff's picture by his city's sign.  What a place.  It looked like an abandoned military base and in fact was an abandoned Uranium processing town that once had 6000 people and now has 200.  Boarded up homes and apartments.  When the lady at the motel asked us if we had a reservation we thought we would laugh.  She wasn't kidding.  She was booked for the night with 14 Mormons and three other people so we went on to Rawlins which was the nearest town with accommodations. The heat and the desert conditions are getting to all of us.  The roads go on in a straight line for a long ways and are very boring to ride on.  Most of us find this type of riding to be no fun.   
We left Rawlings this morning on schedule and rode along I80 for 13 miles.  This is the first time we had ridden on an Interstate Highway.  We found it very difficult getting the bicycles up to speed with the traffic in order to merge (joke).  At first everything was fine as we rode along the shoulder but then we came to some construction and we were forced to ride within inches of the 65 mile an hour traffic mostly heavy trucks.  Quite scary.    After we got off the Interstate we had a 20 mile ride through the hot Wyoming desert to Saratoga.  Tonight we are staying in a motel and plan to be out of town before the fourth of July parade starts tomorrow morning. Today was Walt's Birthday and he rode with his very loud US Postal Shirt in celebration.  Go Lance Go.
Tonight we are staying in Riverside.  Jeff and Walt went to the local fireworks display at Encampment, CO.  The show was quite interesting.  The locals set off the longest display of fireworks we had ever seen, over an hour.  However, the debris falling upon the two girls in front of us and the rocket that went off sideways and hit the baseball backstop, led to some concern.  It was almost as dangerous as riding I80 but Jeff and Walt survived.  This fireworks display will be remembered forever.
   Again today was hot in the high desert with mostly flat terrain.  We had a narrow shoulder but not too much traffic so the ride was pleasant.  The terrain was sage brush and grass, cow country. There was no place to stay so we moved forward to Kremmling.  In Kremmling we had a very nice camp site at a trailer park with real green grass which we rented for two nights.  Tomorrow we will have to go back to Colorado Creek to start our ride where we left off.  We will actually end our ride in Kremmling tomorrow night. We found the food in Kremmling to be not too good.  In fact we have had trouble getting good food lately.
Because of the bad food we have been getting Jeff was going to cook for us this evening in Kremmling but thunder and lightening with heavy winds caused us to have to go out and eat again, not good.   Tomorrow its on to Dillon/Silverthorne and all the tourists and traffic.
  The bad shoulders with heavy traffic continued today.  In order to avoid at least some of the traffic we decided to go around Green Mountain Reservoir costing us an extra 4 miles and several steep up hills but the scenery was great and the traffic was non existent.  But all good things come to an end and we had to get back on the poor roads to finish the ride into Dillon.    One good thing about the heavy tourist area of Dillon was some good restaurants and we took advantage of it.  Dinner was at a nice Italian restaurant with great food.  The first real food we have had in a number of days. We did a preview of Hoosier Pass (11542 ft.) and it scared the hell out of all of us.
  We had beautiful bike paths all the way from Dillon to Breckenridge (19 miles) which made the ride a pleasure because it avoided all the tourist traffic.  Once we started up the pass the weather began to get cloudy and got worse the higher we climbed.  About 3 miles from the top all hell broke loose with cold rain and hail balls the size of peas (some larger).  It was like mother nature was trying to tell us not to climb her pass.  We didn't listen and keep on climbing with our rain gear on and finally made it to the top (11542 ft., the highest on the Trans-American Trail) wet and cold.  This was the first wet weather we have had to ride in since Oregon.    Show links to this Hide links to this       July 8, 2001   Tonight we are in Fairplay, a very interesting little town, complete with a rebuilt western style town museum.  We did some shopping and wandered around town until dinner and had another bad meal. Tomorrow its on to Canon City.
  Today was one of the most beautiful rides we have had with bright sunshine and clear skies.  The first 16 miles was uphill but after we crossed Currant Creek Pass (9404 ft.) it was a great downhill ride.  The scenery was beautiful with Fir trees, rolling hills and flowing brooks.  While we haven't eaten yet, we are hoping that Canon City is large enough to have a better choice of food than we have been experiencing.  Bob claims he can feel his arteries closing a little more every day eating local food. This was our next to last day since we will be in Pueblo tomorrow.  We all are excited about going home but will miss all the different experiences we have had every day.
After the ride we drove to Colorado Springs where we picked up a motel room, showered, and headed by car for Pikes Peak.  The trip up Pikes peak was highlighted by the car over heating on the way up the mountain.  We stopped and waited for the car to cool and made it the rest of the way up the mountain.  What a great view from the top.  Well worth all the effort. This is our last day and ends our trip for this year. Thanks to all who sent us messages, we enjoyed them very much.  Tune in next year for the continuation (maybe) of our adventure. Jerry, Jeff, Bob, and Walt.
We stopped in Tamaroa dropped off Jerry and had dinner with his lovely wife and daughter.  Jeff and Walt were very impressed with the size of Jerry's farm.  They had been hearing about it for 40 days and now had a tour of the entire facilities including the grain bins and how they work. The following morning (the third day) we headed for Cumming, Georga to drop off Walt.  We arrived in Cumming at about 4:30 pm and found a place to drop off the U-Haul after empting it of all our gear.  We would never have made it without the U-Haul, it was a trip saver.  We had already taken off the plastic carrier from the roof of the car in Tamaroa (it belonged to Jerry).  We spent the night with Walt and left for Port Jervis N.Y. and Bethany CT the following morning (the fourth day).  We got on the road at 6:30 am and arrived in Port Jervis at about 9:30 pm.  The ride from Port Jervis is about 2 hours so I arrived home at 11 pm.  Its well over 900 miles from Cumming to Bethany so it was a long day. The ride was great allowing us to see some of the most beautiful country in the world at a very slow pace.  While we have not made any plans for next summer, I'm sure that all of us will be back on bicycles doing some kind of ride ever if its not together. Thanks to all who visited our site and left messages, we loved them.  Happy riding.
Off to "Down Town" to the Royal British Columbian Museum....WOW now that is a museam...... I would have to say proberbly the best one that I have ever visited.... Then off to the Parliament Buildings...... built in 1803 I think....almost 200 years ago......again beautifully restored and maintained...... They had actors tell some of the history of the place.... Amor el la Cosmos and Nelly....... An excellent day...great company.....beautiful weather.......
I will cycle up the East Coast of Vancouver to Port Hardy...then catch a ferry to Prince Rupurt, which is right on the BC and Alaska boarder and then cycle HW16 all the way back to Jasper and Baniff...about 1000km, but absolutely breathtaking........ Had my bike checked at a local bike shop.... bought some extra wet weather gear for the trip.......
Pretty cruzy day...watch a video What Women Want....Jan did not understand it.....Oh well....... The Vancouver trip is about 500km it should take me about 5 days.....
Boy did that make my eyes water.......
I went thru Fanny Bay, I was wondering what the funny smell was then realized that this is where they harvest huge amounts of oysters.... I know what you were thinking Pete!!!!! Met some other cyclist in the campground....... Had a few beers....A nice Canadian drop Okanagan Spring Brewery....not bad but beer is quite expensive here in canada...
Cycled thru Parksville and Qualicum Beach (funny name....impossible to pronounce!!!!) Then into Courtenay, Comax.... I decided to stay at Miracle Beach....very nice  campground.... very clean and well set out.... The public beach was just great...shady areas to sit and quite nice water for swimming (If you like hobbling over rocks, and shells to the water which is 200m  out when the tide is out..... I went to the Amplitheatre (sp) and listened to a great talk on whales.... The sun does not set here now till 10:30pm...WOW and it is up at 5am.... Tomorrow Campbell River and get some information for the rest of my trip... I will catch the Ferry from Port hard on Sunday for Prince Rupurt...it takes about 15 hours...I am really klooking forward to the trip...it should be the highlight......
Very pretty though ..... back to Campbell River and then on HW19 to Sayword... A big day, quite hot but really great...... I camped at a rest stop because there was no camping ground... It was good, plenty of grass. toilets...what else could a man ask for...... I finally pitched my tent at 10pm.....and straight to sleep  ZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz............
The Nimpish Valley is quite pretty....... mountains.....snow....on either side of the HW..... Rolling hills, beautiful lakes......boy some people have it tough..... This area is pretty remote..... I could not find a campgroung to stay..... looks like another rest stop tonight..... I had a "bush" shower..... stripped to my birthday suit and hung a water bag in a tree.... it worked well, the river water was a little cold!!!!! I cooked my tea about 20m from my tent and hung all my food from a tree....better safe than bear food..... A little rain.... not too heavy....into the tent and a warm sleeping bag....
Easy ride to Woss, tea and bickies....then a nice ride into Port Hardy.... The Ferry to Prince Rupert leaves from here at 7:30am tomorrow...... The Wildwoods Campground is very nice, only $7/night...bargain....and a hot shower!!!!! Met some fellow cyclists.... A Belgium guy, 63yo very organized..... Canadian guy ..... nice guy Glenn, from Victoria, he has done a lot of cycling in Canada and US... he is on a three week trip with an American, Paul,from New Hampshire, also a super nice guy..... I'll tell you more about these two later.... They are quite wakky and it will be good fun riding with them.... We shared a couple of Buds (Paul and me)to bed...... Now did I tell you that Tasmanians are a really different breed..... A Tassie guy and his young son, arrived......boy where they happy campers!!!! I dont think they had camped before.....they really had no idea.....I was really tired and they talked all night.... Glenn was about 10 seconds from snotting one of them...... Finally to sleep by 1:00am....... I am really tired tonight......
The ferry winds its way between islands in Queen Charlotte Sound... its quite a fantastic trip..... there are hundreds of islands here....and some of the communities are really isolated....... In fact some of the places are only visites by boat once or twice a week.....many only by sea plane.... It was quite comfortable on board....they have movies, talks and serve really nice buffet style meals.... I pigged out at the dinner buffet on salmon.....Orgasmic!!!!!!! The ferry was really late and arrived at 1:00am Monday......really late (almost 3 hours!!!!) Really tired... only a 1 km trip to the campground.......No lights.....thank goodness that the Belgium guy had lights on his bike!!!!!!! Pitched the tent in the dark....the ground was so soggy that there were wooden platforms for the tents........  Crawled into the tent........hope I sleep.....
Only 4 hours sleep...I hope I survive today..... These guys hammered today and we did almost 100 miles...... WOW.....the Skeena Valley..... fantasic.......Very flat riding, huge mountains....water falls, thousands of feet tall..... snow capped mountains... The Yellow Head HW is fantastic.....it follows the Skeena River for hundreds of km..... and guess what..... tail winds!!!!!!! Unfortunately the lack of sleep over the last few days has finally caught up with me...... The campground at Terrace was lousy!!!! No showers.....muddy......but I think we were all so tired that we did not notice it that much....... Tomorrow the ride to Kitwanga should be really nice.... there are Indian Villages there with Totem Poles.... These are really interesting..... they have marriage totems which dipict the history of the families...They are thousands of years old!!!!!
I am a little saddle sore... I have bought a new saddle (special male one...to help protect the crown jewels!!!!) I kissed the old one goodbyebefore I thew it in the bin...we have grown quite close over the past few months...... The Skeena River is very fast flowing and there are hundreds of fisherman catching (or trying to catch) salmon.....huge ones (20-30 pounds!!!!) It would be a great river to do some kayaking on......quite wide.....and a good flow.... 10-20 km/hr at least.... Again plenty of mountains......snow caps......wonderful!!!!!! The RV park was excellent......$5 night, plenty of grass and surrounded by mountains........ Glenn is the cook and he has cooked up some really nice meals.......spag bos...very nice...... A good night's sleep I hope..... I played my first game of horseshoe......I got rolled by Paul......but managed to score a ringer!!!!!!!
Saw the totem poles at Kitwanga - then on to New Hazelton, what a neat little town...... I spent a couple of hours looking around..... Caught up with the guys in Morice Town, a nice RV park here, only $4/night...... Glenn made Clam Chowder and ham and cheese sandwiches for tea..... I like travelling with these guys...... Genn, from Victoria, the mad Canadian, mid 50's interesting guy, he has done a lot of cycle touring in Canada and the USA, he needs to put some of it on the web for otheres to share..... Paul, American, from New hampshire, 60ish, quite (this is very unusual for an American!!!!) Any way Glenn is the cook, he buys the tea and cooks it, Paul and I are the lackies, we clean up...... Hey I dont mind I have had the best meals in 2 months.... Glenn has this thing about going to a restraunt for breakfast...... it does not matter if we have to ride 10km or 60km, he still stops for breakfast, bacon, eggs, toast, pancakes....the works!!!!!!! We are now travelling along the Bulkley River, the Hazelton Mountains are on one side...... Lots of high peaks, snow capped, the highest peak in this group Mt Cronin (2,386m)...... The ride is really nice, shit hot!!!!, if fact........
I had a side wall blowout on my rear wheel, I will not be buying City Slickers for my bike again, that is two tyres in 6,000 km, they just do not make them the way they used to!!!!! The seven sisters, a group of snow capped mountains, are absolutely spectacular, they have glaciers...... Had a nice climb today.... Hungry Hill, 6 mile climb to 844 m, not bad.....
I went into town and had a look at the largest fly fishing rod in the world, 50 feet long....... Nice rolling hills, plenty of trees and lakes....quite pretty.... Stopped at Rose Lake....now this place was very nice and you can free camp there.... Finally stopped at Burns lake, KOA campground.... rang Nat for the first time in ages... Hi Nat!!!!!  Did you know that my Natalie now has a degree in marketing from Notre Dann University!!!!! She graduated this month.... I am very proud of her and I will be using her skills to make a lot of money (NOT)..... Natalie now has a job with the Broome Tourist Dept, (click to show email), and is really loving it......  Well Glenn excelled himself tonight... we had all American (Canadian Beef) hamburgers..... I would have to say that they were the best I have had in a very long time...... As I said... I am quite happy to be a lackky if someone does all the cooking..... Paul and I just sit down and read our books!!!!!!!!!!! Anyway tomorrow is a short ride...... The weather has been perfect..... No rain, Warm, and a tail wind..... I think that Jan must be praying for me!!!!!
Now me I get up, make a nice pot of Englisg Breakfast tea...... then I have my bagles, peanut paste (not peanut butter!!!!!) and banananana (I know how to spell banana, I just dont know when to stop!!!!)......... Well the guys went off..... God gets even....they cycled 60km before breakfast...., It was lunch time and they had stop serving!!!!!!! Me..... I have my coffee at a 7/11...... $1 for a big 20oz cup.... the Big Gulp!!!! I got caught in a thunderstrom...only lasted 20 minutes.....then it dried out...and the night was really pleasant..... The campground was really nice..... its great travelling with other people... One of the advantages is that it only costs $3-$5/night vs $15-$18..... Bed by 9pm, it is really hard to get to sleep when it is still dard till 10:30pm....
A 20km/hr tail wind right up the Klacker!!!!!!!! Nice rolling hills, a few lakes...very pleasant..... Tea was very healthy.... 5 hot dogs..... Boy I felt sick!!!! (Not that it was Glenns cooking, I just stuffed myself!!!!!) Did a little maintainance on my bike and tent... seam sealed all the stitching and oiled and adjusted the running gear..... Tomorrow Prince George.... Glenn has a good friend there, Ben, he is a real cowboy!!!! I am enjoying the guys company heaps...they give me shit about my peanut paste sandwiches but hey..... I will be the one to laugh when a bear chases us and I have the energy to out-race it.... Boy the mosquitos are bad.... I have been bitten on almost every part of my body....except there!!!!!! Long pants, tucked into socks, long shirt...... and the b........s still manage to find a place to bite ya..... At night you should hear them on the mesh of the tent....... Lucky I use the "Sascha, piss bottle" that way you dont have to leave the tent during the nite.....
Quote "It is only a short ride today....., 15 miles, breakfast just over the hill" Anyway 30 miles later we got to Ben's house.... what a great guy, he is the lease manager at the local Ford Company..... We went cruzing in a truck!!!! What a beast!!!!! Big V-8, grunter....... When Ben finished work we went Bear spotting on a local ranch, 500,000 acres...that is big.... Well be did not see any bears but we some two really agressive bunnies....... His loverly wife Marie made a great tea....... thanks guys... They have a loverly home just outside Prince George, about 5 acres, two horses, a barn..... really neat..... and they are very civilized and drink tea..... camped out on the back lawn..... A required motel evening because it was the final game of the Stanley Cup and one of the guys (who shall remain nameless) was not about to miss seeing his man Ray Bourque's last bid for the Cup after his 22 years in the game.  Matt enlightened Phil and Chad (admitted hockey ignoramuses) on the finer points of the game so we could all enjoy this historic event a little more.  Congrats Ray!  We're sure the folks back in Boston enjoyed that moment too.    
Crossed our first time zone en route to Wisconsin so we reset our clocks to transport us to that magical place known as the 'Central Time Zone'.  Took some photos at the Welcome to Wisconsin sign and checked out the visitors center for route ideas to take us across Wisconsin.  We were all struck at how beautiful, green, and clean Wisconsin appeared and, especially in comparison with Michigan (no offense Michigan), how well maintained and marked the roads were...the local county roads which we prefer for cycling are lettered so our route would be something like count road A to P to X to C to XX to CS, etc Started to rain on us shortly after we hit the road and continued to soak us silly.  We hit our 1,000 mile mark and shortly after we came upon a smiling moose - actually 'The Smiling Moose', a bar and grill in the unincorporated town of Osman.  A woman on the porch next door suggested that we should stop a spell as music was about to begin and she even offered to let us put our bikes in the garage - couldn't pass up the opportunity to hear some local music, dry out a bit, and christen our 1000 mile marker with a beer.  Listened to some blues and rock by the Brent Anderson band from New Orleans before getting back on the road - the weather had cleared up quite a bit and the rest of the ride was absolutely gorgeous through rolling farmlands and no shortage of cows (in addition to being Chad's birthplace, Wisconsin, the Badger State, is of course 'America's Dairyland').  We started looking for places to camp and a guy on an ATV (the second fully intoxicated ATV pilot we had encountered) offered to let us pitch tents in his yard.  Decided this may not be the best place for us to lay our heads so pushed on to what may have been the buggiest place on earth in a park whose defining feature was a marsh with very social mosquitoes who wanted to get to know us intimately.  Quickly set up tents and called it a night.         

A tornado is something that, for those of us in the Northeast, is just a word or a movie effect.  We'll get back to that.   We pulled into town and grabbed a little cottage, by chance, and settled in.  Soon it was time for some eats and possibly a beer.  I was on the tired side so I decided to stay at the cottage, try to write a bit, and sleep.   Chad and Phil were interested in a little taste of local culture and decided to head on out for some nosh.  As I walked outside with them chatting about the next day I noticed an impressive storm front moving in.  We had heard about it but did not pay it much attention as we had weathered much already and foolishly thought we knew what was coming.  Thunderstorm Warning, by Northeast standards, don't require much prep other than the preparation for rain.  We were inside, so we were all set.  There was one other phrase tagged onto the warning, Tornado Watch.  Something that in my mind was still just an academic phrase, certainly not reality.  The radio voice also went through the explanation that this only meant that the conditions were right and not that there was one or would be one.  Anyway, as Phil and Chad left I proceeded about 200ft from the front of our cottage to the lakefront, to watch the storm roll in.  The line of clouds moving in were impressive and I thought I could get the chance to see a rain line move in over the lake.  The storm cloud front was also shaped like a phoenix with each wing tip stretching out to the horizon on either side (very cool).  It was dark now and very calm.  I was watching hundreds of little winged insects swarming a light very close to where I was.  The bugs were also all around and I was thinking about getting my camera and bug repellant when the wind just picked up.  Within five seconds there was a steady 15 - 20 mph wind and I had just enough time to think 'Great the bugs will go away'.  10 seconds later it was a strong 25 - 35mph wind. Again I had just enough time to think 'Wow this is really cool' when in less than another 10 seconds the wind had increased to 40 - 50 mph.  My mind now went quickly from 'This is Cool' to 'This may not be good'.  Maybe it was just an experiential comparison that caused alarm, where I had never felt wind increase so fast.  I know it was this quick because my mind had barely enough time to process the information.  There was a gust, on top of the steady wind, that knocked me back and my eyes fell on the water.  The water was churning in all directions where literally only moments ago it was calm.  Alarm turned to fear and I turned to make quick haste back to the cottage.  After about fifty feet the driving rain just appeared almost instantly soaking me and I was certain the wind had increased even more.  The wind was whipping in all directions and branches were breaking off the trees as I ran.  This is when that abstract word came back to me, tornado.  With the wind whipping and the rain driving and the water churning I remembered I was somewhere that tornadoes actually happened.  If this wasn't enough to scare the strength out of my knees, the rowboat that flew 6 feet in the air, 25 feet across a little inlet was.  By the way, I know it was 6 feet off the ground because I am 6 feet tall.  A flying rowboat, eye level, has a special effect on someone who is already trying to remember where you go in a tornado.  I covered the last 100ft in about 3 steps.  Oh and sometime between when I started running for the cottage and when I arrived the lights all went out.  When I opened the outer door of the cottage the wind caught it and knocked me off the porch.  I ran in and closed all the windows but the inside of the cottage was already ransacked.  I got a flashlight and realized that it had been a few minutes it had been a few minutes and I wasn't on my way to OZ.  Maybe no tornado.  But serious weather and it finally occurred to me that Chad and Phil were somewhere out in it (finally is a relative term, it had only been 5 minutes since I was standing serenely on the shore).  I threw on rain gear, grabbed the headlamp, and headed in the direction they came.  Self-composed-movie-based-tornado theory has it that one white guy alone will definitely get sucked up.  I found them hurtling down the road not too far off and we all raced back to the cottage where .I locked us out.  It took a few moments of recovery from what a bonehead move that was to remembering I didn't lock the windows when I shut them.  Chad, apparently sharing my alarm, began to climb in the window behind me when Phil reminded him I would soon open the door.  Phil on the other hand was having a good laugh.   We survived but the next day 75mph gusts were reported and a state of emergency was declared for the area around where we were due to the damage.  Also, about 3 miles from where we started, there was a fifty foot wide path of destruction that snapped and uprooted big trees, trashed a barn, and flipped and tossed very large farm equipment.  They called it straight line wind, possibly up to 125mph
  
  
      
The categories are Consumption, Flyby, Impact, and what we will call the Amplifier.  These are all equally intriguing and fascinating patterns of Human Bug Interaction (HBI).  They are patterns because they happen 50 - 100 times a day. CONSUMPTION.  Consumption has 3 sub categories, Hole in One, Chew, and Lucky Bastard.  Hole in One, refers to biking with your mouth open and getting any variety of insect types to fly right down the old pie hole.  No questions, no chances, no alternatives but to swallow immediately.  The Chew is when the bug does not fly as true and comes to rest in the midmouth.  This results in the reflexive mouth close and a good chance of starting the chewing process.  The size of the bug is directly related to the crunch factor.  The Lucky Bastard is very rare but observed on several occasions.  This is when the bug flies into the foremouth, is not chewed, is spit back out, and miraculously flies away unharmed. FLYBY.  The Flyby is visually impressive.  It involves usually bigger bugs that head right for your face and at the last minute veer off to miss only by fractions of an inch.  This is very common and can suggest purely by the frequency that it is purposeful.  Maybe a bug initiation of sorts.  The more exaggerated the duck and dodge by the Human results in more prestige for the Bug.  This is a dangerous maneuver, if miscalculated it will lead to the next category  IMPACT.  Impact has 4 subcategories, Single Impact, Ricochet, Multiple Impact, and Bulls eye.  The Single Impact is self-explanatory.  One bug + One hit = No Bug & One welt.  Ricochet can take many forms or combinations.  There is the Cheek/Elbow/Thigh combo.  The bicep/other bicep/neck combo.  The knee/thigh/chin combo, etc etc.  It isn't known how many bugs survive these impacts, as there is never any sign of life or death.  The Multiple Impact is just a swarm of bugs impacting either singly or ricochet at near exactly the same moment.  The Bulls eye is one of the most painful and involves one large bug and a single impact on the tip of the nose.   AMPLIFIER.  Without question the most unnerving of the interactions.  The Amplifier is when any size bug gets caught either directly or after a ricochet between your helmet strap and your ear.  The size of the bug does not matter as the proximity to your ear makes it sound like Mothra has landed on your head.  Flailing and violent head shaking is the usual result with irrational certainty that the bug will crawl into your ear for safety and that it is a bee.  This never happens but when the Amplifier occurs you always have the same reaction, same intensity.   Thank you for your time,  One of 3 Guys Biking
