Sunrise or Sunset Your Eyes Relaxation Peripheral Vision Here's how: -  Just before Sun is either rising in the east or setting in the west, take a moment to get into a comfortable relaxed state (as much as possible).  Empty your mind of distractions for just a moment or two.  For the rest of the instructions we will use the instance that the sun is setting but both work just as well. -  Don't look directly at the Sun.  When the sun is in contact with the horizon look to the left or the right keeping the Sun in your peripheral vision.  You may need to change your point of reference occasionally to see the Sun clearly in your peripheral.  Also, nights that have a not so bright Sun work best. -  At this point, if you are relaxed and relatively motionless, you can probably see the Sun setting, or in other words moving toward the horizon.  It is easiest to see this right at Sunset as the horizon accents the sun disappearing.  The horizon need not be flat or natural.  This can be done in the city or anywhere there is a defined horizon.  Actually the more there is on the horizon to show the relative movement of the earth and the sun, the better. -  This is sort of time sensitive, in that you must slow down time in your mind.  You can't see the sun setting in real time, you must watch over the course of a few minutes and you will see the differences (still in your peripheral vision).  If you slow down the run time in your head you will see the sun moving.  -  Now here is the tricky part (you must still be relaxed, even relax the muscles in your face).  Once you have a good sense of the sun moving then, at this point (not earlier), remind yourself that the Sun is not moving the earth is.  Remember that the earth is rotating away from the sun.  Don't try to see it, just know it.  Don't think about it, just let the reality settle in.  Stay with the slow run time in your mind and let what you see in your peripheral wind around what you know.  It won't happen right away but all of a sudden the Sun will stop moving and the earth will start rotating. Try it it's fun.  PS - No drugs of any kind are needed :)
  
  
    

    
      
  
And then there was the Knights Cellar.  Ahh Guinness.
  
    

After our talk, Chad and I pedaled out of town, both of us turning oven and over in our minds the information that Matt had shared with us.  I was in a foul mood and the coal mine with the tourist overlook that we cycled passed did not hold my interest.  From there on Chad and I biked separately for 30 miles.  There were no towns, few houses and the only store was one selling custom guns. Then we came upon the town of Spotted Horse.  The town is surrounded by open land and ranches, but has had a history of oil, coal and now, in the last couple of years, methane being drilled from these rolling hills.  The methane boom has brought more money to the area but at an environmental and community cost.  Troy, who came down the road on a 1963 John Deere tractor, told me that he hates the entire industry.  The ranchers feel forced to allow pumping on their property since the government often own mineral rights on the land (40 acres and a mule minus the minerals?). They get paid good money but mining pollutes the water that they desperately need.   The one thing that has not changed in Spotted Horse since 1924, is that there is a bar (that's the only thing there).  I will not bore you with all the bar stories, although I will say that the owner Dr. J. (who is at the bar more than he is behind it) and the two bar maids, Babe (who had a tattoo of a large mosquito that read "bite me") and Bull's Eye, took good care of us.  We slept in the field out back.        
    
For the first time in over 5 weeks, the 3 guys are sleeping in three different locations. Matt is in Cody, Chad went ahead to Shell and I decided to spend the night on the mountain.  As I hiked up a trail I ran into John, a local coming the other way. He sent me to this meadow to watch for Moose and Elk, none yet...          
    
1) 'I regretfully must inform all of you that I am not going to make it to the Pacific' 2) 'It is my great pleasure to inform all of you that I made it all the way to Wyoming' As you can see both statements are true and both statements are loaded with emotion, albeit contradicting.  I'm afraid that the one thing that they both say is that I am going home.  I am very proud of my accomplishment but at the same moment exceedingly disappointed that I will not make it to the other side with Phil and Chad.  Actually all things considered (40 lbs overweight when we started, minimal training, not an avid biker, etc) I have no idea how I made it this far.  I knew the pace we set was difficult in theory but I didn't realize how intensely difficult it would be in practice.  A typical day for me ended with complete exhaustion and the last two weeks contained many days that ended with exhaustion to the point of collapse.  Like my bike seat in the beginning of the trip I just figured that the exhaustion was the name of the game and that I would be stronger by the time we hit the mountains.  No doubt I am stronger now but by daily bringing myself to the outer edge of my physical capability I seem to have used up all my stored 'after-you-can't-go-any-further' energy (which I drew upon constantly).  I have never done any long distance anything, that required me to test my physical limits and I didn't know when, where, or how I would hit that fabled wall.  I waited for it on many a day, knowing that I was continually over extended.  My mistake was that I expected it to hit and just stop that day's effort.  I did not know, that for me, it would build up and stop the trip.  I am truly and completely exhausted.  Wyoming is quite a feat and there is no question that I have given all that I have to give (and more) but it will be difficult to sort out the feelings of accomplishment from the feelings of disappointment.  In order to complete a task of this size you must be quite focused and goal oriented.  The backlash to this is that if you don't make it, it is very difficult to not think of it as a failure.  I have taken a few extra rest days to try and sort all this out and to see if I could recharge, to see if I could finish at this pace.  As much as I don't want to believe it I have taken myself past my limit.   But on the other hand, what a limit!  I have never challenged myself to close to this level and I made it to Wyoming!  Phil and Chad could not have been better people to attempt this with (I was already of the opinion that they are two of the finest people on the planet).  They have been beyond supportive (they came up with more options; they could carry my gear, they could block the headwinds, they could pull me, they could carry me etc).  They have been the first to point out that just getting out here and giving it a shot is worthy of great pride.  And, although I didn't think it would be, it is.  There is quite a rush associated with having tried something so difficult.  I used to think that it was rationalization for people who didn't finish and maybe it is, but there is also a great feeling associated with just having got my fat ass and trying. If this were easy everyone would do it.  If you haven't stopped to consider the enormity of the whole trip and the level of difficulty still left for Phil and Chad to overcome, then do it now and stay tuned to the web.  Send encouragement via the guestbook on this site, it is great to get and believe me they will need it.  Obviously my heart is with them and I am sorry that my body is not.  Great Thanks to everyone who helped and supported me in this.  I surely would not have gone as far as I did with out you.   And then there were two.
In the late afternoon, once rest day business was complete, Chad and I went for an early dinner.  We ate at Irma's, the restaurant that was built by Buffalo Bill himself and named after his daughter.   Again blindly following local culture I had a buffalo burger.  It tasted much like a beef burger, but the thought of it was heavy as I explored the Buffalo Bill Historical Center. The white man wiped out 30 million Buffalo (bison) in a 30-year period.  Buffalo Bill is credited with brining the west to the rest of the world with his 'Wild West' tours at the turn of the century.  Although Bill's show presented a stereotypical image of cowboys and Indians, his thinking was apparently more progressive.  Bill is quoted as speaking out for the rights of Native Americans, the rights of women (Wyoming was the first territory to allow women to vote) and against the white man's mass destruction of the buffalo.  Wick and I re-grouped that evening at the salon for a couple of 'fat tire' ales before heading back to our 'OK Corralle' campsite.
      
By the side of the road I saw a moose grazing, having his morning meal.  Two or three cars had pulled to the side of the road to watch as well.  I stood by my bike and listened as someone approached the moose trying to get that perfect photo. 'That's always the problem, they just keep their heads down.  You can't get a good shot of them' said someone in a truck.  The person in the field whistled, coo-ed and clucked hoping to get a smile from the moose.   Having seen enough, I continued on.  Later after two tour buses arrived at the West Thumb geyser basin shortly after we did, I came up with an idea.  I proposed that once a week the national park should institute a quiet visiting day - a day in which no one could say a word while they were in the park.  Chad, being uncharacteristically argumentative (maybe after 6 weeks, he would like me to keep more of my thoughts to myself), responded that such a policy would unfairly discriminate against humans.   I thought back on our breakfast this morning, we didn't say much but the birds and the little creatures of the wilderness did make a lot of noise.  In particular there was this one bird that perched itself no more than 3 feet above our picnic table that chirped and coo-ed as we ate.   Maybe he was sending out the message 'I have two early risers here at J-446, with some scrap potential.  One bag of Life cereal with a small hole in it and another bag of granola, stand-by for future updates...'  So maybe Chad is right, we may be at a disadvantage if forced to stay silent.   Before lunch we passed the Continental Divide - twice, which of course means that we are on the wrong side of it and we will be crossing it again, which means more climbing. The divide is the line (which is by no means straight) that separates the watershed.  Water that falls on one side of the line will flow out to the Gulf of Mexico via the Missouri and the Mississippi Rivers, while water on the other heads out to the Pacific via the Snake and the Columbia Rivers.  We squirted our water bottles to test this  Old Faithful lived up to its name for us.  We decided that we would have this as a lunch stop and try to view an eruption while we were there.  Right after we pulled up we learned that she was predicted to blow again in 10 minutes.  Sure enough gushes of water and steam shot up into the sky 40-50 feet. After lunch we toured the Old Faithful Inn, which had been built in 1904 for those who were both adventurous and rich.  The wooden inn is massive (traveling with a preservationist, I will not even try to describe it).  On our ride out we saw a couple of buffalo right beside the road (- did I mention that these are 2,000 pound animals?) and 3 mule deer walking up a stream.    We crossed the line out of the park and into West Yellowstone, Montana and celebrated the 4th complete with an all you can eat pasta night and fireworks.                 
  
Per usual Chad and I took care of the rest day business; web, route plan and laundry.  Having not run into any snags along the way we finished in the early afternoon.  With extra time on our hands we visited the town museum to help unravel some of the questions that we had. One major factor in making this town what it is today is the Teton flood of 1976.  Long story short is that the Bureau of Reclamation had a dam built that was complete in '75, the environmentalists opposed it, and some engineers apparently made some miss calculations.  It burst, sending a wave of something like 80 billion gallons of water out into the Snake River Valley; thousands of animal livestock killed, farms destroyed, buildings floated away and quite remarkably only 11 human deaths.  The other major piece of information that we learned at the museum was the importance of Mormons in shaping this area.  In the 1870s and 1880s Mormons faced persecution, leading them to disperse and develop their own schools.  One such school, Ricks College, based here in Rexburg, was the largest private 2-year college in the country.  Recently it became part of Brigham Young University.  Being tourists in Mormon territory caused us to be on the look out for polygamists.  As we ate dinner at a Mexican restaurant and celebrated by drinking virgin Pina Coladas, we thought that we may have spotted some, but sorry, no photos  Thank you to all who sent happy birthday wishes -- both those received and un-received.    Rach, I can almost taste those vegan cookies .
    
Wick had been sick.  He spent the day in bed.   I slept on the floor and had the longest sleep of the year, and then in the afternoon, took an additional two-hour nap.  When I wasn't sleeping I went to the hospital to see if they had any free insight and then shopping for soup and crackers.   Not much more except bad TV.
Caught up with Phil about 20 miles down the road at Craters of the Moon National Monument.  My stomach decided I needed to sit down for a bit and not move which gave me some time to take in the weird landscape stretched out before me.  "Craters" was one of the places NASA astronauts visited in the '60s when they were looking for an encounter that might help prepare them for the moon.  In 1924, Calvin Coolidge signed a proclamation creating the COTM National Monument to preserve volcanic formations, plant and animal life, and other natural and cultural features unique to this site.  Often described as "weird", "beautiful", "unearthly", all appropriate terms, it is a place that becomes a unique experience for everyone who visits, especially if you actually go beyond the Visitor Center and do the 7 mile loop road.  In my current state of malaise I regretfully declined the extra miles.  I would carry on to a place called Picabo where I would meet Phil who stayed back to get the full Craters experience.  Had an absolute dream ride - pretty much all downhill and really interesting landscape showcasing similar features we saw back at Craters and high desert flora and fauna.  Phil arrived at the caf/grocery/gas store in Picabo and with him came the rain.  This part of Idaho had been experiencing a major drought and the proprietor thanked us for bringing some relief after we told her of our rainmaking powers discovered earlier in the trip.  She told every farmer who came in that we were the one's to thank/pay.  Pretty funny - very nice people.  Now that our miracle work was done we pushed on to Stanton Crossing - just off route 20 skirting the south edge of the Sawtooth National Forest - and took advantage of its free camping sites.  Rain continued a good part of the night but broke at least long enough for us to set up tents and climb inside to relative dryness - or perhaps we MADE it stop just long enough hmmm      
Although desolate, the area had a familiar history.  It was a place where the new Americans and the Native Americans clashed.  In the morning we passed a plaque commemorating the Bannock War of 1878.  The inscription was clear that members of the Bannock tribe waged their attack as a result of the treaty that they had signed with the U.S government being violated numerously. The discovery of gold in the area and the path of the Oregon Trail by way of the Goodale Cutoff, were two of the reasons why the treaty had not been honored.   The landscape was rugged, desert scrub not more than 18" tall is the only thing that grows.  At times there seemed to be no pattern to the hills and mountains.  Riding in the valley floor there was a sea of rounded and jagged peaks that surrounded us.  I must say I was grateful that there was a road. Wick kept his struggle to himself.  I encouraged him to eat and drink, and he persevered.  Our destination was Mountain Home; its warm welcoming name may have helped our motivation.  And that, I learned was the intent.  In the days that gold was being mined in this area, as to not discourage potential workers from coming the name of the stagecoach stop was changed from Rattle Snake Creek Crossing to Mountain Home.  After arriving, we did have a fantastic dinner (which included an Oreo milkshake for me, Chad drank water in an effort to recover) at a restaurant honoring the original name.          Show links to this Hide links to this               
Downtown Boise is very walkable and a downright pleasant place in which to relax and explore.  Did some Bento (a really nice change) for lunch followed by a walking tour to get a better sense of this place.  It's one of those cities that successfully maintains a small town ambience so it just feels comfortable.  Boise sits along the Boise River between the foothills of the Rockies and the high mountain desert.  Its name is derived from the French "les bois" meaning "the woods" and is why the city is known as "The City of Trees" (you were wondering, right?).  Incorporated as a City in 1864 and proclaimed the Capital of the Idaho Territory its Capital Building, a replica of our nation's Capital, was completed in 1886. One of the things we liked a lot about Boise is that it seems to actively encourage people to "go by bike" (the Chamber of Commerce guide notes that bicyclists are "expected" downtown).  The citywide bus system called BUS (Boise Urban Stages) runs on compressed natural gas and has buses equipped with bike racks - maybe not so unusual but people actually use them.  It is also a city that has a lively cultural and arts scene with bars, nightclubs, coffee houses, museums, galleries, etc all in all a neat little city that we'd like to come back and explore some more.         
The day started in all the normal ways for a traveler, pack up and leave this town for the next.  Heading out of Boise we found that the town continued on in the direction that we were going, northwest.  Urban sprawl would be too strong to describe this since its suburbs, small towns and lots of farmland.  The point is that there were people, which recently has been uncommon.  Another uncommon experience was that the wind was not dead against us.  It seemed to come from a lot of different directions, but it was more favorable than foul. We past a replica of an 1834 British fur trading post and read more about the struggles between the Native Americans and the new settlers.  The little voice had been quiet (or perhaps the other voices had been louder) until Chad and I met up together at a road juncture.  Chad had been waiting since our plan was to turn here and cross the state line.  I joked about continuing on so that we could ride through the town of Fruitcake, but we took the turn.  This was our last state crossing, but the line itself turned out to be disappointing.  It was wimpy little sign just past a brownish looking river and there was a sugar factory in the background.  Immediately the tune (different than the little voice) "Is that all there is?  If that's all there is my friend, then let's keep dancing" played in my head.  We did the obligatory line crossing activities and went into the town of Nyssa.  We ate at the Twilight Lounge, which did not fulfill our stomachs but did get us re-oriented.  As I sat in the booth realizing that I was now hungrier after lunch than before, a guy from the next table asked where we were going.  He had a large bourbon bottle, which Chad reckons was sun tea, and was playing Lotto.  But within a minute of him saying 'bad roads and hills' we changed our route.  We were out the door, crossing the state line back into Idaho, heading to that intersection, and off to Fruitcake  Later we did cross the state line back into Oregon.  It felt more right this time.  But the lack of substance from the lunch was starting to wear on me.  We were working our way down the Snake River; there were farms but no towns.  When we had crossed the line I had mentioned to Chad how good a root beer float would taste.  As I biked this fantasy  desire  need, grew inside of me.  Around each corner I looked hoping to find a town, a diner or just a gas station.  Finally up ahead I saw a building that looked like it was too close to the road to be a house.  As I got closer, but still a half mile away, I thought I saw a Coke machine.  I wondered if it was the little voice or my big stomach drawing me to this building.   Once I was close enough I could read the window;  VERN'S COUNTRY E(nter) T(oo) C(ee) The caf was closed, but Vern, in the convenience store, after hearing of our yearnings, took some root beer and Oreo ice cream (no vanilla) from the coolers and went into the backroom to make our floats.  After hearing about our travels, she asked us to sign her guest book and gave us a ceramic angel to guide us along the way.  Shortly after leaving the land changed again, to desert like hills on both sides of the river, the color of camel backs. We pitched our tents at a park named Oasis.               
Our only other stop today was for a cow jam - literally a herd of cows just hanging out in the middle of the road.  They were being separated by those that had been branded, vaccinated, registered for the draft, etc. and those that hadn't, and this required their temporary takeover of the entire road.  We waited patiently and Phil inquired about the process, chatting up the friendly cowgirl (for lack of a better term) who towered over us on her very impressive horse named Poopsalot (well that should have been its name).  Once the cow jam cleared she offered us sodas from her cooler which we thankfully accepted as there had been no services along the entire route today.  She said we should stop by and say hi to her mom who was having a yardsale today up ahead in the town of Pleasant Valley, a place that used to boast a motel, gas station, grocery, and post office but today seems to consist of nothing more than said yardsale.  Funny, and sad, how places grow and prosper and then fizzle out to mere shadows of their former selves.  Place morphology could have been a great topic of in-depth research on this trip - maybe next time For now we're just happy to have finally made it to our LAST rest day of our transcontinental crossing - now to explore Baker City and ice some sore muscles and joints (not in that order).      
Baker City is a town trying to hold on to its history and get the interest of tourists.  About 7 miles out there is the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center.  It is on top of Flagstaff Hill, alongside the trial itself. Since there was no public transportation (then or now), I hitch hiked to the museum (The ride there was great; a friendly river guide picked me up. The ride back was not as comfortable, I shared the back seat with two small dogs, and a large wet spot, which I tried to avoid.)  I came away from the Oregon Trail story in awe.  In awe of its magnitude - it may have been the largest voluntary migration in the world, an estimated 300,000 travelers.  In awe of the challenge - the trip from Missouri was 2,000 miles long and took 5-6 months; one in ten people died along the way, an average of one gravesite every 80 yards!  And in awe of how it shaped world history - the concept of 'manifest destiny', the demise of the Native Americans and the political struggles between the U.S and the European powers.  After returning to town, continuing in our effort to not think about biking, Wick and I went to micro-brew pub for supper.       
After the first two passes we stopped at the one and only store in Austin Junction where we dined on some particularly unsatisfying microwave ham and cheese sandwiches.  Still, we were thankful for the water stop before our final pass which climbed gradually before dropping us down into Prairie City, the downhill portion rewarding us with a striking vista of Strawberry Mountain - and then on to John Day where we provisioned for dinner (cheap pasta) and breakfast (cheap granola) supplies at the local Thriftymart.  While we were glad to finally reach the state park where we would camp for the night we were both struck by how overrun it was with RVs, motorcycles, and people in general.  Phil was particularly troubled over the fact that the designated 'hiker/biker' site, provided by state parks for backpackers and bicyclists exclusively, was filled with motorcycle tourers.  Later we discovered they did receive permission to camp there but it was the principle of the thing (we bicyclists can sometimes take on a holier- than-thou attitude when it comes to these things - but hey, we don't ask for much).       
    
  
I got the break that I needed at lunch.  Chad and I sat on the lawn outside of a DOT building and each ate three avocado, sprout and cheese, bagel sandwiches.  As we were getting ready to leave, a forestry truck pulled up and a guy name Jim offered to give us the 'beta' on what lies ahead, saying that the other side of Hood was 'likely to be snaughty' (outdoor enthusiast lingo that we had not heard for a long, long time).  Although he invited us to stay at his place, we got 'dialed up' and 'grinded on through'. At Government Camp, 4000' up Mt. Hood, we could see nothing and someone commented that it looked like it was snowing.  Somehow I was buoyed by this. Wick and I layered up for our descent; 6 miles of 6% grade ('a hypotenuse slide').  Gliding at 30 MPHs we quickly popped through the cloud that clung to the mountain.  We pitched our tents at Camp Creek and had an early dinner (me: a box of mac and cheese mixed with a jar of salsa, Chad: turkey sandwich and a candy bar), so that I could get a hike in.  Finally off the expressway, I could hear the river water flowing, the wind in the trees and I remembered where I was.          
  
Our morning routine long perfected, Chad and I left Bret and Linda's shortly after 6:00 A.M.  We rode across the Hawthorne Bridge under gray skies, exactly the type of weather that East Coaster's stereotype this region as having constantly.  There was no sign of Mt. Hood, and I doubted its existence.  But biking through downtown was a pleasant surprise; there were functional bike lanes.  We were passed by some businessmen commuting to work - what a concept!  But the roads became less biker friendly as we peddled up the hills out of the city and discovered that many people commute out from Portland.  Eventually we found ourselves back in rural countryside and surrounded by farm land.  By this point I was hungry again, and not knowing if we would find anything else along the way, we stopped at a convenience store for some microwaved oatmeal.   We had only two challenges ahead of us, climbing up the coastal range and then getting ourselves to the Ocean.  Climbing the 1600' was not a problem, but reaching the Pacific was elusive.  Both of our maps showed a paved road off route 26 that would bring us to Manzanita.  The Oregon bike map had it coded as green for biker friendliness.  Both of us were caught up in the spirit of the road - winding its way through the state forest following the Nehalem River to the sea; it was the road less traveled.  But we had second thoughts when the locals didn't know the road, and those that did couldn't remember if it was paved. Nonetheless, we were assured that even if it wasn't paved, 'it was a great road for bikes.'  It wasn't.  A great road for mountain bikes, yes.  A great road for aluminum framed, fully loaded touring bikes, no.  14 miles of dirt, gravel, bumps and rocks. It seemed as though we had now completely betrayed the bikes (they do have feelings, right?).  We had rode for thousands of miles with no mechanical problems to speak of, and now to finish with this.  Fortunately, we make it back to a paved surface without a mutiny or breakdown.   Maybe because of all this it didn't feel like the last day.  It didn't feel like journey's end.  In the last quarter mile of this 93-mile day, as the trip odometer turned to 3,500, we saw the Pacific for the first time.  The sun sparkled over the gentle shore break, we pushed our bicycles through the soft sand and laughed as the water rushed up passed the front tires and soaked our sweaty feet             
For now here's some pics we've taken while enjoying our stay with our hosts Bret and Linda Hodgert here in Portland.  Postscripts will come later... Oh yeah, if you happen to know of any employment opportunities in Public Health or Historic Preservation here in the Northwest we'd LOVE to hear about them!           
   Cycling Trips..... Western Australia...mainly South of Perth Mandurah, Pinjara, Dwellingup, Margaret River, Augusta Tasmania ~ 2,000 km (January 1998, Summer) New Zealand (South Island) ~ 2,000 km (January 1999, Summer)

I would also like to see the Franklin River south west of Hobart, but again not enough time.  Cradle mountain is stunning the and the old museum hut at Cradle Mt were cheap A$10/night I traveled fairly light and camping in caravan parks and National Parks. Hobart on New Years eve was great, the Sydney/Hobart fleet had arrived and the atmosphere was electric . There are plenty of hills (not mountains) and the diversity of the flora and fauna is quite amazing  Expect to find lots of 'road kill', you can smell it well before you see it, Tassie Devils and wombats (The devils get run over while eating road kill) They suggest you throw the road kill to the side of the road only trouble is I would have had to stop every km    Itinery .. Biker's Porriage..... This is a big breakfast..... Bring 1 litre of water to the boil.... Make a cuppa with the water when it boils.... Add 1/2 cup of rolled oats..the cheapest generic brand are the best, You don't have to buy super refined pre cooked, pre digested oats... Bring to the boil and reduce heat...simmer for 2-4 minutes stirring to prevent oats sticking (I hate cleaning burned pots)  Add sugar to taste (2 or 3 spoons) Add powdered milk (3 spoons) Stir and continue simmering for 1-2 minutes (Until oats are not 'gritty') Add a sliced banana. a handful of sultanas...enjoy......

Up at 7am....No rain...you beauty!!!!!! But its freezing.....5 degrees celsius..Sasch has a cycle computer with the lot!!!!! including an altimeter ( A thing for measuring height Pete!!!!!) All my gear is soaked...but I dont care.....It was so cold I thought that I had lost my fingers and toes....I put a pair of socks on my hands, dont laugh it works!!! (You have a little trouble changing gear on the bike!!!!) We headed for Windy Ridge....WOW what a great ride, plenty of elevation gain....but really woth it.... The blast zone from Mt St Helens is increadible.... May 18, 1980 I still can remember it.... Huge forests completely flatened, trees 2 and 3 feet in diameter brocken off like match sticks.....all lying in perfect rows away from the blast zone.... It is hard to imagine, over 1000 ft of montain blown away, temperature of the blast 500 degrees and 300 miles an hour......Millions of animals and plants killed instantly......Pray to God this type of event will never occur again..especially if it is mane made....... Spirit Lake is beautiful....a huge part of the lake is completely covered by fallen trees..... the lake rose 200-300 feet because of the blast..... I cannot describe it, the whole thing is fantastic.....what a wonderful experience... We camped the night at Beaver, a piknic spot...really lovely with a fabulous view of the montain.... What a fantastic day.... The only down side is that both Sascha and myself have run out of food......Oh well we will have to chew on bike parts till we get to Randle.... I got on the train at 2:38 am in Elyria, and arrived at the Buffalo station at about 7:15.  Arriving in Buffalo, I thought the train would never stop at the station.  But it did, and it took me about 15 minutes then to set up my rig.  I was eating breakfast at Alton's on Walden Street in Buffalo by 7:45. I arrived at Best Western Hotel on Delaware Street at 9:00, tired from lack of sleep.  I asked the clerk what time I could check in, and she said 2:00.  Then I asked if I could leave a piece of luggage at the hotel, since I had a reservation and was going to check in later.  So she changed her mind and let me check in immediately.  I took advantage of that by sleeping for three hours. Next I went out to ride across the Peace Bridge.  Originally, I had planned to ride up to Niagara Falls on Sunday.  But I changed my mind; it was just too rainy and cold.  So I just went for a tour of the Niagara River.  As I was riding up Porter Avenue toward the bridge, I noticed a big parade up ahead.  "Wow" I thought, "they didn't have to have a parade just because I came to town!"  But as I got closer, I saw a banner in the parade that read "Gay Pride Day".  I guess the parade wasn't being held in my honor after all. All in all, I had a very nice ride along the Niagara River in Canada.  Afterward, I took a shower and went in search of food.  I had an absolutely delicious meal of Broccoli Pasta at the TOWNE Restaurant. Total mileage today:  27.0      Show links to this Hide links to this     
In Dunkirk, I stopped at Marshall's Waterfront Cafe for a cup of coffee.  The moment I walked in, Marshall, the owner, introduced himself and asked where I had ridden in from.  I told him I just rode from Buffalo, and that I was headed for Elyria, Ohio.  Marshall was quite impressed, and even called the local paper to do a "story" about me.  They apparently weren't as impressed as he was, because they didn't come.  Marshall's grandfather is famous.  At the age of 110, he made the Guiness Book of World Records for being the world's oldest licensed driver. The ride was quite hilly today, with a pretty strong headwind too.  But still, I arrived and got settled into camp at Lake Erie State Park by 4:00.  Shortly thereafter, I went into town for dinner, but there were no restaurants anywhere nearby.  The owner of the local general store heated up some rice for me in her microwave.  I was so impressed by her kindness, I promised to send her a hat for her huge hat collection. The rest of the evening was spent playing Upwords and watching the sunset on the lake with two new friends, a couple of vagabonds from North Carolina. Total mileage today:  65.9   
Just before I got to the Pennsylvania border, there was a sign stating Route 5 was closed ahead, so I continued on to Erie on Route 20.  I crossed the Pennsylvania border at 9:40 am.  At about 10:30, I stopped in the charming little town of North East, Pennsylvania for a "library break".  Libraries are my favorite place to find clean, public restrooms.  I'm glad I got off Route 5 for a while.  It's pretty, riding along the lakeshore, but there are few places to stop for a break or buy food.   Both Routes 5 and 20 in New York and Pennsylvania are good biking roads.  They both have huge paved clean shoulders, and little traffic.  There is more commerce on Route 20 and more beautiful scenery on Route 5, and the two routes run parallel within a mile or less of each other, so I often alternated between the two routes. Route 5 has five names:  Route 5, Bike Route Z, Seaway Trail, Lake Erie Circle Route, and Purple Heart Highway.  All the names are never posted at the same time, once I saw four of the names co-located so I took a picture of all the signs.  I wonder why they have so many names for one road. Somewhere along route 20, I stopped at a roadside stand and bought some fresh strawberries.  They were so juicy and delicious.  I ate half of them after my camp was set up, and attempted to save the other half for Wednesday?s breakfast. My campsite Tuesday night was right on the beach in Sara Coyne Campground on the Presque Isle Peninsula in Erie.  It was a really cool campsite.  The sunset on Lake Erie is just beautiful.  Both at Presque Isle and Lake Erie State Park, I enjoyed awesome sunsets.  I wondered to myself if the sunset at home in Lorain was as nice. Total mileage today:  58.7   
Before leaving Erie, I had breakfast at McDonald's.  Most mornings I would ride for about an hour first, but this morning, I was so hungry.  An hour later, I stopped enroute for a break and ate the rest of those wonderful strawberries. At some point during this past week, I started referring to my bike and trailer set up as a "rig".  Well, with the trailer attached, I'm not just riding a bike; I am driving a rig, right? There are a lot more hills on this route than I thought there would be, which leaves me wishing I had done more hill training with my rig.  The hills are difficult with a rig, and I make it up some of them at a snail's pace.  And, once I looked at my computer, and my speed was 3.1 mph.  I was surprised the bike was still upright at that rate.  Still, I think pedaling up at a snail's pace is easier than pushing the rig up the hill on foot!  So, I just keep spinning. I entered Ohio at 10:16 am, hoping to see a restroom soon.  After taking care of that in Conneaut, of course I had to ride down to the dock to see if any ships were in port.  The FRONTENAC was being loaded with coal.   Next stop, a nice little roadside park near Ashtabula for a snack and a break.  The lake was very hazy that day, but I could see the Ashtabula breakwall out to the west, and in the distance I could see a freighter that appeared to be at anchor, because it wasn't moving for quite a while. I had lunch at Doxies Deli by the coal dock in Ashtabula.  The DAVID Z NORTON was at the coal dock at the time, loading coal.  A watchman from the ship stopped me and asked if I knew where there was a bike shop.  I told him it was on Route 20, and we talked for a while about my trip, and I asked him if he knew my husband, but he didn't. I arrived at Geneva State Park at about 3:30 pm.  This was the first day I rode without a headwind, but it was hillier than the previous days.  For most of the evening after I arrived, it rained on and off.  There were no restaurants open in the area, so I bought a submarine sandwich at a local store for dinner. After watching another beautiful sunset, I was amazed at all the sounds in the park.  The sounds of the birds singing was almost deafening there were so many of them.  And there was some sort of a locust that buzzed for about a half hour after sunset, then again for a half hour before sunrise.  It had a different sound than any other locust I have ever heard. Total mileage today:  65.8
About six miles of rolling mesa later, I passed through the town of Hambden, also known as the town of NO PUBLIC RESTROOMS.  Both of the buildings in this dinky town had huge signs on their doors declaring this.  So, I didn't bother to stop.  And then, the three mile descent into Chardon!  At the bottom of the hill, a sign stated ?Welcome to Chardon?, but I wondered, where is everything?  Answer:  you have to climb another huge hill to get to the downtown area.  Well, when I got to the top, it was only 11:00, and I wondered if I should stop for lunch.  But then I saw the sign, "Hilltopper Cafe", and I knew I had to eat there!  They fixed me a delicious turkey sandwich and salad, and many people in the store were interested in my trip.  One of the customers had seen me climbing the hill with my rig, so he started the conversation by asking me where I was headed. Later, as I was entering the town of Chagrin Falls, I was surprised to see a popcorn factory!  I love popcorn, so I stopped and got some.   Behind the popcorn store was a stairway down to view a gorgeous waterfall.  Now I don't feel so bad about missing Niagara Falls. Several hills later, I arrived in Bedford at 6:00 pm.  Wow, today was the most mountainous day I have ever ridden. Total mileage today:  66.1  very mountainous miles   
Brecksville wins for the most difficult hills, I had to walk up two of them, they were just too steep.  One was on Riverview Road just west of Brookside Road on a "marked" bike route.  The other was on Weese Road about a mile east of there.  Entering Brecksville, I treated myself to a big breakfast at McDonalds.  After that, the day was fairly uneventful, and the terrain flattened out. On route 82, as I crossed Columbia Road, I realized, 'I'm almost home!'  Tears filled my eyes from joy and sadness.  I have triumphed and completed my dream trip, but it's almost over.  I finally arrived at the Elyria Train station to retrieve my van at about noon.  There were several people there, waiting for the train.  I wondered what adventures they were on their way to, were they as exciting as what I just did? A lot of people ask me what I think about on all those miles riding alone.  Well, I think about the beautiful scenery God has given us in this world, and how we are often traveling too fast to see it all.  I think about the awesome sounds of nature, which we usually close out in favor of air conditioning.  And I think about the wonderful aromas that we are so often too busy to notice.  And this is why I love to ride, because I have nothing to do but ride and enjoy all these things. Total Mileage Today:  44.8
100% pure New Zealand Pedaller's paradise Lonley Planet destination New Zealand
New Zealands Westcoast Map of the West Coast  When cycling north from Queenstown to Westport (or the other way round) you many many times are conviced to be riding the best bike ride in the whole world. Unless it is raining. Unfortunatly it is raining most of the time. Then you probably will be thinking something different. Especially if not only the rain makes you wet through but also the stormy wind forces your bike into the ditch. But at the end of the day - and we shared our thoughts with many other pedallers along the West Coast Highway - the conviction, that it I S the best bike ride in the world, let you forget all the endured agony.
To give you an impression just read what the tourist brochures say to promote this New Zealand number one holiday and adventure resort:  Queenstown. Home of the Bungy Jump. By A.J.Hackett. It all started with the people of Vanuatu in the Pacific, who have been throwing themselves from high towers for centuries with nothing more than a few vines tied to their feet. This ancient ritual inspired the Oxford Dangerous Sports Clubs to try a few experimental jumps back in the late 70's. As Hackett saw a video and his imagination took over, teaming up with fellow speed skier Henry van Asch they developed Bungy into the modern Ritual it is today. After some extensive stress testing on latex rubber cords a series of extreme jumps were made, first in Tignes, France, from a ski area gondola 91 meters above the snow. In June 1987 A.J. jumped from the Eiffel Tower and into the international spotlight - the Bungy legend was born. Bungyjumping with 43 meter splashdown, it's wet and cools you off. The big wilderness trip and 71 meter Bungyjump, getting there is half the thrill. You're 400 meters above the town and you've got a few choices to Bungyjump. Pipeline Bungy, 102 meters, tested on humans. Fly By Wire, six minutes of exhilarating adrenaline rush. Skydive-Tandem, the highest, the fastest, most spectacular adventure of them all. Tandem-Hanggliding, your tandem hang gliding experience. Actionflite, not only will you fly at speeds in excess of 300 kph. You will be doing it whilst experiencing up to +6 and -3 G's. Jet Safari, the first explorers to venture into magnifient wilderness. Speedboat, experience the thrust of our V8 engine as you accelerate up on the Shotover River. Riverrafting, triple thriller, helijet, jetboat ride and riverrafting. Riversurfing, the final rapid is the infamous 'Chinese Dog Leg' and a half minute of raging Grad 4 whitewater! Can't get enough! Canyoning, action, fun, bizarre, adventure. Helicopter up and Mountain Bike down. Paintball, 'Capture The Flag' or 'Storm The Fort'. Paraflying, fly stay dry. Vertigo Canyoning, an abseil adventure, plunge into pools, rappel the ravines, slide the chute, explore the canyon. Note from our diary (German): Ja auch hier hrt man von den Lawinenunglcken in den europischen Alpen. Aber das sind so ziemlich die einzigen Weltnachrichten, die bis hierhin gelangen. N.Z. scheint ziemlich mit sich selber beschftigt zu sein, zum Beispiel mit der eben beginnenden Rugby-Saison oder mit den Anschuldigungen gegenber der Prime Ministerin Jenny Shipley, der man vorwirft, das millionenschwere Budget fr den neuseelndische Tourismus anlsslich eines privaten Nacht-essens ihrem Bekannten, dem Direktor der Saatchi und Saatchi Werbeagentur, versprochen zu haben. So luft es nun mal. Nachdem wir Christchurch zu genge genossen und uns vor allem kulinarisch durch die halbe Welt gefuttert hatten, waren wir wieder bereit fr neue Abenteuer. Wir beschlossen, ganz in den Sden der Sdinsel zu reisen. Frs erste mal ohne Velo, da die Distanzen sehr weitlufig und die schnsten Orte eh nur ber Schotterstrassen zu erreichen sind. Und von denen hatten wir nach unseren tasmanischen Abenteuern eher genug... Mit einem etwas alternativen Busunternehmen, "Bottom-Bus" genannt, machten wir uns auf den Weg. Wir passierten kleine Farmsiedlungen und verschlafene Provinznester. Die ganze Sd-Region wurde seit Wochen von einer grossen Trockenheit bedroht. Viele Flsse mit einem Tiefststand an Wasser, die Weiden knochentrocken, sodass die Zillionen von Schafe eher etwas verloren aus der Wolle schauten. Weiter ging's dann nordwrts nach Te Anau, dem Tor zu den Fijordlands. Dutzende von Reisebussen, Hotels, Motels, Souvenirshops, organisierte Gruppen, Backpackers, Treker, Biker, Abenteuersuchende. Wir wurden abrupt durch die neuseelndische Realitt und den florierenden Tourismus der Superlative eingeholt. Frhmorgens schon schlngelt sich ein fast nicht endend wollender Konvoi von Cars, Mietautos und Campervans durch eine majesttische, von Gletschern geprgte Berglandschaft: Steile Felswnde, tosende Sturzbche, breite Flusstler, dramatische Aussichtspunkte. Und dann der Sound. Zwar kreuzen rund ein Dutzend Schiffe tglich durch diese unvergleichliche Fijordlandschaft, doch einmal auf dem Boot angelangt, berfllt einem doch so etwas wie Ruhe, Gelassenheit und Bewunderung fr diese einmalige Szenerie. Dann Queenstown, noch weniger nach unserem Geschmack. Hier wurde das Bungyjumpen erfunden, seitem ist es zur Heimat aller "Thrillseeker" geworden: Wer hat noch nicht genug von Riverraften, Skydiven, Jetboaten, Paragliden, Helibiken....? Tag und Nacht ist hier Betrieb und wir sind froh, endlich wieder unsere Velos in Empfang nehmen zu knnen." Unser Ziel ist es nun, von Queenstown aus an die Westkste und dann den Highway hoch bis Westport zu radeln. Was ist so speziell daran? Nun ja, es handelt sich um die Gegend, mit der hchsten durchschnittlichen Regenmenge in N.Z. Und es ist die Heimat der berchtigten Sandflies. Kleine lstige Biester, die sich mit Vorliebe an den Kncheln festsaugen. Aber es ist auch der Ort, wo sich die Strasse zwischen den steilen und schneebedeckten Abhngen der Sdalpen und der tosenden Tasmanischen See durchschlngelt und sich durch einen tiefgrnen und dichten Urwald windet.

Ein schwler Morgen erwartet uns. Bei 20 Grad und wolkenverhangenem Himmel fahren wir los. Unsere Route folgt dem Lake Hawea, einer berwiegend flachen Strecke, nur mit kleinen Hgeln unterbrochen. Nach einer Stunde beginnt es zu nieseln. Der Regen hrt zwar gleich wieder auf, wird aber von einem leichten Wind abgelst, der direkt auf uns zublst. Er wird strker und wir versuchen uns mglichst aerodynamisch auf den Rdern zu halten. Doch die Naturgewalt fordert bald schon die letzte Kraft. Auf dem See werden die Wellen aufgewhlt, ein Sturm ist im Anmarsch. Wir radeln durch weite Graslandschaften und Schafweiden, die von vereinzelten Baumgruppen unterbrochen werden und erreichen das Dorf Wanaka. Hier begann ein arbeitsloser Aussteigertyp in den 70er Jahren mit dem Bau eines Labyrinths, den er bald den Touristen ffnete. Die waren so begeistert von seiner Idee, dass er dem Garten eine dritte Dimension hinzufgte. Damit errang er lokalen, nationalen und bald schon internationalen Ruhm, und fortan war er in der ganzen weiten Welt damit beschftigt, weitere Irrgrten zu bauen, was besonders die spielfreudige Seele der Japaner entzckte. Wir entscheiden uns trotz strmischen Wetter weitere zwlf Kilometer zu fahren und unser Zelt am Lake Hawea, auf einem direkt am See gelegen Zeltplatz aufzubauen. Inzwischen hat die Windgeschwindigkeit orkanartige Ausmasse erreicht und wir bangen um die Sturmtauglichkeit unserer Ausrstung.  
Letzten Abend hatten wir eine Auseinandersetzung mit unserem Kocher. Der Treibstoff Kerosen wollte nicht brennen, eigentlich erzeugte er nur schwarzen Rauch und Stichflammen. Dazu tobte der Sturm und wir waren hungrig und mde. Das heisst, unsere Nerven lagen ziemlich blank. Auch heute kmpfen wir auf dem Fahrrad gegen den Wind, diesmal blst er mit doppelter Kraft auf uns zu. Dabei knnte diese Tagesetappe, den beiden Seen Hawea und Wanaka entlang, so vieles frs Auge bieten. Doch die nahen Berghnge der Southern Alps bleiben hinter drohend, dunklen Wolken verborgen. Eigentlich wren da eisbedeckte Bergspitzen, kalte Regenwlder und stiebende Wasserflle. Die Gegend ist einsam, keine Drfer, keine Siedlungen, fast keine Menschen. Unterwegs begegnen wir nur ein paar weiteren Radfahrern. Die meisten haben noch ehrgeizige Tagesziel vor sich. Es scheint jeden Augenblick losgiessen zu wollen. Im Shell Tankstellen-Shop in Makarora decken wir uns mit Trockennahrung ein Minestrone, Erbsen und Tee. Letzte Einkaufsmglichkeit fr 90 Kilometer. dann beginnt der Regen. Es giesst aus Kbeln und wir strampeln die letzten 12 km bis zum D.O.C.-Campground (Departement of Conservation) in verzweifeltem Tempo ab. Natrlich campiert hier heute kein Schwein. Wir werden herzlichst von einer Meute Sandflies begrsst. Sie machen sich sofort auf Nahrungssuche und finden diese auf unseren Hand- und Fussgelenken, im Nacken, hinter den Ohren.... Christian versucht, sich im nahegelegenen Fluss den Schweiss des Tages abzuwaschen. Eine gute Idee, finden die Sandflies. Bei der anhaltenden Feuchtigkeit und dem immer noch gleich untauglichen Brennstoff wie am vorhergehenden Abend, hat der Kocher seine Startprobleme. Fluchen, Schreien, Weinen, ein letztes verzweifeltes Stossgebet und die Suppe wird irgendwann, irgendwie trotzdem noch warm. Wir sind von Kopf bis Fuss vermummt. Mindestens zwei Schichten wrmendes und trockenhaltendes Material, das uns vor der Nsse und den Sandfliegen schtzen soll. Unvergesslich diese heisse Suppe. Es regnet fortwhrend, die Tropfen klatschen vom Himmel und von den nahestehenden Bumen auf die Zeltplane. Alles hlt dicht, trotzdem kriecht die Feuchtigkeit durch alle Ritzen. Das andauernde Trommeln hlt wach, nur hie und dann dsen wir weg, um gleich vom reissenden Fluss zu trumen, der uns mitsamt Sack und Pack davon schwemmt.
Es ist Morgen und es regnet in Strmen. Unter den schtzenden Zeltplanen aber auf beengendem Platz versuchen wir unsere sieben Sachen zu organisieren, zu packen und zu frhstcken. Draussen vor dem Moskitonetz wetzen sich bereits wieder Hunderte von Sandflies die Beisserchen. Wir starten knapp acht Kilometer unterhalb der Passhhe (535 m . M.). Es ist eindrcklich, wie sich die Strasse durch dichte, moosbehangene Regenwlder windet. Das gesammelte Regenwasser strzt sich in Hunderten von Wasserfllen ins Tal. Manche Wasserflle erzeugen im Flussbecken eine derartige Wassergischt, dass dichte Nebelwolken durch das Tal ziehen. Die Regenpellerine ist lngst nicht mehr dicht, auch die Hnde sind von der Feuchtigkeit aufgeweicht und fhlen sich klamm an. Das Wasserbett in den Schuhen lsst unangenehme Klte die Waden hochsteigen. Wir auf einer Tour de France-Bergetappen preschen wir den Berg hinunter, in der Hoffnung, bald auf ein trockenes Zimmer, ein kuscheliges Bett und eine heisse Dusche zu stossen. Dieses befindet sich in Haast Township, im Motor Inn, das fr einmal seinen Preis wert ist. Der kleine Elektroofen luft auf Hochtouren, das Zimmerklima verwandelt sich alsbald in ein tropisches Abenteuer. Aber wirklich clever ist der grosse Gerteschuppen nebenan, wo wir Zelt aufzuspannen und trocknen lassen knnen. Ist das ein Leben! Fernseher, heisser Tee, Kche und Doppelbett. Wir versorgen uns im nahegelegenen Supermarkt und buchen gleich eine weitere Nacht, da die Wettervorhersagen keine Besserung in Aussicht stellen. 
Wet, wet, wet die weiteren Aussichten. Wir entscheiden uns am bernchsten Tag trotzdem, die Reise fortzusetzen. Zumal es am Morgen etwas schont. Wir berqueren Flusslufe. Eine schnurgerade Strasse fhrt der See entlang. Ab und zu durchschneidet sie den Regenwald, dessen Vegetation von Menschenhand weitgehend unberhrt geblieben ist. Sie weckt Erinnerungen an ferne Zeiten und verwunschene Sagenwelten. Wie die wilden Ritter reiten wir auf unseren Blechrssern durch die verzauberten Urlandschaft. Ab und zu taucht zwischen den mit Moos und Flechten behangenen Bumen ein Teich auf. Was schlummert auf dessen Grund? Dann wieder scheint hinter dem Bltter- und Buschgewirr ein Dinosaurier aufzutauchen. Oder erregte bloss ein abgestorbener Baumstamm die Fantasie? Weiterhin kmpfen wir gegen den Wind. Sehr zum Aerger von Christian. Wtend schiebt er sein Rad an den Strassenrand und steht - unverhofft - mittendrin in prall behangenden Brombeerstruchern. Eine Pause, vier Hnde greifen nach Beeren und das seelische Gleichgewicht ist wieder hergestellt. Um zum Knights Point zu gelangen, mssen zuerst drei respektable Klippen berwunden werden. Wtendende Windben und ein Dauerregen, der erneut einsetzt, machen uns das Leben schwer. Unter uns tobt die tasmanische See und wirft graue Wellen schumend an die Felsen. Es strmt was das Zeugs hlt und in einem schtzenden Unterstand ziehen wir uns trockene Sachen ber. Thermowsche und Regenhosen geben minimalen Schutz. So erreichen wir Lake Paringa und die gleichnamige Lodge, in der Hoffnung auf ein trockenes Bett. 
In Lake Paringa glaubten wir wieder einmal den Tiefpunkt erreicht zu haben, als wir ein muffiges (und berrissen teures) Quartier bezogen, das wir spter auch noch mit zwei, ebenfalls durchnssten, Deutschen Radtouristen teilen mussten. Wenigstens gab es ein Caf mit warmem Essen und freundliche Menschen. Draussen blieben smtliche Himmelsschleusen weiterhin geffnet. Es schien, als wrde jemand den Versuch unternehmen, die gesamte Westkste in die Tasmanische See zu splen. Besserung war auch nicht in Sicht, als wir uns schlafen legten und uns (alle vier!) gegenseitig Mut zu sprachen. Wrde der nchste Tag wirklich das ersehnte trockene Wetter bringen? Doch was keiner zu hoffen wagte, trifft tatschlich ein: Am Morgen tropft es zwar noch von den nassen Bumen, und aus dem Buschland steigen dichte Nebelwolken, doch der Wind hat sich gelegt und ber uns zeigen sich erste blaue Flecken, die die Wolkendecke durchbrechen. Ein herrlicher Velotag beginnt! Khle frische Temperaturen, einsame, schnurgerade Strassen, die uns durch dichten Regenwald fhren. Die Sonne leuchtet golden im Gegenlicht und bringt alles zum Glitzern. Vgel zwitschern aus dem dichten Gest, die in den Waldlichtungen grasenden Khe, Schafe und Pferde blicken uns sehnschtig nach. Was gibt es schneres, als unter solchen Bedingungen ber flache Strassen zu fliegen? So schnell sind wir noch nie unterwegs gewesen, trotzdem geniessen wir jeden Meter der Strecke, bis uns in der Nhe des Etappenzieles, Fox Glacier, wieder die Realitt einholt: Das Verkehrsaufkommen nimmt zu, die Touristen wirken gehetzt, berall werden teure Attraktionen angeboten. Vom Campingplatz aus beobachten wir die startenden und landenden Helikopter, die im Fnfminutentakt die Talschaft hinaufklettern, um denjenigen Menschen, die immer nur vom Grssten trumen, eine kurze Befriedigung mit Flightseeing ber der Gletscherlandschaft zu verschaffen.
Mit dem Lrm der ersten Helikopterflge erwachen wir um Sieben Uhr. Die Feuchtigkeit, die sich in der Nacht als Tau auf unserem Zelt abgesetzt hat, tropft uns auf das Gesicht. Es ist Zeit aufzustehen. Auf den nchsten 18 Kilometern stehen drei Berge an, die zu berwinden, unsere letzte Kraftreserven kosten. Unmittelbar hinter der Bergkette liegt die nchste Gletscherzunge, Franz Josef Glacier. Wir machen Pause, essen etwas in einem Caf, kaufen Lebensmittel fr die nchsten zwei Tage ein und beobachten den Rummel. Ist das eine Hektik, Busse voll mit Touristen stoppen vor dem Besucherzentrum. Wo sind die Attraktionen, wo ist die Helikopter-Basis? Reicht die halbe Stunde, bis der Bus wieder weiterfhrt? Schaffen wir es heute Abend noch bis Queenstown? Uns reicht es. Was wir jetzt wieder gebrauchen knnten, ist die Ruhe und Einsamkeit, die Schnheit und die Mystik, die diesen Teil Neuseelands ausmachen. So fahren wir einige anstrengende Kilometer weiter, um das kleine Fischerdrfchen Okarito, das abseits des des Highways gelegen ist, zu besuchen. Das ehemalige Schulhaus wurde zur kleinsten Jugendherberge Neuseelands umgebaut. Der General Store steht nur noch als Museumsfassade da. Auf dem Zeltplatz zwitschern geschftig die Vgel. Wir suchen uns einen Platz aus zwischen Eukalyptusbumen und Agaven. Hier scheint es sich um einen geheimen Radlertreffpunkt zu handeln. Nach und nach trifft eine internationale Gsteschar auf dem Platz ein und eifrig werden Tourentipps und Erfahrungen ausgetauscht. Wir haben uns auf den ersten Blick in Okarito verliebt. Dort wo die Wellen an die Felsen schlagen, donnert das Wasser durch schmale Kaminlcher in die Hhe. Immer dem Fluss entlang, wandern wir unter einem schtzenden Farmbltterdach. Der Boden ist von den Regengssen schlammig und aufgeweicht. Im Fluss schwimmen ste, ja ganze Baumstmme. Am Abend entspannen wir uns in der Punakaiki Tavern und geniessen neuseelndische Lebenskultur und Gastfreundschaft. Rex, der Lwenjgerhund schnffelt sich von Tisch zu Tisch, ein Glas Speights rinnt locker die Kehle runter. An der Wand hngt der Fernseher und Sky Television bertrgt ein Super 12 Rugbyspiel. Die Stimmung ist munter. Ausschnitt aus einem E-Mail von Christine: "Nach em Rge schiint d'Sunne" bldeln wir beim Nachtessen, whrend sich draussen die Bsche dem Wind biegen und der Regen sturzbachartig aufs Dach und gegen die Fenster trommelt. Einfach drber schlafen und optimistisch bleiben. Tatschlich: Im Morgenlicht glitzert der See, aus dem Wald, der tropfnass ist, steigen Nebelschwaden empor, hinter dem Berggipfel lugt die Sonne hervor. Die folgenden Tage werden wir belohnt mit strahlendem Sonnenschein, ja ungewhnlich heissen Tagen, unvergleichlichen Landschaftsbildern, Urwldern, Vgeln, Gletschern, Strnden, Seen und Lagunen. Die Route ist einfach toll zum Radfahren. Es hat fast kein Verkehr und wir finden die Ruhe und die Ein-samkeit, die wir uns erhofft haben. So vergehen die Tage. Wir campieren viel, treffen hufig Radler an, mit denen wir Erfahrungen und Reiseplne austauschen. Einmal mehr verlieren wir das Gefhl fr Zeit und Raum. Entlang der ganzen Westkste keine Natelverbindung, die paar internetfhigen Computer, die wir finden, sind meist out of order oder berlastet. In Punaikaiki schliesslich bricht auch noch der Strom und das Telefonnetz fr einige Stunden zusammen."
Es regnet bereits morgens um Sieben, und wir mssen unseren ersten Startversuch abbrechen. Also beobachten wir die Wetterfront, die eigentlich Besseres versprochen hatte. Von woher weht der Wind eigentlich? Ah ja, aus dem Osten. Das wrde bedeuten, mit zunehmender Windstrke und falls diese Flecken dort am Horizont wirklich blauen Himmel andeuten, knnten wir in einer Stunde losfahren. Also warten wir ab. Dann um Acht Uhr, der Himmel immer noch leicht bedeckt, geht's los. Gleich zu Beginn sind zwei Steigungen zu meistern. Die Strasse klettert die steilen Felsklippen hoch, mitten durch den dichten Regenwald. Dann folgt eine rasante Abfahrt. Mittlerweile peitscht der Regen etwas unfreundlicher ins Gesicht und wieder dringt die Nsse langsam ein, bis sie das innerste Kleidungsstck aufgeweicht hat. Bei Kilometer 30 erreichen wir Charleston. Zudem blst ein krftiger Wind endlich mal vom Rcken her, und macht das Radeln zu einer einfacher Angelegenheit.
Das letzte Dorf am Nordende der Westkste gelegen, lebt heute vom Fischfang und der Zementherstellung. In der nheren Umgebung wurde bis vor 20 Jahren Kohle im Tagbau gefrdert. Zu dieser Jahreszeit sind die Jungen etwa acht Wochen alt. Sie spielen im seichten Wasser, robben durch den Seetang, ben mit den Wellen, whrend die Mtter sich auf den Felsen ein Sonnenbad genehmigen. Im nahen Bistro-Restaurant, mit dem schnen Namen "Where fresh food and the ocean meet", verspeisen wir zwei Stck exquisite Kuchen und geniessen die Aussicht von der Terasse.
