Oder - wie Christian dies in einem E-Mail beschreibt: "Das Leben auf zwei Rdern ist sehr angenehm, entspannend. Wir berlegen, ob dies nicht gleich fr den Rest des Lebens so bleiben knnte."
  Riding a tandem across America East to West (4230 miles is a very special trip for us, this journal records a Nine day tour we did in November 2002. We cycled with the Cycle Touring Association of Western Australia.(click to show email) We looked on it as one of a few warm ups in readiness to the BIG ONE. We can be contacted at click to show email  This tour was in the South West of Western Australia. A group of 120 cyclists participated in the tour some coming from the Eastern States of Australia. The tour offered a sag vehicle, mechanical support and two meals a day. Accommodation was in your own tent. Catering for the evening meal was arranged with local groups such as Apex, Rotary and High Schools and assisted them in their fund raising activities. About 120 riders take part in the annual event that chooses a different region on Western Australia each year. The rides are a huge success and all places are booked out months in advance.     This years ride started in a small town called Kendernup just north of Mount Barker (for 9 days). We passed through a lot of land growing grapes, of course the grapes are used for wine manufacture so obviously we HAD to sample the product - as OFTEN as possible. The coast line in this part of the world is splendid to the eye. It abounds with ocean life. Albany was until a few years ago home to a whaling station. Fortunately that activity stopped in the mid seventies, but a very interesting museum exist where once the whales were dragged ashore and processed. The mileage we will do on this Whale of a Tour will kick start our training regime building up to cycling the TransAmerican Trail USA . We are lucky we live close to a Freeway cycle path so we are able to get in lots of kilometers without the worry of traffic On this tour we took many item we never even used, particulary clothing, we (Trish) will have to be a lot more disciplined in what we actually take for the big one. The organisation committee(CTA) including the volunteers deserve a big pat on the back for a an excellent job well done, one problem COLD SHOWERS. We are city slickers not used to them !! Well actually the mens showers seemed to be warm most of the time but the ladies were often cold. That didnt stop Trish though, she got Phill to guard the door to the men's community showers whilst she took a hot shower after the days ride. If you cant beat 'em join 'em or at least tell 'em to clear off is her motto (well it is an equal opportunity world we live in). 
When we arrived there were already some familiar faces from last years trip.  The bus arrived from Perth with the rest of the crew 120 people in all, it was great to catch up with everyone again the meeting place was such a hipe of chit chatter about who had done what and where during the previous year. With all the bikes unloaded from the truck and cars parked for the 9 days we all set off for our first part of the trip , we first cycled to Kendenup Hall for lunch (cannot ride on an empty stomach. After lunch we set off on our journey to Mt Barker.  Tonight we are camping in the local Caravan Park. Lots of trees and grass and just a short stroll into town for a coffee (and cake).  Today was a short ride a very good ride a few hills which wasn't to bad (little did we know there were many more and steeper ones to come). The weather was very wet towards the end of the ride. We heard at the camp ground that one of the Tandem teams had taken a fall. They had slipped on a railway crossing. Luckily not too serious just a bit of skin missing.  We had dinner at the hall in town which was organise and cooked by the local community Excellent as always.   
We go back to the hall were we ate last night for the traditional Toast and Porridge breakfast that will power us to morning tea tea stop. We cross the highway and start the climb towards the Porongurup Ranges. The ride was really good with plenty of down hill and a fair share of up hills but the down hill rides more than made up for the up ones. Plenty of wild life to see (snakes) and the biggest Red Kangaroo I had ever seen jumped straight accross the road in front of our bike very impressive sight. We stopped for morning tea at the 30klm mark and a welcome cuppa it was - Phill found a cake from somewhere.     We arrived in Albany about 1pm We are camping in the Albany Recreation Hall grounds theres plenty of room for the tents but we are supprised to hear that there is a live concert by MIDNIGHT OIL performing at the centre. Not much chance of an early night tonight. I was awake most of last night and Phill was awake early so the thought of a Rock Band keeping us awake was not something we wanted. Nothing against Midnight Oil but we decided we would pike out tonight and  get a room at the local Caravan Park and I must say we had the best night sleep and a very HOT shower (little did we know that this was probably going to be our last hot one for the trip).   Whilst in Albany we took the opportunity to call into family we hadn't seen for a few years , good to catch up. Excellent meal again at the sports club. The object is while doing all this travelling we would lose some weight but the meals we get are so good that pardon the pun (Fat chance of that). 
The town folk of Albany must have been suprised to see so many cyclists on their streets. Various little groups set off to visited the Whaling Station, Blow Holes etc. Phil called into the Old Jail Museum were a local lady ambushed him and told him the whole history of Albany - well she was set to and managed half of it till Trish rescued him. He loves history and would have spent the whole day talking with her as she was so informed. After the mandatory coffee stop (Phill had a cake) we joined Wendy and Pat (alias Jo) for a ride to Middleton Beach and then on to Emu Point. The weather was absolutely gorgeous. Setting off from the coffee shop was interesting,we struggled like hell up the hill then turned and found we had to peddle even going down hill. The two girls in front of us were getting further and further away from us, when trish released the Drum Brake was still on,we just about span the back wheel and vowed to make sure the brake level will be double checked to ensure the brake is OFF before we start riding in the future.    Plenty of wild life yet again,lots of black King skinks or are they lizards ? around here, and would you believe it quite a few big hills, but fun anyway. The coast line here has an excellent Bike path to follow. the path is raised and affords a great view out to sea. The water is cold in these parts for most of the year today is no exception.     We stopped off for an icecream at Emu Point and meet up with some fellow cyclists, they were guys from the Perth "Over 55's Cycling Club" that joined us for this years tour, all very nice people.     
We left Albany town traveling West. The coast here is rugged and there are many granite hills to see and such a beautiful sight.  The ride was uneventful apart from a few snakes here and there!!!Lots of wildlife out at the moment some of the flower are just so pretty, weather at around 24C, although now into the afternoon we have a very good head wind make life a tadd harder. Morning tea was just after Cosy Corner (Phill had a cake again). Mary one of the cyclists who we be-friended (nothing to do with the fact that she picks a nice bottle of red wine or that she looks after us at meal times) just a very lovely lady, sat behind us and drafted for about 15klm which was good for her. The road was almost a straight run than was beauty, but we are finding it very hard going up the hills on the Tandem, great coming down but oh boy, havock on the legs. We arrive at Denmark in exceeding good time, my Knee which I had operated on not too long ago was doing okay.  The Melbourne Cup was being run today. The Cup (a hourse racebrings Australia to a stand still) was being televised at the local pub where a lot of the tour group flocked to watch and cheer. We sat on the bank of the river and watched wild ducks and geese swimming up and down. It was not long till someone suggested a coffee so off we went (guess what Phill had). We arrive at the camp site and looking forward to a nice hot shower, no chance cold again. Trish wasn't going to let that stop her this time. She decided to rock up at the men's shower and wait until they had finished, well cannot lie she hurried them up a little and then Phill kept guard whilst she had a piping hot shower to her hearts content. She could here the guys waiting outside shouting how long are you going to be, she had a little chuckle to herself and continued to enjoy the very hot shower, wasnt long before the news got out and a few other ladies were doing the same thing. Cant have the men enjoying themselves too much can we, ha,ha,       
Some serious hills today, light headwinds with a 22c max temp. For those unfamiliar with Western Australia the country roads here have no shops and very few homes along the way. You will often go miles without seeing a car.  We, together with Mary, Wendy & Pat decided to take a detour to the Treetop Walk. This is a suspension walkway built high into the tree tops of the Tingle Wood forest. Tingle Wood is a unique tree to these parts that grow tall with a wide girth.  The walkway allows tourists to enjoy viewing the forest without harming it. To reach the Tree Top Walk we added about 14 Klm to our ride. What we did not know (till we got there) was that the extra ride was all uphill and very very serious uphill. It left us feeling extremely tired very testing for us all. By the time we got to the top we were totally stuffed to say the least, and there was worse to come, we thought we would be okay with a nice cuppa and a bite to eat,(wrong). They don't sell food at the visitors centre, luckily for us Wendy, Pat and Mary came prepared a cracker biscuit, oysters and salmon went down very nicely, and for sweet Mary had a large block of Dove Hazelnut chocolate yum,yum, we needed the energy, ha,ha,. Tonight we are camping on the local sports oval. For such a small community the sports facility for the town folk is very good. Our evening meal is in the gymnasium. The place looks quite new and is a credit to the people of Walpole. One of the things we enjoy about this ride and particularly about the evening meal is the chance to sit with like minded people and discuss the days activities. Of course after a glass or two of wine the stories get better, the cycling gets faster and the hills even bigger, but this jovial conversation is not to be missed.     
This part of WA was perhaps the last to be explored and settled. Dutch , French and British explorers in turn seldom approached the complex rocky shores in high seas to chart these coasts. The first to penetrate many areas were whalers and sealers of various nationalities, who had little need to make records.  Not until the late 1830s did Preston and Clark chart the area. This town has an Ecco Walk path almost in the center of Town. The path is well maintained and leads through some native bush area. There are signs along the route that identify the various flora to be seen. The visitors centre has head-sets for a small hire fee discribing the local forna and flora. As we wander around the little town looking for the elusive "nice thing to buy" Trish spots a porcelain container at the Glass Shop. It has a Fairy on the top and is very delicate and pretty.Instantly Trish identifies it as the only thing that can house a 5 3/4 year old girls tooth. Our granddaughter Ailish is loosing teeth as her second set pop through. Such a container is obviously mandatory to any Nan worth calling a Nan so it is purchased. Phill secretly wonders if it will ever make it home without breaking but he's only a guy and obviously is not in the know about these things. Ailish loved the new container and it has been the recipient of a couple of teeth already.    This is just a spot full of beauty some parts that we had never seen let alone heard of (Williams Beach to be one of them) such a pretty place and the scenery is actually breathtaking.   
The boat is operated by the most enthusiastic man we have had the pleasure to meet in a long time. His knowledge of local History and the Environment is incredible. His ancestors services the passing whaling ships with fresh food and water. He has photographs and news clippings to show and tell. He quotes news paper reports, poetry, and anything topical you might remotely think of. His boat takes us to the "hidden" river outlet. He describes it as hidden because it took us a torturous path around sand banks to find our way out into the open sea.   . We enjoy an afternoon tea on a landing jetty within the estuary then we walked over the hill onto the beach. Waves roll in as we stand on white sand, restricted to just a few visitors (this is a National Park and has no access)     Going back in the opposite direction gives you a different perspective on life.  Not only so you see things from the other side but hills have opposite effects. Those horrible ups become glorious downs and (unfortunately) vice versa. A strange phenomina occurs to all cyclist we think, no matter what direction the bike is pointing in the wind is opposite.    On the way back to Denmark which was a reasonable ride we decided to stop of at our friends winery http://www.jindicreek.com.au we thought it was only a couple of klm's up the hill but how wrong we were it was a couple of klm up a gravel road and then further some more and some more and some more, we were totally stuffed to say the least when we arrived. Was worth the trip the welcome and the service we got was second to none, the wine was superb and the hospitality and food was great.  If you are every down Denmark this is the place to go. Ask for Rose & Mick tell them that we sent you.   
The ride was pleasantly not too bad at all. The road up to Mount Barker was rolling along but steadily rising. We came up to a popular wine yard (Trish's favorite drop) and had to call in. It looked like half the tour group had the same idea with lots of the produce being sampled. We sat in the manicured gardens and enjoyed the ambience with our friends. Alas they there plotting something and we where not to be included. We where politely asked to . We where politly asked to move on.    One of the traditions of the CTA ride is the last night concert. The concern is just any of the group getting up on stage and performing. There may be a song, a joke or even a Belly Dancer. Our friend planned something and we where not to find out until tonight. We moved on towards Mount Barker and soon found a problem, the bush was on fire, lots of smoke and ash drifted across the road as we cycled up a hill of a couple of miles. Flames were quite close to the road and the thick smoke made us cough as we passed by.  Unfortunately the bush is so dry here that this kind of deliberate patch burning is more desirable than a full scale out of control Bush Fire latter in the summer. We camped at the same site as day two and even had a hot shower. We ate our evening meal at the local hall again but we didn't linger to ensure there was enough time for all the volunteered acts to get on stage.  Singing, comedy, dancing, and even a bagpiper entertained us. The evening progressed and soon our friends there on stage to perform a Naming type Christening for our Tandem (about 9 months old). Earlier in the week we had told the girls that our Tandem was to be named Lilly from Trish's middle name, but they suggested it should also has Phil's middle name. Hence Lilly J Jnr was officially welcomed into the world with a song and blessing. Our rector the Revered Ever-ready called on the "Great Wheel Builder" in the sky to ensure Lilly J Jnr has tail winds, straight roads, down hills, and fresh air in her tyres for her long life on the open road. It was a lot of fun and the girls had written and sang a song that was pretty good. Don't think they should give up their day jobs though. A really good night had by all with lots of fun.     
  The ride home in the ute was so uncomfortable. It was in the mid 30's and the ute has no air conditioning. It was great to get into our own bed that night. Now we get serious about time on the saddle. 
The Characters: Kevin Rodger and Tom Jolliffe both cycle actively around their home base of London, Ontario, Canada. Both "gentlemen" are members of the London Cycle Club. Kevin is the young fellow, at 43 years of age (although this is constantly fluctuating), while Tom is a ripe 50 years old (I think). Since teaming up last year for a cycle trip from Frankfurt to Munich along the infamous Romantische Strasse, we have been very resourceful in planning cycling vacations, probably adding a lot of consternation to our wives' lives in the process. We usually plan one week long cycling trip per year into our hectic schedules - soon to come: Vienna, Austria to Budapest along the Danube (subject to approval from the holders of our purse strings), or another try at the Canadian Rockies. Originally, Tom and I had planned to cycle through the Canadian Rockies from Jasper to Banff at the end of June 2000. However, a scheduling conflict precluded that trip. Tom and I quickly sought an alternate destination that would fit into my vacation period at the end of May (it snows in the Rockies in May, that is why we didn't go there during this vacation period). We didn't have much time, as we still had to obtain airline tickets for Tom. We finally settled on England because of the availability of flights, and because of an itinerary we had seen in the book "Europe by Bike," by Karen and Terry Whitehill.  We would arrive in England on May 27 and depart June 5. This allowed for a day to travel to Oxford, seven days of cycling, and a day to see a few sights in London. As you can see by our web pages, things changed, and flexibility was a must. We altered our schedule somewhat so we could further enjoy some sightseeing. As a result, most of our cycling ended in Salisbury. We did, however have the opportunity to cycle directly into Heathrow Airport, where we left our bikes at left luggage for two days while we gallivanted around London. I must give credit to my riding partner, Tom Jolliffe for providing most of the written input into these web pages. Tom, even though he is much, much older than I am, seems to have an impecable memory. The detail he provided was invaluable in setting up this web page. Maps: I thought it might be appropriate to mention my thoughts about maps. Prior to leaving our hometown of London, Canada, Tom and I obtained the most detailed map we could find, a 1:250,000 scale map of south west England by Collins. We were able to find this map at the bookshop located upstairs in Novaks, an outdoor outfitter located in downtown London (Canada). This is the only map we used for the entire trip. While it proved satisfactory, I highly recommend abiding by the Whitehall's suggestion in their book: "If you haven't purchased a map with good detail up to now, do it before you leave Bath. Even a 1:50,000 map won't be overkill for this stretch of cycling. Your pence will be well spent." We actually tried to purchase the Ordnance Survey maps while in England, but every time, without exception, the map we required was always out of stock. By going to this web site, you can pre-order any maps you might require.   
We called our friends, Sharon and Ray, in Egham and they graciously encouraged us to come to their house and start our cycling trip from Egham. A good plan, visit with Sharon and Ray and then cycle to Oxford instead of taking the train.  We hailed a cab. "You want to go where? ...with two bikes? Will this be a cash fare?" Tom hesitatingly replied, "Yes." "50 quid!" was the response. We couldn't believe our luck! Only five minutes out of the Heathrow Airport, and our first chance to get ripped off! The hack driver's response was that it would take him out of the cue, and nothing less would be worth his while. Besides, nobody else was going to do it. We were somewhat distressed at the prospect of spending the equivalent of $115 Canadian to travel the less than 10 kilometers to Egham. Cycling to Egham would be easy except we did not have a detailed map of the area and so had no idea how to get to there, and we were also very hesitant about cycling out of the airport. So we agreed to the rip-off and were in Egham at Sharon and Ray's house within 30 minutes.  Sharon and Ray had recently moved from our hometown of London Ontario to England. They were members of our local cycling club and so it was very exciting to reconnect with them and to catch up our their new experiences in England. After coffee and gossip we donned our cycling gear, assembled our bikes, loaded our panniers and the four of us headed off to Windsor.  We connected to a cycling route from London to Oxford and soon entered the gated Windsor Great Park. This large park houses both the Queen Mother's residence and Windsor Castle. Enroute we passed a very impressive tree-lined promenade that extended for a mile through the park toward Windsor Castle.  We entered Windsor then stopped to view Windsor Castle. After a few photos we were on our way to Eton where we said our good-byes to our "British" hosts. Many thanks to Sharon and Ray forgetting us on our way toward Oxford.  We cycled west out of Eton, through Eton Wick and joined the A4 east of Maidenhead. Billowing clouds grew dark and drizzle soon accompanied us to Maidenhead. Drizzle strengthened to rain and by the time we arrived in Maidenhead, to hail. We waited for two brief hailstorms to pass, then headed on the A4 toward Reading. We encountered very heavy traffic on the narrow A4. The roads were in very good condition, but there was no shoulder on the A4. The terrain for the better part of the day was what I would call gently rolling with no major hills. Heavy rain soon returned and did not abate. After parking under a tree for some shelter from the driving rain, we weighed our options. Two very wet and cold cyclists determined that Oxford was not in our reach today.  We turned off at the next road into the town of Twyford. Here we stopped at a very "proper" Bed and Breakfast. A nice looking gentleman answered our knock at the door only to inform us that there was no room at the inn (I think his reaction might have had something to do with our overly wet demeanor). In any case, a quick call to another B & B secured us accomodation for the night.  After backtracking for 5 kilometers to arrive at Kiln Green we were greeted by Mary Berry and her dog, Charlie. Once dried out, somewhat to our surprise, Mary asked us to accompany her to The Old Devil Inn, a local pub located just across the street. Once there, Mary and Charlie joined two other B&B patrons. Kevin and I ordered some beers and proceeded to have a great time chatting with Mary and her two mates. More beers followed, but we were no match for Mary's gin and tonics and her mates' multiple rounds of Tangle Foot beer. With a few suds, some fish and chips, and very little sleep on the previous night's flight and the effects of jet lag taking hold, we retired early.       
After a short stint on the A4 we turned onto a "B" road through Wargrave and then joined the A321, following the Thames River valley to Henley-on-Thames. Some rowers were on the river, but there was certainly no regatta for our viewing. We continued west on the A321 until we joined the B480, which lead to Oxford.  The B480 was a quiet country road with a gradual rise through a picturesque valley. We continued to face a stiff headwind and now, for the first time, we were cycling up a long hill, appropriately named Pishill. How could we resist - we turned back and took our obligatory photo in front of this now famous sign.  The hill steepened for the last kilometer and then once at the top, it was downhill the rest of the way into Oxford, about 25 kilometers away. We restored our energy with some lunch, then continued to cycle the B480 to arrive in Oxford about 3:30 p.m. A visit to the crowded Tourist Information booth and our lodgings were easily arranged at a not-so-nearby hotel: The Hawkwell House Hotel. This hotel, located at Church Way, Iffley, Oxfordshire OX4 4DZ was offering a special rate for the night of only 40 pounds, including breakfast in the morning. Once checked in and shed of our sweaty spandex, we were ready to tour Oxford by 5:00.  Our late start and lengthy time to check-in left us little time to view Oxford. We ambled through some colleges and marveled at their detailed, intricate architecture. We walked into the New College courtyard and were politely, but sternly, ushered out by a proctor. We passed under Oxford's version of the Venice's Bridge of Sighs, then paused to view Edmund Halley's former observatory. We continued to stroll about the university town. We regretted our short stay in Oxford and wished we had additional time to learn some of Oxford's history.        
Crossing the A415, we found our way to a series of confusing and unsigned country lanes that wound their way through Yelford and Ashton where we rejoined the B4449. Then we made our way through the beautiful village of Bampton with its many picturesque cottages. We left the B4449 for the B4477 and made a rest stop at the "The Vines" in Black Bourton. The cost for lunch was a reasonable 4 pounds.  Continuing west on the B4477 through Alvescot, Kencott and Broughton Boggs, we crossed the A361. From here we found more quiet gently rolling country lanes. Kevin and I missed some turns in this section and ended up tacking our way towards the A417 just east of Cirencester. A short cycle on the A417, and we were at the Tourist Information booth to book our B&B for the night. This night we stayed at the Leauses, 101 Victoria Road, Cirencester. The cost was 40 pounds for the both of us,and of course that price included the standard "full English breakfast." You guessed it: one fried egg, sausage, bacon, and cold toast.  Cirencester was the centre of the medieval wool trade, and is sometimes referred to as the "Capital of the Cotswolds." Nineteen hundred years ago Cirencester was second only to London in importance and size. At one time it was also populated by the Romans, and it has many ruins from this period. We wandered the town to view the cathedral and some Roman ruins, then headed to the pub for refreshments. Just outside of the pub several young brits made fun of the fact that Kevin was wearing shorts.  The temperature was of course a bit on the cool side, but you get used to that when you live in Canada. We Canadians were too early for dinner, as usual, so we settled for beers until the pub dinner hour arrived around 6:30 p.m.. Beer was always very appreciated after several hours in the saddle. After a couple of hours of drinking beer and chips we departed for our night's accommodations. Before we made it to the B & B, we did summon the strength to stop by another pub for a drink.   
We found it interesting to see phone booths located on quiet country roads - perhaps a throwback to the days when not everyone had their own phones. Upon entering Malmesbury Kevin experienced his one and only flat of the trip (at least while riding). We stopped, changed the tube and then walked 50 yards to a very conveniently located gas station to pump up the tire. We took advantage of the air pump and topped up our tires. At this point, Kevin noticed that my rear tire was feathering in several locations. I had neglected to inspect my tires prior to departure and this oversight in basic bicycle maintenance would come back to bite me. After leaving Malmesbury we ventured back into another maze of country roads heading for Castle Combe. After several quick map referencing stops we cycled under the busy M4 motorway and had our lunch break just outside of Castle Combe.  The Cotswold village of Castle Combe lies at the bottom of a steep sided valley. This quaint "wool" town has gained stature as the "prettiest village in England." We toured the village, inspected the church graveyard (which appears quite haunted due to the tombstones, which appear ready to fall over), admired the hotel grounds and crossed the quaint stone bridge. Now the hard part - cycle out of Castle Combe.  With a steady pace we tackled the tree-lined valley wall and in a few minutes emerged from the valley. Now we were once again on our way to Bath. The gently rolling countryside of the Thames River valley was now behind us. Hills grew larger and steeper. We crossed the A420 at The Shoe and the upcoming hill did Tomin. Half way up he dismounted and walked up the remainder of the steep incline. Out of sympathy (or so he said), Kevin also dismounted. It was the only hill in England where he did this, finding out it was just as easy to slowly grind up in his lowest gear. After a few more kilometers we made an exhilarating descent into Batheaston. Kevin reached a top speed of 70 kph, whereas I gave my brakes a workout and descended at a slower speed. We now joined the heavy Bath traffic and cycled our way into the centre of Bath. Once cleaned up at our B&B (Avoca, 16 Newbridge Road, Bath BA1 3JX), we toured some of the Bath sites: the Royal Crescent, The Circus, Pultenay Bridge and the Roman Baths.  I had arranged to meet with a couple from Bristol, Ela and Jitu in the evening. Ela and Jitu had been visiting with their family in London Ontario for Christmas and it was great to reconnect with them. We had a very enjoyable, but much too short visit in the Abbey Courtyard.       
Wonderful cycling along lanes with the high hedgerows and no traffic was a real treat for us today. We cycled through Paulton, Midsomer Norton and Chilcompton then found the B3139 that lead to Wells. A long coasting descent took us into Wells. After our lunch break we toured the Wells Cathedral.  Outside, we met with some other cyclists who were also headed to Glastonbury. A large group of 30 cyclists on tandem bicycles were out for a two-day trip culminating in a rendezvous in Glastonbury. This was our only time on our trip we met a group ofcyclists.  We quickly left Wells for the short trip to Glastonbury, hoping to make it into town before all accommodation was taken up by the other cyclists. Sunny weather gaveway to clouds and by the time we reached Glastonbury there were a few brief sprinkles. After booking into The Old Bakery Bed and Breakfast, located at 84A Bove Town, Kevin toured the Tor, while Tom remained behind at the B&B to nurse the beginning of a cold.  Before the end of the last century the White Spring flowed from out of a cave within a small combe orvale at the foot of Glastonbury Tor. Its sister spring, Chalice Well or the Blood Spring, lies a few yardsaway on the other side of Well House Lane.  The grotto around the White Spring was originally overhung by trees and was full of shade and moisture-loving plants. It was a popular local picnic spot. Where the spring emerged, accretions of white calcite (calcium carbonate) built up on the exposed limestone and upon any twigs or branches which lay in the water, giving rise to the name. It is also known as the Tor Spring. Beside the White Spring an offshoot of Chalice Well water emerged and stained the stones in that part of the combe a dark red.  Unlike the Chalice Well the water of the White Spring has very little iron content and an irregular rate of flow. This can vary from 500 to 50,000 gallons per day. The source of the water is unknown but it must pass through the limestone beds which underlie this part of Somerset for a fair length of time before being pushed upwardas a result of artesian pressure below Glastonbury Tor. Here it is diverted by the hard Midford Sandstone of the summit and flows laterally through the softer layers of blue limestone and marl to emerge at the White Spring. No doubt the water has created caverns and flowstone formation below the Tor, access to which may once have even been possible.  The tradition of the White Spring is that it forms the entrance to and the exit from the pagan Underworld, the Celtic Annwn. The colours and the creatures of Annwn are traditionally red and White. The entrance is guarded by Gwynn ap Nudd "white son of night" Lord of the Underworld and King of Faery. Glastonbury legend says Gwynn and his fairies were exorcised by St Collen in the 6th century. Having one artesian spring into which has leached a distinctly coloured mineral is unusual enough, but to have two quite differently coloured springs rising side by side means that not only in fiction but in fact Glastonbury Tor lies over a mysterious subterranean realm! The colours red and white have further symbolic resonance in the British mythological tradition.  From "The Red and White Springs: The Mysteries of Britain at Glastonbury" by NICHOLAS R. MANN.  After Kevin's return we ventured out to tour the town. Glastonbury appears to host a rather eclectic group of artisans and hippies. This was much different to the throngs of camera clad tourists that we had become accustomed to and identified with. A pub dinner with several beers preceded our return to the B&B.         
In no time at all, we were off our intended course. After about 15 kilometers of cycling on flat country lanes we found ourselves about 7 or 8 kilometers off course. We joined the A361 to the A371 and endured the heavy traffic until the B3081.  Flat countryside was again behind us - we weren't especially fond of what we saw in our path. We made several climbs and an especially long climb prior to Bruton and then a quick descent into the town. We continued on the B3081 and more tough climbs. We cycled parallel to the A303 to take advantage of a more gradual incline. We joined the B3092, cycled under the A303 and headed into Mere for our lunch stop. From Mere we cycled into another maze of country roads towards the A350 and East Knoyle. After crossing the A350 we tried to plan our route to avoid another large hill. But no luck, we missed a valley route and instead climbed yet again before descending into Tisbury. From here to Salisbury the countryside was much flatter. We joined heavy traffic on the B3089. A strong tailwind helped us quicken our pace to 35 Kph all the way to Wilton.  At Wilton Tom stopped to get some cold medication. While in the drug store Tom's feathered rear tire gave way with a loud boom. This was actually a humourous experience for Kevin. Just as the "explosion" occurred, several young teenagers were walking by.  Not only did the blast scare the living daylights out of them, but Kevin initially thought they were playing a gag on him by exploding firecrackers nearby.  Ironically, the teens had just bought a tire repair kit from a local store and offered to help. The rear tire was a write-off. Fortunately, Kevin had some tire repair tape that he used to line the feathered sections inside the tire - it was deemed that five sections of tire needed the repair tape. The temporary fix held for the remaining 10 Km into Salisbury.  With a late start, a long ride and a flat tire we just made the Tourist Information Office 5 minutes before closing at 6PM. The office clerk seemed to take pity on this sniffling tourist and after several calls helped book a B&B. It was 7PM by the time we had checked-in and were ready for dinner. There was much to see in Salisbury, we decided to forgo the next day's cycle to Winchester and stay two nights in Salisbury. We walked downtown for dinner, and along the way we met another cyclist asking for directions.  We were actually able to help him out, as he was staying at the same bed and breakfast as ourselves.  He was quite grateful for our help, as he had over-extended himself that day by cycling over 120 km into headwinds.  We continued on our way to the downtown area where we strolled into a pub to sample yet another beer. Two young chaps noted our accent and stuck up a conversation with us. These two chaps were well primed with beer and kept us entertained while one called his Uncle "Knobby" on his cell phone. "Talk to Uncle Knobby, he lives in Canada too," the inebriated, but jovial lad said.  After talking tohis uncle for a few minutes we found out he lived only 45 minutes away from our homes, in the village of Strathroy. We greatly enjoyed the banter and often thought of how these two fellows must have coped the next day.  The next day we made our decision to stay longer in Salisbury.  Tom's cold had worsened by now, and we needed any excuse to get in some additional sightseeing,as well as beer drinking.  Unfortunately, our bed and breakfast for the first night, the Holmhurst Guest House was fully booked.  Karen Hayward, the proprietor was kind enough to call a friend on the other side of Salisbury, and we were quickly booked and on our way to the Old Rectory Bed and Breakfast for another fun filledday.    During our second day in Salisbury, we decided to take a quick bus trip to the legendary Stonehenge.  While this grouping of ancient monoliths had always held a special interest with us, once we arrived we found it a bit of an anticlimax.  The site was fairly small and not totally awe inspiring.  Admission to the site includes the use of a digital audio guide.  The use of this piece of equipment does provide some insight into the stones at Stonehenge, and I highly recommend its use to get some return for the high price of admission.     
I copied freehand from a detailed map at the train station of the Heathrow area. It did not look too complicated.  We were off to an early start for the big city after stowing our bikes in the small bike area on board the train.  There really was not enough room to stow both bikes in the one stall, so Tom sat his in the passageway and kept close tabs on it so it did not impede anyone.  We switched trains part way to London for the short journey to Hounslow Station.  In Hounslow, we started our ride towards Heathrow by following signs, our rough sketch, and a passenger van that had "Heathrow Express" written on the side.  Somewhere along the way we got ... well - lost again.  We stopped at a bike shop for directions, and we were promptly on our way once again.  Traffic into Heathrow on this Saturday was not as busy as I expected.  Most cars respected our space, except for one that Tom accidentally cut off while entering a large, confusing round-about.  Part way along we came to a cycle path and things were good.  We rode, and rode, and rode.  We seemed to be going in one big long circle around the entire airport!  Eventually our bike path ended at an underground tunnel.  What were we to do now - I didn't relish cycling through with a throng of cars behind.  Upon closer inspection of the tunnel, there was a silhouette of a bike painted on the pavement, and an accompanying sign that said cyclists have priority in the tunnel.  I was quickly off.  With the noise deafening (it sounded like a prairie freight train five feet behind), I rode at the breakneck speed of 40 kph through the tunnel.  Arriving at the other side I waited for Tom's arrival.  And waited...  He appeared after about five minutes.  Tom had not seen me enter the tunnel, and took a bit longer to get his nerve up and take the plunge.  After leaving our bikes at the left luggage area of Terminal 3 in Heathrow Airport, we caught an underground train for downtown London.  Because Saturday was an extra day in London, we had not prebooked a hotel, and the Hotel we were staying in on Sunday (Regent Palace) was fully booked.  We opted for a more expensive sister hotel a couple blocks away.  This was a worthwhile extra expense, as we both enjoyed the privacy of our own bathroom for the one night stay. While in London, we enjoyed doing the usual "tourist" things, such as touring the Tower of London (Kevin's third time through), and evening pub crawls, and ghost tours. Monday morning came, and we realised our vacation was over - we made our way back to Heathrow Airport, collected our bikes and proceeded to check in.  Tom was most gratified when they upgraded us to business class.  On the way over to England, we were "crammed" into the centre isle of a 767, and Tom (being fairly tall) managed to spill no less than three drinks on the gentleman seated next to him.  It was hard for Tom to repeat this in the upper deck of the 747 400 series, as the next passenger was a good 12 inches from his side! Although it took me less than six weeks to complete this trip, it's taking me much longer to sit down and try to describe. As more and more time passes from my trip it's more difficult to put down the events that occurred to me during this 6 weeks of travel. The inspiration to write down what I've done came to me as I've found this nice site maintained by Neil Gunton. It was his writing and the writings of others that encouraged me to put down my story as well. Otherwise I would be procrastinating even more, as I was planning to have my own WEB site to publish the memories of my trip. The next few sections give in more details about the planning, the selection of the equipment and some of the resources that I've used to plan my trip. I would like also take the opportunity to introduce the rest of my family. My wife, daughter and the cat(s). My role at home in addition to cycling among others is also to take care of the cats, water and hang the plants.           
When I've started thinking seriously about my trip I've purchased and read in the winter 1999/2000 some bike books talking about long distance bicycle touring and read some stories of long distance touring on the WEB. I've also written to all the pedestrian/bicycle coordinators in each of the states that I was planning to cross and requested as detailed map of each state as possible. I got the maps from all the states that I've requested. While not all of the maps were too detailed they suffice to plan my route. In addition I've also purchased from Adventure Cycling association their Southern Tier Maps.  My thought was to select as simple route as possible between the starting point and the end point of my trip. Since the Adventure Cycling maps already cover most of the route to be covered, I had to plan the remaining pieces of the puzzle. Which were the initial and the final phases of my trip. The plan was to go SouthEast and later connect with Adventure Cycling route somewhere around Phoenix, AZ. Originally I planned to go west through Mount Hamilton (the home of the Lick Observatory), continue through Yosemite than south on route 395 through Bishop. What caused to change my mind were the reports I've read on the CA State Parks site about bears in Yosemite being very active that year. Therefore to simplify the matter I've decided to take another route, one which will take me South through Gilroy, Pinnacles National Monument, Coalinga, Bakersfield and Mojave.  Also comparing the Adventure Cycling maps with the state maps, I've noticed that their route was passing through routes less traveled. This of course would add somewhat to my mileage, but I was interested to finish the trip ASAP. Therefore when I could use a straightforward route to go from point A to point B, I would select it instead. This did not prove to be a wise choice in some instances, as we'll see later. The last section of my trip in Florida, I've planned as I went along, just by looking at the Florida State map, which was quite detailed and had other good information as well. 
My preparation included daily commute to work, a distance of about 26 miles with my panniers loaded. I was riding to work with my front pannniers full of one gallon water bottel on each side. The rear panniers were always loaded with my books, clothing to change, including shoes as well as my lunch and sometimes breakfast. In addition to this I've made at least three , 2 day trips fully (almost fully) loaded in the area. The disatnce was for the 2 days of about 200 miles. These trips proved that it's not as easy to travel fully loaded especially in a heat and uphill. I've carried with me the camping equipment as well as some food and extra clothing. but it was nothing close to what I've palnned to take for the cross country trip. These trips taught me how to set up my tent in the darkness as well as how to use my stove. When the spring of 2000 approached, the pace of the work in my company also has picked up and I did not feel that it would be the appropriate time to take off. So I've decided to wait few months untill the fall of 2000.

 You can also see the reflective strips on the wheels for extra visibility at night.  is of my bicycle while still being on my workstand the day of my departure, Sept. 13th 2000  taken in the morning. It was in this postion for a few days while I was working on the packing and making sure it's in sound mechanical shape. You can imagine yourself the comments I was getting from my wife with the bike standing in the middle of the living room! for all the time I was loading. I certainly greatly appreciate her patience and cooperation. Here are some details on the bicycle and the equipment attached to it: 1. Frame Merlin http://www.merlinbike.com/ Titanium a 1994 model.  2. Equipment Shimano XTR components, groupo year 1994.  3. Handlebars equipped with "Nuke" drop down and extension bar. They used to advertise in "Adventure Cycling" magazine. I can not say that it's a too great product. The drop down I've used was the "L" type. Maybe their other version of the classical dropdown would be better.  4. Bontrager rims with Continental http://www.conti-online.com/ Top Touring 2000 tires.  5. Front gearing 26/36/46 chainrings.  6. Rear gearing, of 13 through 28. 8 speed. 7. Jandd Mountaineering http://www.jandd.com/ expedition bike rack.  8. Old Man Mountain http://www.oldmanmountain.com/ front rack.  9. Zeffal fenders and home made flaps with extra reflectors.  10. Union generator set, this was my workhorse for the night cycling as well as on the longer days. The days were getting shorter and shorter and to cover more distance I had to extend my cycling into the night more and more. NOTE: It adds some drag to the tire therefore it slows you down a bit. This is one of the sites that carry it: http://catalog.bicycleblowout.com/site/intro.cfm?PageID=37&Category=82 I've seen at http://www.harriscyclery.com/ that there is a Shimano brand that comes mounted in a hub and has very low drag.  11. Two red Vista flashing taillights and one white for front. In the desert in the middle of the night this was actually enough to light the road in front of me.  12. Terry Men's Fly Bicycle Saddle. 13. Three water bottle cages, one for the stove fuel and two for water. Spare spokes (x6) and Blackburn compact pump. 14. Rhode Gear rear view panoramic mirror. I think it's a must on a cross-country trip. 15. An Avocet 50 Altimeter (not available anymore). I had it for over 9 years and needed to repair it once. They still keep the PDF version of the manual on line at: http://www.avocet.com/instrpdfs/50Eng.pdf/ 
Front Left Pannier: Total weight about 10Lb. Stove and matches, frizzed-dry food that need to be cooked in boiling water. Power bars in small packages. Veggie soup bullion jar and oats in two small containers. Panniers cover. Front Right Pannier: Total weight about 11 Lb. In a foldable pouch all the tools plus spare parts (included tie wraps, electrical tape, grease + injector, ball bearings, cones and various screws). Cleaning rags. Package of disposable latex gloves. Spare tubes (x2). Spare brake pads. Spare cleats SPD. Duct tape, various c-clamps. Rim tape. Dental kit including flossing, paste plus other stuff (I've a lot of problems with my teeth). A jar of multi-vitamin, GU-energy gel(s) and Pannier cover. Rear left pannier: Total weight 20LB. Fleece jacket. Warm-up suit. Warm gloves, leg warmer, cookware + utensils, toiletry, adventure cycling maps + individual state maps. Wool socks, spare micro-cassettes, shopping bag extra straps and rope. Cycling jerseys, two short and one long sleeve. Cycling shorts. Spare latex gloves for repairs and puncture repair. Baby wipes. Cycling socks (3). Bandana, 2 pair of underwear and swimsuit, a one gallon collapsible water container. Extra film + various batteries for the Pentax camera, Avocet altimeter, mini flash lights. TEVA sandals, small water bottle and pannier cover. Rear Right Pannier: Total weight 20LB. Ground cloth, tenth + stakes + plastic mallet, sleeping bag and pillow. Various manuals for bike, tenth, MSR stove. Various size batteries like (I had enough batteries probably to go around the US perimeter. Also you can get them along the way.) Petzl headlight and my radio/alarm clock. Spare parts for my SILCA pump + plastic fit for the fork when the bike will be shipped back. Spare garbage bags for extra protection during rain and ZIP lock bags. Extra toilet paper and baby wipes. Spare Velcro bands for tying stuff. Petzl headlamp, another small water bottle, and pannier cover. Handlebar bag:  Camera, portable radio, few power bars and GU gels. Toilet paper and baby wipes in small package. Bicycle lock, tape recorder, suntan lotion, chamois butter, lip balm and crash pack from 'Brave Soldier'. Seatpost bag: Spare tube and patch kit, tire levers, and spoke wrench, chain tool, chain links and pressure gauge. Also I had an extra pair of sunglasses, bandana, small flashlight and magnifying glass for reading maps. Extra Stuff Sack that rode on top of rear rack: Sleeping matters/pad, rest pad/chair, spare tire, bicycle lock, and extra insulation tubing for making new handlebar padding. Silca floor pump, which extended a bit beyond the stuff sack. Also included rain gear (pants and jacket) and GORTEX socks. Jandd Mountaineering Hydration Pack: In addition to the water pack it contains I also had there my wallet, sunscreen, lip balm, chamois cream, some power bars and Yellow bicycle jacket. (All of the above four weighted approximately 20 LB.) 
Before departing on my trip, I've left an approximate itinerary of my trip with my wife at home. I've left my home at exactly 2:00 PM what looked to be a nice and warm day. The trip was relatively easy as I knew the route, but I forgot that I'd hit the relentless afternoon rush hour in the heart of Silicon Valley. After negotiating the street traffic and the numerous turns to take me out of the city I've reached Monterey Highway which took me South to Gilroy. Gilroy for those who may not know is famous for it's garlic. It's very well known here in the Silicon Valley area during the "Gilroy Garlic Festival" that takes place for 3 days during the month of July. It's very hot there but if you like garlic and want to sample some of the culinary achevements made out of it it's worth the trip. You can eat there anything from roasted garlic through garlisc pie to garlic ice cream. Anything garlic goes there ! On my trip South I've been passing many motorists stacked in traffic and have been wandering that they must be happy finally making it closer to home. While I was thinking that it's only the beginning for me to the relatively unknown road in front of me. Around 7:00 PM I've reached the city of Gilroy and stopped by a local Pizzeria for a big slice of pizza and some drink. While there I've asked the owner for a cheap Motel in the area and he recommended Motel 6 saying that they are cheap, around $60. This was too steep a price for me so I went to look for something less expensive, read further. I've  continued until I hit a quite road and found that it was passing near a nursery. I've circled the place and decided that it's peaceful enough to pitch a tenth in the area. I've crossed a field and parked my bike near the fence beyond the nursery so nobody could see me. Behind me was a dry creek so it felt relatively safe and only in distance I could see some lights from houses as well hear dogs barking. I hoped that nobody is going to explore the area where I was situated. The next picture shows the setup as photographed early morning the next day.   
I've washed myself using a towel dipped in water and cooked my oats and ate a power bar. Around 8:00 AM I was on my way toward Coalinga. I've started south on Hwy 25 and later on merged to Hwy. 198 leading to Coalinga. I'm quite familiar with this route as it's also the route of one of the local centuries (currently discontinued) called the Gilroy Garlic Festival century. As I was passing the main street of Hollister, a quiet and neat town on Hwy. 25 I could smell the smell of fresh muffins and donuts. So I stopped at a local bakery for some cakes, juice and coffee. This enrgized me for the rest of the day which turned out to be more difficult than I could imagine earlier. There was not much traffic going my way and the wheather was perfect. The only problem that concerned me was my bicycle wiggling or oscilating when I tried to get up from my saddle or to accelarate. You can judge for yourself on the condition of the traffic on my route from the following picture.    Since I felt relatively good I decided to skip the camp site I know is available at the Pinnacles National Monument site, just of Highway 25. It takes few miles deviation to go inside but I decided to continue in hope that I'll find a place to sleep somewhere along the way.  Once I've decided to continue and knowing there are no services until Coalinga, I've stopped at the California Department of Forestry fire station and filled-up all my reservouirs with water. The firefighters that saw me with all my gear were quite impressed and showed me to their kithchen  where I also ate light dinner consuming couple of my power bars. Theys also told me that I'm lucky to find them here as the station is seasonal and is closed after October.   As I continued I've noticed that it was getting dark very fast, because the mountains were on my right side and the sun was already hiding. After passing the entrence to the Pinnacles National Monumnet there were few small climbs and nice descents on Hwy 25. It became already completely dark and I entered unfamiliar terittory. The route winded and climbed more, winded even more and climbed and I was getting very tired with all my equipment. I've started to look around if there is any place to pitch a tent but it was all mountain slope going down. At ceratin point I've decided that I'll walk as it was realy hard to pedal up. I've probably walked for a mile or so to a place that looked like a peak to me. I did not want to continue since it was very foggy, I could see how my lights were reflcting back from the fog. I looked around but it was all fenced area. I found what looked like an opening in the fence but I was too tired to carry the bike through. It was also late, close to 11:30 PM, suddenly I've spotted a small hill with a big Oak tree on top of it. So I climbed there and decided to retire. But I was also very hungry at the same time so I've preapared the fast meal from a freeze dry food from REI. Just add boiling water, wait few minutes and ready to it.  It looked dry under the tree and I did not pitch my tenth. I was a bit worried as I foudn some human garbage in the area, namely bottles and something that looked like hunting knife holder. However I took the chance and fell a sleep very fast. 
I was awaken early in the morning by the water dripping on me from the Oak tree, that was probably the result of the condensation on the leafs. I've cooked some oats ate a power bar and drank some coffee as well. Very soon I found myself going downhill on a very nice descend. So my guess last night that I've reached some peak was correct. The sun starting to break through the fog and road became dry soon. It was a bit winding but I could go quite fast as the traffic was again very sparse. Actually I've seen only one tractor going up with some workers, but other than that nothing else. The series of picture here were taken shortly after I've finished the descent and entered the area around Priest Valley, which as far as I could see had only few houses. The place is marked on the California map but if you go to Yahoo/Maps you'll not find it, strange          The Valley was very nice and peaceful. Just a perfect begining for a long cycling day. A cattle was on the pastures on both sides of the road. The bulls started to run as soon as they saw me and what is strange they were running in the same direction I was going. Luckily a fence at the end of the field stopped them, since I've started to worry a bit already. My plan for that day was to send home some of the stuff that I carried and that deemed not needed for the rest of the trip or stuff that I could give up. Some of the items I've sent back were needed later on, especially the warm clothing. In any event as soon as I've reached Coalinga I looked for a US Post Office. Coalinga appeared to be much bigger and nicer town that I've imagined. Among others I've sent back the handlebar bag, the Silca floor pump, some of the warm clothing, my "Teva" sandals (having size 13 shoes, this was some weight saving as well) and the micro-cassette recorder (I wish I did not). This obviously reduced my total weight by few pounds. However it did not eliminate the wiggling or oscillations completely. I continued South on Hwy 33 and on my way stopped in a local restaurant and ate a good sandwich for lunch at a local restaurant. Also I've filled all my four water bottles and the hydration pack with water. This was a good idea as it became hotter and there was no water until the town of McKittrick. That time of the year was apparently a harvest time for nuts in Southern California and therefore there were many trucks passing on the road. When they passed me I was blown back and forth making my progress more and more difficult and I became covered with dust. Not all the drivers slowed down or made sure they keep safe distance when passing me. The road was also quite narrow and rough. Along the road I've seen many nuts trees. Among them I've also seen Pistachios trees, which I've learned grow on trees and not on bushes like peanuts (this what I thought). From a distance and in the late afternoon sun they looked to me like some kind of grapes. This picture shows some of the Pistachios trees I've seen on my way.    And more Pistachios trees.    In addition to the nice pictures of the Pistachios there was a lovely smell of roasted nuts along the way. This was coming as I've learnt later from a huge processing plant located along the highway. The name of the consortium that owned this plant was named 'Paramount', I'm not sure if there is a relation to Hollywood. I continued my ride in to darkness and started to see area with a lot of lights and thought I'm approaching the town of McKittrick. So I continued further and have seen great deal of huge trucks and started to smell some strange smell, not too pleasant. This reminded me something of the nature of oil processing plant which I recognized from past experience. As I continued I started to see many oil pumps going up and down and trucks and more trucks, but strangely I did not see any humans. This spanned for few good miles and the smell was killing me. It reminded me some episode from a 'STAR WARS' movie. I wanted to get away from this as soon as possible but was getting exhausted and I started to look for a place to retire. I've waved to some of the trucks to ask the drier about a place to stay but none of them stopped. I was too tired to continue further and also was not sure about whare exactly I was and  McKittrick was out of site. Although from the reading of my odometer I was supposed to be around somewhere. I thought to myself that may be I've taken a wrong turn and therefore I do not see it. From the Blackwell Corner it said that it's 25 miles to McKittrick and 45 miles to Taft. My only concern now was to get some rest and configure the rest next day in the morning. So I gave up and when I thought I got far enough from the bed smell I entered a road into one of the plants and turned into the low desert bushes. They were not high enough to hide behind and the trucks entering and leaving could see me clearly. When I stopped moving and there was no noise from my generator I could suddenly hear very well an orchestrated noise from a bunch of Coyote in a distance. This made me a bit worried if this is going to be safe and if they may not get close to me. Although I was planning to lay down on a mattress in my sleeping bag only, but due to the howling of the Coyote I've decided to set my tenth. I was so tired that I fell asleep very fast and luckily no one bothered me till the morning. 
After a ride of 2 to 3 miles and some climbing I've reached the top of the hill and only now I could see the town of McKittrick in the horizon. This also explained why I could not see it yesterday night. The sign on my right said that the population of this town is only 130. As I entered the town I've noticed a school on my left side. What was strange that it was very quiet and I did not see any students outside and it looked like deserted although the gate was open. So I thought to myself that it was only Friday, but it turned out that it was Saturday and the school was closed today. In any event I've entered through the gate and found a faucet with water. Suddenly I've seen a woman exiting one of the classes and I've approached her and asked if there is any place I could take a shower here. She replied that there is none, but I've seen a pool on the other side of the lawn, so I concluded that there must be some shower or something like this. She stepped into one of the classes and after a while she emerged back and said that her husband will open the pool where the showers are located. But she said that the water may not be warm, which I did not care as I've not showered or shaved for the last 4 days. Once inside the shower area I've also laundered my bike clothing and changed, so minimum you need two pairs as not always there is a camp or make laundry anytime you wish! Later on I've stopped and a local grocery, (looks like the only one in town) and paid for a small sandwich and Gatorade $5.50. While in Coalinga for a much bigger sandwich and Gatorade I paid only $3.00, well  just money. I left Coalinga and continued East on Hwy 58 toward Bakersfield. However I've tried to avoid to pass through it.  Around 7:30 PM I've reached a small town named Panama. Since it was already dark and I did not want to continue as it looked like tomorrow will be a hilly day. I could already see the mountains in the horizon, the ones that I'll be climbing tomorrow. Along the way thre was a small church and decided to stop and look if I could spent the night over there. It was a bit remotely located from the houses and stood by itself in front of a corn field. I  went to look if there might be somone to ask if I could pitch my tenth behind the church. However it appeared that there was nobody around. So I went behind the last building near the farming fields and pitched my tenth there. This is the 1st time in few days that I was able to prepare my dinner while sitting at some picnic table. I've also repaired the flat and done some work on the bicycle that was making noise from the tailgate lamp rubbing the spokes from the panniers pressure on it. These desert place are becoming very cold at night and I've started to be sorry for shipping the fleece jacket and my Silca floor pump when I had to pump my wheel. 
  At that instant I've also heard noise like someone walking around the church and noticed that the pastor has returned (may be late at night ?) and was cleaning and rearranging stuff around. I was wondering what is the purpose of him doing all this so early in the day. When he approached me he said god morning and I replied telling him that I slept here and he said, 'Oh I may have forgotten to close one of the doors to a class.'  He did not realize that I slept outside in a tenth, which was still standing at that time. I told him that I'll be leaving in a while and he asked me where am I heading. I replied that I go to Florida and he said have a safe trip. In any event after a while I've seen guests ladies and gentleman dressed neatly arriving and gathering in one of the classes and after a while someone started playing piano and the choir sang. Well I forgot completely that it was already Sunday and hence the festive gathering. I've arranged my stuff washed and ate breakfast while the people were still singing and left the place toward Mojave in the direction of Hwy 58 but before that I had to climb the Tehachapi pass. On the left is the Sierra Nevada and on the right are the Tehachapi mountains. Somehow from the map I've configured that there must be a shortcut to Hwy 58 and I entered some secondary route that was leading me through an agricultural area. I've seen there water melons, oranges and other fruits growing. This is the heart of the famous Kern County. The climate is very hot but there is no water around. It's brought from the north through the famous California aqueducts. Well after I came closer to the mountains I realized that the route I took ended and I wanted to turn left toward Hwy 58. I met two farmer ladies and asked them if this road leads to Hwy 58, and they replied that not. As the result of this I had to retrace my way back loosing some time. After few turns I finally entered Hwy 58 and it looked very buys. It is a divided Hwy and carries great deal of traffic of al kind, including many heavy trucks. Throughout the day it became hotter and hotter as I approached the town of Tehachapi    and the Tehachapi pass. I made it to the top (almost) when the sun started to set down already. On my way up I've stopped at some restaurant along the way. It was the only ony on the climb, while the sandwich was so, so the place was nice and cool. It was a needed break before heading further to Mojave.    After the climb to the Tehachapi peak I had nice and very long descend toward Mojave. Due to the headwind that was blowing in the opposite direction the ride downhill was not as fast as I would like. There were also trucks and cars passing me all the time. The traffic was pretty heavy one and because it was already dark on the other side of the mountain I kept some bigger distance from the shoulder. I wanted to avoid any surprise hitting a pothole or another obstacle. Some of the drivers did not like it and passed quite close to me.  Mojave surprised me as quite neat looking town. From the conversation with one of the waitresses in the Pizzeria I ate my pizza dinner I was told that many of the residents are working or serving in the Edwards Air Force base. It had neat restaurants and numerous motels, but I was looking for something cheaper. I asked the waitress if she knows where a local campsite is located. She said that she does not know but said that there is a public park near the school and gave me directions. I've decided to look if I could sleep there. On my arrival I've seen few youngsters and asked them if they think I could sleep in the park they said that they've seen people sleeping there. Since it was already after 10:00 PM I've decided that I'll pitch there. There were also public restrooms there with running water. The park had nice green grass and it worried me that the sprinklers might operate at night. I found a corner under some pine trees where there was not grass. After washing myself lightly in the cold water I went to sleep. 
Another interesting thing along this way was many of the retired and not used airline planes. I could read the names like TWA, NorthWestern, PanAm, Continental and some others. This looked like a graveyard of the big planes. Although recently I've heard that there were many airlines that retired early their fleet of planes due to overcapacity and underutilization. The last few miles before Barstow were very busy, as Barstow is a major hub for few highways, namely 58, interstate 15 and 40. One has to be a bit more careful when making the entrance and also not to end on one of the interstate highways. When I reached Barstow I did not look for a campsite but decided to stay in a Motel and sleep during the day do some maintenance on my bike as well as my body. My butt suffered from a bad boil and also had to plan my trip ahead. Namely how many more sections shall I do in California as well as what would be my route to Arizona. It actually changed later on the spot from an advice I got from a local. I've stayed in Barstow the next night and the day resting and taking care of business. I did not go sightseeing but watched some TV when not sleeping and doing other stuff. The Motel I've stayed is called Desert Inn and paid $22 for night. 
The day was devoted mostly to some rest, maintenance of my bike and of my body as well as planning of the next segment of my trip. This was not planned clearly before my departure and I was planning to take care of this during my trip based on the current conditions. Since the distance from Barstow to Needless California was about 150 Miles and based on my experience in the desert I was not able to make it in one shot even with some effort. This was mostly due to the heat and the limited time I could cycle. I've decided that I'll leave early Wednesday morning, actually around midnight. 
I should perhaps also add that I've left with all my water containers full. This included the 4 of the bottles, Jandd hydrator and the 1Gallon collapsible water container. The right starts with a portion on I-40. However soon on the outskirts of the town you merge into the a frontage road that goes almost parallel to I-40 and later on in Ludlow you take the 'National Trails Highway'. All this road including the last one is in very bad shape. There are big patholes and the asphalt is split in many places. As a result of this I've been going many times illegally opposite to traffic (luckily there is not much of it) on a narrow section that was just dug for putting a fiberoptics cable. This narrow section on the left-hand side of the road was well paved. This and the heat as well as the fact that I was standing on my pedals for long period of time (to avoid the bumps) were taking a toll on me. The fact that I've rested well the last day and night was a very good idea before this trip. This was a reason that I liked the idea of riding on Interstate highway as it's allowed in Arizona. But more on this will be told in the Arizona segment. Early in the morning after about 7 hours of travel, right after Ludlow I've got flat #2 of my trip. My close investigation revealed that the 'Mr.Tuffy' liner cutting into the tube caused this flat. NOTE: My experience as well as this reported by others Mr. Tuffy is not good protecting you from flats on fully loaded tours!!! I had this experience myself while commuting with Mr. Tuffy to work. But I thought that by wrapping the liner in electrical tape as well as smoothing its edges and removing the overlap, I would not get the flat. Well this has proven to be a false expectation. Therefore I got read of the Mr. Tuffy liner on my rear wheel. I repaired that flat and continued.  Along the way there was an interesting spot it's the Amboy Crater that is designated as one of the National Natural Landmarks. The next set of pictures shows the place and one of the pictures gives the fuller description of this location.          Show links to this Hide links to this          After repairing my tire and making few pictures near the Amboy crater I arrived just in time to the famous Roy's Cafe http://www.rt66roys.com/ in Amboy for a hearty and cheap breakfast. There is also a motel there but being save conscious and still feeling strong I decided to continue. This probably was a mistake since after few miles further the heat and the exhaustion caused me to start to look for a spot to take a rest. I've found some drainage spot along the road and dragged my bicycle across the desert sand and pitched my tenth. I probably took a nap for 45 minutes or so when I was awaken from the sun shining just into my tenth and causing me to perspire like a hell. This was around 11:00AM, and the temperatures did not peak yet. I gathered my stuff fast, washed myself from the sticky sweat and sand and continued along the way to Essex. When I arrived there I was told that the temperature just reached 112 F and I really was feeling like it was so at one point. This was the day that as I cycling and I saw a freight train in the distance that I thought to myself if I could only get somehow a ride on the train to my next destination. But it was only a dream. Finally I've arrived at some spot where there was an overpass under the railway tracks and decided to pitch my tenth there. As it was already late, probably after 10:00 PM I've set my tenth just near the the overpass. It was too narrow to place my tenth under the overpass. The ground there was very soft, actually white beach sand and it was an ideal place to rest on. However I've noticed that the train were passing there quite often in both directions and with every pass the wind blow was terrible and I worried that this will flip the tenth. Also I worried a bit that the train may overturn and I'll be killed. So I've dragged my tenth few feet away from the underpass toward the road and left the bicycle locked to one of the poles under the overpass. I also put earplugs into my ears and fell asleep very fast; none of the trains passing above me bothered me at all. 
I've arrived in Needles around noon with temperatures hitting again the 112 F border. I ate some tuna sandwich, drank Gatorade and Coke in a Chevron gas station convenience store. After that I cycled around until I found a decent motel, it was Motel 6 and decided to stay there for the rest of the day and evening. As usual in the desert my plan was to continue in the middle of the night whenever possible. This Motel 6 was not cheap but I could not find a cheaper place there despite the fact that there were almost no people there. I guess the proximity to the Colorado River in the middle of the desert determines the price. They charged me $40 and I was too tired to go and look for cheaper place. I cooked my meal in the room and packed my bicycle ready for the next segment of my trip and went to sleep. 
My map did not show the exact climb from Needless and it turned out to be a killer. Firstly the road was winding and the hot wind was blowing against me, making the climb much more difficult. There were also many big trucks going at night and passing me often on this route.  Originaly I planned to continue from Needles to Kingman AZ, travel on I-40 and than Hwy 93 toward Phoenix. From looking on the map it looked like it will be an easier route that the one I've made. I've changed my plan based on information I got from an owner from a tire repair workshop in Fenner, Ca the previous night. I'm not sure if this was an easier route but it definitely was not easy. In any event in the middle of the climb the front tire had a flat (#3 and before the last till the end of the trip). After taking off the tire I've again determined that it was the liner cutting into the tube. I got read of the last liner and used a spare tube to repair the flat. It was night and in the middle of the climb and trucks passing me very close so I had to hurry up. After finishing the climb the rest of Hwy 95 appeared to be peace of cake it was relatively straight. However the climb took a toll on me so I've pulled my bike toward some low lying bushes along the road around 6:00 AM and used my ground cloth, mattress and the sleeping bag to take a nap. I woke up as usual with the desert sun starting to operate and heating up the air. This was around 9:00 AM. However this short nap definitely boosted my energy level and I was able to continue to Parker Arizona. After turning east at Vidal junction and continuing on Hwy 62 I've arrived to Parker AZ in the early afternoon hours. The heat goes on as I arrive to Parker, AZ. Although it seemed to be a bit cooler that in Needles. Parker is on the eastern side of the Colorado river while Needles on the Western side. May be these makes the difference in the temperatures? Also possible it's the proximity to the water.  Here are some pictures showing a train bridge parallel to my road over the Colorado river in Parker AZ and a gentleman water skiing on the river.    I've spotted on my way to town another Motel 6 and decided to take this for the rest of the day and evening. As usual I was planning again to continue in the middle of the night until I get out from the desert zone.   
This was another long day and I did not find any suitable place to sleep along the way. The terrain was mountainous as well as was abundant in vegetation but mostly of the cactus family. Finally I thought that I found a good spot to pitch my tenth when I've spotted a rattlesnake sneaking into one of the many holes in the ground. When I looked more carefully around me I've spotted many other holes in the ground and thought that there might be snakes in some of the holes around. So despite being tired and it was getting dark already I've decided to continue. I arrived late evening in Wickenburg and rode along the main street, which was also the route I've arrived, when I've met a young gentleman smoking outside of a Safeway supermarket. I've asked him if there is any park in the area or a campground and he told me that on the other side of the town, there is a RV park. I've found it as he described and since it was already after 10:00 PM there was nobody in the office to register. I've knocked on a door in one of the mobile homes in the park, where a mother and son lived and were having a grill outdoors and they told me to pitch a tenth in an empty spot and to I look for the owner in the morning. I've done so and selected a nice spot near one of the houses under a big tree and nice lawn and felt a sleep very fast. 
On this section I finally for the first time made use of the Adventure Cycling Maps on part of my route this day. As I approached Phoenix the roads started to get more crowded with cars. There I've spotted a nice looking old style building that was a dinner and a restaurant. As I was not sure how much more I'll be circling before I find a spot to rest I stopped there for a good lunch and some rest. The Adventure Cycling maps take you throughout the Phoenix area on a route that avoids most of the congested areas by using the trail along the aqueduct. This aqueduct crosses most of the metropolitan Phoenix area but it ends at certain point. At least it ended somehow for me. It's easy to follow as long as you can read the signs around you because it's still enough light. Once it start to become darker you must be careful not to take a wrong turn as happened to me, causing me to do a bit extra miles. Luckily for me I've met this local cyclist, Chris Forsyth who was riding in the area this Sunday afternoon. We started a conversation and it turned out that he is ex Silicon Valley resident who moved into the Phoenix area because of affordability in housing. He went out of his way to show me the route by accompanying me all the way until somewhere in Tempe. Here he treated me to a dinner in a Subway restaurant, which by the way became one of my favorite eating places along the way later on.
