After that he showed me where are some of the Motels in the area and we parted after he phoned his wife to pick him. The Motels turned out were not too cheap, in the vicinity of $60 and I was not ready to pay this amount especially as I just rode 70 miles today and was still feeling good. I continued for a while until I passed near the airport and started to look for a place to retire. In the course of my search I've spotted a sign to a local park and decide to head there. The park turned out to be a trail and some trees and a golf course. The gate to it was closed so I decided to pitch my tenth near the gate to the golf course on top of some small hill. Except of the occasional noise from the airplanes taking off and landing it was very quiet. My luck was that the gate to the golf course was closed because the sprinklers went off shortly after I've retired. This experience was not enough to avoid another sprinkler shower later on in Arizona. 
 , was taken from my spot where I slept in the morning after being awakened by the early birds arriving for a golf session. It was amazing to see many interesting cactuses in one section of Arizona, mostly before Phoenix and I told myself that there would be enough time to take some pictures them. However suddenly the landscape changed and there was no more interesting vegetation so I could not show you some of the nice and tall cactuses I've been seeing along my way. After a breakfast that consisted of cooked oats and coffee I've continued on Route 60 to Globe. It was a hot day and some climbing in the excess of 4000 Feet. I've arrived to Globe around 8:00 PM and slept for $5 at Gila County RV Park.  I think that $5 is a reasonable price to pay for a campsite for a cyclist, because as an alternative you may consider sleeping for free wherever.  In the campsite I've met a couple from China that were travelling the US by car and sleeping in campsites. They were speaking a reasonable good English and we engaged in brief conversation about touring in general and bicycle touring in particular. They were quite impressed when I told them that I'm going to Florida and have started few days ago from San Jose, CA. Well another short encounter with car riders, but these people seemed to be interested more in cycling than the average traveler I've encountered. It's probable due to their background. From a documentary I've seen about China looks like most of the people there are riding a bicycle. 
The day was going a bit slow and I've made multiple stops to rest. As I approached Fort Thomas it started to get dark. When suddenly I see two guys waving to me from the side of the road. I've decided to stop and see what is going on. These two guys were two fellows from Holland, Vincent and Huub. They were doing the Adventure Cycling route, from San Diego to St. Augustine, FL. They had taken it easy starting in September and planning to finish in March in Florida.  This place Ft. Thomas is a place where a monument to commemorate the founder of Lions Club International, Melvin Jones is erected, http://www.rimcountry.com/lions.htm. Lions Club International is an organization that helps blind people all over the world. The guys from Holland told me that they have just finished doing their laundry and ate their dinner in the small restaurant nearby and are planning to spend the night here in the park near the monument. The small park there had a nice green lawn and I told them that it's Arizona and the sprinklers will start late at night. But they wanted only to lie on the grass. I can understand them going through the desert and suddenly having a nice and green piece of land. In any event they hanged their laundry around on the fence and we spread our mattresses on the grass and fell asleep without even erecting our tenths, as it was quite hot. Well couple of hours later in the middle of the night the sprinklers started their work wetting us and their clothing and sleeping bags. We woke up fast and grabbing our belongings we ran away from the sprinklers. We ended sleeping behind a wall that had only sand in its vicinity and were not disturbed until the morning. 
I've continued on Rt. 70 toward I-10. This was not the Adventure Cycling route but it was a more straightforward one from the Arizona State map I had.  When I rode along Rt. 70 I've passed a state prison and worried about the signs saying do not pick up strangers in this area. I've seen many more signs like this later on and always worried about any surprises. Along Rt. 70 I've started to see some thunderstorms and worried that there will be big rain pouring down soon. The next pictures were taken during the thunderstorms I've seen in the sky. It was also a sunset and it was getting dark already. To describe my experience from riding on Interstate highway it really feels great. The road is not as winding as the other route and there are fewer climbs as well. The only negative things are the volumes of traffic, the tractor-trailers blowing you away when they pass and do not change lanes. Most of them actually do, especially at night when I was more visible. Another problem seems to be the noise of the sometimes-exploding tires on the Semi Trailers and they even do not bother to stop as they have double wheels. This debris from the steel belted radials finally works it's way through the bicycle tire causing a puncture. This happened to me once. This kind of a hole causes a slow leak because the wire is very thin and you notice suddenly a very soft ride. Since it was already dark I've decided to stop by Bowie and look for a place to camp there. I was looking for any place to sleep. It was so dark over there that I could not see any houses around or a place to pitch my tenth. Only than I've spotted a local country store and stopped by to purchase some bread and sardines. Also I've asked the lady owner if there is any camp and she told me that near the entrance to the town, the way I arrived from there is one. However she emphasized that they might be closing already. She was kind enough to locate their phone # and told them to wait for a cyclist that should arrive there shortly. I've arrived there just as the night guard was closing and he told me I can sleep here and pay the owner in the morning. I've notice that he also as many other people I saw in Arizona had a gun at his belt. There was only another trailer nearby and I've pitched my tenth under some tree nearby the road. This small place had even showers. Because of the proximity to the prison I had a difficult time to fall a sleep but was so tired that I fell asleep after all.     
I've left and continued on Interstate 10 toward Deming New Mexico. This last place, Bowie I've stayed is just not far from New Mexico border. The ride on I-10 was again smooth except of the noise and sometimes the turbulence from the passing trucks. Along the way I've stopped and ate at some gas station. Some of them have good and abundance of refreshments as well as some fruits and veggies.  I've arrived to Deming after dark and started to look for a place to sleep. I did not see any open space or park along my way as it was already night neither I saw any people around to ask for a place to stay. However after a while of touring around I found what appeared to be a health club which also had a pool. It was situated in a quiet area and I did not see people around. So I've decided that it's a safe place to stay overnight. I've approached the building from the rear entrance and decide to make the night at the entrance to the pool on the concrete. I did not bother to attempt to pitch my tenth as it was hard ground around and also did not want to raise any suspicion. I've tied my bike to the gate of the pool and fell asleep fast in my sleeping bag. 
I've arrived in Las Cruces at night already and passed a road that had few motels. I've stopped by one and asked the lady attendant how much they charge. She told me it would be $22 and includes coffee and donuts in the morning. Since I wanted to save on accommodation whenever possible I used her yellow pages and called three RV parks in the area. However there was no reply from any of them. So I've decided to stay at this Motel. It also had laundry so I took advantage of this and did some laundering before retiring and called family in CA as well as my mother in Florida. As soon as my mom heard me she told me again to take a plane and arrive to her this way. However I was getting closer and did not consider her offer of funding my airplane trip to her. But I still did not reach the lone star state of Texas! 
The distance from Deming to El Paso is not too big, but the city of El Paso is quite big and also extends East to West along the US-Mexican border. I've cycled as much as I could throughout the day and major part of the day was spent crossing the city of El Paso. In the midst of my trip through the city I've notice at one point that people wave to me and some even stop to ask me where I'm going to Mexico, and they also shouted viva Mexico. Only than I've realized that I took a wrong turn and instead of going east I somehow took a turn on the road which lead me to the Mexican border. I've turned around and found my way back to my route. As this time I did not intend to go to Mexico but rather go toward Florida through Texas. After some wrong turns I finally arrived late night at one of the campsites in the city that is mentioned on the Adv. Cycling map. The place I've arrived was located on a hill and looked nice, until the guy who was in charge that night told me that the price is $20. I though he must be kidding. After paying for a campsite as low as $3 or camping for free, the $20 price looked steep and a rip-off to me. I told the guy that I'm going to talk to the owner the next morning and this gentleman just wanted me to make sure I've registered.  Since I've arrive already late the local Pizzeria was closed and I've decide to cook something before I retire as I was getting very low on energy. I cooked some oats and Rahmen noodle soup and ate some fig bars, which together with the Rahmen noodle soup became a component in my array of foods consumed during my trip. Since I was not able to fall a sleep, probably being upset about the high price of the accommodation I've turned my radio on and scanned the dial when I came across an oldies station from either El Paso or Ciudad Juarez which is bordering El Paso. In any event the music was so good that I've listened to it for long time into the early hours of the morning, and I fell asleep while listening. 
As soon as I hit the road I've placed my earphone with the oldies into my right ear. I never block my hearing while cycling, but I could not give up on this station. The cycling was very easy despite the heat and the head wind, with the nice music I was listening to.  After leaving the city I've continued on state route 20 and 258. The road was passing very close to Mexican border and I've seen numerous border patrol police cars along the way. At one point of my trip I've seen along the way few horses, looked like wild horses on the left-hand side of the road. The left side was elevated, approximately 20 feet. Suddenly I've seen one horse started to gallop in the direction of my trip than turning and changing the direction on the road and directly toward me on the right side of the road. I became very scarred and moved automatically to the left side of the road, at which time the horse turned in front of me and run again back to the other horses to the left of the road. Well this was a bit scary experience, and to this date I'm not sure why he did galloped toward me as he did. I've arrived into Sierra Blanca at night and started to look for a place to stay. I've spotted a Motel, which also said RV campground. I've asked the owner if I can camp here and how much it should cost. He said, I guess you're a cyclist and will not be using the electrical and water hookups, therefore you can stay for free. It was a well-deserved change for better, after paying the other day $20 for a campsite. I was the only person in the campground area and found a spot behind some bushes where I've decide to pitch my tenth. This was just along the main street of the town. 
I've arrived in the early hours of the afternoon and noticed that most of the motels are along the central street of the city. I've toured around until I found what looked like a cheap Motel but also was not run down. I knocked on the door and it looked like a neat place, and the price was right of $18 only. It had a cable TV and nice clean looking room. Also decided to treat myself for a decent lunch, the first time in the duration of my trip. This was also about the midpoint of my trip in terms of time elapsed. I ate a full course lunch with soup and multiple deserts (sweets are one of my weaknesses) and coffee all for the price of $13. The name of the small Mexican Caf was Rosa's Caf. I would heartily recommend this place for any one ever visiting Van Horn Texas. After lunch I bought some supplies in a local supermarket and decided to retire early to plan for the next part of my trip and to decide how much shall I use the Adventure Cycling maps and how much the state maps. I've decided that I'll be going a different route that the Adv. Cycling recommends. My route although may be less interesting and more traveled was a more straightforward one. I've decided to use Rt. 90 from Van Horn to Marfa and than to continue to Alpine. Since it looked like there will be no services for the next 80 miles or so I had to take enough water and decided to fill-up all my containers including the one-gallon collapsible one. 
I've arrived in Marfa late afternoon and decided to make my stop here in this lovely little town famous for it's display of lights at night, http://www.marfachamberofcommerce.com/. I've stopped by a local gas station to buy some food as well as gasoline for my MSR stove. It appears that the stove is very efficient as I still had some gas left and decide to fill the canister now in the middle of my trip. I've asked the attendant if she knows of any park in the area that I could possible camp. She replied that her uncle is an owner of a local RV park and gave me the directions. I've found the place easily and when I've arrived there it already became dark. It looked like a family operated business and they charged me only $7. The place had showers and nice outdoor covered kitchen and the owner told me that I could use all the facilities of the kitchen. I've taken the advantage of it and decided to cook a good meal for dinner tonight. This saves me the effort of starting my MSR stove and washing my utensils.  Since I had the full kitchen to my disposition I took advantage of it and went to nearby grocery to buy some supplies. I bought 6 eggs, mushrooms, potatoes and milk. I've prepared scrambled eggs from 3 eggs with mushrooms and mashed potatoes. This was quite satisfying and tasty meal. The rest 3 eggs I've boiled to take with me for breakfast and lunch tomorrow. After taking a shower I retired and fell asleep fast.         
I've arrived in late afternoon hours in the little town of Marathon, http://www.marathontexas.net. On my way I've stopped to eat some cakes at a nice little bakery that even has it is own web site, http://www.geocities.com/shirleysburntbiscuit/. It was just after 4:00 PM and the older lady owner looked like closing the place. However when she saw me parking my bike in front of her store she opened the door wide and welcomed me with a smile. Inside I found various types of cookies, muffins and banana nut bread. I bought one muffin and one loaf of banana bread to eat for dinner. The lady also told me that she opens early morning and she serves breakfast as well. Since I was getting very hungry I consumed the big muffin and left the banana bread for later on.   I've toured briefly around the place and spotted a sign saying RV Motel and park. I stopped there but did not see anyone. It was a huge place with hookups for RVs, water and benches. I went to a small house that looked like an office and it said welcome and if no one in the office please just leave the money here. It also specified that the rate for a campsite is $10. The place had showers and clean restrooms and I decided to stay but was a bit worried as I was the only person in this huge what looked like parking lot and there were no trees around. As I was getting to retire I've suddenly spotted a bearded gentleman with a backpack and sleeping bag and a mattress on his back, nearby my tenth. I've not noticed him arriving. At first I was worried a bit as I've seen this stranger. After a while we struck a conversation and he told me that he missed today's train and will try tomorrow. He said that this place is 'not much of a town' and he has seen nicer spots in his travels. He told me that in recent years he's travelling by trains but when he was younger he used to travel by bicycle like myself. We did not speak for too long because I was planing to get up early the next day, and needed some rest for tomorrow. It took me long time to fall asleep and I'm not sure what was the reason. However once I've heard my new friend snoring, I also fell asleep instantly. I guess I fell asleep soon after since I did not hear him anymore.
It was still very hot during the day and I've stopped what looked like a place to cool of a bit. This was the only store in the town of Dryden. This building also serves as the post office for the area. Although the store did not have many items it a t least had some cold drinks and candies bars to eat. It was also cool enough inside and I spent about an hour chatting with the owner and consuming some junk food. Shortly after I left Dryden I came upon an abandoned house which actually was looking very good and it was painted in white. I've gone behind the house toward the patio, where there was a lot of light from the early afternoon sun and the reflections on the white walls. I've taken my panniers off and decided to study my chain when I spin the pedals in high gear and also turning them back. When I started to move the chain slowly and observed it carefully I've notice that one plate was rubbing the front gear changer. What happened and I've never had such an accident before, was that the pin of the chain moved out and the chain started to separate but still holding together. This made the chain thicker in one spot and it was the part that rubbed the changer. As I've mentioned before I had almost all my tools with me, but in this case the simple chain tool did the job. I've pushed the link back and all the noise was gone. I was really very happy as this noise was bothering me for two days. Later during the day it became very cloudy with winds gusting as usual blowing the wrong direction. It started to rain but these were only single few big drops of rain but it was still very warm. I even did not bother to put on my rain gear, which always causes me to become wet from the perspiration than from the outside rain. When I finally reached the town, population 20 or so of Langtry I stopped by the local convenience store to get something to drink and buy a sandwich. A passing by shopper asked me if I've some rain gear and warm clothing. At first I did not realize the question when she completed by saying that there should be cold front moving to the area tonight bringing rain and temperatures should drop to 40s. I was not ready for this after twenty dry and hot days of travel. Unbelievable change, one day the temperature is the low 100s and the next day in the 40s. However I had no choice I was going forward to Florida. Langtry is famous because it's association with the life and work of the judge Roy Bean, http://www.desertusa.com/mag98/aug/papr/du_roybean.html. I've bought some food there and asked the owner where can I camp here and he told me that in Langtry near the old school now vacated I could camp for free. I cycled further until I reached the end of the winding road. I should perhaps point out that the town itself is very close to the Rio Grande river and Mexican border. The place did not have any showers but there was running water and I found a nice spot under a tree to pitch my tenth. It was very windy even at night, which was not usual from my experience of the previous days, and I made sure that my tenth is staked very well. Despite the wind I fell asleep very fast. 
Soon after I've afterwards it started to rain and it looked like the rain was going in my direction. Since I had some tailwind I was moving a bit faster than usual. The rain intensified and I found some tire repair store along the way to hide and wait out the rain. The guy in addition to the tire store also had some supplies, which I nibbled on while it rained. When it looked like there was a break in rain I picked up myself and continued. The rain however started again just before Rio Del. The winds stopped and it was a steady but light rain. Along my way I've noticed chamber of commerce for the city of Rio Del and stopped by to pick up some brochures as well as to see if there are any cheap motels. From the list I've picked up I've found one for $22 and decided to look for it. It was not the best looking Motel but with the bad weather I've decided to stay there. I ate my dinner in the room cooking some of the stuff I had and opening couple of cans I've purchased in Dryden earlier. The rain continued all the time and I was wandering if I should stay here another day. However I did not like the Motel and decided that I'll continue weather permitting. 
It was raining very bad all the way. The creeks started to overlfow and the water was covering the low lying portions of the road. I was hoping that I'll get to Brackettville before I will need a boat to continue. One thing that was keeping me moving were the passing motorists and giving me thumbs up. However none offered to give me a ride or asked if I needed anything. When I arrived to Brackettville in the late afternoon hours the streets were deserted. I was looking for someone to ask if there is a place to stay. Finally soaking to my bones I found an open hardware store and a salesperson gave me directions to Fort Clark, where he said I should be able to find accomodations, http://www.fortclark.com/. I cycled for a little while and was stopped on the way by a uniformed guard but no gun and I told him that I look for a place to stay. He directed me further into the Fort and I found the main office which was still open. They said that they had rooms and told me it costs $50. Well I was a little bit shocked but in this weather I probably would not be able to find anything else. They however mentioned that there is also a campground nearby for $12. But looking at the ground which was soaked and the water running down in streams I've decided to take the room hoping that I'll stay one night and continue next dy. The rooms were very neat but there was no TV. In the rooms. (As a side NOTE: from reading today on their WEB site they say that there is a Cable TV in the rooms!). But this is what was available. Looks like there were few other guests and the Motel looked like almost full. After showering and resting a little bit I've changed into my sweat pants and sweatshirt and headed to the restaurant which was situated in and adjecent building. One thing which I've forgotten to mention is that Texas is great on steaks. There is so much cattle and ranches that you'll barely find any vegeterian meal. It's steak and steak all over the state. After dinner I've read a bit in the magazines I picked earlier in the office and fall asleep in a very comfortable bad. 
The next pictures show the beautiful green scenery outside and the water coming down. There was not much to do and I mostly rested did some exercise running up and down the stairs of the motel and once for shopping in a small supermarket located in Brackettville to make preparations for the continuation of my trip.         
According to my maps the next closest location was Camp Wood a distance of about 50 Miles and the next location was Leakey a distance of about 80 Miles. Since I've rested well and ate well I decided to try to reach the town of Leakey. I was riding all the way in the steady rain and the cold. Some of the climbs were warming me but the descends were freezing me. Just before Camp Wood I've started to fill that my ride is a little bit soft. I just started to roll into the town and noticed that my rear tire is soft. I tried to pump it but after a while it was soft again. I stopped in some deserted building and tried to repair the flat. My hands were so frozen that I could not take the tire off. After a great deal of effort I finally repaired the flat and pumped my wheel. Looked around and decided to stop by at a small grocery on the corner of the main street. There I drank some hot chocolate and ate some bananas and few donuts. I also asked the ladies working there if they know of any cheap motel in the town. They called couple of places for me but there was not reply. My hands were so cold thatthe store manager lady recommended that I get myself couple of dishwashing rubber gloves. They told me that some motorcyclists that passed here before and were also suffering from the terrible cold bought them as well. This was not a bad idea and a good investment, they definitely helped my hands to stay warmer although they were wet from perspiration. After a while someone stopped in the store and the lady asked if they know of any motel that is open and the lady said there is Bead and Breakfast that is available. The lady from the store called around and found that there is one for $25. She gave me directions and I found the place by knocking on some doors and asking people around. The lady that owned the B&B said that she'll charge me only $25 but normally she charges between $75 and $100. Well lucky me! Actually the B&B turned out to be couple of rooms that the lady rents in her house. She also gave me a pair of dry sweatpants and sweatshirt so I could dry mine, which were completely soaked despite my rain gear. I took a shower and got dinner. After that I've retired hoping that my clothing will dry till the morning near the fireplace that I had to keep burning by loading some heavy logs of wood. 
The road was very winding and with many hills, not in particular very high but consistent up and down. This caused me to have an elevation gain of over 6000 feet during that day and to feel very exhausted. The section of the road that run along the Guadalupe river was very nice, winding along the river and was flat . This whole ride could turn even nicer if not for the cloudy skies and the occasional rain. As I've started to see houses it was also getting dark and I've decide that I'll be looking for a place to stay here. I've arrived to Ingram toward the late evening hours and decided to take a first Motel that was along the way. I did not look further as I was quite exhausted and getting hungry. The Motel name was Hunter Inn Motel and there was a nearby restaurant that also advertised some special catch of the day. The Motel cost me $42 and the dinner in the restaurant $11.  NOTE: I'm still not seasoned enough to sleep in a campground when it's raining and the ground is soaking wet. I'm not sure how others are doing it but I definitely would like to know. The relatively high price of the Motels is taking its toll on my budget. 
In this park there was an announcement on the office door saying if it's closed than look for person in spot # (this and this) to get your spot assigned. In such nightly instances my Petzel lamp becomes very handy as it gives me enough light to look around. As I also found many of the campgrounds are located in woods and most of them do not have any lightning except for place like bathrooms or showers. In any event after meeting that gentleman he assigned me a spot and also registered me. The cost for this accommodation was $12. Since I was hungry on my arrival I've cooked Rahmen noodle soup fortified with my oats and some bread. I've taken a shower and retired. Fell asleep fast despite cool winds outside, because it was very warm in my sleeping bag. Woke up at night hearing the rain drops falling on my tenth. Since I was prepared for it I've put the rain cover on my tenth, something which I not always did, if it looked like it will be warm at night. Since I always carry earplugs with me I've used them this time and have fallen asleep right away again. 
Sometime during the early afternoon hours I got terrible pain in my Achilles tendon while cycling. The pain was so bad that I could not push on the pedals with my left foot. This was the foot that got the pain in the tendon. The pain was so bad that I was pushing for a while with my right foot. When it happen I've stopped at the side of the road and attempted to do some stretches but the pain was very bad. I've decided to pull into a parking lot near some small shopping center. As I was stretching there a local gentleman approached me and asked where I'm going and where I'm coming from. I've told him what I've been doing and he said that he has two sons and they will be very inspired to hear my story. He offered me to stay with him in his house and spend the rest of the day with his family. Since it were only early hours afternoon I wanted to cycle more despite the pain and told him that I still have a lot to go today and thanked him for his offer. He was very disappointed but declared that he understand that I had to move forward. Looks like the stretching did help a little bit and I was able to continue with the lingering pain in my tendon. After arriving to Bastrop: http://www.bastropchamber.org/ I was looking for an accommodation and in particular for some cheap Motel. I wanted to rest a little bit and take care of my tendon. It appeared that all the Motels were full. I've decided to stop by the local Pizza Hut, which had some special but when I entered they told me that they are closed already. I told one of the waitresses that I've just arrived after cycling the whole day and I'm very hungry and if she could do something about it. After short consultation they gave me many slices of Pizza and a drink and charged me only for one slice, (very nice of them!). I was planning to eat the pizza outside but before leaving I've asked them if they know of any park in the are I could camp. They gave me directions to Barstop State Park that was on a hill on the outskirts of the town and I headed to spend the night over there. When I got to the vicinity of the park I could not find the place where that campsite was as it was very dark in the area. Luckily for me a couple just left a local bar and they showed me the exact way to the park by leading me with their car. On my arrival to the park I've found that it was already closed, actually there was none in the office and I've decided to sleep there despite this. The place was almost deserted but I could see few RVs between the trees in the dim light that was available in the area. I've found a spot away from the other cars and set my tenth, took a shower and fell asleep very fast again. This is the link to the beautiful state park: http://www.tpwd.state.tx.us/park/bastrop/, but I did not have the time to appreciate all this beauty as I was on a trip and not so much on a tour. I think that on my next crossing of the US I'll make sure to stop more in the nice places and enjoy the surroundings more than I did this time. 
The Motel I've stayed was OK, and since I already was in a Motel I've decided to do some laundry and also to eat out again, after a long break from eating only self cooked food and occasional sandwiches/pizza along the way. I've asked the attendant in the Motel, HILLTOP MOTOR INN about a good restaurant in the area and she recommended a close by a Mexican restaurant which turned out to be very good and reasonable priced and as well as serving big portions. The last part was always of importance for me on the trip, since I've been almost constantly hungry. The place she recommended was the 'CASA OLE MEXICAN RESTAURANT'. From the fact that the place was packed I could judge that it must be a good and popular restaurant. I can only add that I was not disappointed. The only thing that bothered me a little bit was that I did not have any suitable clothing to go there in. So I dressed on top in one of my T-shirts and the bottoms I had my cycling rain pants, which are black, with some reflective straps. But nobody paid attention. The reason I've dressed like this was that I was worry about the air conditioning being too cold and having bad impact on my tendon problems. I do not recall the price I paid but it was not more that $15 for a full course dinner and a tip. After dinner I went back to the Motel which was just across the street and watched some TV before falling a sleep. 
As usual when sleeping in a Motel I've started the day toward the late hours of the morning. I've checked out at the designated time from the Motel around 11:00 AM and was on my way toward Navasota. Navaosta is a nice little town full of colonial buildings and many small shops. I did not stop in the town as it was early afternoon hours and the streets were very busy with shoppers. Since I was feeling relatively refreshed after the late night in the Motel I decided to cover larger distance today. I've used Route 105 that passed through Sam Houston National forest. But this route also was without any place to stay or camp along. I've started to think about camping in the woods but they were very thick on the edge of the forest and I decided to continue further. It was getting darker as I was still passing through the forest and I was not sure when it's going to end. I've been desperately searching for a place to stay but there was nothing suitable along the way. Therefore I continued further until late at night I've passed a sign that pointed to a place called 'Pumpkin RV Resort'. It was among very tall trees and was looking very clean, but the resident manager apparently already retired so I decided to select a spot and settle there and see what happens in the morning. The place had very nice and clean facilities and also a recreation room with kitchen for use by all the residents.  I've showered there ate at the clean and roomy kitchen and retired to my tenth. 
This was a relatively easy day and the temperatures were comfortable and despite the low hovering clouds it did not rain at all. I think I already had enough rain for the rest of my trip, although I still had the rain gear and was prepared for any surprise that may emerge. This also was my last day of the whole section being in the state of Texas. As some people were saying to me earlier during my trip in New Mexico and Arizona, do not consider yourself done until you cross the 'great' state of Texas. It really started to feel easier altogether once I had the sense that I'm approaching the eastern border of Texas. Due to it's varied terrain and weather surprises this state is more challenging than other on my route has. OK, California desert was also tough, but at least it was consistently hot. Once you set your mind on the fact that the weather is such and such you can get used to it and work your way around or through it. But haven't temperatures jumping from low 100 s to low 40s in couple of days can definitely take the toll on your mind if not your body. I've approached the town of Silsbee TX toward the early hours of the night. I've started to look for a place to pitch my tenth and passed nearby a sign pointing to an RV park. I've deviated from my route and reached the park in short time. I've met some people there probably local residents having barbecue outside. I've asked them if I can stay here and they said that I need to talk to the manager and showed me the house in which he lived. Although it was late I dared to knock on his door and he opened dressed in his pajamas. I've said sorry to bother him so late and he said it's OK since he was watching late night TV. I've asked about accommodations and he said that he does not have camping here due to lack of bathrooms. Seems like the other people have had some other arrangement in their RV and mobile homes in the park. I continue on Rt. 190 and saw a cheap looking Motel. I've stopped there and for $30 made a night stop. The place was OK and I was already so tired and it was late that I did not bother to continue looking further. Although it always hurt me afterwards whenever I've had to spend this amount of money and I could sleep in my tenth. I promise myself that I'll be taking advantage of my tenth more on my next trip. 
I've rode Rt. 96 to Kirbyville and than followed the Adventure Cycling route to Louisiana. Early afternoon along my way I've met another cycling going in my direction. This gentleman name Steve was going from San Diego, CA to St. Augustine, FL. He was travelling on a racing bike with very light load and even had aero wheels. He even told me that he had problems earlier with his wheels and he had to get a new set. Looks like he was mostly staying in Motels and occasionally slept hanging among tree on a bivouac. We continued together to Louisiana and talked along the way. The trip this way was much easier. The shoulders were wide enough at this section of the road and we could ride side by side. As we crossed to Louisiana it started to drizzle. We continued for a while until we reached the town of DeRidder in LA. We followed the Adv. Cycling directions and decided to stay in one of the Motels they've recommended. We found the Skippers Motel for $38 for the night and decided to stay there. Originally along the way we spoke about the possibility of sharing the room to save expenses and he was ready to this idea, however at the registration he changed his mind and wanted to stay by himself. I went along with this idea. This was the last time we spoke or saw each other. Looks like the guy wanted to be left by himself and would not be a good companion anyhow for the rest of the trip. In the Motel which was very neat and nearby a Domino's Pizza parlor and other small shops I've taken a shower watched some TV and went down to buy some food. I've ordered extra large Pizza that was on special that evening and while it was prepared I've stopped by some groceries store and purchase more food for the rest of my trip. When the Pizza was ready I've taken it to the Motel and consumed most of it while I watched TV. It was quite a big Pizza and I've left two slices for breakfast for tomorrow morning. I've felt a sleep soon afterwards in the comfortable Motel bed.
Surviving this I've approached Opelousas http://www.cityofopelousas.com/ also known as the 'Zydeco' music capital of the world. This fact was not know to me before arriving there, otherwise I would be looking for a place to listen to this nice music of which I'm a fan. I've learnt this fact only while writing about my trip these days. After arriving to the city I've started to look for a place to pitch my tenth, since it was already close to 6:00 PM and I was tired enough to call it a day. Along the route I saw a sign pointing to camp. I've followed the signs through some wooded and neat looking and tree shaded streets until I've arrived at the South City Park. The main office in the park was still opened and they told me that I could camp anyplace in the park I wish for free. Well this was a nice surprise to find a spot like this. I've looked around and located myself not far a way from a place where there was more light and running water as well as not far a way from the restrooms. These facilities luckily for me stayed opened throughout the night. The place looked pretty safe and except for some wandering couples it was empty. I've not seen also many campers except one RV camping in the whole park. Possible because it was Tuesday only. In the park there were picnic tables that were situated under a metal roof on a concrete embankment. I've decided to sleep in one of these places without setting a tenth. It was warm enough and the roof would protect me from any surprise rain. Also I did not feel any mosquitoes in the area so they would not bother me I thought. I've cooked something light and ate couple of bananas I've bought earlier. After that I went to sleep using only my mattress and sleeping bag. Luckily none bothered me at night and I've even seen a Police patrol car that comes there once in a while to check what is going on. The light from the policeman flashlight has awakened me. This happened only once and none shinned light in my direction afterwards. I slept well until I was awaken by a water condensation dripping from the metal roof on me. I've moved under the picnic table where the water could not reach me and fell asleep until the morning. 
The road was mostly flat road but again the Rt. 190 proven to be quite busy thoroughfare. It passed mostly through agriculture area and some forests. There were sections of the road that did not have any shoulders and the dangerous moments were during rush hour, when there were motorists approaching from both directions. Sometimes they forced me to go of the road as some of the motorist did not pass and I did not felt secure having someone just behind me all the time. So I gave them right away. On my way I've stopped to buy some groceries in a small town grocery store. I've been eating some of the food they prepared and also bought some to take with me. The people in the store, in particular the ladies were wandering if I'm going to eat all myself, on which I've replied that yes. I've explained to them that if one cycles as much as I do in one day with all the load than this person needs more than average quantities of food. At the same time there came a bread delivery truck to deliver bread to this grocery. When the driver overheard the conversation he asked me if I want some bread to take with me. I told him that I already bought some food that he said this is free and offered me two loafs of fresh bread, which I've taken and thanked him. I continued to Baton Rouge, LA. The section of Rt. 190 just before the city became very busy, but it also widened and there were some shoulders along the route. On the western side of the city I was approaching the Mississippi River. There just the arched metal bridge crossing the river two guys in a pickup truck stopped by and offered me a ride over the bridge, asking me if I can make it since it may be too steep for me. I've thanked them and said I've already climbed steeper roads than this and than they asked me where I'm going. When I told them that I'm going to Florida they were quite impressed. Than they asked me where I've coming from I've said from California, or more exact San Jose CA. Of course they did not know where San Jose was but the word California was enough to impress them even more. We talked for a while and I've started my climb over the river. It was really very steep but when I've used my low gears it was really not so bad. What was nicer than this was the descent on the other side of the bridge to the city. I continued straight on Rt. 190 through the city where the traffic was quite bad but I've crossed it without any incidents.  After crossing the city the road became again the more familiar and quieter the way I like it. The passage through the city of Baton Rouge was quite hectic but not as bad as it could be and the view from the bridge on the river is really spectacular.  I've continued on Rt. 190, also called 'Florida Blvd.', until the little town of Albany located at the junction of Rt. 190 and Rt. 43. When I hit Albany it was already dark and I did not see any Motel along the way. Being also tired and hungry I've stopped by local grocery that was still open. I bought some supplies and also asked the owner about Motels in the area. She said that there is a bigger town further east called Hammond and it has many motels. There is although one in Albany she said but she's not sure if it has vacancy. After consuming some of the food I've decided to push myself a little bit more and in about three-quarters of an hour I've reached Hammond. Right away I could see few Motels and restaurants along the main street and decided to look for a Motel in that town. I've found a Motel for $29/night and decided to stay there. Although the room was pretty small it had clean bathroom and a big TV to compensate for. The owner also told me that there is a good pizza in town if I would like and they still may be opened. I decided to play it large and instead of going there I've called in and ordered large pizza. It arrived shortly, even before I had a chance to take a shower. I ate the pizza while watching TV into the late hours of the night.     
The gentleman told me that there is a State Park along the shoreline and I could camp there. He told me the directions on how to get there and I've headed to the place that was few miles away. The road took me along the beautiful coastline of Louisiana and it's white sands. When I approached the place it was already dark and in the light of my headlight I've noticed a sign along the road saying 'Alligator crossing'. It of course scared me and I've started to pedal faster to get away from the place which looked to me like a swamp. After hitting a higher ground the water around me disappeared and I've seen the gate to the park. The office was already closed but there was a person who was assigning the spots for the campers and he told me it costs $10. After registering with him I went to put up my tenth. The place was warm and there was also some sound of mosquitoes buzzing around. I've put my rain gear on and my cycling cap, which protected most of my body except of the face from the a bit aggressive mosquitoes. The place I've stayed for the night was called Buccaneer State Park. Actually later on I've learned that there are alligators in the swamps in the are I was and the sign I've seen was a warning sign for cars not to hit the alligators that cross the road. Since I was not a car by cyclist I've worried a bit because of what I've seen. After setting down I've showered and went straight to sleep as I was not hungry after consuming the big and delicious waffles and the Waffle House earlier that evening. 
This section of Rt. 90 passes along the Gulf Coast and was one of the high points of the trip. The white sands of the beaches, the warm weather and actually warm and friendly people. They are also very good and careful drivers in this area of the country, at least this was the impression I got. Since this section has such a beautiful landscape the cycling was very easy and enjoyable throughout the day. Despite the fact that I've stopped many times along the way I've still cycled almost 90 miles. At one point along the route I've seen a sign pointing to a bike road which was going to the right of my route on Rt. 90. I've deviated and found myself on a shaded straight like an arrow section which was the bike path. As I sat down on the grass to check if my maps show where does it lead I've met two cyclists coming from opposite direction. I've asked them for directions and they told me that this section of the bike trial was built on an old railway trail and therefore is so straight. I've asked them if there is a grocery store along the way or a place to buy food as I was getting hungry at this time of the day. They told me that few miles down the road there should be a store few miles down. They also told me that this bike path goes for another 12 miles or so but later there are unfinished sections and I may need to get back on Rt. 90 to navigate around. I've continued along this bike path for sometime already but did not see any store. At this point I've met a gentleman who looked like a policeman on a scooter riding the path as well. I've stopped him and we chat for a while. He told me that he has this part time job in addition to his main job and he works as a park ranger patrolling the bike path and the adjacent areas. He also asked me where I'm headed and I told him to North of Miami Florida. He asked me where I came from and than I told him from California he was so impressed that he decided to step down from his scooter and started to talk to me more. I've interrupted him and asked if he knows of any place to buy groceries in the area and I'm actually also thinking about camping somewhere. He told me that there is a Chevron gas station selling hot foot and groceries further down the road near Rt. 90. He also told me that there is a campground but it's in the other direction, i.e. I'll have to retrace some of my route to get to the camp. I've decided to go first for the food since I was really very hungry at this time. I've followed his instructions and soon found a Chevron gas station that also served hot lunches and other stuff. I've decided to eat light meal plus treated myself to an ice cream apple pie desert. I've also bought some food to take with me for dinner tonight and for the road for tomorrow. When I came back this gentleman was heading in my direction and told me that he just phoned his friend who is an avid cyclist and he said that he told him about me. The friend so he tells me very impressed with the story and wanted to know if I could wait until he arrives and meet me in person. Since it was getting rather late at this time I've said that I would rather look for a place to stay and if he knows of any campground in the area. He showed me the way to the park and I've parted with him. I cycled for another half an hour and arrived at the road that leads to the 'Gulf Islands National Seashore Campground'. When I arrived at the gate the visitor center was already closed and I've decided to go in despite that. It was already dark and I barely found my way around and had to use my Petzel headlamp to find the way to and around the park. I've found a spot that looked like a campsite and decided to pitch my tenth. After a while I heard some people talking and I've asked them where are the showers in the park. They told me how to get there and I took a shower ate my dinner and retired relatively early this day.       
As I was proceeding on Rt. 90, which in Mobile is also Rt. 98. Suddenly I've noticed that I've arrived to an entry to a tunnel. When I approached further I could read the small sign saying, 'pedestrians, motor driven cycles and bicycles' are prohibited in the tunnel. The tunnel name is Bankhead tunnel on the name of a famous Alabama governor that was responsible for many projects in AL during his tenure. I was already almost in the tunnel as I've passed this sign. I should admit that I almost did not notice it. So when I backed up again the road and read again what it said I could not believe my eyes. I've not planned any alternate route and was ready to continue Rt. 90/98. So I decided to do some thinking and I was telling myself what could happen if I go through the tunnel. The problem was that I did not know how long the tunnel is and where does it end. Also the traffic there was pretty hectic since it comprised of only one lane in each direction and no barrier in between. While contemplating what to do I've spotted a pickup truck with the logo of Alabama Dept. of Transportation stopped on the street. The driver was a young worker of the Dept. and I've decided to ask him if cyclist can go. He said cyclists should no cross the tunnel. Than I've asked him if he has seen cyclists crossing it and he said that occasionally he has seen. This was enough for me to decide and make the crossing of the tunnel as well. Actually it is not as bright as in this old photo and the traffic is very heavy through it. Luckily it's only about 1 mile or less long but it saves about 12 miles going around through the Bay Bridge or using a ferry, which I even did not know existed until later. What was even more amusing was the fact that after I've crossed the tunnel with motorists driving after me and waiting for the opportunity to pass, I've ended somehow on I-10 going to Florida over the Mobile Bay. There was some confusion when I entered I-10 due to an accident and none of the policeman there paid any attention to me. The wind on I-10 was so strong and it was a tailwind that I was doing probably 30 miles/hour crossing the Mobile Bay going to Florida. All the way I was worried of being stopped but there was also no way to exit as the Highway is crossing the bay. As soon as I hit the other side I was relieved and exit the Interstate on the 1st opportunity on the Florida side. There in a distance I could distinguish a small town and decided to stop there for late lunch. To my satisfaction I've seen the 'Waffle House' sign and made a U turn across the road to get to restaurant, which was on the other side of the road. As I sat at the bar there was a gentleman that sat at the bar as well and we started a conversation me and a conversation broke and he asked me where I was going and I said that I plan to travel on Rt. 90 to Pensacola Florida. He said that this is probably not the best way if I do not mind the ups and downs on the hills of Florida, and I thought that Florida is completely flat. Well not entirely as I've learned later. It's true it's flat in the South but not so in the northern part. It has similar wavy hills of the type I've encountered in Texas, but luckily it's green and the temperatures were not hot as in Texas. But every down was followed by a climb, which of course put some strain on me, and required constant gear changes from high to low and vice versa. I should perhaps interject at this point that Florida with its green scenery, mild temperatures (that time of the year), abundance of campsites and fruits and vegetables was the most enjoyable state to travel. This of course excludes the drivers of the state that were the worse among the drivers of the states I've crossed. Since I felt so good after the food I ate and the ease of crossing the Mobile Bay to Florida that I've continued for a while. I've arrived to Pensacola when it was already dark and passed through the main street and I've seen many youngsters and police directing the traffic. After a while I could hear the noise of  Rock Band playing in an outdoor concert somewhere nearby. Originally I've been thinking to find a public park to camp but the thought that so many young people being late at night outside would not go well with this idea. I've continued on the main street to the other side of the town where I've seen many Motels. I've selected one that looked relatively clean and quiet. I stopped there and took a room for $35 for the night. While not as cheap as I've been ready to spend I was already getting too tired to look for another one. After a nice shower and some light dinner I went to sleep without even watching TV.            NOTE: The Bankhead tunnel under the Mobile bay/river which is on Rt. 90/98 saves about 12 miles or so of travel when going toward Pensacola Florida, from Mobile, Alabama. When not using the tunnel one has to travel over Cohrane bridge. The length of this tunnel is 3,400 Feet, which is approximately 0.7 Miles, however when you've all the cars behind you feel like it's much longer. 
     At one point in my ride I've spotted a small grocery along the route in a place called Harold and decided to stop there to get some food before continuing.  While in the store I've started to chat with the lady owner and her son and asked them about any campground in the area. They told me that over the train tracks few miles to the north there is a State Park that also has campsites. I spent there another fifteen minutes or so and decided to taste the cooked peanuts that they were selling. This is one of these delicatessen that the people in that area and also earlier in Mississippi like to eat. I should add that I did not fall for it and did not sample any more of these specially prepared peanuts. I bought some extra food items in this store and headed toward the campsite. The place was located nearby a river or a lake since along my way I've seen boat rental shops. However they were closed at this time of the day. When I arrived the gate was still opened and the ranger there told me that there is another cyclist who is camping in the campground. Only now I've found the name of this park, it was Blackwater River State Park. He also told me that the price for camp is $8, which was not bad for a neat place like this.  When I arrived at the campground I went to look for the cyclist and found him despite the darkness that already fell on the place. He was already ready to retire, but when he saw me he got quite excited and we decided to talk a little bit before retiring. He told me that he has quit his job in San Antonio, Texas where he lived and worked and decides to make a bike tour from his brother graduation place, a University in New Jersey back to San Antonio, TX. From which I concluded that he was going the other way and I thought I missed the opportunity to ride with a companion. The guy was only 23 and he traveled in the minimalist style having only the necessary equipment in his two small panniers. He used a mountain bike and did not even have cleated shoes. Well it's much easier to travel like this when you're young. At this age not many things bother you and not even the cold. After our conversation I went to take a shower and set my campsite and went to sleep. Even though the place was near water (which I did not see) there were not many mosquitoes, probably due to the light breeze that blew at this time of the night. Id did not bother to eat and retired right away. Before that however I've also noticed another gentleman in my vicinity that was camping but he had a car and a racing bicycle on top of a rack.   
After a while we parted and the young guy and me started toward the exit. Along the way he told me which is the better route to go through Florida. We also talked about some other things and we parted at the junction of Rt. 90 when he continued west while I continued east along Rt. 90. The road continued to have it's up and down patterns, but I already became used to this and was taking the advantage of the downhill descent but than working hard to get back up to the top. The road passed through nice forests and little towns. I've stopped for lunch along the way in a Subway restaurant for some good sandwich and continued to Chipley. When I've arrived there it started to get dark and I've asked if there is any campground or park around. A lady in a restaurant directed me to the Falling Waters State Camp. It took me some time to find the place as it was located of Rt. 90 and it was already getting dark at this time. I've continued in the general direction and was looking for the 'state park road' leading to the park. I've found it with the aid of my Petzel headlight, which comes handy in situations like this. The road leading to the park was winding a little bit and also going up and down. It appeared that the park was located on some hill. When I've arrived at the Falling Waters, State Camp it's gate already was closed as the rules in Florida are such that the park as I've already found it out closes at sunset. I was looking for a place to get through but than decided to take the rear panniers of so I could move the bike under the entrance gate, which was like a railway-crossing gate. I've put the panniers back once on the other side, as there was enough light at the entrance to see what I was doing. I've continued along the road for another couple of miles before I've started to see some RVs. The place was quite dark and I did not have any idea where are the spots of the campsites. I've used again my light and toured around for a while before I located an empty spot. After a while when my eyes became used to the darkness I've spotted the showers a small distance from where I set my tenth. I've retired in my tenth right after showering and eating something for the late dinner.   
In any event I was directed toward the Wakulla Springs State Park. I've assumed that like other State Parks this one will have a campground as well. When I've arrived at the park it was already becoming dark, but there was still enough light for me to see the nicely situated park with many types of trees. I followed the directions until I arrived to something that looked like a beautiful castle. There were many cars arriving there and people were dressed formal dress. The ladies were dressed in dark dresses and men mostly in black in suits. It appeared that there was some convention-taking place in this establishment. It papered that it's a hotel in the park and it looked really nice. I entered inside and asked at the reception if there is also a campground in the vicinity, but I was told that there is none. So I was thinking to my self just to go and sleep outside at the park but than I was not where to look not to be too close to the Hotel. To make the story short I ended up staying in this establishment which was very nice except the price I had to pay and it was $75 for the night. Of course I was shocked but at this late time of the evening and after cycling over 100 miles today I was not ready to look further. To describe shortly this place had marble floors in the rooms covered with carpets. Nice windows antique looking bathroom. There was a restaurant on premises and nice view from the window of my room. There was no TV in the rooms but a big screen TV was available in the lobby. After paying this outrageous sum of money for the accommodation I've decide to cook my meal in the room, instead of going to the restaurant downstairs.  After showering and eating my meal in the room I've listened a little bit to my radio and than fell a sleep in the comfortable bed. Before I'll forget here is a link to this rather nice and interesting place called Wakulla Springs Park. It has many more attractions than the Lodge I've stayed and do plan to visit it again when I'll be in Florida in the future.         
The road continued to pass through forests and farms and nice little towns. There were also plenty of orange, grapefruit and lemon groves. They distributed nice aroma as the day heated up along the way. The weather was mostly sunny and light breeze was blowing. Again I'm remembering this really nice days of my crossing through Florida. Along the way I've stopped to buy some fruits from a vendor that was selling his stuff along the way. Shortly after that I've stopped to make a picnic in an artificial tree farm, where they were growing trees and each section was of different size. The people were going in and out of the place but nobody bothered to stop and ask me what I was doing there. I decide to take also a short nap, just to be interrupted by big ants walking all over me in search probably of traces of the food which were still lying around me. This was the sign for me that I need to continue. After about additional 2 hours of cycling I saw on the LHS of the road a small house that was also a grocery and cars entering and leaving. It also smelled good nearby. I've decided to stop there and see what kind of busy place it is. This happened to be a small grocery and also they were making their own food. They were preparing all kind of fresh home made food that smelled very good. I bought there some stuff and also some groceries and ate my late lunch on the small patio. After the lunch I became a little bit sleepy and decided to seat another  and hour on their patio. I've continued on Rt. 27 toward Cross City. At certain point of the ride when the road was doing its ups and downs, although less than along Rt. 90 more to the north, I was attacked by few vicious dogs that were roaming along the road. This time I've screamed loudly at them which did not help and accelerated, since luckily I've hit the downhill portion of the road I was able to accelerate and outrun the dogs which were hanging around for quite a long time. They gave up as soon as we started the climb seem either they were out of their control zone or they became tired like myself. It was late afternoon and I've started to think about a place to stay. The route was mostly passing among forests and occasionally I could see houses along the way. It was saying that it's about 25 miles to Cross City where I was planning to arrive. Suddenly I've seen a sing along the road that there is a camping available in a Chevron station about 10 miles down the road. So I've decide to reach this place and was hoping that the sign points to some real target and not like happened in the past that some of them were old sign and what they said was not true anymore. I've reached the place after another hour of cycling when it was already completely dark. The place was Chevron Gas station and behind the station they had an open space where the campground was located. There were benches and water and some primitive facilities they called showers and bathroom. But it was something better than nothing at all was. They told me that the cost is $8 per night. Before going to setup my tenth I've decide to eat at this Chevron Gas station that also had a restaurant there and convenience store. I ate there very well again as it was relatively cheap and the food while fat was also very tasty. I've also treated myself to a nice desert. Today I really ate very well and most of it outside, but it did not cost much. I've spent total of about $12 for the lunch and the dinner combined. After the dinner I've entered that campground and started to set my tenth. I've looked around and notice that there was only a couple that traveled with their old RV and they approached me as I was setting my tenth. The gentleman told me his name and told me that he passed me many mile to the North about 2 hours ago and here we met again. He asked me where I was going and where I came from and was very impressed when he heard that I came all the way from California. He was one of those retired people leaving between Florida in the winter and the Northeast in the summer. He was going to Fort Myers where the couple was residing during the wintertime. For those of you who do not know the winter starting October and ending in April is a high season in the wintertime. I took a shower and went to sleep without much delay. 
The day turned out to be nice and warm and the route I've selected passed near the bigger city of Ocala and which I tried to avoid on my trip, the same way I was avoiding other big cities whenever possible. Along the way I took the opportunity in the early afternoon hours to lay my tenth on some bushes along the way and dry it. The road I've selected to ride today was Alt. Rt. 27 and it was in very bad shape. It has been worked upon and had many opened trenches as well as parts of the road were barely passable by the cars due to roadwork along the way. I've seen in Florida this phenomena many time where the highway crews are working on some section and than leave it opened with signs and go and work on some other place. You can see it all over Florida. However compared to some other states they are at least trying to maintain their roads. Since I was on bicycle I took the advantage and road on the section that still looked unfinished with fresh tar but is was quite without cars, which were still packed on the old section of the road. I rode among the trucks and the tractors and other heavy equipment but they were slow so I could navigate among them. Nobody bothered me I continued the ride undisturbed by the cars. After a while I've seen Subway restaurant at an intersection and decide to stop to cool myself down as well as to eat one of their tasty sandwiches. There in the restaurant I've met a group of youngsters who were on a baseball team. Since I was sitting in close proximity to them weve started a conversation during which they started to ask me where I'm going. I told them that I'm going to Boca Raton. They did not seem to know the name of the place but I told them it's North of Miami. Than they started to tell me how far each of them have ridden in his bicycling life. At certain point I was asked where I came from and than I told them from San Francisco, California. I did not want to say San Jose as may not know where it's even though in terms of population San Jose is bigger than San Francisco. When I told them my starting point they could not believe. Well I do mention this just in passing by, however it happened on numerous occasions that people simple couldn't believe that someone would embark on such a long journey by bicycle. I'm sure that those of you who are cyclist will have much easier time to grasp this. Even I myself when I write about my journey more than 2 years after it happened can't believe that I've done it. But during my trip it simple seemed natural, if not a little bit challenging. After the lunch I've continued and by mistake selected the wrong road that looked like it will take me toward the city of Dunnellon, where the campground that I found on the map is located. This few deviation during the day caused me to do more miles today without really advancing toward my target. After some time I got back on the road that had the sign 'Rainbow Springs State Park'. However as it happened the park and the campground where in two separate locations despite the fact that the map gave the same address. When I've arrived at the park it was already late afternoon but I still was able to appreciate the beauty of the park:          It had water that was simple blue and there were few people at this late hours swimming in the water. I've started to look around and asking if the people know where is the campground, but none of them seem to know. Suddenly a gentleman in his swimming costume approached me and asked what I'm looking for. I told him that I look for a campground that should be here. He told me that actually he knows the campground but it's on the other side of the park. But there is no connection from this side to the place where the campground is. I'll need to go around a distance of few miles. It was already getting dark and I was very frustrated that I could not find the place faster. But after weighing my options I decided to continue, as this side of the park did not look like a place to pitch a tenth. It had a lot of small stream in addition to the mail river from the spring and very many trees and shrubs. In addition the gentleman told me that he comes here quite often and he has seen alligators in the spring waters here. This was enough for me to stop thinking about making my camp on this side of the park. Without much choice I've grabbed a can of Coca-Cola from the vending machine that was there to get some energy boost and decided to head to the campground. The guy also told me that I should probable get there before they close the gate, but he was thinking as someone going by car probably. The trip I made looked like traveling along the letter U. along the way I had to stop few times and ask people for directions as it was not obvious how to get there. Everyone was giving me directions based on a known road sign along the way. It was easier for them as they live there. At the end someone mentioned that the road goes near a school and this is a mile after I pass the school. Again wrong estimate by the people and it looks like this if you're motorist. In any event at the end I've found the place and it was north of the school but more like 3 miles after that. When I've arrived at the gate of the park it was already closed, it was after sunset. I've went around the gate through some trees on the sides of the gate and back on the road leading to the campground. It took another 2 or 3 miles of pedaling before I've reached the campground, that is I was now actually completing a circle and was probably not far away from the original spot I came from separated by thick trees and water. The campground appeared to be very big and had nice facilities and even a swimming pool. I've pitched my tenth, cooked my dinner and went to take a shower and retired not before spotting few more tenths and RVs in the park. Looked like it was a popular spot with travelers and passing by tourists. 
I've found my way back to Rt. 41 that is also known as N. Florida Avenue and continued southeast. The road passed through nice little town situated along lakes and interleaved with citrus orchards. I've stopped couple of times to purchase fresh fruits along the way as well as to drink some farm fresh orange juice. Later I've connected to Rt. 27, which is a divided hwy used heavily by trucks. This route is also called Rt. 98 and sometimes alternates into other numbers on the maps. Of course I did not know this and as I've said earlier my goal was to get in the fastest/shortest time from point A to point B. this of course was not always the safest route. Toward the early evening hours I've started to look for a Motel along Rt. 27. There were actually numerous sites pointing to RV and campgrounds available. When I've seen the sign saying something like: Citrus Growers Valley Campground, I've decided to call it off for the day and to settle at this campground. While the name sounded nice the entrance to the park was a complete mess and it looked liked a bombed place. There was a lot of broken concrete and piles of dirt and heavy equipment. The route was making detours and took me some time before I got into the campground itself, which appeared to be much cleaner, that the surrounding area. When I've found the office I was told that they are constructing a new apartment complex in the vicinity and in the meantime turning everything upside down. Seems that because it was already late Friday afternoon the work ceased for today and luckily tomorrow being Saturday, there will be no heavy-duty work during my departure either. At least to minimize the amount of dust being raised by the cards there was a truck that periodically was spraying the road with water to keep the dust on the ground. The manager lady told me that the price for the night is $17, which seemed to be a little bit steep for such a badly surrounded area. But since it was already late and I was tired I did not bother to continue and look further. In addition the place was few miles from the road and it would be too much to go back. On the plus side I've found the place to be very clean and well maintained and every hour the guard on duty was making a trip around the place in an electrically powered vehicle, keeping the noise level to minimum. It had also a guestroom to watch TV and very clean, looked like a fancy hotel showers and bathrooms. I've decided to locate my tenth closed to the bathroom/shower area just in case I'll need to use it. The place had RVs, and mobile homes in it and it looked like I was the only camper in a tenth. After taking a shower and cooking something in the kitchen, I've spent some time talking to the guard and retired to sleep after 10:00 PM. 
The ride was quite uneventful except at one point when I worried when I saw police cars at night and many youngsters trying to get to some dance club. At first I thought that there might be some demonstration, but later realized that they just waited to get in to some crowded dance club or may be a show? Along the way I've stopped in the city of Okeechobee for a late Pizza dinner and was starting to look at the Motels along the main route checking their prices. But when I did not see anything cheaper than $65 I've decided to continue hoping that there might be a campground or I'll find another place to sleep. Once I've started going I continued to cycle to the night and did not stop for a long time. At one point I hit the section of the road that was very dark and foggy and I could not see more than few tens of feet. Luckily there was not traffic on this road but I also did not see any lights, which showed that the road passed either near a lake or some water. I was afraid to step of the road, which had very steep embankment because I worried of falling into water, or whatever hide there down in the darkness. Even my powerful Petzel headlight did not shine through the fog, which reflected the light. The few cars that passed me did so carefully once they saw all the light I had as well as the reflective material on the wheels and the bike as well as my rain jacket that also had reflective stripes. The reason I had the rain jacket was that if was very foggy and the humidity very high. I could almost feel the water droplets in the air. At one point I finally started to see some lights and thought that it was a city or town but it appeared to be a power line rely station which was well lighted and spread on big area. After few more miles I did finally reached the Western suburbs of West Palm Beach Florida. At this point I started to feel close at home (not mine but my mothers) since I was familiar very well with this area. I've decided to continue for a while until I reach the state Rt. 441. When I reached Rt. 441 I turned South to follow the road until Yamato Rd., which is one of the two main roads crossing and leading Boca Raton, Florida. I looked at my watch and I noticed that it was around 3:00 AM. If I continue toward my mother's house at this time I'll probably would arrive there too early and would awake her up. It was only another 30 miles or so to get to where she lives. Since it was Sunday morning I thought my mother would be still asleep. I continued in a slower pace in order to fill in some time. Just before 5:00 AM I've reached a Chevron Gas station that was just opening the services to the public. Like many of the Chevron gas stations along the way this one also appeared to have a well-equipped convenience store. I've decided to stop there to rest, eat breakfast and call my mother. The store manager appeared to be a young Palestinian who came to the US from Jordan. Of course I told him that I'm an Israeli and as soon as he heard this he got very excited but in a positive way. As usual such a meeting sparks a political debate. He told me that he came to this country and first worked at Ford assembly line in Detroit but later on he married an American woman and decided to move to the south and got a job through his friend that owns few gas stations in the Florida area. I also told him why I'm here on a bicycle that actually I came all the way from California to visit my mother who just recently moved to Boca Raton from Israel. He has treated me very nice, he asked the cook to prepare a nice meal for me later asked me if I want some donuts and coffee and I said providing that I'll pay but he adamantly refuse any money. We spent there talking for about two hours and a policeman patrolman who stopped to get some coffee joined us. The policeman said that he's going to find out how is the traffic and weather in the Boca area and left. After a while he called and said that the weather is still foggy and that I should probably wait for a while before continuing. He also said that if I want he can give me a ride since the traffic is very heavy at this time along Rt. 441 and it does not have shoulders at many places. On this I've thanked him and said that if I've survived so far I'll take the chance and continue on my own. I've called my mother around 7:30 AM and I woke her up of course. She was very glad to hear that I'm already very close nearby and told me to head carefully toward her place.
