I've parted from the gas station manager and wished him all the best in his work and he wished me a safe trip, and after about another hour on the road I've arrived at the place where my mother lives. She was very exited to see me alive and well and said that I look very good but a little bit skinny. Well first thing I've done I jumped on a scale and weighed myself. It appears that I've lost about 16 pounds on this trip. I've started about 186 pounds, which is my average weight and was about 170 LB the day I finished the ride. 
This was the material that I've read before the trip. 1. The Bicycle Touring Manual, by Rob van der Plas, although now out of print it's still availble: http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0933201877/polarisadventure/102-1000535-6046542/  2. The Essential Touring Cyclists, by Richard A. Lovett. http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/0071360190/102-1000535-6046542?vi=glance/ 3. Bicycle Touring, or How to Prepare for Long Rides, by Steve Butterman. http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/0899971741/102-1000535-6046542?vi=glance 4. Bicycle Touring in the '90s', from the Bicycling's Magazine Staff.  5. Bicycle Across America, by Barbara Siegert. http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/0963707728/102-1000535-6046542?vi=glance 6. All of them have a very useful information for the long and short distance bicycle tourist. 
After my trip to Amsterdam had totally convinced me that my future lay in a round the world tour, I was completely happy to make the trip on my 60 year old BSA Paratroopers bike. Over a period of time though my thoughts turned to the idea of using a Penny Farthing, I had never ridden one before, but I didn't think that this mattered too much. By late summer of 99 the Penny was up and running, I had made a three speed version to my own design with a 50" diameter front wheel, and a 20" rear. As the year 2000 celebrations approached the thought came into my mind to ride the Penny to Paris..... Boxing day is traditionally a day of rest to help get over the celebrations, not so this year as we were up with the larks on day one of my trip. I had already dismantled the Penny and loaded it along with my provisions and kit into my dads reliable old Citroen. The trip down to Dover was very uneventful, due I presume to it being the day after Christmas, the time when most people are still sleeping off their Christmas day over indulgences. My only worry at the moment is the rotten bout of flu which I have just caught, it certainly couldn't have had better timing for its arrival, though my immune system is now being helped by every pill and potion that exists under the sun!  Arriving in Dover we parked up, carefully removed the bike from the car and I started to rebuild it into its complete state. This took no longer than 20 minutes, and once loaded up with my vast array of paraphernalia we were away. When I say away I ought to quantify this a little better, I rode a good 100yds to the ferry booking terminal ! Here after queuing for an age I was told that I had seven minutes to make the 9.15am boat. With a big rush I raced outside wheeled around the corner and had to foot the Penny up the first hill that I came too ! By the time we reached the boat I found to my dismay that we were too late, and would now have to wait and catch the 12.30 sailing. This was rather a disappointment as this vexatious delay meant I lost a good half days riding time. When it was time to wheel onto the ferry it felt as if all eyes were on me, I had been having a chat with a group of coach drivers who were heading for Switzerland, when I was ushered away as the first person to load. This was splendid as it meant that I was only second in the queue for the restaurant when I went up into the ship. I was then immediately promoted to first place when the people before me asked if I was the mad Penny Farthing rider they had just seen. They then explained that they thought that I probably needed a good intake of vitamins sooner than they ! The crossing took an hour and twenty minutes which was nice, and by about 2.30pm we hit the roads of France ! The truth in those words is greater than you probably realise, I shall explain. Heading away from the Ferry into Calais you first go through a very run down area with a bad road and no people. I was trundling along here pleased as punch that we had at least made it to France when I crossed a set of old railway tracks set into the road. The first ones gave us a bit of a bump but with no ill effects, then we approached another set with even more gusto, unfortunately these were set at more of an angle across the road than the previous ones, so, Crash, Bang, and finally gracefully spread across the road was I. Here I lay in a  sprawled condition across the road once again! Picking myself, and the Penny up, we were approached by a somewhat surprised and concerned looking French fellow, to whom I signed that I was sound in body, though perhaps not in mind. I was extremely thankful that I hadn't buckled the wheel, so I mounted the bicycle again and headed off into Calais. I stopped in the town to do a few running repairs, as I had noticed that the brake was now declining to work, and the handle bars were pointing out at a intriguing angle ! The bars duly re aligned, I quickly spotted that the main axle nut on one side was loose which had caused the lack of brakes. Off I set again and quickly found the road to Coquelles, before this I passed the impressive fort of Nieulay which I liked and thought of as a good camping spot, I decided to press on though to get a few more miles under our belts before the sun went down. Passing through Coquelles it gave the impression of being a typical missed by most type of town, with quite a few empty old buildings about the place. We then came upon a rather long hill which I started to ride up but unfortunately ran out of steam and had to foot the rest of the way. When I reached the top I managed to wheel again for a little distance but then chose to stop as by this time it had become dark. I had pulled into the back entrance of a sleepy farm, and as I wasn't overlooked from the house I thought it would be a good place to pitch the tent for the night. Well big mistake ! I unfolded my tent, then all of a sudden a howling gale appeared and tried to send us both into orbit, as the gale obviously didn't travel alone his acquaintance Monsieur sleet now arrived to keep him company. The next problem was to try and get the tent pegs in, I had chosen stony ground which of course helped matters, and after 15 minutes of struggling with a flailing tent I gave in and repacked it into its bag. On the other side of the road was a large posh hotel, I stumbled over lent the penny against their shiny door, walked inside and dripped on their floor. 65.00 for one night, not possible I'm afraid, I would rather freeze. My alternative was to head back into Coquelles and book into a b+b I had previously observed. Rolling back down the hill I had already pushed the Penny up was fun, though I'm not thinking about having to foot the bike up it again tomorrow at this moment in time ! When I arrived at the b+b hotel the heavens had truly opened, which again was pleasant for me, but fortunately I was let in to the foyer by some Polish people. They had been refused entry into England for Christmas to see their respective boyfriends, girlfriends, and now were sadly heading back to Poland. Officialdom doesn't appear to have much Christmas spirit in the UK. The proprietor of the hotel kindly allowed me to bring the bike inside and block the fire escape which was kind of him, so at least the bike isn't going to get a soaking. I shall cook myself a nice meal on my stove in the room tonight to try and lessen the weight that I seem to be carrying. I have covered a somewhat stunning 6.9miles, with a maximum speed of 17mph today.    Show links to this Hide links to this     
All of these were way too steep for us to wheel up, so it was just down to pushing. I don't normally walk anywhere because I cycle, so all this effort was found to be most draining upon my person. I crossed under the A16 and carried on Southwards in this same pattern and finally arrived in the very pretty but closed town of Marquise. It was here that I turned left onto the D191 and wheeled into Rinxent, to then take the D127 once more in a Southerly direction. The rolling landscape and incessant headwind is really taking it out of me now, and our progress has now become very slow indeed. Even on the flat parts it would seem that I can only generally pull first gear for most of the time, and the down hill sections are soon taken up with a fast coast. I am wondering though how well I could have faired with my old BSA over this terrain ?  Reaching a cross-roads I lent the Penny against a piece of Armco and surveyed my route ahead, the road wound its way up to the church and village of Alincthun placed, not to surprisingly upon the top of a very steep hill. One step after another I pushed the 125lbs of Penny Farthing and kit until finally arriving at the top, exhausted. Here I met the friendly vicar of the village who asked me to pose for him for some photos infront of the church, this I duly obliged to do and then set off again on my journey. Way off in the distance I could see my road dip down into a valley and then off up a sharp inclination into a forest. When I arrived at the base of the climb and looked up ahead, I was only grateful that at least I would be pushing up through pleasant greensward. This walk seemed to take an age but upon finally reaching the summit we had a nice coast down to the bottom of the hill into my destination for the night, Desvres. Here I then started to foot ride again to get up into the town and find the marked campsite. After a deal of toing and froing I was told by a friendly local that the campsite was closed, so with this I quickly gave in and found a small hotel, I put the Penny in their garage and decided that I felt totally exhausted. I was sitting in the bar drinking a rather expensive cup of coffee when the only other patrons entered to acquire some beer. They were five Indian chaps from Leicester who like me were over in France for the Millennium. We had a bit of a chat and laughed that the owners only customers were English, I then had a pee in the most horrible outside latrine, and then retired to a very welcome bed. Today I had covered just 27.8miles, with a maximum speed of 23mph, this is a lot less than I had expected for all the effort it involved     
Here we started another murderous slog of pushing up to the town, we eventually reached the town wall and entered under a beautiful arch. Immediately to my left I found a fabulous cobbled road going up to a fork with fantastic old houses on either side, I of course stopped and took some photos and had a nice chat with some locals.  Unfortunately all the roads then became cobbled and as I wasn't about to try my luck on them, back to footing it was. In the town centre I was accosted by some nice Dutch people for some photos, and then spoke to a friendly French lady about the trip while her husband video'd it all. I then wheeled out of town on the deserted D139 heading for Roussent, along this stretch of road the surface was very bad and also very narrow so I was glad that I was the only traffic. Hunger started to knock on my stomach door at this point so I stopped under an old bridge had lunch, and also a nice brew up, which proved to be a splendid energy boost and wake up. Off we set again and of course went straight into a big hill. When reaching Roussent I turned East and headed along the river for Douriez, the theory being that the route will be flatter along a river. Arriving at Douriez I crossed the river and turned South onto the D212 aiming now for Crecy. After about half a mile I saw ahead of me yet another hill, this turned out to be the worse one of the day, it seemed to be never-ending and when finally reaching the top I really was all but done in. I stopped shortly afterwards at an cafe for a coffee and a refill of my water supplies and then set off to find a camping spot for the night. I found a lovely spot in a corner of a field and thankfully there was no wind so I didn't have any problems with my tent. Having cooked myself up a nice dinner, I curled up in my sleeping bag and fell into a deep sleep. I had covered 37.4 miles with a maximum speed of 20mph.         
They then kindly informed me that it was only one more km of hills then it would be flat, I was very relieved. By the time I reached the Somme river at Pont-Remy I realised that it was his son who was the only cyclist in his family, as there were still plenty of steep inclinations for me to negotiate.  I crossed the Somme at Cocquerel to follow the D21 and on to join the main D901 route. In the town of Airaines I stopped at a Supermarche to stock up on chocolate and other supplies, they sold me five Cadburys type bars all together for just 95p ! When I came outside quite a crowd had formed around the Penny, and when chatting or mainly signing I got an invite for a coffee and a photo by a friendly old Italian fellow. Unfortunately I had to turn him down as his Grand Chateau was in the wrong direction, and I unfortunately couldn't spare the time if I was to make it to Paris for New years, but I hoped for a similar type of invite at the end of the day as well. I wheeled on through the rolling countryside over never-ending hills and still headed south, at this point I managed to devour two whole bars of chocolate to help boost my energy levels, and very nice they were too ! I was so tired from all of the pedalling and pushing that I decided to get a hotel at 4 o'clock, I had just reached the town of Thieulloy l'Abbage and stopped to ask for the whereabouts of some accommodation, unfortunately no hotels was the answer, but 6km further on I would find one. The energy levels were very low at this point so six more km I could have done without, and also it was now getting dark and sleeting. I dug deep and put a big spurt on to reach the town of Poix-de-Picardie in 35 minutes, I was shattered as I wheeled down a long hill which I prayed I wouldn't have to re climb, thankfully I stumbled upon a hotel. Falling through their door into the bar they all looked rather shocked as to what had just arrived ! Having safely stored the Penny in the rear courtyard, I immediately retired to my room to cook some food and have a very deep sleep. I had covered 36.2 miles, with a maximum speed of 23mph.   
After undoing then redoing up the spokes for the third time, I regrettably still had a wheel the shape of a figure of eight, added to the fatigue of the days wheeling and footing, with this outcome I was none too pleased. Visions of this being the end of the road for the Penny and I flashed before me, as I knew that to have any chance of making Paris for New Years Eve, the wheel would have to be repaired tonight. I sat in the foyer of the hotel with a cup of steaming coffee in my hands thinking over the problem, then it gratefully came to me, I must remove the rim from the wheel, straighten that first and then respoke the wheel. Later, as I held a bent 50" Penny Farthing wheel rim in my cold hands, while pushing it against a concrete pillar, I wondered what a funny sight I must be to all my friendly fellow guests residing within these walls. When the moment of truth and several crossed cold fingers arrived, I was mightily pleased to find that I once again had a rideable wheel. I had previously hoped to enjoy an early night and be completely recharged for the big push to Paris tomorrow, this wasn't to be, but trust me when I say that I slept soundly. I had covered 29.9 miles, with a maximum speed of 16mph      Show links to this Hide links to this         

Arriving at the Place De Varsovie which is infront of the tower I was captured by a film crew who had me riding up and down for their sights of Paris show, they then did an interview, and had me say something in French before I rode off into the sunset, or should I say off towards the  Louvre.  I crossed the Seine again at the Pont de la Concorde bridge and entered the long open avenue up the Jardin des Tuileries, here I was told off for riding my wheel which I thought was funny. When I was standing studying with admiration the great glass pyramid which stands within the  courtyard of the Louvre I was approached by a fellow showing interest in the wheel. The friendly fellow who's name I regrettably never acquired offered then to kindly show me around the rest of the Paris sights as he was doing just that himself on this day. My route was to then head north to the Gare Du Nord station to catch the train home, so we led a winding course via the beautiful Notre Dame and the ugly Pompidou centre to the awaiting trains. Now my friend was rather a timid fellow and with the ticket bought he started to fluster over whether they would let me put the Penny on the train. I explained to him that I would just put it in the carriage anyway and not worry about it, he flustered and said that we must ask the controllers permission first because dire consequences could occur otherwise. Being tired I didn't argue, the controller said no, and my train left without me. The next train wasn't until the evening so the plan was to smuggle the Bicycle onto the Metro in a dismantled state to at least get North of the city. I gradually took the machine apart and broke it down to the smallest items, chains, pedals, sprockets, everything off to try and disguise it a little, this operation acquired the attention of the police who came and pointed their guns, but departed again when I pleaded ignorance. Carrying all of the parts and my kit while rolling the wheel wasn't easy, but down we went to the metro over many a stair without an escalator in sight. Sitting waiting for a carriage to arrive the announcement came over the tannoy that all the trains were cancelled due to a strike by the railwaymen, this meant a very long climb back up to the main station, which I did find quite exhausting. Here now of course they had closed the electronic barriers which had been open when we had previously passed through, owning no ticket for these the game was to wait until no one was looking do a little climbing and pass the whole paraphernalia including the wheel over the top. Returning to the main platform I explained to my friend that as soon as the evening train  arrived I would put all of the parts in the carriage tie them up and go to sleep.  The evening arrived and the plan worked to great satisfaction, I bid farewell to my friend and closed my eyes. Pulling into Calais the time was 11.30pm, I pulled all the parts off of the train and on to a handy trolley and then proceeded to wheel them to a covered part of the station.  At just after 1am I had finished rebuilding the machine, I then discovered that they had locked me in the station and that there was no apparent way out, after wandering about for a while I thankfully came upon a night watchman who helped me cross the tracks and escape out of a back entrance. I wheeled around onto the main road, had a little chat with some amazed people, found a hotel that was thankfully still open, then slept the sleep of the dead. Returning home I knew that I would never forget the turn of this century, it has been quite an experience I have to say, but I know that I couldn't ride around the world on this bike, it is just too plain heavy. I have now started to build a much simpler, lighter ungeared version for the next adventure.......   
Although I will not be able to do a ride on the scale of last year's journey for a long time, this summer will have in store a handful of short rides like this one.  Ever since I rested up from last year's trip (a couple of weeks after my return to New Orleans), I have been thinking about new trips and the possibilities they could hold.  This little ride promises to be about 200 miles of fun.  I'll start in the hilly piedmont and endure some mad hills in the river valleys to the northeast like the Patapsco and Susquehanna.  I then hope to enjoy the flattening out of the land as I creep southeast on day three towards a wonderful vacation at a beach house my brother and sister-in-law have secured.   I'll have a digital camera with me this time (thanks Gail!), so I should be able to get a better quality and quantity of shots of my ride and some of the things I encounter.  Thanks for reading and please check back in a couple of weeks after I return and upload the tales and images from the ride.   
Accommodations:  Patapsco Valley State Park campground    Dj vu when I left the house this morning at 10:20.  Almost everything I did the same as I did eleven months ago when I ventured off to New Orleans.  The photo ops were the same.  The dog was equally sad.  The clothing and equipment were almost completely identical.  The excitement in my chest was there but not as pronounced as it was last year.  This time I knew what I was up against.  This time I was in better shape.  And sadly, this time I wouldn't be going as long.  Actually, my trip will be a mere fraction of what it was last year.  I learned, however, from last year that the trip isn't about mileage or the destination - it's about the journey.  So, I stayed away from self-deprecation about the wimpiness of this puny little ride and instead concentrated on having fun.  You could say I wanted to stop and smell the roses a little more often.      The first few miles of the ride took me past two of my alma maters, Cooper Intermediate and Langley High Schools, and then shortly thereafter, the George Bush Center for Intelligence (insert joke here)(actually it's named after George H. Bush)(a.k.a. the C.I.A.).  I crossed the Potomac River on Chain Bridge into the far western corner of the District of Columbia where I cruised on the sidewalk past motorists stuck in traffic.  I rode on the C & O Canal Towpath for a tiny bit before gaining access to the Capital Crescent Trail at the railroad trestle over Canal Road.  As I rode the 10 or so miles clockwise around the city, I made sure to stop and read the historic markers and kiosks (thus sticking to my policy, with a name I just devised, of 'smelling the roses and whatnot'), although I must have been looking the other way when I past the 'Welcome to Montgomery County, Maryland' sign (which I know exists 'cause I've seen it before).  So, unfortunately, no Maryland sign and not surprisingly no D.C. sign (there aren't many of them anyway).    Towards the end of the Capital Crescent Trail I had some trouble following the signs and got myself lost in Rock Creek Park and later on the campus of Walter Reed Army Medical Center.  I asked an MP for directions to Georgia Avenue, and the young lady in fatigues happily obliged following her instructions with a loud 'sir!' I crossed under the Capital Beltway on Georgia Avenue under the hot early-afternoon sun.  I was happy to be unlost and my legs and body for the first time of the trip were buzzing well.  Sometimes it takes a few hours to get into a ride - not surprisingly today wasn't an exception.  About a mile later I found the Sligo Creek Trail, a shady path that runs six miles from D.C. to Wheaton, Maryland.  I rode on it through Kemp Mill where a Giant (no, not a record store) sat adjacent to the trail.  Although I was feeling well, I knew I should stop.  Grocery stores really are the key to healthy bike touring.  No triangle sandwich here, just some soup, chips, yogurt, and a lot of cantaloupe.  My afternoon was pretty basic and a little frustrating.  I had a lot of trouble navigating through the wiles of suburban Maryland, although it did get a little bit easier with each mile I put between myself and the District.  Suburban landscapes are rife with unmarked 'No Outlets' and 'Dead Ends.'  Moreover, the main roads aren't always labeled on my atlas and the GPS serves little purpose pinpointing my location on the atlas, because the area is so dense that when I look on the map I could be on any one of three or four different 'lines' (signifying, of course, roads).  So, the compass came in handy, and I tried my best to be going north and/or east at all times.  Eventually, that tactic worked to get me on the more farm-like (used very loosely) roads southwest of Baltimore.    Around five or so I rode through a gem of a town, Ellicott City.  I, unfortunately, know nothing about the place, but I am sure to visit again and spend an entire day exploring.  Ellicott City bears the closest resemblance to a European town I have ever seen here in the U.S. (although my memory databank is churning - 'Does Ellicott City deserve superlative status?' I ask myself - I'll continue to think back to places I've visited).  The hills are steep and the roads narrow in Ellicott City.  The storefronts are stoic stone structures, and the railroad museum beckons me back for a look-see (it was closed when I rode through town).  Ohh yeah, one more plus:  New Cut Road, south of town, when traveled northward into the valley which is Ellicott City (elevation 10 feet), is a kick-butt windy, (mostly down)hilly three-mile road great for riding.   More information on Ellicott City from a posting in my Guestbook. I found my way to my campsite, #436, in Patapsco Valley State Park.  I made my reservation two days prior via the internet at the Maryland Department of Natural Resources web site. The park had plenty of tent campers (only compared to other camping experiences) but still a ton of open spaces.  Unfortunately, my site was adjacent to an occupied site, #435.  The people weren't in their the tent when I pulled up, but I figured I should try to move - to afford privacy to both sites and the ability to get a good night's sleep.  I got on my cell phone and called the 800 number to request to be moved to a vacant site three down, #439.  The agent on the phone told me that I would be charged another 12 dollars for canceling my reservation and rebooking a new one.  I pleaded with her, saying that I was just trying to be polite and not aggravate my neighbors when I get up early in the morning and pack up.  'Sorry,' she said, 'I don't make the rules.'  It's strange, here I am in the semi-wilderness (I say 'semi' because I can hear the buzzing of U.S. Rte. 40 in the background, and I have the knowledge that Camden Yards in Baltimore is no more than twelve miles away), and although I see an empty site (even the agent told me that it wasn't reserved for the night), I won't take it because I don't want to get in trouble with a ranger and/or be charged an extra 12 dollars.  Frankly, I was kinda pissed.   Only two minutes after hanging up with the agent, a ranger drove by.  I put my hand up requesting him to stop, and I stated my request.  Actually, I stated it so that it wasn't a request, but more of a favor for my fellow campers.  He was very understanding.  He asked for my cell phone number, because he said he'd call me back after he drove back to the office and checked this out in the computer.  We talked for another minute or two about my travels then he took off, promising me he'd call soon with a determination:  either to stay or to move.  So, I sat and bided my time by eating, stretching, map reading, taking a photo, etc.  As ten minutes stretched into twenty, it started to rain.  First lightly, but as twenty minutes became thirty minutes, it started to pour.  I was in a bind about where my place of rest would be for the evening:  site #436 or site #439.  I just started to set up where I was - everything was getting soaked and I couldn't wait any longer.  Ten more minutes later the phone rang, I answered it in the pouring rain with tent stakes in hand.  'Matthew' the voice on the phone said, 'I'm having some computer problems here, and I've been on the phone with the tech people.  Do you just want to stay where you are?'  By this time I was nearly finished setting up, so I answered, 'yes,' and thanked him for his help.  So, the moral of this story Technology is great, but it shouldn't supersede the decision-making ability of qualified frontline employees - because technology will fail - a ranger won't on an issue such as mine.  Maryland Department of Natural Resources:  please heed!      I rode back out to 40, waiting 15 minutes en route in a pavilion to wait out the most violent part of the thunderstorm.  On 40 I rode another five minutes to a Subway which I had spotted on the way to the park, and in retrospect where I should have just stopped on the way to the park in the first place.  I bought a USA Today and enjoyed my sandwich in the store.  On the short ride back I did experience a problem with the bike:  As I turned the pedals, at about 10 o'clock through the revolution my left crankarm would just give way and freely fall to about 7 o'clock.  I couldn't figure out if it was something with my left pedal or something with the crankarm itself (which was new and installed by me very recently).  This problem worried me, but frankly there was nothing I could do about it at the time.   Back at the tent I sopped up the water inside with my newspaper, read my Outside magazine, and wrote in my journal:  'Never fully got in groove.  But last year I didn't either on day one.  Tomorrow will be better.'
Accommodations:  Lums Pond State Park campground    I didn't wake up early after all; I awoke at nine, and lay in my sleeping bag fighting off the day for a half hour.  I shouldn't have complained, I fell asleep at 10:30 the night before.  More sleep is needed on the road, but I should have been content with ten and a half hours.  Nonetheless, I got going and my morning ritual of breaking camp, packing the rig, and performing a little bit of preventive maintenance took the usual 90+ minutes.  Within a couple of miles on the road, I noticed a bike shop, so I stopped in to see what kind of opinion I could get on my drivetrain problem.  I was told that it was most likely the pedal that was causing the problem in that it was old and tattered and literally falling apart.  I was told that eventually it would fall apart.  At the time I believed the diagnosis, especially because the problem is solely on the left side.  The price was very right, $40, on the most inexpensive set of SPD pedals.  I purchased them, and packed them away - I'll do some roadside surgery, if necessary, later on.  But, for now I'll try to get the rig to Dewey in one piece.  Adjacent to the bike shop was a Denny's and a Grand Slam breakfast was way too tempting after my lackluster tentside breakfast of a Balance bar and a Clif bar.  I went for the ultimate breakfast choice, The Lumberjack Slam, which was probably a little too much for me.  But, I took a good half-hour to eat as I sat at the counter, relaxing and reading my USA Today.  In the end, I slammed everything but one of the sausage patties.  By 12:40 I was back on the road -- much later than I would normally want to get my day going, but really there was no rush.   My original route called for riding around Baltimore, even though cutting straight through was at least 10 miles shorter.  While I sat waiting for the ranger to call me back last night, I did some calculations and concluded that I should cut straight through town.  Going through a big city has its advantages and disadvantages.  In this case the advantages were that I was cutting off a significant amount of time from semi-circumnavigating Baltimore, the scenery is different, and the people-watching potential is much higher.  The downsides of riding through a city, particularly U.S. 40 through Baltimore are that roads can quickly turn into expressways (which happened in this case, but fortunately, I had no problem as it was quite empty in the early afternoon) and that roads can take you through areas that have a significant potential for bike-jacking.   My experience in Baltimore was amenable, and I suffered no significant problems.  At one stop-light in a rougher section of town, in fact, I was questioned by a fellow in a truck next to me about my 'rims' and how much they cost.  I (believe it or not, have been asked this before - multiple times in downtown New Orleans alone) gave (and always give) a low-ball figure, 'a couple hundred.'  This interrogation was short and it gave the individual an opportunity to talk about his ride:  ' a five hundred dollar bike with Rock-Shox.'  I kept the attention on him with follow-up questions about how often and where he rode it.  The light turned green in the middle of one of his responses and his buddy, who was driving, sped off.  My acquaintance stuck his head out the passenger-side window and looked back at me and kept talking (shouting).  I just gave him a thumbs-up, and he eventually stopped moving his lips and instead just smiled. In Aberdeen U.S. 40 parallels the Amtrak Northeast Corridor train tracks.  And along one stretch the only thing that separates the road and the railroad is about a twenty-foot deep thicket of trees.  I pulled off the road and through an access road (really just gravel) to the train tracks.  Strangely enough, this stretch of rail is a rarity in that it is not protected on either side by a chain link fence as it is through Northeast D.C. along New York Ave, or through states up north like Rhode Island.  Nonetheless, I cautiously took advantage of this freedom to get close to the United States' fastest land transportation medium -- I leaned the rig up against a signal box and waited.  I didn't have to wait long for a train to come from around the bend (approximately a quarter-mile away).  A Northbound Acela came my way at over 100mph, and got by me so quickly that I didn't even have a chance to steady my camera on it.  As the train passed the engineer gave me a little toot of the horn.  I am fairly certain that it was a friendly toot, in that it was short, and I think that the engineer didn't perceive me to be a nuisance or a potential suicide (it does happen).  If so he would have instead given me a long, 'Get the hell outta here' blast.  In the span of fifteen minutes a total of three Acelas passed me by - all so quickly that I couldn't get a good shot of them.  A static photo wouldn't have done them justice anyway. I rode along U.S. 40 for about 60 miles today, and I was surprised by the large number of seedy-looking strip clubs, XXX shops, etc.  It seemed like between Baltimore and the Delaware state line I passed by at least five places, all of which, even more strangely, were on the south side of the road.  Maybe it's some funky zoning regulation. I pulled near to Havre De Grace around 4:45pm and decided to take a detour through town.  Havre De Grace sits at the mouth of the Susquehanna River almost at the northern-most tip of the Chesapeake Bay.  It's just at water level so the railroad and highway bridges that cross the river there jump from the palisades on either bank out high over the town, thus providing a picturesque backdrop for the otherwise peaceful village that had a strong sailing and fishing aura to it.  I didn't stay in Havre De Grace long, but I knew that I wanted to go back to this Maryland gem, and spend some time walking around and looking at the historic homes and gleaming waterfront.    At the corner of the small road leading out of Havre de Grace and US 40 was a McDonald's.  I stopped in for a small meal -- something to tide me over for the rest of the afternoon.  Soon I was back on the bike heading northeast to cross the Susquehanna River.  As I rode down a small hill to the base of the bridge my roadway got narrower and narrower -- first losing a lane, then the shoulder, and then elbow room in my lane.  And just as I was about to cross the expansion joint of the bridge I saw a small sign to the side of the roadway:  "Bicyclists and Pedestrians Prohibited."  I let out an expletive, pulled on the brakes, and jumped the Jersey wall with the rig to a small pedestrian walkway.  I pulled out my map and evaluated my options.  It was 20 miles out of my way to ride upriver to the Route 1 bridge and cross there, and I wasn't sure if I could even cross there.  I was a little frustrated and frankly surprised -- after riding throughout the Southeast where I steered clear of Interstates, just as I have done here, so as to not have to deal with bridges that have bicycle prohibitions.   The only sensible option was to attempt to catch a ride over the bridge.  I walked the rig away from the foot of the bridge towards an intersection.  There I pulled out my notepad and Bic ballpoint pen and started scripting a sign.  As I was bold-facing my third grade handwriting, I heard a deep male voice, "You need any help?"    "I'm trying to get across the bridge. I didn't know that bikes weren't allowed on it," I responded to the man as he now stood in front of me.  I was so engrossed in my sign-making that I hadn't noticed that this man had pulled his blue Ford Escort station wagon (with a bike rack on the hatch -- KEY) off to the side of the road.  Without hesitation he offered a ride.  I walked the rig over to the vehicle and with a little bit of teamwork we were able to quickly strip the packs off and throw the bike on the back.  Beryl was my helper's name.  He threw the week's worth of mail that had accumulated on the front seat into the back on the floor.  I took a seat in the Escort, and we were off over the Susquehanna.  I offered to pay the toll on the far end of the bridge.  He declined, because he had paid a flat fee to have a pass to get over the bridge which was really a large UPC bar code-like-sticker on the rear driver-side window.  We drove past the toll booth at a slow speed and a large laser gun positioned at a preset height scanned the sticker -- kinda neat.  I learned that Beryl was on the way to a minor league baseball game with his "gal" (a.k.a. girlfriend) at the new Cal Ripken Jr. Stadium in Aberdeen.  We chatted about a bunch of things in our five minute river-crossing, including Beryl's own bicycling adventures. Once on the northside of the Susquehanna River Beryl offered to take me, "up the road a ways," but I declined.  I courteously asked him to drop me off at the first gas station on the right sign, and he obliged.  We said our good-byes, and I wrote my website address on one of the envelopes in the big stash of mail on the floor.  Although he said he didn't have internet access, he did say that his gal's a teacher, so maybe she'd check the site out sometime at her work.  [Beryl's Gal:  Tell him thanks again for me, please!] It was about six o'clock when I saddled back up after my two mile cheat over the Susquehanna.  It was about 15 miles or so to the Delaware state line and an additional five to the campground.  The first hour on US 40 was pretty basic, but right before I crossed into Delaware on US 40 I took a right turn to the south on Malonry Road outside Elkton, thus prolonging my time in Maryland.  The route to the campground via backroads looked promising, so I decided to go for an adventure and get off the boring US 40.  Malonry Road and its connecting roads proved to be perfect:  windy roads, in and out of stands of trees, in and out cornfields, and then into the state of Delaware.      It was now the hour before sunset, and although the campground was no more than three miles away, I couldn't get to it -- I was stuck in the suburban sprawl of Newark, Delaware (Yeah, can you believe it!?!  Even Delaware has sprawl).  I could have gotten frustrated because my map didn't have the names of the streets that have been laid on what was recently a cornfield, but it didn't seem to matter.  A compass and a little bit of sunlight was all I needed.  I was in a great mood -- the day had given me many things to enjoy, and this mini-quandry wasn't going to ruin it.   Okay, so I made it to the state park.  The campground was a simple loop roadway with perhaps 50 sites on it.  Surprisingly, at least half of them were occupied.  I choose one not too far from the entrance and not too far from the bathhouse.  The rest of the day was nice and relaxing even though I didn't catch any dinner on the way to the campground (previously purchased beef jerky, snack mix, and balance bars had to do).  After a shower and some phone calls, I easily drifted off to sleep to the sounds of muted campfire conversations.
   After a wonderful night of sleep, I awoke at 6:30, and after a quick photo of my campsite I was on my way by eight.  The weather was perfect - cool, sunny, and with a nice breeze at my back.  Five miles into my ride I visited the Delaware Veterans Memorial Cemetery and then crossed the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal at Summit Bridge.        Passing many bicyclists and many more fields of corn I floated down US 301 at an easy 19mph.  The morning wasn't eventful, but that's fine by me, because it was perfect.  The air was at that point where sweat resided on my skin for a short time before it evaporated and provided me with a pleasant chill.  I made a quick pit stop in a grocery store in Middletown for a more substantial breakfast:  OJ, a bagel, yogurt, and a banana.     Then back on the bike to navigate through windy, shady, and scenic roads in and out of the many tracts of the Blackbird State Forest northwest of the state capital.   Connecting current events with the real world:  As I rode through the late morning in the Delaware countryside I followed one particular mail car as its driver was doing his Saturday route.  As he pulled to the side of the road I would pass him, and then he would speed past me to the next house down the road.  As we continued this trade-off a handful of times I observed many residents (all elderly) walking out to their mail boxes immediately after the post man delivered.  What seems to most as an inconsequential routine, mail delivery is extra important to those that spend most of their days at home, inside.  It is their connection to the outside world.  The Postal Service has been toying with the idea of nixing Saturday delivery so as to save money.  And although I understand the Service's reasons, this connection to the outside world is so important for many people and worth holding on to.  Well, anyway... I stopped for lunch in Pearsons Corner at a general store/deli.  I ate outside on a bench and watched the Amish stop by in their buggies to do some shopping.  I bought a cantaloupe at a nearby stand from a young boy whose older brother had just earlier delivered the produce via buggy.  I wasn't familiar with the Delaware Amish, but I enjoyed my few experiences with them.    Back at home my curiosity has gotten to me about my Delaware Amish encounters.  Some cursory online searching has yielded some pretty good results -- some Delaware-specific, some not: Great general info clearinghouse:Amish Links OpiumMagazine.com article:  Amish in the First State State of Delaware sites:State Agencies Unveil New Roadway Sign Project to Increase Safety of Amish Community (PDF file)Safe Driving in Delaware's Amish Community (PDF file) The temps were in the nineties, but I made it through the day just fine.  In fact, the day went great, and I now think that Delaware is my favorite cycling state.  It's relatively flat, rural, green (very green), has windy roads, and plentiful and accurate signs.  The Amish were icing on the cake.  I know I've only ridden in twelve states and the District of Columbia in my short life, but my little over one day of time spent in Delaware has won me over.  I will be back. I rolled down Route One into Rehobeth Beach.  I was amazed how the commercial section of the beach has crept farther and farther out from the beach.  I hadn't been there for five or so years but many things had changed -- more traffic, more stores, more pavement.  All annoying.  But, some things are still the same:  Dr. Habib Bolourchi, Certified Cardiologist, still strangely has his office on the roadside outside Rehobeth and the Jolly Trolley still makes its appointed rounds in Dewey and Rehobeth.    I made it to my brother and sister-in-law's rented beach house, hugged Gail, and then went for a dip in the ocean.  All in all a great trip.
    RIDING 217 miles -- Total distance 16 hours, 40 minutes, 44 seconds -- Ride time 13.0 mph -- Average Speed  3 days -- Trip length 0 -- Days of rest (0-10 miles/day) 0 -- Days of very light riding (11-30) 0 -- Days of light riding (31-50) 1 -- Days of moderate riding (51-70) 2 -- Days of heavy riding (71-90) 0 -- Days of very heavy riding (91+) 72.3 miles -- Average riding per day (=217 miles/3 days)   0 -- Dogs that chased me   ACCOMMODATIONS 2 -- Nights spent on the road 2 -- Camping GEOGRAPHY 3 -- States traversed (plus the District of Columbia) FOOD 3 -- Bananas consumed 14 -- Energy bars consumed  LOGISTICS 0 -- Tubes flatted
  My inspiration for this tour came--as it often does--from a map.  All travelers know the syndrome: we innocently open a map, and soon we are lost, picking out routes, wondering what that pass is like, where the best camps can be found, what are the views from that hill?  While studying a map of southern California, I discovered that it would be possible to ride a huge loop starting and finishing at our home in Tehachapi, at the very southern tip of the Sierras, that would include some of the best terrain of the Mojave desert, especially the East Mojave Preserve and Death Valley National Park.  Moreover, the majority of the route would follow remote, lightly traveled roads, including a long stretch of the famous Route 66.  When pondering what to do for a winter vacation, I suggested this tour.  My wife, Jodi, agreed.  So the project was launched. For many days before departure, we constantly checked the weather forecasts.  After a week of changeable conditions--snow, wind, sun--things finally cleared.  We canceled our backup plan and got packing. We were both pretty anxious the night before setting sail.  Over 600 miles through remote desert country is a big undertaking.  Could we pull it off?  What would the wind be like?  This was winter, after all, and much of the Mojave is high, cold, and lonesome.  These challenges were part of the game, however; the trip would lose its meaning without them.  So, like excited children, we went to bed. (Note: For those interested in a discussion of our equipment, see my Arizona Trike Tour account and look under "Equipment.") 
     It was hard to believe that we were really, finally, actually started, rolling down our familiar hill, the trike loaded and two weeks of open road stretched out before us.  Suddenly, we were the richest people on earth. A cold, snappy headwind set in quickly.  Toes went numb, fingers, too.  We pushed on to the first pass of the trip: Willow Springs at about 4,700 ft.  Snow clung in patches beneath the spinning wind turbines.      The Tehachapi area produces the world's largest amount of wind-generated electricity, and these turbines are part of many views in the area.  I've always liked them with their elegant spinning blades, some as long as thirty feet each.  The pass, which Padre Garces used back in the 16th century, marked the start of a fantastic ten mile descent into the town of Mojave, home to high winds, burger joints, and aerospace development.  We plunged deliriously into the high desert, the folded, furrowed mountainsides and bajadas covered in Joshua trees, creosote bushes and the occasional juniper.  Mile after mile, we pedaled and descended.  We outwitted the actual town and traffic by using secondary roads and eventually hooked up to Sierra Highway--a straight shot of many miles into Lancaster on the far side of the Antelope Valley. The road was good and traffic generally light.  The scenery--fantastic up high--lost some of its luster but did present us with "classic" desert scenes:  rusting cars, houses composting into the blow sand, doublewides with peeling paint, barking junk-yard dogs behind chain-link fences.  One "church" of note: A converted mobile home with some hack, spray-painted, graffiti-style version of an Hieronymous Bosch depiction of hell: the souls of the damned tormented by the fires of hell, all in crude outlines of black in red flames! The snow-covered peaks receded, and the endless plains of creosote, burro bush and their ilk embraced our route, led us on, vanishing against the San Gabriel mountains in the distance. In Lancaster, a sprawl of homes and a mauling of malls, we stopped at Gil's Bike Shop, in business since 1957.  These nice people sold us some back-up replacement spokes.  One fellow gave us directions to the grocery store but commented that the street was very "hoody," as he put it.  We swung onto this street, half expecting shot-gun shacks and gang banger types.  Instead, nicely maintained homes and children playing confronted us.  We rode into a "gang" of seven to twelve-year-olds who exclaimed "Wow! "Tight bike!"  "Cool!"  For a hundred yards or so we had a yelling, screaming escort of children, some running, others on "razor" scooters or BMX bikes.  Simply delightful. Outside the health food store, I met a friendly man, a vegan Seventh Day Adventist, who was convinced that the milk supply NATION WIDE was contaminated by human sperm: "It's been factuated!" he declared.  As we were discussing the relative merits of vegetarianism, my wife returned with a few supplies, including a pint of half-and-half for the coffee.  The man just smiled and didn't say a word. Because of a lack of campgrounds (and a fairly large gang presence, moved north from L.A.), we were forced to get a motel.  Somehow we managed to wedge our 11 1/2 foot long trike into the room.     Nice hot showers, washing a few clothes and a mediocre meal were the order of the evening.  Tomorrow, we would head due east for many miles on dead straight back roads to connect with Route 66 where, no doubt, we would get our kicks. 
   Some of these "classic" structures were obviously fake, like the gas station and, perhaps, the "Last Chance" motel.  These seemed to be constructed or converted for the movie industry--who knows?  The roads were lightly traveled, the winds mild, and parts of the route were quite beautiful with granite crags and boulders and Joshua trees.  In spite of the mind-numbing straightness of the route, I enjoyed most of the day. Just as we rolled into Adelanto, winds from the predicted weather front began kicking in--pretty fierce 30--40 mph gusts that sometimes pushed the trike off course.  The day was getting old, and gray clouds bore down upon the mountains.  My anxiety level notched up a bit.  Where would we stay?  We attempted to get a spot at an RV park ($25!), but no tents were allowed.  Humph.  A pox on them and the Winnebago they rode in on.  So with the wind beating across our path, we pushed on for Route 66 as the sun faded into the brooding clouds. After a fight with raging cross winds and terrible pavement (more like raunchy cobblestones) we turned onto Rt.66.  In less than a mile we came upon a wonderful "Nature Park" set amid granite boulders and dropping down to the Mojave river, which actually has water here.  We pushed the trike under the locked gate and rolled down to a grassy patch and children's playground.      Jodi, rightly worried about the sprinklers, suggested we pitch the tent in the sand of the jungle gym area--perfect.  A fine dinner of polenta, sauted onions and green beans, kale and cheese set our hunger to rights.  This was made perfect by a cup of fine Syrah we'd carried from home. Soon, however, we realized our good fortune was not without its problems.  Every few minutes, a massive train would grind, squeal and groan its way through the narrow, stony canyon, the din echoing and vibrating in our very bones.  Earplugs helped a little, but sleep was to be a rare condition for most of the night.  We did some reading and got what rest we could.  Oh, well, guess we can't have everything. 
  The night was not good, so we were happy to be out of the place, even though it was beautiful, especially after the rain that fell for about half the night.  We awoke to clear skies, however, and chilly temps.  We would find that most mornings would be in the mid 30's.      We brewed up some coffee and set out as soon as we were warm enough to move.  Groggy and frazzled, we headed northward on Route 66 for a stretch and finally east to Barstow. The morning was cut from fine crystal and a biting wind, which would soon be a tailwind--heh, heh.  We stopped for a moment to take pictures of a bottle-tree garden, another strange, delightful desert artifact.  In these dry regions, some people just feel free to express themselves in unexpected ways.    Shortly after the bottle forest, I heard an odd rattling and looked down to see one of the fender mounts broken clean through.  Arrgh.  We pulled over and quickly had the offending unit fixed with the timeless standbys:  duct tape and bailing wire.  No kit would be complete without them.      At a little store shortly down the road, I could tell that Jodi wasn't feeling too well.  I didn't push with many questions, but when she gets that "look" and is strangely quiet, I know something's brewing. We set off for a wide-open section of the highway that dropped at a mild angle down towards Barstow.  The sky scrubbed clean, a ripping wind at our backs, we fairly flew--30+mph for miles.  A glorious run.  We coasted into Barstow, and when we stopped, we really understood how strong the winds were.  Flags were STARCHED.  People walked uncertainly with heads down.  We resupplied quickly and headed out, hoping for a better camping situation.  We were not to find it. After being told that part of Route 66 was now a military base, we had to get on Hwy 40 for a few miles.  We ended up in a tight spot for camping, just nowhere to go.  So, in desperation, we crossed to Hwy 15 in search of a KOA.  The way was blocked, however, by a ground-level sand storm, an opaque sand blaster cutting across our route just a foot or two above the pavement-- perfect for a low-slung recumbent trike.  We shielded our faces with our hands and pedaled quickly through.      The KOA was the expected nightmare: Hard on the highway, choked with generator buzzing RV's.  Hot showers helped, but I could tell that Jodi's mood was not improving.  She was in a serious tailspin, and there was nothing I could do about it.  She wandered off for some time--not a good sign.  At long last, she returned and disappeared in the tent.  Despite the wind, I was hungry and decided to make myself a simplified dinner while I brooded over Jodi's brooding.  After messing with the stove for some time in the dim light of my headlamp, Jodi emerged and began helping me with the preparations.  We finally got to talking about what was eating at her.  She was tired, hated the camping, regretted coming on the trip and thought bicycle touring was a big mistake.  Then she really lost it, broke into uncontrolled tears, a total knock-down, drag-out melt down.  Any attempt I made to reason with her resulted in just more tears.  I was feeling terrible.  I just figured some bad days were part of the mix, things you had to work through to find the gems, but Jodi....  I just wasn't sure what to do.  I could see that she wasn't getting out of the trip what I was.   "Jodi," I said, "we can end the tour, ride back to Barstow, rent a car or truck and just go home." "I'm not quitting!" she replied through her gasps. "But what's the point if you're this miserable?" "It'll get better!  I want to finish this." Feeling pretty confused and uncertain about the future, we ate a quiet meal with a bit of "damn-it-all" aka wine, and crawled into the tent as the winds died.  The next day we'd be out in the wild desert, away from KOA's and busy highways. Despite the noise, we slept better than we expected. Maybe things would be better. From the Stoker's Corner:  Scott never really asked me what was brewing within; he simply got quiet, no doubt hoping it would go away.  And who can blame him?  I wanted that, too.  But I was exhausted.  Christmas events had tired me out more than I realized, and coupled with an ongoing lack of sleep, the fatigue was taking its toll (it wasn't hormones--this time).  But the real clincher for me was that, while the cycling and scenery were mostly just fine, I was feeling blasted by noise:  cars and RV's out for the holidays; city traffic; hotel noises.  Our usual winter trips involve heading quickly out to remote areas in our camper for many days of hiking and/or climbing, with plenty of time for quiet relaxation.  I wasn't getting it.  I was overwhelmed.  And ending up at a KOA seemed absolutely absurd and completely depressing.  But what Scott has trouble comprehending, even after 15 years together, is that when I cry, it never means the world as we know it is coming to an end, it's simply a release of pent-up tension.  Then I can get to an emotional place where I'm able to make a decision that's workable for me.  My decision to keep going had less to do with being stubborn or simply committed to finishing what I'd started, but rather that I knew that things were about to get dramatically better once we hit the more remote desert regions.  And they did. 
  Apologies to Thomas Paine, but the pavement on this stretch tried everything.  The day started well enough.  After some excellent coffee and a chilly start, the day warmed, and we made good time to Newberry Springs and the famous "Bagdad" Cafe, the very place featured in the film of the same name.      We met an old desert denizen fascinated by our trike.  He claimed himself an inventor of a four-seater bike but admitted he'd never built any of his inventions.  Other folks gawked and pointed.  The trike sure worked to bring out all kinds of people wherever we stopped. I had to eat something at this famous cafe.  We read the visitors book while I ate some pancakes, homefries and orange juice.  The book was packed with entries by people from all over the planet, especially Europeans and Asians.  Apparently the Euro's love to visit the desert--in the summer!  I'd heard this before.  Lots of Germans especially.  They flood into Death Valley and other spots when the rest of humanity stays away.  We found one entry by an Iranian who joked that the place should be called the "Tehran Cafe" and followed his English with an entry in Farsi--a beautiful, flowing script. After spending too much time at this landmark, we pedaled down Rt. 66.  Brown mountains, sand, and a fantastic flow of basalt extended into the clear air.  The day warmed nicely.  But the promise of cycling ecstasy was not to be.  Shortly after leaving the cafe, rough seas began pounding the Good Ship Greenspeed (Greenspeed is the brand name of our trike).  Route 66 quickly became the devil's highway, el camino del diablo, Route 666!  We hit the worst pavement of my life, about thirty or forty miles of it.  Rutted, split, cracked, bulging, blasted, blighted, crumbled, crusty, corroded black top led off into the distance--forever.        We struggled and bounced and jolted our way along.  The day was beautifully warm, but the pavement soured my mood a bit.  At one point, a long descent, which should have been a fantastic drop, became a spirit-thrashing ordeal.  I just had to pull over to recover for a few minutes.  Jodi, with the shock-dampening load on the panniers, was not having such a bad time.  I just hung my head and wished it were over.  With virtually no traffic and the wonderful weather, Jodi's mood had turned 180 degrees.  We were determined to continue. At long last, we rolled into Ludlow, a road-side stop with a little cafe and a couple of gas stations/mini marts.  We purchased water and set off again, planning on getting clear of Hwy. 40, which Rt. 66 had paralleled, and rail road tracks.  Our track, however, was as bad as ever.  More rough pavement. As the sun fell low in the sky, we pulled off on a dirt road and made camp.  Thankfully, we were far from tracks and highway barely audible in the distance.  We drank in the view of mountain range upon dessicated mountain range as the colors shifted from yellow and gold to azure and lavender and the deepening shadows of dusk. A second day of minor knee pain worried me.  My biggest fear for this tour, now that Jodi seemed to be back in the swing, was that my body would give out.  Retreat from some of these distant locations would not be easy.  I did okay today, but the knee.  Maybe fewer miles the next day. We were feeling pretty extended, remote.  The feelings we were searching for.  The best riding was still to come. 
  This was a great, frustrating, strenuous day.  We had a glorious sunrise outside of Ludlow, did a few repairs (the other fender!), and finally set off about 9:30am.   The terrible pavement finally relented, and we rode on acceptable if sometimes rough surfaces until Amboy.  As we descended further into this remote basin, I began to feel really "out there."  At times we would ride for a full half hour without seeing a car.      Dusty brown bajadas tilted for miles up to furrowed volcanic peaks--the Bristol Mtns. to the north, the Bullion Mtns. to the south--mountains of brown, burnt umber, beige, dun, tawny sands, and all of it capped by a brilliant blue sky.  Except for the road and train tracks to the north, the works of man were not to be seen, just raw, vast distances, peaks, ranges and basins fifty, sixty, seventy miles distant.  We pedaled steadily through this strange, forbidding landscape.  To be honest, however, it was precisely this powerful confluence of the internal and external landscapes that I hoped to find. My worries, besides the anxiety brought on by our remote location, mostly concerned my knee; it bothered me off and on throughout the ride.  Just had to keep going.    Amboy was as dismal as I remembered it, a decaying blister of a town, a place where crimes happen but are never reported.  The population listed on the road sign claimed twenty people as residents.  We met a local, however, who said the true figure was closer to seven.  We finally got some water from Roy at Roy's cafe, which was depressingly empty.  He cautioned us against the water and said we could procure some about ten miles up the road--spoken like a true driver of an automobile.  These exchanges were all most difficult as his English was heavily mangled by his still fresh Hispanic roots.  He did have pint bottles of water, but not enough for our purposes, especially at $1.50 each.  Finally, he said that some people drink the local water.  He reluctantly filled our container.  I bought a $2 ice cream cone by way of thanks. We set about cooking up a meal just across from the cafe and made a discovery: the stove was now useless.  Jodi had left behind the connecting hose back at last night's camp.  After a bit of fuming on my part, Jodi hit on the idea of ordering a new stove from REI and having it shipped to Death Valley.  We'd just eat cold or eat out until we got there.  Sigh...the travails of the trails test us mightily: no morning coffee!  We could perhaps make fires, but I doubted we'd take the time, and, this being the Mojave desert, there often wasn't much to burn.  We ate our cold lunch and set out.  The riding at first was fantastic, the sun warm.  We reveled in jagged mountains and clear light.  Then came the Kelbaker grade. At first we climbed fairly quickly, hammering out a steady 7 mph.  Although not very steep, the route is relentless, making up for lack of severe incline with mile after mile after mile of distance.  With one brief reprieve, we'd climb this hill for twenty-five miles.  My knee kept me anxious, and the climbing and unrelenting straightness of the road wore us down.  Distant objects seemed to never get any closer--grind, grind, sweat, grind, sweat and go no where.  But hills do submit, Sisyphus triumphs if even momentarily.  We made camp on a dirt road not far off the main route, pitching the tent in the gathering dark. My knees were sore, especially the left one.  We decided  to add a link to my chain to extend the pedals.  This would prove to be a big mistake, but at the time it seemed the most reasonable thing to do.  I've since learned to not make big changes to a bike's setup during or just before a long ride.  Regardless, at the time, I felt better.  In general, the riding had been more difficult than we expected.  Because of the cold nights and mornings, we didn't get started until 9am or so, and by 3:30pm, the days were feeling almost over, especially when we had to find and set up camp.   So our new year's eve was spent huddled in a tent as the cold Mojave night closed around us.  We scratched in our journals and spooned down cold beans and salsa, not bad, really.  The next day would see us finishing this climb to Granite Pass at over 4,000 ft.  The East Mojave Preserve also awaited, some of the most spectacular riding of the trip.  I burrowed into my sleeping bag and wondered how all this would turn out. 
     We topped the first pass (Granite Pass) at about 10 am.  It was cold, blustery, but the sky was blue, and the granite peaks and crags that give the pass its name stood out beautifully in the morning light.  We suited up for the huge descent to Kelso station.  This was a good ten mile drop with some of the grandest views imaginable.  The Granite Mountains fell behind while the vista to the west opened on the Kelso Dunes, a mountain range of dunes covering miles of the basin.  To the east jutted the limestone peaks of the Providence Mountains, some of the steepest of the Mojave, soaring thousands of feet above their bases.  Tucked at the bottom of the gradual parabola we rode sat Kelso, an old rail road stop currently being rebuilt by the park service.  It's a classic stucco and tile roof structure that should be a nice place to visit when refurbished.  We had lunch in front of the boarded-up Post Office, got some water from a local, and submitted ourselves once again to the discipline of hill climbing.      At about 3:30 pm, we cracked the last grade and camped near the summit of another pass, once again over 4,000 ft.  With numbing fingers and toes, we pitched the tent in a nice sandy spot beside a Joshua tree, Kelso Peak as our front door view.  Jodi had an idea for a cold tuna/tofu veggie salad...and excellent it was.  I was looking forward to another stove, but we were managing well enough.  The next day, we had a very long descent to Baker, CA., home of the famous "Bun Boy" and the world's tallest thermometer--and a motel room, hot showers, a hot meal, and, perhaps, coffee in the morning. 
  Finally an easy day.  The night before was cold, once again in the 30's in the tent, but the morning was bright and warmed quickly.  Jodi couldn't warm her feet, so I placed them against my chest for a while.  We ate our usual breakfast of almond butter sandwiches.  Covered in layers of extra clothing, we braced ourselves for the long descent into Baker, 25 nearly effortless miles.    As we dropped off the pass, the virtually cloudless sky opened to views of distant peaks, more sand dune wastes, snow-capped peaks on the horizon perhaps a hundred miles away--fantastic. Once we rolled into Baker, got a room, got clean, we were both doing even better.    We had lunch and dinner at a place called The Mad Greek, a crazy-busy place with delightful Greek music bouncing off the walls and a packed stream of people coming and going, and the best thing: espresso!  The road gods were smiling, and so was I.  The food was run-of-the-mill, but I rather enjoyed the friendly chaos of the place, the blue and white paint job, cheap copies of Greek statues and giant posters of idyllic Greek islands.   Our room was clean and large with plenty of room for an 11 1/2 foot long tandem.  We lounged, watched a movie, washed and dried clothes.  In general, we were excited about the next phase of the trip and resolved to get an early start and drink coffee on the road as we pedaled north.  Drinking and driving--what a country. 
With coffee and a greasy ball in my stomach, we rolled out of this enchanting burg shortly after 8am, a record for us on this trip.  The sun at our backs, we pedaled north up Hwy 127 through some awesome desert scenery--light traffic and excellent pavement.  We were in heaven.  We had crossed some line, stepped into a magic time when all is right with the world.  We rode strong and sure, the sun warming, the mountains round us like old friends too long absent.      After about 30 mi. and a low point of 460ft., we finally started to climb steadily, the usual non-stop desert grade for about 12 mi.      We felt strong, and, with a stop for lunch, topped out in a couple of hours.  On the way we passed the turn-off for Dumont Dunes, a vast OHV area.  In the distance, we could see a virtual city of RV's, the hive-center for a swarm of two, three, and four wheel vehicles carried from distant cities and now buzzing about in random confusion.  I was reminded of the old sci-fi movie, Road Warrior. From the top of Ibex Pass, Jodi and I were treated to one of the finest stretches of road we have ever experienced.  A long, gradual decline led down into the Amargosa River valley closed off to the surrounding world by high, layered volcanic mountain ranges and sedimentary peaks and ridges.      To the NE, Tecopa looked green and busy, but we were headed for Shoshone--a good thing, too.  After several miles of rolling through old deposits of the ancient river--gray to white rounded lumps and curving washes--we entered the town.  Besides some sort of government facility and a Catholic church on an alkali hill top, the first thing to greet us was C'est si Bon--Espresso and Internet Cafe--hoooray!  We brake for espresso.  Could life get any better?      It did when we met the proprietor, David.  A warm, friendly man, he gave us a nice place to camp and a delicious strawberry smoothie.  We pitched our tent in a thick grove of tamarisk trees sighing gently in the breeze, overhead a model "tin-man" constructed out of tin cans.      David kept the hospitality flowing with offers of food, a place to shower, a key for access to a bathroom.  All of this in a quiet and quaint little town owned by the same family for over 100 years.  The founder's great grand nephew cooked and served our meal that night in the Crowbar Cafe just down the street from C'est si Bon.   After one of the best veggie burritos we'd ever had, we waddled back to our camp in the tamarisk trees.  Before bed, we got side-tracked by David and talked for a couple of hours in his cafe.  He had closed down shop, so it was just the three of us.  He showed us around.  He had totally rebuilt this old train station, which itself had been moved from a now defunct town a few miles up the road.  It was a comfortable place to sit and talk about our lives and the events of the world.  We lingered over the table in the flickering candle light.  Finally, too tired to keep our eyes open, we dragged ourselves back to our tent in the singing trees.  Tomorrow we faced one of the biggest passes on the route and our entrance into Death Valley National Park.  We were both really excited.  My knees ached some, but they hadn't exploded and only ached a bit when I squatted.  Tomorrow would be a test, Salsberry Pass. 
   We had a long and beautiful climb to the pass.  Cars were so infrequent we often felt the road was built for us alone.  We pushed hard and soon found ourselves bathed in sweat.  From the heat generated on some of the climbs and the chill of some of the nights and mornings, I was starting to call this the "Freeze or Fry" tour.  From the top of the pass, we were treated with one of the great experiences of our lives: the fifteen mile drop into Death Valley. The sensory and emotional flood that this dry landscape evoked in us is hard to describe.  This descent is one of those experiences that, afterward, I can't imagine my life without.  We dropped at a steady but not too quick pace into this massive sink, two hundred miles long and the lowest point in North America: Telescope Peak mantled in snow, alluvial fans, runnels, gullies, canyons, rip-saw ridges and peaks, oceans of air and light opened up to us with each bend of the road.  I gasped, hollered, laughed out loud.  I was shot-through by a giddy light-headedness of pure joy.  The hard climb followed by such a gift, a reward of the quest.  Vast, awesome, unreal, we reveled in the experience and floated into the valley below. We had another brief stretch of rough pavement, but then it improved.  We spun merrily along the ancient shores of the long-gone Lake Manley and submerged ourselves in the golden light of late afternoon.     We thought for a time that we might push on for Furnace Creek, but by 4pm we realized that would necessitate riding in the dark for more than an hour.  Why bother?  We camped off the side of the road, the summit of Telescope Peak over 11,000 ft. above, one of the great mountain walls on the continent.  We pitched camp and watched the moon drop behind the peak, the stars emerge, perfect and sharp.  We drank a fine merlot and attended the best church I've ever known.  Only one car passed as we set up camp; one passed as we were breaking camp.  The night was silent and utterly still. 
  Last night, I didn't sleep much.  It was a bit chilly, and my brain would just not shut down.  Often, I just put on my glasses and scrutinized the stars or brushed away the one fly in a thousand square miles.  We stayed in our bags as long as possible in the 34 deg. shade.  At long last the sun crept down the wall of Telescope peak and reached our bags.  We packed, and with numb toes, started for Furnace Creek. Shortly after starting, however, I knew something was wrong.  My left Achilles tendon was hurting a little.  The soreness increased as we went, inflaming a bad mood, a dark mood of foreboding in the process.  What was this?  Was I to overcome my knees only to be felled by my ankle, my Achilles heel?  I'd felt so strong the day before.  In retrospect, I've learned that I extended the reach to the pedals too far and so aggravated my tendon, a common mistake.  But what were we to do?  I was committed to a rest day at Furnace Creek; maybe that would be enough.  I doubted it.  I know how the tendon game is played. We purchased a few supplies at the little store in Furnace Creek and found a campsite just down the road.  As we were going about our chores, we noticed what appeared at first to be cloud banks drifting across the peaks. To the north, the valley was gone, just obliterated.  But these were not clouds in the sense of water vapor.  They were clouds of dust on the move from we knew not where.  At valley floor, the air was still and clear.  Once the sun started to drop behind the mountains, Jodi and I put on jackets in the chill and headed to the restrooms.  A few yards from camp, we were enveloped in a wash of warm air--so strange!  Then the dust hit.  The winds instantly spiked, carrying with them trillions of tiny dust particles.  We rubbed our eyes and ran back to camp to secure everything.  The omens were gathering.  We weighted and tied everything down and dove for the "shelter" of the tent.  We had something of a windbreak in a stand of tamarisk trees, but still the gale raged much of the night.  And we ate grit.  Ultra-fine powdery grit filtered through the netting and settled onto our bags, into our hair, into our noses, lips, teeth.   Aeolus gave us a sound thrashing that night.  I read Tony Hillerman and watched dust particles filter past my headlamp beam. 
The stove was broken.  More portents.  I'd have to go find some witches to see if Birnam wood had come to Dunsinane!  Fortunately, the stove was still usable.  I brooded some then brewed some.  The coffee was the needed tonic and provided a little chemical optimism.  It was really a great little stove--an MSR Dragonfly. We lounged in the warmth (mid 70's) and talked with people drawn to our strange vehicle while I cleaned the bike and puttered around.  We met the executive chef for the two restaurants in the area, the Furnace Creek Ranch (low end) and Furnace Creek Inn (high end), although everything costs a lot in this remote location.  The chef told us that his previous job had been in Fairbanks, Alaska.  Talk about going from the freezer to the frying pan.  He said that, overall, Death Valley was much more livable.  Jodi got to talk food and nutrition--oh, happy day!  We decided to eat out at the Inn. One problem: The dress code.  Jodi called ahead to see what could be done.  She explained our circumstances and said they could hide us in a remote corner of the restaurant--whatever was needed.  This was a resort where the rooms start at $250 a night, a pretty rarefied atmosphere for these road-ragged cyclists.  Still, the dinner sounded like fun.  The staff said they could accommodate our scruffy selves.  We did shower, however. That evening, we put on our best clothes--exactly what we'd been wearing for the last ten days--strapped the lights onto the trike and pedaled up to the Parthenon a mile up the road.  We rolled up to the elegant stone building at about 6 pm and looked for a valet, but he was elsewhere, his station abandoned.  He must have known we were coming.  We locked the rig up to a railing and ascended to the inner sanctum.  Subdued lighting and rustic yet tasteful furnishings stretched out along the front room.  Acutely aware of the juxtaposition of our less-than-tasteful dinner dress (Jodi looked far better than I) and not really giving a damn, we approached the receptionist's desk.  Prim, proper, prune-ish, the obviously disgusted woman behind the counter could barely contain her contempt.  Jodi said, "We have 6 o'clock reservations for dinner." "Well, you know," she intoned, "there is a dress code."  "Oh, we know, but we called ahead, and they're ready for us."  "Well...all right."  We then unloaded a pannier and seat bag on her and swaggered into the bar.  I ordered a nearly $5 beer and sat down in the lounge with Jodi to wait for the dining room to open.  I was having a blast.  We sipped the beer and watched how the "beautiful" people live.  Pretty nice.  But staying in a place like this would never give us a story of camping in a dust storm.  Such lodgings have their benefits, but I'd never give up the challenges of the road for them.  For a night or two, however?  Hmmm.... The host did indeed seat us in a far corner, which was quite nice with a view on a cactus garden outside.  The host and our server were both interested in our adventures.  The waiter, in fact, was a cyclist himself and so quite sympathetic to our situation.  We had a delectable dinner: two kinds of bread and three kinds of butter, egg plant parmesan for Jodi; for me, grilled Bambi (venison) from New Zealand in a "cherry-berry reduction sauce" with herbed mashed potatoes and asparagus spears.  We sipped merlot and contemplated our adventures.  Dessert was a hot banana chocolate bread with sauteed bananas and intense chocolate ice cream, plus two complementary chocolate truffles that we saved for later.  I drank most of the wine.  Life was just great AND expensive.  Well, what the hell are Platinum cards for, anyway? With a hoot and a holler, we descended from Mt. Olympus, for mere mortals cannot long endure the abode of the gods.   In camp, I contemplated the next day.  I did not have a lot of faith in my ankle, but I was more at peace with whatever would happen.
