We would make the run to Stovepipe Wells, and, if my ankle allowed it, start up the grade toward Townes Pass, one of the highest in the park.  Our plan was to camp about halfway up at Emigrant Junction and from there head up to Emigrant Pass, a little higher than Townes but not so steep.  We adjusted the pedals back, so maybe with this and careful pedaling technique, I could make it.  Either way, it had been a great adventure.
  We woke to a perfect morning and headed off into cool, clear desert light.  Soon, however, I could tell that my left ankle was not going to like it.  After a long, gradual climb before a drop to Stovepipe Wells,  I knew it was over.  To continue up Townes Pass would have been foolish in the extreme.  I was not in agony nor did I want or plan to be.  I learned this lesson years before: When tendons talk, listen.  I was, of course, deeply disappointed, and I know that Jodi was feeling our "failure" just as acutely.  We could not ask for better weather or scenery.  We wanted to keep riding forever, for the rest of our lives, to let our remaining days slide from one to the next, a seamless stream of human powered experiences, each day a new place, a new challenge, new people and insights.  But it was over, at least for now.  In the myths of ancient Greeks, the prophesies are never wrong; the portents and signs hold true, and so it was for our little odyssey.  We made our last turn and began the final descent to Stovepipe Wells. After a few yards, however, something felt strange.  The back end of the trike was swaying back and forth, the tail wagging the dog.  What the hell?  Ah, a flat tire, of course, the final nail in the sarcophagus of the journey, the ultimate sign from the road gods that we had reached the end of the line.  The trike and I were one, limping the last miles.  We stopped and fixed the tire.  No wind, bright sun--a nice place for roadside repairs.  A kindly ranger stopped to ask if we needed assistance, but we had things under control.  A few minutes later, we finished our descent. There was nothing to do now but engineer our escape.  We parked in the shade, ate lunch, and worked out a plan.  I would hitchhike to Ridgecrest over a hundred miles away, rent a truck and return for Jodi and the gear.  While I sat out in the warm sun (in the low 80's now), Jodi approached people getting gas.  She succeeded before I did.  There was not much traffic, so I could have been sitting out there for a long time.  Paul and Anita, mid-forties retro hippie types in a mid-80's VW camper, were to be my hosts.  Very nice people, they seemed to have trouble making ANY kind of decision. She wanted to go to Cuba.  They were thinking about going to Bishop and Mammoth but had no concept of the high, snowy passes and generally freezing temperatures they would encounter.  Jodi borrowed a term for people like this: flat-liners.  Finally, they decided that they would go north and could drop me in Lone Pine, a town with a truck rental agency. So at last, I climbed into their camper filled with two dogs, books, balls of yarn, bundles of sage, rocks, crystals, photos of various Eastern gurus, sticks, twigs and general chaos--classic.  We ascended the pass at a startling speed.  I was used to 4mph hill climbing; fifty miles per hour seemed impossible and disconcerting.  I was struck, too, by waves of disappointment again.  I wanted to be doing this on the tandem, Jodi and I using our own strength.  It was going too quickly.  I wanted to go slowly, linger in this dramatic landscape.  But the end was decided now.  I sat back and enjoyed the views and marveled at the power of internal combustion. We crested the Inyo mountains in the late afternoon and were presented with one of the clearest views I've ever had of the Sierras.  Mile upon mile of the snowy jagged crest marked the horizon.  I wished Jodi could see it.  Fifteen minutes before the U-Haul agency closed, I stepped through the doors.  The owner expected me, expected me not to make it.  We worked quickly through the paperwork, and as darkness poured into the Owen's Valley, I began the mountainous drive back into Death Valley.  By seven that night, I was sitting with Jodi in Stovepipe Wells. 
So it's over.  So what?  We learned a hard lesson about adjusting bikes.  We learned, too, about ourselves, our resolve, our strengths and weaknesses.  We learned about the landscape and some of the people.  We learned about sunlight and wind, dust and heat and cold, about warmth and climbing and the wild release of the descent through impossible desert canyons.  We learned that much of life is lived too quickly and that four miles per hour up a never-ending mountain side is just about right.
Enough of this. It's time to get ready and actually start the riding part. Tonight I will finish packing my gear, hope that I have everything, and force the box shut. Tomorrow night it's off to Montreal and an early flight to Vancouver on Tuesday. For those interested, the ride will take me west to east mostly following the Trans Canada highway. My goal is Sydney, but I have to finish by mid October. I'll be solo and camping most of the way. Onward!
I flew out of Montreal at 7:00 AM. My friend Jason picked me up in Vancouver. It was great to see him. We hiked up the Squamish Chief, followed by a sampling of the Howe Sound brewery. We were able to get the obligator photo at the waters edge (didn't dip anything though). It was nice to get to meet his friend Nola for the first time. They are now driving to Ontario for the fall. I'm looking forward to riding with them there. Tomorrow the riding begins!   
I met a couple riding home to Seattle who had ridden through Jasper and Banff parks, then down the more southern path on the return. It's always great to meet others having fun doing this.  The weather has been great so far. I won't say any more so as not to jinx myself.     
I had originally thought I might stop at Lytton, but I decided to go a little further. From Lytton the Trans Canada takes one up the Thompson river. I was amazed at the contrast from the Fraser. The scenery changed from lush high mountains to high desert sagebrush hills. It reminded me a lot of the Sevier valley in Utah. My first wildlife encounter came when I startled a coyote. I almost got caught in the small landslide it started as it scrambled up the hill to get away.     
The weather has been consistantly good. It starts off sunny then clouds over a bit. Next morning it is nice and sunny again. Last night was a little warmer than before. This is a great relief as my sleeping bag is a little light. Tommorrow could be a big day. I may try to ride to Revelstoke. I'll see how I feel.   
Tommorrow is Rogers Pass.       
I'm excited to ride into Yoho and Banff parks tommorrow. It will be my last day really climbing in the mountains. I wonder if Kicking Horse Pass will be like Rogers Pass was today. It's hard to convey how beautiful it is here. It will be sad to leave the mountains.       
Almost imediately out of the campsite I rode past some bighorn sheep. They were curious about me (maybe wondering if I was going to make the pass or not). The ride up through Yoho National Park to Kicking Horse Pass was beautiful. I actually had a bit of a tailwind! It did start to become obvious that I wasn't going to make Banff today. Lake Louise looked like a good option. Upon arrival in Lake Louise I found out that all camping was closed due to bear activity. They said there might be a few tent sites in a special area surrounded by electrical fence. I didn't think that sounded too fun. As room prices in Lake Louise are astronomical I decided that maybe I would ride down to Banff after all. Luckily I met Morgan, a cyclist doing the "Golden Triangle" route. He had stayed at the Castle Mountain Hostel the night before and thought it would have space. This meant only a 30km downhill / flat ride.  The clouds started to give way in the evening. It would be really nice to have a clear day before I leave the park.       
 
So what does someone riding cross-country do on their day off? Rent a mountain bike and go ride a trail of course. I had seen pictures of the Lake Minnewanka trail before and thought it looked nice. It was. For the most part it is a slightly rough singletrack following the lake shore. It was really fun and suprisingly different from my daily riding. The water around here really does have that crazy colour in all the pictures and everywhere you look is a stunning mountain backdrop. Tonight I'll relax a little and head into Calgary tommorrow.     
Maybe the best way to spend a day like this is with friends. Darrell and Alison Jones invited me to stay with them in Bragg Creek. Darrell rode out to meet me coming in from Banff. We had to climb back up into the mountains after descending, but I'll get it all back as downhill! It was a very nice day amidst much rennovation at Darrell and Alisons. We shared a nice lunch, dinner, beers, and a hot tub. 
The riding today was very lonely and boring. I guess I'll get used to it. There will be more of the same for a while. One thing that stood out are the grasshoppers. There are a lot of them all over the road and they are big! Another thing to get used to is the lack of services in some towns.     
Today I awoke to the tailwind I've been waiting for. I made really good time going into Medicine Hat. It's hard to believe how many grasshoppers there are here. I ran my errands in Medicine Hat and struck out for the Saskatchewan border. I met Sebastion, a French cyclist heading west. He had been battling fierce headwinds all across the praries. I felt bad for him, but not so bad that I couldn't secretly celebrate for myself. I reached the border around 4:00. There was an Alberta information centre, but nothing for Saskatchewan. I rode on in with no map. That was my first mistake. Actually my first mistake was believing the Alaberta info staff that the next campground was 50km up the road. I finally got to the Saskatchewan info centre after 40km. It was closed of course. I took the opportunity to steal a small map of the area from their phone book. It did not look promising for a campground in 10km. Eventually 50km further down the road I came to a place to camp. It was maybe a campground (at one time anyway). It did OK for the night. By the way, I did make it before dark.   
 
I started seeing prarie dogs today in addition to the grasshoppers. There are not as many as I might expect. One was standing guard by the side of the road. It was not doing a very good job as I got within ten feet before it seemed to notice me. I almost made it to Moose Jaw, camping about 30km to the west. There were some really nice people I met who gave me some stove fuel.   
I rode on and stayed in a campground in Indian Head. There was laundry here so I was able to get caught up on that. Since today was uneventful it gives me a chance to mention my wife, Susan. She has really supported me in this trip (as she does with everything I do). All of the times it seemed like a lot of trouble to do this she knew how important it was to me and didn't give me the option to back out. She is at home taking care of our house, animals, and finances (with one less paycheck). Every day I call to let her know I'm safe. She brightens my day if it's been bad, and listens with exitement if it's been good. I could not do this without her. I love you Susan.   
Although I don't have too many people to talk to out here I am sure to say hello to all the animals. The horses (and llamas!) seem interested in what I'm up to. They always come running up to the fence from wherever they are. Cattle always listen to what I have to say, but don't seem to grasp it well. There are lots of mosquitos and flies at night whenever I am setting up camp. It is very hard to cook dinner any time after 5:00 or so.     
 
The day started off well. I had the wind at my back and was riding fast. I made it to Brandon a lot faster than I hoped. The weather was perfect and the sun didn't seem as intense as usual. There were hardly any grasshoppers. I got a flat late morning, but it wasn't a big deal - a staple which I didn't see. The problems started around 4:30. I got another flat, this time in the rear tire. I didn't have a new tube anymore so I had to patch one. I used the one from the flat this morning as it would have a very distinct hole from the staple. Everything went well and I was rolling again. Ten minutes later I was losing air already. I pulled the tire off again and re-checked for something causing it. Nothing. I patched up the other tube I had and was on my way again. Not for very long though. Both tubes definitely had slow leaks. Standing on the side of the road in the wind and passing traffic I couldn't find any air escaping (and therefore no place to patch). Did I mention that I fix bikes for a living? Things were starting to look a bit grim, but luckily Tom, who was returning from shuttling a train crew to Brandon, came and offered me a ride to civilization. I ended up in Winnipeg at Olympia Cycle and Ski. They were extremely helpful. I was able to fix myself up, get their advice on Winnipeg, use their pump to make sure I was fully inflated, and use their internet.  Tommorow I will ride toward Ontario, hopefully with the wind at my back and air in my tires.
Outside of Winnipeg I passed the geographical center of Canada. The halfway point of my trip won't come for another few hundred miles. The road today was fairly flat with longer stretches between towns. Approaching the Ontario border one rides through Sandilands forest reserve. It looks like a popular snowmobiling area, but is pretty deserted now. There was a slight headwind today. I outraced a thunderstorm into Falcon Lake. I hope that tomorrow brings clearer skies.     
 




   After tourist info and a sip of water, I was on my way, under the cloudy sky but so humid and tropical air of Auckland. Where I'd go was a problem. I wanted to crash, and fast, and I got indications for the nearest campsite but got it all wrong as I swirled around "round-about" those English like intersections.So confusing when you don't know, and when you are looking at the traffic (even the stirring wheel is on the wrong side of the car!) Well, what a cultural shock to ride on the left side of the road!!! Geez! I felt like I was learning again to ride! But drivers were mostly very friendly and generous with their space and I managed. After 25 km that were supposed to be only 10, I found myself at my first campsite and got acquainted with the other campers, mainly cyclists and backpackers. The campsite is equipped of a full kitchen, all you gotta provide is your pots and utensils. The washrooms are equipped of a hair drier, so much for not bringing my hair spray!!!! :-) (And my make-up)and wahers and driers for laundry. I had a nap and woke up cold, and with the need to go change money and go buy food for dinner. I had lunch with the chocolate bar my sister sent me. Though it was yummy, I need some other vitamins and minerals!!! I am sure planning on having a full night of sleep tonight and make a decision about my travelling mode tomorrow to reach the south island. I mean, train and ferry or airplane? I am not sure I want to do another 11 hours of motorized transportation... Talk to you later! Had dinner with this French couple that's been on their tandem for the last 7 months, across USA, Thaiti and now NZ, Australia and coming will be South East Asia. How impressive and inspiring!!! They shared their bottle of NZ wine, said that the French wine was better, and I shared my chocolate from France and everybody was happy!
     Getting closer to town I had the surprise of my life, the very Canadian and Quebecois Cirque du Soleil was in town!!! Proud Canadian and Quebec flag were floating on the top of the big tent. Small world even if I am at the other end of the world... Eventually I reached my destination, the America's Cup Village where I stopped to the visitor center and purchased my train ticket to Wellington for tomorrow and the ferry for the next day. I didn't spend much time downtown. Part of me wanted to linger and shop a bit, but in a cycling attired and worrying about my bike was not much fun. I purchased a phone card that I would use as well for the internet and checked out my mail. The way back offered me the opportunity to check out my endurance and power as I had to climb this one challenging hill, where you wished you had a grannier than granny gear but I made it. The Great South Road happened to be a big boulevard, busy and used by lots to exit the city. I had to be on the look out for myself. But I made it and gladly sipped on a Pepsi back at the campsite. I had to return on the bike for groceries after that and purchased an all made up Ceasar salad along with couscous, a favorite of mine at home. Yummy. I didn't have any desire to socialize that night and soon retreated in my tent. This older gent from England made a few attempts at starting a conversation with me but sorry, man, no luck tonight, the shop is closed. Wow! Things are going fast. Not that I am in any rush but I feel like I have to experience in the fast lane to see everything I want to see...  I will probably relax with the days going by and once I am in quieter places. Lots of traffic here. And lots of campers in the campground.  It is 8:30 Pm and I am ready to sleep. Had a long day cycling, chain tatoos behind the leg, sunburn on one ankle where I forgot to spread the suntan lotion. You really gotta be careful with the sun in here. It is strong indeed.
  
   First, the captain announced that there were dolphins playing with the waves. Looking down on the water, you could see dozens of dolphins coming to play, two by two. It was so exciting!!! It was a very good moment.I tried to take a picture of them like many of my fellow tourists but they were quick the little buggers! They made the show for 10 minutes and left. The scenery was quite nice, untouched, and some sailing boats around. Mountains, high ones. What a spectacle!  Arrived in Picton, I lost Ed and that was ok, because even if he was really nice, I wanted some time to think about what I would do. I stopped in a bakery and bought a very yummy chicken sandwich with the freshest grain bread I ever had. Then I started cycling. South. I thought I'd cycle to the first town, Blenheim and decide myself tomorrow. It would give me a short day cycling so I thought I'd tour around the wineries and also check out the quilt store, as I saw it advertised on a flyer at the ferry terminal. Stopped at a juice bar and got myself tempted by a very yummy and thick juice, and bought some fruits. The riding was nice, as I was enjoying a strong tailwind. I checked in a a campsite recommended from the visitor info bureau, and I didn't regret it. Away from all the other campers, I found myself by a quiet river under a large tree (weeping something) in between fields of sheeps. Only it was a little far from the toilets and kitchen but I loved it...    After unloading and pitching my tent, I left for my ride, and soon after stopped in a winery where a wine glass was pushed in my direction for a free tasting... All white wine, and even a dessert wine... That was fun, and after that I decided not to stop in all the wineries because I wouldn't be able to come back to the campsite...    The ride took me farther than I thought and I came back by 6:30pm tired and hungry. Cooked myself some nice pasta with tomato sauce and talked with the other campers before retiring for the night   
   The first climb of this tour took some of my breath away and I was all sweat, but I did it. I had to find some good reasons to stop and taking pictures was a good one... 40 km after leaving I got hit by strong headwind that slowed me down considerably. All of a sudden, I was fighting to go at 10 km/hr. Geez! That was not fun. I was getting frustrated and angry at myself for choosing "clockwise" but carried on. I crossed path with a few cyclists going in the other direction and they seemed to have a jolly time. One stopped and told me to turn around!!! No I said, I'm going this way!!! I carried on for 2 km more that took a long time, and then I said that's it! I can't do it. And I turned around, climbing back what I just descended and all of a sudden my speed was 35-40 km/hr in the flat!!! I stopped in Seddon for tea and cake and met up with the same guy that was cycling with a support van, along with a dozen people. We talked about cycling, New Zealand, Canada, USA, power outages in California, parrots and everything in between. I got coaxed to stop here for the nightwith them and reassess the next day. Which I did. Talked with a lot of nice people, sipped on tea, had a delightful shower, wrote my journal,went for groceries and took it easy. We returned to the tea house after dinner for a drink and retired in our tent when the rain started...
         It was a  long day cycling. I got some headwind but not as much as yesterday. My average speed is the witness: 17-18 km/hr. When I finally made it to Kaikoura, I pitched my tent at the campground and went to town to do internet work. Well the connection was so slow that I got frustrated very fast. It was when I came out of there that I met this couple from Holland, one guy with a bob trailer and his girlfriend, and they have been on their bike for the last 2.5 year!!! They left Holland to Turkey, then travelled east: Iran, middle east, India, Nepal China, and South East Asia. They are now in New Zealand for a few months... That is quite impressive ot me. I felt like having some company tonight and invited them at my campsite but they declined. They travel very cheap, see, they sleep in the bush, filter their water from rivers and live quite cheaply... The motorcamp in Kaikoura is a brand new facility, brand new turf and brand new kitchen for the guests to use. For 9$NZ I thought it was pretty good. I pitched my tent on the outskirt of the campsite so I could have a view on the mountains when I'd get up and hopefully I would get a quiet night.That evening I had a good look at my map and started to do some planning. I have been looking for white gas for my stove for a while now and haven't been able to find any. Mind you there are a lot of services around so far anyways. I want to cross over to the west coast now and hope to get away from the head winds.  Went to bed by 8:30PM and fell asleep quite fast...
   I was really counting on a bottle of Coke at the junction where I would turn towards the West coast, but nothing. Bare. Just a deserted rest area. No picnic table, even. I was disconcerted because I was running out of water too with at least 20 km to go in the heat of noon time. There was a RV at the rest area and I asked them for water, and they gave me some with some reluctance. The man was reluctant. His wife insisted that he put some ice in the water, which I was thankful for. It was sooo hot! And dry. The creeks were all dry, I couldn't even refresh. I would say around 35 degrees. Maybe more. After a snack and some water, I carried on, this time against the wind. Bad news. The cars were very scarce and the views quite nice but I had to focus on the cycling and to remain hydrated.     I inherited  a flat tire on an uphill as a gravel truck was passing me. Great! No shade nearby to protect myself so I did the job and carried on against the wind, always. 9-12 km/hour was my speed, so much for bragging about the speed of 28-30 km I liked to do, loaded or not... It was frustrating but also a bit scary to be so remotely located, on my own and at high risk of dehydration. Heat stroke can hit at any time. I was worried of running out of water but I kept drinking, because I had to. At 80 km on my computer, I was waiting for the town to appear in front of my eyes but it didn't. Just yet another hill to climb that kept me discouraged with the strong wind that was pushing me backwards. The views around were astounding but again I was exhausted and overdosed on sunshine. Soon after there was a fun windy downhill and found myself in town.    The motorcamp is basic but cheap too: 5$ I pitched the tent in the deserted field had a shower to get rid of the grit acquired from changing the flat tire, and went in town to buy some food. Had pizza for dinner, as a treat. Crunchie bar for dessert. And my long time wanted Diet Coke. Yummy. I felt dehydrated, and my urine was dark yellow. I must have drank 5 or 6 big water bottles today. So I keep drinking. Not many people in the campsite, it was a quiet evening and night.
     The last few km were long as I was against the wind, and I was tired from the days before. Maybe still recovering from dehydration.. But I did it, arrived by 11:00, or shortly past. I checked in at the backpaacker hostel because it looked nice and conveniently located in town. The town looks like a  swiss village, and the hostel looked like a chalet. Small yard for camping but I asked if it was quiet around and she said yes. So I rented my tent space and started pitching. There was a  german guy in the garden and a bull dog laying there, sleeping in the heat of the day. Had a hunger attack and made myself a cheese sandwich and heard snoring in the garden. Wow, I thought, this guy is snoring loud!!! Few times I was looking and the guy seemed like doing some reading. After a while he made the remark that it was the dog snoring and not him... Ah ah ah!!!! That was too funny. A snoring dog... I had a shower, and did an hour of web page work, replied to few e-mails, and went in town. The afternoon went slowly, it was way too hot to do anything but hang out in the shade. Had dinner and then watched a movie on the VCR- The Green Mile. That was a very good movie. Everybody else went to the hot springs, and as for me, I couldn't understand that by this heat you would like to soak in hot water. My tent site got invaded by 2 more tents including some people that speak real loud. I wasen't very happy as I wanted to rest and catch up with my sleep. Never again, I promised myself, I would go to a backpacker. Fortunately I had some ear plugs for the night...
   As I headed west I could notice how the mountains gradually becamee greener and forested, and the air was becoming more humid. Funny transition. Eventually I found myself all wet from a  shower. It actually felt good to be rained on. I didn't even bother putting on my rain jacket as I wasen't cold at all, still climbing and working hard. Welcome to the Wet West Coast, I seemed to hear from the sky... Duh!!! I met a lot of cyclists going the opposite direction, most of them were sagged doing the Arthur Pass and the Lewis Pass circuit through Christchurch. That was before the rain. The bugs seemed to find me everytime I stopped today. I was glad I had some repellent (bought yesterday). The wind found me as well today. Head wind of course. The the rain found me... Gradually it started to downpour, especially on the pass, and on the 6 km downhill I had to coveer till my destination, Maruia Springs.I put on my jacket before I got too cold and my shoe covers. The way downhill was nice, I didn't have to pedal and didn't have to drink from my water bottle, as I had all the water I wanted. It was very lush green around, beautiful sceneries but I had to focus on the riding.     Maruia Springs announced itself and I checked in for a tent site. I rushed in the washroom to pour some hot water on my cold hands. Pitching the tent in the rain is not my favorite activity, as as soon as I put the ground sheet down, there was a puddle of water there and then  my tent got all wet and then there was a puddle on the floor. I learned quickly what sandflies were and what they wanted (your skin) as they invited themselves in as soon as I opened the door. I let few swear words out. It was a tough one all together. I rushed in the hot springs for some warming up and to forget it all up for few minutes. Beside the smell and the staining of my silver ring, it was wonderful. I stayed there until my skin looked like a prune, showered and then I had to face again my wet tent and the sandflies. Once settled in my tent, it wasen't that bad... My sleeping bag warmed me up and I dozed for half an hour. When I woke up I made myself some dinner, standing up and fighting with the sandflies that clouded around me. I was the only one there until a couple came in but kept to themselves. Who would like to camp in the rain anyways? The campsites in NZ rarely include picnic tables in their pieces of furniture. It's quite weird. So I had a bla dinner, pasta with a mushroom soup and tuna, atanding up and dancing around to keep the bugs away. The food went in nicely. I needed the energy. After dinner, dishes and brushing my teeth, I felt pretty sedate and found refuge in my sleeping bag, for the night. My legs were sore from all the climbing I did today. Let's hope for a sunny day tomorrow, ok???
  I have long to say about where I slept last night. I slept well after chasing all the sandflies from my tent. In the morning I woke up having to pee and I didn't want to leave the warmth of my sleeping bag as it was quite cool out there. The good news was that it wasen't raining. The bad news was that the sandflies were  waiting for me as I went out and didn't leave me alone until I was on the road. The breakfast at the lodge was 15$ and included all the greasy and low carb stuff. I passed, had a light breakfast of leftovers and decided to have something in the next town. The packing was aweful with having to wring everything and  to pack it up wet.Being on the road again felt comforting to me and it was all downhill, so that was good. It went very fast, and soon enough I was sitting in front of a cup of tea and 2 dry and almost burnt toasts.They offered me some vegemite and sorry you guys, I am Canadian and vegemite tastes like... yeast. I am not putting that on my toasts...  The clouds had gradually lifted and  given place to the sunshine, however it was cool. Ahhhhhh!   Leaving Spring Junction, the road took me uphill for about 8 km, which gave me a little sweat, wearing long sleeves this morning. This shirt was however nice on the downhill afterwards as it was partly shaded.  And it took me to Reefton, where I decided I would carry on all the way to the West Coast to Greymouth, which would give me  140 km for the day. The rationale to that decision was that I was having a good day, I was going downhill all day losing more than 600 m  over 70 km and I could enjoy the servicess that a big town had to offer including drying my clothes and buying some food cheaply, and also do my banking. Well I forgot we were Saturday today, and the bank would be closed to change my traveller's checks tomorrow.  140 km takes a long time to cycle. I will admit to that much. And the services in between the last section were inexistent as all of them beside pubs were closed. I was hoping for a break, a bottle of Coke, and maybe some chocolate. I saved my money (by default) and kept cycling. Gradually the valley I was cycling into enlarged and the forest got farther and farther, Lots of cows and lots of opened fields towards the end. And the wind became stronger, increasingly.  Head wind that is. Ohhhh.... again I made it to Greymouth shortly after 5pm, after having spent 7 hours on the saddle. Looking for places to stay I chose the backpacker hostel called "Global Village". (Believe it or not, I chose a backpacker)  I saw pictures of it at the visitor information and the philosophy of the hostel seemed quite nice. I checked it out and after 140 km, you don't want to fart around for a place to crash, and you are sure not too fussy. I had pizza for dinner tonight as a treat, after putting the tent and gear to dry and taking a shower. That was yummy and very fast to cook. I planned my day off as... a really nice cycling day trip for tomorrow and got to bed early that night.  There were people not far from my tent around a fire that were giggling and chatting, and I was worried they would be roudy but I put on my eaar plugs and settled down nicely.
   So scenic. I got real excited. I truly believed I was in paradise.    Though there was a bit of work involved, I was happy. The flowers, the mountains, the ocean, everything was just perfect! The ups and downs, the cliffs, the ocean views, all that lasted for 14 km. I stopped many times to take pictures, just because I felt inspired. Then the road took me inland again with some rolling hills and I faced a bit of a headwind. It also got a bit cooler as the clouds had rolled in. Arriving into the final destination, Punakaki, I went directly for the vistas where I took some pictures and ate my yummy Crunchie bar. The views were nice but not too surprising to me as I already saw it in picture so I didn't lingeer there too much. It was infested with tourists also which took away some of the experience.      The visitor center featured some cave interpretation and had as well some track information. (hiking trails). I reflected about what I was missing out by sitting on my bike, as I didn't have hiking gear. I was wondering whether it was possiible to incorporate those activities or maybe it was just better to come back on another trip and explore in a different way. The way back home, using the same route, was different to my eyes. First I noticed that I had a tail wind. YESSSSSSS!!!!! Tail wind! Finally! Thank you thank you!!!!     I met a few cyclo-tourists going the other direction of course, and we just waved hi and goodbye. Again this was a lonesome ride, not too many people to talk to and to share with. I resigned to think that it may be like that for the rest of my trip as everybody have a destination in mind and have their own pace. It is difficult to match that. If ever it happens that I can match that with someooone else, fine. But I am all right on my own. Not sad about it, I hope this is not the message I convey. Not even disappointed.  The tail wind made me happy and made me pedal harder on the uphills so I don't lose my speed. I kept looking at the lush green mountains and thinking that the monkeys would be real happy here. The only reason why there is no monkey here is that they haven't been swiming from Indonesia as of yet. They don't know what they are missing. The evening has been leisurly, after a nice salad and couscous dinner. Decided to cycle some more in the evening to catch a glimpse of the sunset over the Tasman sea...     
   The second part was much more scenic as I could see the mountains with some snow on its peaks, and I weaved through national parks, protected lands, up some hills and down crossing rivers, crossing twice on a shared car-train, one way narrow bridge.That was cool and the cars patiently waited that I am through before passing me.    The "highway" was pretty quiet, some of the time I didn't see any car for 5 minutes. I have heard some birds songs that were quite pretty. I wonder what those birds look like... I made it to my campsite by 4:00 PM. It was a relief, as the end was getting quite hilly and I was geting tired. There is a tavern on one side, where I paid for my campsite and there is a teahouse/museum/small farm/whatever across the street, where I purchased some pepsi.    This guy is quite un-ordinary, he has a giant sandfly hidden in the roof of his building. Every morning he gets the giant sandfly out for the tourists to see from the road and every night he gets her in to make sure she won't get cold... The inside of the museum is full of little saying to its wall. I retained one in my journal: "Save the forest, eat possums".For those of you that need explanations, possums are the racoons of Down Under. They don't feast off camper's leftovers but on tree bark. They are nocturnal animal so you never see them unless the are road kill. They were introduced to New Zealand from Australia which was apparently a very bad move, so I have been told... Ahhhh! Pepsi! I am on my own here camping and 2 couples at the hostel beside where I go to the washroom and use the kitchen facilities. It would be nice to see some cyclists sometimes, and even share the campsite! I saw 5 or 6 again today, but all of them going in the opposite direction. The nerve... That is it for the day, had a nice pasta dinner and had some cookies for dessert and I couldn't stop eating them and I ate it all... The stars appeared one by one tonight in the sky, it was quite the show, and as I fell asleep listening to 2 owls calling each other...
   When I went to the visitor center in search for info and for accomodation, they told me that the town was filling up quite fast and to hurry up to get a spot, even for camping. So the first backpacker I found there was a camp spot available and I took it. It's cramped, it's busy and my tent spot is on a piece of lawn as big as... well a sheep would finish it in 1 hour! Not much ambiance at the hostel I think. Nobody talking to anybody. I eventually went to town, bought some food, made dinner and ate reading my guide book. The first thing you notice of Franz Josef is the constant helicopter landing and taking off for the tourists in it to enjoy. It is quite irritating and one wished they could stop sometimes... After dinner I went back to town for an internet session and went for a walk to watch the sunset which was terrific tonight. Lots of pink hues in the sky, that was awesome. I got terribly bitten by the sandflies and it was getting cold, so I missed the grand finale, but oh well.    I am exhausted tonight and I can't make a decision about what I will do tomorrow. Will sleep first. OK. Bye.
   Met up with some tandem riders from Kansas city and we talked about cycling and other things for a while. Spent the evening watching tv after eating yucky pizza, and talking with the others in the tv room. A lot of people think I am quite brave to cycle all those hills in NZ. Those are the people that go sky diving, bungee jumping and what else...I am trying also to figure out what I will do in the next few days. Duh. Cycling. But I have only 70$ cash left in NZ currency and no bank for 4 days. So I am examining the options...
  
   Got myself organized at the campsite and 2 german guys came in and set up close to me. Cyclists!!! Finally! The grocery store was very expensive and restricted in fruits and veggies and I did my best to buy stuff I could use. I had less and less money and had to be careeful. The little shop didn't take credit card. I also met at the campsite one of those cyclists that want to check out whether the earth is round. This one is from Switzerland, and has cycled from home, through the middle east, then India, Pakistan, Nepal and Tibet, and he said he ate Ramen Noodles for 3 months in Tibet because there is no food there.2.5 years later he is in NZ. Very impressive. Along with a couple from England, our little group had dinner together and we inherited of the leftover turkey of a senior group that were at the motorcamp. We also had some leftover cake that was quite yummy.I got so stuffed because I made myself a big dish of pasta. There is a bit of guilt involved here but I thought it would be ok because I would have a big day tomorrow. 80 km of nice views and 14 km of hell... So, I am clean, I am fed, nails cut, laundry done, rested, all that's left is to climb that hill. And live to tell about it... Good night!!!
   After the bridge there must have been a 12 or 13% gradee for 1.5 to 2 km; it was really tough and my knees could feel the load I was carrying, as well as my lower back. I was sweating. You should have seen the eyes of the tourists on the tour bus that was going the opposite direction. All the chins were down on their laps. Haast Pass is only 591 m high, the lowest of the passes on the South Island. The grade was bad but got better and I found myself enjoying the views and gradually it stopped raining.The yellow wildflowers got quite stunning and the creek water was turquoise. Then all of a sudden, it was it! Haast Pass, the top and it wasen't going any higher. Geez, that's it? Just when I was starting to have fun? I met a couple of Dutch cyclist on recumbents and going South too. I was glad to see them, I wanted to talk to them a bit but I think that I intruded on their privacy. So I carried on.    The downhill was not too long as I was going to 300 m not to sea level and found myself gradually emerging of the clouds and the low pressure system and as I was exiting Mount Aspiring National Park, the sun came out! There was now a healthy tail wind and my bike computer started to work again. It doesn't like the rain I guess.    The riding was really nice, the geography was changing gradually leaving the rainforests behind for something drier. Mountains, still, high ones, but without the forests. Arriving to Makarura, I was disappointed to still find very little services. Just teahouse, and a very small store some internet access, and camping and cabins. There was barely a banana in the store. I didn't want to stop here, I still had energy to carry on and I wanted to enjoy the nice tail wind I had.I talked to few people in the teahouse's parking lot as some cyclists heading North were thinking about what to do seeing the rain falling on Haast.They were also facing the wind which made the riding difficult. I was sure glad to head South with that screaming tailwind. It was giving me a firm push up the hills, and no efforts on the downhill.I was singing out loud and calling the sheeps around. BEEEEEEE I found the DOC campsite on the edge of Lake Wanaka and it was very windy. It dried my stuff in no time. It is rather cold though. But very little sandflies. My poor feet were like prune when I freed them of the soggy cycling shoes. Found my watch unpacking tonight, it was in my sleeping bag. Had dinner of Ramen noodles, a Crunchie Bar for dessert and an orange and cookies for 2nd and 3rd dessert. Ahhhh! The great outdoors... Makes you hungry. So enough for tonight. As I write this last entry in my journal I am itching everywhere from all the sandflies bites. Not pleasant at all. And still finding some live ones in my tent... Grrrrrrr! Should start an import-export business.
   It passes at 405 m at its highest then descends to Lake Hawea on a windy scenic road to the lake. Funny thing is as much as I had a tail wind few kms behind, I started on a light headwind at first that increased as the lake uncovered. Weird, uh?      From the neck to the city of Lake Hawea it was much hillier, and some of the hills were quite steep! I met up with other cyclists heading North wishing them luck by psychic power as I knew they'd get rain, and stopped in the little town for sport drink. The way to Wannaka was up and down, lots of it and same story, some of them steeper than other. My front speed shifter is acting out and when I want to shift to the smaller ring sometimes, it won't happen. So I just have to take off my show from the cleat and kick it a bit and it will change. But it is not always practical as sometimes I need a lower gear and I need it now...as I lose mementum quickly. The other problem on my bike is my left handle bar shifter grip that is ripping off. It has now become an antique part and I couldn't find it in the US and I am now expecting to have the same problem here. But hopefully in Queenstown... The first thing I did when I made it to Wanaka was to stop at the visitor center, where people book huts for tramping (hiking) and get info about the different hikes around. Well I wanted to know where the internet stations were in town and they looked at me weird... Well, I know it sounded a bit odd hence I am surrounded by beauty and in a district of conservation office. But the girl has to do it, so... And then I asked about keas, the mountain parrots to see if I had a chance to see them around here. Well, I would have to meet them in their habitat on the glacier around Mount Aspiriing. It would be a full day trip with the bus. Too bad. Can't do it. Next time. Then I checked in at the campsite which has a hiker-biker section and met up with 2 other cyclists coming from Invercargill by bus today. They were very friendly. Morris is coming from Auckland (a local) and Cindy is from Boston. We had a brief chat and they were off to town, so I pitched my tent and left for some more cycling as I only did 54 km today and wanting more. By that point it was very sunny and hot and the views around this part of Lake Wanaka were astounding. It is very dry here. I headed on the west side of the lake and followed the road leading to Mount Aspiring for 12 km, to Glendhu Bay.    I had fa-bu-lous views all the time, passing a hiking trail, a few farms, a couple of donkeys, sheeps, a winery (looked the other way) and the views of the lake were forcing me to stop often and take pictures. It was hilly and the wind pushed me all the way there, I had a blast. The way back was head wind but I managed ok without the weight of my packs. Then I headed in town and found the internet place. 2 hours on the computer, in the shade until I had a hunger attack so I had to go. Then I hit the groceery store. My god! First real grocery store in 7 days. It was food paradise. Great fruits and veggies section. For once. The bulk section was great too. I found everything I wanted at a great price and came back to town with a full pack inclluding Pepsi and chips. The shower felt great and I had dinner with Morris and Cindy joined in later. I am so thrilled by this day.   
   South of that lake was Cromwell, my halfway point, and the fruit orchards. Peaches, apricots, apples, pears. Veggies too.I stopped in one of those fruit stands and bought 2 plump peaches and some prunes. Yummy. In Cromwell, I stopped for a break and found a bakery. Bought some Coke and a muffin and sat with this biker- motorcyclist that is; he is a Kiwi from Wellington. Looks like Kevin Costner :-)  We talked for quite a while, sharing stories of the road and he showed me his pictures of a bungee jump he did in Queenstown. That looked impressive. I enjoyed his company but after a while it was time to say goodbye, and head West towards Queenstown and him East toward Christchurch. Awwwwww, bye, Kevin Costner! From Cromwell it got better and better. I started getting side wind and then tail wind and entered Kawarau Gorge.    Dried mountains, semi desertic, rocky. The road. And on the left side, in the bottom, this sometimes wild sometimes quiet turquoise creek that would twist and turn. That ws great!!! Apparently Cindy and Morris have been discouraged to ride this section, but to me it was just a hint that it would be interesting... In fact, it was spectacular!!! Lots of roadkills though, and sometimes I had to wind my way around them: rabbits and hedgehogs especially. As I climbed and got on a higher plateau, wineries and vineyards got more and more frequent and were adding more beauty to the panorama. Then came the bungee zone. A bridge over the creek. And lots of people paying to jump off the bridge... I watched some people jump and got all carried on by the adrenaline rush, just for watching...    And I continued my journey. The 80 km mark... then 90...I was running out of steam with the afternoon heat. The 100 km was worse. And my bike was playing games with me, moody with the gear changing especially on the harder hills. So I had to grind on a higher speed than I wanted to bargain. The kick to the thing trick was not always possible... Then the traffic got heavier and the mountains more spectacular. Here I was in Queenstown!!! Wow! The Whistler of NZ! I've been coming from far and here I was!!! I was tired and headed to the visitor center for info about motorcamps. Another hill later, I pitched the tent on a potentially noisy campsite. It was 5:00 PM. And all I wanted to do was to go around and have a look even though I was very tired. There were paragliders doing circle in the sky nearby and the gondola taking people to the sky for a nice view. For tonight I chose a visit to the Kiwi and birdlife Park for a view of the infamous keas I wanted to see and the kiwis as well. As I entered to the gift shop to pay the netrance fee, I had left the door opened and a duck came right behind me and entered like he was living here! The ranger escorted him out, before he gets into messy trouble.    So I saw the keas. Bigger birds than I imagined. Green and the inside of their wings are orange. Those one were born in captivity and are in a tastful aviary outside. Very nice. And about the kiwis... We had to enter a dark room to view them as those guys are nocturnal animals. No wings. Long, very fine beak that sure could help me with those tent pegs!!! And a round body a bit smaller than a basketball. They are funny! It took the help of the ranger to show me where they were on the display. That was soo cool!!!! Then I headed into town, did some internet work, bought dinner and came back home. Will call it a day real soon after dinner. Am skipping the shower as I am too tired even though I am quite dirty. I don't care. Looked at my plans for tomorrow, at maps, and there I was... la la land...
    

   Then we took the tunnel down towards the Sound, 1.2 km long, in the dark, 10% grade.It is also unlit as there is no power coming up this way. That tunnel took 20 years to dig, through the mountain's massive rock. On the other side we had to weave our way through a serie of switchback in 20 km, steeply down the hill. We met 2 cyclists that were coming up the hill under a heavy rain. I sure didn't envy them, but in the same time I was wondering whether I made the right decision not to cycle through this section.It was so pretty, and I would have liked to spend more time with the keas. In counterparts, Te-Anau gets 44 inches of rain every year and Milford gets an astounding 300, being 120 km away from one another! So down the hill we go and without warning, and without ceremony, there it was, Milford Sound and its famous Mitre Peak, the one we see on all the post cards and lots of posters of New Zealand. Unfortunately we didn't stop for pictures and headed right into the terminal where we would board the ship.    On the ship, still raining pretty hard, I wanted to stay outside and savour the moment, look at the Sound and take pictures. Well, there was no point to get wet before we even started, really, so after a while I gave in and served myself some hot tea. I was the only one travelling by myself and the average of the crowd was well over 40, but everybody was really nice. Had nice conversations with a couple from South Africa and England. The South Africans found the exchange rate very bad and were finding everything very expensive. It made me thing about how lucky I was to be in Canada. I also found out they are owned by a parrot too...      As we left the port we saw few groups of sea kayakers exploring the coast and its waterfalls that were quite loaded with water. The first ones you saw were quite impressive. As we went towards the Tasman sea, there were hundreds of them. It was because it was raining hard and the water had to go somewhere. The waterfalls would all stop falling 20-30 minutes after it stops raining. So you pick: a sunny day, great views,no waterfalls or a rainy day, big and lots of waterfalls...      As for wildlife, we saw seals. But seals are boring. Lots of seals in BC. The sea got quite agitated towards the end of the sound and my stomach got quite queasy. The visibility got close to nothing so we headed back. When the boat got more stable, I ate my lunch, drank my Diet Coke and ate the yummiest cookies for dessert, the kind that don't exist if I don't bike. I was glat to return onto firm ground, and sit in the van. However the way back, beside being rainy was quite windy and I got motion sickness again. The rain carried on and instead of stopping in all those nice places for short walks, we just headed back. Group decision. The keas don't like the rain either and so they were nowhere to be found. The waterfalls close to the tunnel were more numerous than in the morning and the water would rush down furiously. It was surreal. We were dropped off in our respective motel/motorcamp under a clearing sky in Te-Anau. I was glad to get off the van and thought "never again". The motion sickness would stay woth me the whole evening. No more car trip for me. I will ride my bike thank you! I spent a quiet evening at camp, updating my web-site, icing my knee and having a nice dinner: macaroni with tomato and veggies sauce. Yummy.  I am heading South as planned tomorrow, towards Invercargill and will see how far I will go. Riverton is said to be pretty but it's 148 km away from here! I'll see how it goes.And depends in the winds too. I hope to sleep well tonight as last night my neighbor was snoring quite loudly. I could do with a good night of sleep. Kia Ora

   Then I reached the coast. Wow! Blue water, nice sandy beach and the sound of the waves crashing on the beach. The time for a picture and off I was again, climbing and going down hills. I saw a couple of wooly escappees wandering the Southern Scenic Road and as a car or a woman on a bike would come close, they would attempt to join back their friends only to crash on the wired fence. I felt for those guys because they looked so scared! And I wouldn't improvise a rescue as I just didn't know where to lead them. Passing Riverton there was an "Estuary Fair" going on and I stopped at the teahouse for hot chips and a sandwich, oh, and Diet Coke. I sat outside to watch what was going on and I was greeted by:" Hi, do you recognize me? I met you in Kaikoura!" Good memory, that girl! It was the girlfriend of the guy I spoke to that was travelling around the world for the last 2 and a half years. They now had some family visitting and had been renting a car with them for the last 3 weeks. It was nice talking with her again and share experience. As I left there was a parade in preparing but I didn't want to stay any longer.  The second part to Invercargill was rather plain as I was going through... plains and the traffic got heavier. I had a light headwind and was trying to stay over 20km/hour. Arriving to Invercargill, the South of the South, I was greeted by my first traffic light of the South Island, a Mc Donald, burger King and a Pizza Hut. Wow, welcome back into civilization! I found the visitor center downtown and chose a campsite nearby, right behind a prison! It is the closest to downtown and as I have a long day tomorrow I don't want to ride extra kms just to leave town. 7.50$ was pretty decent and I aslo purchased token and soap for laundry. I wasen't really due but I thought it wouldn't hurt. See, it is part of my need for comfort. Tent pitched, I had a lovely shower and headed for groceries. The full alley of fruits and veggies amazed me and again I felt like being in food wonderland!!! After that I hunted for an internet place which lead me right back to the visitor center, and as it was pricey and coin operated, didn't manage to do much more than answer e-mails, and I am now 3 days late to my trip report! It won't get any better as I don't expect any computer access in the next 3 days. I headed next door to Queens park and visited an aviary with keas and other large parrots and some smaller and more colorful parakeets. Had dinner with ceasar salad and couscous, and yogourt for dessert. I have been eating rather junk food lately and was sure glad to see greens on my plate. Have been talking with this german guy that has just finished law school and is travelling now trying to decide what he will do with the rest of his life. He is travelling by bike and also does some hiking and has left his bike behind to do some hiking on Stewart Island. When I came out of the kitchen that night, the East was pitch black, the top of the sky was royal blue and the Western horizon was orange. And when I came out of the washrooms, few stars had popped in and a half moon was shining. Kia Ora! See ya!  A few words about how my trip is going. There are now 17 days left to it and I feel rushed!!! I feel there is not enough time! I would need 3 months, maybe more. For the South Island, that is. Well, I will make the most of it. I will come back, and that is a promise!
   The sunshine. And the ocean. I didn't ride by the ocean at all but if I was high enough on a hill, I could see it. I stopped for a long break 12 km farther at Tokanui for Diet Coke and chips and got some info about Curio Bay, the side trip I decided to make. Curio Bay is known for the Hector dolphins that come quite close to the shore. So I took a different road from Tokanui, involving some gravel unfortunately. And it climbed, climbed and climbed.... Again the panoramas were really fabulous. And so was the downhill after the climb.. I was being real careful not to fall, remembering my falls from few days ago. I needed to keep both hands on te handle bar and look out for oncoming traffic. I hated to cross cars because it meant that I would get covered with a film of dust and I would have it everywhere... Including my eyes and my mouth. Eat dust... Eventually I made it to Curio Bay and Porpoise Bay. I headed first to Curio Bay where there is a "petrified forest" by the ocean that is 180 millions years old. The fossils are visible from the cliffs and you can even go and walk on it and see from up close. That was neat.      There was also an unofficial view point where I saw people watching a scene and as I am curious I went by... It's a penguin! Standing there alone on a beach in a small cove. Wow! That was impressive. He was far away, at least 300 feet away but I was lent some binoculars and I could see him from much closer. That was exciting to see a penguin in the wild. Then I headed for Porpoise Bay where there is a campsite, a nice viewpoint on top of a hill and a huge bay sandy beach, with turquoise water.     The Hector dolphins are known to hang out here but considering the white caps on the water, I didn't bother checking if they were around. I also had quite a bit of distance to cover before I reach my chosen motorcamp so I was better get going. The next 20 km were very scenic and hilly and it felt like Christmas when I reached the sealed road... That was at the 100 km point that I started to climb again seriously and shortly after that the gravel road started again. Hills and gravel road together are not much fun. Especially when the gravel is unstable and at times there weren't any track and my bike was treatening to fall. In the same time I was getting more tired  and the wind was still bothering me.What a day! It  was past 6 PM and hungry and not near my campsite yet...    I made it to Papatowai by 19:20 tired, cold, hungry and a bit irritable.(Low blood sugar?) The corner store was closed and there was nobody to greet me to recieve my money so I had to self register. I pitched my tent quickly, completely aware of the noisy neighbors and jumped in the shower. I had to warm-up, and quick! Then, as quickly I started to make dinner, sipping a cup of soup in the meantime. I served myself a generous and yummy serving of macaroni with veggies, tomato sauce and cheese and a Crunchie Bar and an apple for dessert. After that, well, I called it a day. I sure hate those rushed evenings when I come late and hurry for everything before dark and don't have time to watch the sunset. Tomorrow will sure be better as it will be a much shorter day. And tomorrow is my birthday!!!
   After about 30 km I made it to the city of Okawa, which to my surprise has good services, and even a quilting store where I gladly stopped and visitted. The owner is addicted to quilting and showed me her work. Then the next stop was the internet cafe where I spent an hour updating my web site. A good rest for my legs. After that, reluctantly somewhat, I was on my way again. There was another hill that I knew about and though it wasen't that bad I sure was afraid of it and apprehended the grind. I got the wind either behind me or on the side and with all the cookies I had, the energy was coming back... And I knew the end was coming. I guess it helps. The outskirts of Balclutha were not so nice with the very first industries I encountered on the South Island and also a very smelly landfill. I was glad I had a short day. Camp was set up in a smallish camp and I headed for the internet where I updated for an hour worth but lost the whole work into cyberspace because the stupid computer wouldn't save it. That was very frustrating. Fortunately the girl didn't make me pay, but still... All this effort for nothing. I hit a large grocery store and stocked up like if I wouldn't see another store for 2000 more years. I wanted to cook some rice and go to a takeway and pick up some fish (in batter) but it wasen't practical as my rice wouldn't be ready for at least 20 minutes. So I gave up the idea and bought instead some really nice dessert, a strawberry cheesecake.There was a lot of it and I ate it all and now I have a sugar overload.... That was a big meal really.... So this was my birthday ride. I would have liked it to be memorable and exciting but well, it was just another day into my trip. That's fine. No big deal. I am glad to be here and this is special enough...
   Well, what can I say, the sheps need an ocean view to thrive! I kept looking for penguins and no, I didn't see any. The penguins usually go out to sea for the day to feed  and can be seen in the morning and evening. Oh well, it will be for another time... I took a little break in Brighton, little town that I found quite pretty and simple. The houses were not wealthy but the owner were quite proud of them and maintained them well as well as their gardens. Past Brighton, it started to climb again, just a bit at first but my @#$@%$ bike wouldn't change the speeds for me so it was tougher than it should have been (Where is that whip?) But the worse of the climb still had to come, a hill in the suburbs of Dunedin called Costorphine. Oh my god. It was steep, long but paved and at the end of the day, it was a real tough one. I started to count my pedal strokes mentally to 20, over and over again. And it hellped, I did it. It went down right after that to cool me down. Now, Dunedin is not very nice for its cyclists to the fact that they don't sign where the bikes CAN go but they sure sign where the bikes aren't allowed to go. I found myself in the motorway where the bikes are forbidden, and as tired as I was I just couldn't care less. It was all downhill, and flat after that. Lots of shoulder. Totally safe. And so I was in Dunedin. What a relief... The motorcamp was infested with school kids on a few days trip and I had to find a good camping spot to shelter myself from the noise. There were lots of tents around and it was hard to predict which ones would be the noisy ones... Had a shower and felt like getting out of the routine I had set up for myself day after day after day. So I took my bike for a little ride following the "no sweat" rule. The path took me by the beach for a view point and then on the takeways row, for fast food New Zealand way. Nothing sounded appealing as I smeeled the grease from the street so I ended up at the grocery store and bought myslef a chicken pie, and boiled veggies that would make my dinner. Lots of ketchup on top of everything. That was yummy and a good change.  Tomorrow I will visit Dunedin for half of the day and then take the train to Timaru, the begining of a ride towards Lake Tekapo and Pukaki. Should be interesting. Kia Ora from Dunedin...
   On the train I could see that north of Dunedin is very scenic and I wasn't sure I would have seen this from my bike, but who knows? I was glad that I wasn't riding today as I was tired. However I will ride to Pleasant Point which is a short ride from Timaru. It feels like my days have been adding up and have been pretty routine like, a little too much to my liking. Pitching the tent, shower, eat sleep, lift camp, eat, cycle, cycle, cycle. Find food, find a keyboard. I wonder what I can do to make my travelling more interesting and diversified. Does it mean I am bored? Feling too rushed? Tired physically? Mentally? I sure haven't had a full night of sleep lately and have been pushing my body quite a bit through the hills, the gravel and the country. 9PM... I think I am a bit homesick today. On the train I had been seated facing the back of the train and I've been experiencing motion sickness again. I will need to do something about that before I take the train again. The train ride had been 3 h and 30 minutes with the delays and parts of it had been very scenic with the turquoise water of the ocean. Arriving to Timaru, I took advantage of the quiet booking office and reserved a seat on all my onward trains and ferries to Tongariro National Park which is in the middle of the North Island. That means I have to stick to the schedule I made for myself and that means going the distance everyday. Then I clipped on the pedals and headed towards Pleasant Point, a little town on my way to Lake Tekapo. The highway was busy and it was warm, not so enjoyable ride. I ended up in a small suburb town with an empty campsite.I am the only camper tonight beside the caretakers. I set up camp and cycled into town for groceries. Spent my evening watching tv and looking at my map, and by 8:30 prepared myself to go to bed hoping for a restful night.       The birds are sure present around the park and a white cat greeted me out of the washroom and sneaked behind me towards my tent like if I was a bird, trying to hide behind... That was funny.  The moon is getting fuller now and the weather forcast is very good. I need a good day tomorrow and hope for ompany in the evening.
     I found Peddlers Paradise, the cyclists hostel easily. Led by the author of the guide book I am refering to all the time, Nigel greeted me and showed me around. Located in the back of his house, the kitchen has a view of the lake. I had a lovely shower and headed into town. As I set up camp another cyclist dropped in but I haven't seen so much of him. Quiet type I guess? Had another dinner with boiled veggies and meat pie and lots of ketchup, and had a few desserts... Crunchie bar,an orange, and some cookies that are caramel filled and chocolate coated. They are devilish and it's hard to stop eating them, even if I hide them... Then after dinner, Nigel, Chris and I sat at the table with the NZ map and we discussed routes, headwind, hills and points of interest. Of course he told me that my route was all upside down and that if I had carried on clockwise I would have had more tail winds. Ha! Nigel also talked to lenghts about the Lonely Planet guide to cycling in NZ which just came out in the book stores a few months ago and which is now in direct competition with his book and he knows he can't win. His problems rise around distribution of his book as he doesn't have a distributor at all, even in NZ.Well, let's say that I've learned about the difficulties of having your book sold and even accepted in NZ bookstores. The thing is that unfortunately, the Lonely Planet cycling guide is not a great guide, not complete and not showing the real nice parts of NZ and the alternatives. But because it is called Lonely Planet, they get the publicity and distribution all over in the world. If you ever go cycling to New Zealand, try to find the Peddlers Paradise at home or wait to be in New Zealand to purchase it. It is cheaper, encourage a local and you can even have your copy autographed by Nigel!!!
     We made it to Omarama by 16:45 and the English guy waved us goodbye wanting to cover more distance today. Fine. Not me. I was very glad to set up camp in a most civilized campsite get my shower and have my laundry done. Had dinner with Carine and as we talked I poured the dish soap in my dished including my cup as I had a bit of wine. Then we talked some more and Carine decided to have some hot chocolate and I wanted some too. As I didn't rince my cup wad was busy talking, my hot chocolate had a dish soap taste!!!(Kids don't try this at home) Carine and I had a good laugh about it... Nice to have some good company.
   There were sheeps grazing nearby, some dogs tied up to their dog houses, a few kitties running scared at each move I was doing, and a few massive bulls resting.        The surrounding mountains were beautiful, bare as the clouds had now lifted. As we laid there on the grass the sheeps got curious after their initial scare, and came near enough to be petted and to accept some grass from our hand. That was a real change of behavior!!! Later, I would serve myself with some cookies and each time they would hear the paper noise, they would come running!!! Leisurly evening tonight after a yummy dinner shared with Carine. Life is good.
   Had a great day today. Slept well- but the usual getting up in the middle of the night thing. The moon rise over the mountains was beautiful as it is getting fuller and fuller.      This morning, Carine and I left early as we wanted an early arrival to Oamaru, so we could view the penguins as they come before sunset. We retraced our steps from last afternoon riding 4 km in the gravel and downhill back to the highway. The air was quite crisp and even though I had my leggings, 2 pairs of socks, long sleeve thermo-shirt and a wind breaker, I had chills and my fingers were like popsicles. Oh well. With the blue sky and the bright sunshine I would eventually warm up. The way to Kurow, about 20 km was up and down. nothing too difficult really. Maybe one longer hill made me sweat some but  nothing to be scared of. We stopped in Kurow for tea with a quarter of a cup of sugar in it for me ( had to ask for more sugar in the pot) and I also had some yummy chocolate fudge. I stocked up with a muffin ,juice and a Crunchie bar for the road as this morning, I litterally ran out of food. There was just an apple and peanut butter in my bags, and really not much services but that tea house till Oamaru.      We opted for the scenic route to Oamaru passing through small villages and through lots of farms. There was also the very interresting "elephant rocks" a weird rock formation in the form of large boulders in a field, very popular to the local rock climbers.    We stopped and took some pictures and after that we climbed and climbed as the road meandered and then were allowed to go down, and that was a real nice long descent into the bottom of a canyon. Quite scenic. Carine and I ended up in Weston after passing a few sunflower fields and we bought some well deserved bubbly refreshment (Coke) and had a snack(chocolate). In fact we were just a few km away from our destination but I was glad to get the break. In town, after finding the only motorcamp, we set up and  headed in search of an internet cafe as it's been a few days already. We didn't find anything open so we went to the grocery store. I was becoming increasingly irritable and the noise of the  street, the kids jumping with their skateboards, their music, everything was unbearable.  I got a dizzy spell down the alleys at the grocery. And I really knew then that I needed to get some food in and fast... I was low in blood sugar... I sat down right into the store and ate before I pass out and then Carine and I headed to the motorcamp for an early dinner, boiled veggies and meat pies. Lots of ketchup. The way to the yellow-eyes penguin colony is not flat (hihi) There is a big hill to climb up and then down the other way almost to sea level, including a part in lose gravel. There must be 40-50 people around here. On the hide, it is written to come in, to be quiet and wait for them to come ashore. If we see them coming, not to move, and hide so they don't see us. If the penguins see people on the beach or anywhere they won't come  and feed the juveniles waiting at the nest. Well, as I am writing this there are people sitting on the fence right above the cliffs, well in view, overlooking the beach.  We have been waiting well over an hour and still no penguin... 21:45 Back from the penguin viewing... We saw 3 or 4 yellow-eyed penguins from so far they wouldn't make a dot on a picture. But it made a nice meditation on how fragile this specie is and how important it is to respect mother nature. I must say that our patience have been tested as you will wait more than you will see. I observed that there are some people that just can't sit there and say nothing. They have to talk, they have to laugh, they also have to say very stupid stuff... To me, this was the time to be quiet and respect the penguins in their environment. We are the visitors, they are home. OK. Enough said about that. By 8PM, Carine and I were happy to move on to the next "viewing" area, the blue penguins. Well, to see them you must pay 8$, however the profits made goes into penguin conservation, research and education. They are much smaller, about 25 cm or 10 uinches tall and weigh about 1 kg. They're not as shy and sensitive as the other kind of penguins    and  they would come as close as 4 feet of people.    They come off to shore for the night and return to sea with the descending tide to feed again. The molting ones would not be waterproof and would stay ashore, not eating for 15-17 days. The one molting we saw was quite in a foul mood and was hissing on the other penguins nearby. See what the lack of food do to you??? We also saw the full moon rising from the ocean, which made the whole experience quite magical. Then by 21:15, Carine  and I were yawning and it was time  to return to camp... So after putting the lights up on the bikes, we left the harbor and had the surprise of our life when, 100 m later we almost ran over a crossing penguin that was heading for his nest... He passed right in front of our wheels...     

   Gradual, meandering climb of 5.5 km I cycled past the beautiful homes and gardens perched on the hills , all of them having a view on the oceean and the estuary.     I had a work out out of the climb but my legs were used to it by now and I didn't carry the weight of my packs. On top of that hill (350m of it) past the houses, there was some spectacular views around each turn I was taking. First the estuary and the beach, then, East and South I found myself on the edge of a crater and looking at some old volcanic land.        This was fabulous. I had to stop often to click the camera and admire the panorama. The way down too was wonderful passing the gondola (what's the point of paying 15$ for the gondola when you can cycle all the way up there yourself???) and a famous restaurant, the Sign of the Kiwi. I really enjoyed myself downhill, still meandering and passing lots of cyclist on their uphill work out.       Oh yeah, I almost forgot mentioning about my bike computer. Kaput! Gone! Finished! Finito. After the wiring being a problem, I  found that the taping along the frame got unglued and the wire was dangling freely. I didn't make a big deal out of it as I was busy admiring the panoramas and at some point, I didn't even notice, the wire got caught on one of my pedal and the latter got a big bite out of it, like a shark. Gone. No more. I realised quickly I lost one of my bearings... Will hang tight to my watch.... may be useful in the future to know the time. Heading back in town I stopped for errands and headed back "home" for a delightful shower. After dinner, wanting to avoid staying longer than wanted at the motorcamp I took a ride downtown to places I haven't been like the Art Gallery building and the outskirts of the botanical gardens. The usual internet work got into my schedule and I came back home to an astounding sunset as the rain that was supposed to come didn't and left behind some clouds that got lightened by a descending sun. I called it a day early as I was rather tired.
       Close to Picton we watched the efforts of helicopters with barils of water trying to put out a forest fire before it made too much damage. It would be critical they hurried because of the dryness of the area and the wind that is always strong.      As we made it into Picton I didn't have much time to hang out, I had to get my boarding pass for the Interislander and head to the quay so I could get in the boat. There were many cyclists like me waiting to get the signal to board- (Well, where were they anyways? Didn't see them cycling)  I started chatting with an Irish girl travelling and working in NZ for 9 months before returning to school and we hung out together for the duration of the sailing. We saw briefly a small pod of dolphins once and we then headed inside as it started to spit rain. Finding my way through Wellington was almost as easy as weaving my way in Vancouver; I found a bike path over an overbridge and headed South in a rush hour Wellington. I was disappointed that the hostel wasen't farther as I needed the workout, but no. Nicely located, there is a grocery store right in front of the YHA  (Youth Hostel Association) and we are very close to the downtown area, if not in it. I found myself in a 4 beds dorm and realized that it was the first time in 5 weeks I would be sleeping in a real bed. Impressive, uh? There were 2 old ladies that would be my roommates for the night and I was glad as I thought I'd have a good night with them. I quickly changed in shorts and cycling attire and headed out the door for a much needed spin. I have been recommended to head to the cable car and take it up for 1.50$ and to go down through the botanical garden. Well, duh! I wanted a real work out! So I climbed to the cable car by bike which was really a piece of cake, not even 100 m and came down the same way.     I almost passed in front of the most beautiful quilt store of NZ so far but unfortunately (and fortunately for my wallet) it was closed. All I could do was admire this large queen-size Baltimore appliques quilt. The ride didn't take the edge off- I probably would have needed at least 50 km of riding but it didn't happen as it was getting dark. After showering I crossed to the grocery store and it had to be the best stocked store I ever encountered in NZ wit ha lot of choices at the deli counter and the bakery and I stopped my choice on a gourmet chicken and vegetable pie and a garden salad bowl that included the dressing. Yum!         The evening was spent walking downtown in search of a computer place to catch up with my work but they were all closed. However I enjoyed watching people dining in the restaurants and groups of people having a drink at the pub, and looking at what people were up to in Wellington. Saw a casino but resisted to get in. Wanted to keep my money for myself thank you! Went to bed quite early, shortly after 9 and the lights were already out in my dorm which I considered a good sign...
     All three are in Tongariro National Park, a must see if you come to New Zealand. I took quite a few pictures and thought I was better get going if I wanted to make it tonight... As I headed towards the mountains I came across one of those yellow signs saying "kiwi crossing" .    Wow! I was on kiwi country! (They need a very specific environment to live in) I would never think of seeing one in the wild as they are nocturnal and very shy, but you never know... I took a side trip to Whakapapa (pronounce Fakapapa) up a long hill of 6 km on the side of Mt Ruapehu where trekkers do the very popular crossing of the mountain, being picked up on the other side by a shuttle bus.
