It was very tempting to do this trek but I don't have the proper foot wear and have to stick to my schedule. One of the hiker came back limping (she very likely twisted her ankle) even though she had the adequate ankle high hiking boots. As for me, it will be for another time. Have to come back. This side trip was... uphill but I was glad to huff and puff although I was wondering how high it would go. There was a gondola going up the mountain but unfortunately it was closed for the day by the time I came in.     Shortly after going back on highway 47 towards Turangi, I noticed that my rear tire was getting quite soft so I gave a try at putting some air in it but it didn't work out so well so I resigned to change the slow leak. As I was putting a patch on the tube, a car stopped and the woman offered that I use her foot pump. Sure, I said! This woman-a triathlete- just ran 36 km today in preparation of the Australia Ironman. Wow! How impressive! And... What a good idea! I will make some thoughts about it! Unfortunately for some reason her pump didn't work on my american tube valve but oh well, I am glad she stopped and she kept me company as I was doing the job, and we had a great conversation. Further down the road I stopped in a rest area and there was a couple busy picking stuff from the ground and I got curious as of what it was they were after. Well, this man, and Italian now living here with his NZ wife started talking faster than his mouth could move. It was funny because all I could understand was: Mama mia... Canadian... Mama mia... mushroom... Mama mia... Turangi... hill, big hills... Mama mia... His wife was smiling and so was I. I was delighted to see so much excitement. They honked the horn when they passed me on the hill. Yeah, the hill... After the rest stop there was a good size hill that required me to concentrate on my pace.I had to strugle with my small ring again and "the kick" had to be repeated a few times with some swear words in order to work. There were a few curves to the road so I couldn't see when the hill would end so I just kept going just in case the end was near around the next curve. It felt good to sweat a bit. The downhill was exhilarating but a bit cold as I made the last kilometers to Turangi. I stopped for a lookout for a nice view on Lake Taupo and everything around but I ran out of film so no picture... Boo woo... Made it to Turangi by 7PM and got to eat by 8. Definitly quite late but oh well, not so bad to get out of the routine once in a while, uh?
   There was a fair load of traffic on the road and had a close call once with a truck that really could have given me more space as there was 2 lanes and nobody beside him. I thought I could say today I didn't see any sheep but not a chance, nearing Taupo I saw hoards of them! Checked in at the motorcamp downtown, as I wanted a close acces to town, pitched my tent and headed for "Crater of the moon" which is a geothermal area. To get there there was a fair amount of climbing to do, then after riding on a small road, I saw a vast field with thick steam coming out of several spots on the ground.    The area was still green with plants , amazing that they can survive such hot grounds.    There was a walkway meandering the steamy land so we could view the craters and other natural phenomenons such as bubbling muds, boiling water, craters and also hear the steam exiting furiously the cracks of the earth.It was quite impressive to see and I took several pictures. Felt sorry there was no one to share with.      Randomly I headed towards other attractions a little out of town but didn't visit anything but a bee hive demo disguised as a tourist trap, then stopped at some waterfalls and was disgusted by the amount of tourists there as a big bus just stopped at the same time than me so I headed back to town.    I found an internet spot in Taupo and the connection was quite fast. I was impressed and glad. I had fun typing my report but lost the whole thing when the stupid machine wouldn't save my work and when I pressed the back button, wouldn't reproduce what I did today. The guy working there had a look and thinks it's MSN and not his terminal. This is totally frustrating. He charged me 2$ instead of 6 and I left, for food. Food would make me feel better! When I came back to camp, to my disarray and distress there was a couple of dozens of motorcyclists with their Harley that had checked in and had made their homes in the cabins nearest to my tent. Billy Idol's music was being played for the whole campsite and they were turning on and off the engines of their bikes and having scenic tours around the campsite. I didn't need that tonight. Put me in a foul mood. And it was only 5 pm. Was wondering what it would be like by 11:00 pm... So I decided to do something about it, I moved my tent and all my junk somewhere much quieter. I just want somewhere nice and quiet to sleep. The motorcamp has a kitchen but nowhere to sit inside and there are only 2 picnic tables outside for the whole camp. So I set up on one of the table and a guy joined in and although I didn't feel like talking felt in the obligation to maintain a minimum of conversation and small talk. It's one of those days, you know, and I just feel like doing my own stuff... No aggravations, please. Had pizza, yogurt and started into a bag of cookies. They are realy hard to give up even though I chose a type of cookies that aren't as yummy as usual. (Cookie monster me) I found refuge from people and mosquitos in my tent and will call it a day for tonight. Tomorrow will be my last official cycling day going to Rotorua as Sunday will be spent there and Monday is spent going back to Auckland by train. Kia ora from Taupo
         After that I headed towards Rotorua, more tired and having to negociate some hills and the traffic but it all went well. I was glad to make it to town, and found a campsite and took it. No playing fussy tonight. It's close to town, seems quiet but I can be wrong as you never know in advance what it's gonna be like at 10 PM. Splurged in a delightful nap once my tent was pitched , feeling very un-rushed. Eventually I got up and cycled to the internet cafe but unfortunately I couldn't access my web site. Hit the grocery store (am I getting boring???) and had dinner with a yummy chicken pie with steamed veggies and a few desserts (Haven't finished with those yet...)  Tonight is time change, we have to set out clocks back one hour. I'm glad to know this now so I don't get caught up on situations with the wrong time... However it means that daylight will be shortened in the evening by one hour which is kind of being cheated by one hour. That's bad... Oh well, I don't have any control on that...
       That was way cool! The guide also showed us the pools where they go bathe every day as there are no shower in their village, but in 5 houses. Very impressive.    After that I went for grocery and then internet work and the computer allowed me to update 2 more days to my journey which I am quite pleased with. I ended after 2 days because I was pretty annoyed with the music being played, some kind of dizzying techno where many times I thought the CD was jumping and repeating the same stuff.. Yuk. I had a headache so headed back home.  It's raining on and off, so will try the jaccuzi tub before the shower... Later... So it rained at dinner time. I tidied up my tent then went for dinner, the infamous caesar salad with couscous and a few healthier desserts. Now I have to be serious about it and decrease my food intake. No more of those big meals and no more multiple desserts... Chocolate will have to go too... Boo woo!!! I cleaned up both my food panniers, emptied my gas stove of the fuel by burning it and gave away my lighter. It's 7:30 PM and as tired as my body thinks it's 8:30 PM and feels it's time to sleep. Tomorrow I am taking the train by 1:00 PM and I have a little bit of time to do a bit of shopping and also some internet work. I have a few NZ$ left and I think I will have to exchange another 50$ Can traveller's check to get me going till Tuesday- food, camping, presents...  Well, I am really nearing the end. I have feelings of satisfaction. I think I had a pretty nice trip and that I did well considering the circomstances. I wonder what awaits me around the corner. What the challenges will be. Trials and tribulations.   
This thought is dedicated to the thief that stole the content of my saddle bag probably yesterday when I was doing e-mail. I didn't notice until this morning when I loaded the bike. So if I remember well, I had in it my tire irons, 2 flat tire repair kits, a small flashlight and my chain lube. I found the pocket fully opened and empty. Well I hope that the thief will make good use of those items. I had a good night of sleep and took it easy this morning but even then by 0830 I was ready to go! Not much is opened by this time but I went to the grocery store and bought enough for today and for the train trip. Then I had an intensive session on the computer, 1h30 and it cost me only 10.20$ ! I was allowed to get the bike inside near me so I was in peace with that. Didn't do much after that, not really wanting to leave my bike alone. I stopped in a book store and saw this guy roaming around my bike like a bee. I usually leave my bike unlocked in front of the glass windows in the small stores. But to be sure asked the cashier and she actually told me to put it right in the entrance so they could have an eye on it. I was thankful of the advice. I didn't find a book to read but would manage with the paper and bought some more post cards. By then it was time to head to the train station. The attendant there made me unload the stuff off my bike and I did, not wanting to make a fuss. It kind of bugged me a bit as it doesn't take much more room loaded than not, but of well. Whatever. So 4 hours in the train and I will be in Auckland for my last evening and last night in NZ. I would need to cycle 20 km to the motorcamp close to the airport. Another chapiter in on the verge to be finished... I need to arm myself with courage and determination to go through the next months as I will make some decisions for myself, like my professional future and build a better nest for my parrot and myself. I miss my parrot and can't wait to see him... Bla bla bla... Train babbling... I really should have got a book to read... 9PM. We made it to Auckland, a bit late, by 5:30 PM and decided to go downtown a bit to see the sailboats and cycled the 20 something kilometers to the motorcamp I have been to some 6 weeks ago. The sun turned out to be quite low by the time I started and I arrived in total darkness. It's amazing all the glass you find on the road and other sharp objects when you don't have any patch kits with you! When it got dark I put on my reflective jacket and turned on my rear flashing light, and really pushed myself. I was kind of worried by the heavy rush hour traffic and I guess worried of not being seen. But it all went well and got home by 7 PM, feeling relieved. Pitching my tent in the dark and looking for my headlamp in a bag full of clothes was a lot of fun, really! By now after 40 something nights in a row spent camping I could pitch my tent with my eyes shut. I opted for a shower remembering the sticky and stinky experience I had a few weeks ago and then had dinner. I lost a plastic red bowl here when I left the motorcamp- I don't know if I even mentionned it. Well, I was delighted to find it back! That was real cool! I had left-overs tonightm boiled veggies and cheese, and now beside an apple and a banana there is nothing else perishable. I am hoping to get some pastry for breakfast and to pick up soem sushi for lunch at the mall tomorrow. 48 hours away from my parrot and from home...

Like you see I had a very leisurly morning. I woke up with the sunshine and that was good because the tent fly was all wet, in and out. I needed the precious sunrays to dry my bike bag as well (which has been my ground sheet all along). I remember being glad my last day in NZ was a sunny one. It made me happy. I headed to the mall early to buy few things I needed. Treated myself with a muffin and a glass of milk and did half an hour of e-mail/web business. Bought some groceries and bubble wrap to protect my bike from potential rough hands at the airport. I bought some long time wanted sushi and also found a book to read while on the plane. After that, I went back to my tent for a shower and the final packing up. I enjoyed having plenty of time to do this and the sunshine...wow! was it ever hot! Here I was packing up, having just showered and I was already sweatting like crazy! The ride to the airport was fine, I enjoyed it but 2/3 into it I had a visitor stopping in front of me, and just for me... The police! A woman. Nicely she asked whether I knew I was riding on a motorway that prohibits cyclists or pedestrians. No, I replied, I didn't know, but I would be happy taking an alternative if she would be kind enough to show me a different quieter road to lead me to the airport. She said there was none, unless I would head back to Auckland and take a bike path which would be 2-3 hour detour by bike. She told me to carry on the way I was going but to be careful and to ride as far left on the shoulder as I could as the traffic could go quite fast. I said thank you and she left. I smiled. Even the cops are nice people in NZ! I had a "moment" arriving at the airport, for some reason. Don't ask me. Just full of emotions probably because I knew a chapiter of my life was just finishing. Didn't last long. I found a bench by the departures area outside and started the job of preparing the bike and my luggages for the journey across the Pacific Ocean and the Equator. Pedals gave me a bit of a scare but I had a long wrench that I have been carrying for 6 weeks just for that event so I did ok, didn't even have to use my instruction book to know which way to unscrew them. I was annoyed by the spot I chose as the smokers would gather nearbuy and bother me with their smoke. There was a wait time at the check-in area as it wasen't opened yet when I lined up. I happened to fall on a very unknowledgeable clerk as she pointed that I had too many pieces of luggage and that I would have to pay a surcharge for the excess of weight for my bike. So I had to review with her the rules of Canada 3000 and her co-worker gave the knod of approval so I was let alone and she checked in my stuff. Then I was rushed to take my bike into a narrow corridor to the fragile item area, and as my bike laid across the cart and I had carry-on to struggle with. I couldn't rush. I got ticked by the rush of the lady, and of course my bike would hit the wall or fall off the cart. Geeez! Give me some time, would you? It got me a bit irritated but that went away fast. After that started a shoping spree. Shopping with a vengance. I went through the stores, looking and looking again for 2 hours. Then I passed through the gates, the customs and wow, more shops. They got my attention (and my credit card's) up to the last gate .. So I am finally on my way home. Had dinner and started to read this book I bought this morning. And watched the Richard Gere movie presented: Autumn in New York. Nice. 21:30 NZ time. We landed in Raratonga (Cook Islands). My seat neighbor was a young guy travelling with his new wife for a belated honeymoon, and he's been suffering from motion sickness in the last few minutes of the flight to the Island. He was white like a ghost but near the end had a sweather over his head and a paper bag at his mouth...like if you had to be ashamed of motion sickness.. I tried some acupressure points on him but didn't work so well. I was glad he didn't throw up because the beef stroganoff wouldn't have been too  impressive half digested. I was a bit amused looking at him but I must admit I'd rather it was him than me... So we made it nice and clean to Raratonga and the opressive heat of the air rushed in as I got out of the plane. Can't imagine what it'd be like in daylight. It is so humid too. I guess it would be totally appreciated after a few months of -20 degrees weather but it's a bit too much to my liking. 06:25 Honolulu time. Probably 04:25 NZ time. So here I am living March 20th for a second time all over again today... Sunrise over Hawai... They made us get out of the plane so they can look for bombs and... uh... So they can clean the plane and bring the food in. Have had 2 empty seats to my left but even lying down I haven't been able to fall asleep. The 2 movies presented were not so good, a James Bond which I have no interest at all in and Fargo who is playing again probably because it's a Canadian movie. So I read my captivating book. Who knows, I might finish it before I make it to Vancouver... March 20th 2:00 Vancouver time, and March 21st 0900 AM Auckland time. One more hour to go on the plane and I'll be almost home. I have read a whole book since I left Auckland. It's a sad story and had to hide some overflowing water in my eyes many times. I like to read auto-biographies and true stories, like the Everest 1996 story for instance. This one was poignant, about a woman that learn she has inoperable brain tumor right after the birth of her daughter. She tell the story of her last year, with her husband contributing by his reflexions about his wife's on-line journal entries. That was heavy duty to read but very beautiful. This reading has one message for me, and it is enjoy life, and enjoy it now. Make a wish and just do it. It's happening today. And you make it happen because nobody will do it for you. So I am a tired cookie but still holding. I will be home soon. Beyond picking up my parrot I don't have much plans yet. I am working on Friday and already have few overdue things like a hair appointment, grocery shopping and cleaning my bike. Looking forward to having my ears cleaned up (I know, too much details) and telling all about my trip (already done), develop my pictures and talking to my family and friends (not necessarily in that order... or maybe, yeah!) I am looking forward to see my pictures and to scan them (stay tuned), to sort my mail out hoping there is not too many overdue bills and hoping there are a few checks waiting for me. 20:00 Home, sweet home... I arrived quite tired at YVR and somewhat impatient and irritable waiting in the slowest of the line-ups at the customs. Some people have been jumping queue amd other have been quite confused as for what to do. No patience for that today. I want home... I decided to pick up the parrot tomorrow, well rested instead of today and to cycle home. I put my bike back together having difficulty screwing the pedal because I was unscrewing (duh), loaded the thing and rode home. I am pretty happy I did that. Just what I needed after 18 hours on the plane. It relaxed me and gave me a good work out as I pushed myself quite a bit. I got comments from other cyclists like... "You have a lot of panniers on your bike" Uh, yeah...I do... I go to work every day loaded like that...
I recovered my parrot the next day and he happened to be fine, little bundle of joy as he is. Of course he remembered who I was. Was pissed off at me for leaving him with the doctor that prod and gives him needles, but apparently he was just fine. I made life changing decisions after this trip like changing field of practice within nursing, so that kept me busy and stressed for the months afterwards. I guess that my trip refilled my energies enough to dare making that much needed change. New Zealand is a country of fast terrain changes, very compact in itself, and like the guidebook I was usign say, a peddlers paradise. It is not crowded except for the sheeps and the increasing cow population (did I also mention sandflies?) but their people are very friendly. I will come back, that is for sure. Go see for yourself, you will be impressed!
"When you want what you've never had, you must do what you've never done." Anonymous
When we moved to Boulder in 1992 I joined a hiking club.  We would pick a different hike every week and usually summit 12-13,000 foot peaks.  At 40 I was the baby of the group.  Most of the women were in their 50's, 60's and even 70's.  What a great inspiration they were to me.  We are blessed that in Boulder we have so many active seniors who are out there doing it all and I thank them for the great role models that they have become.   My husband, Doug has been the biggest cheerleader this past year.  Last September when I turned 49 he gave me a bicycle charm neclace and told me that there was no turning back.  This past year has been consumed with research and discussions about my ride.  Every new idea has been thoroughly hashed over and he has shared the joys and accomplishments along the way and has also been there when the tears flowed over the dam.  His biggest challenge now will be to boot me out the door when I ride through Boulder in late June. Thanks Honey Bun! I also want to thank our kids who have encouraged me along the way.  Last summer Jennifer backpacked Europe all summer and now this summer I will be on the road. I told her it's her turn to wake up in the middle of the night and wonder where her mother is!  Thanks, Mark for the logo design, it is awesome.  Kudos also to Chris Wesselman who stepped in to help with the techie stuff when Doug was on the West Coast attending school. You saved my life and now I can sing along to Italian Opera when I'm in the cornfields of Iowa!   I have been so blessed to have such wonderful support and backing from all my family and so many of our friends. I take numerous angel pins and a very precious rock with me for good luck as well as all your love in my heart. "Live to ride, ride to live."   
HOT BATHS-If you like hot baths at the end of a long ride like I do you should carry a rubber bath stop.  I don''t have one so one night we stuffed a wash cloth in the drain (which worked) and another night the plastic lid from a Pringles can did the trick. CAMELBACK WATER PACK-A few days before I left someone who has ridden cross country three times told me the most valuable thing to have is a Camelback so I took her advice and got one.  I also have two water bottles but the Camelback works so well, especially when you are working up a grueling hill and can hardly move your hands to swat a fly.  The water hose with the bite valve is right there. Usually at lunch time I add ice so I not only have ice cold water but the pack cools my back as well. BED & BREAKFAST INNS-Try to stay at B&B's if possible. It feels so much better and is just like being at your Grandmother's house. A hearty breakfast is served each morning and the cost of lodging is sometimes cheaper than a budget hotel chain.  The proprieters are very friendly and a good source for local information. GORE TEX RAIN CLOTHES-Spend the bucks and invest in Gore-Tex. You will probably still get wet, more from sweating on the inside but the Gore-Tex does breathe and you will not get cold.  Make sure that your underlayers wick the sweat from your body as well.  I have a jacket designed for bikers and good rain pants with side zippers and velcro closures around the ankles. DRINKING WATER-Your source for drinking water will vary every day.  Always taste the water before filling up your bottles and Camelback.  I filled up at a gas station with tap water from the bathroom sink one day and five miles down the road, with another 15 miles to go I realized that the water was not fit for human consumption.  It was horrible and I was afraid it would make me sick.  Needless to say, I was very dehydrated at the end of that ride.  I should have purchased bottled water-well worth the few dollars. CLEAN CLOTHES-If you can, rinse out your clothes every night.  Even in clean water, if nothing else.  Putting on smelly clothes in the morning is not fun and I think the sweat and salt can be abrasive on sensitive parts of your skin.  Most materials are made to dry very quickly. RAILROAD CROSSINGS-After my latest wipeout with a roaring train bearing down the tracks with me inches away, crashed and clipped into my petals, I propose that as you approach the tracks you unclip in anticipation of needing to stop quickly. FOOD-When you leave for a ride make sure that you have some type of nourishment in your packs.  Even if it's something you aren't craving at the moment. Believe me, when you get to that town that you thought had some kind of gas station or grocery store and its' a ghost town, you will be happy you've got that boring granola bar or apple in your pack. CELL PHONES-If you carry a cell phone try to get in the habit of recharging it every night so that you have the added insurance of a full charge in the morning.  Recharging every night does not hurt the new cell batteries.  If you have a phone that is analog and digital you will go through a charge much faster when you are on analog.

I know that a lot of you have been asking about my route.  I had hoped to scan one in but that did not happen (maybe later) (Mark L.??)  So, I will give you a quick rundown of my planned ride so that you have a better idea of where I am going and if you happen to start getting postcards from Texas you better come find me!   Leave New York City on May 11th and head north along the Hudson River.  Cross over into New Jersey at the George Washington Bridge. (that should be interesting!) Head north and ride through New York, along the Jersey border and head to Port Jervis, NY. From there we will ride towards Scranton, PA and then into northern Pennsylvania and follow Hwy 6 across the state, heading into Cleveland where Doug will fly home from on May 25th. Then I will be alone for a bit and will stay fairly north central through Indiana and Illinois and stop in Mt. Pleasant, Iowa to visit my sister, Diane Rouse and her husband, Mike. My parents, Joe and Gladys Tupy will sag me with their motor home from somewhere in Illinois through Iowa. Get those kolacky's ready, MOM! From Iowa I will dip down through a small bit of Nebraska and Missouri and take Hwy 34 across Northern Kansas and into Colorado. I will stop in Boulder for a bike and body tune-up and some serious family and friend time.  Then a posse of Boulder friends will join me over Trail Ridge Road in Estes Park. Doug will continue with me to Steamboat Springs.  From there my sister Cindy Tupy will take over and ride with me through a bit of Utah and into River Falls, Wyoming.  The baton will then be passed to Doug and Christy Speirn-Smith who will ride/sag to Pocatello, Idaho where Christy's brother lives. Then I will be alone again for a bit so I want to ride through the Sawtooth Mountains of Idaho and then stop in Boise to visit friends, Betty and Allen Frazier.  Allen, get the plane ready, maybe we'll fly over the Sawtooth's instead! From Boise I will head due west through central Oregon to Florence, on the coast. My cousin Margaret Carfi and her two friends will ride with me the last 600 miles to the Golden Gate Bridge, with the able assistance of her husband Ron. So, my next tome will be penned in NYC.  I will upload more photos once we are on the road! P.S.  I just weighed my duffel and it's a nice, light 24 pounds so I'm pretty happy about that. "The traveler must be born again on the road, and earn a passport from the elements."  Henry David Thoreau   
We left the hotel at 8:45, again, not an early start but who wanted to go out in pouring rain.  We actually rode in rain ALL day long.  Doug had two flats. The first was at mile 5.8 so we stopped under a hotel awning to change it.  The second one started going flat a few miles later and I noticed a bike shop about a half mile back so we walked the bike back and had a whole new tire put on.  Apparently the spoke liner was worn and not protecting the tube from the spokes.  I think the problem is solved; now if I can just stop falling off my bike! The rain poured and poured.  We continued  on, heading towards Scranton.  Around 7 we stopped for dinner, knowing that a hotel was within a few miles. I cried through the whole dinner, knowing we had to go back out in the rain and cold and I was so miserable I just wanted to go home.  We mounted the new front light to Doug's front fork and headed up the hill, only to have the damn light fall off twice but we had street lights and numerous cars honking to tell us we were nuts.  But within two miles, there was the Dunmore Inn.  A warm room and shelter over our heads, nothing fancy but at 10:00 who cares.  We decided to sleep in until we woke up and agreed that no matter how far we got tomorrow we were stopping at a decent time. Total miles today was 61.  Yeah! "Traveling may be....an experience we shall always remember, or an experience which, alas, we shall never forget."  J. Gordon, English Writer
  

There is nothing better than the smell of bacon and fresh coffee in the morning.  Ruth filled us with french toast, bacon and English muffins and  by 8 we were on our way.  We hope to get to the hotel in Cleveland that is close to a bike shop that will be boxing Doug's bike before he flies home. We are way ahead of schedule; Doug was supposed to fly home on May 25th. It is a warm and balmy 27 degrees when we leave and around lunch it is probably a high of 40.  The clouds keep spitting little drops and snowflakes but so far no downpour. I am doing everything in my power to delay the inevitable but nothing is working. Towards mid-afternoon the clouds diminish and the sky turns blue.  It is still chilly out but we are relieved that there is no rain.  We approach the outskirts of Cleveland and the traffic gets heavier. The worst is the condition of the roads; the potholes are enormous and if you don't get off your seat there is major pain.  We wind our way through the streets of Cleveland and ride through downtown and head towards North Olmsted, which is where our hotel  is for the night and also where Eddy's Bike Shop is. We check into our hotel and just a bit up the street is Eddy's; we get there around 6 and by 7 they have my bike tuned up and Doug's bike boxed.  They give him a ride back to the hotel and then we go next door to have margueritas and a delicious Mexican dinner to celebrate. I cry through most of the dinner because I am now realizing that starting tomorrow this ride is all mine! My buddy is going home and I am on my own-what a scary thought.  But I am taking tomorrow off-Doug's flight is at 5 so right now all I want is my snuggle partner and a warm bed!  Nighty night!   

What a day!  I left the hotel at 7:00 with butterflies in my stomach. My biking buddy was gone and the day was here. The sky was bright blue, a little breeze blowing.  I followed the directions Doug and I had written out and before I knew it I was on a route that was posted PEDESTRIANS AND BICYCLES PROHIBITED!  I kept going but my good old Catholic conscience kept knawing at me so I stopped at a gas station and asked a few people for an alternative route.  They couldn't think of any and told me the other route was even more heavily traveled so off I went, (mea culpa, mea culpa)wondering what the local jail food tasted like.  But no flashing lights or sirens and before long I was in beautiful Ohio countryside. The shoulders are still in horrible disrepair, which makes looking around a little difficult. A lunch stop in Milan, OH, which is the birthplace of Thomas Edison.  I've already gone 40 miles.  Finished at 2:30, 64 miles.  I wish every day was this good!   
Bicycle touring has always held a fascination for me.  You take only the bare essentials and then rely on your muscles to get you from point A to point B. After a few weeks you get the routine down and things become sort of mechanical.  Eat, ride, drink, pee, eat, ride, drink, pee........BUT, there is so much more to it.  I started my ride this morning at 6:30.  It was so beautiful out. Once I got off the busy road and onto a country road I started really looking around and taking in all the sights and smells that one can only observe by being on a bike.  As I approached one small town I was riding against a line of cars that were all heading to work in the other direction.  I knew what they were experiencing-flipping radio channels trying to find a good song, worrying about being late for work, making mental lists of what all had to be done that day.....And here I was, just pedaling my bike on a country road in Ohio.  I became intoxicated with the smell of fresh cut grass, I heard birds chirping all around me, I smelled the fresh turned earth that was being prepared for planting, a small airplane flew overhead, a car passed and I could smell the perfume the driver was wearing, a cow mooed in a barn, baby sheep were munching new grass in their pen, a farmer's wife was doing laundry and I could smell the clothes dryer, a car passed me and the driver honked and waved, a burst of scent from some lilac bushes, oh yucky-another road kill, the sound of a rushing river, fresh silage being put into a farmers' silo, the breeze blowing and cooling my face and the smells from a bakery as I passed by. (And yes, I did stop for a cup of coffee and a maple cream bar!) WOW, intoxicating is right.  I was in heaven and so happy that I was where I was!   So, that is all I have to say for today.  It was my longest ride so far and I am exhausted but content.  I have a beautiful room at the Augusta Rose Bed abd Breakfast in Napolean, OH and I will sleep like a baby.   
I left later than usual today. I wanted to stop at a library but the Napolean one was not opening until later so I headed to Defiance.  I arrived there by 11 and spent a leisurely hour checking emails and looking up some travel quotes that I like to use.  The weather was overcast but quite warm.  Well, I pushed my luck and within a few miles of leaving Defiance I was in a rainstorm.  But it was actually very pleasant.  It was warm and the rain was falling very softly.  It felt so good on my face. Grandma Tupy used to catch rain water in a bucket and she used it to wash her waist long hair.  She said it was the best for washing hair.  Well, today I got everything washed!  I'm sure she was smiling down on me; seeing how much I was enjoying it.  Within an hour I had biked out of the rain.  I was going to only go about 40 miles today but when I got to Paulding I didn't like peoples' comments when I told them where I was staying so I continued on to VanWert, a little out of my way, but I am now in a nice, clean room, showered, laundry done and ready to go for dinner next door.  Life is good!  I'm sure my good luck won't last forever so stay tuned for more exciting journals.  I'll see what trouble I can get into!
I cross over the Ohio/Indiana border and by twenty miles and a few little rain showers I have stopped for hot chocolate at a gas station.  The lady informs me that it is only 8:30, not 9:30 as I am now in Central Time.  I'm feeling pretty good about having that extra hour.  My plan was to only go to Huntington, IN but by 11:00 A.M. I had in 50 miles and I was within 7 miles of Huntington so I got the maps out and decided to aim for Wabash.  In the middle of nowhere I pull out my cell phone and call ahead to the Lamp Post Bed and Breakfast.  The owner, Janet Conner tells me she will hold a room for me.  I have about 20 some miles to go and am already looking forward to a nice, 4 poster bed.  About the time I start pedaling again the wind kicks up a notch and I am reduced to 7-8 M.P.H., disappointing after I was sailing along at 15-18 all morning long. I have to say, the Indiana people are very, very friendly but the dogs did not do very well at doggie obedience school.  I was chased by at least 8 mutts and only by my screaming NO, NO, NO and kicking up the speed a notch was I able to lose the little and big rascals. One guy caught me totally off guard, I didn't see him coming and I almost went into cardiac arrest. The funniest were the mutts that were tied up to a leash but started chasing me anyway.  Yikes, that must hurt when you realize you are at the end of the rope!  Serves em' right! And yes, I was humming that damn song all afternoon! So, as I'm fighting the winds I am slowly making progress towards the Salamonie River State Forest.  The roads get a little hillier and the rain clouds are threatening.  As I am crossing the dam I start to feel a few drops so I stop to put my raincoat on. A little further I can sense that this is not going to pass so I stop to put my rainpants on.  Within a few minutes I am in the most incredible rainstorm.  It was coming down in sheets.  I kept pedaling, shuddering with each roll of thunder and crack of lightening.  It was raining so hard that I could literally feel my shoes filling with water.  In the midst of this I had to stop under a tree to consult the map as I was within 7 miles of my home for the night.  Good thing my map was waterproof!  I worked my way out of the park and the rain starts letting up.  But wait, I think I have a flat tire.  Of course, the rear flat.  So, I pull over to a grassy/muddy knoll and get to work.  The tire comes off, the tube comes out and I have one more good, unused spare.  I quickly replace the tube and start pumping in air.  In my haste I forgot to open the end of the pump that fits over the Presta valve and proceeded to pull off the valve end, PPPSSSSTTTT, there goes all the air!  Deep breath, swear words, OK, start over.  This time I had to use a tube that had a patch on it.  That quickly went in, got everything put together, packs mounted, trailer hitched and I'm ready to go.  But wait, what is that bump, bump, bump every time I pedal?? I don't see anything obvious so I get my map out and see that there is a bike shop in the next town.  I call there and get some advice.  I am told that perhaps the tube has a kink which is causing the wobble. Well, I press my luck and decide that I can handle the bumps if I ride slower.  Well, the bumps didn't like the bumps and within a few miles I had another flat.  OK, I am no longer having fun.  I stop at the edge of town to go pee at a gas station/diner.  As I'm coming out of the bathroom Frick and Frack are sitting in a booth.  Frick says, "Where ya headin', or are ya just out riden?"  I look at them both and tell them I'm doing a cross country ride.  Frick says, "Where did ya start?", and at the same time Frack says, "Where ya goin?"  I said, New York City to San Francisco and they both unanimously say, "HMMM."  It was hilarious.  I needed that to keep me going the last mile that I had to push the bike to the B&B.  I was anxious to get there and find some shelter to change the tire. I knock on the door and am greeted by this sweet, sweet smiling lady. I ask her where I can change my flat before coming in and getting cleaned up.  We go around back to her garage.  I start to get disassembled and her neighbor, Steve Porter comes over.  The are both helping with rags, a bucket of water and tons of questions.  An hour or so later the task is complete.  I still have a problem adjusting the rear brake but that will have to wait until tomorrow.  I decide that I will spend two nights here and take Sunday off like I had promised myself when I was planning this adventure. I shower and Janet and I walk downtown and have dinner together. The funny thing is, I am still in high spirits and blessed with such  wonderful, caring people that are there at the right moment.  I fall asleep to the smells of banana cake being prepared for tomorrow's breakfast. Sweet! F.T.C. Gladys 2   
I share a wonderful breakfast with Steve and Jo from Milwaukee, WI.  Before long Steve is in the garage with me, helping me fix the brakes.  What have I said about people coming into my life at the right moment?  I get goosebumps thinking about it.  We say goodbye and I join Janet for Sunday church services at the United Methodist church two blocks from her home and then we go out for lunch.  I spend the day cleaning my bike, making phone calls, plotting over maps and arranging my lodging for tomorrow night. Sorry, no adventures today but wait a few days, I'll see what I can dream up.
Happy Birthday to my Dad, who, with Mom, has spent his birthday on the road, leaving southern Minnesota and heading to Illinois to meet up with me and be my sag support for a while.  Thanks, Dad!  Mom, start cookin,' I'm eating like a horse these days! I hugged my new friend, Janet, goodbye.  I felt like I had known her for a long time.  I headed back north to catch the Adventure Cycling route west.  I thought that I had only 50 some miles to go so I putsed along, stopping frequently.  Everytime I would stop at a farm with cows or horses the animals would slowly amble over to the fence to check me out.  Some of them were more interested than others and we had a few chats.  I was on country roads almost all day so lunch was a Luna Bar and trailmix.  By early afternoon I realized I would do more than 50 miles so I picked up the pace but I also hit some very bumpy roads and a section under consruction that was covered with loose gravel. My rear tire decided to start losing air so about every 2-3 miles I had to stop and add air. I wanted to get to my Inn to change the tube so I could put it in water to find the leak.  I finally arrived a little after 4:00, changed the tire, showered and went to dinner. I'm going to get a beer belly if I'm not careful.  I've never liked beer much, but at the end of a long day on the dusty trail a beer tastes so damn good! F.T.C.  (Flat Tire Count) 4 "Afoot and light-hearted I take to the open road.  Healthy, free, the world before me.  The long brown path before me leading wherever I choose." Walt Whitman 1881
I stuck my thumb out and it felt so awkward that I immediately withdrew it and as two trucks passed I thought to myself, 'that's OK, I really don't need a ride.'  Here I was, a woman just three months shy of 50, a grandmother; hitchhiking!!  I sucked up some courage and tried again.  This time a bright red pickup truck came to a screeching halt right behind my handicapped bike.  I accepted a ride to a town 11 miles from where my tire went flat.  I had no good spares and no patches left.  When I arrived in the town of  Brook I was dropped off at the Farm Equipment Store and between them and the local hardware store I was able to buy a patch kit, fix both tubes, have a nice lunch and hit the road.  I think I met every resident of Brook that afternoon.  I continued on, touching base via cell phone with my Mom and Dad who were driving east through Illinois.  By late afternoon, two more flats and an afternoon downpour I was close to our meeting spot.  We kept calling each other and at one point it was like a scene from the Keystone Cops.  "Where are you?"  "I'm on 52 West heading to Ashkum."  "OK, we'll be right there."  Two minutes later- "OK, you're not there, are you really on Hwy 52?" Somehow we managed to find each other.  Finally I see a beautiful Winnebago off the side of the road. I started crying and waving in excitement.  I had finally found the Tupy Traveling Hotel. And what a beauty it is. Brand new, only one week old and it is a luxurious home on wheels with all the amenities you could ever need.  It will be a treat not to have to hunt for loding every night for the next week.  Not to mention my Mom's great cooking and Dad's expert bartending.  OK, now I want you all to know that I know how much you enjoy my misadventures but this has got to stop.  I know that you are a very demanding bunch but it would be OK if one of these days I wouldn't have much to say. I'm sure that some of you think that I am making all this up-I wish I were that creative.  Rest assured that none of these stories are embellished.  My goal for tomorrow is 85 miles so we'll see.    FTC. 7
Well kids, today was probably the most normal day a bicycle tourist could ask for.  Other than head winds and a slight uphill road, it was a pretty uneventful day.   But let me tell you, if you are ever on a bicycle tour and have the luxury of being sagged in a motorhome-do whatever you need to convince the owners to sag you. Promise them the finest scotch, steaks, whatever it takes.  It is worth it!  I am enjoying this so much. Honey, my birthday is coming up, what color should I order? Mom made a light breakfast and I was off.  By 11:30 we met in Dwight, IL and had lunch together.  Than Mom and Dad went ahead to Streator to get set up at the campground.  By 3:30 I was enjoying cheese, crackers and a cold beer.  (So far no beer belly).  Do you notice that so much of touring revolves around eating?  I have a voracious appetite and I think I'm actually even losing a few pounds.     
The 10 mile section of road leaving Henry had a Road Closed sign at the intersection but I decided to ride on it anyway.  I didn't see any activity indicating road work..........until about two miles down the road.  Then I saw a sign that said "Fresh Oil."  Oh, a biker really loves to see that.  I had visions of my lime green bike jersey looking like a leopard at the end of the day.  But by then I was committed. The worst thing a bike tourist wants to do is backtrack, and the oil was covered with a fairly even coat of heavily crushed sand.  (I know there is probably a special word  for the sand but I don't know it.)  I continued at a pretty good pace and was happy that there was almost no traffic. I approached the top of a hill and was stopped to plug in my earphones to listen to music.  Then I saw in the distance a truck coming up the hill but I also noticed what looked like a biker in front of the truck.  And sure enough, I think I was about to meet my first bicycle tourist of this ride.  As we passed each other we turned around at the same time as we realized we were both gypsies on the road. We stopped to talk.  I asked him where he was headed and before we knew it we were shaking hands in amazement that we both lived in Boulder, Colorado! His name is Manfred Schwoch and he is biking to his 50 year high school reunion in a small town in Indiana.  His wife is sagging him in a camper van. Our meeting kept me going for many miles today.  I was totally inspired by him and felt even more convinced that this is what I really should be doing.   I arrived at the campground after 4:00 and was very, very happy to be done for the day.  85 degrees so it was hot, windy, dusty and hilly.  Sort of like poking a needle in your eye all day long, but I'm still smilin.'
I left earlier today, hoping to avoid the terrible heat of the afternoon. At 7 A.M. the bank clock said 72 degrees!   I headed west on some roads and south on others so I had a break with the winds.  Not as hilly as yesterday, either.  About twenty miles out, on a nice, smooth country road I was watching these cute little black birds. They had a red marking on their backs and there seemed to be a lot of them.  All of a sudden I could see ones'shadow right over my head and it was dive bombing my head.  After a bit another one would take over. I swear they chirped over to the next electrical line and passed the harrassment on down. At one point I took my bicycle pump and starting madly waving it in the air.  I'm sure the car that passed me at that moment thought I had lost my marbles.  I felt like the guy in the "Karate Kid" movie, trying to catch flies with his chopsticks.   Eventually they got tired of me or perhaps I was out of their territory. (True story in case any of you are wondering if I am making these up!) In the little town of Henderson, IL I stopped a car at a stop sign for directions.  She was very helpful and about 5 blocks away she had turned aound to come back to give me better directions. By 11:30 I was at 48 miles and approaching the town of Galesburg.  I stopped at a gas station for ice water and a break.  I asked about a campground  that was supposed to be in the next town over.  Several guys gave me directions.  A few minutes later one of the guys came back to clarify a few things.  I started on my way and then stopped under a nice, big, shade tree for my lunch.  Before I knew it I was sound asleep! Wow, that felt good. I continued on towards the town with the campground and all of a sudden, in my mirror I saw a big pickup truck with its' flashers on, and it wasn't passing me.  At an intersection it pulled up beside me.  It was the same guy from the gas station that helped me earlier.  He had his wife and son with him and he had made some phone calls and located the campground so he drew me a very detailed map on how to get there.  He had an enormous USA flag mounted in the back of his pickup truck.  Good people in the state of Indiana! Time for that cold beer!
We woke during the night to an incredible rain storm but by 6AM the sky had mostly cleared.  I left byh 6:45, anxious to beat the heat but more anxious to get to my sisters house in Mt. Pleasant, knowing I could put the bike away for three nights!   Just before I crossed the mighty Mississippi River at Burlington, IA I guess Illinois was giving me a kick in butt with a flat tire.  This was a flat tire that had the new, super duper, heavy duty inner-tube in it.  I had a new spare so quickly changed it.  You would all be quite impressed with how fast I can change a flat!  My mother brought me some bright purple surgical gloves so I'm sure I looked the sight, changing my flat wearing gloves.  Hey, I hate greasy hands!   I crossed the river and then met my parents at Bickels Bike Shop in Burlington.  I put a new tire on the rear as the original one had several puncture holes in it and the new one is a little heavier.  They told me that it's possible I am having so many flats because my tires were very underinflated.  I was told in Boulder I did not need a tire gauge but bought one today because I thought I always had enough air in the tires but I guess not. Back on the road and arrived at my sisters by 1:30.  My clothes are already washed and dried.  Thanks Sis!  And I even shaved my pits and legs and curled my hair today!   Now for some serious R&R! F.T.C. Gladys 8
    
Before hugging my sister goodbye I told her we were not going to cry.  Besides, who could cry hugging a weirdo like me, wearing a bike helmet with a turtle glued to the top!   Diane cooked and together with Mom and Dad they all helped with my repairs and errands. It was nice to spend some time together and we did a lot of talking and laughing.  Thanks Sis! Today I awoke to the smell of coffee and quiche.  How can one lose weight when assaulted with the wonderful smells of a good cook's kitchen? I felt so rested this morning and it felt like I had been off my bike for ages.  Who ever said Iowa was flat?  Yikes-today was like a mini version of Pennsylvania.  I call them turtle hurdles.  But I made very good time.  About 35 miles out of Mt. Pleasant I was on a road that had a sign that read, "Iowa Amish Trail."  It was a county road with very little traffic.  Soon I saw an Amish buggy coming toward me.  Inside were a Mom and her four children.  They had on bonnets and straw hats and the children seemed very shy and would not smile. A little further down I observed two different homesteads where the mothers were out in the garden with the children.  I felt like I was intruding so I just waved and took a mental picture. Five miles down the road, as I'm slowly working up a hill, I noticed a black speck in my mirror that kept getting closer to me. I turned around and saw that it was a horse and rider, at full gallop, coming up right behind me.  As they got closer they crossed to the other side of the road to pass me.  It was a beautiful 10 year old Amish boy with the biggest smile on his face.  In his left hand he was holding the reins, in the right he had a brown wrapped package and his straw hat.  He had probably been returning from   the post office in town.  He turned onto a driveway in front of me, all the while smiling; probably excited about what was is the package.  His mother was working in the garden.  I felt like I had gone back in time. It was a very beautiful and peaceful scene.  I arrived at the campground around 3:00.  Mom and Dad arrived a bit later and we shared another wonderful dinner.  Now I am icing my knees.  They are bothering me a bit so I don't know if I have to lower my mileage a bit, ice them every night or pour scotch into my Camelback water pack.
I left the campground around 7:30 and had only gone a few miles when one of our camper neighbors stopped me in his truck.  He saw me leave and was worried that I was going to backtrack and he knew of an easier way to get to my main route so he jumped in his car and came to find me. He and his wife lived in the area and were at the campground with their two granchildren.  I am so blessed that there are so many friendly people in this world.............. But, I AM FINALLY GOING TO VENT!  (Oh yeah, finally some good stuff!) But I will warn you that if you don't like swear words you should take your little mouse and fast forward to the next paragraph.  I was on Hwy 2 heading west and had no shoulder. I was in the middle of an uphill and saw a truck coming towards me and one in my rear mirror.  I tried to stay as close to the white line as possible.  The trucker behind me kept coming and before I knew it both trucks were meeting each other with me on the right shoulder.  He was so close I could feel the truck almost brush by my arm.  I could not believe the rudeness of the asshole trucker that he could not wait and pass me safely. I was so angry and upset.  What was the rush?   I was wishing him all kinds of ill will- 'Damn you, I hope you get a flat tire today, that you stub your toes when you get up to pee tonight and that the IRS audits you because I'm sure you are the kind of dead beat that has not paid your taxes for years!'  I also was thankful that his behavior was in the minority among truck drivers.  I saluted the next trucker as he passed me and gave me all the space I needed.   OK, that feels better.  The happy news is that at 6PM my son Mike and my two grandbabies met us in Leon, IA.  Yes, they are my grandbabies even though they are 8 and 4, they will always be my grandbabies.  I was greeted with many hugs and kisses and am so happy right now.  We are going for ice cream right now! So, today had a good ending.
As I waved a tearful goodbye to my Mom and Dad I had two little cheerleaders standing at the end of the hotel parking lot shouting, "Go Grandma, Go."   Mom and Dad, I just want to tell you how special it was that you were able to sag me for the past 9 days.  I had such a great time and felt very pampered.  Each day I would look forward to seeing that beautiful motorhome parked under the trees at the campground.  Inside would be a cold beer waiting for me and a nice snack before dinner.  I slept like a baby every night and will have wonderful memories of the time we spent together.  Thank you for all that you have done.  I will miss you both very much. Today was a short day so I could spend as much time with Mike, Austin and Nicole.  I had a pretty hilly start the first half of the day.  By noon I only had less than 20 miles to go and the hills became a little gentler so I plugged in my Disco music.  Wow!  You should see me dancin' on the bike.  It's quite interesting and I might have to take the show on the road!  It's a pretty new routine and I checked my mirror before dancing to make sure no cars were coming. It was hilarious. It's amazing what one can do to pass the time on a bike.  I was getting tired of counting the bumps on the road today so the dancing was a nice diversion. I know, I'm whacked!! I met my son and the kids at 2:00 and we stopped to get some beer and then took Austin and Nicole to a park.  Later we went to the hotel where we spent the rest of the afternoon swimming.  Now we are going for dinner.     
Another tearful goodbye today but I was also so happy that I was able to spend two days with my son Mike, and our grandchildren, Nicole, 8, and Austin, 4. We slept in this morning and after breakfast went swimming.  I repacked all my gear and after lunch we were driving to my drop off point in Bedford.  Took a few pictures and then I was off. I'm so used to riding in the early morning and by 1:30 today it was in the high 80's.  I only biked to Maryville, MO because I could not find lodging any closer to St. Joseph.  As it was I had a hard time.  The winds were from the South/Southeast and I was heading South!  Of course! Plus I haven't had to haul my gear for the past 11 days.  What the heck is in all these @!?# packs anyway? I'm working on a poem about the wind but I have to try and delete some of the swear words.  When I do that there is not much of a poem left!   
I left the hotel by 6:30 this morning, trying to beat the heat.  Much slower going with a full load but making forward progress.  At around 2:00 I saw this car in the other lane, honking the horn, waving at me. The car quickly turns around and I realize it's my crazy sister Marlene.  She jumps out to get a sweaty hug and then runs back to her car.  She comes back with an ice cold wash cloth.  Do you know good that feels on a 90 degree Kansas day?  We loaded up her car with my trailer and panniers.  Now I was cruising along at 18 MPH instead of 8.  Yeeh hah! NOTE:  If you go back to the Table of Contents I have added a chapter on The SIMPLE THINGS IN LIFe.  I will add to it as I think of things.  I have also added a chapter on LESSONS LEARNED. Mostly for those of you who may be crazy enough to be considering doing a cross country tour. Anyway, my sister is here with me now for the whole week.  We are spending two nights at the Majestic House, a Bed and Breakfast in Atchison, KS, birthplace ofAmelia Earhart.   The Majestic House was built in 1890 by the brothers of Saint Benedicts Abbey.  The home is out in the country and is beautifully appointed with antiques.  The owners Jan and Junior have 5 guestrooms in the main house and are restoring the old barn which will have 20 rooms!  The house pet is a cute, white fluffy dog named Muffy who loves to pull weeds in the yard. After my ride today we stopped for fresh fruit, bread, cheese and wine and had a picnic dinner out on the grounds of the Inn.  It was a warm summer evening and later we soaked in the hot tub and watched the fireflys.  Back in our room there was a tray of fresh baked pecan cookies and ice water.  I'm telling you, life just doesn't get any better than this. After a running jump to get into the high bed I think it took me 30 seconds to fall asleep!   
A fresh cinnamon roll scent woke us up at 8:00. That was a snack before a breakfast of pork chops, scrambled eggs, farm potatoes and fresh biscuits. Do you notice how much I talk about food? After breakfast we went to Sunday church at St. Benedicts in Atchison.  When we got back to the bed and breakfast to gather some munchies and Marlene noticed that my flag pole had broken off of my bike.  It only had the Illinoisand Iowa flag on it but I was pretty bummed so as we drove back towards town we backtracked where we thought the flag may have broken off yesterday.  Sure enough, there it was by the side of the road so I was happy about that.  Then we went to the Amelia Earhart Earthworks where her profile is in the side of a hill and made out of different grasses and rocks.  Later we drove to the little town of Weston, Missouri.  We browsed amongst the antique shops and sampled McCormick vodka's and liquors.  On the way out of town we spotted a sign for Pirtle Wines so we sampled some wines, bought a bottle of wine and sat outside in the vineyard having another picnic.  You know, this trip would be a lot of fun in a car!!  Just kidding, but today was a very nice, fun day.   
I could have sat and visited with Jan and Junior for hours this morning but forced myself to get going around 7:15. Marlene rolled over and enjoyed the morning at the bed and breakfast while I worked the hills of Kansas. Damn, everyone kept telling me how flat some of these states are but THEY'RE NOT!! But, by noon I had 50 miles again and was enjoying my lunch under a tree.  By 12:30 what was a very humid but cooler, overcast day turned into a steam bath.  I felt like I had just stepped into a tub of sugar water-sticky all over. And the winds kicked up a notch, coming from the South/Southwest.  With 15 miles to go I turned North and had a blast. The wind was blowing straight north and literally blew me to the top of the each hill.  With 7 miles to go I met Marlene approaching on the other side-pushing her bike up a huge hill, against the wind. I told her she had to bike if she wanted a beer after. Man, you should have seen her fly! So.....Pssshhh......Aaah...... yup, it was a cold one. Now we are sitting at the laudromat, in front of a fan, having afternoon cocktails, trying to think of humorous things to put on this page :):) I must apologize if you are looking for the nitty gritty of biking.  After all, what can one say about biking?  It's a way to get from one end of the state to the other end and I really enjoy what happens before and after the biking.  Yes, I enjoy the smells, the animals, the views and the fresh air but I especially enjoy the people I meet and the things I see. So, Boulder get ready, I'm comin' home and I'm hug deficient!   
Marlene drove me from Seneca, where our hotel was, to Centralia, where I stopped yesterday. We had just left the hotel and heard a strange sound towards the back of the car.  I was worried that one of the straps was loose on the bike rack so we pulled over.  As Marlene got out of the car a jogger was passing by, pointing to the top of her car where her very large and heavy purse was!  At 6:30 am it was very humid and the skies were rumbling. By the time we got the bike off the rack the lightening bolts were striking as well.  We debated what to do and decided I would start out and pray a lot.  At 5 miles I pulled over to put on a windbreaker and within 10 minutes I was drenched.  The thunder and lightening was all around me and I kept trying to make myself small, hoping the bolts would find a more desireable object than little ole' me. Maybe it was the bright green jacket that did it but soon I was out of the rain.  I love the feeling of being outside right after a rain storm.  The smells are wonderful.  Marlene caught up with me after checking out of the hotel and we met for coffee in Frankfort. I started out again and soon after had another rainstorm. This time it cleared up and I could feel the thermometer just go crazy.  It's amazing how much more tiring it is to ride in hot, humid 96 degree weather.  With 25 miles to go Marlene met me on her bike to finish the day.  We took a break at one point at a little roadside rest area. There was a pickup truck parked there and Sis noticed a cooler in the back of the truck. She walked over and did not see anyone in the cab so she snooped in the cooler.  It was full of beer! We commiserated for a while about how much money to put in the cooler for two beers.  After checking again she realized there was no ice and the beer was warm, and since we still had 8 miles to go we decided to pass.  The heat was definitely affecting our behavior and luckily we are now in our comfy hotel room instead of the Clifton Jailhouse. The only dining establishment in town was Brett's Club. The lady at the hotel suggested it.  We opened the door and had to be buzzed in to the second door. We should have known-Brett's CLUB!  The minute we walked in some guy said, "here come the dancers." Yeah, right, you're a loser!  The gal at the bar said that if we wanted to have dinner there we had to be a guest of someone or pay $10.59 to join! This was hilarious.We told her Roberta from Newell's Country Lodge sent us there, so she said, "Oh, well then, you can have dinner here."  As we were leaving another guy came and asked us if we were the bikers going cross country.  Word travels fast in small towns; good think we didn't hock the beer from the pickup truck! Our exciting evening ended with a stop at the only gas station in town for some Kansas Cashball lottery tickets.  I've already checked the phone book for a Harley Davidson dealer.   
Oh, what a day!  I was in the saddle at 6:15 and just cruisin' along.  Marlene met me 2 hours later in Concordia for a good, old fashioned breakfast at the downtown cafe.  I continued on and with a nice wind from the North/Northeast I felt like I was flying.  I met about a hundred bikers going in the opposite direction that were with the B.A.K. group.  (Bike Across Kansas)  I had 61 miles by noon and Marlene met me with 11 miles to go.  We stopped in Cawker City to see the world's largest ball of twine!  (Yes Dan, we took a picture!)  Boy, that was momentous!  We also stopped at the library/City Hall and were the first users of the libraries new computer.  It only took them an hour to figure out how to turn it on.! On a more serious note-I have now biked through a good representation of America's breadbasket.  What an eye opening sight that has been.  I have seen farm machinery designed to hold huge tanks full of fertilizers and pesticides that is being sprayed on what will become our bread, cornflakes, soy products, crackers, cookies, etc.etc.  The machinery has hazardous material signs on the back. And it's being sprayed on our food?? That in turn is being filtered through the soil into our ground water, lakes and rivers. Not to mention the same sprayed crops being fed to the meat that we consume. It was a very upsetting sight.  And we wonder why cancer and other diseases are so common. What can we do about it?  I know for sure that I will try to buy organic foods more often now and I know we can all support our local farmers' markets that sell organic fruits and vegetables in the summer months. If we don't support them they will go out of business.  At breakfast this morning I noticed a man with a baseball cap with the following written on it: Avoid Cholesterol, preservatives, carcinogens, pesticides, and starve to death!  HHMMMM.  Perhaps we all need to read (or re-read) John Robbins' Diet For A New America. And add to the reading list, Fast Food Nation as well. Tonight we are staying at the Howell House Bed and Breakfast.  The owners are Steve and Joan Heide and Steve's sister lives in Boulder. A very comfortable bed and breakfast in Downs, KS.   
This morning my sister actually left before I did. She wanted to get a head start and get to Phillipsburg early so she could then get on her bike and ride towards me.  That was the plan, anyway.  I left the B&B about 30 minutes after she did.  Within 5 miles I was in a huge downpour, soaking wet. I had only taken my windbreaker-my raingear was in her car-DUH! We talked on cell phones and Marlene decided to turn around and come back.  When she got there I crawled into her car like a wet puppy-dripping all over.  It was pretty cold so I changed my shirt and socks and put my rain gear on. Sis decided to stick close by in case of severe weather.  Another 15 miles and the rain was letting up.  I thought only Colorado had weird weather. As I was biking along at one point I saw a bagel in a baggie, attached to a road sign with duct tape.  I knew who the culprit was as I loaned her my duct tape yesterday so she could attach a second water bottle to her bike!  That amazing duct tape!  We met for lunch at a small town diner and she still had time to go ahead to the hotel, check in and then ride towards me to finish the day. What a sister! I am so blessed.
Oh I hate goodbyes.  Today was the last day that my sis was with me.  I started out early again and Marlene drove ahead to Oberlin.  She jumped on her bike and met me 18 miles out so she did 36 miles today!  Northwest Kansas is rolling hills but it was a beautiful day, much cooler since yesterday's rain.  We finished around 2:00 and celebrated with onion rings and a rootbeer float at A&W.  Tonight we are staying at the Landmark Inn, a bed and breakfast in a renovated bank building.  The owner is also a chef and we had dinner in the Teller Room. Tomorrow Marlene has offered to drive my trailer and bag to my hotel in St. Francis, KS-due west of here about 70 miles and then she will turn around and head 630 miles northeast to go back to Minnesota.   So, goodbye sis and thank you from the bottom of my heart.  I had a great week with you, lots and lots of laughs and girl talk about every subject under the sun. I appreciate you taking your time to drive all through the Midwest to sag me and take such good care of me.  I love you dearly but please don't embarrass me by taping bagels to street signs-you might get picked up!     
At 5:00 am we were awoken to a hard rain and then hail.  My watch alarm went off at 5:50 which I turned off, rolled over and went back to sleep.  Marlene's alarm went off at 6:15 and she did the same.  Finally at 6:20 I decided it was inevitable that I had to hit the road and send her on her way as well.  We were out by 7:00 and she went ahead to St. Francis to drop off my stuff.  Then she came back towards me and we had breakfast together before our sad goodbye. I will let the pictures do the talking today.  My only diversions were the tumbleweed that blew across the road and big, black bugs that were scurrying around on the side of the road.  I put my music on and that helped pass the day.  I also crossed into Mountain Time so I gained an hour but I am staying at one of those super budget motels and this is one day I would have been happy arriving late.  I swear to God that my parents stayed here with us kids in the 50's and they haven't redecorated since then-brown, yellow and gold shag carpet, bright gold paint on the walls, mustard yellow bedspread and the window air-conditioner that will lull me to sleep!  Yikes!  But a nice surprise was the cold beer and fresh cherries waiting when I arrived.  Thanks, Marlene! Anyway, I am ready for the mountains and some new scenery-bring it on! Happy 52nd Anniversary to my Mom and Dad!       
I was anxious to leave Kansas and head for home.  My hotel experience got even worse last night when, at 3:39 A.M., a very noisy cricket found his way into my room through the door and proceeded to serendade me for the next 3 hours.  Each time I would turn the light on to try to find him he stopped creaking. At 4:30 I considered getting dressed and heading out but I really wanted to sleep.  So, at 7:00 I left, which was really 6:00.  Remember yesterday, I THOUGHT I was already in Mtn Time so when I went to dinner at 6:45 I found out it was really 7:45 so I was all screwed up.  Anyway, within 22 miles I was in Nebraska which lasted for about 8 miles.  I needed breakfast but both tiny towns in the Nebraska corner were ghost towns.  I crossed the Colorado border, stopping to take a picture of the "Welcome to Colorful Colorado" sign and calling my husband and daughter to share my excitement with them. (Neither one answered their phone-oh well!) About 8 miles further I stopped in Wray, CO to get my late breakfast at a 7-11. While there I met my second bicycle tourist.  And guess what? He was from Colorado also!  Vern is from Denver and had just left yesterday, heading to Lincoln, Nebraska on a one week tour.  So far, Colorado bicyclists rule! My room tonight is a lot nicer and so far no crickets!  Jennifer and her friend Chris are driving to Fort Morgan tomorrow to sag me for two days so I am very excited to see them.
Man, I got my butt kicked today!  I left Yuma at 6:30 but it was already 63 degrees.  Colorado gave me a warm Welcome Home with head winds coming from the west.  Every pedal stroke was painful. The miles ever so slowly turned over on the computer. I kept drinking water and after 13 miles stopped in Otis for breakfast. I put my music on but the wind was so strong that I had a difficult time concentrating on the songs-forget about singing along!  Yikes, what a day.  I pulled into Fort Morgan at 2:00 and the bank building showed 99 degrees and the weather channel said the wind gusts were up to 16 miles an hour.  I'm beat! My daughter Jennifer and her boyfriend Chris borrowed my Miata and drove to Fort Morgan tonight so we had dinner together and they are sagging me for the next two days into Boulder.  It was so good to see them.  She is a nanny for the summer and also cashiers at Whole Foods Market in Boulder so this big road trip is the highlight of her summer.  Hey, it's Mom's turn to play-last summer she was in Europe for three months!
I think I was half asleep when I asked the hotel manager how to get back on Hwy 34 to head to Wiggins,CO. She sent me in the opposite direction and after two miles I realized I was headed to Greeley-opposite direction of home!  So back I went and found Hwy 34.  I have to tell you, there is a huge difference between a sagged tour and a self contained tour.  When I began planning this ride I knew that I would have to haul my own gear but I am not a purist or into self torture and I have been so blessed with all the support that I have had so far.  But, one can get spoiled when someone else is carrying all your gear. I was just cruisin' today at 15 miles an hour. Jen and Chris came by at 48 miles and we found a shade tree in Prospect Valley and they had fresh olive bread, cheese and grapes for lunch. Where was the wine, Jen?? I only had 21 miles left and as I biked through Hudson I noticed a railroad track sign.  I always slow down before the tracks to check them out.  This time, however, I got right up to the tracks and noticed a huge, enormous gap before the track so I thought, 'oh shit, I better get off the bike and walk across the tracks.' I was almost at a stop and once again, realized I could not unclip.  So, down I went! Except this time, I immediately heard the RR gate come down-BEHIND ME!  I looked left and just around the corner I saw the train!  My front tire was inches from the track.  A gentleman in a truck shut his motor off and quickly came over to help me.  I unclipped and we moved my bike behind the gate and WHOOSH, there was the train! Woah, this was a little too close.  So, another biking lesson learned. From now on I promise that I will unclip before I cross the tracks!  My elbow bled like crazy and has a huge bump on it. My saggers were waiting for me at the hotel so Jen patched me up and now we are going for a movie and dinner.   

      
So let me tell you about the 'Trail Ridge Challenge'. When I was working on my routing I decided that I would take more time and a scenic route and see the sights I really love.  I knew that I wanted to ride through Boulder so it also seemed 'natural' that I would go through Rocky Mountain National Park and on to Steamboat Springs.  Which also meant going over the only road through Rocky Mountain Park-Trail Ridge Road. I put the challenge out to several Boulder biking buds and had two takers. Doug Speirn-Smith and John Accardi. Of course I think the most enticing aspect for them was the promise of beer and burgers after the ride. These two guys are serious, serious bikers and to them going over Trail Ridge Road is a warm-up ride and to me it was comparable to scaling Mt. Everest.  This morning Doug and I drove back to Estes Park from our cabin and met Doug and John at a very early 6:30A.M. We started out at 7:10 A.M.  A beautiful morning, cool temps and no winds. I do have to add here that my husband Doug and Doug's wife Christy said their goodbyes and then headed into Estes for a breakfast of omelets, crepes, and cappuccinos while we were sucking down powdered energy drinks.  HMMMM.  Not fair!! Trail Ridge Road leaves the beautiful city of Estes Park from the East entrance to Rocky Mountain National Park.  The climb is a  4,500 foot gain in elevation starting out at 7,500 feet and peaking at 12,020! John and Doug paced me at a nice even speed as we immediately began to climb.  We stopped frequently for photo moments, water, snacks and potty breaks.  My newest addition to all the other 'stuff' I haul on my bike is a squeaking turtle that is mounted on my handlebars. Thanks, my dear girlfriend, Christy.  This turtle came in very handy today.  Instead of hollering "car back" each time I saw a car in my mirror I would give the turtle a squeeze so the guys would know.  However, there were times I was concentrating so hard on the climb that I forgot to holler or squeak!  Before we knew it we were at 11,000 feet.  What incredible views and what a gorgeous day.  A little more climbing and then we were met by Doug, cruising by in my Miata convertible to take a few pictures and at the summit we stopped at the visitor's center for a nice lunch. Unbelievable that we had gotten to the top so quickly.  Of course, we were the center of attention as people marveled that we actually rode all the way on bikes!  As we passed some people they just looked at us and shook their heads.  Soon the clouds were threatening so we donned rain gear and started the steep, curvy descent down the other side of the mountain. What a gas that was! We crossed the Continental Divide, (another quick photo op) and kept on moving as we saw the rain clouds following us.  We rode through a few rain showers and arrived at the Grand Lake Lodge at 1:10 in the afternoon. And as promised, burgers and beer were the reward of the day.   In the afternoon we said goodbye to John, Doug and Christy and were joined for the rest of the day by Rick and Karen Sinner.  We browsed the shops in Grand Lake and then went back to Grand Lake Lodge for cocktails on the front porch swings overlooking Grand Lake and a wonderful dinner to end a very memorable day. Thanks to all my great friends for making this such a fun day. I am truly blessed!  And thanks to my partner Doug who took another week off from school to be in Boulder when I came through. For those of you interested in seeing the profile of this ride you can go to the following link: http://www.accardi.com/gladys up trailridge.htm If that does not work then go to Guestbook and find entry #75 from John Accardi and click on the link to see an amazing profile of Trail Ridge. (Thanks John) "This is my life.  It is my one time to be me.  I want to experience every good thing."  Maya Angelou           
Another morning of goodbyes.  We said goodbye to Rick and Karen and then I got my honey off at 7:30.  Decided that I would just relax at Grand Lake Lodge instead of rushing off to Kremmling.  Visited for a while with a very sweet couple from Flagstaff, Arizona. They were very interested in my ride and were on a two month car trip, heading to Minnesota where they used to live.  I did a little bit of computer work and then around 10:00 I realized I needed something to eat.  I packed up and wanted to enjoy the brunch at the lodge but it was closed.  So I stopped in the town of Grand Lake for a late breakfast and then headed to Kremmling.  By 11:00 it was very warm and very windy but I covered my miles in a little over 3 hours, but I don't think I'll stick around next time.  I much prefer riding in the early, cool of morning.  I must admit, there is nothing to do here in Kremmling and I don't have internet access tonight so it's TV for me.
After a good nights sleep I was on the road at 6:45.  Even though the daytime temps get very hot the evenings and early mornings are very cool.  Perfect riding weather.  The terrain around Kremmling is high desert with large ranch farms and the mountains in the background in a beautiful morning haze.  I was in no hurry so I took my time and enjoyed the sights.
