I was on a very mild grade going uphill most of the way.  At about 20 miles I notice two riders gaining on me from behind so I stopped and pulled over to meet them.  They looked like pack mules-totally loaded where you could barely see the bikes.  Poor guys!  Joe and Jeff were with 16 others riding the Transamerica Trail with Adventure Cycling; having left Virginia on May 5th and heading to Oregon by early August. They are camping all the way so they have to carry their camp gear and the group shares in carrying all the camp kitchen items and food.  We visited for a while and then met further up the road to take pictures at the Continental Divide-Muddy Pass, where they turned off and headed northeast and I headed up Rabbit Ears Pass and down to Steamboat. Joe said Colorado was his favorite state so far-I would definitely agree with him.  I worked my way up Rabbit Ears Pass and just loved the beautiful views and wildflowers. I was rewarded with an 15 mile down hill ride into Steamboat.  I had to stop several times to rest my hands from all the braking I was doing but what a blast!  Now I an resting at a condo that was graciously given to us for two nights by Doug and Christy Speirn-Smith.  Thanks again, guys!  You're the best!  My sister Cindy will arrive this afternoon to ride with me for a week and coincidentally my son James is here with his girlfriend, Jill for a wedding, so we will have dinner together tonight.       

What a way to leave Steamboat-we left the condo at 6:40 and just two blocks away we saw 2 hot air balloons getting filled in a large field.  We pulled over and watched until they were airborne.  Then we found a bike path that took us into the downtown area where we stopped for cappuchino and bagels.  It was a very cool morning so we headed towards Craig and enjoyed the rollng hills and rock formations.  By 11:00 we were within 15 miles and the heat was back.  Very interesting how cold it is in the morning and within 6 hours it is 90 degrees but the low humidity makes it more tolerable. At one point we were working up a hill and I noticed a little blue stuffed character on the side of the road.  It was Cookie Monster from Sesame Street. I hung him on Cindy's bike but then across the road we saw a pile of colored stuff so Cindy went over and turns out it was the rest of the Sesame Street gang.  It had been a crib mobile and was missing a few characters.  Cindy pulled off Big Bird and hung him on her bike.  I chose Elmo and Ernie.  Neither one of us wanted Cookie Monster so he got tossed back in the ditch.  Later as we were going through Craig a lady honked her horn and told me I lost something at the intersection.  It was poor Ernie, laying in the middle of the street.  Cindy went to rescue him and he's back on my bike. I have so much 'STUFF' hanging on my bike it's a wonder I make forward progress. Cindy was an awesome rider today and it's fun having companionship.  Not to mention it's amazing what sister talk about! Tonight we are staying at the Deer Park Inn in Craig. This afternoon we went to the Museum of Northwest Colorado.  My good friend, Kristy Horst from Boulder, taught in Craig a few years ago.  I won't say how many. But, her picture was in the museum and I am including it on this page.  For those of you that know her, please call her and give her some grief about it, ok?       
His name is Bill Perry.  He is the reason I am doing this ride.  And the reason that I ski, snowshoe, hike, run and scuba dive.  I want to be just like Bill when I grow up.   We met on Hwy 40 heading west towards Dinosaur, CO.  Cindy and I had about 20 more miles to go in our day and we were working up one of the many hills in Northwest Colorado.  All of a sudden up ahead we saw that a large, white Cadillac had pulled off the road just ahead of us.  Out jumped this happy, vibrant man.  He quickly approached us and asked if he could ask us a few questions.  He wanted to know all the details.  "Where are you going?  Where did you start?  What kind of tires and bike do you have?"  I quickly surmised that he was also a biker and he said, 'yes,' he and his wife Barbara were headed to Salt Lake City where he was doing a triathlon. He also told us he was going on a bike trip to Ireland this fall!  Then he told us he was 81 years old!!  He looked like he was 60!  What a joyful man.   Today was one of those days that you would sort of rather forget but yet it was such an unforgettable day that you know you will always remember and retell the story many times. My watch alarm went off at 6:00 am.  Cindy stirred a bit so I asked her if we should just sleep in a bit as we were planning on only riding to Maybell today-an easy 30ish miles.  We both went back to sleep and didn't awaken until 7:30.  We had a leisurely continental breakfast in the hotel lobby and finally pushed of at 9:00 A.M.  We enjoyed the morning and casually strolled into Maybell before noon.  Maybell is a hopping metropolis with one restaurant, one gas station, and two hotels.  We checked out the hotel that was suggested by the lady at the gas station. It was comfortable but we wondered what we were going to do in Maybell for so long.  We went for lunch and over lunch decided that we were going to go for the gold today.  Another 55 miles to Dinosaur.  It was 1:00 by the time we left and the heat had kicked up a notch.  We had a difficult hill heading out of town and soon realized that there were many more hills where that came from.  We were in the high desert with not a shade tree in sight.  We were told that there was nothing in the town of Elk Springs but a few shade trees so after 20 some miles we saw the sign for the town of Elk Springs, and sure enough, there was a small grove of shade trees off the side of the road. It was 4:30 and sweltering hot.  We found a few tufts of grass and within minutes we were both sound asleep.  By 5:30 we were back on the road; refreshed but tired and sore, knowing we had another 25 miles to go. With 20 miles left we met Bill.  I needed that boost of energy and  inspiration that he brought.  We kept battling the hills and the heat.  I counted close to 100 fire vehicles that passed us, heading west to battle fires in the Flaming Gorge area of Northeast Utah.  At 16 miles to go we see a white Cadillac approaching us.  The car turns around and pulls off in front of us again. It is Bill and Barbara.  Bill tells us that there is absolutely nothing in Blue Mountain and that we need to make Dinosaur before nightfall.  We thank him for the update and continue on.  By now it is around 8:00.  We can smell the smoke in the air from the fires and watch the bunny rabbits scurrying around off the side of the road.  At one point we are surrounded by huge Mormon crickets. The road is thickly covered with them.  I hate crickets!  We pass the 79 mile mark on my computer and I whoop with joy.  I have broken my daily mile record for this ride. We also know we have only about 6 miles to go.  But wait, is that Bill in his Cadillac again??  Yup, he's turning around!  We worry that perhaps the road is closed due to the fires.  He jumps out of his car again and comes back to tell us that he has made hotel reservation for us at the Terrace Hotel in Dinosaur and that we are almost there. We smile in amazement at such kindness and know that this has been a very, very special day.   
Well, good thing today was a low mileage day. Our bodies felt sluggish and slow, even with only 34 miles. I guess 86 miles will do that to you.  We left Dinosaur around 9:30 and after some stops at the CO and UT Dinosaur Visitor Centers we arrived in Vernal, UT around lunch time. We found a hotel with a nice outdoor pool and spent the afternoon doing laundry, soaking in the warm pool and taking a little nap. We keep getting updates on the fire that is out of control in the Flaming Gorge National Recreation Area at the UT, WY border.  One of the two roads going north into Wyoming is closed.  The other road is extremely steep and longer but that is the road I had planned on taking anyway because it is probably more scenic.  The fire is the #2 priority in the nation.  The trucks passing us yesterday seemed to have an urgency to them as they flew by us on the highway. So we plan on leaving very early tomorrow and seeing what happens.  We decided that we would hitchhike over the mountain if the fire poses a real health hazard in terms of breathing. Something new every day!     
What a spectacular day!  What an incredibly hard day! We knew we had high miles to do today so we were on the bikes before 7:00.  Within 5 miles of town we were climbing, knowing that would be the norm of the day.  Little did we know how much and how hard.  The first sign was an indication-it said, "5 percent to 8 percent grades, 10 switchbacks, 9 miles."  We painstakingly worked through the climb but that only took us into the heart of the mountains.  The whole day was pretty much a continuous climb. Around noon we were so tired of climbing that we stopped at a rest area and fell asleep on the black top next to the bathrooms!! The only thing that woke us was a fire ranger who pulled up in her pickup truck.  She probably thought we were dead! We had a nice lunch at the Red Canyon Lodge and thought that would energize us for the 25 miles we had left but we were slowly losing steam no matter how much water we drank or what kind of food we ate.  Just after lunch we saw two bike tourists across the road.  We stopped to say hello.  In broken English we found out they were from Germany and on a one year bike tour from Seattle to South America. Their bikes were very rudimentary; again, loaded down like pack animals.  No helmets, wearing Teva sandals, but looking very fit.  They were camping along the way and commented on how much they missed German food. Wait till they get to Mexico!  Refried spaetzle? There was a nice 5 mile downhill overlooking the Flaming Gorge Reservoir which as always, was fun.  Around that time, as we saw more hills, Cindy took two spills within 30 minutes of each other so now she has war wounds to take back home with her. We were both so tired that we laughed ourselves silly. The last 6 miles were mostly uphill into Manila; that is always very hard at the end of the day.  I was becoming severally overheated so I pushed my bike for several miles and then dug deep to finish.  No fireworks tonight. Our hotel has a lot to be desired.  No A/C, the shower drips constantly and our dinner was a cold beer, Pringles chips and a bag of fresh cherries! Yum! Hope you all had a great 4th of July.     
I always knew this bike ride was really two seperate rides.  New York to Boulder and Boulder to San Francisco.  Well, I think I was right.  The mountains are.....mountains. What else can I say?  Hill after hill after hill.  But, I have also been very spoiled so far with so many family and friends helping me haul my gear.  These past five days I have hauled my B.O.B. trailer and full panniers and it is HARD, thigh burning work!   The alarm went off at 6:00.  Cindy says, "I'm not getting out of bed.......unless you bring me a warm washcloth."  So being the good older sister, I lured her out of bed and we got going. We headed due north on a sunny, already warm morning. Within a few miles we were snapping photos at the Welcome to Wyoming sign.  Five miles after that the road sign read, "Loose Gravel."  We were able to keep riding but not for long.  Gee, we haven't had a flat tire for a while and we wouldn't want to get out of practice, right?  Rear tire flat, of course.  Close to where I had the flat we saw several large road construction earth movers so we pulled up next to one to use as a prop and also for shade.  With two extra hands the flat was quickly changed. We continued on. The 45 mile stretch between Manila and Green River was high desert. Very hilly and not a single thing for shade.  It was extremely hot and hard. To amuse ourselves we discussed what we would want if we came across a palm thatched cabana off the side of the road.  Pina coladas, rum punch, ice cold watermelon and cold cantaloupe filled with vanilla ice cream were the top picks. We stopped in Green River for a late lunch and decided to go the extra 15 miles to Rock Springs.  Cindy is flying home from Rock Springs on Sunday morning so now I have two days off instead of one. I have to say, my Mom and Dad raised some tough girls.  Cindy, you are awesome and one tough biker dude. I have had a great week with you and will have many fun memories.  Thanks for sharing this week with me.  I hope your bruises heal and that your coworkers don't laugh at your cute biker tan.  I Love You! SIS F.T.C. Gladys 9     

My support crew is relentless!!  Another changing of the guard today. Cindy left early yesterday morning and my bestest girlfriend, Christy, arrived from Boulder at 3 in the afternoon. The main thing that kept me going today was the promise of fresh olive bread, cheese, cherries, olives and a nice bottle of white wine. And chocolate, of course! This morning I was on the bike at 7 am.  It was a beautiful, high desert morning.  Rock Springs has the second largest number of wild horses in the USA.  Soon after I started out I saw a dusty trail off to the East and was so excited. My heart was beating so fast, the dust tail was coming towards me and I could almost see the wild horses heading in my direction. I was ready to stop at any moment and snap a ton of photos. I kept waiting, waiting. Turns out it was a pick-up truck on a dirt road!!  Bummer! Anyway, our destination today was an easy 40 miles to Farson, WY. Christy met me at 10 miles out of Farson on her bike and tried to gently tell me that the hotel we had reserved was a dive.  It was only 9:50 am; so we pulled in to the hotel and talked to the owner.  We told her that we had decided to continue on towards Pinedale.  (Actually, no continuing, it was do or die because there was nothing between Farson and Pinedale except 58 more miles of road!)  She was OK with canceling our reservation so on we continued.  Shortly after that the winds kicked up; head winds of course!  I kept on grinding away.  But it really wasn't that bad.  The scenery was so beautiful and the mountains kept getting closer and closer.  Christy met me a second and third time and by 4 we were finally pulling into Pinedale. 98 miles on the odometer!  I am amazed myself, today I feel like the bionic woman! The hotel was on the north end of town so we stopped for a beer and had a 1/2 mile to go to get to the hotel.  And as promised, a delicious Italian spread; showered and in my wild zebra pajamas!  Life is good!  Truly!   
Have  you ever gone somewhere where the scenery is so beautiful that your eyes can't take it all in?  That you look and look and wonder and realize that nothing man-made could ever compare in beauty?  I have been blessed in my life with many memories like that.  Some of the ones that stand out are seeing the deep blue glaciers of Alaska, the bright red, yellow and purple coral under the sea, the sun setting over the ocean on Seven Mile Beach in Grand Cayman, a loon gliding across the water in the Boundary Waters of Minnesota, and the vineyards of Italy.  I am lucky that I live in Colorado and can enjoy the mountains whenever I like but there is no greater appreciation and wonder than seeing them on a bike.   I left Pinedale at 6:30 this morning and had a slow, gradual climb for about 28 miles.  The snow capped Tetons and Rockies almost surrounded me.  At every turn there was another beautiful view.  Christy met me at 2 different points today.  She drives ahead and then gets on her bike and heads towards me. At the second stop she surprised me with something that every biker and hiker must have!  I call it my Neck Weenie. It is like a bandana but is sewn like a tube. You soak it for 30 minutes and it has a gel inside that puffs up and stays cool around your neck.  It feels so good when it gets very hot out! My friend takes very good care of me! We had a wonderful tailgate picnic after I had a nice down hill coast for many miles;  then I had another 20 miles left where the road meandered, with gentle hills along the Hoback River. I finished at a nice early 1:00 in the afternoon. We are staying at the Hoback River Resort, right on the river, where the owner Kathy is a very sweet, accomodating hostess.  She even let us do our laundry in her washer.  I hate hand washing clothes, so thanks Kathy.  In the afternoon we headed into Jackson for some power shopping. I have been shop deprived this summer because whatever I buy I have to carry and I knew Christy could take my treasures home in her car.  Actually, I only bought a pair of slacks. We had dinner at the Blue Lion restaurant.  Very tasty Idaho trout. I'm happy that I am back in fresh fish country. Night, night!     
It was a very crisp 40 degrees this morning when I left Hoback Junction.  It has been a while since I have had to wear my fleece shirt, fleece beanie and long fingered gloves.  Summer weather in the mountains is the best.  The days can get very, very hot but the nights are so cool.  We slept with the sliding door open a bit so we could hear the river. I headed north towards Jackson and about 7 miles out of town there is a path for bikers, bladers, runners.  I was amazed at the amount of traffic at 6:30 in the morning.  Mostly workers bees on their way into town. All the tourists are still snuggled in their motorhomes and tents and lodges. The path was much hillier than the road but I was surrounded by the mountains, fields of horses and wildflowers.  I met Christy at Jedediah's for breakfast.  Their specialty is their sourdough bread. Yum! Here I go talking about food again! I continued on and just outside of Jackson as you turn the bend the Grand Teton Mountains stand shockingly tall and majestic.  I couldn't help myself and kept stopping to take photos.  The airport is north of town and it was neat to watch the airplanes taking off with such a background.  At about mile 33 Christy met me at the Snake River Lookout rest area.  We saw several rafts going by.  We took a few more pictures and planned to meet in 10 more miles.  Christy didn't ride today.  Afer breakfast she found herself a physical therapist who helped her with a sore neck that she has had for a while.  She also needed to get a part repaired on her bike.  So, I guess no beer for her today! We met around noon at the Moran Junction Entrance to Grand Teton National Park. I racked my bike and we drove out of the park to the Cowboy Village Resort at Togwotee.  Now we have a nice, quiet, restful afternoon before tomorrow's exciting entrance and ride through Yellowstone. Here Moosie, Moosie!       
Of course the first woman on the list is the biker babe Gladys!  In the four days I have been with her she has reaffirmed the strength, grace and fortitude I knew she had all along, but to see it in action is a sight to behold!  She literally jumps out of bed every morning, packs up and is ready to roll within 30 minutes!  I have now seen her ride up 7 to 9 percent grades in 90+ degree heat, pee incognito in the woods faster than you can say "whiz", dodge RV's on the no shoulder roads of Yellowstone doing 30 miles an hour down hill, and on threat of having to stay in a cat smelling 4x4 room ride 98+ miles in one day. In every minute she is energized, smiling and truly enjoying all the moments of the day. Nothing is too much for her or too great a challenge. I am so very blessed to share this unique and special time with my dear friend. The second incredible woman is a physical therapist by the name of Noorene in Jackson, Wyoming.  Waking up with a locked up neck (what's wrong with this picture-I've been riding for 2 days and Gladys has no injuries and has been riding since May11?) this biker/sagger would have been "road kill" if it wasn't for her wonderful spirit and hands.  As the Gladys Karma (as I call it and of course it is all so good) follows us, Noorene had a cancelation first thing in the morning and I was back on my bike within 2 hours! But that's not the whole story. Noorene gave me exercises to relieve my strain and I am now a devout biker climber...she pointed out that climbing is so much easier on the neck and shoulders, and she was/is so right!  Give me the hills! Trail Ridge here I come!  The final incredible woman is Mother Earth!  As I reveled in my "new" neck and headed into Yellowstone National Park I was climbing up my first really big hill of the trip.  Because I go so slow I had a lot of time to look around...the landscape was very inspiring. Everywhere you looked great old pine trees stood without their needles or cones-just bare spirals against the deep blue sky standing straight and proud after having lost their lives to the devastating fire of 1988.  The smell of charred wood was still in the air in such a subtle way.  But looking deeper, beneath these monuments to time, a carpet of the sweetest smelling grasses, wildflowers- and yes- 4 to 6 foot lime green pine trees! What a miracle to accomplish so much in only 14 years!  My time flew as a climbed that mountain!  So...three women, all with such special gifts to give and I have the great pleasure of knowing them all...  Gladys writes: Today was a spectacular, awesome, rich day.  I left my drop off point and around the first bend I came across three buffalo. Two female and one  very virile looking male.  I screeched to a stop and unclipped my left foot, ready to reach for my camera. Right then I saw the male look up at me. Granted he was in a meadow a ways off the road but there I was, all ablaze in my bright green windbreaker with no piece of steel between us to safeguard me.  I'm telling you, we were making eye contact so I high-tailed it down the road. I told myself that I had to settle for a picture in just my mind so sorry about that!  5 miles later Christy was waiting for me at the entrance to Jackson Lake Lodge.  She asked me if I saw the moosie just down the road.  I missed it but I was happy that she got to see one.  I stopped at the lodge to get a cup of coffee and admire the Grand Tetons through the massive windows in the great room.  I continued on and the traffic got heavier.  Christy again met me at the entrance to Yellowstone for more photos and we racked the bike to get through the toll booth and save ten bucks.  By now the road turned to a tight two lane road with absolutely no shoulder. And yes, I did dodge the RV's as they rumbled on by. I did a lot of praying during that section.  17 miles out I met Christy again for lunch and from that point on the shoulder was a little better but my energy was zapped. I had some pretty good passes to go over-I crossed the Continental Divide three times!!  Christy met me on her bike with about 4 miles to go and escorted me into the Old Faithful Inn where I was lucky enough to see Old Faithful erupt as we were pulling into the lodge.  What a marvelous day that I will never forget.     
  
Another early morning to take advantage of the cool morning air.  Just outside the hotel as I was leaving I saw a lone buffalo grazing just off the side of the road. I bravely took his photo and was close enough to hear him tearing off the clumps of grass.  Being on a bike brings you close and personal to all things outdoors. But I didn't linger long.  Just last week a visitor was flipped by a buffalo as he was walking in the same area so I didn't want to press my luck.  The ride through West Yellowstone was beautiful. Flat and downhill all the way to the West entrance. I stopped at the Fountain Paint Pots to watch the bubbling mud ooze out of the earth.  This area is amazing.  I saw a huge male elk wading in the water, an eagle, and geese. Christy also saw a coyote. Once through the west entrance I rode through a tiny bit of Montana and then reached Idaho.  Now I only have 3 states left and in a few days I will break the 3,000 mile mark so I guess I'm making progress. My buddy rode with me for a total of 30 miles again today. It is always nice to see her smiling face on the other side of the road.  We reached our hotel at noon and I had 52 miles so I decided that I would put a few more miles on to reduce the 90 mile day planned for tomorrow.  When Christy arrived with the sag wagon it was 104 degrees out!  Many hotels in the area aren't air conditioned but luckily ours is.     
Wow, there is nothing like a flat road, no headwinds and a cool morning.  I just had the best time today.  I averaged 15.4 miles per hour.  That may not sound like much but for me it's huge.  A few miles out of Idaho Falls I saw a flock of 11 geese flying above me.  I was very intrigued by them because they were just up there playing.  I had to stop and get off my bike and watch them.  They just kept flying around, doing different formations and acrobatics. They stayed in the same airspace the whole time.  Five minutes later they went off in a V formation.  I would never have been able to see that if I had been in my car! And I sort of felt like a bird today-so fast and free!  Awesome! We got to the hotel by 12:30 so we showered and went to a movie, shopped a bit and had a great Italian dinner. Kind of felt like I was cheating!
Some days I have a lot to write about.................... This morning I only had 50 miles to get to Pocatello so we slept in a bit and took our time getting going.  I left around 7:20 and headed south.  Christy met me at 15 and we rode together for 10.  At one point I heard a blood-curdling scream in front of me.  I thought it was just a loud sneeze from Christy.  Then I find out that she had just biked over a snake.  We both started to freak out so we slowed down and decided to go back and see if she killed it. She was telling me it was all coiled up and I had visions of a huge diamond back ready to strike. Well....it was actually a tiny garden snake about 10 inches long...........and, he looked like he had been dead for a while. So, that got the adrenaline going.  We laughed about what we would do if we came upon a snake while we were peeing in the bushes. We were riding through potato country and in one area there were several crop dusters swooping down low over the fields and letting go with huge sprays of pesticides.  It was fascinating to watch them do their work and to see how low to the ground they could get.  We could smell the pesticides in the air. Yucky! We got to Christy's car and she continued on to the next stop.  Several people at the gas station were interested in my ride. A sweet lady sitting in her car noticed my Coasting 2002 logo on my rear pack so she started asking questions. When I told her where I started from she stared at me in disbelief and just looked at me in shock. I gave her my card so I hope she checks the website. It's interesting to see peoples' reactions the further west I get. New York is a long, long way from here.  I started down the road again and pulled over to make a quick phone call to my Mom.  As I was dialing, a car pulled up behind me and a man jumped out carrying a notepad. The first thing he said was, "It's OK, I'm not a weirdo."  I figured he must be from the local paper.  He said he had a few questions for me after I was off the phone.  His name is Winston and he is organizing a 600 mile regional ride from Idaho to Washington and noticed that I was touring so I shared some ideas with him and tried to answer a lot of his questions.  I think his head was spinning after all the things I told him but I was happy that I could help him. We arrived just outside of Pocatello around noon and were met by Russ Speirn-Christy's brother who escorted us to his house. We are staying with Russ and Marilyn for the next two days.  The weather is still unbearably hot so getting in earlier in the day certainly helps. A thank you to my dear friend............ We met in a crowded busy concession stand. Christy's daughter, Sterling and my son, James, were both members of the Boulder High School marching band. We were the dedicated band parents that ran the concession stand as a fundraiser.  I had my head stuck in the popcorn machine when Christy walked in.  She was like a burst of sunshine-all smiley and happy and energetic and before the night was over I felt like I had a found a new friend. We ended the night with our two Doug husbands at the local brewery enjoying a drink together.  That was almost 10 years ago.  We continued with the concession work until our kids graduated and have had a wonderful friendship as a result.  She is the happiest and most positive person in my life.  I never see her down or angry or bitter or mean.  And if I'm down I just have to see her smiling face and things instantly feel better.  We have shared so much.  Eight days with our husbands exploring Rome and Tuscany;  losing track of how many bottles of wine or olives we have eaten.  We've shared gourmet dinners together and sleepovers at their Vail house and our riverside cabin.  We've skiied together, snowshoed hut to hut and soaked in the hot springs at Glenwood Springs.  When the four of us get together hardly an evening goes by without us dreaming or scheming up a new trip. When I told Christy about my crazy bike idea the first thing she said was, "I will do whatever section you want me to do."  And she stuck to her word.  Eight days ago she arrived at the hotel in Rock Springs, Wyoming armed with a car full of cheese, crackers, wine, cold wash cloths, neck weanies, AND, a box of chocolates!  What a friend!  This past week has been a blast. We have hunted for moosies, screamed over snakes and she's listened to my daily cravngs for 'oot beew fwoats!'  I have laughed and enjoyed every minute with her and will miss her terribly.  But, now I have more memories to hang on the wall. Thanks, my dear friend! P.S.  If you want to read a very sweet and funny poem from my hubby, go to the Guestbook on my website.  I think he's in the wrong profession!       
Last night we had a wonderful chicken BBQ prepared by Russ and Marilyn Speirn.  We had a little rain shower just before dinner so it cooled off enough for us to eat outside.  After dinner we took their three dogs, Pilot, Rascal and Hobbs, for a walk-or perhaps they took us for a walk!! I always thought kids were a lot of work!!  You should see these dogs eat ice cubes! I'm so used to getting up early that at 7:00 I had been laying in bed for an hour so I got up and had a great cup of coffee, read the paper and did some computer work. Late morning Christy and I ran some errands and went to the mall.  I got my hair trimmed and bought some new clothes so I can send some of my other stuff back to Boulder with Christy.  We returned in the afternoon and I snuck in a 30 minute nap before leaving at 5:00 with Christy's brother, Russ and his two Yellow Labs, Pilot and Rascal.  He competes with the dogs in field competitions. Tonight was a training night before this weekends' competition.  There were about 6 dogs and they worked on drills having the dogs retrieve fresh killed birds and hidden rubber throws. The dogs had to travel a long distance, swim across rivers, go through brush.  If the dog was off course the owner would blow a whistle, the dog would stop, look at the owner and follow his command or hand gesture. It was very amazing and interesting.  We returned quite late and Marilyn had a nice pasta dinner waiting for us.  Staying in a home is so much nicer than a hotel. Thanks for your hospitality, Russ and Marilyn. Dinner at the Sims' when you come to Boulder!
He almost jumped into my lap!  The cutest little dog, with a large, round black nose.  I had to stop my bike, and, the attached B.O.B. trailer that is now my appendage for the next 4 days. I rode back to the side of the road and there he was, abandoned in the dirt and hot sun.  His new home is on the top of my handlebar bag and his cute ears flap in the wind as the truckers pass.  I immediately named him Nose as that is the first thing I see when I look down. Hopefully he can read maps as he is totally blocking my map so he may have to be relegated to a rear pack. Sad, my friend abandons me and I have to talk to a stuffed dog!!  CHRISTY!!! WHERE ARE YOU???? I thought I would be on my own all day today but Christy decided to spend another night at her brothers house so we both left Pocatello at 6A.M. and we drove back to Blackfoot where my turnoff was to head towards the Sawtooth Mountains. I rode for 20 miles and Christy 10 more with me and then she went ahead again and did another 7. By then we were close to the National Historical Monument for the first Nuclear Power plant in the USA so we diverted off the main road and toured the facility.  Pretty scary stuff. This area is littered with radioactive material, buried in huge containers. I think I'm glowing!! Well, another goodbye to another great sagger.  I have been so blessed and have had so much fun! I continued on with B.O.B. and now, the latest buddy, Nose! My hotel in in Arco, ID tonight. Their claim to fame is that Arco was the first USA city to be powered by atomic energy.
