Song and lyrics by Brooks and Dunn Yesterday afternoon as I was looking for my hotel in Arco, ID (Population of 1,200) I rode past "Grandpa's Southern BBQ."  I returned later for dinner.  The menu boasted all the yummy southern BBQ foods-ribs, chicken, cole slaw, beans, collard greens, corn bread and sweet potato pie!  Lloyd is a 30 something black man who owns Grandpa's. I was amazed that he and his wife made sure that they stopped to visit with every person having dinner at their restaurant. Lloyd shook everyone's hand, and made sure he knew their name.  His restaurant is so successful that he is opening a second one in Idaho Falls and hopefully in Boise.  The Boise newspaper did an article on Grandpa's and they were lined up out the door. My dinner was excellent, topped off with fresh peach cobbler.   I listened to the song "Only in America" this morning while riding and thought of Lloyd. This song has meant a lot to me personally during this ride. I feel so blessed that I have seen so much of this world and that this dream of mine is no longer a dream.  I got a chance, and I got to DANCE! Today was another beautiful day. Cloudy most of the day so a nice break from the heat.  I left at 6 A.M. and was in Hailey by 2:00.  The Sawtooths are beckoning and I begin my ascent tomorrow.     
A whopping 12 miles today-I feel a little embarrassed!  But hey, no one said this had to be all work and no play, right?  So, after feeling guilty for about 2 whole minutes and finally getting out of bed at 7:30 I got me gear together and got on the bike path right next to my hotel.  The path goes from Hailey to Ketchum and was such a nice break from the heavy travelled road.  I stopped on the path and had my banana, bagel and juice, with beautiful views all around.  Shortly after I met up with a very nice couple, Scott and Mary Alice.  (Hey you two, if you get around to reading this please go to Guestbook at the top of this page and send me you email address, OK?)   They were both on recumbents and were into their 50th month of travel and fun.  Yes, 50th month!  They have no home and live in their van/camper and travel all over and then spend three winter months in Mexico.  They are 50ish, retired, and having a blast. They hike, bike, swim and just play.  It was fun talking to them and wondering what life would be like to just play every day.  I arrived at the Kentwood Lodge at 10:00 and was lucky to get into my room right away.  Shortly after I took my bike to a local bike shop to get my handlebar tape replaced. Then I went to the library to do some work on the internet. I had a nice lunch at a sidewalk cafe and spent the afternoon shopping-just a few new things to add to my bag!  Ketchum reminds me of Boulder but the population here is only about 3,000.  The town is surrounded by mountains-what a neat place.
Actually, I don't think one can ever overdo being outdoors, especially on a day like today.  I awoke at 5:45 to the sound of cars driving in rain. By the time I left the hotel the rain had stopped and I could tell it was going to be one of those incredibly beautiful summer mountain days.  It had cooled off to the mid 40's so I got a cup of coffee, some juice and toast and was on my way.  The same bike path I took into Ketchum continued north of town for another 5 or so miles.  Then the road followed the river on an ever so gentle incline. I meandered along, enjoying the beautiful Sun Valley homes, the horses and the mountains. The mountain air is indescribable. The smells are so sweet and as I ride I feel the changes in air; one second warm and musty, the next cool and clean. I want to gulp it all in and hope that I can remember the feeling when I return home.  At about 15 miles I began the climb up Galena Pass, which summitted at 8,450 feet.  At the top I was treated to spectacular views of the valley floor below and a 5 mile, 7 percent downhill grade. Then the road was very flat with the Sawtooth Mountains looming overhead to my left. I think the Grand Tetons and the Sawtooths are some of the most beautiful mountains in the world.  Around noon my friend, Betty Frazier from Boise caught up with me.  Traveling with her are her two grandaughters, Sara and Katie who are on summer holiday with Betty and Allen for a month.  They live in Wichita.  Betty stopped in Ketchum this morning to retrieve my B.O.B. trailer and duffle bag which made my climb a lot more fun! At around 1:00 we met in Stanley, racked my bike and drove 9 miles to Stanley Lake for a picnic lunch.  The girls swam in the lake and then we drove back to Stanley to enjoy the Mountain Mama's Art and Craft Fair.  After our fill of snowcones and  kettle corn we drove 21 miles to Clayton where our cabins are for the night. We ate dinner in the restaurant and then enjoyed sitting outside and studying the maps.     
Every night my husband and I talk on the phone and he asks me how my day was and each day I tell him, "I had a great day!"  I'm sure you are all getting tired of all the good news and good times I'm having.  And, where are all the horror stories of flat tires, rain storms, snow, sleet, hail.............????  I cannot begin to tell you what an experience I am having.  When I think of coming home and answering all the questions of, 'how was it?' I get very emotional and at a loss for words.  And I still have over a month left to go!  I feel so pwerful and so healthy-the best I have ever, ever felt. The first 13 years of my life I was raised on the farm and played hard but also worked hard. That is why I love the outdoors so much but imagine having three and a half months of playing every single day-as an adult!  This is a dream that is a thousand times better than I could have ever wished for.  I have been with wonderful family and friends and met so many awesome strangers.  But, I will quit for now because this isn't even my swan song.  Besides, I am sitting here with two very cute, energetic girls who are roasting marshmallows at the campfire and my smores is getting cold.  Night, night!       
The mornings in the Idaho mountains are very, very chilly. We left our cozy, warm cabins and Betty and the girls drove me to my drop off spot from yesterday. I was on the road around 7:30.  I rode along the Payette River for a good part of the morning, mostly downhill or a few gentle uphills.  At Horseshoe Bend I saw what Betty had warned me about - the road snaking up and up the mountain!  I pulled over and put some disco music on for inspiration and with the help of granny gear I made it up and over another pass.  I think they're getting a little easier-my god, by now they better be!  At the top I had a wonderful 14 mile downhill to Eagle.  A few turns and I was at Betty and Allen's beautiful home.  A cold beer, a long shower and now for a few days of just goofing off!   
After breakfast Allen and I drove to the Caldwell Airport and pulled his Beechcraft Baron out of the hangar.  The Baron is a twin engine, pressurized, 6 seater airplane. It had been years since I had flown in a small plane so I was pretty excited and just a little nervous.  I don't like bumps on the huge jetliners and I knew this could be even more exciting so I warned Allen that I might scream if things got a little rocky. I also asked him where the sick bags were,  just in case, and he handed me four bags! So, after all the preflight checks and instructions we were off.  It was very smooth for the first 15 minutes but then we hit some bumps but I was really enjoying the scenery out of the window and wasn't feeling a bit nervous or sick.  It was fascinating to be in the co-pilots seat and watch all the action up close and personal and Allen did a great job explaining all the different controls.  The only time I got a little sweaty was when he put the autopilot on.  It was very eery watching the plane just fly itself-especially when it turned!  We flew over a part of Oregon, Nevada and then Utah.  We climbed to 15,500 feet and had a huge bank of smoke from the forest fires in the region.  We landed in Cedar City, Utah; very close to the Arizona border-about 500 miles from Boise. Allen said he had to deliver something to a guy so he had them put fuel in the plane and then we went in to pay the bill and wait for his friend to arrive.  We went around the corner of the lounge to get a soda from the machine and then stepped back into the lounge. There were some steps off to the side and I saw a guy coming down.  I saw his feet, his shorts and  then his shirt.  I said to myself, 'Wow, my husband has the exact same shirt.' Within 2 seconds I saw the head connected to the shirt and realized IT WAS my husband!  A very well planned out surprise!  I had told Doug several times that he should meet me in Boise and spend a few days at Allen and Betty's house.  He kept telling me that he had to finish school and get back to Boulder to start his new business.  Well, he did finish school and planned the whole surprise out with Allen and Betty.  So, we had another passenger on the flight back and we now have 2 days of fun in Boise before he heads back to Boulder and I continue my journey west.  What fun! We ended the day with a delicious Italian dinner and caught up with old friends until midnight.     
Doug and I decided to take an extra day off so I'm not riding until Friday and Allen will fly Doug back down to Cedar City so he can get his car and finish his road trip to Boulder.  Today was quite a lazy day.  We did some computer work in the morning and then the guys went off to have lunch with some HP guys from the past. Betty and I did some shopping/browsing in Boise, went to the Boise Art Museum and then we all had a summer BBQ dinner with Wayne and Phyllis Bradburn, Brock and Kelly Frazier and Sara and Katie.  Don't you just love it when you get together with friends that you have not seen for a long time and you just continue where you left off years ago?  The only thing that seems to have changed is that somehow all of our kids have grown up, gotten older, gotten married, had babies..... but, we haven't changed a bit!  We laughed all night long!  Friday July 25, 2002  This morning the guys are off for a game of golf and the girls will hit the mall. This is my last chance to send things home to Boulder!    Word is that this afternoon the brave ones will get in tubes and float down the cold Boise River.  Well, crazy and brave is more like it.  We packed up the car with blow up rafts, towels, and kids.  One car was dropped off at the end and then we all drove upriver.  They are very serious about their rafting here.  At the park there are stations, very much like a gas station, where you belly up with your raft and blow them up with air.  We had four rafts and three inner tubes amongst us.  About the time we started to raft an incredible wind kicked up and even though we were floating downriver, the wind was actually pushing us back. We crossed about four diversion dams and Doug and I managed to get completely soaked at the first two.  Our raft was also losing air so by the time we finished we were sitting in about two feet of water. BBBRRRRRR!  A rainstorm hit shortly after we got out of the water.  I actually took a hot bath when we got back home.  Great pizza and a glass of red wine topped off a very fun day!  Thanks again to Allen and Betty for all of your generosity and friendship!  Good memories!     
I kissed my husband goodbye at 8:30 as he was leaving with Allen to head to the Caldwell Airport for his chauffered flight back to Cedar City to get his car.  I've had three cushy, lazy days off but it felt good to be back on the bike.  The sights and smells today were wonderful.  I passed twelve foot high corn in the fields and aromatic mint fields that made me breath so hard I thought I was hyperventilating!  I also went by onion, sugar beet and green bean fields.  I had to resist the urge to stop at the small farmer's market stands as I had no room in my packs.  OK Allen, you jinxed me.  You mentioned that I stopped keeping track of flat tires (because I haven't had any!) but guess what?  I had a flat tire today, my first front flat.  Much easier to change though.  I had been getting out of practice plus I love the looks I get from people when I put my purple gloves on!  I finished my ride around 2:30 and treated myself to a 'woot beew fwoat at A&W. There is nothing better than cold root beer and ice cold ice cream, yum!  When Doug left this morning he took B.O.B. back with him. (My trailer)  Wow, what a treat.  That means that I will have someone supporting me the rest of the ride.  I left my duffle bag behind in Eagle and my parents are swinging by to get it on their way to the RV Park tonight.  Yes, THEY'RE BAAAACCCKKK!  for another round of sagging!  The plan is for them to be with me until we reach the coast.  So, I had another great day and the adventure continues.  And yes, Mark, your Mother will be in Oregon tomorrow, OK? F.T.C. Gladys 10 
OK, the debut of the poem I have been working on for two months! Oh the west winds they do blow. I know this because you've all told me so. I spun in granny gear all day long, because the winds were oh so strong. My minds been in a vortex haze, as I've remembered calmer days. My music has tried to soothe my soul, as I try to complete another days goal. My teeth are full of bugs and sand, from this great and wonderful Oregonland. So, wish as I may and wish as I might, you know I'll be prayin' for calmer winds tonight! I don't think I need to say a whole lot more about today other than if I would have more days like this I think I'd be back in Boulder by now.  I don't know what happened today but I struggled through every mile.  I was very tired and just could not get my energy level up to fight the winds. We are in Eastern Oregon and there are large distances between any campgrounds so we had planned on going back to last nights spot.  I anticipated having in about 60 miles by 12:30 and my parents passed me at 11:30 with only 38 miles.  My Mom opened her window and I said, "OK, I've had enough fun for the day."  So I bailed early and am hoping that tomorrow will be better.   
I slept very well last night and was rarin' to go this morning. However, shortly after I left the winds were back.  But I felt much better today and was enjoying myself in spite of the wind.  The terrain was high desert, similar to areas of Kansas, Colorado, Utah and Wyoming.  I had two passes to climb and slowly began seeing prettier scenery and more trees.  Mom and Dad had a spot at the Unity Lake State Park campground.  Just outside of Unity is a Fire Camp where 1,200 hot shots and firefighters are camping to help with the 16 fires burning in Oregon.  It is a virtual city with tents all around and shower and cooking facilities  to handle all the crews.  We went into town for dinner and noticed a pick up truck with firefighters loading up all the bagged ice from the local gas station.  I'm sure the winds are causing all kinds of problems.     
The wind continues to blow like crazy, yes, from the west but there is not a whole lot I can do about it.  Except complain, but life is too short to do a lot of that.  So, off I went this morning.  First pass was a moderate grade 12 mile climb and then I was into the beautiful Malheur National Forest. A second climb took me to 5,200 feet followed by a nice downhill into the valley.  As I turned the bend I saw one of the forest fires quite close to where I was.  All day long I was being passed by hotshot crews heading to one of the fires.  A coyote crossed in front of me today. He was pretty close to me so as I started reaching for my pepper spray he noticed me and immediately bolted into the woods. He was pretty mangy and scraggly.  I was also passed or being met by 11 logging trucks. I'm going to try and keep a log each day to see how many pass me.  Amazing what games one comes up with when the days are long and hot.  Todays game was I had to have so many cars pass me before I could look at my odometer.  That was when the heat and wind were at their worst and I was getting tired.  A fun story to share-my Dad was chatting with someone at a general store in Unity yesterday.  He told the story of an 80 year old biker that was on a cross country tour. When he got to the midwest he had a heart attack.  After he recovered he wanted to continue the ride so his daughter and son-in-law (who were probably in their 50's or 60's) agreed to follow him in their van.  When the biker encountered a large hill the kids would rack the bike and give him a ride to the top.  He would then bike DOWN the hill, get picked up again and dropped off at the top to continue on.  What determination.  I want to be like him when I grow up!  Speaking of down the hill.  I love bike touring where I have never biked before.  What keeps me going is the curiosity of what is over the hill or around the bend.  I especially like it when I have a nice downhill! Tonight we are at the Clyde Holliday State Park outside of Mount Vernon.  We have a nice shady spot by the river and Mom's dinner smells pretty good!     
I had to laugh this morning. During the first 10 miles I passed so many farms.  There were cows, goats, horses, ducks, roosters and chickens.  The locals here must truly love their animals-see the photo below. The first 35 miles were mostly flat or downhill so I averaged 14.5 miles an hour.  I met Mom and Dad at the John Day Fossil Bed Visitor Center around 10:00.  The fossil beds cover 14,000 acres and preserve a 40 million year record of plant and animal life. The rock formations in the area were very beautiful. I have never been to central Oregon so I didn't know what to expect. I met some riders with the same Adventure Cycling group that I met in Colorado. They went through Yellowstone and up to Montana while I did the Sawtooths and by coincidence I met the same group in the middle of Oregon. The 32 miles in the afternoon were horrible.  The winds kicked up, I had a pass to climb and the heat was unbearable.  I am exhausted. Our facililties are a little primitive tonight.  But we do have electrical hookup for A/C.  Right next door is a local business that makes furniture from twisted juniper.  The trees get twisted from lack of water and constant sun and excess heat.  The trees are usually found on only south facing slopes. A king size bed frame is $5,000 and we would have to enlarge the bedroom at the cabin for the bed to fit!   
"Three essentials to happiness in this life are something to do, something to love and something to hope for."  Anonymous

I was questioned quite frequently regarding my choice of an East to West coast ride.  There were times when I was second guessing my choice but after today I know that I made the right one.  I left Bend and had an easy 22 miles to the very tiny but very cute town of Sisters, OR.  The town had so many neat shops and restaurants but at 8:30 most were still closed so my wallet didn't lose any money! Immediately out of Sisters I saw all the caution signs warning any motorists that if they were pulling anything longer than 35 feet they better turn around.  I knew that I had a 12 mile climb to 5,300 feet so I settled into my slow and steady pace.  I kept waiting for the hills.  I was climbing but it was very manageable.  Within an hour I saw the summit sign and realized that I was reading the Adventure Cycling description written from a western approach to the summit! At the top of McKenzie Pass I had beautiful views of several mountain peaks and lava fields all around.  Not much grows in the lava so it looked like the moon.  It was pretty cold at the top so I added some layers and started down the 22 mile descent through some of the most spectacular forest I have ever seen.  The trees were thick on both sides of the winding road and the forest floor was lush with green ferns.  The traffic was very light because cars and RV's are encouraged to take the Santiam Pass alternate route so it was very quiet and peaceful. I wanted to stay there all day!  When the two roads joined up I thought I might run into Mom and Dad but I bet my Mom is shopping up a storm in Sisters so I found our destination for the night and am relaxing at the Belknap Hot Springs Resort and Campground until they arrive. I started getting concerned when they didn't arrive by 6:30 so I called 911 and the operator told me to call the Oregon Highway Patrol. They told me that a semi truck had jackknifed on the road that Mom and Dad had to take over the pass.  He said there were no motorhomes involved in the accident so I was relieved.  When they finally arrived at 7:30 they told me they were not in the traffic jam. They stayed behind in Sisters to go to church and their phone messages on my cell did not go through! So, only two more days before I see the Pacific Ocean, I'm getting excited!     
OK, this is the second attempt at today's journal. I hit the wrong button and deleted the first one.  Duh!  Oh well, I really didn't like it anyway. I had a very nice ride today, pushed myself a little so I could work off all this good food that Mom has been preparing.  The weather has finally cooled down. It is in the 70's during the day which is just perfect for riding.  Mom and Dad met me on the outskirts of Eugene as I cannot ride on the interstate-legally, anyway.  We found our RV park and after I showered we drove to Springfield to attend the filbert festival. We were expecting to see filberts in every conceivable concoction but all we found were roasted, sweet filberts.  They had a great country western band that was clashing with the Scotish bagpipers.  It is funny to see all the local festivals across the country.  They all have kettle corn, slushies and the local brews along with the crafts of the region, which are also pretty similar.  Neclaces, painted gourdes, lotions made from local stuff, hand stitchery and the local chiropractor wanting to check your spine.  How fun! Tonight after dinner we went to visit with my Dad's second cousins which was very enjoyable.  Like I said yesterday, retired people just love to sit and talk and they always have the greatest stories to tell.   
When my oldest son, Mike was a teenager he lived with his father in Minneapolis.  He would come for visits when Doug and I lived in Laguna Niguel, CA. Our home was about 5 miles from the beach.  The minute he would jump out of the car when we got home he would say, "Wow, Mom, I can smell the ocean from here."  Well Mike, today I smelled the ocean too and I thought of you when you were a young man.  It is a wonderful smell!  At 3,888 miles I have biked across this wonderful country of ours and by 5:30 Grandma and Grandpa and I were walking on the beach, watching the fog roll in. Then we went to town and celebrated with martinis and the freshest dungeness crab I have ever had.   Today was another spectacular, very memorable day.  One of those top 10 days that I will always remember.  I left Eugene this morning and found a bike path very similar to the one we have along the river in Boulder.  I stopped to talk to a very sweet couple who helped me with directions and soon I was on the outskirts of town.  I stopped at a scooter shop and they happened to have the exact scooter that my daughter Jen and her Daddy just bought before she goes back to CSU.  On the west side of town I noticed that there were huge bushes of fresh, ripe blackberries off the side of road.  I came to a screeching stop and stood in awe at what was before me.  As luck would have it there was a clean plastic bag under one of the bushes so I spent 30 minutes gathering a surprise for my Mom who loves blackberries.  About two hours later Mom and Dad pulled over and I surprised Mom with my morning pickin's.  We had lunch together and waited out a nice rain shower.  I left again with about 35 more miles to go. The area between Eugene and Florence is National Forest, fairly hilly and very beautiful.  I rode through another rainstorm and then along the North Fork Siuslaw River into Florence.  I met Mom and Dad at our meeting spot and cried and laughed at the wonderful feeling I had inside of me!  Here I was, at the Pacific Coast!  This simple farm girl-I BIKED ACROSS THE USA!!  I BIKED ACROSS THE USA!  Unbelievable!  We drove a few miles to the coast and walked on the beach.  The fog was beginning to roll in-it was so beautiful. Then we drove into town and found the best seafood restaurant in town and celebrated with martinis and the best, freshest dungeness crab in the world!   LIFE IS GOOD!  But wait, this ride is still 800 miles short of my goal so not too much celebrating girl!  But, I will take two days off and drive up the coast with Mom and Dad where they will kick me out of the nest (again) in Astoria where I will begin the last leg of this awesome journey.     
August 6, 2002 My parents are leaving soon so we decided to take two days off and just play and sight see.  We left Florence the morning of the 6th (after sleeping in until 7:30!) and stopped for a coffee and scone in town and then headed up the coast.  The Oregon coast is spectacular.  One beautiful scene after another. A light fog hovered over the beach.  We took our time; stopped at the beach for a walk in the sand and a lunch stop. We stopped in Lincoln City and booked a hotel room for Friday where my cousin Margaret and her husband will meet me and I also dropped off my duffle bag.  When we arrived in Tilamook we toured the Tilamook Cheese Factory where they store 50 million pounds of cheese a year!  We also toured Blue Heron Cheese Factory where we sampled some very good Brie cheeses as well as Oregon wines.  There is an Air Museum here that my Dad wants to tour so we found an RV park south of town and will do the tour in the morning. August 7, 2002 Happy Birthday to my sweet husband, Doug.  I feel so bad that I am not at home to celebrate with him but I know that Jennifer will make the day special for her Dad. We toured the Air Museum this morning.  It was one of those museums with wonderful displays of war memorabilia and touching family stories where you could spend days reading everything.  In the afternoon we headed north and crossed a spectacular bridge between Astoria, OR and the state of Washington.  We went back to Astoria and walked along the riverfront.  In its' heyday, Astoria was the salmon canning capitol of the world with over 40 canneries. We had some excellent fish and chips at the Buoy 9 restaurant in Hammond and then spent the night at the Fort Stevens State Park.   
Well, I got the boot today!  I spent my last night in my bed and breakfast on wheels.  Time for Mom and Dad to start heading back home and for me to head south to meet up with my cousin.  We had a very tearful goodbye this morning.  Mom and Dad sagged me for three whole weeks during the course of this ride and we had a very special time together.  We had some very quality time to sit and visit, to sight see, to go to church together, to chat, to visit with family in Iowa and Eugene, OR,  to share some wonderful meals together and to do a lot of laughing. Memories that no one can ever take away from me.  Thanks from the bottom of my heart, Mom and Dad. You are simply the best! I spent a leisurely day heading down the coast, stopping often to stare in awe at the most beautiful coastal scenery I have every seen. I sat on the beach for a muffin and banana break and should have taken my shoes off and gone for a walk. The weather was a perfect low 70's, with no wind until the afternoon. I talked to a bike tourist who left Boston 8 days before I left New York and today our paths crossed with him heading to Astoria where he will go home and I'm heading south. He was refreshed and like me, not eager for his ride to end.  I also talked to an older gentleman who had been traveling in his RV for the past year and a half and when I told him I was celebrating my 50th this fall he said he was guessing that I was about 32!  Sweet!     
I left my hotel at 7:30 and was back in Tilamook around 9:00.  I picked up some cheese and Margaret and I talked on our cell phones about our meeting plans for later in the day.  I followed Adventure Cycling's maps and instead of following 101 South I decided to take the Three Coves Scenic Route closer to the coast. Well, it was certainly beautiful and scenic but also a lot more windy and hilly.  I rode through patches of fog and dense forests.  I had a huge climb before Cape Lookout and as I started downhill I was met by Ron, Margaret and Ryan.  I kidded Margaret that she must have planned meeting me at the top of the climb and that she was cheating going down the pass but not up. We had more ups and downs and another huge climb before descending into Lincoln City where Ron and Ryan were waiting for us.  We had a very delicious dinner at Kyllo's across from the Lincoln City Inn.  I'm tired today-that's what I get for taking two days off the bike! But hey, I should be-my odometer now reads over 4,000 miles Yeah hooh!     
It feels weird heading south each day. I still cannot believe that I am on the west coast.  It's great having the prevailing winds coming from the north and the west.  By the afternoon the north winds were so strong that we were actually boosted along as we were going uphill!  What a blast that is!  But I got my butt beat today by trying to keep up with Margaret-she is an amazingly strong rider, makes it look effortless, hardly sweats and makes me work my A_ _ off trying to keep up with her.  We haven't seen each other in a year and have a lot of catching up to do so when the shoulder is wide enough we like to ride side by side so we can solve all the world's problems. Anyway, we left the hotel in Lincoln City by 8am and were at the Oregon Coast Aquarium in Newport around 11:00.  We spent a few hours there and then stopped at a 50's diner for lunch.  That sort of stop does it for me and it always takes me a while to get back in the groove.  Today's ride was very hilly and at one point as I'm going up a hill-with Margaret in front of me-I hear a guy in the deep woods, coughing.  I looked down into the mountain and see a guy standing there, stark naked!  I didn't know what else to do so I said, "Hi."  He was so shocked to see me that he instinctively hunched over and covered his privates!  I laughed all the way up the hill and was mad at myself that I didn't stop and say, 'can I help you?'  That would have been a more interesting web story!   Ron and Ryan went up ahead to Yachats to look for a hotel and everything was full so they drove up ahead to Florence, got a room and came back to get us. Tomorrow they'll have to drive us back to the drop off point. My parents are still in the area so we are all having dinner together tonight.     
We got a late start today.  We had breakfast with my parents and said goodbye (again) around 9am.  By the time Ron drove us to our drop off spot north of Yachats and we were ready to roll it was around 10:00.  We stopped at the Seal Caves for a potty stop and then kept rolling at a fast pace.  Today a large portion of the Oregon coast was the Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area where huge sand dunes form close to the ocean and it is a huge recreation area for dune buggies.   We stopped in Reedsport for lunch at a Subway and while we were there we met the cutest young couple from Germany.  They were teachers and were bike touring from Seattle to San Francisco-with their 2 year old daughter in a Burley trailer! They were camping each night and sounded like they were having a great time. They only rode 40 miles a day so they had plenty of time to enjoy the sights. They fly home from San Francisco on September 5th and start back to teaching on the 7th!   Margaret came out after lunch and realized she had a flat so we changed that first and then we left for Reedsport and headed to North Bend/Coos Bay.  Ron called to say that we had a hotel in Coos Bay but to be careful on the bridge.  The wind was progressively getting stronger in the afternoon. The bridge over Coos Bay is very large and as we approached closer to the bridge we decided to ride across on the pedestrian walkway that was elevated about a foot off of the roadway and was only about 2 feet wide.  We seemed to be doing OK on the approach but as soon as we were on the bridge itself the wind was just brutal.  Margaret was ahead of me and we were both struggling with the wind. I stopped briefly to check things out and as I started getting back on my bike the wind kicked me into the metal railing. My knuckles on my right hand got bruised and that is when I decided to walk to bike.  Margaret decided to do the same.  I have never been in such a strong wind.  I could have left the bike go and the wind would have just carried it off!  We finally made it across and I think my shoulders were glued to my ears!  Very scary! 
A lazy, slow day today.  We slept in, had coffee and left around noon, heading to Bandon to the home of Pat and Fred Richert.  Pat is the sister of Ron Carfi, who is my cousin Margaret's husband.  We arrived in Bandon around 2:00 and had a late lunch and did some shopping before going out to Pat and Fred's house.  They farm 13 acres of cranberries for Ocean Spray so I learned a little about cranberries.  They are grown quite conventionally in what looks like a sunken field.  At harvest time the berries are beat with a machine to loosen them from the vine and then the fields are flooded so the berries float to the top and then they use boomsticks to round up the berries and elevate them into a truck. Another method is to dry pick the cranberries with a different kind of machine.  In Orgeon about 3,000 acres are dedicated to cranberry farming.  Bandon used to be well known for its'logging and fishing but is now more of a tourist area where the Bandon Dunes Golf Course is number two in the country behind Pebble Beach.   Pat prepared a wonderful dinner of fresh summer salad, bread and lasagna, fresh berries and ice cream.  Another wonderful night in a home rather than a hotel room.  Thank you Pat and Fred!       
We said our goodbyes at Patti's house and Ron drove us to the end of their dirt road.  After 5 miles we stopped at Misty Meadows-a shop that sold local jams, jellies, soup mixes and such so we picked up a few items and then hit the road.  A few miles later Margaret had another flat so we took our time and leisurely changed the tire, with me supervising and Margaret doing most of the work.  I never knew that I would become such a pro at changing flats!   At Port Orford we got a sandwich to go at a small restaurant and then stopped later for lunch. Ron and Ryan met up with us so we unloaded some of our goodies into the truck, picked a few wild blackberries and continued on to Gold Beach. The weather today was very unusual. We started out with sunny skies but by late morning it all changed to very foggy and cool temps. You know how introspective one gets when it's a cold, foggy, rainy kind of day?  I felt very blue all day. First of all it was my wedding anniversary and I wasn't with my husband. Secondly, I realized that tomorrow I will cross over the California border and I know that I need to start preparing myself for the end. Each time I tried to put into mental words how I feel about this whole experience I would get too emotional. I plan on spending a few solitary days close to a beach so I can put my final thoughts into coherent words. We dressed warmly and went to dinner and when we returned we noticed how smoky the air smelled.  We have been told that the smoke from the fire south and west of here is very dangerous and we are not sure if we will be able to ride through it so we will survey the situation tomorrow morning.  So far the Florence/Brookings fire has burned over 330,000 acres and is no where close to being contained.   P.S. Happy 19th Anniversary to my hubby!!     
The weather continues to feel like my spirit but I'm trying to take advantage of it and start working on my final thoughts. I even had to pull over once today to jot some thoughts down on paper.  We left Gold Beach at 9:30 to a very, very heavy fog-almost misty out.  I skipped my vitamins and breakfast. As you will see, I paid for it later in the day.  Anyway, after a cup of coffee and a banana we were on our way.  At about 15 miles we met up with a bike tourist that we met briefly yesterday.  To protect the innocent I will not go into details about him but within moments of meeting him yesterday both Margaret and I thought he was a little strange.  Well, as luck would have it, we met up with him again today when the traffic was stopped for road construction and he pulled up right behind us.  His greeting to us was, 'well hello ladies.'  We tried to avoid him but he stuck to us like glue.  After a mile I told Margaret we should stop and call Ron on the cell. Well, he stopped also!  By mile 25 we were entering Brookings and we knew that we were stopping at Ron's sisters restaurant but we didn't want 'tagalong' to follow us. As we worked the uphills into Brookings we worked our asses off trying to ditch this guy but he always seemed to catch up with us on the downhills.  Our  knowledgeable sagger Ron informed us a few days ago that we will soon pass through an elk reserve and that the elk can run up to 35 miles an hour so we thought that this would be a perfect opportunity to train for running from the elk!  At a stop sign he asked where we were headed so I told him we had family in Brookings and that we might spend the day and night.  When we got to Jeanette and Mels restaurant we saw him passing by.  He was also headed to Crescent City like we were but we got to the hotel without running into him again.  Anyway, back to my weird body.  I decided that I could skip a nutritious meal this morning and had a cup of coffee and a banana.  Within a few hours I had some dried fruit and then in Brookings I had a bowl of soup, some toast and another cup of coffee. Sounds OK for a sedentary person but by 3:00 I was low on energy so I had an orange. That lasted for about 30 minutes and I totally BONKED. I had absolutely no energy and I knew that we had less than 6 miles to go but Margaret suggested I eat a Cliff Bar which luckily kicked in and got me to the bike shop for a quick repair and then to the hotel for cheese and crackers.  It is amazing how much energy my body requires for hour after hour of pedaling.  Luckily my body tells me when it is running low on fuel and what it needs to keep going but it is kind of scary to feel so empty.  I now know what they mean when they say you've 'hit the wall,' or 'bonked.'   The fires seem to be far enough east of us that we are not affected by the smoke.  It is strange for it to be so cold and foggy here but the weather channel says cit is in the 100's further inland. Good thing Ron and Margaret have a pool at their home in Ukiah so I can work on this lovely biker tan of mine.     

A day spent in Ukiah with my cousins and Aunt.  Margaret and I left her house on our bikes around 9 this morning and did a few errands in town and then we headed out to the Fetzer Winery. The road wound through the beautiful countryside with vineyards and pear orchards all around.  The pears are being picked right now and we were passed by farmers pulling trailers with huge crates that were overflowing with pears. The grapes will soon be ready for the crush and the vines are heavy with purple and green grapes.  I picked a small cluster of  purple grapes and was amazed at how sweet they were.  Margaret didn't want me to lose my strength on the bike so she put me to work at a very serious pace around the curves. This woman is amazing, I'd like to bottle some of her energy and sell it.  She goes in high gear all day, both on the bike and off and at night time her head hits the pillow and she is out!  No wonder!  She would be a great personal trainer!  Anyway, Ron and my Aunt Marion met us out at Fetzer for lunch.  Each time we travel to Ukiah we make a visit to the winery.  I think it is one of the most beautiful ones, not to dismiss that their wine is some of the best in the world. The grounds are beautiful and they have a Bed and Breakfast there also. The tasting room is abuzz with tour groups and the gift shop and deli are stocked with all kinds of items one must have. I always leave with a bag full of goodies.  The tasting room manager's name is Pat.  She is a bubbly, funny gal who is always there to help with the wine selections and makes sure that we have a little more than a tastes' portion in our glasses. We returned to Margarets for a dip in the pool and then enjoyed a family dinner at my aunt's house to celebrate cousin Sue's birthday. Speaking of birthdays, my son Mike and his wife share the same birthday today.  Happy Birthday to both of you with love from your wandering mother!     
Sunday August 18, 2002 Yesterday my Aunt Marion and I left Ukiah at 4PM and drove to the drop off point where Margaret and I left off on the 15th. We stopped in Eureka and arrived at the Trees Motel around 10::00. Monday August 19, 2002 I felt like Superwoman today. I effortlessly pedal up the hills like I have been doing this my whole life.  Amazing what three months in the saddle will do.  I kept chuckling today thinking back to a year ago-I sent a letter to family and friends announcing my crazy idea.  At Christmas I got a card from an acquaintance whose husband biked the Pacific Coast a few years ago. He told his wife to tell me that I was nuts!  All I could think today was, 'if you could see me now.' (I also thought - 'eat my dust.'!! ) I left Klamath and within 5 miles I took a scenic 10 mile drive through the Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park which runs parallel to Hwy 101 but with much less traffic. It was a magnificent ride. I wanted to bottle the sights and smells-I could have made a fortune!  I met my Aunt in Trinadad and I had a sandwich for lunch. I only had about 15 more miles to go and I arrived at our hotel in Arcata around 2:30.  After showering we drove into Eureka where we shopped and browsed. We went to the Samoa Cookhouse for dinner. This cookhouse has been serving food continuously for 105 years but they only began serving the public in the 60's. Prior to that it was a cookhouse for the local loggers. The food is served family style with hearty portions of fried chicken, pork, potatoes, corn, soup, salad and peach pie.   
OK Patti, I found another gem for you to explore on your next visit to California!  Patti is a teacher friend of mine and last week she sent me an email telling me how wonderful Bandon by the Sea in Oregon is.  The day I got her email is the day I spent in Bandon. A few days ago another email telling me to check out Trinidad and ironically I stopped there and got the email that night!  She also mentioned Mendocino where I will be next week. So Patti, if you haven't been to Ferndale you need to go.  Ferndale is a small town 25 miles south of Eureka.  It has beautiful "Painted Ladies."  A term used for lovingly restored Victorian homes.  Lots of tiny shops and even a Rexall Drugstore.  We spent a few hours there this morning.  One of the stores had wooden floors and all the old creams, soaps, salves, candies and goodies from earlier days.   After lunch I got back on the bike-yes, I am still biking in case it sounds like I'm doing too much other fun stuff!  At the 40 mile mark I took the exit to Avenue of the Giants.  It is a 32 mile stretch of road, off of Hwy 101 that goes through beautiful redwood groves.  After about 5 miles I noticed my Aunt pulled over by a vegetable stand.  The owner was selling homemade blackberry popsicles, made with fresh berries, sugar and water.  A tourist that stopped for the same thing was nice enough to buy mine-my Aunt couldn't wait for me and had already eaten hers!  They were delicious.  We bought some local tomatoes and headed down the road only to be stopped by blackberry bushes heavy with fruit.  My Aunt had an empty container in her car and within 20 minutes we had picked a quart of sweet berries.   Now we are relaxing at the Redcrest Lodge.  Comfy, cozy cabins with porches that just beg you to sit on them and read-so we did!   
I will pass on the comentary for today and just let you enjoy some of the sights I was so fortunate to experience.  I walked in the woods today with the gigantic redwoods all around me and with tears in my eyes I marveled at their awesome beauty and felt so blessed to be standing there in their presence. "The redwoods once seen, leave a mark or create a vision that stays with you always.....from them comes silence and awe.  The most irreverent of men, in the presence of redwoods, goes under a spell of wonder and respect"   John Steinbeck         
Adventure Cycling describes todays ride:  "At Leggett you'll leave US 101 and return to the coast via SR1, but not before climbing abruptly to 2,000 feet above sea level. From either direction this road is a steep, twisting climb and descent on a narrow roadway that is hemmed in by heavy forest cover.  Allow ample time for the arduous 28 miles between Leggett and Westport." I guess some would think it arduous but I thought it was spectacular.  Not many cars on SR1, thankfully, because the road twisted and turned all the way up and all the way down.  As I approached the coast I rode in and out of fog banks and it was very cold.  At Westport we had coffee at a funky Inn where the Innkeeper offered us samplings of his homemade jams for us to sample along with our bagel.  I left Westport and stayed on Hwy 1 to Fort Bragg.  The road hung precariously along the rocky coast. This was a gear shifting challenge because the road was so twisty that at one moment you were going down a steep grade only to come around a very sharp corner to a steep uphill. I had to be on my toes constantly, watching for traffic and making sure I was in the right gear. I listened to my musicand had a blast!  I met my Aunt in Mendocino where we had lunch and then drove back to Ukiah.       
After spending three days in Ukiah off the bike I was ready to hit the road and begin this last week of my journey.  My Aunt protested when I told her I was riding from Ukiah to Mendocino and at one point had me convinced that she would drive me here but the more I thought about it the more I felt like I needed to ride.  My cousin has a home on over an acre of land in Ukiah and it is like a litle farm, complete with numerous animals-chickens, guinea pigs, a baby bearded dragon, (a lizard that will grow to be very, very large!) four cats, (one of them treated us one night by dragging a baby snake into the house!) and three dogs, two large and one small.  Well, this morning as I was leaving the driveway on my bike Emma and Chalupa decided to follow me so I turned around, guided them back, closing the gate behind me. I started off down the hill and half a mile later I see Emma running behind me! I tried to tell her NO, and GO HOME but she was insistant on following me.  I was not wanting to turn around and escort her back home so I called Ron on the cell phone and he had  to come and get her with the truck.  Seems they forgot to tell me that she was supposed to  be locked in a special gated area of their yard. Sorry Ron! The road from Ukiah to Booneville is very, very steep with NO shoulder but the loaded logging trucks were all going downhill and I was going up.  Things leveled out a bit and I rode through more vineyards.  Seems like the wineries keep expanding north and west of Napa and Sonoma. I passed about a dozen tasting rooms but decided it would probably not be a good idea to stop and imbibe in the spirits, knowing I had another 40 some miles to ride.  I rode through another beautiful section of redwoods close to the coast.  These forests are much younger than the ones up north but they hold much promise if the loggers don't get to them first.  I stopped at the Von Damme Beach which is a short distance from the Glendeven Inn where I am staying for the next two nights. The beach was rather small and after a few moments I found a large piece of driftwood that was just the perfect size to lay down upon.  I tried to start gathering my thoughts for my ending journal pages that I need to work on but after 61 miles I was enjoying a blissful nap, to the sounds of the ocean! So, now I am at the Glendeven Inn. I just took a nice hot bath and soon will join the other guests and the Innkeepers for some wine and appetizers.  I decided to come to Mendocino because my husband and I just love this quaint, seaside village and I wanted a few days to begin the process of gathering all my feelings and thoughts about this summer.  I wanted to do it in a very quiet, peaceful place where I can stroll the beautiful gardens, walk the beaches and listen to the ocean and hopefully be inspired to put my thoughts into words.  I feel that if I don't do it now it may never happen. A lot is waiting for me when I return home so I will indulge myself and hope that I am productive. P.S. Happy Birthday to our daughter Jennifer who celebrated her 19th birthday yesterday! Also, today is her first day of the new year at Colorado State University so, time to hit the books again, girl!     
August 27, 2002 A day to reflect, write and cry! (Yesterday) I awoke this morning and stepped outside to fix a flat that occurred on my rear tire after I arrived yesterday.  In front of the B&B I met two women, Linda and Nancy, who had their tripods set up and were photographing the beautiful flowers in the garden. We chatted for a while and they invited me to join them in Mendocino for lunch.  I had a nice two mile walk and met the girls at an outside cafe overlooking the ocean.  I immediately felt a connection with these strangers. They are about my age and have such energy and love of life. They had spent some time in Bandon, Oregon where Nancy was doing a photography workshop. Her workshops are about encouraging personal vision and they emphasize intimate landscapes with an interpretive emphasis. They were so excited about my ride and we talked a lot about role models, being women, and cool stuff like that.  When we left we went to their car and Nancy loaned me a book titled, "Everday Sacred" by Sue Bender. The book is based on the monk that would take a begging bowl to the village each day. Whatever was placed in the bowl was enough!  Even if it had two grains of rice in it!  The author encourages us to approach every day with this 'bowl.' And no matter what is put in the bowl, rather it be good or not so good, to acknowledge it and be thankful for it.  If the bowl gets too full than we need to make it less full so that we have room to grow and learn. This book was placed before me at a very unique time in my life.  What a blessing to meet such incredible women! I returned to the B&B and found a comfy chair in the living room and began working on my Final Chapter!  At one point the Innkeeper, Higgins asked me how I was doing?  I told him I was making progress but that I thought I needed a box of kleenex. He turned around and within seconds was holding a box for me!  Can you tell I'm getting a little emotional here? But the words (and tears) started to flow and I feel good about what I wrote. August 28, 2002 I awoke this morning and felt horrible!!  I was dizzy, my stomach was upset and for a moment I didn't know if I could ride today.  I just wanted to crawl back into my beautiful down filled bed and go back to sleep.  But Linda and Nancy were having breakfast with me and I knew that I had the next three nights of hotels booked so I got a cup of coffee and went outside for some fresh air. We had a wonderful breakfast with such inspiring conversation. We chatted with Martha and Michael, a couple from the Bay area that are moving to New Mexico to begin a new business and a new life by opening a retreat center on 65 acres of land.  By the end of breakfast I was feeling better so I packed up to leave. The ride down the coast continues to be breathtaking but today the winds were not in my favor and I fought extreme winds coming from the south all day long. I stopped for some chicken soup and peppermint tea and was thankful when I got to my hotel in Point Arena. I think my body wants to go home!  Four more days!     
This area of the California is called the Lost Coast.  I never could find out where the name came from but it is pretty desolate along this stretch.  The enormous rocks stand like arsenels along the coastal waters and the land is pretty barren except for an occasional dairy farm. It is weird to see cows grazing so close to the ocean. I wonder if they enjoy the salt air as much as I do?  The coastal waters also have a lot of sea kelp floating on the surface and around Gualala I heard the bark of the sea lions on the rocks but the road was too far up the cliff for me to see them. Hwy 1 weaves up and down and in and around the various coves with little seaside villages that hardly deserve a dot on the map.  I stopped at one such town and inquired at the General Store if there were restaurants in town and I was told, 'this IS the town.' This afternoon my aunt met up with me at our hotel just north of Fort Ross.  We drove south by car to check out Fort Ross. It was closed but a sign in front of one of the old houses talked about the area in the 'olden days' when herds of cattle and sheep were raised here and huge potato farms were cultivated.  The farmers took the potatoes by boats to the towns along the coast. I wonder if that is why they put potatoes in the clam chowder?  Just wondering. I have a lot of time to do that these days!   "Travel has been my comrade, adventure my inspiration, accomplishment my recompense."  Charlotte Cameron
OK, can I start tooting my horn??  What a happy day I had.  I listened to music and felt like Superwoman screaming around the corners and effortlessly moving up and down the hills along the coast.  My body had served me well this summer.  NO days of illness or injury! My thighs feel like steel and my heart and lungs no longer burn and scream in pain when I work up the hills. (Standing, I might add!  Which I have never enjoyed doing on a bike!)  I do not feel like I will turn 50 in a few weeks! Tomorrow around Pt. Reyes I will turn inland off the coast and start heading toward San Francisco. The coast has been such a special part of my ride and I have immersed myself in the salt air and sounds of the ocean.  Today in particular the salt air was very strong and with an overcast day the eucalyptus     
Kudos to Adventure Cycling and their awesome maps.  I left Bodega Bay this morning and followed their routing along some very interesting roads and paths that I would have never been able to find on my own!  I rode through Fairfax, San Anselmo,Kentfield,Larkspur and up the hills to Corte Medera.  At the top of the mountain I looked left and saw the most beautiful sight I have dreamed of for months-the city of San Francisco. It was completely shrouded in fog but you could see the tops of the buildings so it looked like they were just floating on a cloud.  To the left was the tops of the Bay Bridge.  I got to Mill Valley and found the bike path that leads to Sausalito and before I knew it I was in Sausalito. I stopped to take a picture of the Hwy 101 sign directing cars onto the Golden Gate Bridge.  How long I have pictured this sign in my mind.  I return a phone call to my Mother and find myself on this bike path, crying. Passersby hopefully figure out what is happening if they observe the Coasting 2002 logo on my packs. Later, a very helpful woman at the bus stop told me a better way to the city was on a ferry.  Another helpful local on a bike led me to the pier and at 3:15 I was on the ferry to the city.  On the ferry I met Dimitri.  He was on his way to his hotel job-close to our hotel-and was kind enough to show me the shortcuts. Well, I say shortcuts but I'm really not sure.  Before I knew it we were on Market Street heading UP to Powell. You know the picture if you've been to San Francisco. I say to Dimitri, 'we're going up THERE??  Dimitri is from Greece so in his broken English he tells me "we keep going up hill and I tell you later where we will turn!" I started pacing myself and a few red lights helped with the heart rate.  Green light-Dimitri is now on the sidewalk trotting/pushing his bike up the hill and I am still trying to prove something-I don't know what. I look around and I see every other sane person pushing their bike up to Powell so I joined the ranks.  We said goodbye at his stopping point and I screamed down four blocks to the Canterbury Union Square.  I am now enjoying a scotch and soda and will go next door for some sushi before Doug and Jen join me for the beginning of the celebrations.  Yeah, LIFE IS GOOD! "My homeless Mother has been found!"  Jennifer Marie Sims     
A happy and bittersweet morning.  Doug and Jennifer drove me back to Sausalito and I knew that I was but miles from the ending of Coasting 2002. I worked my way up the hills of the south part of Sausalito and after asking a few local riders, found my way to the west entrance of the bridge.  I had a few minutes to spare to give family and friends time to gather at our meeting spot on the south side of the bridge.  Local biking groups were all curious about my ride so I passed the time telling them about my journey.  At 11:30 I started crossing. It was a spectacular morning with a little bit of fog but clear for the most part.  At the half way point I saw Doug and Jennifer. Doug had a huge bouquet of flowers and Jen was holding a sign that she made that said, "Way 2 Go Mom!" I got teary eyed but was just happy to be there, having thought about that very moment so many times in the past.  The end was inevitable and it was time to rejoice, not cry.  We slowly worked our way down the last half of the bridge, stopping a few times to wave to people (strangers) on the other side of the bridge who were taking my picture and hollering congratulations!  Towards the end a bunch of my cousins and friends started cheering and clapping.  We all managed to reunite, hug, laugh and take tons of pictures.  Strangers kept coming up to me wanting to know all about the ride. I called my parents and shared the joy with them and then we loaded the bike and headed to the hotel where Doug spent an hour disassembling the bike for the trip back to Colorado. We shared a glass of champagne together at the hotel and then we all met the group at 5:00 at Fiore d'Italia, a wonderful Italian restaurant in North Beach for the celebratory dinner. Final mile count on the bike computer was 4, 744 miles!  What a ride, what a journey, what an experience!!   P.S.  Doug and I arrived back in Boulder on the night of the 2nd after taking Jennifer back to CSU in Fort Collins.  My sweet friend Christy had dropped off a cooler with a welcome home note and an ice cold beer-a Boulder Beer!  It is good to be home. Thanks girlfriend!! Where do I begin??...........at a loss for words.................scattered pictures runnng amok in my brain...........like so many seashells scattered on the beach. My daughter's sweet soulful voice is on the phone this morning asking me if I am meditating.  I have come to a beautiful Bed and Breakfast in Mendocino, California to spend a few days by myself.  To reflect, ponder, search, question, and celebrate. The result of all this will be my final chapter. (Of this particular story, anyway.)   I have managed to put all the seashells into a shoebox.  You see, I have been collecting them all summer long.  The box is very full so I spill the box out at my feet and begin to pick up each shell.  Each one has a memory painted on it.  There are so many of them. I decide that I need to sort them out and put them in some kind of piles so that I can explain each pile to you.  The Shell Neclace: I strung these shells together as I went along this summer. I wore it each day to remind me of the friends in my life that inspired me, coached me on and always believed in me.  There is John Accardi and Doug Speirn-Smith, coaxing me up Trail Ridge Road in Colorado and celebrating with me at the top. A day shared with special friends that I will always remember. This shell is Betty Frazier, giggling and smiling as she sags me through the Sawtooths.  There is Rick and Karen, Tom and Kristy, Karen and Gary, Kim, Muffy, Patti and Robin, Nancy and Bob, Penny and Bob, Dora and Valvin, Laurie and Gordon, John and Nancy, Pete, Susan, Allen and Betty, Freeman and Peggy, Roland and Sandee, Christy and Doug, Chris, Nancy P., Nancy B., Bill and Jill, Carol, Sharon, Faye, Marlene, Diane, Cindy, Kathy, Mary Jo, Mike and Mark who were so dedicated in their frequent emails that so inspired me, made me laugh and just kept me in touch with life back home. Wow, what a beautiful neclace! I will wear it often. Thank you from the bottom of my heart! The Familial Shells: Wow, this group of shells all kind of look alike! My sister Marlene joined me for a week in Kansas and remarked how there are some things I do that remind her of herself! Like the way I chew or the way I pronounce certain words. Funny how different we can be as siblings but yet how similar as well. I look at this pile with warmth in my heart. My family came through with shining colors this summer.  I have such dear memories and I just want to mention a few. Of course, there is that crazy bagel that Marlene hung on a sign in Kansas.  And who could forget the story of the temptation to steal the warm beer from the pickup truck?  We had tons of time to talk and solve all of our problems, didn't we?  Thanks for the memories, Marlene! You were a real trooper. Keep riding, would you? Then my baby sis, Cindy, met me in Steamboat and rode with me for a week through Utah and up to Wyoming.  Cindy, I hope you check your bed each night.  You never know if you will find undies or porn magazines there! You were awesome and had perhaps the roughest week of the ride.  The heat was unbearable but meeting Bill Perry gave us the hope and inspiration to keep pedaling.  I will never eat another hamburger no matter how hungry I am!  I enjoyed all the sister talk time that we had and look forward to the next time.  Mom and Dad, where do I begin?  At first you only wanted to sag me in Iowa and then after your new motorhome arrived you were anxious to hit the road and you sagged me through all of Illinois and most of Iowa.  I felt like a spoiled brat the whole time-being totally catered to and so well cared for. Mom your cooking is delicious as always and Dad, thanks for the help with all the flats and mechanical stuff.  We all had so much fun that you decided to come back for another two weeks through all of Oregon!  I remember so well taking Dad's picture as he was standing on that picnic table with his rolled up pant legs!! And the day I was so mad at you that I didn't want to talk to you after you were missing in action for hours.  They say you never stop worrying about your kids but it goes the other way as well!  I loved the walk on the beach in Florence and later sharing a celebratory martini after I reached the west coast.  Your dedication to your children is obvious and I will cherish the memories. You truly are the best and I love you! To my sister Diane and her husband Mike. You opened your home to me and made me feel very welcome.  I just have two requests-I need a ladder for the bunkbed and would you please figure out what time Mass is?  Thanks for all the repair work on the bike and for all the salty snacks. To my sister Mary Jo who so painstakingly edited, cut and pasted my journal pages and then copied them a dozen times over to mail to family and friends that did not have daily access to a computer.  You were the lifeline that kept everyone connected with my ride. You are simply the best! Cousin Margaret-so many times people look at us and ask if we are sisters.  You are like a sis to me and the week we spent together was so much fun.  Even though you worked my ass off and kept up a hellish pace.  The only way that I could catch my breath was to holler that I wanted to take a picture! I will frame the 3 shots that I took of your back as that is what I always saw every day-but hey, I got to see the naked guy-you missed him because you were going too fast!!  What can I say? Mike, Nicole and Austin, thank you for taking time to drive to Iowa to visit with me and sag me for two days.  You know how much I miss having the grandbabies in Boulder for two weeks this summer so seeing you for a few days was so sweet.  Next time we'll find a better hotel.  Don't put so much air in those tires next time, OK Mike?  Also, thanks for the encouraging emails that always made me smile. My kids James, Mark and Jennifer were always there with so much pride and joy over what I was doing.  I never heard a discouraging word from them.  James threw a good luck stone into the Atlantic Ocean for me and sent me the sweetest emails! Mark told me that he was proud of me and marveled that usually it's the other way around-parents being proud of their kids. Jennifer-my sweet child. For three summers in a row you were off exploring Europe and this summer I was the one who flew the coop and left you home in charge. I know that you missed not having your Mother around this summer so I have a lot of making up to do when I return. Thanks for your responsibility and care of our home and feeding Dad all those wonderful meals you prepared. The Shells with Pearls: I only found two of those on the beach and they deserve very special mention.  One is my husband Doug. I look back at the first 10 days we spent together and how very lucky I was to have you with me and keep the show going.  My lowest point was the night that I cried through the whole Italian dinner wondering what the hell I had done. The high point was the night before you were to fly home from Cleveland and the vote of confidence you gave me and the faith you had in me that I could do this. I also have numerous memories that make me chuckle-your graceful flip into the mud and your true spirit in the pouring rain.  I dedicated a whole page of my journal to you and I meant every word I said but I will say one more time-Thank You and I Love You!  I'm comin' home, fluff up my pillow!  My other pearl is my greatest friend Christy.  She sagged me from Rock Springs, Wyoming to Pocatello, Idaho. We were together for about 12 days and I had the time of my life with her. She came with a car loaded with so many Italian goodies that for lunch each day I thought I was in Tuscany again!  She was the encouragment behind the 98 mile record day and I will always remember the cold beer that we shared after-I was on such a high!  I won't say what you don't wear to bed at night as people might start talking and luckily you don't snore at night so you make a fabulous travel partner. You truly are a lustrous pearl in my life.  Thanks! Some Very Unique Shells: There are a handfull of gems that are real keepers: Margaret's husband Ron sagged us down the Oregon Coast and took his responsibilites very seriously.  At the end of each day there was a bottle of chilled wine, local cheeses and crackers.  He scoped out the hotel scene and had the truck unloaded each night.  In the morning he would have to reload everything while we attended to our bike duties.  Ron, please don't wear those sperm bike socks in your Corvette.  You don't need any more help in that department!  If you ever see licorice salt water taffy, send me a bag, would you? Thanks also to Ron's sister Pat and her husband Fred for sharing their home and dinner in Bandon, Oregon. Hats off to Christy's brother Russ Speirn and his wife Marilyn for opening their home to us in Pocatello.  There is nothing better than a home bed and home cooking when you are on the road.  Also Allen and Betty Frazier in Boise.  Betty sagged me for four days through the Sawtooths with her grandaughters, Sara and Katie.  We had so much fun and caught up on old times.  Allen, you did a superb job covering up the airplane ride story to Cedar City, Utah where Doug was waiting with a surprise visit.  Very well planned.  But next time I would like a raft that doesn't leak!  Keep working on the retirement thing, I think you've almost got it figured out. To my last but not least sagger-my Aunt Marion.  You joined me through the beautiful California Redwoods and I will always remember the cute cabin in the woods on the Avenue of the Giants and the not so cute cabin in Leggett.  You are a very special part of my life and I am so happy that we were able to spend these special days together. Next time we will control ourselves and not order dessert every night! The Scattered Shells: All shapes and sizes, each holding a very unique memory of Coasting 2002.  The beautiful Bed and Breakfast's I stayed in.  The not so beautiful, old, rundown places that were protection for the night but that I just as soon forget about.  The homecooked meals in smalltown U.S.A. where Granny was in the kitchen cooking her heart out and filling me with nourishment for the day.  The mountain passes that loomed at me on the maps and made me anxious the night before I was to attempt them.  There was Rabbit Ears Pass and Galena Pass.  And of course Trail Ridge Road and McKenzie Pass.  There were all the bike tourists that I met and exchanged stories with. The German couple with their 20 month old baby in a trailer made me smile. What memories they will have.  Or the young single guy who was anxious for his ride to end so he could go home to his sweetheart.  There was also the first tourist that I met who happened to be from Boulder.  There are the sights and smells that filled my lungs and heart with so much pure oxygen that I thought I would burst! I have so many shells in this pile and so many memories that I could go on forever. There were the beautiful animals that I saw every day.  The birds that wanted to sit on my helmet, the cows that ran along the fence with me and the crazy dogs that made my heart race. There were the roadside memorials to loved ones lost in car accidents and all the signs acknowledging groups that attempt to keep America clean by picking up trash. There were the numerous railroad crossings that I finally learned to maneuver across after almost becoming front page news.  There were all the times I stopped my bike in record time so that I could answer the cell phone and not miss anyone's call. I look forward to reading my own journal in the months to come to relive all the things that I experienced. There are so many of them!  I hope that I touched on some of the special ones! The Mirrored Shell: I pick this unusual shell up and I see my reflection!  I think I'll throw it back in the pile.  No?  Well, OK, but I have never been very comfortable with talking about myself.  I'm sure that everyone is anxious for me to get back home and see how this trip has changed me.  I may not be able to talk about it for a while.  I don't even know that I can write about it right now but I will make an attempt and if necessary, at a later date I can add or change as I look back. I have always loved the outdoors and I have always been athletic.  I spent the first 13 years of my life on a farm so obviously I spent a lot of time outdoors.  At age 15, months before my junior year in high school I went off to the Boundary Waters Canoe Area in northern Minnesota and experienced a month at Minnesota Outward Bound.  There I learned how much I really loved the outdoors and survived all the challenges of the program including a 3 night solo on my very own island!  Those experiences at that school have served me well throughout my life. The Outward Bound motto is "To serve, to strive and not to yield."  In my early 20's I played softball and joined the running team for the computer company that I worked for.  I remember my first 10K road race. I was pathetic.  It was in St. Paul, Minn and there were several thousand runners. I came in dead last!  All the scaffolding was taken down and all the runners were inside, enjoying the free beer and food.  I took off my running number and went to the stage, handed my tag to the speaker and told him that I wanted to make sure I would be listed among the participants as having completed the run!  Sad!  I should have given up the sport then and there.  But no, there is one thing that I do have and that is perserverance!  A few years later I trained with my then teenage sister, Cindy and we competed in a half-marathon in Iowa. Again, dead last.  But my father was there, following me in the car in case I wanted to jump in and escape. But I crossed the finish line with a smile!  Since then I have successfully completed the New York City and Los Angeles marathons!  I even placed respectably in my age group!  I gave up running and started doing more hiking, snowshoeing and skiing in the last 10 years.  As a youth I was an avid water skier and last summer I had to prove that I could still get up on skis.  It took me a year to heal a severe hamstring injury!  About 8 years ago my husband and I did an 6 day bicycle tour in British Columbia. We biked from Banff to Jasper and I was hooked!  For several years we took part in the Denver Children's Hospital Courage Classic, a 3 day, intense ride in the Colorado Rockies.  Every time I got on my bike I was in heaven.  Whenever I would see a cross country rider, pulling a trailer or toting bulging packs I was so envious of what they were doing.  I decided I wanted to experience it myself. In all the sports that I have taken part in it was never important to me how fast I was or how good I was. What was the most important was how good I felt about myself after I did t. When we moved to Boulder I joined a hiking group.  At age 40 I was the baby of the group. How inspired I was by the youthfulness and vitality of these women. I resolved to stay active and not let age slow me down.  However, I have seen the last of a pair of water skiis! I remember the 81 old triathlete who helped my sister and I in northwest Colorado-he told me how proud he was of what I was doing and that I inspired him!  Well, I think it was the other way around.  After my son came to Iowa with Nicole and Austin I received an email from Nicole. She said, "You are a very cool Grandma!" If there is one younger woman that I have inspired through this ride than it was worth every pedal stroke. I have many role models that I aspire to be like 'when I grow up.'  My cabin neighbor Lillian who at 93 still cooks, travels, and has a sparkle in her eye when she talks about all her planned travels and activities. My mother-in-law Betty Denesha who at 82 plays tennis, golfs and lifts weights regularly!  I love reading about Isabella Bird who was a pioneer woman who explored the west, on a horse, wearing a skirt!   So, here I am!  My persistance and determination are no longer a dream but a dream come true.  For the first time in my life I have had three and a half months all to myself.  Without the demands of my job or my domestic duties at home.  I have had hours spent on the bike, leisurely perusing the countryside; singing at the top of my lungs or quietly reflecting each moment of the day. I have had free time to read, hike, browse or have reflective conversations with family and friends. I will always cherish the hospitality of strangers that I met along the way and will remember the many kindnesses they showered on me. I worry about going back to the real world.  I have seen things at such a slow pace, with so few worries and anxieties.  I want to make changes in my life that will allow me the freedom to do more of the important things in life and less of the mundane.  How do I find that happy balance?  I guess it is something that I will need to work on every day. Remember the bowl, accept and be thankful for what is in it every day. In closing I have only two thoughts.  One is that when I wrote about my ride in one of the opening  chapters I said, 'stay tuned.' And I'd like to close with those same words.  Who knows where my next adventure will take me but I know there will be another, so ...........stay tuned. (How do you say bicycle and cooked egg in Japanese??) One of my hobbies is collecting quotations that I use in my journaling and in my scrapbooks and one of my alltime favorites is: "Here I am, safely returned over those peaks from a journey far more beautiful and strange that anything I had hoped for or imagined-how is it that this safe return brings such regret?"  Peter Mathiessen, American writer I have now taken all the shells and strung them together in one huge neclace. I will wear it often with joy in my heart. It is not heavy or burdensome because it tells a very special story of a very special summer-COASTING 2002! Thank You to everyone that has helped me and supported me in this dream.  I love you all and could not have done this without you!  You were the wind beneath my wings! Gladys Marie Sims September 2, 2002
A couple of hours later, I was standing with my Cannondale on a slab of concrete in the middle of nowhere watching the train pull away. I was sure the conductor had said this was Madera. There was, however, no trace of a city or of much else either. I was standing on a concrete and pipe rail structure that resembled a cattle loading chute. I scanned the horizon for a city skyline and, finding none, started out on the only road west and hoped. A few miles later I found the town, stopped at a local convenience store, and procured water for my three bottles and direction out of town. My destination for the day was Hanford. The roads were full of traffic until after 8:00 when, presumably, everyone got to work. There was a gentle tailwind which was not much help but certainly didn't impede my progress and I was able to maintain a nice 16 mph pace. The scenery was grapes and groves. I had a muffin and coffee on the train, saving breakfast proper for twenty or so miles down the road. I stopped in Kerman according to plan and found a little coffee shop which looked OK. It's always a puzzle whether to stop at the first place or go on a little farther, hoping to find a better restaurant. This place had good food as witnessed by all the locals already there ahead of me. My pancakes took about 45 minutes to get to me and about five minutes to eat. I had lost some time but the tailwind would help me gain it back. Lunch was to be in Caruthers. My usual on the road meals consist of pancakes in the morning and rice and corn tortillas at mid-day. I am a sort of vegetarian, making exceptions for a little chicken, fish and chile verde from time-to-time. I also eat tons of non-fat cheese, yogurt, cottage cheese and milk. It tastes great to me but then it's been so long since I've had the fatty variety I probably wouldn't know. Getting in and out of Caruthers was the biggest challenge of the day. For a ten mile radius around the town all dogs are apparently free to roam unfettered, looking for bicycle targets of opportunity. There are probably more dog chases occurring there than anywhere, with the possible exception of Arkansas. The vehicular traffic was, for the most part, well-behaved. The commercial truckers almost always pulled far out into the other lane to pass me when circumstances allowed. I usually gave them a friendly wave to show my appreciation. Having said that, I must say that people's tolerance for bikes deteriorated the farther south I went. I attribute this not to the locale but to the time of day.
