In the morning, the folks in cars still had cheery hopes for a great day. By mid-afternoon they were possessed of no such illusions and were decidedly grumpier. It was only mid-afternoon when I arrived in Hanford, so after a fudge sundae fuel stop I decided to press on to Corcoran. This was more progress than was originally planned, especially since I had gone an extra 8 miles by missing a turnoff south of Kerman. I was pedaling merrily along towards Coalinga when I woke up. By 4:00 pm I was cruising into Corcoran and 100 miles was coming up on the odometer. The Budget Inn had a room (they always do) and life was good. 
After she showed up 15 minutes late and I was stoked with the usual pancakes, I decided to hit the road before dawn. I had lights and I knew the road immediately south had a nice shoulder, having made this part of the trip several times before. By the time I got to the narrow shoulder, it would be light. I left Corcoran with all the prison employees heading south. Prisons are a big industry for some of the little towns in the Southern San Joaquin Valley. Then, after sunrise, there was nothing but that boring stretch between Corcoran and Wasco to test my resolve. This forty mile stretch always seems twice that distance to me. To top it off, I had lost my tailwind and even had a slight headwind at times. The boredom was only relieved once by the two dogs at the junkyard south of Colonel Allensworth State Park, real junkyard dogs, giving chase. But they had allowed me to get past them before giving chase so there was no contest. A stop at Teresa's in Wasco for more rice and tortillas led to the final ride into Bakersfield. I felt OK and the bike performed flawlessly with no flats. The train makes these little jaunts possible.  Amtrak San Joaquin trains have three bike racks in each car. This allows you to 'roll on' your bike without boxing it. Of course, as with any intrepid traveler, you may have to improvise. You could be faced with bike racks obscured with piles of bags and luggage, in which case you must discreetly rearrange the offending pieces to accommodate your bike. Amtrak only provides the racks, they don't guaranty that you can access them. My next goal is to ride Amtrak to Oakland, then cycle back to Bakersfield. Anyone want to come along? 
Route: SW out of Madera on State 145 through Kerman to Jensen. SE on Jensen to Dickenson. SW on Dickenson to Henderson (careful). SE on Henderson to Caruthers. SW on Marks out of Caruthers to Grangeville. SE on Grangeville to 10th  Ave. SW on 10th Ave. through Hanford , jog to 10 Ave, to Whitley. SE on Whitley into Corcoran. Hwy 43 South out of Corcoran to Wasco and home. 
First, Tom Jolliffe, the "old man" of the group, at the ripe age of over 50.  Tom is an accountant, and the manager at a London credit union.  Tom has been an avid cyclist for many years with the London Cycling Club, and has completed many bike tours with myself, including tours through Germany and England. Tom and I had originally planned to cycle the Icefields Parkway in 2000, but due to a work requirement, we agreed to reschedule for a later date. We were to find out the wait was well worth it! Tom rides a light blue Marinoni touring bike.  Paul Delconte, the youngest member of our trio, and the only one with any amount of hair, has been a friend for many years.  Paul works for the company formerly known as Imation. Paul works for the company formerly known as Imation. Paul works for a company called DecisionOne. Paul is an electronics technician, and repairs testing equipment used by telephone and utility companies. We share a common bond in that we both have sons with developmental handicaps.  I had joined Paul in the past on small day trips with our respective partners.  I have been trying for several years to get Paul to join the London Cycling Club.  Last year, I finally succeeded, and Paul was soon engrossed with the idea of cycle touring.  Paul's "steed" is a red Norco mountain bike. The gearing on this bike was great for a trip through the Rockies, but Paul falls behind a bit on the flats (understandably so).  We are gradually swaying Paul toward the purchase of a road bike. One more year, and I think we'll have him hooked. Lastly, myself - Kevin Rodger.  I am a pilot for Air Canada Jazz.  I've been cycling since I was a kid, but just got back into cycling in a serious way about eleven years ago.  I try to combine my love of travel with my passion for cycling.  I joined the London Cycling Club, and rode my (at that time) fifteen year old Nishiki 10 speed to many rides.  In the second year of my membership, I purchased a Cannondale H-400 hybrid bike, which I still use to do the occasional tour.  I have toured Mexico (from Cancun to the border of Belize), Germany, England, Bermuda, Antigua, and most of the province of Ontario by bicycle.  The next tour I am planning is from Salzburg to Budapest along the Danube River bike trail.  I have been riding a Mikado D'Iberville touring bike for about five years.  My next upgrade - a Bruce Gordon Rock 'n' Road touring bike (if I have my way on the home front).  THE RIDE We were to be rewarded with reasonable weather (no rain or snow), and some of the world's most spectacular scenery.  The Icefields Parkway technically covers the 230 kilometre stretch of road from Lake Louise to Jasper.  We added a couple of hundred extra kilometres by cycling from the Calgary Airport to Banff and then via the Bow Valley Parkway.  The hardest things to figure out were which way we were going to cycle, our enroute accommodations, and how to get back to the airport.  The route we chose from south to north, was picked solely on the availability of flights: there are more flights to the Calgary Airport from Toronto than from Toronto to the Edmonton Airport.  Many people have asked me which direction would be easier.  While I'm no expert on cycling through the Rockies, I would have to say it doesn't really matter - there are two big climbs and two fantastic descents no matter which way you go!  As for wind, we didn't really have a whole lot of that, except on the first couple days, so I really can't comment.Originally, I had wanted to make this excursion into a camping vacation.  However, neither Tom, nor Paul wanted this - I knew Tom was not a camper, but I thought Paul might like to try it.  In the end, the decision to use hostels instead of camping was a bit of a godsend, as many of the campgrounds were closed to tent camping due to a problem with bears. Although there were lots of bear sightings, we personally did not see any.  We did, however wonder why there were lumps of bear "poop" spaced every 500 feet or so along the shoulder of the Parkway.  The hostels we used were ideally spaced for bike touring.  We stayed at the International Youth hostels in Banff, Lake Louise (our unequivocal favourite), Rampart Creek, Beauty Creek, and Jasper.  We were also scheduled to stay at the Mount Edith Cavell Hostel, but my two comrades mutinied (something about showers, or lack thereof), and we bypassed Mt. Edith Cavell in favour of a hotel in Jasper.  More about this sad tale later     
We left Calgary International Airport at approximately 1:30 p.m., bound for our first day's destination of Cochrane.  We selected Cochrane because we originally were unsure of what time we would arrive in Calgary, plus we thought 150 km in one day on fully loaded touring bikes was not much of a holiday. As I mentioned, the weather was partly cloudy with a few very light showers along the way.  The route we took us north of the airport through two street lights on Barlow Trail for (approximately 2 km).  We then turned left (west) on Country Hills Blvd.  This route was generally uphill through the northern part of the city until turning south west on Stoney Trail to connect with Highway 1A (running north-west) for the remaining 19 km. into Cochrane. The route we selected was generally gently undulating terrain, with some very pleasant scenery.  We enjoyed a fairly wide shoulder about eight feet wide, narrowing to about four to six feet during the last 10 kilometres of the ride. In the last 3 km. Before you enter town, this road takes a very nice, steep downhill "dive" into the city.  On this section of road, I obtained a top speed of 68 kph.  Not bad, considering we were combating a 30 kph headwind, and were riding fully loaded touring bikes! Just after arriving, we were greeted by a rather large rain shower.  Timing is everything!   We checked into the Super 8 Motel, where we were well received by the staff.  We were allowed to keep our bikes inside the locked boardroom for the night.  Our room was very large, and included three queen size beds.  The price was perhaps a bit high, at $150 for the night, but after splitting the price three ways, it was reasonable.  The price included an ample continental breakfast in the morning.That night we ate at the Boston Pizza restaurant just across the road from the Super 8 Motel.  Total distance travelled for the day:  43 km, total time on the bike: 2 hours, 26 minutes, for an average speed of 17.6 kph.  I know it sounds slow, but the wind was brutal!     
     We arrived in Banff at 2:00 p.m., travelling the 114.8 km. In 5 hours and 22 minutes (which also includes a slow ride up to Sulphur Mountain for a soak in the Hot Springs).   Our average speed was 21.4 kph, and once again I reached a maximum speed of 68 kph. Since we could not check into our rooms at the hostel until after 1500, we decided to ride up Sulphur Mountain to have a dip in the Upper Hot Springs.  We dropped our panniers off in the available lockers.  Tom got a bit frustrated, as the locker he selected ate his loonie.  I did not know this, and while he was out of the locker area, I deposited a loonie, and locked the locker. Tom needed an item out of the locker, so we opened it up again, deposited another loonie only to have the locker once again malfunction.  The frustration had begun!  After sorting this mess out, we rode towards the hot springs.  Halfway up the mountain, I heard several expletives emanating from the person riding the Marinoni bike - something to the effect of "What the "heck" am I doing this for?  I don't need this "funky" aggravation!"  Tom never made it all the way up the mountain.  Tom never got a "ride" in the hot springs.  Paul and I continued the slow grind up, and were rewarded with some great views (including those of the mountain vista), and we were able to rest our weary muscles in the 39C pool.  All this for only $10.00, including the use of an official Upper Hot Springs towel! Due to a computer issue at the hostel, our reservation for the night was lost - and the hostel was full (it was Thursday night, after all).  We were assured by the hostel that they would find us beds after 6:00 p.m.  Tom had already checked out a few hotels, so we told the hostel that if they couldn't find a room, that is was OK.  Tom called to confirm the hotel room, but he was informed it was already taken.   When we were finally assigned a room in the hostel, we found it was already occupied.  We waited another 45 minutes before we were finally assigned beds, but in two separate rooms.  Paul and Tom got to bunk in with girls from Germany and France.  Some guys got all the luck.  I got the "Italian" suite - three friends from Milan.  This room probably would have been better for Paul, as he speaks fluent Italian.  The problem was, it took me a while to figure out which language they were speaking. The time was now after 6:00 p.m. Dinner this night was at the hostel - I expected inexpensive food, but it was about the same price as anywhere else in town.  However, the portions were very large.  Actually, I got off pretty light here - after a few beers, followed by dinner, and another beer, I retired to my room.  Only after I retired for the evening did I realise I left Cougar Pete's Bar and Grill without paying.  I had only hoped that Paul was not too upset with me for stiffing him with the bill.  I found out the next morning that Cougar Pete's had actually charged him for all three bills (even though Tom had paid his portion).  This was sorted out, and we were (or should I say, I was) once again on good standing.   The Banff Hostel is on a nice setting at the top of a relatively steep hill.  It is a large hostel, with a large contingent of mostly young people from around the world.  It is also very noisy.  The doors are equipped with magnetic card locks.  The problem is the locks don't work very well.  All during the night, as people made their way to the washroom, one could hear the constant clicking of those plastic "credit cards" sliding through the locks. This was followed by a bit of cussing, and finally, apologies to the person who eventually had to get out of bed to let them in.  Not only that, but we found that most people did not retire until after midnight.  I can tell you that after a hard day of cycling, I was ready for bed at 2200! 
          
Bow Valley Parkway is a very palatial road, with little traffic.  It had no shoulders, but we found they weren't necessary.  Every kilometre or so, there were areas where we could pull off the main road to view the scenery or take a rest.  This route was very scenic, especially in the area close to Castle Mountain.  Just before Castle Mountain, there was a rather large downhill.  I traversed this area first, and waited for the rest of the "crew" to arrive.  Next came Paul, after a few minutes.  But alas, there was no Tom.  We waited several minutes for him to arrive to no avail.  We decided to go back and look for him, fearing him may have fallen on the steep downhill, or had a mechanical problem.  Back we climbed for four kilometres, and we finally saw him coming down the hill.  He explained that at the last stop a tie from his pannier had wrapped itself around his front rim, effectively stopping movement of any kind.  We shuddered when we considered the effect this might have had on the downhill portion!   Distance covered today was 79.2 km, in 4 hours, 12 minutes, for an average speed of 18.8 kph.  This speed reflects a steep 4 km section up to the actual lake above the townsite of Lake Louise.  I estimate we climbed about 1400 feet or more in this short distance.  We enjoyed bright sunshine today, with no wind.  It had clouded over by the time we arrived in Lake Louise.  Our park pass was inspected for the first time since entering the park, and we were informed by the attendant that a grizzly bear had been spotted the day before crossing the road 100 metres from the gatehouse.  We did not encounter any bears today, but we did manage to photograph a couple of elk, and we spotted a deer in the woods.   At the hostel we met four American cyclists - Joe and Gerard, and their wives, who were going to be riding the Icefield Parkway southbound from Jasper.  Graciously, they offered to bring some food up to the next two "wilderness" hostels for us.  Paul and I quickly made a dash for the supermarket to rapidly collect some food staples, and a bottle of Merlot wine - our prize upon arrival at Beauty Creek.The Lake Louise Hostel was very nice - close to hotel standards.  The rooms held two bunk beds, and each room had its own toilet and sink.  Showers were right outside the door, and it appeared we shared the shower with only one or two other rooms.  The price was $30.67 apiece, inclusive of taxes.         
We left Lake Louise at 8:00 a.m., but Tom soon discovered that his front rack had a sheared bolt.  This was probably a result of the previous day's ride where the tie had wrapped itself around the wheel rim.  Tom rode back into town to seek out a repair.  Paul and I waited about an hour before Tom arrived from the bike store with a new bolt attached to the rack.  The ride continued.  About 34 kilometres out of Lake Louise, we stopped for lunch on the shore of Bow Lake, the source of the Bow River.  The restaurant was the Num-Ti-Jah Lodge.  The following description of the lake is taken from their web site:  "Num-Ti-Jah Lodge overlooks one of the most dramatic scenes in the Canadian Rockies. Out of Bow Lake the mountains rise steep and rugged. The blue ice of Crowfoot Glacier hangs suspended over the turquoise water. To the west, the craggy peaks of the Great Divide tower over Bow Glacier."  Lunch was buffet style.  We needed this fuel to get us over the upcoming Bow Pass.  Bow Pass was not as difficult as we had feared.  It was long, but the climb was not steep at all - at least in the direction we were heading!  From Lake Louise, at roughly 5000' above sea level, Bow Pass tops out at 6785 feet.  However, there are sever plateaux along the way.  The steepest part of the pass climbs about 800 feet in only six kilometres.   It is all downhill after the pass.  I left Paul and Tom behind on the downward portion of the pass.  Riding downhill is my fort!  Highway 93 generally follows river valleys.  On the north side of Bow Pass we follow along the Mistaya River. The Mistaya eventually joins with the Saskatchewan River.  At Saskatchewan River Crossing, where we had agreed to stop for lunch, I waited for the rest of the gang to arrive.  After fifteen minutes, I can see the whites of Tom's eyes coming up the slight hill into the restaurant.  After a quick snack, and drink, we departed once again for Rampart Creek, only 12 kilometres away. We arrived at the quaint hostel of Rampart Creek around 4:30 p.m. Rampart Creek was virtually deserted at this time.  Only the manager and one other cyclist from Calgary were present.  We took advantage of this quiet time to "case out" the joint and surrounding area.  Rampart Creek Hostel consisted of two accommodation cabins, one food preparation cabin, the manager's cabin, a wood fired sauna, and a very comfortable outhouse located at the entrance to the hostel.  Rampart Creek Hostel was nestled beside a creek with fast flowing glacial water, and high cliff walls around the creek - ample space for nice hiking. Today, we covered 79 km in 4 hours, and thirty-four minutes of cycling, for an average speed of 20.9 kph.  I achieved the respectable speed of 79 kph in one downhill stretch of the Bow Pass. Around the supper hour more people started to arrive, with a tour group consisting of about 10 people, mostly from Australia, New Zealand, Germany and France.  We checked to see if our food had arrived, and were pleasantly surprised that it had.  We enjoyed bowls of soup, and bread. That evening, Paul and I took advantage of the wood burning sauna, completed by a dip in the cool mountain stream running behind the sauna.  Make that "cold" mountain stream!  I believe it was Paul's first experience with a sauna, and predictably, he was the first to venture into the stream.  I say "predictably," because Paul was sitting right beside the fireplace.  The so called "hot seat!"  Paul did not return after this cold foray. Mary, from New Zealand was next, followed by a Korean "team" of three people.       
After Bow Pass, I can honestly say we weren't expecting a real difficult climb. Our profile map, however showed a 1900 foot climb over only 16 kilometres.  The first 18 km climbs quite gradually, then the grade rapidly increases.  Just before the real steep part starts, we stopped for a break at Parker Ridge, just below the Hilda Creek Hostel.  There are many hiking paths evident here, and with more time, we would have liked to have attempted a hike.  Our climb continued   As I had passed Paul and Tom on a downhill stretch prior to the pass, I had a good lead.  I stopped part way up to take some pictures of an impressive waterfall. I could see buses and cars stopped on a hill about 1000 feet above.  That, I thought must be the summit.  I timed a bus as it made its descent downhill to where I had stopped.  It took four minutes.  I estimated it was about five or six kilometres to the upper observation point, and the top of the pass.  Boy, was I wrong! I waited until Tom had caught up with me and we continued on our way.  After climbing for another two kilometres, the road made a turn to the left and started a shallow descent. The road made a big u-turn in a clearing, where we were battered by turbulent winds seemingly coming from all directions.  The climb then restarted in earnest.  After what seemed like hours, we reached the summit.  Tom reached the "top" of the pass first, followed by myself, and then finally Paul.  After taking some pictures of our conquest, we continued on our way.  Around the next bend the climb continued, and continued. The views from the 6676' pass were astounding.  It was impressive to see the terrain we had just covered on our bikes.  Pictures simply do not do it justice. We thought we had reached the top of the pass, but behind the next hill we continued our climb.  The 34 tooth rear cog I had installed the previous week came in handy, and was well utilised.  I still could have used a smaller inner chainring.   The downhill portion of Sunwapta did not seem as steep as Bow Pass, however, I was confident I would be able to exceed 80 kph somewhere along the way. Unfortunately, going downhill I ran into headwinds which impeded my progress.By 1:15 p.m. we found ourselves rolling into the Columbia Icefields.  We ate lunch in the cafeteria because the restaurant side was full.  After lunch we decided to take a Snocoach to the bowels of the glacier.  This cost almost $30, but we felt it was a reasonably value.  Somewhere along the way, the guide told us about the ecological impact visitors had on the Columbia Icefields, and how Brewster Transportation (operators of the Snocoach tours) were trying to minimise it. She mentioned they carried anywhere from 4000 to 4500 visitors per day via Snocoach to the glacier.  We roughly calculated that in a year, Brewster would make roughly $2,000,000 before costs in a short five-month season. We left the icefields behind at 4:25 p.m., and continued the short 18 kilometres to Beauty Creek, arriving at 5:10 p.m., the same time as our American friends were arriving from their southbound trip from Jasper.  Roger and Diane, the managers of the Beauty Creek Hostel had done a lot of renovating, including the installation of a makeshift outdoor shower facility, complete with running warm water.  Cold water was heated by a large propane burner, and then Roger mixed the hot water with cold in a five gallon holding tank to produce the desired effect.  Nothing like a hot shower with a view of the mountains! After showering, we prepared our gourmet supper for the evening - spaghetti with tomato sauce, bread, and a nice bottle of wine to top it all off!  Our total distance for the day was 56.9 kilometres over 3 hours and 19 minutes, for an average speed of 17.1 kph - not bad considering the climb at Sunwapta Pass.           
Some of my fondest times were camping in the Canadian Rockies with my dad.  Mount Edith Cavell held some great memories for me.  My mom still delights in telling stories of how her six year old son climbed half way up Mt. Edith Cavell.  I am sure it was only a couple hundred feet or so, up some well groomed path.  Today's journey was mostly downhill.   Early in the morning, on my way to the impressive Beauty Creek outhouse (it has some interesting quotes to peruse while one does his or her "business"), it was very foggy, and you couldn't see more than 25o metres in front of your nose. By the time we left, however, there was bright sunshine and no evidence of any fog.  The temperature eventually warmed up to 23, and we were able to finally cycle in shorts and jerseys.  We left Beauty Creek around 10:15 a.m.  After 32 kilometres, one bee sting to my temple, and 1hour and 25 minutes of cycling, we reached Sunwapta Falls.  This is a fast moving, narrow falls, with a rather large drop off through a rocky gorge. There are all sort of hiking trails along the sides of the Sunwapta River around the falls, as well as a wooden footbridge to cross for a view from the other side.  We spent about a half-hour at the Falls before proceeding out the road intersection for lunch at the restaurant.We finished lunch and resumed our journey at 1:15 p.m.  Our next stop would be at the equally breathtaking Athabasca Falls.  This stretch of 24 kilometres took us the better part of an hour.  Athabasca Falls had lots more water dropping down a similar gorge to the one in Sunwapta, but I for one did not find it as spectacular.  It was also more crowded. In fact, we bumped into a German couple we had met the previous night in Beauty Creek, and they agreed to take our group shot by the Falls. Cycling out, we stayed on the main highway, #93, instead of 93A.  This meant that we would certainly bypass Mt. Edith Cavell.  I rode by myself, several kilometres ahead of Paul and Tom.  I stopped at the junction where the two roads rejoined, just after crossing over the Athabasca River and waited for my two "comrades."  From this point it, was 5 kilometres back to the junction of the Mt. Edith Cavell Road.  I had contemplated starting out on my own, but I wanted to remain friends with the others, so I waited.  Besides, there was a park entrance, and I didn't know if they could get through without the National Park Pass, which was in my possession.  Upon their arrival, Paul said that they would go on to Jasper, but I was free to go to Mt. Edith Cavell if I wanted.  I thought about the logistics, and I capitulated and agreed to accompany them to Jasper.  Mt. Edith Cavell would have to wait.  We did however take a few pictures in front of a directional sign showing the distance to the turnoff - me with a "thumbs up," Tom and Paul indicating a "thumbs down."  Isn't democracy wonderful? We arrived in Jasper at 4:40 p.m., covering 92.8 K in 3 hours and 51 minutes of cycling time, for an average speed of 24.1 kph.  I attained a maximum speed of 71 kph.  I thought at one point I would surpass my downhill record of 79 kph (also achieved on this trip), but alas, a van pulled out 1/3 down the hill and I had to brake to stay behind him.  I guess that's not bad, considering this was in a 50 kph zone! We found a hotel called the Tonquin Inn, which was very nicely situated and answered the needs of Paul and Tom quite nicely. OK, I admit it - I did enjoy that warm shower, as well! 
Upon Tom and Paul's return, we started off for the hostel, about six kilometers away on a relatively steep uphill.  It is fairly close to the Jasper Tramway, located on Whistler's Mountain.  On the way up this hill, Tom and I decided to stop (yes, it was that steep).  This proved to be a bit of a mistake, as it was very difficult to get the momentum to continue without falling over by the time we re-clipped into our pedals.  Paul, on the other hand, with his mountain bike gearing simply spun away and easily beat us to the hostel. We checked into the hostel, and made another decision.  If Mount Edith Cavell was this steep (as we had heard from other hostellers), we didn't want any part of it today.  We decided to hike up Whistler's Mountain and return on the skytram instead.  We were told this would take us about three hours. We started up, as we had a lot of time on our hands.  The first part proved to be quite easy, with relatively good trails up the mountain in a series of switchbacks.  Gradually it got steeper.  At no point were we discouraged however, as we passed a few families with very young children climbing up today. It was about 27C when we left the hostel, and I was sweating profusely.  My t-shirt was completely soaked with sweat, and the single water bottle I had was starting to run low.  As we climbed, the tall alpine gave way to smaller and smaller trees, and finally just rocks.  It looked like the moon, and the crisp atmosphere made things even more surreal.  We reached the top in 2 hours and 35 minutes.  Not a record by any stretch of the imagination, but a good effort for the over the forty crowd. Paul and I continued to the summit, about another 800 feet in elevation.  It offered some spectacular views, including one of my coveted mountain - Edith Cavell!  Our adventure was almost over.  We made our way back down to the tram, paid our $11.00, and were whisked back down in a matter of minutes. At the hostel, I prepared the grossest meal I have had to eat in a long time.  It consisted of a mix of two different "add water and eat" dishes.  Tom had his plate completely cleaned off by the time I sat down to eat.  I stomached my way through about one-half of my plate, before I chucked the rest in the garbage.  I don't think Paul made it that far.  Tom still claims to this day that he ate everything on his plate.  Damn, that boy must have been really, really hungry!!! Sleep came early that night, surrounded by about 50 other bodies in the same common sleeping area.  But it ended rudely at about 5:00 a.m., as we had to get ready to leave.The Sun Dog Tours van showed up almost on schedule at 6:00 a.m.  After a bit of seat moving, we managed to fit the bikes and luggage in the van, and we were off for the Calgary airport.  Along the way, our eagle-eyed driver pointed out about 40 elk, and one bull moose along the highway.  We still did not see any bears.  The five hour drive kind of trivialized our six days of bike riding, but I don't think you can ever truly enjoy the vistas the way we saw them from the back seat of a steel cube moving at 100 kph!                 
(click to show email) ?The Natchez Trace may well be the most historic roadway in North America. First appearing over 8,000 years ago as a buffalo and Indian Trail, eventually the path knew the wagon wheels and horses? hooves of the expedition led by explorer Hernando DeSoto, in search for gold, around 1540?. (Mississippi 2002 The Official Tour Guide. P. 43)
We arrived in Natchez about 7:00 pm. We drove to the visitor?s center but it was closed. We did drive over the Mississippi River into Louisiana to say we had made it over there. The river seemed to be up and had a very muddy look probably from the floods that are happening in Illinois and Missouri. We then went to the Natchez Trace State Park where we camped. It was a nice campground and had plenty of spaces available. There was a bathhouse although we never showered. Our plan of riding was to have two bicycles riding while the third person drove the van 20 miles up the Trace. The driver would then park the van at a designated spot taking their bicycle off the van and riding back down the Trace. When the bike that left the van caught up with the other two bikers coming up, he would join them to ride back to the van. Once at the van another driver would take the van up the Trace another 20 miles. This was the method we used to insure that each rider got in about the same amount of miles. 
We stopped in Sunken Trace and toured it. There was an old graveyard there with many dead Pattersons. We stopped at the Lower Choctaw boundary. There was a line of trees that had demarked the end of the Choctaw lands. The trees are still standing. It is now the boundary between two counties. We discovered that the Trace as one of the last places for settlers who were heading west. The last place to get provisions before they left civilization as they headed for new settlements. Soldiers constructed the Trace in the early 1800?s -1801. The area was where a Civil War Battle of Raymond was fought. General Grant latter made his headquarters on the Trace.  At this point on the Trace we were only about 35-40 miles from Vicksburg. Jim left the van at Deans Stand---the outpost that this man had set up where he sold provisions to travelers, itinerate ministers, vagabonds and settlers. We went 66 miles in 5 hours 30 minutes of riding the bike. We arrived at our second campsite Rocky Springs. The National Park Service operates it. There is a small building that has restrooms and literature on the area as you enter the park. There is a pay phone there but someone took the receiver so it was of little value in my need to let the family know I was ok. Jim?s cell phone would not work here either. This is a nice park but it has minimal services. I was really hoping for a shower but all it had was a sink and flush toilets. There were plenty of campsites available and Jim selected one for us before Bob and I got there. (We later rode 20 more miles up to Deans Stand, which is where we will start on Tuesday). There are several people in big huge camper vans with cars in tow. The one from across the street came to tell Jim and Bob (I was reading in the tent) that he was retired from General Motors. He talked in a big booming voice, I guess he was used to talking loudly and distinctly over machines for 30 years. He does not like to see retired people walking in Malls and meeting for coffee. No sir, not him. He drives all over the country and is enjoying himself. He had a lady friend who he broke up with last year because all she wants to do is sit at home. So this happy retired man with his little Chihuahua dog walked gleefully to the rest rooms. He was pretty large, shirtless and hairless with just a pair of shorts on and flip-flops. Before he left my earshot he told the doggy that he was a ?good boy, are real good boy?. Lucky dog. I am a bit sore from this first day of riding but it has been a beautiful day. The temperature was in the 70s with an occasional head wind but it did not persist. The Trace is so beautiful and unspoiled. It is well kept being well mowed and clean. The road is a bit windy but mostly it is flat with a wide mowed tract on either side of the road. The trees are large and the forest is very dense on either side of the road. Mostly as we rode we are unmolested with traffic. It did seem that the traffic was more constant in the early morning and then picking up around 4:30PM. But all in all we were alone with the Trace. We did meet another biker at Mangum Mound. He was riding a Navallo bike that is sold by REI. He was complete in their clothing and matching two bags on his front tire and then two bags on his back wheel. He was on a 16-day ride from Murphy, NC to Baton Rouge LA. He was going to go there and then return riding by himself. He was very thin, almost emaciated and very happy to see us. We talked with him for a few minutes and then we were off again. He was not tenting as he said he was ?credit-card camping? staying in a hotel every night.  We talked with the Park Ranger at Natchez State Park on our first night. He was from Peoria Illinois but was raised in Mississippi. He took our ten dollars for the site and he talked with us for about 20 minutes. After the ranger left a couple from a camper across the road came over to talk with us. They were interested in the recumbent bikes. He had to comment on them then he made Jim a bit angry because he did not understand why bike riders did not ride on the left side of the road like walkers. We explained that it was the law and safer to ride with the traffic. He then said that if he drove buy us and we fell in front of him while he was driving it would be his fault. He would never ride a bike on the road, under any circumstances. He would only ride a motorcycle. I am trying to eat right on this trip so here is a run down of the food for the first day. I had a spinach, Swiss cheese and mushroom omelet for breakfast. I had a few almonds in the morning. For lunch I had several slices of Swiss cheese wrapped in turkey. I also had some dried fruit. For supper I made a pan of tofu with cabbage, green peppers, and onion. I had a large tasty pear for desert with my cup of decaf coffee. Jim and Bob ate different foods from me as they are eating more canned goods. I am the only one that had a cooler with food in it. 
I spotted several birds of prey flying on their early morning hunt. At one point along the road I saw several deer standing on the side of the road. They were looking straight back at my van as it approached. I thought at first that they looked just like the kind of deer that people buy to set in their yards. But then I realized that they were live deer. I slowed the van (the maximum speed on the Trace is 50 and I was going that speed). Just as I slowed, deer closest to the road broke and ran. In a few short seconds that it took for the van to pass, I noticed five white tails disappear into the woods. The Trace is literally covered with trees on either side of it. Although the sides of the road have big spaces that are approximately 100 to 200 yards on either side of the road, there are trees that block out all vision from anywhere else. It as if I ride my bike in a grand park that stretches for 400 miles. The tidiness of the parkway impresses me daily. The grass is all trimmed and the hundreds of trees are all manicured as if this were designated as some palatial gardens of kings. I have walked in the gardens of kings in England, China, India and Africa but nothing compares to the expanse of beauty of the Trace.  Just after seeing the five deer, I encountered a large dead doe in the middle of the road. It had been killed recently as the body was still oozing of blood. I had to wonder if the five deer were not looking for their lost brethren who was lying dead so near.  A short time later as I pulled the van in a pull off near mile 86 that I noticed a dead hawk in the middle of the road. Why that would happen is beyond me. I guess that living in the United States I expect to see deer dead on the road. They are allowed to over breed and naturally run from place to place especially at night when car lights blind them and drivers are not left with options. They are a real nuisance but to see a dead bird of prey in the middle of road is hard to understand. I pulled the van into the wayside and pulled my bike off to meet my fellow bikers. I had only gone 5 miles and they meet me. They had been riding a bit fast. We rode back to mile 82 and Jim decided that he would go get the van and meet us as we meandered our way through and around Jackson. The Trace is being reconstructed around Jackson; the detour for bikes is 23 miles. It takes the biker through Clinton and Ridgeland before coming back onto the Trace. Just before we took this journey off the Trace, another through biker that Jim had met the night before at Rocky Springs joined us. His name was Gary and he was riding from Natchez to Chicago (Naperville). He had the map also so Bob and I decided to go with him and we would stop at the first breakfast place we could find. It was a winding road but yet the directions were quite clear and we ended up at a Sonic Drive in for breakfast at about 10 AM.  Gary was from Illinois who had two daughters who were music majors from the University of Illinois. He used to ride his bike down to visit them. It was only a 110-mile trip. He and his 23-year-old daughter rode from Illinois to Vermont last year. He was a French major in college but did not want to teach French so he joined the Peace Corp and spent 2 years in Tunisia. He later got into computers and now at 53 is retired. His wife will retire in 2 years and then he is out of Naperville. It stuck me that I am the same age as he but I do not plan to retire until I am 70. Is it because I have a young family that I desire to work or is it that I like my work? What about him was he happy to retire or was he forced out? This is hard to say from our brief encounter. He seemed happy enough to be riding his bike and enjoying life. I wish him well.  He was a fast rider and we followed him for a good while but I knew that he was being held back. We had come up to a train crossing with a train blocking the road. Rather than wait we took off for 2 miles down the road to get around the stopped train when we got to the road a passenger train sped by us. Gary said that was the train he had ridden to get to the Trace. The freight train was waiting for it and so should have we waited and saved ourselves some time. We actually spent more time trying to find our way back to the map.Bob and I did get lost a bit and it took us longer to get back on the Trace than we had expected. When we did Jim said that Gary had passed him saying that he also got lost. That last two entries on the map needs to be changed. Bob was stopped by a woman just before the entrance to the Trace in Jackson. She was excited about his recumbent bike. They talked for 10-15 minutes about the bike and how it was good for someone like her who had back problems. Those recumbent bikes make people ask questions and want to know more about the bike. Jim met us almost immediately when we got back on the Trace. The ride around Jackson and Clinton was exhausting because the directions were well described but the last two items did not tell us where to turn. On a bike, a missed turn can mean lots of extra work, which it did for Bob and me. We figured that we rode about 4 miles out of way just to find Highway 51 and the entrance to the Trace.  We stopped by an overview of the lake and talked with a guy who had a dog. He said that the dog had found him by showing up at his workplace. The dog was part Chow and something else! It was a beautiful dog (remember that I am not much of a dog lover so this animal was impressive). To me it looked like a pup but was actually 3 years old. The dog owner was perturbed with all the people letting their dogs run free when they should be on a lease. I had to agree with him. (People who treat their dogs as if they were humans perpetually disturb me.) Dogs have a place but they need bounds. The dog owner and I agreed on that. He was a pleasant man who willingly took pictures of the three of us with my camera. Later I would wonder what this man?s occupation was. Standing there looking out at the beautiful lake with people walking back and forth, I thought this could be any exotic resort in the world. But here it is a part of the Trace. The water was spectacular and the view was awe-inspiring. Boats drifted or flashed across the scene. The shores of the other side of the lake exposed a great expanse of tress that makes the Trace. Trees are everywhere manicured and sculptured into a 400-mile garden. I rode on from the picnic area up the road that meandered around the lake. It was as if I was riding a bike down the Pacific Highway except the pristine view makes it the natural beauty of the Trace. I felt clean and alive as I rode those miles but knew that the road would lead me away from this gorgeous body of water. Yet I peddled on. At one juncture, there was a man on the other side of the road moving dirt with an earthmoving tractor. As I passed the earthmover there was one man sitting in a car and one sitting on the car. The man sitting on the car yelled ?Where you going?? I stopped and chatted with him for a few minutes. He was watching the man using the earthmover. He said that his job and the other guy in the car were to watch the guy on the earthmover. They worked for the earthmover. They were both African-American and the earthmover man was white. I wondered how much they were paid to watch that man. I felt I was missing something about Mississippi in that conversation.  They asked me where I was from and I told them the Appalachian Mountains of Virginia. I said it was pretty much nowhere (rural, unpopulated, beautiful) and the man sitting on the car said well that is what he tells people about this part of Mississippi.  As I rode off I thought that they were near Jackson and this was a big city, now why would he think he is from now where America? Perhaps people never see the beauty of their home area.  I rode for several miles with trees on one side of the road and water on the other side. Many people were fishing. People drive their car and trucks to the shore to fish. When people looked up to see the passing bicycle the hands immediately went to waving. I waved also as the friendliness of the Trace permeated me. I rode my bike to Ratliff Ferry where we camped for the night. It is a very redneck place with campers stuck next to each other like an unkempt yard. Not well kept with tall grass that needed to be cut. But this private campground did have a shower that was great with lots of hot water. There was no pay phone but the young man in the camp store said that I could use his store phone to make a calling card call. My call to my wife did not go through but he said that I could come back later to use it, as the store was open until 7PM. I was impressed that he was young but yet there was another young man sitting in a chair talking with him. My experience has been that it was older men sitting talking to each other but here we had the makings of a new generation of stores-sitters.  Before I showered, I rode another 20 miles up the Trace. I was mileage accumulating. It had been a tiring day with going around Jackson so these 20 miles were serene and cool. They seemed to click off as I rode. I was relaxed and back at the campsite after 85 miles on the trace. I showered and went into my tent cocoon. 
We went to sleep or at least attempted to but there was continual noise. Mr. Tattoo was talking loudly to his friends who had shown up after dark. But near me (one site over) was a pop up camper. A monster that screamed sporadically during the night occupied it. Big Ohhhhs and Ahhhss but sounding so fearsome like he had been awakens from a very bad dream. Then there would be silence and I would sleep, I think. But then the sounds would occur. Thus we started off the day all a bit tired and distraught except for Jim who had slept in the van (as usual), he heard nothing.  We had read that there was a breakfast place nearby. It was only a few miles but in reality it was a gas station with a bit of food. Thus my hope of a nice omelet became a soggy sausage and cheese biscuit. I was relieved to see that there was a working phone. I had not been able to connect the night before because I knew they were at the ballpark. The store at Ratliff Ferry closed at 7PM so I was not able to try them. The breakfast was a wash but here it was 7:15 AM (8:15 eastern) so I was able to make a quick call connecting this time. All was well at my home; I would ride a bit more relaxed knowing that.  I dropped Jim and Bob off just above the Choctaw Boundary then I proceed to drive the van to Cole Creek. This whole region was the habitat of the Choctaw Indians. There are various demarcations noting where large trees marked their boundaries. Signs and historical markers discuss the connection with the Choctaws and the whites. It seems that more of the emphasis is on the white men who married the Choctaws or sold them goods. The Choctaw Chief Red Dog was the one who signed the treaty for the removal of the Choctaws from this region.  As I rode the bike back down the Trace, I meet Jim and Bob at the Kosciusko information center. This center had an interesting museum about this Polish man who came to the United States during the Revolutionary war at the age of 30. He came to help construct fortifications being a principle in the building of West Point. The museum host was Mr. Jackson, a 75-year-old Mississippian who had to make immediate comments about Yankees. Which Bob and Jim promptly told him that I was. He said they grew harvested cotton in the summer and Yankees in the winter. He was a jolly fellow who had to show us a century old newspaper with an advertisement for his family?s store. He offered us fresh water and a good trip. He also informed us that this town was the home of Oprah Winfrey but the host was more interested in talking about the Revolutionary War. He had really no comments on Oprah except to give us a brochure on her. I had noticed that the small white-framed church where Oprah attended is shown in the Mississippi Tourism magazine. Mr. Jackson directed us to a large restaurant that served both breakfast and lunch. We arrived as they were between setting-up for lunch but they told us to come in, as we wanted the salad bar. Belinda was our pretty waitress who brought us our drinks and kept us informed about when the next food was ready. We had the cold salad bar and then hot soup. We left there to make our journey farther north. Our next stop was at French Camp were a man had married a local Indian and became famous in the region. He was French. The little town has numerous buildings and exhibits for the public. It seemed to be an active little town making its glory off of the history of the region. We arrived at our campsite at Jeff Busby. It has a gas station with some food. The campsite is nice with a new restroom but no showers. It is free and well kept. We rested for an hour and then took off for our final twenty miles of the trace going to mile marker 214 at Line Creek. The last twenty miles were actually the best of the whole day as it was cool and pleasant. I did 71 miles today. At one point I stopped at a lay-by where a U Haul van was parked with it lights on and the door was open.  I had seen the lights through the trees for several miles. The driver was sitting there with his head back. I walked up to him to see if he was ok. He woke immediately and said he was just tired. I told him his lights were on and he said well God Bless You. His battery would have worn down and he would have been stuck. I had remembered seeing this same man at the Kosciusko museum. He had come up to the museum as we were leaving and I remembered he told Mr. Jackson that he was moving to Tupelo. It is a small world in this little populated state of Mississippi. 
We saw a coyote and a hen turkey in the morning. It is always nice to get on the trail earlier when the animals are out feeding. The air is so fresh and there was the periodic strong smell of pine. Later in the day strong beautiful smells of honeysuckle would pass my path. The smells would transport me as I thought about how many miles I had gone and how sore by butt was. Then I would drift on into some imaginary place as my legs went round and round. These kinds of moments make riding the Trace more enjoyable. This day I did discover that Line Creek was the boundary line between the Chickasaw and Choctaw Indians. It is now just a fact of history considering that all these Indians were removed. As one signpost noted that an Indian council house had once stood there: It is a memory of the Indians history with it only living on in the names of towns or counties in the region. That is all the Indians received for all their centuries of livelihood in the region. Along the Trace there are several turnouts that display Indian history. There are the mounds all along the Trace and The Chickasaw Village in Tupelo. The site has the original village laid out with paths for viewers to follow and read the descriptions of their history. I would say there is an attempt to depict the history and lifestyle of the Indians in these displays. However many of the signs on the turnouts seemed to describe the trials and tribulations of the settlers. The Trace was notoriously difficult to cross. It was built on ridges and attempted to avoid the valleys as much as possible. The settlers had to deal with the mud or the mosquitoes when they traveled. The Natchez Trace Visitor Center is in Tupelo. It is a modest building but well organized with displays and reading material. It reminded me of being in a library when I visited because it was so quiet and subdued. They offer a 12-minute video in their mini-studio. I watched it, as I needed some time to be off of my feet. The video is well done with pictures and history. The narrator is as "country "as they come to give the film its authenticity. Some things I learned was that Abe Lincoln?s father (Thomas) had been to the Trace. And Andrew Jackson honeymooned here. And Meriwether Lewis killed himself on the Trace. It was an important road before the white man but also important afterwards with Natchez at one time claiming to have the most millionaires in the country (that is why there are the beautiful ante-bellum homes there).  While at the visitor?s center, I was also able to copy down a few of the books on the Trace so the reader can consult more authoritative literature than these mere ramblings of a bike rider. I spoke with a couple of people at the visitor?s center. One gentleman who was a local commented on how lucky we were to have this kind of weather in May. In fact many people remarked about it being in the mid-70s in May. I loved it! I had asked him and several other people what the word ?TRACE? meant but no one could tell me. The film said that the whites used the word to describe the Native Americans who traversed the road. It was said that when the Chickasaw and Choctaw Indians traveled they did not leave a ?trace? from their movements. I had thought that perhaps trace had something to do with the type of paths that the buffalo left but my concept was wrong. However the buffalo were the first to make this path. They pounded it. Numerous makers point out where the original Trace was once located but now the road is straighter than the animal paths. The absence of the buffalo on the Trace was noticeable. After leaving the visitor?s center, I stopped at the Pharr mounds. Here I talked with a man who travels the Trace all the time. He loves to drive it as he has family in Natchez but he is from Tennessee. We watched as local farmers harvested big rolls of hay. He talked about hay, tractors, Russians, chickens and the free market economy. He is a cost accountant, farmer and auctioneer. He was most comfortable talking with me, a global sociologist. I think the Trace brings together people to just talk and share as we did.  After leaving there I drove for a short while and then I was meet by Jim and Bob. They reported that no campsites were available so we had to drive up to a bike campsite at Colbert Ferry. This is in Alabama near the Tennessee River. It was a very primitive and secluded campsite that was crawling with poison ivy. I am hopeful that I do not get any although I was very careful. Jim wanted to go out to eat so we took off for Florence and ate in a small town caf that was serving the locals. The food was not good as it was but it was a break from the bike. We then drove to the Winn Dixie to get some more camping food and we were back at Colbert Ferry at nightfall. Then I was off to bed in my tent. 
Then I was scheduled to drive. But before we all left for the Trace, we took a road down to the river where there was a boat ramp. As we rode down there three deer darted in front of Bob and I. The fishermen were putting in their boats and heading out to mid-river. It was fresh and clean here at the dock. The fishermen were efficiently putting in their boats with outboard motors. I stood watching the fishermen put their boats in the river with the Tennessee River Bridge as the backdrop of it. The view was immense. Large boats becoming mere specs in relation to the bridge.  There were numerous geese with goslings strolling in the early morning mist. Geese are a bit too arrogant for me. I will not feed them as so many tourists do. I do believe that is why geese are all over this country: people over feed them and so they stay.  They are not stupid but they can be demanding. I drove the van over to the turn out across the bridge at Lauderdale. Here I parked it and took my bike over the bridge. I meet Jim and Bob about midway. We took pictures of each other and of the river. The boatmen all seemed to congregate in the middle of the river. I wondered who set the idea for which place to begin to fish. I drove back to the bottom of the bridge and then turned around. As I was riding back up I saw a few pennies on the ground. I stopped to pick them up and before I got to the other side of the bridge I had found 10 bridge pennies. I was ecstatic. As a bike rider, I often am speeding by when I see a coin on the ground however when I can I always pick them up. My old Chinese teacher Chiang Laoshi had said that if you do not pick up the pennies then that mean you do not want money. Bad luck I guess. I put ten pennies in my bike pouch. I drove to Steelwater Branch and parked the van. This was 35 miles from leaving Jim and Bob. Just as I was ready to ride another bike rider came in to the turn out. It was Frank and we rode for 15 miles together. He was born in 1944 and said he did not ride much. He had never ridden over 45 miles but today he was going to try to do 50 miles. I told him about what we were doing, not to brag to but let him know that I was riding with guys a lot older than him. We rode together and then I got ahead of him but he later caught up with me. I introduced him to Jim and Bob when we meet and then he was off. I am sure that native Huntsville guy will be riding more in the future. When I told him my name was John then he told me about his family having children named John and he has a son with that name. His name Frank was also a family name. He was named for a cousin who was fighting in World War II and the family feared he would not return so he got the name Frank. Well cousin Frank came back got married and named his first son ?Frank?. And so the story goes.  It is interesting the things that people tell us and the things we tell prefect strangers. It was nice to have a riding partner who was new and had interesting things to say. I never asked his occupation.  However, I encouraged him to ride just a little every now and then because it is fun but no hobby should be a chore. When I was riding back to Sweetwater branch I passed a Tom Turkey running across the road. He took flight and then ran fast off into the woods. A beautiful bird it was. It made me appreciate Benjamin Franklin?s desire to have it as the national bird of the United States. The bird and the smell of honeysuckle made me think of all the history that I had been seen here on the Trace. We camped at Meriwether Lewis campground. The Meriwhether Lewis campsite is excellent. It is a primitive campsite with flush toilets and water. No showers. The camping area is about one and half miles from the Trace. It is a long winding road but it takes you to a very nice camp area. It was Memorial Weekend so there were many tents and campers at the site. This was another primitive campground. I am beginning to feel a bit smelly to myself. I am writing now in the campground. A motorcycle pulling a trailer just came by. The driver was a big man with a big woman sitting behind him holding a big coke and smoking a cigarette. Only in America. I should mention that as we travel the people riding motorcycles are very friendly. They almost always wave to us and of course they are able to pass us easily. The campers and big mobile home travelers are fast and trucks pulling trailers can be fearsome. We did 15 more miles this evening and then we will have 40 miles in the morning.  When I got back to the park (this truly is a park for you could tour and visit without ever knowing there was a camping area), I went to the Meriwether Lewis memorial. It is a simple and beautiful monument to this great man who died at his own hands in a fit of melancholy. The monument and the language written on it moved me. I prayed for understanding as I stood alone with helmeted head in bike clothes in front of this American hero?s ashes. He did not know his own greatness nor do many of us. There I stood alone also in this immense area with a manicured lawn and circular pavement. I stood there with no other human being or the sound of one. I was alone with Meriwether  Lewis. The Trace offers so many of these moments to be alone with history as you silently pass it by. I got back on my bike to ride to the site where the cabin had been where Lewis had died. I went into the small exhibit building to look at the history of the place. My most interesting concern was the guest book. Here were names of people from Australia, New Zealand, England, Illinois, Wisconsin and everywhere. They commented on the serenity of this park, the numerous wild turkeys, the history of the region and the beauty. After leaving there I used the pay phone to call my wife and family. There was so much emotion of the Trace that I could not describe but yet to say that I had to bring them here to experience the complex beauty of the region. 
Well it got us up early. We were packed and leaving at 6:45 AM. I liked getting out on the Trace early. We saw many turkeys that morning. The lay of the land also changed. It was much more rolling hills now. Some places it seemed as if we should be going down when in fact the road was going up. The road was good here in Tennessee. It is asphalt and that makes it so much easier to ride. The rock and gravel are hard for peddling. We continued our tag-driving this morning as we had done. Jim dropped us off so Bob and I began the ride this morning. I soon lagged behind him so I essentially rode alone this last morning. Jim took off after 20 miles so I rode 41 miles to the terminus of the Trace. This day brought out the most bicycle riders we had seen since being on the Trace. We were headed north and the riders were all headed south. It must have been the Nashville crowd out for a Saturday drive. Many of them were looking pretty severe as they rode. It seems like ?through? riders are a bit friendlier and will stop to talk. Mind you, I encountered three of those people in the 400 plus ride on the Trace. When I got to the terminus, there were two women there. We talked about the Trace. One was an elementary school teacher and the other one was a former teacher from Kansas. What was ironic is that one of the teachers is married to a man from a town just near me in southwest Virginia. In fact, she only lives 60 miles from me now. Here she was on the Trace. This meeting of these women confirmed to me that I was meant to be there. We exchanged picture taking. And when Jim and Bob came, we all had stories to tell each other. I rode 423 miles on the Trace. I loved it. I want to return.
