Seven-Day Journal of biking on the Natchez Trace was written by Dr. John Brenner of  Lebanon, Virginia. He is a global sociologist and world traveler. 
Sandy is a physical education teacher, president of the PBA and the youngest of the group.  Ron is retired Army and currently works at HDK Bicycles.  We all depend upon his expertese and equipment.  I am retired Air Force and a teacher of eighth grade physical science and math.  Bob provides SAG support and will attempt to ride 10 to 20 miles/day.  Sandy, Bob and I all ride Trek 520 touring bicycles while Ron relaxes on his Rans recumbent.  He gets all of the attention, especially from ladies at service stations.   
We took eight days to complete the ride some were rainy, some cool and each was enjoyable.  We climbed hills followed rivers, met some wonderful people and learned about Virginia through the historical markers.  The worst part of the trip was when we were packing up to return home. Bob, Ron and Sandy are departing from Newport News for Florence, Oregon on June 7.  I have some commitments and will fly into Eugene on June 12.  The great adventure will start from Florence as soon as the drivers arrive.  We will update the page periodically as Internet access is available.   
The official departure time was 5:20 and we stayed at the RV Park in Mapleton. We had a wonderful quiet evening camping by the river. Dinner was steak at Frank?s Diner and Lounge.  We arrived after the dining room had closed but Frank, the owner and cook, came to our rescue and provided a wonderful meal.     
  
The car needed a new heater core.   The people that serviced it for me went out of their way to get it done and us on our way.  Tomorrow we climb Santium Pass elevation 4817.  We have about 30 miles to the pass then 16 into Sisters, where we will spend the night and do some laundry.  This route is the alternate since McKenzie Pass is closed until July 4.   
      
  
I learned that bikers need to make an addition to Newton?s 1st Law which states, ?For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction?.   An example might be that a biker sits on the bike seat with a certain pressure and the seat exerts an equal but opposite pressure on the posterior.  Bikers might add that the slower one goes the more the seat exerts a pressure on the bikers posterior.  I know this to be true because my posterior became very tired as we climbed at 4 to 6 mph.  It does not get tired going down hill at 35 to 40 mph.   The summer reading program is progressing well. I finished Rise to Rebellion by Jeff Shaara.  I have read all of his books and greatly enjoy the way he brings American History to life.  This novel is about the events leading to our Declaration of Independence.  John Adams, Sam Adams, and Ben Franklin have taken on new life for me.  I also enjoyed Abigail Adams comments about coffee as I also am not a fan of coffee.   The next book is The Physics of Star Trek
This was a pretty easy day.  We started by diving off of Ochoco Pass descending to about 2500 followed by a climb to 4350 to cross Keys Creek Pass, followed by about 34 miles of down hill into Dayville.  We had breakfast in Mitchell at the Little Pine Cafe.  Marjorie the waitress and cook did a great job at the Caf in the center of town.  Ron had the biscuits and gravy; it was enough for 2.  The breakfast burrito is also very good.  Very interesting town.  I really enjoyed the juniper furniture factory at the west end of town.  While at the caf we saw Ralph and Janet, who were on their way to Missoula.  They were also planning to stay in Dayville but at a bed and breakfast. Dayville is a milestone because we stayed at a church on South Fork Rd.  This is our first chance for a shower since Thursday.  This is really a great service for bikers.  We had lunch at the caf in Dayville and went to the John Day Visitor?s Center to learn about fossils.  There we met a teacher from Hampton who was working for the Forrest Service as a part of their summer program.   While Sandy and I were visiting the visitors center, Ron and Bob met the girl who was our server at the caf.  She was unable to get her car to run when she stepped on the gas.  A check under the hood revealed that the key had broken which connected the throttle to the carburetor was broken.  A little bailing wire and she was on the road again.   The John Day National Monument was named after a person who delivered mail and was robbed by the indians.  They took his mail and his cloths         
The descent from Dixie Pass to Austin Junction was a great way to end the day.  We stayed behind the Austin House for no cost.  The food is excellent and the owners, Jeff and Christy Keffer, consented to open early to provide us breakfast.  You might want to try the berry of the forrest pie. I finished The Physics of Star Trek; it was an easy read with many interesting excerpts from the show.  I learned many interesting facts about Light and Space, which can be related in the classroom.  We may even watch Star Trek in class one day.  I am starting In Harm?s Way.  I feel the need for a little excitement.  Bicycling is great for the summer reading program.  I have not watched TV for over a week.  Tomorrow we go to Baker City.   
Once out of the hills the more gradual descent was offset by the head winds and gusts.  Sandy and I stopped by the Sumpter Valley Railroad recreation and enjoyed the park. In town we visited the US Bank where they have a gold nugget weighting 80oz.  This area yeilded more than $10,000,000 prior to the termination of excavation in 1956.  We are still talking and having fun.       
You are following the Powder River.  During the ride I heard fish jump and saw a fisherman land a nice sized one.  The climb over the 3,653 seemed quite steep.  We stopped and visited Halfway, the first Dot.com City; they were preparing for a rodeo on the 22 and 23.  While in Halfway , I bought a puit.A puit looks and  tastes like a pear.  The ride from Halfway to Pine Creek was pretty much down hill, just what we needed as the sun came out and it became quite warm.  We spent the night in a trailer at the in Pine Creek.  Tomorrow we will enter Idaho.  We sure will miss no sales tax.     
  
  
  
We departed Grangeville at 5:38 because Ron got us up early. He was still on Mountain Time.  The Lion?s Club Park is a great place to stay.  We watched little league baseball and girls baseball.  We also were able to listen to kids play basketball and blast music until after 10:00.  Be sure to let the police know that you are there because they will patrol the area more and leave the restrooms unlocked. The departure from Grangeville was a pleasant surprise as we descended about 1300 feet very rapidly almost like a roller coaster.  There was little traffic so we were free to fly.  The downhill continued all of the way to Lowell.  The Luchsa River Valley is a knockout.  White water rapids and steep hills all very green.  Sandy had a deer jump in  front of her today.  There is no place to eat in Stites; the two cafes are closed.  We stopped just west of town and watched the activities of a lumber processing plant.  Along the way we traveled through the Nez Perce Indian Reservation and learned about the battles and movements of the tribe.  The caf in Koskia, where we stopped, served Bison and Yak. We decided that the water in the river looked inviting especially since the temp was pushing 90.  A walk in the river proved that it was quite cold.  I also almost stepped on a snake while taking my dip. There is very little in Lowell, a small store and caf.  These are the only services for 66 miles.  We rode Split Creek Bridge but stayed at the Apgar Campgrounds annotated on the map, 7 miles east of Lowell.  The temp was to be over 90 and tomorrow approaching 100.  It will be an early start to beat the heat. I finished reading I Harm?s Way.  It is a great book if you enjoy history.  It is the tale of the cruiser Indianapolis that was sunk by a Japanese submarine.  The Indianapolis delivered one of the nuclear bombs, which were dropped on Japan to end the war.  The captain of the Indianapolis was court-martialed because his ship was sunk.  The book tells of the courage of the crew left to float in shark infested waters for 4 plus days.  The description of what happens to the body after one drinks seawater is eye opening.  The survivors fought for many years to overturn the injustice, which was done to their captain with little avail.  Then a middle school student in Florida was doing a history project and wrote to a Senator who took an interest in the case and eventually the ship?s captain was cleared of all wrong doing.  You never know what you can do until you try. I will now move back to the area of schoolwork and read Absolute Zero and the Conquest of Cold by Tom Shechtman.  Absolute Zero is always an interesting topic in 8th Physical Science.     
  
    

We stopped for lunch at the Lost Trail Hot Springs Resort and elected to stay due to the persistent rain.  The rain stopped about 3:30 so we started the climb to Lost Trail Pass.  This was a 6-mile climb gaining 1800 feet to an elevation 6995.  The climb was not bad, made easier because Ron had changed my granny gear from 30 to 28 teeth before he left.  Chief Joseph Pass (7241ft) was just a short climb further; there we crossed the continental divide.   The 11-mile down hill was great passing through unspoiled wilderness.  Total mileage toward completion was 55 miles.
We had breakfast in the land of 10 thousand haystacks.  We rode through some very nice scenery and had the chance to see lots of cows, deer, prong horn antelope and hawks.  We saw a hawk catch a prairie dog.  The lodge in the town of Jackson Hot Springs has some beautiful trophy heads on the walls.  In this area Lewis and Clark recorded, ?that a piece of meat about the size of three fingers cooked in 25 minutes.?  We also talked with a mother in the town who indicated that she liked the school system.  The town has a two room school for elementary through middle school.  The two teachers teach all approximately 25 children.  The high school kids are bussed to Dillon, which is about 40 miles away.   The climb after Jackson was rewarded with a descent approaching 50 miles per hour.  We enjoyed a visit to Bannack, which was the capitol of the Montana Territory.  I had a chance to pan for gold and had little luck.  I did get a collection of garnet.  Bannack is famous for Sheriff Henry Plummer, who was hanged by vigilantes.  He was convicted of causing the murders of about 104 people. I completed Absolute by Tom.  It was a history of the quest for cold.  The book went into how the thermometer and the scales we use to day were developed.  I covered much of competition between scientists and discussed superconductors.  There are several points that I will be able to use in my 8th grade physical science class.  For example how 32 degrees was designated the freezing point of water or for that mater how the increments named degrees. The video about Bannack tells how the people survived the winters.  It indicated that when people would awake in the morning that there would be frost on their pillows and bed cloths.
My current book selection is Under Siege by Stephen Coonts.  He is one of my favorite authors and I felt the desire for some adventure after learning about the quest for cold.   
We awoke refreshed after our night in the teepee.  It was 43 degrees for our departure for Cameron.  We had breakfast at the Star Bakery and Caf in Nevada City.  It was a nice rustic place with the restrooms out behind the caf.  We were early enough in Virginia City to be able to take some photos without lots of tourists around.   The climb out of town was about 3.5 miles and good test of our stamina.  The descent was tremendous.  We coasted 10 miles into Ennis.  We passed a couple heading up the hill and had pity on them.  Ennis is a nice town.  We watched horses walk down the main street.  I was especially impressed with the memorial that is being build for service men and women.  The have a wonderful stature of a cowboy with a helmet and paper in one hand and his cowboy hat placed over his heart with the other.  The plaque talks about the paper being his discharge papers or orders to duty.  The hat over the heart is in respect for the flag and those who have died defending it.  The large flag over the monument was being taken down because it had developed a tear due to the wind.  It was being replaced with one in proper shape. We rode in two parts today.  The first part was 45 miles and then 8 more after a rest.  We did not enjoy the head wind but thought that it would be nice not to over 60 miles to West Yellowstone on Wed. This trip is amazing, I have seen so much good and beauty that it is impossible to tell or remember all that transpires.     
  

    
      
  
The ride was through very sparsely populated arid land.  We had about a 1000-ft climb that seemed more difficult because you could see the road just go and go and go.  Along the way I saw a badger.  This is the first that I have ever seen in the wild, actually I thought that they were all in Wisconsin.  We also saw many antelope.   I often retreat into myself while riding sometimes doing math problems or thinking about family and home, today was no different.  While I was on one of these retreats, a RV coming towards us lost a wheel, which came bounding down the highway.  Sandy says that it bounced several feet in the air numerous times but I did not see it.  The wheel and tire eventually went off of the road.  A car tried to flag the guy down and we stopped to show the driver where his wheel had gone but he never returned.   We spent the night in the JS Motel in Jeffrey City.  There is a park that is free to campers but it is very primitive.  There is no water and latrine facilities are marginal.  The small motel has about a dozen rooms and most are filled with bikers such as we.  Jeffrey City is little more than a post office, caf and motel.  The town was founded in 1955 and grew up around a Uranium Mill, which has since closed.  I finished Under Siege by Stephen Coonts.  The book is an easy read very fast paced entertainment.  My next selection is Atom by Lawrence M. Krauss.  This book says that it is "A single Oxygen atom's odyssey from the Big Bang to life on Earth and beyond".  It should be useful in my Physical Science class.  The author also wrote "The Physics of Star Trek".   

    
  
  
  
   Show links to this Hide links to this       July 16, 2002    

The terrain is severely flat.  We were able to make grate time but there is not a lot to see.  We stopped in Ordway and had breakfast.  I had a pancake sandwich.  A pancake sandwich is a ham and cheese omelet with pancakes above and below.  I was expecting something more like pigs in a blanket. I am still on the tour thanks to Joan.  I thank you all for your interest and time.  I am greatful to each and everyone of you. Please check back for photos as I am in the Tribune library and can not use disks with their computers.     
    
    

      
The wind was against us most of the day, blowing from the east at 10 to 15 mph.  Bob drove to Nickerson and rode his bike back toward us.  Along his ride a female biker asked him if he was a member of "3 Old Guys and a Gal".  Denise has been following our trip in the net as she is traveling and updating her site, Boston to Oregon: a cross-country celebration. which may be accessed by clicking on "Whats New?.  We had a nice visit, exchanged photos and admired her bike. She has a Bike Friday which folds and stores in the case she was pulling behind.  Great idea, she can check the luggage rather than paying the airlines to carry a bike.   We stopped in Buhler, Ks for a Coke break although most places have Pepsi in the West and Kansas is no different so far.  We went to a grocery store and sat on the benches outside to enjoy a few minutes off of the bike seat.  The people were the most friendly that we have met during the trip.  Everyone stopped to say hello, welcome to Buhler and wished us well.  Later Sandy and I took a break under a shade tree in a farmer's front yard.  He came out and sat on the ground and visited with us.  He also offered refreshment and restrooms but we just needed a seat break.  All in all today was a great experience in Jayhawk Country. We stayed a the campgrounds in Hesston. I finished "Fatal Voyage" by Kathy Reichs.  It is an interesting book about an airplane grash and how the NTSB investigates the cause and also how bodies are identified.  I especially liked the "Afterward".  It was an easy read. CHECK BACK FOR PHOTOS     
Yesterday we noticed some cornfields seemed to be eaten up.  The leaves were deformed and droopy.  Today we may have found th reason, grasshoppers.  Grasshopers were everywhere, we developed a game to see how many we could run over. Departing Cassoday we took the wrong road and ended up at the campground in El Dorado.  We had planned to stay at the campground but would have ridden the 9 miles off route in the van.  Now we must make up the milage tomorrow.  One consolation, by taking the  wrong road we avoided a 3 to 4 mile section of freshly laid tar.  Bob's bike was a mess after just one mile.  I must check the map more thoroughly next time.
We met two cyclists from the Netherlands.  They were riding from Miami to the West Coast.  One was a teacher.  He indicated that he was able to take the time to do the ride because teachers over 50 get one half day per week off.  He had accrued 3 months off and was using that plus his summer break for the trip.  He indicated that there was an extreme shortage of teachers in the Netherlands.  He attributed this to the fact that students are responsible for their own education and teachers function as coaches. We also saw a new critter crossing the road.  A skunk passed in front of us and we were sure to stop.  No need to make a tough day tougher. We stayed at the City Park in Chanute.   
We are camping again in a city park.  These towns really are great allowing we vagabonds to camp for free and use the pool facilities for showers.  We will be in Missouri tomorrow and expect to start climbing.  Those we have met say it is like a rollercoaster.  Lots of ups and downs.  We must be back in civilization as we have had Wal-Marts in the last three towns.
We awoke at 4:30 to get an early start before the 100 degree heat.  The ride to Golden City was much like Kansas, flat to slightly rolling.  Breakfast at Cooky's Cafe was great.  The place is known for its pies and is a must for bikers passing through.  The polish sausage and blueberry pancakes are a good choice for breakfast.  The prices are very reasonable.  They are not open on Mondays so plan accordingly. The terrain becomes much more rolling with a few pretty steep climbs after Pennsboro.  We are camping once again in the city park next to the pool.  The pool, showers and camping are free to bikers.  I believe this says something for the responsibility of the people who are biking cross-country.  All most every town we have passed through in the last few weeks has open parks and facilities for bikers. Biker Bob needs is quite the schmoozer.  When we get to town he knows everybody and everything.  He even scheduled internet time at the library for us.  The President could use him as an advance man.
We saw a fox this morning.  The night in Ash Grove City Park was not real restful.  A bird in the tree above us was talking all night.     
The ride today was great.  It was overcast with a slight tailwind.  The temperatures were in the 70s at noon.  We even got rained on a very little.  The hills had moderated and we made great time.  We stopped at a gas station/store in Bendavis.  The owner was very friendly and had a book for bikers to sign.  I asked the background on the name of the town.  She indicated that it was named after a stand of Bendavis Apples.  I did not know there was such a thing. We saw and unfortunate sight today.  A dead possum by the road with a live young next to it.   So far Missouri is not as bad as we have been told but the tough part is to come in the next few days.
We spent the night in Houston, Ks at the park.  We slept on the picnic tables under the pavilion rather than put up our tents.  Charlie and Carrie decided to continue on to Summersville, 22 mi, rather than stay in Houston.  They slept in rather than ride in the rain and met us in Eminence.  Carrie may less than her bicycle but she is part goat. She beat me up the hills and she was fully loaded.  They also continued on another 12 miles to Centerville rather than stay in Ellington.  We are spending the night at the park with a repeat of last nights sleeping arrangement.  The library in Ellington is getting internet access on August 1. I saved a turtle today and Sandy and I climbed a fire lookout tower.  That brings the total to four saved turtles.  The lookout station was closed when reached the top.  There is more to this trip than biking. Dan, my mascot, got wet for only the third time.     
The ride was very nice, rolling early and then flat by Missouri standards.  Only one or two major hills to climb. Our turtle saved count is now at 4. We are staying at the city park next to a minor league baseball park.  Hope there is a game tonight. Chance of rain so another night on the picnic tables. PHOTOS TO COME     
We took the levee route out of Chester, which was nice and flat.  It was nice cruising without traffic.  We elected to stop at Neunet and have Bob carry the remaining 15 miles into Murphysboro.  We were hot and tired and not having so we will enjoy the ride tomorrow. We stayed at a motel in town as did Charlie and Carrie. Illinois has been friendly so for but Missouri was a bear to the end. Last night Jessie showed up about dusk and spent the night in the park with us.  Today is his 23rd birthday.  He was going to make it a short day to celebrate.  I game him an MRE with pineapple pound cake for a birthday present.     
A little food improves the outlook and we continued to Tunnel Hill.  The terrain was rolling but not like prior to Goreville.  We returned to Goreville and stayed at the Ferne Clyffe State Park.  The park was very nice and the showers were great.  Unfortunately we did not have a pavilion and tables to sleep on.  We went in town and ate at the Late Bloomer Caf.  The service was great but the steak was not.
        
We planned to stay at the Elementary School Park, which has a nice pavilion with good looking picnic tables.  We were set to spend the remainder of a hot day in the shade of the pavilion.  Earlier however, Bob had been invited to a cook out at the Utica Baptist Church, which was just up the street from the park. Two smelly old guys and a gal showed up with hands out and were met by gracious people offering all types of good food and home made ice cream.  Needless to say, we felt compelled to partake of their offerings.   I'm not sure whether it was our sighs over the air conditioning, our many references to the heat or divine intervention that precipitated the invitation to stay in the sanctuary but we lost no time getting our things from the park and setting up in the church.  We were not alone because the parishioners left the remaining chips, soda, ice cream and sandwich materials for our midnight snack.  Move over Buhler, KS, Utica, Kentucky is now the friendliest place on our trip.  Thank you, Rev Everett Berry and the Utica Baptist Church for your wonderful hospitality.  Jessie showed up later sporting a new haircut.  Good to see the new 23 year old.       
  

We have set a time and place for our arrival home at Yorktown!  At the present time we plan to bike from Jamestown to Yorktown via the Colonial Parkway and arrive in front of the Duke of York Motel at the beach on Water Street between 8:30am and 9:30am on Tuesday, August 13! We would love to have you come and watch us come in or if you would like to bike with us on the last few miles Bob Flynn will meet you in front of the Duke of York Motel by 7:30am on Tuesday morning.  He will be leaving right at 7:30am to ride back toward Williamsburg to meet us on the Colonial Parkway. If you have questions please contact this web site.  Should there be a change it will be posted on the web site. Bike riders need to have helmets.
   While we were in town we visited Ft. Harrodsburg and learned that Daniel Boone lived here for a while.  They have a play nightly near the Fort.  It runs from 8:30PM to 11:00PM, which was to late for tired homewordly motivated cyclists.    The ride to Berea was not as bad as we expected.  Whe had some moderately steep climbs but nothing to stressful.  The cool weather definitely has made life easier on us.  The wind was not a factor today.  The ride out of Berea was very nice mostly downhill but on a very rough road.  It was nice to get off of 21 and onto 594.  Bikers really must be on their toes to keep track of the road changes on the route from Harrodsburg to Berea.    I finished reading "Ghost Soldiers" by Hampton Sides.  This is a very powerful account of the rescue of WWII POWs held in a prison camp in the Philippines.  Many of these prisoners were the last survivors of the Bataan Death March.  The book documents man's inhumanity to man and man's ability to withstand hardship.  I highly recommend the book and I believe that the History Channel has produced a documentary on this rescue.
We also had a chance to do a good deed (Boy Scouts) today.  A car had dropped its front tires into a ditch and we helped push it out. We took the Murphy's Ford Short-cut between 594 and 89.  This three mile single lane road cut off more than 10 miles of the route.  It is flat and I would recommend it.  The route had some pretty long climbs but not as bad as we expected and can in now way compare with Missouri.  Kentucky roads, thus far, follow the rivers; Missouri's seem to just go over the hills. We are spending the night at the Booneville Presbyterian Church. 
The first 23 miles to Chavies was tough.  We had some long climbs with several false summits.  Many times we thought we were at the top of the hill only to start climbing again.  We stopped for some gas station chicken in Chavies and met an interesting fellow.  He had recently returned from a trip to the Eastern Shore.  He had taken a 70+ year-old townsman to see the ocean.  The gas station had his picture at the ocean displayed.  It may have been his first time outside of Kentucky.  Chavies to highway 80 was flat to rolling but the climbs became pronounced on highway 80.  We exited 80 at Dwarf and followed the river into Hindman and on toward Pippa Passes.  The route was flat and very enjoyable.  Dogs were not a problem today, they seem to respond to a kind confident voice.     
The first 15 miles were along a drainage pattern and were flat and fast.  We had a pretty long and moderately steep climb in the area of Melvin.  The tough climb came prior to Lookout.  The road is very narrow with many washouts on the side.  The downhill is also a challenge because the road is very rough and with steep turns.  Sandy had a blow out going down this part of the route.  There is another moderate climb between Hiller and Ashcamp then the route resumes following the drainage and is flat.  The eight miles from Elkhorn City to Breaks Interstate Park was much easier than the climb up from the Virginia side.  We were really sweating the climb much as we had the climb up Hoosier Pass and were pleasantly surprised by both.    Dogs were not a problem.  We found if you talk to them they are much less threatening.  One dog was especially friendly, bouncing and playing around the bikes.  Sandy gave it some potato chips, which he ate with glee.  There were some dogs up on a hill that became interested in us but by the time they made it to the road we were long gone.  They just ran around chasing their tails. It only rained two days during the entire tour but today just as we arrived at Breaks Interstate Park it started to sprinkle and then pour.  We finished just in time, 4:13 in the afternoon.     

I found my cycling partner for this trip, Tom Jolliffe from within the ranks of the same cycle club that I ride with: the London Cycle Club. Tom would be in France with his wife for three weeks before flying out to meet me in Frankfurt for the start of our journey. We both had new touring bikes that we had purchased in the last year, however we decided to take our "trusty" old steeds instead. Mine was a four year old Cannondale H-400 hybrid, while Tom's was a five year old Raleigh hybrid. The real reason we took these bikes is that we wouldn't cry as much if the airlines damaged them in transit.  I like to try to cycle from beginning to end, with very little reliance on local sources of transport. While researching this trip, I tried to find out if it was possible to cycle directly from the Frankfurt Airport (one of the busiest in Europe) without being impaled on somebody's Volkswagen Jetta. Some of the people I corresponded with thought I was crazy: "German drivers are too aggressive," or, "... there are nothing but autobahns around the Frankfurt Airport." However, I had made up my mind to find out if this was true. I finally found a web site put up by an American cyclist, Boyd Simmons, who had done almost the same trip I had planned, only a year earlier. And he had cycled directly from the airport. This gave me a great deal of encouragement. However, Mr. Simmons did not include a whole lot of detail, so my quest continued. I came upon another web site specifically set up with information of cycle touring around the world, with emphasis on taking your bike on airplanes, etc. Through this web site I got in touch with David Alexander, a teacher from Alberta, Canada who had also cycled from Frankfurt Airport. With his detailed instructions, we found our way out of the airport with exceptional ease. His instructions are paraphrased in a link on Day 1 of our trip.  During our eight day cycle trip we discovered a few things:  1.First, pack light! I had intended to take only enough "stuff" to fill my two rear panniers, leaving the front ones empty for various purchases along the way. Unfortunately, I got a bit carried away, and filled them all to capacity. I found there were several items I really didn't need. For example - rain gear. I took rain pants as well as booties for my shoes. What I found is that I sweat more than the rain made me wet. So leave the rain pants and booties at home. Besides, after 8 hours in the rain, not much stays dry anyhow. I did see many locals riding with ponchos - these would seem to be cooler, and might not be a bad idea. The camera I took was my old reliable Canon A-1 - a great camera, but it weighs in at probably 3 pounds ... about 5% of the total weight of my panniers. Get smart, go out and buy a portable camera, or get a disposable one.  2.Put a green garbage bag inside each of your panniers, then put all of your carried items inside them. Pack your clothes in large freezer bags (Ziploc), then put the bags inside the garbage bag. I did this and even after riding through eight hours of rain, and plunging through some flooded cycle paths over 9" deep, everything remained perfectly dry.  3.Do install fenders on your bike! These things will not only prevent you from looking like a skunk with a big black stripe down your back, but if you ride in a group, your partner who is chasing your tail will thank you immensely. Unless, of course, he likes eating mud! In case you are wondering, no we didn't have them. And yes, we ate a lot of muck!  4.Interesting books for the trip: I like to have a bit of background about the country I am travelling in before I set out. I also like to have a look at the maps I need before I depart so I can plan the trip, and have an idea on how long the trip will take before I leave. That being said, I would recommend cycling shorter distances in Germany on a daily basis. Tom and I had several days over 100 km. long. While we enjoyed the cycling part, and relished the spectacular scenery enroute, we failed to really enjoy the towns we stayed in. Sometimes we found that we arrived at 6:00 p.m., ate dinner, had a few beers, and went to bed, only to do it all over again the next day. Remember, the Romantic Road is very historical in nature, and includes many sites that involve more than just a cursory glance. Take your time!!! Here are some of the books we used for this trip, and can recommend:  Europe by Bike -18 Tours Geared for Discovery, Karen and Terry Whitehill. Published by the Mountaineers, 1001 SW KlickitatWay, Suite 201, Seattle, Washington 98134.  Germany The Rough Guide, Gorden McLachlan. Published by Rough Guides Limited, 1 Mercer Street, London, U.K. WC2H 9QJ. Rough Guides on the Internet: http://www.roughguides.com  Maps: It was hard to find cycling specific maps for Germany prior to leaving Canada. I found that the Michelin series road maps were satisfactory for the most part, however they missed many of the cycle routes that cycle maps did include. Once in Germany almost without exception, every bookstore carried cycle touring maps. We even found them in gas stations as well as the Frankfurt Airport. They were very expensive, at about 11 DM for a map that would cover roughly two days worth of cycling, but they were well worth it.
By the time I arrived at the departure gate for the Frankfurt flight, there were no people left in the lounge. An agent asked me my last name, and proceeded to give me a boarding pass for the business class section. This doesn't happen on a frequent basis for us airline employees, so naturally I was rather elated! Then he spied my bike and box containing my panniers. He indicated that these would not arrive with me. Since it was senseless to start a bike journey without my bike, I elected to wait and take the later flight to Zurich. Here, I would transfer on to a Lufthansa flight to Frankfurt, arriving well ahead of my cycling partner, Tom Jolliffe, who would be arriving from Toulouse, France.  I carted my bicycle and other belongings down to the Zurich departure gate. I took the bike to the great personnel at special services, where I was told I would have to pay $65 to have the bike shipped. A new Air Canada policy (apparently valid even on overseas flights) dictates bicycles can no longer be considered as one piece of luggage. Through a bit of clever negotiating, the agent agreed to turn a blind eye.  Unfortunately, the Zurich flight started out late - once again Air Traffic Control. After we pushed off the gate, nearly an hour behind schedule, it turned very dark and ominous outside the aircraft. Due to thunderstorms in the Toronto area, the flight was delayed a further hour before it got airborne. I knew now that my connection to Frankfurt would be missed.  The rest of the flight was pretty much uneventful, however, I do not necessarily recommend the exit row on a long flight.  After many hours in the air at sub zero temperatures, the emergency exit doors become "cold soaked."  And sitting next to one for several hours can get pretty darn cold, even with two blankets. We arrived in Zurich about ten minutes after my flight was to leave for Frankfurt. I waited for the next flight, which would still put me into Frankfurt at the same time as Tom. For the honour of taking my bike with me I was to be charged 50 Swiss Francs, but because I was an airline employee, they reduced the fee by 50%. Some comments about the Zurich airport: there seems to be smoking everywhere, even though they boast over the P.A. system the Zurich is non-smoking airport. The washrooms were excellent, even the stalls are like walking into your own private room, with a full door to close behind you - and yes, they even have ashtrays in the stalls of this "non-smoking" airport. You can probably guess by my sarcasm that I am a non-smoker.  This flight was, yes, you guessed it ? late again. I arrived in Frankfurt at about 3:45 p.m. Tom's flight was also delayed, and I had time to set up my bike prior to meeting him. Tom showed up at approximately 4:35 p.m.  We put Tom's bike together and proceeded to cycle out of the airport using some excellent instructions given by David Alexander from Edmonton, Alberta. The time was 6:00 p.m., and the temperature was about 17C, in very light drizzle. After a "disorientation" tour of the town of Zeppelinheim, we finally made our way out of town via a "yellow" class road leading south - Highway B-44. We had actually gone by this road at least twice already, and thought it might lead to the "autobahn," as we were not yet familiar with the German road signs. We decided to investigate it on out third try because it was getting late, and the rain was also making us miserable at this point. After riding down the entrance ramp, I saw other cyclists using the road, so I knew it was O.K. for us. This night we stayed in the small town of Morfelden, about 20 km south of the Frankfurt Airport. The first two inns were booked, and we finally settled on what was the last room in town at Gasthaus Luleys. We had cycled 30.8 km in 1 hour and 53 minutes, for an average speed of 16.2 kph. Not bad when you consider the number of times we had to look at the map.  I now highly recommend a map holder that attaches to the handlebars.  That alone will save you several hours on a trip like this.  The 40 DM apiece for our accommodations included breakfast in the morning which included coffee, boiled eggs, and various breads and rolls with meat, cheese, and various jams. We also ate dinner here for 20 DM. I had wiener snitzel, french fries, vegetables, salad and a beer for only 20 DM (about $16 CAN).   
After Dieburg, we took Road 45 to Hochst. Hills entered the picture at this point, and continued the rest of the way to Eberbach. After each hill, however, there was always a descent. The hills did not seem very steep, but they were very long.  We ate lunch in the town of Michelstadt at an outdoor cafe opposite an old timbered building with a clock. After a little window shopping, and the purchase of a few postcards (which I am still looking for), we continued on our way.  Our maximum speed for the day (on the downhill of course) was 58.5 kph. We completed a total of 93 km in 4 hours and 31 minutes, for an average speed of 20.6 kph.  We spent the night in Eberbach, a town right on the River in another guesthouse: Gasthaus Gruner Baum.  Again, the cost was a reasonable 40 DM, and we even had a "garage" for our bikes!  Actually, they spent the evening in the well stocked wine cellar just outside the Gruner Baum.       
Today we had rain almost all day. As the day wore on, the rain seemed to increase in intensity. There were many hills on this day as well. In Bad Wimpfen, we decided not to go all the way into town because of the hills, and because this would be a very long day cycling as it was (yeah, I know - a feeble excuse). We stopped at the rail station - about halfway up the steep incline into the altstadt. Here, Tom ordered six of something neither one of us could make heads nor tails of, but we thought it sounded as if they were something like sausage. About ten minutes later the waitress arrived with Tom's order of six ? snails! Escargot is spelt "schnecken" in Deutsche!  Just after leaving Bad Wimpfen, and crossing the Neckar River, we encountered a long, steep hill that ended at the junction of a road near a churchyard. I made it up the hill first, and while waiting for Tom, started a conversation with a 62 year old German gentleman with a one-speed coaster bicycle. He commented on how he would love to travel to North America. After Tom made it up the hill, this man directed us to a cycle path that would take us all the way to Mockmuhl without the traffic of the main road. And it was paved most of the way! He would even lead us to the entrance. I wished we had met this cyclist prior to the long hill, as he lead us down once again. His rear tire wobbled visibly from side to side as we made the descent at speeds in excess of 45 kph. The cycle path lasted 24 km., following the twisting path of the Jagst River valley.  In Mockmuhl, we refueled on donut like pastries at a local bakery. The rest of the day was uneventful for the most part - just more rain! We got slightly "lost" in Dorzbach, where we left the Jagst River valley and headed up a long hill northeast towards Bad Mergentheim. The guidebook indicated the uphill would last about 8 km, followed by a long 6 km descent into the city. I did not seem to find it that long - perhaps 5 km, followed by a 6 km descent. In any event, it was nice to coast into town. Our total mileage for the day: 133.8 km in 6 hours, 53 minutes, for an average speed of 19.4 kph.  Bad Mergentheim was the birthplace of my German friend, Birgit (with whom we would be staying at the end of our trip).  She had asked if I could take a photograph of the hospital where she was born, as she had not been back "home" for many years.  Unfortunately, it was raining fairly hard, so we bypassed this opportunity without too much thought.  The first pension we checked out on the road into town, just after the hospital was full. We rode downtown where we were given directions to a local hotel. This hotel quoted us 148 DM for the night - a marked increase over what we were used to paying.  Sensing we did not want to spend quite that much money, the receptionist called around to a couple other hotels in the area, then redirected us to the Hotel Wolfgang.  This hotel was priced at 100 DM for the two of us, which included "fruhstuck," or breakfast. Hotel Wolfgang was very nice with big rooms. They also allowed us to store our bikes in their garage for the night.  For dinner we wandered down to the markplatz where there appeared to be a blood donor clinic in progress, with entertainment provided, as well as food and refreshments.  I considered giving a pint, but I wasn't quite sure how well I would perform on the bike for the next week.  I passed on this opportunity.  We found a very nice Greek restaurant right next door to all the festivities.  After the standard menu items, we once again indulged in that great German pastime - drinking beer.  Tom had pils, while I once again had weisenbier.     
We ate lunch in the medieval town of Rothenburg. Rothenburg is probably one of the most famous towns in Germany. Once again, in keeping with Germany tradition (as perceived by us cyclists), this town was found perched high above (well, several hundred feet, anyway) the River Tauber. Rothenburg initially had very prosperous times back in the medieval period. It was declared a Free Imperial City, but as it found itself cut off from major trading routes, it vegetated into a very provincial market town. In 1945 the town suffered some damage from American bombing, but due to the efforts of an American civilian, working with the US army, the town was spared further bombing. Rothenburg is one of the best preserved medieval cities in the world. Even today, its conservation policies are the strictest in Germany. Even McDonalds is obliged to carry on this tradition by displaying only a small steel sign and flag outside its entrance by the marktplatz. After a quick tour of the town, we once again departed for Dinkelsbuhl at 2:45 p.m. We arrived in Dinkelsbuhl at 5:45 p.m. As a festival was on - the beginning of the Whit Sunday and Whit Monday holiday, there were no rooms to be found. After calling about 12 different hotels, pensions, and zimmer freis, without success, we turned to plan "B." As Tom's knee was starting to bother him due to the constant hill climbing of the day, and because a cycle ride to the next "major town" would put us in the dark, we would take a bus to Nordlingen, about 30 km away and stay there for the night.  The bus ride took about 30 minutes, and cost 7.90 DM apiece, including our bikes. There were very few rooms to be had here as well. We were lucky enough to have the one hotel owner call about five different hotels before securing as a room close to the local McDonalds, and right next door to the Judenherberge (youth hostel). This was the Hotel Schutzenhof, just outside the city walls, and a relative bargain at 59 DM apiece, including breakfast. We were not about to argue. Today were very happy, as we did not get any rain, just twenty minutes of very light drizzle. Total mileage for the day: 103.5 km, in hours, minutes, for an average speed of 17 kph.  Nordlingen is a also a medieval city with a surviving wall surrounding it. During medieval times this wall provided protection for those living within. Nordlingen is built in the crater of a meteorite that crashed to earth many years ago. The Apollo astronauts trained here in Nordlingen. As a mark of their gratitude, they presented the city with a chunk of moonrock which is on display in one of the local museums. The fact that they are extremely proud of this chunk of rock was illustrated at dinner, when one of the local elders sat with us during our meal. His English was very limited, but was much more extensive than our German, but I think he mentioned that moon rock no less than 12 times over the course of two weisenbier.  I think in some ways that Nordlingen proves to be a better example of a medieval city than Rothenberg. For one thing, it has fewer tourists, so there are fewer people to interfere with you being a tourist. Because there are fewer people milling about, many of the ancient buildings are also easier to preserve.
Tom made it about 3 km before his knee started to give out. We went our "separate" ways at this point - him via train, me via bike. We agreed to meet in Dachau sometime on Wednesday, and stay in touch via my friends who lived near Munich. The first 16 km of the ride were very easy over flat terrain, and with a light wind. The weather was sunny now, with a temperature about 16 to 18 degrees. The hills started at this point, with the usual up, followed by down. Harburg, about 2/3 of the way along was a castle high in the hills. There were a few detours in town because of "hoch wasser" once again, and also because of a local church ceremony, so I had to walk the bike part of the way through town, and ride around some water donated by the Wornitz River. The bike path up to this point was very good, and paved the whole way. Afterwards, it turned into a muddy tractor path which I followed only because of other bike tire marks heading in the same direction. After two km of heavy slugging, mostly uphill, I turned around and headed for the road. There was one more hill to climb before town, followed by a 4 km descent. Donauworth initially seemed very big and spread out versus the usual compact German towns we were used to. I cycled through the "downtown" area and the square (marktplatz) looking for zimmer frei or pensions, but could find none. So, I went to the bahnhof (train station) in search of a tourist information booth. Here I obtained a brochure listing the various accommodations for the town. I went outside to peruse it. While sitting down, I sensed someone looking over my shoulder. As I turned around, there stood Tom Jolliffe in all his glory! He had taken the train to Donauworth instead of Munich, and was willing to give it another shot.  We tried one pension, but it was full. We finally settled on the Gasthof Feurle - Ragusa. After a shower, we settled in a bit, then went for a beer, and a town tour. The Danube was very high, and many locals were out to view it. We ate dinner at the Gasthof. It was very good, and included a generous portion of salmon, broccoli, potatoes, salad and beer for 26 DM.  Total distance for the day: 38 km in 2 hours, 10 minutes, for an average speed of 17.5 kph.     
We walked down to the Marktplatz for dinner, Tom had stew and scalloped potatoes for dinner (20 DM), while I munched on a feast of sausage and sauerkraut (15 DM). We ate out in the open under beautiful sunshine. Oh - the wine with dinner was a nice touch. We also had a beer a bit later at a streetside caf. Total mileage for the day: 65.2 km in 3 hours, 22 minutes, for an average speed of 19.5 kph. Maximum speed today: 43.5 kph.       
The scenery today was mostly gently rolling countryside. Tom compared it appropriately enough to the countryside one would see around Guelph. For every hill going up, there was always a hill going down the other side, but these hills were not terribly steep. Along the way we passed a young fellow in a wheelchair modified into a bike that he pedaled with his arms. He seemed to keep up a respectable pace as well, even his seat looked more comfortable than ours?.  We found the information bureau just opposite the Rathaus in the altstadt area. They were very helpful (as always), and with their various brochures, we were able to find accommodations on one of the main streets - Mittermayer Strasse 15. The gasthaus was called, appropriately enough "Gasthaus - Fremdenzimmer Mittermayerhof. The price was once again 50 DM apiece.  After lunch at the hotel - pork roast with a big dumpling, salad, and of course, beer, we headed out for the concentration camp at the east end of town. We spent a few hours here touring and reflecting.  When we got back to the hotel, we walked downtown and toured the outside of the schloss Dachau (closed at this time). From the castle we had a reasonably good view of nearby Munich. Afterwards, we had a beer at an outdoor restaurant right beside the Rathaus. The beer ended up costing 27 DM apiece, because we also ordered soup (cream of asparagus - spargel) and salad. Then, the waiter talked us into delicious strudels to have with our cappuccinos.  We did a little window shopping, but decided the large screen TV (about 30") was too expensive, at 2600 DM. I used the bank machine here in Dachau (Deutches Bank) to withdraw another 400 DM for the remainder of my trip.  During the evening, some violent thunderstorms rolled through, but they did not last very long at all.         
Langenback is a small village (once again on the side of a shallow hill) just 10 kilometres east of Freising. We found ourselves maintaining speeds of 30 kilometres per hour as we approached the town. We found a phone booth down by the post office (next door to an excellent local bakery) in Langenbach and called Birgit. A few minutes later she was there to meet us with her three year old son, Benedict and take us to her apartment on Birkenstrasse (Birch Street).  The total for the day: 48.0 km in 2 hours, 4 minutes, for an average speed of 23.3 kph. Our cycling trip was now over. We had completed a total of 559.2 km in 29 hours and 17 minutes of cycling, for an average speed of 19.1 kph.       
Support freedom Many people decide to do long distance tours on bicycles, but it appears that not too many of them do it on three-wheeled bikes. When we decided to do this trip, we had just purhased new Novarro Touring bikes from REI.  Unfortunately, we were never able to get past the "wall" of uncomfortable bicycle-butt.  Added to this were shoulder, wrist, and arm pains that are associated with many long hours in the saddle. We had long considered recumbent bicycles for touring, but really had no experience with them.  We made a trip to a recumbent bike shop and test-rode several different models, both long wheel-based and short, over-seat steering and under.  The problem with recumbents is that since the center of gravity is different than on a regular wedgie, it takes some getting used to. We spoke to one of the workers at the shop about the kind of riding we were planning on doing, and he suggested that we try the Greenspeed Trikes.  We laughed!  They looked like wheel chairs to us.  He finally convinced us to at least give them a test-ride, but I assured him that we CERTAINLY were not going to buy one. After the test ride, we were sold.  The rest is history. Trikes are MUCH more comfortable to ride than upright bikes are.  The only drawback is that since you are pretty much lying down to ride, you can't stand on the pedals for power; it all comes from your legs, and that takes some conditioning.  Other than that, they're great!    If you take the time to read about the trip, please take the time to sign the Guestbook.  Thanks!
    We got everything loaded into the RV and Bill's sister Terri's Honda Passport and headed over to Mollie's Restaurant for the "Big Family Breakfast" of eggs, toast, fried potatoes, pancakes and bacon. It was enough for the 5 of us to have breakfast for 2 days! We had them package up the leftovers and we put it in the RV fridge. We were on the road by 9:30, with Bill's brother-in-law Frank driving our RV with Bill, Katie and Sammie aboard. Jan was with Terri in the Passport. The traffic through the LA area was heavy, but not stopped. We missed the turnoff for Malibu Creek State Park and ended up at Leo Carrillo State Beach Campground. We had planned on having Malibu as our starting point, as we had already done a lot of the route south of Malibu on day trips.  Also, since we were planning on tenting as much as possible, and tent spaces south of Malibu are few and far between, we felt this would be a good starting point.  It was packed, with no more RV parking, but the hiker/biker camp was open. Since we all wanted to camp together, we checked for the next available facility with open sites. It just happened to be Point Mugu Naval Air Weapons Station Recreation Area. It was right on the water. Katie and Frank headed to the beach, while Bill and Jan put the trikes together.  Terri and Jan picked up some drinks from the commissary, and Terri got lunch together for us all. And, of course, everyone had their turn on the trikes. Katie put over 9 miles on Bill's! Her legs didn't even bother her.     Our tent site was right across the street from the RV. Katie joined us in the tent when we went to bed. We were all really tired. But, before bedtime we had a big fire on the beach and ate 'smores while Frank played his guitar. It was fun. Right before going to bed, we noticed a bunch of sea lions had moved into the lagoon across from our tent site. It was pretty neat, but they made noise all night long.        

Don't miss the RV park life yet. We are still in campgrounds so it is still sort of the same. Just not RV Parks. Today we got to ride on the highway! Traffic whizzing by at 70MPH....Jan was a little frightened. We had a really wide shoulder though and most of the cars moved over anyway. Not everyone is an idiot I guess. As we were riding along the side of some big RVs one jerk in this huge bus RV blasted his air horn when we went by. We jumped, and blasted him right back with our air horns....surprised him!! 
     The camp host told her he would contact someone from the park staff.  The park superindentent came by a few minutes later and told us we would need to move, for our own safety. Since it was very early in the season, they weren't using the hiker/biker sites yet.  He told us that the restrooms were closed because some vandals had gotten in, and being cold, had started a fire in one of the trash cans.  That, in turn, set the whole restroom on fire.  He helped us move with his truck.  We ended up camped across the street from the family with the bus.  They are the Hanc's, Dave and Donna, and their kids, Jocelyn and Ryan.  Dave is a school teacher in Maine, and they are traveling around the country visiting other school districts, searching for ideas to take back to Maine.  They are going up to Alaska when they leave California. Dave is absolutely one of the most laid-back guys we have ever met.  He has the unique ability to find something positive in even the worst situations.  It's impossible to be around him and not be cheered up.  The name "HMMMM Bus" is derived from the humming sound you make when meditating.      After we got set-up the 2nd time we had dinner with them. We had minestrone soup and corn muffins with soda. It was delicious. We sat by a campfire afterwards. We finally got to bed at 9:30. We were tired.        
     One young girl painted a poem.  Jan painted a picture of our trike on the side of the HMMM Bus. It turned out pretty good!"    

  Travelled 13.66 miles to Gaviota State Park from El Capitan.  We had a 730 ft altitude gain.  The torque lever seems to have found the spot it likes, and has stopped moving.  Jan's bike seems to be working well enough with the broken parts disconnected.  We have tools and parts coming from Australia to Jean Anderson's house (a fellow Greenspeed Triker) in San Luis Obispo.  After getting our tent set up we spent quite some time swapping stories with the camp hosts, Jack and Jean Della Santa.  They are very nice.  They let us use their phone to check our e-mail and use their computer to update our website.  It was wonderful.  We also found that this campground has water and showers.  The ACA map said that they had neither, and we lugged quited a bit of water with us that we didn't need to!  The weather is wonderful.          

A little about Lompoc:  Confined to the coastal meadows by the elements, their diet and the grizzly bear, the first settlers of the area were simple food gatherers.  In the 1770's the Spanish discovered these lands inhabited by the Chumash Indians. Their diet consisted of mussels, abalone, crabs, lobsters, berries, sage and acorns.  They later moved inland where they subsisted on game and fish, as well as plant materials.  Like other California Indians, they lived in small, clan-like "triblets" with well-defined territories and separate dialects. The first European land expedition into California was lead by Gaspar de Portola, along with his contingent of Spanish and colonial soldiers, in 1769.  On December 8, 1787, the Franciscan Monk, Francis Lasuen, began the La Purisima Mission which began the Spanish and Mexican occupation of the valley, and the decline of the Chumash.  The Indians were baptized, offered beads, cloth and food and readily became part of the mission life, which they were forbidden to leave.  By 1804, 1,520 Chumash had been "converted" within La Purisima Mission.  By 1846, only 160 were left due to many diseases brought by the white man.      Show links to this Hide links to this      Colonel W.W. Hollister was one of the valley's first Anglo-American owners.  He headed west from Ohio with 200 head of cattle and later 900 sheep to build a fortune in 1851.  He became partners with Thomas and Albert Dibblee and acquired a chain of contiguous Mexican land grants, including Lompoc.  Here, vast herds of his sheep grazed before he sold part of his holdings to the Lompoc Valley Land Company in 1874.  The lands consisted of the Lompoc Rancho and the Mission Vieja de la Purisima Rancho.  The town was laid out nine miles from the coast, near the center of the Lompoc Valley.  The lots sold well and the town flourished. The Chumash Indians called the area "Lum Poc", meaning little lake or laguna, for a now vanished lake.  The Spanish called it "lumpoco" accenting the second syllable.  By the time settlers began to arrive in the valley, the name had been Anglicized.  The founding fathers of Lompoc modeled their city after Vineland, N.J., a thriving termperance community, and proposed that it be called New Vineland.  However, the citizens of Lompoc opposed the idea.  Another try in 1939 to change the name to La Purisima was also defeated. 1875 and 1876 were good years.  One of the worst droughts on record hit in 1877, however.  Sheep and cattle died and people were in need of food.  A diptheria epidemic broke out in 1878.  The valley recovered to become one of the most versatile agricultural locations in California, yielding vegetable, field, seed, nursery, livestock, fruit and nut crops.  In the late 1800's, rows of blue gum and cypress trees were planted to raise the temperature of the fields through windbreaks, which could increase the ground temperature by as much as 10 degrees.  Lompoc has now become known as the "Flower Seed Capital of the World". (Adapted from Lompoc: The first 100 years, published by the Lompoc Centennial Committee). We headed out of town towards Vandenburg AFB around 1 p.m.  It was a long trip because it was up and down hills and it was really windy. We have been out on our trip one week now.  Jan added up our found money for the past week and it added up to $3.16! Arrived at the Vandenburg Famcamp at around 4:30 p.m.  Got our tent set-up and then hung out in the nice camper's lounge.  We were able to watch TV even!  We were beat! Another 20 mile day up hill and into the wind. Just before dark we both felt the need to take a walk to Burger King.  We arrived there at 7:30 p.m. and it was already closed! We couldn't believe it, but remember, we are on a military base and it was Sunday.  The shoppette was right there so we went in there instead and picked up the needed snacks and sodas. It was a 3 mile walk round trip. Our legs were already getting stiff and the walk did us good.  It is quite cool and windy this evening.      Show links to this Hide links to this

We visited Bubble Gum Alley, located between the businesses at 733 and 737 Higuera Street.  Much to the delight of gum chewers everywhere, this sticky landmark has taken gum from under school desks and restaurant tables to its rightful place... on the wall.  Sometime in the late 1950s or early 1960s--the exact date is not yet a part of the history books--a bubble gum-chewing kid (or perhaps an adult?) stuck a wad of the pink goo on a solitary brick.  Slowly, the idea caught on and today the narrow 50-yard-long corridor is decorated with relief designs in a rainbow of colors.  There are flowers and initials, greetings and hearts, faces and dates.  One thing there isn't is obscenity.  Gum chewers, it seems, are above such things.  This is art, after all, not street gang graffiti.  Although some public officials have called the landmark "tacky and vulgar," no one has had the gumption to scrape the bricks clean--or to issue an ordinance against artists with chewing gum-laden palettes. After we got set up we went on a short hike to see the Lime Kilns.  The manufacture of lime at this location dates back to the early 1880's when Rockland Lime and Lumber Company began lime kiln operations.  Four stone and steel furnances were built at the base of a large, natural landslide that eroded from a limestone deposit.  These kilns were loaded with the stone, which had been sledded to the site, with large quantities of cordwood to maintain a fire.  This process, called "firing", slaked, or purified, the limestone, which was then packed into barrels made on the spot and hauled in wagons nearly a mile down the canyon.  At Rockland Landing a steam engine powered cable loaded the barrels aboard shipping vessels for a trip up the coast where lime was used as cement and in other commercial products.  The trail we walked roughly follows the old wagon trail, and you can see the massive furnaces and parts of the old roadbed once used to move the lime to Rockland Landing.  The trail to the historic lime kilns meanders along cascading Limekiln and West Fork creeks and through a small grove of redwoods.  We are 56 miles south of Carmel, CA.  The land from Limekiln Creek to Cone Peak presents the steepest coastal slope in the continental United States.  The redwoods growing here are some of the oldest and largest in Monterey County.  This area is where you first start seeing California's magnificent Coast Redwood, which is the world's largest known tree and one of the world's oldest trees.  Average mature trees, several hundred years old, stand from 200 to 240 feet tall and have diameters of 10 to 15 feet.  In the most favorable parts of their range, Coast Redwoods can live more than two thousand years.  Redwoods are named for the color of their bark and heartwood.  The high tannin content of the wood gives the trees remarkable resistance to fungus diseases and insect infestations, and periodic fires which occur naturally.  It is generally believed thad the last ice age limited the Coast Redwoods to their present range, a narrow 450-mile strip along the Pacific Ocean from central CA to southern OR.  There is also a 300-foot beach area here and is one of the few on this coast which is readily accessible.  After our hike we had supper and visited the beach one more time at sunset.  Then we hit the sack - we were tired.

A little bit of history about Pigeon Point Lighthouse to start today off:  On January 28, 1853, the clipper ship "Carrier Pigeon" set sail from Boston for San Francisco, carrying 1300 tons of cargo.  On June 6, 1853, she ran aground near what was then called La Punta de la Ballena (Whale Point).  Although the ship was wrecked, the crew was saved.  Before long, the point of land was renamed Pigeon Point in memory of the "Carrier Pigeon".  The lighthouse stands 115' tall and sits on a 35' cliff and has been guiding mariners since 1872.  It was constructed following a string of shipwrecks.  Constructed of unreinforced brick, the lighthouse is the 2nd tallest on the West Coast.  The original first-order Fresnel Lens (the largest size) is still in place in the tower.  Invented by the frenchman, Augustine Fresnel, the lens consists of 1,008 glass prisms enclosing a light source.  The prisms concentrate the light, allowing a low-intensity light source to project a strong beam over a great distance.  Initially, the lamp inside the lens was a series of concentric wicks fueled by lard oil, giving off a light measured between 60,000 and 80,000 candelpower.  Later a kerosene lamp was substituted, and then a lamp which used vaporized oil, providing yet a stronger beam.  Finally, in the late 1920's, Pigeon Point switched to a 1,000 watt electric bulb, increasing the light to 680,000 candelpower (visible for more than 20 miles).  Each lighthouse has its own distinctive light pattern which makes it identifiable to passing ships.    We had a nice ride today. We took a bypass route that was beautiful.  We found some wonderful freshly baked bread at the Arcangeli Grocery Company in Pescadero as we were told by Richard and Alberta, our hosts back in Aptos.  We got sandwiches for lunch, too. Some information about Samuel P. Taylor State Park:   Samuel P. Taylor, scouting for a supply of lumber for his lumber interests, entered this area on horseback over Indian trails in 1854.  He purchased the 100 acres that is now the center of the park from Radael Garcia.  In 1856 he constructed the first papermill on the Pacific coast.  Almost a century later, in 1946, this area was included in the formation of this State Park. This area was one of the first in the United State to offer camping as a recreational pursuit.

   Following that visit, officials of the fur company made plans to establish settlements in California as sources of food for its trading posts in Alaska.  Fort Ross, once located approximately 10 miles south of Stewarts Point, was founded by the fur company, and was the chief outpost of Russian civilization in California. In the spring of 1812, the Russian ship Chirikov, deposited a party of fur traders under the command of Ivan Kuskof.  They began building a fortress, and on August 30, dedicated it with a ceremony, naming it Rossiya (Russia).  They also established the settlements Port Roumiantzoff, Bodega, and Kuskof.  The Russians cultivated land towards the tip of Bodega Peninsula, and erected two warehouses for grain.      Despite the efforts of apprehensive Spanish officials to check the growth of the fort of the Russians, the Russian colonists began a thriving trade with the San Francisco Presido and mission, exchanging grain, peas, meat, tallow, flour, and hides for tobacco, sugar, iron, cloth, wax candles, and other required supplies.  When two additional missions, San Rafael and San Francisco Solano, were founded to halt Russian expansion southward, the Russians extended their trade to include these new mission customers.    In 1835 General Mariano G. Vallejo gave three American sailors large land grants on the condition that they settle at the border of the Russian claims and check further Russian expansion.  However, it was the rapid extermination of the sea-otter along the coast and resulting low revenues that ended Russian expansion in California.  Unable to make a living from farming, and restrained by the Spanish from expanding southward, the Russian colonies ended in failure.  In 1824, Russia agreed to limit its future settlements on the west coast of North America to the Alaska region.    Johann August Sutter, founder of New Helvetia (Sacremento), took ownership of Fort Ross in 1841.  The price -- including 1,700 head of cattle, 940 horses, 9,000 sheep, a small arsenal, and even the 20-ton schooner Constantine -- was $30,000.00, most to be paid to the Russians in yearly installments of produce and wheat.  Sutter dismantled the fort and buildings and shipped everything he could carry on his schooner New Helvetia.

     On the way to the forest we only met one man out for a run. On the way back to the campground we met several people on their way out. It was a nice trail, that was quite wide and followed the Little River most of the way.  We had 8 crossings of it.  We also walked by 10 hike-in environmental campsites at the 1.75 mile marker.  The Pygmy Forest and the terraces below it disclose an intricate web of ecological interaction of soils, climate, and geology that produced an area that is unique in the world.  Here, and nowhere else, are found these species of plants that are decades old but are only a few feet tall.  Their gnarled, lichen-encrusted trunks are less than an inch in diameter.  There are several species of plants that are exlusive to this forest.  This was definately a unique and interesing phenomenon to see.  We returned to the campground by 1 p.m. and had lunch.  Then we walked up to the visitors center to get coffee, and spoke with the camp host for some time.  Returned to our tent and relaxed for a little while. Some info about Fort Bragg: The famous Skunk Train, ran by the California Western Railroad, is located in this town.  It runs from Fort Bragg, 40 miles, to Willits.  Originally a logging railroad, the "Skunk" line dates back to 1885.  Steam passenger service was started in 1925 when the self-powered yellow "Skunk" rail cars were inaugurated.  The little trains were nicknamed for their original gas engines, prompting folks to say, "you can smell 'em before you can see 'em."  Now, as then, travel on this line is delightfully casual, with frequent stops to deliver mail and groceries in areas inaccessible by car.  This train is a standard gauge system.  Originally it's route had 115 bridges.  Today there are only 30. Interestingly, the celebrity status of the skunk train did not come until the 1950s when fame suddenly arrived.  This came through articles in Sunset Magazine, the National Geographic, Trains, Model Railroader, and other publications.  It became even better known through it's use in the motion picture "Johnny Belinda" in 1948, which won an academy award for Jane Wyman. It was used in the films "Runaway on the Rouge River" by Disney, in 1974, and Paramount's "Racing With The Moon" in 1984 also. Fort Bragg was once known as a working lumber town.  Downtown Fort Bragg's architecture dates back to the early 1900's, rebuilt after the same terrible earthquke of 1906 which destroyed San Francisco. This earthquke caused an economic boon because local mills furnished much of the lumber used to rebuild San Francisco. On July 20, 1850, The Frolic, a brig hauling goods from China to San Francisco, was wrecked on the coast about 4 miles south of Fort Bragg.  Those who came here seeking treasure from the wreckage found instead the richness of the redwood forests.  This was the catalyst for settlement.  Prior to this time, Fort Bragg was home to the Pomo Indianas, a tribe of hunters and gatherers.  In 1856, the Bureau of Indian Affairs established a 25,000-acre reservation.  The next year (1857) the Fort was established next to the reservation to maintain order.  The military outpost and reservation was abandoned in 1864.  During this time, a number of small lumber mills sprouted up in the area. In 1885 the Fort Bragg Railroad was founded and C.R. Johnson established the Redwood Lumber Company.  In 1891, small mills combined to form the Union Lumber Co.  Fort Bragg was incorporated as a city in 1889 and C.R. Johnson became the first mayor.  The city was named after Colonel Braxton Bragg.  Fort Bragg, NC, was later named after the same officer. 
We have already met some really nice people here. There names are:  Robert and Naomi Swinney and Larry D. Rioux and his girlfriend, Stacey.    Found the bicyclist camp and got set-up. "Gobble, Gobble" he said and walked away.  One thing we have noticed right away different about today is that it is warm and we didn't have to wear any coats all day!  The mosquitos here are ferocious, though.    This park is considered the gateway to California's "redwood country".  Standish-Hickey State Recreation Area began as a 40-acre campground, donated to the state in 1922 by the Hickey family.  It was to honor Edward Ritter Hickey, son of a local lumberman who had died of influenza while caring for victims of the 1918 epidemic.  In the late 1950s the Standish family donated over 500 acres.  More additions were made through the years, thanks to the Save-The-Redwoods League.  It is over 1,000 acres now. 
A young man came in just before dark on a bicycle towing a BOB trailer (a one-wheeled bicycle trailer).  He had ridden close to 100 miles! It wasn't an easy 100 either.  We couldn't believe it. We got up at our usual time and got packed up and on the road by 6:30 a.m.  We had a good shoulder on the road, which was nice.  Then we got on Hwy 271, which had no traffic, so it didn't matter whether or not we had a shoulder.  The ride was beautiful and not too hard.  For once it seemed we had more downs than ups.  We enjoyed the ride immensely. We rode by Confusion Hill, which says that magnetic currents upset gravity, providing unusual phenomena. It was closed when we went by. It's really just an illusion created by building a house on a hill at an angle that makes everything off-kilter a bit, and it seems that objects roll up hill.  We made a rest stop at a 76 station, which we found to be only 1 mile from the entrance to Richardson Grove State Park where we intended to stop. On the way we stopped and saw the Grandfather Tree.  This Redwood tree is world-famous for its picturesque qualities.  It stretches 245' tall with one of the largest tree trunks on the Redwood Hwy, measuring 24' in diameter and 55' in circumference.  Then we visited the One-Log Home.  In 1946, this famous 2,000 year old, 40-ton log was painstakingly hand-hewn to form living quarters. It toured the country for some time, but now has a permanent home at "Bear Meadow".  There were many carved bears and other items for sale here. Walked back to our campsite and had supper. The most prominent natural feature of Richardson Grove State Park is the old-growth redwood forest itself.  Many trees in the main grove are more than 1,000 years old.  Quite a few are more than 300 feet tall.  It was very impressive and a memorable experience to walk the trails among these redwood giants.
