It was just opened recently and very nice.  We watched a video and looked at all the displays.  One of the most interesting things was Charles Kellogg's Travel-Log, which must qualify as one of the world's first and most unusual motorhomes.  It is a masterpiece of nature and craftsmanship, made from a section of a giant redwood tree from Scotia, CA.  It is the largest single piece of hewn timber in the world.  It is mounted on a Nash Quad truck chasis, the only truck capable (at that time) of transporting such a load and meet its requirements.  Using an axe and adz, Mr. Kellogg hollowed out the log and fashioned it into this most beautiful and complete dwelling; it has a kitchenette, folding lavatory, toilet, clothespress, 12 lockers, folding double bed, stove, dining table, bookcase, dresser, electric lights, running water, guest room with single bed, lockers, etc.  The log out of which this beautiful home is made is absolutely solid; walls, ceiling, floors are all made of one piece, weighing in at six tons.  This particular log was about 4800 years old  when Mr Kellog built the Travel-Log, which he drove around the country in the early 1920's to publicize the importance of preserving and protecting the California Redwood forests.  An interesting note about the Nash Quad truck is that it not only was a four-wheel drive vehicle, but all four wheels were steerable, which was useful in negotiating the difficult and narrow, winding mountain passes.  The park that we are camped at, Humboldt Redwoods State Park, is, at 53,000 acres, the third largest State Park in CA, stretching some 40 miles along highway 101.  It contains 17,000 acres of old growth Redwoods, and the largest remaining stand of ancient Redwoods in the world.  The oldest recorded coastal Redwood tree, more than 2,200 years old,was found in the park.        

   The Dyersville Giant is a Coast Redwood that fell to the ground in 1991.  At the time it fell, it was recognized as the "Champion" Coast Redwood by the American Forestry Association.  Before it fell it was at least 362 feet tall and 17 feet in diameter, 200 feet higher than Niagara Falls, or comparable to a 30 story building. It was probably the tallest tree on earth at that time.  Jan waited with the trikes while Bill went with the camera to take a picture.  While sitting here I saw many logging trucks come out of the back of the park filled to the rim with the huge trees.  It is 7 a.m.; wonder if this is an every day activity?  Also witnessed several local people stop by and put their household garbage in the park dumpster. Interesting, the things you observe while sitting on a bike.  People seem to think I am invisible, I guess, because I am on a bike.  A park ranger just drove up and jumped out and walked rather quickly up the same trail Bill did.  We are the only people here because it is early.  After Bill returned a couple from Illinois drove in with their 5th Wheel.  Jan walked the trail with them.  Rode a few more miles to the town of Redcrest and stopped at the local cafe for breakfast.  It was about time.  We were starving because it was after 9 a.m.  The Eternal Tree House was in back of the cafe.  It was once a towering giant that was hollowed out into living quarters.  14 new trees over 40' tall have grown from the still-live roots.  It was interesting.     Left here and rode to the town of Scotia to do the Pacific Lumber Company Mill Tour. It was a free and self-guided tour on the catwalks of a working lumber mill, which just happens to be the largest redwood sawmill of its kind in the world.  Since 1869 they have been growing trees, making wood products and employing people in Northern California and maintaining a proud history of forest care.  We were able to leave our bikes with the security guards to watch while we did the tour.  The first thing we saw was the log pond/debarker.     The pond covered 32 acres.  Logs are moved in the pond by workers using long poles and a small boat.  Water from the nearby Eel river shoots through a hydraulic hose at 1600 psi of pressure and at 1200 gallons per minute, sending stripped bark pieces flying.  The Douglas Fir then goes into the log pond to be floated to the other sawmill in Scotia and the redwood is put directly into Mill B.  The cutting section was closed due to some environmental activity going on locally.  The next section we saw was the End-And-Edge-Glue Division.  Short and narrow kiln-dried boards are finger-jointed together on the ends and glued together on the edges to produce longer, wider and higher-value lumber.  Used as paneling, siding and fascia, this product is an economic alternative to solid lumber and makes use of small pieces of wood that were previously wasted. Remanufacturing was the next operation.  Equipment for cutting, planing, beveling and sorting operations are arranged down the center of a large building.  Jan's favorite part of the tour was was the monorail that was moving stacks of finished product on tracks overhead that ran the length of the building.  Then we saw the Grading/Shipping section.  Kiln-dried lumber is inspected and marked according to its "grade" or quality.  The finished lumber is then shipped from Scotia via truck or rail car.  We arrived at exactly noon. The entire town of Scotia is owned by the Pacific Lumber Company.    Left this place and made a stop at the grocery store for lunch.  Headed out of town to Fortuna and the KOA. The Lost Coast is a nearly forgotten land of mountains, valleys and isolated beaches near Cape Mendocino, the western-most point in the lower 48 states.  The paved road follows Mattole Road for 70 hilly miles between Ferndale and the Avenue Of The Giants.  It was certainly a beautiful ride.  The famous San Andreas Fault terminates near Cape Mendocino.  In 1992 a strong earthquake shook the north coast and did much damage in Honeydew and Petrolia.  We went grocery shopping around 7:30 p.m. Got back around 9 and took showers, cooked bread sticks and a pizza and did our laundry.

   First we climbed to the top of Lookout Rock and then we followed the rim trail to Patrick's Point Rock and this is where we saw a California Gray Whale and her calf!  We saw them come up for air many times.  This was our first whale siting.  Continued on the Rim Trail to the Wedding Rock and Mussel Rocks Overlook.  Walked to Agate Campground and then returned to our camping area by road.  When we got back we worked on this journal and did several chores around our campsite.  The sun was wonderful.  The beach here is named for the semi-precious agates that the ocean polishes here by the constant movement of sand and water. 

   Ed was on a REI Navarro and Randy was on a Vision recumbent.  They are heading to San Francisco from Seattle.  They headed out about 9 a.m., which is when we met them at the front gate.  We were there extending our stay and heading out to hike.  We became our other personas, Spiderman and Nunnehi (our trail names from the Appalachian Trail) today out on the trails.  It was 12 miles round trip.  We walked to Fern Canyon.     Lush ferns covered the canyon's 50 ft high walls and moss carpeted fallen tree trunks.  The most common fern there was the delicate five-fingered one.  We also saw lady and sword ferns.  We followed the crystal clear creek that wound into the canyon floor and then hiked back up the stairs into the forest.  We were on the lookout for a rare species of tailed frog, but did not see it.  To get to the Fern Canyon Loop trail we hiked the James Irvine Trail from the Visitors' Center.  We could see the ocean from the parking area when we arrived at the Fern Canyon loop.  Here is where we also saw a large elk with a huge rack of antlers.  We got some good pictures.     After we got back to our campsite we worked on fixing our tire tubes with patches and worked on this journal.  The weather was wonderful.  Warm and sunny. 
           The group that came to visit were all females, except for one young male, called a spike, because of the two little spikes of antlers.  Yesterday, while visiting Fern Canyon, we saw and photographed a large bull elk, with a magnificent set of antlers, but dared not approach too closely.  Full-grown males can exceed 1800 pounds, and can be dangerous.  We have been told that the females are not especially aggressive, but can be unpredictable.  Getting stepped on by one would certainly ruin your day!  We spent the remainder of the afternoon just lazing around enjoying the serene beauty of this park.  This park, like Pfeiffer Big Sur State Park and Richardson Grove State Park are on our list of "Best" California State Parks.  We will be sure to return here in the future. 
   Our first stop was the Forest Cafe, a really neat place across the street from the Trees Of Mystery, for a breakfast treat.  We needed it.  All day long we seemed to be climbing.  We had a cumulative gain of about 3500 feet today.  We finally arrived in Crescent City at about 3 p.m. and made a stop at Wal-Mart to pick up some tire patch kits.  Jan had another flat today just as we got into town.  She also bought another tube, but at the end of the day, we discovered that someone (expletive deleted), had switched tubes in the box, and we ended up with a tube that is way too big for our bikes.   Was on the road at our usual time.  Weather was great! Our route took us off Hwy 101 and into the nearby farming communities.  It was wonderful....until Jan had another flat! Headed out on our way again around 11:30 a.m.  After a very steep climb back up to the highway, Brookings was only 1 mile down the road.  Checked the hours of the library for tomorrow.  Stopped at a Fred Meyers store and picked up some more tube repair stuff and some food and some other items.  Jan had ANOTHER flat while we were stopped here.  Fixed it and decided to stop for the day at Harris Beach State Park Hiker/Biker Camp.  It was crowded compared to all the others we have stayed at.  4 tents were already set-up.  The price was odd too - $4.24 per person.  That's because the park is within the city limits, so there is a bed tax of 24 cents.  Even the laundry at the KOA last night in Crescent City had an odd price - $1.10 per load.  Usually it is 1.25 or $1.50.   Set-up our campsite and then walked to the Visitors' Information Center across the street from the park.  Here we obtained a mile-by-mile guide to Hwy 101 in Oregon.  Just what we were looking for!  Picked up few other informational items on Oregon also.  After a stroll through the campground we made supper on the grill and then took our showers and worked on this journal and some other daily stuff that has to be done.  It is quite windy in our camping area, we noticed, but not in the other areas of the campground.  The beach is really close and that may have something to do with it.  Brookings is known as the Oregon Coast's Banana Belt.  It benefits from weather patterns that give it the warmest average temperatures on the Oregon coast.  It is the gateway to Oregon and home to an increasing number of retirees.  The Brookings area produces about 75 percent of the Easter Lilies grown in the United States, and vast fields of these beautiful white flowers can be seen in early July and I guess we are going to miss them.  They ship them all over the world.  If Harris Beach SP is any indication of what the rest of Oregon's State Parks are like, we will be quite pleased.  This is one of the only State Parks we have seen that has laundry facilities. 

   We all made plans to attend a dinner and show here at the campground at 6 p.m. at the Black Forest Restaurant.    The fog was rolling in so we turned around after we were within a mile and stopped in the picnic area and ate lunch.  Met some people here who we talked to for a little while about our trip.  Then headed back to our campsite and relaxed the rest of the day after eating supper and completing other chores.  Met two cyclists from Canada tonight.  Talked to them awhile by our campfire. 
Attracted by gold, fishing and lumber, the first settlers arrived at the Coquille Valley in 1853.  As late as 1886 there wasn't so much as a wagon road between the Coquille River and Coos Bay, only about 30 miles apart. Transportation and communication between the communities depended upon waterways. The geographic location of Bandon at the mouth of the Coquille River made it the hub of all river transportation.  Inbound merchandise and passengers were transferred from their ocean-going vessels to riverboats for delivery to upstream destinations.  Valley farm products and outbound travelers were transferred at Bandon for their journeys to other ports.  Dozens of boats would be in the harbor at a time, loading and unloading freight and lumber. But shoals at the mouth of the river made the bar entrance unpredictable.  If the entrance to the Coquille River was to be of any real commercial use, jetties were essential.  In 1887 the south jetty was built.  Dredging created a depth of 10-12 feet at high tide, but shoaling continued to be a problem. In 1888 a report published by U.S. Engineers contemplated improvements at the mouth of the river; a lighthouse and a jetty on the north side were requirements. Finally, in 1891, Congress appropriated $50,000 for the construction of the Coquille River Light Station, the last to be built on the Oregon Coast.  A local engineer interceded, however, and designated some of those funds for repair to the Point Gregory Lighthouse at Cape Arago.  The Coquille River Lighthouse was built four years later for only $17,600...the smallest lighthouse on the Oregon Coast. The lighthouse reserve included 11 acres, including Rackleff Rock, the island on which the lighthouse was built.  It was connected to the mainland by a footbridge until 1905, when the north jetty was completed and the channel filled in to connect the island to the mainland. The light station went into service on February 29, 1896 with Lightkeeper James Barker in charge.  He and his assistant, James Cowan, along with their families, shared a large duplex 1/10th of a mile north of the lighthouse.  The head keeper earned $800 per year; his assistant $650.  If equipment was lost due to negligence, it was docked from their pay. Families of the lightkeepers had chores to do, too, but were not compensated for their labors.  Women rowed their children across the river to go to school.  During a storm at night, family members often went on 4-hour shifts in the tower to make sure the light did not blow out.  Lighthouse inspectors were notorious for surprise inspections, and women were required to keep their quarters as clean and polished as the lighthouse. The Coquille River Lighthouse presents a relatively simple exterior due to the small scale of the structure, and resembles characteristics of the High Victorian Italianiate style.  On average, it is 10 to 15 feet from the base of the structure to the water below.  The tower measures 47 feet from its base. The lightroom was equipped with a Fourth-Order Fresnel Lens, illuminated by a Funck Heap lamp, and was visible 12 miles at sea on a clear night.  The orders refer to the size of the lens, a first order being the largest.  The signal beam was on for 28 seconds, off 2 seconds, signifying that it was a "Harbor Light".  There were shutters that came across in front of the light for the 2-second occlusion, operated by a clock mechanism similar to a grandfather clock. The fog horn was a DaBoll Trumpet, which used steam to generate the blast.  Its signature was a blast of 5 seconds, followed by a silent interval of 25 seconds.  It was replaced by a fog siren in 1910. The lighthouse provided safer river conditions, which stimulated the local economy.  By 1910 Bandon had 5 sawmills, a woolen mill, 2 shipyards, a creamery, and a pair of canneries. In 1914, fire destroyed the business district in Bandon. Another fire in 1936 devastated Bandon, leaving only 16 of the existing 500 buildings.  The lighthouse played a significant role in the 1936 fire, directing light across the river to aid the fire-fighting.  They provided water and shelter to survivors and homeless.  The ships' radios provided the only source of communication with the outside world. By 1939, technical navigational apparatus was commonplace and there was no longer a need for marine beacons, foghorns, and lightkeepers.  The Coast Guard extinguished the light at the Coquille River Lighthouse and replaced it with an unwatched automated beacon at the end of the south jetty.  It signified the end of an era.  The light was removed from the tower and the lighthouse was abandoned.  The lighthouse, the lightkeeper's house and outbuildings succumed to neglect, severe weather and vandalism.  While standing in the tower, it was easy to imagine what it was like to be out there on the tiny little island, alone in a severe storm, with waves crashing all around.  Not something I would want to do.  Rode back to the campground and had lunch.  Walked around the campground and worked on the journal and read our books before taking our showers.  Almost everyone in the campground packed up and left by noon.  What a quiet place it was for us until the new batch of campers arrived.  Visited with the camp hosts and the resident turkey hen before having dinner.  After dinner we sat by a campfire.  There are several cyclists here tonight, but they did not camp in the cyclists camp area.  It is a rather small area for so many tents.  The weather was good most of the day and got cold and windy in the evening as it does most nights. 

                       This park is the former estate of a lumber baron, and contains one of the oldest formal gardens in Oregon.  The roses now growing in the garden are truly beautiful, as are the ocean views from the grounds. 
     
We are staying just on the outskirts of the Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area.  Most wonder how all this sand came to "rest" in this 40-mile section of the Oregon Coast.  Geologisits are still unraveling the story of the dunes.  To date, research indicates that the Oregon Dunes are part of a hugh sand dune sheet that begins in southern California and reaches into Washington.  Most of the sand dune sheet is not visible, covered by vegetation and developments. Over millions of years, glaciers reduced mountains to sand.  Rivers picked up the sand and carried it to the ocean.  The force of the ocean waves, and strong winds brought the sand ashore along the entire coastline.  The sand is exposed in this area (7 miles north of Lakeside) allowing us to see the enormous dunes.  The KOA we are staying in has a private entrance to the recreation  area and practically everyone staying here has ATV's with paddle wheels for running in the sand.  We are staying here today for rest and relaxation.  We did take a walk to see the dunes area.  No big deal.  We didn't even take a picture.  It might be impressive to someone who has never seen a sand dune.

Kelty Clark Tent I began to wonder if the person who named this tent purposely spoofed "Clark Kent".  It's a remarkable piece of gear and weighs only 3 lbs.  It's not a free standing design, but it's light and bombproof. Speedplay Pedals I love them because I've had knee problems in the past and they allow my feet to pivot freely. I hate them because it's a high maintenance pedal system.  I had to stop and clean out my cleats on several occasions and broke one of the  springs before all was said and done. B.O.B Yak Trailer I have nothing but praise for this trailer. I could not have used my Specialized M4 on this trip without it. Next Mini Pump It's almost a good design but poor quality. I needed a pump that could give me 130 psi in my back tire and this pump was advertised to be capable of 150 psi.  I promptly broke the hinge pin in the handle and later had a problem with the check valve. It was priced lower than similar pumps but not worth the savings.  It's not the type of thing you want to ride through the desert with.
Laying your bed roll down under the tent allows you to test the spot for comfort and saves the floor of your tent from damage by sharp stuff. Truck stops are from heaven. They have showers, cheap buffets, and don't mind if you camp out back. Routing I used a standard road atlas (sans the extra pages of states I wouldn't be passing through) and plotted my route according to my needs based on rumors, rivers, trains, and expected traffic.  Water doesn't go up hill and trains have a tough time with hills too. The wind blows out of the South West 90% of the time. Cycling I made it with 4 water bottles (in November).  Some towns on your map in NM don't exist, so be careful and ask the locals. The longest stretch I had between water stops was about 80 miles. The sun sets in the West and makes it hard for motorists to see you in the afternoon if you're going the same way.  This is a good time to call on the power of prayer and/or get off the road. I didn't need to be as obsessed about weight as I was.  The trip may have been more comfortable if I had brought a normal pair of shoes.  Heavy stuff might slow you down, but broken stuff can stop you! (My trailer weighed 40 lbs. loaded.) Saddle sores... I found that using antibacterial wipes for a long time ( I was putting them in my shorts while riding at times) helped but I eventually developed a rash (presumably this was the cause).

This didn?t worry me particularly, and I got booked into a B&B in Milngavie, North of Glasgow. We had no problems with the trailer, even though it seems to track about 1 or 2 inches left of center.  Bill thinks that may be because the back wheel on the trike is offset by about that much.  The ride was not bad, but the temperature was over 100 degrees by 10 a.m.

 If our rig had been any taller or longer we would have had to pay $10 extra for an escort.  As we exited the long tunnel we saw two elk on the side of the road.  One had a large rack.  When you enter one end of the long tunnel and then exit the other, the landscape changes dramatically.     On one side is Zion Canyon with its massive cliff walls and on the other side is slickrock country.  The first mountain we saw as we entered the south end of the park was the sandstone Checkerboard Mesa.  It is the most prominent example of naturally sculptured rock art.  We didn't take the 90 minute shuttle ride up the scenic drive because we have Sammie with us and it was too hot to leave her in the RV since we could not run the generator to run the air conditioning.  We did take time to visit the visitors' center.  We parked in the shade and turned the fan on.  Sammie was fine and is doing much better today overall.  Zion National Park was established in 1909 as Mukuntuweap National Monument and then was expanded in 1919 as Zion National Park.  The scenery can be found nowhere else on earth.  The sandstone cliffs are among the highest in the world.  The park is 229 sq miles.  The name Zion is a Hebrew word referring to a place of safety or refuge. It was name by Mormon pioneers in the 1860s. For lunch we stopped at an Historical site in Fillmore, UT and had a picnic under a tree. Sammie enjoyed this the most.  A little bit of lunchmeat here and a little bit of cheese there and a gulp or two of ice and soda for her.  Paid for two nights at Utah Lake State Park.  Immediately unloaded our bikes and hit the bike trail.  The Provo River Parkway trail runs right beside where our RV is parked. We rode the short section and saved the longer part for tomorrow.  We rode around the park and along a nearby country road into town and back.  The payphone in the park is not working so we were unable to use our pocketmail machine.
            


 These fish are commonly found throughout the Columbia and Snake Rivers.  They like deep, cavernous areas and are bottom feeders.  They are grey in color, with bony plates along their backs and can live up to 100 years.  They can grow to 20 feet long and weigh up to 1,800 lbs.  Some of the other fish we saw were: Salmon, Steelhead, Shad and Lamprey.  We also went to the actual dam area and viewed the fish ladders.  Here we saw fish counters.  We decided that had to be a hard and boring job.  The Bonneville Lock and Dam is located in the Columbia River Gorge National Scenic Area 40 miles east of Portland. It forms a connecting link between the two states of OR and WA.  It was built and operated by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and was the first of eight federal locks and dams on the Columbia and Snake Rivers.  Total construction cost was $88.4 million.  Our next stop was Horsetail Falls and then Multnomah Falls.    Both places were very crowded.  We walked the trail up to the bridge across the falls.  Multnomah Falls, at 620 feet, is the fifth highest waterfall in the U.S., and the second highest year-round waterfall in the U.S.  We stayed on the old Historic Columbia River Highway when we could.  Our last stop on this highway was the Vista House.    Here we had a wonderful view of the gorge and surrounding areas.    Originally built in 1918, it is currently under renovation and won't be completed until 2004.  After this stop we headed into Portland and went to Powell's City Of Books.  This bookstore was certainly the biggest one we have ever been in.  It had used and new books, hard cover and paperbacks all on the same shelves.  It is open 365 days a year.  They have 6 stores in the Portand area.  From here we headed to the Portland airport to pick up Sharon, Harry's wife.  We made it just in time. We then went to the restaurant Sweet Tomatoes in Vancouver for dinner.  Last stop was the fireworks show in Hood River.  We stayed on the WA side and watched the fireworks across the water. Got back to the RV at 11 p.m. and immediately went to bed.  We sure had a fun-filled day. 
 Didn't get on the trail until 11 a.m. Sammie declined to join us.  She wanted to stay and play with her new dog and cat friends.  It was funny.  For once she is actually acting like a dog.  The hike was very nice.  Not too streneous.  We hiked out about 2 hours and then returned.    We also hid a microcache out there that we are calling Pacific Crest Trail Adventure.  On the way back we noticed that a fire had broken out on Dog Mountain on Hwy 14 in the Gorge. The road was closed and they were searching for 10 hikers up there.  We had discussed hiking that trail before we decided on the PCT.  It is closer to where we are staying.  Hopefully the fire will not spread our way.  The winds are not blowing much today, fortunately.  We are tired of fires.  Returned home and relaxed the rest of the day.  We are tired from our hike.  The day could not have been nicer weather-wise.  There are many wildflowers in bloom also.   

The first hint of trouble came on March 20, 1980, when the mountain gave a violent shudder of 4.1 on the Richter needle.  Then, on March 27, the first eruption opened a crater and sent a plume of ash and steam 7,000 feet into the air.  Quake followed quake in the next few weeks.  A major eruption was predicted at this point.  Everyone who lived and worked in the area found these predictions hard to believe.  They had been warned.  Finally, on a clear Sunday morning in May, the mountain blew. We were on the road to Mount St. Helen by 8:30 a.m.  Got half way down the mountain and Harry realized he had forgotten his wallet, so we turned around and went back and got it.  We had taken Sammie with us, but decided to leave her at home when we returned for the wallet.  She wasn't doing too well on the mountain roads.  Headed back out again.  We took the scenic route which was windy and curvy, with hairpin turns all the way.  Jan immediately became car sick.  We all switched seats several different times until Jan ended up in the front seat and Sharon was driving.  Dakota went with us and was fine the entire ride.  He was a very well-behaved dog.  We went to the north-east side of the mountain where the explosion occured.  We saw Spirit Lake, where Harry Truman stayed with his lodge and was buried completely, and the destroyed car from some people who were staying in a cabin nearby.  There were destroyed trees laying all over the place along with new growth.  We stopped at the Ranger Station Visitor's Center and looked over the displays and watched a 25 minute movie about the explosion.  At the mountain vista we took pictures and attended the ranger's talk.  It was very windy and cold at the top.  There was snow all around.  We headed back home after having our picnic lunch.  The drive back was 100% better for Jan especially.  Started raining and storming on our way back to our friends' house.  Stopped for dinner at All Sports Pizza in Bingen, WA. Returned home and relaxed the rest of the evening.  Sammie and all the other animals were scared and hiding most of the evening because of the storm.
At 9 a.m. we made a stop for gas, snacks and breakfast at the Super Wal-Mart in Kennewick, WA.  After that stop we made a stop for chocolate at the chocolate factory on I-395.  Figured this would get us in for sure at our friends Karen and Jay's!  No one can resist chocolate.  Arrived at Karen and Jay's at 1 p.m.  They live in a small farming community of 1700 people. Their county (Lincoln)is the 2nd largest wheat producing area in the country.  They are 35 miles west of Spokane.  After the reunion Bill went with Jay to mow grass at the apt complex they manage.  Jan and Karen went walking to downtown.  They went to the post office and the pharmacy, which is basically the everything store.  Nice short walk.  We all met back at the house and headed into Spokane.  First stop was REI to get Bill a pair of pants to replace the ones the zipper came off of yesterday.  Found some in the "attic" there which means they were half price.  Then we parked and walked through the Riverfront park.  We saw the Spokane Falls, the Louff Carousel, the big Radio Flyer Wagon and many other things.  Went to see Men In Black 2 at River Park Square Theatre.  We all enjoyed the movie.  The dog stole the show.  We were shocked at how cheep it was to get in.  It was only $7.50 for both of us!  After the movie we all had dinner at the Olive Garden.  It was excellent as always.  Returned to the van through the park and took a different route back to Davenport.  After we got back to their house Bill sifted through all our AOL mail.  75 messages!  Jan got the guest room ready by bringing in all our "luggage".  Finished up the journal and whatnot and finally hit the sack sometime after 11 p.m.  Totally beat.
After our bike ride we rearranged our trailer to load one of our trikes and Jay and Karen's recumbents.  Bill's trike will go on the roof of their van so we can all go riding the Centennial Trail tomorrow. Had supper and then headed out to the Grand Coulee Dam.  It was a 50 mile drive.  Our friends took us the back way in and the straight route out.  Jay drove really slow around all the curves so Jan wouldn't get car sick.  It worked!  We arrived at the dam a little early so we stopped at a 50's diner and had ice cream. The Grand Coulee Dam is the largest hydro power producer in the U.S.A. with a capacity of 6,809 megawatts and third largest in the world.  The dam is considered one of the largest concrete structures on earth.  It contains almost 12,000,000 cubic yards of concrete, which is enough concrete to build a sidewalk 4 feet wide and 4 inches thick, 50,000 miles long, or twice around the equater.  Or, you could build a highway from Seattle, WA to Miami, FL and back! The Grand Coulee Dam has 3 times more concrete than the Hoover Dam and produces 3 times as much electricity.  However, the Hoover Dam is 176 feet higher than the Grand Coulee Dam. We specifically went to see the 10 p.m. Laser Light Show.  We heard about this show from our cyclist friend Mark who rode through here a few weeks ago.  The Dam is transformed into one of the largest screens in the world.  The massive spillway gates open and sheets of white water blanket the face of the dam.  The show was narrated and told of the history of the river, the events leading to the construction of the dam, and the benefits of electrical power, irrigation and recreation that electrical power has produced.  Accompanying the narration were fanciful free-form patterns in many brillant colors that danced across the face of the dam. There was also background music by Neil Diamond and Vangelis. It lasted 36 minutes. The lasers came out of an enclosed glass projection booth located inside the Visitors' Center.  A digital audio tape controls all the equipment and timing for the show.  The lasers are low-intensity lasers.  Because of their low-intensity, no damage is done to the surface of the dam.  The images we saw were 500 to 1000 dots which were scanned in sequence, connecting them to produce still images or cell.  The cells were projected on the face of the dam at approximately 24 cells per second, which we saw as galloping horses, jumping fish and eagles soaring across the front of the dam. We took our lounge chairs and had front row seats just outside the visitor center.  The show was awesome.  Believe it or not it was FREE too!  It was definitely a memorable experience.  There were 1000s of people there.  We returned to Karen and Jay's after we were able to get out of the parking lot. Didn't get home until after midnight.

After resting most of the afternoon we headed to the Two Rivers Casino, located on the Spokane Indian Reservation 25 miles away.  We all had the $5.99 Prime Rib Dinner special.  After dinner Jan watched Jay gamble and Bill and Karen read books in lounge chairs down by the river.  This arrangement lasted less than an hour and we headed home.  On the way we hid another Geocache on the bottom of an old broken down wagon near a convenience store.  Forgot to mention hiding a Geocache along the Centennial Trail yesterday.  It was found already today.  That is good.  All the caches we have hidden on our trip have been found.  Decided to stay with our friends Jay and Karen one more day and spend it geocaching.  There aren't as many to choose from here as in Arizona, but it will be just as much fun, we are sure.  Watched the movie Coyote Ugly and hit the sack.
Was up and out of the house by 7:30 a.m. to go Geocaching.  The first cache we found was "Battle Of Four Lakes".  It was a film canister with a log sheet to sign that was hidden at the base of an historical monument.  We found it at 8:08 a.m.  Easy find.  Headed off to "John A. Finch Arboretum" Cache.  Parked and went off through the grass the direction the GPS took us.  Beautiful park. Found the cache hidden under a bridge in a creek at 8:58 a.m.  It was an ammo box.  Another fairly easy find.  This Finch Arboretum occupies about 65 acres of beautiful tree-covered land along Garden Springs Creek in the southwest part of Spokane.  We saw lots of marmots and gophers on the grounds as we walked.  Just had to stop for coffee and danish at Cabin Creek Coffee, then headed out to find "Manitou Ugly Duckling" cache.  It was in Manitou City Park.  First stop in the park on the way was Gaiser Conservatory.  The plants were beautiful.  Found the cache in a small tupperware container at 10:25 a.m.  Took a shell and left nothing since we left our trade item in the car.  This cache was hard to find because the coordinates were off by 75 feet.  Next cache we went for was "Minnehaha" which was in a park by the same name.  Man, this was a steep hike up a mountain to the top and it was scorching hot.  Found the cache at 11:15 without much trouble.  Signed the log and headed back down to air conditioning.  Next stop was Viewpoint #3 on the Centennial Trail.  We had to find out how many square miles the aquifer covers.  The answer was 135 miles. We rode this trail two days ago.  It is a State Park with a 372 acre day use park, that is 37 miles long.  It is a paved trail that meanders along the Spokane River extendng from Nine Mile Falls to the Idaho state line.  However, it doesn't stop here but extends another 20 miles or so to Lake Coeur d'Alene. The trail has 42 historical and archaelogical sites, most of which remain to be marked. The trail was dedicated and named the Centennial Trail in 1989, in commemoration of Washington state's 100th birthday that year. All the planned caches were found so we went touring.  First stop was the Arbor Crest Wine Cellar.  It is a long-established winery of international prominence.  The home of Arbor Crest, the Cliff House, is a national historic landmark.  Perched on a commanding rock promontory, the estate rises 450 ft above the winding Spokane River.  We had a wonderful panoramic view of the surrounding countryside.  There was a giant checker board on the grounds.  It was neat.  The flowers all around were really nice also.  We saw the Riblet Square Wheel Tractor here, too.  It was made in 1924.  The promotional description was that it fits any make and size of tractor.  Doubles the drawbar twice faster.  Works in any soil and mud or snow.  Goes any speed on pavement. Needs no lubrication.  It was certainly interesting. Did a driving tour and then stopped by the mall for a late lunch.  Jay got his hair cut.  We thought about going to the movies, but the wait for the next one was too long.  We had to make a stop for Krispy Kreme donuts.  We were able to snag two free ones, each!  We went for a scenic drive back to Jay and Karen's and we all made cool drinks and relaxed.  Recorded all our caches and worked on the journal and got everything mostly packed for our trip tomorrow heading to the coast of Oregon.  We are hoping it will be much cooler there.
Took a couple of other rest stops along the way.  Arrived in Newport, Oregon at 5 p.m. and the South Beach State Park Campground was full.  Spoke with the head ranger about our trip and he said no problem about getting us in a site.  We could stay in the Hiker/biker camp for two nights, but have to park the RV and trailer across the street in overflow.  We paid the same price as a primative campsite.  This all was just fine with us.  Set-up our tent and started putting our gear together.  What a job we have ahead of us to organize all the stuff we need to have with us.  We are just happy at this point to have a place to stay. Met several other bikers and actually had dinner with one at our RV.  He is a school teacher from Maine. Went bike riding when we got back to the park.  We rode the trails in the park all the way back to the aquarium and then down a couple of local country roads. Then we rode back to the RV and ate lunch and rested.  Then we rode north to the north end of the Otter Crest Loop, which was 4 miles up hill! But it was 4 miles down coming back!  What a blast it was coming back down! Stopped at Cape Foulweather and picked up some post cards.  The shop and lookout is 500' feet uphill.  This area was named by Captain Cook in 1778.  The views from here of the ocean were breathtaking, abd 100 mph winds are not uncommon.  Hence, the name.  We rode past Yaquina Head Lighthouse today also. The 93-foot tower is Oregon's tallest.  Returned to the RV and loaded the bikes up and headed north to Lincoln City.  We are staying at the KOA for two nights.  Tomorrow we will continue where we left off on our bike route.  Jan went window shopping.  After our ride we took Sammie and hiked the short trail in the park.  Sammie loved it and met new friends that petted her.  Returned to Lincoln City and did our grocery shopping before returning to the KOA.  Laundry was on the agenda this afternoon.  Relaxed the rest of the day.  The weather today was very foggy and cold. F or those of you who don't know, Oregon has very wide shoulders on most of their highways for us to ride on.  In some areas it is even wide enough for us to ride side by side. 

We crossed over "D" River today.  It connects Devils Lake with the Pacific Ocean and appears in the Guinness Book Of Records as the world's shortest river at 440 feet. Was up and out riding by 7 a.m.  Rode from the KOA to Drift Creek and back. Took a different route out than back.  The route back was a nice route around Devil Lake, which is in line with our earned title of the "World's Slowest Bicycle Tourists" bestowed upon us by our friends Brian and Caryl Bergeron - The World Cyclists!  The entire route up the northern Oregon coast is either up or down...no flat!  So, we have the rest of the day to relax.  We did some bicyle maintenance and repair and cleaned them up.  So far no flats or any serious problems.       
Was up at our usual time and found it was really wet outside.  Not actually raining, but close to it because it was so foggy.  Decided to have breakfast at Mel's Kitchen here at the KOA.  It was good.  We ate with Mel himself.  Headed out in the wet by 8 a.m.  Rode 30 miles today.  It was a very nice ride.  We rode what is called the Scenic old Hwy 101 - Slab Creek Road.  The route follows an old highway through some beautiful old-growth forests and farm land.  The total elevation rise is the same as that on U.S. Hwy 101, but over a greater distance, which provided for gentler grades and a more pleasant ride. On the way back we took a little bit of a different turn and went through Otis with a population of 25.  Stopped at the Otis Cafe which is famous for its down-home food.  Met up with a couple of the 4 long distance cyclists that passed us a few minutes before.  Only the guy from Switzerland stopped and actually talked to us for quite some time when he passed going up the hill.  He was very interested in our unusual bikes.  Returned to the KOA by East Devils Lake Road. Loaded up the bikes for travelling tomorrow.  Didn't get back to the park until after 3 p.m. so don't have as much time to relax as usual, but that is OK. Planned our route for tomorrow.  The weather didn't really clear up until we got back to our campsite!  As an interesting side note Jan read that the ascent over Cape Foulweather was 1 mile at 6% grade and the descent was 5% for 2 miles.  We rode it both directions a few days ago!  No wonder it seemed hilly!

After getting the RV set-up we walked across the street to see what was going on.  It was a Dory Days Festival.  We walked around and looked at all the booths and ate at the  "all you can eat" fish fry.  It was pretty good. Returned to the RV and watched TV!  Haven't had TV reception in over a week. Tonight we have total cable.  100s of channels with nothing to watch!  An interesting note about the campground we are staying in is that there are pet bunnies all over the place. This morning we just couldn't get it together. It was cold and foggy as usual here on the Oregon Coast.  We both hurt pretty much all over.  We both got pretty sunburned yesterday, too.  We left the RV Park around 9 a.m. and headed to our latest starting point.  Unloaded the bikes and headed out as we have for several days now.  However, it seems neither of us were really into the ride anymore.  Bill spoke up first and Jan agreed with him totally.  The trip was more fun in 2000 as a self-contained trip - not sagged.  It isn't any fun sagging yourself and riding the route both directions.  We don't meet other cyclists camping in the RV at night either.  So, we loaded up the bikes and went to the Tillamook Cheese Factory to get some free cheese samples and ice cream.  We made our route decision while we ate our ice cream.  We decided to head on home pretty much on the same route we came out on.  We have plenty to do at home.  We don't have to be back to work until August 6th. Drove by the Tillamook Naval Air Station Museum, which is listed in the Guiness Book of World Records as the largest wooden clear-span structure on the planet. The building is 192 feet high, nearly 300 feet wide and 1,072 feet in length. It is more than seven acres in area - big enough inside to play six football games.  Inside the building is a collection of warbirds and vintage aircraft, most of which are fully restored and operational. Today's highway mileage was 295.  Spending the night at the Wild Horse Casino and RV Resort.  Heading over to the casino to find something to eat.  More tomorrow.
Finally got through all the stop and go traffic in Salt Lake City. Stopped for the night at Lake Side RV Resort on Utah Lake in Provo.  We drove 606 miles today!  Wow!  We are both beat.  The plan is to be home in Apache Junction, AZ by tomorrow sometime.
It is a holiday in Utah today we discovered.  It is Pioneer Day.  We ran into several parades.  In all the little towns we went through they had their holiday flags flying.  Many stores and other businesses were closed. Interesting.  The radio stations were all brodcasting from the different festivals.  That is how we discovered what was going on. Ending mileage was 659.  Arrived back in AJ just after 6 p.m.  Darwin and his family invited us over for pizza.  We picked up our mail and house keys from them also.  Passed out souviners. A te and talked some and then went home.  Man the storms sure have made a mess on our patio with leaves and whatnot.  Unloaded only what we needed for the night. End of the Summer 2002 Adventure.
The forecast is for occasional rain and scattered thunder showers. Frankly, this does not trouble me. My bike is a 2001 model Bianchi San Remo with Continental 2000 Touring tires; 700 by 35 as I recall. This set has somewhere between 1500 and 2000 miles on them so far; the back tire shows wear, but not enough to warrant concern for this ride. I fully expect to get the rest of the season out of them. I have Ortlieb rear panniers and bar bag. They have proven their worth in rainy weather.    I look forward to the trip. 
  I was on the road by 6:15 AM. I headed out of Jefferson by way of highway N and the Drumlin trail. I have a lot of pictures to add once I get my camera downloaded.    I traveled the Drumlin Trail east until Mansfield Road. I followed Mansfield east to highway 89. On the bike maps 89 along this stretch is not recommended for biking, but I have found it to be acceptable. The traffic can be busy at times; usually the morning and evening commute periods, but I have never experienced any problems. Most drivers in this area are acclimated toward bicyclists.    I traveled to Waterloo, stopping briefly to review my map and drink water; and then I went on to East Bristol Wisconsin by way of Clarkson Road, taking Deansville Road north to highway V. East Bristol is not much. I did manage to find food and water at a roadside gas station. By this time the heat of the day was picking up and I wanted to make certain carried enough water. I had two of the 750-milliliter water bottles and a 1-liter Nalgene bottle. At the gas station I purchased a gallon bottle of water and refilled all my bottles and drank my fill before moving on down the road. Drinking all that water proved to be a rather poor move; I spend the next hour with a dull ache high on my ride side just below my rib cage. I think my system was struggling with the water, and sandwich I ate when I stopped. It was enough that I slowed my cadence considerably.  Heading on from East Bristol by way of highway V east, I went to Kroncke Road and then north all the way up into Columbia County. Somehow north of Leeds Center I ended up going west and then north. I realized my mistake once I came upon highway 16. I did not want ride highway 16 so I backtracked to Drake Road. The wrong turn added mileage. I am not certain of the amount, but I think perhaps 7 miles. I will say this for the episode, I forgot about my side ache.  Once on Dunning road I was on familiar roads. I used to ride this area years ago on my old Peugeot, which by the way hangs in my garage and is the proud possession of one of my daughters. At this point it was nice to not have to look at maps and simply ride. It was also about here I started seeing wildlife. Got pictures of deer and Sandhill Cranes.  I lunched in the shade of a wood lot along Dunning road at about noon taking my time to cool down and eat slowly. The side ache was a good lesson. Once I headed on to Portage, I did so taking my time the last twelve miles or so; I used the old route I used to ride years earlier when I worked in Portage and lived down off of Dunning Road on highway B.  Most remarkable to me was the damp smell of the swampy land in the Portage area and the seemingly loud sound of frogs, crickets and other swamp creatures. The heat seemed to make the swamp odor more animated and prevalent.  Once in Portage I made a quick stop to visit friends from the past. It was short, too short. I had hoped to hear from them that afternoon once Roger got home, but I never did. My choice of motel for this credit card tour was the Super 8 chain. The one in Portage was not easy to reach by bicycle. It sits on the north end of town near the highway 78 and Interstate 39 junction. Next time I will find something on the south side of town, perhaps along highways 16 and 51. At the end of the ride this first day I was spent, but not so much that I felt I over did the pace. I did carry about 30 extra pounds on the Bianchi including a full load of water. When I do this trip again, I discovered that I will be able to pack lighter and make use of washer and dryer facilities to clean my gear for the next day's ride.       
I found a wonder county park, Muir County Park, that looks to have good fishing and and toilet facilities. No camping is allowed best I can tell. I bet I saw between 20 and 30 sandhill cranes today. I took some pictures of them. I also numerous deer and turkeys as well, but these are harder to get photographs of when biking.  Once out of the swampy lands of the Portage area, the landscape is simply wonderful. And, Marquette county is simply superb. I ate alongside a tank in Dakota Wisconsin and after about a half hours rest continued on to Wautoma, making Wautoma by about 12:20 PM.  This was the most scenic portion of my trip.                     
I started out of Wautoma headed northwest on county highway C. As travel roads go, this one is acceptable, but it had a tad more traffic than suited me. When reached 12th Avenue I turned north. This had the added benefit of putting a county park with facilities; no matter how well one plans, when facilities become important, they are important. And, I was fortunate to find a nice county park just up the road about a half mile. After a few pictures of the lake and park I continued north by way of 12th avenue. I was looking for  a Beaver Drive according to the information on biking map I received from with Wisconsin Biking Federation. I never found Beaver Drive. I was fairly certain of my whereabouts and accordingly I decided that Beechnut Drive, must be the new name. As it turned out, it was the correct road. Scenery continued to be wonderful. I stopped a couple times to photograph the landscape and roadway for this journal. During one of my photographic stops, it seemed as if I could just make out the whine of Interstate 39 in the distance; it was just below the sound of the woodland birds. As it turned out it was an electric motor situated just the other side of the valley that serviced a huge sprinkler system. I saw a number of these pump installations throughout the day. Once I left Beechnut Drive I came out on to flat land that contained huge fields of crops. The wind was more prominent here, but the fact I was headed due west made the impact of the wind more insignificant; I made better time.  Eventually I was able to head due north on 7th and 6th Drive toward Plainfield. Plainfield had a greasy spoon open and I stopped for light breakfast. The food was so-so, and the air inside the cafe was poor; nearly everyone smoked, and I found myself sneezing a good deal. After I left Plainfield I followed my planned route west to the area west of Interstate 39. I had never been in this area before and I wanted to see what there was to see. It proved both interesting and an adventure. I managed to get about 4 miles west of the interstate before I discovered the road I had planned to head north on was a very poorly graveled road. I tried it, and it was too soft for my bicycle and tires... I had to back track. Such are how biking adventures go. Eventually I managed to get as far north as county highway W. I thought things were getting better, but as it turned out, I was still having trouble getting north on paved roadway.  I stopped to read the map, take in some food and water and consider what to do on highway W west of the interstate. While stopped, a pickup truck slowed to a stop. It contained a farmer, his wife and what I think was a grand daughter of about 10 years old. The conversation started with them asking if I was having some trouble, to which I replied that I was hoping to find a paved road north west of the interstate. Grandma and Grandpa began a brief discussion between themselves the eventually supplied me with the information that there was no paved road north unless I went a considerable distance west toward Wisconsin Rapids, or back east of the interstate. They did decide to agree that Taft road, did have some pavement, but as to exactly how far north of highway W it started was anywhere from 1 to 3 miles.  Since the wind was keeping me to a 11.8 mile an hour average, after checking the conditions on Taft, I decided to strike out north on gravel. It was an adventure. I managed to pace along with a group of tractors, baling straw or weed bedding, all the while being down wind of their dust. I simply could not get clear of the dust, and to top it off I actually had more truck traffic on Taft during the gravel portion, that the entire time I was west of the interstate.  Eventually I did get to pavement, and was able to make it to Plover.  In Plover, I managed to have only bad luck, finding only people incapable of giving verbal directions. I ended up putzing around Plover for almost an hour trying to work north to Stevens Point. Eventually I did get there, but it was strictly by luck and instinct. Between instructions and road construction, I seemed doomed an eternity wandering Plover. I made Stevens Point and my motel by 2:30 PM. It was good to be able to clean off the dust and sand.                 
As it happened, I managed to find a bridge out and I had to route around it a bit. But it was not bad riding. This is the area of younger days, and I had rode parts of this area earlier in the summer on the Bike Northwoods Tour. The weather was nearly perfect and the wind light and variable. It was nice. I got to Marshfield by 11:30 AM and ate lunch with family on Walonnie drive.       
The bottom bracket is original, but I changed the gearing to 44-39-24. If I ever do go long distance and end up out on the road more than a weeks time, I will re-think my gearing and perhaps change the bottom bracket to allow for some even smaller middle chainrings and granny gearing. The freewheel cassette is original, it is 9 speed and runs from 11 to 26 I have a Tubus rear rack, a Blackburn front racks, Ortlieb bar bag and Ortlieb rear bags. The Ortlieb rear bags are a recent upgrade. I also own Kirtland bags, both front and rear, but I always seem to catch rain. Of course this time with Ortlieb  bags I did not. My fenders are SKS and my saddle is my trusty Brooks B-17. Best darn saddle I ever owned! This bike is staying in the touring riggings. I got my go-fast bikes to satisfy those Saturday and Sunday treks around Jefferson County. I have no more tours planned this season. But I am already looking at Minot North Dakota to Jefferson Wisconsin next year... ya think?
   Show links to this Hide links to this      Maybe it's this proximity that gives rise to visions of travel. I can never see the Gold Rush, parked and static in my office, but always place it in my daydreams far from home on some scenic winding road. It was during one of these temporary lapses in meaningful work that I hatched my latest plan. We were into April because I had just turned 67 years old and had just had my annual physical. If I have a birthday and a checkup it must be April. Work, weather, visits to my daughter in college and assorted stuff had gotten me out of my riding pattern. It would soon be time to attend Return to Freedom, an event I had missed in prior years but had every intention of participating in this year, riding Amtrak to the Bay Area and then returning by GRR to Bakersfield. Our local recumbent group, probably for the same reasons as mine, had fizzled out. I needed a shakedown cruise before RTF - not too long and not too hard. I retrieved some county maps and spread them out on the plan table (over the plans, naturally - that could wait). Soon, I had mapped out a little three day tour, Bakersfield to Corcoran to Porterville and home, maybe 160 miles or so. Each day culminated in a little town with a cheap motel. Not the most scenic tour but OK for the first one of the year. Lately, the usual prevailing winds from the northwest had been mostly from the southeast, so I would utilize this tailwind to get me off to a good start. 
After a delicious short stack and filling of water bottles, I struck out north again. The wind, if anything, was even stronger - maybe 15 mph. The traffic was light and courteous and the shoulders were adequate if not overly wide. I appreciated the Gold Rush, boring into the wind with low profile and fairing. I was sure that with a diamond frame bike and a higher profile I would not be making as much progress into the wind. When I become tired or uncomfortable on a DF bike, I tend to not use the handlebar drops and just sit upright placing my hands on the tops. This further increases the wind drag. I noticed that with my rear panniers loaded on the rear rack and centered over the rear axle the front end steering seemed a little lighter. It presented no problem, just different. The landmarks along this stretch of Highway 43 were few and far between and I had seen them many times before on other trips. About halfway along was a junkyard complete with a standard issue junkyard dog. In the past this guy had given spirited chase but this time he was a no show. A little further on was Colonel Allensworth State Park, a historical site that I would surely visit if it were located at a destination. Instead, it was just a landmark along the way no matter in which direction it was passed. I was in no mood to stop. I gave myself permission to stop every five miles to rest if needed. Surprisingly, I only stopped twice, once to remove clothing as the day warmed and once to switch water bottles between cage and panniers. Soon, I caught sight of Corcoran Prison and knew my destination was close at hand. Corcoran Prison has a reputation among inmates (I hear) as one of the roughest in the California Correctional System. Seeing its lights and towers and slits for windows, I had no reason to doubt it. I was grateful, even laboring against a headwind, to be free and clear on the outside! That evening I walked around town a little, ate and retired to my motel to watch the Lakers beat Sacramento. 
This proved to be a good decision. The traffic subsided and the road wasn't at all bad, except for that one spot that flatted my front tire. This was to be a short leg today so I was in no hurry. I sat down and changed the tube very methodically. It was still accomplished in under fifteen minutes. Soon, I was pedaling into Porterville with a soft front tire (I never could get a hundred pounds into a tire with a frame pump). I found a bike shop (all BMX, all the time) and the owner helped me get my tire up to pressure. My motel was not ready for my early arrival, so I returned to the bike shop and bought a 20' tube to show my appreciation and kill some time. If I had needed a rear 700c tube I would have been out of luck at this shop. 
Here, there was a wide paved shoulder only marred by heavy traffic, rumble strips and dead truck tire fragments. Each shard of tire casing came with those fine little wires that are capable of giving you not just one flat tire, but multiple flat tires, if you don't discover the embedded wire the first time. This was my preoccupation then, avoiding pieces of exploded tires while making good time towards home. Finally, a nice tailwind had kicked in. Then, something happened - something that would have been avoided had I stayed off Highway 65 until after Ducor. But who can say my fate would not have been worse if I had stayed on that back road? That's the thing about fate - you just never know. I was traversing a bridge midway through a wide, sweeping left turn. The shoulder narrowed slightly and was flanked by steel barrier rails. The only approaching vehicle was a large tank truck pulling a trailer. The truck would be starting his own wide, sweeping right turn to cross the bridge I was on. Only he didn't turn. I watched, in a sort of fascination, as the truck crossed into the opposing traffic lane and continued in a straight line directly toward me! Oddly, there was no fear on my part, just awe. I couldn't believe it. I had several thoughts, all with the speed of light and not expressed in words. I could jump off the bike and climb over the barrier rail. There was no time for that, besides the truck would hit the rail right where I was. I could veer to the left and out of his path, but what if he discovered his error and corrected his course at the last moment? I would then have placed myself in front of him again. I had no options. I stared at the grill fast closing on me. At least it would be quick. The truck now crossed onto the shoulder and over the rumble strips on my side. I gripped the Gold Rush's handlebars and braced for the collision. Then I saw some activity behind the truck's tinted windshield and it made a quick correction to the right accompanied by the screech and protest of tires at the limit of adhesion. Missed me! The truck continued north. The opposing traffic had avoided it. I was heading south in relative quiet with a tailwind and a smoothly functioning bike, in good health and soon to be home. What had just happened? Had it happened? It was unreal. Business as usual.    The rest of the trip home was given over to philosophy. Cycling is healthy. It can make your life better and it can probably extend your life. It can also end it abruptly. Did the truck driver have his head in the cockpit and not see the curve? Did he fall asleep? If so, had the rumble strips awakened him just in time? If so, I will never malign those things again. If I saw a vehicle in my rear view mirror drifting over onto my shoulder would that be any different than this head on encounter? I don't think so. The considerations would be about the same with very little time to react. I do not expect to alter my cycling habits. I love the idea of traveling somewhere by bicycle. As with any endeavor, cycling on the road involves risks and you are at the mercy of the competence, experience and mind set of every driver along your route. Those risks still appear to me to be manageable. Now that I have had my close encounter maybe the statistics will spare me another. Maybe not. Soon I was home, pushing my Gold Rush up the hill to my back yard. Another completed mission with no problems except an errant driver and a flat tire. This was to be a trial run for later and I came up with a few issues. The panniers hanging off the rear rack worked just fine but how much better would the underseat panniers be? My 700c x 28 rear tire also worked well too, but should I go up a size? My sense is that it is not very important compared to being in shape. As usual, fitness wins out over mere style or technology. I'm ready for Return to Freedom! (Note: Return to Freedom is a weekend get-together at the Easy Racers' factory in Freedom, California for all owners of their products.) 











When we arrive at St. Remy, it is in the midst of its weekly market and the whole downtown area is mobbed.  Riding or even pushing the tandem is not easy in this crowd.  We decide to head over to the tourist office, get a list of lodgings and take care of that.  We find a very peasant place on the southern edge of town.  This one has two distinctions.  The B&B rooms are in an annex recently built just for that purpose, behind a modern home - three very pleasant rooms.  Also this is the only B&B we stayed in where the hosts speak only French.  We have enough for basic communication, but miss the chance to chat and learn about the area that we had in Reillanne.  Once we are settled in and walk back to the town center, the market is closing down, so we walk around the town seeing the sights and checking out restaurants. 



We spend a good chunk of time visiting the museum of traditional Provencal culture - Musee Arlatan.  This museum was founded by Frederick Mistral, whom I mentioned a couple of days earlier, and is devoted to preserving the traditional Provencal way of life that was already dying out at the end of the 19th Century when Mistral was at his peak.  A word on Mistral:  He won the noble prize for literature in 1914, the only poet who wrote in a minority language to be so honored, and was passionate about the preservation of traditional culture and language.  He is revered locally as a local boy who made good in a big way. A few more tourist sights and the day is done.  I feel more tired than I would from a day on the bike. 

Though our experience is limited to this one trip (so far), it seem like the prime times for cycling here in the south would be May and the first half of June, September and the first half of October.  Mid summer would be too hot for riding and crowded enough to make the roads busier and lodging harder to find. We were very glad we had put in the effort to learn a little bit of French.  We didn't have much - we certainly could not converse in any general sense, but enough to get basic needs met.  At the very least, learn numbers and polite greetings.  Life in France is more ceremonious than in the US.  One does not just walk into a store and state your business without politely greeting the staff first.  In small towns and country places, everyone you meet will offer "Bon Jour".  If you picnic in the town square as we often did, most of the people who pass will wish you "Bon Apetit" Contrary to what many Americans have heard, people treated us very well.  Most of the hotels we stayed in were very small, with little space to spare, but every one managed to find an indoor place for the tandem, sometimes at some inconvenience to themselves.  French drivers are fast, but mostly pretty skillful and respectful of bicycles  We Look forward to going again, hopefully with a bit more of the language next time. 
   Just before we took off, I noticed that Bruce's helmet said "HEADWINDS" in both sides.  Aaaaugh!  I scribbled over "HEAD" with a Sharpie, and we were off.  I think it worked, since the first five miles of our journey were downhill with a tailwind.    Follow along at home:  We took the ferry from Vashon Island (Washington, that is, the moldy corner of the American linoleum) to Southworth, then rode through Bremerton, Silverdale, Paradise Bay, and Port Ludlow before camping on a beach just outside of Irondale. Bruce and Cindy are good friends that I met when I lived in Portland, Oregon.  They currently live on Vashon Island.

He's had the bike for 13 years and has never replaced any part of the drivetrain, which is quite impressive considering how much he rides (a lot, through the rain most the time). It's a good thing that we stopped at the bike shop.  I learned that my freewheel wasn't completely tight, which was causing a bit of play in the rear wheel.  Now it's nice and tight, and we're cruising along splendidly. Follow along at home:  After taking the ferry north from Port Townsend, we camped at Deception Pass State Park. No rain and a good tailwind until Concrete, where it started to drizzle and our tailwind went away.    Thanks to Mom for the guardian angel, a little coin in a plastic case that looks like it's been run over by a train a few times, and thanks to Rob for sending me an extra pin for The Pig.          Food as fuel: I ate 1,500 calories of peanut butter at 7 am, and was hungry a couple of hours later.  After a day of peanut butter and Snickers (warm, of course), I needed some ruffage. We went to a brewpub in Winthrop to drink beers, eat gobs of food, and watch the Mariners lose.   
It's a beautiful day - 70 degrees and bright sunshine - and there's nowhere I'd rather be.  Winthrop is having its Pioneer Days, or something to that effect, this weekend, so we may walk around and look at things, whatever those things may be. I'm on a self-imposed water fast after yesterday's peanut butter - Snickers episode.  It was great for energy, but ...

Ate lunch at the Caribou Cafe in Okanogan, the type of place where the waiter comes to your table and asks what type of burger you want. Mom - don't read the next sentence.  Highlight of the day: I reached 44 mph coming down the pass.  The bike felt real stable, especially after truing the rear wheel and replacing the rear tire with the spare in Winthrop. I camped right in Tonasket, at an RV park, and watched the Mariners win. Beautiful high desert country - there's a definite difference between the forests to the west of the Cascades and the east.    Had a anchovy - feta calzone in Republic before heading to camp. Scene:  I'm riding through town, in the rain.  This guy gets out of his pickup (of course), and waves me over: Guy: "Come here." Me: "Hi." Guy: "You might want to stay in town tonight. I rode across this bridge this morning, and could not figure out how this guy managed to fall off, what with the guardrail and all. SANDPOINT, Idaho (AP) -- A bicyclist who fell off a pedestrian bridge clung to its girder and yelled for five hours before he was rescued -- ignored by two boys who walked away laughing, police said.  Christopher Blair apparently tipped over a guardrail on an unlit bridge over Lake Pend Oreille at about 9:30 p.m. Saturday.  The cyclist managed to scramble to safety on the bridge's concrete piling, and then climbed onto support beams 12 feet above water, where he began to scream for help.  "He said that he had been yelling for help all night and had even been located by two juvenile boys, but they would not help him," Sheriff's Deputy Ben Sterling said in a report filed Tuesday.  A nearby resident finally heard Blair's screams at 2:20 a.m. Sunday. A search by flashlight found Blair perched on the beams, suffering from early signs of hypothermia.  "I could see that he was trembling, he was wet, and he had a very red nose," Sterling said.  Rescuers lowered Blair by basket into a rescue raft and took him to Bonner General Hospital, where he was treated for minor injuries and released.
After a series of troubling events, I made the executive decision to leave Sandpoint last night at 4 pm.  Rode 15 miles east on Rt 200 from Sandpoint to a primitive campground. The most disturbing thing that happened to me in Sandpoint: someone pulled Queen Lukihulapuli off her mount.  It happened while I was in the the grocery store.  When I came out of the store, she was dangling by the spring, detached from the mount.  Later that night in camp, I reattached her with some duct tape.  I'm thinking of duct taping her dress on, as it's slowly coming off.  Hmm. Montana is wonderful, definitely my favorite state so far.  The people are friendly, the scenery is breathtaking, and the roads are in good condition.  Not as many logging trucks, either.

I usually have a song in my head as I'm riding along, and most of the time I have no idea where it came from. The ride:  Rode from Whitefish through Columbia Falls and West Glacier to the Apgar Campground in Glacier National Park.  After dropping The Pig off at the campground, I rode up Going-To-The-Sun road as far as they'd let me (no, not the voices in my head, the Park - the road still isn't completely open), and then turned around to head back to camp. Song-in-my-head of the day: Another Lonely Day by Ben Harper. They had the GTTS road closed to motor traffic beyond Avalanche Campground, so it was a nice and quiet ten-mile ride up to the first tunnel, where the signs asked me nicely to turn around, don't go any farther, this means you.    As I was descending on the GTTS road, I saw a grizzly bear standing in the road.  Brakes, brakes!  A guy on a bike was standing about fifty yards from it, looking at it through binoculars.  He's seen a lot of grizzlies, and estimated this one to be 2-3 years old.  It was bigger than a cub, and smaller than an adult. Sooooo, in order to save this guy and two other cyclists coming up the road, I quickly got out my pepper spray, just like I'd been practicing the night before, and discharged the whole can into the bear's undoubtedly evil eyes.  It then stood on its hind legs, started pawing at its eyes, and stumbled off into the woods.  Immediately afterwards, while the onlookers were all cheering me, I blew the steam off the spent pepper spray canister, twirled it around a couple of times, put it back in my pack, and rode off into the sunset.  It kinda reminded me of that scene in A Christmas Story when Ralph defeats Black Bart. Uh, no, sorry, disregard that previous paragraph.  Couldn't help it.  The bear was munching on grass on the side of the road, as peaceful as can be.  After he was a good 15 feet off the road, we decided to ride by him.  I couldn't help but glance at him as I rode by, and he had the cutest eyes.  As Molly would say, Sweeeet Baby!

Scene:  We had just turned off the paved road onto the dirt road heading towards Polebridge.  Floyd, kind of a loose rider, hit an unfortunate series of divots in the road, his front wheel immediately turned 90 degrees, and he went sailing over the bars.  Complete yard sale.  Two older ladies in a sedan with Washington plates were about 50 feet away, driving towards us slowly. Floyd (with bloody forearms) to the ladies, after getting up: "Did you get a picture of that?" Ladies: "Oh, gosh, are you ok?  That looked like it HURT!" Floyd: "Oh me, I'm OK, I like to do that about every five miles." Floyd got hit a couple of years ago and has huge scars on his head from the crash.  He wasn't wearing a helmet.  He still doesn't wear a helmet.  Hmm.   
Song-in-my-head of the day: I've Been Wondering by The Minders. Had a 10-15 mph headwind all along Rt 206, as I was headed south.  Then it started raining.  And the wind didn't let up.  Huh.    My mom's friend's nephew and his wife (got that?) invited me to stay the night at their place Kalispell, and I gladly accepted.  It was great - I took a shower and washed my clothes!  Aah, cheap thrills.  Thanks Scott and Heather!
The Ride:  Rode south from Kalispell to a country blacktop road that connected me to Rt 82, turned east on Rt 82 into Big Fork, then headed east then south on Rt 82 to Swan Lake.    Song-in-my-head of the day:  God Bless America (I heard it in a gas station, then saw it on a bumper sticker, and it stuck) Saw a couple of wild turkeys between Kalispell and Big Fork.  Thought about dinner.  Right before entering Big Fork, it rained hard - big, cold drops - for about five minutes, then stopped.  It was an exercise in clothing layer management. At camp, I met a guy from Germany that's leading a bunch of German teenagers from New Mexico to Vancouver, B.C.  They stopped for candy bars and a 12-pack of Coke, then they were off to Big Fork - 23 miles away, at 8:30 pm.  Hmm.
The ride:  Rode south from Swan Lake on Rt 83 through Condon (Kathy! Jim! Elizabeth!) to Seeley (Slideshow Rob!) Lake.    Song-in-my-head of the day:  Cult of Personality by Living Colour. I thought that today's ride would be easy, but it ended up being all uphill.  In a hailstorm.  With bears chasing me.  And locals shooting at me.  In the dark.  Backwards.  OK, I'll stop. During my lunch stop at Condon, I talked to some bear hunters.  They hadn't seen any bears yet (I pointed them to Glacier), but they were still looking.  It was funny seeing these big hunters decked out in camoflage eating little ice cream cones.   
   Song-in-my-head of the day:  Rain by The Beatles. I realized that it's rained every day since I've been in Montana.  Except for the Eureka rain-to-snow incident, nothing extended, but still rain. Scene:  While riding along the dirt road, I stopped to talk to a couple of guys standing by their pickup, looking through binoculars. Me:  "Whatcha looking for?" Guy:  "Gophers." Me:  "Why?" Guy:  "We're shooting them." Me, kidding:  "To eat?" Guy:  "No, just for fun." There's gophers, or prairie dogs, whatever you want to call them (targets?) all over Montana.     
Missoula's a great town.  I'm glad I rode out of my way to hang out here for a day.  Nice downtown area, and the weather is great!  (80 degrees, bright sunshine). I spent the morning riding from my campsite to the KOA ($8, not bad), cleaning the bike, drying out the gear.  Bruce and Cindy - thanks for the books. Hung out for a couple of hours in the Adventure Cycling main office.  The maps that I used from Anacortes, WA to Sandpoint, IA, and the maps that I'll use from ?, Illinois to Bar Harbor, Maine were created by Adventure Cycling.
For lunch, I had a huge plate of some of the best jambalaya I've ever had, in this dingy bar in town.  The type of place with tinted windows and no name on the front.  I was eating at the bar with a few guys drinking PBRs (it is Saturday afternoon and all), watching a Discovery channel program about penguins.  It was funny - we were totally captivated by the show, me eating my jambalaya and them drinking their many beers. Tonight I'm going to see Reverend Glasseye and his Wooden Legs, a band that, I'm told, sounds like Tom Waits.  Hmm.
The ride: rode east from Missoula  on Rt 200 to Ovando, where I turned south on a nice dirt road that wound its way between farms, to Rt 141 where I turned north to hook up with Rt 200 heading east again.    A big badger crossed right in front of me while I was on the dirt road.  It ran to the other side, sat down, and stared at me, like it didn't know what to do.  As it was a badger, I didn't hang around long to watch it. Song-in-my-head of the day: Jerry Was A Race Car Driver by Primus. Camped just to the east of Lincoln, just off the road.  I haven't been too crazy about paying for campsites lately.  Montana's big, plenty of space, and I don't leave a trace, so why should I pay $10 to be able to use a picnic table?  Hmm. Caught up with another bike tourer today on Rt 200.  She just graduated from the U of M, and is riding back home to Seattle.  She's basically taking the same route that I did, only in reverse.  She's riding a Bianchi mountain bike that she found in the trash - it was clean, and looked to be in pretty good condition.  I'm riding a Bianchi mountain bike as well, bought it new in '94 and have been riding it ever since, but mine looks like it was just pulled from the trash.
Song-in-my-head of the day:  Strange As They Say by Blinker The Star. An interesting weather day.  About a mile from the top of the pass, I felt the temperature suddendly drop about five or ten degrees, and then it started to hail / sleet on me.  OK, so I sped up, made it to the pass, donned the Gore Tex, and waited for the storm to pass (30 minutes).  A couple hours later, as I crossed I-15 on my way to Hauser Lake, I looked in my mirror and saw clouds, lots of them.  I turned around and could see the sheets of rain heading across the valley.  Aaaaugh!
