The approaching storm turned the headwind that I had been riding into for quite a while into a 20 mph tailwind, so I sped up, ducked into a barn, donned the Gore Tex (again), and waited for the storm to pass (30 minutes).    Found a great campsite.  Lots of wildlife.  A deer came and stood about 30 feet away from me for a couple of minutes, not knowing what to make of me.  Of course, he was upwind - otherwise, his eyes would've started to water and he would've run off, trying not to gag. Added some more duct tape to Queen Lukihulapuli.  Her dress keeps wanting to come off.  Hmm.
The ride: Rode south from Hauser Lake to Helena. Song-in-my-head of the day: Summer of '69 by Brian Adams.  Yep, heard it from a passing pick-up, and it stuck. Helena is great.  It's a cute town of about 35,000, nestled in the foothills to the south with the big flat valley to the north and east.  I'm camped at Mt. Helena City Park.  It's a nice site, I've got a great view of the city, but camping in the foothills didn't give me any flat ground, so I'm on a bit of a tilt.  The nice lady at the visitor's center said, "Sure, you can camp in the park, why not?"  I like that reasoning.  The sign at the park said "No Camping", but it didn't say "This Means YOU!", so, remembering the visitor's center lady's advice, I camped.  Why not? Wednesday, 6/5/02: Song-in-my-head of the day: Moby Octopad by Yo La Tengo. I rented a mountain bike (a Schwinn Mesa aluminum hardtail) and rode some of the trails around town.  I'd heard that there's good singletrack right outside of Helena - today proved it.  I rode south from town up Grizzly Gulch road, then caught the Mt. Helena Ridge Trail back into town, a 13-mile loop.  It was great.  Sometimes the trail reminded me of riding in the Northwest, all pine covered, and other times it reminded me of riding in Crested Butte, Colorado, across bare slopes with lots of wildflowers. According to the bike shop owner, there's 95 miles of singletrack accessible right from Helena.  I'll have to come back another day to check out the other 82 miles.    Thursday, 6/6/02: Spent the day in the Library, reading, checking stuff out on the Internet (it's on computers now!), etc.  Pretty uneventful - a wonderful day. Last night I saw a band called RoxSlyde played at Helena's weekly Alive at Five thing downtown.  Yikes.  They did mostly cover songs, and they were quite loud for a lazy evening in little Helena.  Kids these days ...
The ride:  rode east out of Helena on Rt 284 (generally, the higher the number, the quieter the road) to Rt 12, headed west into Townsend for lunch, then headed east on Rt 12 to Deep Creek campground.    Song-in-my-head of the day:  Best Friend's Girlfriend by The Cars.  Don't know how that got there. Had breakfast at an organic market.  The usual stuff - bagel, apple, raspberry-pastry thing, but it tasted way better than the usual Safeway swill.  It seemed to last me longer, like my body was able to process it easier than the typical over-processed-partially-hydrogenated crap. Passed a house with a couple of dogs hanging out.  They saw me, and started charging.  I thought, there's two fences, they can't reach me.  Well, the yellow lab reached me, and I was surprised that it could run 17 mph.  After a few seconds of that nonsense, I yelled, "BACK OFF!!" at the dog.  It immediately slowed down, and had this Holy-$#!+-it-can-talk look on its face.
It started raining at 5:30 am, and didn't stop until 9 am.  Finally started riding at 11 am.  It was a damp misty morning, all the way to the top of the pass.  At the top of the pass, it was 38 deg. F, and a 25 mph wind was slapping me in the back, yelling, "giddyup!"  OK. I zipped up, then headed down.  Fast.  With the tailwind and the steep road, the bicycle computer says I got the rig up to 51.2 mph (how 'bout that, ma ?!?).  Could've gone faster, but - damn, that's fast enough.  Where's the fire?  James Brown may be a sex machine, but at the bottom of that cold descent I was a snot machine.  Hey!  Good God!    Saw a huge hawk sitting on a fencepost along Rt 89.  I yelled at it to see it fly, and it must've had a 8' wingspan. Song-in-my-head of the day:  Hash Pipe by Weezer. Found a beautiful place to camp on the side of a dirt road.  I'm reading Big Rock Candy Mountain by Wallace Stegner, that has the following line: "The next night ... they camped in the clear evening with the sun pink on the Crazy Mountains east of them ..."  Funny, when I was reading that, it was a clear evening with the Crazy Mountains just to the east of me - I could see them from my campsite.
The ride: rode west then south from camp on Rt 86 over Battle Ridge Pass into Bozeman.    It rained the whole ride, but the Gore Tex did me well.  The Gore Tex jacket's hood fits nicely over the helmet, the Gore Tex gloves fit well over the bike gloves, and I was all flashed and counterflashed with the Gore Tex pants and socks.  Pit zip management. Song-in-my-head of the day: Life of the Party by Beulah. I was planning on camping once in Bozeman, but with the rains, I made a beeline to the hostel.  $14, and the roof doesn't leak - ok!  Actually, it's a great place.  Met a guy from Poland that's working at Yellowstone for the summer - he talked about his summer job and Poland post-communism, I talked about my bike trip and life in the US. On a D'oh! note, I accidentally dropped my toothbrush in a pile of cow manure. On the way into Bozeman I rode by a mountain called Gobblers Knob.  Hmm, where have I heard that name before?  Wasatch?  Joni, isn't that your secret backcountry skiing spot?  Oops, sorry.
Today I'm hanging out at the library and the hostel, reading.  The hostel has a good stack of Ad Busters magazines that I hope to plow through tonight. Tomorrow I head to Chico Hot Springs, near Emigrant, to meet my brother and dad for some fly fishing in/near Yellowstone.  Should be fun.
     In Emigrant I picked up a couple of things at the Post Office from Kurt and Mel.  Kurt - thanks for the cans of Whoop Ass (an energy drink with lots of riboflavin and stuff).  Mel - thanks for the Chili.  We'll cook it up when I get to Chicago (it takes an hour and a half to cook, and I don't think my stove would last that long or do it justice). On the dirt road I passed a family riding from Bozeman to Yellowstone, for a few days of dodging RVs in the park.  The dad/husband once rode from the east coast to California, so ... First song-of-the-day in my head: Going to California by Led Zeppelin. Then I got to thinking about the dropped-D tuning in that song, so ... Second song-of-the-day in my head: Fat Bottomed Girls by Queen ("Get on your bikes and ride ...") Had a dream last night that I was laying in my tent, and a guy with a little tape recorder playing an Elvis Costello tune I couldn't recognize kept jumping back and forth over my tent.  Hmm.
6/12 Wednesday We went into Yellowstone, went to the Fountain Paint Pots and Old Faithful, saw a lot of bison and elk.  Yellowstone is an amazing place - everyone should visit.  Don't worry about the crowds - yes, there's lots of people, but, damn, the geysers, wildlife, scenery ...   Just go. After seeing the sights, we fished the Firehole river.    6/13 Thursday We fished a spring creek with the help of a guide - Jake from Big Sky Guides.  It was a great day.  The creek was very clear, with lots of cutthroat and rainbot trout.  Dan caught a couple of rainbow - one was an absolute pig - and a cutbo, Dad caught a rainbow, and I caught a brown trout (everybody out). Later we ate dinner at the bar in Chico, played cutthroat (a billiards game), and listened to the bartender tell ghost stories (Chico Hot Springs is haunted).      6/14 Friday We drove up Mill Creek Canyon looking for a place to fish.  The water was quite high, so we decided to go back to the Firehole and stay in West Yellowstone.  After fishing we made burritos for dinner by the side of the river.  We shuttled my bike and gear from Chico to West Yellowstone.   
The ride: Rode east from West Yellowstone to Madison Jct, then north to Norris Jct, east to Canyon Village, south to the Mud Volcano area, then north back to Canyon Village to camp. Songs-in-my-head of the day: Perhaps, Perhaps, Perhaps by Cake (originally done by ?), and Pictures of Me by Elliott Smith. South of Canyon Village I saw a herd of bison crossing the Yellowstone River.  When they reached the other side, most of them started tearing around aimlessly.  Maybe the water rejuvenated them.    The Mud Volcano area is great - lots of pools of mud with sulfur dioxide bubbling up.  What a mess.  My favorite sign read "Danger: Hot Spattering Mud.  Keep a safe distance."
   Song-in-my-head of the day: Bad Moon Rising by Reeves Gabrels (originally by CCR) At the bottom of the 1,000' climb to the pass, I opened up a fresh can of Whoop Ass and drank it slow (that's the key).  I think it helped - the pass was pretty easy. Later at camp I had a headache, I think caused by the elevation coupled with NOT DRINKING ENOUGH WATER (D'oh!).  Today was a hot, long day with lots of climbing (~3,500' total).
Some Elevations: Salt Lake City: 4,200' Base of Alta ski area: 8,530' Top of Mt. Hood, the highest point in Oregon: 11,240' Camp last night: 6,841' The pass that I dragged The Pig and Queen Lukihulapuli over today: 10,947', over two miles high Camp tonight: 4,500' Some Stats: Bottom to top: 7.2 mph avg, 22.7 miles Top to bottom: 18.4 mph avg, 49.1 mph max, 41.2 miles The Ride: Rode east from Cooke City on Rt 212 to the junction of Rts 212 and 296 (the base of the climb), opened up and drank a fresh can of Whoop Ass (thanks again, Kurt), rode over a windy Beartooth Pass to Red Lodge, then turned east on Rt 308 to Bearcreek.    Song-in-my-head of the day: Col. Bruce Hampton and the Aquarium Rescue Unit's version of Working on a Building, a traditional song For camp I treated myself to a lovely cow pasture just east of Bearcreek. Saw a few chubby yellow-bellied marmots during the climb.       
Song-in-my-head of the day: One Man's Dream by Greazy Meal. Murphy is definitely with me on the ride.  In the middle of nowhere, just me and the sagebrush, on the deserted dirt road west of Rt 310, my rear deraileur cable broke.  Fortunately, I had a spare.  If I didn't, I would've been in the highest gear from then until the next bike shop (?!?).    This morning at 5:30 a huge herd of cows about 200 yards from me started mooing at - what?  The sun?  So, sleep was a bit fitful after that. Lovell is a great town, mostly because they have free camping and free showers right in town!  That's my criteria anymore. Watched a little league baseball game tonight right near camp.  The wind was gusting at around 30 mph, no lie, which made for some interesting baseball.  The outfield was located downwind, so as long as they hit it in the air, they were pretty much guaranteed a home run.
1. Eat a whole 12" pizza the night before the ride.  All of it.  Crusts and all.  Think about eating the box. 2. Go to bed early the night before, get up late the day of the ride. 3. Open up and drink a fresh can of Whoop Ass at the base of the climb.  http://www.jonessoda.com/files/whoopass.html 4. Don't look at your odometer during the ascent.  At 4 mph, you won't be getting very far very fast, and you don't need a computer to tell you that. 5. Eat before you're hungry, drink before you're thirsty, shift before the hill. 6. Don't be mashing the pedals less than 60 rpm.  Do whatever you need to do to keep your cadence around 80 rpm - granny (lowest) gear, make-your-own switchbacks, whatever. 7. Enjoy the looks of astonishment from passing motorists. 8. Above all, pay attention to your breath.    The ride: rode east from Lovell on Rt 14A to Burgess Jct. Song-in-my-head of the day: Freedom of '76 by Ween. When I reached the top, I saw a couple of moose hanging out by the side of the road. At the end of the ride, I was completely wiped.  I camped on top of the "pass" (more of a plateau), where the overnight temperature dropped below freezing.   
The ride: rode east from Burgess Jct on Rt 14 to I-90's Exit 14, rode I-90 for two thoroughly awful miles to Exit 16 (I had no choice!), where I was more than happy to exit and make my way on a couple nice backroads to Sheridan.    Song-in-my-head of the day: Belong by R.E.M. I didn't start riding until 10 am.  Yesterday's ride whipped me.  I sat and stared at the babbling brook that I was camped next to for a good hour - not eating, not reading, just staring.  If I made any sound, it was probably "uuuuuuuuuuuuuuhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh." Today's descent was probably my favorite of the trip.  The grade was perfect - I was able to cruise between 35-40 mph without using the brakes, ooh yeah.  I passed an RV. In Sheridan, I showered at the YMCA (I don't shower much), and was surprised to find out that I've lost 15 lbs since starting the trip.  I'm down to 159 lbs.  Yikes. In celebration of the last pass, I drank 25 oz of Sierra Nevada Pale Ale at a local Grub & Pub. Interesting:  If I took the most direct route from Seattle to St. Charles, Illinois (where my parents live), I'd be in St. Charles by now.  Hmm.
The ride:  Rode east out of Sheridan on Rt 336 for 15 miles of paved then 25 miles of dirt / gravel road to Clearmont, took a left on Rt 14 16 (east) thru the bustling metropolis of Spotted Horse (one bar, it was closed) to camp, ten miles east of Spotted Horse. I was relying on the bar in Spotted Horse to be open, so I could get some water for dinner and the ride the next day.  D'oh!  Luckily (?), there was a hose on the side of the building.  I filled all my water containers (two 32-oz Nalgene bottles and my 100-oz CamelBak) to the brim with water that tasted like rubber hose.  Ick.    I saw lots of trains along the dirt road, mostly transporting coal.  This is coal country, big time. Song-in-my-head of the day:  When The Levee Breaks by Led Zeppelin.
The Ride:  Rode east from Spotted Horse on Rt 14 16 to Gillette, rode east from Gillette to Moorcroft on Rt 51 (parallels I-90), took a left in Moorcroft on Rt 24 (north) to Devil's Tower.      A long day, but the tailwind from Gillette to Moorcroft definitely helped. I didn't have to pay the $5 entrance fee to the Monument.  In an effort to get us obese Amercins off our duffs and to the Great Outdoors for some exercise, Dubya waived the entrance fees to all National Parks and Monuments for the weekend.  Woo-hoo! Song-in-my-head of the day:  Airbag by Radiohead. I can see wild turkeys from camp.   
Hung out at Devil's Tower for the morning.  Saw license plates on RVs from all across the U.S.  Lots of prairie dogs in the Devil's Tower area - I could've sat and watched them all day. The Ride:  Rode north on Rt 24 from Devil's Tower across the Bear Lodge Mountains (8% grade uphill, 7% grade downhill) to the WY-SD state line, where Rt 24 turned into Rt 34, continuing east to Belle Fourche.    Belle Fourche (pron. bell foosh) is the geographical center of the U.S., so I had that going for me. Song-in-my-head of the day:  Money For Nothing by Dire Straits. A thermometer in Belle Fourche read 92 deg. F.  It was hot.  I need to shift gears and start riding earlier in the day.  For the last two days, at 4 pm, I've been sapped, can't go any farther, must stop, ugh.
The Ride:  Rode east from Belle Fourche on Rt 34, turned south at St. Onge onto a deserted, paved farm road (ooh yeah), rode under I-90 and picked up Rt 85, which I took south into Deadwood. Somg-in-my-head of the day:  Strawberry Fields by The Beatles. If you're ever thinking about biking Rt 85 from I-90 to Deadwood, think again.  It's a four-lane road with a three foot shoulder, no big deal except that the shoulder is taken up by a rumble strip every twenty feet or so.  So much for riding in the shoulder.  I had to ride on the far right side of the right lane, hoping that anyone coming up from behind would get into the left lane.  Most did, a couple didn't, and that didn't make the climb into Deadwood any easier.    I'm treating myself to a hostel tonight.  Shower, laundry, roof over my head - luxury!
I've seen lots of cars from Minnesota here in the Black Hills.  What gives?  Wait, I should know ... The Ride:  Rode south from Deadwood on the Mickelson Trail, a beautiful rail trail that runs north-south from Deadwood to Edgemont through the deep woods (read: cool shade) of the Black Hills, through Rochford, Mystic, and Hill City to Crazy Horse.    Lots of elevation gain today (3,500'), but it was all pretty easy with the gradual grades of the rail trail. Just before Crazy Horse, along a particularly deserted stretch of trail, I came across a herd of cows standing in the trail, probably 30-40 of them, all sizes, pooping and peeing all over the trail.  When they saw me, they turned around and started walking down the trail, and wouldn't get off.  I followed them for probably ten minutes before coming to a spot with a meadow on one side of the trail, where I ran through the meadow, around the cows.  Poor things - they looked really scared.    The Crazy Horse Memorial is incredible - it's a huge mountain carving (in progress) of Crazy Horse and his, well, horse.  It's a non-profit project, built by the "interested public and not the taxpayer."  http://www.crazyhorse.org Song-in-my-head of the Day:  Black Flag by King's X.
The Ride:  Rode south on the Mickelson Trail to Pringle, took Rt 385 east to the Wind Cave National Park, then after touring the cave I went south on Rt 385 through Hot Springs and north on Rt 79 for a bit to camp (cow pasture again - why not?).    Song-in-my-head of the Day:  Against All Odds by Phil Collins (not by choice, it wouldn't leave!) - you know, "take a look at me now ..." With this heat, I find I'm drinking more and more water.  Today I drank almost all 100 oz. (close to a gallon) of water out of my CamelBak from Crazy Horse to Wind Cave, and that was only the first 26 miles of the trip.
The Ride:  Continued north on Rt 79, turned east through Buffalo Gap and into the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation onto a gravel road that paralleled the southern boundary of Badlands National Park, turned south on paved Rt 27 to Sharps Corner, camped off a farm road just outside of town. I hung out in the Badlands Visitor's Center from 1 pm to 3:30 pm, the hottest part of the day (about 102 deg. F outside), watching some films about Badlands, Indian Traditions (filmed in '73), and Bison (filmed in '67).  The Bison film was great - the ranger and I were the only ones in the visitor's center, and we were admiring the psychedelic effects used in the film.    Song-in-my-head of the Day:  Funky Monks by the Red Hot Chili Peppers. The southern half of Badlands NP is inside the Indian Reservation, and there's a fair amount of controversy related to some fossils that were discovered in the area.  The Indians claim them, the Nat'l Park claims them, you get the picture.
Well, at the General Store in Batesland (pop. 88, B.F.E.), the owner gave me the guest book to sign.  I opened it up, and there it was, staring at me, mocking me: "Lars Clausen www.onewheel.org."  Dude is flying - he started in Oregon on April 29 (about a week before I started), and now is in Wisconsin. The owner of the General Store has a cute 7-year old dachsund named Leo that's just as calm as can be, which is the opposite temperament of Mouse Dog (the old, vicious, yappy shop dachsund that Bruce and I encountered at Port Townsend Cyclery). Leo's owner: "Ooh, Leo, is it too hot out there for you?  Come let momma hold you and give momma a big kiss, yes, yes, it's ok ..." Mouse Dog's owner: "Mouse Dog, be quiet!" The Ride:  Rode south from Sharps Corner to Porcupine (near the Wounded Knee Massacre Site), where I turned east on a gravel road to Batesland, then headed east on paved Rt 18 to Martin (Suzi! Don! Don! Don! Don! Pat! Katie! Jeff!), home of the trumpeter swan (!). When I got to Martin it was 106 deg. F (101 deg. F windchill). In Porcupine I pulled up to a house with a guy sitting outside to ask where I could find a grocery store and some water.  He pointed me in the direction of the grocery store, and said I could fill up my water bottles at his place.  Sure, why not?  He offered me a cup of coffee, but since I don't drink coffee, and it was 96 deg. F at 11 am, I declined.  While I was filling up, he showed me the marijuana plant he's growing.  OK.  Then his cousin came by and asked me if I wanted to smoke some pot before the ride.  Uh, no thanks.  That would probably kill me. The ride from Porcupine to Batesland was not pretty.  102 deg. F, 20 mph headwind, on a dusty road.  I was absolutely caked with dirt by the time I reached the pavement.  I looked like a raccoon.    While I was eating a calzone at the bowling alley in Martin, I had a great conversation with a guy named Les Bearnose that used to be one of four investigators on the reservation. Song-in-my-head of the Day:  Hail Hail by Pearl Jam.
The Ride: Rode east from Martin on Rt 18 into the Rosebud Indian Reservation to a road that branched off south just after Rt 63 branched off north, which I took to Rosebud and then St. Francis.    Three miles away from Rosebud, with a climb ahead of me, I ran out of water.  Not good (it was over 100 deg. F). Me, after filling up my water bottles out of a spigot on the side of a lady's house in Rosebud:  "Is there a grocery store in town?" Lady:  "Up on top of the hill." Me, not remembering a grocery store on top of the hill that I just descended into town:  "That hill?" Lady, pointing to a different hill:  "No, that hill." Me, realizing that I had another huge climb to get to the grocery store, which was not on my way to St. Francis:  "D'oh!" Song-in-my-head of the Day:  Suddenly Everything Has Changed by The Flaming Lips   
First 16 miles:  7.2 mph avg. (ugh) Last 24 miles: 18.2 mph avg. (woo-hoo!) An odd morning.  Here's a sequence of events: 2 am:  The wind changed from a nice, cool breeze from the north to a hot, humid, strong wind from the south.  Uncomfortable sleeping. 4:45 am:  I heard some commotion outside my tent (I was camped about a mile outside of town, just off a dirt road).  I looked out, and saw four kids (punks!) coming right towards me (it was already light, since St. Francis is at the far eastern edge of the time zone).  They saw me, backed off about 40 feet, and one of them (punk!) lit a bottle rocket and launched it at me.  I'm thinking, this is odd.  Luckily he missed, probably because of the strong wind in his face.  Then they ran off.  They were probably up all night, since I could hear people shooting off fireworks all through the night. 5:30 am:  A stray dog came by and was so excited to see me, he almost damaged the tent trying to get to me.  Just a minute, just a minute! The Ride: Rode south from St. Francis off the Rosebud Indian Reservation and across the state line to Kilgore, Nebraska (headwind), where I turned east on Rt 20 into Valentine (tailwind). Song-in-my-head of the Day: (song #7 on Aenima) by Tool. Valentine has free camping and showers.  I think I'll stay an extra day. Met a fellow bike tourer at camp.  John, a member of the LAPD, is riding from LA to Boston.  He hopes to be in Boston in 2-1/2 weeks.  Yikes!  In 2-1/2 weeks I'll still be in Nebraska, waiting for RAGBRAI to start.  I like my pace better.
This morning at 7:30 am in Valentine it was 66 deg. F and 97% humidity.  Kinda foggy cloudy eerie.  But then at 10:30 am, halfway through the ride, the sun came out, the wind started up, and, of course, the wind was smack 15 mph in my face.  So, instead of pressing on to Bassett, I shook my fist at the wind and stopped in Ainsworth. The Ride:  Rode east from Valentine on the Cowboy Trail for a few miles, then continued east on Rt 20 to Ainsworth.    The Cowboy Trail is a rail trail that parallells Rt 20 that I was hoping to ride for 150 miles east from Valentine.  However, the surface is soft, and for the few miles I was on the trail I was plodding through two inches of gravel.  Ah, yeah, I think I'll stick to the road. Song-in-my-head of the Day:  Summertime Rolls by Jane's Addiction
   I kinda lucked out on finding the Golden Hotel.  $29/night, A/C, TV - OK!  The nice lady at the front desk rang my room at 10 pm on 7/4 to tell me that there's fireworks happening at the O'Neill Country Club and that I could probably see them out my window.  In your face, Holiday Inn Express! Sat around and watched a lot of baseball while waiting for the storm to blow over.  Read a book for a while at the library on 7/5, but that was a challenge as I was a bit dizzy and kept falling asleep. The Ride:  Rode east from Ainsworth on Rt 20 through Bassett, Newport, Stuart, Atkinson, and Emmet to O'Neill. Song-in-my-head of the Day:  Fourth of July by Soundgarden (Kate - thought of you and your friend at the People's birthday bash (?) with the line, "light a roman candle and hold it in your hand").
The Ride:  Rode southeast from O'Neill on Rt 20 275 through Inman and then southeast on Rt 275 through Ewing and Clearwater to Neligh. Song-in-my-head of the Day:  California Girls by The Beach Boys (saw 'em performing it on TV - catchy tune!). The corn is definitely "knee high by the 4th of July", thanks to heavy irrigation.
The Ride:  Rode south from Neligh on Rt 14 through Elgin, Petersburg, and Loretto to Albion, where I continued southeast on Rt 39 to St. Edward.    Song-in-my-head of the Day:  Headache by Liz Phair. Ate lunch at the Pizza Hut buffet in Albion.  Since I was feeling much better and had rode 32 miles by that point, I bellied up to the boo-fay and came close to putting them out of business.
The Ride:  Rode southeast from St. Edward on Rt 39 to Genoa and Silver Creek to Rt 92, where I turned east and then south on Rt 81 to Stromsburg. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Positive Bleeding by Urge Overkill (Paul Shafer and the CBS Orchestra played it during a commercial break the other night, and it stuck) I arrived at Stromsburg (the Swede Capital of Nebraska!) by noon, which is good since at that time it was already 93 deg. F and rising.  The humidity is almost deafening.
- lots of fireflies (none were flying more than two feet off the ground) - a squirrel and a bunny rabbit playing - the squirrel would lunge after the rabbit, and the rabbit would jump out of the way, sooo cute - lots of little owls divebombing me (none made contact, but I ducked more than once) Today's ride was simply lovely.  For the 40 miles between routes 81 and 79, I rode on a two-lane blacktop road between cornfields, with hardly any traffic.  One of those thin grey lines on the map.  Ooh yeah.    The Ride:  Rode south from Stromsburg on Rt 81, turned east on Rt S12C which turned into Rt 66 to Valparaiso, where I turned south on Rt 79 to Raymond. Song-in-my-head of the Day: Wilma's Rainbow by Helmet.
As I was trying in vain to find the All-Star baseball game last night on the radio, I found that AM radio now consists of the following: 75% sports talk radio, 15% news, and 10% more sports talk radio.  Out of curiosity I listened to a sports talk radio show for a while, and was amazed that so many people can recite so many stats with so much passion about sports. The Ride:  rode east from Raymond then turned south into Lincoln on quiet, unmarked two-lane blacktop roads.    Song-im-my-Head of the Day:  Poundcake by Van Halen. OK, today I figured out how Poundcake keeps getting into my head.  As I was riding east from Raymond, I had a strong crosswind from the north.  When I was getting close to the intersection where I was going to turn south, I realized that the wind would be behind me after making the turn, and I thought, "lemme get on some of that" about the wind, which is precisely what wordsmith Sammy Hagar says in Poundcake about his baby's, well, Poundcake. I'll be hanging out in Lincoln for the next week, visiting a good friend and waiting for RAGBRAI to start.
The Good News:  A couple of hours after it was stolen I found it a few miles away and stole it back. The Bad News:  Not everything was on the bike when I stole it back. 4 pm:  After a tour of Lincoln's huge, beautiful Capital, I went to the downtown library to read for a bit and beat Suzi at online chess. 5:50 pm:  I left the library to head to my friend Matt's place, where I've been staying for the past week beating him at foosball, watching bad (good) kung fu movies, and waiting for RAGBRAI to start.  When I got to the bike rack, I noticed my bike wasn't there, and I had one of those surreal experiences where I doubted everything - did I lock it somewhere else?  Is this a dream?  Am I on Candid Camera?  Is the Tour de Moser over? 6:05 pm:  After a panicked call to Matt, he picked me up and we went to the police station.  An officer took my information, and told us about a few hot spots where my bike may be, for us to check out.  He didn't sound too hopeful, but said if we've got nothing better to do, it's worth checking out. 7 pm:  At the last hot spot to check (People's City Mission, a 24-hour shelter located a few miles from the library), I didn't see the bike, but asked Matt to circle around the building.  I had a hunch, and I was right.  The bike was laying on the lawn, with a couple of guys standing around it.  I said "There it is!", and hopped out of the car, I think before it stopped moving.  My adrenaline was surging, and I ran up to the bike as fast as one can run in flip flops, grabbed it, shouted a few profanities at the guys standing near the bike for good measure (I saw one of them near the library eariler), and rode away.  Those guys could've been armed to the teeth and I wouldn't have noticed.  I was a man on a mission (pun intended).    The handlebar mirror, rear rack bag, helmet, rear light, cable and lock, and my favorite baseball cap are gone, ripped off the bike, as well as the three bike tubes and two books (sorry Dan, the books are officially gone, but the Snickers were saved!) that I just picked up General Delivery from the Post Office.  Today was spent replacing those items, at considerable expense.  Could've been worse - I may have had to buy a new bike. The weird thing?  The bike was stolen in broad daylight, right near the main entrance to the library, and it was locked to the bike rack.  They didn't take the bike right next to mine that wasn't locked up.  And for those of you that have seen my bike, you know it's not the most appealing bike, with rust, duct tape, stickers, etc. So, I'm set to shove off tomorrow for Sioux Center, Iowa, where RAGBRAI starts Sunday.  I was going to leave today, but no big deal.  I'll have to ride three 65-mile days instead of four 50-mile days.  Should be ok. It's still tough to believe that I actually found the bike.  Lincoln is not a small city (225,000 people, home of the University of Nebraska), and I found the bike at least a couple of miles away from where it was stolen.   
The Ride:  Rode north out of Lincoln on 14th St, which turned into lovely 2-lane blacktop.  I rode that north then east into Ceresco, where I turned north onto Rt 77 into Wahoo.  I continued north on Rt 109 to Cedar Bluffs, turned left (west) on an unmarked road to Rt 79, where I turned right (north) to North Bend.    Before leaving Lincoln, I stopped one last time at my favorite bagel place and bulked up for the morning (one everthing bagel with egg and cheese, one everything bagel with chive cream cheese, ooh yeah). The Welcome to Wahoo sign proudly proclaims that Wahoo is the home office of the Late Show with David Letterman. Today was a relatively easy ride since I was fresh out of the gate, and I had a tailwind. Talk about the weather:  When I pulled in to North Bend at 1 pm, the bank thermometer read 97 deg.  At 4 pm, weather.com told me that it was 99 deg. and 35% relative humidity.  I don't need a psych chart to tell me that's icky.  When I left the cafe (I ate a pork chop in order to prime myself for Iowa) at 6:30 pm, the bank thermometer read 96 deg.  That's when I got on the bike to ride nine miles north of town to camp (right next to a cornfield, lots of mosquitoes and daddy longleg spiders).  It got down to 75 deg. overnight, but the humidity, oh the humidity ...
Highlight of the day:  I was interviewed for a story in the Pender, Nebraska paper.  How 'bout that?  When I was riding through town, a guy pulled up alongside me. Guy: "Where are you headed?" Me: "Maine." Guy: "Where'd you start?" Me: "Seattle." Guy: "Which way are you headed out of town?" Me, confused as to why he would ask that question: "North." Five minutes later, at a gas station on the north side of town (I stopped for a Gatorade, the third of the day), a lady came in and asked if I was the one riding across the country (she saw the bike leaned up against the wall outside).  She works for the local paper, and the guy that I talked to earlier is her dad, the owner of the paper.  So, she interviewed me and said that she'd send the paper with the story to me (she's sending it to my parent's place, where I'll be in less than two weeks).  Hopefully I'm not misquoted ("Yeah, I usually ride between seven and ten miles a day.  During this heat, I only ride between 2 and 6 pm.")    After the interview, she snapped a few photos of me outside with the rig.  When she was finished, I snapped one of her.  However, it wasn't that seamless - The Pig was being mischievous.  Not a second after I took her picture, The Pig gave a twitch and the whole rig almost came crashing down on her.  Fortunately, she escaped with only a bit of grease on her leg from the chainrings.  Bad Pig!    The Ride:  Rode north out of North Bend on Rt 79 to Snyder, where I took a left (west) on Rt ? to Dodge.  From Dodge I headed north then east to West Point, where I turned left (north) on Rt 9 to Pender and then Emerson. According to mapquest.com, it's 72 miles from Emerson to Sioux Center, the start of RAGBRAI.  Yikes.  Better get an early start tomorrow. Song-in-my-head of the Day:  Hey Jude by The Beatles.  It was played in a movie I saw a couple of nights ago (The Royal Tenenbaums), and it stuck.
The Ride:  Rode northeast from Emerson on Rt 35 through Hubbard and into Iowa after crossing the Missouri River.  From Sioux City (right on the river), I headed north on Rt K22 to Rt C12, where I took a right (east), and rode through Craig and Struble to Rt 60.  I rode Rt 60 northeast for a bit to Rt K64, where I headed north into Orange City. The stretch from Sioux City to Orange City was hot and fast, and I bonked.  I had the wind behind my back, but it was blowing at the same speed that I was riding (about 15 mph), so I didn't get to take advantage of the cooling effect from the wind.  I was hoping for a store in Craig to get something solid in my stomach - nope.  Struble - get outta here.  So, I pushed it the whole way to Orange City, where I pulled in to the first store I saw (a Casey's, of course) and ate a Snickers and drank a Gatorade.  The last ten miles into Orange City were not pretty - I wanted food, and I couldn't have it!    It's now 95 deg. F and 56% relative humidity.  Just stupid hot.  At 95 deg. F, Salt Lake City rarely gets above 14% RH.  It's supposed to cool down in a couple of days (only 85!), so there's that. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Something by The Beatles.  I read The Beatles Anthology at the Emerson library yesterday.  I could think of worse songs to have in my head.  Phil Collins comes to mind.
   The Ride:  Rode east from Orange City on Rt 10 through Alton and Granville to Rt 143, where I (we!) turned south to Marcus.  Rt 143 turned into Rt L36, and when we reached Rt C38, we turned east to Cherokee. Somewhere along the ride, I saw a big plume of white smoke up ahead.  I thought, "Is that what I think it is?"  Sure enough, two miles later, I passed Pork Chop.  I didn't stop to partake in pork, since I just finished eating six pancakes (all you can eat!).  I'm thinking of eating just pork for a day, see how that goes.  Pork products and Gatorade - mmm. There is so much food and drink along the ride, it's all easy.  Lots of all-you-can-eat deals to choose from, the library is open 'til 8 (on a Sunday!) just for Ragbrai, and there's bands playing in town tonight. Song-in-my-head of the Day:  Higher Ground by Stevie Wonder.  It was playing on a lady's radio that was attached to her bike. Favorite t-shirt phrases: Gears are for wimps (worn by a guy riding a single-speed cruiser) No drafting off the fat guy! (worn by a fat guy) Rehab is for quitters (worn by a waitress in a Marcus bar - the bar was packed, people were drinking, and it was 10 am)
The Ride:  Rode east from Cherokee through Rembrandt (pop. 228), Marathon (pop. 302), Webb (pop. 165), and Ayrshire (pop. 202) to Emmetsburg, via the following roads (make sure and pay close attention to this): M10, C25, M27, C16, M36, C25, M54, C13, M54, B63, N14, B53, N18, B53, and Rt 2.  Got that?    Along the way I stopped to pee in a cornfield.  When I was about 30 feet into the cornfield I remembered that cornfields are very scary places, and I was glad that I found my way out. At Marathon I stopped for lunch (two pork burgers - when in Rome ...), and watched a great blues band.  Turns out the bass player used to be in the Sun Dogs, a reggae band that used to play in Ames, Iowa (where I went to college (Iowa State) back in the early 90's), so I had that going for me. Webb was probably my favorite town, as they had bikes strapped 10 feet above the ground to the telephone poles that lined the main street.  And, they were selling Gatorades for $1.  Can't pass that up.    Speechless, mouth-gaped-open moments: 1. At breakfast, I watched a lady playing "Take Me Out To The Ball Game" on accordion while her friend from the choir sang along in a voice that was heavy on vibrato and sustain. 2. I saw a guy carrying his dog on his bike, in a child carrier.  A cute little white puppy. 3. I saw and talked to a guy that's riding RAGBRAI on a bike without a seat.  He's standing up the whole way, grinding away with his 60-tooth big ring (that's big - my big ring is 44 teeth).  I asked him if he uses different muscles than when he rides with a seat, and he said, "I dunno, I never use a seat."  I nodded, and then backed away slowly and quietly. 4. Just before entering Ayrshire, I saw four older ladies tap dancing on the concrete front porch of a house.
The Ride: Rode from Emmetsburg through Fenton, Lone Rock, Titonka, Woden, and Crystal Lake to Forest City via a bunch of two-lane country roads.    I definitely feel different riding in RAGBRAI than on my own. On my own, I look around at the scenery, keep a steady pace - it's generally meditative. Riding in RAGBRAI, there's always someone beside you, so lots of talking, lots of speeding up and slowing down, and lots of stopping. In the overnight towns there's usually bands playing, lots of food, and multiple beer gardens.  The main campground is close to town (within a couple of miles), but most people stand in line to take a shuttle bus from camp to town instead of riding their bikes, which baffles me.   
Bad joke of the day, as told by the singer of a band playing in Nora Springs:  What is the definition of endless love?  Stevie Wonder and Ray Charles playing tennis.  (I think some people hurled some stuff at the stage after hearing that one) It's easy to spend a lot of money at RAGBRAI, or put another way, it would be quite different to ride RAGBRAI with a big wad of cash.  A $4 pork tenderloin here, a $2 Gatorade there, and let's not forget the $3 pie, and hey you can't pass up ice cream for $1, and before you know it, you're out $20 easy for the day, and that's without spending money on many beers.  D'oh! The town of Bolan, pop. 80, baked 96 pies for Plymouth to sell, so I had to have one. I saw the Tubador playing in Charles City, a guy with a tuba and a tambourine.  He's got a CD for sale, but I didn't buy one since I had already spent enough money on food. In Charles City they had a "tug-of-war" contest that involved the fire department, a keg of sumthin', and willing volunteers from the crowd.  The keg was suspended about 20' in the air on rollers on a wire (it could move along the wire), and near each end of the wire was a guy from the fire department with a hose and a kid from the crowd, and the object was to spray the keg to the other end of the wire.  Wow - that was difficult to explain, and reading it again, I don't think it makes sense.  Whatever.  How 'bout a picture?    If I were to ride RAGBRAI again, I think it'd be fun to do it with a gang of people that I know, with a support van or bus.  I'd still use the BOB trailer, but it would be used for towing a stereo system, or maybe a cooler for refreshing mixed drinks (margaritas with a pedal-powered mixer?), or maybe a midget playing a ukulele (the trailer has a pesky 70 pound weight limit). Food for the day:  When I crossed I-35 (85 miles north of Ames), I ate a granloa bar.  Then I had a turkey sandwich, slice of pizza, and a piece of rhubarb pie with ice cream in Plymouth, a veggie dog and baked beans in Rudd, and an all-you-can-eat lasagna dinner provided by the Methodist Church in Charles City.   
   The Ride:  Rode from Charles City to Oelwein via Nashua, Tripoli, and Sumner. In Nashua I rode by the hug-a-pig booth. $1 gets you a squealing little piglet to hold for a bit.  Only in Iowa. Today I hopped on to the tail end of a few groups of riders, and man it was fun.  I've never really done that before.  While I'd be poking along at 15 mph on the flats, I'd look in my rearview mirror until I'd see a big group (~10 riders) coming up behind me, then just as they'd pass I'd speed up a bit and hop on the train.  It was amazing - I was riding at 22 mph with hardly any effort, with my front wheel about 6" behind the rear wheel of the rider in front of me.    Usually there's kids hanging out along the side of the street that give the riders high-fives as they're riding into town.  Well, riding into Sumner a guy in front of me was going to give a kid a high five.  At the last second, the kid (accidentally, I hope) moved and got smacked in the forehead instead of the hand.  He didn't look hurt, just a bit shocked.  Funny, it sounded just like a hand slap.   
I'm not the pheasant pluckerI'm the pheasant plucker's sonI'm just here plucking pheasants'Til the pheasant plucker comes (memorize, then sing out loud in front of your friends - hah!) The Ride:  Rode from Oelwein to Anamosa via Stanley, Aurora, Winthrop, Quasqueton, Troy Mills, and Central City.    I don't think RAGBRAI would work in any other state.  The people here are so nice, and the little towns really do a good job of creating a festive atmosphere.  It's like you're in a bike parade for a week.  At some of the intersections, the State Troopers would shoot passing cyclists with water guns.  Better than real guns, I suppose, but not as exciting.   
The Ride:  Rode from Anamosa to Bellevue via Amber, Scotch Grove, Canton, Andrew, and Springbrook.    Due to the rain, the road was almost deserted today.  A lot of riders hopped in their team van or bus, and drove home or to the end of the ride.  The ride was quite hilly (~2,800' of cumulative climbing), and very scenic. It was so humid that my fingers were slipping off the shifters when I'd go to shift. I hooked up with another group of riders heading east, and we camped along the banks of the Mississippi river, right near a lock and dam where barges were traveling through all night.
The Ride: We rode south on Rt 52 to Sabula, where we crossed the Mississippi over a scary high bridge with steel grating that you could look down through and see the water, into Savanna, Illinois.  From there we headed east on Rt 52 to Mt. Carroll, then southeast on Rt 40 through Chadwick and Milledgeville to a lovely quiet road that took us into Dixon.    We rode into Dixon as the sun was setting, and the ride just before Dixon was great.  Tall corn and lots of silos.  The corn in Iowa and western Illinois looks way healthier than the corn in Nebraska.  In Iowa and Illinois there is little to no irrigation, whereas in Nebraska they're throwing water in the air everywhere to water the crops. Rt 52 in Illinois wasn't a pleasant road, and a car that was passing us clipped the driver's side mirror off a car that was coming the other way.  The car that got clipped was swerving all over the road after the accident, and it was scary to see it swerving in my rearview mirror. After we stopped for lunch in Savanna, we saw another bike tourer, and he joined us for the ride to Dixon.  So, with Anthony, the mob grew to seven. We left Bellevue at 10 am, and arrived in Dixon at 8 pm.  However, we only rode for six hours, which means we had four hours worth of breaks.  It was great kicking back in the shade and hanging out with the group.  I'm glad I met up with them - they're a great bunch.   
   The Ride: Rode northeast from Dixon on Rt 2 to Flagg Road, where we turned east to Flagg Center and Rochelle.  From there we took Rt 38 to Dekalb and then Rt 23 northeast to Sycamore.  Sycamore is where we picked up a rail trail that parallells Rt 64, and we rode that into St. Chuck.    At the trailhead in St. Charles, my mom was waiting for us.  She rode with us for the last 2-1/2 miles from the trailhead to their place, where I lived for the last two years of high school.  It was great riding with her, even though she was riding a bit fast for us (!).  Good job, mom!  For those last miles, The Mob was nine, and we were pretty much invincible. I'll be hanging out in St. Charles for the next week or so, eating a lot, hanging out with the family, and going to baseball games and amusement parks.    Andrew is peeling off from The Mob to continue pedaling around the Midwest, and the rest are continuing east after doing laundry, taking showers, and working on their bikes in St. Charles.  I'm going to miss them when they take off, and it will definitely feel different when I'm riding by myself.  Sprocket, Pantano, Arial, Erin, Sarah, and Randy (left to right in the photo), it was great to meet you, and I wish you continued success in your travels.  Happy trails!   
The Ride:  Rode east from St. Charles on the Illinois Prairie Path Geneva Spur to the Timber Ridge Forest Preserve, where I hooked up with the Great Western Trail and continued east.  About ten miles west of downtown Chicago, in Maywood, the trail ended, and I took Washington Blvd for the rest of the way to Grant Park.  On the way back, I branched off the Great Western Trail in Villa Park and took the main Illinois Prairie Path and the Elgin Branch back to St. Charles. Song-in-my-head of the Day:  "Roll With The Changes" by R.E.O. Speedwagon.  Kate, Dan, Molly, and I went to Great America on Thursday (a Six Flags amusement park), and we heard that song in the car on the way there.  Oh yes, it stuck. When I got back to St. Charles, we went to a baseball game (the Kane County Cougars).  They lost, but it was a great game, and after the game we were treated to a few parachuters that landed on the field, and a spectacular fireworks show.  Fortunately, they waited to do the fireworks until after the parachuters had landed.  At the game, the announcer proclaimed over the loudspeakers, "Dave Mosen is joining us at today's game.  Dave rode his bike all the way from Washington!"  The crowd didn't go wild, but I still got a bit red in the face.
   The next few days I'm visiting a bunch of family, and I'm excited.  Tomorrow I'm riding to New Lenox, IL to visit cousins Cathy and Jim Condon, Friday I'll be in Dowagiac, MI to visit Aunt MaryAnn and Uncle Maurice and their kids and grandkids, and then Saturday I'll be in Kalamazoo to visit Uncle Tom and Aunt Arlene, and Uncle Buzz and Aunt Rosemary.  Busy schedule!
   The Ride:  Rode south on a bike/ped path along the Fox River through Geneva, Batavia, and North Aurora to Aurora, where the path ended and I headed generally southeast on busy two-lane roads through Plainfield and Lockport to New Lenox.    The traffic from Aurora to New Lenox was non-stop.  Where are all these people going?!?  Three guys in a pick-up truck yelled "faggot!" at me when they passed me in Plainfield.  It was pretty funny. In New Lenox I visited my cousin Cathy, her husband Jim, and their 2-year old Elizabeth, who was highly entertaining, as usual.  When asked to sing "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star", she sings "Papa Was A Rolling Stone" instead.  A true Chicago gal.  Cathy made pork chops, mashed potatoes, and corn for dinner, and Elizabeth decided to bypass the potatoes and sample the butter straight from the tub.    Song-in-my-head of the Day: Sleep on the Left Side by Cornershop.
Temperature-wise, today was ideal.  It never rose above 75, so I just kept riding, and riding, and ... The Ride:  Rode east from New Lenox through Frankfort and Matteson on the Old Plank Road Trail (a beautiful rail trail), to Park Forest, where the trail ended and I headed south on Orchard Rd to Steger Rd.  I took Steger Rd east through Sauk Village to the IL-IN border.  After the border, I took a variety of two-lane roads through Schererville, Merrilville, and Valparaiso to Kingsbury, where I camped off the side of a quiet dirt road.    There is a vast difference between the quality of roads in Porter County (Valparaiso area) and Laporte County (Kingsbury area).  The Porter County roads are bumpy cracked poorly-patched asphalt, but the Laporte County roads are smooth blacktop.  Go Laporte!  Trust me! Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Keep On Rocking in the Free World by Neil Young.
The Ride:  Rode NE from Kingsbury on a buncha quiet roads to Chicago Rd, which turned into Bertrand Rd after crossing the IN-MI border.  I turned north on Rt 51 and rode through Niles to Sumnerville, where I took the Indian Lake Road north to 95th Ave.  I took 95th Ave east between Big Crooked Lake and Cable Lake, then east on Karl St to Aunt MaryAnn and Uncle Maurice's place, on the north shore of Magician Lake. After the ride, I spent the afternoon tooling around Magician Lake with Uncle Maurice, and eating dinner with him, Aunt MaryAnn, her niece Serena, and her niece's boyfriend Tim.  My cousin Jill, her husband Dan, and their kids Erica, Danny, and Andrew showed up later, and we stayed up until 1 am talking, drinking, and watching and listening to the nighttime boat traffic.  It was a great day.    Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Ballroom Blitz by Sweet.
Today was a fast day (14.0 mph avg), but it didn't feel like I was going that fast.  What gives? The Ride:  Rode east from Magician Lake on the Territorial Rd to Decatur, where I took a bunch of two-lane roads to Schoolcraft.  From there I made my way north to Portage and then Kalamazoo to my Uncle Tom and Aunt Arlene's place.    I had dinner with Uncle Tom, Aunt Arlene, their son Andy, Uncle Buzz, and Aunt Rosemary.  Cousin Matt stopped by, and it was a big family fest for a while.  I'm really getting into this family-to-family bike touring.  Tomorrow I'll be staying with Tom and Arlene's daughter Monica, so I've got that going for me.   
The Ride:  Rode east out of Kzoo on N Av to 34th St, where I did a quick jog left then right (I had time to jog) on MN Ave.  I passed a bit south of Battle Creek, and hooked up with Michigan Ave in Marshall, which I took all the way to Monica and Jon's place.    Just outside of Kalamazoo I passed by the Kalamazoo Container Division of Green Bay Packaging (my dad works for Green Bay) on E Kilgore.  I waved to the building - why not? In Marshall I saw a black squirrel.  Apparently they're popular in this area of Michigan. Monica and Jon have a six-year old chocolate lab named Willie that's everything a six-year old chocolate lab should be, and a cat named Spot that has six toes on each paw.  With those big paws, she's quite effective at "making biscuits".  Monica made lasagna for dinner, and I had to limit myself to three pieces in order to avoid those astonished, embarrassing looks that I know all too well. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  T.G.I.F.U. by Babe The Blue Ox
   I rode right by the Michigan International Speedway in Brooklyn, and I was amazed at the size of the bleachers.  Race fans!  Sunday, Sunday, Sunday!  I fail to see the attraction of watching other people drive cars around a track for hours on end, but hey, that many fans can't be wrong, right?  Left turns! At the intersection of routes 156 and 34 in Michigan, I stopped for ice cream and a Gatorade at a gas station.  The cashier saw me pull in on the bike, we talked for a bit, and then: Me: "So, how far to the Michigan-Ohio border from here?" Cashier:  "Oh, about fifteen minutes." Me, looking for some clarification:  "Fifteen miles?" Cashier, looking confused:  "Uh, yeah." It's interesting that we often measure distances in units of time, and vice versa ("How long until we're there?" "Oh, ten miles."). At the Napoleon library, I heard someone almost shout, "Where's the bike tourer?" from the other side of the library.  Yikes!  Take cover!  It was a fireball named Jack, and he's quite a character.  Went into a coma in November of '97, came out in March of '98, rode his bike across country with his son (from Seattle to Washington, D.C.) in the summer of '99, and he's now running for congress.  He's 73 years old.
The Ride:  Rode east from Napoleon on Rt 110 to Grand Rapids, where I peeled off the main drag and followed a bunch of quiet two-lane roads through Tontogany, Bowling Green, Pemberville, Gibsonburg, Fremont, Clyde, and Avery to Huron.  Between Fremont and Clyde I rode the North Coast Inland Trail, a paved rail-trail.    The only sign posted in the men's toilet room at the Pemberville IGA: "Pick up after yourself.  Please keep your shoes off the toilet rim.  Thank you."  That baffled me - I wonder what happened that made the management post that sign?  Shoes on the toilet rim?  Hmm ... Huron is right on Lake Erie.  As I was pulling into town, I was in my usual find-a-shower-then-find-the-library mode since it was warm and I was stinky, but then I saw the sign for the public beach.  Beach!  I forgot - I'm near a big body of water!  It was so nice.  I swam in Lake Erie for a long time.  The water temperature was great, and there was a nice breeze to keep the bugs away.  After swimming for about a half hour and reading a book for an hour, I set up camp a couple miles east of town. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Sugar by System Of A Down.
Today was a beautiful ride along the southern shore of Lake Erie.  The next few days should be the same, as I'll be right next to Lake Erie all the way into New York.  Hope the lake doesn't catch on fire - wait, those were the old days. The Ride:  Rode east from Huron on Rt 6 through Vermilion, Lorain, Sheffield Lake, Avon Lake, Bay Village, Rocky River, and Lakewood to Cleveland, where I snaked my way to Shaker Heights, a town just southeast of Cleveland. I'm using the Adventure Cycling maps from here to Maine, and then from Maine to at least Richmond, Virginia, and I was glad to be using them today.  Winding through Cleveland was a bit of a challenge with all the twists and turns, but the route was safe and easy. The highlight of the day was visiting the home that I lived in from late 1970 to late 1974 (I was born in April of 1970), in Bay Village.  The house is still the same, the only thing that's changed is the landscaping (a few trees died and were removed to brighten up the place and reduce the number of mosquitoes, and the sandpit that we played in is no longer there).  I knocked on the door, an older lady answered, and we chatted for not even a minute.  With my shaggy hair sticking out from the bandanna on my head, and me stinking up the neighborhood, she was a bit on guard, and I heard the lock click when she shut the door.  Hmm. The neighbor in the house to the east of our old house heard my conversation with the older lady, and she and I talked for a bit.  Her name is Donna McAnn, and she moved in a few months before we moved out.  Unprompted, she said, "I remember your cat Moselle."  Wha?!?  How does she remember the cat?  That was a bit strange to hear from, basically, a stranger.  It was great talking with her, and before I left I took a bunch of photos of the old house.  Of course, everything in the neighborhood looks much smaller.      Tonight I'm staying with friends Kristin and Eric in Shaker Heights, a beautiful town with lots of big, old, well-designed homes.  Kristin is a good friend of my sister-in-law Molly.  They've got a cute 6-month old Bernese mountain dog named Sophie that's really well-behaved, but still likes to gnaw on rugs when no one is looking.
The Ride:  Rode east from Shaker Heights on S Woodland Rd to Gates Mills Blvd, which I took northeast to Gates Mills. Heart-stopping moment: lost my Palm Pilot at the library.  D'oh!  Someone was nice enough to turn it in at the lost and found.  Whew!  How 'bout that?
The Ride:  Rode north from Gates Mills on Rt 174 to Rt 84, otherwise known as Johnnycake Ridge Rd, where I turned right (east).  I used to live near the intersection of Johnnycake Ridge Rd and Johnnycake Rd (call me Johnnycake), in Mentor, but I didn't see that intersection as I was riding.  Willoughby, where I was born, is just west of Mentor, so today's ride had a bit of History of Dave.  I took Johnnycake Ridge Rd to Painesville, took Rt 84 to Madison, turned north at Unionville, and hooked up with Lake Rd.  Lake Rd hugs the southern shore of Lake Erie, and I rode that through Geneva-on-the-Lake, Ashtabula, Conneaut, into Pennsylvania, and through Lake City to Fairview, where I camped for the night.    Higlight of the day:  In Ashtabula I bought 3,460 calories of food for only $3.48.  That's a lot of energy. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Jealous Again by the Black Crowes While reading the paper at the grocery store in Fairview, I learned that The Smithereens were playing tonight in Erie, at a downtown festival.  D'oh!  Since I was already showered, Erie was still 16 miles east of Fairview, and they didn't start playing 'til 10 pm, I didn't hop on the bike and continue east to see them.  But I almost did. I camped between two farms, in a lovely grassy area that was surrounded by trees (read: no one could see me).  As I was hanging out at camp, a kitty, probably from one of the farms, came over to say hi.  It slept on my lap as I was reading.  Soooo cute.
The Ride:  Continued east from Fairview on Lake Rd through Erie, into New York, through Barcelona (or, as Ruben Farr would say, Barcelonia), Dunkirk, Silver Creek, and Irving to Point Breeze.    Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Girl Like You by the Smithereens In Point Breeze I hung out near the beach to watch the sunset.  It was nice - I worked on my bike a bit, adjusting the brakes and cleaning the drivetrain, and watched the sunset before returning to camp.
The Ride:  Continued east from Point Breeze on the Lake Rd to Lackawanna, where I took South Park Ave to Buffalo.  I crossed the Peace Bridge into Fort Erie (Canada!), then rode the Niagara Recreation Trail northwest to Niagara Falls.  After hanging out there for a bit, watching water fall and getting sprayed by the mist, I took the Lewiston-Queenston Bridge back into the US, and took Upper Mountain Road east through Pekin to Lockport. At Niagara Falls I went to the gift shop and bought some funny looking Canadian candy.  Next time you're in Canada, check out the candy.  Trust me.    The highlight of the day was crossing over the bridge back into the US from Canada.  Auto and truck traffic was backed up on the bridge, and I cruised right between the lanes, ooh yeah.  Luckily, no one on the right side decided to open their driver's side door - oof!    In Lockport I camped in luxury behind the Wide Water Drive-In restaurant near the public marina along the Erie Canal.  Free camping for bike tourers, free showers, and greazy food.  I hung out at the canal, talked to a bunch of folks, and watched the beach chickens (seagulls) feed on litter. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Tennessee by Arrested Development
   At some point along the ride, can't remember where, I had to take a detour off the trail.  As I was riding along the road with cornfields on each side, a deer popped its head out of the cornfield.  It was funny - all I saw was a deer head, like it was mounted to a cornstalk. I pulled in to Brockport at 2 pm and decided that I was finished riding for the day.  Brockport is a cute town, as are most of the towns along the canal, and it has a great bike shop, main street, and library, so I had that going for me.  I bought a new tire for The Pig, since the old one was all cracked.  The bike's rear tire is another story: it has NO tread, and is cracked as well.  It needs to be changed bad, but if it ain't broke don't fix it, so I'll wait to change it until the next flat. I had burritos at camp that were so good I could barely stand it.  Refried beans with green chiles, shredded cheese, corn, tortillas, ooh yeah.
The Ride:  Continued east along the Erie Canalway Trail through Spencerport, Rochester, Pittsford, Fairport, and Macedon to Palmyra, where the trail ended and I was shocked by the harshness of the road.  So much traffic!  Such hard surfaces!  Where'd the wildlife go?  From Palmyra I took a bunch of two-lane roads north through Marion and Williamson to Pultneyville, where I hit Lake Ontario and couldn't go north no more.  Where Lake Erie has vineyards, Lake Ontario has orchards.  I turned east on Lake Rd and rolled in to Sodus Point.    I like the name Sodus.  I think it'd be a cool name for a dog.  Maybe some kind of retriever, or sumthin'. I stopped at a gas station in Pittsford to use their toilet, and was impressed by the amount of stuff they had crammed in the 6'x8' toilet room.  There was a furnace, a 40 gallon water heater, a toilet, and a sink, and amazingly there was still plenty of room to move around.  I'm sure it wasn't ADA compliant, and a few building code regulations may be violated here and there, but wow! At Sodus Point I hung out at the beach for a long while.  It was a beautiful afternoon - cool, cloudless, enough of a breeze to keep the flies away.  For some reason, Lake Ontario feels bigger than Lake Erie.  I showered in the bath house (seems appropriate, huh?), read a book for a while, then left at around 6 pm to find a campsite. I found a lovely campsite in an apple orchard - just me, the apples, and the slugs.  As soon as I set up camp, the slugs were all over my stuff.  Yes, the willies surfaced again.  I listened to the Yankees play the Angels on the radio as I made dinner (Velveeta shells & cheese with a small can of tuna and a small can of mixed vegetables, down the hatch). Song-of-the-Day in my Head:  The Distance by Cake
   In Clay I'm meeting a friend who drove from Salt Lake City (Suzi), and we're going to hang out in Clay, drive down to NYC to visit her cousin, etc. for the next week or so.  Suzi's parents live in Clay, so how convenient is that!  Her dad wins my vote for nicest guy on the planet.  I arrived in Clay at around 2:30 pm, and this is the conversation that took place right after I parked the rig: Don:  "Hey hey, what can I get you to drink?" Me:  "Oh, 7-up sounds good."  He brings me a 2-liter of Sprite! Don:  "What about to eat?  A sandwich?  Pizza?  C'mon, you must be hungry!" Me:  "Well, pizza sounds good ..."  Almost before I could finish the sentence, he was in the car and off to buy me a pizza. In Clay I'm going to replace the chain and rear cassette (8-speed 11-28) on the bike.  It's not skipping, but the chain is definitely stretched. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Revolution #9 by The Beatles
In Clay, Suzi and I went to the New York State Fair to eat salt potatoes and look at the animals (human and otherwise), then we went to NYC for a few days.  Highlight of the trip:  I bought a pumice thing at The Body Shop in NYC for my nasty cracked feet, ooh yeah.  In NYC we spent some time in the Brooklyn emergency room, flip flopped around Central Park, attended gospel church in Queens before driving to the eastern tip of Long Island (quite a contrast!), iced a hyperextended knee (separate incident), etc.      The Ride:  Rode east from Clay on Rt 31 through Cicero, Bridgeport, and Lakeport to South Bay, where I turned left onto Rt 13.  I rode Rt 13 north through Verona Beach, Sylvan Beach, Vienna, McConnellsville, and Camden to a thin grey road that took me through Florence to Osceola, where I called it a day.  The quads started screaming at me in Camden.    Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Time For Me To Fly by R.E.O. Speedwagon
The Ride: Rode east from Osceola on Osceola Rd through West Leyden to Boonville, where I turned on to Moose River Rd.  Moose River Rd parallels the Moose River!  I rode east to McKeever, where I turned NE on Rt 28 through Thendara to Old Forge.  At Old Forge I turned on to South Shore Rd, and rode that to Inlet.  South Shore Rd follows the south shore of the Fulton Chain Lakes!    Old Forge must be the schnick-schnock (bric-a-brac, knickknock, etc.) capital of the US.  Lots of arty stores, with little wood carvings, ornaments, etc.  I ate lunch at Old Forge, mostly because I couldn't pass up such fantastic people-watching. At Old Forge, I met the west edge of the Adirondack Mountains.  They were laughing at me - c'mon punk.     
The Ride:  Rode east from Inlet on Rt 28 through Raquette Lake to Blue Mountain Lake, where I turned north onto Rt 28N.  I rode Rt 28N through Long Lake to Newcomb, where I turned east onto Rt 2.  In North Hudson, after riding under I-87, I turned north on Rt 9 to Rt 4, which I rode east for a bit to camp. In Newcomb I ate lunch within sight of Vanderwhacker Mountain (3,386').  I like to say that, as well as type that:  Vanderwhacker Mountain. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Anna Begins by Counting Crows I found a great campsite off of Rt 4.  Very little traffic on Rt 4 to bug me, and the distant drone of Rt 87 lulled me to sleep.  After I set up the tent, cleaned the bike chain, etc., I decided to take a walk around camp, and noticed that I was camped within 50' of a swamp.  D'oh!  Since there was no breeze, a bunch of mosquitoes were bugging me, but they were no match for a couple sticks of Nag Champa (incense).   
Ride uphill at 4 mph for two minutes, thinking ticka-ticka-ticka.  Then ride downhill at 30 mph for fifteen seconds, hands up high and screaming.  Repeat for six hours.  With 28 gears to choose from, I think would've been just fine today with the lowest gear and the highest gear.    The Ride:  Rode east from my lovely campsite on Rt 4 to Moriah, where I hopped on Rt 42 for the rest of the way to Port Henry.  From there I rode south on Rt 9N to a road that crosses Lake Champlain via Champlain Bridge into Chimney Point, Vermont.  I stayed along the east shore of Lake Champlain through Panton to Vergennes, where I turned north on Rt 22A.  Just past Ferrisburg, I hopped on to Greenbush road, which parallels Rt 7 but is much better for biking (read: not as much traffic), and passed through Charlotte to Shelburne, where I hopped on to Rt 7 for the rest of the way into Burlington.    It had been a few days since I showered (I don't shower much), so I held my breath and paid $4 (!) for a foo-foo shower at a health club in Shelburne.  That shower was perhaps the best of the trip - I had my choice of herbal good-for-yer-hair shampoos, and a cotton towel!  Wow! Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Alright Hear This by the Beastie Boys At the health club, I learned that I've gained one pound since the last time I weighed myself (Helena, Montana).  I've ballooned from 159 lbs to 160 lbs! I think I got a bit too close to Burlington before deciding to look for a campsite.  It took me a while, and in the interest of setting up camp, cooking, and eating before dark, I settled on a spot in a field in the 'burbs, within plain sight of six houses.  Not the best campsite, but it's home.
I spent the morning at the Library, then farted around town for the afternoon before heading out to find a campsite.  I ate dinner at the Vermont Pub and Brewery, and had an IPA.  I was going to have a porter, but summertime was still rolling.
6 am:  Wake up after eight hours of sleep.  Go back to sleep. 7:30 am:  Wake up, damnit.  Pack everything up.  It's a windy morning.  Shove off by 8:30 am. 9:30 am:  Stop in Richmond at a bakery / cafe for breakfast.  I had an everything bagel sandwich with a fried egg, cheese, and prosage (vegetarian sausage, ooh yeah).  Read the Burlington paper for a bit.  It's a cloudy day. 10:30 am:  Ride along lovely two-lane country roads through the Green Mountains.  I think that Vermont is greener than, dare I say it, Oregon (gasp!).  Pass a graveyard with the tombstone of somebody that died in 1813. 12 pm:  25 miles and 2,700' of elevation gain later, I'm huffing and puffing at the top of Appalachian Gap (2,356'), or Ap Gap as the locals call it.  For the last half-mile to the top, it's at least a 10% grade.  In Vermont, they're gaps, not passes.  I miss the passes - the last one I did before the Ap Gap was in the Black Hills of South Dakota.  I'm out of practice, though - I forgot my celebratory candy bar for the top.  D'oh!  The clouds have broken up, and it's a bright, sunshiney day.  The Long Trail crosses the road at the top.  I don't know how far south the trail extends, but the sign says that it's 108.9 miles from Ap Gap to Canada along the trail.  Start the long and well-deserved descent to Warren.    1:30 pm:  Stop in Warren for lunch at a frou-frou general store.  Lunch:  two yogurts, an everything bagel, a bit of Vermont cheddar cheese, and a banana.  After lunch, a local guy and I were talking about my route to Maine, and he suggested an alternate way from Rochester to Bethel.  Between these two towns, the Adventure Cycling route takes me along a river, nice and gentle grade.  His suggestion was to ride up and over the ridge between the two towns, which is shorter than they AC route and has excellent views.  A sucker for a good pass, er, gap, I took his suggested route. 3:30 pm:  A few miles and 1,300' of elevation gain later, I'm at the top of the gap.  The views are breathtaking - I can see the White Mountains to the east, in New Hampshire.  Start the descent into Bethel, get the rig up to 47.5 mph. 4:30:  Bethel, chartered in 1779.  After filling up my stove fuel bottle with high-grade unleaded ($0.09), I asked the attendant if there's a grocery store in town.  She pointed at a little teeny building labeled Bethel General Market, and I'm thinking uh-oh, might be Ramen and Chili with Beans again.  Wrong - the market had everything I wanted, and then some.  The people were great - there were lots of people shopping, and everyone knew each other.  Since I stood out like a sore thumb (and stunk like one too), I talked with lots of locals.  A great place. 5:30 pm:  Find camp behind the local pool, a great spot on the lawn, nice and secluded.  I hopped the fence (the pool was closed), and showered in and outdoor shower - hot water! 6:15 pm:  Make and inhale dinner:  Velveeta Shells & Cheese with a can of tuna and a can of mixed veggies.  Dessert:  Junior Mints and a bag of pretzels. 6:45 pm:  After cleaning up, listen to the Yankees play the Indians on the radio for a bit before heading into the tent to escape the mosquitoes and read for a bit.  Right now I'm reading a book about the history of America, my dose of non-fiction.  Next up is a book of short stories from the New Yorker. 9 pm:  Stop reading, go to sleep. The Ride:  Rode east from Burlington on Rt 2 through Williston to Richmond, where I turned south on Main Rd through Huntington, Huntington Center, and Hanksville to Rt 17.  At Rt 17, I turned east and rode up and over Ap Gap.  On the way down, I passed the Mad River Glen ski area ("Ski It If You Can", as the bumper sticker says) and hit Rt 100 at Irasville.  I turned south on Rt 100 and rode through Warren, Granville, and Hancock to Rochester, where I turned east on a little road up and over the ridge to Bethel. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Wait by White Lion.  I know, it's terrible, and I have no idea how it got there.
Today I got to ride across two covered bridges - one just west of Thetford Center and the other just east of East Thetford.  Both were at the bottom of a hill, of course, and the surface of the first bridge was quite bumpy, which I couldn't see due to the shadows (remember, it's covered) - since I was cruising at top speed, I got tossed around a bit but managed to keep the rubber side down.  The second one - smooth as glass.  I rode back and forth over it a couple times.    The Ride:  Rode east from Bethel on Rt 7 to Sharon, where I hooked up with Rt 132 and rode that through South Strafford to Tucker Hill Rd.  I took Tucker Hill Rd through Thetford Center, Thetford Hill, and under I-91 to East Thetford.  I crossed the Connecticut river, entered New Hampshire, and took the River Rd and then Rt 10 north through Orford, Piermont, and Haverhill to North Haverhill.  There I turned right (east) on Rt 116, which turned into Rt 112, and rode that up and over a pass (where the Appalachian Trail crosses, near Mt. Moosilauke) to North Woodstock and then Lincoln.    By the time I got to Lincoln, it was late.  I had 45 minutes to shop for dinner, find a campsite, set up camp, and cook before dark, but I managed to do it with minutes to spare.  I found a great campsite about 15' from the East Branch of the Penugewasset River.  The babble of the rapids lulled me to sleep and also drowned out the traffic noise. In Lincoln there was a Corvette gathering.  They were passing me all day. Highlight-of-the-Day:  On the descent into North Woodstock, I got the rig up to 52.5 mph, the new high speed of the Tour de Moser.  The Pig behaved and didn't give me any twitches. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  "Last Stop: This Town" by the eels.
The last three miles of the ride up to the pass are 9% grade, and the first eight of the downhill are 7% grade.  The top was absolutely lovely - about 70 deg. F, light breeze, bright sunshine, and the view was huge.    The Ride:  Rode east from Lincoln (elev. 800') on Rt 12 up and over Kancamagus Pass (elev. 2,855'), then down through Conway and Center Conway on Rt 113 to Fryeburg, Maine (elev. 500'), where I ate lunch.  From Fryeburg I took Rt 5 northeast to Lovell, then Rt 93 east through Sweden to South Waterford, Rt 37 north east through Waterford and East Waterford, and finally Rt 118 east to Norway / South Paris. I haven't had a broken spoke on this trip, knock on wood.  In fact, I haven't even had to turn a spoke to true either the front or the rear wheels.  Before the trip, I laced a new rear wheel with a Mavic D521 downhill mountain bike rim.  It's way heavy, I remember I could feel the added rotational weight the first time I rode on it, but it's sturdy as hell, so I've got that going for me. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Lovely Host by Xtra Large
   The Ride:  Rode southeast from South Paris on Rt 119 through West Minot to Minot, where I turned east on Rt 121 into Auburn and then Lewiston.  After "showering", grocery shopping, and hanging out at a bookstore in Lewiston, I rode east for a bit on Rt 126 through Sabbatus to Rt 197 east, where I camped. One thing that I've noticed about people that live in Maine:  they don't talk much, and when they do, they usually say "no", or some variation of "no".  A conversation I had last night with a gas station attendant in South Paris: Me:  "Is there a pool or a health club in town?  Somewhere that I could take a shower?" Attendant:  "Nope."  After talking to him, I rode along main street and found a health club in South Paris. Me:  "How about a grocery store?  Is there one in town?" Attendant:  "Let's see - no."  There was a great little grocery store 1/4 mile down the road from the gas station. It was a hot day in Lewiston, and I needed to take a shower no matter what.  The YMCA and the YWCA were closed, there are no hostels or campgrounds in town, so I ended up "showering" in the bathroom of the Save-A-Lot grocery store.  Actually, it went great.  I won't get into details, but no one came in when I was "showering", which was a good thing, and I felt clean and refreshed after the "shower". I walked around the Save-A-Lot for a while, enjoying the air conditioning, buying lots of food, and reading ingredients of various foodstuffs.  See if you can guess the food item with the following ingredients (the answer will be revealed in tomorrow's entry, and no I did not buy it): Mechanically separated chicken, beef tripe, partially defatted cooked beef fatty tissue, beef hearts, water, partially defatted cooked pork fatty tissue, salt.  Less than 2%: mustard, natural flavorings, dried garlic, vinegar, dextrose, sodium erythorbate, sodium nitrite. At camp, it was hot.  Luckily, I bought a little battery-powered fan at the New York State Fair in Syracuse, and it worked great.  It fits perfectly in a little elastic hoop on the inside of the tent, and was aimed right at my head and chest.  Aaah, convection.
The Ride:  Rode east on Rt 197 from Sabbatus through Litchfield Corner and Richmond to Dresden, where I left Rt 197 for a bit to ride the Bog Rd and Rabbit Run Path before hooking up with Rt 194, which I rode through Alna to Rt 215.  I took Rt 215 southeast through Damariscotta Mills and Newcastle to Damariscotta, where I hooked up with Rt 1.  I rode Rt 1 through Waldoboro to Warren, where I hopped on Rt 90 through West Rockport and Rockport to Camden.  I found a great spot to camp at Camden Hills State Park, in full view of the water.    Just east of Dresden, as I was climbing a hill, I met a couple other bike tourers named Steve and Susann, but they were in a car, not on bikes.  We chatted for a bit, I was asking them lots of questions about their trip along the Continental Divide a couple months ago, and then they invited me to their place to rest for a bit.  As I just started the ride, I declined, but I'll probably take them up on their offer when I ride back from Acadia NP, on my way south to Key West.  I'm psyched to see their slide show of their trip this summer, and also just to hang out for a bit. Between Rockport and Camden I rode by a field with nothing but grass and belted galloways.  Rockport is located right on West Penobscot Bay, and about a mile from the water the temperature dropped and I could smell the sea.  Ooh yeah.  As I was riding through Rockport, I thought about how I just rode from the Pacific to the Atlantic oceans, and I smiled. In Camden I stopped at a bike shop to top off my tires, and I talked with the head mechanic / owner for a bit.  He seemed to know a lot about how hydrocarbons, ozonation, free radicals, and fully hydrogenated synthetic rubber (?) relate to the quality of tires.  Mostly I just nodded my head as my eyes glazed over. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Why You'd Want to Live Here by Death Cab For Cutie
According to the Bangor paper, the hottest town in the country yesterday was Fryeburg, Maine, at 98 deg. F.  I wasn't too far east from there.  It's hot, and the humidity is up around 2,754%. The Ride:  Rode east from Camden on an awfully busy Rt 1, with no shoulder.  It was the worst road I've been on so far.  After a stressful half hour, I reached Lincolnville and turned NW on a quiet road to Rt 52, where I turned east.  In Belfast, I hopped on to Rt 1 (this time with a nice, wide shoulder), and rode that through Searsport, Stockton Springs, Verona, Bucksport, Orland, and East Orland to Ellsworth.
