I camped in a clear-cut area just south of town, along Rt 230.    I rode across a great big high oh-my-gosh bridge on the way into Verona, across the Penobscot River.  The best part: I get to ride it again, going the other way, in a couple of days.  Woo-hoo! Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Perfect Candidate by Michael Penn
The Ride:  Rode south, alert and defiant, from Ellsworth on Rt 230 past the eerie kids to Goose Cove Rd, where I turned east to Trenton.  From there I took Rt 3 south onto Mount Desert Island, then east through Eden, Salsbury Cove, and Hulls Cove to the Acadia National Park visitor's center.  After gathering a bunch of maps and observing a minute of silence at 8:46 am, I headed into Bar Harbor to eat lunch.  From there I took Rt 233 west to Rt 198 and then Rt 102 south to Bernard.    A $20 gift certificate to Thurston's Lobster Pound was waiting for me at the Bar Harbor post office (general delivery).  Thanks, Mom & Dad!  Thurston's is located in Bernard, and I ate a 1.58 lb. lobster.  It was great, and I was in quite a food coma afterwards. At Thurston's there was a little kid there with his family.  He kept whining that he wanted his own lobster, but his Dad didn't get him one because all he'd do would play with it.  When the kid was playing with his Dad's lobster claw after the meat was out, he got his finger stuck in the claw and was screaming his head off.  It was kinda funny - the kid wasn't hurt, and most the people in the place were laughing.   
The Ride:  Rode south from Bernard on Rt 102A through Bass Harbor to Ship Harbor, where I did the nature walk.  Afterwards, I took Rt 102 north through Southwest Harbor and Somesville to Rt 198 east and then Rt 3 south to Sargent Drive, which hugs the eastern shore of Somes Sound, to Northeast Harbor.  After eating lunch in Northeast Harbor, I rode on carriage roads for the rest of the day. The carriage roads are great.  Rockefeller Jr. created them for non-motorized use back in the 1930's, and they have gentle grades, lots of shade, and no cars (nice for a change).    I woke up not feeling so hot - I had a sore throat and a headache.  The headache went away, but I had the sore throat all day, and was feeling kinda dizzy.  I found a great place to camp, right off a carriage road near Jordan Pond, so I set up camp kinda early, read a lot, didn't eat much, and went to sleep early.    Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Down by 311
The Ride:  Rode from camp to the top of Cadillac Mountain on the paved road, then back down and clockwise around the Acadia NP Park Loop Road.  After doing the loop, I went back into Bar Harbor to eat lunch, then hopped on Rt 3 through Hulls Cove, Salisbury Cove, and Eden to get off the island and start snaking my way down the east coast.  I rode Rt 3 north into Ellsworth, then took Rt 172 south then west to Surry.    The word of the day would be "blustery".  The top of Cadillac Mountain (elev. 1,530', the highest point on the east coast) had a steady 20 mph wind from the SW, with gusts to 30 mph.  I didn't stay at the top too long - it was a real Griswolds-at-the-Grand-Canyon moment.  There were lots of people at the top - lots of tour buses and all that. I left The Pig at the bottom of the climb to Cadillac Mountain, and it made for an easy climb.  It felt so good that I left it for the Loop Road as well.  It's funny, I like the feel of the bike with The Pig attached, it's more stable, but I can definitely appreciate the added efficiency without that boat anchor dragging me down.  Without The Pig, the bike feels all loosey goosey.  The Loop Road was a nice ride, right along the coast. At the Bar Harbor grocery store I found a little bottle of Classico Basil Pesto, so I had that with some vermicelli for dinner.  It was great.  I didn't drink much water at camp, though, since the water smelled like sewer.  I've never had water that tasted as bad as that (I filled up the CamelBak and my water bottles at the General Store in Surry - consider yourself warned). Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  One Week by the Barenaked Ladies.  Awful, just awful.  That song entered my head in Bar Harbor, and would not let go until the Ellsworth grocery store.
The Ride:  Rode north from Surry on Rt 176 to Rt 1m which I took north and then west through East Orland, Orland, Bucksport, Verona, back over the great bridge outside Verona, Stockton Springs, Searsport, and Belfast.  At Belfast I hopped on Rt 52 and rode that to Lincolnville Center, where I turned west on Rt 235 and then south on Rt 105 to Camden.  In Camden I too Bayview St to the farm with the belted galloways, and I camped near a pond in that area.    Except for the pinecones falling all around me, the campsite was great.  Beautiful weather, and a nice view of the sunset, which happened right over the lake. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Drown by Smashing Pumpkins.  I heard the beginning of the song during the Red Sox game the other night.  Y'know that two-minute part at the very end, where the bass and drums are repeating that quiet 8-beat phrase and the guitars are all feeding back?  Yeah ...
The Ride:  Rode west from Camden on Rt 90 through Rockport, West Rockport, and Warren to Rt 1, which I took west through Waldoboro, Damariscotta, New Castle, and North Edgecombe to Wiscasset.  At Wiscasset, I veered off the ACA route to take Rt 27 north to Steve and Susann's place in Dresden. I met Steve and Susann on the way to Acadia, and I took them up on their offer for a place to stay on the way back.  It was great hanging out with them for the afternoon and evening.  They've done two west-to-east road cross-country bike tours so far, they were Traveling Trainers for Leave No Trace in 2000 and 2001 (they gave me a shovel to help with my Catholes Across America!), and they just got back from riding the Great Divide trail (which I'm hoping to ride next summer) from Canada to Mexico.  We drank beers and chatted about all that stuff in the afternoon, then ate a great dinner and ice cream a bit later.  Afterwards, they showed me their slide show of the Great Divide trip.    Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Dragons Awake! by Guided By Voices
   The Ride:  Rode south from Steve & Susann's on Rt 127 to Woolwich, where I hopped back on the ACA route that took me on a bunch of backroads through Bath, New Meadows, Brunswick, and Freeport.  At Freeport, based on Steve's suggestion, I veered off the ACA route in order to ride through Portland (the ACA route makes a wide arc around Portland).  I took Rt 1 to Yartmouth, where I hopped on Rt 88 through Cumberland Foreside and Falmouth Foreside and then merged back on to Rt 1 into Portland.  I took the Casco Bay Bridge south out of Portland, then veered east to see the Portland Head Light at Fort Williams, the oldest lighthouse in Maine.  I continued on Rt 77 through Cape Elizabeth and Higgins Beach to Rt 207, which I took to Rt 1 and Scarborough.    In Portland, after eating at the largest grocery store of the trip so far, I spent some time riding around the downtown area, especially the Old Port area. Along the 1-mile Casco Bay Bridge, I saw a big rusty red ship called the Mekhanik Vraskov sitting in the bay.  It made me think of that time in 1993, in Bremerhaven, Germany, when my sister Kate, cousin Pat, and I ate cold fish and drank warm beer on a big rusty scary Russian ship. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Gett Off by Prince.
The Ride:  Rode south on Rt 1 fron Scarborough through West Scarborough, Saco, Biddeford, Kennebunk, Wells, Moody, Ogunquit, Cape Neddick, and Kittery to Portsmouth (New Hampshire), where I reconnected with the ACA route and took a bunch of two-lane country roads generally west through Exeter, Kingston, and Danville to East Berry.  I could've veered off of Rt 1 to ride a bit closer to the coast, and on quieter roads, but I really wanna get to Boston on Wednesday, so fast and noisy Rt 1 it is.  It wasn't so bad, there was a big wide shoulder, and lots of miniature golf places to look at.    In East Berry I camped right next to a big cemetery.  It was quite convenient, as the library and a general store were within short walking distance.  In the restroom of the general store, a sign was posted on the wall that read:  Stop - Peeing on the toilet seat "Please". Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Pets by Porno For Pyros
The Ride:  Rode southwest from East Derry to a bunch of quiet, hilly 2-lane roads through West Windham to Rt 111, where, annoyed by all the turns that the ACA route had me taking, I veered off the route and stayed on Rt 111 southwest to Hudson.  In Hudson I hopped on Rt 3A south, entered Massachusetts, and rode through Tyngsburgh to North Chelmsford, where I turned south on to Rt 4.  In Chelmsford I turned onto Rt 27 and rode that through South Chelmsford and North Acton to Acton.  In Acton I got back on the ACA route for the rest of the way into Boston, and rode Rt 119, Strawberry Hill Rd, Barrett's Mill Rd, and Lowell Rd to Concord.  At Concord I turned on to Walden St., rode by Walden Pond, then traveled generally east on Baker Bridge Rd, Sandy Pond Rd, Trapelo Rd (said "hey" to the house where Steve Paige grew up), Smith Rd, Concord Ave, Mill St, Trapelo St, and Main St (lots of turns!) to Watertown, where I hopped on the Charles River Bike Path for the rest of the way into downtown Boston. By veering off the ACA route, I chopped off about ten miles and who knows how much elevation gain.  Besides, it's tough to get in a good bike touring groove when you're always looking the map and turning every mile on unsigned roads. The ride from Acton into Boston was simply lovely.  The weather was great, the roads were generally quiet, and I got to see a lot of historical stuff.  From Acton to Concord I followed the same route as the line of march of the Acton minutemen on April 19, 1775.  In Concord, I went out of my way to ride over North Bridge, the site where the Colonial militia men met the British Regulars, and where the "shot heard round the world" was fired. Song-of-the-Day in my Head:  Lionel Richie's version of Easy, by the Commodores. You know, "easy like Sunday morning."  I heard it in a 7-11 when I was filling up my CamelBak, and it stuck.    Today it struck me that it's usually one of three kinds of drivers that cut me off or pass too close: 1.  Drivers over 75 years old. 2.  Male drivers over 60 years old, driving SUVs. 3.  Drivers talking on their cell phones. Today I happened to see all three either cut me off or pass too close.
Now, when I saw "in Boston", I don't mean out in some damn suburb.  I stayed in a condo in Beacon Hill, a few doors north of Boston Common (on Walnut St, between Beacon St and Chestnut St, near the State House at the bottom of the map) and near Acorn Street, the "most photographed street in America".  The condo is vertically oriented, five stories high, and I stayed in a little room on the top floor.  It was a true Boston experience, and it was definitely a highlight of the trip.        It's funny how things work out.  The condo belongs to Steve Paige's Aunt and Uncle (I met Steve while riding through Maine).  Don and Louisa live in Boston with their kids Sarah, Sam, and Georgia, and their two standard poodles Jack and Zoe.  Thank you, Don and Louisa, for your generous hospitality.  It was great to meet you, and I can't imagine a better way to see Boston. 9/19 Woke up, grabbed a bagel, and walked the Freedom Trail.  The weather was gorgeous, the historical sites were fascinating, and the trail is a great way to see the city.   At the Bunker Hill visitor's center I saw some wonderful dioramas of the battle. Then I walked the 275 steps to the top of the memorial, for a wonderful view of the city. Another highlight of the visitor's center was that I got to use a waterless urinal for the first time. Yippee! After walking the trail, I took a ferry back to Long Wharf, and ate lunch at an Italian restaurant in Boston's North End.  In the evening I ate dinner with the Paige's, then walked the dogs with Louisa. 9/20  Another beautiful day.  At 10 am I took an interesting and informative hour-long tour of Harvard, led by a senior undergrad majoring in Government.  Then I found the offices of Dewey, Cheetham, and Howe and browsed the stacks at the Harvard Book Store.    After that, at 2 pm, I took a bland 1/2 hour tour of M.I.T., led by a senior undergrad majoring in Mechanical Engineering.  The highlight of the tour was the $2.25 falafel sandwich I had from a street vendor at M.I.T.  Soooo goooood ... In the evening, I joined the Paige's in seeing an outdoor production of the opera Carmen in the Boston Common.  Can you stand it? Song-of-the-Day in my Head:  Joy by Lucinda Williams.  I heard it in a store in Harvard Square, and it stuck.
Guy: "How's it going?", in a thick Boston accent Me: "Great." Guy: "Where you headed?" Me: "Key West." Guy: "No kidding." This is the funny part.  After taking a few seconds to let it digest, he shouts to me, as I'm already well past him: Guy: "Lucky Bastard!"    The Ride:  Rode from Boston to Acton in reverse of the way that I came in, along the Charles River.  From Acton I rode west and then southwest on a bunch of two-lane roads with names like Nashoba Rd, Sawyer Hill Rd, and Solomon Pond Rd through Littleton, Harvard, Bolton, South Berlin, and Northborough to Westborough.  I camped just southwest of I-90.    Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  a song from Carmen, the one with castanets.  I think it's the one that Carmen sings for Don Jose.
   While riding between Oxford and Dudley I passed just north of Lake Chargoggagoggmanchauggauggagoggchaubunagungamaugg (!).  Everyone!  Three times fast!   Chargoggagoggmanchauggauggagoggchaubunagungamaugg is an Indian word meaning "the boundary lake" and "You fish on your side, I fish on my side, nobody fishes in the middle." In Crystal Lake I went for a swim in, you guessed it, Crystal Lake.  The temperature was great, but the bottom was a bit murky, so I got the willies a couple times when my foot brushed up against some vegetation.  At least I hope it was vegetation. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Rusty Cage by Soundgarden
The hills of Connecticut are impressing me.  You have to have a sense of humor about the whole thing, otherwise you'll go mad.  Imagine riding up a 6% grade and rounding a corner thinking you'll see the descent, only to see more climbing.  D'oh!  The routes I've been riding in Connecticut are either up or down, not much level.  But I'll take hills over riding flat roads where you can see you're route stretch out in front of you for 20 miles anyday (think Midwest). The Ride:  Rode west from Crystal Lake on Rt 140 and a buncha two-lane roads to Windsor Locks, on the west side of the Connecticut River.  From there I took Rt 540 and then Rt 189 to Granby, where I turned west on Rt 20 and then Rt 219 through New Hartford to Rt 202.  Right on Rt 202 (west) to Torringford, where I turned south on Rt 183 and then south on Rt 4 to Harwinton.  Right on Rt 118, and then left on Rt 222 (south) to Thomaston, after passing under I-8.  From there I took Rt 6 to Watertown.    After the ride, at the grocery store in Watertown, I almost fell asleep standing in line at the registers.  Today's ride spanked me, 72 miles of hills.  The kid cashier was asking me about my backpack (a Gregory with a CamelBak 100 oz. bladder), and I had to really concentrate to stay awake and talk to him. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Chalkhills and Children by XTC.  That one's a mystery - don't know how it got in my head. Today was the first day of fall.  I've ridden in three seasons so far - yikes.
The Ride:  Rode west and then south from Watertown on Rt 6 through Minortown, North Woodbury, and Woodbury to Southbury, where I rode under I-84 and took a bunch of byootiful two-lane roads south to Rt 34, near Riverton.  From there I went west on Rt 34 for a bit to Stevenson, where I hopped on Rt 111 and rode south through East Village to Monroe.  After updating the website in Monroe, I took Rt 59 south through Upper Stepney and Easton to Fairfield.    Fairfield is where my cousin Chris lives with his wife Kristy, their kids Grant and Lauren, and their yellow lab Caymus.  My Aunt Kathy (Chris' mom) came over for dinner, and it was great to hang out with them for an evening. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  (Listen to the) Flower People by Spinal Tap.  When I pulled in to a gas station in Minortown, I heard somebody say "listen" and then a pause before continuing.  During the pause I was waiting for him to continue "to what the flower people say".  I was obviously still tired from yesterday's ride.
After riding around the driveway with Grant for a few minutes, I took off at around 9:30 am.  I saw more roadkill than usual in the shoulder today.  Mostly squirrels, but also some raccoons and a couple of woodchucks. Today while eating dinner, I made the mistake of reading the ingredients in one of my favorite things to eat for dinner, and was horrified to learn that it contains "partially hydrogenated lard."  Yikes.  First one to guess the food (in the Guestbook), or the closest guess, wins a personalized journal entry for tomorrow's ride.  Good luck! The Ride:  Rode northwest from Fairfield on Rt 58 through Redding Ridge and Bethel to Danbury, where I continued on Rt 39 and entered New York.  After getting lost for a bit around Ball Pond, I surfaced at Haviland, and took Rt 22 north.  Just south of Pawling I turned left (west) on Rt 55 and rode that up and over a few ridges through West Pawling, Billings, Freedom Plains, and Arlington to Poughkeepsie (pron. puh-kip-sie, I still can't get it right).  I crossed the FDR Mid-Hudson bridge (a highlight of the day), and found camp just outside of Highland.    Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Have You Ever Seen The Rain by CCR.  I heard it in a gas station in West Pawling after lunch, and it stuck.
The Ride:  Rode out of Highland and immediately got lost.  I wound up on a road called Pancake Batter Road, or something like that, and it spit me out at Clintondale.  OK, now I know where I am.  I rode west on Rt 44 / 55 through Ardonia, Modena, Ireland Corners, and Gardiner to Rt 7, where I turned left (SW) and rode through Shawangunk, Dwaarkill, Ulsterville and Burlingham.  Just before passing over I-17 I turned right and rode a 2-lane road that parallelled I-17 to Wurtsboro.  From there I turned SW and rode Rt 209 through Westbrookville, Cuddebackville, Godeftroy, Huguenot, Port Jarvis, crossed the NY - PA state line, rode to Milford PA, then crossed into NJ to Montague.  From there I rode the Old Mine Rd to Layton. It started raining before Port Jarvis, and didn't stop for the rest of the day, a very, very wet day.  I haven't ridden through rain like this yet.  Up until now, it's been spotty - more showers than steady rain.  This is steady.  I hid in the Port Jarvis library for a while, and the Doppler Radar looked almost comical.  It was just one big blob of green, indicating rain.    Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  The Spark That Bled by The Flaming Lips
   The Ride:  Rode sw from Layton on Rt 615 through the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area, a beautiful ride, through Walpack Center and Millbrook Village to Delaware Water Gap, after crossing the Delaware River into PA.  I then rode Rt 611 south through Portland, Mount Bethel, and Martins Creek to Easton, where I crossed back into NJ, ate lunch at a small but not-so-quaint market in Phillipsburg, and continued south on the River Rd through Carpentersville and, via Rt 627 and a detour on Church Rd, Milford.    Today was not what I would call a great day for a bike ride.  It started rainy, the rain tapered off by 11 am but the humidity and warm mugginess stayed around.  Oh, and I had three flat tires.  The last flat I had before today was a month ago, sometime well before Syracuse, NY.  Pennsylvania?  I say Glassylvania. Flat #1:  Near Millbrook Village, I heard a strange sound coming from The Pig.  The tire had gone flat, the first time in the entire Tour.  I took the tube out, inflated it, and couldn't hear a leak.  I searched the tire for any sharp pointy objects and, after finding none, put a new tube in and continued on. Flat #2:  Between Martins Creek and Easton, the rear tire went flat in a hurry.  Took the tube out, inflated it, found the leak, patched it, took out the glass that was in the tire, and continued on.  Ugh. Flat #3:  Just outside of Milford, I heard that dreaded wubba coming from The Pig, and decided that I had fixed enough flats for the day.  I found the first suitable campsite (behind a deserted barn), and made camp.  Going to sleep with a flat tire was a bit like going to sleep with dirty dishes to wash, but I didn't care.  I was sick of fixing flats for the day. In Delaware Water Gap I crossed the Appalachian Trail.  Pretty cool.
In the calm and clarity of the morning light, I found a piece of glass wedged in one of The Pig's tire's treads, so I took it out, patched the tube, and headed down the road confident that it wouldn't go flat for at least 30 minutes. The Ride:  Rode to Milford via Church Rd and Rt 519 (the detour), continued south to Frenchtown, then picked up a great crushed stone bike path that parallels the Delaware River through Byram and Stockton to Lambertville.  From there I headed east on Rt 518 through Woodsville, Hopewell, and Blawenburg to Rt 206, which I took south into Princeton.    The wind today was swirly and gusty, probably to do with Isidore.  A beautiful day for a bike ride, though. In Princeton I'm staying with my friends Sam and Cate Blanchard, their kids Bjorn and Ursula, their great dane Cosmo, and their cats Zeke and George.  I used to work with Sam in Portland, Oregon before we both moved on to greener pastures. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Undone - The Sweater Song by Weezer.
Today was a short day, which was nice.  I've got 90 miles to go to Chadds Ford, PA, my next stop, which is too much for one day but a nice lazy two days. The Ride:  Rode from Princeton to Lambertsville the same way that I came in, although I took Rt 601 from Princeton to Rt 518 instead of Rt 206.  At Lambertville I crossed the Delaware River into PA, passed through New Hope, and headed SW on Lower Mountain Rd.    I've said it before, and I'll say it again.  It's funny how things work out.  It's about 4:30 pm, I'm riding along Lower Mountain Road, and I see this Subaru Outback pull into a driveway up ahead.  When I reach the driveway, there's a guy standing there, and he asks me if I'm on a bike tour.  We get to talking, and he offers me a place to stay for the night, at his place.  Ken and his wife Barb have toured by bike before, and tonight I'm staying in their guest bedroom.  How 'bout that?  Thanks, Ken and Barb!
   Rt 30 and Rt 100 were, for the most part, obnoxiously busy.  I veered from the ACA route to get to Chadds Ford, and experienced suburban Philly traffic in all of its glory.  Yikes. Chadds Ford is where my friend John's architecural office is located.  He and I worked on a project in 1998 when I was living in Portland, and we've loosely been keeping in touch since then.  I threw the rig in his car, and we drove the rest of the way (seven miles, not much of a cheat) to Kennett Square.  John and Laura, his wife, are in the process of remodeling a huge old barn into a 8,000 sq.ft. home.  It's a huge project, and should be done in the next twenty years or so.  We went out to eat at a great mexican restaurant where the waitress kept asking us "Do you need anything?" instead of, say, "Is everything ok?" or "How is everything?"   
The Ride:  Rode west from Kennett Square on Old Baltimore Pike, which parallels Rt 1, through Avondale, Jennersville, and Oxford to Nottingham, where I turned northwest onto Rt 272 through Little Britain and Wakefield.  At Chestnut Leve I turned west off of Rt 272 on to River Rd, and took that to Rt 372.  I took Rt 372 across the Susquehanna River, turned left (south) on Rt 74, which turned into Rt 165 when I reached Maryland, and rode that through Whiteford, Pylesville, and Federal Hill to Jarrettsville.    It was a good route, with a big wide shoulder, but not the most peaceful.  Except for River Rd, I saw a lot of dump trucks, more than usual. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Amado Mio by  Pink Martini
The Ride:  Rode south from Jarrettsville on Rt 146 through Hess to Manor Rd, where I continued south through Sweet Air and then turned sw on Dulaney Valley Rd.  I skirted around the south side of Loch Raven Reservoir (best said with a Scottish accent) on Loch Raven Rd, Providence Rd, Seminary Ave, and Bellona Ave to Rt 139.  At Rt 139 I turned south and headed into Baltimore via Rt 139, Lake Ave, Roland Ave, University Pkwy (went right by Johns Hopkins University), and St. Paul St.  Before splashing into Chesapeake Bay, I turned west to Ellicott City via Rt 144 (Lombard St and Frederick Ave).  I stayed on Rt 144 to West Friendship, where I turned south on Rt 32.  In Glenelg I hopped on Ten Oaks Rd, rode that through Dayton, turned right on Highland Rd, turned right on Brighton Dam Rd, turned left on Rt 650, turned right on Rt 108, then turned right on Dominion Dr.    In Sandy Spring I'm staying with Anne and Joe Connor, parents of my friend Steve in SLC.  Anne made a big pasta dinner and a great apple pie, which hit the spot.  After that, we walked around and found glowworms.  Ever seen fireflies?  Same thing, except worms.  I did a load of wash and hung the clothes outside to dry, which was kinda stupid since it was 4,000% humidity.  They were sopping wet the next morning.   
   The Ride:  Rode west on Rt 108 to Baltimore Pike Rd (I think), where I turned north and then west on Gold Mill Rd (I think) to Rt 97, where in Brookeville I turned north and then a quick left on Brookville Rd.  Between there and D.C., I took Rt 108, Muncaster Rd, Rt 115, Shady Grove Rd (busy - that's where I crossed I-270 at the tail end of morning rush hour), Darnestown Rd, Glen Mill Rd, South Glen Rd, Democracy Blvd, Newbridge Rd, Kentsdale Dr, Bradley Rd (Rt 191), Broad Branch Rd, and, finally, the Rock Creek Bike Path.    While riding by the Chevy Chase Country Club, I couldn't help but think of Irwin M. Fletcher, the Underhills, and Mr. & Mrs. & Mrs. Alan Stanwyk. In D.C. I met up with a good friend from SLC, Mel, and we hung out for the evening.  She was in D.C., specifically Dupont Circle, for work - funny how things work out.  We had a few beers at a bar with the largest beer selection I've ever seen (she sampled Norwegian and Greek beers, I had a couple English ales), went to eat at a Malaysian restaurant with her cousin, and then I crashed on her swank hotel room floor.  It was nice to escape the high humidity for an evening.
Friday 10/04 I took guided tours of the Library of Congress and the Supreme Court.  Then I spent a couple hours wandering around the National Gallery of Art.  The East Wing, designed by I.M. Pei, is amazing - I enjoyed the building as much as the collections.  I then went to the International Syp Museum, but balked at the $11 admission (all the others were free).  At 7 pm I went back to the Library of Congress to watch a 1950 movie called I Want To Live! for free. After I got back to the hostel, I stayed up for a bit talking to people from all over the world - from Germany, Portland (Oregon), the Czech Republic, St. Louis, etc.  Most of the people staying there speak English, and some of them have gooder English than me.  Hostels are great - most everyone is open, and interested to hear where you're from, where you've been, where you're going, etc. Saturday 10/05 First I went to the National Air & Space museum with a guy named Burke who's also staying at the hostel.  After oohing and aahing at some of the stuff they have, we split up, and I spent a buncha time at the National Museum of American History and then a quick visit to the National Building Museum.  Not much stuff at National Building Museum, but it's a beautiful building, especially the interior.  After that, I visited the National Museum of Natural History until they kicked us out at 5:30 pm.  I hung out for a bit at a bookstore, reading this and that, then went back to the hostel, cooked dinner, and played cards for a couple of hours with five other people staying there.  It was a great time. I stayed in a 8-person dorm in the hostel, and most of the people in the room weren't the same as those last night.  After saying goodnight in our respective languages (Slovak, Hebrew, Danish, Japanese, and English), I went to sleep fast after a long day of walkin' around.  Enough of this walking, I'm looking forward to getting back on the bike.
The Ride:  Rode back through Rock Creek Park, crossed the Potomac River via the Arlington Memorial Bridge after seeing the monuments, then rode the Mt. Vernon Bike Path all the way down to, you guessed it, Mt. Vernon, the historic home of George Washington.  From there I rode Rt 235 and Rt 1 to Lorton, then Rt 600 west, Rt 123 northwest, and Rt 645 northwest through Clifton to Centreville.    In Centreville I'm spending the night with my cousin Tom Carmody, his wife Rebecca, their kids Molly, Ethan, and Sydney, and their jack russell terrier Mattie.  I haven't seen Tom and Rebecca in over ten years, I think we figured out, so it's great to see and visit with them outside of a big crazy family setting.  I got there at about 4 pm, Tom and I visited Manassas National Battlefield Park, where the first battle of the Civil War took place.  Then we ate dinner and talked about all sorts of stuff for the rest of the night.
The Ride:  After eating a big breakfast at the Carmodys, including a bowl of Molly's favorite cereal, I rode south from Centreville on Rt 28, a four-lane divided highway with a shoulder that looks like a gravel and glass dumping ground, through Manassas to Rt 619, which I took southeast to Rt 611.  My mood instantly improved when I turned south on Rt 611, as it's a deserted two-lane road meandering through farmland.  I hooked back up with the ACA route and took Rts 611, 612, 646, 616, 627, 651, 628, 626, and 607 to Fredericksburg.  In Fredericksburg I rode through the Fredericksburg Spotsylvania National Military Park (where Confederate Commander R.E. Lee said, "It is well that war is so terrible - we should grow too fond of it!") on Rts 638 and 636, then camped off a dirt road off Rt 608 (just before reaching Rt 17 Byp). Rt 28 was a fast road, but not a great road for bicycling.  Every now and then I'd see a separate paved bike path alongside the road.  So, I'd take it, only to have it dead end in less than a quarter mile.  It was kinda frustrating, so I just held my breath and stayed on Rt 28. Note to self:  When camping within 100 yards of train tracks, hang out for 15 minutes or so to see if there's much train traffic.  After I set up the tent, the train traffic picked up, both passenger and freight.  D'oh!    Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  End Of The Line by Concrete Blonde
The Ride:  Rode south from Fredericksburg on Rts 608, 633, and 607 to Guinea.  From there I went southwest on Rts 606 and 632 to Cedon, which is right near Rt 1.  Then I made my way south, parallel to Rt 1, on Rts 661, 603, 684, 685, 738, and 667 to Ashland.  After picking up some stuff at the Post Office, I continued south on Rts 626 and 623 to Richmond, where I snaked my way through town on Rts 161 and then southeast on Rt 60 and Darbytown to camp, just before passing under I-295.    As I was walking the bike out of camp, I noticed the rear tire was dead flat.  D'oh!  Not the best way to start the ride.  So, I patched the tube, removed the piece of metal from the tire, and found a piece of wire that was also lodged in the tire, at a different location, but hadn't punctured the tube yet.  They may have been remnants of yesterday's ride in the 'burbs. The highlight of the day was the package of goodness waiting for me at the Ashland post office.  My mom sent me a buncha homemade cookies, and a couple of books (store-bought, not homemade books).  I ate most of the cookies standing in the post office lobby, and was glad that I had another 30 miles to ride as I needed to work some of those cookies off. Just outside of Cedon I passed a field with about ten vultures circling low, at about tree level, above a family graveyard (only about four headstones).  It was about the eeriest thing I've ever seen.
The Ride:  Rode southwest from Richmond on Darbytown Road, left the ACA route and hooked up with Rt 5, and rode that for 42 miles through Charles City to Williamsburg.  From there I rode south to oh-so-historic Jamestown (where the first representative assembly in the New World convened in 1619), took the free ferry across the James River to Scotland, and rode Rt 31 to Dendron.  I rode southeast from Dendron for a bit, back on the ACA route, and camped in the woods across from a cotton field. I took Route 5 instead of the ACA route, based on Mr. Rosecrans' suggestion, and it turned out to be a great road.  The surface was great, most of it was under a canopy of trees, and even though it didn't have any shoulder to speak of, the traffic was very light.  Also, it went right by a buncha old plantations, most built in the early 1700s.    After buying lunch and dinner at the not-so-quaint mega-huge grocery store in Williamsburg, located in the Ye Olde Towne Shoppinge Centere, or something like that, I rode around for a bit, looking at a buncha old buildings. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Gypsy Road by Cinderella.  Yes, THAT Cinderella, the 80's hair metal band.  I saw a road called Gypsy Road, and that was all it took.  I can still picture the lead singer, king of the hair farmers, flapping his lips in the video about how his gypsy road can't take him home.  Aaaaaaaaaugh!  Make it stop! I can't remember the last time I've seen a cotton field.  After dinner I went over and picked a piece of cotton, and was surprised how easy it came out of its "shell".  I didn't loiter for too long, though, for fear the hound dogs would start barking.  I've entered the land of hound dogs, and I like to hear them howl at me when I ride past.    At camp, the mosquitoes were out in full force.  Instead of seeking shelter in the tent, I tried to light a couple of Nag Champa incense sticks since the air was still, but no go.  There's hardly any incense left on the sticks - it's rubbed off after being jostled around in the handlebar bag since Port Townsend, Washington.  Oh well, the tent it is.
The Ride:  Rode southeast from Dendron on a buncha quiet roads (I'm not even gonna name 'em - who cares?) through Central, Isle of Wight, Suffolk, crossed into North Cackalackee, rode through Holly Grove, then picked up Rt 158 for the rest of the way into Elizabeth City.    For the first 40 miles, with no headwind and the roads flat as a pancake (mmm ... pancake), I averaged 14.6 mph.  But, at 11 am, the winds picked up, and the average for the day dropped to 13.5 mph. Good thing I had a NC state map with me - Elizabeth City is just off the ACA maps, and is a big town with a grocery store.  If I would've stayed on the ACA maps, I'm sure it would've been Chili without Beans from some podunk store for dinner. Camped in a swamp - I didn't have much of a choice.  After all, I'm riding through the Great Dismal Swamp - how's that for an oxymoron?  Got to camp at 6 pm, and it was already dark.  By 6:45, after everything was set for the night and I sat down to dinner (rigatoni with spag sauce and parmesan cheese, the real cheese not the junk from the green container), it was officially dark.  And humid.  And lots of mosquitoes.
If you read this by the end of the day tomorrow, click on this and wait for the radar loop to load.  Then kick back and thank your lucky stars you're not me.  It's kinda amusing, in a scary sort of way.  See where it says "HSE" in the lower right hand corner?  Yeah, that's me.  It stands for Hatteras sumthin' or other. Severe Weather Alert from the National Weather Service  ...SEVERE WEATHER OUTLOOK NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE NEWPORT-MOREHEAD CITY NC 829 AM EDT FRI OCT 11 2002  ...SLIGHT RISK OF SEVERE THUNDERSTORMS WITH ISOLATED TORNADOS THIS AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT...  THUNDERSTORMS WILL BE WIDESPREAD OVER EASTERN NORTH CAROLINA LATE THIS AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT IN ADVANCE OF TROPICAL STORM KYLE. A FEW OF THE THUNDERSTORMS COULD BE SEVERE WITH DAMAGING WINDS...AND ISOLATED TORNADOS WILL BE POSSIBLE AS WELL. THE MAIN CHANCE OF SEVERE WEATHER WILL BE BETWEEN 4 PM AND 4 AM TONIGHT.  KEEP ALERT TO THE POSSIBILITY OF THREATENING WEATHER THIS AFTERNOON AND TONIGHT. IF YOU BEGIN TO HEAR THUNDER...THAT IS THE TIME TO CONSIDER SEEKING SHELTER. LISTEN TO NOAA WEATHER RADIO FOR THE LATEST WEATHER CONDITIONS AND INFORMATION...OR TUNE TO LOCAL MEDIA TO KEEP ABREAST OF THE LATEST WEATHER TRENDS. The Ride:  Rode east from Elizabeth City on Rt 158 to Barco, where I turned south and rode through Coinjock, Aydlett, Poplar Branch, Grandy, Jarvisburg, Harbinger, Point Harbor, and Kitty Hawk to Kill Devil Hills.   
   For the first 60 miles today, from Kill Devil Hills to Buxton, I averaged 18.8 mph, which is just plain flying (usually I average 14 mph if it's flat and there's no wind).  At Buxton I turned west, so my average for the day was reduced to 16.4 mph, which is still the fastest average of the Tour to date. The Ride:  Rode south from Kill Devil Hills on Rt 12 through Nags Head, Rodanthe, Waves, Salvo, Avon, Buxton, and Frisco to Hatteras, where I took a 40 min. ferry to Ocracoke Island.    The hostel was great, as usual.  When I got there yesterday afternoon, it was just another guy and I.  Then a group of kayakers rolled in that got blown off the water due to the storm.  Later I met Sara and Virginia, who live in Wilmington.  They offered their place for me to stay at (Wilmington is a couple days down the road), so I've got that going for me.  The whole group hung out on the porch watching the rain come down in buckets.  I was glad to be there, not just for the roof over my head, but also for the company. In Waves I watched a kite boarding competition.  Think giant kites and snowboards - it was insane.  These guys could fly twenty feet in the air, doing flips and twists, and sometimes land on the water with the board, sometimes not, which made for some spectacular crashes.  It was absolutely crazy. In Ocracoke I went to Howard's Pub and had a crab cake sandwich that was so good I could barely stand it.  I also had a beer from a North Carolina brewery (Highland St. Terese's Pale Ale), which was not so good. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Testify by Rage Against The Machine
The Ride:  After taking the ferry from Ocracoke to Cedar Island, I rode southwest from Cedar Island on Rt 12 to Rt 70, then continued through Stacy, Williston, Otway, Bettie, and Beaufort to Morehead City.  From there I took Rt 24 through Bogue, Cape Carteret, and Cedar Point to Swansboro.    Last night the mosquitoes were ruthless.  I set up camp in record time, since I couldn't stand still for more than a second without them swarming over me.  During the night, they were hanging out on the inside of the tent fly, which was creepy.  There were literally hundreds of them - it was like the movie The Birds. The ferry ride was great.  The weather was nice, and we were way out there, couldn't see any land for a stretch.  I started riding at noon, and had a great tailwind that pushed me right down the road.  Right after I set up camp and made dinner, it started raining.  Good timing, but with the tent fly sealing in the heat and humidity (I had a pot of pesto pasta that was making things a bit warm in the tent), I had my own sweat lodge for a while.  I thought my days of eating dinner in my skivvies were over, but guess not.
The Ride:  Rode west from Swansboro on Rt 24 to Hubert, where I turned south on Rt 172 and entered Camp Lejeune Marine Corps Base.  I rode through Camp Lejeune for 20 miles and was hoping to see tanks and troops crossing the road, doing training exercises, but as it was only 9 am, they were probably still all asleep, lazy bums.  Just south of the New River, near Sneads Ferry, I turned south on Rt 210 and rode that right along the Atlantic Ocean to Surf City, where the road turned inland to Hampstead.  From there I rode Rts 210, 1002 and 1318 to Wilmington.      I got to Virginia and Sara's place at around 3 pm.  I met them at the hostel in Kitty Hawk a couple days ago, and they're students at the University of North Carolina.  First thing I did at their place was start a load of wash.  After the washing machine blew up, probably due to the stink of the clothes involved, we finished the job later that evening at a laundromat / bar in downtown Wilmington, which turned out to be a great place to hang out for an hour or so.

THE NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE HAS EXTENDED THE FLOOD WATCH THROUGH TONIGHT FOR THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES...  IN NORTH CAROLINA THIS WATCH INCLUDES 6 COUNTIES...    The Ride:  Rode south on River Rd from Wilmington through Carolina Beach and Kure Beach to Fort Fisher, where I took a 30 min. ferry to Southport.  After stuffing my face with cookies in Southport, I rode west on Rt 211 to Supply, then southwest on Rt 17 through Shallotte to Rt 57, where I entered South Carolina.    Shallotte, of course, is home of Independent Championship Wrestling.  Thankfully, I didn't see any of the wrestlers walking the streets. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  The Silver Hawaiian by Helmet
   Good deed of the day:  I saved a turtle from almost certain death.  It was crossing the road, and very slowly at that since it was a turtle and all.  I picked it up from the center of the road, and put it in the weeds on the side of the road.  Of course, it probably walked back onto the road and got crushed by a truck as I was riding down the road feeling like a good samaritan, but hey, it doesn't hurt to try. The Ride:  Rode southwest from Brooksville just to the south of Big Swamp on Rt 57.  At Wampee I contined on Rt 90, turned northwest on Rt 31 for a bit, then took Rt 905 west into Conway.  From there, I rode Rt 701 south through Bucksport, over the Great Pee Dee River to Yauhannah, where I turned west onto Rt 261 and then Rt 513 to Pleasant Hill.  From there, I continued southwest on Rt 513 and then Rt 41 into Andrews.    After visiting the grocery store and the library in Andrews, I set out to find a place to camp along Rt 41, which is the dividing line between the Boggy Swamp (yes!  I love these names!) and the Johnson Swamp.  In other words, I had a tough time finding a spot.  I pulled off onto a dirt road that looked promising, only to run into a hunter with no teeth that was just getting out of his pickup to go shoot some more deer.  Uh, ok, I think I'll go down Rt 41 a ways.  I eventually found a spot that wasn't saturated with water from the rains that Kyle dished out, but the mosquitoes were out in full force.  I slopped on some Natrapel, and they didn't bother me no more.  The stuff works, and it doesn't give me that skin-searing feeling like DEET does. Andrews is the hometown of Chubby Checker, so they've got that going for them.
The Ride:  Rode southwest from Andrews on Rt 41 through Jamestown, then a buncha quiet two-lane roads that wound their way through a path of destruction left behind by 1989's Hurricane Hugo, on Rts 48, 125, and 171 through Bethra and Witherbee to Rt 402, which I took to Rt 17A and Moncks Corner.  From there I took more quiet roads west-southwest through Ridgeville to Walterboro.    In Walterboro I found a great campsite among the pines, right near the intersection of Rts 17A and 63 and right before entering the Great Swamp. Song-in-my-Head for the first half of the Day:  But Anyway by Blues Traveler Song-in-my-Head for the second half of the Day:  Burn One Down by Ben Harper   
The Ride:  Rode south from Walterboro on Rt 17A through Hendersonville and Yemasse to Pocotaligo, where I peeled off the ACA route (for the rest of the Tour) and hopped on a frontage road that parallels I-95.  I rode that through Ridgeland and Switzerland (!) to Hardeeville, where I ate a yogurt-banana lunch and continued south on Rt 17.  Upon close inspection of the map, I saw that Rt 17 turns into a restricted interstate right before Savannah, so I turned west on Rt 170 into Port Wentworth, Georgia, then took Rt 25 the rest of the way into Savannah. Right when I crossed the Savannah River into Georgia, the first thing I saw were palm trees.  I didn't see any in South Carolina. I got to the hostel in Savannah at 2 pm, only to find out that they don't open until 5 pm.  OK, so I rode around Savannah for a few hours, and it was great.  I stayed in the historic district, and rode by all of the squares (the hostel is located a couple blocks away from Monterey Square).  The historic district is a mess of restored houses, old churches, monuments, cobblestone streets, shady sidewalks, and the lush green squares.      I went back to the hostel at 5 pm, showered (aaah), made dinner, watched a bit of the first game of the world series, then went to bed.  I was wiped after today's ride.  The first 75 miles were getting from Walterboro to Savannah, and the rest were spent tooling around town.  The hostel is an odd one - it's a very sterile environment, no books to read, no art on the walls, and not many people staying there, which surprised me since it's the weekend at all.  The best part was that I had the whole dorm to myself, so I could switch beds every now and then if I wanted, but I didn't.   
The Ride (this is an easy one):  Rode south on Rt 17 from Savannah through Richmond Hill, Midway, Riceboro, and Retreat to South Newport.    Mosquitoes rule my world.  They were out in droves at camp, so once again it was a mad dash to set up the tent and get inside.  I escaped relatively unscathed, but these mosquitoes seem to be particularly ruthless.  Another observation:  the roadkill in Georgia smells worse than in any other state, possibly because the humidity is still hovering at around 5,000%.
The hostel consists of a few big wood domes (one common room / kitchen, one staff quarters, and the other a big, huge library) and a bunch of tree houses and huts to sleep in.  I arrive at about 2 pm, showered, then checked myself into the Dragon's Lair, a hut located near the pond.  Lots of ducks, lots of frogs, no mosquitoes in the hut, it was great.      A big banana spider whose web canopied the path between the main huts and the Dragon's Lair added to the swampy feeling.  The thing was huge, and it's back looks like a skull, which is a bit creepy.  I was ok as long as I walked quickly under it. As far as Mother Nature vs. the Sweat Lodge, Mother Nature won, big time.  As tonight was a full moon, the hostel was doing a sweat lodge, which consists of sitting in a hot room (naked, unless you like to be drenched in sweaty clothes) and meditating, chanting, etc.  The hippies - er, employees of the hostel spent the whole day getting the sweat lodge ready by tending the fire.  I didn't see the sweat lodge as it's located down a swampy path that was currently under 12" of water, and I figured if I were to make the trip, it would be once.  Well, at 5:30 pm, there was a crash boom bam kerrang thunder lightning rainstorm that quenched the fire and put the kibosh on the sweat lodge.  Oh well. The Ride:  Rode south from South Newport on Rt 17 through Eulonia and Darien to Rt 303, which I took around Brunswick to Rt 82. At 8 pm we ate a big communal dinner of pasta and a great couscous-sweet potato-squash dish.  There were about 25 of us, and it was fun to eat dinner in the screened-in dining room with everyone else.
Today's ride was, well, boring.  Rt 82 is a four-lane divided highway with light traffic, no hills, and hardly any curves.  After Waycross things got a bit more scenic, but not much. While riding along Rt 82, I rode by a semi that was stopped in the right hand lane because two of its wheels had fallen off, no lie.  They were the left rear wheels of the truck (not the trailer), and it looked like the axle shaft had broken.  The driver was standing in the road scratching his head, which was understandable. The Ride:  Rode west on Rt 82 through Waynesville, Atkinson, Lulaton, Nahunta, and Hoboken to Waycross, where I continued west on Rt 122 to Cogdell.    I'm surprised that I made it as far as I did today, considering I didn't leave the hostel until 10:30 am.  I was going to stay a bit longer, but the combined smell of patchouli and sawdust was getting to me. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Deeper Shade of Soul by Urban Dance Squad (don't know where that came from, but it stuck)

The Ride:  Continued west from Cogdell on Rt 122, also known as the William Jackson "Moogie" Lee Highway through Lakeland to Hahira, where I took an unnamed quiet road to Morven.  From there I went south on Rt 76 to Quitman.    While riding through Lakeland, I saw signs along the road that said:  Re-Elect Peg Blitch State Senate.  Talk about an unfortunate surname. Today was all about animals.  First I saw about fifteen vultures sitting close together in trees right alongside the road.  It was eerie, of course, and it was also a message to me that there was a dead animal close by, so I held my breath and kept riding. Then, a bit later, I heard a noise coming from the forest to the left of me.  I looked over, and saw a piglet pop out of the forest with another piglet in hot pursuit.  They ran alongside the forest for about ten feet, then ran back in the forest.  It was the cutest thing I've seen on the Tour so far, cuter than the bunny playing with the squirrel in Stromsburg.  I mean, come on, a wee little piglet chasing another wee little piglet?  Ah, I could barely stand it. On the road between Hahira and Morven I saw a black dog standing in the middle of the road.  As I approached him (or her, or it, but I'll stick with him), he moved to the side of the road.  When I got real close, he ran towards me with the rips, legs flailing, then ran alongside me in the grassy ditch for about a mile.  I was impressed that he could keep up (I was going about 15 mph).    On that same road, after the dog had given up and walked back home (presumably), I saw about ten brown cows with long, floppy ears.  It was a bit confusing - they had the body of a cow, but the head of a dachsund. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Skinned by Blind Melon   
The Ride:  Rode southwest on Grooverville Rd from Quitman into Florida, then south on Rt 149 to Monticello.  From there I rode Rt 90 west into Tallahassee, got lost for a bit in the crazy busy outskirts of Tallahassee, then eventually found my way to my Aunt Ann and Uncle Wayne's place. Between Quitman and Monticello there was hardly any traffic at all.  It was a beautiful ride.    In Tallahassee I'm hanging out with a buncha family for a while.  Then I plan on getting back on the bike on Monday, 10/28/02, for the final push to Key West.
On Friday Aunt Rita and I went to Wakulla Springs, one of the world's largest and deepest freshwater springs, and where a certain famous movie was filmed.  We took a boat tour and saw a bunch of birds, some jumping fish, and a few big lazy alligators sitting in the water.  We then ate an interesting seafood lunch, then went out to see the St. Marks lighthouse.  That evening we went back to Tallahassee and went downtown with Laurie and Aunt Ann to a city party for the next day's big game.    Saturday Aunt Ann, Aunt Rita, Wayne's cousin Jerry and I went to the Florida State - Notre Dame football game.  Talk about a major game - they've never played before in Tallahassee, and they're both good teams.  To say that Florida State football is popular in Tallahassee is an understatement, so for this big rivalry the fans were excited.  It was a good game for the first half (it was 10-10 at the half), but then Florida State fell apart the rest of the game and lost 34-24.  Oh well (easy for me to say - I'm not from Tallahassee). Sunday I went to see Holly and Doug's place with Aunt Ann, Holly, 1 yr old Sarah, and my new best friend 3 yr old Hanna.  She was so cute - she would not leave my side.  We all went to Aunt Rita's place for dinner on Sunday night.
   The Ride:  Rode south from Tallahassee on a bike trail that parallels Rt 363 through Woodville to Rt 267 (Wakulla), which I took southeast to Rt 98 (Newport), which I took east through Hampton Springs to Perry.    Right outside of Tallahassee my rear tire developed a slow leak, probably due to a sharp pointy thing that I rode over sometime in Tallahassee.  As I was fixing the flat, under shelter, it rained, so it was good timing. Just before reaching Wakulla a couple other riders joined up with me, and we rode together to Newport.  I wish I had someone else to ride with - the miles flew by as we were riding together and talking.  Along the way we saw a dead coral snake in the road's shoulder. I'm surprised at the number of dead armadillos that I've seen - not that so many have been hit by traffic, but that there are any armadillos at all in Florida.  I always pictured them as more of desert creatures, but today I probably saw fifteen on them.
The Ride:  Rode east from Perry on Rt 27 through Fenholloway, Mayo, Alton, Branford, Hildreth, and Fort White to High Springs.  From there I rode Rt 441 to Alachua.    Just before Branford I saw a wild pig running in a field by the side of the road, and about a half mile later I crossed the Suwannee River.  This is significant because during a family vacation when I was a kid, we stopped at a picnic area along the Suwannee River for lunch and saw a dead pig floating in the river.  We didn't stay to eat, it was just a bit too eerie. In Branford I stopped for lunch, and hung out in the air-conditioned library for a bit, where I learned that it was 82 deg. F and 70% relative humidity outside.  That's sticky.  I'm looking forward to getting back to the dry mountain climate. Today was a difficult ride, both mentally and physically.  Mentally because the roads were generally flat and straight with not much change in scenery, physically because I had a punishing headwind the whole day. Tonight I'm staying with someone from the Warm Showers list.  The Warm Showers List is a list of Internet cyclists who have offered their hospitality towards touring cyclists. The extent of the hospitality depends on the host and may range from simply a spot to pitch a tent to meals, a warm (hot!) shower, and a bed.  To get the list, you need to put your name on the list, simple as that.  It's a great idea, and if you're a touring cyclist, click here to learn more.  I wish I knew about it sooner in the trip, I may have been able to shower more often.  I don't shower much. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Little Lord Fontleroy by Quasi
The Ride: Rode south from Alachua on Rt 235 to Newberry, where I continued south on Rt 337 through Bronson to Tidewater.  From there I rode Rt 336 and Rt 40 east to Dunnellon.  Then I took Rt 41 south until I saw a paved rail trail alongside the road.  I got off the busy Rt 41 and hopped on this trail (the Withlacoochee trail) for the rest of the way to Inverness.    Rt 235 was a rainy busy mess complete with dump trucks, but Rt 337 was everything a quiet two-lane road through the country should be. Today was another hot one, a high of maybe 85 and not much cloud cover.  I can't understand how people can live with this hot sticky weather.  It's almost November and it's still hot!  Sure, air conditioning makes it possible, but does that make sense?  That's a lot of energy being used just to make life tolerable. Bodily function discovery: Pringles make me poop.  Now, this is not at all a bad thing.  Say things didn't move as much as I was hoping they would in the morning.  Well, for lunch I can eat one of those little cans of Pringles (usually $0.59), wait about fifteen minutes, then head back into the grocery store with a determined look on my face.
The Ride:  Continued south from Inverness on the Withlacoochee rail trail through Floral City, Pineola, and Ridge Manor to somewhere near Trilby, where the trail spit me out on Rt 301.  I rode Rt 301 through Dade City and Clinton Heights to Zephyrhills, where I turned south onto Rt 39.  I rode Rt 39 through Crystal Springs, Knights, and Plant City to Keysville, where I took a road that looked good but ended up getting me pretty lost.  It was a great road, really, no traffic, windy, scenic, but I had no idea where I was.  It finally spit me out on Rt 39, and I rode that south through Picnic to Fort Lonesome.    Early in the ride, along the rail trail, I saw a big doe (I say, D'oh!) standing in the trail way up ahead of me.  When I got closer, a baby deer came out from the woods onto the trail, and momma and baby went walking into the woods on the other side of the trail.  That baby was really cute, all legs.  If you've ever been in Florida, you know that Florida has the worst drivers in the U.S.  Every car ride I took in Tallahassee was a stress fest, and the bike rides I've done since then have been a test of my defensive riding skills.  Drivers in Florida don't use their turn signals much, and they also like to turn right in front of cyclists.  I think they assume that all cyclists are going 5 mph, and wouldn't mind stopping to let a car turn in front of them.  Yikes. Song-in-my-Head of the Day: It started with Friends in Low Places by Garth Brooks, dunno how it got there, but thank got it left.  After a few other songs surfaced and retreated, Galaxie by Blind Melon was with me for a couple of hours.
The Ride:  Rode south from Fort Lonesome on Rt 39 to Rt 62, which I took east through Duette.  At Fort Green Springs, I turned south on Rt 663 to Vandolah, where the road turned to dirt.  Well, dirt is a strong word - it was more of a sand road.  For the three miles I was on this sand road, it was about half hardpack (rideable), half 6" deep sand (not rideable with skinny tires and a 50 lb. trailer).  At Ona it turned back to a paved surface, and I rode that south  to Limestone, where the road turned into Rt 661.  At Rt 70 I turned east to Arcadia, then continued south on Rt 31 through Babcock to Rt 80.  I turned east on Rt 80 for a bit, then turned south onto Buckingham Road to Lehigh Acres.  Phew!  That's a ride.    Along Rt 31, just south of Babcock, I saw a bunch of stuff up ahead in the shoulder.  From a distance I couldn't figure out what it was, but as I rode into the traffic lane to avoid it, I saw that it was a dead alligator.  Now that's roadkill!  It was probably five feet long, lots of teeth and claws, and it was certainly dead.  After that, since I was riding through swampy areas, I kept looking for more alligators, but didn't see any.  Oh well.  I may see more as I get deep into the Big Cypress Swamp tomorrow. I think tonight may be the last night of the Tour for poaching a campsite, and I found a great one, the pinnacle of the poach.  It was off the road about 1/4 of a mile, very secluded, and it was in a grove of pine and palm trees.  It looked like a movie set (that nice!).  The floor consisted only of pine needles.  No spiders, only a few mosquitoes, and a nice breeze.  It was great.  The breeze reminded me of Key West when I visited a couple of years ago, which seems appropriate because I'm pretty close to Key West.   
   Somewhere along Rt 29 I saw a dead piglet in the shoulder.  It was kinda sad 'cause it was kinda cute. At Sunniland I entered the Big Cypress Swamp and was immediately told to watch out for panthers crossing the road for the next seven miles.  Panthers!?!  Then another sign said that there are no more than 30 left in the swamp.  That eased my fears a bit.  This part of Florida is what I've been looking forward to - the Everglades / Big Cypress part.  It's chock full of wildlife.  There are lots of birds with long beaks, long necks, and big wingspans flying around everywhere.  The few vultures that are here look out of place with their little beaks and little necks.  I saw a little alligator swimming in the canal alongside Rt 29 (it was about 24" long), as well as a bunch of fish slurping stuff off the surface.  Lots of big turtles as well. Just east of Carnestown I officially entered the Big Cypress National Preserve and, since the auto traffic picked up, I saw less wildlife.  Damn cars.  The landscape is crazy - lots of grasses, and the land slopes at only 2" per mile to the south (Florida Bay and the Gulf of Mexico).  Add 60" of rain per year, and that makes for some wet land.  The National Park brochure is hysterical.  Here's some highlights: "Hikers should be prepared for wet areas from ankle- to waist- deep in the rainy season and early in the dry season." "Alligators and venomous snakes (including water moccasins) are found almost everywhere in the preserve.  Watch where you walk, sit, or reach." Today I lucked out.  I made a beeline for the visitor's center just east of Monroe Station to fill up my water bottles and CamelBak and ask about camping.  I got there at 4:22, eight minutes before they closed, and filled my stuff up.  I asked about the campground a mile away.  They said it's closed and the nearest one is five miles back the way I just came from, but I put on my tired face (that wasn't too tough, since I was very tired) and asked if I could camp at the closed campground anyway.  They said ok, and I was happy (and lucky). Camp was good.  A beautiful swampy sunset, and there was a pond there, so I washed up using pond water that I hauled from the pond to camp as a good leave-no-trace'r.  The passing motorists were honking at me as I was washing up, butt naked of course (I was camped about 100 yards off the road).  It was another hot day, high in the mid- to upper 80's, so I had no reservations about washing up in the wide open.
The Ride:  Continued east on Rt 41 to Miami, then turned south on 57th Ave to Coral Gables.    Today's ride was a slow one, with a brutal headwind and no cloud cover (11.0 mph avg, 17.3 max mph - wheeeeee!).  And, to top it off, I had a flat tire.  Not mushy-can't-ride-it-gotta-fix-it flat, and not flat enough to bother pumping it up, but flat enough that it slowed me down. In Coral Gables I'm staying with my friend Steve's Aunt and Uncle, Julie and Terry Connor.  They live in a beautiful two-story Spanish-style house on a palm lined street, and I'm staying in a little guest house out back with, get this, a warm shower!  Terry took me to a bike shop in Coral Gables, and I bought a new rear tire to replace the treadless wonder that's been giving me flats lately.  That's two rear tires I've gone through on the Tour, and I've still got the same front tire with hardly any signs of wear. Tonight Julie, Terry and I went to hear a talk given by William Langewiesche at a great local bookstore called Books and Books.  His new book is called American Ground: Unbuilding the World Trade Center, and it was very interesting to hear him talk about the culture of the workers at the site.
Yesterday I woke up (a good way to start the day), and decided to go to Miami Beach for the day with the bike but without The Pig, to hang out on the beach and ride around a bit.  Well, the Metrorail nazis put the kibosh on that plan.  They wouldn't let me take the Metrorail since I don't have a pass, and they would not bend one bit.  But, that's ok, because my legs were telling me that they really didn't feel like working today, especially since they haven't had a rest day since Tallahassee.  So, I went to the Coral Gables library and sat in air conditioning, reading this and that.  It was a great way to spend the day. This morning I hung out with Julie and Terry for a bit, then shoved off at about 9 am.  Traffic was still pretty heavy, but I managed to get out of Miami without incident. The Ride:  Rode south on 57th Ave to Old Cutler Rd which, among other roads, I rode southwest to Rt 997.  I rode Rt 997 south through Homestead to Florida City, ditched The Pig at the Everglades Hostel, then rode west on Rt 9336 into Everglades National Park.  After hanging out there for a bit, I rode back to the hostel to spend the night in air conditioned comfort.    In Everglades NP I spent some time in the visitor's center, then walked the Anhinga Trail, an elevated boardwalk that winds its way through some deeper water areas inside the park.  I saw lots of birds, as well as about ten alligators, all over eight feet long.  Very impressive.  It was a great way to spend the afternoon.   
This morning I got up and started riding early.  I knew I'd have a headwind, so I wanted to get the bulk of today's ride finished before the afternoon winds really started whipping. The Ride:  Rode south from Florida City in Rt 1 to Key Largo, where the road turned southwest.  I continued on Rt 1 and various bike trails and side roads that parallelled Rt 1 through Tavernier, Plantation, Islamorada, and Lower Matecumba Beach to Layton.    I stopped at a gas station in Plantation to guzzle a Gatorade - the day was hot, and the heawdinds were brutal, exhausting, relentless, etc.  As I was drinking the Gatorade outside the gas station, I looked at a newspaper to see the election results from yesterday, and I saw a blurb about me and the Tour, more on pg 18.  So, I bought the paper, and on pg 18, sure enough, found full page article.  So that's what that phone interview in Miami was about! In Layton I'm staying at Long Key State Park, and it's great.  The campsites are covered, and are located just off the boardwalk on the Atlantic side of the Keys.  I arrived at camp at around 2 pm, so I had a few hours to goof off on the beach. My best friend Kurt from Portland flew into Miami today, and he stopped by camp at around 9 pm, with bullhorn in hand.  We hung out for a bit, then he left for Key West to get some sleep before waking up tomorrow to orbit me in his car and generally embarrass me, I'm sure.
At 3 am this morning, I woke up due to the cold.  Cold?  I thought that the warm southwestern breeze would keep me (uncomfortably) warm all night, but when I was awoken by the cool breeze, I knew the wind had shifted direction.  Sure enough, I had a tailwind for today's ride, from the northeast. I couldn't ask for better weather today.  73 deg F, tailwind, not a cloud in the sky, ok.  I'm so glad that I was able to cruise easily today with the cool tailwind, being the last day of the Tour and all.  The scenery was more water than land, and Rt 1 was an easy ride, with big, wide shoulders if there wasn't a bike trail running right alongside the road. The Ride:  Continued south-southwestish on Rt 1 and various bike trails and side roads that parallel Rt 1 through Conch Key, Key Colony Beach, Marathon, across the Seven Mile Bridge (with a big, big shoulder, nice and easy), through Spanish Harbor, Ramrod Key, and Summerland Key to Key West, where I jumped off the bike at the last second and let the whole rig fly into the Atlantic Ocean off a pier near the Southernmost Point.  Just kidding.    A few miles outside of Key West, I was greeted by my friend Kurt and his folks, Jim and Marie (Jim and Marie live right in Key West).  Jim was driving the convertible, Marie was navigating, and Kurt was filming the last few miles of the ride and shouting through the megaphone at the same time while wearing a two-piece suit and tie, cowboy boots, and a cowboy hat.  A true Key West experience.    I followed behind this pace car for probably the last five miles of the ride, all the time being showered with confetti and asked questions by megaphone Kurt to the bewilderment of onlookers/tourists, to mile marker 0, then down Duval St, and finally to the Southernmost Point of the continental United States.  There, the real fun began.    With the camera still rolling, I dipped my front wheel into the Atlantic Ocean and somehow managed to keep the rig from falling in.  Then, Kurt asked me a bunch of questions and read a list of reasons why I rode my bike almost 9,000 miles (more on that later).  When I was good and hot and, needless to say, very embarrassed with tourists scratching their heads and pointing at this freak in spandex with Hawaiian leis around his neck being interviewed by a cowboy from hell with a megaphone, Jim snuck up from behind and smushed a key lime pie in my face.  So now, I'm covered with confetti, sweaty, red-faced embarrassed, with key lime pie on my face, and as soon as I cleaned the pie off my face, a bottle of Korbel is opened and sprayed around, hitting anyone (and everyone) within easy spraying distance.  It was a wonderful way to end the Tour. Song-in-my-Head of the Day:  Margaritaville by Jimmy Buffett.  Seems appropriate, huh?  I saw an ad for Jimmy's restaurant (Margaritaville) somewhere along the way, and the song stuck. A couple of frozen Gino's East Chicago-style pizzas were waiting for me at Jim and Marie's house.  Thanks, Mom and Dad!  We're planning on consuming them on Sunday, and I'll be thinking of you.   
Riding a bicycle, being exposed to the elements, hearing the chain make its way around the gears makes me feel aware, human, and connected, obviously much more so than tearing around the country at 70 mph in a glass-and-steel shell with the AC blasting and not taking time to stop, get out of the car, be aware of the weather, walk around and get sweaty and, if you're lucky, bloody, and talk to some locals.  It's also satisfying to know that I can fix and tune anything on my bike, from fixing a flat to truing a wheel.  I'm not at the mercy of an auto mechanic in B.F.E. who, when asked how much for the repair, replies, "How much you got?" The toughest part of the Tour was leaving the security of a good paying and personally satisfying job.  Economically, of course, the Tour didn't make sense (although it ended up being cheaper than I had planned), but spiritually and emotionally it was the thing to do.  After giving my notice at work, it felt like a weight had been lifted, and the planning shifted into high gear.  So, looking back, I'd say follow your heart because it won't steer you wrong.  Don't discard an idea that at first appears irrational.  If it's something that you think will truly make you happy and enrich your life, even though it involves, say, quitting your job and not being guaranteed a shower every day, then the irrational thing would be to not act on that idea.  I don't think anyone has ever said "I've had a good life, but I wish I would've worked more" on their deathbed.  Whoa, deep thought. As for me, my world view has changed.  I feel more compassionate to others, which I think is a result of the unsolicited acts of kindness I experienced on the Tour as well as the conversations I had with people of all walks of life along the way.  These experiences made me think that each of us is interesting in our own way, but we all experience feelings of joy, sorrow, amazement, frustration, etc. Now, look here, we can all agree that the world is filled to the brim with interesting people and places to discover and experience, and that we're only here for a speck of time on the cosmic scale, so why is there any reason to worry?  Are the things we worry about truly worth worrying about?  Breathe deep (life in, anxiety out) - you are breathing, right? - and make sure you're doing things every now and then that make it easy for you to see that life is beautiful.  Life's too short to be: 1. Feeling like the world is out to get you 2. Not doing what brings you joy 3. Worried about dying 4. Worried about what others think of you 5. More concerned with how you look and, while bike touring, how you smell than how you feel If I were to do the Tour over again, I would try a bit harder to find others to do the Tour with, even if it was with people that I didn't know.  For the first few months, I didn't feel that way - it only hit me during the last half of the Tour.  Now, that's not to say that I didn't enjoy riding solo.  Typically, the first couple of hours each day were spent spinning down the road in pleasant meditative silence, leaving my mind open to whatever thoughts (and songs) want to surface, not checking the odometer much to see how much farther I have until the next town, just enjoying the morning with the voices in my head. The Tour confirmed a suspicion that my heart belongs in the hills.  Even though the hills require more physical effort than the flatlands, I'll take the snow-capped peaks of the Cascades, the steep Wyoming ranges, and the Adirondack roller coaster over the flat plains of the Midwest and the slow-draining swamps of the South anyday. Will I tour by bicycle in the future?  I don't think I can afford not to.  Bicycling is at the core of my being, which is convenient since touring by bicycle is a great way to feel connected to the world and the creatures that inhabit it. OK, enough of my yakking.  For the grand finale, here are 23 reasons why I did the bike tour, according to my friends and family (in no particular order, and gathered by my good friend Kurt Robinson, the Cowboy From Hell): 1.  One too many Forrest Gump viewing parties. 2.  Because a bad day on the bike is still better than a good day in the office. 3.  Because it was there. 4.  I lost a bet. 5.  I have this thing about 'One Less Car'. 6.  To prove that I'm better than everyone else. 7.  So I could get bent. 8.  A life changing event, to get from one state of being to another. 9.  Someone triple-dog dared me. 10. I just wasn't chafed enough. 11. Two words: Yeasty Boys. 12. To see how long I could go on paying rent without actually living in my apartment. 13. Have YOU ever lived in Salt Lake City? 14. I wanted to have the opportunity to buy beer on a Sunday. 15. I thought that by doing this, I would win a year's supply of any beer of my choice. 16. I wanted to see if I could grow a full beard by the time I crossed the finish line. 17. I set out to tour with my favorite band Banyan during their North American tour, but was not notified that due to poor ticket sales, all venues had been cancelled. 18. On a road trip, I see and smell a lot more detail at 15 mph. 19. I needed something to do while waiting for the statute of limitations to run out on those trumped-up "lewd conduct" and "public indecency" charges from the killjoys at Temple Square. 20. Because all the boys at work were teasing me about the songs in my head. 21. To promote Bad and Worse's debut album, "Badder Then They Ought To Be." 22. My cat Biff and I needed some time away from each other in order to contemplate where our relationship was going. 23. I couldn't get any good seafood in Utah.
The most important piece of advice I can give someone going on their first bike tour is this: don't rush it.  Leave yourself time to spend an extra day or two in a town with a good vibe, go on a scenic detour, wait out bad weather, hang out with locals and other bike tourers you meet along the way, etc.  I met more than one bike tourer along the way who did nothing but eat, sleep, ride, repeat - what about relax?  The difference between a loose schedule and a tight schedule can be the difference between a fun trip and a forced march. I'd recommend going on a few shorter tours to get the hang of bicycle touring.  I went on two three-day rides the fall before the Tour, and I'm glad I did.  Immediately after the first ride I replaced my saddle with a big cushy Specialized saddle (9,000 miles on a $10 saddle, folks), and bought a one-man tent (small, lightweight, but still withstood high winds and a few snowstorms) to use instead of my 4-season 2-1/2 man tent (big, heavy). Also, it definitely doesn't hurt to join the Adventure Cycling Association.  As a member, you get discounts on their great bike maps, a copy of The Cyclist's Yellow Pages, and their monthly magazine.  And no, they didn't pay me to say that. The pages that fall under this one contain info on what worked and, more importantly, what didn't work for me on the Tour.
Spin at a high cadence (90 rpm).  Any lower and your legs will get tired pretty quick.  I was on the bike for about six hours a day, so I avoided any sudden, sustained bursts of energy, unless there was a dog in hot pursuit. Before the ride I looked at the bike and imagined what could go wrong during the ride.  I took all the tools to repair a flat, turn every bolt on the bike, true the wheels, replace a spoke, etc.  Everything short of removing / replacing the cranks, removing / replacing the bottom bracket, servicing the wheel hubs and headset, removing / replacing the freewheel, and welding the frame.  Get to know how to maintain your bike.  Here are the mechanicals that I had along the way: 1. About 20 flat tires.  I usually patched them until they had about three patches already on them, then it was time for a new tube.  I probably went through four tubes.  Make sure you have the right tube for the tire you're using.  I had a difficult time finding tubes that would work for my 26x1.25 tires.  Also, if you're towing a trailer, bring a spare tube along - my trailer had two flats during the Tour. 2. Two broken rear deraileur cables, both of which happened in the middle of nowhere.  After breaking the second cable, I wised up and relubed the cable housings whenever they felt dirty (usually after a rain storm). 3. In Syracuse, when I was staying with friends, I replaced the chain and the rear cassette since they were worn out.  Now, at the end of the Tour, they again require replacement. 4. I replaced my rear tire twice and my trailer tire once.  The front wheel is the same one I started on, and still has some miles left before replacement. I was surprised that I didn't break a spoke.  For that matter, I never had to turn a spoke to true the wheels.  I used a downhill mountain bike rim for the rear wheel, which I think was a wise move.  It slowed me down a bit, since it's heavier than a normal rim, but it stayed true and felt solid. If you're debating whether to take something or leave it behind, I'd take it if you have the space.  Don't be a weight weenie, especially with tools.  It won't matter, you'll get used to the weight.   
Almost every library has free Internet access.  Usually I'd update the website, check e-mails, and most importantly, check the weather.  The Weather Channel website has an accurate wind forecast for the next day if you click on Detailed Forecast. During the start of the Tour, when the weather was cool, I didn't need to shower every day since I wasn't sweating.  But during the heat and humidity of the Midwest, a daily shower was necessary. First I'd look for a campground to take a shower.  In the Midwest, during the height of the summer, my first place to look was at the local public pool (they usually don't charge).  If there's no campgrounds or public pools in town, I'd look for a YMCA or YWCA (usually $2 a shower).  Barring that, I'd look for a gym / health club.  Nope?  Then I'd resort to the restroom shower.  Grocery stores are the best for this - you're almost guaranteed not to be interrupted since people rarely use the restrooms at grocery stores.  The ideal situation is a big ADA accessible stall with its own sink and a floor drain (oh yeah, make sure the restroom has a floor drain).  Otherwise, lock the door and go nuts.  Just make sure to dry the floor with paper towels when you're finished.  If you're organized, the whole process should only take a couple of minutes. No restroom shower?  Then head to camp and use a couple of Pampers Wet Wipes. Trust me, Pampers are the way to go - accept no substitute. I washed my clothes at a laundromat every week or so.
