I had three short sleeve and one long sleeve lightweight shirts, three pair of bike shorts, six pair of socks, a fleece jacket, two pair of bike gloves (short and long finger, make sure they have plenty of padding to avoid numb fingers), and three bandannas.  Nothing cotton except for the bandannas.  I had a few t-shirts, a pair of convertible pants, a couple pair of cotton boxers (ok, the secret's out), wool socks, slip-on Merrell shoes, and flip flops for times when I was off the bike (at camp, in cities, etc.).  For wet, cold weather, and for something to wear at the laundromat while washing all the other stuff, I had Gore Tex pants, socks, gloves, and a jacket. If you don't have a cell phone, phone cards work well.  I cancelled my home phone and used a voice mail answering service (cheaper) during the tour, and decided not to get a cell phone since (1) I was riding through B.F.E. where cell phones wouldn't work anyway, and (2) I wouldn't use it enough to justify the cost. Post offices are your friend.  If you need something sent to you along the way (urgent bills, cookies from Mom), pick a town about a week away, then have the stuff sent to that town at the following address: (your name) General Delivery (town, state, zip) Simple as that.  They'll hold it for about two weeks, and after that, it disappears into the ether. A word of warning: if you're going on a long tour and don't do any regular exercise except for the ride, you'll lose strength in everything above the waist, and your legs will hurt when you walk / run.  It's about two weeks since my last day of the Tour, and I'm a hurting unit after lifting weights and running, getting ready for the ski season.  Looking back, I would've done some pushups and situps each day after the ride (but no burpies), even though the last thing I felt like doing after six hours on the bike was more exercise. As far as what to take for camping, use the same stuff that you use for backpacking.  Tent, sleeping bag, inflatable sleeping pad with a chair converter, tarp, stove, bug juice, lights for reading, yadda yadda.
During the last couple of months of the Tour I had a pretty good system.  Besides the foods listed below, I'd also have Pop Tarts, Snickers (the best candy bar for energy - trust me), and peanuts (for protein) on hand in case I was hungry and there wasn't a grocery store in the immediate area.  "Eat before you're hungry," sure, but some days are more demanding than others and hunger crept up on me a few times.  On a bike tour, it's more like, "Eat until you can't stuff any more food through your pie hole." Breakfast didn't vary much.  It was usually four packets of oatmeal (boil two cups of water with the stove) with some raisins or dates sprinkled on top to provide flavor and texture. Lunch was a chance to refuel as well as a chance to rest the legs.  I'd usually eat lunch at around 1 pm, and I'd buy lunch at a grocery store.  Ideal lunch: one banana or apple, two yogurts (lowfat, not nonfat), something crunchy like Doritos, Pringles, or pretzels, 32 oz of Gatorade (from the powdered mix), and a chocolate goodie to cap it all off - Kit Kat, Butterfinger, one of Mom's homemade cookies that she sent me, etc. Dinner was usually one of two things, cooked at camp: pasta or burritos.  I ate a lot of Velveeta Shells and Cheese at the start of the Tour, but later my body was telling me, "Enough!", so after that it was either pesto pasta or pasta with a red sauce.  For burritos, I usually had a can of refried beans with a vegetable (corn, mixed veggies in a can, etc.), taco seasoning, cheese, whatever.  Anything that sounded good at the time.  Of course, if there was a Pizza Hut buffet in the town where I was sleeping, I'd belly up to the boofay and eat 'til I couldn't eat no more.  Mmm ... pizza buffet.  I never bothered to check back and see if I put any of those Pizza Huts out of business, but I wouldn't be surprised. I used a Primus Himalaya multifuel stove, and decided to use unleaded gasoline as the fuel.  The stove runs great on white gas, which is cleaner than unleaded, but I figured that white gas would be tough to find along the way in anything smaller than one gallon containers.  Also, it was fun to pull up to gas station and fill up my 11 oz fuel canister with $0.12 of the highest grade unleaded available.  Make sure you know how to clean your stove at camp, especially with unleaded.  Unleaded is dirty, and leaves things black and clogged. My stove needed frequent cleaning at the start of the Tour, but not as much later - maybe the stove was used to the nasty fuel by then.
1. Indoors: With friends and family.  It was great to visit with family outside of a big family reunion setting, and I hung out with some friends and family that I hadn't seen in years. 2. Indoors: With someone from the Warm Showers List.  I wish I would've heard of this list earlier in the Tour.  Check it out if you're planning on going on a bike tour. 3. Outdoors: At a free campground.  I found most of these in the Midwest, right in town, and most of them had warm showers. 4. Outdoors: In the woods, away from a busy road, where no one can see me.  This is where I slept most often on the Tour (It's cheap! It's quiet! The woods! Hey, I'm camping!), and I followed the rules of Leave No Trace.  During the last couple months of the Tour I didn't bother with digging "catholes" anymore for solid waste, I'd pack it all out in a plastic grocery store garbage bag and pitch it in the first trash can I'd see.  As for selecting a site, a dirt road with a chain across it and a No Trespassing sign (but not a This Means You sign) works great.  If it was raining, I'd try not to set up my tent under the canopy of trees, because I would want to break camp when the rain stopped the next morning without water from the trees dripping on me. 5. Outdoors: At a fee campground.  I mostly stayed at these at the start of the Tour as I was still getting the hang of bicycle touring, and also in bear country.  Many campgrounds in bear country have bear boxes, secure steel boxes for all your food and anything that could have a food scent on it (basically, everything except what you need to sleep). Along the way I stayed at a few hostels: in big cities (e.g. Washington D.C.), when the weather was really bad (e.g. Kitty Hawk during Tropical Storm Kyle), or when the hostel was highly recommended (e.g. Hostel in the Forest).  I'm partial to hostels over hotels, even if the price were the same.  Staying at hostels is a great way to meet people of all ages from all parts of the globe and feel connected, and I think that's truly what gets our juices flowing - feeling connected to others.
I shipped my bike from Key West to Seattle via Greyhound.  It cost me $50, whereas the plane would cost $75 - $100, depending on your carrier.  Bike boxes are readily available for free at local bike shops. I checked the trailer on my flight from Miami to Seattle.  Before shipping the bike I took off the trailer fork and stuffed it in the bike box, so the trailer didn't have anything pointy on it when I checked it.  The ticketing agent looked at it funny and kept referring to it as a bike, and I kept reminding her that it wasn't a bike, but a trailer, basically just a bag with a metal shell and a wheel on the back.  They didn't charge me to check the trailer (gee, how nice of them), and it was waiting for me at the Seattle baggage claim area, with other travelers staring at it and wondering what it was. It was a very long flight from Miami to Seattle via Chicago, which is when it really hit me that I rode my bike across the country, and then some.  I'll take the bike over the plane any day.
Q: Would you do it again? A: I'll definitely go on more bike tours in the future, but probably not the same route.  In fact, definitely not the same route.  I'd like to do some touring in Europe, in New England during the fall colors, and along the Smoky Mountains.  I'll definitely ride RAGBRAI again. Q: I'm considering a tour from Chattanooga to Key West. I've heard some pretty nasty things about riding in Florida, particularly on US1. I was wondering if you would share your experiences on that particular stretch of road. A: I also heard some horrible stories about riding along Rt 1 between Key Largo and Key West, but I was glad to see that those stories come from the age when Rt 1 didn't have a shoulder.  Rt 1 was my favorite road to ride on in Florida - if it wasn't a separate bike path, it had a wide shoulder.  These photos were taken every 20 miles from Homestead to Key West, so you can be the judge:            A couple more photos here and here. Now, as for the rest of Florida ...    Q: Say, did you ever put together a map of your journey? A general sorta, waypoint kinda map would be nice. A: The following image and highlighting my trusty 1994 Road Atlas are the extent of mapping the journey.  Close enough!   

Planning: Amtrak to Longview, TX.  The train fare is LESS than what it would have cost just to take the bike on a plane!  So I've given up a day on each end to save the money. Generally, I ride into Louisiana, then south to the coast, then east to Ocean Spring, MS where my sister lives.  I'll spend whatever "slack time" I have and then leave again along the coast to Pensacola. The return trip: Greyhound to New Orleans, Amtrak to home. I have the Amtrak tickets, but I'll wait on the Greyhound tickets until I get to Ocean Springs.  This gives me the option if interrupting the trip early and returning to New Orleans in time to meet the train going home. I've been using DeLorme's Atlas Deluxe on the computer to plot a route.  It looks like around 750 miles, but I know it'll turn into more than that.  I also have a paper-copy of DeLorme's Louisiana State map which I'll take with me or at least copies off.  The computer printed maps just don't seem to cut it but it's useful for planning.   
Yesterday, 4/13, I rode a 40-mile loop, out from Chicago along the North River Trail and back through the Botanic Garden and south along the North Branch Trail.  My knees started to hurt, so I started spinning (i.e., shifting to lower gears and pedaling faster instead of harder) and that seemed to fix that problem.  However, my tail started to hurt and there's no easy cure for that except to keep doing it. The following Thursday 4/16, I rode out to O'Hare Field in Chicago, to see if my web page instructions were still current.  About a 30 miles round-trip.  Wasn't as bad, I bucked a headwind going out but had the wind at my back coming home.  The page I was updating is at http://www.neiu.edu/~rkastig1/bike/bik2ohar.htm . Yesterday, 4/25, I participated in the monthly Last-Friday Chicago Critical Mass Ride.  Maybe 30 miles overall, including the trip to and from downtown.  Actually, the Ride itself is almost too easy to be called a training ride, but I did at least get out a little further than the local grocery store! More information at Chicago Critical Mass Starting the countdown: less than a week left before I leave!
I asked at the ticket counter about adding a sleeper - $220! Gulp, no thank you. I asked on the train about adding a sleeper.  $36!  And that included meals. The train left on time, I had the steak for dinner. Throughout this journal, I took pictures.  There's four "albums" of pictures, with some annotation, at: http://community.webshots.com/user/kastigar 
Set up the bike for the trip, left around 2 pm.  It was hot, mid-80's and humid. The road to Tatum was very hilly.  The total distance was 29 miles.  When I got to Tatum, the 8-room motel/apts was full, had to ride 5 miles out of town to Martin Lake State Park.  Nice campground, however.  Hot showers.  I didn't see any way to register, so I didn't.  In the tent by 8:30 or so. On the road for about 6 hours, but only pedalled about 3-1/2.     
No motels in Logansport!  Found another (free) spot in a trailer park which some lady directed me to.  Actually, the trailer camp was back on the Texas side of the Sabine river.   Got a little lost on the way - someplace in Carthage I actually rode north about 5 miles, thinking that I was going south.  As a result, I missed the central business district in Carthage, TX - if there is one.   Weather was overcast all day.  No sun, but around 80 or so.  Didn't put suntan lotion on until late afternoon, no harm done.   
Good breakfast in Logansport - bacon, eggs, grits, toast.   Got talked into heading up Rt 509 instead of going straight east on 84.  Truck stop, supposed to have showers but didn't.  But a pretty good lunch, beef tips and rice.  Little spicey.  Continued east to Rt 1, then south. Wind picked up pretty good (this was the day after the tornadoes north of where I was) so I spend about 90 minutes in a little country church yard.  Good potential place to camp during the week anyway.  Grass was cut, set way back from the road, isolated.  Even running water from a spigot in the back.  So I took a sponge bath and spread out the towel and took a nap for about an hour.  Crossed over the Red River into Coushatta around 6 pm or so, found a cheap motel ($28) which was well back from the road, quiet, and cool.  Chatted with a couple of 'old boys' staying there, living there, I think.  Went out to the local fast food/fried chicken place and had a shimp dinner.  Met up with a couple more locals, guy named Glascow and the owner of the motel I was staying at.   Total mileage today around 60 miles.     
Rode into Campi, small town - no library - one gas station.  Then took 486 to LA 6 and into Natchitoches.  Crossed the Red River again, this time going east-to-west.  By around 2 pm I made it to Natchitoches.  (Kinda hard to pronounce)  Some rain, but not much.  I went to the public library in Natchitoches.  Chain slipped of the front drivewheel, and I'm not too sure about the front derailleur.  No bike shop in Natchitoches, though.  I may have to wait until Alexandria, which is about 50 miles away.   Natchitoches is kindofa tourist-y town, too rich for my blood to stay her unless I can find a cheap place out of town.  There are a couple of campgrounds west of the city.   Changed my mind: it started to rain again, and the Days Inn was only 40 bucks. Right across from the university, and a couple of restuarants nearby.  However, no more luck with the pictures: Louisiana's Northwestern U. is running NT, and the USB ports don't work.  Ergo, no pictures to put up yet. So, in summary I only rode 39 miles today, and quit about 3 PM, which is early but the next stop, Alexandria is 50 miles south and not much in between unless I want to camp again. ...and there is a LOT of swamp land, even this far north in Louisiana so camping, especially stealth-camping, isn't very high on my agenda. Actually, it was worthwhile staying - met up with some cyclists on a tour, part of Cycle Main Street - something like that.  We swapped stories.  There's was an organized tour.  Had fried catfish at a place called McGee's Patio, pretty good.  Tried to get access at the University - no luck.  And their USB ports didn't work since they were using Windows NT!     
A light mist turned into a heavy mist, so I put on the rainshoes, put everything under plastic, and continued on.  About mid-morning it quit so I changed clothes again.   Took a complicated route involving 494 to 419 back to rt. 1, which pretty much follows the Cane River.  Several plantations along the way, including a plantation with a for-sale sign! Along the road someplace, I met up with the older couple from southern Illinois who were on the tour.  We shared a bottle of water, and chatted some more.   In Cloutierville, met up with a retired displaced Chicagoan!  He wanted to chat about all the old neighborhoods.  He knew Sis Daley died, but didn't know about Meig's Field being torn up, so I got to share that bit of gossip. This area is filled with a lot of pecan farms.  Big fields with big trees all nicely in rows.  The few stands I saw were closed, or I would have investigated pecan farming a little.   At the start, Rt. 1 was flat, but then turned into gently rolling hills,  but with the south wind left over from yesterday it was still tough going.  Fried chicken for lunch in Boyce.  At the edge of Alexandria, I came across St. Mary's Residentail Academy, a home for retarded kids.  Services the whole state.  There was an attractive bench under a tree, so I stopped for a while, but then was politely asked to leave by an administrator and guard.  I must have ridden in behind a car before the gate closed, as they had to open the gate to let me out again.  Still, it was a nice break in the day.   It was a pretty hot day, so I continued down Rt. 1, a busy commercial strip until I came to a Motel 6, the closest, which I grabbed just to get out of the sun.     
Breakfast at Schonies, not really great but filling.  Left the motel around 7:30am, now following rt. 71 south.  There was some frontage road, but it was kinda rough.  Rt. 71 did have a pretty wide shoulder.  Maybe the worst day for the wind, though.  Avg. speed was onlyu 5-7 mph.  Took Rt. 456, which roughly parallels 71.  Found this happened often: a little road that paralleled a big road.  Smaller, but usually shadier and less traffic but sometimes harder to deal with the traffic because the road was narrow. Got worried about where to stay, but Bunkie was bigger than I though.  Cheap motel ("truck parking" is always a good sign!) then rode a couple of miles to Rockie's Bar anbd Grill.  Had the seafood gumbo, with Rockies own special roux.  Didn't realize how spicey it was until I finished.  Had a 2nd Barq's Root Beer.  Then stopped for an ice cream cone on the way home. Also bought a large size beach towel.  When I tood a nap earlier in the day, I realized the towel I was carrying wasn't quite big enough.   At 7:30, when I returned to the motel, it was still very windy out, so I'm glad I quit early. 
Continued down Rt. 182, which turns out is going to be my principal route.  It's the old Rt. 90.  Before that, it was called the Spanish Trail. At Opollusa (sp?) had the first flat.  But, right in front of a truck repair shop with a high pressure air hose.  Tiny tack sticking right in the sidewall, so I had no problem finding the leak.  Patched it, filled it, and I was on my way.  Would that all flat tires were that easy. Hot, in the high 80's again.  Pretty much intermittent strong wind from the south again.  Went through Beggs, Washington, a few other small towns. Saw some rice fields, chimney ants, and took a nap someplace north of Lafayette.  When I woke up, an Acadian gentleman came over with a large glass of root beef for me.   Stayed in a cheap motel that took only cash.  The air conditioner worked.     
Ran into one of the cyclists from earlier, fixing a flat.  I helped a little bit, it was an upscale bike, 150 lb. pressure tire!  He had a CO2 cartridge for filling it, maybe a good idea. When his buddies returned, they suggested a route - which I tried to follow and got lost, very lost.  Bunch of numbered bike route signs, plus some paint markings on the road.  In different colors.  One was called "Cajun Man's Route."   Anyway, I wound up in St. Martinsville, which I didn't intend to go to.  Got turned around in the right direction, after asking.  After arriving in New Ibertia, found out the next motel was about 30 miles, and it was already mid-afternoon so I decided to stay.  Went to 5:00 PM mass at St. Peter's.  Long, full, high mass.  These people take their religion seriously.  But it was in English, with a strong cajun accent.  Rode out of town to a place recommended and had a bowl of seafood gumbo.  It didn't taste spicy - until I finished it but then it was too late.   Rode around the park, then around Teche Bayou.   Went to the library and updated a couple of days but still couldn't upload the pictures.  When I went back to the motel, I couldn't find my maps!  Went back to the library and found 'em in the garbage, which must have happened when I threw some other stuff away.  I think the heat and sunshine does something to your brains.  Short term memory seems to go.  It's easy to get befuddled. Went to the local tourist info place (about 5 miles west of my route) to check on the home of Joseph Jefferson.  (19th century actor, for whom the Chicago Jeff Awards are named)  The place is no longer open.  It was a combination of Joe Jefferson and the Rip Van Winkle Garens, because Jefferson played Rip Van Winkle on broadway, his most famous part.   Minor disaster a few years ago: drilling for oil in a lake, they broke a hole into a salt deposit, draining the lake!  One home got destroyed, and some minor damage was done to the Jefferson home as well.   I didn't go out there since it wasn't open.   An observation: amongst the litter on the road, there's lots and lots of plastic beads.  Necklaces, bracelets.  I dunno.  Plastic beads seem to be pretty popular down here.   Todays avg speed was 7.9, maximum was 18 mpg.  I was out riding for 9 hours, but the bike computer said I pedalled for 5-1/4, so I must have spend the difference sitting around or napping or something.       
Saw a sign warning of bears! Went through Baldwin and Berwick.   Got directions back to Rt. 182, and finally crossed the Atchafalaya River into Morgan City.  Ate at my first Waffle House,  my favorite!  Then rode out to Lake End Park, and camped for the night.  Sunday night, it was crowded and noisy.  Bunch of kids, not camping, in the camping area.  If you ride down this way, avoid this park.  Actually, it settled down later.  I set up the tent as far away as I could.  There was even a guy camping there with a full set of drums set up under a screened-in tent!   Showers worked. Planning ahead a little, I think this 182 will take me somewhat back to New Orleans, but I'm going to have to ride on Rt. 90 at least part of the way.       
Flat country, criss-crossed by bayous, streams, and canals.  It seems like every road runs along a bayou, and most of the times there's a road or street on the other side as well.  Occasionally, a bridge crosses over the bayou.  About 17 miles to Gibson, and then about 20 miles or so along Bayou Black.   Wound up in Houma and decided to try and find a bike shop to see if I could get somebody to look at my derailleur, which has been slipping.  Got directions to two bike shops, in the same area, but about 5 miles out from the downtown, historic, district.  Both of 'em closed on Mondays!  A conspiracy?   One of the bike shops was near Duet Street.  I mention this, because I know how I would pronounce this, but it isn't pronounced the way you think.  It's dew-AY Street.  I was going to ask what their word is for two people singing together, but I didn't ask.   Houma is known as the Venice of the South.  Canals and Bayous all over the place.  Park Street and Main Street are each one-way streets, basically north-south, and run along side of the Black Bayou, I think.  Then there are streams and bridges that cross into the bayou, and every couple of blocks a bridge crossing over the bayou, to the street on the other side.   I checked into the Sugar Bowl motel, reasonable.  Then went looking for Robbie Po'Boys, which a local itinerant mentioned as cheap.  Up and down Park and Main again a couple of times, and by the time I found it, it was closed. So I decided to explore the town a little.  Nice town.  Big church, with a cemetary adjacent, the typical southern swamp area cemetary with the graves all above ground. So to get a sandwich, I stopped at a local, almost yuppie-like coffee shop (no Starbucks down here!) and had a great roast beef and cheese sandwich, dressed.  And the coffee shop had internet access as well.  Can you beat that?  Yes, when I left I rode a couple of blocks to a local ice cream shop and topped it all of with a chocolate malt. And wound up getting back to the motel around 8 PM, riding in the dark.  So what started out as quitting early wound up as getting to bed late, by the usual biking standards.   Left the campground at 6:30am, got to Houma at 3:30 PM.  9 hours on the road, but only 6 hours pedalling, so I must have sat around 3 hours.  Avg spped was 8.6, with a max of 21 going down after crossing a bridge near Amelia, the intercoastal waterway, I think.       
Followed 182 out-of-town but missed a cutoff I wanted, so instead wound up on Rt. 90.  Like an expressway, so I got off at Rt. 1 and backtracked to Raceland, and I'm following Rt. 182 again.  Right along the road, the Raceland Public Library, so I thought I'd catch up a little. Route 182 is going to peter out, though, and I'll be stuck riding on 90 again. And it did, and I was.  Nothing really spectacular along Rt. 90, almost like riding an expressway.  Wide 4-lane highway, with a very wide shoulder.  Good for travelling, not at all scenic. Where Business 90 splits off to the south, Bayou Signette State Park is only about two miles east of that point.  Ride in found a spot, chatted with a couple of campers, used the shower, set up the tent, in the sack at about dusk.  A little warm, not much breeze so plenty of mosquitoes.  Zip up the tent FAST!         
  Found my way to La Petite Motel, only $75 for two nights.  Only about 14 miles from the state Park to Jackson Square in the French Quarters - could have stayed in the state park, taken the ferry across the river each day.   Minor disaster: had to have the front deraileur replaced.  But Joe's Bike Shop was just a couple of blocks down from the motel, and they took care of me right away. For anybody who's considering travelling to New Orleans, keep these places in mind: La Petit Motel - 2836 Tulane - (504) 822 1420.  Just a couple of blocks out from Broad and Tulane Streets, Rts. 90 and 61.  Near the Criminal Courts building, and only about 10 minutes ride down to the Vieux Carre (French Quarters) and the Central Business District.  Not a fancy motel, cheap, warm shower, cheap, good air conditioner, cheap, and 1st floor rooms.  Cheap, too, if I didn't mention that.  Joe's Bike Shop - 2509 Tulane (504) 821-2354.  Just a couple of blocks south of the motel.   Went to a free concert in LaFayette Square that started at 5PM.  It was OK, pretty much jazz.  I didn't stay long, returned to the Vieux Carre, there was a better street concert there - and impromptu group of street musicians. Truthfully, New Orleans is a city of sounds and smells - neither of which is suitable for internet transmission.  I rode down Bourbon Street and you're assaulted with music - jazz, Zydeco, blues - and smells from the different restuarants.  Stopped for a Po'Boy on the way back to the motel.  The first time ever I found my way without getting lost!  Got back before dark. I'll stay one full day before continuing on to Ocean Springs to visit (freeload) with my sister, Susie.   
Spent the whole day in New Orleans, going nowhere, just pedaling around.  New Orleans is great for just hanging out.  Lots of good places to eat or just snack, lots of interesting people, local and tourists, to just watch.      Left the motel around 7:30am.  (New Orleans is probably more of a late-night city, but it's kinda tough to navigate on a bike after it gets dark; ergo, it's early to bed and early to rise!) The public library, right down Toulane on the bike, didn't open until 10am, so I went looking for an internet cafe.  Found one, took me two hours to bring this journal up-to-date and to upload the pictures.  Very user friendly, allowed me to telnet and to download the desktop application to upload the pictures.  At the same time, I had them burn a CD with the pictures I'd taken so far.  All the pictures, including the bad ones.  I'll sort 'em out when I get home. I took the 'poor-man's-cruise' on the Mississippi: the Canal Street ferry over to the Algiers section.  Some really great seafood gumbo at the Dry Dock cafe right off the dock area.  The last time I was here, I got lost and had a hard time finding my way back, but this time it was easier.  The levee on the west bank has a path along the top.  Paved on the southern section, hard packed gravel on the rest.  So I rode the distance, saw some of the industrial zone. Didn't cost anything to cross the river.     Then I just kinda piddled around the Vieux Carre (the French Quarters) and the Central Business District.  No real destination.  Had bignettes early in the morning with coffee along the waterfront someplace.  Watched the barges travel back and forth.  More tugboats than anything else.  The littlest tugboats had the loundest horns.        Biggest disapointment: the little shop in the Jax Building catterwampus from Jackson Square that used to be famous for bignettes:  well, it's now a Crispy Cream Donut shop!  I like Crispy Creme, but it didn't seem the same at all.   Later on, went back to Jackson Square for a little more impromptu street concert.  Same band, different tourists.   But when the sun started to go down, I went back to the motel to get ready for the next day and travelling again.     
Around 9am, I came to the NASA plant where the manufacture the first-stage rockets for the space program.  Big!  Shortly after that, I came to the Bayou Sauvage Wildlife Area.  Rode/walked the bike along the path, boardwalk into the bayou area.  Saw my first snake, but of course it disappeared to fast to take a picture.  Beautiful area, primitive, scary.  Lots of noises from strange animals or birds, couldn't be sure which.   This isn't a bad route out of the city: I-10 is out of the question, and even Rt. 90 can get busy and crowded so I tried to take the old roads as much as possible.  But soon Almonaster turned into Old Gentilly Road, and that ended back on Rt. 90. Heading east, Rt. 90 turns back into a two-lane road with an intermittent shoulder.  Not much traffic but it does move fast.  Not a lot of highlights along the way.  Crossed several small bridges, may 6-8 along the way.   Near the Fort Pike area, I stopped at the shrimp market where I'd stopped on a trip 10 years ago and saw the whole thing in operation.  This time, it was closed!  Dunno if it's permanently closed or what.  Most of the equipment was still in place, but nobody around.  I found out later that the Lousiana trawling season is open, but the Mississippi season isn't yet.   So I crossed the Rigolets bridge and continued east.  At the roadside rest area (picnic tables and shade, but no facilities) the camera batteries finally wore out, after two weeks.  I changed them, then came across my first alligator in the wild.  Small, there were two of them.  Some local people came out to feed them with what looked like cat food.   Along this way I met up with another cyclists with only a backpack heading for Philadelphia.  A little down on his luck, I think.  Going through a divorce, unemployed, couldn't get in touch with his children, etc.  I shared some Gatorade, gave him a couple of bucks, suggested he get some kindofa water container of something or he was going to get dehydrated.  Right around Waveland, I headed south to go along Beach Road and the Gulf, he continued straight on Rt. 90 which was more direct. I had breakfast earlier, but wasn't hungry but getting near the campground, so I stopped and had a Po'Boy which I coudn't finish.  It seems like you lose your appetite riding.   Arrived at Bucanner State Park around 5pm or so, even registered this time.  The Camp Store wasn't open, so it's a good thing I'd eaten earlier.  Nice spot, not to far from the shower house.  Unloaded the bike, set up the tent, then rode around the park until it got dark and was time to go to bed.   The average speed was 9.3 mph but I achieved a maximun of 24 mph, probably on the downside of one of those bridges leaving New Orleans.  Rt. 90 up to Buccaneer State Park or Bay St. Louis is OK for travelling but no real bargain for scenery.  It's flat, turns back into a 4-lane highway with a wide shoulder. But it's still grinding out the miles. No real place to stop, and it would be tough to find a place for guerrila-camping if that became necessary. At least Beach Road was more scenic, even if it added a couple of miles to the trip. 
The bridge (causeway, I think) is a mile or so long, 4-lane.  Years ago, I rode it carefully on the sidewalk.  I started out that way, but decided to be a little more agressive and 'take the lane.'  I rode out in the right-hand lane, about 1/3 of the way out from the edge.  Cars had to pass by getting into the other lane, then couldn't squeeze by by riding in the same lane as me.  The bridge is flat, so they had plenty of time to see me.  This seemed to work out pretty good, I didn't get run over.  Later on, a similar bridge between Biloxi and Ocean Springs had a much wider sidewalk, so I took the sidewalk for this one. Found a Waffle House and had a real breakfast finally, although later in the day.  Once you cross into Pass Christian, it's pretty much civilization all the  way east from that point.  Long cities, stretched out along the Gulf of Mexico.  Pass Christian, Long Beach, Gulfport, Biloxi.  Lots of sand-drifts, just like our snow-drifts up north in the winter.  Same riding, be careful you don't slip and slide.  When they was across the road, you need to be careful pulling out into traffic.   Still, you're not going to run out of scenery, food, or water.   I did stop at the Beau Rivage, one of the more upscale resorts, just to use their ATM machine.  First ATM I ever ran into that gave me 100-dollar bills instead of 20's.  Well, at least at a casino you can get change easily, without playing too. Made it to my sisters by 3pm easily.  On the road for about 7 hours, but only pedalled 4.75, so I must have spend about 2.25 sitting around.  This ratio seems to have held up most of the trip.     
Sat, like a vegtable, most of the day. Considered my alternatives for the rest of the trip.  Still haven't decided yet.  I think the heat and sunlight makes it hard to think. 
Leaft around 7am heading east, towards Pensacola.  Really a 3-day trip for me, not 2.  Once again, a very stiff headwind most of the day.  That seems to be the story for this trip.  Riding 90 east isn't really a bargain, wide road, wide shoulder in most places but it's commercial/industrial, and where it isn't it's long, flat, boring, and hot.   Cool and misty in the morning.  There's a catfish pond in the yard, and there were several frogs croaking in the morning.  Sounded like a bunch of tuba players trying to get in tune.  At one point, I swear the frogs were playing the theme song from Jaws.  To bad I didn't record it. 10:30, 21 miles: Pascogula. 10:50, 24 miles, the Singing River Bridge.  New bridge, being constructed, to replace a drawbridge.  The eastbound traffic was still using the old bridge.  When they replace these bridges, the build 'em high enough to allow ship traffic under the bridge.  Do they realize what they're doing to cyclists when they build these "hills" into the route! 1:00pm, 37 miles, the Alabama State Line.  There was no fanfare, just a sign. 1:30, 42 miles, Hwy 188.  I almost missed it, or I got onto a sideroad that led to it, I'm not sure which! 4:00pm, 57 Miles, the Fowl River.  'nuther bridge crossing.  Middle-gear headwind again, kept it up. 5:00pm, 64 miles, the foot of the bridge to Dauphin Island.  This is really high and long!  But there was a sufficient shoulder and perfectly useable by bikes.  I was a little concerned about this.  Rain threatening, so I packed the camera up safely.  But the temptation to take pictures from the top of the bridge was too great, so I unpacked it again.    Shortly before 6:30, I arrived at the ferry.  I could have taken the last one, but instead decided to stay at the campground, which was right across the street from the ferry.  $16, a little high, but nice.  I set the tent, went to take a shower, just as it started to rain - hard! But the good news, my tentsite was right next to a community building, enclosed, covered.  The campground lady wanted to lock it up for the night, but I talked her into letting me stay inside so I didn't have to take my bike out.  I slept on a picnic bench!    Rained like hell all night, all I had for supper was a beef and cheese stick for 99-cents from the camp store.  But I was dry, had cranberry juice, nectarines, and grapes. Life is good.  Bikes are fun. 
Anyway, the first ferry wasn't until 8 am so after getting up early I rode the two miles or so back to the 3-way intersection expecting coffee.  Instead what I found was a deli with scrambled eggs, grits, sausages, biscuits, and jelly.  Yum!  Ate outside again at the picnic table.  Even though I was inside under cover all night, the tent was wet and the sleeping bag was damp.  I had left it to dry but it didn't much.  So I boarded the ferry promptly at 8 am.  Not to busy, only two other cars.      Lots of seagulls hitching a free ride across the bay and a bunch of pelicans following.  Seems like the birds enjoyed trying to see how close they could fly to the people on the ferry.      Not far off on the other side, maybe 12:30 or so, I came to Gulf State Park - and took a refreshing afternoon shower.  Nice area for riding.  I had been following Rt 180, but it was really Rt. 182 I intended to follow, so I was slightly lost.  But I found my way back to Rt. 182. In the Gulf State Park and continuing to Orange City there was an off-road bike path started that continued through most of the city, and even when it ended there was a bike lane marked on the road shoulder - again separated from the traffic lanes by a couple of feet.   This terminated abruptly at the Florida state line.  That shoulder went to zero, nothing right at the state line.  Found my way to the Big Lagoon State Park, and a library about a mile away.  However, the only place with something to eat was a Burger King so I compromised on my promise to stay out of chain places.   Nice park, but the whole park is nicer than the campground.  I got in a spot right across from the toilet and shower.  However, no cover.  The shower was up a hill, and a set of about 20 steps or so up.   Funny thing I noticed about the shower area: in the men's room there was a handicap equipped toilet and shower both - but there was no way for a handicapped person to make it up to the building!  A high set of stairs only on both sides, no ramp, and the only alternative was climbing up through the sand.  So what was the point of equipping the stalls for handicapped use?  Some government regulation?  I all for making these things available to the handicapped, but for heaven's sake why at the top of a hill they couldn't possible climb? The campsite was set up for an RV and the gravel was impenetrable with the tent stakes.  I found I could move the picnic bench out and the area where the picnic bench was, was soft.  So I set the tent up there.  Then I noticed I was only about fifteen feet or so from a creek or bayou.  Alligators?  Snakes?  Too late to move.  All kinds of life, though.  They started singing early and kept it up late.      Around 9pm I awoke to the rain.  So I dashed outside and quickly put the rain-fly over the tent.  The bike bags were secured under plastic and the important stuff (camera, shoes) were inside the tent.  So I crawled back in, damp, and tried to sleep.  That rain fly really cuts down on what little breeze there was, so it became warm and damp and the frogs and wildlife set up a real symphony.  And the rain continued - all night long.  A real gully-washer.   In the morning, the tent was wet, the sleeping bag damp, the bugs were out in full force.  Not quite the accommodations of the night before.   After over two weeks of no rain at all it was mostly psychologically difficult to deal with rain two nights in a row. 
By 6:00 or so it started to get light.  I packed the wet tent, damp sleeping bag, and everything else.  The gas station with coffee was about two miles from the campsite, but it had real cream (most of the places use that powdered stuff), blueberry muffins, and a picnic table outside well away from the gas pumps.  That's nice, if you can put some distance between you and the gas pumps in the morning.  However, the next five miles or so along Beach Road (I think) on the way to Pensacola was about the worst road of the trip.  Narrow, two-lane, no shoulder - and a tremendous amount of continuous traffic.  Perhaps commuter traffic into Pensacola?  It was moving pretty fast for a country road, and frequently cars would pass.  That is, the first car behind me would slow for me, but the second car couldn't see me and would pass the first car.  By the time both cars came along side me, there was no room for the first car to nudge over to the left to allow me additional room.  I had to pull off into the grass a couple of times.  Once, a pickup truck passed another car coming from the opposite direction!  That's a little bit scary, seeing a truck approaching you head-on in the lane you're supposed to be in.   It was about five miles or so before the road gained a shoulder which made riding a lot easier.  And, looking at the map later, there really wasn't much in the way of an alternative route since it's near the coast and most of the adjacent land is swamp.      I opted to head for the north end of Pensacola, the Greyhound station, and a cluster of motels.  Got the ticket, made sure they had a box, checked into the nearest motel, unloaded the bike and prepared for about a 10-mile ride back south to the downtown area and the coast.  Only about 20 miles to this point, but it seemed like a lot more. Pensacola has a nice downtown area, historic, scenic, restored.  Seems like lot of government buildings.  I headed east again, along what I think was Rt. 90, and had a heckova time finding the Welcome Center.  It's set off to the side, along another road, but had a nice park, covered picnic tables, and an entrance to the Fishing Bridge. Fishing Bridge:  Many of the bridges down south were low bridges, causeways actually, with either a turn-bridge or a lift-bridge in the middle to let the ships through.  Many of these bridges were replaced with bridges with a very high section in the middle that ships can pass under.  However, they didn't tear out the entire old bridge - they just cut out a section in the middle.  So you can walk/ride out to the end of these old sections.  Lots of people fishing - and pelicans walking - along these half-bridges.      Yesterday I complained about the lack of bike facilities when crossing from Alabama into Florida - but this section was very bike friendly.  For example: the bridge to Gulf Beach, about three miles long, had a marked bike lane.  This was at the extreme edge of the roadway and there was about a 3-foot "shoulder" between the traffic lanes and the bike lane.  Interestingly, this must have been added later because you could see the old lane markings.  They shaved about a foot off of each of the two traffic lanes, making them narrower to gain an addition couple of feet on the side for the bike lane.  I'm sure AAA wasn't too happy about this.   Before I crossed the bridge I was sitting in the park and it started to rain - heavy rain.     It was around noon and I was about to give up the idea of crossing but it stopped and the sun came out so I went ahead.  Even after crossing the three-mile bridges the bike lane continued or there was a marked path along side the road.  Frequent signs along the bridge or roadway suggested "Watch for Bikes" or "Roadway Shared with Bikes" or something similar.   Another thing I noticed: the motorists all stop at the light behind the white line.  None of this creeping forward stuff.  Sometimes three or four lanes of traffic, but the first cars at the light all lined up at the white line, not at the imaginary line where the traffic signals are.   I had to cross another bridge to get to the outer island.  Pretty much a tourist area.  The right-turn led to the old fort and the sign said "Road Ends in 9 miles".  I didn't ride the entire distance, it was getting late and I knew I had the long 20-mile ride to get back to the motel.  The tourist area is centered around the intersection and it gets a little more sparse at you get away from this area.   But some dark clouds were appearing and I thought I'd better head back.  Getting caught in a rainstorm along a 3-mile bridge without any chance of cover didn't sound attractive to me.  Especially with the wind atop the high part of the bridge.   When I got back to the Welcome Center on the mainland I schmoozed the ladies there for a little more information.  The information they had was very car-centric. One woman did suggest another route back to the area I was staying.  It was along 17th Avenue, a minor through street mostly residential.  This took me to Texar (and that is NOT pronounced like you think it is, it "te-HAR" and she couldn't explain the pronunciation either!) and across back to the highway where I only need to ride a short distance.  Found a local rib joint, Smokey's BBQ, along Pensacola Avenue.  Great!  Pork ribs, pecan-smoked.  A mild sauce.  Baked potatoe and coleslaw, 10 bucks.  Picnic table type of setup inside.  Waitress kept refilling my soft drink.   Pensacola is in Escambia County, and the transit system is operated by the county, not by each city which is a good idea.  The Welcome Ladies, however, weren't at all familiar with the bus system.  I had noticed that all the buses were equipped with the bikes racks in front.  In fact, I saw two busses that had a bike on the rack.  Just for the cheap-thrill I considered taking a bus for part of the distance.  They did dig up for me a 60-page booklet with the various routes - but like any visitor unfamiliar with the terrain I couldn't really figure it out.  It listed about 35 routes, but some were evening and weekend.  Each route formed some kind of loop, and there were transfer points.  It may have been possible to take a bus from the outer islands all the way up to I-10 (which I was staying near) but it would have been necessary to transfer a couple of time.  Sheltered bus stops too.   Another thing the welcome center had was two internet kiosks - which was interesting.  Nobody was using them, and a sign suggested limiting use to 15-minutes or so.  So I check my email.  It did rain a little more while I was there - so it wasn't a bad day when it rains twice and both times I was under cover someplace.   After the rib dinner I got back to the motel before dark No more rain, I could have stayed out later but of course you don't know that at the time. 
This area around I-10, Rt. 29, Palafox Road, Pensacola Highway is known as Car City, and it is.  All kinds of car dealers.  Big ones, small ones, new cars, used cars, trucks, RV's SUV's, anything you want.  Not the most attractive riding area.   But if you stray away into the side roads and neighborhoods it really isn't a bad area.  Lots of trees and vegetation and this cuts down, almost eliminates, the traffic noise.  It was a lot more pleasant than I thought it would be.   About Greyhound:  this was my first experience traveling with the bike by Greyhound, so I got to the terminal around 8:30.   First, the bike box is different from Amtrak or the airlines.  It's smaller but wider and it was necessary to remove both the front and rear wheels to get the bike into the box.  I used their tape and secured the bottom.  I unloaded and secured the two pair of panniers from the bike and checked them as checked luggage.   Even after removing the wheels the bike, removing the pedals and turning the handlebars the bike wouldn't quite fit!  The front-rider lowboy carriers took some room and the kickstand I had was one of those mounted near the rear axle.  When I got done I had to tear a corner of the box, and the kickstand protruded about 6 inches.  Nobody beefed about that, however.   I put the bike in upside down, so this protected the gears and derailleur mechanism.  Of course the wheels went in along side the frame.  When I closed up the box and taped it it was slightly misshapen, but I figured it would travel OK.  I just threw the pedals in the box but forgot to pack the front handlebar bag in so that was one more thing I needed to carry on the bus, along with the tent bag.   There was a bus change in Mobile.  The first bus was a Greyhound, with plenty of cargo space and the bike box stood upright.  I was cautioned by the people at the terminal in Pensacola to watch the baggage handling in Mobile, to make sure the checked luggage stayed together, and got on the right bus.  The policy of Greyhound, I think, is that you are responsible for schlepping your own luggage, though they'll help.   The bus from Mobile to Biloxi was a Trailways bus, and the luggage compartment was smaller - and the box wouldn't fit upright.  They laid it down on the bottom, but put my bags on top.  Only about four people were on the bus for this first leg of the journey so there wasn't a lot of luggage - fortunately.  I was concerned about what would happen if they packed heavy boxes or luggage atop the box and potentially doing damage the dismounted wheels which were the most fragile.   But the bus stopped in Pascagoula and then Biloxi, so there wasn't much chance for damage.  In fact, the bus got off I-10 and followed Rt. 90 most of the way - the same route I'd traveled a couple of days earlier.   I asked about getting a bike box in Biloxi: No.  The terminal there didn't stock them.  So I carefully opened the box and talked them into saving the box for me.  I had a choice: either ride back to New Orleans, leaving Tuesday or staying with my sister and taking the bus to New Orleans leaving on Thursday.  Trying to keep my options open.  I'm pretty sure I can leave the bike in the Greyhound box and put it on Amtrak directly.   Only about a 20-mile ride from the Biloxi terminal to my sister's house in Ocean Springs.  Stopped at Fayards for a Po'Boy Sandwich.  It's a gas station along the route back to I-10, doesn't look like much more than a big gas station until you get inside and find out they have a full deli and tables - and make about the best Po'Boy sandwiches anywhere.  About the best of the trip.  Of course, I had learned about this on one of my earlier trips.  Unless I decide to ride back to New Orleans, this may have been the last day of extensive traveling with the bike. 
It was my sister's birthday, so we put the bike and bags in her SUV (gag!) and went out for breakfast.  At the bridge to Bay St. Louis she dropped me off to ride Beach Road, along the Gulf.  In looking at a map I saw a road I never noticed before that bypassed a lot of Rt. 90.  Lower Bay Road. I explored it and it was a much more pleasant ride.  It bypassed all of the 4-lane section and a good deal of the 2-lane section.  The road actually crossed Rt. 90, but turned into a gravel road which I took anyway, just to see.  It led into Pearlington, a large wide spot in the road, along the Pearl River and eventually back to Rt. 90 which is kind of hard to totally avoid, since it's the only road along the coast with marshed all over the place.  Stopped and watched the same two alligators in the pond - swimming alongside a half-dozen turtles, so I guess they must co-exist. Met up with another cyclists along the road.  He was a local, going east but decided to go back west to ride with me.  We got stopped by a turn-bridge so we watched the boats go through.  A ton of traffic from the west backed up, but not much from the east.  We decided to let it pass, got to talking, and the darn bridged turned again!  So we had to wait another cycle of boats to get across. This was right near the Rigolets area, the Fort Pike Historical Preserve and there's a picnic area and sheltered cover right nearby.  This was around 4pm or so, to late to go on to New Orelans (I wasn't ready to anyway) so I hung around and waited for it to get dark to set up the tent.  It isn't really a campground but it has everything except a shower and bathrooms.  A nice boat ramp to go down and soft-of wash up in the Gulf of Mexico! Beautiful night, soft breeze, the stars were out and it was reasonably cool as well.  Several picnic tables under the shelter so I had most of the conforts and conveniences of home and knew I was only about 30-40 miles from New Orleans. The only bad part - it was a 10-mile ride west the next morning before I found coffee. 
The hard part was the 9 miles before I found an open place to get coffee, but that went by pretty fast.  I think I sometimes miss a lot when I'm riding to find that first cup of coffee.  After that, it was another 6 miles to the Bayou Sauvage area, and I stopped there and looked around again.  I had time to kill since I wasn't leaving until the next day and was so close to New Orleans anyway.   I didn't have a map of New Orleans (this is my fourth bike trip that included New Orleans and I still can't find my way around!) so I decided to stick with Rt 90 all the way.  Turned out not to be a choice ride - it's a busy secondary highway with lots of businesses and industry.  I rode by Old Gentilly Road (the route I'd taken when leaving New Orleans earlier) but stayed on Rt. 90.  It turned into a suburban/business area.  Busy, nothing really interesting except maybe crossing over the high bridge that crosses the navigation canal.   I was at Broad and Tulane (Rts 90 and 61) which was near the motel I was planning on staying, by about 11:30 or so.  Really, I could have taken the train the same day since it didn't leave 'till around 2 PM or so.  So much for planning.  I considered riding to the campground on the other side of the river but I started to get tired and opted for the motel instead.  Rode down to the French Quarter (again!) then decided to unload the bike so I went back to the motel, registered, and got ride of some of the weight.  Took a shower, and a long nap - so I must have been really dragging. Got another map and decided to explore a little more of the city.  Found out that, coming into New Orleans, I could have easily found a way up to Lake Ponchatrain, ridden along the lake, come down through City Park and the Jeff Davis Parkway path.  Next time. So I did take the Jeff Davis Parkway, at least until City Park.  New Orleans has a lot of these parkways or boulevards, divided streets with trees and grass separating the one-way streets.  Jeff Davis has a path right up the middle.  Yes, you have to grapple with the intersections but the traffic is reasonably show and it's not bad.  Not all of the side streets cut through the path, only the major streets.   Returning downtown, I then rode out to the Garden District, only a short distance.  To avoid getting lost (again) I just followed the St. Charles streetcar tracks, then going off the tracks for a block or two into the side streets, making sure I could find my way back to the streetcar tracks again.  The Garden District isn't much different from the French Quarters, except it's all residental, bigger, and more spread out.  Old, though.   Lunch or dinner at a small tavern along St. Charles.  I saw a lot of police cars in the lot, so I figured this must be the place to go.  It was.  A combination plate that included gumbo, jambalaya, and red beans and rice.  A little spicy, but two big glasses of iced tea did OK. Riding into the periphery again, I stumbled blindly across the D-Day Museum, which my brother-in-law, Les, had suggested.  Full of WWII artifacts.  I got there around 4, and it closed at 5, so I didn't get to see much of it.  WWII afficianados would appreciate it.  Seemed to me they had a large contingent of WWII veterans active in the museum. Across the street was a new art museum of some sort - but in a brownstone building I recognized from a previous visit.  Previously, it was a civil war museum.  I didn't visit the art museum but I enjoyed the civil war museum a lot on the previous visit.  A little Political Correctness at work here? Back to the French Quarters for a little (free) entertainment, people watching, and then to the motel shortly after dark.
My usual practice is to take the pair of front and rear panniers, link them together with a threaded chain-link replacement.  Then I use one of the bungee cords that used to strap the tent/sleeping bag stuff bag onto the rear carrier. That way, I have two "bags" to check instead of four.  This is in addition to the bike, which this time cost me a total of $15.  I seem to remember it was more in Chicago - dunno why. I put the stuff I want on the train (toothbrush, book, etc.) into the top of the stuff bag and carry the thing as carry-on luggage.  This gives me the stuff I want plus I have the sleeping bag to snuggle into if I have to sleep in the coach car.   During a bike trip, you're on "Lived-Time" instead of "Clock-Time" so I don't wear a watch but depend on the clock in the bicycle computer if it's necessary. So I take the computer off the bike and put it in my fanny-pack.  The hard part, at the end of a trip, is transitioning from Lived-Time back into Clock-Time.  No problem checking the bike or packing it and I hung around the station for over an hour since I was so early.  Without a bike you can't go to far!   The train was very crowded from the start, and got more crowded as we headed north.  Alas, no sleeping compartments were available.  Worse, some fat girl squeezed into the seat next to me also going to Chicago! My mistake, I think, was dressing like a human being (walking shorts, sport shirt) instead of like a cyclist (grungy shorts, dirty cotton pullover shirt, look like an unkempt bum) for the trip.  Had I looked like a cyclist, I'm pretty sure I would have retained the whole two seats to myself.  This makes sleeping a little easier.  But it wasn't bad, once I shimmied into the sleeping bag.  Woke once during the night, walked around, went back to sleep.  I must have slept pretty good, because I don't remember any of the stops, particularly Memphis which is a 40-minute wait while the uncouple and re-couple cars.   One unexpected thing: my rear-end hurt sitting in the seats.  The tender parts from riding the bike.  No kidding, at that point the bike seat riding seemed more comfortable than sitting.  I never thought I'd have a problem sitting, but I did.  Spent a lot of time standing on the train.  Had breakfast on Friday morning on the train, as soon as the diner opened.  Eating on the train is expensive - around $9, not including tip, for bacon and eggs.  Get the sleeping car (cheap) if you can or else be prepared to bring your own snacks.  Even a cup of coffee from the snack bar was a buck-and-a-half. The train left on time, and amazingly arrived on time in Chicago.  I retrieved my bags, and the lady checking the tags told me to leave them, retrieve my bike from the downstairs shipping, then come back up and retrieve the bags.  This made it very convienient to re-load the bike.  The train arrived around 9 AM, and I was ready to roll out shortly after 10 AM.  Don't try and cheat but load the bike just as carefully as if you were going 100 miles, even though you're only about 10 miles from home. A very pleasant ride back to my apartment! Except that it was comparatively cold, aroung 65 degrees. It even rained a little on the way home. A bike lane on Canal Steet, a bike lane on Milwaukee, a bike lane on Elston, and a bike lane on Lawrence Avenue.  Compared to some of the other cities I visited, Chicago wins hands-down for being bike friendly.  I suppose it helps that I know my way around. 
From a note on the garage wall, I rode 1100.2 miles total. I spent 2 nights on a train, 9 nights in motels, 10 nights in campgrounds, and 7 nights at my sister's house.   When I left Chicago, it was cool 60's.  The south was hot, 80's..  When I returned to Chicago, it was cool, 60's.  Big temperature difference.  On the train ride back, I noticed the corn grew progressively shorter as we sped north.  Most of the trip was hot, but dry.  The only rain was the two days on the way to Pensacola but that was enough to make up for it.  Most of the trip, particularly the first three weeks, I seemed to always be riding with the wind in my face. Northern Texas and Louisiana is hilly, but further south it flattens out quite a bit.   Having friends or relatives at the end of a trip, or near the end, is a big plus.  You don't need to ride to meet a deadline or a ticket-date.  This is the flex-time of the trip: you may spend an hour, a day, or a week visiting - depending on the time it takes to ride the route you've planned.  The big thing is to SLOW DOWN.  Tough to do, psychologically, when you consider the miles in front of you.  Particularly in the start of a trip like this, you tend to rush and maybe bypass things you shouldn't because they'll take an hour or two from the day - and drop your distance by 20 miles or so.  Ride each day as if you'll never return again - because you may not. Camping is not bad, even guerrila-camping or stealth-camping where there are no campgrounds.  I passed a lot of places where I could have safely pitched a tent for the night.  Small churches in rural areas, isolated, are a good spot.  The grass is cut, you can hide behind the structure and not be seen from the road, and even find a water spigot.  I saw several locations along the way that would have served the purpose.  Asking directions is a good way to meet people.  I have the usual "guy-thing" about asking directions, but once I overcame that it became an important part of the trip.  Don't be surprised when people ask YOU for directions.  They figure, on a bike, you must be local.  And the bike makes you more approachable too.  Sometimes you even have a map and can help them out.  Dogs weren't really a problem.  I was never concerned about my safety, and was more concerned about attracting dogs out into the middle of the highway where they could get into more trouble than me! Sleeping is a great part of the trip.  In order to get a good sleep, you need to be both tired and relaxed.  If you don't have both, you won't sleep well.  At the end of the day you are (or should be) both tired and relaxed.  Tent or bed, it's really a great part of the trip, falling asleep each night. Time to start planning next year's wanderings....
If you've made it this far - thank you - maybe you can read a little further. The purpose of this site is to keep friends and family in tune to what I'm up to this summer - traveling from Washington, D.C. to New Orleans alone by bicycle.  I'm afraid that this site will only be a skeleton until late August when I can upload photos and enter more elaborate journal entries.  For the time during my trip (approximately July 15 to August 10) I will be stopping at public libraries throughout the Southeast to enter basic information of my whereabouts and plans and perhaps a few of the more interesting journal entries that I will be writing daily by hand. Please come back and visit again, and if you haven't yet, sign my guestbook.  Thanks!!!
  Show links to this Hide links to this      July, 2001 The idea for this trip came to me during the fall of 1999.  I had purchased Bicycle Across America by Barbara Siegert.  The author, a woman in her 60's, relates tales from her five cross-country bicycle rides.  I was amazed that someone at that age could accomplish such a feat many times over.  I basically figured, "If she could do it, so could I."  The imagination kicked in, and I thought about how a trip like that would incorporate many of the things that I derive enjoyment from:  bicycling, traveling, camping, being outside, getting lost and then finding my way, seeing new places, visiting friends, meeting new people and so on.   So, the decision to do a big trip came awhile back, but I had to wait for the opportunity.  As this past school year went by, I saw the opportunity blossoming for the ride to take place this summer.  Once I had the trip dates in my calendar, I could start planning.  I have enjoyed the planning phase immensely:  where I'll go, who I'll visit, what to bring, what to eat, etc.  So, after I finished a short ed course at UNO early this summer, I packed up my junk and drove to my parents' house in Northern Virginia.  The bike ride was definitely on my mind, but I put it on the back burner as my friend, Pat Lovett, and I backpacked throughout Western Europe (which was, by the way, a great time) for half of June and half of July.   I don't know exactly what to expect out of this trip.  I have done my research, but I will never know how it all feels until I actually go out there and do it.  I think traveling the Southeast at 12mph is going to be great fun - it's just fast enough to be making daily progress towards a goal, but it is slow enough to experience the world around me as I pass through it.  I am excited for the actual riding, but more so, I am excited for the adventure. There will be, of course, problems along the way.  I feel like I have planned quite well to minimize the likelihood of them, but certainly I will face some adversity - be it flat tires, poor weather, unwelcoming townfolk, sore legs...But, it is those tribulations that I will derive the most enjoyment from surpassing.  If everyday was 70 degrees with a tailwind, down hill, on smooth pavement without cars, and with a 7-11 every five miles, the trip would be much less of an experience.
I am very excited for the adventure that awaits me - certainly the biggest traveling one of my life.  I am excited to arrive at my doorstep in New Orleans a few weeks from now with a great accomplishment under my belt.  But, more than all of that, I am excited for the daily tedium of riding.  It will be boring and hot at times, but I hope to transcend all of that and derive pleasure from those things that would aggravate most people. I plan to head out tomorrow morning and make the 12 mile ride into the District of Columbia where my DC-residing relatives (aunt, brother, and sister-in-law) will be there to greet me.  All of us will ride around town for a little bit, do some photo-ops in front of the Lincoln Memorial, and then I'll cross the Potomac for the second time to head south.  This trip will start at one great river and end at another, and it will start in one beautiful city and end at another.  I think when I say good-bye to those folks it will really sink in:  four days to Chapel Hill, North Carolina and no familiar faces along the way - just pavement.   I'm excited.
Accommodations:  Aquia Pines Campground      It felt quite strange leaving my parents' garage and heading out to Georgetown Pike.  I have made that short jaunt by foot, bike, and car thousands of times before but this one was different.  This bike ride would not terminate here.  I headed into the city on some of the wonderful paved trails that Northern Virginia has to offer.  It was early on a Sunday morning but there were joggers and bikers everywhere.      Show links to this Hide links to this      It was special for my family and friends to meet me where I crossed into DC, Key Bridge.  We talked for a little bit and took some photos.  And then I was off, and as I thought it would, I felt awkward.  I wanted to turn around and just hang out with them -- you know, for the rest of the summer.          But I moved on.  I crossed the Memorial Bridge and unofficially started my trip.  From now on I will be heading south and west.  The ten mile ride to Mount Vernon (George Washington's home) was filled with great scenery and a packed bike trail.  I didn't mind the people really, soon I will be the lone biker.  Two different guys struck up conversation with me on this leg - nice folks wishing me well on my trip.      Leaving Mount Vernon, I had about a 25 mile stretch of riding on Route 1.  It may be the predecessor to I95 but it is still used a lot.  But nice shoulders and no big trucks, so no complaints about the road.  Well, except for one thing, it's filled with hills.  I can handle rolling hills just fine:  out of the saddle, in the saddle, repeat once or twice.  But, these hills are much more than that - half milers that can break your will to ride.  I learned quickly to pace myself - no hurry, take a break (repeat). I am pleased with how the rig has held up so far.  I got a flat in Triangle, Virginia (coincidentally, at about the same place I got one with my car five years ago - but this one was at 6mph not 70).  The flat was my fault.  I had the rear tire well underinflated and overweighted.  I changed tubes and decided to break out my new Conti tire that I had in my pannier.  It is a superior touring tire, and I can keep inflated to 110psi.  It is doing much better than the old tire.  I also took my sleeping bag off the back and tied it to my handlebar bag, and that seems to be helping.  I am using the gears on my bike like never before.  I am constantly shifting gears to let the mechanics help me with the work.  I think as this trip goes on I will become even more adept at the use of my 24 gears.  Finally on the rig side of things, my GPS came in handy a few times already.  I have used it to pinpoint my location on a map and figure out how much farther I had to go to the campsite for the night. The campsite I stayed at was quite basic, but it had what I needed:  flat, soft ground and a shower.  My sweat today was very salty probably due to the fact that I haven't worked out this hard for awhile, and I had to get all of those toxins out of me.  I think the half hour it takes to set up camp is the reward for a hard day's work.  Setting up camp while the legs are still throbbing and the endorphins are still pulsating has a very calming effect.  The smell of the campfires blazing, of course, brings back good memories.  Dinner, however, was not the normal camping-fare.  I walked a quarter mile down Route 1 to a Chinese take-out joint:  beef with broccoli and plenty of rice.
Accommodations:  Christopher Run Campground Quote of the Day:  "Work is for people who don't fish" Seen on a bumper sticker at the campground    After doing some research last night, I had to decide between going about 85 miles to a campsite west of Richmond or about 45 miles to a campsite northwest of Richmond.  The decision was easy this morning, because the legs were definitely sore.  I will be making the shorter trek today, and I think that that is the smart thing to do.  In the beginning of this journey it is very important to follow up moderate days (like yesterday) with a lighter day.  Later, when I get in better shape I can double up moderate and/or heavy days with less difficulty. I left the campground this morning after an hour of packing up my stuff.  I am finding that managing my load will be a major aspect of this trip.  I headed out of the campground and south on Route 1 for some more huge hills.  In Fredericksburg (home of Mary Washington College; yeah Michelle!) I started west on Route 3.  I passed a library sign, and I couldn't resist the temptation of air conditioning and internet access.  So here I am at the Central Rappahannock Regional Library in Chancellor, Virginia. -----      After some excellent navigational work through the wiles of the Central Virginia wilderness, I arrived at my destination.  The campground charged me five bucks for anywhere on the green behind the RV camping area.  As I rode through the RV camp a young man in front of his RV, with the Confederate flag flying high above on his makeshift pole, gave me a look of amazement.  I smiled and waved and rode on.  One could only assume what he was thinking.   Choosing a spot on the lawn didn't take long.  Although the area was large and without other campers, I decided quickly on the only spot in the shade.  I set up camp and headed up to the camp grocery in search of food.  Since town was five miles away I figured I would have to make do with whatever they had:  Hungryman Turkey dinner and a microwave.    Otherwise uneventful.  Plotted out course for next day in a gazebo by the lake.
Accommodations:  Bear Creek Lake State Park Campground Quote of the Day:  NONE due to the fact that I saw under 25 cars the entire day and not a single person (besides a few service station cashiers) outside of a car.  The campground was even on an honor pay system.    Today was my best riding day yet.  I was on the back back roads of the state.  I am finding, however, that those back roads, although they are the straightest line between points A & B, aren't necessarily the fastest route.  This is usually due to a large amount of hills that help rack up the miles and the pain factor quickly.  Large state highways aren't so direct but are easier because the road is well developed:  straighter and flatter.  I will keep that in mind as I plan my route through rural Alabama. So, back to the actual riding.  I had a great time on the unlined, empty state routes.  I was less worried about cars and was able to take up some more space in the road.  I had been on gravel state routes before on a cross country road trip (by car) I took after college, but those were only in rural West Virginia.  I didn't think that a state route that is marked clearly on my map could be all gravel, but I found that to be the case with Virginia State Route 608.  It travels through the heart of the Cumberland State Forest.  I was a little concerned at first at how the rig would hold up under those conditions - but it did just fine.  Those 15 miles were probably my favorite of the day.  An hour and a half in the forest with no one else around...just the rig and me cruising swiftly. I have noticed that a lot of the state routes in Virginia (I will probably find it elsewhere) really don't connect anything.  Nor are there residences on the road.  They seem to solely exist for the loggers and for fire-fighting access to the forests.  In fact, about thirty miles of my riding today was done on roads through forests.  I passed an occasional logging truck or VA Department of Forestry vehicle but that was about it.   I had my first dog encounter today.  As I was riding through one of the inhabited areas of the state I passed a house with two older Labs out front, a black one and a yellow one.  The yellow one gave chase, as I suspected one or both of them would do.  I was a little worried because normally I can kick the bike to 25 or 30 and out sprint a dog, but with the decked out darthcycle I wasn't sure I could achieve such high speeds.  The yellow Lab started giving chase, and I immediately pulled out my pepper spray.  I started spinning the pedals pretty hard and for a little bit of time we had a good little race going on.  In the end that poor old pooch was no match for even the weighty speed of the darthcycle - I pulled away to the sounds of winded barks.  I put the pepper spray back in the holster - not needed this time. After I set up camp, I had to decide whether to go pedal the one mile up the hill and out of the creek valley to the general store for dinner or to cook on my own.  I went with the dehydrated meal:  noodles and asparagus in an alfredo sauce.  Of course, when you open up the bag it looks like Gatorade powder but smells worse, but I am amazed what boiling water and a little bit of stirring can do.   The rest of the evening was quiet - just a removal of my first tick of the trip from my right shoulder blade.  Went to sleep to the sound of crickets.
Accommodations:  Days Inn Quote of the Day:  "I like riding my bike from time to time, but I ain't riding to'no Louisiana." The most interesting conversations occur outside of gas station food marts, and that is where I met the author of today's QOTD.  He thought I was crazy, but I took that as a compliment.    Awoke at 5:50 to rain coming in my tent.  I immediately ran outside and put on the rain fly (which I had taken off before I went to bed because it was so hot) and then ran my bike up to the bath house where it could stay dry under the awning.  Because I was up, I figured that I would try and find breakfast.  So, I suited up with my tevas and rain jacket and made the trek to the general store.  I ate breakfast on a picnic bench out front of the store and talked to some of the locals (one of which I asked for directions much later in the day ten miles away).  I bought lunch too and then headed back to the tent for a nap.  I awoke late morning as the sun peaked out and heated the tent up.  I decided to eat, pack up, and make use of the second half of the day. I was just about to leave for the day when the rains came again, this time much harder.  I was wet anyway, and I already had packed up, so I decided I'd head to Farmville.  I had a quick little jaunt (something like a time trial in the Tour De France) southwestward to Farmville.  On the way, I passed by some interesting Civil War sites.  Appomattox Court House is only about 25 miles from Farmville so there are some very interesting late war sites in the area.  I stopped at one of them where the Army of Northern Virginia denied the Union's request for surrender.  I won't go on, but I will say one last thing.  At these roadside sites there is, of course, a sign, but there is also a small radio transmitter where you can tune your AM radio and listen in to a more detailed description of the site.  Naturally I had to stop, pull out my radio and listen in.  The loop of audio that was playing had actors reading letters from troops that depicted what went on there.  It was funny to me that the voices of the Confederates had a thick drawl, and the voices of the Union troops had the classic Yankee accent (one that many Alabamians said I had when I lived there).    I got a pizza from Domino's in Farmville, and I decided to go for the Cynastix as well.  They were quite good, but they do not go well with a large deep dish pizza with tomatoes and mushrooms (mental note). I soaked up as much of the Gary Condit coverage as possible.  Quite interesting, as is Dubbya's trip to Europe.  I went to sleep early, because tomorrow I make a big attempt at Chapel Hill:  120 miles away.  I might make it, I might not.
Accommodations:  Olivia & Courtney's Apartment Quote of the Day:  This one has a little story that goes with it.  Picture it:  Bullock, North Carolina, Tammy's.  Tammy's, that's it - well, it's a gas station (no pay at the pump here) and a small grocery.   I had laid my rig up against the front wall of the food mart while I was in the bathroom around the corner.  After my trip to the bathroom, as I was rounding the corner, returning to my rig, I heard two men in their 60's looking over the bike.  One said to the other, "It's got everything on it, except a motor."  The other man laughed and replied, "Yeah, it needs a motor."  He then looked at me as I was approaching and then said, "Here come 'da motor right now." So, that is the quote of the day:  "Here come 'da motor right now."  And henceforth, I will refer to myself as "'da motor."      Today was an amazing day - my biggest daily mileage ever.  I think that is great but what amazes me more is the fact that I did it on the rig, with sore legs, and at such high rate of speed - the fastest of any day yet.  When I pulled into my friend's apartment, I was a little worried that maybe I had done too much, but the fact that I had a great appetite at dinner and that I slept soundly and for nine hours tells me that everything was okay.      I had a 54 mile morning, starting at 7:35am, cruising through southern Virginia and eating lunch in Clarksville.  I ate at Gino's Italian restaurant, and however cliche it may sound, I had the best Turkey and Ham sub of my life.  I lika the juice.  It was good.
