In the morning I had also stopped at a small post office in Wytheville, Virginia to mail to New Orleans my Virginia Atlas, gloves and my long underwear top, all of which will be no longer needed in the South.  I can't say I felt two pounds lighter, but I think that over time my legs were happy to pay the $3.95 in postage.  The weather was cooperative - it never got very hot.     The day was otherwise uneventful.  I ate at a fruit stand where a moustached elderly lady was very sweet to me and thought it was cute that I was riding cross country.   My friend, Olivia, had a great pasta dinner waiting for me upon my arrival in Chapel Hill.  We all had a relaxing evening swapping stories of the past year since we last saw each other.  Later, Olivia had to study for her Accounting class, so I talked with Courtney and wrote in my journal before easily falling asleep.
I slept late Friday morning, did some laundry (showering with my clothes on isn't quite as effective as a good GE washer/dryer), and then took the S bus up the Chapel Hill.  I headed over to Carmichael Auditorium (former stomping grounds of MJ and MS [me]) in search of my track coach.  He wasn't in, but I did talk to the distance coach for awhile.  Strangely, he had heard about my bike trip (kinda cool).   Off to Lenoir Dining Hall where I had the decision of paying a la carte downstairs or paying $6.75 to go pig out upstairs.  Listening to my appetite (my legs were definitely in repair mode, so it was huge), I pigged out upstairs.  I sat down at my normal table, ate, and read The Daily Tarheel, just like I did when I was here.  It was all too strange but fun too. I headed over to Davis Library to get on the computers.  Now this joint holds an extra special place in my heart and strangely on my head.  This is the source of my many gray hairs.  They sprouted the spring of my senior year as I sat in a study carrel exactly seven floors above from where I am sitting now.  After my trip to Davis (I am typing this in on Saturday now), I checked back for Coach (he wasn't in) and then went to South Campus where Olivia picked me up after her class day.  We went over to Performance Bike, and I purchased some Clif Bars, Power Bars, another spare inner tube (a replacement for the one popped on day one), derailer cables (a spare item I should have brought with me in the first place), another Continental Ultra 2000 tire (it will be my new spare; threw out the one I took off on day one), and a big bottle of Endurox drink mix.  So, I am restocked and ready to go Sunday morning.  But, all of my work of culling down my load is negated by the eight pounds of stuff I just bought.  However, I think of it this way, most of that weight is food products that will be gone soon anyway, and I feel that as the trip goes on I will be holding on to just the stuff I really need.  I.e. I really need those derailer cables I just purchased, but I don't need the long underwear top, so I mailed it home.   Rolled around town and went to a social function with Olivia at a local restaurant where the students in the MAC program got together.  I talked to all of the former math teachers-turned-accountants.
  Accommodations:  Olivia & Courtney's Apartment Quote of the Day:  "I like poop -- I think it's funny." After I ate three bowls of Optimum cereal (14g of dietary fiber per bowl), Olivia and I got to talking about the power of fiber, and in the ensuing conversation she graciously blessed me with this wonderful QOTD. Slept late and then got a ride up to campus to fix all of the errors I made yesterday as I hurriedly entered my journals.   Because it is such a nice day out and my legs need to be loosened up a little bit, Olivia and I are going to go on a 25 mile jaunt around Jordan Lake.  She is quite the bike stud, so I hope she doesn't ditch me in rural NC.  I am going to strip the rig down and just have fun - not worrying about my stuff or my speed.  ----- Plans changed very quickly Saturday afternoon.  I had checked my email before I left the library here at UNC and noticed that my friend, Allen, had sent me a message saying that he would be in town during this weekend recruiting at a track meet at Duke.  Allen is the throws coach on the Track & Field team at Syracuse University and a good teammate and friend of mine from my track days at Carolina.   We got in touch and planned to meet with Kim, a mutual track friend and fifth year at UNC, for dinner.  But before that, Olivia took me on about a 20 mile stroll around Jordan Lake.  We went kinda fast , but it felt good on my legs and even better to ride with someone else.   Allen, Kim, and I had a great evening on the town - it felt, for a little bit, like I was back as a student here.   Allen is going to be in town for one more day, and I thought I would put off leaving town for one more day as well because this is such a chance rendezvous.   
Accommodations: Shared Holiday Inn Express hotel room    After waking up very late, I packed up my things and said goodbye to Olivia.  I headed back up Chapel Hill, this time with the rig.  I wanted to visit my friend Kim again, who would be working at the Student Rec Center (SRC).  The SRC also holds a special place in my heart, because that is where I used to sneak in my freshman and sophomore years when I was down in Chapel Hill visiting.  Many a squat workouts were performed there while I lifted under the guise of an everyday UNC student.          Anyway, I talked to Kim for awhile, and we got a stranger to snap a photo of us out front.  I headed back to the library for one last check of the email and update of this site.  Then I was back on the road.  I rode down to Franklin Street for some last minute reminiscing and then coasted back down the Hill, this time to the northeast (not towards New Orleans), towards Durham where my friend Allen was staying.  This side trip was out of the way, but I figured it was well worth it - I had allowed myself time in my schedule to do things like this.  The rig felt real heavy, maybe it was the extra stuff I was now carrying (from Performance Bike store), but it was probably because the day before I went riding without any gear and I was running on a little adrenaline trying to impress Olivia.    Allen and I went to dinner and then headed down to the brand-spanking-new indoor track that was built over the past two years to replace the decrepit "Tin Can" that we used to train in.  I had contributed some money ($$) over the past two years towards the program, so I was hoping that my name would be somewhere on the building's list of donors.  Well, we got there and the Eigth Wonder of the World was locked.  We couldn't believe it - for the first time in many years the facilities guys had actually locked up the track - they never did that for the tin can, well maybe that was why it was so decrepit.  So, I didn't get to see the plaque donning my name, but that's alright because, on second thought, I think you had to contribute ten thousand dollars while I gave more like ten dollars.  We had a good time, though, hanging out - I'll see Allen again in two months at his wedding.
Accommodations: Bill's Moto Inn Quote of the Day: "I have been sick to my stomach all day." Heard outside of Wendy's (after I ate there) as two employees conversed during a smoke-break.  Dave Thomas would not be proud of their professionalism.    Unfortunately, I have very little to say about today.  I had a lot of trouble getting the body going.  I have been getting enough sleep, but I think because it has been shifted a few hours back in the day, my body feels a little funny.  I'm not tired, just groggy. My atlases are great in the country, but are of little use in downtown areas.  So, to get out of Durham (the Holiday Inn Express was on the north end of town) I had to navigate using the compass to find my way southwest to my outlet road, NC Rte. 751.  I rode that for a while, a nice country road through tobacco fields.  I hit US Rte. 64 and headed due west for Siler City where I arrived in the middle afternoon.  At the first motel, the Heartland Inn, the only room available was the executive suite, which had a minibar and jacuzzi.  However tempting that was, I decided to stay across the street.  Anyway, who needs a jacuzzi when you have wood panelled walls and a 10 inch TV.
Accommdations: Eldorado Family Campground Quote of the Day: "Will Keep Children Call 625-1003" Seen written in magic marker on a piece of cardboard tethered to a mailbox somewhere on a backroad in the Uwharrie Mountains.  Does the FBI know about this service?  I am sincerely hoping that "keep," in this case, means baby-sit.    I hit the road in Siler City traveling due west on US 64 with Asheboro as my lunchtime destination.  From there I had planned on heading southwest on NC 49 which had a few campgrounds listed in my AAA book.  The 25-mile ride to Asheboro was no problem, but I was quite hungry on arrival.  I spotted a Food Lion grocery store and my mind was made up.  Grocery stores, I believe, are the perfect lunch stop, especially for a bike rider.  They have all that I need, plus AC and a clean restroom (an appreciated amenity).  So, I got my pre-wrapped sandwhich (the kind that comes in an isosceles triangular prism-shaped [I love geometry] box), some fruit, and chips.  Back outside, sitting on my rolled up sleeping pad, I enjoyed my lunch and said hello to the folks as they came and went from the store.   One middle-aged woman stopped and started up conversation.  She used to bicycle tour, and she pegged me quickly.  She was a native of Vienna, Virginia (crib!) who moved down to Asheboro and has loved the change of pace.  I grilled her on what my afternoon riding might bring me on NC 49.  She told me that the road runs through the Uwharrie Mountains, which are the oldest and therefore the most delicate mountains in the US.  We talked some more, but conversation drifted to what each of her six kids were up to (actually it wasn't that bad).  Later as she exited the store she wished me good luck again.  I watched her get in her 1970's white station wagon - kinda a cross between the one the Arnolds had in the Wonder Years and the boxy 1982 Grand Marquis, Juliette, my neighbor, had when we grew up (you know, the kind with simulated wood panelling on the inside).  She drove off, waving goodbye one last time. After eating I find it hard to jump right on the bike so I usually take that half-hour food-coma-time easy.  Olivia gave me a book as a present before I left Chapel Hill.  Briefly, the book, A Walk Across America, by Peter Jenkins is a story of a recent college graduate from Greenwich, Connecticut ($$$) as he walked across the USA in 1973 amidst all of the cultural and political chaos of the time.  It is an easy read, and I find it neat for a number of reasons, including a few things about it that are close to me:  Peter walked from the northeast to New Orleans; he walked down Route 193 outside of DC (the street on which I grew up); and he wrote the book at the New Orleans Baptist Seminary (a landmark along the railroad in Nola, and within a mile from Brother Martin High). I read about 15 pages and then found it was time to get scootin'.  Within a few miles on NC 49 I had been passed by about twenty trucks.  Trucks usually aren't a problem, but this road lacked a shoulder and the lanes were only average-sized.  I thought I'd stick it out because 49 is the only route to the southwest from Asheboro.  A few miles later, my heart skipped a beat as a pick-up truck laid on its horn as it passed me.  At first, I thought it was just some locals trying to scare me, but as the vehicle passed I noticed the CB antenna on the roof and the "Wide Load" banner across the bumper...quick assumption:  he was an escort vehicle.  I turned around and saw three houses, literally, barreling down on me.  I pulled off to the side of the road and let them pass.  After I caught my breath, I turned on the GPS to get my bearings and pulled out my map to find another way to go. Not too far down the road was Lassiter Mill Road which led to some other roads which eventually led to, according to my map, a campground.  Now this campground wasn't in my AAA book, but neither was the campground where I stayed on Day 2.  I made my turn to the left, southward, and passed tobacco drying barns and fields and fields of that leafy green cash crop.  As it does so often in the South in the summertime, around three, it started pouring.  With no other options, I pressed on for that unnamed campsite on Baden Lake.  After a while, my route took me on North Carolina State Route 1301 (nicknamed "Low Water Bridge Road") - it was all gravel and winded me through what seemed like a vast jungle of wilderness.  The road then sloped steeply downward as I picked up speed but kept my fingers on both brakes anxiously.  Two minutes of rocky descent led me to the Low Water Bridge.  I came to a halt about 60 meters above the bridge to see better what I was up against (and to snap a photo) - simply, it was a narrow concrete bridge like those that cross Scotts Run to the residences off Swinks Mill Road in McLean.  I saw that the way was clear, I let off the brakes and coasted the rest of the way down the hill, hoping to get up some speed for the inevitable horrendous climb that awaited me on the other side.  In the gravel, I made it, maybe 10 meters, up the other side.  So I shift all the way down and spun up the other side at 6mph.  The rain continued, but by this time the sun was peeking out at an angle above.  It was hot, rainy, muddy - I felt like I was fighting guerrillas in the tropical rain forests of Guatemala, but I loved it.  This was traveling.    I eventually made it out to the "main" road (I hadn't seen another car for two hours) and a few turns later I found my campground.  I don't know where to start with this experience...I'll try though.  It was seven p.m. when I saw a makeshift sign on the side of the road that read "Eldorado Family Campground."  Making the left turn, in the now just drizzle, I had my eyes peeled for an office, but all I saw by the sign was an old single-wide home that didn't look like it had been lived in during this decade.  I rode in low gear through the mud around the grounds, finding eight RV's (all trailers sans accompanying vehicles) and a bathhouse.  There was trash everywhere and two semis parked in a gravel parking lot nestled in the woods.  The bathhouse was the nicest edifice there - I leaned the rig against it, under the awning, and went walking - in search of humans.  I peeked in a room attached to the bathhouse that had a worn out sign on the front reading, "office."  Inside were two washers and dryers (circa 1970) and what appeared to be old tractor parts on the shelf.  Still no humans.  I walked back to the rig and debated my options:  stay here; ride 18 miles in the drizzle to Troy and hopefully find a motel; or ride 8 miles to the nearby National Park on Baden Lake that had, according to the AAA book:  only primitive sites, dump toilets only, no showers.  It was late, and I was tired, so I picked a site under some pine trees near a water faucet.  I set up camp quickly and then hit the shower, all the while looking for an occupant of one of the RV trailers. The campground had a screened-in-on-all-four-sides shed that had a full kitchen inside (inside used in the loosest sense of the word) - kinda nice.  I got some water boiling and had my second of two dehydrated meals, Teriyaki Turkey.  Inside the screened-in cage, I analyzed everything around me trying to get a sense of what the problem with this place was.  The cabinets were all labelled on the outside in very neat handwriting, with no misspellings on words like:  pots, pans, knives (that f to v thing can be difficult).  So, I took that as a plus, but the extremely neat handwriting was a little disturbing.  My mind was playing tricks on me.  After dinner, I went back to the tent to read for an hour.  Rain drops through pine trees can grow very large and make sounds similar to that of someone walking nearby.  But, after I realized that I was fine.  I fell to sleep with no problem because it was such a tiring day, but I kept "one eye open" throughout my sleep.  Still no humanoids spotted since the mid-afternoon.
Accommodations: Holiday Inn Express Quote of the Day, Runner-up: "Ed Smith Deer Processing" Seen on a sign in front of Ed's house.  This is a rarity for me, the urban-dweller. Quote of the Day: "Proclaim Your Southern Heritage, Call 1-800-MY SOUTH, Sons of the Confederacy" Seen on a billboard ten miles northeast of Albemarle.    Awoke with the sun.  Sleep was broken but good enough.  Around midnight I heard the winds come in and the temperature dropped, at least in my tent, a good ten degrees.  I knew that after the all-day rain yesterday, I had a nice cold front moving in with high pressure behind it (Thank you Dr. Konrad, UNC meteorology prof).  My bike was filthy and needed a lot of TLC, but I was not in the mood.  I did some minimal maintenance on it - I wanted to leave.  I broke camp quickly.  I made it through my visit there without seeing anyone and consequently not paying a cent.   My predictions about the weather were right.  The day was beautiful and my morale was lifted.  I cruised five miles in the dry, cool morning air to a general store in Eldorado where I got my "on-the-road" breakfast:  OJ (for Vitamin C), pound cake (for carbs), peanuts (for protein), and peanut butter crackers (for a good combo of each).  Yes, they are all high in fat, but nothing in a general store in the South isn't.   I was heading south on a main road in the mountains keeping an eye out for my right turn to the west, River Road (one of many River Roads in this country), when I passed by a house with an old man and his dog both sitting on the porch.  The dog was a pit bull mongrel (half pit bull, half super ugly).  Of course, when the pooch saw me he gave chase.  I was happy to have my first dog encounter witnessed by its owner, you know, in case there was a dispute about who started the whole thing.  The dog gave chase and I upshifted, got out of the saddle, and dusted the poor thing (Note to self:  I'm awesome).  However, in the confusion incurred by my little race, I missed my turn, and it wasn't noticed until I was a mile up a mountain (Note to self:  Amend previous note-to-self to now read:  I'm sometimes awesome).  I turned around and coasted back down to River Road - no biggie. Coming out of the mountain portion of the day, I found a general store.  They had gorpe (it's an acronym, if you know what it stands for please write it in my guestbook, but it has peanuts, m&m's, raisins, and other goodies), which is the all-time best bicycling food.  Enjoying my food on a picnic bench out front, I was interrogated by two nice kids and their father about my trip.  The little girl, about 8, asked questions about water & food, while the brother, about 12, asked about my GPS and the pedals on my bike.  I found their pattern of questioning to be interesting and the questions themselves quite intelligent, and because the father saw that I didn't mind talking to them, he allowed the questioning to go on for about ten minutes.  The father, himself, got into it too.  He wanted to know if I was documenting my travels on a website.  "Funny you should ask," I said, and then I proceeded to tell him about my site.  Hopefully you found it!   After that fun run-in I had the most difficult climb of the trip.  I crossed the Pee-Dee River (pronounced just like you think) and ascended out of its steep valley.  The climb didn't take more than twenty-five minutes but it was easily the steepest moderately-sustained climb I have had yet.  I pulled over a few times to catch my breath.  At one of my stops, I looked over my left shoulder and watched a tanker truck struggle up the hill.  It couldn't have been going faster than 15mph.  As it passed I waved and smiled to the driver, and he did the same for me with that "I know how you feel" look.   Ate for second day at Food Lion, this time in Albemarle.  Most people walk past as I sit on my rolled-up sleeping pad and make no eye contact.  I think those people are scared, not necessarily of me, but of something foreign to them.  Then there are those that smile, and sometimes say hi or start up a conversation.  Those people know - for they've got the Chi and they are happy to see that the Chi is visiting from the outside.  I smile back with a look that says, "Hey baby, I know where ya' comin' from." Traveling at a slow speed throughout the U.S. has allowed me to see all different types of police patrol cars.  I move through each county and state slow enough to catch a glimpse of them all.  Be it stateys, county or city PD, or sheriffs' departments, the officers have all waved to me; maybe because they are jealous of my journey but probably because they are just good guys.  I had my first run-in with law enforcement this afternoon and, not surprisingly, it was with one of those good guys.  I pulled off NC 24-27 to sit in the shade and rest during the hottest time of the day.  Along came a patrol car that pulled up beside me.  Out from his Carrabus County Sheriff's Department vehicle stepped a stout, bald officer in his mid-thirties.  He was shorter than me, so when I stood to make his acquaintance I positioned myself down in the shoulder ravine a bit so he would be able to talk down to me.  Officer C. E. Carlee simply said, "I was driving by, and I would be mad at myself if I hadn't stopped to see that you were alright."  My fret turned to appreciation as I explained that I was trying to stay cool.  We talked for about five minutes about my bike trip and his previous encounters with touring bicyclists (one of them, a female around 60 years old).  He was very caring for me and at the same time respectful of my journey and all that it entailed.  He wished me luck, and he went back to his vehicle as I did to mine. Pulling into Charlotte during rush hour was interesting but fun.  I have been here a few times before but only to UNC-C for track meets, so I had not seen the big skyline before. At the motel I did a load of laundry in the bath tub and fell asleep watching The Best UFO Evidence Caught on Tape Ever, Part II (apparently the first one wasn't convincing enough).
Accommodations: Executive Inn Quote of the Day, Second Runner-up: "Pinecrest Mobile Estates" Seen on a sign in front of a trailer park. Quote of the Day, First Runner-up: "Whoooooohooo!!!" A passer-by at a food mart in South Carolina in response to my declaration that my trip was 1200 miles long. Quote of the Day: "God be whitchuu!" After I had eaten my meal at McDonald's, I returned to the counter to order three Nestle's chocolate-chip cookies and a carton of milk for dessert.  Johnna, my lovely server, saw that I had a map in hand and asked...(what follows is a replication of the dialog and actions that took place leading up to the QOTD in that empty McDonald's in Chester, South Carolina at 8:40pm): Johnna:  Where are you traveling to? Matt:  New Orleans. Johnna:  Why are you passing by here? Matt:  I'm riding my bike. Johnna:  What kind of bike?  [she then leans over to pick a carton of milk out of the commercial frig that is at floor level] Matt:  A bicycle.   Johnna:  [Almost falls over and hits her head on the floor]  Here baby, let me get you another milk [and she does]...(to the entire work crew): Hey everyone!!  This boy is riding his bicycle from Washington, D.C. to New Orleans! MANAGER:  [Working the fryer, and then enter stage left]  God be whitchuu! Matt:  Thank you, ma'am.    I took my time getting ready this morning.  In fact, I barely got out of the hotel by the check-out time of noon.  I was tired, and I had a lot to do:  blow-dry my laundry, bathe my bike in the bath tub, and pack up everything.  Once on the road, my body didn't want to cooperate.  Again, getting out of an urban area with just my atlas proved to be difficult.  Around mile 8 or so my body starting warming to the fact that it would be a riding day, but just around then I got lost in a large residential area twice the size of the McLean Hamlet, rife with dead end streets.  I finally found my way out and saw a Harris Teeter grocery store, so I decided to take my lunch break even though I had only made it three miles south of Charlotte proper.   Across the state line, I instantly felt something new.  Maybe it was just because I was now way out of suburban Charlotte, but nonetheless, things were definitely different.  Kudzu appeared for the first time on the trip.  According to my railroading buddies in Alabama, kudzu was introduced from Japan in the late nineteenth century and railroads were leading pioneers in its use.  Kudzu shored up rights of way and kept other weeds around the track to a minimum.  It's too bad that the stuff is everywhere in the South, because in the winter time it looks like a hideous dead brown vine.  Great kudzu website here:   http://www.cptr.ua.edu/kudzu/. My goal was to stay in Rock Hill, South Carolina.  I thought that because it was one of the larger cities in the state and home to Winthrop University (a Division I school) it would have, at least, one motel.  Bad assumption.  I rolled through the entire town on the main drag, US 72, and saw no such hoped-for accommodations.  Winthrop is a nice looking school - it kind of reminded me of Franklin & Marshall College but a touch bigger.  Winthrop is the alma mater of Andrew McFalls (LHS '94) - I passed by the arena where he played bball and achieved multiple conference (I don't know which one) player-of-the-week awards. Leaving Rock Hill on US Rte. 72, I felt disheartened.  It was 6 pm and I was headed towards Chester, 18 miles away - and I wasn't even sure if I would find a motel there.  On the edge of town I stopped on the side of the road to eat a Clif bar, ingest a lot of water and prepare for an unanticipated ride to Chester.  Morale was low, but I hopped back on the saddle and started rolling down and out of the hill that is Rock Hill, South Carolina.  Within a mile I passed by a handsome new middle school with a large black and red electronic message board out front.  In stone above the board, the sign read, "West Saluda Middle School," and on the electronic sign below was displayed the school's QOTD and present weather conditions:  "'Without Stress, there is no progress.'  Temp:  88  Time: 6:16PM."  I wanted to stop and take a photo but I had used my last photo on a pic of the SC state line sign (I'm not even sure if that one took because when I snapped the photo the camera made a "hey I'm not sure if I got that one," sound) and my other roll of film was buried deep in my left saddle bag.  For one of the first times on this trip, I was under stress.  I wasn't worried - I wasn't freaking out - but I was under stress - and I decided to take advantage of it.  The 17 miles that followed may have been my best yet.  My now golden brown legs stroked the pedals efficiently and tirelessly.  I cruised into Chester in just over an hour, found my hotel, and was so excited about my ride, I just pedaled up to the office and while I was still on my bike, I opened the door with my right hand and asked, "Do you have any rooms?"  Seeing a positive nod, I dismounted the rig, ran inside and probably blew the lady away with my positive energy.   I showered and went to Mickey D's.  But before I was blessed with one of the funnier incidents of the trip (see above - at least to me it was funny), I sat in the restaurant and wrote in my journal:  It is now 8:30 here at McDonald's, and I have 38 hours to make it across the state (about 120 miles) to the Calhoun Falls, SC post office before it closes Saturday morning at 10:30am.  I'm beat, but I've got a few different battle options, most of which put me there at 10.  Another option, I may consider Saturday morning, is calling and pleading with the postmaster to leave the package on the front step or perhaps with a local merchant.  I hadn't mentioned this before, but before I left my parent's house in Virginia, I mailed myself c/o "General Delivery" a large package of trip goodies to Calhoun Falls, South Carolina.  I picked that city because it is a border city and I didn't want to hold on to atlases any longer than I had to.  Moreover, it was about mid-way on my trip, and also quite importantly, it was a city I'd pass through before heading into the twigs of central Georgia and southeast Alabama.  In the package I had assembled: Georgia Atlas Alabama Atlas 12 new CD's (more on that later) Power & Clif bars Two pounds of Endurox drink-mix powder I certainly could go on without most of things, but the atlases are a must.  I'm not crossing in to Georgia without that atlas.  It just happens that, unless I really haul tomorrow, Friday, I'll end up going through Calhoun Falls on a Saturday afternoon or Sunday when the post office is closed.  We'll see what happens. * John Donne
Accommodations: Ramada Inn Quote of the Day, Runner-Up: "My prayers are with you." At a food mart outside of Clinton, the clerk asked me about my trip, and after I went through the story with her, she simply asked, "What's your name?"  I responded, and then she blessed me with this QOTDRU.  I have found that many people want to know my name.  I can only hope that they want to know it for the same reason as this nice lady did. Quote of the Day: "Welcome to Whitmire, Pearl of the Piedmont." A warm-hearted middle-aged woman started conversation with me at a foodmart as I was leaving Whitmire.  She was very interested to hear about all of the places I have been to, so she jokingly chimed in with this QOTD.    After an enthusiastic ride yesterday, it was hard to wake up this morning.  I eventually pulled myself out of bed and went to the lobby of the Executive Inn for their "continental breakfast."  I found that continental breakfast has varying meanings across this great land of ours.  Here in Chester, it meant OJ and a cinnamon roll no more than two inches in diameter.  I gobbled that down and headed back to McDonald's because the Executive Inn breakfast just wouldn't cut it for this calorie-burning machine.  As I walked over to McDonald's, I thought to myself what this day had in store:  about 90-120 miles of riding to put me in position to pick up the package at the post office in Calhoun Falls by 10:30 tomorrow morning.  At first, I was daunted by the task ahead of me - I was quite tired.  But walking through the grass that separated the McDonald's from the adjacent bank, I instantly caught that morning grass smell.  That smell always wakes me up.  It is the smell of a new day and new possibilities.  I told myself that I could do it.    My morning ride was uneventful:  30 miles to Whitmire.  I spotted a Piggly Wiggly supermarket on the way into town and decided it was time for lunch.  This place was perfect, it had a bench out front so I wouldn't have to sit on my rolled-up sleeping pad as I ate.  I leaned the rig up against the wall and sat on the bench to stop my sweating so when I went in the inevitably cold store I wouldn't catch pneumonia.  Not long thereafter, a beat-up early 1980's Ford Ranger-type pick-up pulled into the parking lot with an old, grizzled driver.  He parked the vehicle and waddled his way up to the bench.  He sat on one end of the bench-built-for-three, and I sat on the other.  It was an eerie silence for a few minutes as we both sat, but as I got up and prepared to go into the store, I said, "hello," and he returned the favor.  Back outside, ten minutes later, he still sat there.  I wondered, "Does he ever actually go shopping?"  I don't remember who started it, but we got a little small-talk going until he decided to finally get up and go inside the Piggly Wiggly.  Upon his return, with two pouches of chewing tobacco, he sat back down.  I decided to try a little harder:  use the map trick.  I pulled out my map and he instantly scooted over towards me.  Words flowed from his mouth like water:  what kind of hills were where, what the best backroads were, where I could find a place to camp, etc.  His description of the surrounding area was interrupted every minute or so by him standing up taking a pace forward and giving a power spit (he was a pro - a good eight to ten feet) into the parking lot.  At first I was thrown off by this action, because I would be talking to him and he just stood right up and walked away from me, but once I realized what he was up to, I understood.  Anyway, he imparted quite a bit of knowledge of the area on me that afternoon, most of which I found to be true as I actually experienced the area.  We said our goodbyes, and he headed back to his truck. After he left, I pulled out my book for some afternoon reading and relaxing.  The more I sat, the worse I felt.  There was no way I could handle another 60 to 90 miles today.  The positive vibes I had in the morning had clashed with the reality of my exhaustion.  I reviewed my options again in the atlas and decided to stop short of my goal and settle on Clinton, about 20 miles away - and hopefully find a motel.      However, once I got going, I found (like I usually do) that I felt fine.  But, I think it was a smart decision to stop in Clinton.  I'll call the post office in the morning and see if they can leave the package for me somewhere, and if not, maybe take an extra rest day before getting my package Monday morning.  In Clinton, I did a load of laundry, this time in an actual washing machine with laundry detergent, at the hotel.  Otherwise, I took it very easy and enjoyed the air conditioning.
Accommodations: Calhoun Falls State Park campground Quote of the Day, Runner Up: "Adopt-A-Highway Litter Control Program:  S.C. Parole and Probation" Seen on a roadsign.  Luckily, today was not clean-up day. Quote of the Day: "Do you want it all the way?" Let me explain - what follows is the dialog between me and a female employee at Snake's burger place in Calhoun Falls: Employee:  What would you like? Matt:  Yeah, I'll have the Hamburger plate. Employee:  Do you want it all the way? Matt:  Excuse me??? Employee:  Do YOU want it all the way? Matt:  Do you mean fully dressed??? Employee:  Yeah... Matt:  No, I don't want it all the way, just part of the way - with ketchup.    First thing this morning I called the Calhoun Falls post office to ask them about my package.  I knew that I wouldn't make the 65 miles by their closing time, 10:30.  The clerk I talked to acknowledged that my package was there waiting for me.  I gently coaxed her into helping me out of my quandary.  I told her about my trip and that I would like to get my package but not wait until Monday to do it.  I asked her if she could leave it with a local merchant and after a few ahh's she agreed.  She told me it would be waiting at the Amoco station across the street from the post office.  I then checked out and made the three mile jaunt from my motel off the interstate into the actual town of Clinton where the post office and public library were.  I mailed home a few more items, including my South Carolina Atlas (my route from Clinton to Calhoun Falls was direct) and a case of 12 CD's (12 different ones would be waiting for me in Calhoun Falls), totalling a little over two pounds.  At the library I quickly checked my email and typed in a few of my journal pages.  I had to move quickly because of overcast skies and what looked like impending rain.   I ate across the street from the library at a service station.  Around noon the fire siren went off.  This one, like the one in Fort Montgomery, New York, is pneumatic and takes a while to warm up, but once it does there is no hiding from it.  The fire house was located adjacent to the library and therefore across the street from me where I was sitting on the curb of the gas station.  The alarm got so loud that customers pumping gas got in their cars and rolled up the windows or ran inside.  Hearing the siren gives me a good reminiscing feeling of Fort Montgomery.  But, the good feelings the siren evokes are quickly diminished by the fact that it is near deafening.  It makes me wonder:  wouldn't pagers be better???  Instead of having a siren at the top of a pole they could have an antenna, and they could let technology do the work of what brute force currently does.  I ran back inside to use the restroom before I hit the road - the store was all abuzz with talk of the siren - I overheard the cashier say that it is the fire station's weekly Saturday noon test.  Lucky her. The ride to Calhoun Falls was entirely in the afternoon which made me worry.  I usually like to knock out a substantial amount of a day's ride before lunch when it is cooler.  Fortunately, today wasn't all that hot and the ride went real well.      The miles came easy and before I knew it I was in downtown Calhoun Falls where I easily found the Amoco station.  As I leaned the rig up against the front of the building, I looked inside and could see the cashier immediately reach under the counter for my package - I guess that they don't get many cross-country cyclists there.      Now very heavy, I headed two miles north of town to the state park, on man-made Richard B. Russel Lake.  After I pitched the tent and went through the daily necessaries, I threw on the tevas and went for a calm, cool, peaceful swim.  The water was murky but very refreshing.    After a shower, I got on the bike and rode out of the park and to Snake's, a highly-recommended (by the Amoco folks) burger place/gas station.  I ate my greasy dinner on the bench outside as the sun went down.  I felt good after a very productive day, and I found myself excited to get back to the tent to read my book.
Accommodations: Travelodge Quote of the Day: "Ain'tcha a little wet?" Heard at a red light in rainy Athens.  I knew instantly that I had a QOTD on my hands, so I glanced a peek over my left shoulder and noticed a group of Georgia peaches in a Ford Explorer.  The author had her back-seat window down and when she smiled her braces glistened under the sunlight that was trying to peek through the clouds - this young peach needed a little more time on the windowsill.    I crossed Richard B. Russel Lake into Georgia during the fourth and fifth miles of the day.  Although state lines, as far as I am concerned on this trip, are just political boundaries with no real implications except different sales taxes, it still felt good to move from one state to another.  I know that I can't make it to Louisiana without first going through a slew of other states, so with the crossing into Georgia, I am one step closer to my goal.    On my morning ride I passed a huge (I counted 45) group of motorcycle riders out for a Sunday spin.  The encounter was a little mysterious.  Many of the riders were wearing orange shorts that said, "Cycleworld of..."  I couldn't see where they were from, because their guts overhung the word after "of."  Perhaps they were going out on a dealer-sponsored ride.  Even more strange was that there were three vans (an equivalent of sag wagons for motorcyclists?) and a hearse following the riders.  Ohh well, all of the guys paid no mind to me, but I got a few, "whoo hoo"'s from the lady passengers.   Shortly after the sign welcoming me to Georgia, I had also noticed a sign welcoming me to Elbert County, which was the self-proclaimed "Granite Capital of the World."  I had always thought that that was New Hampshire's claim to fame.  I ate at a Winn Dixie in Elberton (not surprisingly, the county seat) where I, as usual, leaned my bike up against the front of the building and relaxed for a few minutes before I headed into the chilly grocery store.  I noticed that fire lane enforcement was not high on the Elberton PD's list of things to do.  There were at least six cars parked in the fire line simply because it was close to the entrance and it was in the shade created by the building.   After I purchased my lunch I took a seat on a bench in the antechamber of the grocery store - it was perfect temperature.  I said hello to folks as they entered in the store and most said hello back with no apprehension, despite the fact that I was in my cycling apparel and they in their going-to-church-finest.  Two teenage male employees approached me on their way back in the store from corraling buggies in the parking lot.  I have to give them credit for initiating the conversation, but I felt that they needed to expand their adjective database beyond, "cool."  Soon, we ran out of things to talk about, and I continued to break eye contact with them, hoping that they'd understand that I just wanted to read my book in peace.  After a few more minutes of discomfort, they got back to work.   In Elberton, I noticed quite a few gravestone stores, and I passed by the Elberton Granite Museum.  But, unfortunately, like the Sistene Chapel, it was closed on Sundays.  Outside of town I had another memorable dog encounter...  Minding my own business, I was cruising along U.S. Route 72, when I looked up and saw a young girl (about 10 years old) riding an ATV just off the other side of the road.  She, also, seemed to be having a good time on her Sunday spin.  Well, running at her side was a golden retriever.  The dog, upon spotting me, quickly lost interest in his mistress, and made a B-line towards me.  (Football players pay attention!) Luckily, the dog was a poor geometer, as his pursuit angle was horrible.  He didn't account for my swift closing speed and flew passed me at about four feet from my left knee.  By the time he slammed on the brakes and reversed, it was too late, I had put plenty of distance between us. Shortly after my dog encounter, the sky quickly darkened, and I was hit with a fierce head wind and a drop of about ten degrees.  Knowing that I had a short time to find shelter before the thunderstorm hit, I pressed on looking for a bridge for refuge.  Fortunately, I didn't have to go far.  After an hour wait under an overpass, I hopped back on the bike and continued westward under overcast but now quiet skies.  Ten miles later, the rains came again, this time with no thunder, but because I was in no hurry and I had found great shelter, I stopped.  I was in Carlton, Georgia (photo below), which was nothing more than a beautiful post office and five abandoned store fronts.  The 'strip mall' did, however, have a rickety but charismatic aluminum awning, which was a perfect place to set up for awhile.  I leaned the bike against a store window and sat down on my rolled up sleeping pad.  I read my book while the rain tapped against the ceiling above.  It reminded me of when I was five, and I would color in my coloring books on the front stoop of my parents' house during rain storms.  I felt then, as I did today, special to be outside during a storm but safe from its ill effects.    Eventually, the rain dwindled to a drizzle, and I decided to make my final press towards Athens, where my cousin Jenny attended school a few years back.  In town, I checked in, did my laundry in the bathroom sink, and went in search of Sunshine Cycles, a bike store I found in the Yellow Pages.  Fortunately, it was close and looked to be a reputable place.  I decided that is where I would take my bike in for service tomorrow.  The bike store was directly across the street form the 40 Watt, a famous nightclub where R.E.M. and the B52's used to perform back when they were young musicians with a lot of talent and little exposure.  I did some more exploring through downtown Athens, which seemed to be a great mix of the quaintness of downtown Chapel Hill and the hilly contours of the UAB area of Birmingham.  I certainly liked Athens - I just wished Jenny was here to give me a more in-depth and personal tour.  I ate at the Broad Street Bar and Grill where the requisite red and black memorabilia adorned the walls.
Accommodations: Holiday Inn Express Sunshine Cycles opened at ten, so I slept in a little and took my time getting ready.  On the way to the bike store I noticed my speedometer malfunctioning - giving me a speed reading of zero when I knew that I was going 15 or 20.  I debated shelling out 30 bucks at the bike store for a new one, but I decided to hold off - maybe the problem could be fixed with some MacGyver work.  And anyway, this trip was more than just a number on my odometer.   At the bike store, I explained my situation to the mechanic, telling him that I was traveling cross country and I just needed some drive train and brake tuning.  He said that he was booked with repairs until Wednesday (two days from now).  But, after some mild pleading, a reemphasizing of the fact that I was just passing through town for a day and all I needed was a tune-up, he gave in.  I left all of my gear, except for my trusty journal, at the shop and headed to campus. I went straight to the library and tried not to stick out too much with my UNC track shirt on.  Apparently, no one cared, or probably they just didn't want to get near me because I stunk (despite the bathroom sink washing of my clothes).   I spent all morning and some of the afternoon at the library.  Around lunchtime, I got myself lost (on purpose) on the way to the student union.  It was a good chance to see the campus (beautiful!).  After lunch I went to the neighboring bookstore to look for postcards.  Now, I have been to at least ten college bookstores for whatever reasons over the past decade, and UGa is the only one that has a Clinique counter inside the store.  Not just that, but the girl with the painted face behind the counter works solely for Clinique (no asking her for the location of the postcards!). When I checked into Athens last night, I told myself that I might only be taking a half day rest - leaving in the mid-afternoon after I picked up my bike.  After lunch, however, my body was telling me to rest.  Because I seemed to be doing okay on my schedule timing, I decided to take a full day off.  After I picked up my bike (I tipped the mechanic five bucks for helping me out - he greatly appreciated it), I went motel shopping again - the Travelodge was booked, so I headed to the Holiday Inn Express.  I took advantage of the guest laundry in the basement and washed every textile good that I had with me (except for my nylon trail shorts and rain jacket - I can't be in the laundry room naked!).  After dinner I stopped by a natural food store where I purchased some GORPE (what does it stand for?!?) and other energy-supplying sundries.  Two more hours at the library, and then I was back at the motel sound asleep.  Athens has been good to me.
Accommodations: KOA Kampground    The Holiday Inn Express had a wonderful spread for their "Deluxe" continental breakfast, so I decided to indulge.  The big breakfast was a great welcome compared to the sparse ones of weeks past.  Before I left town, I ran an errand at a local formalwear shop where I got fitted for a tuxedo for my friend Allen's wedding.  It was only a mile ride from the motel to the store, but because it was 80 degrees and rainforest humid, I entered the shop quite sweaty.  The young women helped me out and refused my tip even though they deserved it for dealing with my b.o.  Adjacent to the formalwear shop was a barbershop.  It was still only mid-morning, so I stopped in and shed some of my deadweight (my fro). On my way out of town, I passed by an off-campus bookstore and noticed a poster advertising UGa Track and Field, much like the ones we had at Carolina.  On the poster was All-American shot putter Reese Hoffa.  Neat for me because he is a guy I competed against when I was at Carolina.  Let me rephrase that, he and I were in the same meet together.  And I would watch him throw in the finals long after I was finished for the day in the prelims.  Anyway, it was cool for me to see the poster because it kinda gave me a small world feeling - something that happens when you travel and you realize this world is much more interconnected than once thought. Yesterday I did plenty of walking and a tiny bit of riding, but relatively speaking, I didn't do much.  In just that short time, my body has slowed down.  The metabolism wasn't churning like usual.  I thought that would be a problem: jump-starting myself.  But, surprisingly, sometime in the early afternoon, after lunch, all gears were turning smoothly inside my body.  I was fully awake, and happy to be riding again.  The legs felt pretty good, and my fatigue level was moderately reduced from my day off in Athens. Besides my errands in the morning, the day had no out of the ordinary experiences.  The bike felt like it was supposed to, tuned.  I pumped the miles out easily and enjoyed the Central Georgian scenery.  I did, however, have another unpaved road to ride on outside of McDonough.  This one was different than other gravel roads, because its base surface was a soft Georgia clay that gave way easily.  I had difficulty navigating that road and at times had to walk the bike due to lack of traction.   McDonough also holds a special place in my heart.  It is home to the Norfolk Southern Railway training school.  My first year out of college I spent a total of six weeks there learning to be a railroad conductor and later a railroad engineer.  In McDonough, I know where all three Waffle Houses are, I know where the best BBQ joint is, and I know where there is a great running trail (where I used to spend my days after class reviewing in my mind a locomotive's air brake system as I jogged around).  This time in McDonough I picked up a sub for dinner at Blimpie and then pedaled over to the campground.  I figured there was no need to go exploring down by the school, but it was neat for me to know that it was nearby (the locomotive horns in the distance reminded me of that fact).   The two elderly couples that worked the front desk at the KOA were blown away when I told them that I was bicycling across country.  They asked if I had a Harley Davidson or a Honda, and I reassured them that my vehicle make was a Cannondale (with a two-cylinder super-charged engine).  I was even followed out the door by one of the guys, because he didn't believe me.  To say the least, I stuck out big time at the KOA.  I was the only tent camper amongst 70 RV's.  Everyone gave me the eye, as I rode past them, while they sat in their lawn chairs in front of their mammoth mobile edifices.  The KOA "security" (two overweight old guys in a golf cart) kept an eye on me throughout the evening.  I understand their feelings - what is a single male doing on his bicycle riding across the US??? - he must be crazy.  Exactly.  And that is fine with me.  I just smile and wave at everyone I see.  Maybe people will realize it's not so crazy after all.  It's just different.   So, I ate my sub at my designated picnic table there in McDonough, Georgia.  The roar of I-75 could be heard nearby.  This place was less of a campground and more of an RV stop for Atlanta visitors.  Whatever it was, it served my purpose:  clean showers, potable water, and a place where I could lie my head down and feel safe. Tomorrow I must start doing what I have been putting off for awhile:  crossing the Appalachians.  When I was stationed in Birmingham working for the railroad, I often went on day trips for work through eastern Alabama and western Georgia.  I remember being surprised at the size of the mountains there.  Nothing huge (about 1500 feet), but plenty more than I expected for being at the southern edge of the chain.  I am a little nervous for the challenge ahead, but I think I'm ready for it.
Accommodations: Ramsey RV Park Quote of the Day: "I like people." Robert Lovett - read today's entry for the complete context of this QOTD.    It wasn't exactly cool out this morning, but it certainly was cooler than normal.  As usual, it took me two hours to eat breakfast, work on my bike, and break camp, so by the time I got moving it was 9:00.  The air still felt nice.  There was humidity, but instead of it being oppressive, it was refreshing.  My morning ride was excellent, in fact it was going so well that after seeing a sign for a public library in Hampton, I was tempted to just continue on.  But, I thought I should stop.  It has seemed like public libraries are hard to come by, and because I won't be passing through any major metro areas for a while, I figured I'd take advantage of the opportunity. I spent an hour at the library, just enough time to check my email and type in and proofread a day's entry.  At this pace, I won't be able to stay current with my website, but that's okay, because it is more important to do it right than to hurry it and end up doing it half-ass.      I ate at a Winn Dixie in Griffin.  After my standard triangle sandwich, chips, melon, yogurt, and a banana I sat and wrote the postcards that I purchased in Athens two days earlier.  The afternoon ride was uneventful but very enjoyable.  I rode quickly through the afternoon heat like it didn't bother me.  By three-thirty I was at a gas station in Woodbury buying a gallon of spring water for 99 cents.  That's when things changed... I gulped my water down and was headed out of the parking lot for my last eight miles of the day when I heard three deliberate honks of a horn coming from behind me.  I could tell the honks were for me because there wasn't much traffic around at the time.  I looked back and a man in his pick-up truck was gesturing for me to stop.  I thought he maybe saw that I had a flat tire, so I looked down and saw nothing; I thought he maybe saw that I left something behind at the gas station, so I looked back at where my rig earlier rested and saw nothing.  He pulled his small dark-bluish-purple pick-up next to my right side and started asking me about my trip -- the standard questions:  "Where are ya going?" - "How long ya been ridin'?" - "Where did ya leave from?"  He was in his 60's, in good health, and with a dark single-tone tattoo on his left forearm.  He had a juicy central Georgian accent and had no hesitation in his line of questioning or in his storytelling.  He'd ask me about my riding:  how the trucks are treating me on the roads, where I'm sleeping at night, and how does it feel to ride alone.  He told me of other cross country riders he has met in Woodbury, a Swedish couple that was riding truly cross country in a U-shaped route passing through Georgia early in their trip.  He beamed when he told me about a young man that he met while on a business trip in a Georgian beach town, who was canoeing around the eastern half of the U.S.  We talked for a total of ten minutes.  At the end of the conversation I gave him my website address, and he gave me his business card.  Robert Lovett was my acquaintance's name.  We said good-byes, and I left Woodbury with a smile. On my wonderful eight-mile ride from Woodbury southwest to Warm Springs, I thought to myself, "I'm going to see him again."  Something about Robert was different than other people I have talked to, even those that I have held extended conversations with.  He had a solid character and was fully engaged with my trip.  I told him before I left that I was heading towards Warm Springs, and he recommended the campsite that I was already planning on, one just outside of town.  So, I knew that he knew where I was headed.   Without much surprise, about a half-mile from the campsite a pick-up sped ahead of me, pulled over, and out stood Robert flagging me down.  I slowed in anticipation of what he had to say.  He told me of a friend, Mr. Bill, an avid bicycle rider, who lives on nearby Pine Mountain.  Robert said he had called Mr. Bill, and he would like to meet me.  Robert added, "Now, I know you have met a lot of weird people on this trip, but I'm not one of them.  I just think it is great that you are riding across the country."  Robert said he'd be back at 6:30 to take me around Warm Springs and then up Pine Mountain to meet Mr. Bill.  I believed that Robert was being honest with me, and without hesitation I told him I would love to go.   But first, Robert sped ahead again to the RV park.  When I showed up a minute later I found Robert in the office shooting the breeze with Mr. Ramsey.  I later learned that Robert knows the Ramseys well because Mrs. Ramsey is the mayor of Warm Springs and Robert, in his line of work, has a lot of dealings with her.   The charge to stay for the evening was ten dollars.  I parted with Robert again, and we reaffirmed our date time of 6:30.  This park was interesting to me.  Again, I was the only tent camper, in fact, I would say that I was the only camper.  The RV's that were there belonged to families that actually lived there.  The husbands came home from work throughout the early evening as I set up camp.  And the kids played wiffle ball on a green by the pool.  My accommodations were simple:  sleep on the lawn next to the Ramseys' two-floor aluminum-siding home and use the pool's bathhouse.   I later wondered why Robert just didn't part with me when we first set our meeting time of 6:30.  Instead he drove to the RV park not just to talk to Mr. Ramsey but to herald my arrival and to ensure that they had a place for me to stay.  It seems that in the countryside of the U.S. people know customer service and hospitality better than anywhere else. After I showered, I sat waiting for Robert on a shaded picnic bench near the Ramsey home.  Robert showed up on time and stepped out of his car bearing gifts.  He first handed me a new baseball cap that said, "Georgia Rural Water Association."  (he had told me earlier that in addition to managing water systems for Woodbury and Warm Springs he is the president of that statewide association) and a book titled, Miles From Nowhere.  According to him the book was written by a woman who has toured the U.S. extensively on bicycle - the stories she tells inspire Robert to take off and ride.  I thanked him for the hat and told him that I could get the book on my own.  There was no need for him to give me his only copy, especially when I am in the thick of reading another book right now.  He also told me he would have brought me some of the wine he makes on his property in Woodbury but was afraid that there wouldn't be a way for me to carry the bottle (true). We both sat down at the picnic table, and he told me that Mr. Bill was expecting us at 7:30, so in the meantime he had some memorabilia to show me and then he was going to drive me around Warm Springs (where FDR died).  Robert had a packet of photos, maps, and emails he had collected over the past few years in his visits with the Swedish couple that passed through Woodbury and Nat Stone, the guy that was canoeing around the eastern U.S.  As he opened up his manila folder of goodies he looked me square in the eye and said, "I like people.  I think it is great that you are biking across the country.  This country was built by people like you."  I was very flattered by his high impression of me.  We sat for about ten minutes, and he went through every photo he had of his previous encounters.   We hopped in his pick-up and headed into Warm Springs where Robert gave me a short but extensive tour of the town.  I got a lot of the history on FDR's connection with the area, the technicalities of the springs themselves, and Robert talked about his family too.  I could tell he was enjoying taking me around - and I too was enjoying listening and asking questions.  In fact he even told me, "I just enjoy showing you around.  It is fun to tell people about where you're from."   As Robert drove me up Pine Mountain he reminded me that I will be doing the same climb tomorrow on my bike.  And hearing his engine struggle up the slope, I got worried that my engine would be doing the same tomorrow morning.  He threw in a little story of when he was younger and went for a bike ride with a young lady up this mountain.  He said he was having trouble making it up the hill and he desperately wanted to get off the bike and walk it for a while because he could barely turn the cranks.  But, he joked, "If she wasn't going to stop, I sure wasn't going to get off the bike and embarrass myself."  So he said he struggled up the mountain, trying to hide his grimacing.   Mr. Bill and his wife own a log-cabin antique shop where they work during the day.  And recessed down a 100 foot driveway was their home (I later learned that they owned another home in Hampton and spent most of their time there - coincidentally, I was in Hampton earlier today checking my email).  When we pulled up to the log-cabin shop, Mr. Bill (that's what Robert calls him, maybe because he's Robert's senior) was out front preparing his small (I might add though, it was a perfect size) RV for roadside sale.  I stepped out of Robert's pick-up and Mr. Bill greeted me with a big smile.  This man had a huge aura surrounding him.  He was at least 6'3", in his early 70's, and in great shape.  His legs were muscular, his hand shake firm, but what I noticed most was his very cheerful laugh.  We exchanged greetings and headed down the short driveway to his home.  I instantly felt comfortable.      Mr. Bill's wife fixed us some cokes and we sat out on his side porch.  For about an hour, Robert, Mr. Bill, and I talked about bicycling, family, railroading - anything.  About twenty years earlier when Mr. Bill retired, he purchased himself a retirement present - a guided bicycle tour on the dirt roads from Montana to Alaska.  I, of course, was enthralled with any story he had to tell of his journey.  He also told me about bicycling the C&O Canal towpath recently - all 186 miles from Cumberland, Maryland to Washington, D.C.  Since I know a third of that course quite well we exchanged some stories.        It was my favorite time of the day, the hour before sunset.  The time when the sun creates subdued colors and the air has calmed down from a long day of heating and rising.  I think I smiled for the entire time I was there.  I was amazed by these older fellas' comfort with me, someone just a fraction of their age.  Never did they call me nave or joke about my inexperience in life.  I was equally amazed by these guys' physical condition and comportment.  Robert was very polite and interested in everything anyone had to say, and Mr. Bill was in such great shape and his childish but throaty laugh made him a pleasure to be around.   At the end of the hour, Mr. Bill's wife showed us around the inside of their home, we snapped some photos, and Robert and I were on our way back to the pick-up.  Before we left, Mr. Bill invited me back - he said next time I'm passing through town just give him some advance notice and they'll fix me dinner and let me stay the night.          There was nowhere to eat in Warm Springs to my liking, so Robert brought me to the BP station where I scrounged for dinner while he waited in the truck.  On the way to the campsite we talked about my route to New Orleans from Warm Springs, and I told him that I was nervous to head through the backwoods of Alabama where I will be as alone as ever.  Robert told me to call him if I ever needed any help.  He said he had colleagues in the Alabama Rural Water Association that would help me at the drop of a hat.  Back at the camp site, we said our good-byes and he snapped some photos of me with my bike in front of my tiny tent.        The trip, in my mind, has taken a new turn.  I think I had this encounter at the perfect time.  I am beginning to tire physically and more importantly, emotionally.  Although the riding has been good lately, I have found myself just wanting to get there.  In my conversations with Mr. Bill and especially Robert, I remembered that this trip is more than just getting to the destination.  Robert's enthusiasm about my travel made my enthusiasm multiply. For whatever reason, very few people do stuff like this.  I relish in the knowledge that I am a pioneer in my adventuring.  I sat in the dark at the picnic table at Ramsey's RV Park with my miner's lamp shining on my potato chips and chocolate milk, thinking to myself, "This changes everything."  Tomorrow will be more than just another day closer to New Orleans.
Accommodations: Howard Johnson Express Inn    My sleep was broken last night, but I was in bed for eight and a half hours so I felt fairly rested when I awoke.  I packed up and headed southwest towards Columbus, Georgia and its ugly kid brother across the Chattahoochee River, Phenix City, Alabama.  That would be only a 40-45 mile ride, but I thought that a shorter day would be good for my legs.  And anyway, the ride was going to have at least one big climb in it, Pine Mountain, so a 60-mile mountainous day was out of the question. I stopped by the post office I spotted the night before in Warm Springs as Robert toured me around town.  I mailed back to New Orleans a few things:  Georgia Atlas (except for the one page that I needed to make it to Alabama), the gift hat Robert gave me last night, my UNC hat (my hair is now short and no longer needs to be hidden in public when I take my helmet off), and my pair of long spandex pants (I bought these for any emergency where I found myself in cold weather, but I am now so far south the odds are against needing them).  The package weighed two pounds, but I thought that it was worth the stop and the postage because that would be two fewer pounds I would have to lift over Pine Mountain. The climb over Pine Mountain was rough, but don't get me wrong, it's nothing like any of the French Alps those studs devour.  Granted I am carrying a lot of weight, but those guys can climb for hours on end, this only took 20-25 minutes.  I threw the bike into granny gear and crawled up the hill at about 5 or 6 miles an hour.  I probably could have run faster up it, but then again, I am carrying my living-quarters and necessities.  The climb consisted of a long 8-10 percent grade followed by a short 12-15 percent grade.  I turned on the GPS/altimeter for the steeper portion of the climb just to see what kind of work I was doing.  I climbed that portion, 204 vertical feet, in under four minutes.      At what I thought was the top, the road flattened for a little bit as I passed by Mr. Bill's shop and home.  I then had some rises and falls in the road, with more ascent than descent.  I finally reached the top when I saw nothing but downhill ahead.  I was 1204 feet above sea level.  Georgia isn't known for its tall mountains, but in my book, it was the highest I've ever been on my bike.      It's really hard to describe the descent.  And statistically-speaking I can't portray it easily either.  My speedometer on my cyclocomputer failed for the entire descent and the speedometer on my GPS was giving me funny readings.  But I was getting what seemed to be accurate readings from the altimeter:  a descent of 460 vertical feet per minute maintained for 40 seconds - the ears were a poppin'.  I was disappointed that the cyclocomputer speedometer wasn't working, and when I got to the bottom of the mountain I checked out my GPS speedometer and it had registered a max speed of 88.5mph.  Now I know I was going fast because cars were having difficulty passing me, but I highly doubt that I was going that fast.  It was probably more around 50.  The GPS probably got some inaccurate readings because my head was directly above it (GPS picks up very weak satellite signals and any occlusion of line-of-sight to the sky decreases the unit's accuracy) as I tucked down into my Spaederdynamic stance. In Waverly Hall, Georgia at 11:00am I spotted Cooper's Grocery store and decided to stop and call it quits for the morning.  I had some Lunchables along with yogurt, a banana, and an apple.  As usual, I read my book after lunch and had short conversations with passers-by.  One fellow in a beat-up pick-up truck offered me a ride to Columbus, but I turned him down telling him that that would be cheating.   I encountered quite a few hills on my approach to Columbus from the northeast, and later I encountered a lot of traffic in downtown.  I wanted to stay in Alabama for the evening because although it is only a mile between Columbus and Phenix City, I would have another state under my belt.  Crossing into Alabama on a secondary bridge over the Chatahoochee, I was dismayed to see no sign welcoming me to the state.        I quickly learned that crossing into 'Bama for the evening may have been a mistake - I couldn't find a motel anywhere.  I should have remembered from my younger days as a railroader -- I did a lot of traveling out this way, and I always stayed in Columbus because lodging in Phenix City was so sparse.  After riding a few miles around town I crossed back into Georgia on another secondary bridge.  I headed south for US 280, the central artery in town.  I thought that I would definitely find something off that road, either in Columbus or Phenix City.  Intersecting 280 I looked west towards Phenix City and noticed a billboard for a Holiday Inn Express in Phenix City off 280  (2 miles away).  I saw nothing so promising towards the east, so I hopped on my bike and crossed the Chatahoochee for the third time of the day.  This time I got a nice state line sign.  I thought, "I'll  be in Bamy for a while,"      I ended up staying at the Howard Johnson's adjacent to the Holiday Inn Express for no other reason than that it looked to be cheaper.  I went to my room, a little aggravated by the heat, and a little frustrated that my short day was five miles longer than it needed to be as I hopped from Georgia to Alabama, back to Georgia, and then back to Alabama.   After cooling off and resting I ventured out on to 280 on foot and walked a mile westward towards some restaurants.  I ate at the nicest Italian place in town - a huge plate of spaghetti w/ meat sauce and a salad for seven bucks.  Perfect.  My frustration was quelled and my body replenished.
Accommodations: Blue Springs State Park campground Quote of the Day: 'I don't know where that is, but it sounds far away.' A passer-by at a grocery store in Eufaula in response to my declaration that I left on my trip from Washington, D.C.  An uneducated statement or profound political commentary???    I was on the road by 8:45 this morning headed due south.  I would be paralleling a railroad route towards a paper mill in Mahrt, Alabama.  I was familiar with this area of the state again from my railroading days.  The route was hilly and filled with trucks reeking of paper pulp (who thought something from a tree could be so nauseous).  But the shoulders were large and the scenery was beautiful.  I had a pleasant conversation with a farmer at a gas station somewhere along the way.  We both complained about the trucks, but we mostly talked about my trip.  Twenty minutes later he passed me in his late 80's Dodge Dakota and gave me a toot and a wave - that made me smile.  It was a 42-mile ride to Eufaula along the palisades of the Chatahoochee.   I pulled into town around noon and headed for the Winn-Dixie.  The conversation there blessed me with the QOTD.  Two elderly women stopped to talk with me as they were walking by.  They said they saw all of my bags on the bike and knew that I must be traveling.  I told them about the trip and they gave me the QOTD.  I was a little thrown off by them not knowing where our nation's capital is, but we continued to talk and I continued grinning in delight of their sweetness.  I closed the conversation as they were walking away by saying, 'Take care, ladies.'  They looked like they got weak in their knees.  One of them replied, 'Ohh, okay baby.'  I think they liked me.   I left Eufaula after some reading and resting.  It was hot - as hot as I have felt it yet.  Outside of town, climbing a hill, a blue sedan passed me and then pulled into a driveway and then the driver waved me over as I rode by.  I stopped and talked to the woman driver, about 40 years old.  Her septuagenarian mother sat silently in the passenger seat eating her Sonic french fries.  The woman wanted to wish me luck on my trip.  We chatted for about two minutes, and I told her that I was headed for Blue Springs State Park.  She beamed about the fact that the park was near her home (both of which were 15 miles away - apparently she and her mom went in to Eufaula for some fine lunch dining:  Sonic).  She told me about the park, mentioning that the word around Blue Springs was that there is now an alligator living in one of the ponds.  In Texasville, I took a left on to Barbour County Route 53.  For the next five miles I basked in the wonder that is Alabama.  CR 53 wasn't more than 15 feet wide and looked as if it hadn't been paved since its original surfacing decades ago.  The tarmac was a course aggregate that created significant resistance on my thin tires, but I glided through it all because I was in such a good mood.  I had U2 on the CD player blasting in my right ear and rhythm running through my legs.  The vegetation was lush and the houses that spotted the way were true homes, no trailers.  You trudge through a hundred miles for a few miles of pure pleasure like this.    I made it to Blue Springs buzzing.  The state park was only one or two hundred acres large, but the camp sites took up at least half that area.  I was one of two tent campers there, and there were a few other small RV's.  It was a Friday night and the camp was filled only to about 5% capacity.  I wondered if the place ever fills up.  The primitive site was $5.20 (state parks always charge an uneven amount - it's probably the state legislators setting strange taxes rates). I had plenty of places to choose from.  I looked for a site farthest away from the pond (away from the gator!), but none of those were flat.  I settled on a flat one in the shade that was still far enough away from any danger.  Today was an awesome day of riding, and heavy on miles too - my second biggest yet.  The endorphins still pumped through me for a full hour after I finished riding mostly because I stayed active in the heat as I set up camp.  I did, however, feel a deep-seated tiredness inside.  I can make it another day or two without rest, maybe three, but that'll be it.    After the daily evening chores, I sat to eat an energy bar before taking a shower and finding dinner.  I had purchased a cookies & creme Clif Bar at a service station earlier today.  This would be my first Clif Bar of that flavor.  I opened it up and noticed that it looked different than most Clifs - it looked to be made of sandlike grains adhered together around a central core.  I took a bite and after two chews I looked back at the bar for my next bite, only to see about twenty mite-like insects in the bar.  I spit out what I had in my mouth and immediately washed with water.  I suppose it could have been worse, I could have inhaled the whole thing without looking.  My body is pretty resilient at this point of the trip, and I don't think any of those insects will hurt me.  I took the remaining three quarters of the bar and got into the discus stance and hurled the infected bar into woods (Coach B would be proud of my knee-tuck). I listened to the National Weather Service on my weather radio as I ate a different energy bar.  Tropical Storm Barry is on its way towards Mobile, as was I.  I've made it this far, I'll just press on tomorrow and keep me ears peeled to the radio.  At this point of the trip I have to start thinking about how I'm going to cross the Mobile Bay.  I have four options:  Option A:  hitchhike over the bicycle-prohibited I10 bridge; Option B:  hitchhike through the tunnel on US 90; Option C:  Ride into Mobile then north 6 miles on Alt 90, cross the bay on a secondary bridge, and then ride south another 6 miles to get back on to US 90; Option D:  ride through the panhandle of Florida, along the Gulf and then cross the bay at its lip on a ferry.  Options A and B aren't out of the question, but I would rather not hitchhike.  From Blue Springs it is exactly equal distance for Options C and D, but D is more majestic, and I'm all about majesty.  Option C doesn't sound fun, D does.  I don't have to make the decision for another day and a half of riding, so I will wait to hear where Barry is going.  There are few campgrounds and even fewer towns large enough that look like they may support a motel here in this part of the country.  So, I must divert from my Chapel Hill to New Orleans straight-line path that I have been sticking to.  I have no option. For dinner I walked to the only business in Blue Springs, a BBQ restaurant.  And, however clich it may sound, I had the best pulled pork sanwhich I've ever had.  Added to that I had a baked potato, beans, a tall glass of Barq's, and a slice of pound cake for dessert.  Maybe food tastes better when you are camping, or maybe the best barbeque is in Blue Springs - really I don't care which statement is true, maybe they both are. When I checked into the Howard Johnson yesterday in Phenix City, I asked the clerk if I was in Central Time yet, and she told me that Phenix City for some reason stays on Eastern Time (my speculation:  Columbus, Georgia across the river is five times the size and the little brother wants to keep time with its elder).  She couldn't really tell me where Central Time starts, but I assumed that it was somewhere on the outskirts of town.  I never saw a sign today (I wish I had, I've never biked across a time zone before), but looking at the clock in the restaurant I realized that I have made the change.  I will be using the extra hour not to ride but to sleep. And so I did, at nine.  I fell peacefully to sleep under clear starry skies.  Today was good.
Stats: 4:34:44 ride time 13.2mph avg speed Accommodations:  Travel Inn Quote of the Day: 'Where you from again???  I gotta tell my buddies 'bout 'dis.' Closing comment from a convenience store conversation.    Last night's sleep was perfect.  The stars were out, the air was dry and cool, and I slept like a baby - for nine and a half hours.  I woke up this morning refreshed.  The legs were sore, but I had a lot of energy.  With a relaxed rhythm I ate breakfast, packed up, and quietly rolled out of the park.    I had an uneventful first 10 to 15 miles of the morning, but that didn't make it bad.  I cruised through the county roads, enjoying the warming sun.  This part of the U.S.A. seems to be full of rolling hills that can be steep at times but are not very long lasting like they have been earlier in the trip.  I am definitely in the Piedmont of the Southeast, and it won't be too long until I'll be at the Gulf of Mexico. Enjoying a nice downhill coast, sometime in the mid-morning, I didn't prepare myself for the inevitable bridge that lay at the bottom of one stream valley.  The bridge and the road were separated by almost two inches and the impact of the bridge lip on my rear tire was quite violent.  Not surprisingly, within two wheel revolutions of the impact, my rear tire hissed loudly.  After five seconds of cursing myself for letting this happen, I slowed the rig to a stop and leaned it up against a utility poll.  I think early in the trip, a few seconds of anger at myself would have progressed into many minutes if not a half-day or more of frustration.  But, I have matured in the past three weeks.  As long as I am safe and I have the tools to fix the problem, I don't get phased anymore by mechanical mishaps or anything else.
