My tubes, tire irons, and pressure gauge are not surprisingly kept at the very bottom of one of my panniers, so I took my sweet ole' time getting to them - unpacking everything on the shoulder of that Barbour County road.  I was humored by the location of my make-shift repair shop - this road was completely devoid of houses except for where I set up shop.  Midway through my repair job as I sweated through the tire-pumping process I looked up to the large window in the lone edifice on this road to see a middle-aged woman staring at me.  Immediately, she took her hands out of the horizontal blinds that she had propped open to sneak a peek at this crazyguyfixingabike.  I smiled and went back to working on the rig.  I did, however, think to myself, 'Lady!  Don't just sit there, a glass of ice-water would be nice.'   But, I moved on and found myself in Ariton, Alabama by 11:00.  I picked up some refreshments and the QOTD at the general store in town.  I asked the author for a mileage estimate to my lunch stop, New Brockton.  'Twelve miles,' he said, which is what I had predicted.  Perfect.  I rolled out of that one-caution-light-town and as I climbed a hefty hill on the outskirts  I heard an old pick-up chugging up the hill only slightly faster than I was.  I sensed the truck off my left knee, and I saw out of my peripheral vision that it was a 1950's Carolina Blue pick-up - my kind of truck.  I turned my head to get a better look at what was going on just two feet away.  In the cab were two enormous black guys, about my age.  I immediately pegged the passenger as a spitting-image of my college teammate, James Wagstaff (Note:  'Wags' was also a starting offensive tackle (340+ lbs.) on the football team and is now with the Miami Dolphins).   Nonetheless, these guys were intimidating merely by their size and the fact that they were only inches away.  They immediately quelled my anxiety with a simple remark from the driver, 'Hey friend, where ya comin' from?'  My stone face turned to a huge smile as I gladly exclaimed, 'Washington, D.C.'  A one minute conversation ensued as we moved at 8mph up a hill that gradually flattened towards the top.  Once I saw that they were creating a minor traffic jam behind them (three cars), I thanked them for saying hello and wished them a good day.  It is those chance encounters that are the essence of enjoyment for this trip.  Those guys didn't need to stop and say hello, but they did it anyway.  I also learned that a great way to get a positive response out of a stranger in an unsure situation is to open your conversation with a, 'Hey friend.'  Ohh, and the passenger after seeing my smile had the exact same smile as Wags does.     I ate lunch ate a Piggly Wiggly in New Brockton.  The grocery store had one cashier, one bag boy, and one manager, but a plentiful selection of food.  I declined the bag boy's offer to carry my groceries out to my car.  I sat outside on a long glossy wooden bench which was in great shape despite having only a small awning overhead for protection from the elements.  I took an extra long time today to eat and rest, partially because it was so hot and partially because I had already set my sights on Opp which was a meager 15 miles away.  In the lack of a rush I got to enjoy conversations with the proud store manager and one long-time resident who kept asking me if I was in a bicycle race.  I'm not sure if he ever got the idea that I was just riding across country for fun, but at least he made an effort at talking.  He also assured me that I would be able to find a motel or two in Opp, which was comforting because according to my weather radio, Tropical Storm Barry was only a day or two away. The temperature read 94 degrees at the local bank as I left New Brockton.  I felt fine though.  I took the first few miles out of town slowly, until my body was awakened and ready to pound out some miles.  And so I did.  Through quiet barren roads, I swiftly plodded - past a half-dozen Baptist churches and their accompanying picnic grounds and graveyards.  Properly reflecting their settings, the churches were aptly called such beautiful names like Mt. Olive.  I had U2 again playing in my ear, and before I knew it I was in the metropolis of Opp.  I had two choices for motels in town (like my acquaintance said I would).  I chose the Travel Inn merely because it was across the street from a service station where I stopped to purchase a Florida Map.      The cashier, a woman in her young 30's named Sassi, was floored at the revelation that I was riding my bicycle across country.  She told me to hang tight while she called the local news station.  After she waited on hold for a minute or two, I, wanting to get out of the freezing interior of the Chevron Food Mart, wrote down my name and where I was staying.  Sassi, was anything but, so I was hoping that she simply and only used that information for its intended purpose, a TV interview.   Outside the store I spotted an Alabama State Trooper pumping gas into his majestic blue and gray (mostly gray:  this is the South) Crown Vic.  I struck up a conversation with the statey, telling him about my journey.  My objective was to get advice on how to cross the Mobile Bay, a task that I'll have to encounter in the next two or three days.  He said he couldn't help me with my request because his jurisdiction was the southeast portion of the state, not all the way west to Mobile.  He was, however, inquisitive about my route up until Opp, so I shared a few sentences with him and then headed back to my rig. As I was getting my stuff together to walk the rig across the street to the motel to check in, I was accosted by a family from Paducah, Kentucky that was passing through town on their way back from the Gulf Coast beaches of Florida.  Both the son and daughter snapped photos of me, why I'm not sure.  The father jokingly said they wanted a picture of the bicyclist that made it almost all the way from D.C. to New Orleans before he was hit by a truck.  Yeah real funny    After a shower I gave the Alabama State Police in Mobile a phone call to pose to them the same question I posed to the trooper in person earlier.  It took a minute or two to make the operator understand what I was doing and that I really was on a bicycle.  But, after that she was very helpful.  We discussed each of my four potential Bay crossings.  Two were immediately out of the question for riding (but not for hitchhiking, if push came to shove), one because it was the interstate and one because it was a tunnel.  I was left with two options, a bridge crossing 16 miles out of the way to the north of Mobile or a ferry crossing at the lip of the Gulf of Mexico.  After some research (using my headphone cord as a measuring device on my map) I found that they were almost identical in mileage.  So the question was begged, a boring bridge crossing or a fun ferry ride?  The former was too drab, the latter was something novel and besides it would require me to go through Florida - and unplanned odyssey.  Florida it would be, now I just have to see what Mother Nature will do.   I walked to the Arby's for dinner and the IGA grocery store to pick up some Wheaties Energy Crunch cereal (very good) and milk for breakfast.  More Gary Condit coverage before bedtime 
Quote of the Day: 'C'mon man, let me in!'  Heard at my motel room door at 3:15am after a round of loud knocking.  Needless to say, I didn't comply. The storm that seemed imminent yesterday late afternoon didn't pass during the night.  In fact, according to The Weather Channel, it didn't look like it will be in downtown Opp until midnight tonight.  So, I could've conceivably headed out and done a good 40 miles of riding and then hunker down again, but my legs were so beat that they felt bruised.  And, I was fine where I was anyway - I had a grocery store across the street, a great book to read, and the most basic of cable TV to watch.  Relatively speaking, I was in paradise. I tracked the storm throughout the day in my journal: My location:    31.3N  86.3W 4am 27.8N  86.6W   Moving:  NNE @ 6MPH 8am 28.2N  86.4W   NNE @ 6MPH 1pm 28.6N  86.5W   N @ 6MPH 10pm 29.9N  86.2W  N @ 6MPH And later in the afternoon I wrote:  It is so odd to me that this trip which has been planned for months is now held up at its waning moments by an impending hurricane that is directly headed for my path.  Kinda frustrating, but I'll just wait - no hurry.  I have been busy this entire summer with my classes at UNO, my trip to Europe, and this bike trip.  I could be bumming around in New Orleans or here.  I would rather be there, but here is okay, so I'll just be super-rested for my last four days of riding. I went over to the IGA sometime around dusk to pick up dinner and some granola bars. I ran into Sassi (Chevron clerk) who was shopping with her girlfriends.  We exchanged 'hey''s (hers more southern than mine), but no mention was made of the TV interview that didn't come to fruition.  Despite the Alabamians lack of interest in a TV news story about my ride (I'm not sure, after all, why the interview didn't happen), as I walked back to the Travel Inn, I felt a renewed admiration for the state of Alabama.  There is something about the 'Heart of Dixie' (as it is so called on their license plates) that is special.  It is hard to explain in words, but I know I felt it when I lived in Birmingham, and I feel it again now.  And I feel it in Peter Jenkins' words as I read of his travels through this state.  Alabama:  its people, its land, its roads, its contours - has got something special about it.  Sometimes it is so colorful that it's full of character, and sometimes it is so devoid of charm that it strangely feels full of character.  Hard to articulate, but I'll leave it at this:  Alabama is juicy.  Now it's up to you to explore what I mean.   Back in the motel room I assembled a package to send home to New Orleans.  I got rid of a lot of stuff that I hopefully won't need over my last four days, including:  one pair of cycling shorts, one shirt, the cell phone charger, and a few tent stakes that hadn't been used yet. I lay in bed for most of the day and alternated between watching TV and reading my book.  One passage, in particular, inspired me for the next days' journey; Peter writes about leaving town after a period of rest  As always when I left a town with fluffy beds and instant food, it would take me all day to get my body and mind into flowing gear.  Flowing gear would make me move effortlessly while I looked, watched and listened. I hope the storm will pass tonight, so I can merrily be on my way - my last leg to New Orleans.  A few hours into the ride tomorrow, I'll be sure to kick it into flowing gear.
Accommodations: Holiday Inn Express Quote of the Day: 'Don't forget to put his cell number.'   That's cell, as in prison cell, not as in cell phone.  Overheard in the Opp post office between two women discussing their imprisoned husbands and the need to properly address letters to them.    I slept late and after breakfast I checked The Weather Channel.  Tropical Storm Barry had moved through Opp during the evening and was currently centered 25 miles southwest Selma - the forecast for Opp was partly cloudy skies, no precip.  I called the public library in town to see if it was open so I could update my site.  The elderly fellow on the other end said that the library was closed for the day because of the storm and that he was just in the library for a few moments to make sure that nothing was damaged.  How cute. I took my time getting my stuff together and heading out of the motel room.  I wasn't really in the mood to ride quite yet, but I knew that I had to put some mileage in.  After getting lost a few times in downtown Opp I found the post office (a new modern one) on the outskirts of town where I mailed a package of stuff to New Orleans.  My last errand in town was at a gas station food mart - where I picked up a triangle sandwich and chips.  Most likely lunch will be eaten on the road, because according to my map, my path into Florida went through no dots.         I headed out of town south on US 331.  There were few cars on the road but plenty of fallen branches from the storm the night before.  The wind blew hard out of the southeast and into the left side of my face.  The five or so miles on US 331 were a pain because I didn't really want to be riding (yet) and the wind slowed my pace to a meager 10MPH.  Fortunately, I made a right turn off of the main route and into Conecuh National Forest.  I now had the wind at my back.  For the next five hours, I would not see more than two people, one car, and two dogs  Somewhere in the northeast corner of the national forest, as I rode along an old paved road, I passed a house with two large yellow lab-like (but much bigger:  100lbs. each) dogs standing sentinel out front.  'No big deal,' I thought, I've encountered many dogs on this trip.  But these dogs were different:  they were bigger, faster, and apparently hungrier than any of those I've met before.  Going about 20MPH, I had each dog, fangs exposed, about a foot away from each of my ankles.  I rode hard for about ten seconds to see how intent they were on having me for a meal.  And although they never chomped down on me, they never slowed nor backed off from their locked-aim on my ankles.  So, like I have before, I pulled one of the cans of Halt! pepper spray off of my front handlebar bag.  But, because there was no shaking these guys with speed or shouts of, 'No!' I decided to unleash the pepper spray on these unsuspecting but nevertheless vicious canines.  They each got three seconds-worth of liquid in their eyes, first the dog on the right and then the dog on the left.  As I stood out of my saddle to put more umph into the rig's drivetrain and therefore separate from the predators, I glanced over my left shoulder to see the two dogs furiously rubbing their faces into the grass of the road shoulder.  'They'll get over it,' I told myself.  So, yes the Halt! does the job of saving people from dog attacks, but there is a caveat  Pepper spray irritates humans and canines - we all know this.  Obviously, it irritates eyes and mouths first simply because of their exposure, but it will also irritate skin - it just takes time.  I found this out the hard way.  Apparently, when I was spraying those blond marauders, I got quite a bit of spray on my fingers, legs, and water bottle (mounted on the down tube of the rig).  Recovering from the chase, I took a swig from my water bottle to only feel five seconds later not refreshed, but like I was sucking on twenty red-hots.  There wasn't much I could do but take hits from my Camelbak water and swish it around my mouth.  Meanwhile, during the ten minute latent period, I was unknowingly spreading the spray all (read:  ALL) over my body.  So just as I was getting over the red-hot predicament with my mouth, my body felt like it was frying.  Granted, it was noon and the temperature was in the high 80's, but it felt like I was in the high 200's.  It wasn't really painful but just very irritating.  I kept riding, trying to focus on something else to take my mind off the feeling that I was entering Dante's third ring of hell.  I eventually pulled over under a shade tree and went searching for my bar soap in my left saddle-bag.  And there in the middle of desolate southcentral Alabama, I took a very rudimentary shower:  taking water into my mouth from the Camelbak, spitting it into my cupped hands and rubbing the water and bar soap over my burning body.  I knew that time would be the biggest healer of this ailment.  I hopped back on the bike, only slightly relieved and pedaled on, just waiting for the heat to dissipate.  This feeling was certainly better than being mauled by dogs, but at the time, I had a hard time rationalizing that in my mind.  I was mostly just mad at myself for getting myself into this situation:  irritated by heat and now with less than half of the Camelbak water left as I entered the hottest time of the day.  I had learned my lesson though:  get the pepper spray exclusively on the canines not the human using it. The lack of water didn't prove troublesome until after lunch when I was deep into the forest on quicksand-like roads.  I was depending heavily on my compass, GPS, and atlas to navigate through the wiles of the unsigned, unpaved roads.  I knew that the town of Wing, Alabama was on southern end of the forest, on the Florida border.  Surely, there would be provisions there.  As I felt the weight on my back wither down, I knew I had to conserve energy and water (inside my body and out) to make it through this predicament.  My pace slowed, but I was sure that I would make it through this because I felt fine and felt no panic or hurry inside of me.  Fortunately, by this time (about two hours after the dog incident) the irritation had completely ceased.  I listened to a faint NPR signal and slowly revolved the cranks.  And anyway, in a pinch, I could purify water from one of the many streams in the forest.  But, it never came to that  Going southwest of Forest Road 14, while in the process of dismounting the rig to portage it over a fallen tree, I heard a motor vehicle in the distance behind me.  I waited for a few moments and saw a dark green Ford F-150 pull up.  'Ahh -- humans,' I thought.  The driver-side door read, 'Dept. of Agriculture United States Forest Service.' The 'Ahh -- humans,' turned into an, 'Alleluia -- humans!.'  I stopped the truck to ask if I really was on Forest Road 14.  In the ten minute ensuing conversation I learned a good bit about these guys' jobs (keeping the roads of the Conecuh clear for passage), why some National Forests have houses in them (they are residences that preexisted the creation of the National Forest), and how I was to make it to Wing (I really was on FR 14, headed the right way).  They offered me water out of the cooler they had in the bed of the truck.  They repeatedly apologized that the water was a little warm.  I assured them that I was not picky.  So, my Camelbak took on some water, and these bad-asses in Carhart apparal (they deserved to be wearing it) rode over the branch I dismounted for, and off into the distance.      I finally made it out of the Conecuh National Forest, and into downtown Wing - a service station.  I bought two gallons of water - ingested one in the parking lot, and stowed the second for the remaining haul of the day.  Before I left Wing, I called home and talked to my dad assuring him that Tropical Storm Barry was no threat and that I would be in Florida in minutes.  The plan, at the time, was to stay at a campsite fifteen miles over the state line. You would think that at this stage of the trip I would be out of spine-tingling events or merely too tired to have any, but crossing into Florida and taking a photo of the rig leaned up against the pretentiously large welcome sign, I felt a huge sense of accomplishment and excitement.  I had ridden my bike from my parent's driveway to Florida, a place I had been twice before (once for family vacation and once for a track meet) but only getting there by airplane.  The excitement also stemmed from the fact that this part of the trip was unplanned for.  I never thought Florida would be on my list of 'ridden-through' states, but for the next twenty-four hours I would be cutting through the far reaches of the Floridian pan-handle.  And every second that I was in this state I would feel like I was adventuring to a higher degree.      Going due south again, I suffered from the same wind resistance that I had earlier (wind knows no state lines).  I made it to my potential campsite, outside Baker, around 6:30 under drizzling skies.  According to the wayside sign, the campsite was three miles off the main road I was on.  Although I felt good, I was not in the mood to ride three miles up some gravel road to a campsite that I had little knowledge about (only a mark on my Opp-purchased map indicating a camping area).  I decided to make a break for Milton, 20 miles away.  It was off of I10 and would surely have a requisite motel or two.  I turned right out of Baker and on to U.S. 90.  I would be on this road off-and-on all the way into New Orleans.  In fact, my place of employment is on U.S. 90.  Those twenty miles to Milton went by in a little over an hour and were a great joy.  The drizzle was light enough so as to not create a nuisance but heavy enough to keep me cool.   I found the Holiday Inn Express that I expected would be there - within one hundred feet of I10.  I checked in, ordered pizza, and did laundry.  I loved doing this bike-touring thing, especially today, because you never know how a day will turn out until its over.  And when you think things couldn't get worse (pepper spray on the epidermis) just persist, and you will have rewards (endorphins pumping during a fantastic stretch of flat riding with the wind at your back).
Accommodations: Gulf State Park  Quote of the Day: 'Hold on Bryan, Daddy's going to the bathroom.'   Heard inside the bathhouse of the Gulf Shores State Park as I brushed my teeth.  The author, in a stall, was trying to remotely control his son who was running all over the bathhouse and at the time of this quote, peeking into the stall.    I left the Holiday Inn Express and made the three-mile ride into town to the library under a light, chilly rain - the kind that would be refreshing at the end of a long day.  But, this rain irked me and portended a rough day ahead.  The Milton Public Library was in a municipal complex halfway up a hill in a residential part of town.  I explained myself, like usual, to the clerk at the front desk and was given an hour at a terminal.  In that time I finished one day's entry, updated the other days on the Table of Contents, and checked my email.  Promptly at one hour, the clerk asked me to relinquish my spot to a waiting patron.  I gladly complied, but not before helping an elderly fellow seated next to me - he was having trouble closing out Internet Explorer.  I showed him how to click on the 'X.'  He responded with a, 'Thank you, sonny.' A light rain fell throughout my morning of riding through the extreme western portion of Florida's panhandle.  For safety in the low-visibility conditions I made sure my red flashing light and amber strobe were on the entire morning.  Unfortunately, the strobe light uses up my rechargeable batteries very quickly.  Just outside Pensacola, I noticed that it was out of juice, so I pulled over to a park, which was nothing more than a parking lot on a man-made island between bridges in the Pensacola Bay. As I pried open the battery cover to the strobe light, my knife slipped and went squarely into my left thumb - leaving me with a half-inch gash that bled steadily.  I went straight to the first aid kit mounted under my saddle and patched up my self-inflicted wound.  This injury coupled with my multiple calluses on the palms of my hands ached and throbbed throughout the rest of the day.   I ate on the front curb of a gas station north of Pensacola under an awning - the standard fare:  a triangle sandwhich, chips, yogurt, fruit, and cookies.  Although I was wet and probably should have gotten back in the saddle to warm up, I sat, rested my tired body, and finished the last twenty pages of my book, A Walk Across America by Peter Jenkins - a very good book, not the best I've ever read, but still a fun, fulfilling, and easy read.  Whenever I got frustrated with the author's amateurish writing style, I had to remind myself that Jenkins was my age when he wrote the book, and he simply set out on his journey never intending to become an author.  I know my writing has plenty of problems, so I passed over his and concentrated on the great stories he told.   I remembered what my friend Olivia told me when she gave the book to me back in Chapel Hill.  Instead of mailing it back to her when I was finished, like I first suggested, she told me to give it to someone else.  I kinda took her advice - I scribbled a note on the title page - something like: To whoever picks up this book:  Please take this book and read it.  I hope it inspires you and opens your eyes to America's beauty like it has for me as I do my own journey from D.C. to New Orleans.  -Matt Spaeder  8/7/01  www.crazyguyonabike.com/doc/spaeder I left the book atop the leftmost public phone at that gas station at the corner of U.S. Alt 90 and U.S. 90.  [Please sign my guestbook if you have the book!  I'd love to hear from you.] Surprisingly, Pensacola had a good bit of hills, which taxed me more than I had hoped.  The light rain that was only a slight bother before, turned into a downpour for about thirty minutes as I rolled through downtown.  Not wanting to stop, I pressed on.  The rain finally finished completely, the sun came out, and the temperature rose.  I passed a General Nutrition Center in a suburban mall southwest of town and stopped in because it was Super Tuesday (the first Tuesday of each month is 20% off with a GNC Gold Card!).  I loaded up on Power Bars and the like.  'Eighteen miles to the state line,' the girl behind the counter told me.  And I was off. I rode steadily through the mid-afternoon down roads that wound through flat forests.  It didn't seem like the Gulf of Mexico would be on the other side of today's riding, but sometime around five, I saw my first resort condos rise out of the distance, and I knew the beaches and water couldn't be far.  I climbed a tall bridge over the Intracoastal Waterway and paused to take a photo of the waterway, the Gulf of Mexico, and the small spit of land in between, which would be my land for the next few hours.  Atop the bridge, exhausted and wet, I felt an incredible feeling of accomplishment wash over me.  The pain in my hands, the water in my shoes, the salt in my eyes, and the lactic acid that pumped through my blood vessels were momentarily dissolved from my active thoughts - I had ridden my bicycle from Washington, D.C. to the Gulf of Mexico.  I remembered when I was very young and it was a big deal for my brother and I to ride from our neighborhood to the next neighborhood over, Potomac Overlook.  And, a few years later we adventured into downtown McLean.  Now, I have made it halfway across the country to a body of water named after another nation.        I crossed back into Alabama in the late afternoon and battled winds as I traveled westward towards my place of rest for the evening.  At the huge Gulf State Park I went inside the park ranger hut to pay my $5.08 for a night's stay.  On the wall was a filing system that had one slot per campsite.  Only a few of the RV slots were occupied, and all of the tent camping sites were vacant - except now for me.  I only wondered about the lack of tent campers for three minutes - the three minutes it took me to ride from the hut to my site.  After leaning my rig against the picnic table, I instantly became intimately acquainted with the Alabama State Bird:  The Mosquito.  They were all over me.  Adjacent to my campsite was standing water and there was a canopy of trees over the grassy area of my site.  It was as if the mosquitoes had been waiting for human flesh to feast on.  I took my left saddlebag off the rack and searched through it for my insect repellent, all the while walking at a fast pace to try to keep some of those things off of me.  I caked on the DEET insect repellent which had only a moderate effect on the bugs.  I decided to set up camp on the other side of the camp road away from the water and away from the visible swarms of bugs.  As I buzzed (pun intended) from having the DEET flow through my blood, I quickly and sloppily pitched my tent.      I showered and rode a quarter-mile to the camp store, where I bought a loaf of bread, a mini-loaf of ham, and chocolate milk.  The clerk at the store told me to watch out for the alligator in the lagoon.  I think he told me this as less of a warning and more of a tourist tidbit.  He said the gator usually swims by the store at sunset.  So, as I ate, I sat by the lagoon on a bench waiting and watching for strange ripples of water.  I saw nothing.   I went back to the tent to relax and fall to sleep.  The air was thick and heavy, and I went through three pairs of rechargeable batteries in my fan trying to stay comfortable.  Now, without a book, I had little to do but write in my journal ("Worst day yet:  rain, then wind, then mosquitoes") and look at maps.  I fell into an uneasy sleep around ten.
Accommodations: Dauphin Island Motel    I awoke at 2am to the sound of rain on the outside of my tent.  I needed to go to the bathroom, but the prospects of going right outside the tent and being eaten by mosquitoes wasn't appealing.  On second thought, nor was making the 50 yard trek to the bathhouse.  I did, however, opt for the bathhouse, and I moved there with alacrity, hoping that the bugs wouldn't get me in transit.  Back in the tent, I quickly realized that I had some unwelcome guests piggyback in from the outside - more mosquitoes.  One by one I swatted them off of me and waited for them to take up perch on the inside of the tent.  I squished each one, leaving a small smattering of blood on the tent cloth.  This activity went on for a while, as I tried to rid my body and tent of about ten of those critters.  It was stuffy in the tent and the light mist falling (or rather, sitting) outside didn't help.  I told myself that I'd try once more to sleep before starting my day extra-early. At 3:15 I gave up and decided to eat breakfast and get my day rolling.  I ate inside my tent and then quickly broke camp.  One last trip to the bathhouse to shower and wake myself up.  I put my two last good rechargeable batteries in my strobe light and at 4:15 I left Gulf Shores State Park - taking with me memories of the worst night of my trip.  But my dismay with my current situation didn't seem to matter, once I was back on the rig.  I rode through the light mist two miles into town, not seeing a single soul.  I couldn't say that I felt energetic, but I was happy to be moving on - and moving on early. The Waffle House in downtown Gulf Shores burned bright as a beacon of civilization (and air conditioning).  I decided to stop in for a second breakfast.  There were no worries of looking like the strangest person there, in my spandex, as it was 4:30 in the morning and in my abnormalcy I fit right in.  After my deluxe breakfast I walked the rig across Alabama Route 182 to the Circle K to pick up a four-pack of Duracells - they would light my way to the ferryport. So, brightly lit up I rolled another two miles into a more commercial section of town.  There I got a better look at the road to Fort Morgan where I would catch the ferry across Mobile Bay.  After a quick glimpse at the tight two-lane unlit roadway, I decided to wait for daybreak.  I leaned my rig up against a storefront in a small strip mall and went to sleep on the concrete using my rolled up sleeping pad as a pillow.  Sunlight woke me up at 6:15, and I was rolling seconds later.  The ride to Fort Morgan was 19 miles and despite my lack of sleep, went by easily.  Morning talk-radio out of Mobile kept me company.  Fort Morgan, Alabama was nothing more than a Civil War-era fort and a handful of houses.  There was no sense of community.  No stores, no gas stations, except for a convenience store at the ferry dock which was closed when I was there.  I settled for two Sprites out of the soda machine.  After sitting down on a bench for a few moments I quickly realized why Fort Morgan wasn't so inhabited - mosquitoes.  They were everywhere and tenacious.  I walked out the ramp to the ferry about 50 feet over the water and just sat, so I could be left alone.        The 45-minute ride across the bay was scenic, but unsettling at the same time - a storm brewed to the northwest, my direction of travel.  I tried not to worry about it, because there was really nothing I could do.  I did make friends with a fellow New Orleanian, who I learned had a daughter in high school who needed tutoring in Algebra II.  We exchanged phone numbers, and I promised that I would call once in town.  [Spaeder-note:  This connection proved fruitful, as I was able to tutor the young lady throughout the fall semester, hopefully improving her logarithmic (and other mathematical) abilities.]    A light rain began to fall as I rolled off the ferry ramp and on to Dauphin Island.  As I rode away, one of the ferry's deck hands shouted to me:  'That's quite a storm ahead.  I saw it on our radar.'  A little worried, I rode, basically because I had little else to do. According to my map, it looked like there was a four-mile-long bridge between Dauphin Island and mainland Alabama.  It took about fifteen minutes to ride across the island and to the base of this bridge.  Just as I reached the bridge the heavens opened and dumped not just rain but pools of water.  I found refuge under a bank's drive-up window shelter.  The three tellers didn't give me any trouble for the twenty minutes I waited there, probably because they didn't receive any business during that time.  After the near monsoon slowed to a heavy shower, I decided to assess the situation on the bridge.  After climbing the first tenth-mile up the bridge to where it levels out and provides a good view of the entire span, I decided to call it quits.  The bridge was four miles long with a huge rise in the middle for boat traffic - all entirely too dangerous in the present conditions.  I turned back and decided to tackle this problem later. I rode to the nearby gas station to ask the clerk about the library and motel situation.  My hope was that I would bide my time in the former until the rain passed or check in to the latter and make an attempt in the morning.  My options were limited:  no library on the island and only one choice for motel.  It was still early in the day, around noon, but I thought I'd give the motel a chance.  I was tired of being wet and tired (literally).  The clerk at the Dauphin Island Motel did help me out by checking me in early, but he made a point of the fact that he was doing me a favor.   I checked in, slept, and woke up to partly sunny skies around five.  I was tempted to take off again and make it to Mississippi, but opted to eat, get to sleep early, and wake up at 4am for an attempted 150 mile assault on New Orleans.  Final duty for the evening was to purge all unneeded items:  two dehydrated meals, candy, & spare tires.  I wanted to be as light as possible for my big day.  Asleep by 8:30pm.
Accommodations:  Best Western Quote of the Day: "ERN3HRT" Seen on a license plate in Ocean Springs, Mississippi.      I was up at 4am and out the door by 4:50.  Brightly lit, I rode off of Dauphin Island and on to the bridge that was impassable for me yesterday.  It was a queazy but exciting feeling to be on this bridge alone over a big body of water in the near darkness.  I felt safe, because I could see cars coming for many minutes in advance.  Predawn light flickered in the sky as I made it over the huge rise in the bridge.  Yesterday, from a distance, this rise seemed tame, but now that I was climbing it I realized just how big it was.  At the very top, I paused my pedaling and coasted to a near stop.  I was about 50 feet above the sea, and yet again amazed at the places this bike trip has taken me.      Back on land, I really wasn't "on" land - I was on a bridge over marsh with the Mobile Bay to my right and high scrub brush to my left.  One boat of fishermen leaving the slip for the morning shined their flood light on me and give me a wave and a loud, "Hi!"  I bellowed back with a, "Hello!"  Each minute in the morning brought more light and more pick-ups on the road en route to their oyster boats for the day. I rolled through Bayou La Batre, the shrimping home of Forrest Gump, and stopped quickly at a gas station for some water and to pump up my front tire - it had been losing air slowly throughout the early morning.  Every few minutes I glanced at the time and my average speed to calculate and recalculate how I was doing and my ETA in New Orleans.  And around 8am, I crossed the state line (sorry, no sign) into Mississippi, right on schedule.  It was warm, but certainly not the worst it's been, but I noticed that I was drinking much more water and sweating more than usual.  I was able to find water throughout the morning with no problem, but I did wonder why I was consuming so much.  Nonetheless, I figured if I kept up my pace I would make it into the Big Easy around sunset.  A few miles west of Pascagoula my slow leaking front tire pinch-flatted.  This occurrence was the turning point of the day for me.  I could barely muster the energy to change the flat (a front tire, the easier of the two, nonetheless).   Once I completed the change-out, which took 15 minutes, ten more than it should have, I unwillingly got back on the bike.  I was now off of schedule, but more importantly out of inspiration.  I told myself that New Orleans wasn't happening today, it just wasn't a smart idea to make that assault in this heat, with my dead legs.  Once I made that decision, I actually felt considerably better - the pressure was off, and I could just enjoy the day.   I rode about five more miles to Gautier where a green sign of an iconographic person reading a book caught my eye - a library was nearby.  I stopped in for an hour of much needed cool air and computer-time.  I updated my website with information concerning where I have been and my new ETA in New Orleans:  5:00pm tomorrow. The rest of my day consisted of slow riding through resort towns and the boring 6 lane stretches between them.  Two more flats on the front tire began to make me wonder if it was a good idea to purge my spare tires in the motel last night.  At that time I thought I had my two best tires on the rig, but maybe I was wrong.   I stopped for forty-five minutes at the wayside Mississippi Vietnam Veterans Memorial.  The structure wasn't anything impressive, simply an open marble structure the size of a small house.  But inside were large photos on the walls of every serviceman from Mississippi that perished in the war - with their name, rank, and hometown listed underneath.  It wasn't the memorial itself, of course, that was intended to impress me, it was feelings evoked by those photos of guys my age or less that were killed in action while fighting for freedom.  I don't know how many there were from Mississippi, my guess would be about one thousand, but I made sure to glance at each photo, even for only a second or two.  Doing some research (looking in the yellow pages) I found a bike store in Biloxi where I stopped in for two more tubes and to shoot the breeze with the kind shopkeepers.  One of the men asked me whether I was riding the Southern Tier of the Transcontinental Route (there are three main cross-country semi-friendly bike routes and the southernmost-one passes through Biloxi), embarrassed that I was doing less than half of that, I explained where I've been and where I'm going to.  They were, nonetheless, excited for me especially because the trip was almost over.  We chatted some about New Orleans and the French Quarter  I checked into a Best Western near the casino-section of town, and immediately took a shower and gulped down a large Papa John's Pizza.  I relaxed the rest of the evening, except around nine when I went for a short walking tour of that part of town as I was in pursuit of an evening snack.  Before I went to bed I wrote in my journal, 'Tired.  Wish I were home.  But excited for tomorrow.'    I was very happy how the trip had been going, but that night my senses were dulled with fatigue. 
   My morning riding went by easily, as I knew that later that day I would be home.  I did, however, continue to have some trials and tribulations mechanically.  Actually, the rig itself, performed wonderfully, as it has done for the past four weeks.  The cyclocomputer, which had been giving me fits for the past many many days finally quit on me.  The problem, a loose wire connecting the sensor to the computer, has been creating a few gaps (nominal ones, only a couple of minutes at a time) in my distance calculations.  But, today no matter what shimmying I did with the wire, the computer would just give me a zero reading.  I decided to plain ole' forget about it and simply calculate my mileage the old-fashioned way - with a map.  Consequently, I don't have my ride time or average speed for the day.  But, this problem seemed kind of fitting:  the ride isn't about numbers or mileage, it's about the journey (in the broad sense of the term).   Besides, that inconsequential problem, I got another front tire flat outside of Bay St. Louis.  Like the three flats yesterday, I thoroughly inspected the tire for debris and again was surprised to find nothing.  There were a couple of small holes that I patched up with double-layered inner-tube rubber (from the tube that just went flat) and duct tape.  I was hoping that my jerry-rigged tire would get me home.  To cover my butt, however, I checked a yellow pages in Bay St. Louis for a bike store on my route home, and to my surprise found none.  I did stop, however, at a Wal-Mart in Waveland and purchased a tire and one tube (so I now was carrying two spare tubes).  [Spaeder-note:  I was in such a tizzy at the Wal-Mart that I didn't bother to check the valve type on the tube.  I had accidentally purchased a Shrader valve.  I didn't realize this until two days later when I was unpacking my stuff.  Fortunately, I didn't need it anyway.] Shortly after my Wal-Mart visit U.S. 90 took on a new look - no longer serving Gulf coast resorts, but now ducking through flat scrub brush.  I crossed the state line into Louisiana around 1pm and encountered bridge after bridge over swamps and bayous as I made my way southwestward.  I have been out this way on day rides, so I was somewhat familiar with the territory and I knew where my water availability was.  By this time of the day the morning clouds had mostly burned off and it was very hot - easily in the low 90's.          There was a possibility that there would be some students waiting for me at Brother Martin High School at 5:00pm, so I tried my best to stay on schedule, despite one last flat tire (a rear one).  An impending thunderstorm kept me on my toes, but fortunately passed to the north.  I am told that New Orleans is one of the largest cities (in area) in the country.  Much of that land is uninhabitable due to topographical reasons, but it added a little frustration for me because I was in New Orleans proper by about 3:15, and I knew I still had a long way to go.  I reached the city-like part of New Orleans by 4:30, and despite running low on water I just rode non-stop.  I could taste victory.    WARNING:  If you can't stomach grotesque sites, kindly scroll over the following photo quickly.  This ride was brutal and I saw some ugly sites - here's one of them:    I rode along the railroad tracks of the railroad I used to work for, then adjacent to Lake Pontchatrain where I used to go for Saturday afternoon bike rides, and then by Brother Martin where I currently work - no students waiting, but I wasn't surprised.  I kept going south on Elysian Fields Avenue into the French Quarter, and then I rode down Decatur Street.      I'll forsake any philosophizing here for the sake of brevity, but I will say that I was amazed that I had made it so far - that it really was possible to ride my bicycle halfway across the U.S.A.  The streets were abuzz with activity as it was a warm Saturday evening.  In some ways I felt like I was in a bubble, unaffected by the things and unconnected to the people around me, and at the same time I have never felt more alive, more in tune to my surroundings.  The feelings that washed over me throughout those last ten miles are hard to explain.  My mind and body were playing wonderful tricks on my mood and emotions - triggering intensities that had not been felt ever before.  My physical and mental elements had been working full throttle over the past four weeks (and prior, in training and planning phases), and now they were signaling my emotions and feelings to soak up the success.   The last few miles took me down St. Charles Ave. where I raced (and beat) street cars to Audubon Park - finally, through the park and to my apartment on Magazine Street.  My landlord was out washing her car, and asked, 'How was your summer?'  Too excited to really elaborate, I just smiled and said, 'Great.'    Show links to this Hide links to this

TOP FIVE ITEMS THAT I WISH I HAD WITH ME... 5.  Digital Camera - for easier and cheaper posting to the website. Although my $30 35mm camera got the job done, having a digital camera with me would have been a treat.   4.  Dictaphone - for on the road journal entries.  All too often I thought of something that I wanted to write about, something I experienced, and by the next time I could write at a pit stop the lucid description had left my memory.   3.  More Training - would have enabled me to go farther, faster with more time to stop and smell the roses.  I was traveling in Europe for the month prior to my bike trip.  And although I was active and managed a few jogs in random places and was in pretty good shape anyway, I wasn't as prepared for this trip as I could have been.   2.  Rear View Mirror - for the obvious.  It's an easy safety precaution to take that can have definite safety advantages. 1.  Business Cards - for all of the people that asked about the trip.  So many times people would question me about what I was up to and some actually asked if I had a website.  A card provides a tangible memory to folks (I still have Robert Lovett's from day 18) and is a handy record of my website address.
Neil Gunton - He is the mastermind behind crazyguyonabike.com.  He runs the site for free and has provided help to me over the phone and via email on a wide range of technical issues - not the least of which was standing guard over my site this summer as some of my tactless students posted unsavory guestbook entries.  When I started my journal in April, 2001  I was one of the first five journals on the site.  Since then the site has grown tremendously, and its features have made it more user friendly and fun.  Its growth stands as a testament to Neil's excellent vision and attention to detail.  The trip itself was very fun for me, but the ability to have a wonderful place to post my thoughts and photos multiplied my enjoyment.  So, thanks to Neil for not just the creation of the free site but also the superp administration of it. Olivia Seney, Courtney Everett & Allen Bradd - All three of these folks are fellow Carolina grads that graciously opened their apartment (or in Allen's case, motel room) to me as I passed through town.  Chapel Hill wasn't exactly on the way but knowing that I had a place to stay and old friends to visit made it worth veering off course.   Dave Blazejewski - Dave is a good friend of mine that I met while working on the railroad (insert joke here), and has remained so even after my locomotive days were over.  He resides in New Orleans and provided (whether he knew it or not) inspiration to me during the spring of 2001 while I was planning the trip.  Dave is an adventurer in his own way, spending any free time he's had in the past or now in the present, traveling the U.S.A. and more often than not, chasing trains.  It was good to bounce ideas off of him while I was conceptualizing the trip, and he was sure to give me any interesting railroading trivia and geography about the places I'd be riding through. Harry Hardin - Harry is my roommate here on Magazine Street in New Orleans and provided a ton of logistical support to me this past summer, including:  paying the bills, receiving mail and packages, mailing my mail to me during the summer, taking the "before" and "after" photos, allowing me to use his computer after mine was fried, and on and on.  But, most of all, he has had to deal with my strange lifestyle, that in the spring of 2001, revolved around planning for this trip.   Mom, Dad, Mike, and Shannon Spaeder & Gail Mierzejewski - Owning a dog is a wonderful thing.  Samantha (my geriatric black beauty of a Labrador Retriever) has given me a lot of joy over her twelve years of life, but of course she wasn't allowed on this trip.  I did entertain an option (momentarily) of putting her in a trailer and hauling her myself south to New Orleans.  However, the Spaeders in Northern Virginia and D.C. willingly (with a sigh) took care of her for the time I was riding the rig.  This may not sound like a big task, but I know that they have grown accustomed to life post-Sam and would rather not have the hair, the whining, or smells in their domiciles.  So, I thank them hugely for taking Sam in.  Without this help, the trip could have never happened.  I would also like to thank Gail for volunteering to fly with Sam (as baggage -- that is: the dog as baggage, Gail as a passenger) on a USAir flight from BWI to New Orleans on August 31st.  Sam needed a way to get down here, and Gail volunteered to brave the heat and humidity of Nola to help me out. Guestbook signers and website visitors - I'd like to thank the readers of www.crazyguyonabike.com/doc/spaeder for checking out my site throughout the summer and afterwards too.  Thank you for your patience as I took way too long to finish this thing.  In under a year there have been over 11,000 individual page requests on my site alone making it the tenth-most popular journal on all of crazyguyonabike.com (and the best ranking journal for an under-one-month-ride).  I know that there are a few people that can account for a large amount of those hits, but I feel that the journal has had widespread appeal.  Thanks to everyone for signing my guestbook, and if you haven't yet, please do.  It was a great inspiration to read, during and after the trip, the postings to my guestbook.  Knowing that people were reading the site made me enthusiastic to not just write but also ride and experience more things.   Mom and Dad Spaeder - No, they weren't going to get away with just being thanked for taking care of the dog.  As I planned the trip this past spring I knew that I would have a hard sell on my hands convincing my parents that I should go.  Sure, I am at the age where I don't need to ask for their permission, nor was their blessing necessary, but I did want to feel in my heart that I wasn't hurting them emotionally by riding my bicycle alone through the South.  They did basically, all I could ask them to do:  ask questions, show their concern, but wish me luck.  I made a pact with them to call at least every other day, and fortunately I was able to keep to that (actually, I was able to call almost every day).  I think that helped, as well as the two of them reading on the website about what I was up to.  I do know that this trip made my mother worry a lot (so I am told by my family members and her co-workers and friends), so that is why I must thank her even more so for being so "cool" (for lack of a better word) with me on the phone when we talked.  So, a big thanks goes out to Mom and Dad for handling the situation perfectly, just as they have handled most everything with me over the past 24 years.  And one more thing, although the Spaeder family wasn't a traveling clan as the children grew up, Mom and Dad did instill in me an intellectual curiosity, a strong work ethic, and a tolerance for others that were essential for this trip. I sincerely I hope I didn't explicitly forget anyone.   Finally, I would like to thank all of the people on the road that provided me with funny, touching, and long-lasting memories.
This trip, by far, exceeded my expectations.  It was more of everything than I thought it would be:  more fun, more difficult, more exhilarating, more work, more surprising, etc.  All too often people (myself definitely included) walk through life not living it to the fullest.  For four weeks my life centered around a goal, and I felt completely alive.  My mind tired but never got bored nor inattentive.  To anyone thinking of doing a similar trip, I say, without reservation, "Go for it!"   This trip was much more than being about Matt Spaeder.  It was, more importantly, about visiting places and people other than those familiar to me.  On that note, and in conclusion, I'll finish with a passage I wrote in my journal on a bench outside a gas station on day 12 in Fort Mill, South Carolina:  This country is filled with mile upon mile of what we metropolitan inhabitants call "fly over territory," simply because that is as close as we'll ever get to it:  viewing the land from an airplane window.  But that land is filled with beautiful wilderness and wonderful people.  Sure, many of them are parochial in their views and tacky in their exterior home decor, but on the inside many of them are great people.  They'll sit and talk for awhile and never look at their watch.  They'll wave at 'ya on the highway or give a thumbs up.  Their interests may be different than mine, but their hearts know what dedication, caring, and kindness are all about. -ms
  February, 2003 I've decided to take a different approach with this journal.  Compared to my previous journals, you'll see that this one is much less wordy (phew!).  I'm going this route, because I think I went a little overboard on some of my other journal entries - going into extra-fine detail in areas where it wasn't needed.  Moreover, I've taken some very good photos -- I'll let them speak for the trip.  Also, I didn't get to write in my journal on the road after day one, because I was way too busy, so recalling each aspect of each of my days would be too difficult.    I don't have scanned-in detailed maps of each day's route like I did for the previous two trips, because my maps were either ruined in the rain or burned as fire-starters somewhere on the C&O Canal (where they were no longer needed - the navigation home from the canal is easy).  I've acquired, via the wonderful world wide web, some great and not-so-great maps that I'll share with you throughout the journal.  I'm not going to worry too much about trying to depict the terrain on a two-dimensional map, because frankly the computer screen won't do the topography justice.  West Virginia is called the Mountain State for a reason, and no amount of staring at contour lines or ridges on a map will make that fully sink in.    From a navigational (of this site) standpoint, I have a few things to say...   First, the mileage data is approximate.  I didn't bring my cyclocomputer with me, because I was on such a short trip, and the C&O Canal portion was fortunately marked with mileposts.   Secondly, CLICK TO ENLARGE!!!  I've got a ton of photos and maps (i.e. the light green map above) that had to be shrunk down to comply with the parameters the webmaster created.  To see my images in their full-sized glory, simply click on them.  Then when you're ready to return to the journal entry, just hit the back button on your browser.   Or try another option:  if your connection speed is fast enough and/or you don't mind waiting for large images to load, you can set this site to always give you the "Large" versions of the pics.  To do that is also quite easy:(1) Click "Options" at the top this page.  (2) Select "Large size pictures," and click "Set option."   You can give one of those techniques a try to view the large version of the photo below...    Okay, I'm almost done...Since I won't be writing a concluding entry for this trip, and I won't be writing much in the daily entries, I wanted to share a few thoughts.  First, this trip kicked my ass.  But I loved it.  Mile for mile this journey was much more difficult than my trek to New Orleans of two summers ago.  The mountains gave me incredible elevation variations that ached my legs on ascent and my hands as they worked the brakes on descent.   The weather varied between raining and 40's on day three to sweltering hot in the high 90's on days five and six.  I corrected many of my mistakes that I made from the New Orleans trip including packing a little better and training a lot harder, but I still underestimated how far I could go in a day in the mountains.  Sixty miles, fully loaded, up and down big mountains just isn't possible for more than one day.   On two separate nights on the Canal I went through all of my matches as I tried to start a fire to heat up dinner, all to no avail; I ate beef jerkey and snack-mix both times.  I was frustrated like crazy by multiple flat tires from a slightly ill-positioned brake shoe that slowly shredded the sidewall of my tire with each unsuspecting pull of the brakes.  But I made it home - somehow.  I learned from the experience and won't let it (or my other mistakes) happen again.   Yes, there will be another trip.  I don't know when, but I'm hooked -- and I've got miles and miles of America to explore.
         
  Accommodations:  Blackwater Falls State Park Quote of the Day:   "I dunno.  It's gotta be a West Virginia thing."  Overhead in the deli/gas station/convenience store in Grantsville as two Maryland women discuss their boyfriends.  One of their beaus is from West Virginia, and the two women can't figure out why he's been acting strange lately.      My experience with Greyhound was excellent.  It wasn't that anyone provided me superb customer service, rather it was simply that Greyhound provided me the opportunity to ship myself and my bike almost anywhere in the U.S. with little hassle.   From the depot in Northeast DC we traveled south over the Potomac on the 14th Street bridge and west along the Geoerge Washington Memorial Parkway.  From my perch on the right side of the bus I had a good view of the river that I'd be intimately involved with for the next week.  After an hour ride to Hagerstown I departed the bus and carried the bike box over to a nearby McDonald's for a second breakfast and a relaxing read of the Hagerstown Herald.   I walked my box back to the bus depot, lay it down outside and sat inside, reading magazines.  The depot in Hagerstown was about the size of a small double-wide home and was staffed by one elderly woman.  During my layover I chatted with two seniors at James Madison University from Woodstock, Virginia en route to New York City.  They were Greyhounding to Baltimore and then north to the Big Apple.  They were excited because besides touring the normal attractions in NYC they had tickets to the Late Show with David Letterman.  Pretty cool.   One more Hagerstown bus depot story...A white van pulled up with a uniformed officer and two large men.  The officer asked the ticket agent for one ticket to Baltimore and one to DC.  She obliged.  He paid her, and wished his newly released cons good luck; "I hope to never see you again," the corrections officer said with a smile.  He shook their hands and left.  Of the twenty minutes that we shared together in that depot the men spent all of it smiling and much of it trying to win the attention of a young lady.   My second Greyhound dipped in and out of valleys as we made our way up to Grantsville via U.S. Alt 40, making brief stops in Cumberland and Frostburg.  At my destination the bus eased to the side of the road and the front door opened.  The driver quickly but not hurriedly followed me out and then opened the baggage bay, and I pulled the bike box out.  As quickly as he got off, he was back on -- I heard him kick off his brakes and slowly pull his diesel away.  The trip thus began:  one day to the start of the river, then four or five days following it to Alexandria.        The afternoon was a ton of work getting over the mountains, but the scenery was spectacular.  One check of the map near Kearney told me that I'd have a great coast down into the Potomac River valley.  The map wasn't wrong.  I cruised into Gorman very excited to see the river for the first time since DC.  A nice waitress filled up my water bottle free of charge at a restaurant at the river's edge, and I was off to cross into West Virginia for the first time (no sign though).      I paralleled the river for a dozen or so miles keeping it to my right, pulling moderate climbs as I got closer and closer to the start of the river.  In Henry, WV my route broke away from the river and started heading more southward toward Davis, which was my camping spot for the evening and an excellent staging point for a pilgrimage to the Fairfax Stone (the headspring of the river) the following morning. John J. Rambo (straight out of First Blood) seemed to be passing through Thomas, WV at the same time as I was - fortunately we were going in opposite directions.  What this guy lacked in brawn, he made up for in weirdness.  I don't remember who stopped whom (I think I was just traveling slowly and I eased to a stop at a safe distance from him as he began talking to me), but I remember a brief exchange with him on the main drag of Thomas near a city water fountain.  "Rambo" was wearing a bandanna around his forehead, a cut-off heather grey sweatshirt-turned-t-shirt, and a large camping backpack (circa 1982) with a tattered grey bedroll strapped on top.  His monologue consisted of three consecutive elements: 1)  "The people in the grocery store are mean." 2)  "Don't drink the water." (pointing to the water fountain) 3)  "The trucks are trying to run me over."     I think I just nodded at each of his declarations or said, "Okay," and then our "conversation" was over.  As I rolled away I looked over my left shoulder and saw him giving the finger to a passing truck.  The Rambo similarities were too obvious to ignore - and I spent the rest of my time in Thomas thinking about this guy taking on the local police in a crazy guerrilla battle. I stopped at the grocery store anyway (no mean people there), picked up dinner and breakfast, packed them away and rode the last few miles to the campground in Davis in the post-sunset light.
  Accommodations:  Mountaineer Motel Quote of the Day:  "Yeah, it's got a motel, but I wouldn't stay there - it ain't been American owned for a while."Heard from the convenience store/deli proprietor in Bayard, WV in response to my question, "Is there anywhere to stay in Mount Storm?"  More details below.                                      I made an unplanned stop at the post office in Bayard, West Virginia and sent home as much stuff as I could do without.  It didn't end up being a lot, but every ounce off the rig was well worth it for my legs.  I asked the postal clerk for places to find a sandwich, and she directed me to next door.   My club sandwich was excellent and about halfway through eating it, the proprietor's husband and son walked in the store to say hello to their wife/mom.  Before that though, the middle-aged man and his nine year-old son inspected the rig as it leaned against the front wall of the grocery.  I recognized the man from the day before.  I passed through Bayard yesterday evening going in the opposite direction, and I remember having this one man stare me down as I rode through town.  At the time, yesterday, I thought the stare was one of anger, but as soon as he walked in the store today I could tell that it was really a stare of curiosity.  I sat, eating near the front door of the grocery as the father and son walked in.  After a quick hello to the owner, they stopped by my table and struck up conversation.  The father and son had big smiles on their faces as I told them of my travels.  The father mentioned that he had seen me the night before.  Well, anyway, we chatted for a little bit, and then I told him that I was hoping to make it to Cumberland tonight and if not, that I'd like to stay somewhere along the way.  Right about then I was given the QOTD by his wife who had joined the convesation midstream.  Her comment didn't really sour me to the conversation, but it did make me think about what I was going to find in Mount Storm.  Anyway, we talked for a total of ten minutes as I finished up my sandwich and packed up the rig.  The man told me about how he'd always wanted to ride the C&O Canal from start to finish but never got around to it.  In the 80's, he said, he had ridden about 60 miles of it with a buddy and enjoyed it a lot,  but never got around to riding the whole thing.   My ride to Mount Storm had huge climbs and descents that took a lot out of me.  It was a pattern that I'd repeat often:  climb at 4 to 5 mph for 20-30 minutes and then sit in the saddle and enjoy the descent at 30mph.  During the course of one of my climbs one particular beat-up blue mid-80's sedan passed me twice, each time going in opposite directions.  On the second pass the passenger threw a plastic beverage bottle at me hitting one of my saddlebags.  Nice.  I guess that must have been exciting for them. I made it to Mount Storm, which consisted of the motel, a volunteer fire department, a few houses, a library, a West Virginia DOT facility, and a convenience store (which I didn't see until I was riding out of town the next morning).  The proprietors of the Inn were a husband and wife, looking to be of Indian descent.  They had their five year-old son with them.  It was odd to see anything but a white person in this part of the country, but to say that these folks weren't Americans was simply simple-minded.  Anyway, they gave me the keys to my chalet.    Before I moved in I inquired about food, first borrowing the yellow pages to call pizza places, all to no avail.  Mount Storm was too far away from any business's delivery zone.  So, I asked the owner if there was a gas station nearby, and he told me that one to two miles down Route 42 (the road that intersects the road that I was on as I came into town) there was a BP station.      How this place made money (I was the only guest at $20) or why this family, most-likely not from West Virginia, chose to live here were objects of my curiosity.  But, I never got to learn those things because I didn't see the owners again during my stay. I stripped the rig down and suited up in the drizzle for a short jaunt to the BP station that the owner had told me about.  After about three or four miles down Route 42 I got a little frustrated, because I was unable to find what I was looking for.  Just before I turned around, I stopped at an office for a mining company that had a light on.  The gentleman told me of the BP station, another one or two more miles down the road.  I thanked him and huffed in frustration at my bad direction-giver back at the motel.  Anyway, I got some goodies at the BP and then headed "home." After dinner, I took a shower and while drying myself off in the bathroom hit my head on the single exposed 60 watt light bulb that lit the bathroom at 6'1" off the ground (note:  I'm 6'2").  The light shattered, and I found myself tip-toeing out of the bathroom in barefeet.  After dressing and eating, I cleaned up the mess.   The local news stations were out of Pittsburgh and were centered around the mining disaster in Quecreek, Pennsylvania.  At the time the miners were still stuck underground.  Even though my day was centered around finding the headspring of the Potomac and following the flow downriver, my journey took me extensively around Maryland and West Virginia coal-country.  The news struck more of a chord with me today than it would have if I had never made it to this part of the country.  Maybe that's what traveling's all about:  seeing new places and experiencing new things so as to widen the realm of understanding of all things.
  Accommodations:  Irons Mountain Hiker-Biker campsite on the C&O Canal

  Accommodations:  Antietam Creek Campground on the C&O Canal    Visit Number ONE:  Hooligans 2:09 a.m.  Awoke to the sound of fireworks being shot off from the banks of the nearby creek. 2:11 a.m.  Dialed 911 and told dispatcher of my quandary and location.  Referred to the National Park Service's C&O Canal Ranger number. 2:13 a.m.  Spoke to the Ranger Dispatcher and again explained my situation.  Fortunately for me (for proving that there was a problem), the fireworks were still booming away while I was on the phone.  I was told that the ranger on duty would be calling me soon. 2:15 a.m.  Ranger Nayler promptly called and said that he had just returned home from a different call.  He said that he would suit back up and be on his way. 2:33 a.m.  The dispatcher called and told me that Ranger Nayler was on his way - should be there in twenty minutes.  I sat silent in my tent while the fireworks became fewer and farther between.  I could hear faint conversation between two male voices.  I was separated from the scene of the crime by about 30 yards of thick forest, but a semi-direct path led from them to me.  I didn't want them coming my way, so I just sat still and hoped that these innocuous but annoying pains remained the former and didn't move so they could get nabbed when Nayler arrived. 2:54 a.m.  The phone rings again:  the dispatcher.  "The ranger has arrived.  Walk around and see if you can find him."  I thought it was a strange suggestion, but I hadn't heard anything for ten minutes, so I thought the coast was clear.  I headed out of the tent with flashlight, knife, and pepper spray at the ready, and walked up to the tow path.      Visit Number TWO:  Ranger Nayler, National Park Service The ranger was a middle-aged man with a moustache.  Don't let the olive green uniform fool you, this guy meant serious business, and was packing heat like your everyday street cop.  Ranger Nayler traveled alone but carried confidence and curiosity with him.  He said he had found evidence of the hooligans, spent fireworks, and that the lone car parked by the creek had dead plates.  He was glad that I called this in, and he told me he was going back to look for the suspects.  He said that everything would be fine and that I could go back to sleep, and then finally he asked whether I was alone.  And then that was it.  My experience was over.  I don't think anyone was caught, but at least I got a little peace of mind.  I tip-toed back to the tent and surprisingly fell right to sleep.        Visit Number THREE (and by far, the best):  Gail, my ladyfriend  Gail made the 80 minute trip (it ended up being much more than that because of bad signage in Sharpsburg) from her apartment in DC out to Antietam to bring me a BBQ dinner, some bike supplies, and many smiles.  I went for a swim while she cooked our turkey burgers on the grill and snapped some photos, and then we relaxed together over a good meal.  Plus, she brougt a ton of chocolate.  Around sunset she headed back home to make it to work the next morning.  (Thank you very, very much for coming!)
