Sometimes, Lori rode with me; other times, she rode around the BWI trail with Karen or Kelly instead.   The distance to work was seven miles each way.  I started by driving my bike to a mall near work and riding one mile to work.  As I got used to this, I moved the car farther and farther away until it was about 4 miles away from work, parked in a MARC station, a month or so later. I got stuck there for a while.  There wasn't another good spot to park between there and home.  Besides, there was a big hill.  It was enough to convince us, though, that we could keep it up.  So we got ready to buy new bikes. Then, we saw the map.  Maryland puts out a little map that rates roads for bikability.  A line through the middle of the state indicated the path of the American Discovery Trail (ADT), a trail from coast to coast.  We thought that sounded like fun.  My contract was scheduled to end in February, and there were some other travel opportunities we wanted to pursue, but we decided to add a bike trip to our plans. We bought our bicycles, both hybrids for stability and for use on trails, and by August, I was biking at least 3 times a week the entire 14 miles roundtrip to work and back.  By October/November, though, the weather was too rough and I dropped off to hardly riding at all again.   We did some planning and purchasing over the winter and early spring.  We found that the ADT had major portions which were not suitable for bicycle touring, but we also discovered the Adventure Cycling maps.  We had to figure our own way up to the Adventure Cycling routes, but we didn't think it would be too much trouble, what with the C&O Canal towpath & Pennsylvania trail system almost getting us all the way from DC to Pittsburgh.   There was some panic as we bought last minute items, and we were on our way.  The following pages are my journal, kept on a Handspring Visor, and transferred directly to the site via modem whenever we could get a good connection.  There are also some essays by Lori.  Because we couldn't find a keyboard for the Visor (we bought the Edge to conserve weight, but its interface is different enough to prevent using the keyboards that work with the other Visors), she decided to keep her journal on paper.  Using the Visor means that my entries are generally terse.  Lori is now transferring her journal from paper to the site.  These entries will appear at the bottom of the site as she gets them in.  Her entries will likely have a lot more detail than mine.  (She is the writer, after all.)   As we went along, I tried to incorporate changes in the kind of information included based on reader comments. Seattle is Very Far Away We realized pretty early that we just did not go fast enough to get across the country with the time & money we had set aside.  We tended to go 30-35 miles on days we rode at all, and we took lots of breaks.  My impression from other sites is that ardent cross-country cyclists hit 70-100 miles/day.  We also realized that it wasn't the goal of going across the country that was so interesting to us as much as it was the interest of seeing people and things along the way.  So, we stayed at lots of B&Bs instead of camping, and we kept to a slower pace, allowing us to see and experience the country around us (Lori even participated in pottery contest in Cambridge, Wisconsin).   The weather was terrible, too, for the month after our first two weeks.  The wind and the rain slowed us down and discouraged us greatly.  Approaching Chicago, we were considering stopping there at the beginning of June.  But we rested well in Chicago with our friends, we received encouragement from several sources, and we really looked forward to seeing Minneapolis.   So, we decided to keep going until we got close to the Fourth of July, then find some nice little town to spend the holiday.  I think we picked a great place.   The original title of these journals was Washington to Washington, but we changed that to Washington to Wherever when we revised our objectives.  Otherwise, I didn't really change anything after-the-fact, so these journals are pretty much my feelings as things happened (or within a day of things happening).  I think it will be a few more weeks before we can really review the trip and answer one of the two questions we get asked most: "Did you enjoy the trip?"  Apparently, it's not obvious from the journal entries.   I hope you enjoy this site.  I think that Neil performed a great service by giving us an easy way to keep folks in touch with our goings-on.  So, now the bike trip is over and we return to normal life.  Well, not really.  The bike trip was just another leg in our 2001 Life Odyssey.  After trips to the American SouthWest and New Zealand, followed by this here bike trip, we are ready to settle down and find work.  We'd like to find work overseas, especially Scotland or Ireland, so we'll be spending some time searching for work.  I guess we could keep a journal on the search and eventual migration.  Hmmm. If you know of anyone in Ireland or Scotland who needs a configuration/release/project manager, drop us a line.  Somewhere around Minneapolis, I thought it would be cool to get to 1500 miles because the journal entries added up to something within 100 of that.  I was elated when we got to Bayfield, and I could say we had ridden over 1500 miles.   Unfortunately, I had entered the same day twice in these web pages so the total was wrong.  We've removed one of the entries, now.  And, sadly, we didn't quite make it.  But, as I said before, we learned early that for the trip to be fun, we had to make sure the objective was seeing stuff and experiencing the country, NOT making arbitrary mileage goals.
"Wouldn't it be fun if we rode across the US on our bikes?" he asked his wife, L, almost as a joke, pretty sure she'd say no. "Sure!" she said, surprising J.   And that's how we decided to ride across the country on our bikes.  It turned out that the ADT is not really suited for a cross-country bicycle trip, though it looks great for a walking trip.  So, we settled on Adventure Cycling's Northern Tier (see http://www.adventurecycling.org/routes/notier.cfm). We didn't want to start in Maine, so we are going to start with the C&O canal (see http://www.atatrail.org/seg-maps/cno15.htm), which should feed us into the Great Allegheny Passage (see http://www.atatrail.org/seg-maps/overmap.htm).  This will drop us just outside Pittsburgh.  We'll take US 30 into Ohio (see http://www.cs.cmu.edu/afs/cs.cmu.edu/user/spok/bike/raccoon-creek.html), and use the cross-state trails in Ohio (trails CT & K, see http://www.dot.state.oh.us/bike/Default.htm) to get us to the Northern Tier, which will take us through Indiana, Illinois, Iowa, Wisconsin, Minnesota, North Dakota, Montana, Idaho and Washington.  The end point of the Northern Tier is Anacortes, Washington.
      
We have our bags, finally -- thanks to College Park Bicycles! -- and our camping gear.  I think we have nothing left to buy except some food.   But we still have to pack and practice using these weird clipless pedal things.  Today, we go out for a spin around the BWI trail.  Hope we don't kill ourselves before the trip! I wanted to list people who've been nice to us: The camping guy at REI (not the bike guy) Chad at College Park Bicycles Everyone at Sun&Ski up at Arundel Mills Mall Ann at Columbus Outdoor Pursuits (Ohio) --> http://www.outdoor-pursuits.org  Jessica at Allegheny Trail Alliance (PA) --> http://www.atatrail.org Bud in Upper Sandusky Those Happy Kids at J'ville Pub & Grill And, this website was very helpful --> http://www.his.com/~jmenzies/urbanatb/trails/canal/canal.htm  It has good milepost lists for the C&O canal, including a PDA-friendly version more stuff I want to remember to look at again later: Wisconsin: Wisconsin Trails (http://www.dnr.state.wi.us/org/land/parks/specific/index.html) Glacial Drumlin State Trail (http://www.glacialdrumlin.com/)
We're trying to figure out whether the advantages of the C&O canal towpath outweigh the disadvantages: Advantages  Disadvantages  Haven't stayed at a place that lets my PDA modem hook up, so the reports will continue to be intermittent.  These first few days were entered from a library in Hancock, MD.
This is what I wrote in my PDA: 1:10pm:  Lunch at White's Ferry (19mi).  Snack bar is closed for season.  There are picnic tables to rent -- only $1.50.  Unfortunately, no one was around to take our fee.  The ferry runs all year, though, and boy, is it loud. 2:50pm:  Viaduct at about Milepost (MP) 42 (we started at MP16.6). We had to walk our bikes across.  There were very bad ruts in the packed dirt path for 3 miles north of the viaduct.  Too much sweat! 5:19pm:  Brunswick.  MP55.  Stopping for the night.  Asked direction from car person -- bad idea.  His sense of distance is all out of whack.  Only restaurant not closed on Monday & Tuesday apparently is King's New York Style Pizza.   Only one hotel is here and it is "always booked," according to the locals.  Called George's Mill Bed & Breakfast  (http://www.georgesmill.com).  They're in Virginia, but they sent a truck for us.  That was an awfully nice thing to do.  It kept us from having to camp. 6:00pm:  The B&B is wonderful!  It's an ancient stone house that has been in the family for 8 generations.  Lori's taking a bath and I'm sitting on the porch.  I forgot to get our mileage, but it's something over 40 miles.  I plan to sleep for hours. Finished the book I was reading (Stonehenge).  I don't recommend it.  It's a bit of a slog to get through with little reward for the effort.  I'll leave it on the bookshelf here.  Started Blindness by Henry Green.
The bike shop is closed down.  The owner got lime disease.  We had wanted to get bikes tuned and buy a new spoke wrench.  We had lunch at Blue Moon Cafe.  The hill up from canal to bridge to Shepherdstown is huge (and not really worth it). 7:39 pm:  MP90.9  Camping.  Lots of river traffic.  Met a mushroom hunter.  Travelled 5 miles on a hilly detour.  It was the fastest 5 mi of trip so far.  Dinner was prepackaged dried strogonoff & cilli mac.  Not bad. (Note:  our mileage won't match the mileposts because a) we've gone off-canal a couple of times for food and lodging and whatnot, and b) the mileposts are not exactly a mile apart.  Sometimes they're more, sometimes less.
2:07 pm:  Hancock-MP124  Econolodge is uphill without easy walking access to town, but the town itself is well-situated from paths.  From Ft Frederick to Hancock, we took a paved rail-trail.  The 10 miles of asphalt was nice, but sunny and hot.  This is the most bike-friendly town by far so far.  But the bike shop is closed on Wednesday.  Trying to decide what to do about Cumberland and detours.  We may stay longer.  Late lunch/early dinner at Weaver's.  Great pie.  Odometer works when I clean contacts and press hard to connect.
Will be taking a rest stop here until tomorrow because of the bikes and because we could use the rest.  The gravel is tough on the wrists.   Lori's parents drove up to bring us shoes that Lori ordered and bike maps for Ohio that I had ordered.  Neither had arrived when we left.  It was nice to see someone from home, and I think for Lori to have someone to talk to.  We did laundry and ate every single meal at Weaver's.  Yum-yum. Nothing wrong with our bikes, really, just got them cleaned and tightened.  Boy, the brakes are good now and our wheels are true.
First calamity:  John's chain broke.  We made it all the way to the C&O parking lot across the river from Paw Paw.  On the way up the hill, the chain snapped.  We spent half an hour re-linking the chain.  Half a mile later, it snapped again.  Walked up the rest of the hill to the PawPaw Patch B&B, where we did have a reservation.   The closest bike shop is in Cumberland, but we can't seem to interest anyone in taking us there.  Our cell phones are only sort of working.  Dang, we're in a tight fix. We did walk through the amazing 3000 ft Paw Paw canal tunnel.  It was pretty dark and scary inside.   This chain has made us realise how vulnerable we are.  We're also seeing how much we just expect things to be available.  Imagine a whole town without a taxi service!   
The owner of the Paw Paw Patch B&B was nice enough to give us a ride to Cumberland to get a new chain.  Then, he was extra nice and gave us a ride across the state line.  So we only rode 13mi on the bikes today, but we're a lot further down the trail than we had expected to be. In Meyersdale, the trail starts at a restored train station.  The station has some great model trains.  We spoke with an enthusiast for quite some time before heading off.  Actually, we had to talk longer than we planned because I came up with a flat tire, a tear right through the tread.   First, I patched the hole with a sticky patch, but it didn't hold air.  I replaced the tube with one of our spares and put a dollar bill inside the tire to help cover the hole.  Lori transferred some of the weight to her bike.  Two of the bike shops on our list turned out to not be bike shops (and one was rather snippy about it).  We'll have to wait at least until Ohiopyle to get a tire.  (If there, after all, tomorrow is Sunday.) The trail is pretty rough for about a mile from Meyersdale.  It is mostly large gravel, but after the bridge (great bridge!), the trail is very fine gravel and hard-packed dirt.  The fine gravel is much nicer than the C&O, but there are patches of the large gravel that are destabilizing with our weight and inertia.  The trail has been pretty level, perhaps a might downhill, but this was negated by the headwind-the worst so far.  Feels like a storm is coming.  We saw several waterfalls along the trail.  The benches seem to be well-placed.  We also saw some huge tri-bladed windmills.   Lunch was at a gas station in Garrett.  We are sleeping at the most well-placed lodging on the trip.  It's directly on the trail.  Amazingly, no one else is staying tonight. 7:54 pm: The B&B has a litte porch-side snackbar, so we had burgers for dinner.  Several older locals sat around talking about deaths and lawnmowers. We played Scabble (Lori won).  Some bikers came in with scary stories about the Ft Hill/Confluence detour.
Lunch at The River's Edge.  Very nice and relaxing.  We're sitting on the porch listening to the river flow by. Mile and a half detour around tunnel on trail was no worse than any part of the C&O.  Detour from Ft Hill to Confluence was a nightmare-410 ft climb in a little less than a mile.  We had to walk it.  Then it was 6 miles downhill.  At 30mph, the bikes really wobble.  Yesterday, we met two road bikers on their way up to Meyersdale and back.  They're from Columbus.  One of them caught up to us here.  He lost the other one on the unfinished part of the trail. The other guy showed up after an hour with a torn sidewall. 5:44 pm: Ohiopyle (31mi)   We had to move from room 14 to room 13 because the AC didn't work. Finished Blindness.  It's very artsy, with only a little bit of plot.  His descriptions are fantastic, but the book didn't do much for me.  No books here.   

Lots of bugs today and a bad headwind, but we hope to make it farther today and rest tomorrow. We met the trail manager today.  He was nice, but we complained about the lack of restrooms north of Connellsville.  Connellsville had a nice-looking bike shop right on the trail. 8:08 pm: McKeesport, PA (62.43mi).  Our longest ride yet.  We definitely pushed too hard. The trail just ended in the middle of nowhere.  A kid on a mtn bike gave us horrible directions up huge hills through the woods.  We wound up at some subdivision on the wrong side of the river. A pair of older women argued over directions for us.  They also showed us the swimming pool and pictures of ducks.  After some bad hills, we made it into McKeesport.  Unfortunately, I got us lost again.  After stopping at a gas station, we got back on track and stumbled into the Angel's Inn. It's pretty much a hostel.  We're moving from one room to another because the first one stank (and I broke the bed by sitting on it).  This used to be a convent. McKeesport is a hole.
We're taking a day off because we pushed too hard yesterday.  We'll probably take another day off in 2 days so we can get our bearings and get ready for Ohio.  We'll be near the Pitt airport, so I imagine there'll be some nice hotels there.  Looking forward to some luxury.   It's raining today.  Now that's a nice coincidence.
Short, but scary, urban ride today. Yesterday, we spent so much time driving around in the rented truck that we stayed another night in McKeesport.   I have to give PA thumbs down on drivers and signage.  Drivers do unexpected things and turn left in across your path with no warning.  And all that was while we were in the truck.  We spent a lot of time driving down roads without names or numbers, because the theory seems to be that only the minor streets need signs.  Maybe everyone just knows what the roads are.  I was surprised that this was true even on the US routes. But we did get to take in a movie at a new Loews at the Waterfront.  The Mummy Returns.  (Movie review: If you don't expect much, the movie is pretty funny, but Brendan needs a better script.)  And we got to grab some Indian food and visit a mall.  Picked up The Subtle Knife (Philip Pullman), 2nd in a series that started with The Golden Compass.  (Lori is reading this now.) There are few shoulders here near the city.  We used side streets when we could and I even used a few sidewalks on hills & bridges.  Lori hates that.  The trucks could give us a little more space, if you ask me.  I couldn't get any good pictures of the bad spots. We stopped to talk to a gate guard at Kennywood.  He told us it is the oldest amusement park in the US.  He also threatened to call an ambulance for us.  The park opens tomorrow.
My odometer broke again today.  This time, messing with the contacts did nothing.  So we got new ones for me and Lori.  I figure if one goes out, we'll have the other for backup.  The brand is called Cat Eye. Our bank's web site is temporarily unavailable due to the "apparent financial difficulties" of their ISP.  I wonder how ProcureZone is doing. There is a terrific thunderstorm.
When we got back, we found a fruit and cheese tray left for us by Stacey at the front desk.  She wished us good luck on the bike trip.  That was nice. And we could use luck the way my bike keeps breaking.  We started to clean our bikes and discovered that one of my spokes had broken.  We got out the cool spoke wire kit, but it requires a saw!   So Lori, angel that she is, has ridden -with my rear wheel strapped to the back of her bike-down to the bike shop we stopped at yesterday.  She's wonderful.
Three states in one day!  Lori says that WVa doesn't count, but I say if we went through it, it counts.  We could tell we were in WVa because the five miles were full of night clubs.  And the shoulder went away.  In Ohio, the shoulder comes back, but it's a divided highway. Our first real traffic scare came in East Liverpool.  An idiot pulled out of a gas station into our path almost hitting Lori.  Then another idiot pulled out of the other exit of the same gas station and stopped, blocking the road.  But it is a relief to be in Ohio, even if we did go the wrong way up a huge hill before calling to get good directions to the hotel.  Mapquest's directions to the East Liverpool Motor Lodge are WRONG.  And the motel people failed to mention the big hill up the parking lot to the motel.   The world is just not oriented for bicycles. For those of you playing along at home, we travelled 32.16 miles today-about 3 or 4 on trails, most of the rest on US30, and a couple on East Liverpool streets.  It was pretty hilly with two killer bikable hills, two walking hills, and a 2 mi 7 per cent grade down to the river crossing. My knees are sore and Lori's a bit bruised, but we're less than 20mi from our Ohio bike map route.  The worst part of this has been feeling like we aren't sure where we're going.  We hope the bike route maps will make us feel more secure. 3:23 pm: Called our mothers and grandmother, but none were home.  There's a huge crowd at the special Mother's Day buffet here at the hotel.

Finished The Subtle Knife last night and started Venus (Ben Bova).  It's quite startling to go from the rich narrative of Pullman to the stark storytelling of Bova.  I don't know what Pullman has against God and religious figures, but he is setting up some great battle to come in the next book.  His description is great, and the story hard to put down.  It's a shame that he has set up a false dichotomy:  those who want to help humanity with learning and those who want to submit.  As if a society could exist without  submisssion.  And as if submission could mean anything without knowledge. I can't wait for the last book. 12:33 pm: Lisbon, OH We've stopped at a very nice little library to check our mail.  The library has stained glass and lots of hardwood.  It was erected in 1897.  In E. Liverpool, we rode 2mi to breakfast at Bob Evans.  When we got to the top of a monster hill to get onto US30, we found it prohibitted bikes.  But the nice ladies at a Walmart gave us good directions to Lisbon.  There were gentle hills, mostly, along this route.  I'd hate to have gone the other direction, though. Another chilly morning.  Downhill wind is quite cold after a sweaty uphill.  Some headwind and some sidewind.  We can't be more than 5mi from our maps (Cardinal Trail).   7:45 pm: North Georgetown, OH - 35.5mi I don't know who thought the Cardinal Trail was bikeable, but they were wrong.  The route the Walmart ladies gave us was better.  The hills are unbelievable and the roads are very rough.  It's almost as if someone threw down a bunch of gravel and then poured tar lightly over it.  It makes our hybrids shake something fierce; I'd hate to be on a road bike going down these hills.  I lost count of the number of hills we had to walk. But I will give them this:  the traffic is very light. So I ended the day discouraged.  My knee hurts and I'm tired.  I can't keep doing these hills.  Surely, there's some flat, somewhere.  I'm also disappointed in the maps. We're camping tonight.  The maps implied a camp ground in the wrong place, but advice at a restaurant got us here.  The campground is very nice.  We put our bikes under a pavillion because we heard it might rain tonight.  The skies look clear now, though. When we rolled into the campground, a sign on the way in said "closed mon".  The office & restaurant had a closed sign, too.  We decided to camp anyway and pay in the morning.  As we were looking around at the sites, the owner came out and we were saved!   I hear a woodpecker and other birds and there's even some road noise for Lori.  I also hear either a burro or a choking dog.   Our first dog was today, too.  It was a little yap dog that couldn't even reach our pedals.
Now this is more like what I imagined Ohio to be like-only colder, wetter, and with more oil wells.  The rain started early this morning.  It was gentle and looked like it wasn't going anyplace soon, so after breakfast at the campground's restaurant, we packed up and headed out. The rain continued until a little after lunch.  It continued to be cold and gray, so I didn't get any pictures of the farmland or the little oil wells.  I did take a picture of the little frog that visited our tent this morning. Today was a much better day, and I'm now more confident that we'll get to Indiana.   Especially if the rain stops.
Started off wet, but the rain has stopped now.  We're having lunch at the heavenly hash restaurant. Our Cardinal Trail maps call map 16 rolling farmland, but we didn't get to farms until 2/3 the way across the map.  In Canal Fulton, the road signs take you onto a road called Market St instead of Marshallville St.  It eventually will become Marshallville St, but there is a bridge out.  You can detour around it, but it isn't well-marked and you're a bit nervous because the map doesn't say anything about Market St.  But there seem to be more and more bike route markers as we head west. 4:34 pm: Hampton Inn, Wooster, OH - 33.5mi They greeted us with towels.  Wooster is a nuclear-free zone.  There's a Fazoli's restaurant here! Rain started up again, so we're doing another hotel.  It's supposed to be dry tomorrow, but thunderstorms on Friday.  The wind started about 5mi before the end--hope that'll push the rain out. Had a jerk drive behind me on a hill holding his horn button down today. Pretty farms this afternoon.  Too bad about the weather-this'd make some nice pictures. For those of you playing along at home, these are the towns and townlets we passed through.  Some of these are not much more than cross-roads:  north canton, canal fulton, marshallville, madisonburg, wooster. 5:12 pm: Interesting note:  I've been selected for jury duty.  I'm supposed to appear 12 July.  Hmmmm. 9:49 pm: I guess Wednesday is our movie day.  We went to see the worst movie of the year--A Knight's Tale.  It started with We Will Rock You, moved to Golden Years, and ended with American Thighs.  Can you name  those artists?  If so, you're too old for this movie. The theater was something else.  Neon everywhere.  The bathrooms had black and white diagonal striped doors, black and white square wall tiles, and green and purple stalls.  It made me motion sick.
I'm willing (though reluctant) to ride in rain, but fog is too dangerous.  No rain this morning, but the fog is pretty thick, even this late.  I thought we were going to do some real riding today, but that doesn't seem to be playing out.  And it's supposed to rain again this afternoon and tomorrow. Lori didn't sleep well last night. 9:49 pm: Rm412, Holiday Inn, Mansfield, OH - 36.49mi It was a 3 dog day.  Just west of Jeromesville, 3 dogs came after us all at once.  Neither of us was bitten, but these dogs were very scary.  They were quite irritating.  And that was a shame because in Jeromesville we met the nicest folks so far.  Two women at J'ville Pub & Grill were very interested in our trip.  They wanted to feed us, but we weren't hungry yet.  They tried to give us sandwiches, but I really wanted to get on the road since we got such a late start today.  They qave us a tshirt and a sweatshirt.  They also gave us their number in case we got caught in the rain.  An offer of a pickup is going to be hard to beat. Though it threatened through the day, we made it all the way without any rain.  Instead, it was hazy and humid.  We had to stop and clean our glasses fairly often.   We learned two valuable lessons about maps today:  We left Wooster and headed west.  Instead of going back north 5mi to meet the trail where we left it yesterday, we thought we'd meet it as it came south on the west side of Wooster.  We rode 9mi of the hilliest road since North Georgetown.  We were exhausted almost immediately. But we perservered and made it to yet another depressing steel town.  We did have a nice dinner at a nearby dive, though.  We left the Cardinal Trail today (map 14 has a typo) and started on Trail K.  K will take us to Indiana and the Adventure Cycling maps.    
Short day today.  The rain came on harder than we expected.  And the flat tire (Calamity no. 4) didn't help.  Now I've had flats front and rear.   How come none of these calamities happens to Lori?  Actually, I'd rather they happen to me.  And either way, we're both stopped. Well, the tube's been replaced (it was stuck to the tire), but the rain really made it hard to see-and to be seen.  This old motel on the old Lincoln hiway is our first seedy stay.  The knobs on the shower are mislabeled, and there is no bath tub.  But it's dry, and there's a restaurant next door. There was another unplanned (and not well-signed) detour today.  No idea what was going on, but part of Millsboro Road was closed (bike route K, map 32).  We had to bike about 3mi off-route.  We had to guess how best to get back on the route. 
Beautiful riding day.  Whenever we were headed east or south, we had a tailwind.  I can't imagine flatter land.  That's nice because it means we can afford to take detours.   It was also nice because I broke another spoke.  We spent a lot of time trying to put in a new one, but we just couldn't manage it.  The spoke that broke was one that attaches to the cassette side (gear side) of the rear wheel.  There seems to be no way to get a new spoke in there without removing the cassette. Bud Miller confirmed this for us.  We hobbled about ten miles into Upper Sandusky without the spoke (I adjusted some of the remaining spokes to make the wheel straighter-at least enough to keep the rim from hitting the brakes).  After we checked in, I called Bud Miller's bicycle shop and asked for his hours.  He told me he closed at 3.  I had called at 3.30!   But he said he'd drive out to the hotel and pick up the wheel. In fact, he took us back to his shop and replaced the spoke, cleaned out the axle, and trued the wheel.  He also told us biking stories-he was head of GOBA (Greater Ohio Bicycling Adventure) for several years. We also had stopped earlier to fool with Lori's front derailleur.  Her chain had been rubbing.  It seems okay now. I think we could have made 60 or 70 miles without the mechanical difficulties.  Oh, well.  Tomorrow will be a short day, too, because we want to take the next day off to avoid the thunderstorms (and to go to a bookstore, etc).  So we'll probably stop by Bud's church, too.  (He told us that when he heard we were from DC, he was worried we'd be liberals.  We told him that, well, hey, I mean we are from DC after all.) We took the opportunity to get some pictures developed and to play miniature golf. 
Took in a service at a very friendly church in Upper Sandusky.  The folks at Trinity Evangelical Methodist church really made us feel like family. The weather was beautiful for our ride today.  Of course, we're both a bit sunburned.   We rode into Findlayfrom the south and had to bike north and west to find a hotel.  But the hotel is very nice and we look forward to a day off tomorrow.  We need to hit a bike shop and a book shop.  There's a hundred per cent chance of thunderstorms tomorrow.  Rain is one thing lightning quite another.  Of course, there's rain scheduled for the next week (and highs in the low 50s!), but no lightning. Still, we can't really camp with this wetness, so we may have to figure out an alternate route for the week. 6:27 pm:  Forgot to mention the dogs.  There were several today.  Many pretty much stayed in their yards.  A very big St Bernard barked at us, but he couldn't be bothered to move.  I think he was trying to pretend to be a dog, but he's really just a bear. But we had 3 dogs come out of their yards at different points today.  One was an Irish setter.  He had a little trouble keeping his balance on newly cut grass.  I watched him run alongside Lori, barking up a storm.  Then, he slipped on the grass and hit the ground-boom!-all four legs flying.  So when I rode by, he came into the road. A loudly shouted "back!" seems to keep them from getting too close, but the adrenaline does get pumping. 

The towns are just not placed properly.  We're going to stop here and then leave the K trail to go join the Adventure Cycling maps in Paulding.  This takes us north only to come south again, but it seems our best bet with the wind and threat of rain. We were off-route the whole day.  We took US224 all the way from Findlay.  It was quite a joy to see the wind batter and push away the clouds.  The blue slowly spread across the sky.  Unfortunately, it meant we spent the whole ride fighting a relentless headwind.  It was like riding uphill. So I made up a song about the wind.  Imagine this with an Irish lilt: Hear the wind blowing, It's calling your name. Hey, Lori!  Hey, Johnny! Hear the wind blowing, It's taunting your name. Hey Lori & Johnny, go home! Well, we laugh at the wind And we laugh at the rain, We laugh at our butts 'Cause we laugh at the pain. We ride through the day and we sleep through the night We see people thinking, "Hey, they're not too bright." Hear the wind blowing, It's calling your name. Hey, Lori!  Hey, Michael! Hear the wind blowing, It's taunting your name. Hey Lori & Michael, go home! We ride through the highlands,  We ride through the low. We sometimes ride fast And sometimes quite slow. When trucks pass us by They cause quite a fright,  But they cancel the wind So I guess that's all right. Oh! Hear the wind... 4:35 pm:  Rm 9, Lee Bell Motel, Ottawa, OH - 25.5mi Hey, you can't beat $37 a night. 
We raced the rain and won.  The morning started beautifully, but the wind can beat you down.  The wind and the fear of rain were enough to bring us here-not to mention our sore bottoms.  The options were 40 miles here or 65 to Indiana.  We chose here.  But we'll easily make Indiana tomorrow-only 35mi to the next hotel. We had to turn north 10 miles back to get to the hotel.  The tailwind was nice, we easily got to 20mph without a hill.  Too bad the first 30mi was into the wind (winds out of SW today). The terrain continues to be flat.  We pass large fields with young wheat or corn plants.  The wheat is a good two feet tall, but the corn is only a few inches.  So you can still see a lot of dirt in the corn fields, but none between stalks of wheat. The little towns we pass through between large ones are generally just 10 or 15 houses spread around a large intersection and a couple of side streets.  Once in a while, they'll have a gas station, but there are no hotels between Ottawa and Paulding (neither of which has a AAA-rated lodging), and we did see two restaurants, but they were closed. We passed a few mounds (probably built by what the phone book calls "the county's first settlers, prehistoric mound builders").  We had one dog encounter today, but it's hard to take weiner dogs seriously.  He did give it the old college try, though, running into the road as fast as his little legs would carry him. 
We have crossed the state line! Wind is bad.  Rain is worse.  Together, they are terrible.  We spent the morning in a steady downpour, riding into a headwind.  Crossing the state line got rid of the rain, but we're, even now, still cold & wet. This is the first motel that's been dirty. Everyone in Monroeville was very friendly.
We raced the rain today and lost.  West of Zanesville, we took refuge on the porch of a house under construction.  We shivered for about an hour as it hailed and then rained.  There was a good thunder & lightning show.   It was also a big dog day.  I lost count of them.  It started with a dalmatian and a chihuahua. The dalmatian gave up pretty quickly, but the chihuahua caught up to us. Poor thing couldn't reach us. The other dogs were scarier.  There was one pair with puppies to protect.  They ganged up on us with real skill.  We haven't been bitten yet, but I'm ready to get a weapon.  I know it's the owners' fault, but they're not around when we're being threatened.  Hurrah for cats. I'm so sick of rain. Now that we're on the Adventure Cycling maps, we're finding that folks are more used to cyclists.  There have been so many that the postmistress made little postcards for them.  A mini-mart owner keeps a little cyclist guestbook.   On the one hand, it's nice to see that the route is doable.  On the other, I miss the sense of awe that folks have been showing us. 
We raced the rain today and lost.  West of Zanesville, we took refuge on the porch of a house under construction.  We shivered for about an hour as it hailed and then rained.  There was a good thunder & lightning show.   It was also a big dog day.  I lost count of them.  It started with a dalmatian and a chihuahua. I'm so sick of rain. Now that we're on the Adventure Cycling maps, we're finding that folks are more used to cyclists.  There have been so many that the postmistress made little postcards for them.  A mini-mart owner keeps a little cyclist guestbook.   On the one hand, it's nice to see that the route is doable.  On the other, I miss the sense of awe that folks have been showing us. 
I am tired of complaining about the rain. We're having trouble putting our hands on the point of it all.  Why are we putting ourselves through this? Peru is the home of Cole Porter and the circus hall of fame.  As the rain let up, we tried to walk to dinner.  When the rain picked up, we took refuge on a porch.  After dinner we saw a rainbow-God's promise that he won't drown us on this bicycle trip.  Maybe he'll get us  with a tornado instead.  One was spotted north of here-the route we were scheduled to take.  We're on a shortcut-US24. The B&B is a huge home from the 19th century.  There are lots of books in a panelled room with a fireplace.  There are also antique toys.  We aren't actually in the house.  Instead, we are in the carriage house, above our bikes.  The tub is huge.
Rain. Two men spend half an hour every morning praying, reading Psalms and chanting.  The sanctuary of the Anglican Catholic Church of the Trinity is otherwise empty for Mattins (or Matins).  It is a reflective time. This was followed by a liturgical service - with six women in attendance.  I was the only guy in the congregation.  It was very formal, incense, holy water (it didn't burn me!), and all.   The bell is named Benedict.  The rector is from Oxen Hill, MD. Monticello is the home of Indiana's oldest amusement park.  We have not yet seen it.  We are on the banks of a lake created by damming the Tippecanoe River.   We've been in Alvin Maker territory for some time, but we haven't met anyone with a knack yet.  (Orson Scott Card fans will understand the reference.) We spent another day off-route. 

The paper say, "Partly Sunny-No Rain, Not Even Tonight!" 5:03 pm: The White House B&B, Rensselaer, IN - 34.5mi Lori and I were discussing the relative merits of urban and non-urban living as we were riding along.  I was defending - can you imagine? - the rural life, extolling its quiet and safety, when someone in a blue and white van threw a AA battery at me.  It caught me on the back of my head right under the helmet.  I was a little dazed for a second.  I'm okay.  I came away with a small cut and will probably get a little lump. It's always good when your cynicism is restored. On the other hand, a bit later we stopped to take a picture of a broken-down school.  John Eaton came running out to say hello.  The school had closed in the '60s.   Then it became a church where his father had been a pastor.  Now, John lives in a trailer behind the school and hopes to some day have the money to tear it down. He has helped lots of x-country bikers and runners.  He offered us a bed for the night, but we really wanted to get farther west.  And we were looking forward to a nice B&B. This is definitely a nice B&B.  The tub is huge.  The owners are a psychologist and a professor at the local college (not RPI, can you believe it?).  They're expecting a grandchild, but they put us up any way.  They'll have to run off at any moment to watch the other kid.
We expect to ride into Illinois tomorrow, rent a truck, and drive to Chicago.  We'll take a real break there and decide how and whether we'll go on.
My bicycle has 24 gears, in 3 sets of 8.  (Octaves!)  Today was the first day on the whole trip that I was consistently able to use the highest octave.  (Hey, I have an idea-a symphony based on how I changed gears during the trip.)  The tailwind definitely helped us get the first 38 miles in before noon.  After lunch, though, we started north and had to fight the wind. We started the morning at Janet's Kitchen (the B&B's grandchild finally called them away, so there was no breakfast), but we didn't sit at the reserved table.  It was reserved for "farmers, golfers, fishers, and other liars."  Several locals sat there giving each other a hard time.  One tried to sell us a car. We stopped for our snack in Beaverville.  This small town has a huge Catholic church.  It is impressive, with beautiful stained glass. 
Finished Lives of the Monster Dogs, by Kirsten Bakis.  It's the story of a group of people who, through mysterious operations, give dogs artificial hands, mechanical voice boxes, and intelligence.  The idea is to make an army of soldiers, but the dogs rebel and massacre their creators in their hidden Canadian outpost.  Then, the dogs show up in New York and become celebrities. There's a great similarity between this book and the novel Frankenstein.  Ultimately, though, I'm just not drawn into the story.  It's obvious that the narrator cares very much for the dogs.  She has a close friendship with one, and a strong attachment to another.  It was never really clear to me why she cared.  There was too much telling, nt enough showing. I think that not engaging me emotionally kept the book from inspiring me to think too deeply on its themes:  what is humanness?  What is loyalty? Etc.  -Tales of the Wayside Inn, Longfellow 
Rode around a pond/lake to stretch.  This area of Chicagoland has some very nice paved bike trails.  They pretty much have to; the streets are terrible.  Most of them are under construction.  They are all falling apart-chunks of concrete everywhere.   We're spending a wonderful time with our friends Saundra and Paula.  We get to play games tonight!  They are trying to get us addicted to the television series called Buffy the Vampire Slayer.
 
Well, we're nearing the end of our stay with Saundra & Paula.  The week has been very relaxing.  They took us to play miniature golf.  We even got to buy some jeans and hang around all week wearing denim.  And the pickup truck was fun. You cannot imagine the joy of regular clothing.   They introduced us to the Schaumburg library.  It's a new one with something like three dozen web terminals and two hours of access time.  Unfortunately, they kick you off after two hours, whether or not  someone is waiting. They let us play with their two cats and a chihuahua.  (We've forgiven them for owning a dog.)  They cooked us very good food.  They took us to the movies and to Mars 2112, a space-themed restaurant. And, best of all, it pretty much rained off-and-on all week.  Anything's better than riding in that junk. But we're getting antsy, so we'll move north tomorrow.  This, in spite of the forecast morning rain.  This cannot go on forever, right? Right?  Before we stopped here, we had been contemplating our next steps.  The unending rain, lack of progress, and general homesickness had gotten us down.  Before we got to Peru, we had little contact with real people (day after day of motel receptionists). And this week, I was called by a headhunter in London who told me that the job market completely disappears in August. But we have decided to ride for another month.  If you want to know why, tune in tomorrow.
 We dropped off the truck at 1pm or so, after visits to the post office and a restaurant.  Then we headed north.  The majority of the riding today was bicycle trail.  About half was paved, the rest fine stone.  We took our last 5mi on a Wisconsin road.  Looks like we're back in rolling country. The trails started off in nice neighborhoods, went through a fantastic neighborhood, followed by a rundown neighborhood, then switched to farmland as we got furthest north.  The trail did a lot of at-grade road crossings, and there was a lot of broken glass.  But it was nice to be off-road again, even for just a day. We could tell we were in Wisconsin because right over the line was the first person to return our cheery greeting. Once again MapQuest steered us wrong in getting to the hotel.  But we made it here safely.  Now we can eat.  8:32 pm: So why are we continuing?  It's hard to truly pin it down, but I'll try.  Our disappointment was really a reflection of our personalities.  Forgive me for going Meyers-Briggs on you, but Lori and I are both INFPs.  MB categorizes folks by their personalities using four letters. ( I think it's pretty unusual for a couple to have all the same letters.) The "P" tells you that we are comfortable with change and with not really having a schedule.  I think that Ps are likely to decide to do things on a whim-sort of like this trip. The "I" tells you we are introverts.  That's great for biking because we spend an awful lot of time alone, or at least unable to talk, while riding. So why did we get depressed.  Sure, the weather had a lot to do with it.  But deep down I think it has to do with that "NF"-in two ways.  First, there is this great attraction to causes for NFs.  The "whatever" attitude of the first few weeks is overtaken by the need for purpose. Second, the NF means that we're loyal and need human connection.  We strongly believe in the idea of community, and yet we voluntarily cut ourselves off from it on this bicycle trip.  Hence the homesickness. So what should we do, give up?  Well, I hesitate to do that for several reasons.  First and foremost, I feel like I have a tendency to not finish projects like this.  And this is only a few months of our lives.  This is something we may never have the chance to do again. How do we go on without a purpose?  Well, really, we have our purposes.  We just need to better articulate them so we can grab on to them even in the rain, and, more important, we need to consciously do things to work towards those purposes. One example is something that goes hand-in-hand with working on the homesickness.  I want to meet people and see how they tick.  If I can, I'd like to see how communities have formed and grown.  The Adventure Cycling maps tend to take you away from population centers.  Couple that with our tendency to stay in motels, and you see how we'll never meet anyone real. So, we're going to do our own navigating through Wisconsin to Minneapolis.  Now that June is here, we'll pass more community picnics.  We'll plan our route to go through small towns.  We'll sleep at B&Bs when possible.  And we'll take the time to walk around the towns, really see them. We realized some time ago that we don't have time to make it to Seattle, so now we're just aiming for whereever. We have others,too, and those will come up as we go along.  We also, by the way, came to understand that we are not completely isolated.  All of your postings, emails, and even phone calls have helped us to remember that you're all beside us, looking over our shoulders.  Thanks. And please don't stop.

morning mostly sunny afternoon mostly cloudy warm strong headwind terrain: hilly (no walkers), flat on trail  We rode through Kettle Moraine State Forest.  It was a beautiful ride.  Part looked like a miniature version of New Mexico's Calderra.  A huge flat circular valley ringed by hills.  Of course, in NM it's a dormant volcano.  Here, glaciers did the landscaping. We joined the Glacial Drumlin Trail in Sullivan.  As far as I can tell, a drumlin is a ripple in the prairie caused by melting underneath a glacier.  The seven or eight miles we spent on the trail wound through marshland and spooky forest. In Wisconsin, the state trails require a pass.  Daily passes are $3, and annual passes are $10.  That's not a bad deal, I suppose.  We purchased our annual passes from a Sullivan grocer who told us Wisconsin mosquito jokes (which sound remarkably similar to Alaskan mosquito jokes). The owner of the Jefferson B&B is having an operation, so we're in a motel tonight.  Tomorrow's a light day so that we can look at pottery. We saw a deer farm. 
grumpy clouds laced with rain sprinkles  late afternoon sun strong head/side winds terrain: rolling to hilly (no walkers)  It meant that we had plenty of time to see the pottery festival and watch the US pottery games.  Today was the high school competition.  They were short a contestant, so they asked for a volunteer to join and show how hard it was. Lori volunteered. The five contestants sat on a flatbed trailer with electric wheels and lumps of clay.  They competed to see wh could make the highest cylinder from 5 pounds of clay and the widest plate from the same amount.  Lori's cylinder came in 4th.  She was given a coach who said that she didn't make the same mistakes that most first-timers make.  She got a lot of applause and a free t-shirt. I sat in the crowd thinking, "That's my wife up there!"

Guess they were hoping to make up the difference with the profits from their stand. Madison has a nice approach for bicyclists along paved bicycle paths.  Unfortunately, some of the signs are rather confusing.  For example, one sign told us that the bike route went straight ahead.  Or, it turned to our left.  Or, it turned to our right.  A little arrow indicating how to get downtown would have been nice. We made our way downtown without getting lost (though I do think we took the long way).  The city sits on an isthmus between two sparkling blue lakes.  The bike path takes you along one, and there are bike routes and bike lanes throughout.   There are more bicycles in this city than I have seen anywhere before.  Folks were riding many of them, but many were scattered about on lawns, on balconies, and in bike racks. It was a good place, I guess, to blow another spoke.  I blew another cassette-side spoke, and we had to tootle down to the bike shop to get a repair.  The shop was so big and busy that we didn't even get to do our cross-country biking shtick. But we did get the spoke fixed.

morning rain afternoon sun warm no wind terrain: long slight ups and very long slight downs  The Elroy-Sparta trail is the nicest one we've been on.  There's a good variation to the things to see, and the trail is broken up by 3 tunnels.  They are 1/4, 1/4, and 3/4 mile long.  In the middle of the last, you cannot see either end. Truth be told, we were pretty muddy from the trails, although it (the trail) drained very well and there was no standing water.  Sparta claims to be the bicycle capital of America, but it isn't clear why.  Elroy has more trails; Waterloo manufactures Treks; Madison had better bicycle access to the city.  Sparta's roads are cracking concrete, and there are no bike lanes. Sparta does have a giant statue of a cyclist.

sunny warm slight tailwind hilly (no walkers)  The Mississippi is starting to become monotonous.  It's a nice river and all, but all the towns look alike.  They're skinny gatherings of buildings squeezed between the river and the bluffs.  Some are bigger than others, and they're all friendly enough. Note how easily I make unreasonable generalizations based on little evidence. While Lori napped (the cat meowed all night and the lunchtime burger didn't agree with her stomach at all), I finished Prelude to Foundation.  The book does a good job tying together Asimov's Foundation and Robot series.  It's a fun (if not completely surprising) romp in the old-fashioned science fiction style.  It also gives us a better glimpse of Hari Seldon.  Unfortunately, I didn't like Hari.  This isn't much of a surprise; I rarely care about Asimov's people.  But I thought Hari was a bit too naive, and at times a jerk. Similar to Orson Card with Ender's Shadow, I felt that Asimov spent a book recreating his hero as somehow less and as somewhat less of a prime mover in his own history than was indicated by previous stories.  In a way, that's admirable, or at least a little more realistic.  But one shouldn't be surprised when we're disappointed in the revealed humanity of our heroes after-the-fact. On-the-other-hand, Seldon still has no character flaws, and who wouldn't like a gentle nudge of encouragement once in a while?

(Or so we're told.)  We'll be picking up debris from a hayfield. 6:08 pm: St. Paul, MN Gosh the soft bed feels nice.  I'll bet the shower will feel good, too, though we both got a good deal of sun. The family's house was gone.  They had spent the storm safely in the basement.  They're living in a camper while their house gets re-built.  The contractors were throwing up walls pretty quickly. In the hayfield, we started off fairly organized in spite of the fact that the complaining redhead didn't join us.  We formed a line and started combing the field, using trash bags for the smaller bits of sheetrock, wood, and roofing material.  We carried larger things (boards, window frames, small trees, chunks of chimney) to a pile off the field.  When we found things that might be salvagable (glass birds, napkin holders), a young girl named Sarah carried them up to the family for inspection. Fairly quickly, though, our line fell apart.  The trash bags tore pretty easily and it never felt like we were making progress.  So we started making smaller piles in the field, clearing circles around them.  Some of us found buckets, and someone found a wheelbarrow.  The rest of us built up the piles or helped transfer them to the big one by hand-carrying larger pieces. We met folks from St. Cloud, MN (Mike and Kasey), a den mother and boy scouts from Houston, and others.  Mike kept us entertained with constant banter. I think we helped, some, but the field needed another pass or two even when we left.  Since it's been a week, I suppose, the community seemed to be handling it pretty well.  At least, the family we worked for was in good spirits.   Although it seemed pretty disorganized at first, I think they had it pretty together considering that a disaster had struck and all.   8:15 pm: Finally, good food.  We had some excellent Indian cuisine at a place in a strip mall.  I am so stuffed.

1.  We were awakened last night by the sound of a vaccuum cleaner in the hallway.  It started and stopped, started and stopped.  Finally, I poked my head out the door.  An employee holding a vaccuum cleaner smiled at me.   "Can I help you?" he asked. "What's going on," I said. "Nothing." "Nothing!?" I exclaimed. "You're vaccuuming in the middle of the night!" "Does that bother you?  I'm sorry." I shut the door and got back into bed.  Lori called the front desk. "Could you tell the housekeeping staff not to vaccuum in the middle of the night?" she asked. "Oh, that's not housekeeping," came the reply.  "That's maintenance.  He probably just forgot to do it earlier." 2.  We stopped in at Cracker Barrel for breakfast.  We had some problem figuring out how to get to it, so we were quite hungry.  We ordered breakfast, and the waitress brought us drinks.  I went outside to get the papers (we have to get both local newspapers to get as many comics as the Post).  We read through both sets of comics. No food arrived.  Our waitress had disappeared.  After half an hour of waiting, we flagged down another waitress to see what was going on.  She got the manager, who came over. We needed our food.  Maybe an apology would have been nice, too.  Instead, we got an explanation. "Your waitress had to go to computer class," she said.  "Another server was supposed to help you." We told her we just wanted our food. The eight miles came from a quick jaunt in Minneapolis.  After the four of us visited Minnehaha Falls - the largest urban falls in the US - Lori's father and I rode bike trails around two of Minneapolis' lakes.  The trail around the Lake of the Isles was filled with bumpy cracks.  The trail around Lake Calhoun was much nicer.  Even taken together, though, they make a short ride. One interesting note is that the lakes had seperate paths for bicycles and pedestrians.   Spring's rain has been so bad that parts of the pedestrian path were still under water. After a quick visit to the Mall of America for lunch, we drove up here to Duluth.  The hotel is on the canal and the lake is in sight.  Unfortunately, our room has no windows.  It's an interesting room, though.  The building used to be a packaging plant for a hardware distributor.  It was renovated and given rooms, a restaurant, and a pool.  Our room is a studio suite.  It has a high wooden ceiling and a huge pillar in the middle.
We walked around the harbor, eating burgers and watching the horizontal drawbridge.  We also stopped by the Army Corps of Engineers Museum. It had a large display of model boats and mock-ups of cabins and a pilot house.  It had no t-shirts for sale, though. The aquarium did have t-shirts, but it wasn't nearly as nice as Baltimore's. We also did some driving.  I'll bet Duluth rivals San Francisco for hilly streets. 7:48 pm: We saw AI.  Take random pages from these authors: Bradbury, Dick, Vonnegut, Clarke, and Disney.  Put them together in that order and you have AI.  It was nice to see a sci-fi film that wasn't a horror film.  And it was mostly interesting to watch.  Spielberg was doing his best to be Kubrick, but he didn't quite make it.  That's not necessarily a bad thing, you understand.   
 
cool sunny slight headwind hilly dogs: 2  We made two mistakes today.  First, we underestimated the distance.  Partially, this was due to us leaving the trail, but mostly, we just miscalculated.  We hadn't gone much over 30 in a few weeks. We left the path outside of Superior because it was terribly mushy, covered with thicker gravel than we feel stable on.  It also would have slowed us down quite a bit. So we took several county roads that our map said were bike-friendly.  The map was pretty much right; we had little traffic and saw much farmland and hilly woodland that we would have missed on the trail.   The second mistake we made was not bringing food when there was a chance that we'd not see  civilization until the end of the trip.  It has been rare for us to go 30 miles without any sort of food source-restaurant, gas station, or (most often) a bar.  There were no facilities for the entire 40 miles because we went north of any towns. And nowhere to go to the bathroom, either. 
overcast cool a few raindrops half hilly, half downhill 
grumpy clouds, mixed with sun comfortable sidewind rolling, with one big hill  The road portion of the ride today may have been the nicest of the trip.  Except for one hill, the rolling terrain gently brings you high enough to get pretty glimpses of the lake and the woods all around.  The road is in good shape-nice shoulder without the annoying bumpy cracks of yesterday's US2.  
We took the ferry over to Madelin Island to watch the Independence Day parade.  The island's small town of La Pointe would probably be described as quaint by a travel guide.  There seems to be a small hippy contingent--odd artwork and greenie slogans abound. The parade reflected a mix of hippy with old-fashioned small-townness.  It began with the blaring siren of their fire truck, continued with a group of environmentalists protesting a planned fire tower, and ended with a papier-mache freak show.  Interspersed throughout were clowns, business-sponsored floats, classic cars, beauty queens, and a band.  Everyone had candy to throw at the kids. Not that the kids deserved it of course.  The little beasts rushed into the street to grab the stuff, to fight with each other, and to even snatch it right out of my hand!  In some way it's nice to be reminded that rudeness is universal and not just confined to our much-maligned East Coast cities. We arrived early enough to select a good viewing spot, but it soon became evident that we would not be able to see when the crowds started pressing in.  We maintained a small beachhead on the edge of the blacktop, and we sat cross-legged to keep from obstructing the view of those who arrived later.  The children seemed to feel it was their right to stand in front of me.  They battered each other with flags.  They made  annoying noises.  They climbed on, hit, and kicked me.  Parents encouraged this behaviour, they also seemed to object to their kids being pushed in front of floats.  Go figure. One father and his two sons (named after the local towns, La Pointe and Bayfield--truly!) decided to stand in front of me.  He didn't want to block the view for his wife and in-laws.  Eventually, his wife joined him so that she could talk to an elderly woman who figured I wouldn't mind staring at the backs of two more knees. But all-in-all, it was a beautiful island and a nice parade.  The kid gave me back my camera and didn't cry too loudly when I stole his Jolly Rancher.   But you should read this book and ignore these failings because it does a great job at defining its crisis.  The book is about a man finding his faith and then losing it..  The crisis of faith is well-drawn and the author doesn't attempt to answer the question it keeps asking:  how could God do that? The title comes from Matthew (10:29) and a character's observation that although a sparrow does not fall without God's knowledge, the sparrow still falls. Generally, I don't like books this open-ended, but I really liked this one.  I think it is a great jumping-off point for considering: the value of faith, the formation of community, and the approach to interacting with strangers (aliens, of course, and by extension, human cultures).  One warning: the book has a graphic discussion of a rape.
sunny cool breezy flat  Last night's fireworks were good, too.  They fired from the little harbor, and we watched them from our balcony.  There were a few drops of rain, but it was nice to spend the 4th in cool weather for a change.  And the safety of our room was only a few feet away.  The show itself was very good, and there wasn't the crazy crush of people DC gets. We could also see Madelin Island's fireworks across the channel. Tomorrow, we drive 6 hours to Minneapolis and fly home.  I miss everyone at home, but I don't look forward to summer in Maryland. 

bugs bugs bugs bugs bugs bugs bugs bugs DUST bugs bugs bugs bugs bugs bugs bugs It's dry and sunny and not too hot - I suppose we shouldn't complain. Gnats don't really taste like anything. Our guide book said there would be a restaurant at White's Ferry - the Ferry is operating, but it doesn't look like the restaurant has been open for a while. So we had a picnic from our food packs - bananas, peanut butter, crackers. There was a cool gutted three story brick building with the forest growing up into it, we stared into that for a while. At mile 42, the bridge over an inlet is under construction - we had to walk the bikes and lift them over the metal cross braces. Passed by Miss Lettie's place on the river and had a chat with the woman smoking on the porch. The rambler is ideal lawn ornament nesting ground and overlooks the Potomac. Point of Rocks brick tunnel entrance for the train tracks. Also passed a power plant with puffing smoke-stacks. We stopped in Brunswick and learned not to ask people in cars where anything is. We'd read that this was a problem in another biker's account - but until you experience it yourself, it's hard to believe that a person whose lived their whole life in a town can so grossly underestimate distance and hills. We asked a man taking photos of the trains if there was a place to stay in town. He assured us that the only place would not have any available rooms - always booked. Also couldn't seem to think of anywhere for us to eat except King's Pizza. We biked over the tracks and up the steep hill (everything away from the Potomac is up - as always with rivers.) And had some good Italian food. We looked in the phonebook and called George's Mill Farm B&B. Turns out to be quite a lovely place. When she heard we were on bikes, she offered to come get us, which was good because it was over the river in Lovittsville, VA, and fifteen driving minutes through quite hilly country. Saved us an hour and a half of biking. The farm has been in the family for seven generations, and is still operated by the son in law. The daughter and her family live in a renovated barn on the property, and her mother operates the B&B in the gorgeous old farm house. Friendly dogs. Claw-foot tub. Thus ends our first day on the road!
Here's another poem: "Serene, Wooded Trail" Butterfly suicide  In my front spokes  Spinning  Can't stop  Pop rocks  Off my tire  Bomb ducks flap-quacking,  Quite mad  Can't stop  Papa goose hissing  Spread wings  I'll take you on, you metal buffalo Stay away from my babies! Hiss  Can't stop  Turtles plop  Drop in the soup  Awoken from a sunny nap  Who was that masked man?  Can't stop  Gotta get to the other side  If this is the slow lane  Why am I speeding by  Sorry bug, goose and duck  Sorry turtles, too.  I'm busy getting to that quiet spot  Can't stop for you  Can't stop. It's one a.m. and I can't sleep. We're camping at Opequon Junction right between the canal and river. Evverything was fine when we got here. We set up our camp and made a nice campfire. We cooked our dinner and enjoyed the peaceful, cool woods. A local guy came by and chatted for a while. He was out hunting mushrooms. Says it's been too dry this year for them, but he was looking anyway. He bikes the trail, ten miles a day, for his heart. He's fifty and lived in Falling Waters, MD all his life. We got all settled in the tent a little before sun-down, so we could read and relax. I was naked - the butt is really sore and a night out of the bike shorts seems to help. We had the tent flaps wide open towards the river because no one was out there and the breeze and view were lovely. Just at sunset, three hikers arrived that scared the wits out of me. They came in loud and crashing through the woods. They started immediately to set up a roaring camp fire, and talked about our camp, not realizing we were in the tent. They sounded drunk to me, and cursed about the obvious presence of a woman at this site - so much camping gear and such. "Oh, why's a bitch got to be here?"  "Why not? They have to go and do everything these days." I asked John to go out there and greet them so they'd know we were here and know that there was a guy present. John climbed out and talked to them, but he left the tent flap wide open while I was still struggling to pull up my shorts. I'm near heart attack, and feel like John, my only protection, doesn't even seem to realize how threatened I feel. When we talked about it later, he was surprised that I was so scared of them. In his view they were harmless good old boys just blowing off steam with their talk and not really a threat at all. I had visions of Deliverance. Sorry, but I am a city girl and quite prejudiced against poor country folks. Especially when they like to yell and burn things. I climbed out of the tent and helped John clear our junk off of the picnic table. They're very young, and are hiking to Harper's Ferry to do some climbing. They were going to ride bikes, but discovered at the last minute that the bikes were all broken down. One guy brought a hook on a string and is trying to catch a fish, and the others bet that he won't. They complained of having no pot to cook on the fire. I was convinced they were going to club us with branches as soon as we lay down in the tent and steal our bikes and mess kit.  But John seemed quite calm, so we went back to bed and darkness fell.  1. Cannot get comfortable. 2. Dogs begin barking at sundown, incessantly, from miles up and down the river. More people around than I realized. 3. Frogs start up and sound like broken ambulance sirens. 4. One hiker is determined to burn every scrap of loose brush within an hour's hike - he's got a huge bonfire crackling and he stomps all around the camp site - I hear him go by our stuff repeatedly.  5. Bull is bellowing from across river in West Virginia. 6. Strangest sound - I think the owls are mating, seemingly right next to the tent. So now I'm up, sitting at the picnic table keeping an eye on the pyromaniac and scribbling away in my journal. At least tonight we have a reservation at the Econolodge in Hancock, MD. We'll get a regular night's sleep, do some laundry, and check out the bike shop, then head for Cumberland on Thursday.  There are a few more detours off the path ahead of us. Williamsport is ten miles north - maybe we'll find a good restaurant for breakfast and a flushing toilet.
We got up, cooked a snack, packed up all of our gear, and left the camp site by 7:30 a.m.  The hikers seemed to be impatiently waiting for us to leave. We had invited them to share the picnic table with us, and they'd refused, but when we left they jumped onto it and got all comfy. I guess they didn't like us any more than we liked them. We easily biked the ten miles to Williamsport. Right on the trail the park service has restored an antique brick warehouse and uses it as a museum and visitor center. It's quite well done and the fellow there told us where to go for breakfast. Again, away from the river is always UP, but at the top of the hill, we found a smoky little diner and had a GREAT breakfast. We met two bikers from Ontario, Murray and Jerry. They're biking the whole C&O canal - Cumberland to D.C. (the downhill direction) and are camping the whole way. Since they came from where we're headed and we came from where they're headed, we shared info. They told us about a friend of theirs also biking but at a slower pace - told us to keep an eye out for Dave. And they highly recommended the bike shop in Hancock - we hope to find some good advice about how to bike over the Eastern Divide - our bike book strongly advises against it, but it's a few years old and perhaps there's a new, safer route. After Williamsport, we biked fifteen miles more to Big Pool, then took a detour through Fort Frederick, a reconstructed revolutionary war fort. It was such a surprise. The name didn't ring any bells with me, it wasn't until we biked into it that I recognized the site - Dad and I had hiked to this park a few years ago. Mom and Dad were staying in a cabin in West Virginia, and I'd joined them for a few days. Dad and I hiked out with only a rough impression of where we were going. We ended up hiking for hours, illegally crossing a train bridge, and came out at the fort. I called home on the cell phone from there to say, "Guess where we are?" We found the ten mile Rail to Trail path - the reason we left the canal, and biked it. It's paved, arrow-straight, smooth, and shadeless. Got more sunburn. By this time we were really tired and hungry for lunch - the path comes right out at Hancock and we straggled up the hill to the Econolodge.  Our butts are so so sore. The desetin doesn't help, it hurts even worse. We discovered that the wonderful bike shop is open all week EXCEPT Wednesdays! So we decide to take tomorrow off for bike advice, laundry, and butt recovery. We showered, changed, and WALKED back down the hill to Weaver's Restaurant. They actually had filet mignon on the menu, and it was quite good! Also had an old country style salad bar - apple butter, cottage cheese, macaroni salad and pickled eggs. But the absolute HIGHLIGHT at Weaver's is dessert. Wonderful freshly baked pies and sweetrolls towered in a glass case by the counter. We got two slices of caramel apple nut pie to go and hobbled sleepily back to the hotel. I called Mom & Dad to commiserate about the horrible camping experience and ask Dad's advice about the Divide. Turns out that the Ohio maps and flat shoes we were waiting for had arrived, so they decided to come meet us in Hancock, only a few hour's drive for them. We stumbled back down the hill one last tonight and checked email at the library, then collapsed into bed and slept REALLY well.
Went back to Weaver's for lunch - it turns out that when Dad was a boy his family would always come through Hancock on their way to the farm in WV where they vacationed. They'd always stop and stock up on bread and baked goodies at Weaver's! Also, Mom and Dad came here a few years ago, too. So they enjoyed the trip down memory lane and we enjoyed the food again. The homemade bean and ham soup, salad bar, and chicken fingers. All delish! After lunch we went back to the room and looked through our mail. We went through all of our bags to see if we could send anything home with the parents. I almost cried when they left. It seems more serious now - I won't see them again for months. Plus, I'm tired and weepy anyway. We took a long nap then went to George's to get the bikes. We rode over to the library - lots of emails, especially from Richard. Wonder when he'll be joining us! Back at the room we ordered a sub and a stromboli from Fox's Delivery. We made a reservation at the Paw Paw Patch B&B  for tomorrow night - we're going to take the last bit to Cumberland in two parts and hope to be there by Saturday. Still don't know what to do about that divide. We'll just keep asking around.
We biked back to Weaver's for our last meal in Hancock and met Dave, Jerry and Murray's friend from Ontario. Back home, they're all in a bike club together that rides weekly. But Dave couldn't take as much time off as the other fellows, to bike the whole thing, so he was just biking some of the more scenic sections. Since we were both going north, once out on the trail we caught up with him and chatted for a bit. When John and I were ready to pass him, we took photos of each other and said farewell. We also played tag all morning with a foursome - they went faster than us, but kept stopping for things. They were camping near Hancock and only biking out and back from there, not going one way. So they didn't carry their gear, just lunches and fishing poles.  The path is rougher up here. We saw lots more turtles and I ran over a snake. He didn't move at all, so I hope he was already dead. He was different shades of brown which a diamond pattern - wonder if it was an actual Diamondback. We had a picnic lunch at a little camp site on the trail. We passed beaver heaven - every tree for a quarter mile was chewed down or at least gnawed on. The bit of canal at that point had beaver dams every several yards. Didn't see any of the critters, though. Then we came to the Paw Paw Tunnel.  The path gets very rocky and narrow as it cuts up into the mountain. On the left, the rock rises straight up from the path to higher and higher heights. On the other, it drops away immediately into the canal, actually flowing here. The path goes right into the tunnel, hugging one wall. A railing separates us from the drop into the canal. We walked our bikes through in the darkness - I think I drove John crazy quoting Bible verses - "Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will not fear, thou art with me "  It's 3,000 feet long. But then we were out of it and not far from the B&B. We went to bike up the hill from the towpath - and we encountered our FIRST CALAMITY! John's chain snapped. We sat be the side of the road and struggled to repair it - we have chain tools, but no extra pins, just an extra bit of chain. It's really hard if you don't have the little pins with the extra bit to hold it in place - using used pins is almost impossible. Cars with empty bike racks sped past us waving. I could have thrown my alien tool at them. Two girls in a tiny hatchback with no room for bikes or us asked if we needed any help. Ironic. John got it fixed and we're happy to say that the marriage survived snappishness under pressure. Not naming names. I plead the fifth. We got into town and to the post office, halfway up the hill to the B&B (of course it's at the top of the hill) when it snapped again. So John walked his bike the rest of the way up the hill - almost a mile.  And here we've collapsed, at the home of Kay & Bill. We got cleaned up and made a bunch of phone calls to bike shops and shuttle services. Left messages and then walked back down the hill to the only restaurant in town - the Riverside. The turkey sandwich and fries with gravy were good comfort food - no dessert, though. They only had coconut cream pie and ice cream. We walked back up the hill - our phones don't work here. There're no bike shops in town. No one sells spare parts. We asked around town (at the restaurant and gas station) if there was anyone in town who might be willing to give us a ride to Cumberland, thirty miles away and the closest bike shop. Everyone at the gas station thought of Josh at the same time - says he does odd construction contracts from time to time, but is mostly the jack of all trades in town - little bit of this, little bit of that. And - a requirement for residency - he has a truck. So the folks tell us he comes in the gas station every day for lottery, so he should be by sometime - we tell them we're at the Paw Paw Patch B&B. Turns out Josh is Bill's grandson! So while limping back up to the B&B, we discussed the strange experience of truly being in need and at the mercy of strangers. Before we could ask Bill about how to contact Josh, he offered to drive us himself (in his truck). So tomorrow, we'll impose upon his gardening time and ride into Cumberland for a new chain.  We talked about a few things today - first, we agreed that we're only doing this because we want to. We are not answerable to anyone about whether or not we bike the whole way. So if we get a ride or decide to take the train or buy an RV, it's our choice and we should be enjoying ourselves. Second, I realized that having Seattle as our goal was freaking me out. I felt doomed to failure - watching our average speed (too slow to get to Seattle), miles covered per day (not far enough to get to Seattle), and seeing snags like the chain and the day off for exhaustion (more obstacles in the path of reaching Seattle). So we decided to set this goal instead: 10 weeks or $15,000 - whichever ran out first. That way, it takes the worry out of the day to day. We'll just see how far we do make it with the time and money we have. I feel much freer to enjoy the journey when I'm not seeing an impossible goal ahead.  Oh, and I decided to shave my legs - I've been abstaining for a couple months - trying to be more natural and not need shaving cream and razors and such - but I don't care. I wasn't getting used to the Euro look and I just didn't feel clean! Leg hair collects mud and bugs, yuck. So you can't take the girl out of the biker, I suppose. We chatted with Bill and Kay for a while before heading for bed. Kay wants to retire - she's tired of the B&B and the work is too much for her. Bill wants to keep going for another year at least - he's helping with the housekeeping now and thinks their 16 year old granddaughter could work for them over the Summer and help them get through the busy tourist season. Bill's been cleaning the guest bathroom, and he got the bright idea that the tub would stay shiny and clean with a little turtle wax! Seems to work fine - the bath was quite refreshing.  I keep getting bitten by bugs, despite copious repellant. Maybe I should try a different brand. If we could find a mall, I would like a Victoria's Secret for some comfy boxers to replace hurty ellastic underwear, an Eddie Bauer for some larger khaki pants, a new stationary box that's waterproof and sturdier than my cardboard one (it's gotten wet and ripped up), some dove soap  Sigh. Dreaming of stuff less than a week on the road. Good night!
As we loaded up the bikes and chatted with some fellow riders (with interesting bike seats that were in two pieces, separately adjustable for perfect bun support), one of them noticed that John's rear tire was flat as a pancake. So while he unloaded his gear, tried to patch the inner tube, failed at that, replaced the inner tube, patched the tire, put it back together, pumped it up and reloaded his gear, John the train guy told me his whole life story. He's only 23, dreamed of being a trucker but can't get his license because he's diabetic, He loves trains and runs a mail-order company for serious collectors for high-quality model trains and sets. He hopes to get it online soon, and to open a hobby shop.
