Anyway, in between John's storytelling, I made some calls to "bike-shops" listed in our trail guide, to find out when we could replace John's tire. But the first place I called, listed in Rockwood, said "we don't have no bikes." "Well, you're listed in the trail guide as a bike repair shop." "I ain't listed in no trail guide." Stunned to silence momentarily by this logic - "Okay, well, uh  where would the closest place be where we might get our bike fixed?" "Somerset's the only place near here." Forty miles due west of the trail, of course. The calls went downhill from there. Seems most of the places listed as bike shops are really river rafting shops. Have no idea how they made this list. Guess we'll see how long a dollar bill can hold out. After an hour, we were finally ready to bike. The beginning of the trail and whenever the trail crosses a driveway or road, the gravel is large, loose and mushy. I'm very scared of biking in that stuff. But mostly the trail is wider and smoother than the C&O towpath was - it's crushed limestone rolled flat. Right as we started, a blue bird of happiness crossed our path. A good omen for getting underway! I'm so grateful for Bill & Kay's generosity. I feel more optimistic about actually getting somewhere on the trip now.  We stopped for lunch at the Citgo in Garret, PA - they made good subs. The young girl working there was excited to meet us because she and her boyfriend were planning a trip to D.C. tomorrow. We gave her tourism advice then got back on the trail for a few more miles. We finished the day in Rockwood, PA at the Rockwood Trail House, a B&B that borders the trail. They run a snack bar on the back porch, bike rentals out of the shed, and he's planning on building a bike repair shop. Great little place for those on the road! John's tire seems to be holding out, but we do need a new tire since this one's got a hole patched with a fraying dollar bill. Right now we're hiding in our room, all clean and showered, washing laundry (I really like doing laundry, you may have noticed), and enjoying the ceiling fan on our naked butts. No new bug bites or bruises to report. We hope to get to Ohiopyle State Park tomorrow, thirty miles up the trail. Also hope there's a bike shop there. We should be in Ohio in four or five days. We had dinner at the Tail House's snack bar - they made great burgers from the owner's own beef - they're in the dairy business, but are getting out (which means Bossy becomes lunch).  The local elder generation gathers here on the porch in the evenings for ice cream and gossip. I enjoyed eavesdropping on the news of the town. We played scrabble - I trounced John! I always play better when exhausted. We met Steve and David - they're from Columbus, OH, and drove over to the PA trail to ride part of in over several days. They're going down and back, so we'll probably cross paths again. They're on road bikes! They warned us that the detour from Fort Hill to Confluence is a killer hill, up 400 feet in less than a mile. Sounds like they plan on trying out the unfinished trail on they're way back - the railroad ties have been removed, but the surface is large loose gravel. Not sure which I prefer - road rash from wiping out in a pile of large rocks, or heart failure from pedaling uphill. I've noticed the trail changing - MD & PA are quite different in a lot of ways.  Maryland's trail is much more closely wooded with deciduous trees and tangled undergrowth. The Potomac River is wide and flows lazily. The trail is deeply shaded and winds about - pierced by patches of living rock and root. There are many bugs and birds under the trees, too. As we got into Western MD, I noticed a shift to more evergreen - the forest took on that twilit cast, pine needles blanketed everything, and scented the air like Christmas. In PA, the land tilts in terraced angles up from the Youghiogheny River - the trail is partway up the ridge and open to a much wider view across the river valley. The forest here is light Aspen woods, clear floor, and broken often by pasture and crops. The Yough winds tightly and flows narrow and swift - we get great water sounds up here on the trail. And the trail itself is wider and smoothed over - more tame and easier to ride. The trees are set further back from the trail, so less shade, fewer bugs and birds. Also, they're noticeably behind MD's trees seasonally - MD is lush and well on towards Summer, PA is still only about half budded, looking like early Spring. Frank Lloyd Wright built Falling Waters here in southwestern PA - the land  bordering the trail reminds me of that place. Water trickles and cascades over layered rock topped by monstrous rhododendrons. When the hillside peeks through, sometimes it's limestone flecked with mica, sometimes red clay turning the runoff into chocolate soup.
Let's see - we started the day in Rockwood - Debbie came to cook us breakfast before going to church to play piano. It was delicious - freshly smoked sausage from a local farmer, pancakes and eggs. Lynn and Debbie are the owners - they're the ones getting out the dairy business and getting into the B&B business. It took them two and a half years to fix this place up. The town was abuzz with rumors as to what the couple was planning. For example, Doug owns a convenience store and deli down the road. He's known Debbie all her life - she used to baby-sit his children. But he decided that Lynn and Debbie were going into the restaurant business or something that would put him under. He began driving the one block down the road and turning around slowly in the parking lot across the street - trying to peak in at them during renovations. He never asked to see the place or asked what they were up to, just kept spying. She said the name of his shop, and I was stunned - that's who we called yesterday about a bike shop! I told Debbie about the trail guide listing him, and my baffling conversation. Debbie was dumbfounded that Doug had told us to go to Somerset, because everyone in town knows that Lynn stocks a wide variety of bike parts in his basement and can fix or replace just about anything! Seems like Doug is still holding some sort of grudge against the Trail House. Anyway, Debbie called Lynn at the farm and told him to come over when he was done milking, and get John a new tire. Debbie told me all about their four daughters and another business she's planning to start - an hour away in a larger town - a fitness center for women called Curves. It's a chain, and three of her daughters already have franchises in different towns - one is in Easton, MD!  I got to meet one of their daughters and their grandson, and Lynn's parents run the snack shop in the back, so we'd met them last night. They were going to close the shop, because it was too much to do with the farm and the fitness center - but his parents got upset and said they couldn't close it - they enjoyed the local gathering place too much. So Lynn and Debbie told them - well, if you run it, you can keep it open. So they did. Debbie finally had to go - we packed up, and Lynn arrived and gave John a new tire. Turns out that the bikes he rents to people on the trail are the exact same Trek model as John's. So off we went, aiming for 20 miles before lunch - we want to get to Confluence, PA because we'd heard a trail rumor that there's a nice restaurant on the river there. For twelve miles, the trail was beautiful, then we arrived at Fort Hill, the beginning of the detour that Steve and David mentioned. A big sign warned us to get off the trail and take to the roads. We peaked around it at the gravel - tire-shredding rocky gravel. I said, "Nope." So off the trail we went. The hill curved up a hill to the right, disappearing around the first bend. We biked around it and hit a practically vertical wall of asphalt. I said, "Nope" again and walked my bike all the way - almost a mile. My chest was exploding, my head spun - horrid! Then we got on a busy road and biked steeply downhill for six miles - yahoo! It was a bit scary, going so fast. There's no way we could have stopped our bikes. We  sailed into Confluence - a cute little town with touristy businesses right along the Yough and the beginning of the South Yough Trail. It's quite lovely. We found the restaurant - a fancy, whimsical place that is also a B&B! I had a fried fish sandwich - quite tasty. As we were eating, David arrived and was seated at the table next to ours. I guess they wanted to keep the stinky bikers together. He was conspicuously alone. "Where's Steve?"  David told us the whole story - they made it down to Myersdale after seeing us in Rockwood, but not until after dark. Mrs. Yoder, the proprietor of the dingy motel in which they'd made reservations, was not happy with them! (She said that - " Mrs. Yoder is not happy!") Sounds like Myersdale is just full of fun characters. Today, Steve and David headed back up the trail, and got the Fort Hill just fine. David decided to try the trail out - he said Steve was behind him when he started, but must have chickened out and gone back to take the road. As  we ate and chatted, it was longer and longer without any sign of Steve. "Don't you think you should go back?" "Naw - he's coming." We got the distinct impression that David was enjoying very much showing up the younger man. After forty-five minutes, Steve showed up, walking his bike, flat tire, grumbling and snapping. He'd ripped the sidewall out of his tire on that evil gravel, and tried to patch it unsuccessfully, so he'd walked the whole way. Not a happy camper! He dropped it off at a bike shop and sat down to some lunch, not speaking much to David. Don't blame him. He'd never done trail-riding before, and David had sworn that his road bike would be fine. Well, we hit the trail again and as the afternoon progressed, I felt more and more woozy. Also, the trail began to fill up as we entered Ohiopyle State Park. It's Sunday afternoon - and the park is beautiful today - it's weird to see so many people. And they're not as friendly as the long-term bikers we meet during the week - they don't seem to know simple etiquette about passing and staying in single file and such. And no one says hello. Maybe it's a Pittsburgh thing. But I felt quite wretched by the time we got into the town of Ohiopyle. I sat on the ground next to the trail while John biked around and found us a room. David and Steve arrived and stopped for a sugar break. They still have 36 more miles to get back to their cars. I get the distinct impression that Steve won't be making any more bike trips with David.  So John came back and got me - I crashed in the room all afternoon. We went and had dinner at a filthy convenience store that brags "Campbell's canned soups," which they were out of at the moment, and were instead serving what tasted like Lipton soup packets. Oh well. I took lots of medicine and am going to bed, now. I hope this doesn't mean I'm really sick - I really feel awful right now. So ends our first week of biking. Good night!

We aimed to get to Smithton before lunch, another 18 miles in 2 hours. We did fine except for total lack of bathrooms! I used the woods, but I hate that. We met a trail manager in Smithton and registered our vote for portapotties. He says they're planning to break up the long stretch with a permanent toilet - they don't like portas because then the service truck has to drive on the trail. We biked uphill into town and went to Charla's place - I had lots of fried food, and John got Pierogy Pizza! Now it was decision time. There were hotels in Smithton, we could have stopped for the night, we'd already don 36 miles. But it's only lunch time and McKeesport, the end of the North Yough Trail just south of Pittsburgh is only 25 miles away. We had visions of a large hotel chain with data ports and whirlpools. So off we went, taking 5 mile butt breaks. The going here was so easy - the trail is smooth, the grade slightly downhill, and we have a tailwind. This is the life! We made it 20 miles to Boston, PA, an old little town  with lots of square, brick houses. A baseball game was going on at the park. A couple of B&B's are listed here in Boston, and we both feel shaky. But it's only five more miles to the final goal! The map shows the last three miles of trail into McKeesport as unfinished, but John had read an article in the paper about McKeesport's mayor fighting to finish the trail and biking down to Boston to show it off. So on we went. Today would be a day of hard lessons. A few hundred yards out of Boston, the trail just ended. A non-bike trail went off to the left into Dead Man's Hollow. The path in front of us turned into a train yard littered with tire-ripping garbage. Stuff was stacked on pallets, and train tracks ran alongside us. No Trespassing signs were posted. We don't know what the mayor biked on, but it could not have been this. Lesson number one. When in doubt, go back to what you know.   A teenager came biking towards us through the train-yard on a stunt bike. We asked him how to get into McKeesport. He was unsure, which should have been a red flag, but then told us to go through the train-yard a bit, up this hill to the road, and over the bridge to the right which would take us into town. Sounds simple. I asked how steep the hill was. He said, "I did it without any gears." I said, "Yes, but we're old people." Lesson number two. Never ask a teenager for directions.   We headed into the train-yard. You'll notice by now we are making really stupid mistakes. We found his hill and walked our bikes up a rutted, dirt path into trashy woods. We carefully passed a spot where the path had washed down the steep slope. A huge pile of garbage dumped along the trail from the road above. Finally, we came to "the road." We could see it above us, straight up a steep hill about 200 feet that was once paved with asphalt. Broken asphalt has to be the absolute worst surface on the planet. There was no way possible to a human to bike up that (unless you're a teenager.) So we walked. We struggled, shoving our bikes in front of us, bursting our lungs. I just had visions of getting to the top and gliding down over the river into a lovely city with hotels lining the road. We crested the hill and found - nothing. Lesson number three. Never go up a hill unless you know you need to. All we could see was a road going off in two directions, neither of which giving us any clue as to which way the bridge might lie, and little suburban houses lining the streets in both directions. The lawns are tidy and colorful - the houses little brick ramblers. I decide it was a horrible mistake to ask a teenager for directions, so I go in search of an adult. I find Mary and Irene. They're neighbors, and they're at Irene's house having a nice chat and a few drinks. I didn't spot the half-empty plastic jug of whiskey until later. They were extremely friendly, and  determined to be helpful. I almost screamed when Irene's first instruction was to go back down that hill to the train-yard. But instead of listening to her, I was so desperate and angry by that point that I refused - there had to be another way. . They thought for a while, then off they went in a talking race, arguing, changing their minds, talking at the same time. Mary's dentures were loose. Still, I got a general idea of which way they wanted us to go, and asked if they had a phone book. I wanted to make a reservation at the big lovely hotel we're going to stay in. They brought it out and chatted, telling us about grandkids and time spent in D.C. during WWII. They're both so sweet, but I am so tired.  The phonebook has no listings for big lovely hotels. The phone book has next to nothing in it - a few scary sounding places - Harry's Roadside Motel - and the Angel Inn. The ladies had never heard of the place, but it sounded better than the alternatives, so we called. John made a reservation - a room costs $47. This nightmare is becoming more and more horrific. But the farther we get, the less we want to give even an inch of this hard-earned ground. After looking at family pictures, checking out the pool out back (and spotting the jug), we headed down the road.  Lesson number four. When people give you directions, listen to them. We biked nervously through turn after turn, came down a breakneck hill through town on a busy road with no shoulders. I was so tired, and didn't expect to have to do any of this. The map showed the trail just going straight into town, with accommodation right alongside. John read that the trail was completed all the way through. This was all wrong. We still couldn't see any bridge. I biked up a steep hill and crunched, barely able to get my shoes unclipped off of the pedals. I stand there, legs shaking, unable to lift them, let alone get back on my bike. Then John tells me that I went the wrong way and we need to go back down. That's when I lost it - I started crying. I couldn't go on, but had to, and couldn't believe all of this was happening. I wanted to go home right then - we can't even make it to Pittsburgh, what do we think we're doing?! John just stood there, not knowing what to do about me - he's exhausted, too, but I don't care, this is all his fault. He must have misread the article. He thought of this whole trip in the first place.  So fueled by steely, self-righteous indignation, I got back on my bike and turned around. We came out in front of the bridge and saw with bitter irony that the train-yard came right to the road on our right. If we'd never gone up the hill in the first place, we'd have been to the bridge in five minutes. If we'd listened to Mary and Irene, we would have missed the crunch-hill. I'm already seeing how one day far far in the future, this will probably be hilarious. We biked over the hill and promptly got lost trying to get to the Angel Inn. I'm no longer speaking to John, I'm walking my bike, and refuse to move until he asks for directions. He does, and heads out - I walk behind him in grim silence, hoping I pass out just to spite him. Lesson number five. Never go into the unknown when exhausted. Stop before you're too tired to continue. Lesson number six. Don't say any of the things you think in your head when you're exhausted. If I had opened my mouth, we would have been arrested for domestic violence. He may not like the silent treatment, but it is because I love him that I clench my teeth. The Angel Inn is an old convent that has been converted into a hostel - shared bathrooms, dorm-style lodging. McKeesport is a horribly dilapidated suburb of Pittsburgh - when steel left and the malls were built in other towns, this place curled up and died. All it has now is a huge aging population who can't leave and a depressing low-income population. The rooms weren't made up, yet, so while the owner bustled about, we carried our bikes up, unloaded our stuff, carried the bags up another flight of stairs, showered and changed. Then we sat in the living room, unable to move. She took pity on our exhausted selves and drove us around the corner to the Eat-n-Park, a Denny's style diner. The food really hit the spot, and I had regained enough fortitude to treat John with civility. We hobbled back to the inn and discovered a wretched, eye-watering odor in our room. I could not imagine walking through the door, let alone sleeping in there. Then John sat on the bed and it collapsed onto the floor. So we moved our stuff across the hall and tried to find some sheets that would fit the bed. Couldn't find any. So we called the owner at home. She was on her way back over anyway, so she said she'd make up the other room for us. We watched junkyard wars down in the living room while we waited, then finally we fell into the little bed in the little room, the end of this too long, too far day.
We went to the Eat-n-Park for breakfast - what an adventure! The breakfast buffet was great. It had such oddities as potato cakes, mashed and deep fried sweet potato nuggets, breaded and fried banana nuggets. What fun! We got our first roll of film developed at the Rite Aid and enjoyed looking over the first week of our trip. Also, we bought a detailed atlas map of Pittsburgh and rented a big honking truck! I love the truck. We could just drive past Pittsburgh, return the truck on the other side and bike from there. Or we'll at least drive our route and find the best way through before setting out on the bikes again. I'm a little nervous about the unknown for some reason, can't imagine why (see yesterday). Anyway, we went to the mall and I soaked in the chain stores like a hot tub - Victoria's Secret, Eddie Bauer, Disney Store! Heaven! Boy, exhaustion makes you shallow. We had lunch at the food court and found me some boxer shorts and John a new book to read. Then we took a long drive through icky traffic to a bike shop. It's a great place, though - nice people. We got more bike shorts, a new pair of gloves for me (I left mine on Mary and Irene's glider yesterday), bike pump, inner tube, cliff bars  We are at least supporting the independent bike shop industry with this trip. The bike dude there suggested riding through the city along the river, rather than trying to piece together the disjointed bits of trail that goes around the city. It'd be shorter, anyway.    By the time we got back to The Angel Inn, I was really hungry. We found an Indian restaurant in the phone book and drove through town. It was pretty good! After dinner, it was too late to go driving through town looking for our bike-route, so we'll have to do that tomorrow morning before returning the truck and biking into Pittsburgh.
Then we came to a hill. It was purely evil - steep, curved, shoulderless, busy - no way. So we back tracked and tried to find a way around it. But the deal is - this thing is a high bluff that starts as a cliff right on the river, and extends inland for a long way. The houses and roads are strung along the sides of this thing like Christmas tree ornaments. I freaked out - I felt like we didn't have any options - we'd have to give up on getting past Pittsburgh, and if we were always going to be hitting impossible spots, why were we even trying to bike across country in the first place? It was almost noon, late for checking out of the hotel, late for returning the truck, and we were hungry.  So John decided to go ahead and reserve another day at the Angel Inn, another day on the truck, and find someplace to eat. After lunch, and feeling a little less apocalyptic, we looked at the map carefully and tried another route. We found a way that extends a few miles inland, climbs the bluff at a shallower incline, and crosses over at a low point. It'll still be a long uphill, but at least I'm sure we can bike it. Once we found our way back to the river, we continued Northwest on 51, thinking we could just stay on it all the way into Ohio. But it was shut down to two lanes, with no shoulder, construction for miles and miles. So we went back and checked out northern end of the Montour Trail, a bit that's finished for 11 miles from route 51 west to the Pittsburgh International Airport. It looks like a beautiful trail, and there are nice hotels at the airport. The bit of trail crosses route 30, and we drove that all the way into Ohio - it's long roller-coaster hills all the way, but it's a nice country road with a wide shoulder. Should be fun. So we headed back to McKeesport for ONE MORE NIGHT, confident that tomorrow we can bike out of here and eventually get to Ohio.  We went to the movies and saw The Mummy Returns - very silly. We had a yuppy dinner at the Cap City Diner, and mailed a large package of stuff home.  I suppose I should explain why we didn't mail ourselves home after the eighth day - the horrible day. In the morning, after some good sleep, the hideous nightmare was in new perspective. We talked about it (once I could speak without screaming) and agreed that we had learned some valuable lessons. If we quit now, we'd waste what we had learned - if we continued, we knew better now what we could do, and what our limitations are. Besides, the first 60 miles of that day were great! So we've taken a day to recuperate from overdoing it, and a day to trail-blaze. We'll be back on the road tomorrow, and once we hit the Ohio bike-maps and then the Adventure Cycling maps, it should be much easier. So it's the end of another day, and we are READY to get moving!
So we started this morning with one last breakfast at the Eat-n-Park, then loaded up our bikes and threw it all in the truck. We drove to the Enterprise office and they drove us to the beginning of the trail - we wanted to see if the trail got us over the river into town before disappearing. It didn't go anywhere, so we got onto the roads and headed north. At first I was panicky about the traffic - so many cars, so fast  watching how close they would come to John - I had horrible visions of him getting run over by a big truck. Or a volkswagon. Or that SUV. Or  they really drive like maniacs up here. John kept biking up onto the sidewalk for particularly narrow stretches. Twice, we had 18-wheelers stuck behind us, unable to pass for short bits. They seemed patient with us, though, and we were careful to get out of their way as soon as we could. We stopped at Kennywood Park and talked to the elderly gate-keeper. The amusement park opened in 1895 as a recreational stop on the streetcar line, to draw more customers to use the public transportation. It's been run continuously as an amusement park since then. They still have the original carousel, but now they have roller-coasters to attract a younger crowd. The man was funny - he said he was going to call an ambulance to follow us, sure I was about to pass out and collapse into the road. I suppose I was a bit red-faced and breathless. But we had a nice rest break listening to his stories. He also told us about a time he picked up a girl hitchhiking - she was from Germany and he picked her up to tell her how dangerous it is to hitchhike in this country. He called his wife and they made up a bed for her. He lectured her about how things were different here and she couldn't rely on the kindness of strangers. Then there was the time a guy was biking south from Canada or something, and had no money and no where to stay. He wanted to know if he could set up a tent, and the guy took him home, too, with a lecture and a shake of the head. Seems to me that with enough kind strangers like this fellow, the U.S. isn't such a scary place, after all.  We took another break from the crazy streets at the Waterfront - a newly developed area that used to be part of the continuous chain of steel mills up and down the river banks. They've left a few of the old brick structures for visual interest, and paved and landscaped the rest, bringing in restaurants and a movie theater, etc. The roads are very wide here and mostly empty, since quite a few of the places haven't opened, yet. It'll probably be quite a crowded hot spot when it's all finished. We biked on and had lunch in a historic old neighborhood that's beginning to see some gentrification - we ate at Cuska's caf - a burger and beer joint with a very rude waitress. By sneaking through some parking lots and over an abandoned, littered lot under a bridge, we managed to avoid an intersection under construction.  Our last bit of biking today brought us to another area of new development - Station's Square - a little like Harbor Place in Baltimore. We got a taxi to take us to the Relax & Wash laundromat. The driver is a grad-student - she was fun to talk to. She gave us postcards of the city. We washed all our stuff and watched (appropriately) soaps. We had dinner at Houlihans, and are back in our room for the evening. We plan on biking to the airport tomorrow, and then we can celebrate getting through Pittsburgh!
John likes to jump on and off sidewalks, ride through or walk through cross walks, etc. That makes me really nervous. I don't like going on and off the street and up and down the handicap access dips on the sidewalks - weaving around, climbing on and off the bike. I figure once you get on the street and establish your presence on the road, you should be consistent - not swerve unpredictably. We make the cars nervous enough as it is. So I told John I was just going to stay on the road because all the weaving was wearing me out and making me nervous. Still - I followed him onto the sidewalk at this one crazy intersection where we had to stop and wait for a light to change on a steep incline. When I tried to get off my bike I tipped over - it's just so heavy with all the gear that once it gets going I can't hold it up. I threw a hissy fit and kicked my bike a couple of times. I also told John that I wanted to weigh our bikes because I think the weight distribution isn't fair - mine's heavier. Waaaah! I know how to have a tantrum. We continued on up and John made it all the way to the top - I had to walk a bit. Total crunch. I just hit a wall on long, sustained exertions. So we rested and snacked at a gas station near the top. Then we got to go, "Wheeeeeee!" for a few miles and the roads were much emptier in this neighborhood and better shoulder. Nice ride! We got back on 51 along the river and had one ugly underpass with construction, then we were on the Montour Trail heading west towards the Airport. The trail had a slight incline, so it was hard pedaling right before lunch, but so much nicer than the roads. A large group of volunteers was working on one spot - landscaping it with flowers along the sides, and painting a large mural under a bridge. We thanked them. We stopped at a bike shop on the path to replace John's bike computer that kept blinking on and off. We got one put on my bike as well.  We biked on to the airport and after a harrowing detour off the trail to the Marriott - they actually have signs on all the roads around there "NO PEDESTRIANS" - it's all exit ramps, no traffic lights or crosswalks. Crazy! We got room service for lunch and I sat in the lovely hot tub. We got internet cable on the TV and surfed for info on Ohio. We had dinner in the hotel's restaurant - steak and salmon - and enjoyed the parade of prom kids all dressed up - there were two high school proms in the hotel. They look so nervous! Ready to walk into a wall, because they're thinking about their shoes, their hair, their makeup   We, the old, unglamorous people shuffled comfortably back to our room and called it an early night. We survived the ride through Pittsburgh!
We got the hotel shuttle guy to drive us to the post office. It's only a mile away, but it's atop this monstrous hill, and across those evil roads with no crosswalks. We mailed more stuff home, and got a fabric marker to write on my biker shirt where we've been. It has a map of the states though which we plan on biking. I wanted to trace our route on it. I bought some more Luna bars and we had lunch at Subway. We picked up a menu for a Chinese delivery place and began the long walk down the hill. Problem: unless you remembered to bring your bungee chord for jumping off the top of the hill, the road winds and switchbacks a long way out of the way to get down. It was probably five miles. We saw a Marriott Suites along our route - so we stopped there to see if their shuttle would take us back - he was much nicer than the guy at our hotel. We had a pleasant surprise when we returned to the room. Stacey at the front desk had sent us a fruit and cheese tray with a note of good wishes. That almost made up for when we sat down to tune up our bikes we discovered a broken spoke on John's bike. We'd brought spoke-wire, this stuff that John at the bike shop back home swore by. But John discovered that it needed to be sawed off at the right length, and surprisingly, the hotel room did not have a saw. So I strapped his wheel onto the back of my bike and headed three miles back up the Montour trail to Trailblazers, the bike shop that we stopped at yesterday. He fixed it all up and I bought some extra spokes. So I at least got to bike six miles today, but I suppose it doesn't count since we didn't get anywhere. I visited the hot tub again, and we ordered Chinese food and vegged out. Rain or shine, tomorrow we are back on the road!
We got to Route 30 and got off the trail. Don't know when we'll ever be on trails again - looks like road biking here on out. 30 has long rolling hills, most of the time the downhill is enough to get you up the uphill, but sometimes not, and then we pedal until we crunch, and then we walk. I walked a lot. You know how they say, "What does up must come down?" Well, anyone who's biked knows it should be - "What goes down must bike back up." And "It's all uphill from here" doesn't sound nearly as positive. "When you hit bottom, there's nowhere to go but up." I think I'd prefer just staying put in the bottom, thank you. I suppose the glass-half-full attitude would be that once you get to the top, going back down is lots of fun. We stopped for lunch at a smokey little diner - good food, but a family or chimneys (with children!) chain-smoked us out of the place. We ate our dessert out on a bench. We stopped for a sugar break near Raccoon Creek and had a nice chat with a fellow at the Traverse Inn. He seemed concerned with our safety, with all of the truckers on 30. We assured him that we were careful. I suppose there's not much we can do if one wants to run us down, though. The mini-golf on the other side of the creek was closed.  We crossed for a few miles through the northernmost tip of West Virginia's panhandle - and down a long, 7% grade. At the bottom of the hill we crossed the Ohio River on a golden steel bridge, and entered Ohio. What a triumph! We're out of Pennsylvania - hooray! John had gotten directions off of the internet to the Motor Lodge. We biked through East Liverpool, formerly known for it's pottery industry, and up a 10% grade for almost a mile. It is a famously evil hill on the historic Lincoln Highway. I thought we were on the wrong side of route 30, so I made John call the motel. Mental note: check directions BEFORE going up hill (didn't we already learn this lesson once?) The woman at the Motor Lodge cheerfully told us that they'd had lots of people complain of this - the directions on line are WRONG. We had to bike back down the hill. Argh! Then we had a near death experience at a horribly confusing intersection - three roads and two exits from a gas station all intersected with one traffic light. Cars were coming out of the gas station willy nilly. Yikes! A few more miles over rolling hills brought us to the Motor Lodge. It used to be a Best Western. The room is large - we threw all of our clothes in the coin-op washer and hung around in our rain gear. The hot tub is closed while they're repainting the pool. Bummer. We went to the steak house in our rain gear for dinner because the dryer was taking forever. No one seemed to mind. We each called our moms to wish them Happy Mother's Day - I talked to mine for a long time. Thus ends our second week on the road!

So we biked back to the Walmart and looked for a map. They sell every imaginable road atlas EXCEPT one for this county. We asked the friendly greeter if anyone in the store was familiar with the area. Between two check-out ladies and some customers, we got excellent directions to Lisbon, on FLAT back roads. Lisbon is a wonderful little town, with quaint, restored Victorian homes, tree-lined avenues, the Lepper Library in a lovely old building with stained glass windows, and a steel trolley diner. We did some emailing in the library and had lunch at the diner - great comfort food.  Heading north from Lisbon, we missed the turn onto the Cardinal Trail - the first leg of the road route that our maps use to take us across the state. So we had to backtrack. The hills are so exhausting. We hit a really bad one, and when we stopped to rest, I got bitten by a bionic mosquito - it really hurt! But we finally got on the maps, and although I have to say their definition of "rolling hills" frightens me - we got to North Georgetown where we planned to camp. Someone at the restaurant in town told us about Camp Timashamie. Turns out the office is closed on Mondays, but the owner came over and welcomed us. He showed us where we could set up our tent, where we could store our bikes, etc. Very hospitable. It's a lovely place with a lake and woods, and lots of kitties. The bath house is well lit, with hot and cold running water. And the restaurant will be open for breakfast. Yay! We had a pleasant evening at our campsite, cooking dinner on our little stove. I took a melatonin pill and slept well, but had very strange dreams and woke up on and off. I dreamt that a guy named Alejandro came and bashed in our tent. He and another Latino guy were in one of the RV's next to the lake. . Seems I worry about tent bashing a lot, and that I'm even more of a racist than I thought - now I'm prejudiced against poor white folks and Latino campers. Then I dreamt that a feral cat got in our tent and was standing on my butt - I couldn't get it to jump off. But despite the odd and menacing dreams, it was a great night of camping - I could get used to this!
Hills hills hills. I thought the midwest was supposed to be flat. I can't believe these hills. We got just east of North Canton, and I had to go to the bathroom very badly. We stopped at a hair dressers. The ladies there have us directions to a road called Sunset Strip. Very funny. That's where all the hotels and restaurants are. We still got a little lost - things are just always farther away than people realize. We checked into a Microtel - they have a hot tub! We went to Cracker Barrel for dinner - the catfish was pretty good.  Oh I forgot about another good thing today - we found a little tree frog in our tent this morning - very cute. He's brown and gray with little yellow arm and leg-pits and tiny suction cup toes. He's perfectly camouflaged for sitting on bark and picnic tables. I was a regular crocodile hunter - "Crikey! What a bute!" I held him while John took photos of our little safari. So good night, and hope the rain stops.
"Pure West" Biking west Finally, pure west But it's raining and  There's no wind To move these clouds. I scan the horizon in front of us Just hoping for an edge of blue An end to all this But it's snapped down Like a Tupperware lid over Ohio. No miles I can bike in a day  Will take me out of the bowl. So I'm just biking  Biking in rain as fast as I can, Pure west.
He finally agreed to go around 11 a.m. As we went, visibility increased the farther we got from Wooster. Seems the fog was pretty local. But the hills are still so big here. Three days into Ohio, and it's still so steeply rolling. Where're all the flat cornfields?! We came to a little bake shop in New Pittsburgh and were hungry for lunch, so we bought some fresh rolls and pumpkin cake and had a picnic on the back steps of the place.  Back on the road - hills hills hills. It's too bad that we couldn't have waited until Jeromesville for lunch, because we met the nicest people at the J-ville Pub and Grill. We went in for drinks and a potty break and ended up staying to chat for a while. They asked all about our journey and they got so excited. They wanted to feed us and give us a ride - they gave us tee-shirts and sweat-shirts and made us promise to call them if it started raining on us - they planned on picking us up and giving us a ride to Mansfield! We posed for photos, and got back on the road, reluctant to leave such generous hospitality.  I was just thinking what a nice day this had turned out to be - no rain, nice lunch, friendly people - when I was nearly mauled by a pack of vicious farm dogs. They came off a porch snarling, snapping, and barking just as I got to the top of a hill - I was exhausted and had little strength to pedal, but I pedaled anyway and screamed like a maniac and bared my teeth - I don't think I've ever been so ferocious. The lead dog snapped two inches from my ankle - but whenever I screamed he veered away. Finally, I picked up enough speed and got far enough from their house that they gave up the chase. I was so worried about John, though! He was far behind me, and now the dogs were all riled up and ready for the next biker. I was sure they were going to eat him. But he came down the hill after me with the pack barking madly behind him. He says they ran along on both sides of his bike but didn't nip at him. Guess I put the fear in 'em! Grrr! Seriously - it was a horrible experience - I felt nauseated and dizzy and angry. I only wish an 18-wheeler had come along at 60 miles an hour and had jumped the fence and crashed right into the front of the house, taking out the stupid, obnoxious owner. I really don't blame the dogs for being dogs - just the people for being jerks.  Later, when a shelty with a flowing, gorgeous coat came chasing out after us, flopping like a mop from a Vidal Sassoon salon, it was hard to take her quite so seriously.  On the happier side, we saw a deer farm and emus and some VERY friendly cats (we were never once chased by a vicious pack of cats.) And lots of horses and cows. Some young, teenager cows even ran along beside John in their field. Probably wished they were dogs.  We made it to Mansfield after riding through a gorgeous state park with camping on a placid lake. The city was a bit of a let-down. If it weren't so cold, and they weren't calling for rain, it would have been such a great place to camp out again. But we didn't want to risk the thunderstorms, and I wanted to do some laundry. So we went to the Holiday Inn - coin-laundry, hot tub.  The city is a little like Pittsburgh - another steel town largely dying and dirty. We tried to have dinner in the hotel's restaurant, but we were ignored for so long that we gave up and walked down the street. We discovered Cycle Night (motor, of course) at Mr T's coffee house! Mr. T's is a cool diner with good fries and batty waitresses.  So ends another day on the road. We sure could use some good weather and flat land.
Then John got another FLAT TIRE. We sat outside the East of Chicago Pizza place, in the rain, and fixed the flat.  That was all in our first five miles. We weren't even out of Mansfield. ARGH! But when we finally got out of town and got going, at least we were moving. And once we got west of Ontario, the hills started flattening out. The traffic disappeared. The riding would be wonderful it wasn't COLD AND WET. So we stopped at Moe's Minimart and gas station for some nuked lunch and the locals there steered us to the Rainbow Inn in Galion as a place to stay. We decided to cut the day short and get out of the rain. It's supposed to be SUNNY tomorrow and Sunday, so we just decided that enough was enough.  The Rainbow is a bit of a motor-lodgey dive, run by an Indian family that either doesn't speak English well or hates us. Either way, they weren't very friendly despite our attempts to chat. We both had a weird homesick sensation - we hadn't realized how WHITE Ohio has been. The lobby smelled of wonderful curry, but we were stuck with fried fish and burgers at Granny's diner. Bleah!  I'm getting kind of depressed and grumpy. All we do is eat, sleep, bike - pack, unpack - get wet, and dry off again. I'm tired and this is not fun. I'm having dreams about clothes, too. I dreamt that I had a nice, clean, sturdy pair of blue jeans. I so enjoyed the sensation of pulling them on, then I thought, "Oh, no, I can't bike in these, and they're too heavy and bulky to pack. Where's a post office? I have to mail them home!" In another dream, I'm in a Victoria's Secret, and I'm picking out new bras and underwear - they all fit so nicely and smell so clean, in a wide variety of fabrics and designs  I'm losing my mind. BEWARE BIKES OUT FRONT  I think it's so nice when we pass yards with piles of bikes out front - we've passed quite a few. Kid's bikes, grown-up bikes, old-fashioned grandma and grandpa bikes. Some look like the owners dropped them there a moment before and ran around back. Some are rusted with weeds entwined in the spokes. Some have weathered "For Sale" signs propped in front, and some are accompanied by villages of lawn ornaments and farm tools. I think, "Look at all of the people who bike, or at least used to" - I feel so included. We even saw one bike hung on a wall with flowers planted in the handlebar basket. Then I get the "creeping feeling" - I know what's really going on here. Evil grab bicyclists and gobble them, smacking and slurping. They burp up the indigestible penny-farthings and tandems, Huffies and hybrids, and toss them out the front door. Gangs of neighborhood children popping wheelies and biking in lazy circles - snatched in a squealing mass. Old couples with a picnic basket strapped to the back gasp in surprise but don't have time to scream. Speedy, middle-aged Lance-wannabes never even see the monster coming, their heads down, pedalling with all their might.  Sometimes after a tasty meal, Mrs. Ogre takes the time to arrange the leftover bikes as planters. Sometimes Mr. Ogre feels industrious and frugal, and decides to try to sell them - perhaps this will even encourage more prey to pedal by!  So next time you're out on your bike, and happen to pass a mysterious pile of bikes in someone's front yard, keep your eye on the front door, and whatever you do, don't stop to take pictures.
We talked to a nice family in Nevada, out enjoying the weather on their front porch. Then we got to the Amerihost - and called the bike shop. Bud Miller came and got us, even though he was closed for the weekend. He fixed John's spoke, trued the wheel, and cleaned out and repacked the bearings - incredibly kind of him. He invited us to his church tomorrow. After we got cleaned up, we biked to the drug store and dropped off film, had dinner at The Steer Barn - obviously a popular place, and got to try exotic delicacies like pea and peanut salad and spaghetti salad. After dinner we played minigolf and picked up our photos. I suppose it wasn't that bad a day, I just feel wretched. Bleah.
We biked north to Carey - used the bathroom at a drive-in restaurant. Carey has a waterworks park that is famous locally for it's wonderful well water.  We had lunch at a gas station in Vanlue. We had trouble getting back on the route again after Vanlue, but then we made it into Findlay (where I had to make another emergency bathroom stop at an equestrian center on the outskirts of town) and got a room at the Hawthorne Inn and Suites. We had dinner at the Diamond River steak house - it was okay.  Still grumpy, despite the gorgeous weather and lovely tailwind. I think we're taking tomorrow off, so maybe a rest will help.

We rented a pick up truck from Enterprise again and dropped the bikes off for a tune up - my front derailer is rubbing when I try to shift gears. In fact, yesterday I had quite a break-down. (Me, not the bike.) I was having some trouble with it, so stopped to try and adjust it. The more I messed with it, though, the worse it got, and I couldn't get it back to where it was when I started. John just stood there not saying anything, and I got really mad at him. I was despairing - losing all hope of finishing this trip. I missed my friends and my family, I didn't know why we needed to do this, I didn't have the strength or courage to keep going, and John just stood there. I felt like I had been helping him to go on, to get moving everyday, but he didn't do anything to encourage me or help me through my despair. So I cried and yelled at him. I felt so lonely and wanted to go home. We talked, and he tried to be more encouraging and helped me get my bike in workable order, and on we went. It did get me thinking about what my friendships mean to me - I love John, and I really like our relationship - but he is not an extrovert, and I need more human interaction than just one introverted guy - even though I'm an introvert, too, there's something really valuable I get from my girlfriends. Besides, I'm PMS-ing.  Anyway, we went to Fazoli's for lunch, again. Then at the library I got some great internet time and John found some places for us to stay over the next few days. We have to alter our route somewhat because the Ohio maps only show camping, and the temp. goes into the 40's at night and they're calling for continued rain. No way, man. After the library, I called mom and we had a nice long talk. John went to a used book store - Books on Main - and got himself two books. Then we tried the new book store - B. Dalton - because I'm reading a couple of series that are newer and aren't in used book stores yet, and they didn't have anything I was looking for! We're spoiled by Borders. I bought underwear - see, I started out with underwear, but when the bike rash got bad, and the elastic just seemed to make it worse, I mailed them home and got some boxers at the mall in McKeesport. Then a few days ago, I started having some menstrual spotting, and needed to deal with that - which doesn't work well with boxers. So we went to K-Mart and bought some regular underwear again - I was almost stuck with turquoise tiger striped. It was the only package in my size, until I found one package of white on the wrong peg. Why on earth would anyone design turquoise tiger striped underwear?! I certainly don't ever remember seeing any turquoise tigers, and I watch animal planet all the time. We picked up our bikes - they replaced my cable, but pointed out that the last time John changed his tire, it didn't seat properly and it's worn the sidewall a bit. The said it MIGHT blow, or it might not. So helpful! Guess we'll find out, won't we? Then we went and had dinner at Japan West, an excellent Japanese steak house (In Findlay! Go figure!). I had a combo of salmon, swordfish, and scallops, each with a different sauce. John had chicken. After dinner, we tried to get John a new cell phone - his got wet in the rain and isn't working. But the Verizon stand in the mall only sells to new customers - she was quite rude to us. Theory: they have absolutely crappy customer service because you're stuck with a two year contract and they don't seem worried about keeping customers after they squeeze out the two years. Then we went and saw Shrek - cute movie. Silly and sweet. Back at the hotel, I got some hot-tub time and we turned in. Tomorrow we're back on the road, heading west!
No rain today, despite ominous cloud cover. As we biked, we rode right out from under them into partly sunny skies! Haven't seen that in a while! Saw more farms, but also some forest preserve - first time we've seen large stands of trees in Ohio. We passed a park with an historic, restored farm house, with all of the outbuildings. Stopped to use the restrooms and look around. Also, passed an 1880 brick church that's for sale! Hmmm... We rode through Gilboa and stopped to take a picture of Stinky's bar - thought Steve and Michele would like that. At a farmer's market, we got supplies for a picnic, but we made it to Ottowa before lunch, so we'll save the picnic for later. Both Ottowa and Gilboa were founded in the 1830's, settled on land newly wrested from the Native Americans. They seem so depressed and poor - as far as I can tell, the only reason they're here is that they were along the railroad. Ottowa has some lovely little Victorian homes, and a factory. We're staying at the Lee Bell Motel, a dinky motor lodge - the only accomodations in town. The next place is thirty-five miles away - not sure we could make it today. The menu for Henry's, posted on a board in the motel office, looked enticing, so we biked there for lunch. But they'd changed their menu, and it was crowded and the food was mediocre. Similar to a Benigan's type place. We biked back to the Lee Bell and took a nap. I'm amazed how exhausted we are from such a short day of biking. We had a strong head-wind the whole way - gusting up to 25 mph, and I suppose that really takes it out of you. Wind is like invisible hills. John composed what I am sure is the first ever Irish song about biking in Ohio. He sang happily about biking into the wind, and I huffed and puffed and pedaled. Crazy man. After our nap, we went for a walk all over town and waved at people. The sign outside the elementary school read, "He who expects nothing is never disappointed." Perhaps the public education system should avoid irony. We had dinner at Burger King and bought some playing cards. Back in our room, we played rummy. I called my friend, Gemma and had a wonderful talk with her - catching up and hearing her voice. Tomorrow, we're aiming for Paulding, Ohio, where we'll meet up with the Adventure Cycling maps. Then the day after that should be our last day in Ohio. Indiana, here we come!
We're still biking into a head-wind, but despite weather channel predictions, we dodged rain for another day. In fact, the skies were gorgeous. We rode through Glandorf, Ohio, a tiny town with a gargantuan, towering steeple on the Catholic Church and a large garden grotto. More wind, more wind, more wind... slammed by gusts, grateful for every stand of trees in this wide, flat, empty farmland.  In Grover Hill, we stopped in a filthy, cluttered filling station and convenience store, because a sign in the window advertised Skin So Soft, the Avon bug repellent that works so well. Also, needed to use the bathroom. I think it was worse than an outhouse, though. Worse than an all guy garage bathroom. Icky. The woman went digging in boxes for the Skin So Soft, and was gone for a long time. When she finally emerged, she produced a dusty bottle and sold it to me for $2 off. We thought we'd stop in Haviland for a picnic lunch, but as we biked through town, everything on main street was boarded up, no little parks or any benches, and the sky was looking darker. We got to where we needed to turn north for Paulding, and decided to race the rain - no place to stop for shelter, so we biked with all our might. Now with the wind behind us, smooth pavement under our tires, and not a car as far as we could see, we flew down the road at 20 mph! What an absolute rush! Effortless! Exhilerating! We biked into town and turned left - a few doors down and we were in the driveway of the Bittersweet Inn - just as big rain drops began to splat around us. We made it! Then we decided to unload our packs and bike the mile into town for lunch at the Red Owl Inn. Got a bit rained on , but not much. After a typical burger lunch, we stopped at the mini-mart to stock up for dinner and breakfast - the Bittersweet is just an inn, not a B&B. We took leisurely baths, read lots of magazines, and played scrabble on the porch, watching the sun set in the moody Ohio sky. I've thought a lot about porches on our trip through Ohio. We're so vulnerable to the elements out here. And there really is nothing but private property as far as we can see - no place to rest or take shelter except people's houses or barns or garages. But our culture does not welcome the wanderer  - signs everywhere say, "DO NOT ENTER" "PRIVATE PROPERTY" "NO TRESPASSING" "KEEP OUT" "TRESPASSERS WILL BE PROSECUTED TO THE FULL EXTENT OF THE LAW." What is everyone so afraid of? No one invites the stranger to come and sit, rest and chat. The isolation feels like a prison. I expected to find communities, see gathering places, encounter those places where everyone knows everyone. Instead, we've seen so much empty, disconnected, abandoned, fenced off space. I suppose I'm not much of a typical American - the "rugged individualist." If I had a wide, wrap-around porch with rocking chairs and hanging flower baskets, I'd sit on it and wave to all who went by. I'd beckon to the walkers, the bikers, or any wayfarer, offer a glass of water, or a snack or something. Where are you headed? Where are you from? I'm the one travelling, but I find myself asking all the questions whenever we find people. Whatcha farming? When was the town founded? Who built this old farmhouse? Has it been in your family? Well, so we pass porch after porch, watch the looming sky and move on - not a welcome mat in sight. Didn't Jesus say something like, "the fox has his den and the bird has his nest, but the son of man has no place to rest his head?" I suppose this is just another part of exploring our homelessness. We realize how much space everyone has and refuses to share. We've stood under a few porches when rain got to be too much - but we always felt like we'd have to move along quickly if anyone showed up - shot-gun in hand, sicing a pack of dogs on us, shouting, "Get off my property."
Wen we turned west on Monroeville Road, we biked right out from under the rain and the wind was mostly at our backs. What a lovely welcome to another state. We came into Monroeville, the first town on the Adventure Cycling maps through which we're passing, and everyone was so friendly and greeted us warmly. People actually waved from their porches! Seems they really like bikers, here. We had a nice lunch at the Village cafe where we realized that we'd crossed a time zone and gained an hour! The only problem is that we are soaked to the bones and it's 60 degrees - quite chilly when wet. Can't seem to get warm. But the ham and beans were delicious. After lunch, the rain stopped altogether, but the wind shifted and biking was harder. In Hoagland, I took a pitstop at an elementary school. The office lady even let me use the grown-up bathroom. The kids had a good time staring at the weird biker lady. Too bad it wasn't Friday - we missed beach dress-up day! Three miles before the hotel, we passed a Methodist church firing up oil-drum barbecues for a chicken dinner. But by the time we reached the Country Inn Motel, we decided we wouldn't be heading back down the road. We're tired and sore, and this place, although technically with an address of Middletown, IN, has no town in sight and is on a large, divided highway. It'd be difficult to bike down and back. I kind of wish we'd gone, but know how tired and sore we are. We can only do so much in a day. This place is pretty disgusting - dusty, smoky and mildewed, but it's dry and cheap. We ordered delivery and watched TV. Tomorrow there should be a Comfort Inn with a pool and laundry. Oh, the excitement never ceases! THE SERMON - INDIANA You know, you begin to think metaphorically when you're pushing a bike uphill in a cold rain, leaning into a 10 mph head-wind, drenched and muddy, frozen stiff, chased by dogs, chased by people off of their porches when you try to shelter from hail and lightening, nothing anywhere as far as you can see and no where to go to the bathroom except wide open corn fields that this early in the year provide privacy for your ankles. You think, over and over again like a mantra, THIS IS HELL. And heaven? Heaven would be a flushing toilet with a door. A towel. Chocolate cake. Seeing your mom. Clean underwear. Just these things - any one of them, would be just like heaven. At least that's what I do. Then I think WHY am I doing this?! I could go back to Maryland any time and end the torment - no more rain or dogs or wind or dirt. Oh yes, I went on this trip partly to better understand the true meaning of life, to disconnect myself from the material world and my many possessions, from the things of "this world," and to find out what is truly most essential in life. Toilet paper comes to mind. Seriously, I realize all my thoughts are about my physical, personal circumstances and really have little to do with heaven and hell as I believe them to exist (when I take the time to think about them). I believe true hell is separation from God, true heaven - his presence. I realize what makes this rain and cold and wind and hills hellish (besides being thoroughly unpleasant) is that they trap my mind and separate me from a focus on finding God. I came out here to minimize distractions, and find that they grow like corn. I bet the prophets in the wilderness spent a lot of time thinking, "Wow, it's hot. And I'm hungry. Nothing but sand as far as the eye can see." They probably wrote lots of poems about stinky sand in between the wonderful epiphanies and visions. So truly, it is a hellish trip when I can't get my mind off of my bike-seat rash, or when I focus all of my attention on what cable channels our latest hotel offers. When I am reduced to the avoidance of personal discomfort and the pursuit of material relief, I get depressed and discouraged, disillusioned and lost. So the trip west, away from my possessions also needs to be a trip inward and outward spiritually - reaching beyond wherever I am, to continue searching, to continue yearning for more. "As the hart panteth after brooks So my soul panteth after thee, O God. My soul thirsteth for God, for the living God; When shall I come and appear before God?  My tears have been my meat day and night... Deep calleth unto deep at the noise of thy waterspouts; All thy waves and thy billows are gone over me. Yet the Lord will command his lovingkindness in the daytime,  In the night his song shall be with me... Why art thou cast down, O my soul? And why art thou disquieted within me? Hope thou in God; for I shall yet praise him,  Who is the health of my countenance, and my God." (Psalm 42)
As we neared Huntington - about five miles out of town, The wind suddenly changed direction, whipping around to blow in our faces. It changed to a buffet, it sounded as if the trees were being beaten, and the clouds in front of us was an angry dark blue. We stopped in front of a farm house, wondering if we should seek shelter, and in answer the sky cracked and lit up with massive lightning and thunder. We scurried onto the porch. It looks like it's a new house, not occupied yet, and still a little under construction. We got comfortable and waited. First the trees began bending over, then the world darkened. The rain began, and soon was gushing. Pea-sized hail pelted the ground. Lightning and thunder traded back and forth. It certainly was nice to be under a porch - this was definitely not something to bike in. We leaned against the house and felt hemmed in by the wall of water falling - as it tapered to a shower, we watched birds and squirrels come out and explore. Then just as the rain slowed to a sprinkle, a young man pulled up in a pick-up truck. We said, "Howdy! Thought we'd hide under your porch while the storm passed. Hope you don't mind. We even got some hail!" He responded with a grunt. He seemed quite grumpy and said nothing, just went into the house. We shuffled off the porch into the rain.  We had to leave the bike map to go into Huntington. Of course, the road we'd chosen started out as gravel - ominous. But we decided to give it a chance, and it soon became pavement. Riverside Road is quite a lovely ride into town. We stopped at a Mexican restaurant for lunch and had quite delicious tacos, burritos, and corn fries. They carded me! I thought that was quite funny.  We biked on to the hotel - clean, nice, large, BIG SIGH IF RELIEF! The woman at the front desk gave us a ride to the library, because the town's big enough to be too big for walking, and small enough to be too small for cabs. Her mother works at the library, so she didn't mind swinging by there. We looked online for places to stay in Indiana. Then we walked back - lots of huge victorian houses in varying states of preservation, dilapidation, and repair. We did our laundry and watched T.V., ordered dinner from a delivery place. It's hard to explain - I know this day doesn't seem too much different from the others, but I started having one of my anxiety attacks. I get stuck in a thought cycle that leaves me panicked, I get a headache, have trouble breathing and nausea. My thoughts we like this - "What are we doing? This trip is pointless. A three month waste of time. We're not doing anything worthwhile, we're just spending thousands of dollars to piddle around on bikes - exhaust ourselves, eat horribly, see no one, accomplish nothing. This is not fun. This is not building our relationship. I'm not writing. We're not even going to make it across country. So what are we doing? I want to go home NOW. I want to see everyone and stop wasting time and money just to be miserable and lonely. I'm sick of this - different motel, different restaurant, different strangers, having to explain over and over again this stupid, crazy thing we're doing." So I got myself totally freaked out, depressed, and panicked. Usually when this happens, I can't sleep - but at least biking does one thing - I have very little trouble with insomnia. Let's just say I ended this day NOT A HAPPY CAMPER.
And we're both SICK nigh unto death of riding in crappy weather! But I think both our moods greatly improved from a good night's sleep, and a great conversation. We're not sure what we'll do after Chicago - I can't even force my mind to consider continuing - but at least we feel more of a prospect of enjoying the remainder of the journey.  Today we're riding along route 24, a divided highway that runs about 10 miles south of the Adventure Cycling route. There's much less to see while riding, but all of the towns and hotels are along 24. They're still calling for rain and windchills in the 30's! So we don't feel much like camping along the bike route. This part of Indiana, along the Little Wabash  and Wabash River is quite hilly, forested and pretty. We stopped at the Hoosier Pride Caf in the town of Wabash for lunch. A family at the table next to us listened with awe and wonder to their grown son describe the fabled Krispy Kreme donuts. He'd been to a far away land where they had some, and they could barely believe such a miracle as HOT FRESH NOW. We sat and salivated. Then the rain began. We waited until it tapered off somewhat, then got back on the road. Still, we were drenched in a short time, and so cold. After Wabash, we left main route 20 on old County Road 24 and we wove along the Wabash between farms and factories, each with it's own unique smell. The rain stopped for a little while, long enough to dry out. As we entered Peru, we needed a bathroom badly. First we passed a really ugly campground, no luck there. Farther on we stopped at a sparsely stocked convenience store and bait shop - the woman claimed that the restroom was out of order, but she seemed to not like us much. Peru was not shaping up to much. Finally we stopped at a beverage store, again, no luck, but we were right next to a little movie theater. EVERYONE in town must've been at the movies - a rainy Saturday - so we went and used their bathrooms. John called the Rosewood Manor B&B for directions. We had no idea what to expect - after campgrounds and bait-shops, this place could call anything a B&B. Things began to look up as we entered the historic downtown - fixed up old houses, tree-lined streets, a ton of old churches, a stately courthouse - JIM"S BOOKS & BEANS, a coffee and used book shop - we're in HEAVEN! Then we turned down a side street and up the driveway of the Rosewood Manor. What a gorgeous sight! Two  mansions  sit across a driveway from each other, late 1800 buildings, surround by lush landscaping. We arrived just as everyone was checking in, so we got to look around a bit while we waited. Stained-glass windows on the 2nd and 3rd levels flood the entry and curving staircase with richly colored light. The sitting room is paneled and lined with inset book shelves behind glass doors. There's a cozy fireplace, too, appropriate for an unseasonably chilly day. The dining room is in one of the towers, so it's round with lots of cubby holes set into the walls. The butler's pantry is set up with a nice selection of coffee, tea and sodas. There are two other main floor rooms that seem to be set up for a meeting. In the hall, antique store cabinets display a whimsical collection of old tows and books and needlepoint samplers. Locally made artwork and furniture also fill the hall, all for sale. Our room is in the Carriage house, one of the newly renovated outbuildings. It's quite large, with a monstrous whirlpool tub, all our own. The bed linens are luxurious brocade, the room is quiet and secluded. Now THIS is fun. We bathed and changed and walked back down the street to the book shop. It started to pour again just as we arrived. So we had a wonderful afternoon waiting out the rain and talking to the owners. John got a soda and lemon crunch pie, I had vanilla decaf coffee and strawberry rhubarb pie. We savored the books, as well. Jim and his father-in-law were busy making a racket, building book shelves. Tawnya ran the coffee counter, and talked to a table full of locals. A tornado watch came over the radio - one was spotted touching down five miles north of here, near where Jim and Tawnya's daughter was hanging out. She didn't seem too concerned, simply made a phone call to make sure she stayed put. I bought a collection of short stories by Flannery O'Conner and an old, tiny edition of Longfellow's Tales of a Wayside Inn. Thought it seemed appropriate for a journey.  When the rain stopped, we headed back down the street and spotted a Circus Museum. We hopped under their awning just as the rain began again, and discovered that the place was closed today. So we sat on the steps and waited. I read the poem out loud to John - it's quite romantic and fun. The rain slowed, so we began walking towards the Grant's Bar & Grill, which had been recommended for dinner, but we only made it partway, before we were getting drenched, so we ducked under someone's porch. No one greeted us or chased us away, so we stood and read some more. Finally, we made it to dinner only slightly soggy, and had a fine dinner of real yuppy food! Portabello mushrooms and such. After dinner, we strolled back to the B&B. A full rainbow glowed against the navy blue clouds, wrapping the thin spike of a church steeple. Of course we didn't have the camera. So we just soaked up the scene with our minds - then walked on. As we reached the church, we read the sign out front - "It takes both sunshine and rain to make rainbows." So how did the Lutherans manage to arrange that confluence of natural occurances? Wow! We sat in the cozy sitting room, reading and sipping tea, and talked to the other guests as they came and went. There's a large group of folks here from California - come to Peru to find their roots. It's a bit of a family reunion. One man got quite animated talking to John about computers. He's been in the field since 1966, and hates it. He lives in Los Angeles and hates cities. Hmmm!  All in all, this has been a lovely day - the weather has not improved, but at least we met people and had some adventures, and get to stay in this lovely place. And besides, a book store fixes everything!
After breakfast, we walked to the Anglican church to find out what Mattins are. We arrived a few minutes late, and were the only attendees. The priests stood in front of the altar and prayed - chanting, reading scriptures, and singing. I'm sure we were supposed to stand and kneel at certain times, and read along, but we had no idea what to do when, so we watched. Afterwards, one priest came to talk to us. He was very kind, and once he ascertained that we were TOTAL heathens (not anglican or episcopalian) he invited us to stay for mass and to come forward and receive a blessing during the eucharist. That's the polite way of informing us that we are not to take communion. Turns out this berobed, bearded man straight out of medieval times is from Oxon Hill MD. Small world! We stayed another hour - mass had a few more attendees - all old women. But at least this time we could follow their lead and participate in the service.  So by the time we got on the road, it was after 11 a.m., and we only got in 10 miles of biking before the rain started again. It had been sunny all morning. Oh well. We stopped for lunch at Fazoli's in Logansport. The road was exceptionally crappy through that town, and coming into town there had been some treacherous, shoulderless, winding hills. So we sat in the restaurant and rested, and watched the rain come down in sheets, and ate breadsticks. The hills here are such a surprise, and the forests. Not how I always pictured Indiana.  After lunch, the road improved greatly past Logansport. We went through the tiny towns of Burnettsville and Idaville. Idaville had a tall grain silo that we could see from miles away. I pretended it was a high-rise apartment building and felt so comforted. Weird! I suppose I'm more freaked out by the sparse population than I realized. I found the idea of hundreds of people living on top of each other so reassuring.  We stopped in Burnettsville for a snack. Then we got to Monticello mostly dry - it had stopped raining a while back. But we were tired and sore. We're staying at the Victoria B&B, but we're the only people here tonight, so no other guests to chat with. We walked a mile or so up the road to find dinner - not much open on a Sunday night. We ate at the Taco Bell - seems to be THE hang-out place. Lots of teens there, and one old couple had a 10 pak of tacos and sat reading novels at a table beside us.  We went to the grocery store and stocked up on camp food. It's been a week since we took a day off from biking, so we might need one soon, But we're only two days away from where we'll quit and rent a truck to drive into Chicago. I'd like to keep going if we can. Then we get a whole week off! Or forever! Although we've heard about an historic amusement park here in Monticello that might also be fun to check out. So we'll see how we feel in the morning. Thus ends week four on the road!

While the weather IS gorgeous to look at, we're fighting a steady headwind, and the road surface is deteriorating. It's a bumpy, exhausting ride. But the road along Lake Shafer towards Monon has some lovely views. The like is lined with woods and vacation cabins - lots of campers and fishermen. We biked along with another couple for a while. They're locals, and bike regularly.  When we arrived in Monon, the town was getting all gussied up for their big Food Fest - NEXT weekend. We miss all the good stuff. The water tower was being sheathed with drop cloth - suppose it was about to receive a new coat of paint. We had lunch at La Macarena - very authentic, spicy, and good. Fresh salsa, guacamole, corn tortillas, and chorizo. Delicious!  Once back on the road, we discovered that the land west of Lake Shafer is the fabled flat midwest - not a ripple in the land for miles around. We had another bad run-in with dogs - two blood hounds and a chihuahua. Actually, the Chihuahuas are funny - they bark so ferociously and run right past our bikes. Speedy little rat-dogs! When we turned west on the road that would take us into Rensselaer, I posited that these wide open spaces with no one around for miles and miles were creepy - that living in the country would be scary. John disagreed - he thought that the city was much scarier - that people in the country were so much more friendly and trustworthy. I said, no way - in the city, there were lots of people, and you could call the police if something happened. Out here, some nutso could do terrible things and there was no accountability. John was just saying how it's better to have LESS people, because there're less people to do terrible things, when a blue and white van sped by us and he screamed in pain and anger. A million thoughts ran through my head - foremost I was convinced the van had hit John, and I tried in vain to see the license plate before turning to see what they had done. It had to have been going over fifty mph. I turned, and John had stopped and was holding his head. He said they'd thrown something at him and it had hit him in the back of the head. I looked, and sure enough there was a curved dent on his helmet, and a curved cut on his scalp. Whatever they'd thrown had managed to find the spot just below where his helmet would have protected him. I looked around on the ground and found a AA battery - that was the most likely suspect - the curve in the helmet and on his head we just the size of the battery's end. We were so angry and shaken, but there was just nothing we could think of to do about it. John felt okay to keep biking. So we continued on, but I cried, frustrated and scared. I certainly did not enjoy being right in this discussion. In a few miles we came to an abandoned old school building - two stories, brick, ivy covered. The flag was still flying beside it, faded and tattered. John wanted a photo, so we stopped. An old man rushed out to chat. He said, "Are you taking pictures of my school?" He was quite hospitable. He owns the land and the building, and lives in a trailer out back. It was built in 1929 and housed the primary school for the township of Hanging Gardens until 1965. Then his father bought it and used it for his non-denominational church until 1985. After the church disbanded, the building was used for storage until it fell so far into disrepair that it become structurally unsafe - now it's boarded up, and he must keep trespassers out for their own good. After his father died and he retired, he moved into the trailer that had been the parsonage, and has lived there ever since. His name is John Eaton, and after being stationed in Germany in the military as a young man, he became a school teacher. He taught in several different states and in a DOD school near Darmstadt, Germany. What a small world - I attended the DOD school in Berlin for five years. He invited us to have a snack or a drink - he even invited us to stay with him, and told us stories about the bikers and hikers he's rescued in various states of breakdown and exhaustion. We thanked him, but decided to move on, because Rensselaer was only eight miles away, and the next day would be a long one.  We continued on and stopped at a church to use the bathroom. Looks like they have a cool coffee house on Friday nights, but of course we're here on a Monday. We called The White House B&B to see if they had a room available. Turns out that they hadn't planned on taking any guests because their daughter was due to have her baby any minute - in fact, she'd been in labor all weekend and was now 2 cm dialated. But they told us to come anyway - they'd love to have us, they just might need to leave at any time. They are a very nice couple - Tim & Beth Ryan. She's a psychologist and he's a professor at the local college - St. Joseph's. It's an exquisite house, richly decorated. We got all settled in and then chatted with Tim and Beth for a while. Tim was furious when he heard what had happened to John. He almost yelled at us for not having called the police. I said, "But I didn't get the license plate number. What good would it have done?" "They wouldn't need the license plate number - there wouldn't be that many blue vans on that road." So I see a flaw in my city-is-better theory. I think Tim just couldn't believe anyone in his county would do such a thing. We met their neurotic Dalmatian - they kept it locked in the garage while they were gone, because it's been scared of strangers ever since it was beaten by a plumber. I suppose Tim shouldn't be so shocked - evil lurks in the hearts of men everywhere (okay, okay, and women, too.) Poor doggy. We petted her, but she shivered and seemed really nervous. St. Joseph's is a catholic college that offers accredited degrees in many subjects, with a strong emphasis in all majors on the study of human history and civilization.
