A solid third of their coursework, no matter what their major is, is devoted to a strict order of classes in history, culture, and social science. We walked over and had dinner at Devon's Family restaurant, then walked around campus - lovely lawns and old buildings. After a long soak in the whirlpool tub back at the B&B, we called it a night.
Tim & Beth weren't around, so we went and had breakfast at Devon's. Then we biked to the library and got some internet time. This library is brand new, very clean and nice, and hyper-controlling about their computers. We had to turn in our driver's licenses. The library lady took our license and picked out a plastic baggy marked for our computer. She pulled out the mouse ball, dropped in the license, and walked over to the computers. She installed the ball and left us to ponder the menacing posters surrounding the computer - listing all of the things we were NOT TO DO on the internet. SCARY.  After that we explored the Carnegie Center, a lovely old building that had been the library for many years until it was quite run down. So the library moved, and this was renovated and converted into an arts center. We enjoyed looking at the woodwork and stained glass. They did a great job! We had a snack on the court house lawn - the building is in the center of the town's main square. A woman had a Chicago-style hot dog stand. Delicious! Also, there was a bakery. We went back to the room and read for a while, bathed and napped. For dinner, we decided to bike back to the square and try out the City Office & Pub - it was quite a lively place for a Tuesday. So that was our day off. Tomorrow, we have 50 miles of biking, and then we should be in Chicago!  Here's a line from Longfellow - helpful to keep in mind as we struggle against the yucky weather. "The farmers grew impatient, but a few  Confessed their error and would not complain, For after all, the best thing one can do  When it is raining is to let it rain."
The weather is gorgeous today, not a cloud in the sky, not too hot, AND (drum-roll please...) a 10mph TAIL WIND! The road is flat as a pancake. Who could ask for anything better? We stopped for a rest in front of the place I call "The Curious Farm" - a horse, two ponies, cows, geese, a cat, and a child in the farmhouse window all stared at us! It was quite funny - everything just stopped and peeked - through fence rails, over grass clumps, through curtains. The cat even sauntered down the driveway and up onto a concrete slab to have a better view. We waved at the child, but he just ducked below the sill. Curiouser and curiouser. A few miles before the border with Illinois, the road suddenly became quite good. New asphalt, new lines, and wide shoulders. Then at the state line, it was like a wall - the Illinois side of the road wasn't marked and was chunky, dilapidated asphalt. We thought it was quite funny that Indiana had gone to all the trouble to make its roads look good next to Illinois. This was the middle of nowhere - who cares? And Indiana's roads had been so bad most of the way. Very funny. We biked through more and more corn fields - a red wing black bird even got bold enough to dive-bomb my helmet. Wishes he were a chihuahua. In Beaverville, a little town with two roads of houses and a grain mill, we encountered the odd sight of a massive catholic cathedral - St. Mary's Church, currently under renovation, the Romanesque revival building with Munich style stained glass windows depicting the life of Mary was built at the turn of the century. It has an impressive dome, and the opalescent glass is quite striking. We spent some time inside and had a snack on the front steps. It was strange, though, everryone I said "Hello," too, just stared as if I  was from Mars. When we got into the Kankakee metro area, we encountered sprawling suburbs and busy, city-style streets. Ah, Urbanity! The first township through which we passed was called Aroma Park, which John found very funny. They had a smiley face on their water tower, and odd little road signs and shop signs - trying to be a quaint small-townish community. Hooray for them. We got into the city way too early - our truck wasn't supposed to be available until 5 p.m., and it was only two. We stopped at a fast food place called "Poor Boys" and basked in the racial diversity - lots of people, lots of colors. I wonder how hard it will be to adjust to the whiteness of Ireland. I am so glad we were raised in diverse cultures. I'd rather be used to "otherness," and find "monoculture" strange than vice-versa. Anyway, we decided, after a long rest, and trying something called "Italian style beef" which seemed to mean "salty," to bike on up to the Enterprise place. We were at the end of our energy - it'd been a long ride, despite the good conditions, and the city streets were harrowing. But we made it to the place and collapsed. And lo and behold - they had a truck ready early. Yay! So we dumped the bikes and gear in the back and got on the road - north to Chicago! Oh, what a feeling! We got to Saundra's, tired, hungry, dirty, weary of soul. We went and got some dinner then came back and collapsed, in the company of our friends and their cats. As far as I'm concerned, I'm never leaving.


But John is ready to go.  So we packed up the extra clothes we'd bought here in Chicago - tennis shoes, jeans, sweaters - and mailed them home. Then we returned the truck to an Enterprise office north of the city, in Northbrook, and loaded up the bikes. And we're off again. We had lunch at a Shaky's-style place called Barnaby's, full of kids. I suppose they're having end of school parties. Then we biked north along a paved trail running along the power lines. The hum is a little scary. But at least we're avoiding traffic, which we can hear through the brush. When the trail ended, we headed east towards Lake Michigan through a gorgeous neighborhood of mansions on wooded lots, called Lake Bluff. We crossed a little bridge in the woods where an artist from Maine had her easle set up - she was painting a picture of some tree trunks, because of the contrast of lights and darks. An old gentleman from Lake Forest, another neighborhood, was talking to her. We stopped to chat for a minute, and also met a friendly dog. (Surprise, surprise.)  We picked up another trail, this time crushed limestone, that headed north again. Now the trail passes right through neighborhoods and towns - these are old suburbs of Chicago, one after another. We passed the Great Lakes Naval training base. It was run-down, seedy and disgusting. I was surprised at the dilapidation - I would have thought that they'd try to maintain somewhat of a clean image for the public. But the buildings are old and ugly, the train station liked positively third world, and there was broken glass and discarded underwear on the trail. We also passed a jogging group of new recruits, being yelled at and driven to red-faced exhaustion. I think we all exchanged puzzled looks, asking each other, "Why on earth are you doing THAT?!" I suppose biking across country doesn't make much sense either. Next we passed through North Chicago, an exclusively black neighborhood. Then Waukegan, all Hispanic, then Beach Park, all white - with Hispanic people building the new homes. I was surprised at the level of segregation. Race relations must be fun, here. I suppose at home the same sort of thing happens, I just never noticed it. The neighborhoods we've lived in have always been mixed - more socioeconomic segregation than racial. But P.G. county has been unique, I suppose, and is well on it's way to becoming wholly black, with the steady white flight. More important to us, though, was that as we passed through the rainbow of neighborhoods, we did not pass a single place to use the bathroom or to eat. All houses, rolling on and on. In Zion we left the trail and headed towards the lake in search of someplace to pit-stop. Nothing, nothing, nothing. We're exhausted, hungry, shaky, and having trouble steering. We spotted the department of health office. I thought, 4:30 on a Wednesday, they have to be open. And there were cars in the parking lot. But NO - not open. Next door was a "rehab and care center," an alarm sounded when I entered. The woman at the front desk was kind enough to let me use the bathroom, after explaining the elaborate ritual for retrieving the hidden key. The staff was entirely young black people, caring for a bunch of senile, smelly old white people. I think I would have some major resentment issues with that situation. I hope they are very well paid, but I doubt it.  Once back on the bike trail, we were still looking for food. Still nothing. Another mile, and we're in WISCONSIN! The first person to pass us said, "Hello!" and we realized how long it had been since someone had greeted us in return, instead of scowling at us suspiciously. Also, we were greeted by a swarm of bionic mosquitoes. OUCH! We stopped so John could call the hotel and get directions - good thing, too, because Mapquest was wrong again. It'll be five or six more miles than we thought. I frantically slathered on some Skin-So-Soft, and we kept moving. We came to route 165 and turned west, biking through Pleasant Prairie - the town's name ironically painted in happy colors on the water tower, in the midst of an ocean of factories and warehouses belching smoke into the gray air. Pleasant indeed. We passed the Jelly Belly jelly bean factory, but they didn't look open for dinner. Still no food! We passed through more neighborhoods, then arrived at the interstate, off of which towered the Radisson Hotel!! Heaven! We checked into a lovely room and had a satisfying dinner in their restaurant, sat in the hot tub for a while, and then went to bed. So we survived getting back on the road. I certainly hope Wisconsin isn't wall to wall factories and mosquitoes, though. If so, then I'm not leaving the Radisson
The B&B turned out to be right across the street from the library - a nice victorian with gorgeous gardens and bird feeders of all kinds. The owner, Sandy Collins, gave us great books on B&B's in Wisconsin, bike trails, scenic roads, etc. Also, she told us about the Taste of Waterford festival starting tonight at the St. Thomas Aquinas Church. We got cleaned up and walked over there for hot dogs and ribs and cream puffs. There was live country music and crafts and a garden show, too. The beer tent was already lively early in the evening. The sky had turned stormy by now, but it never rained on us. So with a lovely ride through the countryside, friendly people, and good food, this turned out to be quite a wonderful day!
We had hoped to find more fun festivals and such going on over the weekend - it's Friday today. But it doesn't look like anything is going on near up until Sunday. We biked west on a winding road through dairy farms and neighborhoods. Just outside of Waterford we came across a petting farm, loaded with buses and elementary kids. I begged John to let us stop, and he didn't mind. Everyone asked about our trip, and I had a wonderful time petting goats and chicks and ducklings and a baby cow named nutmeg. They had turkeys and sheep and lamas and everything. It was a little sad, though. I'm not sure being handled by all these people is really best for the animals - some seemed quite distressed by the crowds of pawing kids. They even had a cow tied up so the kids could milk her, and they all screamed in disgust when she peed. Where  else was she supposed to go? I thought it seemed horrible. Still, I scratched a donkey behind the ears for a while when the kids were elsewhere, and he seemed to really like that.  We biked on and got the East Troy. Our plan was to stop and get picnic supplies and check out the trolley museum in town. But we biked all the way through town without seeing any markets, trollies, or signs. Nothing but houses - guess we were on the wrong road. We stopped on the outskirts of town and asked at a nursing home where we might find a market. They directed us - and we found it after surviving a huge rollercoaster hill. We stocked up for a picnic then found a much flatter route back to our road. We stopped a few miles down the road in Troy Center, a quaint little township. We ate our lunch on the steps of an historic little Methodist chapel. After Troy Center, the road is not longer maintained by the state or county. There's no description of it on our lovely bike map. So for three miles we road over an unmarked, narrow ribbon of road, with the steepest, breakneck hills we've done so far. Cars and trucks came tearing over the hills much faster than the 35 mph speed limit. I watched a van nearly squash John. The driver screached to a halt right behind him and followed close behind until they crested the hill. Quite scary! Not a safe road at all. This was the basin for Lake Lulu, with a state park and fishing area. We survived, though, and the down-hills WERE fun, if a little dizzying. The drops were so steep that as you'd come over the top of the hill, you couldn't see the road surface down the next side until you were flying down it. Wheee! Then we came into Eagle, where we'd seen another B&B listed that sounded interesting. It was only 2:30, and check in was 4 p.m. again. So we looked around town for something to do, but Eagle is quite dead. Every sho and building on main street is closed and for sale. I went into the bar to use the restroom - smoky, blaring television, video gambling machines squawking, all men drinking. Not a place that I feel like hanging out in - so we decide to find the B&B and hope they'll let us in early.  We biked a mile out of downtown over hills and torn-up, striated pavement, through construction and traffic cones to the B&B. It's an old-style replica of an 1847 Inn built nearby. It's not very landscaped, so no little garden to sit in, and no comfy chairs on the porch. We ring the bell, and the cleaning lady answers, quite flustered by our presence. She informs us that the proprietor won't be back until 4 p.m,, so we'll have to come back then. We explain that we're on bikes and that we didn't see anywhere to wait in town - she says we'll have to find somewhere. How rude! Obviously clueless about what we meant by ON BIKES. We asked her if there was a library in town, or anywhere else she might suggest, and she gives us directions to a library and shuts the door. So we unload our stuff and leave it in the grass, then bike back through the construction and hills into town.  There we discover that the "library" to which we have been sent is an historical research library only, open on Saturday mornings. It's friday. We stand there, stunned by the insensitivity and stupidity of the cleaning woman, then biked around town again in hopes of finding ANYTHING to do. Nope. So we bike BACK and sat on the floor of the porch and waited for the proprietor, not daring to knock on the door again.  Reine Herriges, the owner, showed up at 4 and was very gracious and understanding about our bike situation. She helped us bring in our stuff, showed us where the root beers are kept, and showed us where we could store our bikes out of the weather. She also directed us down the road in the other direction to a place called Old World Wisconsin - why the cleaning lady had never heard of it I can't imagine - where they have a recreated 1800's farming village and a Friday night fish fry in the historic round barn. After getting all cleaned up, we biked over for dinner, and enjoyed a lively evening with all the fried fish, roasted chicken, german potato salad, applesauce, cole slaw, pumpernickel, and potato pancakes we could eat. What fun! Also, there was apple streudel for dessert. The 1.5 mile ride to and from the B&B was quite lovely, too. The road wound through hushed pine forest, with the setting sun slanting through the columnar trees.  Back at the ranch, we talked to our parents and played some rummy in the game room. Also, we were introduced to the other guests as they came and went - Reine enjoys telling people how crazy we are. We met a honeymooning couple, too. So despite the dead town and dumb lady, this was another lovely day!
We took off and bought some salami at the fuel station and minimart in town - the maps don't show anywhere to eat for quite a ways. We headed north and west again towards Sullivan where we planned on picking up the Glacial Drummand Bike Trail. The wind was strong, blowing against our sides, and sometimes in our faces, but it's another gorgeous, sunny day. Kettle Moraine State Forest is a strange, caldera-like valley rimmed with forested hills and filled with deep fens, laced with rusty brown creeks - named things like "Scuppernong" and "Mud."  In Sullivan, we discovered quite a nice little town with a few diners, so we had lunch there, then bought trail passes at the grocer's. He's a talkative fellow who liked telling jokes about dumb Texans. We got on the trail - it's a rail to trail, covered in crushed limestone, flat, straight, and wooded. It's sheltered from the wind here, but tons of BUGS and nothing interesting to look at. BORING! So we left the trail after 8 miles, and biked the main road into Jefferson - still not overly exciting, but much faster on pavement. There was a huge hill on the edge of town crowned by a massive Catholic church and a Franciscan home for the elderly and developmentally challenged. A wending was under way at the church, with a horse and carriage outside. We got to the Rodeway Inn and collapsed, did our laundry, went for Chinese food across the street. The food was very good, but there was only one server for all of the tables, so a cameraderie developed among us as we got him to bring all of our food, drinks and checks. A woman was there with two little girls, and she initiated a guessing game with them - taking turns pretending to be someone and answering yes and no questions until the others guessed. The girls chose to be characters from Powerpuff girls and Harry Potter and some horse books they were reading until the woman got frustrated and told them they had to be real people, not made up ones. Stupid lady. We went back to the hotel and vegetated for the rest of the evening. Nothing fun going on close by, and we're tired. Good night!
I cleaned off the clay at a hose behind the stage, then John and I got some bratwursts and looked at all of the pottery. John also tried something called Kettle Corn - popcorn that was a little salty, and a little sweet - very delicious. The owner of the B&B came over when he saw our bikes - he said, "Are you the bikers?" We said yes - and he introduced himself. He had seen me on stage, and was quite impressed at my bravery. Hah! So he told us to come by the B&B whenever, so when we'd explored as much as we wanted, we headed over. It's a lovely place, and our room is on the first floor - with a "garden" theme - tasteful and whimsical. Bill and Dotti are very nice and made us feel quite at home, as did their two standard poodles. After we got cleaned up and changed, we walked back down main street and had dinner. Then headed to bed. It was another lovely day - our new philosophy on this trip is working so well. I am having so much more fun, as we focus on the places through which we pass and getting to know the people along the way. The weather improving makes a big difference, too! So that's the end of our 6th week ## NO SUCH FILE ##

We packed up, loaded up, and headed west, then north-west into the city of Madison, WI. Bill had given us an excellent bike map of the county - the best map we've had yet. The roads are rated for the quality of their pavement and shoulder, how heavily trafficked they are, and rated for best bikeability. The weather today is bright and sunny without a breath of wind - it's getting hot!! We stopped for lunch at Country Corners in Hope, WI - it was a country music and dance bar - the dance floor was crowded for with tables for the lunch crowd. The sandwiches were good.  A little farther on in the suburbs of Madison, we had to detour because of construction. We stopped at a lemonade stand in someone's driveway and had a nice chat with the family. As we stood there, by rear-view mirror fell off, and Grandpa rushed into the garage to get some electrical tape. He fixed it up for me right away. They told us the best way back to our route, and where we could find the bike path that goes straight into the city. Madison is the most bike friendly city we've ever seen. It's a beautiful, green place with large lakes in the middle. The whole city is laced with bike paths, and most major roads have dedicated bike lanes. The University of Wisconsin is located in the center of town with 40,000 students attending, so it has a very academic feel, and I'm sure that partly explains the bike-friendly atmosphere. We passed the largest bike shop on the planet, Williamson Cycle,  right on the lake, and stopped to get some more maps. Then we wandered through the city streets until we found the Howard Johnson near campus. Once we were all checked into the room and getting cozy, John discovered (drum-roll please) ANOTHER BROKEN SPOKE! This time it's on the cassette side of the back wheel, so we can't replace it ourselves. When will we learn to check the bikes over while at the bike shop? We called a taxi and rode over to the shop with the wheel in hand. They fixed it quickly and then we taxied over to the Den at University Square for "59 minute photo finishing," because one hour just isn't fast enough. We dropped off our film and then walked back to the hotel, got cleaned up, walked back to pick up the pictures, and then down to an extremely friendly Thai restaurant with icky food. Then we went to the library for some internet time.  Back at the hotel, we went to bed and watched some TV. It turns out that while we're hiding all snuggly in the room, a severe weather warning was issued for this area. We turned off the TV and looked outside- Crashing lightning! Drenching rain! Rumbling thunder! And we're warm and dry and safe, ah, it feels so good to be inside looking out on that kind of weather - hoo doggy!
After passing through some quiet suburbs, we popped out into the country. We had to fight our way over a few steep hills (Beware Twin Valley Road!) and through a stead west wind, but not a drop of rain fell on us. Also, it's cooler than yesterday, and that's a relief. In Cross Plaines ("famous for friendliness") we stopped for lunch at Culver's, a Wisconsin chain of fast food restaurants that brag, "Home of the Butter Burger." I had to ask. "What is a Butter Burger?" The woman was very nice and said, "You're not from Wisconsin, are you?" She explained it, and it's not as evil as it sounds. They simply butter and grill the roll before inserting the burger. Sounds like Britain - "but you need the butter so the ham won't fall off the bread!" After lunch, we continued on up the Black Earth Creek valley, skirting steep hills on one side. The valley floor is a wide, flat flood plane covered from one end to the other and side to side with corn, corn, corn. It's the first time we've seen such a large stretch of land dedicated to one crop. In the town of Black Earth, we saw our first "How many miles to Wall Drug" sign. It's more than 700. Don't think we'll make it that far. Mazomanie turns out to be a quaint old town, very western looking, built in the 1850's when the railroad chose to put a stop here. I can picture gun-slingers facing off at high noon on main street. Our B&B, the Walking Iron, is what Mazomanie means in the Native American language - it was their name for the train. We mailed some more stuff home from the little post office in town, then went to the library (housed in the old train station). Then we had dinner at the Old Feed Mill, a beautifully renovated stone building, serving casually elegant food. The B&B is one of my favorites so far. Dave and Karisa are a young couple with three kids, and have restored the old house with meticulous attention to detail, perfectly balancing historic accuracy and modern luxury. The brass and marble bathroom, highest quality linens (scented), hand-painted relief molding... everything contributes to the royal feeling. There's even a small video and antique book library on the third floor in a cozy alcove. The yard is small, and the Black Earth Creek borders it. May favorite details: the classical designs on the tiles inside the tub area, the statues in the bathroom, the giant, soft, scented towels, the kohler toilet with a solid wood seat and a unique vertical brass pull for flushing, the dark rose and gold color scheme of our bedroom, the hand painted gold and champagne wall paper border (Karisa did them herself), the two person whirlpool tub with dual showerheads, and the antique photos of the families that have occupied the house through the years, with historical information posted alongside.  No rain tonight. I finished reading the Moviegoer by Walker Percy. Having some trouble going to sleep - I suppose my insomnia has caught up with me - gotten used to the biking. But that's okay, I can simply lie here and soak up my luxurious surroundings. Maybe I'll even take another bath. SIGH!
We biked into Spring Green and found the main street - a little sleepy, but there's some life to it. We had lunch at The Shed - it was quite crowded, so it must be "the place." John was getting that run-down, achy feeling, so we headed over to the B&B and checked in early so he could take a nap. This is getting to be a regular occurance - one or the other of us comes down with "bikitis," and we just can't stay awake or get out of bed. I took all of the laundry, packed it in two panniers, and walked to the laundromat. It's 90 degrees, I'm in my sweatshirt - the only clean article of clothing I have, and the place is not air conditioned. And the mosquitoes are HIDEOUS. I'm wishing I'd taken Jay up on his offer to use the washer at the house, but my bright idea was that this would be faster - wash two loads at once. So I sit there and chat with a scary man from Russia - he's here in Spring Green working in a glass factory - no family, no friends, in the middle of Wisconsin, and he seems almost angry that we have enough money to take off work and bike across country. So I slap mosquitoes and will the clothes to dry fast. A boy came in to get a soda, and when he came out, some other boys came along on skateboards. One of them tried to do a stunt and smashed into the side of a car. The soda boy and I snickered together.  I got the second bright idea of the day to walk back to the B&B without my shoes on. Hmmm - hot pavement, bare skin. I hopped and skipped all the way back, then discovered that I had burned a large blister on the ball of my foot. Major DUH! Perhaps I need my feet to be in healthy condition to pedal a bike day after day? Perhaps I could have thought of that? Oh well, hopefully it will heal quickly and not hinder the biking.  The B&B has three cats - Sparky, Roo and Tigger. They're talkative and friendly, but not overly snuggly. And we committed the cardinal sin of cat-dome, we chased them around the house going, "Come-ere, kitty kitty kitty!" I'm sure they'll never let us touch them, now.  We walked to dinner (I hobbled painfully) at the oldest restaurant in Wisconsin, The Post House. When we entered, a waitress was behind the counter, on the phone. She was crying and pleading desperately with whoever was on the other end. When we entered, she hung up and ran away. Another waitress came and seated us. Then who should come to our table, but the crying waitress! She was barely under control and very distracted. I asked if everything was alright, and she ignored me and insisted on taking our drink order. We waited and waited, and she never brought anything. Finally, the other waitress came and said that our waitress had had a problem and had left, and that she couldn't read her handwriting, so we re-ordered. How strange! I know everyone has problems, but it seems as though she didn't want anyone to notice while she had a complete breakdown in front of everyone. We weren't sure what to do. But life went on and she never reappeared. So we ate and then went to explore the famous cocktail lounge, designed in the fifties by a student of Frank Lloyd Wright's. It was quite a funky, cool place. I can see where all of the sixties and seventies fashions came from. But lo and behold - the crying waitress was right outside the lounge in the patio area, crying to a fellow employee. So once again, we felt like we were intruding on her privacy, by trying to have a nice dinner and sightsee! She ran away again. So we left, feeling awkward. What an odd experience.  The walk home was more pleasant - we had the quiet streets to ourselves, and it had cooled off a little. My foot still hurts a great deal, but I can walk carefully. We listened to the sounds of a little league ball game on the outskirts of town, and made it back to the B&B before we were completely consumed by mosquitoes.
We took today off biking - we wanted to see what is called "Frank Lloyd Wright" country, and we're due for a break. We had a yummy FULL breakfast, but it was cheesy. Kelly made a Mexican Frittata and a deliciously different picante quick bread. I got the recipe for that - will have to try it out. We talked to Connie and Terri. Terri is 16 and Connie's youngest child, so she wanted to spend some quality time with her "baby" before she was all grown up.  Jay gave us a ride to House on the Rock. I looked at a book about the place, and decided that I was perfectly fine missing it. But John really wanted to see it. I should have made him look at the book. It wasn't at all what he expected, and he was quite disappointed. It's a huge, strange collection of everything imaginable, housed in dark, low-ceilinged halls that twist and climb for 2.5 miles. There were mini-circuses, doll houses, dolls, carousel animals, weapons, armor, cars, asian art, player pianos, player instruments of all kinds. What a strange man, to collect all these things. Why didn't he do something normal like bike across country? It was expensive - $20 per person. And it was old and ratty and shabby and dusty. It renewed my commitment to living as clutter free as possible.  Kelly came and picked us up just as a thunderstorm began. It had taken so long to get through Tacky Palace, and with the rain, we decided to let a drive by of Taliesin and the other F. L. Wright sites to suffice. We saw Hillside, Midway farm, Taliesin and the top of Romeo & Juliet, and the Unity Chapel. Really, they are more beautiful that any photos can caputre. Somehow, the harmonic essence - the way each building fits into and interacts with its surroundings - elude photography. There is a sense of spiritual rightness when you see them in person. I wish we could have spent more time.  Kelly stopped by the office supply store on main street so that I could get some more paper, and then she dropped us off at Rumbleseats, an old-fashioned drive-in restaurant that has expanded to include some indoor seating. It used to be an A&W, but the franchise owner decorated the place with fifties memorabelia, from rock and roll and movies, and A&W wanted him to take it down and make it look like all the other franchises. So he went independent. Good thing! We had home brewed root beer (maple-y), chili corn-dogs and fries, and played with some of the games lying about. John is quite a talented etch-a-sketcher!  We walked back to Hill Street in the rain - the only person to stop and offer a ride only had one free seat. He was an old, scruffy man with a long white beard - and his car was full of fishing gear. I suppose he was only asking if I wanted a ride, not John. He seemed confused when I said, "But there's not room for both of us." He drove on. Quite interesting, that the people who have enough to be generous, never think of it, and the people who think of it, don't have enough. I want to try and pay attention - to give what I have, but how do you know when you're being oblivious?  We hung out at Hill Street until it was time to leave for dinner and the theater. We talked to Mary-Kay and John. The B&B is full tonight, all people going to the theater. Mary Kay and John are from California, they say. But they both grew up in the midwest, then lived in CA for a few years, are both psychologists, got married. When they had their son, they decided they didn't want to raise him in Sacramento, so they moved to Wisconsin. Their kid is nine years old, is a vegetarian because mom says so, (he gets to choose for himself when he's twelve). We talked about child-rearing techniques. I liked them. They're funny, intellectual, self-conscious sorts - too aware to see their own belly-buttons.  Kelly drove us to dinner, to a hotel she described as "right across the street" from the outdoor theater. We already knew that the theater itself was a long walk from the road into the woods. We didn't know that the restaurant was a long drive over a hilly, winding, shoulderless, side-walk-less driveway from the road. So it would really be impossible to walk - too far, and we'd be taken out by a BMW coming around one of those curves. Kelly almost clobbered a fawn and mother deer coming around a corner. So we bet on a shuttle-bus, since EVERYBODY goes to the theater. We had a delicious dinner with a lovely view of the wooded golf course in a "Frank Lloyd Wright inspired dining room." Quite funny. I had steak on a bed of mushroom wine sauce, the baby carrots and zuchinis were superb. Then we asked at the front desk when the shuttle would be going to the theater. The receptionist said there wasn't one. So everyone at this couple-hundred room hotel drove separate cars across the street to the theater. Amazing. As we stood there explaining that we are biking across country, do not have a car, and do not wish to inconvenience our hosts by having them drive all the way back down here to carry us to the theater, and we do not wish to get squashed by the flood of traffic, and couldn't they help us in some way, a woman carrying a large box to her car came to our rescue. She offered us a ride because she was on her way over there now. After we chased a feral cat out of the trash can by the front door (oh, the strangeness) we piled in her comfy, smelly old hatch-back. Let the golfers keep their luxury sedans, we met a wonderful new friend. It turns out that she and her husband are avid bikers and we talked bike-adventure all the way to the theater.  The setting is beautiful - very like the Carter Barron back home. Wooded, with picnic tables tucked into glens and grassy nooks along the path. Live, traditional musicians wandered and played. The theater itself is also open air, but unlike Carter Barron, the seats are quite comfortable, upholstered cushions in a weatherproof material. We had excellent second row seats. As we waited for the show to begin, the rain, which has dogged us all day, returned once again. The theater was quite full in spite of the drenching, steady downpour, and the mood was lively and adventurous, so we waited and chatted with our neighbors. Then a man with a megaphone came down to announce that the start of the play would be delayed, in hopes that the weather would let up. So we got wetter and wetter, and waited. Finally, he reappeared and announced that the weather service was not calling for any break in the storm, so they were officially canceling the performance (something everyone had sworn to us never happens). So everyone would get their money back. However, for those of us who wished to remain, they would attempt to go on with the show. Cheers erupted from the soggy crowd. No one left. Out came the stage crew, to comically sweep the rain off the stage, and to wipe off the chairs with dripping towels. Rain or no rain, they do their jobs! The show began - a french comedy of errors, twins mistaken for each other. The acting was good, despite the soaking costumes, and the play seemed like it would be a pleasant one. But then the sky turned green. That dark, sickly color that makes you say, "Uh oh." And the wind - the wind began to compete with the performers, throwing their voices back at them. The lead actor, now as the saucy twin, pointed and said, "There's a man..." and sure enough, the man with the megaphone returned to call off the performance for good. Scenery took flight. Potted plants left there pots altogether. The pots rolled across the stage, and the greenery flew through the air. The french doors flapped and banged like a clapping toy. The actors ran gratefully for cover and a mass exodus rumbled down through the woods to the parking lot. We called Jay and Kelly, who came to get us. Oh, the adventure of outdoor theater! Someday we'll have to return and actually see a play. But I don't think we will ever forget this day! After hanging everything up to dry and eating some cookies for solace, we went to bed, at the end of a strange and exciting day.
Lovely breakfast, again. Baked, stuffed french toast and bacon, cappuchino muffins, almond danishes. Kelly used to work in a bakery. This morning, we sat with a couple from a Del Webb community in Chicago. (Grandpa and Hope live in a Del Webb community in Phoenix.) They come up every summer for the outdoor theater (By the way, the place is called the American Players Theater.) Also, two women from Milwaukee shared our table. Everyone mostly asked about our trip, so we didn't learn much about them. After breakfast we sat in the living room and gabbed with a family of four - we were reluctant to get on the road because (surprise, surprise) it was raining. So they talked about kids and grand-kids and computers.  Finally we loaded our stuff into Kelly's CRV. Hooray! She'll drop it off at the Lamb's Inn in Richland Center for us. Then off we went, heading north west through a wide valley. The rain and dark clouds were gone - instead we had blue sky, flat road, and a 10-20 mph west wind chasing puffy clouds over our heads. The valley is so lovely - the hills and farms and woods - the cloud shadows playing over the variant greens of the land. Lovely! We had lunch at the Wings Cafe, at the tiny airport. I asked for cocktail sauce to go with the fried clams - and she thought I said TACO sauce - which wasn't bad. But then when she did bring the cocktail, she'd mixed up a huge bowlful! Back on the road, we passed the Sprecher's Farm - we were told that they have lots of kids, more than they can handle or afford. Seems they're "talked about" in these parts. Their barn said "Lactoland Dairy Farm" Literal folks.  We kept fighting that headwind, and then began climbing out of the valley. I knew it was too good to last. Oh, what hills these are! We climbed some real doozies, but still, I think it was the wind that made them seem so bad. Tomorrow, we're heading north-east, so then this wind will be behind us. That ride will be VERY hilly. We arrived at the Lamb's Inn, four miles outside of Richland Center, on the last scrap of our strength. And I had to go to the bathroom. We were greeted by a fat, friendly old dog, part shepherd, part black lab. Her name is Holly. Donna pulled up soon to invite us in and show us around. She let me use the bathroom and helped take our stuff to the cottage. The decor is all 80's K-Mart country, but it is clean and spacious - we've got a whole apartment with a loft to ourselves. I have to say having a kitchen made me giddy. I played with the refrigerator door and the pot scrubber. Wheee. I think it just feels more like "HOME" with a kitchen to ourselves. Psychology is so weird.  We came over and met Jim & Deena - we were told back in Spring Green that this couple from Minneapolis was anxious to meet us. So here they were - power-bike people in their early fifties, newly retired from biotech and management at Pillsbury, biking all over the planet. They don't do any loaded, long-distance riding like we are, but they just got back from New Zealand (we were there in April) where they biked up 3,000 foot passes over which we rode buses. They're insane. But they're also extremely kind and fascinating - we had lots of fun spending the evening with them. We loaded into their SUV and drove for an hour to a dingy bar for the fish fry. They have two grown daughters, and are soon to go biking in Italy. They've bought some land down in the Spring Green area and hope to build their retirement home there, in Frank Lloyd Wright style, if they can get the snooty architects at Taliesin to cooperate. They told us about the things they did at Pillsbury. They worked on the toaster bagels! Wow! They made us eat cheese curds, and just folded us into their lives. They'll be out of town when we get to Minneapolis, but they gave us their number anyway and told us all the best places to eat. We had a wonderful evening - the adventure continues! Never know who you'll meet, what you'll do, or what weird things you'll learn.
We gabbed until after 11 a.m. - we sure get late starts from the B&B's. But the conversation is worth it. Donna took our stuff and will drop it off in Reedsburg. This is our last day of gear-less riding, until the end of the trip. So sad! The first 10 miles were quite speedy - there was a gentle tailwind (I want to know what happened to the 20 mph-er!) and it was mostly flat or gently down-hill. We passed other bikers and said hello. The weather is so gorgeous today, and it's a Saturday in June. We went through a few unincorporated towns and lots of farmland. Then we began to climb. For about four miles, we netted quite an increase in altitude, over many ups and downs. It seemed like every time we had to struggle up a hill, dogs came out to chase us. At one place, with motorcycles out front and hog flags flying from the porch, a pair of baying beagles came out after us. The leather-clad owner called lazily to the dogs, "Harley, Davidson, get back here." He must be a nice owner. They didn't pay any attention to him. We had to hoof it a few times. When we reached the town of Lime Ridge near the top, we stopped for lunch at a bar called Wounded Knee decorated in tacky cowboy and indian decor. Burgers and tater tots were pretty good.  Then we were 11 miles from Reedsburg. We climbed more gentle slopes, still going up for another 6 miles, to the height of all heights. On the broad, flat top, the world stretched away beneath our feet in all directions, on into hazy distances miles away. I felt like I could see Lake Michigan and the Mississippi. (I couldn't. It wasn't that high.) And of course, you know what this means - we still had five miles to Reedsburg, and it's all downhill! That was the funnest five miles on the whole trip, I think. We went so fast, we rattled our teeth and shouted Whee! We sailed, we flew! Up and down hills, all the way down to the Baraboo River and into town. I don't think we had to pedal up one single hill, we just sailed right over them with so much momentum.    We checked into the Parkview B&B - then went to the movies on main street and saw Atlantis. It was okay, but I miss the music. There were no sing-along-songs! There was a problem with the sound part way through the film, so they gave everyone free tickets to any other show. We went back to the B&B, got cleaned up, went to dinner at the Chinese Buffet, then went to see Tomb Raider for free. Brainless fun! Double feature!
Today we biked the 400 Trail, named for the Minneapolis to Chicago train that ran in 400 minutes. We had breakfast with the other guests at the Parkview - strawberry french toast and sausage, then packed our bikes and hit the trail. No more road biking for us for a while! The trail is flat as a pancake, crushed limestone, and is sheltered from the wind by scrubby woods. Quite a change from the wide-open hilly roads we've been on lately. It's a beautiful day, but hot and the bugs are bad. The trail goes through swampy woods and stream valleys lines with rock outcroppings - interesting to look at. Spotted lots of birds - yesterday I forgot to mention we saw a hawk turning lazy circles, riding thermals in the sky. It was piercing the air with it's scream - quite an awesome sound that I'd never heard in real life before. We passed a few other bikers, but not many. And the towns through which we passed were really dead. I don't see how they make it in business if everything closes on Sundays. Seems that if your main industry is supporting the travellers on a recreational trail, you should be open on the weekends. Oh well. We had lunch in Wonawoc at yet another dingy, dark bar. I had a french dip that the waitress didn't think I could eat. HAH! John had the ubiquitous burger. Then we biked on through the town of Elroy. That's the end of the 400 Trail and the beginning of the Elroy-Sparta Trail, the first Rail-to-Trail in the U.S., opened in 1965. They have a lovely trail center in a restored train station - with showers and camp sites and a shop. But as far as we could tell there wasn't any bed and breakfast to stay at, so we biked on. We saw more swamps and rocks. After seven miles we stopped in Kendall. There is a brand new motel right on the trail, and I had reached that level of exhaustion and soreness - the bikitis. We had to check in for the Country Livin' Motel down at the filling station, then got into our room. It's big and clean and quiet. We walked to dinner at the local (can you guess) dingy dark bar, this one claiming to be a restaurant, and seemingly the only place in town that will be open for breakfast in the morning. Oh, joy. Actually, they even sport a salad bar in one dark corner.  Back in the room, we each called our Dads ( it is Father's Day today) and watched a sappy movie on TCM. Too achy and tired to write any more - Good night!

The tunnels are so dark and long that we had to walk our bikes - even with our bike lights and flashlights, we could barely see our front tires. We walked single file and stayed as close to the center of the trail as possible. The tunnels were hewn by hand out of the rock - the oldest was not even lined, as the others were, with bricks. The tunnel entrances have looming wooden doors that evoke medieval castles and dungeons. They're used to seal the tunnels in winter, so that the water inside - from live springs in the rocks above them - does not freeze and cause the tunnel to crack and collapse. The water from the springs drips constantly inside, giving off eerie echoes. From the two shorter tunnels, one end or the other of the tunnel is visible at all times, but in the longest, there is a god portion in the center where no light from either end penetrates.  At the entrance to the longest tunnel, we met Sawyer and his mom and dad. Sawyer's a young fellow, I think four years old, and the family had walked all the way through the tunnel without any flashlights. It had proved too long a walk for the youngster, who'd had an accident. Mom and Dad had cleaned him all up and were just waiting for him to build up the courage to return. (Yes, they had to walk all the way back through!) So we all walked together and talked the whole way, and I think Sawyer held on to the back of my bike. I think our lights were a good reassurance to him. Before we started through, he stood at the mouth of the tunnel, gazing silently into the depths, and up at the ceiling of rock. Who knows what went through his mind, but from somewhere he found the courage to make the long walk back. Brave little man! As we came along an especially quiet spot in the woods, we saw in front of us a family of racoons right on the path. We slowed and stopped, as close to them as we dared come. Still, they scattered at the sight of us, but as luck would have it, Mama and one baby went to one side of the path, and the other three babies disappeared into the trees on the other side of the path. So we held our breath and waited silently. John took out the camera. Sure enough, in a few minutes, the babies began crying to each other, and the mama even answered. Slowly, unsure of what to do, the three babies came out, wanting to run to their mother, but looking at us, they'd scurry back. Then the one baby with mama came out, and met the others halfway, arching it's back and prancing. It looked as if older sister were scolding the siblings for not following mom! They nuzzled each other and chittered and rolled around, and finally the one led the other three across and into the trees. Mama never showed herself, but as we biked by, we saw the babies in the trees, peering at us curiously.  We had lunch at Diamond L'il's, a dark dingy bar with a western gold-rush theme. Lots of locals hanging out. This town is the Black Squirrel Capital of the U.S. Didn't see any, but they seem proud anyway.  We got into Sparta in the afternoon, and discovered that the trail actually ends two miles out of town. As we got to town, we stopped at Speed's Bike Shop and were harrassed by an eight year old boy, apparently the owner's son. He asked us bruskly about our trip and our bikes and gear. He told us about his dream-bike, and stunt or trick bike. Then as we left, he shouted, "Hey, you forgot your special surprise!" And shot us with rubber bands. What fun. Sparta claims to be the Bike Capital of the U.S., but we were frustrated by the lack of bike lanes on the roads, the lack of bike racks anywhere, and the difficulty in getting around by bike in the town. All we can figure is they're the capital because they have a really big statue of a guy riding a penny-farthing called "Ben Biking." Back at the end of the trail, a bulletin board had listed the location of the Strawberry Lace Inn bed and breakfast, which was also advertised on our map of the bike trail. So we called, and they said they had a room available. But when we arrived, tired, sore, dirty, and in dire need of a bathroom, Elsie, the owner, was squeamish about letting us in - she didn't want to let us through her door in the back, but also didn't want us stepping on her rugs. I understand the value of fine decor, but if you've got that kind of stuff, then you really shouldn't advertise on a hiker/biker trail - there's nowhere for people to get cleaned up before arriving! She actually expected us to hose ourselves off in the driveway before entering the house. I don't think my bladder could have survived a cold hose shower after biking all day. But other than that, Elsie and her husband Jack were extremely hospitable (especially once we were all clean) and the house is sumptuous - their attention to detail, luxury, and historic restoration is meticulous. We biked to down town to do our laundry at the coin-op, and then had pretty good Chinese food on Main Street. Then we went to the library for some email time before turning in.
Today we biked the LaCrosse River Trail that parallels the river over the Mississippi bluffs, and to the Mississippi itself. When we began, a huge group of children on bikes clogged the path - it seemed to be a summer camp, manned by too few adults. The kids were all over the place. We passed them slowly, ringing our bells and asking them to stay to the right, but none of them seemed to have any idea which way was right, let alone any kind of bike trail etiquette. They crowded in front of us so we couldn't pass, or tried to race us when we did pass, swerved suddenly towards us - it was frustrating and scary. I was sure we were going to hit one of them. When we got to the front, I told the man in front that he needed to teach the kids to stay to the right on the trail. He apologized. I know I was being a grump, but I don't care, they were annoying. But we got passed them finally and had the wide open trail all to ourselves for many miles. We stopped for a snack in Bangor, WI, at a very fun old fashioned soda shop called Main Street Cafe. Their hot dogs are delicious. It's cooler today, very clear sky, lovely. And not so many bugs!  When we got to LaCrosse and Onalaska, the trail goes through a few confusing turns and down an alley behind dirty buildings, and then becomes a good bike trail again on the banks of the Mississippi. Wonderful! We stood and soaked up the view. This felt like quite an achievement to us, to have reached the great river.  We planned on stopping at a bed and breakfast in town that looked like it was right on the trail. The place is a famous restored lumber baron mansion, and sounded quite fun. Jim and Deena Behnke had recommended it highly, and the restaurant in the place as well. So we biked along, really looking forward to a place with character and great food. We biked and biked and biked. To our left, the land dropped steeply to the river. To the right, it rose up through dense woods to the road and town. The map had made it seem like we could reach the B&B from the trail, so we kept going. When we reached a place where a narrow path switchbacked sharply up to the road, we got off the trail and headed up. We discovered that we'd biked right on through the entire town, missing the B&B and everything. The only thing to do was to bike back - but we'd come up hill for quite a few miles, and I couldn't stand the thought of losing all that ground. In a mile, we came to the Shadow Run Lodge, an icky roadside motel. We had planned on staying in Onalaska for a day, so that we could take a cruise on the Mississippi. But this place was so yucky, that we found a dinner cruise on the river for tonight, and we'll head on out tomorrow.  We walked to the quickie mart for a late lunch, and met a woman selling mints for the Lion's Club. She lives north of here, right on the trail we'll bike tomorrow, so we told her we'd wave if we saw her. On the walk back to the motel, I saw a man mowing his lawn, which had a sign in it, advertising Avon's Skin-So-Soft. We're almost out of the bug-repellant sunscreen, so we asked him about it. He invited us in and explained that his wife sells the Avon, but that she's out. He called her on the cell phone, and she talked him through finding the stuff. We paid him, and told him to keep the change, but he insisted on giving us four dollars in quarters. He didn't understand that we didn't want the extra weight! But I guess we can save them for the next laundry day.  The dinner cruise was lovely - the boat a bit tacky, full of retired people getting sloshed, but the views were what we came for, and we were rewarded. We saw the sun set on the river, spotted a few heron, and the towns on the banks were lovely, sparkling lights in the darkness. We passed a few paddle wheelers, and went under some interesting bridges. Some of the other passengers are on their way to an Airstream Convention in South Dakota. I told them that my bike was an airstream - perhaps I could trade it in on a motor home. They got a big kick out of that and had to tell everyone about the girl with the airstream bike.  The taxi took us back to the Shadow Run, and we called it a day - not what we expected, but not bad overall. Tomorrow should be our last day in Wisconsin!
The trail ends at Route 35, and from there we biked five miles to route 54, which took us over the bridge into Winona, Minnesota. The bridge was high and heavily trafficked and scary, with very little shoulder. But the view was gorgeous when I got up the nerve to look! John tried to stop and take a photo from the top of the bridge, but I freaked out - I'm a bridge-a-phobe. We saw an AmericInn on our way over, so we went there and got a room. Then we biked into town, ate at Hardee's, found a bike shop to get John new gloves, and while we were there, I insisted on checking John's spokes. BROKEN! They fixed it for us in no time. Then we found a book store, and John picked out some new reading material. After a bath and nap, we got a taxi to the "mall." The cab driver is a local guy - he's grown up here in Winona, and lives on a houseboat with no power, no phone, no water. He even invited us over to it - if we hadn't been so lethargic, it would have been fun. He was quite a cool dude! The "mall" in Winona is really dinky - no department stores. But there was a one hour photo shop, so we dropped off two rolls of film. There was a cuban restaurant that turned out to be pretty good. We got some toothpaste and such at the grocery store. Also, I looked at bathing suits at the tanning salon, because I left mine in Madison (Sad - I loved that suit!) But they were expensive and not very well made.  After we got our pictures, we called the cool dude to come and get us, and we headed back to the hotel. We watched some Star Trek before bed - always a treat!
We got back on the road and fought through the wind - knowing that at the end of the day we'd get some kitty time! Wabasha, MN, home of the film Grumpy Old Men, is also the location of Anderson House, an inn that lets you take a cat to your room with you if you want. We've got two nights booked. So we joked about splitting up the petting time, and decided that whoever got to the hotel first got first dibs on the cat. We passed a huge toy factory that had school tours going on, and minigolf out front. But the sky looked ominous, and we were so exhausted and ready to collapse, that we pushed on. Nowhere to hide, no way to speed up, racing to town with our last rags of energy, the wind picked up and the rain came down. A stinging, drenching rain drove into our faces for half an hour. It ended as quickly as it had begun, and the breaking sun lifted a steamy mist off of the road surface. The passing trucks sprayed us pretty well, but we appreciated the piggy-back on their air stream. We got to Wabasha and I pedaled like a maniac. I got to the Anderson well ahead of John, at least half a mile. Hah!  We checked in and got all cleaned up, and waited for our cat to be delivered. We finally decided to go ask about her. The cat lady had just arrived, and let us pick from the entire room. We went back to our room with the one that had climbed onto John's and my shoulders and wouldn't get off, kneading us with her paws. I guess with cats, they do the picking. Ginger is a super snuggly, playful, and demanding little tabby. She has claws, so the kneading gets a little painful. We played with her for a while, then went and had dinner at Slippery's, featured in the film as Chuck's Bait Shop. They really had a horrible flood in April - it destroyed their basement and all of the movie sets they'd collected.  We came back and had a nice evening resting in our quiet, dry room with our kitty. Tomorrow will be a welcome day off!
We had breakfast in the Anderson's dining room - a Pennsylvania Dutch restaurant of all things. I tried one of their famous sticky buns - it was huge! The size of a cake pan! But not outstanding in taste - a little too dry for my liking, but definitely fresh from the oven. Then John took a morning nap while I did the laundry. Of course, Ginger slept peacefully all morning. I played Ms. Pacman at the coin-op and read fashion magazines. When the laundry was done, John and I went to the book store. I enjoyed Asimov's Foundation, so I picked up his newer one, Prelude to the Foundation, because Alwood, a friend of ours, had just read it and wanted to discuss it. Also, I picked out a local book - Bogtrotter, by Dick Coffey. We had lunch at the 3 Sisters Bakery - interesting ham and dumpling soup. We went back to the inn and found that they had taken Ginger! Apparently, someone had specifically requested the little dingbat, so they got to have her. They said we could have one of the other cats. I tried to take a nap, and read the Bogtrotter book, but didn't sleep. Finally, we went to the cat room and they let us pick a cat from the three leftovers. I picked up one that was curled into a ball and sleeping peacefully (I thought perhaps she might be calmer than Ginger.) She looked like a mane coon. It purred and liked to be held and petted. It's an ugly cat, and no one knows it's name (the cat lady is gone for the day.) We decided to name her "Throw Pillow" because she took up residence in an arm chair and curled into an unmoving lump.  We had dinner at the Anderson and came back to the room to discover that the kitty had puked up a hairball on the floor, so now we're calling her "Throw Up Pillow."  Or "Ralph" for short. Just outside of our room's window, the town holds concerts under the bridge that runs over the Mississippi. Tonight it's jazz. We went and sat at the concert for a while, enjoying the music. When the mosquitoes discovered us, we went in, had some pie at the restaurant and then headed for bed.  I forgot to mention that we visited the "internet caf" in town - one computer, ice cream, coffee, and interesting sandwiches on "cro-bags" croissants baked out of bagel dough. It was yummy.  We also went back to the bookstore before it closed so I could get more books. I was almost finished with Bogtrotter, and hadn't really liked it. But it made me want to read the Little House books again. (we're biking up the Laura Ingalls Wilder Memorial Trail.) and Pilgrim at Tinker Creek, by Annie Dillard - I like her approach to the Modern Thoreau movement better than Coffey's self-aggrandizing one. The book shop owner's husband is very into biking, so we chatted, and she said I could return the Coffey book to her tomorrow a.m. at the internet caf, where she hangs out every morning before opening the book store. Cool! So that was our day off - naps and laundry, jazz, cats, books and food!
We got into Red Wing and called the Americinn - all booked. But the Best Western had a jacuzzi room available! So we went there and took a nice bath, had a healthy dinner of salads, and went back to our room to read our books in bed.
We biked to the B&B - the Rosewood, but a note said they were sorry, but were out and wouldn't be back for three hours. We were really early - hours before the check-in time. So we unloaded our stuff onto the porch and biked down to the main street, and historic riverfront of victorian buildings. We had lunch at Professor Java's - good egg salad. Then we walked along,  enjoying the view of the Mississippi for a while. It's much narrower with steeper banks here. The bridge used to be an interesting spiral design that deposited people closer to the commercial district on the waterfront. After killing time, we went back to the inn and the housekeeper took pity on us and let us in. We looked all around - since we're early the place is empty, so I checked out all the other rooms. This place is amazing! Every room has a fireplace and hot tub, but is carefully designed to be romantic and old-fashioned. They make sure that you can see the fireplace from each tub - maximum atmosphere! I highly recommend it as a romantic retreat. They even have special packages that include gourmet dinners and breakfasts in your room! But then I laid down and couldn't get back up. Had some very sick feeling moments. Hope this bug leaves soon!

But we made it to the beltway surrounding the twin cities (Minneapolis and St, Paul) and found a hotel. From there, we called Enterprise rent-a-car and got a car - then we drove into the city to take a look. Since we'd never found any information about bike routes around the cities, we chickened out. We saw the skylines, and drove around the lakes west of Minneapolis' down town - very beautiful. We found a Somali restaurant on Nicollet Street - it was okay, but not air conditioned. Did I mention it's SO HOT?! After dinner, on our way back to the hotel, we decided to go to the mall. I'm sorry, which mall do you ask?  THE MALL. THE MALL OF AMERICA. A better symbol of American culture than all of the Smithsonian and Mount Rushmore combined. THE mall. I left my bathing suit in Madison, and THE MALL has a Nordstrom's , that usually has good suits on sale. So in we went. I did find a nice suit - and then we tottered on the brink - did we escape with our dignity and head straight for the car, or succumb to the shrine of indecent consumption and go INTO the mall? We gave in. Hey, everybody else was doing it. It is huge - four stories of shops - but in some ways indistinguishable from every other mall in the country. All the same stores. Except that it just happens to have EVERY store that there is in the one place. Then when you get to the center, the size becomes fathomable - an entire amusement park sits inside the mall - roller coaster, ferris wheel, merry go round, and many other rides. We found a book store and bought some more books, bought a funnel cake in the amusement park and marvelled at the grand excesses. We even had fun looking at the Lego store. Wheee!  So that was our last day of biking. We halt our westward journey in the midwesternest city  of them all - we biked to the heart of the land and saw what there was to see.
First of all - it took more than two hours to drive there. We're farther than I thought. Second of all - there were many volunteers, and while I thought they were doing an amazing job of keeping everything organized under the circumstances, our group slipped through the cracks and we were dropped off at the wrong sites three times. We tried to make ourselves useful, but there really wasn't much for us to do until we were bussed to the right place and given instructions. So it took us over four hours to finally get to where we were helping. On our bus, there were people from all walks of life - couples from the city taking off work, construction workers, local men from nearby towns, mothers with kids off from school for the summer, even a group of boy scouts from Texas and their den mother. One woman was quite obnoxious at our first stop. We were dropped off in the wreckage of a road of houses - it was a huge mess. People were carrying things in all directions, and heavy equipment was moving around. After a few attempts at trying to find someone to tell us what to do, the woman took charge and started ordering everyone to clean up everything from this one yard. We did so for a while, but then it seemed clear to me that we weren't helping - the stuff had to be sorted and it wasn't clear where the stuff was supposed to go. I decided not to waste my energy, and wait until I knew I'd be doing some good. Anyway, it was lunch time. So I and a number of other stood around eating our lunch and waiting for instructions. But the bossy lady made sarcastic comments to us about not having willing attitudes. Whatever.  After the second drop off in the wrong place, the volunteer coordinator was apologetic, and said whoever wanted to quit then could stay on the bus and be taken back to the parking lot, but whoever was still up to working, could really be used in this farmer's field. All of us stayed to help clean up except the obnoxious lady! I guess she only has a willing attitude if she's in charge!  The damage was amazing - this old couple's life-long home had been shattered into tiny bits, blown completely off it's foundation, and scattered all over their hay fields. Meanwhile, they'd hidden in the basement. Amazing. It was good to meet them and let them know that they aren't alone. While we combed through the hay picking up the bits and pieces, a construction crew was well on the way to raising them a new house. In the basement with them they had had the original house-plans, so they were having it restored. When we told him we were from Washington D.C., he said, "Oh, you live there with my good friend George W." We let politics lie and got to work.  It was hot, and felt somewhat futile. The farmer couldn't harvest his hay if it had all this debris in it - it'd break the machine down. But no matter how carefully we looked, it seemed like the bits and pieces were unending. There were little knick knacks. Small parts off of furniture. Torn and dirty clothing. Sections of window-frame still holding jagged teeth of glass. Far back in the field was a dead deer, the farmer's wife had told us to steer clear of it - we'd know when we were close by the smell. It was hot. The debris was heavy. We didn't finish the field - not by far - but after two hours, the pile had grown, and the work was closer to finished. More volunteers would return in the following days, hopefully cleaning it up enough to salvage the crop. After that we were so exhausted and dirty, we drove back to the hotel and collapsed. I don't think we'll be going back. I'm glad we pitched in, but they really seem to have plenty of willing volunteers, and are well on their way to recovery. It struck me that even in the face of such devastation, in some ways the wealth and prosperity of this country shelters us. Two people were killed, and of course no insurance policy can make up for that, but everything else was covered - businesses, homes, farms, everything would be replaced or rebuilt within a few months. It felt to me like I was looking at the height of the nation's self-sufficiency - we have so much that even in such a case of loss, our excess makes up for it almost immediately. It felt like Americans can't really know what poverty is - in the way it is experienced in other parts of the world. Our possessions shelter us from suffering, but they also shelter us from need. And that may seem like a good thing, but I think something is also lost. By never needing, we never experience grace and mercy. It was a blessing to me to be able to reach out my hands and meet the needs of someone - there was a connection - however small in this land of plenty - between us - the volunteers, and victims - that taught us all about goodness and mercy. We have so few opportunities in this country to learn it.
I also went to a craft store and got some quilting scraps and scissors and thread and stuff. I started making a little quilted square - a picture of a lighthouse. It's a lot harder than I thought it would be - I don't know how to sew two pieces together in a curve. But I think it looks cool so far. I like the fabrics I chose - they're all textured and patterned, and give the impression of different shades of color. So that's all for today - a very quiet day after the physical and emotional rigors of Siren. Interesting, that I respond to devastation by needing to shop.
They got a room at the hotel, to rest for the night, then the plan is to drive up to Lake Superior tomorrow. We went to the little town of Stillwater, back on the La Croix river on the border of Wisconsin and Minnesota. We'd been told that the town has the best German restaurant in the area. It definitely was authentic! It was just like we remembered from Berlin. The roasted pork, wursts, and schnitzel were all delicious, and the Hungarian goulasch was pretty close. Also, they made us spatzie, the mix of orange soda and cola that we used to get in the "Old Country."
We drove north for several hours, and arrived in Duluth in the evening, cramped and tired. Duluth is situated on a steep hill that falls directly into the lake. It's along the Minnesota side of an inlet to the Lake, and its shore is lined with industrial docks and warehouses - this is a major port for the shipping of resources from the breadbasket of the Midwest to the population centers of the east coast. Huge ships, specially designed to carry monstrous loads of cargo on the Great Lakes still pull in and out of the inlet.  We checked into the Hawthorne Suites, housed inside a converted tool factory from the turn of the last century. We ate at the steak house on the first floor, then turned in early. The rooms we got were on the "inside" the middle of the building with no windows out. But the huge sections of pillar that rose through the rooms, and the brick work were all unique. There's a pool and a hot tub, so we did get some soaking time before bed. Another day of bike-free luxury for me!
The weather is so much nicer up here - in Minneapolis, it was sweltering. But just this much farther north, it is so much cooler. We took a drive through Duluth looking at the neighborhoods, and spying Lake Superior from time to time. We walked down Main Street, which lines the road leading to the bridge over the inlet on the other side of which is Superior, Wisconsin. (what a mouthful!) We had lunch at Willy's Filling Station - cute '50's automobile dcor and really great hot dogs and fries. Love their red relish! Of course, we had to visit the Army Corps of Engineers museum. Dad's an electrical engineer, John's degree is in mechanical engineer, and John's dad works for the Corps as a civil engineer. Mom and I survived. Actually, I liked learning about all of the different things they ship through here - grain, iron ore, oil - and there was a relief map of the lakes, showing the depths of the bottom - I found that fascinating. Hills and mountains all underwater. Also, while we stood outside waiting forever for the guys to get done, we saw a seagull gulp down in one bite an entire scoop of ice cream. Talk about the worst brain freeze ever! He had dinner at Tavern on the Lake, done up in an English Pub style, with excellent yuppy sandwiches. We finished the day by going to see the film, A.I.  Can't say I loved it, but it was good, and thought provoking, so worth seeing. Made us all think about the responsibility we have to what we create - and it's not so unbelievable - computers are getting pretty "smart" these days, and yet we still think of them as toasters, not beings. Dad wouldn't talk for a long time after seeing it. He thinks a lot about artificial intelligence, and I think it really disturbed him - perhaps he just can't fathom the possibility that people could be so cruel. I had a hard time believing any sane woman would just dump the kid in the woods, but other than that, I could believe that a mob of fanatics would be like that. Anyway, it did make us all think. Tomorrow, it's back on the bikes - Dad will join John and me while Mom drives the car with all our stuff to Iron River, Wisconsin. Oh, the joys of a sag wagon!
We checked out of the hotel in Duluth and rode in the car over to Superior, where a trail runs east through northern Wisconsin. But south of town the trail turns into gravel - that was really slowing us down, and dad's got a road bike, not a hybrid, and no spare inner tubes. So we took to the road. Big, big, BIG hills. Amazing roller coaster, out of nowhere hills. And fast cars nearly taking us off the road - kind of scary. And no rest stops - snacks or BATHROOMS. I enjoyed it for the first 15 miles. A fifteen mile bike ride is quite nice. Especially with no extra weight on the bike (besides me), and the views were spectacular - of the land, not what was on it. Pretty boring farmish - but the hills and sky were lovely. We stopped at a 1950's school building - a guy had bought it and renovated the interior, and was having a yard sale of all the old junk from the school - desks and books and stuff. He didn't know what he was going to use the building for, but it sure was cool.  After 25 miles, I had to go to the bathroom so bad. Even though we were biking through nothing-ness, I never really saw a place that I was comfortable going by the side of the road. Just enough cars came by, and it was farm after farm, no good trees or anything. So I called Mom on the wonderful cell phone!  Dad & John took off and I waited. Mom drove along and found me by the side of the road. Oh, a gas station has never looked so good! We drove on to Iron River, and just as we got our lunch at the A&W drive-in, Dad biked up. I got annoyed, because when John left me, I got the impression that he could still see Dad from the top of the hill. But Dad said he hadn't ever seen John, and didn't know I'd bagged out - so John was tootling along all alone, no phone or anything. He could get run over by a truck and no one would know. I guess I'm anal - but I think that bikers should stick together, especially if they have no phone. Dad shouldn't have gotten so far ahead that he lost track of John and me. I didn't mean to seem annoyed, but I guess Dad picked up on it, so he biked back to make sure John saw where to turn.  Anyway, it all worked out fine, we all had lunch, then headed for the Trout Haus B&B. It's a comfy, homey, woodsy place - just like staying with friends. They keep trout ponds going, and raise Rainbow trout. A toddler came and caught two fish (with lots of help from his grandpa).  For dinner, we drove to a place called "The Spot," a caf on one of the lakes around here that are rimmed with vacation cabins - it's been a hot spot for this kind of hunting-fishing tourism for a very long time. So the place is rustic and rural, and packed. We had a fine dinner, and then headed back to the Haus for bed.

After the laundry, Mom and I visited JavaTrout, the coffee shop in town also run by the B&B owners. They had a computer there, so I emailed everyone to let them know when we'd be back in Maryland - only four more days! Mom sampled flavored sodas and microbrews while I typed. We had lunch at the A&W before hitting the road.  I decided against biking partly because the weather is cloudy and drizzly today, but also because I've missed my Mom! So we got to spend some time together (getting robbed.) We drove to Ashland in about an hour, and found that the guys had already checked into the hotel. Speedy bikers! We drove to Bee's Caf in the rain. They had excellent soups - pea or beef and potato.  After lunch we drove around town - not much to see. An old concrete dock for loading the big carriers sits moldering on the shore. Northland College was interesting - "an Environmental Liberal Arts School." I have no idea what that means. They had some unique architecture - historic brownstone combined with eco-friendly underground structures with solar paneling. We had dinner at a Victorian era hotel - I had whitefish baked on a maple plank - it was perfectly done, delicious!
It turned out so much better than we could have imagined. First of all, the town, population 686,  is situated on the side of the red clay hills, right down to the shore. It has been a commercial fishing town for a long time, and is closely linked to the Chippewa people living just to the north on the Redcliff Reservation. Earlier this century, mudslides wiped out the entire waterfront. So the only Victorian architecture still standing is inland, uphill. That's where all the written up B&B's are, nowhere near the water. The Bayfront, though, is newly built, right in the center of the new waterfront - in the district of shops, restaurants, and ferry docks. So we had splendid views and were right in the heart of all the action. It's a quaint town with an eclectic population - old fishermen, Native Americans, artists of all kinds, hippy eco-campers, and yuppy tourists who bring the cash. I don't want to think about where we fit in there. Anyway, it is the perfect place to be for the Fourth - the quintessential American small town. Out on Lake Superior, we can see a few of the Apostle Islands, nearest being Madeleine Island with the town of La Pointe. Mom &  I sat on our balcony overlooking the town's park and main road, Rittenhouse. We people-watched until we saw Dad and John ride DOWN the big hill to the waterfront. What fun! We had lunch then wandered through the shops - some fitful rain-showers blew through in the afternoon. John got some much needed introvert time and holed up in our room with his book while the rest of us wandered around.  For dinner we tried Mama Get's Caf - good food and cool jazz. I had BBQ ribs that were yummy and sloppy. Everyone seemed to like their food. After dinner, I enjoyed our jacuzzi tub before bed. This really is an incredibly wonderful room.
