(NOTE TO PEOPLE WHO THINK I'M CRAZY FOR GOING ON THIS TRIP - just do a word search and see how many times I've gotten to relax in hot tubs. I have my priorities straight!) You bike, so that you can soak!
We ferried back over to Bayfield and had lunch at Greunke's - supposedly great, but I thought the fried trout was overcooked. I took a nap after lunch and another bath. John wrote on his palm pilot and Mom and Dad went shopping. I awoke to discover a family of fiddlers in the gazebo below our balcony playing lively bluegrass. I rounded up our troops and we sat in the gazebo and listened for a while, making requests. What a gorgeous day, in such a pleasant setting! Live music, lovely weather, friendly people - just perfect. We got boxed dinners from the caf and boarded a tour boat for a THREE HOUR TOUR of the Apostle Islands. "The weather started getting rough " No, it was quite windy and cold on the lake, but no shipwrecking. We saw three lighthouses, and watched the sun set, and listened to local lore about the area. Back on land, we lounged on the balcony as the park below us began to fill up. Despite a sprinkling rain, the full moon shone out between scudding clouds. The fireworks were wonderful - they went off in the harbor right in front of the park and our balcony. We could also see the fireworks at La Pointe, across the water. An unforgettable day - and a wonderful way to wrap up our bike adventure. Hurray!

  
We will be leaving Aberdeen, Scotland mid May to cycle across Scotland to the West Coast, through Arran to Dumphries to attend the Kirkpatrick Macmillan (designer of the FIRST bicycle, powered mechanically) Rally, then on down through the UK visiting Hoylake (to see friends and relatives), South Wales (to see friends), Hampshire (to attend school reunion) before departing from Gatwick to Linate Airport (Milan). From there we intend to cycle around/through the Dolomites fro 18 days, before returning home.

Which bike to take. Having just purchased second hand Bike Fridays, we are wondering if they (we) are up to this challenge. 
The decision is made, we are taking the Bike Fridays and have purchased the 'suitcases' to be made into trailers. The trailer kits have been purchased and due for delivery on Tuesday. This is going to be an adventure in more ways than we think. 
   Oh no, a vital part was missing, pandemonium for a few hours, all solved eventually. Then we packed our bags and set off. Today was a very short day! only 6 miles to our friends for a birthday tea and bed, before 6 weeks of camping. 

  On the road by 0730 hrs via Auchenblae, Fettercairn, then onto Edzell where we met Sandy Lindsay's sister. The sun was out and we were wearing shorts, however it soon turned colder and layers were being added. We took the lower road towards Kirriemuir and ended up climbing back to the higher road to try and identify the farm of 'Ali's brother's wife's brother - Graham'. This diversion added a few miles. We were lucky and saw Graham on the road and he invited us to have a cup of tea. They were busy putting the cows out to grass for the first time this year and the bulls were creating as they weren't going out for a couple of days. We left to continue our journey to Brewlands Bridge, where we were to stay with Douglas & Ann Macarthur, cycling friends. We arrived there at 1700 hrs in the pouring rain, to a wonderful welcome. Height climbed 975 metres 
Height climbed 1045 metres   
Height climbed 495 metres
     The next ferry was in an hour, so we had our lunch beside the sea. Eventually 2 vehicles turned up to join us in the queue. Over to Lochranza, where we shopped. Set off for Blackwaterfoot but turned back as the headwind was too much, just as the Post Bus came along. We stopped her and cadged a lift to Broddick for 1.80 each (25 miles) - a bargain. Onwards 5k to a relation of a friend for a bed tonight. Height climbed 510 metres   
Height climbed 530 metres

   where we visited the Green House Caf - absolutely fantastic food.     Took the back roads to Barnsoul, making one mistake which took us over the shoulder of Skeoch past the Henry Moore Statues in Glenkiln.     On arriving at the campground, a friend offered to take us into Dumfries to buy stores - great. Stocked up for the whole weekend. Height climbed 490 metres 
  Friday - wet ride out to Clattering Shaws and return via the 'Raider's Road' 16 kilometres through the forest, a filthy wet ride, cold and gale force winds.       Glad of our caravan!  Saturday - down to Caerlaverock Castle     Sunday - Kier Mill for tea and coffee, courtesy of the local ladies (as usual) then  Thornhill and over the hill to Ae (shortest placename in the UK). The shop in Ae was closed, but we managed to stop an ice cream van and all bought one.     It was the first dry, sunny day since we left. Height climbed 2155 metres
   Feeling the hills now. Through Armathwaite, Lazonby to Salkeld Dykes where we found a delightful campground for 4.      This was the second dry day of the whole trip so far.  Spent the whole day checking our computers against milestones, until we think they are fairly accurate now. Height climbed 710 metres 
  Really struggled today, looking forward to our day off in West Kirby. Over Grange Scar and down to Orton. To Tebay then over Borrowbridge before dropping down again to Killington. Took a wee lane with grass in the middle and had lunch in a field where we met an 80 yr old farmer, who was away to spray the nettles. He was fascinated with Roger's leg and our adventure. Onwards down the lane with more grass than tarmac!     To Kirby Lonsdale, then off for the last 15k, which turned out to be 20k as we got lost! Arrived at the site at 1900 hrs. This was a really hard day. Height climbed 1015 metres 
  Retraced steps to take the Quernmore Road  to by pass Lancaster. Then the A6 to Garstang (only option to take this busy road). Onwards to Preston on the A6, where we visited Brucianni's - a wonderful Italian caf, with tables and chairs on the pavement. Main roads a lot today as we took the A582 southwards. Got lost around Mawdesley, before eventually arriving at Ormskirk Rail Station where there was a train at the platform. Bought tickets for 3.20 each (really cheap for a 1 hour journey!). Changed trains in Liverpool - 2 long escalators to negotiate, before arriving at Ali's friend - Jane, who is putting us up for 3 nights. Washed our clothes in her machine - now we smell quite nice again. Out for a meal at a local Bistro before dropping into bed exhausted Height climbed 435 metres 
  
   Lovely little lanes became quite confusing when following a road atlas instead of Ordnance Survey maps.     Wonderful campground on the edge of the city at Coton Hill Farm. Shared the pitch with a turkey and his wife for 2 each and six lovely scones freshly baked by the farmer's wife. Height climbed 465 metres 
Height climbed 910 metres
Wonderful seeing Don & Peggy again and meeting their family. We camped in their garden and were fed like lords. Height climbed 1010 metres
   We talked for ages and he advised us to go on the Aven & Kennet canal towpath,    which we did for 20 flat miles right to the campground at Seend, just West of Devizes. 5.50 each! but wonderfully luxurious facilities. Our bikes are now so dusty. Height climbed 295 metres 
   The plain is not flat as we went through places like Lower Upover, Andover, where we had coffee and scones at the Coper Kettle and got charged 4.80!! We were a bit shocked. We will never enter a Copper Kettle again, as we've previously had a worse experience in one at Kirby Lonsdale last year. Arrived at Petersfield at Roger's parents, eating, resting, washing etc.. Height climbed 840 metres 
Our friends Dorothy & Douglas in Netherley went to our house, found the spares and sent them down Business Post. Many many thanks.  Also, sourced one from the manufacturer to be sent direct. Had a great evening with Lynda (Rog's sister) and Richard eating out in the garden and consuming quantities of wine and Port! Friday 6th - The spares from D&D arrived at 11:00 hrs. Relief as Rog was able to walk again. Saturday 7th - School reunion at Churchers College, where Rog went to school back in the 1960's! Sunday 8th - Off to Milan from Gatwick via Easy Jet.
Arrived Milan airport and travelled by bus and train to Bergamo YH. The trailer cases, packed with bikes and accessories were difficult to lug up and down stairs. Rog was dripping by the time we arrived! Booked a family room at the Youth Hostel - 6 beds but what the heck it was lovely, had our own private balcony, where Rog made up the bikes.  Booked a carry out pizza and beer for tea. Of course, we have arrived when there is a heatwave on - whew!!
Went in search of camping gas (as we can't carry on the plane) and tourist info.  Moved on towards Lake Iseo in the hope that we will be lucky with the gas, or it's cold tea tonight. We stopped at a wee ironmonger's and he had 'Welding Gas' which looked to be the right percentages of Propane/Butane so we bought 2 cylinders. Arrived at Clusane on Lake Iseo, our first taste of Italian campsites not too favourable - 20 square feet of hard packed sand, crammed in amongst hundreds of caravans.     Plus they charge by person and pitch here, it cost us Euro 18 (12). We are now cooking, in more ways than one. On arrival, Rog surrendered Ali's passport as they expect you to pay in the mornings. Height climbed 165 metres 
They weren't worried, they had Ali's passport! Ali wonders if I meant to dump her and had 2nd thoughts! Rather than ride up the lake side through many tunnels,     we caught a ferry to Pisogne. We had our lunch of bread, cheese, tomatoes and fruit on board.     We booked in to Campground Eden on arrival and purchased some food for supper at this rather luxurious hypermarket. Pisogne is surrounded by mountains reaching up to the sky - we wonder which ones we can cycle up. This site is Euro 16.10 (11) and much nicer. We have decided to stay here a while as the heat is just too much to lug our baggage around with us. There are enough options to keep us going for days, if not the whole period. Height climbed 70 metres The site is at 190 metres - now remember that as all our adventures will advise you the height we climb to!! 
We set off for Fraine above Pisogne and thought that we may also go to Grignaghe.  The road climbed steadily all the way to Fraine (825m) were we stopped at a cafe for coffee and fizzy water. Onwards to have our lunch of bread and fruit in a field beside a house.  Ever onwards to a 'ski area' where we paddled our feet in a lovely cooling stream. We kept passing be locals making hay on the steep slopes (the whole families were out working) and they could only use scythes and rakes - no mechanisation here!    We were advised that a side road went around the mountain to Grignaghe, so off we set - guess what - we climbed again. This time to 1295m.  Wow what a view!    Then all we had to do was drop down to Pisogne (didn't turn the pedals once!!) over 10 kms of descent.      But, what about the brakes and rims!!!  Had to stop often to allow them to cool down, under peoples hoses, in streams etc... Height climbed 1170 metres 
A nice lazy day planned - we went over to Lovere - all of 6 km.  Went to Tourist Info and got lots of good info. Then  to Biblioteca (Library) where Rog updated the journal. Coffee in cafe's beside the lake, shade is required as 40+ Deg C in the sun.    Planning to have 1 easy day followed by 1 longer day. May use the train Northwards or the Lake Ferry to reach points South. Not able to load photos here as they only have Windows 98 and I need ME or XP. Oh well, that's to look forward to. 
After arriving, we set off clockwise around the island. There are very few cars allowed here, most of the travel is done on the scooter. So roads don't have to be very wide - most are less than 7 feet. First stop was to visit an 11th century castle - the guide book stated we could get close. They forgot to say that it was private property, and the closest we could get was a gate, with hardly any views.    Decided to climb to the top of the island where there is a 'sanctuary' (church to most of us) at 600 metres.  Got as far as Cure and when the tarmac stopped and the cobbles started, we decided that we didn't really want to see it anyway. Plus the temperature was rising again. Lunch in a field, overlooking the lake, with ferries dotting about.      On setting off again, got lost in tiny streets of Masse, finally found our way out to Carzano, where we swam in the lake. Finally, back to catch the 16:00 hrs ferry back to Pisogne. Height climbed 340 metres. 
Today we plan to cycle thro' Lovere to Rivo di Solto, then climb over to Lago di Endine. We were disappointed, as it's an area of outstanding beauty, NO swimming is allowed in the Lake. Picnic amongst Italian families B-B-q'ing (in that heat!!).    Back over the hill, we stopped for a coffee at a cafe overlooking Lake Iseo, we calculated we have drunk 7 litres of water between us today. Rog had a Pistachio and Hazlenut ice cream (Ali had a lick). Back at the campground we had supper with a German cycling couple we had met - Armin and Mel, who are leaving tomorrow.  A couple of bottles of wine were consumed (or 3 maybe) Just before we went to be, there was some spectacular lightning - maybe we will have a storm and the temperature will drop. Height climbed 515 metres 
Set off for Marone, via an old road right beside the lake. It's closed during the week to allow the overhanging cliffs to be made safe, but opened up for the locals to walk, cycle, stroll along.      Lovely, no cars at all. After Marone, we climbed up towards Zone and the Pyramidi - which are clay pillars topped out with rocks. What has happened, is that the rock on top, has protected the clay underneath from eroding as fast as the surrounding countryside and you are left with these pillars - about 6 in all - most weird.    There was a new priest due to arrive in Zone and the coloured ribbons and banners were all out to welcome Don Stefano. Thought about climbing up to another mountain pass, but both feeling knackered from so much relentless heat, so back down hill agai.  Taking care not to overheat the brakes and rims. On the way back we stopped to watch wind surfers.      Back to Pisogne just as a short shower started. Sheltered in a cafe. Whilst have supper, at about 20:00 hrs, it started to rain again. We quickly got into the tent to have our pudding, when the heavens opened. We were priviledged to have lightning every 5 seconds and continuous rthunder for at least the next 2 hours - fell asleep so don't know when it stopped.  Over 1 inch of water must have fallen, because the wine glass was nearly full in the morning. Height climbed 510 metres. 
Swim and laze around on the beach all morning. Internet and shop in the afternoon. Met a New Zealand couple, who are travelling from Naples to London on bikes.  Maybe another NZ bed in Christchurch there! Eat in the evening, then the rain started. Had half the meal under canvas and early to bed. 
Set off at 09:30 towards Azzone (up in the hills).  After Rogno, climbed towards Capo di Lago. It was hairpin bends all the way, often every 50 yards! Got to the village and the road stopped, just a lane thro' the village (wide enough for a scooter and not much else - as we found out).    Just past the village we came upon a small Lake - Lago Moro.  Continued climbing to Angolo Terme and didn't like the look of the weather AND Ali had a loose crown, so we set off back to Pisogne. Got addresses for Dentists from the campsite owner and the 2nd one we tried was available.  In just 15 minutes all was solved. That just wouldn't happen in the UK. And it only cost us 20.    Leaving the dentist we found a lovely fruit and veg shop, so bought for our supper. Had a celebratory wine (any excuse will do!). Rog had a 'Chocolate and Hazlenut' ice cream. Ali had a lick! Height climbed 365 metres 
     Turned UP towards Castlefranco, S.Viglio and Monti (at 841 metres). Dropped to Angolo Terme (where we got to yesterday) (at 420 metres). Had lunch beside a church at 12:00 hrs.  It played a lovely tune on the bells. Just as it finished, the church over the valley started up with another tune.  So lovely, the church in Pisogne, can't seem to play tunes, just discordant dongs! Onwards towards Dezzo di Scalve (decided not to go for Azzone at another 220 metres!). Beside the River Dezzo all the way to 752 metres. However, tunnels, the first we bypassed on the old road for 1.6 kilometres.     The next, there was no option - it was lit though. The third, we thought we would try this old road again, well not a good idea.  Carved out of the cliff face, the barrier at best 2 feet high, if at all, the drop down to the river about 500 feet at times - scary!"    Got to Dezzo at 14:00 hrs. Damn, all closed until 15:00 hrs. Not much here anyway, so what to do but go back downhill - through all bar the first tunnel! Got to Lago Moro, hoping for a swim, but the locals were not impressed by 'foreigners' and were outright intimidating. So we left them and carried on back to Pisogne.  It had started to rain when we hit the main road, had to stop 3 times for heavy showers, then just before Pisogne the roads were bone dry. The rain was only in the hills! Back at the site, we went for a swim, as if we hadn't had enough water for 1 day! Glass of wine with some Brits in a motorhome, supper just before the rain started again. To early bed, after all the climbing. Height climbed 1080 metres 
Hot, Hot, Hot again. Got up late, moved tent to allow grass to grow. Went to beach, swam, sunbathed, swam, sunbathed, got pink!    Shopped, had wine, eat and to bed. Oh yes, an Austrian motorcycle tour set up at the other end of the campsite, sang bavarian beer cellar songs from 22:00 to 02:00 hrs.  We are so tired from the heat etc. went to sleep at 24:00 hrs No distance or height today. 
   Went to market in Pisogne, bought some food etc..  It's interesting, that here in Italy, the railway lines are NOT fenced in.    Back to beach for swim and laze around. Rog went to the Biblioteca to do the internet by himself. 
Visited the market and bought food for lunch.     Onwards to the Yacht Club to watch boats being got ready for a sail. It was so hot, we sat a while, and a while longer. Then guess what - decided too hot to cycle, so back to Pisogne. Lunch at the campground, swim in the lake, laze around etc... At 19:00, into town - La Cantina del Cavaliere - who were to give us a 'surprise' Italian meal to celebrate our anniversary. The meal was fantastic. Stared with a glass of bubbly, starter of small morsels (don't ask me what they were), pasta with a sauce for 2nd's, followed by a meat balls etc as a 3rd course. All wasked down with a litre of red wine.  The lot for Euro 33 (22). Back to the campground for coffee and 2 Amaretto's each! 
On arrival, went looking for a campground for the next 3 nights. First one we came to, the owner jumped out and invited us to stay - even knocked the price down from Euro 22 to 20. Done we said. He even threw in a table and 2 chairs for our stay - great. (Camping Punta D'Ora). Went in search of a supermarket and did shopping for next days, back to the site for a wine in the bar.
Dropped down to Ome, at the edge of the plain. Wandered around this wine area, vines everywhere, interspersed with fields of maize. Little villages, each with their churches. Back to the site by 14:00 hrs, changed into swimming costumes and went for a swim. Height climbed 760 metres.
Decided to visit the local nature reserve - flooded peat bogs. Followed 'footpaths around - not meant to cycle, but no-one else around. Only saw a swan, a grebe and some dragonflies!  Visited a Monastery - guess what, closed!  Back to site for a swim - still in the high 30's.
**** hot again  35 - 42 deg c. Lots of traffic, tempers getting frayed. Went to train station to check times for tomorrow, then up to the YH, where we packed the bikes away, before our last supper of pizza. Height climbed 310 metres.
Firstly we asked for a 'large' taxi. A car turned up, too small for our bags. The driver dumped our bags on the road and left! Whe tried to order another one - they said we would have to pay for the first one. We missed the planned train! Luckily, a later one would still do. Finally, a large taxi turned up and charged us Euro 20 for a Euro 10 journey. Train to Milan Central station, then bus to the airport.  Bikes weighed and charged Euro 52 for excess baggage. Through to departures - plane delayed 1 hour. Instead of have 2 hours for transfer at Stanstead, we got 1 hour. They close booking 40 mins before departure.  Mad panic, 20 mins to collect baggage, clear customs, check in etc... Just managed it. Met in Edinburgh by friends (Jessie & Graham) who put us up for the night.  I DON'T want another day like this!!!
What a relief. Now all the washing / reading 6 weeks of mail etc... that accompanies any extended journey/holiday.


Valiant plans to assemble the bike at the airport and ride off into the sunrise were curtailed by these credit card woes and general exhaustion.  I took a hotel in Crawley and got a courtesy shuttle ride. I assembled the bike without too much difficulty.  The brakes, as always, were a little tricky to get aligned.  I eventually got them though the rear brakes are a little looser than I like.  They still manage to stop me though, good enough. The plan for today was to take it fairly easy, little did I guess the number of hills en route.  I took the Sustrans route down, it worked out pretty well.  I suppose I was immediately spoiled by signs as there was a brief section without signage that annoyed me a tad, like I can't read a map and figure things out for myself from time to time. Apparently in my training I ignored rolling hills.  As I thought about it, Los Angeles just doesn't have that many rolling hills, you're either in the hills or on flat land, not much rolling to be found.  That was a mistake on my part, not the first or the last I assure you. I made it ok, I'm bumming around Brighton for the day.  I was a little worried about getting a hotel.  I called about four places and they all noted that this is Bankers Holiday, and due to the fact that the weather is also incredible, that everything is going to be booked solid.  Oops.  I found a place in the north section as I rode into town.  I don't know if I'm lucky to find a place or not, but I found a place, good enough for me. (Gap, Borders, blah blah blah) Not sure what tomorrow holds for me, til next time... 
As I hit went outside, I noticed the weather had turned from an absolutely beatiful ~65 or so to ~50-55 and, uh, WINDY.  The temperature didn't bother me a bit, in fact I prefer biking in colder weather, well, as long as it's above 50.  The wind however, well thats just another story....      One thing I immediately noticed about the wind, it was directly in my face, the whole way, and it was blowing hard.  Nothing like pedalling along madly in granny gear going downhill to manage 9 miles an hour.  I managed to take a small accidental detour on the way down to polegate which added a few miles to my trip, mostly uphill, but I suppose I got to come back down the hill with the wind to recover.  All in all, not really worth it. I was going quite slow and didn't get to Polegate until around 4:30pm.  Even though it is the big holiday weekend, I was hoping to find a hotel rather quickly and pack it in, as I was quite tired.  The problem is, there is only one hotel in Polegate, oops.  Even better, that hotel is a student run establishement, and as such, was closed for the holiday.  This bankers holiday is causing me no end of fits. To top it off, my rear tire seems to have developed a very slow leak which is requiring me to fill it up every few miles.  I suppose I could've changed the tube, but it was starting to get late and the "Find a place for the night" panic was slowly invading my brain. I made the decision to push on to Eastbourne.  By this time, the weather had dropped below 50 and the wind was still strong, and in my face.  Joy. I made it Eastbourne around 6:30pm, and I was in full panic about the availability of hotels. It is after all, the holiday weekend. Luckily, the hotels are tightly congregeted in one area and I was able to check several in rapid succession.  The third place had a vacancy, and for cheap!  so I was quite the happy camper.  The owner was kind and let me pull the bike inside for the night, there's no way it would've fit up the tight staircase (all four flights, ugh), so it stayed in the guest lounge, nice. All in all, it was a rough day, spent much time pushing the bike up hills and getting windburn in my face.  How great is that!    Show links to this Hide links to this     
I went outside to another WINDY day, yes, once again, directly in my face.  Not to worry though, the map indicated this day would only be 18 miles, I can go that far in my sleep. I rode for a few miles until I picked up the main trail which was to take me down to Hastings.  Funny thing about trails, they go in two directions, the way you want to go and the way you don't want to go.  The intersection where I intercepted the trail had lovely signage pointing me down the trail.  Unfortunately, the intersection was a roundabout, and the the next road after the one I took had lovelier signage indicating the trail went this was as well, and in the direction I wanted to go. So, I wandered off in the direction I didn't want to go for about 4 miles.  It was really beautiful rolling through the countryside between farms and far off castles.  I was enjoying the view so much, I didn't notice several warning signs, 1> no headwinds, 2> going far away from the ocean, 3> mileage signs to the town I was going were pointed in the opposite direction. Ok, I'll admit the 3rd one kind of got me thinking it was about time to turn around.  After all, I'd gone about 4 miles, and instead of being in an oceanside town, I was far from the ocean, with no town in sight crossing major roads which didnt appear on the map. Back I went....  Yes into the headwind, but again, through the lovely countryside.  Did I mention the wind was blowing, hard? I went back to the roundabout and noticed the brilliant signage at the next road which is in fact, the way I wanted to be going....  All in all, it was about a one hour detour, no major worries, but less than ideal. After I got back on track, the trail went down near the ocean, which simply meant there was nothing to block the headwinds. I rolled into Hastings around 3pm, and went to the hotel.  This time, I was smart and called ahead to make reservations. Again, the owners were very kind about the bike, it's now sitting in a private bathroom completely out of the way...  Once again, there's no way it would've made it up the four flights of stairs required to get to my room.  (Did I mention climbing four flights of stairs after a full day of riding is somewhat painful?) I plan on taking the day off tomorrow to see what's happening around Hastings.  So far it seems to be a cross between Myrtle Beach and some medieval town.  Old castle on top of the hill, cheesy tourist garbage along the shore...  Off to find a pub, must get a beer.

I spent about 5 miles riding along the Cliffs of Dover (sometimes within 30 yards of the edge) starting at the Battle of Britain memorial.  This experience stunned me, and I'm frankly at a loss for words on how best to describe the experience.  It's something I'll never forget.         
Glad to not be hungover this morning as I'd had a few pints at a pub last night.  The Manchester United - Real Madrid match was on, it was quite a scene at the pub.  I can't imagine what it must have been like up in Manchester. I was expecting rain in the afternoon so I got an early start and cruised through the day. The only real challenge was the 13% climb back to the top of the cliffs from the town of Dover.  The road ran around Dover castle, so it was nice to look at as I pushed my bike up the hill... Speaking of Dover castle.  I checked it out yesterday.  It has an amazing history. It had been in active military/government service for oh, about 1000 years prior to the 1960's.  Given the strategic location in regards to Europe, the castle must have seen some amazing things.  It's got exhibits from nearly every time period from ~1200 to WWII.  The range of artillery pieces was a good example as they had: a medieval trebuchet, 18th century cannons, 19th century bombard cannons, WWII howitzers.  I rode along the cliffs for less than a mile before the road turned inland.  I made my best average speed yet as it was downhill and I had tailwinds for a good part of the day. As I was expecting afternoon rain, I cruised through the towns of Deal, which didn't look all that interesting anyway, and Sandwich.  Sandwich looked like a nice town, wish I stayed to look around a bit, especially since the rains never came. I got in to Canterbury around noon and found a room in a hotel about 2 blocks from the cathedral.

I should be back on the bike either Sunday or Monday depending on whether or not I want to stay an extra day in Colchester. I received a number of questions from many of you, I'll be putting up a FAQ page one of these days.  Probably the next time it rains.  In the meantime, I'll be quite happy to keep the weather as it's been.     

By the time I finished eating, the rain had finished, so I was definitely leaving.  One thing about storms coming from the southeast, they gave me excellent tailwinds for most of the ride.  It's quite nice to ride uphills at 15 miles an hour vs 10 going downhill into the wind.  I'm starting to adjust to the rolling hills, or maybe my legs were just rested as I haven't been on the road for a few days as I chugged up hills without much problem today.  Though they weren't very steep. I had another flat on the rear tire.  That's two in like ten days, further inspection of the rear tire shows it's getting pretty worn out. He proceeds to steer off the sidewalk and crash into some bushes.  I'm pretty sure he was drunk.  He seemed alright though, so I chuckled my way down the road. It was pretty entertaining taking my road bike through some of this.  Despite my clutzy tendencies, I managed to get all the way through without falling. Still though, Berwick is a rather nice town and my legs could use the rest after cranking hard for two days and looking at the hills of Scotland during the run into Edinburgh. I started off with breakfast at the B&B.  As a note, some time ago I got completely sick of the traditional english breakfast. The black pudding, um, yeah, nothing good to say about that really. Took a guided tour of Berwick and met a older couple who were taking a cycle tour as well.  They were coming in from the west, where I'll be headed and complained about the hills, but liked the tailwinds.  I guess this means I'll get to do the same hills into the wind, joy.   
I took a more direct route in order to avoid the heavy rains which I expected to start around noon.  Well, they didn't start until 2, but now it's pouring, so I'll be heading straight to a pub in just a few minutes. Big news of the day, I hit Scotland just a few miles into the ride.  That's right, I'm in the land of the Highlander, scotch whisky and groundskeeper Willie.           
Innerleithen is a nice town about 40 miles south of Edinburgh.  There was a good scene at the bar downstairs as Celtic was playing their final match before the big match this weekend in Spain for the European Cup.       
Pretty early into the trip, I passed four Canadians who were going on the same route I was riding.  I actually saw them twice yesterday as well. Once in Galashiels as they were getting off their bikes and heading into the library there.  I also saw them pull into innerleithen several hours after I arrived.  One of them had a flat.  I asked if they needed assistance, but didn't stick around The trip out of Innerleither turned north so I didn't have winds blasting me in the face, that was a refreshing change of pace.  The ride started with a long 10 mile or so climb into the Moorpath hills.  I actually hit the highest point about sea level of the trip today, around 400 meters.  However, the grade was pretty shallow and I rode most of the way up with a few gears to spare.   At the top, I was rewarded with a decent view of Edinburgh  (a little hazy, so pics may not be great) and a long gradual decent.  These are much better than steep drops as I don't need to ride the brakes. After the hills, I added an extra several miles by missing turns and taking the wrong turns several times.  Naviagating through suburban towns can be something of a pain. I finally made it into Edinburgh.  I'm staying in a hostel for the first time.  I'm staying with a Canadian and a Spanish guy.  I think I've met more Canadians on this trip than any other nationality eh.         
I took a train from Edinburgh to Inverness.  At this point, I didn't have a plan for the next section of my journey.  I had vague plans to southeast through distillery country and St Andrews back to Edinburgh or southwest to Glasgow or North to John O' Groats, the most northernly city on the British Island mainland.  At this point, I had about 4 days of available time left and these all would have worked out ok. As happens, I made it to Inverness and fell in love with the town and met some great people at the hostel.  So, instead of moving on, I called it a trip and decided to stay in Inverness.  I took day rides down the loch ness and to Culloden battlefield and the Black Island, relaxed a lot, and hit many pubs. I took one van tour up to Orkney Island for a day.  Orkney Island was beautiful, but the tour itself was miserable for me.  Riding in a cramped van and going on someone else's time schedule wasn't my thing, at all.  Of course, it would've taken me a week to bike that distance, so it was probably worth it. After Inverness, I headed back down to Edinburgh where I met my parents for a couple of days.  Dad was on his way back from Iraq so it was a convenient for him to stop by.  After Edinburgh, I hit London for a week and badly missed the cycle.                         

Cindi's bike: Frame--Litespeed Blue Ridge 53cm   Components--Ultegra in the front, XT in the rear   Brakes--XT Cantilever   Crank--Shimano Ultegra 30-44-52   Wheels--Mavic Open Pro 32h, Ultegra hubs   Tires--Specialized Armadillo 700x26   Seat--Selle Italia Trans Am w/manganese rails   Rear Cassette--XT 12-34   Fork--Kenisis   Pedals--White Bros. Eggbeaters   Panniers--REI Novara   Handlebar Bag--Ortlieb   Rack--Blackburn Expedition
I had some extensive knee surgery a couple of years ago (Meniscus clean-out, ACL reconstruction, Microfracture, and (ouch)Osteotomy).  Biking has been the best thing for my knee and seems to be the activity that gives me the least pain.  Bill also had some knee surgery--a Meniscus clean-out--and he feels his operated knee is considerably stronger now than before the surgery. We live in a rural area with plenty of hills--in pretty much any direction.  You get to the point when you bike that you simply put your head down and grind out the hill.  I'm not sure that it even gets easier as time goes on--but I do know that you come to the realization that it probably won't be as bad as you thought it would be--that it may take some time and a rest stop or two, but you'll make it.  I compare everything to a hill near our house called Allen Canyon--it's the hill by which I measure all other hills.  It took me 3 tries to get up that hill without stopping, and having done it, I know I can do it again tomorrow.       
We drove from our home in Ridgefield, WA to Anacortes in about 4 hours, leaving the Explorer at the Park 'n Ride which is just south of Anacortes, off Hwy 20.  The Park 'n Ride is about 9 miles from the ferry terminal, a pleasant enough ride with wide shoulders on Hwy 20, a section of residential riding, and then back on Hwy 20 for the last couple of miles to the ferry dock.  You can also leave your car at the ferry terminal--the charge is $5-7 depending on the length of your stay.  We wanted to make the 2:40 ferry to Friday Harbor and were in plenty of time.  We had checked the ferry schedules online at www.wsdot.wa.gov/ferries/, and the nice thing about both the Washington State ferries and the BC ferries is that bikes and walk-ons are most always guaranteed passage.  Though they want you to be in line 20 minutes before the scheduled departure, they load first, and unload first.  The ferry ride to Friday Harbor took about an hour and on the way we met a couple from Eugene who were headed to San Juan to do some camping.  We had all picked a good week to tour--the temperatures were in the 70's, with sunny skies predicted for the next few days.  When we unloaded at Friday Harbor, we parked the bikes and went to Friday's Crabhouse for a bowl of smoked salmon clam chowder.  Friday's overlooks the ferry terminal and we had a good view of the seemingly endless stream of cars coming off the ferry and the crowd of walk-ons that were headed back to Anacortes.   We rode the short 2 1/2 miles to our B & B--the Oakridge--and checked in.  We had never stayed in a bed and breakfast before, so this was going to be a new experience for us.  The owners--Tom and Maria--greeted us with a glass of ice water--always welcome to a cyclist.  We left our bags and headed out to Lime Kiln Park, on the west side of San Juan Island, to see if the whale pods were feeding.  San Juan Island is hilly and windy, but not unpleasantly so.  When you get out to Lime Kiln you can often see the whales from the shoreline, but we were about an hour too late.  A message board at the park lets visitors know when and where the whales were last spotted.  There are also plenty of boats that can be chartered to whale watch--and these seldom fail to find the pods that hang out year-round in the San Juans.   We biked back to the Oakridge and got a recommendation for dinner--Vinnie's.  Bill had lasagne and I had "pasta from hell-prawns from heaven".  The service was excellent--I'd give it a 9/10 on my "biased as all get out" scale. We biked back to the B & B around 9:00, so it was starting to get dark and we turned on our rear flashers just to be on the safe side. Breakfast was wonderful.  Fresh fruit, homemade, steaming scones with butter and jam, granola, and hot tea, accompanied by classical music.  Tom and Maria are interesting people, having lived on the island for about 7 years.  Tom is an engineer and Maria is a teacher now involved with Elderhostel.  They moved here from Alaska.  They have seen Tom Selleck and Sandra Bullock on the island, and probably countless others as well.  Their house is an older "craftsman" house--with lovely, creaky wood floors and paneled doors with ornate brass knobs.  The big porch faced the harbor and it reminded me of my grandmother's house.  We thoroughly enjoyed our stay, but hey...we had a ferry to catch.           
We caught the 9:30 ferry which travels north then west along the coast of San Juan Island to Sidney, British Columbia. Before we boarded, we talked with a couple on a tandem from Monterey, CA.  He was 70, and we didn't think it polite to ask her age, but I'd say she was close to that.  I hope I'm still riding when I'm their age.  They were headed to Victoria and then Orcas Island, but had no desire to climb Mt. Constitution, the highest point on the San Juan Islands.  The ferry to Sidney takes a little over an hour, so we read and watched as island after island peeled away behind us.  After "putzing" around the Sidney a little, we stopped at Starbucks, made a few phone calls, and decided to go to the whale museum.  It's a "donations appreciated" museum, and the exhibits were quite well-done. Did you know that the gestation period of an elephant is around 22 months, but a blue whale is usually 10-11 months?   We had some time to kill before we could check in to The Flying Pig, our Sidney B & B, so we rode down Lochside Dr. from the ferry dock. Just before Lochside Dr. crosses Hwy 17, there is a trail on the left hand side of the road (I didn't think it was very well-marked--small white sign with blue lettering) called Lochside trail.  This asphalt and/or hard-packed gravel trail runs all of the way to Victoria some 25 miles to the south.  It is connected to other trail systems as well, (the Galloping Goose) and overall, we found Vancouver Island to be very bike-friendly.  When we were on roads without shoulders, cars seemed to give us plenty of room.   We had gotten great directions to the Oakridge B & B on San Juan, but I only had an address for the Flying Pig.  Not to worry--we have MapPoint.  It's the first time we have found it to be inaccurate.  I think it was a 12-mile missed turn mistake, but a beautiful 12 miles around(and back)Patricia Bay.  We were mostly miffed because we didn't decide to turn back until we were at the BOTTOM of a hill we had cruised down.  The other problem, was that I had done all of the map routing, but Bill was the lead rider.  I prefer him to be in front, but we knew we had to communicate a little better.  We turned back, and found our way and were on their doorstep in no time. Rose and Brick Betsworth own the Flying Pig.  It's a gorgeous place just up a hill from Sunset Beach, nestled in the trees.  Rose showed us to our room, made sure we knew where the ice-cold water was, and while we showered, was baking cookies.  Yeah...I could live like this for awhile.  Hot cookies by the time we were out of the shower.  She suggested the Duinsmore Lodge on McTavish Rd. for dinner, which has a story all its own.  It was owned by a guy who built it as a detox center and expected to make a pile of money from corporate executives who needed to kick their habit.  The expectation was that the corporation would be picking up the expense.  It didn't happen.  The University of Victoria bought it for $1 and the debt it had accrued and today it is a conference center.  I can tell you they manage a lovely dinner with an emphasis on presentation.  Bill had chilled concord grape soup, pork tenderloin with a fig and cognac sauce, roasted potatoes and apples, I had butter lettuce with toasted hazelnuts and a sherry vinagrette dressing, halibut with wild rice in a tamarand and orange sauce.  For dessert we shared a licorice and white chocolate cheesecake, and it came to us with "happy 30th anniversary" written in chocolate on the plate. Rose must have told them...  One other thing...Rose told us that there was a hill in getting to the Duinsmore Lodge, and she was correct.  It would get 3 chevrons on my map, thank goodness it was only a half mile long.  We rode the short 4 miles or so back to the Flying Pig and got there just in time to catch the evening sunset.  So peaceful and I think we were the only ones on the beach.         
Though Bill and I were newbies at the B & B thing, we were becoming enthusiastic believers.  Rose served a hearty breakfast, beginning with local, fresh strawberries with yogurt and granola, sausage, and pancakes as light as "thistledown" (sorry...I couldn't resist...it was actually the name of one of the roads on San Juan Island, and it's been in my head ever since).   We rode down West Saanich Road to the Brentwood Bay ferry terminal.  These six miles of road didn't have shoulders most of the way, and it was busy, but neither Bill nor I felt unsafe as cars gave us plenty of room when they passed, or waited to do so. The ferry from Brentwood Bay to Mill Bay is called Vancouver Island's prettiest shortcut.  Hard to disagree...It's a small ferry, holding a little more than a dozen cars, and it takes about a half hour to cross.  I liked the ferry handlers--they seemed so accomodating, so helpful.  One of them gave me a map of the wineries in the area (there were 13 within a 25 mile radius of Mill Bay). We were headed to Mill Bay to see a friend of mine.  Suzanne Johnston and her husband Bob own Kilmalu Farms, a nursery specializing in daylilies and grasses.  Check out their website at www.kilmalu.com .  We got to her place just after noon and her three deputies were waiting for us.  She has three yellow labs--Ginger, Jake and Jessie, and together they showed us the display garden, shade house, and the two-story home that they designed themselves.  I think the roof line of their house is "very cool".  We had a cup of tea, visited, laughed, and then headed back to Mill Bay.  Suzanne passed on some information that the locals all know--if you buy your ferry ticket at the supermarket in Mill Bay, it's 30% cheaper.  Done.  We rode back to the ferry dock, waited,(you do spend a fair amount of time waiting, but the weather was sunny and warm, so we just kicked back and talked with the other people waiting) and caught the 4:10 ferry to Brentwood Bay. It was early, but we went ahead and rode into Brentwood and found a little Greek restaurant called Piccolo's.  On my BAAGO (biased as all get out) scale I'd say it was a 6.  Service was great, food was okay.  The waitress DID tell Bill that Dino's secret ingredient in the meat sauce was cinnamon.  Bill had ribs and spaghetti, I had halibut and vegetables.  We biked the 6 miles north on West Saanich Road with a fair amount of traffic, and got to the Flying Pig around 7.  After a shower we vegged in the loft and watched a mixture of Mariner baseball and news.  Oh...and we ate the rest of the chocolate-dipped strawberries that Rose had given us to put in the fridge.             
Another great breakfast--strawberry/banana smoothies, bran and date muffins, scrambled eggs, pork and apple sausage, toast with homemade jams, a big pot of tea.  Brick is a pilot for Canada Air and he also runs fishing charters out of Port Renfrew.  He said they usually get their limit of salmon and halibut.  They have two Maltese terriers, Baby and Tinker, that dance around at the end of breakfast for the leftover pancakes. We thanked our hosts and biked to the ferry terminal (about 5 mi.) and caught the 11:40 ferry.   In order to get to Orcas Island, you have to take the ferry back to Friday Harbor on San Juan Island, and then take the inter-island ferry to Orcas.  It was a 45 minute wait--just long enough to have another cup of that smoked salmon clam chowder at Friday's Crabhouse.  The ride to Orcas is beautiful.  We passed Shaw Island and Lopez Island, both of which are flatter than San Juan, and consequently, lovely for biking.  Orcas, on the other hand, is the hilliest of the San Juans, and we got a good taste of the hills as we biked the 8 1/2 mi. to Double Mountain B & B in Eastsound.   The name of the place should have been an indication to me...it sits atop a 3/4 mi. gravel road.  When we booked the room, Gail the innkeeper said there was a sizable hill to her place, but Bill and I have found that what ONE person thinks is a hill is not necessarily what WE think is a hill.  Gail's hills are our hills.  I couldn't ride it, neither could Bill, so we walked.  I guess you have to have elevation like that in order to have the view like she does.  It was breathtaking.  After a short rest (it was 5 o'clock) we decided that if we were going to do Mt. Constitution, we'd have to do it tonight.  There was another couple at the B & B who said they had driven up to the top that morning and waited for over an hour for the fog and clouds to clear, but had given up.  We had had fantastic weather, clouds in the mornings that usually burned off by noon, however, clouds and rain were due to come in overnight.  We had to go down that hill and back up to eat dinner anyway.  So, off we went. Moran State Park--about 12 miles of riding from her B & B, 5 miles of it up a fairly steep grade.  We were in our lowest gear most of the time.  Bill said we were going so slow we didn't even disturb the wildlife.  At 7:30 we were at the top--2410'.  We did it.  Oh, we stopped several times to catch our breath, but I don't think either of us thought it was as bad as people had told us it would be.  The innkeeper said few people bike to the top. We had another couple take our picture, and then we took a bunch ourselves.  There is a stone tower that Mr. Moran had erected and years after he had died, the park service wanted to tear the structure down because of safety issues.  There was a hearing--and his granddaughter showed up with the original blueprints to show that Mr. Moran had hidden a plaque in the tower which said something to the effect--To him that rebuildeth, glory and fame, to him that destroyeth, eternal damnation.  Interestingly enough, the tower stands. The ride down took less than 15 minutes and we stopped to take a few pictures of some deer just outside of a fence designed to keep them out.  Gail, the innkeeper at Double Mountain, said the deer at Rosario Resort are tame and people feed them all the time.  We ate at Rosie's at Outlook Inn--a bit pricey for us, but we were celebrating the ride to the top of Mt. Constitution.  A couple of glasses of chardonnay, spicy babybacks for Bill, chicken phad thai for me.  Bill also ordered some chocolatey, peanuty, and whipping creamed ice cream dessert that we shared.  A 6 on my BAAGO scale. We turned the tailights on and biked the last couple of miles up to Double Mountain. (Yes, we walked the bikes up the gravel drive again)  Showers and off to sleepy-sleepy land.                 
I was very, VERY happy when I woke up at 5:45 this morning and looked out the window to see a cloud bank pouring in, taking over the sunny skies.  By 8:00 it was foggy and cloudy and you wouldn't have seen anything from the top of Mt. Constitution.  I'm so glad we went last night.  We slept in--rolled out to breakfast around 9:00, met another couple who were staying at Double Mountain, Bob and Elizabeth from Seattle and had another stellar breakfast.  Dutch babies--with powdered sugar and fresh-squeezed lemon, applesauce, sausage, fresh fruit, orange juice, and tea.  A word here about bed and breakfasts.  We opted for this route for two reasons:  first, and most importantly, Bill doesn't really like to camp.  He seldom gets a good night's sleep camping.  And second, we really didn't want the added weight of the camping/cooking gear.  It was a good option for us and I think, given the choice, we would almost always choose a B & B over a motel, and certainly over camping. We took our time packing up--talked with Gail about her family and life as the owner of a bed and breakfast, and left for the ferry terminal a little after 11.  We had quite a wait--it was only 9 miles into town and the ferry didn't leave until 1:50, but we didn't mind--both of us were feeling the climb from yesterday.  The ferry was 1/2 hour late and when we got to Anacortes we should have pulled off to the side and waited for a good while until the cars had cleared out, but we were anxious to get back to our car and head for home.  We did wait for all of the cars to exit the ferry, but we caught up to the long line of cars going into Anacortes.  Fortunately, we took a residential detour and missed a lot of their exhaust.  We felt about a dozen raindrops fall on us as we raced to the Park n' Ride.  This, our first taste of touring, was delicious, indeed.     



   A few months later, we had a more official celebration with our families, in Laguna Beach, CA.  This gave us two good excuses to take a trip: 1)  We needed some way to get back home from California. 2)  As newlyweds, we could justify a taking a big chunk of vacation for our honeymoon
  
  

We immediately learned something that would follow our entire trip:  do NOT ask locals for information about mileages or terrain in their local vicinity.  These people do NOT know, and will only mislead you.  (The cashier at the convenience store estimated that the Paradise Cove campground was "about a mile" from town.  It turned out to be 5.)  The campground was ugly and beat up, but at least empty.  Neither of us would go back, but it was nice to have the trip underway. At this point neither of us thought we had a working camera. For no particular reason, I was convinced that the camera needed a new battery, though I never checked to make sure.  Marilyn, on the other hand, had erased any memory of the photos she'd taken at Hans' birthday party a few weeks prior.   At any rate, when we finally got smart enough to take the camera out of its case, it had a perfectly good battery and a roll of film with 9 exposures used.  In honor of our brilliance, here's a photo from Hans' birthday party.     
   We pumped the locals for  information about the climb (distance, grade, etc.), all of which turned out to be inaccurate.  The proprietor at the Canebreak Cafe showed us his astronomical photos (Hale Bopp comet and whatnot) before sending us on our way.  The pass turned out to be pretty manageable, and was followed by a long downhill back to 2300 feet.  Then flat for 9 hot miles between Inyokern and Ridgecrest.  After hunting down a rare nonsmoking motel vacancy, we landed at the Best Western.  The plan is to rest up for a long haul to Lone Pine tomorrow.  Gotta buy a camera battery so we can start taking pictures.
   So, we're hotelling it for one more night before heading to Bishop tomorrow.    This afternoon, we met a college student named Andrew, who bought us smoothies when we pulled into town.  (Thanks Andrew!)  He bike toured last summer, and felt he had some Karma to pay back.  We gave him a "Bozeman" refrigerator magnet.
   For the first time after several times of passing by it in the dark on the way to Mammoth Mtn. as a kid on family vacation, I got to go in and see it.  We didn't take the auto tour, but nonetheless saw foundations and masonry of some of the administrative buildings.  11,000 Japanese Americans in that place, 8 to each barracks for 3 years.  Lots of Ghosts.  They had only the Sierra Nevadas to give them any visual solace in their natural surroundings.      We saw these spectacular peaks for over 60 miles on our northward ride on 395.  The tailwinds blessed us too, and we sometimes shifted to the highest gear and glided along at 25 mph. Found a darn good campground called Brown's Town about 1/2 mile from downtown.  It's got lawns and big shady cottonwoods, and the small store, showers, laundry, and mini-museum block the campsites from the highway noise.  There are the requisite RV's with their bug lights, flood-lit lanterns and televisions, but they are at least parked on the circumfrence of the grounds with tent sites on the inside.  Also, the quiet hours are enfourced starting at 10pm, wich thankfully meant the loud drunk men and the cover song of "Country Road" they were playing on the boombox were turned off.
   We had a good, hot breakfast in town and walked around.  There's also a great cafe called Kava Coffeehouse that has good espresso and fun decor and gifts.  I wish we had something like that in Bozeman. Right now we're lounging in the city park, wich is also nice, if unsheltered from Main Street & 395 traffic.  I've been wavering between heat and ride induced sleepiness and the need to relax.  I'll hit my stride soon.  I'm really enjoying myself.  Now I'm ready for the expanse and quiet of Nevada desert and Mountains.
   Both Dad G. and Jeff had expressed concern about the sparse services between Benton, CA, and Tonopah, NV -- an 81 mile stretch.  My pre-trip research notes showed a "Lodge and Casino" at the top of Montgomery Pass.  However, none of our "scouts" (who drove portions of our route while returning from our wedding ceremony) saw it while passing through.  Of additional concern was the "number out of service" message we got when we called the phone number. Our backup plan was to wait for nightfall and push all the way to Tonohpah in cooler temps.  However, at the cafe in Benton, the locals said the hotel remained open at Montgomery Pass -- even though the casino and restaurant were closed.  Hopeful, but not entirely convinced, we left Benton in the noon heat, sending some extra water ahead with a man named Don, who was on his way to Phoenix with his wife Cindy and small dog Ce Ce. (Thanks to the 3 of you!) We figured that even if the hotel was closed, we'd have enough food and H2O to camp in the shade of the buildings. The hotel was in fact open, as we learned from hand-written roadside signs as we crested Montgomery Pass.       The rest of the "resort" was closed, but the signs guided us around the back of the casino to the hotel office where we were met by several barking dogs and their master, Kevin. Kevin was a pretty deranged individual, stumbling around shirtless in the empty, weedy parking lot, shouting and talking to the dogs and himself.  He scared us a bit at first, but was friendly and cogent once we approached.  I learned that he was the "security guard" hired to look after the resort while the buildings, land, and gaming/liquor licenses got untangled in probate court.  He is very isolated out there, and his only contact with the world is through a CB radio. At any rate, Kevin rented us a surprisingly clean, comfortable room for the $27 cash we had on hand, rather than the standard $30 fee.  (Thanks Kevin!)  Given our alternatives, we totally lucked out.  Even got to spend the afternoon watching "Cable Guy" on the one channel that came in on the TV -- HBO! Montgomery Pass was certainly a strange place, but worked well for us.
Very empty country from Montgomery Pass here to Tonopah, but we made great time.  10.5 miles downhill in the first half hour, and 66 miles in 4 hours, 20 minutes.    It was a good thing we were fast, because the cinnamon Pop Tart, one energy bar, and one Gu were wearing off quickly in the 11am desert sun.  We had only a Pop Tart for breakfast because we bugged out of the Montgomery Pass Inn by 6:40am (with Kevin and his friends cheering us out of the parking lot. "We rule," according to them.)  We stopped in the middle of the empty desert to see what it was like to holler at the absolute top of our lungs.  Since there was nothing around to reflect the sound, it seemed like we were using normal speaking voices no matter how hard we yelled.    Tonopah appeared on the horizon at the top of a series of hills about 12 miles from the end, which made the last 50 minutes (in a headwind) tough.  It was a huge relief to find a Mexican restaurant for lunch, then a good motel for our stay -- the Jim Butler, named after the man who discovered silver in this area in the early 20th century.  Now Tonopah is a "historic mining town" and there is a museum and a tour route of the former mines. The town is struggling, if the many boarded-up hotels, stores, and gas stations are any indication.  The motel information packet had among its many "local pride" items a couple of articles about the test site of the Stealth Bomber, which was here between 1982 and 1992, and employed over 300 people, which must be a sizeable part of the population.  Luckily, we found this friendly, spacious, air conditioned room in a motel that has hung on since 1979.
  After descending from the hilltop in Tonopah, we fought our first significant headwinds of the trip.  After 30 miles or so, we finally turned to the right and had cross-to-tail wind as we rode up the Big Smoky Valley, a broad valley with 11,000 foot peaks to the east and west.  The place is so expansive that its hard to take photographs that do it justice.      A nice short day -- we stopped in Carvers, a fairly prosperous mining town with a small hotel, store, and cafe -- but not much else.  More afternoon HBO in the air conditioned motel room.
As we set off Tuesday, we were thinking we might camp in the Toiyabes near Kingston, but we arrived in only 2 hours and the wind was blowing hard out of the west.  We decided to use those winds to push across highway 50 for Eureka and take a rest day on Wednesday. We made great time.  We also got bad "Baboon Ass" and made up a song about it.  Sample verse: It's the prickly heat Like your sitting on glass Sore in the posterior We've got Baboon Ass! Despite a challenging climb over Hickison Summit, we pushed the high gear at  25 mph much of the way, and took a desperately needed break at a Highway 50 rest stop -- just shelters and picnic tables.    We sailed along the remaining 30 miles with a bit of uphill into Eureka.  Checking into the Best Western, we met Moe and Betty from Indianapolis.  They took our picture in the parking lot.    Moe and Betty invited us to join them for dinner.  Moe is an Electrical Engineer who spent many years recording demo tapes for bands in his home  studio .  He was very knowledgable about music, and as the restaurant tape loop cycled for the 2nd or 3rd time he shouted, "DAMN YOU KENNY G, YOU'LL BURN IN HELL FOR THIS!"  A memorable line that kept us entertained for many days after.   We also heard about their hobby flying free-flight model gliders.  Very nice folks, and we appreciated their company.
   Eureka is tucked into low lying foothills, sheltered from the wind that blew us there.  The town boomed with silver strikes at the end of the 1800's, with its population growing to 10,000 by 1890.  Now it's not much more than 1 or 2 thousand, but many of its buildings from the turn of the century still stand among some closed up businesses. We found a really nice room at the Best Western, a perfect place for spending a rest day.  As we lounged on the lawn of the former Eureka County High School, some pubescent boys were scrambling across and said, "Hi, where are you from?"  We answered, and they responded, "This place sucks -- I don't recommend it!"  We reassured them that most kids their age in this country feel the same way about their home towns.
   A very very quiet road;  we had about 2 or 3 cars pass us from behind, including a UPS truck that passed again from the other direction.    A horse ran with us for about 2 miles, easily reaching 20 mph I would guess.  Don't know what it was thinking, but it ran with us on one side of the road about 100 yards away, then crossed the road in front of us at a trot.  Once it got far ahead of us, it would stop and keep staring at us, then when we passed start running with us again.  I was a little nervous it would decide to charge or try to mate with our green two-headed creature.  Eventually, it tired out though.  Beautiful chestnut colored, rather thin horse.  It was on a ranch, but we wondered whether it might be wild with its ribs showing and all. We camped at cold creek reservoir, near where the pavement ends on highway 892.    There was a cluster of mobile homes across the highway, used to house employees of the nearby Bald Mountain mine.  A man (whose name we never got) came down to the reservoir to exercise his dog.  He drank beer from his cooler (without offering us any) and gave us a good ribbing about our trip.  The discussion went like this: ===== "What are you doing camped out here?!" "We're travelling through." "On THAT?!" (gesturing to our bike) "Yes." "Why don't you get a JOB?!" ===== And on it went.  He was pretty obnoxious, but it didn't bother us too much.  I guess he had a point.  It was pretty ridiculous for us to be out there camping on a bike.  Before leaving, he asked, "So what are you going to have for dinner tonight, SOUP?!"  Actually, it was macaroni and cheese from a box, but we laughed about it for the rest of the trip.
   Highlights of Cold Creek:  lightning show at dusk, clouds covering the blazing sun, a lovely quiet morning with trout leaping and splashing all over the water's surface to catch bugs. Had cloud cover most of Friday's ride, and about 4 ranching trucks passed us for the entire stretch of dirt road -- almost 5 hours of riding.  Very very quiet and desert-pastoral.    Cattle watched us pass by, and we very carefully rode through one pack of mamas and babies, making sure not to get between cows and their calves.    We arrived in Jiggs by lunchtime, but the lone bar there had only snack food.  The older couple running the place were friendly though.  The husband said when he was a young rancher, they'd drive a herd of cattle the 32 miles to Elko over the course of 3 days.  Made our upcoming 2-3 hours seem speedy by comparison. Lots of roly-poly hills to Elko that wore on us.  The clouds also got thicker, and the brief storm decided to strike just as we finished a last brutal climb in high speed, four lane traffic. The minute we hit Elko's outskirts the obnoxious driving joined forces with the storm and nearly knocked us off the bike. The narrow shoulder on the descent had a rumble strip of course.  We should  have used the drum brake and taken our time, but we felt the urgency to beat the rain and get away from the crazy drivers as soon as possible.  The rain really started coming down and the wind gusted.  We rode to the left of the white line to stay clear of the rumble strip, and an especially moronic driver in a camper honked at us, then passed about 6 inches to our left.  With the wind blowing hard from the left, the side draft from the camper sucked us way out into the travel lane.  I put a curse on the driver of that truck:  the propane tank will be exploding and the holding tank bursting open about 50 miles out of Elko -- i.e. in the middle of NOWHERE. After we escaped that catastrophe, we were just reaching the bottom of the hill, getting pelted with rain, when a big gust of wind blew across the road.  I saw it coming from a sandy hill to the left of us, blowing every grain of dirt from the hill and about to pick us up and off the road.  Luckily the wind was not blowing from the other side, because that gale sent us sailing 6 feet over, but luckily away from traffic.  Dan finessed it -- we went over the rumble strip, but we managed not to skid off the 6 inches of asphalt and into the pebbles and sand , where we would definitely have gone down at 25+ mph. We followed a motorcyclist into a car wash bay, and waited about 30 seconds for the storm to end, praising the skies we weren't hurt, and laughing at our filthy, sandblasted bodies.   
After a great sleep in the motel, we set off on what developed into one of the best days of riding so far.  First, however, we took our picture in front of a bunch of motorcycles, just to show how well we fit in with the bike rally that was happening in Elko that weekend.      The day's ride started with a 9-mile climb to Adobe Summit.     It then continued up rolling hills up to Wild Horse Reservoir, on the divide separating the Humboldt and Owyhee/Jarbidge river drainages.  Lots of climbing, but good tailwinds pushed us along.      We made a brief stop at a bar to pick up supplies for cocktail hour in camp later.  After a twisty ride through the Owyhee River Canyon, we arrived at a lovely forest service campground -- a good one to remember in the future.      As a bonus, we can coast 8 or so miles into Mountain City for a hot breakfast in the morning.  Life is good.
   We gorged ourselves on microwave breakfast burritos, and things went pretty well from there.  However, it became clear that I'd made a mistake in my mileage calculations.  The trip to Bruneau was more like 100 miles instead of the 70-80  we'd planned on.  Everything went fine until the last 15 miles or so, when we hit strong, hot headwinds from the north.  The 90+ degree heat made the valley a real blast furnace.  What a contrast with the start of our day in the canyon with all of our warm weather gear on and temps in the 40's. We hunkered down as the last of 62 (Marilyn counted) motorcycle riders from Elko roared by.  About 2 miles from town, on a deceptive uphill into the wind, there was additional insult to our already considerable injury.  I got stung by a bee -- ouch! At the supermarket in Bruneau, we learned that our intended campsite at Bruneau Dunes was 10+ miles away, with considerable climbing in hot wind.  NO WAY. Fortunately, Boyd Campbell came to our rescue. (Thanks Boyd!)  He drove me around town (more or less around the block) in his pickup, and showed me the town's cafe, bar, and (most importantly) park!.  A small patch of shady grass off the highway where we could pitch our tent for the night.  We sat and waited until the Junior Rodeo awards ceremony broke up (good turnout).    Then we settled in for the night.     Surely more adventure tomorrow.
After a great breakfast in Mountain Home, we finally bought an Idaho map at Albertson's.  Dan asked about the terrain from there to Fairfield. On the map, there was a suspicious kink in the road, but no pass or elevation indicated.  The woman at the cash register said there were "a few gentle hills" but nothing too bad. We cursed that woman the entire 3800 feet and 30 miles of climbing to Cat Creek Summit, which we renamed "Crackpipe Summit" in honor of that woman's totally deluded, brain-blown, numbskull idea of "a few gentle  hills!"  The last bit to Crackpipe Summit was a mile of 9% grade and it bumped our total climbing for the day (including the hills out of Bruneau) over 5000 feet.    That woman was friendly enough, but (warning, emotional outburst ahead) JEEZ TAKE A LOOK AROUND YOU, PAY ATTENTION, KNOW YOUR WORLD OR AT LEAST THE PLACE WHERE YOU LIVE FOR THE LOVE OF GOD!!!!! So, that was a brutal day, not knowing we were in for the longest climb of the trip.  On the upside, the ride was beautiful: green flowering hills, creeks and rivers, and when we finally, finally hit the flats, rolling agricultural fields. and the Boulder Mountains. We pulled into the first motel we saw in Fairfield, and there was a group of 19 cyclists from the Seattle area.  They call themselves the Goosebumps, and they were supporting themselves with 2 vans (taking turns driving) on a 7-day loop in Idaho.  They welcomed us and empathised with our travelling stories and the ignorance/boneheadedness of that woman that took us over our limit of belief and patience.  (What, did you think the emotional outburst was over?) We had dinner with the crowd of them -- all really friendly and fun people.  We will be sharing the road with them for a few days, through Ketchum to Stanley.
   That may have just been a polite way of saying, "Hey dumbass, are you trying to get yourself killed out here on the highway?"  But we nevertheless appreciated the tip, and enjoyed the ride into Ketchum for a much-needed rest day.

     We slowly chugged our way up to 8701 foot Galena Summit -- our high point for the whole trip.    The Seattle Goosebumps gang was at the overlook on the other side.  They generously offered their turkey sandwich makings, bananas, broccoli and dip, Fritos, and M+M's among their huge lunch spread.  (Thanks Goosebumps!)    The Salmon River lay below us, and a 300 year old White Pine stood guard at the rest stop.      The Goosebumps went back down the summit to climb up again.  But we two with our TUB (or bike:  "The Ultimate Behemoth") and our BOB (our trailer: "Beast of Burden") could not and would not.  We headed down the other side to Redfish Lake.    We found a great campsite -- a walk-in, tents only loop in Point Campground.  At one end of Redfish Lake are some spectacular snow-capped Sawtooth peaks.  We gazed on them over our G+T's and dinners at the lodge restaurant.  A great place with nice beaches -- must be a zoo on weekends, but great for kids.
   Stopped for coffee in Stanley, and parted ways with the Goosebumps.  We took in more gorgeous scenery along the Salmon, and stopped for lunch in the small park in Clayton.    Finished the day in a motel room at the northern edge of this town fringed with red and beige and cream striped cliffs.
We had a delicious lunch in Salmon and bought some more camping food before taking to the road again on the highway south.  There were lots of cattle and horses to greet along the way, but we were getting tired and the road was flat and strait -- hence, rough on the butt.  Actually the road had a visually imperceptible rise, so the 20 miles to Tendoy and the turnoff for the dirt road to Lemhi pass took longer than I thought -- or seemed to anyway. After a Hostess (cupcakes for me, apple pie for Dan) and cold drink break at the little store in Tendoy, we got on the bumpy but thankfully short dirt road to our BLM campsite.      Agency Creek babbles just a few yards from our tent on this small campground. Tomorrow it is 8 or so miles and 2000+ feet to Lemhi Pass, but on a quiet dirt road and in lovely scenery.
   After that, the climbing got more serious.  There were several sections that were just too steep to pedal a loaded bike -- at least not without a gear lower than our 30x34 creeper.      At any rate, it was only a little bit slower to get off and push.  So, we stubbornly turned down a BLM employee's offer to drive some of our gear to the top, and we pressed on, alternating pedaling and walking.  I swear the last several hundred yards were over 20% grade -- super steep.  At 7.5 miles, we reached the top and officially entered Montana!      Spent some time looking at historical markers with a few Lewis and Clark buffs who'd driven up -- including one who gave us cold Dr. Peppers from his cooler (thanks, stranger).        After we left, we descended 13 miles on bumpy but beautiful dirt roads.    Next came a 20 mile cruise to Clark Canyon reservoir with tailwinds most of the way.  The same wind pushed us the final 17 miles into Dillon.  Hot showers and sound sleep at the Best Western -- ahh.
   After that, we literally had smooth sailing.  The wind blew us to Whitehall, then through the Jefferson River Canyon to Lewis and Clark Caverns for our final night out.      We're starting to look forward to getting a good lickin' from Genki (our dog).  Should be about 55 miles to Bozeman.  See you there!
We also had incredible good luck from a mechanical standpoint.  Over nearly 1400 miles, our biggest problems were cable stretch and chain grit -- not even a flat tire!  Here's our reliable machine loaded up for the last leg of our trip.    Show links to this Hide links to this      We rode the "back way" to Three Forks through Willow Creek    At the Three Forks Cafe, two old timers joined us at our table, and shared conversation and coffee.  It was reasurring to come home to such local friendliness after travelling through so many other places.  We'd made an earlier pact to photograph the first sign that told the mileage to Bozeman.  Riding secondary roads, it came later than we expected, but come it did.    Our friend Maxwell met us on Springhill road as we approached town, and escorted us the final few miles to our house.    Upon arrival, we saw first hand the chaos of the remodel/addition that got underway while we were out of the house for a month.  Things are a bit "rustic" around here at the moment, but we're happy to be back, sharing our adventure with friends and family.   





  For those not aware of some of my more eccentric quirks, I used to choose my travel destinations based on what letter of the alphabet the country started with.  Somehow, a long time ago, I got into a discussion with somebody about travelling, and we realized that I had been to countries from about twenty letters of the alphabet.  I decided to finish the alphabet, and started choosing destinations based on the alphabet.  At the time, I was getting close to finishing, and only needed to visit K,Q, and Z.  Time was running out, as Zaire had recently changed to the Congo.  There were only two countries left that started with Z, one with Q, and a handful with K.  There was also a solar eclipse that would sweep through South Africa, including Zambia, Zimbabwe, and Mozambique.  That sealed my decision, and I booked myself a two month vacation that would go to Kenya, Malawi, either Zambia or Zimbabwe, and if possible, Mozambique.  I would cover off K,Z and a solar eclipse.  What other reason do you need? 
This was a solo trip, and my first one of any great length.  I started out by reading every guidebook I could find on the region to determine whether it was safe to cycle, if the roads were good, and if there was anything to see along the way.  I also consulted the web to get information on the eclipse, including weather conditions, the eclipse path, and what to do about photographing it. Using the eclipse path as my final objective, I looked at all the airports within a few weeks riding distance.  Those with somewhat spotty reputations were dropped, and I finally settled on landing in Lilongwe, Malawi.  As an added bonus, I arranged a one week stopover in Kenya.  It was all coming together. The plan, if you could call it that, would be to fly from Vancouver to Amsterdam, spend a day there and then fly out to Nairobi that evening.  I would stay one week in Kenya, and then fly out to Lilongwe, where I would have about seven weeks to somehow ride a bike to a convenient viewing point along the total eclipse line, and visit a country starting with the letter 'Z'.  Then I would head home.   For Kenya, I decided to splurge and go on a safari.  I found a place in Nairobi called 'Bike Treks', that does supported bike tours, as well as regular safaris.  I got in contact with them via e-mail, and made arrangements to tag along with a group that was leaving the day I would arrive.  Getting gear was next.  The sub Saharan part of Africa was one of the poorest regions in the world, which meant it would be cheap to travel in.  There wouldn't be any need to camp, but there were a few parks that I might need a tent.     So, I would cycle with the occasional night in a tent, and rely on restaurants for hot food.  Originally, I planned to take a bike on the plane, but decided against it because I didn't want to pack and unpack it in Nairobi, one of the more dangerous cities around. As well, I learned it was possible to buy bicycles in Malawi.  It didn't seem worth the hassle. I picked up a pair of Arkel 54l expedition panniers, a waterproof handlebar bag, and a frame bag.  These would have to carry all my gear.   Eventually, I filled them up with the following equipment: Allen keys  Headset wrench   13/15 mm cone wrench   16/17 mm cone wrench   chain break   small crescent wrench   combination presta/shraeder   pump patch kit (with 40 patches)   spare shifter and brake cables   tire irons  'universal'  spoke wrench   white duct tape (useful for making labels, too!)  bungee cords   Leatherman wave two t shirts  gortex jacket  silk shirt  convertible long pants/shorts quick  dry shorts  5 pairs underwear and socks  camera gear (OM-2, 28-200 Tamron zoom, doubler, 24 mm prime, Pentax WR-90, and 35 rolls of film)  minidisc recorder  tent/groundsheetthermarest  mosquito net  hydration pack  reading material  journal  two dozen power bars  plastic spoon and fork  medical kit toiletries  water treatment drops  compass  small luggage locks  padlock  other things that I am unable to remember right now.
   I arrived in Amsterdam in the morning, and took the train from Schipol airport to the central station.  The airport is only a short fifteen minute train ride away from the center, making it one of the better places to have a layover.      I had not been in Amsterdam for ten years, and marvelled at how clean the city had become.  Renovations were going on everywhere, and the streets looked much cleaner than I remembered them to be.  However, Amsterdam still remains one of the most deceivingly difficult places to navigate.
