It is laid out in a horseshoe pattern, with canals all over the place to further confuse and disorient the newcomer. I spent the greater part of the morning trying to walk to the Rijksmuseum, where you can find the works of Vincent Van Gogh, and other Dutch artists.  After several wrong turns, I finally arrived at the museum, only to find huge lineups and an expensive entry fee.  It seemed a bit extravagant to go in, as the museum entrance fee was roughly equal to three days living expenses in Malawi.  Instead, I spent the rest of the afternoon hanging out in the park beside the Rijksmuseum.  Amsterdam is a great place for just doing nothing.      That evening, I flew to Nairobi on Air Kenya.  All things considered, it wasn't nearly as bad as I was expecting.  However, the meal portions were probably suggested by somebody from Weight Watchers.  I recommend bringing extra food. 
Masai Mara National Park is the place where all documentary crews go.  It is literally brimming with wildlife, and the destination of the famous wildebeest migration in July.  Like usual, I was there at the wrong time.  It was May, and the wet season had just ended.  At that time, the park was still green, but quickly turning yellow as the land dried out.  There was still lots of underbrush, so spotting smaller animals was next to impossible, but it was still easy to see the larger ones.    I had a fantastic time during the five days, taking bike rides and going on walks in the area outside the park, and going on game rides inside the park.  The guides spoke reasonably good English, and were very competent.  As this company caters to cyclists, the food was good, and plentiful.  They fed me enough to keep me full, which is an accomplishment in itself.      After the safari finished, I hired the guide/driver for a day of sightseeing in Nairobi as well.  Nairobi National Park is just outside the city, and one of the better spots to see rhinoceros.  We were very lucky, and spotted rhinos twice while in the park.   Afterwards, we went to the Carnivore restaurant, where you can eat many of the animals that you just photographed.  Some people think it is tacky, but eating beef in Africa is far more damaging environmentally than eating the local species that are much better adapted to the environment.  Ranting aside, crocodile really does taste like chicken! 
Lilongwe was only mildly dangerous compared to other African cities.  However, car jackings were not uncommon, and certain stretches of road were considered dangerous to walk along.  I heard a report that a Japanese tourist was mugged in broad daylight while crossing a small, very busy bridge into town and that somebody had been recently murdered at night just outside the guesthouse.   Crime aside, I still needed to buy a bicycle, and headed off to a section of seedy looking shops.  I was in  the automotive section of the city, and there wasn't a bicycle store in sight.  However, one of the store owners knew where I could find a bike, and proceeded to call the shop to enquire about prices, and then give me instructions on how to get there.  He was very helpful, and eased my worries and paranoia. I found the bicycle store, and took a look at a few of the bikes.  Most were Indian made one speeds, but there were a few Taiwanese rigid frame bikes that would be suitable.  I left to see if there was any other stores that had similar bikes.   There wasn't.  It was the only store in the city that I could find that sold mountain bikes of reasonable quality.  This wouldn't make negotiating a price any easier.   I had other things to do as well.  Since I now knew there was a suitable bike, it was time to plot a suitable route.  My original intention had been to fly up north, and ride down to Zambia, visit a national park, and then head to Zimbabwe, cross into Mozambique for the eclipse, and then ride back to Lilongwe and head home. This plan failed miserably, and I ended up doing something completely different.  There were far too many hurdles.  First off, I tried to buy a flight ticket to the north, but the flight I wanted had been cancelled.   They were quite willing to sell me a ticket, but I would be unable to book any date.   Second, the political situation in Zimbabwe was getting increasingly unstable and could be potentially dangerous to ride through.  Finally, it would take a week to get a visa for Mozambique, and I really didn't want to spend the next week in a somewhat dirty city with absolutely nothing to see or do. So, another plan was needed.  Meanwhile, I met two Australian travellers at the guesthouse. They not only gave me recommendations on where to go and what to see in Malawi, but more importantly, showed me where to find the best chicken biryani in the city.  This biryani was a special recipe, and had to be ordered a day in advance.  All three of us ate there every day, no doubt contributing to a new wing in the restaurant owner's home.      Apart from food, the Australians had been in Malawi for six weeks and had plenty of good suggestions on where to go.  With this in mind, I made a plan that not only could work, but one that I actually followed.  Well, mostly.  Nothing ever falls together exactly as planned. I would ride south to Mulanje, via Blantyre and Dedza.  Then, I would head back north to Lake Malawi, and then ride back through Lilongwe, and make a beeline for Lusaka.  From outside Lusaka, I would see the eclipse, and then head back to Chipata, stop at the national park, and then go back to Lilongwe and head home.   Getting everything set took three days.  With the new plan, there was now no need to get visas and I could leave as soon as I had wheels.  Getting a bike and appropriate gear was all that was left.  The day before I departed, I spent an hour trying to bargain down the price of a 21 speed, aluminum frame mountain bike.  The owner knew he had me, and wouldn't budge on price.  He did bring in a mechanic to tune it up, and threw in a few spare spokes and inner tubes.      That evening, I put some puncture prevention strips in the wheels and checked to see how everything fit.  It would work!  Even better, I jokingly mentioned to the others at the guesthouse that I was selling the bike.  An aid worker who was in town that week heard me, and said she would buy the bike from me.  She would pick it up at the guesthouse when I returned in six weeks. Armed with a bike, two dozen power bars, a kilogram of chocolate, and a chicken biryani, I was ready to hit the road! 
   The road was smooth and had a good shoulder.  Within an hour of riding, it started getting hilly, hot and sunny.  However, there was little traffic to cause me grief.  I wore myself out taking on hills too quickly, and had to stop several times for water, chocolate, and of course, chicken biryani.   By one, I was 65 km further, hot, and tired.  A convenient bottle store appeared, and I stopped to get a cold drink.  Just as I finished what seemed like the world's smallest Fanta, a vein in my nose burst.  While I sat there trying to get my nose to stop bleeding in the heat, a South African mining engineer stopped and offered me a lift.   I gratefully accepted, and rode the last 20 km in the back of his truck.  He dropped me off at the turnoff to Dedza, and I pedalled the remaining kilometer into town.  Dedza wasn't a very big place, and I couldn't really figure out why it was where it was, and how it survived economically.  This was the first of many inexplicable towns that I rode through.  Despite its size, there was one somewhat questionable guesthouse which had a cheap room where I could store my bike. The guesthouse restaurant served up some fish and rice for me.  After the chicken biryanis I'd been eating for the last few days, the meal was pretty dull and unimaginative.  I had no desire to eat the ubiquitous nsima, expecting there to be plenty of opportunity to eat it in the future. 
   I was planning to stay at an agricultural station about 10 km before Ntcheu.  However, the police, of all people, gave me the wrong directions to the turnoff, and I rode several kilometers downhill by the time I realized there was a mistake.  As it was too much work to turn around and start riding uphill, I continued to Ntcheu in the hope that there would be somewhere to stay there. When I arrived in Ntcheu, it was mid afternoon.  Ntcheu was bigger than Dedza, in the same way that an ant is bigger than  a flea.  Surprisingly enough, there was a small rest house, and restaurant.  There wasn't else much to the town, except for a local soccer (football) game that was happening down the street.   After the game finished, there was little to do except eat.  The local restaurant had only nsima.  It isn't easy to describe nsima.  It is essentially corn flour that is boiled and formed into palm size balls.  Nsima is usually served with some sort of meat and sauce, fried vegetables, and occasionally eggs.  You break/pull a bite size piece off of the ball, and roll it into whatever sauce is available.   All I can say about eating nsima is that it is an acquired taste that I never acquired, and the thought of eating it for three months was one of the reasons that I decided to go to India on the next trip.      After dinner, I was really tired and tried to write in my journal, before turning in.  The journal entry read 'I am currently in Ntcheu, in a 100 kwacha single. Here is peaceful, but not like times where you punch them and they faint.  So the last standing gets very rich.  Too tired to write anym...'  What was I thinking about?  Only the shadow knows, now. 
  It was downhill, and easy for the first few hours.  However, as the altitude dropped, and the sun rose, the temperature became increasingly uncomfortable.  I was descending into the Shire valley.  This was the hottest part of Malawi, and a bit of trivia that I only found out after it was too late.   By  eleven, it was getting around 32C.  There were some clouds casting shade onto the road, and I spent some time darting between cloud shadows, trying to maximize shade time.  Apart from the occasional cloud, there was no shade anywhere, as most of the trees by the roadside had been chopped down for wood, or to make fields.  My bottom bracket was starting to act up.  I would have to get it adjusted in Blantyre. The next three hours were spent riding short distances, collapsing, eating sugary snacks, and drinking large quantities of water.  Although not much progress was made,  I did break my personal best for most sugar eaten in one day. The heat of the day had passed by mid afternoon, only to be replaced by a more hills.  Now that I was on the other side of the Shire river, the land once again rose, this time to the plateau where Blantyre was situated.  I could feel my legs getting more tired on each stroke.    Somewhere around 4:30, I rode into Lirangwe, the last 'major' settlement before Blantyre.  There was a sign for a guesthouse, which probably hadn't had a guest for years.  The room was small, dirty, lacking a mosquito net or fan.  The toilet and shower were outside, and consisted of two rooms.  The toilet was room with a hole in the middle, and the shower was a room with a bucket of water and a piece of tin corrugation  for a door.   But, the price was right, at only 60 k. As I was the first guest to come by in some time, the owner said she would cook my dinner.  We haggled over price and content, and eventually settled on goat meat with rice.  I was very happy not to be subjected to nsima.  With no dining room, I ate on the steps in the back yard, with a view of  a large pile of corn husks and junk.  Not exactly high living, but good enough for me.  My legs were now running out of energy, and I was asleep within minutes of finishing dinner.   
The heat was stripping what little strength remained in my legs.  It was uphill, with little, if any shade on the road.  Then, I came across a bottle store selling cold drinks.  I had a new system!  Stop at the bottle store, drink something cold, wait until I cooled down, and then ride to the next bottle store.  You don't get far fast, but at least you eventually get there. Three and a half hours  and 15 km later, I wheeled into Blantyre, and found the campsite. At the point of exhaustion, I collapsed on the couch at the reception desk, and could not move for half an hour.  When the feeling returned to my legs,  and my eyes could once again focus, I noticed that I was in a place with toilet paper, and a restaurant that did not list nsima on the menu.  I was back in the tourist part of town.    This was not necessarily a bad thing, even for somebody as tourist averse as myself.  One of the bar staff found me a mechanic who adjusted my bottom bracket for 50 k, and I met several other travellers who gave me valuable information on Mt. Mulanje.    Mt. Mulanje was a huge rock massif, about 100 km south of Blantyre.  It was a nature reserve, and popular for really long ( three-four days) walks.  Several travellers had said it was worth going to, but I had no camping gear, and a bicycle.  According to two Americans,  it would be possible if I got a suitable hiking pack, and found somewhere to stash the bike.  There were huts, and a porter could provide cooking gear. A side note about Americans.  As a Canadian, I have been  culturally ingrained to believe in the inherent superiority of Canadians  over Americans in both international relations, and hockey.  We all have stereotypical images, and the ugly American is one of them.  That being said, I did not meet one ugly American the entire time I was in Africa,  and found those that I did meet to be really great, open minded, individuals.  Stereotypes! Pah!  Sure, there are some ugly Americans out there, but that's not every American.  And the most obnoxious person I ever met happened to be from Canada, and from my home town, Vancouver (well, Surrey but close enough).  I'm still trying to come to terms with that one. As for the rest of the day?  I met the campsite manager, who was from Victoria, the city I attended university.  He had been working earlier in Zimbabwe, and told me that the Canadian ambassador had just been  beaten by a few of Mugabe's underlings.  This prompted the Canadian government to sever all diplomatic ties with Zimbabwe, and pull out all economic aid.  Suddenly, I was much happier about not being anywhere near Zimbabwe.  It would be Zambia for the letter Z, or nothing. 
Apart from email, and pack buying, there wasn't much in Blantyre to attract the regular tourist.  There was, however, a few things to distract somebody like myself.  First, there was a Nando's Chicken.  This is a South African chain that chars chicken to perfection.  It was almost the same price as back home, but a welcome break from the less than culinary delights I'd been eating for the last few days.   In what may be one of the strangest juxtapositions of eating I have ever seen, I also found a combination hardware store/Indian take out restaurant.   The food was very good, and you could get a bag of plaster with your samosas.  So, if you ever have an urge to have a curry, and do some plumbing, I know the place to go... 
After getting  out of the city, the ride to Mt. Mulanje was great.  The M-3 passed through countless, bright green tea plantations, and rolling hills.  Today was much easier than previous days.  It was a net drop in elevation from Blantyre to Mulanje, and I was finally adjusting to the heat.  To top it off, I had plenty of company along the way.  Early in the day, a freshly graduated teenager rode beside me and struck up a conversation.  He was on his way to a job interview for the tourism office of Malawi.  We chatted and rode down the M-3, until he reached the turnoff to the tourism office.    About  five km later, I was joined by Noah, a junk salesman.  He was on his way to visit a friend about 20 km away.  He developed bike trouble soon after, and we stopped to fix the problem.  It was more serious than anything I could fix, and we walked the bike to the next town in search of a bike mechanic. Fortunately, bike mechanics are everywhere in Malawi, and Noah soon had a working bike.  One thing I noticed about Malawi was the complete absence of accessible information. Newspapers were controlled by whoever was in power, as was local television.  The internet was a luxury out of reach to the majority of the people.   Noah was hungry for any news about the outside world and I did my best to inform him of the latest events.        We rode together for an hour, when he spotted his friend waiting for him on the side of the road.  (How does anything get done with such poor communications?)  After he met his friend, I rode on my own for about fifteen minutes.  Then, I was passed by two men on bicycles.  They were two fishmongers on their way to Chipitali and  rode with me the rest of the way.  They were in fantastic shape, and I could barely keep up with them, even though I was drafting them in a headwind, and they both were carrying full loads of fish.      Exhausted, but trying to pretend that I wasn't, we arrived in Chipitali, a small town only a few kilometers from the forestry office.  I stayed in Chipitali that evening, and bought some last minute supplies for  trekking on Mt. Mulanje.  Tomorrow, I would be on the mountain, and could hardly wait.   
   While it is a pretty poor place for biking, the Mulanje massif is a fantastic place to hike.  I could go on and on about walking on Mulanje, but this is supposed to be about cycling and not hiking.  I'll keep it brief.    There is beautiful scenery on the plateau, and fantastic views of Malawi and Mozambique. There are also huts strategically placed on the massif, making it easy to stay for longer than a day.  For my trek, I opted to be a bourgeois tourist, and hired a porter through the forestry office.      Francis was my porter.  He was going to trade school to be a mechanic, but had to drop out because of a shortage of funds.  This was my first real exposure to how difficult life was in Malawi.  Both his father and sister had passed away (I didn't ask further, but believe it was probably AIDS) and he barely got enough work as a porter to get a job once or twice in a year.      It took  three days to walk across the massif.  The walk was a welcome change from cycling, and I was enjoying the scenery immensely.  The flora changed from pine and cedar forest on the slopes, to grassland and scrub on the plateau.  The peaks were stripped bare of vegetation but offered great views of the surrounding countryside.    There were several huts to stay at en route, and these were mostly empty.  It was chilly at night, even inside the huts, and I was glad to have brought some warm clothing and a sleeping bag.    Francis usually cooked with the hut caretaker, wisely leaving me to eat my own cooking.      On the last day, he asked me for help.  I was in a bind.  Should I give him a handout, or just say I couldn't help him?  I didn't want to leave him in the cold, nor did I want to make him a beggar.It was a tough call, because he was a very bright person in a bad set of circumstances.  I pondered the situation all evening. 
  After getting to the main road, we walked ten kilometers to Phalombe, found a rest house, stashed my bag there, and hitched a ride back to the forestry office.  For some reason, everyone  turned and stared at us when we passed.  This might have been plausible if they could see me coming, but I was sitting at the back of a truck that had no distinguishing features, and probably drove that road  several times a day.  Do Malawians have some sort of Mzungu (means 'white man') sense?  It's one of those travel mysteries that I will probably never figure out.  . After we got back to the forestry office, I fetched my bike, and we went to find Francis' friend.  It was no problem to borrow the bike,  and we rode out to Phalombe.  Although we were on a dirt road, the  ride took much less time than I expected, and we arrived with an hour of daylight to spare.      We went to the resthouse, cleaned up, had a meal,  and headed into 'downtown' Phalombe to meet some of Francis' friends at a shake shake bar.  'Shake Shake bar' is the local term for a watering hole that serves traditional beer.  This beer, if you can call it that, was pretty horrible tasting.  It was like drinking half fermented malt water.  After one sip, I didn't even want to try acquiring a taste for it.  The rest of the evening was spent talking with Francis' progressively more inebriated friends, until the bar closed and it was time to get some rest.   
  By the time we got to Zomba, the sky had changed from sun to rain.  It was a welcome change to have a bit of cooler weather, but the rain only fell for a few minutes.  There certainly was not enough to change the drought that Malawi had been in for the last two years, but it did wet down the roads.   The  no longer dusty town of Zomba had a few banks, a large market, and not much else.   Though it took some searching at several nsima only restaurants, we had a last lunch together of chicken and rice.  After lunch, it was time to say goodbye.  Francis went to the market to find some shoes, and I headed out to Machinga.  I felt a bit strange to be on my own again, but glad to be heading north.   Machinga was another 25 km away, but the air was cool, and I coasted down the road. By the time I arrived in Machinga, it was nearly sunset.  I was in yet another tiny transit town.  Built around the crossroads, Machinga  had a few rest houses, and three restaurants.  I was hungry, and went to find some rice and meat.  At the first restaurant, the waitress said they had nsima but no rice.  At the second and third restaurants, they said the same thing.  At this  point, I gave up. It was nsima or starvation.  I ordered some nsima, and told the waitress to make it a large order because I was very hungry.  Of course, I forgot how much I despised the stuff, and regretted making the order when I saw the full platter of nsima arrive at the table.  My mother always told me to finish everything on my plate, and I did, though slowly and unwillingly.  It must have taken some time to eat, as they closed and shuttered the restaurant as soon as I left.  Or maybe they were trying to tell me something. 
After crossing the Shire river, I rode along the highway until I arrived at the Lirongwe turnoff.  This was another town that sprouted up solely because there happened to be an intersection of two roads.  At the turnoff, I bought some chicken and fried potatoes and settled down for a quick and greasy lunch.   Once lunch was over, I continued along the turnoff.  It led onto a  progressively worsening dirt road, that had some questionable sections where it became hard to distinguish the road from the adjacent fields.  About halfway down the road, I came across a derelict bridge and a small river.  The bridge looked less than sturdy, and the river looked quite shallow.  Fortunately, just as I was evaluating how deep it might be, a pickup came by, and gave me a ride across in the back.  The pickup dropped me off a few kilometers later.  After straightening up the bike, I rode along the now very questionable looking dirt road to the park entrance.  There was nobody at the gate, but eventually sombody came by to take my park entrance fee.  The park warden also warned me about elephants in the forest between the gate and the boat jetty.   I rode somewhat uneasily through the kilometer of dense forest, but arrived at the jetty intact and untrampled.  After a few minutes, a boat arrived to ferry myself and several park employees to the other side.  The ride across the Shire river was beautiful and all too short.  I dreamily watched some kingfishers fly by as we approached the jetty. We landed and unloaded at the camp jetty.  Even though we had only crossed the river, it may as well have been a different world.  Suddenly, I was out of Africa, and into some sort of weird tourist pipe dream.  Gone were the nsima serving restaurants and grotty pit toilets, to be replaced with a western buffet, and perhaps the finest bathroom in Sub-Saharan Africa.  Sadly, with western amenities come western prices.  It cost $8 USD for camping, which was roughly what I might spend for one week in a cheap transit hotel.  Price aside, it was a welcome break.      The staff seemed both relieved and disappointed when I said I wanted to camp, and not stay in a cabin.  The cabins had been fully booked, but my choice of sleeping arrangements signalled to them that I was probably a bad tipper.  Despite the potential lack of gratuities, a park worker showed me to the campsite, and gave me a quick tour of the facilities. After setting up my tent, and finding a place to stash my food from monkeys, I took a walk around the tourist camps.  About 50 m east of my tent, there was a sign warning not to proceed further without an escort.   To the west was the Shire river and the cabin compound.  Although a sign said that only cabin guests were allowed into the compound, I snuck in, just to see how the better half lives.   A pack of monkeys already had the same idea, and were lounging about on the deck chairs.  Soon, the paying guests arrived, scattering the monkeys and myself.  With almost nowhere else to go in the strip of no man's land that they called a camp site, I headed back to my tent.  Monkeys were also lounging about my tent, and ran for the trees when I arrived.  With nothing to eat in my tent, there was no reason for them to linger.  I do not want to think of what state my gear would have been left in had I kept food in the tent.      Soon after, it was time to go on the afternoon game drive.  I headed to the parking lot and got into one of those many seated safari trucks that you see in the glossy brochures.  There were several people in my truck already, and I quickly learned that I was surrounded by a group of Southern Baptist missionaries.  Despite my apprehension about spending the next two hours with a bunch of religious zealots, the Baptists turned out to be a good bunch of people, even if they did try to convert me a few times.      As for the game drive, Liwonde National Park was much more picturesque than the national parks in Kenya, but somewhat lacking in exotic wildlife.   We drove through scrubland dotted with baobab, and then headed to the Shire river to watch the sun set with the hippos and crocodiles, and the Southern Baptists.   That night, I woke to the sound of scraping outside my tent.  It sounded like somebody was shoveling gravel nearby, which got me curious.  Who would want to be shoveling dirt in the dark?  When I took a peek out of my tent, I saw a hippo feeding about 10 m away.  In Africa, hippos are the most dangerous animals to man, and can easily trample someone to death if panicked.  With that thought,  I zipped up the tent, and hoped that it did not resemble a giant vegetable in the dark.  Perhaps green was the wrong colour to choose for a tent. 
        The buffet was excellent, and a fine substitute for peanut butter sandwiches.  I loaded up on moussaka, bread, kebabs, and whatever else happened to be within reach of my grubby paws.  Chuck and Lonnie seemed very amused at how much food I could put away.  Bloated and content, we went back to their cabin to discuss the finer points of life and religion.  They were great guys, and replenished my severely depleted supply of snacks with their surplus candy.   By three, I was not feeling well, and went to my tent for a rest.  I was to go on a game drive a bit later, and wanted to be conscious for it.  An hour later, I felt a bit better and headed out into the park on another game drive.  I did not see much, and started feeling ill.  By the time we returned, I felt like vomiting, and almost did.  Montezuma reared his ugly head soon after, and I became well acquainted with the fine bathrooms at the campsite.  Fortunately, there were no hippos in the campsite that evening. 
  We walked for an hour through scrubland and clumps of baobabs, but saw little wildlife except for the occasional antelope and warthog.  Even so, the walk was over far too soon and it was time for me to get my gear together and get back on the road. It took me nearly two hours to pack up.  I was feeling ill and feverish, and did not really want to leave, but did anyhow.  I thought it best to stop at Ulongwe for some rest.  After getting a boat across the river, I rode back along the questionable dirt track/road to arrive at the questionable bridge crossing.  This time, a teenager helped me carry my stuff across the two or three remaining planks on the bridge.  He was really friendly, but I was feeling too ill to carry a conversation.   We rode back slowly, through densely packed farms and houses.  While riding past a school, I was spotted by  some school kids, who ran up to the road side and chanted 'Mzungu! Mzungu!'  They lined up on the side of the road, smiling and slapping my hand as we passed.  This wouldn't be the first time I would be mistaken for royalty in these parts. In Ulongwe, I found a cheap resthouse, collapsed into my room, and spent most of the day sleeping.  I was so tired that I barely noticed the  resthouse doubled as a night time drinking hole.  My stomach had settled by this point, but I thought it best to skip eating for the rest of the day.  Evening after a four hour nap in the afternoon, I was still barely conscious, and slept soundly the rest of the night. 
I headed off along a winding road that passed between Lake Malombe and adjoining hills.  After a few clicks, my legs started to fatigue, and I could feel symptoms of dehydration.  Fortunately, it was early and cool, and easy to ride along the mostly flat road.    I made great time, and I arrived at 9:30 AM, only three hours and change later.  Mangochi was a huge disappointment.  My guide book described Mangochi as a good spot to visit, and full of character.  Relative to any transit town, or big city slum, Mangochi did have some character, but not nearly enough to warrant an overnight stay, or a detour for that matter.    With nothing to see or do for the rest of the day, I had plenty of time to look for a bike mechanic.  My chain rings were coming out of alignment, and the largest ring made disturbing grinding noises on each revolution.  The others would not be far behind if I did not do something about it soon. Sadly, every book on mountain bike repairs had the same recommendation for making a chain ring adjustment.  Each one suggested to get a mechanic to fix it.  This was not going to be too helpful here.  Most mechanics in Malawi knew how to fix Indian bikes, but had little experience with the more complicated mountain bikes.  I would have to choose a mechanic carefully.   I rode to the market, and circled the mechanics section until I spotted a stall with a mountain bike in it.  This seemed to be the best way to handle it. I asked the mechanic if he could true the chain rings, and he said it would be no problem.  Like an idiot, I believed him.  He and his friend then proceeded to bend the teeth of the chain ring with a set of pliers.  At first, I thought they did things differently, and this approach was the standard practice.  When I took it for a test spin, it still rubbed, and I knew that this was not the way to true chain rings.      Back at the mechanic shop,  they seemed convinced they could fix it, and started trying to bend the front derailleur.  Seeing this, I quickly told them it was not as bad as I thought, and peeled the bike out of their hands before they could do any more damage.  It was better to cut my losses, than to let them continue on the remote chance they might fix it.   Now, I had a bike with misaligned chain rings, and bent teeth in the chainrings.  I was on my own and would have to get the job done by myself.  I bent back the teeth with my pliers, and then proceeded to straighten the chain rings by pounding them with my small crescent wrench.  As a side note, this worked, but it would be more effective with a larger hammer and a block of wood.  This is probably not the proper way to adjust chain rings, and to this day, I still don't know what the right way is. 
  It was another easy, short day. The road followed close to the lake, through burned out fields and spindly forests.  Once again, there was little shade on the road, but this was not important so early in the day.  My pace picked up, and I arrived at the campsite/guesthouse just as the owner's family was finishing breakfast.     The family was originally from Zimbabwe, but had their property expropriated some years back.  They were now running a guesthouse/restaurant for passing overland trucks and the occasional tourist trying to escape from the party zone in Cape Maclear.  They had built up a micro resort with cabins, a campground, and a dormitory by the lake. I opted to take a dorm bed instead of pitching my tent.  The dorm was only marginally more expensive, and was currently empty.  After getting unpacked and sorted out, I went to the living room to discover, wait for it .SATELLITE TELEVISION!  And, strangely enough, there was nothing on. That is, unless you count cricket.  I never did understand the nuances of cricket, or even the rules.  An English traveller was kind enough to explain it to me then, and it almost made sense.  I watched the game for a bit, got confused, and then mustered up enough energy to do some laundry.  With that out of the way, it was time for lunch. I was back in tourist Africa again, where nsima is only a bad memory.  The English traveller and I ordered beans and toast for lunch.  We talked, and waited, and waited, and waited.  Finally, after an hour, our meals arrived.  The owner's daughter set our plates down, completely oblivious to the fact that it took an hour to toast four slices of bread and heat up a can of beans.  It seems that African time applies to all people, both white and black. I spent the rest of the afternoon reading in the lakeside bar.  It was a welcome change from the royalty treatment that I was getting whenever I stopped somewhere.  As much as everyone likes attention, it can be very tiring to constantly acknowledge everyone's friendliness, and smile and be polite all the time.  I wonder how Prince Charles manages. That evening, I ordered spare ribs for dinner, and waited, and waited, and waited.  This time, owing to the fact that somebody probably had to hunt down a pig, it took two hours to get something to eat.  Despite the wait, or perhaps because of it, the food was delicious.  While waiting, I saw a bit more cricket, and discovered that the final game of the Stanley Cup  (hockey, for all you unenlightened infidels) was to air in two days.  I thought about staying an extra day to see the game, but had to consider how long it  might take to get served another meal.  To further add to the dilemma, the place was more expensive than non-tourist Africa and I was running low on currency.   
   For the first 20 km, I passed burnt out fields and scrub, with the occasional Malawian pedestrian.  What was unusual was that the people had changed.  Previously, I would ride past children and they would greet me with 'Mzungu' or 'Hello, Mister'.  Today, I was greeted by almost every child (and a few adults) with the universal  cry of 'Give money'.  With such close proximity to the beaches of Lake Malawi, begging from tourists had become a viable career option.        Gradually, the land rose and the flora changed from scrub to grassland.  Cattle lolled about in the shade of the small groves of red barked trees dotting the landscape. It was now nearing noon, and the sun was doing its best to roast me alive.  I tried to find a bottle shop but was surrounded by begging children every time I stopped.  It was agonizing to ride at the point of heat exhaustion, but the thought of being surrounded by open palms and begging voices kept me on the saddle.  Eventually, I arrived in Mua, and nearly kissed the ground to celebrate.        The Mua sanctuary was set up by Father Boucher, a missionary from Montreal.  He encouraged the local villagers to carve wooden figures, and set up a small mission and museum.  I pitched my tent on a grass knoll overlooking the botanical garden and set about to explore the area. The mission was built on the bluff of a small forested hill on the edge of the Dedza plateau.  There were several halls, a botanical garden, a small zoo, and a museum.  The museum focussed on the three tribes in the area.  It was surprisingly good for such a small place, and had very informative and colourful displays of the different types of masks used as well as detailed descriptions of the history of each tribe, and the religious beliefs. The village of Mua was a short walk away.  It was very small, but somehow supported a few market stalls and a lone restaurant.  Sadly, the lack of stalls meant my dietary choices were limited to nsima, and whatever vegetables I could find.      Mua was relief.  With and idyllic setting, and friendly, but not too friendly villagers,  I felt like I could relax and recharge without having to look over my shoulder for criminals or beggars.  The Australians who told me about Mua had given me great advice, and I was glad to have stopped here. 
  I spent three days in Mua. My knees were sore, and there was some numbness in my fingertips.  A few days of rest were in order.  I spent much of the time reading, eating nsima, and helping Father Boucher with various tasks at the mission.      There was also a small craft store that sold wood carvings done by villagers at the mission.  I ended up buying some small ones, being careful to remind myself that I still had to carry them to Lilongwe.   To prevent temptation, I would think about the two Australians who were carrying around  a very heavy, half meter tall carving throughout sub Saharan Africa, and their failed attempts to send it back to Australia 
  By the time we finished chatting about the route, it was nine in the morning and getting hot.  I set off, thinking it was an easy sixty km to Salima.  An hour later, the heat was starting to get to me, and to make matters worse, I could feel myself starting to bonk.  With my body screaming for some sort of energy, I drank a jar of honey, and continued riding.  Surprisingly enough, I felt better and rode into Salima shortly before one in the afternoon. In an all too familiar pattern,  Salima turned out to be another less than exciting place with grotty hotels and restaurants that served nothing but nsima.  There were several hotels to choose from, but being tired and lazy, I took the first one that I could find.  This turned out to be a mistake.  After I checked in, I took a shower to cool down, and then lay down for a quick nap.  I felt a bit feverish when I woke up, and noticed that my arms were developing small pustules. The water must have been dirty, and entered through a cut that I had received earlier. It did not seem serious, so I took the bike out to look for something to eat.  I was very tired of nsima, and cruised the market for fried potatoes and chicken.  I had thought to ride to Lake Malawi, but was now feeling more fatigued and abandoned the idea in favour of resting.    Quite unexpectedly, I found an internet caf near the main market.  The caf may have been trying to cash in on the sparse tourist traffic passing through on the way to Lake Malawi, as there were no Africans in the place. Like most of the internet services, this one was also painfully slow and expensive.  With e-mail finished, I headed back into the market and eventually found some chicken and potatoes.  As simple and greasy as it was, this  meal tasted delicious compared to the nsima I had been eating for the last three days.  Satiated, and tired, I rode back to the hotel for a good night's sleep. 
This was the day when the cycling stopped being fun.  I had seen enough run down hotels, and eaten enough horrible nsima to fully appreciate the African experience, and everyone and their dog asking me for money was starting to really annoy me.      By early afternoon, I had ridden to Mvera, and decided to call it a day.  Whether it was the fever, or my travel fatigue, I was getting increasingly paranoid, and could not help feeling like I was in an episode of Twin Peaks, where everything is normal, but strangely wrong.  There was just one rest house in Mvera.  Unlike other towns, the rest house attendant was very surly, and did not seem to want to rent me a room.  Tired, and unsure if there was anywhere else to stay within fifty kilometers, I used what little charm skills I had, and managed to get him to give me a room.  Unfortunately, a closer look at the rest house revealed disturbing amounts of empty bottles.  I had once again chosen to stay at the local watering hole.  My room was also looking disturbingly familiar.  Bad paint, a run down single bed with questionable looking sheets, and three walls you could touch simultaneously.   Even so, a bed was a bed, and I needed one.  While I was sorting my gear, I heard the not too distant sounds of a woman retching behind the walls of the rest house.  This was my signal to get out and take a look around. With the rest of the afternoon free, I stepped out to explore the market in Mvera.  Despite the stalls, the market area felt remarkably slow, and lacked any sort of bustle or vibrancy.  To top things off, the restaurant signs I had seen early turned out to date from a happier time, when there was some sort of business in town.  I got the impression from the half empty market that Mvera was slowly withering away.  In the market, some kids started shadowing me, and generally were being annoying.  Eventually they got bored of following me, as I did nothing interesting except  buy some fried potatoes for dinner. On the way back from the market, a glazy eyed man grabbed me and said 'I want to be your friend'  Given my state of paranoia,  I said that I was not feeling well enough to go for a drink, and hustled back to the rest house.      The owner was at  the rest house when I got back.  He seemed to be the only normal person in the town.  He had been in the army for 38 years, and retired to Mvera.  It was interesting to talk with him, but the infection on my arms was tiring me too much to keep talking. I tried to get some sleep in my room.  Soon after I lay down, two men decided to have a loud argument in the unfinished room beside me.  This went on far too long, but eventually I fell asleep. 
My arms were getting worse, making me  feverish and tired.  Though it was cooling down, I took nearly seven hours to ride the 65 km to Lilongwe.  On the outskirts of Malawi, I was running out of energy.  When a passing Malawian on a bicycle called out 'Hey Superman!' to me, my spirits lifted, and I proudly rode to the center of town. At the guest house,  I met two other travellers, both of whom were trying to establish tourist related businesses.  Derek was from Sweden, and ran cultural tours to Malawi for Swedes.  Mick hailed from Australia, and was in town to get some permits to set up a small lodge near some rock climbing cliffs in northern Malawi.   We headed out for dinner at the chicken biryani place.  The owner was happy to see me, and more happy to see that I had brought others.  No doubt, she already had further plans for house additions that would be financed by my biryani habit.   
  Guessing that the clinic was closed for lunch, we went to meet with some administrators.  Derek  wanted to arrange for tours of the hospital and needed to get permission from the hospital.  While he was meeting with some of the higher ups, I had a good look at the hospital. Getting into a serious accident in Malawi would be really bad.  The hospital had very few resources, and was very busy.  Sadly, in a country ravaged by drought and corruption, there was not any indication that conditions were going to get better any time soon. After the meeting finished, we headed back to the skin clinic.  It was well past lunch, there was still nobody at reception, and the lineup was still outside.  Not being sure when the clinic would reopen, I tried the door, and found that it had been unlocked the entire time.  I walked in and looked around until I found somebody sweeping the floor.  He fetched me a doctor, who prescribed me four days of oral antibiotics and some topical antibiotic powder.  I felt a bit bad about jumping the queue, but then again, how long would they have waited without me barging in?   When we returned to the guest house, I took the first antibiotic.  The effect was almost immediate.  That evening, I could almost see the infection draining, and the inflammation disappear.  The fever was gone within a few hours.  To help my recovery, I would take it easy, and convalesce.  With little else to do, I helped Mick draft a business plan for his rock climbing/abseiling venture.  I still wonder whether he ever got it off the ground, as we were making it up as we went along, and I was still a bit feverish.   I spent one more day in Lilongwe, doing very little except eating chicken biryani and sorting out what to leave behind on the trip to the eclipse.  Surprisingly enough, I weeded out about 5 kg of exposed film, useless tools, and souvenirs that would not be needed in Zambia. 
I left the guesthouse at 6:30 AM, riding along empty city roads to the highway junction.  It was cloudy that day, and cooler than usual.  The main highway ran straight through the endless brown fields.   It was slightly downhill, and I was making great time. I passed through Nametete at  9:45 AM, about two hours earlier than I expected.  Everything was going great, and then I got the first flat tire of the entire trip. This was surprising because I expected to have flats every day, not once a month.    Like usual, a crowd gathered when I stopped, and proceeded to offer helpful advice and helping hands changing the tube.  Just as I was tightening up the axle, a police car came from a road block that I had passed ten kilometers earlier, and asked if I needed any help.  I said I was fine, and thanked them for their concern.  They turned around and headed back to the road block.  It completely escaped my mind to ask them how they knew, and why they did not have anything better to do than drive ten kilometers out of their way to help a tourist fix a flat tire.  It must have been a slow day. I was getting excited.  The hills that marked the end of Malawi and the start of Zambia were getting closer.  About ten kilometers from Mchinji, I checked the time, and stopped for a celebratory meal of roadside fried potatoes.  It was only two in the afternoon!  I arrived in Mchinji an hour later and found a grotty hotel to stay in.  It had occurred to me to ride to Chipata in Zambia but this was another thirty five km away. This would be risky, as I had no idea what time the border would close or how long it would take me to clear customs.  I certainly did not want to arrive in Chipata after dark, or worse, get stuck overnight at the border post.  Chipata would have to wait until tomorrow.      Mchinji was more pleasant than I expected, but extremely humid.  My antibiotic powder turned into a paste, and I felt cold and clammy as soon as the sun went down.  There was not much too the town, other than a few hotels and a small market.  However, I did manage to find a restaurant in the market that served rice, which was a huge surprise given my past luck of finding palatable food in small towns. 
That being said I ended up leaving Mchinji at 6:45 AM, a bit later than I usually did.  It was about five kilometers uphill to get to the  Malawi border post.  It took five minutes to get stamped out of Malawi, and into no man's land.  I rode another ten kilometers along a slightly uphill road, past settlements, general stores, and rest houses before getting to the Zambian border post.  No man's land seemed only to be a suggestion.  What kind of no man's land has a hotel in it? At the Zambian side, it took about ten minutes to get stamped in.  The border hustlers seemed a bit confused when they saw me.  Unlike most of the mzungu arriving at the border,  I did not need to get a ride to Chipata, nor did I need to change money at extortionate rates to pay for the ride.  And people call cyclist tourists crazy! It was exhilarating to finally get to Zambia.  The letter Z was done, and I could now concentrate on getting to the eclipse.  As soon as I crossed the border, everything felt different.  The cloud tipped hills were covered with lush, dark green forests and grey boulders seemed to pop out of the landscape.  It was a wilder, more desolate place, and much less crowded than Malawi.  The people even looked healthier than Malawians.   (Bear in mind that about one third of the people in Malawi are HIV positive)    I really enjoyed the rest of the ride to Chipata.  It was mostly downhill,  and I was constantly passing and being passed by two Zambian students.  They were riding rickety Indian one speeds, and had to work hard to go uphill.  With superior gearing, I passed them easily.  When the hill went down, they quickly caught up, and it was my turn to be passed.   We had a good laugh each time it happened.  The game went on until we reached Chipata, where they turned off to go to one of the local schools. I found a campsite in Chipata and quickly set up.  It was a bit disorienting.  For much of the last month, I would arrive later in the day, and try to get my business done in a last ditch, exhausted rush before everything closed.  It was still only about nine thirty, I was feeling fresh and energetic, and I had the rest of the day to explore Chipata.   Chipata turned out to be one of the most pleasant border towns that I have ever visited.  It was clean, friendly and attractive, as far as border towns go.  Best of all, it had a large supermarket with a bakery that served cheese bread.  I loaded up with cheese bread, nuts, peanut butter, and biscuits with Rambo on the wrapper.  I wonder if Sly Stallone is aware of this? The regular market was also good.  I bought a papaya, some tomatoes and bananas,  and a few pieces of fried chicken.  Loaded with food, I walked into the hills outside of Chipata, stopping for a picnic lunch on top of a hill.  Forest and hills stretched into the horizon.  Somewhere out there was my destination.   When I returned back to the campsite, I met two travellers who were escaping from the eclipse and all the hoopla. Somebody was putting on a ten day rave in Lusaka.  The rave had just started, and would be ending a few days after the eclipse.  Lusaka was turning into a zoo, with hotel prices and restaurant meals skyrocketing as more and more people converged on the capital.   I decided that I would head to Luangwa  to view the eclipse, and stay as far away as possible from Lusaka. 
    I was staying in yet another filthy room, in a town that had no reason to exist other than its proximity to paved road to Mozambique.  The junk dealers told me the story that was becoming all too familiar.  There was no real opportunity to find work in this part of Zambia. There were no mines, and no industry here.  If you wanted a job with the government, you had to know the right people.   Everyone else scraped by on whatever the could sell or scrounge from the earth.  The economic situation seemed dire, and they complained about a lack of access to markets in Lusaka.  There was plenty of food grown here, but nobody could afford a vehicle to transport it to the big cities.      It was food for thought, and that made me hungry for some dinner.  In Zambia, there was no nsima.  Instead, they had nshima, which was exactly the same, except for the spelling, and the coarseness in the texture.  With no other choice, I reluctantly ate some for dinner, and turned in for the evening.     
  Petauke was my next destination.  The highway was getting progressively worse for wear.  Some sections had been eroding away for some time, leaving a maze of potholes to steer around, while other sections had gradually become more and more uneven as the ground settled beneath the tarmac.  I rode along the highway, doing my best to avoid the potholes and lumps.  By early afternoon, I was hot and tired, but kept pushing on.  I hit a stretch of road that was nothing but repaired potholes, and was subject to the bumpiest stretch of pavement I have ever been on.  My bike agreed, and promptly told me so by snapping a spoke to get my attention.     One of the sounds you do not want to hear is the sound of a spoke breaking.  This type of breakdown was one that I was not equipped for.  I had no vice with me, or even a free wheel tool.  With no other choices, I started pushing the bike along highway.  Fortunately, I had broken down only one and a half kilometers from Petauke.      In Petauke, I found a rest house to stay.  The manager, Nazareth, was with a very friendly, and helped me find a bike mechanic, who proceeded to fix my wheel.  It was fascinating to see the mechanic work.  Without a vice or freewheel tool, he took a hammer and metal pin and proceeded to pound the free wheel loose.   This took him fifteen minutes.   Then, it was easy to replace the broken spoke and rebuild the wheel.   However, I took it for a ride and discovered that the hub had fallen so far out of true that I could not use my three lowest gears.  I took it back to the mechanic, who straightened it enough to get six of the seven gears working.  This would have to work for the next two hundred kilometers. That evening, I ate nshima at the rest house, and started talking to a truck driver who was staying overnight.  He had seen me on the highway, and seemed very interested in where I had been and where I was going.   He told me the road was bad until Nyimba, but was newly paved after that.  It was also downhill for much of the route.   All of the sudden, I felt safe in the country.  Everyone on the road had seen me, and I felt like there would be always be somebody to help me out if I got hurt. Speaking of which, my antibiotics ran out that night.  Although my arms looked like they had healed, I would not know for sure until a few days had passed.  I spent the rest of the night talking with the hotel manager, Nazareth.  He was a bit of an outsider, as his uncle owned the place, and hired Nazareth from out of town to run it.  Nazareth was not intending to stay there forever, and was slowly accumulating a stockpile of bricks.  His dream was to take these bricks and build a general store.  He had not decided where just yet, but was looking for likely locations 
As I was leaving the rest house, a man came up to me and wished me a safe trip to Luangwa Bridge.  This was mystifying, as I had never met him.  It seems that he was a truck driver too, and all the drivers now knew of my destination.  He mentioned that he too had seen me along the highway, and I got the impression that I was one of the topics of discussion during rest breaks.  Just in case I was not, I let him know that I would be looking for a ride on the way back to Chipata, and to let the other drivers know.    The road was still bad.  Some sections were potholed to oblivion, while others had been paved with a gravel like substance that made it impossible to spot lumps in the road until it was too late.  I'm not sure what the scenery was like, because I spent most of the time with my eyes on the road, in search of potholes and hidden depressions.    At Nyimba, the road suddenly changed from potholes to new asphalt.  I was in heaven, as I felt that I could ride on this without further bending of the hub.  Now that I could pay attention, I was able to see that I was passing through the heavily forested hills.    One bad thing about forested hills is that you do not really know where you are, nor can you see where you are going.  I had ridden through the hills for hours, and still had not found Kachalola.  Like usual, nobody I asked had any idea how far it was, and just made up an answer to make me happy.  By the time I found somebody who really knew how far it was, I was able to see it. Kachalola had to be one of the strangest places that I ever stayed in.  The town itself was made up of two small clusters of shops by the side of the road.  The hotel was on the other side of the road, and seemed to be  larger than the town.      I went to the hotel to get a room for the night, and a meal.  Though expensive, the room was clean, and had working lights.  There was absolutely nobody else staying there that night, and I got the impression that they had not seen a guest for some time.  Despite my being the only guest around, my dinner could only be served between seven and nine o'clock.      Having found a place to rest I took a walk along the town. There was a promising looking general store.  I tried to buy some bread there, but they said they only had scones.  Here I was, in the middle of nowhere,  and unable to buy bread, but able to get scones.  The place was taking on a distinct, Twin Peaks feel, and I suddenly felt like I was the road side attraction. Back at the hotel, I counted the hotel staff while waiting for them to get ready to get around to perhaps prepare my dinner.  It looked like there were around ten to fifteen staff members, all of whom had some unknown function at the hotel.  The 30000 k (about 8CDN) I paid for the room would not go very far between the staff, let alone the owner. At seven, dinner was served.  It was beans, rice, and fried chicken, and by far the tastiest meal I had eaten in Zambia.  Granted, this was unfair competition, as the de facto meal in these parts was nshima.  While eating, I asked the cook how the hotel stayed in business.  He did not seem to understand, and said that it was better than working at Bridge camp, where employees only got paid if guests were there.  He seemed reluctant to answer my real question, and I did not want to push him.   After dinner, I headed back across the grounds (a bit like walking across town) to my room.  I tried to take advantage of the working electricity, but was too tired to read, and soon fell asleep. 
Riding from Kachalola was easy.  The road was mostly downhill, and wound through heavily forested hills.  At each ridge, I looked ahead, expecting to see the land flatten, but it never did.  After five hours of riding, I began to wonder how far it was to Luangwa bridge.  The highway in this section had almost no traffic, and few pedestrians.  With hills all around, it was impossible to get a landmark to gauge distance.    The first pedestrian I saw was lighting brush fires ahead of me.  I caught up with him, and he said it was 67 km to Luangwa bridge and asked if I wanted to buy some stones.  Later on, I would find out that he was lighting the fires as a way of gathering rodents for food.  The brush fires drove the rodents into their holes, where he would collect them later. With 67 km to go, I felt weak and defeated.  Five hours of riding and only 23 km?  It did not seem right, but it was the only information I had.  Like it or not, I had to keep riding, and resolved to make it  before dark, regardless.  I picked up the pace a bit. About five km later, I saw a sign for the Luangwa Bridge mission.  Just how big could the township of Luangwa Bridge be?  I continued and rode to the top of a small pass, where I saw the Luangwa river, and the Luangwa bridge running across it.  I had misheard the fire starter, who probably said 'six to seven' and not 'sixty seven'.   Luangwa Bridge turned out to be little more than a small cluster of road side stands and a sign to a gas station in Luangwa.  There was not anything that looked like a bike mechanic shop  in sight.  I stopped at the market for a bit of lunch, and some food supplies.  There was plenty of time.  The camp site was only about two kilometers away. After lunch, I rode the final two kilometers along a bumpy dirt road.  Finally, I saw the campsite gate, knocked on the door, and wheeled my bike inside the compound.  I made it!   The bike tour was officially over here.  With the wonky hub, it was better to stop riding, and use other  transport until I could get to a place where I could fix the bike.  All you people who want to read about cycling can stop here.  Once inside, I had about two minutes to relax.  There were four other people staying at the camp site, and they were just about to take a boat tour on the Luangwa river.  I tagged along for a great time.  The river was quite shallow, allowing the boatmen to use poles to propel the boat.  We drifted down stream, in search of crocodiles and exotic birds.  I relaxed, happy that I somebody else was doing the work for a change.       With me on the boat were two Dutch girls, a somewhat eccentric old Dutch man, and a young English traveller.  They were all heading to Lusaka for the eclipse.  I would have to find some other company to head down to Luangwa.    After the boat ride was over, I went to the campsite bar with the two Dutch girls.  They were students, and had just finished practicums in Zambia.  We were joined by the Dutch man and the English traveller, and played cards until the sun set.  At the bar, the dinner menu was expensive for those on a budget, so we ordered the cheapest item on the menu, which happened to be nshima.  It was one thing to eat nshima at local prices, but almost insulting to pay $3USD for it at the bar.  As it was so expensive, we did not order any drinks.  The staff, correctly guessing we were not going to be spending any more money that evening, unceremoniously shut down the power a few minutes after we finished dinner.  In the now pitch black night, we stumbled down the steep path to our tents. 
As I was stepping out of the restaurant, I noticed that somebody had started deep frying fish steaks by the side of the road.  Not only were they cheap (1500 k, or about 50 cents CDN) they were fresh, and would go down well with some fresh bread from the market.  My dinner was set.  Fish, bread, and tomatoes.  Not all four food groups, but close enough for me.   I spent the afternoon doing laundry, rearranging my packs, and reading.  It was one of those lazy days where going anywhere just is not a possibility.  Some more people had arrived that day, but I was unable to find a ride to Luangwa.  I did not want to hitch, but this was looking like my only possibility.   That evening, I met Rolf.  He was the owner of the campsite, and said that he could give me a ride down to Luangwa.  He did not know precisely when he would be leaving but said it would probably be around lunch  tomorrow.  I was elated to have a ride.  I was finally getting ground zero. 
I waited past lunch, and Rolf was busy running about.  I was getting worried that he would cancel at the last minute, and I would be unable to get  to Luangwa in time.  Finally, at three thirty, Rolf said we were going, and  got into the land rover.  He had a group of three tourists paddling down the Luangwa river, and was arranging to meet them somewhere along the way.   We headed down a horrible dirt road.  It was the kind of road that is fine for cars, but terrible for bicycles. There was plenty of loose gravel, and worse than that, the surface had turned into a washboard from all the motor vehicles.  There were few bicyclists along the road to flatten out a path.  I thought about my wonky hub, and 90 km of dirt.  I was very glad to be in a vehicle instead.   Nobody was really sure where the canoeing tourists were, so we spent a good portion of time finding spots close to the river, and climbing trees to see if they were close.  Eventually they arrived, and Rolf transferred more supplies to them.  With this business done, we headed to Luangwa.  By the time we had met the canoeists, the daylight was fading.  We continued on into the night, passing a few Zambians pushing a pickup up hill.  We saw their tracks on the road for at least five km.  How long had they been pushing , and how long were they going to go? Finally, we reached Luangwa, which was little more than a gas station, a border crossing, and a few scattered houses here and there.  Rolf dropped me off at the gas station, and said that the owner was probably around back. I thanked Rolf for the ride, walked around back, and found the owner and his family in the middle of some after dinner brew drinking.  They showed me to the campsite, where I set up, and settled in. Tomorrow was the eclipse and I could hardly wait. 
   Sunshine!  The last time I saw an eclipse, it was -10 out, and cloudy.  Since that time, I had been loosely plotting a vacation to see an eclipse in more amicable surroundings.  Today would be warm, and with any luck, clear during the eclipse.  I would finally get to see an eclipse clearly. It was still early in the morning.  To pass the time until the eclipse, I took a walk around Luangwa.  While the town was larger than any place I had stayed at in the last week, it was little more than a few houses clustered around a gas station and a customs post.  Even so, it marked the confluence of the Luangwa and Zambezi rivers, as well as the border point between Zambia, Mozambique, and Zimbabwe.  Tempting as it was, I resisted the urge to take a boat across the river.  Mozambique and Zimbabwe would have to be seen on another trip.   After taking a tour of the town, I headed back to the camp site.  Paddy, the owner of the campsite/gas station, mentioned that he would be taking a boat up the Zambezi that morning to meet up with some others.  He said I could get a ride with him if there was any space. Luckily, there was a bit of space, and I was soon on my way down the Zambezi river.  The river marked the border, and it suddenly dawned on me that I was in between Zambia and Zimbabwe.  This was the only place in the world where you could be completely surrounded by countries starting with the letter 'Z'.  Surely, nobody could question my alphabetic travelling prowess now!    Eventually, we landed at a sand bar in the middle of the river.  Paddy said that there would not be time to get back to Luangwa for the eclipse and asked if I minded staying at the sand bar with a group of South Africans for a barbecue instead.  My rubber arms, if they needed any twisting, had no comment, so I accepted the invitation for them. There really is not a good way to describe a total eclipse.  The sun gradually gets blotted out by the moon, looking a bit like a pac man, of all things.  Eventually, only a sliver of sun is uncovered, and the two bodies resemble a diamond ring.  At totality,  the sky turns dark, and there is nothing but a glowing corona.  It looks like there is a hole in the sky.  And then, it goes back to a diamond ring, and then a pacman.    But, don't just rely on my description.  In fact, it may be better to ignore what I just said.  Total eclipses are unforgettable, and religious experiences to some.  Get out and see one.  The next one will sweep through North Africa and Central Asia in 2006.  That's plenty of time to ride there to get a good spot! By the time we got back to Luangwa, it was late afternoon.  Already, the exodus of eclipse watchers had begun.  I thought about asking for a ride back to Luangwa bridge, but deliberately dawdled until most of the vehicles had left.  Although there was little to see in Luangwa, I was very fond of the campsite, and stayed one more night.   
  There wasn't much traffic, and the few vehicles that passed by didn't stop.  Finally, an hour later, a pickup for an NGO picked me up.  They were in search of a broken down truck that had left from Luangwa earlier in the day.  We rode for forty km, and stopped when they spotted the truck by the side of the road.  As they were unloading, a telecom truck came by, and gave me a lift back to the campsite at Luangwa bridge.   I packed the bike up, and wheeled it to the crossroads.  At the crossroads, I spotted a parked 4x4.  The owner was an American missionary who was heading to Petauke with his family.  We strapped the bike to the roof, and headed along the highway.  When we arrived in Petauke, it was nearly four in the afternoon, and the traffic had started to thin out.  I tried hitching anyhow, but couldn't get a suitable ride.  By five, the sun was getting close to the horizon, and it was time to call it a day. Even if I was stuck in Petauke overnight, it was good to see Nazareth and the rest of the staff at the guesthouse.  We spent the evening discussing Nazareth's future plans for his store, including how to make muffins and pies.  Hopefully, one day, you will be able to get a decent piece of pie in Zambia, and it will be all because of my taste buds. 
  They let me off in Chipata, and I headed for the campsite.   It was only 9:30 AM and I was already in Chipata.  At the campsite, I set up my tent, and headed to the bus station to inquire about what was heading to  the National Park.  The bus station workers said the next bus would leave some time in the afternoon, and that there would be no bus tomorrow, as it was Sunday. Hearing this, I rushed back to the campsite, explained the situation, and packed up.  The campsite would store my bike for the three days I planned to be gone.  Then, it was a quick trip to the supermarket to stock up on supplies (including more Rambo biscuits) and back to the bus station.  The bus trip was a disaster that took nineteen hours to travel 120 km.  However, I did meet three other travellers on the bus who I would camp with in the national park. 
            
  At the campsite, I got lucky again.  A German student was driving to Lilongwe, and could give me and my bike a lift the rest of the way.  This was especially fortuitous, as I was unable to find anybody in Chipata who knew how to fix my hub.      The rest of the day was spent eating, and finding things to eat.  The fried chicken seller was very glad to see me again, as was the papaya seller.  I also found a great stall to buy samosas and replenished my supply of Rambo biscuits.  I had finished cycling, but nobody seemed to have told my stomach.   
We ate the remaining samosas, and saved the papaya for dinner. After I set up my tent, I lay down for a quick relax.  It was too hot to put the fly on, so I just lay down inside, staring at the sky through the mesh.  Dreamily, I let my mind wander, barely noticing how the wind picked up.  Soon, it began gusting, but I remained in the tent, oblivious to the outside world.  At that point, I watched the blue, cloudless sky, only to see a tent fly over me.  The tent circled the campsite once or twice and then landed in the forest beside the campsite.  The wind died down as quickly as it had started, and all was peaceful, and the owner's tent was unhurt. Jurgen had driven a beat up Mazda (or something like it) to South Luangwa National Park and back  This was remarkable, as the road  is generally recognized as the worst one in Zambia.  Even so, the car did not survive unscathed.  Jurgen was carrying the muffler and some unidentified pieces of bumper with him, hoping to find some way of reattaching them when he got a chance.  Also, the front wheel made disturbing noises when he turned left.  Further inspection showed that one of the bolts had fallen out of the axle, and the last bolt was dangerously loose.  I was very glad he found the problem, as the bolt would have certainly fallen off, taking the wheel with it.   With mechanical problems out of the way, I took a walk around the campsite, and into the adjoining countryside.  It was beautiful, lush forest, supposedly with lots of pythons, surrounded by fields.  I walked along the road, being passed by numerous bicycles carrying jugs and jerry cans.  Later that evening, I discovered that this was the start of the smugglers road, where people would take cheap petrol from Malawi, and resell it in Zambia.   
  We cruised up the last ten or so kilometers to the Zambian border.  The tightened axle bolt seemed to be holding out fine.  Contrary all my expectations, it was easy to cross the border in a car.  I had expected all sorts of bureaucratic hassles, bribes, and delays, but they never materialized.  Because Jurgen had bought the car in South Africa, there was no need for a carnet, or any other import papers.  Within twenty minutes, we were stamped out of Zambia, and into Malawi.  The Malawi side was just as seamless, and soon we had been stamped into Malawi.      Once we crossed the border, we drove to Mchinji to get fuel and a replacement bolt.  Despite some blatant attempts to overcharge, we eventually found a reasonably priced bolt for the wheel.  Soon, it was installed and we sped along to Malawi.  It seemed strange to pass through Malawi so quickly, considering how long it took to go the other way.  After a few hours of driving, we arrived in Lilongwe.  The guesthouse was full, making it necessary to stay at the camp site.   I did not really like the camp site.  It was further from the center of Lilongwe, and catered to overland tour groups.  However, it was only for one night, and I needed to get the bike fixed. I found a mechanic who looked at the hub, and said that it wasn't a dropped bearing, but a bent hub.  Fixing it would cost only a few hundred kwacha for a new hub, and a 100 kwacha to rebuild the wheel.  Half an hour later, I had a working bike again.   There was one last order of business.  I was in Lilongwe, and had a craving for chicken biryani.  I went to the restaurant to order one for Sunday, only to find out that the restaurant was closed on Sundays.  Luckily, the owner recognized me, said that she would send somebody to open the restaurant if I told her what time I wanted to eat.  It pays to be a regular. 
We walked to the restaurant, and just like it was promised, somebody opened the restaurant for us, and even cooked up something for Jurgen.  When the food arrived, Jurgen had a taste of the biryani, and announced that he would be ordering a biryani for tomorrow, as I wasn't about to share very much of mine.  We rushed through lunch, and followed the growing exodus of spectators to the stadium.     The line stretched far past the stadium and moved at a glacial pace.  Everyone in line was getting impatient.  Crowds of people milled about the edge of the stadium, seemingly for no purpose. I asked some of the neighours in the line whether this was the correct line, and was reassured that we were in the correct line to get inside.       Suddenly, a group of men split off from the milling crowd, and hopped the stadium fence. They easily ran around the now confused guards.  It was like trying to stop a fire with a broom.  Other people got the idea, and hopped the fence as well.   All hell broke loose, as the vastly outnumbered guards tried in vain to stop the horde from getting into the stadium.  For every person they chased back, another would sneak in behind.  Soon, the situation got out of control, and one of the guards started firing his AK 47.  This did wonders for crowd control, and the would be gate crashers quickly retreated, only to lurk at the edge of the fence and wait for another opportunity.      Meanwhile, the line meandered forward.  After an hour, we were within 20 m of the gate.  Everyone started pushing and jockeying to get to the ticket window.  Fortunately, we were taller, and better fed than most of the people in the line, and eventually got to the ticket window.  It was 40 k (less than a dollar, in just about any currency) each, which was a pittance.   Once inside the gate, we had a quick drink from one of the numerous cold drink sellers, and then walked into the stadium.  It was packed solid, and we were the only mzungu in the place.  Suddenly, I heard my name, and saw some of Derek's friends waving to us.  We sat down with them, relieved to finally have made it there.  And the game?  It was good, and ended in a 2-2 tie but anticlimactic compared with the ordeal to get there.      Monday, I finally got a bed in the guesthouse.  It was otherwise an uneventful day.  I cleaned the bike, and tuned it up, and ate chicken biryani with Jurgen and Derek.   The rest of the day was spent spending my remaining kwacha on peri peri sauce and guava juice.   That evening, I arranged a cab to the airport, and went to bed for the last time in Malawi.  It was strange to think that I was heading home, but I was ready to leave.  The infection on my arms was getting worse, and I was really craving a BLT and a bowl of New England clam chowder. 
Despite my outrage at my own stupidity, the plane ride was  very enjoyable.  It flew over Zambia and Tanzania, where I got some great views of Mt. Kilimanjaro.  We landed at the airport in Nairobi around lunch.  I had seven  hours to kill.    This was not really long enough to warrant leaving the airport and heading to Nairobi.  It would have been fifty dollars for a visa, and Nairobi is not knick named 'Nairobbery' for no reason.  I circled the airport a few times, looking for something to do.  Eventually, I found an internet caf, and made arrangements to meet a friend for lunch in Amsterdam the next day.  E-mail really is the greatest!  Then, I headed to a transit lounge, where I ate my last chicken biryani.  I'll miss that restaurant. I flew out on the red eye flight to Amsterdam, and landed in Schipol International at six in the morning.  With nothing to do until lunch, it was an opportune time to take another nap.  I did not sleep well on the plane, and the infection on my arms had spread to my knees.  I was starting to ache. After my nap, I headed out to Amsterdam.  I had to meet my friend at Sloterdijk station, which was just outside the city center.  When I arrived, there really wasn't anything to see.  I always thought of Amsterdam as a place full of old, heritage buildings and instead stepped into a block full of glass, concrete and metal.      I met my friend for a somewhat extended lunch, and afterwards decided that I had enough of tourism for one trip.  It was time to head back to the airport and wait some more.  At the airport, I spent my remaining guilders on chocolate, and proceeded to take another nap. There was not anything else to do.  Schipol was good to wait in, as far as airports are concerned, but there was a limited amount of entertainment available for those who do not like to sit in hotel bars.  After what seemed like too long of a wait, I boarded the plane and fell asleep.  Nine hours, and many movies later, we landed in Vancouver International  Airport. My sister picked me up at the airport, where we promptly drove to the grocery store and bought the raw materials for a BLT and clam chowder.  This was the meal I had been dreaming about for more than a month.  It was good to be home.    Note: I went to the doctor to check out the infection, and it turned out to be from the same family of bacteria that causes flesh eating disease.  Looks like I've got eight lives left. 
The trip was great, and I would do it again, or something reasonably close to it.  Here is a quick summary. Traffic conditions Strange to think that this area would be a good place to ride, but it is.  Outside the major cities, there was little traffic, and drivers would leave you enough room.  Note that this rule broke down to survival of the biggest once the road got busy.  However, a car every 15 minutes was about the right frequency in Zambia, and every 5 minutes in Malawi.   Because there are many cyclists, drivers actually look out for them.
