They may not always make allowances for bikes, but at least they are aware (unlike some suburbs in North America) that you are on the road.   The roads were generally rideable, if a little rough in places.  Most roads were paved, and those that were not were mostly fine for riding.  Some road sections had not been properly maintained, and were full of rough sections.  Usually, you could find a fairly smooth single track through the potholes or washboard, but not always.  Often, there was only one paved road, making it much easier to figure out which way to go. Food Compared with just about anywhere else, the food in sub Saharan Africa was pretty dull.  Outside larger towns, food choices were very limited, and usually nsima.   Crime Big cities were dangerous, and best avoided if possible.  Outside the big cities, people were friendly, and helpful.  I got little indication (despite some perhaps infection influenced paranoia) that somebody would mug me in the small towns. Diseases Africa is rife with all sorts of nasty diseases.  I picked up a mild form of flesh eating disease, met two people who had contracted malaria, and heard of others who got bilharzia.  Stomach troubles will strike eventually, and are unavoidable if you spend enough time there.  That being said,  taking precautions is helpful, and doctors know how to treat the common diseases there. Play your cards right, and you will probably be fine. If you do decide to cycle in this part of Africa, some precautions are necessary.  Roads are generally bumpier than in developed countries, and not always paved.  A more robust bike would be better for these parts, especially should you plan to ride more than a few weeks.  There is little support for anything but mountain bikes, and Indian one speeds.  Bike stores were usually only found in the big cities.  Take spare parts, and have your own tools.  It is very important to know how to fix things, and how to make adjustments,  otherwise you may have to let somebody else fix things, which can lead to other problems.   Food was easy to find, but somewhat tasteless.  There were usually small stores in the towns where you could buy dry goods, soft drinks, and bread.  The restaurants were often limited in menu items I had no difficulty finding places to sleep, but had done some advance planning to make sure there would be at least something in the place I was planning to spend the night.  Most towns of any size had some sort of rest house.  I only camped in the national parks.  Wild animals were everywhere, and food should not be stored where it can be easily accessed.   Again, there are all sorts of nasty diseases that you can catch, so be careful.  So far (2003), malaria can only be prevented by not getting bitten, so high concentration DEET (unless you want to wake up after four hours to put more on) and mosquito nets are essential.  Stomach ailments are often caused by drinking bad water.  Bottled water was available most places, but carrying some treatment or a filter would be a good back up plan.   Despite the dangers, this part of Africa was easy to ride in, and full of friendly people and beautiful scenery.  If you plan for disasters, and don't plan a tight schedule, it should be a great trip. 
The cycle trip was part of a larger trip through Qatar, UAE, India, Sri Lanka, and Europe.  Because of time constraints, congestion, and maniacal drivers, I decided not to bike in India.  Instead, I bought cheap bikes in UAE and Sri Lanka.  This was easier than packing a bike each time I had to take a plane.   My route started from Dubai, and went into the Hajar mountains to Masafi.  From there I went north to the Omani border and then road along the coast to Khor Fakkan and Fujairah.  I then headed back to Dubai, and completed the circle.
For bike maintenance, I took a tool kit of a pump, a cool tool, a set of allen keys, some screwdrivers, and a patch kit.  For baggage, I used a 45 l hiking pack, a strap on cordura case, and 35 l daypack.  Everything dense went in the cordura case and hiking pack, while bulky items went in the daypack.  Because this was a trip through the desert, it was easy to travel light, and I skipped carrying a tent, and camping gear.  However, as I would be trekking in India a week,  I also had to carry a -20C sleeping bag, a set of gloves and a fleece jacket.  Because I was unsure of how many towns would have supplies outside Dubai,  I took five liters of water and a dozen bars of fruit leather for emergencies.      In Dubai, I  bought a brand new Taiwanese mountain bike of questionable quality, but good enough to last a week.  It had analog shifters, passable brakes, and 24 speeds, with 4 speeds being unreachable due to bad tuning at the manufacturer.  The cranks had some play, and the headset was loose.  It was not a great bike, but would do.   Then again, what can you expect for $65?  That is in Canadian smackeroos, too!   
All things considered, it would be smart not to try to cover too much ground at first.  To get at least a bit of pleasant riding time, I left from Dubai at sunrise.  It would be cool in the morning, and I would have to face much less rush hour traffic.  From the center of town to the eastern highway was 10 km of city streets and roundabouts.  Although I am not fond of having to weave into traffic on roundabouts, there was little in the way of cars or trucks so early in the morning. It took an hour to get out of Dubai, and onto the main highway.  Even this early, it was already getting hot.  I resorted to taking rest breaks in the shade of the occasional overpasses.  The traffic on the highway was much less than I expected, and riding was easy because of the paved shoulder.  Not surprisingly, there was sand as far as the eye could see, and in all directions.  The desert was remarkably populated, with buildings scattered along the side of the highway, and the occasional camel grazing area. Because I was planning on returning by the same road, I kept my eyes open for potential camping spots, in the event that I arrived too late to get to Dubai. Most of the road was populated, or fenced off, and I could find nothing that looked all that suitable.      At eleven, I stopped in a small town called Daid. I had lunch at an Indian greasy spoon, bought some more water and continued for 15 minutes to the edge of town.  It was now far too hot, with the heat of the sun assaulting me from all directions.  I hadn't acclimatised, had a full stomach, and was going nowhere fast.  I pulled the bike to a carwash,  and asked if I could take a nap there.  The workers were shutting down for the afternoon siesta and kindly allowed me take a nap on a shady bench.  A few hours later, it was only very hot, and I continued.  As I got closer to the Hajar mountains, the countryside slowly changed from flat desert to rocky hills.  While the passing scenery was much more interesting than the desert, it was also uphill.  By five, I was exhausted, and making only slow progress.  I wasn't sure how long it would continue uphill, and I decided to look for a place to camp.   I took a turnoff to a promising looking quarry, and found a good camping site nestled between two small hills.        With no tent, and no sleeping mat,  it wasn't going to be comfortable.  However, I laid a groundsheet out, used the sleeping bag as a mat. Being a -20 C bag, it was far too much for the night time low of 20 C in the desert, but good enough to pad the rocky ground. To keep away any creepy crawlies, I rigged up a mosquito net and a camera tripod as a makeshift shelter.  After a meal of bread, nuts, and yogurt, I settled in to get some sleep.  Just as it was getting dark and I was drifting off, I heard the sound of a mosque call.  Here I was, in the middle of nowhere, and managed to set up beside a mosque. 
The market had not started because it was too early in the morning.  Despite its name, the Friday market runs every day, and is called the Friday market because that is the day that all the people from Dubai show up.  I passed the market, and rode out of Masafi, an otherwise unremarkable town.  The plan of the day was to ride along the northern road to Dibba, and then down the coast to Khor Fakkan.    The Hajar mountains were beautiful in the morning, and it was downhill all the way.  With little traffic, and a cool breeze, it was a perfect riding day.  I rode into Dibba by nine in the morning, and decided to see a bit of the town.  According to the guidebook, there was a huge graveyard in Dibba that couldn't be missed.  And I missed it.  You would think it wouldn't be too hard to find a 10000 plot graveyard.  Perhaps my navigation skills need some work.    The coastal highway to Khor Fakkan was much flatter, hotter, and noisier.  Just out of Dibba, two dozen Porsches and a few infidel BMWs screamed past me, trying to break the sound barrier.  There is lots of money in the Gulf, and it was showing itself off that day.    My ride along the coast was much slower.  This part of UAE gets the most precipitation, and is remarkably green for a desert region.  The coast is littered with small coves and sandy beaches, making it easy to take lots of breaks.  Despite the beckoning attractions, I continued to pedal, and got to Khor Fakkan by early afternoon. Before, in Dubai, the youth hostel staff had said that there was a hostel in Khor Fakkan that was very good, and close to the beach.  In my infinite wisdom, I had forgotten not only to get directions to the hostel, but forgotten to even get a phone number.  I rode up and down the length of the Corniche, figuring that I could spot it if is were close to the beach.  This proved fruitless, as did several inquiries at shops near the Corniche.  'Hostel' is not commonly used, and cheap hotel will only get you directions to a cheap hotel. Eventually, in a diving store, somebody understood me, and drew a map.  The hostel was easy to find, once you knew where to look, and really was only 100 m from the beach.  It was also an incredible deal, at only 25 dirham, or about 10 loonies. After settling in, I took a walk along the Corniche.  It was Friday, the Muslim sabbath,and the promenade and beach were packed.  Perhaps one of the more unusual sights you can see at a Muslim beach are the women.  It is considered provocative and tawdry for women to show just about any part of their body, so women at the beach dress like they would if they were going shopping.  As such, many of the women appear to be wearing portable tents.   An even stranger sight was that there were no Germans.  Germans are well renowned for their engineering, and their ability to get to the beach before anyone else.  Here was a pristine beach, and not a German in sight.  Puzzling, at first, and a bit unsettling.  How could it be possible to have a beach without Germans?  And then, I realized that Khor Fakkan was in a dry emirate, and there was no beer to be found here.   
I did manage to find Madha, which had multiple turnoffs to it , and a large sign pointing in the right direction.  Madha is an Omani enclave in the UAE.  This place was not nearly as pretty or interesting as I had imagined, but the ride around the mountains near Madha was good, desert temperatures not withstanding.    After visiting Madha, I rode back to Khor Fakkan, and found the best value restaurant in UAE.  For a princely sum of 15 dirham ( about 6 loonies) , you can select a fish, and have somebody cook it for you with a plate of rice and vegetables.  This was a welcome change from the kabobs that I had been living on.
As I continued, I began to realize that the entire road was under various stages of construction.  The shoulder was missing, or being built over the majority of the thirty five km, and I had to ride carefully.  With no shoulder, it was necessary to maintain zen like concentration to ride on the thin strip of pavement between the warning line and the dirt.   It did not help to have what seemed like half of Fujairah screaming past me on the way into town.   The scenery wasn't all that interesting, either.  Most of the road was built up with oversized houses, or soon to be strip malls.  Not that it mattered too much what the area looked like, as I had to spend most of my time keeping my eyes and bike on the narrow strip between the passing cars and the rough. I arrived in Fujairah around 9 and just like the Khor Fakkan, had difficulty finding the youth hostel.  Eventually, after much circling and asking directions, I found it.   Although I didn't think 9:30 AM was early, I managed to wake up the morning staff person.  He showed me to a bed ( the one he had been sleeping on) in a grotty room, and then told me that I could pay in the evening when his boss showed up.  This was by far the worst place I stayed in the emirates, and coincidentally, the cheapest, at only 15 dr/night.   With nowhere else to go for the rest of the day, I took a day trip down to a mangrove swamp by the UAE-Omani border.   The trip was pleasant enough, passing through what seemed to be an extended suburb of Fujairah all the way to the swamp.      The mangrove swamp was quite interesting, with scores of fiddler crabs in the mudflats, and the occasional kingfisher.  I was expecting it to be larger, and it seemed to end abruptly and turn into desert in a few footsteps.      The ride back was better, because it was possible to ride along the beach for much of the way.  Riding in loose sand is an exercise in frustration, but there was a strip of hard packed sand in the tidal zone that was fine for riding.  This was much more scenic than an Emirati suburb, and cooler to ride on.   
Of course, sights that are easy to find are not necessarily sights that are worth seeing.  The fort was in bad need of any restoration, and not terribly elaborate.  However, it was still fun to scrabble around the ruins, and was devoid of any tourists besides myself.     I was hungry, and rode back to Fujairah.   Fujairah, being quite large, had a hypermarket where you can buy just about anything edible.  I consumed a liter of ice cream and a roasted chicken.  It's good to be cyclist.  There wasn't much too do in Fujairah itself.  I rode around town, and discovered that the hostel wasn't far from anything, because there really wasn't anything of interest to be far from.  There was a beach, which was devoid of anything, locals and tourists included, and a strange looking amusment park on the Corniche.      That evening, while I was walking around town, an Arab in an Audi stopped me and asked for directions.  It was surprising that he mistook me for a local, but even more surprising that I knew how to get where he wanted to go.  Lucky for him that he wasn't trying to get to any of the tourist destinations that I had been looking for. 
I left around four in the morning, guessing that I could get the uphill portion done in the cool part of the day, and then cruise afterwards.   Sure enough, the lights were on, and I rode in the eerie orange until daybreak.  It was 25 km of uphill, but the air was cool, and there were no cars.  Two hours later, I passed Bitnah, and congratulated myself for making it to the top of the pass so early.  I could see the hills around Masafi in the distance, and thought it would be an easy ride the rest of the way. 12 km later, I arrived in Masafi, dead tired.  When I looked back I realized that the peak of the road was at Masafi, and I had been riding uphill for the last hour without really knowing it.  The perspective only made Masafi look like it was downhill, and I thought it was heat stroke that was tiring me out. As it was only nine in the morning, I stopped in on the Friday market, despite it not being Friday.  There would have been plenty to buy, had I been in the market for carpets ,ceramic pots, or other suitably heavy items to strap to a bike. There wasn't anything else worth carrying for the next 70 km, so I left after only a few minutes.  A good thing about cycling is that you think twice before buying anything.  That is, unless you enjoy having a closet full of carvings and textiles.     From Masafi, it was downhill for 15 km, which flew by in no time.  I was back in the desert again, on a road I had already ridden.   By 11:30,  I arrived at  the Natural History Museum.  This meant I was only 35 km from Dubai.  As it was getting near the heat of the day,  I decided to take a break, and go to the museum.  The guards thought I was crazy to ride to the museum, and even more crazy when I told them I had come from Fujairah.  With the usual bad luck,  I had arrived on family day, and single men were not allowed in the museum.  However, after much pleading, the ticket taker called the main office and I was allowed in. The Natural History Museum was surprisingly good.  It was more a zoo than a museum, and had several species of indigenous wildlife housed inside.  There was an indoor bird sanctuary as well as glass tanks holding several specimens of creepy crawly critters that I'd rather not know about if I were planning on sleeping in a desert.  If anyone reading this decides to camp in the desert, go to the museum after you have finished camping.   I left at two, as the heat of the day was passing, and I wanted to get to Dubai instead of bush camping.  It was an easy, if hot, ride to the outskirts of Dubai.  I rode into town, and nearly got hit several times by the local drivers.  Not wanting to take an ambulance to the hospital, I called it a day, flagged down a cab, and was driven the last few kilometers to the youth hostel.   
That being said, it is a desert, and very hot.  I rode in November, when it was cooling down, and it was still hot.  Summer temperatures reach 50 C, and it is supposed to be very humid as well.  However, there are plenty of settlements along the way, and water is relatively easy to find.  There is no need to take more than a day of water, or food for that matter, as it is available en route. The terrain is pretty dull near Dubai, but gets much more attractive in the Hajar mountains and the east coast.  It is relatively flat, and steep inclines are not common.   The road itself is in very good condition, without a pothole in sight.  There is a shoulder for most of the way, and little traffic once outside Dubai and Fujairah. Traffic, when you get it, is horrible.  Drivers in this region are like teenagers the day after they get their licence.  Larger places like Dubai and Fujairah are particularily bad.  Stay as close to the edge as possible! 
   I have always enjoyed adventure in the outdoors, I'll use any excuse to get out on a hike, a climb, a bike ride or a paddle in my kayak.  My favorite is to be out for several days at a time, living simply with what I carried out there myself and enjoying the company of good friends. All of this of course has to be balanced with family life and working for a living.  I enjoy the adventure so much more because I have a great family to come home to and a good job that I enjoy doing.  Neglect any one of these 3 and life gets unpleasant in a hurry.  On this trip I will be withdrawing heavily from the work and family bank and way overspending on the adventure side.  My thanks goes out to those who will be sacrificing so I can go play. I have commuted to work by bike off and on for the past 12 years.  I love to ride and since I live close enough to work (12 miles) it allows me to have fun outdoors every day for a couple of hours in all kinds of weather.  It fits with my motto "put adventure in your everyday life". I like to explore new places and try out new routes.  Many days I go miles out of my way just to ride a new stretch of road.  I usually don't feel like stopping when I get to work, I'd rather just keep riding (who wouldn't??).  This cross country ride will be a chance to live that dream out.  Point the bike southeast and just keep riding. I'll be using saved up vacation for the trip so I will be on a limited time schedule.  I need to finish within 6 weeks and I have about 3200 miles to ride so that means averaging 80 miles a day with about 5 days of down time.  A pretty tight schedule. My first goal will be the 2 week ride southeast thru Oregon, up and over the Blue Mountains, across the southwest corner of Idaho along the Snake river, and into Utah, Salt lake and to Moab where I'll take a few days off and do some Mt bike riding with my 2 sons and a group of friends from Seattle and Nashville. From there I will turn east and ride thru Colorado, Cortez, Durango, over Wolf Creek Pass and on into Oklahoma, thru the Ozarks in Arkansas and head south a bit to join the Natchez Trace for the ride into Nashville to a friends house for another little break before crossing the Smoky's and heading for Savannah where my wife will meet me for the flight home. Here is the map of my intended route:    My trip will be solo and unsupported, everything I need will either be carried on the bike or purchased along the way (food etc).  I plan to camp most nights, free when I can swing it, and stay in a couple of motels when necessary. I'll be riding a Trek 520 touring bike that a bunch of great friends and family contributed to for my 40th birthday in November 2002.  My wonderful wife Kathy secretly sent out this letter    to about 50 people and they responded very generously.  It is so great to be riding a brand new bike that is made just for trips like this one.  Many hours in the saddle with light spirits and a heavy load. I hope to be able to update this site every few days from library's along the way and will be mailing photo's back home for processing and will have them posted here as they are available. Feel free to post letters to the guestbook attached to this site, I will respond as I am able. Ben Staley 
I loaded the bike down with everything I am planning to take plus added 3 days food for both of us.  A little more weight than I have been training with so far but not too bad.  Right around 45 lbs including water. We took the Mukilteeo - Clinton 9am ferry across and then rode the length of Whidbey Island on Saturday, mostly in the rain but with a slight tailwind.  The rain tapered off when we got to Oak harbor and even a few sunbreaks for the rest of the day after that.  Lots of hills on Whidbey, 300 ft up then down over and over and over.  We probably climbed 3000 to 4000 ft over the course of the day.  The state parks are in Winter mode and mostly closed so that meant it was nice and quiet once we wheeled our bikes past the barrier and up into the woods where the bike in sites are.  The cost of the sites have gone up 75% since last October when Tim and I were there, ouch. While we were paying, some friends of ours surprised us, driving by and talking for a while.  They were up camping for the weekend also.  We would keep running into them at the funniest places the next 2 days. We set up camp and took a good walk down to the beach and watched the tide going out thru the pass, lots of nice whirlpools. 55 miles, 12.3 mph average, in camp at 3:00pm It rained hard all night but the tent held up well.  I brought the tent I'm going to use so I'm glad it did well. We got a late start for the ride, rolled out of camp at 9:15am, it sure takes longer when everything is wet.  Rode northwest around the top edge of Whidbey thru Anacortes, what a gorgeous town!! Great views out into the San Juans from the hill above town. I got a flat while riding thru town and stopped at a gas station to unload the bike to fix it...rear tire of course, our friends drive up for gas, 3nd time we had seen them that day.  I think we ran into them 4 times at various places where our paths crossed for a few minutes, it was really funny. We were glad to turn north after crossing the bridge on Hwy 20 since the wind was blowing out of the south at 20mph or more.  It was cool to "farmer blow" while riding 19 mph and have it fly in front of you :)  The person drafting you appreciates it also. The end of the ride was on one of my favorite roads, Chuckanut drive just south of Bellingham.  It winds along a cliff several hundred feet above the water with great views of the coastal Islands on one side and rock cliffs rising a hundred feet right at the edge of the road on the other.  It gets kind of tricky some places where it is steep with blind corners and very narrow lane with the rock wall right at your elbow, but so worth it. We camped at Larrabee State park, same situation, roll the bikes past the closed sign (this time with the park rangers permission) and camp by ourselves up in the woods.  After setting up we rode the 5 miles further north into Bellingham just for fun.  More heavy rain and wind overnight.  My new thermarest sleeping pad gave it up sometime during the night and went flat, not a great nights sleep. We packed up camp while it misted rain and rode down to a covered picnic shelter to cook breakfast, 8:30 am start with a long way to go before home.  Our route took us back down Chuckanut drive with the road all to ourselves but headwinds starting to really blow.  We fought against the wind for the whole day, 20 to 25 mph steady.  uugg.  But on the bright side, no rain during the ride the whole day!!  Temps were in the mid 40's. It really was just a matter of keeping the pedals moving, slowly putting the miles by and enjoying the things around us.  Many times during the day Kelly surprised me by saying how great it was to be out there on a ride.  He is such a great kid, looking for the good things around us even when the going was tough. We stopped for a well earned huge greasy hamburger and fries for lunch and finished the ride off right as the sun was setting. 73 miles, 11.8 average mph, in just over 6 hrs of ride time. It was a good weekend to get the body ready for 80+ mile days, I have a new respect for just how hard it will be to do it day after day for 45 days in a row.  I just hope I will get stronger every day instead of more beat up and sore.  Really, it seems like it could go either way, I'm counting on stronger. Pizza and cold beer for dinner, followed by a huge bowl of ice cream and a hot shower...home is good. Ben   
Most people's idea of vacation involves much LESS physical effort, not lots MORE physical effort.  Riding a bike all day, every day for a month and a half sounds more like punishment than fun to most people.  Which explains the second question I get asked:  Are you doing this for some sort of charity? Really, there must be some good reason to torture yourself like this.  Short of being in dire need of some sort of therapy, I mean, are you nuts? First off, I think it helps if you just love to ride your bike.  Everybody has something that they really get a kick out of doing.  Riding a bike is one of those things for me.  I just feel good when I'm cruising along, it slows my life down a little and the exersise really makes you feel good.  Even when the weather is nasty I feel lucky to be riding instead of driving.  I'm in a much better mood when I get someplace on a bike rather than fighting thru traffic in a car. So theres that. Another big reason is that most of the trip cannot be planned in advance.  A lot of vacations are packed full of things that you chose to do while you were at home planning the vacation.  Then you get there and do those things and then go back home.  You know where you will stay since you've already made reservations.  You plan the day's activities because you don't want to waste any time while you are there and you've spent all this money. I guess its the spontaneity that is appealing to me about a trip like this.  Out of the 45 or so days I will be gone, I know for sure where I will stay for 6 of them.  The rest I'll figure out when I get there.  None of my meals are planned other than having stuff along to eat if I can't find a store. The outcome of the trip will be the result of many small decisions along the way, along with a lot of things that are out of my control. It will allow me to experience the places I'll be going thru in a much different way than I would have on a "normal" vacation.  That and I would never even plan to visit most of the places I'll be riding thru.  Really, who would plan to spend an entire day of vacation touring the desert of northeastern oregon....slowly..??  But, I'll bet that there are many things that will be worth seeing and doing there. Most vacations are about DESTINATION.  This one will be about journey. There, hows that for a sum up. People also ask me how in the world I talked my wife into letting me leave for that long, and really, I just don't know.  She will have to answer that one for herself.  Must be something about love. One thing I do know is that she is an incredibly wonderful person and has been way more supportive than I can believe.  This trip will be the longest we've been apart in 19 yrs of marriage. We have always tried to help each other achieve our dreams and goals.  Isn't that what marriage is about? Ok, ok, One last question and I'll shut up. Why are you doing it ALONE?? No great answer for that one. I really don't mind being alone at all, I actually enjoy it, although, I would really enjoy doing the trip with someone else too.  It just seemed to work out this way this time. For one, not many people have the desire to do something like this. Even fewer of them can take the time off work to do it, it is a long time to commit to and very hard to arrange unless you are unemployeed, retired, or are lucky enough to have a bunch of vacation to blow. So thats a pretty limited playing field right there and when you narrow it down even more by the number of people who would be willing to do it with ME.... ........wow...... where'd everyone go??  :)

The day started with the usual 12 mile ride to work, this time with the bike loaded for the trip. My brother Tim rode down at lunchtime and we had some good spicy Thai chicken to keep us warm for the afternoon ride in the rain. I worked really really hard all day :) and after a great surprise sendoff from work, complete with cake, McDonalds gift certificates, Starbucks gift card and balloons (I didn't ride with those) we headed out. Brad and Niels were the escort team taking turns out front for a much-appreciated draft into 10-15 mph headwinds. One thing I learned was that their mountain bike fenders were only meant to keep the rider dry, the person behind gets a nice shower, grit, mud and all, did I mention it was pouring rain the whole ride? It's Seattle springtime after all. Tim and I pulled into North Bend just before sunset, treated ourselves to a fat hamburger and fries and a rest. My wife Kathy and two boys, Kelly and Alex met us at our friend's house in North Bend for the night, drying out sitting by the fire was so nice. Thanks, Rick and Sue! (Editors note: I saw several camera's around, if anyone has some photos, please email me at: click to show email) More photos here
  The ride up Snoqualmie Pass is 2500ft in 22 miles, not a bad grade till the last 3 miles where it's pretty steep, that's where it started snowing. In fact, Thursday night they had 6 inches of new snow but most of it had melted off the roadway. Midway up the climb we came up on the scene of a pretty bad accident. It looked to be a multi-Barbie fatality and there were little clothes and Barbie parts spread out all over the shoulder. Bob pulled over and tried emergency CPR on the severed heads, but there was nothing that could be done but laugh of course and take silly pictures of Bike Seat Barbie and other nonsense. Really, we tried to be solemn, but it was difficult.     My good friend Jim surprised us, driving up for lunch with us at the top of the pass, probably not the last time on the trip he will show up unexpectedly, at least I hope.     It was pretty funny riding past skiers and snowboarders on a loaded tour bike.    Now the good part, downhill and 30 mph tailwinds the whole rest of the 55 miles to Ellensburg. Wow! There were times we were coasting along at 30-35, and the further we got from Seattle, the sunnier it got!        My parents drove over to spend the night with us. It's great to have such good friends and family. Hot tub at the motel was pretty nice also.      More photos here 
   Canyon rd out of Ellensburg south winds down a very cool canyon along the Yakima river.  A lot of volcanic rock along the canyon walls, columnar basalt.  Also nice to be under clear blue skies for a change.  Temps in the mid 50's feels like summer to us after yesterday.     Kathy driving the sag wagon again for the last day and my parents following for the winding, scenic 35 miles to Yakima.       Since I'm a bonehead and didn't think too far ahead, the cars and bikes got separated entering Yakima with no way to communicate with each other.  Bikes took a cool bikepath the final 10 miles and the cars spent time waiting on the side of the freeway, talking to a police officer who nicely but firmly told them to "move it or lose it" then agreed to go look for the wayward bikers. At the end of the bike path we headed across to one of the freeway offramps to start looking for the cars...I'm thinking this is going to be impossible, Yakima is a big busy town and we are 4 small bikes.  You can bet we were praying just a little. At the street light we were amazed to see them in a parking lot across the street...whew!! Lunch was sub sandwiches followed by a very hard goodbye.  I'll be gone 6 weeks, the longest Kathy and I have ever been apart.      Tears were turned into energy and I pedaled hard south out of Yakima, busy streets seemed to go on forever but after 6 or 7 miles I found a bit of a tailwind and was able to really cruise. The miles went by fast but my heart wasn't really in to the riding, I was really missing my family and the joy of the road was hard to come by.  I knew today was going to be hard.  It was. I got to Prosser right at sunset and began the task of looking for a place to stay.  A few nice folks directed me to the center of town and the police station where I was checking whether I could stay at the park...nope....there is an RV park outside town, try there. Finally rolled into the park well after dark and the office was closed, a note said find a spot & we'll find you in the morning.  It was definately under construction, no bathrooms, no showers, no nothing but there was a spot in the grass where I could put up the tent and cook dinner, I was happy. More photos here
Lots of farmland and vinyards, passed right by the Columbia Crest winery and was tempted to stop by for a sample but didn't. Big event today was crossing the bridge over the Columbia river and entering Oregon.  Not much of a shoulder on the bridge but very cool view 100 ft down to the river when the semi-trucks weren't flying by.  I spent the last 26 miles into Pendleton on the Interstate, not my favorite riding, but doable.  Its mainly the noise that bothers me, the shoulders are huge so traffic isn't a problem, just deafening. Got to Pendleton at 3:30 and saw the library and had to stop for an update. Weather was clear but pretty cold all day and now it looks like some high clouds are moving in, may be rain tonight.     
        
Lunch was at a cool town beside the railroad just before the Snake river. I was planning to stop for the night at Fairwell Bend state park but made it there by 2:00 and just couldn't waste the tailwind.  26 miles more to Ontario with about 1500 ft of climbing, the hwy just kept going up and down the 400 ft hills, I'd think I had climbed the last one only to find the road dropped the 400 ft again and headed up again. Finally made it to Ontario at 4:30 Seattle time, Hey, I rode my bike into a different time zone!!! Wind is whipping and the clouds are dark and threatening, rain on 3 sides of town so I wuss out again and find a cheap motel....there goes the budget.  Oh well, its only money.  Cold beans right out of the can for dinner followed by the 4th granola bar of the day for desert. Tomorrow its Idaho!!   
      
I've had beautiful blue skies for the past few days and great riding in the wide open Idaho countryside.  Its been great to be off the main roads for a while and see some of the rugged countryside.  I stopped on a bridge crossing the Snake river for a break and while looking down saw probably the biggest fish I've ever seen, didn't look like a salmon, more bulb shaped but was almost as big as I am.  It was at least as big around. Knee hurt again this morning but by noon it warms up and is fine the rest of the day. My daily schedule has been something like: up before sunrise (I know, I'm a sick monkey, I wake up at 4:30 or 5:00 and can't sleep anymore) Nothing to do but ride my bike everyday and eat all the food I can find.  Lately its been a granola bar and climb on the bike and ride 10 or so miles, stop for a huge breakfast at some small town cafe, ride for a while longer, I've been hitting 40 miles by 11:00am, stopping for a couple PB&J's, 50 miles by noon, stop at a grocery store for a bananna and yogurt or something and pick up a can of something to cook for dinner.  Ride till 4:30 or 5:00 and start looking for a place to spend the night.  This has been harder than I thought it would be.  My choices have been motels (love this choice but can't afford it too often), RV parks (nice to have a shower but they cost almost as much as the motel), and gravel pits :) free but kinda lonely. I'm still loving the ride and am getting a really spectacular farmer tan complete with raccoon eyes from the sunglasses.         
Made it to Burley and got a motel after finding that the next camping was 22 miles away, and yes, my knee was hurting and wanted a warm bed (whiner). Nice to watch the weather channel for an hour and CNN nonstop war coverage. Dinner was a can of chili with minute rice on tortilla's, when that ran out, I ate more tortillas and most of the granola bars I had in the pack.  There was a microwave in the room.       
Back on the interstate for a 12 mile ride to the Sublet rd gas station where I was planning to eat a big lunch, problem was that the cafe was closed and the gas station had almost nothing but chips and beer, I found a box of fig newtons and had a soda.    It was another 35 miles to Snowville with no services between. Bought a can of refried beans to have with the rest of the tortilla's...yum...and watched a great sunset from a very cool RV park named Lottie Dell, there was only 1 other camper there and nobody else anywhere around.  The office was run on the honor system, money into the envelope and thru a slot in the door, a phone there to use (not a pay phone, a real phone).  It kind of had an old log cabin feel, and there was a golf driving range you could use for free if you had the energy.  Hot shower and a few phone calls followed by another frosty night in the tent.  31 degrees at 6:00am when I woke up.       
Another banner day of biking with clear skies and temps in the upper 50's to low 60's perfect....except for that pesky 15 mph headwind. From Snowville I climbed a minor pass from 4500ft to 5300ft and dropped back down to 4700 ft where I rode at 10 miles an hour for 10 miles to another climb back to 5250 ft and another drop into Tremonton at 4400 ft, again at about 10 mph. One kind of annoying thing about Utah freeways is that the rumble strips are on the outer edges of the shoulder and run almost all the way to the right lane of the freeway so you either have to ride right next to the lane (a bad idea when the trucks go by), or get rattled to pieces on the rumble strip.  I did a lot of both, riding next to the freeway lane until a truck appeared in the mirror and moved over till they passed. Several other disturbing things: A) Truck drivers honk at you when you are stripping down to your bike shorts by the side of the road. B) Truck drivers honk at you when you pee beside the road. C) The truck drivers aren't girls....... And finally, the ANIMAL REPORT especially for Lauri: First the dead ones: lots of cats, 7 skunks, many deer, 2 dogs, 2 coyotes, lots of rabbits, and a bloated dead cow floating in the Yakima river. Now the live ones: The funniest ones are the cows, they ALL watch you as you pass, I mean ALL of them.  Its pretty spooky when there are 300 of them looking at you, its like they know you just ate a quarter pounder at McDonalds.  My favorite cow moment was about 30 young calves running away from me the same direction I was going, I rode beside them for about a minute until they had to turn because of the fence. The horses are 50/50, some of them look, others don't, the really cool ones run along beside you, thats fun. The Dogs....what can I say about dogs...I used to like them but its getting harder to maintain my fondness.  When you are on a bike you are a game to every one of them, without exception, every dog I see barks and tries to chase.  My personal favorite dog moments are when a pickup truck comes up behind you and the big dog leans way out and barks right in your ear as they pass.  You just know both dog and owner have a good laugh over a bud lite later in the evening on that one. Lots of hawks in the trees, they just watch you pass. Tim mentioned the huge fish, that was cool. More animal moments to follow. Ben     
Equipment report: I've had almost no problems with the bike, the last flat was in Haines, Oregon, already a week ago. I also feel I have all the right gear with me. The skies over Salt Lake City were brown with blowing sand, most of it blew into my eyes I think. I stopped for the night at a fancy schmancy Super 8 motel and took a nice hot bath and washed my clothes.  I headed down to the motel laundry to use the dryer but it cost $1.50 and right next to the dryer were the candy vending machines.  I returned to the room with still wet clothes and a bag of microwave popcorn...the clothes can hang dry. Another ANIMAL UPDATE!!!  Along the bike path less than 3 miles from the center of Salt Lake City I passed a large farm, maybe 10 acres.  The first thing I saw were about 100 chickens in a fenced area...remember, I'm in the middle of town, I've been riding in town for hours along busy streets etc. The next thing was a pen with about 40 goats (were talkin live animals now, not road jerky) The next pen housed a bunch of Ostrich, at least 10 that I could see with all that sand in my eyes.   
I didn't have a great nights sleep last night, something I ate didn't agree with me......or was it that sewer water from yesterday's photo?? Anyway, woke up at about 3:00 with a really bad stomach and...yes, I drove the white bus, sorry for the graphic sickness. I'm feeling better this morning, even ate the continental breakfast at the motel. They had do-it-yourself belgian waffles, wow! good stuff, ate a bunch of food. and of course more coffee. I'm debating on whether to try for the big pass today, snow is in the forecast along with high winds changing from the south to the west (that would help me since I'm headed south-east) The TV news weather report called for mountain winds gusting into the 60 mph range but didn't say where in the state that would be. Could be an interesting night if I decide to head up the mountain. This report will be a cliff hanger till I decide. Ben decided to continue on toward the pass last night. He pedaled about 1 hour past dark and finally made it to Soldier Summit around 8pm. He had a good climb, albeit through a snowstorm. There wasn't any motel around, but the guy at the gas station was nice enough to let him pitch his tent out back. He stayed warm despite temps into the 20-degree range. [Tim] ____________________________________________________________ Ben here, I called my friend Jim for some advise and encouragment, it was late afternoon and I knew I didn't have time to get up and over the pass at Soldier summit before dark but the forecast was for heavy snow overnight and I really wanted to cross before the heavy stuff hit.  Problem was that there was a cheap motel right across the street from the phone I called from. I headed over to the motel, still undecided and did a few laps around their parking lot making up my mind.....finally it came to me.....what would a CRAZY guy on a bike do??? RIDE ON and see what happened!! What happened next was a hail storm followed by a big drop in temperature and the snow started falling gently but large flakes. I kept riding upward thinking "I'll wait till 6:30 and then find a place to camp" 6:30 passed and I decided to ride till dark and find a spot. Dark came and the snow was still falling but not sticking to the road yet...I kept riding. An hour passed, still climbing and sweating like crazy even though the temp was below freezing.  It got to the point where I was a little worried about stopping anywhere without shelter to change into dry clothes. I finally made the summit and started looking for the motel....the one that had burned down 3 years ago I found out from Rob, the manager of the only gas station on the summit. He was nice enough to let me change in the bathroom, cook some dinner in the microwave and set up camp out behind the store.  Still snowing. Hit the sack wearing every scrap of clothing I had.
I ran from the tent into the store and filled up on hot coffee and junk food until the snowplows had the road cleared off enough to ride on.  Good time talking with Rob and the few customers that passed thru, including a guy named Tim who had just crashed his Bronco truck into the guardrail, it was his birthday.....happy birthday. I had been talking with him inside the store a little and I don't think he knew I was on a bike trip because a little later while I was out packing up the tent he came running over and shouted "Your that crazy guy I saw riding up the pass last night!!!  Thats the most amazing thing I've ever seen!!"  He got a little excited hearing about my trip and just had to give me something, he headed over to his messed up truck and came back with 2 big bags of candy and a $10 bill!!  Cool guy, thanks Tim! The ride down to Price was fast and cold, I hit the brakes anytime I got over 25mph because the road was still pretty wet.  A nice stop for a late pancake breakfast and hit the road again. In the town of Green River I stopped by the state park to check on campsite rates, they wanted $14 for a tentsite and I had just passed a motel that was only $20.95 so I headed back there and got a hot bath and caught up on the news and weather.  Tough choice right? Cooked a pot of chili and rice out behind the motel :) Typical weirdo on a bike.   
It was great to see my wife Kathy and son Kelly again after 2 weeks on the road. We spent the night in the Super 8 but have transfered to a small cabin at the RV park for the next 3 days. Its nice to have a break from the riding and catch up a little on the eating and resting. Its cold and windy here in Southern Utah, high of 48 degrees today when their typical daytime temps are in the mid 70's this time of year....just lucky I guess. Another animal update, while sitting at the park yesterday I had a visit from 2 Llama's who were busy mowing the grass. The ride from Green River was a magic one, nice and quiet off the interstate for the first hour on a deserted frontage road, never saw another person or car, plenty of lizards and 4 deer that ran alongside for a bit then crossed the road and sped away. The ride down hwy 191 was a special one for me since I've driven it so many times on other trips to Moab and it has very good memories attached.....even with the 15mph headwinds.

This area is well known for growing a huge ammount of pinto beans, everywhere you look there is farmland. I kept riding towards Cahone and realized that I had forgotten to fill up on water for the overnight. Well, I'm off for Durango and a crossing of an 8000 ft pass this afternoon.  Tomorrow I'll take a short day and overnight near Pagosa Springs to get an early start on the BIG climb over 11,000 ft Wolf Creek Pass on friday.       
I had a fantastic day. Sunny and 70 degrees with blue skies and even a tailwind! There was a bit of climbing getting to Pagosa Springs. Ended up with a shorter day preparing for the pass tomorrow. Stayed in an RV park in Pagosa Springs. I was in the mood for a real camp treat - hot dogs and beans, so I bought a can and got an 8 pack of dogs and buns. I knew that I just needed to get to Keyes where I would turn east and the winds would be helping since they were out of the south-southwest.  I passed into Oklahoma somewhere along the way and got the typical new state photo by the sign...cool.  5 miles from Boise city there is a dirt road that heads east right to Keyes, I took it and went from working really hard for 6 mph to coasting on a dirt road at close to 15 mph, gave Tim a call while riding along and trying to stay out of the deeper gravel, that was fun. Had lunch in Keyes and found that my rear tire had gone flat while in the store, after lunch (PBJ's of course, and a bag of chips) I patched the hole and decided to stick with the old rear tire instead of changing to the spare for some unknown reason.  I am hesitating to put the spare on, not sure why. After a nice break I decided to try to make it the 50 miles to Guymon but could easily just camp by the road if I needed.  Out of Keyes there is 3 miles of south to get to the hwy east, another hard grind at 5 to 6 mph against the wind but flew along at 20 to 25 mph after turning east, fun stuff. I got to the Walmart in Guymon just at sunset and stocked up on snacks and bought a cheap $5 am/fm sports radio so I can listen to really bad country music while riding thru Oklahoma :) Also to be able to get weather info since I am entering big storm country. Got a cheap motel and ate dinner at a mexican place next door, menu in spanish but could make out that you could get your taco's with shreaded intestines if you wanted...I stuck with beef. Good dinner with great homemade chips and salsa followed by a soak in the motel room tub.  Much needed, I felt really grimey with sand stuck to my sunscreen'd skin. I'm still really enjoying being on the road, I've been pushing pretty hard the past few days to get a little ahead of schedule for the 19 day stretch to Nashville.  I know there will be bad weather or some other delay that will limit my mileage so its nice to get a little ahead of schedule early on.  After tomorrow I will be almost a full day ahead and can back it off a little. PS... Very cool photo Brendan, thanks!  It was probably too much sun and headwind but I couldn't help but think of Austin Powers with a Lance Armstrong body saying "Tailwinds are groovy baby yeah!"  yep, must have been heatstroke.   
Ben had hopes of going 100 miles so that he could be a full day ahead of schedule.  Instead, he had heavy winds and rain. He was able to keep ahead of the black wall of clouds for a couple hours but then it caught up with him.  He had just made it to a truck stop when the clouds opened up.  Even semi trucks were having to pull over because the rains were so hard and they couldn't see.  He stayed at the truck stop close to 3 hours waiting out the storm.  He had lots of coffee and friendly customers to keep him company.  The people of OK have been very kind and hospitable to Ben.  A preacher that came in said that he would come back later and make sure that Ben had a place to stay.  Ben realized that he only had about 20 more minutes of daylight and decided to go ahead and brave the elements when a woman came and asked him if he had a place to stay.  He told her that he was going to try and find a motel in the next town.  She phoned ahead for him and made sure that they had a vacancy.  They did!  He had 17 miles to go in 20 minutes before dark.  He made it there 45 min. after dark but God provided a full moon to light the way for him.  When he got there, the store owner next to the motel asked if he had had any dinner.  Ben said no so he said, "Let me heat up the fryer and cook you some burritos".  So after a crazy day, God provided a warm bed, a hot meal and a full moon to light the way.  Ben had also felt very fortunate not to have been caught up in any tornados that day.  There had been 6 sightings in OK that day and truckers had talked about seeing the tornado tracking vans on the road.  He also said that a tornado had touched down on a school house and ripped the roof off 70 miles south of where he was.
The sky was overcast but not looking as threatening as yesterday, the clouds were flying by along with many many tumbleweeds, some as big as my bike.  It was pretty funny trying to dodge them as I rode, hitting the brakes to let one go by or pedaling hard to get in front of one.  The wind was blowing across at a 45 degree angle over my left shoulder so when the semi trucks would go by they would block the wind for a second or two and since I was leaned way over against the wind it meant that the bike would dive left with every truck then get blasted back after they passed.  I got pretty good at judging when to correct but still ended up bouncing out onto the grassy shoulder a couple of times. One highlight of the morning was when I was coasting UP this gradual hill at 18 mph and could hear the trees behind me groaning and the whine from the powerlines went up in pitch all of a sudden and in about 5 seconds my speed went from 18 to 24.  That was while coasting uphill!!!!  Pretty wild morning. My speed averaged 21 mph for the 70 miles into Woodward, my planned overnight stop but it was only 1:00 in the afternoon and no self respecting crazy guy on a bike would quit for the day at such an early hour on a tailwind day!!  So I bought a bunch of groceries and headed back out on the highway. As the afternoon progressed the wind turned more from the north and my speed went down to 14 to 18 but still was able to make it over 130 miles in about 7 hours of riding, not a bad day!! The scenery past woodward was very nice also, going through a "canyon" (remember, this is Oklahoma) and past the Glass "mountains" (remember again, this is Oklahoma).......((the "mountains" were about 50 ft high)) but it was beautiful countryside.  I've really been enjoying Oklahoma, lots of green rolling hills and wide open views.  Its cool being able to see the next town coming 15 miles away with the big grain silos. I made it into Cleo Springs where an older man at the gas station recommended that I go to the rodeo grounds or fair grounds as he called it to spend the night.  It was a very nice small town, really nothing but residential and probably 800 residents, I found the rodeo grounds after 20 minutes of wandering around and set up camp back a ways in the trees in a nice grassy spot.  I don't think anyone in town even knew I was there, it was pretty and secluded being down a steep wooded hill from town.  The dogs even forgot I went by after a couple of hours of barking. :) Pasta with a can of Italian tomatoes and a snickers bar for desert, headed to bed by 9:00.   
Hey!!  Just because it's only noon and I've already had 4 servings of Malto-meal, french toast with syrup, a banana, 2 homemade cinnamon rolls (1 was so good I just had to buy another), and 2 cups of coffee.....I still haven't eaten lunch yet, boy am I hungry....  The bike shop owner Mikah says his sister-inlaw's bagel shop around the corner is his favorite spot for lunch.  He has been very helpful and will put the tire on and replace the chain while I wander around and visit the library. It was a beautiful morning, woke up at 5:00 and laid there listening to the very different sounding birds, thinking about how far away from home I am and just how lucky I am to be doing what I'm doing.  I rolled out before the sun came up and started in on a great breakfast.  One of my favorite treats after a big bunch of Malto-meal is to take a few slices of good bread, dip them in olive oil and fry them in the pan till they get good and crispy and dip them in syrup...yum yum yum, nothing better.  Very nice sunrise in a grassy green park, cool temps but a magic morning.  Wish they all were like this one.  Its funny how some days you wake up feeling so great, nothing you did, not for any reason it seems, just feeling fantastic.  That was this morning!!  Great to be out here. I rode the 35 miles into Enid, a fairly large town which means the nice highway I was on turned into a 2 lane tight busy grind thru town, people were cool though and went around.  I hate being a pain in traffic but sometimes you just have to take a lane for it to be safe.  I rode about 1/3 of the way over to the right, enough room for smaller cars to go by but the bigger trucks have to change lanes to go around.  Found the bike shop....really, its called "The Bike Shop"....cool.  I have a couple of hours to burn while its getting fixed up. More later, Ben  Because of a tip from a fellow tourer, Ben decided to change his route to avoid some headaches, both from bad roads and big cities. From Enid, he's riding north then east on I-60. He'll probably end up tonight in Tonkawa. His midday stay in Enid sounded exciting. He received quite the celebrity welcome at the bike shop, thanks to Troy. After dropping off his bike and hitting the library, he wandered around trying to find the recommended bagel shop. That ended when he walked past a pub and grill.  Several days back, Ben had a couple first-sightings: an armadillo and a snake (both roadkill). He's also seen several skunks. Kathy said he's still loving the riding believe it or not. ___________________________________________________________________ Got off pretty early from the state park at Disney, no rain overnight and the weather is looking good.  I stopped for groceries in Jay, not too far from the Arkansas border.  Another 2 lb package of peanutbutter sandwich cookies.  Had to eat a bunch before they would all fit into the handlebar bag. On thru Bentonville and a bunch of traffic, dropping south thru Hindsville and up over the hills to Huntsville for the night.  Nice crossing of Beaver lake on hwy 12, another redneck welcome yell, this time still unintelligible but with an arkansas accent.  Cool! Lots of big hills in Arkansas, the roads seem to wind around and around making the most of the topography, hitting every hill possible.  Climb one and immediately there is a nice winding downhill run heading for a gap between the hills but just before the gap the road turns and heads steeply up another hill.  Cruel joke by the hwy planning engineers. Entering Huntsville happens to be a fairly steep downhill.  I passed one motel hoping to find another a little closer to town so I could get some food without riding far.  Found a nice little motel right in town with a pizza place across the street. I rang the bell on the motel office door and a woman came and opened the door and talked to me thru the thick glass screendoor.  "Can I help you?" she asked, "I'd like a single room for the night" I replied.  She started shaking her head no and said "No, we don't allow bikes in the room".  "I can lock it up outside"  I replied still thru the closed glass door.  Very strange, but soon to get stranger. She finally opened the door and let me into the motel office and I filled out the paperwork, she asked me if I was a smoker, I replied that I would prefer a non-smoking room.....she said "No, I asked you if you were a smoker!!"  I said that I occasionally smoked a cigar in the evening but never inside.  "Our policy is to only rent no smoking rooms to people who don't smoke" she said.  I felt like leaving to find something else but remembering the steep downhill on the way into town I kept my opinions to myself. I got a smoking room complete with full sized fridge, stove, sink etc.  Even a big easy chair in front of the TV but kind of expensive, $38  for such a dinky small town.  The other funny thing was all of the Christian literature in the room, it made me wonder if she ever really read the bible, the religion came thru pretty strongly but the Godly love and humility sure didn't.  Could have just been a bad day though, who knows.  Since I spent so much on the room I didn't feel right hitting the pizza place so made rice-a-roni in the room and settled down in front of the TV for a while.  Life is still good!             
When I talked to him at 12:45pm CT, he'd just stopped for a snack at a gas station. In the background I heard a truck passing. He commented that it was a logging truck with the logs stacked sideways. As it passed he said "the tires are smoking like crazy, wait it's on fire, hold on". Then I heard him drop the phone and run. He came back a minute later and said the trucks tire was literally on fire but he was able to flag down the driver. He is planning to stay at a state park at Tyler Bend, a few miles before Marshall. It's unlikely he will be able to find the time to update this journal very much before Nashville.  Ben called Troy around 2:30pm CT. He went through a town called Mt Sherman. It never occurred to him that "Mt" meant MOUNTAIN which means climbing. The summit was 2200 feet. Only 4 miles beyond he entered Jasper at 800 feet. He said it was fast winding run down. He learned that one of the roads on his route is dirt, so he'll go North through Hasty. Although it will add about 8 miles overall, it will get him to highway 65 sooner. He still plans to stay near Tyler Bend tonight. ______________________________________________  Ben here, One really funny thing in Hasty that I really regret not getting a photo of was the sign for the Holiness church in Hasty......It said "Hasty Holiness Church"  I almost rode off into the ditch I was lauging so hard.  Wonder if they specialize in deathbed conversions.....Or could their motto be Slam Dunk? Not far out of Huntsville there was this really cool roadside stop, photo's below. Also did 5 miles extra trying to shortcut across a "low water bridge", it would have cut 11 miles off the day but ended up being 10" deep on the slippery roadway and flowing really fast.  I turned around when a guy in a jeep said he just about backed out after starting across. Just before Tyler bend state park you cross the Buffalo river again, then climb the 400 ft elevation up the other side, then turn into the state park where the road winds for 3 miles and drops right back down to the river again.....gee, thanks!   Very cool state park though.               
Ben stayed just outside of Marshall (don't know if it is before or after Marshall). He had a challenging day yesterday. Lots of steep hills and lots of dogs chasing him. Some were in packs. He never had to use his dog spray but came close with one dog.  1:00pm CT - Ben stayed at Tyler Bend State Park last night. He was very tired, but got a good sleep. Before bed, he was looking at the strange stars in the trees, which turned out to be fireflies (lightening bugs). He had to call me from Timbo, Arkansas. He is having a little better day today, the hills aren't quite so bad and no attack dogs yet. After buying a soda at the store in Timbo, the storekeeper said "you're going to Newport? You'd better start moving, you've got some hills ahead of you" (add you're own Arkansas accent). About an hour back, he passed through the town of Leslie, where he couldn't pass the  Serenity Farm Bread  bakery. He literally could not pass it without buying some bread, the smell was so good. He bought some walnut, raisin bread. His goal is to reach Jacksonport State Park tonight and at least the outskirts of Memphis tomorrow.  Ben made it to Jacksonport State Park, just outside of Newport. He had another difficult day with lots of hills and a long distance. He thinks he is back on schedule after his detour. He was on his bike 9 hours (not including breaks). At around 4:30, he realized he still had 40 miles to go, so he "sprinted" into Newport before nightfall. Actually, he did stop in the town of Oil Trough to pick up dinner. Of course they didn't have anything but a tiny convenience store. He tried to find a can of chili, but could only come up with a can of sloppy joe. When he got to the state park, he realized that the directions said to add hamburger meat, so he had bread with sauce for dinner, bad sauce. His elevation at Jacksonport is lower than his house in Everett: 250 ft. That means the Mississippi River drops 250 feet between there and New Orleans, 500 miles or so south. Tomorrow, he will make it into West Memphis and cross the Mighty Miss Thursday morning.     
  
 Ben called Troy at around 10:00am CT. He was still hiding out, but had eaten breakfast at a place called Grannies Soul Food or something like that. I think he probably stood out like a sore thumb. The guy cooking was named "Sonny". He said another 2 fellows came in with something large in a plastic bag and took it to Sonny. It turned out to be a big catfish.  The cook told the guy if he would clean it himself, he'd fry it up for him.  The rain passed and the sun came out in downtown Memphis. He rode down Beale Street, Ben called it "the blues capitol of the world". Said it kind of reminded him of Las Vegas but 70 years ago. Cobblestone streets and soul food. He rode past a donut shop across the street and just had to stop. He ended up spending an hour there because he met and talked with two guys, one owned a home brewery equipment store and the other owned a local outdoor equipment store. They bought him a couple donuts. If you haven't noticed, he's not making very good speed, but having a great time! He turned east on Union then north on Parkway. He's enjoying the beautiful urban scenery with tree-lined streets. His intended overnight stop was Bolivar, but the guy at the donut shop said that was the state insane asylum. Ben said that he might just fit in.  Ben called at 2:30pm CT from Eads on the outskirts of Memphis. He had a great ride along a great route (thanks to Troy). He lunched at the last possible BBQ joint he could find. He hasn't gotten rained on since the early morning and his shoes are almost dry. He's still planning to make it to Bolivar tonight, only 40 more miles.             
Out of Bolivar, hwy 64 turned into a skinny, two-lane, no-shoulder, just-try-to-stay-alive kind-of road. Usually the big trucks slow down and move over, it's the pickups with Confederate flags you have to worry about. Luckily it changed to a comfortable, divided, 4-lane, with shoulder highway just before Selmer. He's had nice weather, often cloudy and a little rainy at times, but no hard rain. His goal today is to reach the beginning of the Natchez Trace Parkway and stay at the Meriwether Lewis Monument Campground tonight. More info and pictures later.  Troy got a voice mail from Ben a while ago. He was in Savannah, TN just across the Tennessee River. Said a black thunderhead passed him by, looked like it went up to 40,000 ft. Fortunately, it had mercy on him. He said the wind is now mostly at his back and there are several smaller white thunderheads behind him. He had just finished a triple decker p-nut butter and jelly sandwich and a bag of chips. Looks like he has about 40+ to the Natchez Trace Parkway and then probably another 15 to the campground.  Ben made it to Meriwether Lewis Nat. Monument and had a great day!  He arrived at sunset after going about 110 miles.  He had hoped to go to a store before making it to the park but the store was closed.  He gets to have mashed potatoes and cookies for dinner. He is enjoying being on the Natchez Trace and has 65 miles to go till he gets to Troy's house. Ben doesn't know it yet but Katie is cooking steaks for them tomorrow and then they will rest on Sunday. Then Jim will join them on Monday where it will be back...on the bike seat...again.       
There was a group of youngsters riding bikes all over the campground, turns out that they were a scout troop, pathfinders, that were going to do a 50 mile ride south on the Trace today.  They ranged in age from about 8 to maybe 14, a pretty big day for guys that young.  They were VERY interested in everything I had and all I was doing.  It was very cool to talk with them about the trip, they had all kinds of questions and it was great to be able to inspire them and maybe broaden their ideas a little as to what was possible.  They had never heard of anyone riding a bike that far.  Good stuff! The ride was very scenic and peaceful, not very many cars on the road and I can't remember once where I had to bail off onto the grass shoulder to avoid being run over!!!  :)  Very different from parts of hwy 64 yesterday. One problem with the Trace is that there are very obvious mile marker signs every mile and I knew exactly what number was the last one 10 miles before Troy's house and it was impossible to ignore them.  I found myself counting them off and focusing on the milage more than the scenery and just enjoying the day.  I was pretty excited to get to Troy's and couldn't really ever settle into the good easy going pace where the miles float by while I'm enjoying the day.  It didn't help that I hadn't eaten very well last night and was running a little deficet in energy.  I pulled all of the food I had left out and calculated when I could eat what.  All I had left was 1/4 jar of peanut butter, 1 granola bar, 1 dried fruit snack, and a half a pan of angel hair pasta until later afternoon when I finished the Natchez Trace and turned onto hwy 100 toward Troys house. I got pretty hungry and could definately feel that I was low on energy. I called Troy as I approached the big bridge (photo below) and was 5 miles from finishing the Trace.  He arranged to meet me at the Shell gas station right at the junction of hwy 100 and would ride the 12 miles to his house with me.  A pretty big day for him after just running the marathon!!  What a stud! Troy brought a plate full of homemade cookies, a bananna, and an orange.  Add that to the 20 oz coke and super size snickers bar I bought at the store and I was feeling a little more human and thought I might just be able to make it to his house.  We ended up taking a really cool, extra long route thru Percy Warner park near his house, its a huge park with lots of hills and cool roads that curve their way around and thru the forest.  We stopped at the top of one of the hills for my first view of Nashville hidden in the dense forest in the distance.  It really is a beautiful part of the country, lush green and dense woods.  I do realize that I'm there during one of the better weather months of the year.  1 month prior or later and my impressions would probably be different. A great evening talking and eating vast amounts of food followed by coffee and more cookies and a big bowl of ice cream for desert and the evening turned into late night and then early morning before heading off to bed.  It was great to have a house to come to and such good friends to enjoy time with.  A very cool day!         
We had a big dinner on Saturday night, followed by a big lunch at a resturant called "Monells" I'm not sure if thats spelled right but it was a lot of fun.  Its a huge old house and there are tables that seat 15 people or so in different rooms.  You get seated with whoever else is there at that time and they start bringing big bowls of food that everyone passes around.  There is no menu but there are lots of choices of what to eat.  Pot roast, BBQ pork ribs, mashed potatoes, corn pudding, great biscuits and peach sauce (I had 4 of those) you get the idea. I took some time to add photo's to some of the more recent day's postings.  I still have more to go but will wait till I get home for the rest. We did a trip to the grocery store to resupply for the next week and spent some time sorting gear and stashing some of my cold weather gear.  I didn't think I had very much that I wouldn't be needing but ended up with a 10 lb grocery bag full of stuff that I don't expect I'll need.  Cool, I can carry more cookies and hostess pasteries that way. This is the first day I haven't ridden my bike since I left home a month ago.  It felt a little weird but very welcome. Now its time to go ride the Great Smoky mountains....first we have to get out of Nashville during the morning rush hour.  It will be great having Troy's company for the last leg and my good friend Jim will be joining for the first 1/2 day leaving here.  Good fun!
More news from the road later on today....stay tuned!!!  They just left about 9:00 a.m. CST.  It's a beautiful sunny morning, and looking to be quite warm.  Jim is going to ride 50 miles with them and then catch a ride back to Nashville.  Ben left a message in the evening. He had a good ride through Nashville, Troy picked a great route. Jim went 50 miles with them and Ben really enjoyed having him along. Ben and Troy went about 85 miles. Just past Smithville but 12 miles short of Sparta on Highway 70. They found a campground there (Hill Crest RV Park) and they were able to stay there for free. He said it was a little warm yesterday but they're having a blast. They left the campground at 7:00am CT.             
 Ben called at 5:30pm ET. They were hiding out from a storm that rolled in dumping rain and hail and filling up the streets with water. They had no other choice but to eat an early dinner at a hamburger joint.  Ben called Kathy at 9:40 ET. They made it to Lenoir City and are roughing it at a motel. They got in 1/2 an hour after dark. They had thunder, lightning and hail today. Troy is doing great! Especially for only 1 day off after running a marathon and not getting much riding practice in. Keep it up guys, you're almost there. They head into the Smokey Mountains tomorrow.       
 Ben left a message at 4:15pm ET. They had a good breakfast at an all-you-can-stuff breakfast buffet. After riding now for 60 miles, they were temporarily pinned down by the rain at the Sugarlands Visitors Center, the main entrance to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. They have another 26 miles through the park with a 3,500 ft elevation gain over the pass, then down to 3,000 ft to the Oconaluftee Visitors Center on the North Carolina side.  Per Katie (thanks for the requested picture), they are planning to stop at a campground near Cherokee. That would be about 85 miles for today. Per Kathy, she's had some inquiries about the earthquake centered near Fort Payne, Alabama the morning of 4/29 (4.9 richter scale). Ben told her that it woke him up but Troy slept through it. They were sleeping in the tent that night. Now he has encountered just about every kind of weather condition except a hurricane and she prays that there won't be one waiting for them in Savannah. ______________________________________________ Ben here, As Tim said we had a great big breakfast but had to ride a little over a mile west to get it, then retrace back to the hwy.  It was worth it though, all you can eat!! The riding was very scenic, especially the cutoff from Townsend to the Sugarland visitors center.  The road winds along a narrow canyon with great river views and trees lining the sides.  Very peaceful and nice.  It did rain on us some but with the steep canyon walls and the wind direction we were able to stay dry for most of it.  Had to hide out once by the river under the big trees. It was a long haul to get to the start of the climb over the Smoky's.  60 miles to Sugarland with maybe 1500 ft of climbing, then from Sugarland its 13 miles and 3500 ft to Newfound Gap.  A pretty big day by my standards. We left Sugarland while it was raining lightly and thunder off in the distance, we pushed out the climb in a little over 2 hours and made the summit at 7:30, 45 minutes till sunset.  A short stop at the restroom, quick photo and its off to the downhill......well, a little downhill followed by more uphill...uuuggg....finally we make it to the big drop and rocket down the 2500 ft drop with large painful raindrops hitting your face as it starts to get dark. We rolled into Cherokee at 8:45 and started looking for a cheap motel, found one and asked about a resturant open late, the last 2 choices closed at 9:00 so we hurried over and walked thru the door of the Ponderosa Buffet at 8:55 and stuffed ourselves.  Good timing!  and the shower at the Motel felt great.                   
 So far today, they've experienced a few more hills than anticipated, but the weather is nice. When he called, he was at Tuckasegee on hwy 107. They've decided to alter the route slightly, eventually ending up on the west side of Augusta. They should make 90 miles today and will stay near Hartwell Lake just SW of Greenville, SC near Anderson.  Ben called Kathy at 9:47 ET and left a message. They made it to a little town called Townville (no joke). Today was a little tougher than anticipated due to the Nantahala Range but they had another good day. They hope to go 100 miles tomorrow, 90 some on Saturday, and 50 on Sunday. __________________________________________________ Ben here, We headed out from Cherokee at 9:00am and headed for Sylva and the really cool visitors center, photo below, where we tried for 45 minutes to decide on the rest of the route to Savannah.  Once again the route I picked out while in Seattle included 10 miles of gravel road up over a mountain, not great for loaded touring bikes.  The women at the center were very helpful and we soon had a good plan. At a gas station lunch stop in Tuckasegee one of the older local men was discussing loudly with another older gentlemen about all of the bicycle riders getting "KILT" on the road up Glenville Mountain.  It was pretty funny because he wasn't talking to us but was extra loud to be sure we heard.  He really thought his mountain was the BIG one and we were sure to die getting hit by a truck trying to cross it. He was right......It was a BIG climb, almost harder than Newfound gap, maybe because we really weren't expecting it, and the traffic was pretty sporty with narrow windy roads and lots of trucks. The road took us into a corner of the Nantahala national forest and right by a Thorpe lake at 3900 ft elevation.  Looked like a lot of vacation homes and the cars were all pretty expensive looking as they flew past. Our day of climbing paid off as we dropped out of the mountains on some spectacular banked corners, one right after another 25mph signs that we blew past at 30 to 40.  We didn't stop much because there were storms on 3 sides and we were heading toward the only blue in the sky. We rolled into a resort campground a half an hour before sunset $19 for a tentsite but there weren't really any other options close by and we were worn out.  Chili and rice for dinner and the sleep of the weary bike traveler.         
 Ben and Troy had a great day, no rain, temps in the upper 70's, mostly just easy rolling hills on nice roads (but not many shoulders). They were able to average around 14mph. He said the hills were arranged in such a way that from the top of one hill, they could see the next three off in the distance, maybe 1 mile apart. At about the 90 mile mark, they passed a campground, but decided to go for the 100 mile mark. Within a few miles of that decision, the thunderclouds began to surround them, at least on three sides. Just then, the road they were on turned right toward the only blue sky visible and they were able to ride the last 6-7 miles into Thomson dry. About 5 minutes after they got to the motel, the rain started dumping with thunder and lightening all around. They have about 140 miles into Savannah.   
      
Ben and Troy spent last night at the Dreamland Motel in Sylvania, had a big breakfast at an all-you-can-eat breakfast buffet right when they opened, then rolled out at 6:45am.
