They had a good ride into Savannah, 60 miles of mostly flat roads and sunny weather. It was quite hot at 80 degrees and very high humidity. Ben and Kathy will fly back Monday mid-day.         
Kathy and I went to "Shoney's" and had a nice big breakfast, at least I did, eating 2 normal breakfast orders plus half of Kathy's that she couldn't finish. We were flying Delta standby so we headed out to the airport at mid morning to catch a flight to Atlanta hopefully in time to get a connecting flight to Seattle in the afternoon. Flights were pretty heavily booked for the first leg to Atlanta and we waited until around 4pm before something opened up to Cincinnati, it was the plane we had been watching as the mechanics worked on it all day right in front of the window.  It was maintance delayed for most of the day and we ended up being 2 of the 7 people on the flight.  Whole jet was empty since all of the other passengers had gotten other flights out earlier.  Pretty weird! The connection to Seattle was fine after a 2 or 3 hour wait in Cincinnati and we ended up in 1st class!!  I could get used to flying like that! We landed in Seattle at 10:30pm local time and found our luggage, it had been there since noon so there was no delay waiting for it to be unloaded from the plane.  Our 17 yr old son Kelly picked us up out front and I was home and in my own bed by midnight. It was pretty strange being home after such a long time.  Didn't seem real that the trip was done but at the same time it was really nice to be home.  Mixed feelings are to be expected I suppose.  Overall I was just feeling very satisfied to have done the things I set out to do.  My route worked out well, the gear I chose did fine and I didn't really haul along anything I didn't use daily. Tuesday morning the alarm went off at 5:00am and I popped up trying to figure out where I needed to bike to today, I couldn't remember where I was and thought I still had 2 or 3 more days to ride.  It was several minutes before I remembered that the alarm was to get up for work and my bike ride was only 12 miles there and 12 home after.  All my stuff was set out last night and ready to go.  Pretty easy, ride 12 miles, hot shower and breakfast...Malto-meal in the microwave, free coffee....life is good....oh yeah, the work.....not that bad either. I'll be putting together some final thoughts and stats on milage, route, costs, weird body functions......all that stuff in the next few days. Also check back for more photo's soon. I'm glad it has been fun for you to follow along.  My thanks goes out to all who helped make the trip possible and such a pleasure.  Thanks to Tim for all of his fantastic work on this site gathering photos of my trip since I couldn't post them while on the road, and for gathering the information from whoever I happened to call and having it on the site in such short order.  It was fun for me to read the things he was writing and here I was the one doing the trip!! Thanks also to Troy for the many route and weather updates, and to Jim for the encouragment and help putting together the trip home. The most special thing about this trip was the love, support and encouragment from all of my friends and family, and also from the good people, strangers who I met that showed me kindness and helped with information and such. Ben Staley 
Car tour.......It could be a dashboard fire, or spark plug wires getting a little hot, could be the old 8-track stereo finally shorted out, or maybe, hopefully it's that factory over there. Bike tour.......odds are pretty good its you, maybe 80-20 or 90-10.  Could be the factory but not likely,  hit the gas station bathroom and stick your head under the faucet.  Time for a little sponging off. _____________________________________ Hot burning rubbery smell Car tour........you could be taking the corners a little fast or braking too hard, slow it down a little Mario and try to enjoy the scenery.  It's the freeway, not the grand prix speedway. Bike tour.......Its definitely you, find a shower you dirty pig, and rinse out those socks for crying out loud, sheesh. ______________________________________ Exhaust, carbon monoxide, gassy odor Car tour.......Carburetor needs adjusting, running too rich, could also be a leak in the exhaust system.  Better get it into a shop soon and keep the windows down while driving. Bike tour......Whoa Dude!!!  Was that you??? Time to mix up the diet a little, sure those cans of chili are quick and easy dinner but back it off a little, try some pasta or a salad.  Man, that's really not cool, a little warning for the rest of the peloton next time.  _______________________________________ Rancid foul cheesy odor Car tour......what DID you do with that leftover half of the italian grinder sandwich from the other day.  Look under the seat and get yourself a pair of rubber gloves.  When traveling with kids it could be time to empty the dirty diaper bag. Bike tour.......time to brush those teeth, you know it couldn't be leftover sandwich because there's no way you'd leave a good sandwich uneaten.  If you used your toothbrush to clean the crud out of the rear hub, put it back in the tool kit and head for the gas station, use a little scrap of paper towel and some liquid soap.  Time to get creative with the oral hygiene until you can get to a BIG town with a walmart to get another toothbrush.  While you're at the walmart, grab a 2 lb package of those peanutbutter sandwich cookies, open the bag and eat 1/4 of them on the spot with a quart of chocolate milk.  Dump the rest of the cookies right into your handlebar bag and feel free to grab a couple while you are riding over the next few days.  You really need the protein.  Don't forget to brush often. _______________________________________ Clean, pine freshness Car tour.......its the air conditioner blowing past the little tree air freshener hanging from the mirror.  Be thankful you're in the front seat. Bike tour......its a pine tree, you are camping in the woods, its a quiet evening, the sun is setting and you've got that "life is good" grin on your face because you are in the .00001 % of the population that was lucky enough to be on tour today.  Soak in the feeling, enjoy life, sleep deeply and have good dreams.  I wish I could join you but the memories are still fresh in my mind and I'm smiling along with you. Ben Staley 
Prior to the trip I had estimated my daily costs to be $20 per day including meals and campground or motel costs.  The reasoning was that in the past I have done shorter trips where I ate Malto-meal for breakfast, snacked for lunch and cooked all of my own dinners.  The food costs were estimated at:  $2.00 for breakfast, $4.00 for lunch, and $4.00 for dinner.  I grossly underestimated the increased calories needed to support biking 90 miles a day, day after day.  I hadn't included any snack food costs for instance because on my previous trips I just ate whatever I had carried from home.  On the tour though I really needed those stops at Sonic drive in and the frequent gas station for coffee and a donut. I also had been reading everybody else's trip reports where camping in the city park was a normal thing and I expected a lot more nights of free camping than I actually experienced.  I think this was mostly due to me being on a route I made up instead of the standard  Transamerica bike trail. Most of the towns I inquired about free camping in, really didn't know what to do.  The police departments had never been asked about that before and weren't sure what the city ordnance was on tent camping within city limits. I really didn't do a very thorough job of looking for free camping because of the limited time I had to do it.  Most days I was riding until close to sunset and didn't have much time to search out a free spot, I took what was convenient. My actual cost per day EXCLUDING the extra expenses for my wife to fly to Savannah and back, her meals and rental car while there etc, came to $37 per day. I ended up staying in motels a lot more than I thought I would, both because of the lack of camping on my route and foul weather I ran into during the earlier part of my trip. My total costs by category for the 46 day tour rounded off were: Meals  $440 Snacks between meals   $120 Motels     $804  (23 nights) Camping    $117   (19 nights) Misc costs (including bike repairs)  $198 Airplane fair (standby on a buddy pass)  $312 I averaged 89 miles per day over the course of the whole trip not including the 3 days off mountain biking in Moab and the 1 day off in Nashville at Troy's house. My shortest day was 48 miles, which was the friday I left Seattle after working 8 hours.  My highest mileage day was 132 miles, and I had 10 days over 100 miles. Most days I was on the bike by 7:30 or 8:00 am and would ride until around 8:00 that evening.  I would take a lot of breaks during the day but usually none over 40 minutes or so.  Most were 10 to 15 minutes every hour and a half or so. My average speed according to the bike computer was somewhere in the 12 to 13 mph range.  It varied a lot depending on wind direction and terrain. I felt like the wind was mostly favorable on the west to east route although by far most of the days the wind was blowing out of the south.  I really don't think one direction has enough of an advantage to make it the primary consideration in your route selection. I chose to do my trip very early in the year for several reasons.  First on my list was that I really didn't want to be riding in the southeast in the summer heat and humidity.  Since I commute by bike to work year-round I am equipped to ride in the cold weather and really prefer a colder day to a really hot day.  Also the Northwest Church youth group mountain biking trip in Moab was scheduled around my son's spring break from school and I wanted to be there when they were. Looking back on it now I think I got pretty lucky with the weather considering the limited time I had to do the trip.  I only had 6 weeks to complete the tour since I was using saved up vacation from work.  It was pretty cold riding and camping during the first 2 weeks and prime storm time for the leg thru "tornado alley", and I didn't have much time to sit out bad weather.  Any downtime needed to be made up by riding longer days later. It was very nice to be riding in South Carolina and Georgia on 75 to 80 degree days in the sunshine instead of 90 to 100 degrees and humidity. I tried to keep the eating out to one meal a day and it worked out pretty well that way.  I could eat a big breakfast one day then switch it up and have a dinner out the next etc. I really enjoyed eating at the local cafe's or BBQ stands, whatever the area was well known for.  I tried to stay away from the national chains since I could get that food anytime back home.  I wanted to experience some of the culture and food of the area's I was riding thru. I really wish I could have camped more, my best nights were the ones in the tent.  The motels were more convenient on short notice, and its really hard to pay $15 or $18 to camp at a state park or RV park when there is a $23 a night motel with a hot bath and TV right down the street. On a tour where I didn't have a set finish date I would have been able to plan my route to hit more campgrounds and national parks instead of always choosing the direct route between 2 points.  Many times I could have ridden 8 or 10 miles to get to a campground but would have had to retrace the miles to get back on route and I just didn't have the time or energy. I would be a lot more likely to do one of the pre-mapped out routes now that I know more about the difficulty in finding free camping and all of the other day to day things you need.  Its fun to plan out your own route and there are many benefits of doing it but also its pretty hard to get good info on what services are available in the next town until you are there.  Either way is fun so its more a matter of where you want to go and what you want to see. Ok, this was supposed to be a statistics page, not a how-to book on bike touring.  I'll stop there and pick up on another page. 
So for the sake of science I'll tell a few secret details about what I experienced.  Sorry if its gross.  You didn't have to open the page, and you can stop reading now before it gets bad. I commute to work by bike year round, 12 miles each way, 5 days a week and do ride some on the weekends so its been a long time since I had the sore butt you get when you start riding after an extended period of time off.  I didn't have any problem with the general overall soreness like that. What I did have trouble with was ingrown hairs or something similar where the sides of the seat rubbed on my legs and .....well.....in the area behind your....ummm....yeah...and in front of your.....ummm....OK, this is a little harder than I thought it was going to be.  I think you get the idea.  Anyway, they were like pimples and hurt when you sat on them.  They get red and inflamed and really are a pain in the ass....really!!  :) They started during the first 3 days of the tour and I had them on and off for the entire 6 weeks.  I think I only had about a week of riding without some discomfort from them. Some of them in the area under the most pressure and rubbing from the bike seat would scab over during the night and then open up again while riding the next day. I started applying A&D ointment, a diaper rash cream, every morning before riding but it really didn't seem to help much.  Also it didn't seem to be hygene related , showering often didn't seem to change the situation. Several other people I've talked with have experienced the same thing, including 1 person who said he got the same thing from wearing crash pads for football in highschool.  Seems to be caused by the constant rubbing and pressure in a hairy area. I just dealt with the discomfort, it wasn't ever bad enough to keep me from riding. I've gotten some advise from a veteran bike tourist that either preparation H, or a prescription antibiotic cream is available to help with this problem. _______________________________________ Another topic, a little less personal, was knee pain. I had pain in my right knee for 2 weeks of my tour, right beside my kneecap on the inside of my leg.  It seemed to be the tendons or muscle that wraps around the knee and joins the upper leg to the lower leg across the inside. I know the day I injured it, pushing a little too hard up a series of hills at the end of a hard day and I was turning a little too much anger/frustration energy into pedaling energy and overloaded my muscles or tendons in that leg.  I wasn't spinning the pedals, I was forcing and pushing hard up a hill against a headwind and felt a little pain. The next day I knew I had hurt myself but the pain was managable and I started taking Ibuprofen at the max dosage listed on the bottle to keep the swelling down and hopefully speed the healing process a little. It was difficult to push down on the pedal without hurting so I favored my left leg when the right leg hurt.  I spent the better part of 2 weeks mainly pedaling with my left leg, just letting the right one rest during the powerstroke or downstroke on the right side. It really wasn't that bad, it didn't seem to slow me down too much except for on the hills.  Also, the pain would be less after I warmed up in the midday so I would use that leg carefully during that time and less in the morning and evening. One problem was that I was in Idaho, Utah, and Colorado for that time period...lots of hills including the climb over Wolf Creek Pass at the cont. divide. I think I got a rest in eastern Colorado and Oklahoma riding on the flat lands and the pain went away.  It never came back, and I never quit riding because of it.  I was still going 80 to 100 miles a day. ________________________________________________________________ Another problem I had from riding so much was a little change in bladder control, nothing major but..... From about the 2nd week on until the end of the tour I didn't get as much warning as I would have liked that it was time to find a place to pee. I would be fine one minute and all of a sudden....its time to go...like right now....countdown..10...9...8...7.... I like to call it a "drop the bike and run moment" Out on the open road it was no problem, plenty of bathrooms all around, everywhere and anywhere was fine.  In residential Memphis where it might be 5 miles to the next gas station it wasn't so cool. I don't think it was bladder infection or anything like that, I'm just not sure what it was. I kept trying to think of a cool way to rig an "on the bike bathroom" using a tube and waterbottle but never did try it. Could have made for a pretty embarassing and not to mention messy and hard to explain crash under the wrong circumstances. Hey.....it would have given me a fun little something to use on the dog chases, or the redneck welcoming committee (guys in trucks who swerve, honk and yell something you never can understand out the window).
Troy reminded me of a few to start with: Brian's Corner, in the panhandle of Oklahoma, A truck stop and gas station during one of the hairiest rainstorms (Tornado watch) I have ever been in.  The semi-trucks were pulling off the road because they couldn't see to drive.  One truck driver to another "Whacha haulin?.....Sheep......You baptize em?.....Yep" Same spot, I was talking to a ranch owner about the rain, I asked him if it was normal to get a months worth of rain in an hour.  He replied in a slow drawl "You know, we get around 18 inches of rain here a year.......an you can usually remember the day it happened" Countryside somewhere in Tennessee, a man standing by his beat up pickup-truck as Troy and I rode past.  "Man......I sure hope you boys don't get a flat"  I yelled back to him "Yep, that'd put an end to the trip right there"     Was it a warning? Was he wishing us success?, turned out to be more like a prophecy because I had 2 flats that afternoon, first one in 2000 miles, one more the next day and Troy had one also the day after that. 2 older gentlemen sitting in a store in North Carolina the day after we crossed the Smoky mountains.  They were talking to each other but obviously loud enough so we couldn't help but hear.  "You know a biker is gonna get himself KILT crossin Glenville mountain, he'd git hit by a loggin truck for sure" West Memphis Arkansas while waiting for breakfast at Grannies Soul Food Cafe.  The cook Sonny was back in the kitchen making my bacon and eggs when 2 guys come in with a big catfish in a grocery bag and yell for Sonny.  He comes up to the counter, looks in the bag and says "Nope, I ain't gonna take it....you boys go clean it an I'll cook it up for you but I ain't cleanin it...no way....I ain't got time fo that" On a small side road in Arkansas after turning back on a short-cut over a low-water bridge that was flowing too fast for me to try.  A man in a pick-up stops and is just looking at me funny.  I asked him "you think I could have made it across?"  (It would have cut about 10 miles off my day).  He ignores my question and asks "where you ride that from?" I told him "Seattle Washington"  He shakes his head, furrows his brow and says "I can not imagine" and drives off. I stopped at a gas station in Arkansas for a soda and bag of chips to eat with my peanut butter and jelly triple decker sandwich for lunch.  The usual crowd of people forms and they are talking and asking questions, 3 of them are young men who are joking around with me and each other.  They ask where I'm headed, I tell them Jacksonport state park, 60 miles down the road and they are sure there's no way I'll make it before dark.  I say goodbye and head back out to my bike, look around and since there isn't anywhere good to sit and eat I pedal about 4 miles down the road and stop at a church. I'm eating in the shade under a tree when this big truck pulls up.  Its the 3 guys from the gas station and the driver leans out the window grinning and yells   "Boy you better git on yor bike an ride, you'll never make Jacksonport doin' that!!" I'm in Walts Corner, eastern Colorado, I've ridden 35 miles from Trinidad in some of the most remote, empty country anywhere, I was stupid and hadn't filled up on water while in Trinidad, I'm almost empty and there is another 40 miles of wasteland to get to the next dot on the map, a very small town named Kim. Walts corner isn't even a gas station, in fact its nothing but a counter with a fridge behind it and a doorway into a room where the owner is selling his artwork. Paintings of naked women, bronze castings of naked women, wood carvings of naked women etc.  I go in with one waterbottle and ask his wife (not a naked woman thank God) if there is a spot I could fill it up.  She says "We can't give you any water, we don't have very much........a long pause......we do have bottled water you could buy" and she opens the fridge up, its full of bottled water and soda.  I buy a small bottle and a can of coke for $1.50 and head off toward Kim. 
The fun started as soon as we connected with the Orchard Loop trail and began the downhill run. I went first and did my imitation of a human weed whacker for the first two hundred yards. Just a month ago I cruised down this same trail unmolested. Today I was grabbed by hundreds of leafy green arms, clinging to my shirt and bare legs, tensioning and snapping away as I rode downhill. I came to a wall of trail-blocking Oregon greenery and made a quick stop. I had to use an arm to push through a mess of downed tree limbs and sticky blackberry bushes.  The trail became clearer as it rolled under the old-growth section, fast and fun, packed hard, but still a little damp so traction was excellent. We screamed down, making the most of bumps to gain airtime. It was over too quick and we began the ascent up the south contour leg of the Orchard Loop.  A quick five-minute climb and Ned passed me as we began lap number two. I planned out my strategy for the trail-blocking bush and made the best of it, bobbing and weaving under and around the reaching vegetation. It went smoothly and I quickly made up time on Ned on the descent. I passed him as he went wide at the entrance to the climb. We huffed uphill, both in our big rings. I was about to shift down as Ned faded behind when I saw a woman runner up ahead. My ego kicked in and I stayed on my feet, passing her carefully ('On your left'), and winding around the hillside and out of sight where I could finally downshift to a more reasonable, less quad-burning position.  I peaked and strategized for my final pass at the main trail obstacle. I imagine cyclo-crossers use the time they spend climbing, or spinning flat sections, to think about how to set themselves up for the obstacle crossings. I had a plan. As I closed in on the spot, I kicked out my right heel, releasing my shoe. I steered to the right edge of the trail and put my foot down just at the rim. With my right hand on the handlebars, I reached out with my left to lift the bushes. This was the crucial moment of my plan. There was a brief pause where it looked like it might all work. This was followed by a longer moment where I knew it was not going to work and that all of the flailing I was doing was not going to stop me from falling downhill into the blackberries. Which I did.  Ned eased past laughing.  I self-extricated. It took me a couple of minutes. I hear it's illegal to self-extricate in 39 states and three others if a minor is present. We took Springwater back to town, splitting up in Sellwood. The cool breeze from the West felt nice on all the stinging spots on my arms and legs. Hopefully the shower will help too.  Next Friday it's the Giro Delle Colline ad Ovest, which I think means tour of the west hills. Mountain bikes again. Email if you're free. I don't think I'm going to invite Ned.   
I wanted a break from my usual in-town rides in Forest Park, and I was looking for a route that would offer lots of climbing. My plan was to ride out to Powell Butte and then try and connect to Rocky Butte using the bike paths and streets on the east side of Portland.  There was a strong headwind all the way out the Springwater Trail Corridor, or, as it may be more aptly described, the Hobo Highway. I was only hit up for money once on the ride out. What can I say? It was a beautiful sunny day and I made eye contact with everybody I passed. I guess someone was bound to put the touch on me.  Powell Butte was relatively dog free-chased by two, barked at by four today, rightly or wrongly, all of the dogs had owners in sight-and I climbed up the Orchard Loop Trail, taking the east end of the loop to the 640-foot summit. The view of the city was nice from the old apple orchard on top. After a moment on the park bench and a couple of oh-zees (Ed. Note: I use phrases such as 'oh-zees' and 'long-travel equipped' because I know that when Sarah reads it she'll roll her eyes, feign disgust, and say, 'You're such a dude.' It's a nice counterpoint to my teenagers who often observe, 'Dad, you're such a dork') of fluid I was off for the most fun part of the day's trip, single track!  I clipped in and started down the trail, picking up the west end of the Orchard Loop. I pressed the electronic lockout button near my left grip and felt the damper release in the Cannondale Lefty; I was now in full suspension. Slipping down the hill, I picked up speed, the suspension system smoothing out the terrain, keeping the wheels in contact with the ground as I rolled over rocks, roots, and ruts. On the climb up I had seen that trail crews had recently been busy up here. As I descended I could see more evidence of work party contributions to trail maintenance and hillside preservation.  The trail was in beautiful condition, aided by a couple of dry days. I rode quickly over the grass-lined ruts of the meadows on top, down the contour-hugging ravine section and onto the flat, wide needle padded path through the park's old firs. I used the disc brakes as little as possible, trying to maximize my airtime on the descent. The slaloming downhill run was over too fast. I picked up Ellis Street after a five-minute descent, dampened my front fork, and was off for Rocky Butte. I connected with Powell Boulevard and turned west toward I-205. The section of Portland's 40-Mile Loop bike path that I traveled alongside I-205 was quick and easy traveling. Once I made Burnside I used the nineties-94th, 92nd, 89th (not technically a ninety, but a really close associate)-to work my way up to the Great Wall of I-84. The nearest freeway crossing was 82nd which gave me the adrenalin rush that only a live action version of slot cars can offer. It was me versus dozens of harried, pissed-off mid-day drivers. I hung in there for a half-dozen blocks before bailing out on Tillamook and heading back up to the nineties on the other side of the freeway. I picked up 92nd and rode north to Rocky Butte Rd. where the climb to the top of this Northeast Portland landmark starts.   It's a quick pedal to the top and I like the way the road winds through the tunnel and then back up over the top of itself. The ride uphill was warm, with the east wind blocked and the sun shining on my back. I decided to take off my windbreaker. Without stopping. Not a good idea.  I can ride uphill with no hands. I can ride uphill on my mountain bike with no hands. I can also wave an arm around and ride uphill. What I can't do is ride uphill with no hands while waving both arms around, which is why my windbreaker now has a custom ventilation job in the left armpit.     I got a foot down and managed to dismount before crashing; however, I jerked my left arm while trying to catch my balance, at the same time the left sleeve was half off, resulting in a seam-parting that went out two-inches in each direction from armpit central. I like the new feature. However, I think I'll find a less exciting way to add ventilation to the right armpit. As I rounded the last bend and the top of the hill came into view I could see a guy waving his own arms around and jumping up and down on top of the stonewalls that crown the hill. He didn't have a windbreaker. As I got closer I could see the jumper-waver guy had a telescope set up and was spotting planes at the airport. He'd see a plane and get all excited in a manic, talking-to-himself, stalking around sort of way. I would have been nervous, but it was the middle of the day, there were lots of people around, and I've seen just this sort of obsessive-compulsive passion before.  When I traveled across the UK by train I was seated next to a couple of Welsh train-spotters. They would start to talk about the trains they had seen here and there when they traveled the country and they'd get all excited and start waving their arms around in short, controlled, staccato bursts, like an infant trying to get your attention from the car seat.  I was really disoriented by the train spotters, mostly because I had no idea that this sort of thing was an actual hobby. They were speaking in a mish-mash of Welsh and English, which didn't help my understanding at all. I'd catch about every tenth word or so, and initially I thought they might be escaped lunatics.  Further complicating things was that, while I was certain they were speaking complete gibberish, they seemed to understand and respond to each other's blatherings in a completely average way, as though two guys were speaking perfect English and discussing the weekend's football result. I could only watch sidelong and fascinated, certain they were occupying the same insane universe.  When I got to Dublin and related the whole surreal experience to my mates there, they laughed their butts off at me and then explained the concept of a hobby that requires you to spend your holidays traveling around the countryside, keeping a log of every train you see.  Thrilling. After a few more completely unselfconscious rantings, Mr. Plane-Spotter seemed to calm down. I put my newly modified windbreaker back on and tucked the downhill run back to 92nd. The winding trip through the tunnel was quick and fun. I used eastbound streets to reach 60th where I cut over to Stark. There, looming under a dark blue grove of Doug fir was Mt Tabor. As soon as I saw it I knew I had to go for the trifecta of Portland peaks. I was up and down in about fifteen minutes, with Powell to win, Rocky to place, and Tabor to show. I headed down Stark, across the Hawthorne, and south on the Greenway trail toward my home in John's Landing. After three hours of pedaling I was dreaming about pizza and mustard drenched sausages, the food that a bike ride inspires, when I spotted Papa Joe's Sausage and Hot Dog complex. I imbibed in one of Padre Jose's (yep, dude-worthy, you're getting it now) finest double smoked sausages, accompanied by a handful more condiments than it was designed to hold. I don't know the technical-side of what makes a sausage double smoked, but I know that one of the reasons I ride is so I can eat food like this. I highly recommend it; he's about two hundred feet south of the Spaghetti Factory parking lot. Tell him Greg-the guy on the bike-sent you.
The lawn at our house is very small and easy to mow. I have been using it as a cover, taking ten minutes to mow it and another ten to rake. Twenty minutes of manual labor, the house looks transformed and I've got my warm up underway for the day's biking action. I confessed to my use of the lawn as a quick easy chore to cover for my recreational intentions in an article I wrote for Oregon Cycling, and she's been on to me ever since. Now I have to find another way to appear responsible while trying to maximize my fun time. It seems to me that although the truth may set you free in some metaphysical sense it will not set you free to do more cycling.  Fortunately, Sarah was heading out of town to attend graduation ceremonies for a niece and nephew. The coast came clear around ten-thirty. So I set aside the list of domestic chores she had created for me in our compromise (in this case, compromise means I get caught and end up with more things to do) and headed out the door with the road bike. My goal today was Crown Point. I rode downtown and dropped off a rim that needed some professional attention. Then it was over to the MAX stop and aboard for Gresham. MAX can be fun and entertaining and some times it can be just annoying. I managed to catch a train quickly, which seems to be the case during the day. They run frequently and it is predictable that they will only be full during the daily commute and after ball games.  What's not predictable is who your traveling companions will be. Today I rode with two dogs. Not really dogs, like ruff-ruff, but two high school kids, bragging about the fact that they were skipping school and beginning each thing they said with, 'Yo, dog.' That was the annoying part today.  The entertainment came when a sixtyish-looking man got on the train while one of the dogs was hanging off the overhead handrail. He looked at the kid, pointed at the sagging pants and said, 'You're gonna lose those.' To which the dog responded, 'Whuh?' This is how kids respond when they want you to say something over again. Everything sounds stupid when said twice and the time it takes to repeat gives the dog a chance to think up a witty reply. My years of teaching high-schoolers taught me to respond to 'Whuh?' with an add-on statement, pressing the advantage. Unfortunately, the older gentleman walked into the trap, thinking the kid hadn't heard him. Given time to gather his thoughts, the dog riposted, 'Wha choo lookin' fo'?' To his credit, the old guy gave up and chose a seat facing away. Two stops later the dogs got into a discussion about when the Rose Festival was over. Dog A turned in my direction and said, 'Yo, dog. When's the Rose Festival over?'  It took me a moment to realize I was the dog on the spot. I thought about turning and replying, 'Whuh?' Or I could just answer, but then, would I be part of the pack? Too much time passed as I weighed my options and studiously examined the little rubber nodules that stick off the side of my bike tire.  Then, in a polite suburban youth's voice, I heard, 'Excuse me sir. Do you know how long the Rose Festival runs?'  I had to turn and answer that one. I looked at the Gresham-bound youths, dressed in Bronx-bound threads, and I told them, 'I believe it runs through Sunday.'  Maybe I'm not so smart about kids. Maybe it's comforting to belong to a group, to have the security of a pack, when the world seems like a scary jungle.  Whatever judgments I had about the way they dressed, spoke, acted out, I had to put them aside and admit they treated me with the same respect I showed them by allowing them the space to do their thing. I may have been judging them, I may have been annoyed, but keeping my composure and keeping my mouth shut can sometimes be the best thing for me to do, to add to the peace in the world. I rode the train out to the 181st station where I disembarked, saddled up and started pedaling east on Stark Street. It's a quick ride out of town from there, with a nice wide bike lane. I rolled down the hill and across the Stark St. Bridge over the Sandy River, where I picked up the HCRH and turned right. The climb starts immediately, up a gentle hill to Springdale and then more of the same, on to Corbett. The shoulders are a bit narrow in places, but traffic is light and the road winds up hill through the trees. The cars that pass don't seem to be traveling too fast. There is a lot of gravel left over from winter and quite a bit of broken glass. The street could use a good sweep, but I was able to dodge the hazards in relative safety.  I stopped in Corbett at the General Store to fill my water bottles. In making my joyful escape from domesticity, I'd left with both bottles dry. The woman in the store said the state health inspector won't let her give out the water from the sink behind her counter. She showed me where her hose was outside and I used that instead.  I appreciated the help, but the only thing worse than water that has been in a plastic bottle too long, is water from a plastic bottle that has been in a hose too long. I thought I let it run enough to clear out the hose, but maybe that isn't possible. I got a couple of swallows in my mouth and carried on up the highway.  Between Corbett and Crown Point I broke out of the forest and caught my first sight of the river. The view from the Women's Forum scenic overlook is incredible, green on both sides of the gorge and the islands in between all filled in with the mighty Columbia rolling along to the sea.  The Larch Mountain cutoff is just after the Women's Forum pullout. Signs were out up and down the highway announcing a race June 16th. The woman in the store asked me if I was a racer and mentioned that the race was happening on Father's Day if the snow melts on top of the mountain. A mileage sign reads: Larch Mountain 14. There's an orange warning sign that reads: Gate Closed Ahead 10 Miles. From the Larch Mountain intersection it's a quick downhill run to the Crown Point Vista House. Today there is a mobile trailer serving as the information center and a chain link fence surrounds the Vista House. There is a crew working on the refurbishing of the building. It looks like it will be spectacular when they are finished. I would have liked to hang around ask questions about the work, but as I sat on the old wall overlooking the river and ate my yogurt bars, I saw rain headed my way.  I washed down the last of the food with some plastic flavored water and started the pedal back to town.  It was a quick climb to the Women's Forum and then back the six miles to the Stark Street Bridge. I averaged around twenty-eight mph-topping out at thirty-five-for this portion of the return and was greeted by a blue patch of sky as I came out of the trees and crossed the river. The climb up from the river is steep and I was nice and warm by the time I gained the plateau near Zim's. With about three miles to go to the train station, I began to feel the first drops of rain from the advancing front.  I shifted up to the big ring, pushing hard into the wind and light spring rain coming into the right side of my face at an angle. A couple of gusts pushed me to the left edge of the bike lane. I managed to run at about twenty mph down to 181st, where I turned right and arrived at the MAX station as the inbound train was also arriving. I think the driver might have held the door for me as I stuffed the change and ticket into my hip pack and quickly boarded the nearest car. The ride into town was quick and quiet, the train steadily filling up with people (no dogs near me this trip), most of who appeared to be teenagers on their way down to the Rose Festival Fun Center. I got off at the Rose Garden stop and rode down to the Eastbank Esplanade, where I picked up the path and crossed on the Steel Bridge. The west side of the river was lined with Navy ships and the Esplanade was fenced off for security.  I rode up to Fourth Street and stopped at Seattle's Best for a mocha to warm me up. The little chocolate stick that goes along with it gave me the kick I needed to finish the last three miles down the Greenway and home. The lawn looked nice. If I didn't know better, I'd think the guy who lives in this house is a responsible citizen.   
We met a couple a few years back that had ridden a tandem from Alaska to Southern California, and then across the country to Florida.  It seemed like maybe the tandem was the way to go.  So in November of 2000 we bought a tandem and started riding it without any definitive date for this big trip. Last summer we did what we thought was a lot of riding and rode in the STP a two day ride from Seattle to Portland.  That was fun, but Mary was having problems with her knees.  It was looking like the tandem trip across the country wasn't going to happen. Luckily, Mary started seeing Julie Johnson, a physical therapist, who specialized in bicylcing.  After spending most of last fall working through knee strengthening exercises, and figuring out the correct riding position, it looked like the trip was back on for summer 2002. We started training the first of the year, with the goal of increasing weekly mileage 10% a week until the first of June.  We started with a little less than 40 miles a week and have been steadily increasing it. Most of January, February and March we've spent riding in the dark after work, and getting two longer rides in every weekend.  We're both looking forward to daylight savings time when we'll be able to get most after work rides done in the daylight. In addition to the riding we've been making sure everything at home is taken care of while we're gone.  We have the mother of a guy I work with coming out to house sit, and more importantly cat sit.  She was in town in mid-March and Mr. C and Sparky seemed to think she was okay. We still have to figure out our options for getting the tandem to the East Coast.  It is a large item to ship so we'll probably have to send it well in advance of us.
Our training has also been a great learning experience.  All along we've been thinking that we would carry all of our gear in painiers.  The B.O.B. seemed like an option, but a ten foot long bike didn't sound too great for 4000 miles.  Our first over night trip in early April put an end to the painier route.  We did a nice 120 mile weekend, spending the night at a state park.  The fully loaded painiers caused a lot of frame flex and I couldn't really see riding the bike all the way across the country like that.    We came back from that trip and immediately bought a B.O.B.  A very good decision.  Riding with our gear in the trailer makes the bike seem unloaded, and the length doesn't seem to be an issue. It's hard to make sharp turns with a tandem anyway, so the extra length doesn't alter the way we ride. The additional bonus of having the B.O.B. is we'll be able to go mountain bike camping when we get back from this trip.
We've been doing most of our rides with the B.O.B. trailer on the back of the bike.  It was a good purchase.  The bike doesn't even feel loaded when its on there and its a lot easier to access our stuff.    We also aquired a full compliment of Polar water bottles.  It seems a little silly to worry about insulated water bottles when you've been riding in 40 degree temperatures, but I think they will come in handy for this summer. It looks like we've got most of our arrangements done for shipping the bike back east, and having all of our bills paid.  Sometimes it seems like the training is the easiest part of the whole trip.  It's getting all the other things in order that take all of our time.
We've also discovered that our bike needed a few fixes before starting out on this trip.  Buying a used tandem was a great decision, but some things have started to wear out.  We have no idea how many miles are on this bike, but we've put close to 4000 on it. Both our rim sidewalls are getting pretty thin, so.... We decided to bite the bullet and have some hand built wheels made for us.  Nothing like spending half the cost of the bike for a wheelset, but hopefully it will eliminate any potential issues we could have in the middle of the country.  The guys at Seattle Bike Repair have been really great, and are making time in their busy spring schedule to get these done for us ASAP. In addition to fixing the bike up, we've got a name for our bike, "Klickitat Touche".  Don't ask. We've also got a top five list of places to ride from Freemont (not).  We're beginning to feel like experts on where to ride and not ride in the Seattle area: 5. Anywhere in Bellevue -- they don't believe in shoulders or bike lanes. 4. Burke Gilman trail on a sunny day -- more like dodgeball than riding a bike. 3. Pioneer Street in Gig Harbor -- approximately 28.2% grade. 2. Sammamish River Trail during a walkathon. 1. The one mile section of the Burke Gilman trail South of Logboom Park (towards the UW).  The most consistently bumpy piece of trail known to mankind.  This is best at night. We've also found some great places to ride.  Vashon Island is amazing.  No traffic, and the ferry ride is a perfect time to take a short break.  Magnolia has a great bike lane and was perfect for shorter mileage days.  Kopachuck State Park is also great for overnighters.  The biggest surprise is how nice the riding in Renton has been. Only two weeks until we ship the machine.  Yeah!
The bike was shipped June 4th and it's been strange without it around.  The freight company thought it would take nine days to get to Lynchburg, VA but they couldn't guarantee that so we shipped it very early.  Hopefully the rest time before the trip won't kill us.  We'll have to do a lot of mountain biking. The guys at Seattle Bike Repair took care of the packaging and shipping.  Hopefully the people at Bikes Unlimited in Lnychburg will take as good of care of the bike for the few days prior to us picking it up.    We now have a lot more time to get the last minute things done before heading off.  I've been to AAA to collect state maps and trace our root.  It helped to get a broader perspective than you get from the Adventure Cycling maps.  We're not sure we'll actually pack the AAA maps, but it was fun to trace our route out. Just a little more than a week of work.  Then we get to spend a nice week with Mary's parents, and away we go.
  Finally we're off.  It seems like we've been talking about this day forever and its finally here. We left Lynchburg close to 10am.  We were orginally going to start from Yorktown, but due to circumstances out of our control we had to make some last minute adjustments, hence, we're making our own route up as we go. We took the blackwater creek trail out of Lynchburg.  We had to do a little pushing the bike up a dirt road.  We also had to carry the bike and all of our gear over a gate.  Of course as soon as we got all the gear back on the bike a guy showed up who could open the gate.    Next we hopped on route 622.  It was good choice; little traffic, some hills and great scenery.  Stopped at a little mini-mart about 15 miles into the ride.  Had a nice guy ask where we were going.  I said 'Seattle, eventually.'  He just asked 'How come?'  Couldn't really give a good answer.    At route 60 we headed east for about two miles, then caught route 605 to the park.  The last couple miles were surprisingly uphill.  We thought since the park was on the bank of a river it might be downhill for the last bit.  No such luck. It isn't too hot and everyone we've met has been very friendly.  The park ranger invited us into his booth to cool off to discuss our camping options. We had a nice campsite next to the James River.  For some reason, the only other people camping in the park pulled into the site next to us.  They had a nice loud generator and two bassett hounds that liked to bark.  At least they took the dogs in for the night. The only downside to the camping area.  No showers.  We've got a nice funk going on.  Hopefully there will be showers tomorrow. Quote of the day - "That's a cool bike, Mom!" - little girl riding with her Mom on the trail. 
We had learned from the park ranger that our only choice for getting back on the road we needed was to backtrack about 12 miles.  Bummer.  Never trust mapquest. 20 fun miles later we were 1/2 mile from where we had camped, just across the river. We cruised along going through the 'towns' of Norwood and Wingina.  Both of these places were just post offices, not really towns at all.  At least the post office in Wingina had some water we used to fill our water bottles. We ate a little snack on a bridge at about 30 miles.  About halfway through eating we started hearing some noises in the water under the bridge.  Lots of splashing.  We didn't stick around to see what it was.  Could of been a cow or something.  It was making a lot of noise.    We stopped at the market in Howardsville to each drink a pop and enjoy the A/C.  It was starting to feel hot outside.  We talked for a while with a guy who was wearing a ton of UVa periphenalia.  Turns out he went to Virginia (big surprise). We then went another 15 miles to Scottsville.  Nice campsite next to the James River again.  The proprieter said it was 103 in the sun.  Mary heard it was 92 in the shade.  No wonder it felt hot.  Luckily the campground had showers.  The funk was getting pretty bad. Scottsville was a nice little town.  I had been here a few times in college to go tubing down the James.  We had some big old burgers at a shake and burger place.  The library was nice and cool, so we hung around for a while. Back at the campsite we met the wife of the proprieter.  She was friendly, and gave us some watermellon to enjoy.  The campsite was quiet and we had a good night of sleep. Quote of the day - "I didn't think six of you could ride on that bike." - owner of the campsite when she saw six people hanging around our tent.  Four of them were local kids that had snuck into the camping area to dip into the James. 
We headed out close to 8:30 for a short day just up the road to Charlottesville.  Route 20 wasn't great for riding, but it was okay.  We had been spoiled by the zero traffic roads we had ridden on for the past two days.  There was a nice shoulder, but the traffic was moving fast. We got off route 20 for the last 15 miles into town.  We ran into another guy who was out doing a quick ride.  He mentioned always wanting to go on a long tour but not finding the time.  He rode with us for about two miles and then we went our separate ways. In town, we were planning on staying at the Best Western Cavalier Inn.  We walked into the reception area and the guy behind the desk was just strange.  After looking us up and down, then checking his computer, he announced they were completely full for the night.  He said it in a way that we weren't sure if he was joking or what.  It was strange.  He stuck with his story and directed us to a Budget Inn just down the road. The more we thought about it the stranger is seemed.  We have a hard time believing the hotel was full on a Tuesday in the middle of the summer.  His loss.  Maybe we smelled worse than we knew. The Budget Inn receptionist was friendly.  She let us check in early and gave us an easy access room because of the bike.  It was a 180 from the guy at the Best Western. We ate at Littlejohn's.  Neither of us have ever eaten subs anywhere else that taste as good.  Now we're sitting in Stacks at Thornton Hall on the computer.  I'm hoping to convince Mary to pull an all-nighter just for the memories. Quote of the day - "Mary, look at that!" - Rob pointing out a guy mowing his lawn with nothing on but a hot pink banana hammock.  Too bad we didn't get a picture. 
We set the alarm for 5 am to get as many miles in as we could before it got hot.  We were off a little before 6 and the temperature was pleasant.     The riding was nice.  We stopped at a general store in Rockfish Gap.  The store wasn't open yet, but the woman inside gave us some orange and apple juice for free anyway. A couple of other riders came by, Anthony and Sean.  They had started somewhere in Pennsylvania and were going to San Francisco.  We talked for a bit, and said we would see them at the Cookie Lady's house. The first 30 miles took us to Afton, home of the Cookie Lady, June Curry.  She is famous for her hospitality to bike tourers.  We filled our bottles, each had a sandwich and listened to her stories for an hour.  She has met some amazing people, and has postcards from all over the world.  She took our picture and we got addded to the history.    After two long breaks in a short period of time we were ready to go.  We continued up and onto the Blue Ridge Parkway.  For some reason we thought the big climb was over - WRONG. The next 28 miles was a ton of elevation change.  Climb in the lowest gear for 2+ miles, then scream down for another mile.  There was a lot more up than down and it was tiring. We even had to add some miles after stopping to get water near Humpback Rock we started to climb.  After a mile of climbing I wanted to take a picture.  Opening our little front bag I noticed the guide book was missing.  Doh! We turned around and flew down the hill to claim our book.  It was sitting on a bench.  We grabbed it and were off for some more climbing. We got off the parkway and pulled into the Tye River Campground.  We haven't seen anyone else here including the owner.  We did some swimming and laundry. Clean clothes are nice! Quote of the day - "Oops.  We left the guidebook at the last stop " - Rob when he discovered the book was missing. 
Two miles down the road we stopped and ate breakfast at Gertie's.  It was a small general store in Vesuvius.  The owner, Gertie, made excellent eggs and homefries.  It hit the spot.    We moved along after breakfast and pulled into Lexington a little after noon.  A woman at the visitor center showed us some options for hotels. The Hampton Inn was closest to town so we decided to give that a shot.  The groundskeeper let us keep our bike in a storage area.  It was better option than trying to get it into our room. There was a pretty bug thunderstorm in the afternoon so we waited it out in our hotel room, and watched "Saving Silverman".  (Quality cinema Jim and Shanti!)  It was a better way to spend the storm than being on the road somewhere. After the storm we walked around Lexington.  We did a lap around the VMI parade grounds and walked around Washington & Lee. We ate dinner at Pizza Hut and bought some more food for the next couple of days.  Then we called it a night. Quote of the day - "You're 32?" - Pizza Hut manager as he checked out our ID's.  I guess he can't subtract too well, we're 31. 
We took advantage of the continental breakfast at the hotel and both agreed it was nice to eat some cereal.  The doughnuts (Rob) were excellent as well. We packed everything up and headed out in the rain. The hard rain lasted only about 10 minutes.  After that it just sprinkled off and on.    The riding was easy with some rolling hills.  The scenery was great.  We continue to see a ton of deer and today we saw about 10 turkeys hanging out in one field. We are making today another short day because we want to be in Blacksburg on Monday to pick up a car to get to Dan and Aynot's wedding.  With that in mid, we decided to visit Natural Bridge. The girl behind the ticket counter agreed to watch our stuff while we saw the bridge.  With the exception of the hotel in Charlottesville, everyone has been very helpful and friendly.   While waiting in line, we heard the following conversation by a local couple: Woman - "Did you find them?" Man - "No" Woman - "Did you look inside and outside?" Man - "Yep" Woman - "Well I can't believe we lost the kids" Note - all of this was said in very calm tones as if it happened regularly.  They decided to split up and look some more.  We were happy to see the family together later happily walking the trails with a dog and everything. After stashing our stuff, we saw the Natural Bridge.  It was more impressive than either of us expected.  After looking around for an hour or so, we collected our stuff (had a quick lunch of peanut butter and jelly sandwiches) and headed to the campground.    We camped at the KOA. Quote of the day - "How do your ride with this bag on your bike?" - girl at the ticket counter as we brought our huge red bag in for her to watch.  She didn't know we had a trailer.   Mary's favorite quote (little girl at the campground) - "Do you know you (Rob) look just like Tony Hawk.  My mommy said I shouldn't come over and bother you but I just had to tell you." 
We took our time breaking down camp and headed out close to 8.  After a super-nutritious breakfast of Krispy Kreme's we were tanked up and ready to go. The ride to Buchanan was easy, and we pulled in a little after nine.  We found the library and checked email and updated the journal for an hour or so. Back on the road we ticked off another 10 miles.  We were passed by a group of four cyclists who were out for a little ride.  They chatted with us for a little while, but they were moving too fast for us to ride with them.  The riding continued to be great: no traffic, rolling hills, plenty of shade. For lunch we stopped at a little mini-mart and got some snack food.  We both had peanut butter sandwiches for a main course. The last five miles of the day seemed hot.  It was mostly uphill and the trees providing shade seemed to of disappeared.  We set up camp at the Troutville Park.  Amazingly, they let you camp there for free. We were set up for the night a little after noon, so we got to watch the people at the park all day.  It was kind of interesting.  After a while we both felt strange about hanging out in this little town's park for the entire day. I (Rob) once read a weblog where a guy spent an entire day in a Home Depot on a bet.  I felt kind of like that after hanging around in the park waiting for it to get dark for nine hours.  (Read the Home Depot weblog).    We did have a nice dinner of eggs and potatoes.  There was a little market right next to the park that had everything we could need. Quote of the day - "You two at the park?" - woman at the cash register in the market.  Mary and I were baffled that she could tell we were camping in the park. 
We headed out of Troutville a little before 6:30.  It was sad leaving the park after spending so much time there.  The air was cool, and the riding continued to be great. At about 10 miles we stopped at a gas station and had breakfast, then continued on our way.      15 miles into the ride we crossed a bridge that had about 10 huge vultures hanging out on one of the railings.  They flew off when we came along.  They are very big birds.  We were both glad they had flown away. At about 20 miles we had our first bear sighting.  We were just starting to crank up a pretty steep hill when we saw this thing come out on the road about 200 yards in front of us.  At first I (Rob) thought it was a cow or a really big dog, but quickly realized it was a black bear.  It seemed more scared of us than we were of it and it quickly hi-tailed it back into the woods next to the road. We moved fast through that section (even going uphill), and made lots of noise so it didn't come back out. We saw a lot more people out on bicycles today.  The first two guys we ran into were doing a long ride from Roanoke.  We stopped and talked to them for a little bit.  The one guy had ridden his bike across the country three times.  He said he had averaged about 150 miles a day.  I guess when you're doing that kind of mileage doing this trip multiple times might be an option.    We then saw a lot of just recreational bikers out.  They were all going the other way. The last part of the ride was up over a ridge into Blacksburg.  It was  a pretty steep climb for about 2 1/2 miles and then a nice screaming downhill for a mile. We toured around Blacksburg looking for a hotel, and ended up staying in the Alumni Hall hotel.  Now were cruising around the Virginia Tech campus and found the library. This will probably be the last update until after the fourth.  We're off to Lynchburg and then Washington D.C (by car) for my brother's wedding.  We'll be back July 5th or so. 
After saying goodbyes to everyone we headed to Blacksburg close to 10:30.  Driving down 81 it was interesting to go flying past the roads we were riding last week. We picked the bike up from East Coasters at 3 and dropped the car off a short time later.  The people at East Coasters were very generous, and we were very thankful they watched the bike for us while we were gone. The ten minutes we spent getting all of our gear on the bike was crazy hot, but once we were on our way it didn't seem so bad. The ride out of Blacksburg was great.  A short climb followed by 2 1/2 miles of screaming descent.  At the bottom of the hill there was a guy sitting on his porch smoking.  He had been in the exact same spot five days earlier.  He must do nothing but smoke and hang out on his porch all day. We had our first dog incident at about 15 miles.  This vicious killer chihuahua came at us out of nowhere.  Mary impressed the hell out of me with her amazing pepper spray reaction time.  Before I even knew what was going on she was spraying like crazy.  Now she needs to work on her aim. The rest of the ride was uneventful.  We camped at Interstate Park which was surprisingly right next to interstate 81. There was a group of 12 & 13 year old girls in the campground who are riding the state of Virginia. Its going to take them 12 days and then they are rafting for two days.  We'll probably run into them again. The only bad thing is the mosquitoes found our campsite for the first time on the trip. Quote of the day - "Work schmerk.  Do you realize you're living the dream of every bike shop employee in the world." - woman (Amy) at East Coasters when we told her we had to be back in Seattle by mid-September to go to work. 
We were on the road a little after 6 and say an outdoor thermometer that said 63.  Very nice.  Christiansburg was still asleep as we left town and traffic was almost non-existant. At 20 miles we stopped in at a mini-mart for a quick snack.  I (Rob) even had an apple.  It was very dull yellow, almost beige, so I didn't venture too far from my all-beige diet. The owner and his wife were super-friendly.  We sat on a little bench in front of the store talking to them for a while.  The owner gave Dan his condolences on getting married.  His wife responded saying they had been married 45 years so it couldn't be too bad. From the market we went through the town of Draper, where there was supposed to be a must stop market.  Somehow we missed it.  Too bad, it was rumored to have excellent food and be inexpensive. We pulled into the Wytheville KOA at noon and grabbed one of the last spots.  The campground was insane.  It cost $32 for a tent site.  It also had a pool with a huge slide, a large screen TV room showing "Air Bud" continuously, miniature golf, karaoke, horseback riding, batting cages, a basketball tournement, video game room, and we were treated to fireworks.  All we really wanted was a shower. The karaoke was outside, at outdoor concert volume levels.  Literally everyone in the campground was subjected to really bad singing for three hours.  In addition to the poor singing quality, being in southwest Virginia made most of the selections country music.  The best selection of the night was Peter Gunn. Why a karaoke setup would even have that song is a mystery. The jury is still out on whether the shower offset the karaoke. Quote of the day - "Y'all ain't movin' too fast" - man on the side of the road setting up a huge circus like tent.  We were crawling up a fairly steep hill as we passed.  We have no idea why he was setting up the tent in his yard.    
We also had our first equipment breakage.  I (Rob) accidentally rolled up the tent with Mary's sunglasses inside.  Crunch!  The bridge was snapped in half.  Somehow Mary rigged them so they worked for the ride today. We rode close to six miles and decided to stop at a mini-mart for a quick breakfast.  It took close to 20 minutes to get through the line.  One woman wrote a bad check and they let her pay with it anyway.  The next woman wanted some marlboro lights.  It took 10 minutes to figure out they didn't have any.  We finally paid and got out of there. The next few miles was strip mall hell.  Kind of like riding on Aurora in Seattle.  We were both glad it was early and the traffic was light. The rest of the ride was awesome.  We entered the Mount Rogers recreation area and it was beautiful.  We had two long climbs but the grades were so easy we just cruised along.    At one point we stopped to take off our long sleeve shirts and a whole herd of cattle came running to the fence beside us.  They must of thought we were delivering food.  It was funny to see them running. The ride ended with 10 of the last 12 miles being downhill.  We ended the day with an average speed of 13.2 mph.  Almost one mph faster than any other day. We ended the day in Damascus.  The Appalachian trail goes right throught town so there are a lot of services geared towards hikers.  We stopped at a bike shop to see if they had any sunglasses, but they didn't have any Mary liked.    Next stop was a cyber cafe. We checked email and updated the journal. We spent the night at "The Place", a hostel for AT hikers and bike tourers.  There were about 10 other people there.  We spent a lot of time talking to a guy named Jake.  He was spending six weeks trying to hike through Virginia.  He was nice and gave us some duct tape to fix Mary's sunglasses. We ended up going out to eat pizza with Jake.  The pizza was good and Jake had some funny stories. The best was about a guy that hiked the trail with a five gallon paint bucket to hold all of his stuff.  It turns out he was a vagrant from somewhere in Georgia.  The sheriff had driven him to the trailhead and told him not to come back.  Probably an urban legend, but still pretty funny. Quote of the day - "That's a bicycle built for two!" - everyone in Virginia.  It seems like the word "tandem" doesn't exist here. 
It was pretty cool although not as cool as the past couple of mornings.  The first 20 miles past quickly. We hit the first of four big climbs today at about 25 miles.  It was four miles long, and we gained about 1500 ft.  It was still cool so it didn't seem too bad. We passed our first option for spending the night a little after 10 am and neither of us was tired so we moved on. In Rosedale we stopped at a little gas station (okay, a mini-mart) that also served breakfast.  We ate some egg biscuts and talked to another patron for a while. He was a little hard to understand but was nice enough.  He was into ham radio and was talking about how he had recently participated in a ham radio-a-thon to raise money for something.  He had talked to someone from Seattle during this thing and was excited about that.  He was so hard to understand in person we couldn't imagine talking to him on the radio. After Rosedale it was a pretty miserable four miles to Honaker (pronounced HO-nake-er).  Traffic was heavy and there wasn't much of a shoulder. After that things got better and before we knew it we were on our second climb.  It was a little over two miles and again it wasn't too bad. From the climb we moved on to Council, our second option for spending the night.  We still were feeling pretty good so we decided to keep moving. About ten miles down the road we stopped at a little diner for lunch in Birchleaf.  There were four other people in the diner and they were all curious about our trip.  It was fun to sit and talk for about an hour. The last 15 miles were hard.  We passed one thermometer and it said 90.  The second to last hill was only a mile, but it seemed a lot longer.  The heat and the traffic made it less than fun.  We made it over the top and pushed on. The last hill was coming into the park.  It was a killer.  We finally limped into the park at 3:30.    The campsite was nice but frankly we were too tired to enjoy it.  We got the tent setup, crawled inside just in time to miss a quick rain shower and fell asleep.  We woke up about an hour later, ate dinner, then went back to bed. As a side note Rob's diet for the day:  Note - Mary's diet wasn't much better.  Substitute two bananas, a peach, a plum, cheese and crackers, and chocolate grahams for the burger and onion rings. Quote of the day - "See that one of the frogs sitting under the umbrella, everyone has that one." - Mary commenting on all the lawn ornaments people have in their yards.  Our current favorite is the one where there is a little boy with his pants around his ankles with his back turned towards you like he is peeing.  Next to him is a little girl looking shocked.  Tasteful.    
   We passed through Elkhorn City and at Ashcamp started riding on a road that was more like an extended driveway.  It was maybe 15 ft. wide and curved all over the place.  It was amazing to see a road even built like that. We did a mini-climb which produced the first full-body-sweat of the day.  Of course the downhill completely dried us off.  We then immediately went into the second full-body-sweat hill.  This one was the longest we have done yet.  Close to five miles of hard climbing.  It took a full hour to get over the hill. At the bottom of the hill we say and ate a pound of cheese and a rack of salteens.  Yummy. About ten miles down the road we hit another big hill.  The most disappointing thing about these hills is they don't have any kind of name.  You can't brag about riding over something like "Big Ass Hill".  Then all the locals would bow at your feet. At the top of the hill we passed into a new county.  The county we came from must of been dry because there were Bud Light signs all over everything for the next 15 miles.  Then we crossed into another county which must of been dry because the beer sign stopped again. We saw a lot of coal trucks today.  All of them were going the other way.  Hopefully that will continue. We ended the day at a hostel in Pippa Passes.  It's a small town that is home to Alice Loyd College.  The hostel owner showed us where we could do laundry for F-R-E-E.  Such a bonus.  We were also able to get online but the computers were glacial speed so all we could do is check a little email before the library closed. The accomodations are okay. For those reading that went to the Mt. St. Helens cabin with us a few years ago you'll appreciate how musty this place was.  On a scale of 1-10 for musty, with 10 being very musty, this place is a 9 with Mt. St. Helens now placing a distant 3. There are three cats here that we had fun playing with.  One even brought Mary a dead mouse as a gift.  She wasn't very grateful.    Quote of the day - "There's a free washer and drying just down the hill." - Charlotte (owner of the hostel).  After three days of full-body sweat hills and humid sleeping this was music to our ears. 
There was a good sized hill coming out of Pippa Passes but after that the next 20 miles were great.  We were cruised along at 18-20 mph the whole way.    We stopped at a gas station outside of Hazzard to refill our water bottles.  We must of had ten people stop to ask about the trip.  The bike seems to attract people.  All of them were nice, and all of them thought we were crazy. The last 35 miles was more hilly terrain.  There were three big climbs and one decent that made my hands hurt from grabbing the brakes so much.  On the last of the climbs I made the comment to Mary that Jim and Shanti would probably think we looked pathetic on this hill.  They had commented about a group of riders they had seen somewhere in Washington going up a hill about a month before we started the trip.  I'm sure we looked just as bad as anything they saw that day. We saw more coal trucks today.  They've been courteous drivers so it hasn't been too bad.  In some of the road cuts you can see the layer of coal between layers of slate.  It is one to two feet thick in most places.  The mountains around here are full of it. We ended the day at Buckhorn Lake Park.  The campsite was nice and the showers were great, although they were set a hot temperature and you couldn't change it. We walked about a mile to get some milkshakes, then stopped in a general store that had everything from tombstones to canned salmon.  The slogan out front was "We have it if Frank can find it".    Quote of the day - "I'm heading up highway 15 if you want to grab on for a while." - Bud delivery man as we were filling out water bottles.  Unfortunately we weren't going that way.    
Again there was a pretty big hill coming out of Buckhorn, but then things leveled out for a while and we had some nice riding for about 30 miles. We had a pack of three dogs chase us at about the 15 mile mark today.  It was actually funny.  We were moving along at a good clip so we didn't think they could catch us.  They were amazing, and followed us for a 1/2 mile at close to 20 mph before finally giving up.  It was impressive.  I guess they've been in training all summer with the other bikers.  I could envision them getting a little further each time they chased someone on a bike.  By the time the bikes going East hit here, they might be able to follow for a mile. Then the hills started.  Today's were the steepest yet.  Mary has been saying for two days now that Kentucky's hills have been worse than Virginia's and I finally have to agree.  They were steep enough that even in the lowest gear we had we were just grinding away, barely able to get the next pedal stroke around.  This lasted for about 10 miles.  By the end of it both of us were sick of hills. At the end of the hills we stopped the bike next to some abandoned building and proceeded to eat most of the rest of the food we had with us.  We had some old guy stop his truck in the middle of the intersection to talk to us.  We couldn't really understand what he was saying but it seemed funny to him.  He was laughing quite a bit. The last 20 miles of the day was a lot more reasonable.  Still some steep hills but nothing like earlier. We pulled into Irvine a little before 1 and checked in at the hotel.  The guy behind the desk was nice enough to offer to do laundry for us in the hotel machine.  We took him up on it.  He also had some funny comments about the meat selection you can get in rural Kentucky.  We had tried to get some canned chicken to go with our noodles the night before and it seems like all they have here is ham, liver and bologna.  He said bologna is actually Kentucky's finest roundsteak.  He also said he liked to drive out into the country to buy some by the foot. I hiked about a mile to the library to get the journals up to date.  Now I'm heading back to the hotel to take a nap. Sure is a tough life. Quote of the day - "B'careful msdpsd asdfq aoujf pmsdf sdfhlke runover!" - man who turned his car off in the middle of an intersection to ask us where we were going and what we were doing.  We were just checking the guidebook description.  Neither of us have any idea what he said but he seemed friendly. 
It was nice to take advantage of having a hotel room so we pulled the shades and didn't get moving until close to 10.  After the last few days we both needed a good nights sleep. We got lucky with the weather again today.  It was overcast and probably in the low 70's even at 11 when we rolled out of Irvine.  The humidity was pretty high, but with the low temperatures, it wasn't too bad. The first 20 miles of the ride was heaven.  Almost no traffic, and nice rolling hills.  There were a few steep ones, but nothing like what we'd been going over for the past few days.    We did have a couple of dogs chase us today, but overall the number of dogs in Kentucky has not lived up to expecations.  Mary still hasn't actually hit any of them with the pepper spray.  Maybe tomorrow. We stopped at a mini-mart (what else?) for lunch.  We had some pizza left over from the day before so we just got some drinks and chips to accompany the pizza.  The people in the market had a log book for bikers.  They saw a lot of them there.  The two guys we had met near Afton had been through here July 3rd, so they had made up 9 days on us.  We missed five due to Dan's wedding, but still those two are hauling.  They must be doing close to 100 miles a day. There were tables out front and two men and a boy were out there eating huge bologna sandwiches (Kentucky roundsteak).  They were really friendly and wanted to know all about our trip.  They were tobacco farmers and had been working the fields that morning and had collected about 15 arrowheads just this morning.  I guess they are common in the fields, and one guy was talking about how he had uncovered about 20 of them a few years back that were in perfect shape.  The little boy was funny and wanted to know how often we ate there.  We all got a laugh out of that. The rest of the ride wasn't nearly as nice.  In fact it was not good at all.  A narrow two lane road leading into Berea for about 10 miles.  Berea is a town of 9,000, the largest we've hit in a while, and the traffic was heavy.  Then when we got here we had to go through some pretty major construction which is always fun on a bike. We're camping at an RV park next to Interstate 75.  The tent area is near the woods at the back of the facility, and the mosquitoes are awful.  We'll probably eat out tonight to avoid having to cook outside.  It was all we could do to get the tent setup before they ate us alive. There is a craft festival going on in town, so being the craft connoisseurs that we are, we'll have to check it out.  We'll probably pick up a good 10-15 pounds of lawn ornaments to bring home with us. There is also Berea College here.  It's an interesting school.  Students don't pay tuition.  Instead they work 10-15 hours a week doing maintenance on the school to pay for their education.  Not a bad way to get a college education.    Quote of the day - "He was going to trade his arrowheads for a bologna sandwich" - Man at the mini-mart talking about how his son wanted to trade the arrowheads he had found that morning for lunch. 
We started walking back to where we were camped and noticed the sky was kind of dark.  It looked like it might shower so we stopped into an all-you-can-eat pizza and pasta place.  Just then the sky opened up.  It rained more than either of us thought was possible. For close to an hour it rained hard enough you could of taken a shower in the downpour.  We were then lulled into a false sense of security by a break in the rain and decided to walk back to the tent.  About half-way back to the tent the sky opened up again.  We got soaked completely. Luckily the campground had some dryers so we were able to get the stuff we were wearing dry.  We crawled into the tent for the night thinking the rain would probably stop sometime during the night. Instead it poured all night.  I honestly didn't know it was possible to rain this much.  The first real rain of the trip, and it was a doosy. 
We decided to wait out the rain in the dry tent.  Two hours later the rain started to taper off so we ventured out and ate breakfast at a local diner.  We were trying to decide what to do for the rest of the day.  It looked like things were going to clear up so we went back to camp to pack up. In the ten minutes it took to pack up the mosquitoes made a feast out of us.  I counted close to 20 bites on Mary.  It also started raining as we were packing up, but not too hard. We stopped at Wal-Mart to get some supplies (side note: travel wipes are the best thing I've ever used on bike grease).  Then we started riding close to 10. Within two miles of riding the sky opened up again and didn't let up for the next 30 miles.  Between the downpour all night and the all day deluge almost three inches of rain fell. At 30 miles the rain did slow down and we had a pleasant last 20 miles of riding.  We pulled into Harrodsburg with all of our camping stuff completely soaked so we got a hotel room to dry things out. The rain finally petered out close to 4 and the sun even peeked out. Harrodsburg is the oldest city West of the Allegheny Mountains.  They have a replica of the original 1774 fort so we took a tour of that.    At night they have a play, "Daniel Boone, The Man & The Legend".
