We figured we would probably never be here again and we didn't know much about Daniel Boone so we would check it out. Wow!  It's hard to describe how bad this play was.  It was outdoors on a dirt stage.  There weren't any microphones so the actors were all literally yelling their lines.  The play was also way into fighting.  Over half the play was people rolling around in the dirt.  Actually not just rolling around, more like WWF without a ring.  The best was when Danile Boone ran towards one of the Indians, jumped up so his legs were around the guy's neck, and then flipped him over (I am not exaggerating!) The play also used extensive use of explosions.  One went off in this moat in front of the audience and it must of been a mistake.  It completely covered four people in the front row with mud.  They were not happy.  It threw mud about ten rows up.  Luckily we were on the other side of we would of had to go and do laundry.  They also had indians running around in loinclothes and a graphic scalping on Daniel's son, complete with fake blood. The first act was over and hour so we didn't stick around for act two.  We came back to the hotel and called it a night.  We still don't know anything about Daniel Boone. Quote of the day - "If I hear one more person talk about how they need rain I'm going to scream!" - Rob complaining about the downpour that had been going on for over 18 hours. 
After breakfast we packed up and were on our way by 8.  Amazingly everything we had dried out overnight.  It was cool and overcast and it seemed like the humidity was close to 100%. The riding today was nice.  We were finally out of the big hills but it was still rolling.  We were also into the larger cattle ranch type farms which was a big change from the coal mining areas.    At about halfway we stopped in Springfield for an early lunch.l  We ate outside the courthours where Tom Lincoln (Abraham Lincoln's father) applied for his marriage certificate.    After lunch we continued on and rode through the Lincoln homestead.  It's where Abraham Lincoln's father lived until he was 25 and got married. From there it was an easy last 20 miles to Bardstown.  We tried to go to the bike shop in town to get some break pads but it was closed on Sundays. We camped the night at My Old Kentucky Home park.  There was a musical about Steven Foster (composer of "My Old Kentucky Home" who lived in Bardstown), but after the debacle of a play the night before we decided against it. We're finally spending the night in a county where you can buy beer.  We were looking forward to having a drink with dinner but of course it's Sunday and they have blue laws.  Oh well.  Instead we walked to McDonalds after dinner and each had a sundae. Bardstown seemed more affluent than the other towns we've been staying in.  More luxury cars and fewer pick-ups.  The few pick-ups we did see were fancy compared to the standard farm trucks we'd seen the past few days. Quote of the day - "Of course not!" - woman at mini-mart when I asked if I could buy beer on Sudays.  It wasn't so obvious to me.    
We broke camp disappointed in breakfast but we figured we would hit a mini-mark a few miles down the road.  After a mile or so of riding it became obvious the fog was still too heavy to be riding on the road.  We turned around and headed to McDonalds for breakfast and to wait out the fog. It was good to sit and read the paper and after an hour or so the fog had lifted. We headed out and at about 25 miles we took a break in Howardstown to eat a little and finish reading the paper.  They sold beer there and in hindsight we should of bought some, but we didn't. From there it was off to Abraham Lincoln's Birthplace National Monument.  We stopped in and watched the movie.  It was slim on facts and big on braging about Kentucky even thought Lincoln moved to Illinois when he was 8.      We talked to family outside the monument who were funny.  They gave us a root beer and were trying to give us all kinds of chocolate but it would of melted all over our food bag so we didn't take it. From there we pulled into LaRue County Park for some free camping.  Once again we found ourselves hanging around in a park waiting for dark.  It seemed strange to be setting up camp less than 100 yards away from someone's yard.  The park had a pool but the pump was broken so we couldn't swim.  At least they had showers in the park.    Quote of the day - "Just remember when you're struggling up some huge hill in 100 degree weather, it's still better than 1000 miles in an air conditioned car with a nine year old girl" - man at Lincoln Birthplace Monument about his daughter.  I guess she was driving the rest of the family crazy. 
The riding was excellent.  The past few days have been step rolling hills so it was difficult to carry any momentum.  Tody was almost flat in comparison.  The miles just rolled by. At 40 miles we crossed into the Central Time Zone.  It was cool to think we had pedaled far enough to need to set our watches back. We stopped at a gas station/diner for lunch and each had a hamburger and onion rings. From there we went to Rough River Dam Campground and set up camp.  We walked over to the pool and had a nice swim.    After dinner we learned that the national fiddle and bluegrass contest was going to be held at the at the dam's conference center the next weekend. As a result most of the campers around us were musicians and they were all sitting around their campsites jamming. I (Rob) wandered over to one group and they invited me to sit down and enjoy.  I know nothing about bluegrass but these guys seemed great.  It was fun to sit and watch them improvise.    After about an hour the session was cut short when a huge storm blew in.  It ended up raining for over 3 hours.  We were beginning to worry we  might have a repeat of Berea but it stopped a little after 10. Quote of the day - "You ain't had much exposure to bluegrass music." - response from the bass player when I said my only exposure to bluegrass was the 'Oh Brother Where Art Thou' sound track. 
The riding continued to be easy with some nice rolling hills.  We rode through farmland most of the day.    We snacked a little but decided to push to Utica at 45 miles before really stopping to eat.  By the time we pulled into the market I (Rob) was starting to bonk.  No problem.  Nothing a coke, a bag of fritos, and half a large pizza wouldn't fix.  Mary skipped the fritos and coke (Side note - Rob's stomach didn't feel too well for the next few miles). We set off with 30 miles to go.  We hit our first headwinds of the trip.  Nothing too bad but we started having to pedal to get downhill. It also threatened to rain the second part of the ride but nothing ever came of it.    We pulled into Sebree a little after two and headed to the city park where we would be spending the night.  (That's right another city park where we hang around waiting for dark).  They had a nice outdoor pool with a diving board.  I (Rob) played around on the diving board long enough to hit the water once and have my running shorts around my ankles and figured that was probably enough of that (after some quick underwater action to get them up).  Mary was sitting outside under the pavillion and couldn't figure out why I had stopped diving. After swimming we set the tent out in the sun to dry it all out.  It didn't take long.  We also had an extremely annoying nine year old kid pester us for a good hour.  He must have been tired of swimming.  He told us lots of useless information like - "No, there aren't any trains during the night" (raiload directly adjacent to camp area) and that we should definitely visit "Quigley's Restaraunt" if we were ever in Alabama. The pool closed at 5 and just as everyone was leaving another bike tourer came up.  His name was Billy and he was also going West on the same route we were. The first story out of his mouth was a story about trying to get a beer in Kentucky.  We have yet to spend the night in a county where beer is available.  He had spent the previous night in Utica and had run into a guy who drove to the next county to get him some beer.  We haven't been so lucky.  Not that we can't live without it, but when it's not an option, you start to notice. We talked for a while.  Another local cyclist showed up and talked to us for an hour or so.  He was all over the place with his conversation.  He raced mountain bikes, built frames, hiked the appahlachin trail, did mountain bike clinics and wanted to buy our tandem.  He was a talker. Finally we set up the tent in a picnic shelter because the forecast was calling for rain.  At least we'll be dry for sure tonight. Quote of the day - " Leave the man alone."  Dad reprimanding annoying kid as he tried to talk to Rob while he was taking a shower.  Needless to say it didn't deter him in the least. 
   We packed up quickly, said goodbye to Billy, and headed down the road.  At ten miles we stopped in a small town to pick up some drinks. At 20 miles we sat down in the town of Clay and had a quick snack of Ritz and cheese.  We looked for the market that was supposed to be in town but couldn't find it.  After a few minutes of searching we gave up and headed onward to Marion the next town on the route. Marion turned into a very productive stop for us.  We ran into Rose, sort of a town greeter who showed us where the library, a barber shop, the farm market, and the supermarket all were.  She also had big plans to turn a vacant lot in town into a bicyclists stopover type place with showers and water.  It will be nice if she gets it done.  She also offered us some water from her house. There were a ton of motorcycles driving around town and it turned out this weekend was the Little Sturgis rally in Sturgis, KY.  They were expecting between 24,000 and 26,000 people for this thing. We hit the library and read email and updated the web site.  It was the nicest public library internet access we've had yet. Next we both got our hair cut.  Mary got a nice stylish doo, and I had my head shaved (not quite bald).  It feels good in the heat. Finally we grabbed some lunch at the Subway and hit the farmers market for some corn and potatos. After our three hour layover we headed out for the last 12 miles of Kentucky, and onward to Illinois.  We rode down to the Ohio river and right onto the ferry that took us across to Illinois.  The ferry was quite a bit smaller than what we were used to from Seattle.  It was really a barge that held about 15-20 cars at the most, with a tug pushing it across the water.    After getting off the ferry it was a quick but hilly mile to the Cave In Rock Campground.  We set up camp and about an hour later Billy pulled in.  As he was setting up a quick but hard rain shower blew in.  Of course this came just after the ranger had said they hadn't had any rain for three weeks.  We seem to be a rain magnet. It cleared about an hour later and we had a cool night for sleeping. Quote of the day - "I wouldn't dip my foot in that river" - park ranger explaining why we shouldn't go for a swim in the Ohio River.    
The cave was surprisingly large.  Probably about 100 ft. deep and at least 50 ft at its highest point.  The cave has an interesting past.  At one point it was used as a home base for pirates who would attack people traveling on the river.    After checking out the cave we went back to the campsite and packed up for the short ride to Elizabethtown to meet Mary's sister, Laura, her husband Steve, and their seven month old, Sam.  The ride was along the Ohio River and was very hilly.  A lot of super steep short type hills.  On top of the hills the road was the roughest we've encountered.    We got to town and saw a laundry so we decided it might be nice to have some clean clothes to meet Laura, Steve and Sam.  We had an interesting conversation with a woman who tied the rebar in concrete bridge decks.  It sounded like a tough hot job. After getting some clean clothes we rode to the River Rose Inn, the bed & breakfast we were staying in.  Just as we pulled up Laura, Steve and Sam pulled in.  Sam has grown a ton since we saw him in February.  His nickname at daycare is "Smiley Baby" and it was easy to see why.  He doesn't seem to ever stop smiling.    We checked into the Inn which was a huge house built in 1914.  The owners had re-done the entire inside of the house themselves and it was beautiful. After a great lunch of fried catfish we got in the car and drove back to Cave In Rock so Laura, Steve and Sam could see the cave.  Of course in the car it only took 15 minutes to get there. We finally spent the night in a place where we could buy beer so we had pizza and beer for dinner.  It was the best a Miller has ever tasted. Quote of the day - "That one looks like the Super Bowl Trophy!" - Steve commenting on one of the lawn ornaments we saw. 
The owner of the Inn (Elizabeth) put some fruit and muffins out so we would have some breakfast before we started out.  Laura had never ridden the tandem before so we did a quick practice run in front of the Inn before we left.  While practicing this woman came over smoking a huge cigar (at 6:30 in the morning!) and started talking to us about riding a tandem.  She didn't make much sense so we just sort of nodded our heads, smiled and tried to get away.  I guess she owned the hotel across from the Inn and was known to be a little crazy. We got moving before 7 and made really good time going down the road.  With nothing on the bike we averaged close to 16 mph the whole way.  Steve and Mary stuck around at the Inn until 8 and had some breakfast with the rest of the guests.  Then they loaded up the car close to 9 to catch up with Laura and me. Laura and I stopped at 20 miles at a mini-mart for a small package of donuts.  I had to give her the full experience and it just wouldn't be the real thing without eating some crap from a mini-mart.  She said she felt good so on we went. At about 35 miles we ran into our first Eastbound bikers.  They had started in San Francisco at the end of May.  They had some good advice about Missouri (watch out for the logging trucks), and were frightened about the dogs in Kentucky.  I guess they had met some other Westbound riders that had been bitten.  It seems like Mary and I got through Kentucky easier than others on the dog front. After about 15 minutes of talking we moved on.  At about 40 miles Mary, Steve and Sam caught us.  We pulled over to refill our water bottles and then agreed to meet them about 10 miles up the road.  Laura was still feeling good.  We rode the 10 miles and met them in a small town.  We ate lunch at a sub shop and then I decided to ride the last 30 miles by myself on the tandem.  Mary was enjoying her day off and it didn't seem like she needed to get on the bike. So off I went on the tandem by myself.  The miles flew by, it wasn't very hilly and the bike seemed so light it was comical.  I got a few strange looks from people passing by in cars, but no one said anything.  It was a little hot though.  Later we heard it was 95 with a heat index of 106.  No wonder I had the full body sweat going. A little less than an hour and a half later I pulled into Carbondale.  It took about a half hour to find the hotel where Mary was staying.  No one I talked to even knew that Main Street existed in Carbondale.  The fact that I asked one person where Main Street was while actually STANDING ON MAIN STREET makes me think they should invest in a few more street signs in Carbondale.  Of course that person didn't know where Main Street was either.  They also looked at me kind of funny because I was in full body sweat mode riding a tandem bike by myself.  Not really the picture of sanity. I finally found the hotel and we had a nice afternoon spending time with Sam, Laura and Steve.  We went to the bike shop in town to get some brake pads and they guy knew immediately we were riding across the country.  We couldn't figure out how but he said he noticed the tan lines on our hands.  We have very dark circles in the middle of the back of our hands from the cycling gloves. Quote of the day - "There's no Main Street in Carbondale" - answer from one of the people I got trying to find the hotel we were staying in which was on Main Street. 
Laura, Steve & Sam hung around until close to 9 and then packed up to head home.  Sam continued to be well behaved. It also turned out to be the hottest day yet.  96 real temperature and a heat index of 106.  It was nice to be in the cool hotel room. I walked to SIU (Southern Illinois University) and got online for a little while.  The 20 minute walk had me completely soaked with sweat.  It was hot. Later we ventured out to see the movie Men in Black II.  It was entertaining.  We also spent a coupole of hours at a Barnes & Noble.  They had a Starbucks and it was nice to get a little Seattle. Tomorrow we're off to Missouri.  Our fourth state.  It's flying by. 
The first 40 miles today were very nice.  They first 10 or so took us through Murphysboro and then down to the Mississippi flats.  The fields along the river looked the most healthy of any we had seen and it was nice to just cruise along at close to 20 mph.  It was hot though.  We weren't working very hard but were both sweating quite a bit. We hit the town of Chester before 9 and stopped at a Hardee's for breakfast.  It was full of a bunch of men having their morning coffee.  We're not sure if they even saw us even thought the only empty seat in the place was in the middle of them.  We got to hear all about who was sick, who had died recently and who had diarreah.  Nice things to hear about while eating breakfast. Chester is the home town to the guy that created Popeye.  There was a Popeye themed everything in Chester: pizza, burgers, laundry, car dealerships.    It was too early to call it a day but it was feeling very hot.  We tanked up on water and Gatorade and headed to Missouri. On the way out of town we stopped at a statue of Popeye to take a picture.  There were four people there from Oklahoma who couldn't really believe we were riding a bike across the country. After the photo-op we crossed the Mississippi on the worse bridge we've had to cross yet.  It was a two lane highway with heavy truck traffic and no shoulder.  We waited until there wasn't any traffic and sprinted across as fast as we could go.  You couldn't even enjoy the view of the river.    Once in Missouri we had about 10 miles of totally flat riding before heading into some hills.  We experienced our first headwind leaving the river flats.  It wasn't terrible but enough to slow us down a little. The last 10 miles was through some hillier terrain.  Not too bad but a good warmup for the Ozarks.  We ended the day in a nice hotel on Interstate 55.  We wanted to camp but the next campground was 30 miles away and the heat index was 103.  We wanted to get out of the heat. We did some laundry and watched bad daytime TV in the AC.  Tomorrow is supposed to be cooler so we'll see how that goes. Quote of the day - "Let's begin Operation Refreshment" - Mary sitting in the parking lot of a mini-mart about to fill our eight water bottles in Chester.    
Turns out the rest of the ride was pretty quick.  We hit the town of Farmington and refilled our bottles.  Then we moved along leaving on HWY W.  This was not a fun road.  No shoulder and pretty heavy truck traffic. After 8 miles of that we turned off and had almost traffic free riding for the rest of the day.  We stopped and ate a non mini-mart lunch at the park in Pine Knob. Next we visited Elephant Rocks State Park.  It is a series of huge granite boulders that have eroded away to look like large elephants.  We spend about an hour there and then headed out to Johnston's Shut-Ins.      The 13 miles to the park were phenomenal.  It seemed like a gradual downhill the whole way. We ran into an Eastbound biker, Art, just before the park.  He said the park was great and he had loved the Ozarks.  We talked for a little while and said goodbye. The park itself was great.  A shut-in is a steep V-shaped gorge carved in volcanic rock by flowing water.  We played in the water with about 100 other people for a while.  The water was at least 70 and crystal clear.  It was like a natural made waterslide park.    Then we ate dinner and called it a night. Quote of the day - "We never turn away bikers!" - woman at camp check in explaining that they were full but would let us use the Scout area.  Thank goodness because it would of been a very long day if we had had to go to the next campground area. 
We packed up and moved along into the Ozarks.  We had to sneak around the gate to get out of the park.  It seemed strange they locked you into the park. In Centerville we re-supplied and kept moving.  The hills were actually a lot of fun today.  Some of the climbs were steep but none too long, and the downhills were awesome.  We had heard the Ozarks described as a human powered roller coaster and that is a great description.  We even lost our stomachs on a couple of the downhills.  At least Mary didn't get motion sick on me. We entered the Ozark National Scenic Riverways and crossed the Current River.  The climb out of the river valley was the one long climb of the day.  After that we did a lot more up and down into Eminence.  The town is on the Jacks Fork River and bills itself as the canoe capitol of the world. We found a laundromat and watched some TV in the Air Conditioning while cleaning our clothes.  We had a discussion about our trailer with a guy who wanted to hook it up to his dog.  Personally I have a hard time figuring out how you would attach the thing to a dog, but this guy seemed crazy enough to figure it out.  His was had a huge tatoo that wrapped her entire body at chest level.  It was hard to tell what it was because her bikini top covered the front half of it. Next we headed to a campground on the river for the night.  We took a quick dip in the river which was very refreshing.  The were a ton of people canoeing down the river.  The outfitters in town do a shuttle service so you don't have to go up river. Its amazing how full the campgrounds are here.  In Virginia we almost always had the places to ourselves.  In Kentucky they were more full, but not totally full.  Both places we've camped in Missouri have been totally full.  Luckily they make room for cyclists. We walked back into town after dinner to get some ice cream.  The local kids were crusing up and down the main street.  It was kind of amusing to watch. Quote of the day - "It's city water!" - answer to Mary asking where we could get water at the campground.  We guessed that meant the water in the bathrooms was okay to drink. 
We were moving just before 8 and the going was kind of slow.  The steepest longest hills we had experienced yet in the Ozarks. At Alley Springs we stopped for a few minutes to see the spring and an old mill built next to it.  It pumps out 81 million gallons of water per day and feeds into the Jack Forks River.    About five miles past the spring we ran into an eastbound rider.  He was in the stinky-dirty-hairy category but had some good information.  There is a bridge out in Kansas and he showed us a detour.  He also said he had had a tailwind the second half of Kansas and was doing 100+ mile days.  Hopefully the winds will swing around for us.  He also had an interesting way of dealing with dogs.  He sprints ahead, does a 180, then charges at them growling.  That might be hard to do on the tandem, so we'll stick to the pepper spray. Next we hit Sommersville and filled out water bottles.  The terrain had become much more rolling now and we were cruising along.  At about 25 miles there was a fire lookout that you were allowed to climb.  I (Rob) climbed up and took a few pictures. It was probably 150ft. high or so.    Outside of Houston we ran into a couple heading East who were from Kirkland, WA.  It was kind of strange running into two people from Seattle in the middle of Missouri. We hit Houston a little after noon.  We had planned on calling it a day but after eating lunch we both felt pretty good.  Additionally, Houston was just a big strip mall and we were going to have to get a hotel.  The next choice was Hartville almost 40 miles away, so away we went. We zoomed along towards Hartville.  The terrain continued to be fun rolling hills.  We stopped at Beaver Creek and took a quick dip to cool off.  It was probably in the mid-90's and was starting to feel hot. The last 14 miles were a little more challenging.  It was probably a combination of the heat, being tired, and the hills got bigger. In Hartville they allow camping on the courthouse lawn in the middle of town.  I checked in with the sheriff and asked if there was shower anywhere in town.  The sheriff moved two inmates in the county jail so we could take showers in one of the jail cells.  She jokingly locked us in to give us the full effect.  I guess after a full day of riding in 90+ heat we must of looked desparate for a shower. After showering we ate a nice dinner of speghetti on the courthouse steps and got to watch the local kids cruise up and down the street in front of us. About five miles before we hit town Mary noticed a rash, like poison ivy, developing on the back of her legs.  It must of happened after swimming.  The rash appeared to be spreading to her upper legs and we started to worry where else it would spread since we always apply gobs of sunscreen all over our bodies regularly, which would spread the rash everywhere.  In a moment of panic she decides it best if we wash everything we have immediately.  She went into the sheriff office to get directions to the laundry. Mary - "Do you know where I can go to do laundry?" Dispatcher - "10-4 .... I'm not from here, let me ask." Man we met earlier out front who had just turned himself in for something accomppanied by his girlfriend who were in the process of hugging and crying - "What is it you need?" Mary - "A laundry mat" Sheriff, who just appeared - "Oh, it's down by the town and county." Mary - "Town and country?" all - dispatcher, sheriff, convict, girlfriend - all pointing down the street - "You know, the grocery store." Mary (kind of meekly) - "Thanks, I think I can find that." Quote of the day - "I have to finish this trip!" - Eastbound rider explaining that after making it through Kansas he had to finish because he would never ride through Kansas again. 
We packed up and were on the road by six.  The first 20 miles or so were hilly but still pretty fun.  We hit Marshfield before 9 and ate breakfast at McDonalds.  It was the most happening McDonalds either of us had ever seen.  There was also a Wal-Mart so we bought new mini-fans to replace our other ones which had both broken. Then we pushed on in the heat.  In hindsight, the worse decision we have made on this trip.  At about 50 miles we stopped at a mini-mart and sat in the AC for about a half hour drinking water.  It was hot. We stopped again at about 60 miles and again at 70 miles to get out of the heat and drink more.  Did we mention it was hot?  At the second place we met a couple who were going east.  They were animals.  They had started in Eugene three days before we had started and had ridden 1000 miles further.  They were funny to talk to though, and had some good stories about the people in front of us going west they had run into. We did the last seven miles and pulled into Ash Grove thinking the day was over.  I (Rob) swam in the city pool and Mary took a cold shower.  Then we headed to the library to get out of the heat.  It was hot, Africa hot. After about an hour in the library Mary said she didn't feel too good.  She looked white and felt nauseaus.  Classic heat trouble symptoms. A quick check with the librarians informed us that the one motel in town was actually closed.  One of them called City Hall to find out if there was anywhere in town we could spend the night out of the heat.  The town clerk offered to open the "Branson House", a community owned rec center, so we could spend the night in there. The town clerk locked up city hall and drove Mary to the house while I pushed the bike there.  15 minutes later was had Mary on a table, feet elevated, ice behind the nect trying to cool her off.  We were grateful for the generosity of letting us use the place. In the meantime I called my brother, Dan, who is my de-facto goto internet travel agent when I don't have a connection.  He started doing a search of U-Haul's in case we needed to drive the big bike home. While on the phone with Dan, Mary is telling me she doesn't feel any better, and if anything is feeling worse.  I call our friend, Liz, who I know had heat exhaustion once to see if she has any advice.  Her advice is to get Mary to the hospital asap and get an IV for her. I call the ambulance and they arrive amazingly fast.  Next thing we know were taking a ride 25 miles up the road to Springfield to a hospital. I can't speak for Mary but I spent the next two hours in the hospital bouncing between feeling dumb for riding so far in the heat, relieved that Mary was going to be okay, and disappointed because it seemed like the trip was over. It turned out that she was slightly dehydrated and very low in potassium (Gatorade didn't do its job!).  They gave her two IV's and some potassium pills and we were out of there. We took a cab to a hotel.  The cab driver was crazy, he had stories about guns in his mouth while driving a cab in Las Vegas, a wife that was hypoglycemic (sp?) that he had to wedge between two slot machines after he hit a big jackpot and she fainted, and his mother who he was preparing to die (whatever that means).  It was a releif to get out of the cab.  We ate some pizza and Mary started looking a normal color again.  After that we went to bed having no idea what we were going to do next. Quote of the day - "You have to get her to the hospital right now and get her an IV!" - Liz (thanks for the advice). 
After much discussion and exploring of options we decided that Mary would fly back to Seattle and I would continue on with the tandem.  Then, depending on how she felt, she would either meet me with the car in Colorado and we would drive the tandem home, or she could meet me sans car and we would ride the tandem home.  This of course was assuming I could actually ride the loaded tandem by myself. We rented a car and drove back to Ash Grove to see if the loaded solo tandem would work.  We re-packed the trailer with just my stuff and I rode around town.  It handled great.  The bike is pretty light and the long wheelbase seems to make it more stable.  I look like a complete freak but I don't know any of these people so what do I care. We locked the bike up and drove back to Springfield (by the way, Springfield appears to be the largest strip mall in the world.  As far as we could tell there was no "town", just one continuous strip mall.)  We hung out in the hotel and got Mary a ticket home. About 4:30 Mary took me back to the bike and I headed out.  It was not a happy moment.  You know in movies when two good buddies are in a bad situation and one of them gets wounded or something.  The non-wounded one never leaves his friend behind no matter what.  Well, I felt like I was leaving my friend behind.  It's in the top 5 worse moments of my life. I rode to Golden City, about 35 miles down the road.  It was hilly at first, but the last 20 miles were pretty flat.  Talking to cows when Mary was on the bike was funny, without her around it just seemed weird.    The only notable part of the ride was the grasshoppers on the road.  There were 1000's of them.  They would wait until the bike was over them and then jump up.  I had a ton of them hitting my legs for miles.  It must of been because I was riding so late in the day. I arrived in Golden City and went to pick up a key to the hostel they have in town.  Mary and I had been hearing about how great the hostel was from every eastbound rider we had passed. While waiting for the guy with the key I noticed a loaded bike across the street at a gathering of people.  I walked over to find the owner.  I ended up getting ivited to the BBQ by the people having it.  I met about 20 people and stuffed myself on chicken, ribs, salad and pasta.  It was great. I talked to one farmer for about an hour.  He was interesting and talked about how he didn't think any of his four kids would be farmers and that he thought that was a good thing.  That seemed kind of sad to me. The bike was owned by a guy named Jesse who was going east and also spending the night in the hostel.  We said goodbye to the party and headed to the hostel.  It was the nicest hostel I've seen.  Washer, dryer, TV, VCR, movies, and a fully stocked kitchen, food and all. Jesse and I did laundry and talked a while.  He was using an old 12 speed Pugeot. It's probably going to be hard going over some of the hills we've done without the third chainring. I finally hit the sack around 11:30. Quote of the day - "I just thought you were a little weird." - Jesse after I explained why I was the only person riding a tandem. 
Just before heading out of the hostel, Jesse gave me a hat with a huge brim that says "I bet mines longer than yours".  He said he thought it was appropriate for me to have since I was riding a tandem.    At the 30 mile mark I hit Kansas.  I kept moving and felt pretty good.  I went through the towns of Pittsburg and Girard.    After Girard the wind did pick up a little bit.  It was pretty much directly out of the south so it was mostly a cross wind.  I did have one 7 mile section where I went north and it took less than 20 minutes with the wind pushing me along. I hit Chanute at 1:30 and headed to the city pool.  It was feeling pretty hot by the time I hit town. It was the best public pool I have ever seen.  It was huge, at least 50m x 25m.  I had five diving boards, one 3m and four 1m.  The best was it had a huge water slide.  Not some little thing, but a full fledged amusement park slide.    I swam for about an hour, sat for a while and then swam some more.  I attracted a lot of attention.  Everyone knew I wasn't from around there so I got a lot of questions. After swimming I headed to the library but it was closed on Sunday.  I then set up camp at a park on the edge of town where camping is allowed. After a quick nap I ate some spaghetti and called it a night. I woke up around 10:30pm to the start of rain.  I quickly threw the fly on the tent and jumped back in to wait it out.  It was a doozy of a storm.  About 11:30 I got out of the tent and went into the men's bathroom which was right next to me.  The lightning was getting a little too close for my comfort.  About 1:30 the lightning finally died off and I crawled back into the tent and fell asleep.  It was still raining pretty hard and did the whole night. Quote of the day - "You're going to use the slide???" - little girl in front of me going up the ladder to the slide.  I was the only person older than 12 using it. 
I fell back asleep and woke up at 7 or so to grey clouds, no wind, and thankfully, no rain.  I got out of the tent to see that our waterproof bag had a three inch puddle of water in the center of it.  Not good.  I opened it and found another inch or so of water inside.  The only real casualty was a batery charger I had for the camera batteries.  Who knows that might work when it dries out.  (I later heard it had rained 2 1/2 inches.) I packed up and ate a quick donut, power bar and OJ breakfast and hussled down the road.  The storm was miserable for sleep but it made the temperatures great today.  It was only 68 as I left town. I rode off the actual 76 route for much of today.  There was a bridge out for part of the route so I did a detour another biker had shown me.  It was a nice road, 12ft shoulder, and freshly paved.  I stopped in the town of Yates Center to refill my water bottles and downed a couple of peanut butter sandwiches.    The next 30 miles was a straight shot west to the town of Eureka.  I ran into a father, son pair just outside of town.  They had spent the previous night in El Dorado and said it had been nice.  It was off route but was a more direct way to get to Hutchinson, which I wanted to visit.  They showed me their route and we said goodbye. I ate a nice lunch in Eureka in a gazebo in front of the town hall.  Then I hit the library and did some email.  They only had a 28.8 dial-up connection so things were moving kind of slow. After the library I went back outside and it wasn't windy, and there was a thermometer that said it was only 82 out.  I figured I would take advantage of the cooler weather and ride to El Dorado. I pulled into the state park a little before 5 and set up camp right on the lake.  There wasn't anyone else there and it wasn't supposed to rain.  I laid everything out to dry which didn't take too long in the sun.  I then took a cold shower, ate a ton of spaghetti and called it a night.  I slept great.    Thought of the day (I didn't talk to too many people today) - "This is a really big country." 
The first ten miles or so were pretty slow due to the darkness but it was nice to get the miles in.  I also got to see a very pretty sunrise over some oil fields.  The number of oil rigs in Kansas has surprised me. I more or less made up my own route today taking the most direct line to Hutchinson.  Most of the riding was on highways but the shoulders are immense so it isn't too bad if you don't mind the loud traffic. Notable highlights of the ride today were passing a couple of feed lots.  The stink stayed with me for about ten miles for each of the two that I passed.  Seeing these places makes me seriously think about eating beef.  They are gross. I also saw a couple of blue herons and a ton of turtles (mostly smooshed from trying to cross the roads). I got to Hutchinson a little before one.  It took me a little while to find the hostel and when I got there I found out that the actual building that used to be the hostel was being demolished in a couple of days.  They no longer had a real hostel but let me stay in the church basement.  It wasn't too bad but they didn't have any showers.  Oh well, just had to be stinky for a while longer. After a sink bath, I stashed my stuff and headed out for lunch.  Hutchinson has 45,000 people in it, so it had a little of everything.  After lunch I hit the bike shop to get some replacement tires.  Ours were wearing out after close to 2000 miles, and the next bike shop is 400 miles away. I had two weird experiences with people asking me stuff I would have no way of knowing. The first was as I was standing on a corner in the middle of nowhere looking at my map.  This guy pulls up in a pickup and asks where the nearest hardware store was.  Why a guy on a bike looking at a map looks like he would have the faintest idea where a hardware store is I don't know. The second was in Hutchinson.  Just as I'm leaning my bike against the hostel.  This woman pulls up and asks me what I'm doing with the stove on the corner in front of the church.  She wants to know if it works and can she take it.  Again, why I looked like I would know anything about that is beyond me. After lunch and the bike shop I went to the Cosmosphere, a space periphenalia museum in town.  It was pretty spectacular.  They had an SR-71 plane, a full size replica of a space shuttle, the Apollo 13 capsule, and this place is the one and only spacecraft restoration facility in the world.  The Smithsonian contracts with them to do all their work.  Kind of weird that it's in the middle of Kansas.    I saw a planetarium show and an IMAX film about Shackelton's adventure.  It was one of the better IMAX films I've seen.  I then tooled around in the museum for a few hours.  It was a great way to kill the day in the air conditioning. After that I headed back to the hostel and there was another couple that had just arrived.  I let them in and we ended up going out to dinner together.  It was nice to have the company.  They were also heading west, but the guy had had so many problems with his bike that he had ordered a new on in Pittsburg, KS and they were going to rent a car the next day to drive back and pick it up before moving on. b>Quote of the day - "I think it's something Speilburg did about the North Pole." - the description I overheard a man tell his wife about the IMAX film we were about to watch.  It was in fact about Shackelton trying to cross the South Pole. 
The route was northwest for the first 11 miles or so, and with the south wind went by fast.  About 8 miles into the ride I passed a bed & breakfast, exotic animal combo.  They had zebra, antelope and camel in front of the house that must of been where you stay.  It looked interesting.  Maybe next time I'm near Hutchinson, I'll check it out.    I stopped in the town of Nickerson and stocked up on water and gatorade.  There was nothing for the next 59 miles, so it seemed like a good idea to be fully loaded with liquid. I headed out dreading going almost 60 miles with nothing to break up the riding.  It turned out to be a nice ride.  There was almost no traffic and the scenery was actually pleasant.  Sublte rolling hills with fields all in various states.    I ran into an eastbound cyclist about halfway into the ride.  We stopped in the middle of the road and talked for about 20 minutes without seeing a single car. About 10 miles later I stopped by the side of the road to eat.  I had a couple of peanut butter sandwiches, or the equivilent.  My bread had been smushed into a big ball, about the size of a volleyball, so I just peeled pieces off, covered them with the peanut butter and muched away.  I would guess it was a couple of sandwiches worth. While eating I had three trucks stop and see if I was okay.  It was nice of them to check up on me, and it made me feel better that if anything did happen, I would probably be able to flag someone down and get help. The wind picked up the last ten miles of the ride, but I got into town before it really got too bad.  Larned was nice.  The downtown actually still had stores that were open.  It also had a huge public pool, with another huge water slide.  That must be the thing to do in Kansas. I found the library and did a quick update to the site.  Then I found a shady spot and ate lunch.  It was starting to feel hot and my lunch confirmed it.  My peanut butter was completely melted into liquid.  So I sat in the shade peeling pieces of bread off my breadball, and dipping them into the liquid peanut butter.  Kind of an interesting way to eat, but I don't think its going to catch on anytime soon. After my second lunch I hit the city pool.  I jumped in and out keeping cool.  Some of the kids were having a make the biggest splash contest so I joined in on that one.  One of my unknown skills is the ability to make very large splashes off a diving board.  (This skill was developed over years in high school, where, after cross country practice our coach would open the pool and we would do nothing but try and make big splashes).  It had been a long time since I had done that, so it was fun. About 7:30 I set up camp and cooked up some dinner.  It was a nice night, not too hot, and not too windy. Quote of the day - "Can you do a gainer?" - kid asking if I could do a type of dive.  I used to be able to, but somewhere along the line I lost my nerve to even try.  I guess getting older creates a healthy fear of things like smashing your head on a diving board. 
A little before dawn I passed Ft. Larned National Historical sight.  It was open yet, but I snuck around the gate to have a quick look.  It was pretty standard old fort type stuff.  I guess it used to be a stop on the Santa Fe trail. About a mile down the road from the fort there was a sign to see some old wagon ruts from the Santa Fe trail.  I thought about going to see them but the idea of going five miles on a gravel road to see some ruts in the ground on a bike wasn't that appealing.  You just don't do that kind of thing on a bike trip.  Five miles might as well be 100. I turned to go north and had a nice tailwind for 20 miles or so.  In Rush Center I headed west on HWY 96.  It looks like I'll be on this road for the next 3 1/2 days.    I stopped at a nice rest area outside of Alexander and had a conversation with a guy about the pedals on our bike.  He had never seen clipless pedals before and was fascinated with them.  He never even noticed that I was riding a tandem bike by myself.  That was kind of refreshing. Just before Ness City the wind did a 180.  It had been blowing from the south, and but swung around to come out of the north in the blink of an eye.  It was amazing to see how fast it could change directions like that. I hit Ness City and passed the 2000 mile mark on the trip.  Yeah!  There was another couple there, who were also heading west.  They had had seven flat tires in the past two days and were both pretty fed up with it.  Actually it was the same tire that had flatted all those times.  I recommended they use a cotton swab inside the tire to find the thorn, or whatever was in the tire.  There must of been something in there for the same tire to flat that many times. After talking to them for a bit I headed to a diner and ate a huge omlett.  After breakfast I hit the mini-mart and filled my water bottles.  The forcast was calling for highs in the 100's but it was only about 80 so I moved on. About 10 miles outside of the city I hit the 100th meridian, the unofficial eastern edge of the Great Plains.  To really show me a good time the wind picked up massivly.  It was howling.  Luckily it was mostly out of the north, and even a little from the west so it was kind of pushing me along.  If it had been a headwind, I would of turned around and spent the night at Ness City. I flew into Dighton with the wind pushing me along.  It had shifted even more so it was now mostly a tailwind.  I seriously thought of moving on but a 100 mile day seemed like plenty.  I did splurge and get a hotel room because I didn't feel like spending the night in the wind.  The hotel was cheap and comfortable and it was a good decision. The weather channel said the wind was 20-30 mph with gusts to 38 from the norhtwest.  No wonder going 20 on the bike had been so easy.  It also said the wind would continue out of the northwest for one more day, so I would have a tailwind the next day as well.  Very good news. I spent the afternoon in the room, watching TV, dosing.  I ate a dinner of bananas, peanut butter (normal consitency, on normal bread this time), and chips.  I didn't feel like going out for another meal, and didn't feel like firing up the stove outside the hotel. I hit the sack early, and slept like a baby. Quote of the day - "Those are some pedals you got there!" - man at rest stop talking about our clipless pedals. 
I left about half past seven and had a great ride.  The road had a nice shoulder and was completely flat.  The wind was pushing me along and the sun was hidden behind some clouds so it was cool. I made it to Scott City about 25 miles down the road in a hour.  I succumbed to the luar of McDonalds and stopped in for some breakfast.  There was a group of older men there and they teased me about being on the bike alone.  They also tried to give me directions so we could avoid the rockies.  They couldn't understand that I was actually looking forward to the mountains. I said goodbye and zipped down the road.  I had been following the rule of drinking one water bottle every ten miles but today I couldn't keep up.  It was effortless to go 25 mph. After Scott City I passed through Leoti and filled my water bottles.  Between Leoti and Tribue the wind started to shift.  It started coming from the south a little more and was blowing a little harder. Until the wind shifted I was having visions of riding a 250 mile day.  It was so easy.  The slight shift brought me back to reality.  I decided to stick with my plan of staying in Tribune.  I thought of moving on to Eads, CO, but that would of been a 130 mile day.  Too much. In Tribune I ran into a couple from Holland I had been hearing stories about for miles.  They are also riding west and have brought everything but the kitchen sink with them.  They are going relatively short days so I guess the extra weight doesn't bother them too much. After talking to them I hit the library and read a Newsweek.  It was nice to get caught up on some news.  Then I did some laundry. I headed to the city park and was surprised to discover the county fair was going to start that night.  There were a bunch of rides, a tractor pull, an animal auction and best of all a free BBQ to kick the whole thing off. I found the couple from Holland and set up camp close to them.  The three of us headed to the BBQ and ate.  They were very interesting to talk to.  This was their first time to the U.S. and they were riding from Miami to wherever they ended up.  They planned on getting to Missoula and then they didn't know where they were going. The best thing about talking to them is how they were really enjoying the trip itself.  The destination wasn't important.  Very different than all the American riders we had met, myself included. After dinner I watched the auction for a while.  Once it got dark I hit the sack.    Quote of the day - "Three days of this would of been plenty.  Okay I get it - Kansas is flat and windy!" - man from Holland talking about Kansas. 
Hitting the road it became immediately apparent it was going to be payback time for the tailwind the day before.  Even at 6:30 it was blowing fairly hard out of the south and occasionally from the southwest.  Not quite a headwind but I did spend most of the day in my granny gear chainring. At 17 miles I said a sad farewell to Kansas and entered Colorado.  Not much changed except maybe the wind was blowing harder. I can't figure out why most of this part of the country isn't covered in windmills.  I'm not sure the wind ever dips below 10 mph.  Instead the place is littered with oil pumps.  I guess that is a better way to make money, but I still think the windmill thing would be a money maker out here. I hit the towm of Sheridan Lake expecting there to be a market.  Instead, most of the town was deserted.  The one gas station in town was closed for the day, and the lake was all dried up.  The place had seen better days. I needed to get some water so I did manage to convince the people at the post office to let me use their sink.  I got lucky because they were about to close for the day (9:30 in the morning?). I got back on the road and fought the wind for the last 30 miles to get to Eads.  Eads was almost as dead as Sheridan Lake.  The main street did have stores but they were all closed. I found the pool and took a quick dip.  I think I was the only person above 15 there.  I'm not sure there were any lifeguards, just a couple of girls who liked to boss the other 10 kids around.  It wasn't a very nice pool, and I was afraid someone was going to get killed in the mayhem, so I just jumped in a cooled off. It took me a while to figure out where camping was allowed.  I was about to set up camp when I noticed there wasn't any water there, and a huge dark storm was blowing in.  I decided to go to the sketchy looking hotel on the edge of town. The hotel was okay and it rained pretty hard but only for about half an hour.  After the rain I cooked up some mac & cheese then turned in.  Only two more days of riding and them Mary is coming back.  I'm looking forward to it. Thought of the day - "This place is dead!" - me thinking about Eads.  I didn't really talk to anyone today. 
I headed down the road and it was slow moving.  About two miles into the ride I noticed that the bob tire was flat.  Almost 2200 miles without a flat so I couldn't complain. It didn't take too long to fix and I was on my way again.  It looked like it had been a pinch flat so I only did a cursory check of the tire.  Things were a little easier going with air in the tire. About 15 miles later I had another flat in the bob tire.  This time I did a thourough search and found a thorn just sticking through the tire.  I patched the tube and while waiting for it to dry I looked at the other two tires on the bike.  They both had thorns in them that hadn't worked into the tubes yet.  I removed them, fixed the bob tire and moved on. In Haswell I stopped and bought a pop from a machine and sat down in the shade to drink it.  This guy pulls up in his pickup and started talking to me.  He only sort of made sense.  He had been a bricklayer in Las Vegas working for the mob, then jumped to the topic of not allowing furniture on porches (something about a fire hazzard), followed by a diatribe about living with a prostitute that wouldn't give him any action.  It was astounding.  All I could think about was the fact that he was driving.  It was a little scary. I finished my drink, said goodbye and left.  He was still talking. In Sugar City I stopped in a market and had an ice cream sandwich.  It was the first week the store had been open.  The owner had moved from Denver and was super friendly and very enthusiastic.  I hope the store works out for her. From there I rode the last ten miles into Ordway.  It felt hot.  I checked into the hotel which is really a hostel.  The woman that runs it was very nice. I sat and talked to her for more than an hour.  She was telling stories about how this used to be a huge sugar and cantelope producing region.  Then the feed lots bought all the water rights and that was more of less the end of the area having any kind of agriculture base.  Now the feed lots have sold most of their water rights to the city of Denver, so they aren't even around. I turned in early and called it a night. Quote of the day - "Don't sit on any furniture on them porches!" - man in Haswell.  I don't know what he was talking about. 
I changed both the tube and the tire (I had bought new tires in Hutchinson waiting to change them when I got a flat).  Then I was off.  I had a quick ride today, the wind was more or less from the south but was really non-existant compared to the previous days. I pretty much rode straight through to Pueblo.  There wasn't actually anywhere to stop even if I had wanted to.  The two towns I went through were more or less closed up. Once in Pueblo I found the bike shop where I dropped the tandem off.  They are going to replace some cables on the bike that are nice and rusty.  The owner of the shop gave me a ride to the car rental place (which was very nice since it would of been about a two mile walk on nasty highway roads).  I got the rental car and started driving to Denver International Airport to pick up Mary. There were some wicked thunderstorms the entire drive up and I figured that might delay her flight a little.  I was right.  She got in about two hours late, but she came and was feeling fine. While waiting I noticed there was a guy in the ticketing area taking a bike apart to fit it in a box.  I started talking to him and it turned out he was planning on flying to Alaska and riding his bike to Tiera Del Feugo (sp?).  I think he said it was about a 16,000 mile trip and he was going to take 16 months to do it.  Pretty crazy.  What was really crazy is his bike was a complete wreck.  I don't think the chain had ever been lubed, the bottom bracket was shot, his front breaks were not attached to the forks, and we couldn't remove the pedals which was a mess because they had to be removed to fit the bike in the box.  He also had no tools except a little do-it-all type tool you take on a two hour mountain bike ride, not on a 16 month epic journey.  He seemed woefully unprepared for the ride he was about to do.  I'm sure he'll learn along the way.  He did however have a copy of War and Peace (hardback of course). We finally managed to get one pedal off, and fit the bike in the box.  I would love to read a journal by that guy.  He did have a lot of duct tape, so I'm sure he'll be able to write a manual about repairing a bike in the middle of nowhere with nothing but duct tape. Mary arrived and we drove off to the Hotel Udovich.  Chris and Kirk are putting us up for a few days.  Then we're off to Peublo to retrieve the bike and away we go! Quote of the day - "I really missed you!" - Rob to Mary as she got off the bike.  I was sick of riding the bike by myself. 
Monday Night Mary feels good, we're planning on riding again by Friday. Tuesday Mary is feeling good in the morning, but as the day goes on she isn't feeling so good.  Not the sort of news either of us was prepared for.  By the end of the day she is light headed and her stomach doesn't feel so great.  We're pretty bummed out, its looking like the trip is off. Wednesday We decide to not panic and start heading home just yet.  We took a trip to Rocky Mountain National Park and decided that seeing things from a car just wasn't going to cut it for the rest of the trip.  Mary still doesn't feel so great.  We went to see Austin Powers with Chris and that cheered us up. Thursday We get the name of Kirk's doctor and he sees Mary that day.  He is the best doctor either of us have ever dealt with.  He actually talked to us for 15 minutes before doing anything.  His prognosis is that Mary has a virus and will be better in a day or so.  We suddenly have some hope.  Went to see Austin Powers with Kirk; it was so good the first time we had to see it again.  It was actually better the second time. Friday Mary goes in for some blood work to make sure she doesn't have Lymes Disease.  We had seen a lot of ticks.  The blood work comes back negative so we think we'll try riding again in a few days.  Mary is feeling better.  We take a trip to Performance Bike Shop and buy a 5 pound canister of cytomax for re-hydrating on the trip. Saturday We head back to Pueblo to pick up the bike and drop off the car.  Thanks to Chris and Kirk for putting up with us for 5 stressful days (we're riding - we're not riding - we're riding .... etc etc etc).  We did see the new XXX movie.  It was entertaining if you can suspend reality for about two hours. Sunday Mary feels great, but we decide to take one more day off just in case.  We did go for a short ride in Pueblo on a bike path.  It turned out to be the worse bike path in the world.  Covered with glass, huge bumpy sections and best of all, sand.  We took the roads back to the hotel and called 11 miles a day. Our plan from now on is to take it very easy.  We might not make it to Seattle, but we'll be able to ride the entire time we have off. 
   We woke up early and looked out the window to some very windy conditions.  A front was moving in and the winds were a steady 30 mph out of the north.  It looked like it was going to be a slow first day back in the saddle. We packed up our gear and headed to Canon City taking HWY 50.  The actual 76 route takes 96 out of Pueblo, but the guys at the bike shop said 50 had a nice shoulder and was probably a better road.  It was a very nice road with a 12 ft shoulder the whole way.    The wind blew pretty hard for the first 10 miles or so.  It didn't blow the bike around nearly as much as it had when I was on the bike alone.  After 10 miles the wind just stopped.  I was glad Mary got to experience how quickly it could change. We stopped at a market about 15 miles into the ride to tank up on Gatorade.  It wasn't very hot but we weren't taking any chances. We moved along fairly quickly after that.  As we got closer to the mountains they became more clear.  It was pretty riding, and very nice for me (Rob) to be out of the flatlands. We hit Canon City by 10:30 and it was nice.  It seemed like the majority of the jobs in the town relied on tourism.  There was a train that takes people up to Royal Gorge and tons of rafting trips on the Arkansas River.  There was also alot of mountain biking to do outside of town. We found the library and to pay some bills online.  Next we hit the bike shop in town to try and adjust Mary's seat.  It required a 2.5 mm hex wrench and we didn't have one. Adjusting the seat turned into a mini project.  The clamp that holds the seat in place was stuck and the guy at the shop had to use a hammer and a chisel to get it loose.  We finally fixed the seat angle and bought a 2.5 mm wrench to be able to adjust it later.  We weren't willing to carry a hammer and chisel so hopefully we will be able to get it loose. We checked into a hotel and spent the rest of the day lounging.  It was great to be back riding together. Quote of the day - "I once rode 70 miles in a pair of jeans.  It made me numb from my hips to my knees." - bike mechanic explaining why it was important to wear the right clothing while riding a bike.  It was a little more information than we needed. 
We rode up to Royal Gorge which seemed to be nothing but a tourist trap.  We decided against making the four mile detour to see the worlds highest suspension bridge.  We thought we would stock up on some food but the market was closed.  Oh well. We moved on knowing it was another 21 miles to the next market.  The riding was great.  We were in the Rocky's now and it was beautiful.  The going was pretty slow though.  We were doing a lot of climbing.    We went a little off route to the town of Guffey where there was a market.  It turned out the market was more like a bar with food items placed in various locations.  It was kind of a scavenger hunt type of shopping. We weren't planning on eating but it seemed like they had pretty good food so we sat down and had some lunch.  The proprieters were very nice and the food was good so it was a good call. After lunch we traveled on to the hostel.  It was in a beautiful setting.  The owner was nice and showed us around.  We decided to stay in the cabin for the night, especially after hearing there were three bears around that liked to visit at night.    We both took a cold water bucket shower and settled in for a nice afternoon of reading and napping.  After climbing from 5300 ft to 9000 ft we were both feeling a little tired. Quote of the day - "Just use that log to lock the door so the bears won't come in the cabin" - owner of hostel explaining how to "lock" the door by putting a log in front of it.  We were a little skeptical that it would actually deter a bear if it really wanted to get in. 
About an hour later the sun peeked over the mountains and it warmed up to the 50's almost instantly.  We decided that was warm enough and took off.  The first six miles of the ride took us over our first bona fide pass, Currant Creek Pass.  It turned out to be relativly easy and we rolled over the 9400 ft mark.    The next 16 miles to Hartsel were mostly downhill and we cruised along.  The scenery was amazing.  For the entire ride we were surrounded by 11,000 - 14,000 ft peaks.  We also passed a few buffalo farms and saw several hawks. In Hartsel we stopped at a cafe and ate a huge breakfast.  It was probably a little more food than we needed and we felt stuffed.  We rolled next door to tank up on some water and then hit the road. We moved on the Fairplay and the ride continued to be beautiful.  The wind picked up out of the north and soon became a nasty headwind.  The wind combined with the steady climb to 10,000 ft made for some slow moving. We pulled into Fairplay and I (Rob) was feeling the altitude.  I had a nice splitting headache and my ears were ringing pretty bad.  We hit the laundry and Mary washed our clothes while I vegitated and tried to recover. After cleaning our clothes we decided to get a hotel.  Our camping options were a couple of gravel parking lots and it was still very windy so a hotel sounded like a better option to both of us.  After a quick nap my headache was gone and we did a little sightseeing. Fairplay is also known as South Park, as in the TV cartoon.  We had to see if there was any South Park periphenalia.  We were beginning to think no one in town had a sense of humor when we found a life size Mr. Hanky.  Mary got a picture of me in front of it.  Classy photo.    Quote of the day - "It's hot as hell in here" - Mary noticing the heat was on in out hotel room.  I just thought I was hot from the altitude and didn't bother to check. The maintenance guy came and fixed it. 
There was a nice bike path from Fairplay to Alma and it was a nice break to be out of the traffic for a little while.  About two miles past Alma the four mile climb to the top of the pass started.  It turned out to be an easy climb.  Compared to some hills in Kentucky it was a mild grade. We hung out at the top for a bit and took the obligatory picture of us in front of the sign.  Then we flew down the hill to Breckenridge.    Show links to this Hide links to this       August 15, 2002   We were initially impressed with Breckenridge but after running up and down the entire length of the town a couple of times looking for the bike shop and then the library it lost a lot of its luster.  It just seemed like one big upscale stip mall with really bad traffic.  We couldn't imagine what it was like during ski season.  It must be a traffic nightmare. We decided to head on the Frisco and get out of Breckenridge.  There was a bike trail between the two towns.  The views were great and it was nice to be riding amongst other bikers using the trail.    We walked through Frisco looking for a grocery store but didn't have much luck.  Finally Mary asked and of course all the useful stores were near the freeway at the edge of town.  We should of known that's where all the bigger stores are these days, easy freeway access is important. We found the grocery store and picked up a ton of food.  We had two meals to cook this afternoon.  Then we tried to find the way to the campground that was supposed to be just out of town.  It was a little difficult.  Bike paths are nice, but they are rarely signed well, so we ended up riding around in circles for about a half hour before finally finding the right trail.  About four miles later we found the campground and home for the night. We set up camp in a shady site and then just hung out for the day.  We changed the rear tire, it was looking pretty bald, and read books.  About six in the evening a couple in the site next to our invited us over for a beer.  We took them up on it.  They were probably in their late 50's and had lived everywhere.  It was fun talking to them for a while. Then we had a guy pull into our campsite and look it over.  When Mary told him we were camping there he got kind of upset and stormed off to the camp manager.  We had picked a spot that was a "pull-through" for large RV's.  He had a large RV and didn't want to have to disconnect his car from the back so he wanted our spot.  The camp manager told him to pick another spot, so we got to keep our site.  We'll have to be more careful in the future to try and avoid the pull-through sites. After the mad RV'er encounter we ate a nice spaghetti dinner and called it a night. Quote of the day - "Can we camp in this spot?" - RV'er who wanted to use our site.    
We followed the bike path along the resevoir and across the dam.  At that point we hit the dreaded construction we had heard about from several well wishers we met along the way.  It was grooved pavement and made for unnerving riding.  It felt like the bike was going to fall over at any second.  Fortunately there was little traffic and only lasted for about two miles.  We were happy thinking it wasn't as bad as everyone had made it seem. Several miles down the road we hit the "real" construction they must of been talking about.  It was terrible.  Basically all pavement was gone, and it felt like mountain biking on the fully loaded skinny tire tandem.  It was funny later on looking back on it but at the time it was stressful.  Additionally, there was several miles of single lane road so we were in a large stream of cars with people in them tired of waiting for the construction.  We had to go a lot faster than either of us would of liked considering the road condition.  Fortunately we made it through all of the road work and then got a flat tire.  It was a simple change to the front wheel, and considering the bad road it was amazing all three tires didn't flat several times.  Most amazing is that not a single eastbound rider had said anything about this construction.  I guess a few weeks on the road toughens most to adapt to anything and then move on.    We reached Kremling, stopped at the library, grocery store and Mrs. Z's restaraunt for lunch.  It was popular; even the ice cream truck driver stopped there. We headed 7 miles out of town to a campground in warmer temperatures (90 compared to 40 this morning).  We are not sure how the campground got its name, but it should have been called WINDY.  or RIDICULOUSLY WINDY.  We hung out in the strong winds from about 1 pm until sun down.  The wind could be likened to riding on a highway in a jeep.  We are not sure why anyone without a vehicle would choose to stay there, but they did - no trees, gravel, pseudo stonehenge shade makers and sage grass.    We plan to get an early start tomorrow to try and beat the wind before it starts growing to strong. Quote of the day - "You should of stayed at the RV park in Kremling.  They have nice shaded spots for tents there" - manager of the super-windy campground.  It was too late for that advice, we weren't going to backtrack seven miles for a little shade. 
We climbed a short pass, Muddy Pass, and could see Rabbit Ears Mountain in the background (two small rock formations that sprouted out of the top of the mountain looking like rabbit ears).    We turned off highway 40 onto highway 14 for the last 35 miles of the ride and figured we had about 3 1/2 hours of riding in front of us.  Instead we zipped along on a great downhill and tailwind that allowed us to average about 18 mph the last 35 miles.  We flew through the desert landscape.  Riding at its best. We saw prairie dogs, antelope and very few cars.  We pulled into the Roundup Motel just before 11 and were able to check in for an afternoon out of the elements.  (The wind was really taking its toll).  We bought some used books from the library at $0.25 each, bought groceries to make some tacos and did laundry.  It was a good day in Walden. There was a forest fire near Steamboat Springs that blew pretty heavy smoke into town.  It was difficult to breathe.  We were glad to have the hotel room.    Quote of the day - "Yep, the fires out here are all because of the environmentalists." - owners of the hotel very sure that the current fire situation had nothing to do with the EXTREME DROUGHT Colorado is experiencing. 
We slept in and took a nice walk through the town.  It was a nice morning but the forest fires were still blanketing the sky with nasty smoke. After that we changed rooms, then hung out and watched a lot of TV. All in all a great relaxing day. 
We passed through the town of Cowdrey and then hit the Wyoming state line.  We had gone 22 miles in a little over an hour.  While stopped at the state line we noticed we had a tail wind.  Nice!    The next 30 miles were awesome.  Mostly downhill, and a tailwind.  Probably the definition of bike touring heaven. We stopped in the town of Riverside at 9:30.  We were 50 miles into the ride and had planned on spending the night but the wind made the riding so easy we decided to move on. We ate some breakfast at a cafe in Riverside.  The food was excellent but the waitress acted like we were interupting something she was doing.  We also got to overhear another conversation about those damn environmentalists and the fires. On the way to Saratoga we ran into a father and his two sons who were riding east.  They were packed superlight and were trying to make it across the country in 40 days.  The father was sort of manic, jumping from one topic to the next without as much as breathing.  Mary and I were wondering where we could get some of the drugs he seemed to be on.  His sons were both dragging a little bit.  It seemed like their dad was beating them into the ground. We pulled into Saratoga and went to the hot springs in town.  They were hot but also kind of dirty.  Since we didn't have access to a shower we decided against taking a dip.    Then we moved on to Saratoga Lake for the night.  It was a nice little lake.  There wasn't much shade but we managed to stay cool by jumping in the water for a bit and moving the tent every 30 minutes to stay in the shadow of the one tree in the park. We were entertained watching a family of four take turns on a jet ski in the tiny lake.  They would go out about 100 yards then turn around and come back so the next one could go for a spin.  It seemed kind of pointless. Quote of the day - "So far we're averaging 98 plus ... I'm 51 and have more endurance than my sons ... look at that rear axle, its strong ... this bike was made by a tandem maker ... we're hoping to finish in 40 days ..." - all said franticly with little notice of our response. 
The alarm went off at 5:30 and it was still raining lightly and it was windy so we decided to sleep in.  We woke up again at 7:30.  The rain had stopped but it was windy.  We packed up and headed down the road. The first 20 miles were easy as the wind was mostly at our backs.  The animal highlite of the day was having a bald eagle fly across the road about 50 ft above us.  They are big birds when you see them that close. Then we turned west and things got bad.  We had to ride 13 miles on interstate 80 which would of been okay but the first seven miles were under construction.  We rode on the closed road for a bit, but when we hit the actual construction we had to ride on the narrow shoulder right next to the highway traffic.  It was a little nerve wracking because the wind was blowing us all over the place.    We made it through the construction and struggled against the wind into Sinclair.  We stopped in a diner for breakfast, glad to be out of the wind for a few minutes.  Mary had a five or six year old boy who wouldn't leave her alone until she said hello to him.  She was saved by an older woman who thought he was cute. The next 10 miles into Rawlins were not fun.  The wind exacted its pound of flesh for the past few days of tailwinds.  It was a struggle to hold the bike steady.  Fortunately there wasn't any traffic. We pulled into a hotel in Rawlins and were very happy to be out of the wind.  The weather channel said it was 29 mph sustained winds with gusts up to 39 from the southwest.  Not pleasant when your going west. We ran into a couple of women who were riding the great divide mountain bike trail.  They were as sick of the wind as we were.  It sounded like they had been out of civilization for three days and were desperate for a shower. We visited the library and then ordered a pizza for dinner.  The wind was blowing so hard we couldn't light out stove.  It was a good end to a rough day. Quote of the day - "Yeah, we noticed we had a tailwind" - man at diner.  We asked if he was riding a bike.  No.  It was blowing so hard he had noticed it in his car. 
The first 10 miles were a little slow as we fought a crosswind and climbed over the continental divide. We dropped into the Great Basin and thankfully the wind died down.  We had a nice ride across the basin and then out the other side over the continental divide again.    At Muddy Gap the Wyoming dept. of transportation had a nice grove of trees.  We stopped and ate lunch in the first real trees we have seen in days.  A real treat. After Muddy Gap we turned west towards Jeffrey City.  The winds were still calm and it was nice traffic free riding. We stopped at Split Rock, a natural landmark on the Oregon Trail.  While stopped the wind found us.  The last eight miles were rough.  The wind was strong and it took us about an hour. Jeffrey City was a ghost town.  There used to be a uranium mine nearby, but that closed a while ago so the only thing left is a bar and the post office.  We stopped at the bar and had some ice cream.  Then we headed to the city park for the night.  It was just an old picnic shelter next to the highway.  It did provide shelter from the wind so we set up camp and hung out for the afternoon.    The only real adventure for the day was going to the bathroom.  There was a porta-john at the picnic shelter which did not have a door and faced the highway.  We tried to time our use with no traffic, but of course there were always cars going by.  Nothing to do but wave and laugh. About 6:30 another couple, Dave and Rebecca showed up who were riding east.  They had fought wind and hail most of the day.  That made us thankful that all we had to deal with was eight miles of headwind.  They had planned on starting their trip a month earlier, but Rebecca had been hit by a car and had a broken wrist. While talking to them we noticed that a fire had started in the ridge directly behind the city.  We weren't sure if we were in any kind of danger and being in the ghost town we weren't too sure anyone would come to the picnic shelter to warn the bikers they needed to get out of town.  The couple said they had talked to a guy in a store about 20 miles away and he said Jeffrey City wasn't in any danger.  We decided to spend the night. We talked to for a while swapping stories of what to expect next then went to bed early. Quote of the day - "Hard to believe that bike touring wasn't able to sustain the economy of Jeffrey City" - Rob commenting about the lack of businesses in town. 
   About 20 miles down the road we encountered the guy who Dave and Rebecca said they had seen and was riding the same direction they were, but had refused to talk to them.  He opened up to Rob and the bits of conversation I (Mary) overheard didn't really make any sense.  After a debreifing with Rob later (we met at a rest area and I had headed straight to the bathroom), it was confirmed that he wasn't really making sense. Rob: So how is the wind as we continue? Man: I'm not going to tell you any bad news. Rob: Well, it isn't going to keep us from going, we were just curious. Man: Nope - what you need to do is stare at two straight lines in the rock and not anything else. Rob: Okay????? Man: Yeah, just follow the Columbia; that's what I did.  Great bike shop in Lewiston! Rob: Okay, I've got to go now. Note that that guy was in full cotton sweats (not typical), and his entire shirt front was soaking wet. The rest of the ride was mostly downhill with mild wind (YEAH!).  As we rode the terrrain changed from bland to red rock formations and mountains.  It was becoming pretty.    We entered Lander a little before 11 and stopped for lunch.  Everything was so green.  We found out they were not in a drought.  Probably the first place we have been all summer where people didn't talk about how they needed rain. After three sets of bad directions we found the public library.  They were having a party for the reading club out front and the woman in charge was stirring a huge bucket of what looked to be dry ice.  Interesting.  I (Mary) took a nap at the picnic table across the street (under the guise of watching the bike) while Rob updated the web site. Lander was a nice town.  We were surprised to learn it is the headquarters of NOLS (National Outdoor Leadership School).  After a grocery store visit we headed nine miles out of town to camp.  There were two campgrounds to choose from and we probably made the wrong choice to get a few more miles down the road. First, there was absolutely no shade where the tents could be set up.
