We had to hang out at the front porch for the afternoon to try and get out of the sun. Second, surprisingly, it was windy. Third, "Ski" the dog that lived at the campground peed on our front painier, so everytime he came outside we had to follow him around to make sure he didn't do more damage to our stuff.    For sure a hotel tomorrow. We hung out in the shade until sun down then cooked a quick dinner and jumped in the tent for a good nights sleep. Quote of the day - "Were you in Lander earlier, I almost hit you with my red truck at the first light in town." - owner of campground.  We couldn't tell if he was making a joke or being serious.  We had no recollection of almost being hit, so it was probably a joke. 
When we started riding it was a nice day.  The first 35 miles went by quickly. We passed by Crowheart Butte, a rock formation that jutts about 700 ft about the Wind River.    We stopped in the town of Crowheart for some snacks and then headed on to  Dubois (pronounced DO-boys). We continued riding through the WINDY River Reservation, along the WIND river, next to the WINDY mountain range.  About five miles outside of Crowheart the weather started to get nasty. The wind picked up and was directly out of the west.  There were also some nasty looking clouds in the distance ahead of us. The last 30 miles of the ride were brutal.  We were working extremely hard just to move forward.  Then, as an added bonus we were hit with rain and hail. We limped in Dubois and practically collapsed into a hotel room. We went out for Mexican after some power naps and then called it a day. Thought of the day - Wyoming has pretty much beat the crap out of us so far. 
We packed up quickly and were on the road by 8:30.  On the way out of town we noticed Dubois seemed to be into extrememly large renditions of wild animals.  They had an enormous black bear, a huge moose, and a giant trout all in front of various businesses.  The best was a horse sized fake jackalope inside a convienence store that you could sit on and take pictures of. The riding was nice mostly because the wind was minimal.  We met an eastbound rider about five miles outside of town.  It was amazing to still see eastbound riders this late in the year. The next 25 miles we climbed over Togwatee Pass.  It was probably the steepest pass we've gone over in the Rockies.  There was a beautiful lake at the top of the pass.  In fact the whole ride today was getting prettier.  It was nice to be amongst pine trees again after a week of nothing but sage brush.    Once over the pass we flew along for the last 20+ miles.  Best of all the Tetons came into view.  They were a magnificent backdrop to the last half of the day.    We pulled into a campground with an excellent view of the mountains.  After a dip in the pool and hot tub we relaxed for the afternoon.  The relaxing consisted of visiting the mini-mart store at the campground repeatedly.  The people at the store must of thought we were feeding a family of 20 with the amount of food we bought.  We're still not sure why we couldn't of bought everything we needed in one trip. To end the day we were treated to a great sunset over the Tetons.    Quote of the day - "Do you need to ka-ka or do you want to go in the pool?" - father repeatedly asking his son what he wanted to do.  We voted for the ka-ka before going in the pool. 
We fell back asleep and didn't get up until the sun hit our tent at almost 8.  We took our time packing up and Mary made one more trip to the store for breakfast. We finally headed out about nine.  The ride was great for about three miles then we hit construction.  At the gatehouse to get into the Grand Teton National Park the ranger informed us it was National National Park Day so we could get in for free.  This seemed good, but also bad.  Free entrance probably meant more traffic. The first eight miles of riding in the park were under construction but it wasn't as bad as the pseudo mountain biking we had done in Colorado.  Once that was over we were able to enjoy the rest of the ride in the park on a narrow shoulder.  The views were beautiful and the riding was pleasant.    Next we exited the park and rode the seven miles between the Grant Tetons and Yellowstone.  The shoulder disappeared but it was a nice decent so were were able to fly along and the traffic wasn't too bad yet. Then we hit Yellowstone.  By far the worse traffic we have had on the entire trip.  The road was very narrow, no shoulder, and a majority of the vehicles on the road were massive RV's.  No one seemed to understand the pedal to the left was the break. We only had a few people drive too close.  Instead most of the drivers would swerve into oncoming traffic without so much as hitting their breaks to get around us.  It seemed like there was a near head-on collision every few minutes the entire time we were in the park.  All in all it was very difficult to enjoy scenery because it seemed like we were going to cause a fatal accident at any moment. The one time we were glad there were some cars in the park was when there was a big male bison lumbering down the opposite side of the road towards us.  People slammed their breaks on for that one.  A couple of guys in a 4-runner let us cower behind their truck as we went by the animal.  It was nice to have a couple tons of steel between us and the bison. It started us thinking it is amazing people will come to a grinding halt for a wild animal but won't so much as tap their breaks for a couple of people on a bike.  Maybe the threat of damage to their car is what makes them slow down.  It seems like cyclists could come up with some sort of marketing campaign that would make people want to slow down and take our picture.  Maybe riding naked. The rest of the ride was more of the same.  Terrible traffic, great scenery when would could actually look at it.    We pulled into Grant Village, nerves shot.  We ate at the restaraunt, bought some groceries and headed to the campground. We set up camp in the nicest site we've had all trip.  Woods all around, soft place to put the tent.  A good end to a bad day. We had both been looking forward to Yellowstone, but in reality, National Parks have evolved to be enjoyed from cars / RV's.  Bike touring just isn't very pleasant. We both decided we might come back sometime in a car and try to enjoy it a little more. Quote of the day - "Today is National Park Day, so you don't have to pay to get in." - Ranger at the entrance station.  We would of gladly paid a ton of money to stop the flow of RV's in the park.    
We slept in and the walked to the restaraunt for breakfast.  We enjoyed a great view of Lake Yellowstone while eating.  Then we hung out at the campsite until close to noon, packed up, and visited the visitor center.  They had a big exhibit on the 1988 fire that burned in 2/3 of the park. Around 1:30 we decided we would risk the 20 mile ride to Old Faithful.  If the traffic was too bad we would stop and wait it out.  It turned out to be a great ride.  There was a very small shoulder and the traffic was significantly lower. We rode over the continental divide two more times en-route to Old Faithful.  The riding was nice but it did rain on us a bit.    We hit Old Faithful and waited about an hour to see the geyser.  It was fun to people-watch.  Our bike attracted a lot of attention.  We've become used to it, but it made us realize it isn't exactly normal looking with the fully loaded bob. The geyser was amazing.  Definitly a highlite.  After, we headed down the road.  It continued to have a small shoulder and was mostly downhill.  We passed through fields of geysers and hot springs.  It was a surreal landscape.    From Madison Junction to West Yellowstone we saw a ton of elk hanging out near the Madison River.  We were hoping to see a moose but the elk were interesting also.    We crossed into Montana, our eighth state, and rolled into West Yellowstone.  Then it took a little while to find a place to stay.  The first couple of hotels we tried either didn't have anyone on the lobby to help us, or we couldn't find the lobby.  It was like the place was deserted.  On the third try we found a hotel with a lobbey, with someone working in it and checked in for the night. We went out for pizza and then called it a night. Quote of the day - "Oh, this one has a lobbey and someone in it.  Let's stay here!" - Mary getting excited that a hotel would actually take our money for the night. 
We slept in, watched TV, read the paper and finally ventured out close to noon.  We ate chineese and then went to the IMAX theater in town.  We saw a movie on bears.  It was pretty good, not too hoaky.  It made us glad we hadn't seen any bears while in the park. After the movie we stopped in a bike shop and in a moment of weakness decided we needed to get some clean water bottles.  Ours had been with us for more than 3000 miles and were growing some kind of unknown culture in them.  We invested in eight new ones.  Funny how something so little can make us both so happy.  (Note: we've had the new water bottles for five days now and we both feel much better.  We were probably slowly poisoning ourselves with the stuff growing in our old bottles.)    Then we went back to the room and relaxed for the rest of the day.  We used the hotel's communal kitchen to cook dinner and while doing that a really nasty storm showed up.  It hailed some decent sized hail for about 20 minutes.  It made us even more glad we had taken the day off. 
We left at 7:30 and it wasn't too cold or windy.  We were looking forward to the ride since it was supposed to be mostly downhill.  The riding was pretty and traffic was minimal as we headed out of West Yellowstone. We stopped at Quake Lake (a lake that was formed in August of 1959 by a 7.5 magnitude earthquake that clogged the Madison River) visitor center.  After a quick look at the exhibit and a visit to the foulest smelling bathrooms ever  (the stink was still in our noses 10 minutes after exiting the bathrooms) we headed down the road.    We made excellent time despite an annoying but not too strong headwind.  We stopped for lunch in the one-building bar / market / hotel / post office town of Cameran and learned that the wind was normally from the south, but just for us was out of the north for the day.  Just our luck. We finally stopped at a nice RV park in Ennis (like Tennis).  The best feature was a Dairy Queen across the street.  The sky threatened all afternoon and we ended up eating a hasty chewy spaghetti dinner due to our fear it would rain at any moment.  It was topped off with some yummy blizzards at the DQ. Quote of the day - "Are you riding that bike with your girlfriend?" - group of teenage boys at the Quake Lake Visitor Center that were swarming around our bike as we got ready to go.  They were very curious and impressed with the whole trip, but mostly they were impressed with our eight water bottles. 
The first ten miles of the ride was a 2000 ft climb up over a pass.  It was slow moving especially after moving along at close to 20 mph most of the previous day. We climbed over the top and zoomed into Virginia City.  We ate breakfast at a cafe in town.    Then we moved on towards Twin Bridges.  The riding was mostly downhill and we made good time.  A storm blew in as we were leaving town.  It gave us a nice tailwind so we just kept riding in the rain for a while.  It blew past us and changed into more of a headwind, but it was nice while it lasted. The last 20 miles of the ride we climbed over Pipestone Pass.  It was another 2000 ft. climb and at the end of a 90 mile day it was tough.  We also had to deal with another flat tire on the bob.  That's a total of five.  This time there was a small piece of metal that had sliced through the tire. We pulled into Butte feeling pretty beat.  There was a huge thunderstorm closing in on us also, so we just wanted to get out of the weather.  We checked into a hotel just as the sky opened up. Quote of the day - "On the map it shows this Silverbow campground before Pipestone Pass, why don't we stay there" - Rob thinking we could end the day about 15 miles before we did.  The campground never materialized, so we ended up having to go all the way to Butte. 
We took full advantage of the continental breakfast in the hotel before heading out.  The first 20 miles of the ride were on the interstate which was actually very nice riding.  There was a huge shoulder, it was mostly downhill, and the traffic was pretty light considering we were on a major highway. We had to deal with a little construction including the exit we needed to take being closed.  We decided to take it anyway and it turned out to be fine.  One advantage to a bike is you can usually skirt by any closed roads. Our next stop was in the town of Anaconda.  We stocked up on food and ate lunch in a park across from the store.  We had a couple of kids who were hitting golf balls come over and ask how far we could drive a golf ball.  They didn't understand that we had no idea how far we could hit a golf ball.  After hitting the golf balls for a while they must of been bored because then they started throwing their clubs at each other and at the shelter in the park.  We decided it was time to get out of there before we got hit with a golf club. On the way out of town we stopped at Sven's Bike Shop to get a new tire for the Bob.  We've had a total of six flats (one this morning) and the tire was shot.  Can't complain too much, we got about 4000 miles out of the tire. The last 15 miles were great riding along HWY 1.  It had a nice shoulder, minimal traffic and was a designated scenic drive. We ended the day at Georgetown Lake at a campground.  We set up the tent and had to immediately get in to avoid a thunderstorm.  It blew over fairly quickly so we were able to cook dinner.  Another storm blew in after dinner and kept up for most of the night.    Quote of the day - "Shade! You don't need shade!" - woman at the campground explaining why the tent sites had no trees.  I guess she thought everyone who camps in a tent must love sweating to death in the sun in their tent. 
The riding was great coming out of the campsite.  Huge pine trees, a deep canyon with a waterfall and a fun steep decent made for a lot of fun.    We continued downhill going through the town of Phillipsburg (saffire captiol of Montana or something like that), and then onward to Drummand.  We stopped at an interesting cafe in Drummand for lunch.  It was also the bus depot, a video rental shop, and apparently the place in town to hang out smoke, and make personal phone calls.  All in all a very strange atmosphere. The food was good though, and the milkshakes were excellent.  As we walked out of the cafe we ran into a couple of Mormons.  They were so fascinated with our bike and our trip they never even tried to convert us.  As we were talking to them we noticed a huge storm bearing down on the town. We used the storm as an excuse to get out of there before the conversion talk began.  We zipped along a frontage road next to I-90 and got away from the storm.    The frontage road was nice while it lasted, but it dead ended about 17 miles later.  We had to hop on the freeway for about 15 mils.  Again it wasn't too bad with the big shoulder, but the winds started blowing in our faces so we slowed down quite a bit. We got off I-90 in Clinton and rode another frontage road until about five miles outside of Missoula.  Then we had to get back on the highway for the last few miles.  Not too bad except for two bridges we had to cross that had NO SHOULDER! We would ride to the edge of the bridge and then sit and wait for traffic to stop coming and then sprint across the bridge as fast as we could go.  For anyone who has never ridden a fully loaded tandem, it is very difficult to get up to any kind of speed from a dead stop.  We managed to go from 0 to 30 in about 30 yards on both bridges.  The fear of death can get your butt moving when it has to. After the two bridges we were pretty wiped out so we were very happy to get off the highway and roll into town. We decided a near 100 mile day deserved a hotel.  We checked in and then did laundry at the coolest laundramat of the trip.  It had F-R-E-E soap, free internet access and a comfy couch to sit and watch tv.  We gave the Green Hanger five stars for laundry facilities. After dinner at Pizza Hut (our pizza sponsor of the trip - two out of three pizza's eaten on this trip have been Pizza Hut) we hit the sack. The hotel did have a vibrating bed but I (Rob) didn't want to make Mary car sick so we just went to sleep. Quote of the day - "This didn't seem like that kind of hotel." - Mary's reaction to seeing the vibrating bed. 
We stopped at Adventure Cycling Association's headquarters, but it was Sunday so they were closed.  We probably would of taken the day off to visit but they were going to be closed for Labor Day as well and we didn't want to take two days off.    The riding was slow today because we were fighting a headwind from the start and we were more of less climbing from the start. We passed through the town of Lolo and started moving towards Lolo Pass and Idaho.  We had heard traffic could be bad on HWY 12 but it was actually light for us.  Mostly people cruising around on motorcycles. We stopped at a picnic shelter and ate lunch.  It felt like we were back in the Pacific Northwest with the big evergreens and the lush ferns all over the place. Next we stopped at Lolo Hot Springs.  It was actually a pool filled with hot water from the springs.  After Yellowstone it was kind of anti-climatic.  For Mary the highlite was going to the bathroom.  They must of used the hot water from the springs to fill the toilets.  She came out very excited that the toilet water was toasty and steaming.  Ahhh... the little things.  Rob didn't get to try because the one men's stall was occupied. From there we climbed over Lolo Pass and entered Idaho.  We were very disappointed that there was not a sign welcoming us to a new state.  Idaho is lame.  We also entered the Pacific Time Zone so we are now are Seattle time.    We zipped down the other side of the pass and stopped at a market to get some rope to hang our food.  They didn't have any.  We decided we would ask someone at the campground to store it in their car for us.    We got to the campground and then it dawned on us that it was the Sunday of Labor Day weekend.  Not good timing for trying to get a campsite.  We got lucky and grabbed the last one in the park. We set up camp next to the river and then soaked our legs.  It turned out we didn't need to hang our food so we lucked out on that one as well. Quote of the day - "Yeeee hawwwwww!" - group of motorcyclists screaming out as we passed them coming down the pass.  This was accompanied with vigourous arm pumping.  (They were stopped in a rest area, we weren't coming down the pass fast enough to overtake motorcycles.) 
It turned out to be an amazing ride.  The entire ride was downhill, literally.  I was even better because the traffic was practically non-existant.  The only vehicle we noticed was a blue corvette with silver flames that passed us several times.    We made it to Lowell and stopped at a cafe for a late breakfast.  We had gone 60 miles in a little over three hours.  The blue corvette was parked out front and as the guy who owned it drove away the guys in the booth next to us mocked it for looking like a hot-wheels car. We pulled into the campground and it was another great site.  It was right on the Clearwater River, complete with a sandy beach.  We took a quick dip in the cool water and then spent most of the afternoon figuring out what was going on in the campsite next to ours.    There were about seven women, two men about about 15 kids, all dressed like it was against the law to show any skin.  In the end we decided it must be a polygamous marriage cult or something.  In addition to the weird male / female ratio they had a huge camper with a buick skylark parked like it had towed it into the site.  We could not figure out how a car that little had pulled such a big camper.  In the end we were disappointed when they used a big pick-up truck to take the camper away. We built a fire and made s'mores before heading to bed.  It was the first fire we built on the entire trip, mostly because it was the first place we had stayed that wasn't in an extreme drought. Quote of the day - "What is that supposed to be, a hot-wheel?" - guys at cafe mocking the blue corvette with silver flames. 
We had a great breakfast of oatmeal and hot chocolate (new mugs we had bought the day before).  It was the first warm morning we had had in a while which made it even nicer, although it was ironic since we actually we able to drink hot liquid for a change. We packed up and headed out for a short day to Kooskia (pronounced KOO-ski).  We were hoping the short distance would make it seem almost like a day off.  The riding continued to be downhill with light traffic but the gnats were terrible.  Within minutes of riding Rob was covered with little black bugs and it was pretty gross.  Another fringe benefit for Mary riding in the back, not as many bugs.  They continued for the entire ride which made us glad it was a short day.    We hit construction just before town but fortunately bypassed most of it when the flagger gave us a tip for getting into town by taking the first bridge.  The traffic was limited to one lane so we were surprised to see another couple coming towards us on bikes. The standard reaction when you see other bikers is to slow down and say hello.  Instead they just cruised right past us.  Strange.  Strange in many ways actually, why were they heading east so late in the year, why were they going against traffic in a construction zone that was one way, and why didn't they stop.  Probably because they noticed Rob was covered from head to toe in gnat guts. Upon reaching town we scored.  We were able to check into a hotel room at 10 AM and it was only $30 for the night and it had a kitchenette.  The grocery store, laundry, post office, hair stylist, and best internet access of the whole trip were all one block away.  Two thumbs up for Kooskia.  People were very friendly. At the grocery store we had a mild moment of panic when we noticed they didn't take ATM cards and we didn't know if we had enough cash.  Mary ran to the ATM and it wasn't in service.  Fortunately we had just enough cash to cover the costs. After that we hit the bank to get some travelers checks cashed.  The teller gave us all kinds of helpful info.  Where to eat, where to get Mary's hair cut, where to access the internet. Mary got her hair cut, Rob went to get online.  Later in the day we were able to pick up a package Rob's Mom had sent with AAA Washington information.  We didn't really think we would make it this far and suddenly we realized we needed more information on Washington.  Thanks Mom. We cooked up a good dinner in the hotel room, and called it a night.  It almost felt like a day off. Quote of the day - "People just don't give a rats finger about me!" - man in a commercial advertising something.  We were laughing too hard to notice what was being advertised. 
The scenery continued to be great but we couldn't enjoy it.  Route 12 turned out to be a nightmare.  The riding conditions were horrible.  There were semi trucks coming both directions continously.  To make it worse the road was along a winding river, and there was a three foot concrete wall about 10 inches away from the edge of the road.  It was more or less impossible to get out of the way of any kind of trafic.  At the end of 70 miles of this our nerves were shot.    We would our way through Lewiston and crossed the Snake River into Clarkston and our tenth state, Washington. We ran into another couple, Jesse and Beth who had started riding in Michigan and were going to Eugene.  They were actually moving to Eugene and everything they owned was on their bikes.  Certainly a strange way of moving. We invited them into our motel room and hung around swapping stories about our trips.  They had gone off route from the Adventure Cycling maps quite a bit so they had seen a lot of different stuff from us. We chilled out in our room for the night and hoped to have no more riding like today. Quote of the day - Just a long string of expletives from Rob getting totally frustrated with the road and traffic. 
The first ten miles of riding out of town were nice.  The road had a wide shoulder as it would next to the Snake River.  We also had a nice paper mill aroma which added to our pleasure. The next 12 miles or so we started climbing and went over Alpowa Summit.  The last seven miles were some of the steepest climbing we had done in a while.  We started down the other side and it started to rain.  It was only about 50 out, and the rain was cold.  It was a nice welcome to Washington.    We stopped at a cafe in Pomeroy.  We were hoping to wait out the rain but had no such luck.  We ate and then continued down route 12 which lost its shoulder just outside of town.  We were having flashbacks to the previous day. Luckily we turned off route 12 about ten miles out of town and it turned out to be a beautiful road.  As an added bonus the rain stopped and the sun came out. The last 20 miles of the day was great riding.  Almost no traffic, nice ups and downs.  We stopped in the town of Starbuck and the mini-mart.  The owner and one of the patrons sat and talked to us for quite a while.  They were both interesting and nice. We spent the night at Lyons Ferry State Park.  It was a great park, but sadly it will be closed at the end of the month permanently due to budget cuts.    For some excitement Mary got scared to death by a huge spider that crawled out of the shower drain.  It was about six inches across, with a body about the size of a half dollar. We cooked dinner and had a big owl hang out about 20 feet away.  It was the closest either of us had ever been to an owl.  It had big eyes and tufts coming off the tops of its ears, so it looked a little like our cat Sparky. Quote of the day - "Eiahhhh!" - Mary screaming at the top of her lungs when the spider crawled out of the shower drain. 
   After the first big climb we had some good up and down riding with more downs than ups.  We made good time to Connel and stopped at the mini-mart for lunch.  As we were sitting out front eating it seemed like the entire high school showed up for lunch.  They were all driving tricked out Hondas.  Most of them were going for the double corn dog lunch.  Our diets have been pretty bad for most of this trip, but we've never succomed to the mini-mart meat lunch. We continued on to Othello after lunch.  There was another big climb coming out of Connel.  We started riding through big potato fields and there were a lot of potato trucks flying by. The last 20 miles into Othello was along highway 17.  It was a busy road but there was a big shoulder so it didn't seem too bad. In Othello there were no camping options so we opted for an inexpensive hotel.  After doing laundry and eating dinner we sat and watching KING 5 news.  It made us realize that we were getting close to Seattle. 
We had to climb up over a ridge and then dropped down into another valley that was the edge of the Hanford Nuclear Site.  We had climbed up through huge apple orchards, but the drop into the valley was pretty desolate.  We were able to see Mount Adams in the distance which was exciting.    As we continued down the road the traffic started getting heavier and heavier.  It was okay at first, but we started to loose our shoulder.  About 30 miles into the ride we lost the shoulder completely. We had to deal with heavy truck traffic for the next ten miles.  We were basically riding down the road and either cringing as each truck drove by, or for the times there were trucks going both ways we would pull off the road into the thick gravel.  It wasn't very nice riding. The straw that broke us was the bridge crossing the Columbia.  It was another huge bridge with a very small shoulder.  We had to sit and time our crossing when there weren't any trucks coming along. We sprinted across the bridge and pulled into a rest area about 40 miles outside of Yakima.  The longer we sat there watching the traffic the more depressed we got.  It was going to be a miserable and dangerous last 40 miles to Yakima. In the end we decided that we didn't really want to get back on the road.  We made a call to some friends in Seattle (Stacey and Aram) who were unfortunate enough to be home when we called.  They agreed to get our car and come get us out in the middle of the state. We sat around the rest area for about three hours waiting for them to show up with the car.  It was a depressing feeling.  We both felt like we were giving up, but every time we looked at the road we didn't want to get back on it. Stacey and Aram showed up, we put the tandem on the top of the car and drove the last 200 miles back to Seattle.  Not quite the end we had envisioned, but it felt great to be home. Quote of the day - "Stacey, are you busy today?" - Rob asking for a ride home.  Kind of a sad moment, but certainly safer. 
After riding our bike across the country and having a great time, we decided we would make some sweeping generalizations.  It was good to see that there are still pockets in the U.S. that have their own uniqueness.  No McDonalds, no Wal-Mart.  Of course most of these places are very small and we wouldn't want to live there, but its nice to know they exist.  It was also nice to see that the majority of people are kind and helpful. Neither of us had any life changing epiphanies on the trip.  We did decide that taking a serious chunk of time off from normal life is a great thing.  We'll do it again sometime. Milestones we were excited and proud of: Crossing into Kentucky.  We didn't really think we'd make it that far. Crossing the Mississippi River. Hoosier Pass. Seeing the Tetons. Seeing Yellowstone and Old Faithful. Hitting Washington. We've had a few questions about best / worst things on the ride.  Here are some of the more common. Best Riding: Catawba Valley, Virginia. Worst Riding: Highway 12 from Kooskia to Lewiston, ID.  Close second was Yellowstone on National Parks Day. Favorite Part of the Ride: Grand Tetons Best Accomodations: Hotel Udovich Best Camping: Wild Goose Campground, Idaho Worst Accomodations: Pippa Passes Hostel, superdank, aka The Dungeon Most Unusual Accomodations: County Jail Shower in Marshfield, MO. Would we do this again: Probably not the same trip.  However, Mary has been reading about other tours in Adventure Cycling magazine, so we'll probably do another bike trip at some point in time. Lastly, a big thank you to Neil Gunton who created this web site.  It has turned out to be a wonderful way of keeping in touch while on the road.  It wouldn't of been the same trip without it. 
  However, almost every other traveller in India had the same idea, and my travel window was during the Christmas peak season.  Flights were very busy, and the only available flight dates left me a miniscule two weeks to visit.  To further complicate my life, I had to fly out of Chennai (the city formerly known as Madras), and return to Trivandrum.  At least I had a ticket. I wanted to ride around the island, but with only two weeks, this would mean having to ride insane distances each day, and have little time to stop. Something had to be cut out.  Where would be best to visit?  The beaches were in the south, the ancient ruins in the north, and the hill country was in the center.  I decided that I would first go to Colombo and buy a bike, visit the ancient cities in the north, ride to the east coast, and cut back through the hill country.   It was a bit ambitious for two weeks. 
For this trip, I brought the following: Pocket screwdriver/socket setAllen keysBike pumpPatch kit and tire ironsInner tubeCool tool (combination monkey wrench/chainbreak)Duct tape Two water bladders35 l daypack45 l hiking packstrap on cordura carrying casetoo much camera gear (one OM-2 with 28-200 Tamron zoom, one Pentax WR 90,  one tripod and 20 rolls of both exposed and unexposed film I'd been taking with me since Delhi)mosquito netpair of pantspair of shortsan unknown quantity of socks and underwearhiking bootsaqua socks      two t shirtsgortex jacketfleece jacketone good shirtsarongmedical kittoiletriesgroundsheetSri Lanka guidebookReading material (the Baghavad Gita, and the Mahabharata) a bronze statue I'd bought in India
After stepping out of the airport, I caught a taxi-rickshaw to Colombo.  I asked the tout in the rickshaw whether he knew a spot I could buy a bicycle.  Ordinarily, I wouldn't bother asking a tout, but time was short this trip. The tout told me that I was better off going to Negombo, and that he knew a few places.  We turned around, and headed to Negombo to go bike shopping.  There were many stores, with lots of bikes.  Two and a half hours later, I had a somewhat rusty mountain bike, some extra bungee cords, and an outrageous taxi bill.    After settling in, I took the bike out for a test spin.  While riding around Negombo, the rear derailleur popped a screw,  and bits of bike sprayed over the road.  I thought that I was missing a nut, and went off to a bike mechanic to find a suitable replacement.  As it turns out, I didn't and he reassembled the derailleur.   He didn't want any money, but I gave him 20 Rp as he spent some time reassembling it, while being eaten alive by mosquitoes.     That evening I went along the tourist strip to find a good meal.  My guesthouse was very close to the tourist drag, and I thought it would be easy to something to eat.  Earlier in the day,  I had found a place that served chicken biryani and a soft drink for about 100R.  On the strip, most of the restaurants wanted twice as much for just a fish curry.  After much checking, I found a greasy hole in the wall that served up a fish curry and rice, with an egg roti and a bottle of water for 130 r.    This was my first taste of local Sri Lankan food. When it comes to spiciness, Indian food has nothing on Sri Lankan food.  Sri Lankans like their food really hot, and I inhaled water trying to cool down the burning in my mouth.  Despite the fire, the food was delicious, and I thought dreamily of all the meals I would be eating in the coming days.  On the way back to the guesthouse,  I stopped at a small souvenir/gem store to buy some postcards.  The proprietor was very friendly, and both impressed and sympathetic that I planned to ride a bicycle around Sri Lanka.  We talked about Sri Lanka, where to go and where it was safe.  The Tamils and Sri Lankans had been honouring the ceasefire for almost a year, and the entire country was elated that it had lasted that long. According to him, most of the country was safe to travel in, and I should expect little difficulty. 
After a few kilometers, the road connected with the highway, and I once again had to deal with traffic and noise.  The highway was very busy, and almost completed built up with houses and shops on both sides of the road.  Mixed among the various food stores was a small bank with an ATM sign.  I stopped to try out the  ATM.  Half way around the world, in a country just emerging from fifteen years of civil war, and I got money out.  How things have changed! By ten, it was  hot and sunny, but not unbearably so.  It was very humid by that time, and each rest stop turned into a sweat stop.  I was getting hungry, and stopped by the first restaurant that met my criteria.  I have some rules of thumb on finding places to eat.  They seem to work, as I rarely have serious stomach troubles on the road, and generally get reasonably priced meals. 1) restaurant must have patrons.  Locals know where to eat. 2) restaurant dcor must be lacking.  Good food doesn't need good dcor.  Attractive settings tend to drive up prices, without improving the quality of the food. 3) any signs must be in the local lingo.  Tourists drive prices up, and are not good indicators of value in any place I've ever been. The restaurant I found was the typical hole in the wall, or in this case, a shack in the field.  Lacking anything like a sign, or a menu, for that matter, I almost passed it.  However, it was full of truck drivers. Perhaps the best indicator of good food that ever existed!  I ordered a fish curry, and some plain roti.  The proprietor also brought me a plate of assorted stuffed rotis, and I tried one of each.  The food was very good, and just what I needed.  Once again, there was an inferno in my mouth.  Sri Lankans do not hold back on spices! The rest of the day was spent riding along the coast to Puttalam.  Without any bike computer, I had to rely on the somewhat dubious kilometer stones on the side of the highway.  The good thing about riding in Sri Lanka, is that many locals cycle, so the markers show up every kilometer or so.   I arrived in Puttalam around 3 PM.  Not knowing how big the town was, I stopped at the first place I could find, and got a room there.  For 660 R, (about 12 CDN) I got a double room with a fan, private bath, and mosquito net. Surprisingly enough, I wasn't tired at all, and went out to visit the town.    Although Puttalam was a big dot on my map, it was little more than a two bike town.  I hadn't realized I had ridden to the center of town, and when I walked about to see the rest of the town, I discovered I had already seen most of it.  Making life worse was the fact that it was Friday, and a predominantly Muslim area, so almost everything was closed.  Surprisingly enough, the post office was open, and I was able to unburden myself of a few postcards. As there appeared to be no open restaurants in Puttalam, I ate at the hotel restaurant that evening.  Having developed a taste for fish curries, I ordered another.   It was good, but overpriced, given what I had been paying previously.  I think this hotel was used to having more upmarket overseas clientele than me. After dinner, I was too tired to do anything else, and it seemed unlikely there would be much nightlife in a small Muslim town.  It was bedtime, and I fell asleep instantly. 
It was very quiet, with no traffic at that hour, and I heard the cracks of branches breaking  in the jungle.  Was it really true that elephants were irritated by the high frequency squeaks from bikes?  I didn't want to find out the hard way, and pressed on. After twenty kilometers, the road descended and passed by a large lake.  I had hoped otherwise, but it became increasingly evident that the monsoon was not yet over..  Many of the trees were surrounded by water, and the road was disturbingly close to the edge of the lake.   It began to rain at this time.  Just light, fluffy rain, but still rain.   I was getting hungry, and stopped at a small restaurant, which turned out to be a bakery/soft drink shop.  I had a few pieces of passable cake,  and some Sprite.  There was a crate of empty bottles of the local brand of soft drink, and I made a mental note to try it soon.        I headed off, hoping to beat any downpours to Anaradhapura.  About twenty minutes later,   a downpour struck, and I pulled off the road and took shelter under the overhang of a small shop.  Two or three couples with motorbikes did the same, and we waited intently for the rain to slow.  It wasn't a bad downpour, and I was on the road again within 15 minutes.  By this point, I was only about 20 km from Anaradhapura, and wanted to get there as quickly as possible, so I could dry off. The rain struck again about 15 minutes later.  I was coming down hard, and forming small streams on the side of the road.  I tried to continue for a short distance, before realizing the futility of the situation. I could barely see ahead of me.  There was a store ahead with a convenient overhang, and I parked the bike there to wait for a break in the weather.  I bought some cookies from the proprietor, and sat down.  He barely spoke English, but explained that he had sent his son out to fetch his brother, who did.  Although I was thinking of leaving,  I didn't have the heart to, and waited patiently for his brother to arrive.      His brother arrived about fifteen minutes later.  He was a farmer/martial arts instructor who lived a few kilometers away.  As the rain dripped, we talked about Jackie Chan, the state of  the Sri Lankan economy, and most importantly, the weather.  He said the rains were later than usual this year, and I was just unlucky it was so wet.  This wouldn't be the last time I would hear that line. After the rain eased, I explained that I wanted to get to Anaradhapura before the rain started again, and hit the road.  It was only another ten kilometers to the outskirts of Anaradhapura.  The guesthouse I wanted to stay at was on the eastern side of the town, making it necessary to cut through the archeological site.      As I passed the museum and ticket booth, the guards waved me down.  I explained that I would get my ticket after getting a place to stay.  This was good enough, and they allowed me to pass.  The roads were hopelessly twisty, and my map in the guidebook was woefully inadequate.  Somehow, I ended up at the train station, where a taxi driver showed me the route to the guesthouse.  It was a crazy route that took a turnoff onto a dirt road, and  back onto the highway again.  I never would have found it on my own, and wondered how the owner stayed in business.   After I arrived, the owner said that he had no rooms, but if I could wait an hour, one would be available.  Because I wanted to go cycle around anyhow, we packed away my bag, and I rode back to the ancient city ruins.  It was much easier to find the second time around. As it was late in the day, I asked whether it was necessary to buy a ticket.  The guard said that he couldn't sell me a ticket that was good for two days, unless I wanted to buy two one day tickets.  There wasn't more than an hour or two of daylight and that would have made it a very expensive ticket.  It was better to quickly tour the site by bicycle to see what looked interesting, and buy the ticket the next day. The ruins were spread out over about 25 square km.  In theory, you need a valid ticket to go to any of the ruins in the site, but this seemed to be sporadically enforced.  Just in case, I headed to the site of the ancient cities because it was the least likely spot to get checked for a ticket.  The city ruins spread out over a large area, overgrown with trees and moss.  Even though the site has been restored, was really atmospheric.  That late in the day, I was the only person there.  My guesthouse was going to cook my dinner at eight, and it was only five.  I still had some time before the sunset, and rode into the modern part of town to look for some, err , pre dinner.   I stopped at the first promising restaurant, and asked how much it cost for a  5 l jug of water.  They told me it was 160 R, which was a far cry from the 100 R that I had paid in Negombo.  I really hate it when somebody tries to gouge you,  just because you're from out of town.  I took my business elsewhere.  Eventually, I found another restaurant, and ordered some fish curry and a ginger beer.  As usual, the curry was spicy hot and tasty.  I took a swig of the ginger beer and nearly jumped.  Whether it was because my mouth was already burning, or that the ginger beer had so much ginger in it, I don't know.  After my eyes stopped watering, I decided that it tasted pretty good, but I should be a bit more careful in the future. I returned back to my guesthouse, and ate yet another fish curry.  Somehow, this one seemed less spicy.  Was it the preparation, or had some of my tastebuds been burnt out?  I felt exhausted, and headed for my room.  The dinner was sucking all the blood out of my brain and into my stomach.   Once back in the room, I checked how my pack had fared after a day in the rain.  The water had permeated much of my gear, including my guidebook, map and clothing.  I spread everything out to dry, and collapsed into bed. 
  On the way up, I got distracted, and took a side trail.  This led past a small pool, and then to another flight of questionable looking stairs.  These steps led to a higher hill.  Some of the steps were gradually slipping away, others were eroding from hundreds of years of foot traffic.  In the time it took me to climb the steps, some low clouds had crept in and enshrouded the top of the hill.  The view was obscured by the clouds, and the stupa at the top was little more than a pile of neatly arranged bricks. Somewhat disappointed, I descended and headed back to the main complex. As I descended, I could make out the main dagoba through the trees.  The dagoba was impressive in scale, but didn't compare to what I had ridden past in Anaradhapura.  I walked past the main dagoba, and descended into the courtyard.  Here, I got into an argument with the ticket sellers.  They wanted me to buy a ticket for 250 R, and I said it wasn't worth it, and would just leave instead. This wasn't acceptable to them, as I had already seen some of the temple.   After much discussion, we agreed that I could make a donation of 100 R, and see the rest of the ruins. The main complex was also a bit of a let down, as the ruins were devoid of much sculpture or detailing.  I snapped a few photos, and headed back down to my bike.  While riding out of the site, I spotted a small stupa nearby.  Curious, I stopped and took a look.  This stupa had more intricate carvings than anything in Mihintale.  Of course, it was newer, and smaller, but I didn't care.  There was nobody,  Sri Lankans or tourists, at this stupa.  It made the trip out to Mihintale worthwhile.     It was nearing eleven by the time I got back to Anaradhapura.  Strangely enough, (at least for me) I didn't want to spend my time eating in a restaurant,  and bought some sugary snacks instead.  The ruins were huge, with much to see. To sum up, I saw lots of temples, dagobas, and the oldest tree on record in the world.  The monsoon struck while I was trying to see the sights, and I spent a good amount of time hiding under trees.  Overall, Anarudhapura was pretty impressive, and huge in scale.    On the way back to town, I stopped to take a photo of a dagoba.  A man on a bike stopped and offered his services.  This was an immediate clue that I was dealing with a tout.  Rather than go through the charade of making friends and ending up in a souvenir store,  I explained to him that I wasn't lost, did not need to buy anything, that he should not waste his time on me as I had little money, and he wasn't likely to get any of it anyhow.  He didn't seem to believe me, and spent the next two kilometers riding with me, trying his best to sell me some sort of service.  Eventually, I convinced him that I really wasn't interested in any of his services, and he left. By this time, I was almost back in town,  and went to look for some pre dinner.  For a change of pace, I ordered some egg hoppers.  These were bowl shaped pancakes with an egg cooked inside them.  They were very cheap, and filling, and perfect as a pre dinner appetizer.    When I got back to the guesthouse, I checked to see how my drying was coming along.  Before I had left, I hung up some of my wet clothing, and spread out some paper on the bed.  Nothing had really changed.  It was so humid that nothing had  really dried.  The best you could hope for is for things to get less wet. 
It seemed like the rain was slowing down when I set off.  In some places, the monsoon only lasts for an hour, and sometimes less.  I hoped the monsoon in Sri Lanka would be similar.  An hour later, I was still drenched, and the rain showed no signs of letting up.  As a word of warning to other hopeful cyclists, the monsoon in Sri Lanka can last all day.   I stopped at another shop, and proceeded to wring the water out of my gloves, and get a bit less wet. I instantly became the center of attention with all the other Sri Lankans taking shelter.  The proprietor got me some plastic bags, and some helpful Sri Lankans gave me a vague idea of how far it was to get to Habarana.  Unfortunately, their command of English was limited to a few phrases, and my Sinhalese was even more pathetic.  After half and hour, I was as less wet as I was ever going to get, and climbed on the bike again.  It was raining less than it had been before, so I would get wet a little more slowly.  The road was not heavily trafficked, and there would be an occasional stoppage of rain.  It was almost pleasant to ride during the breaks.  About an hour later, I arrived at the crossroads, and turned from the highway onto a much narrower, lumpier road. By this time, the rain had stopped, and I debated whether it would be good to continue or find a place to stay at the crossroads.  It was not even eleven, and soaked as I was, I decided to continue until I found a place.  I would just keep riding until I found a resthouse. I kept riding until I arrived in Habarana an hour later.  There was nothing between the crossroads and Habarana except the forest, and an occasional shop.  At one spot, the road had flooded, but not deeply enough to be impassable. In Habarana, the first hotel I checked at wanted 1500R for a single room, which was about three times more than I was willing to spend.  I crossed the street, and found a more run down guesthouse.  The hired help barely spoke English, but I managed to get a room for 500R, and lunch for an extra 75.  He said they only had fish curry, which was fine by me. The room was a bit grotty, but not bad.  A quick inventory of my stuff made me realize that everything got wet in my daypack.  My camera was  foggy, my flashlight refused to work, and my guidebook was all swollen.  I laid everything out to dry, even though it would not ever get close in the monsoon.  Lunch was calling. After a delicious lunch of fish curry,  I peeked my head outside. It was raining again, and coming down even worse than before.  I wanted to ride to Ritigila to see the ancient ruins there, but the route was supposed to be difficult in wet weather.  It still hadn't stopped after an hour, and I abandoned hope. To pass the time, I took a walk around the town, which took about a minute.  Habarana was small.  Even smaller than Puttalam.  The town extended 200 m in any direction from the crossroads, and then petered out into jungle.  Apart from watching people wait for the bus, there wasn't much in the way of entertainment. I wandered across the street to buy some biscuits and a bottle of ginger beer.  A local started talking to me, and we sat down for a ginger beer.  He was a long distance taxi driver, and was waiting for a fare.  The rain  continued to pour down, and he invited me to play some carom. Carom is a bit like playing pool with checkers.  The carom table is about three quarters meter square with four holes at each corner.  There are eight checkers for each side, and one neutral coloured checker.  Each side (two players per side) takes turns knocking their checkers into the corner holes.  You flick a 'cue' checker and try to knock one of your side's checkers into any of the corner holes.  To win, your side must sink its last checker and the neutral checker consecutively.  There's some more rules, but I wasn't entirely sure what they were.  This might explain all the losses. The rain kept coming down, and I kept losing at carom, but it was a great way to spend the afternoon.  I had to get back across the street for dinner, and was invited back to play carom in the evening.  Dinner at the guesthouse was delicious.  The owner of the guesthouse had returned and taken over from the daytime help.  He cooked a fantastic fish curry, and apologised because the fish wasn't fresh.  I didn't notice.   The owner told me that he had been living in Switzerland for five years as a hotelier.  He had come back to Sri Lanka, and owned this guesthouse and a small plantation in the south.  Most of his clientele were Sri Lankans who had got stuck overnight at the crossroads, and the occasional tourist like myself. He was also hoping that the peace would last, but was worried.  He also said there was nothing worth seeing in Batticaloa and warned me to be wary of wild elephants if I headed north to Trincomalee.   
I left at eightish for Sigiriya, and headed for a back road that was supposed to run by the site.  There wasn't much on the road except jungle and the occasional dirt road.  About ten kilometres in, I saw a dirt road and a sign for Sigiriya.  The dirt road continued straight, and abruptly ended in a river.  I could see the road on the other side of the river, but there was no bridge.  The monsoon was flooding everything.  I would have to ford the river.  Out of nowhere, a man appeared from behind me.  He told me I could get to Sigirya by backtracking and turning at a fork in the dirt road.   Eventually, I found the fork, and rode to the main site entrance, where several guides offered me their services. I politely declined, and entered the site.  Sigirya is a fortress on a sheer sided rock.  It was built as a safe haven by a prince who was paranoid of being attacked by his brother.  Eventually, his brother did attack him, and managed to lure the prince out of the fortress, and defeat the prince on the fields below.  The fortress survived, and was overrun by tourists, several hundred years later.    Sigiriya was impressive when you think of how difficult it must have been to build.  There isn't much more that can be said about the place, other than my camera died there.  I went to take a picture, and the camera refused.  The moisture wreaks havoc on any unsealed electronic items.  Beware! From Sigirya, I rode back to Habarana, had another great meal at the guesthouse, and headed to Ritigila.   It was threatening to rain, and I rode with determination to get to Ritigila.  The monsoon had flooded part of the road, but this was fordable.  The last three kilometers were on a very muddy dirt road, and I wished I had bought a bike with fenders.  The plastic bottle that I crushed  and taped to my rear rack just wasn't cutting it.  I was covered in red brown splatters of mud by the time I arrived at the site.    Ritigila was much quieter than I expected.  There were no tourists there, and the caretakers were making tea behind the office when I arrived.  I hired one of them to take me around the ruins.  Although Ritigila didn't have much to see, it did have lots of atmosphere.  It was a bit like scrabbling through the set of an Indiana Jones movie, with nobody but a guide for company, and thick jungle in every direction.   
I was worried for no reason whatsoever.  By the time I got to the elephant loitering zone, they were long gone.  The checkpoints waved me through, if they were manned at all, and it didn't rain the entire day.  How disappointing.  It's hard to be a pessimist when everything goes well.   Going from Habarana to Trincomalee was more tiring than I expected.  Even though it was cool, and overcast,  I was still exhausted by the time I got to Trinco.  The last 20 km may have done it, as the road was frighteningly bumpy, and hilly as well.  By the time I arrived in Trinco, I was tired of seeing  hills and jungle.    No, I was just plain tired. Being on a budget, I sought out a cheap hotel near the center of Trinco.  Most tourists want to stay near the beach at Nilaveli, but I was planning to put the bike on a bus and needed to be near the train or bus station.  And, with a bike, it is easy enough just to ride to the beach. In Trinco, I chose the cheapest place listed in the Lonely Planet guide, and went there.  Like many places listed in the LP, the owners had figured out that being listed meant there was a virtually endless stream of tourists coming anyhow, and raised its prices accordingly.   It was extortionate.  After asking about other hotels, and getting lost, I ended up near the bus station, and found a very cheap room.  You get what you pay for.  No mosquito nets, shared toilet and shower, and dubious sheets.  But, for 200 R, (about 4 CDN) it was the cheapest place I found in Sri Lanka.  At least the fan worked.   It was less humid, and I was almost able to dry (ok, make less wet) some laundry.    After a short power nap, I walked outside and headed to the park across from the guesthouse.  The dogs that were lazing about near the fence turned out to be spotted deer!  It seems that they are protected by the town and wander freely within the city limits.  Dutch beach was a close by, and a good place to walk amongst fishing boats, small herds of deer, and ubiquitous drink stands.     I got hungry, and headed back into town for fish curryand ginger beer.  Once again, I found a hole in the wall with low prices, low sanitary standards, and no holding back on the chilies.  I ordered a chicken breast, too, just for some variety.    Trincomalee itself was a fishing town turned military base. The military presence was everywhere, and the town was littered with barracks, bases, and checkpoints.  Apart from the occasional ruined building, the town had rebuilt, and there was a beautiful Hindu temple close to the hotel.  Though the atmosphere felt a bit oppressive, I took an instant liking to the town and was very glad to be staying more than one night.
    
Taking no chances, I woke at five, and headed to the bus station.  Like most bus stations in developing countries, it had no signs in any language that I could recognize. Finding the correct berth, if you could call it that, depended mostly on an unrecognizable attendant whose job it was to direct people to the correct bus.  Eventually I found him, and he told me that there would be a bus around six, and it would have a roof rack. There was a minibus getting ready to leave, but it would be impossible to stow the bike inside, or outside.  I would have to wait. I had read that the busses in Sri Lanka were nightmarish, with no storage space, and horrible crowding.  My thoughts started racing towards paranoia.  Not an uncommon trend, when you consider sitting in the dark without a clue where the bus is, and how you will load a bicycle and luggage on to it.  I started asking drivers of the busses with racks whether there were heading towards Polonnaruwa.  Nobody was.  I would have to take my chances with the yet unseen bus. Eventually, a rickety old bus pulled up.  It looked like it had been through a few wars, (and probably had) and was woefully lacking anything like a roof rack.  This would be my ride to Polonnaruwa.   I found the conductor, and explained to him that I had a bike with me.  He told me not to worry, and asked me to bring the bike inside the bus.  To my surprise, we got it inside, where we strapped it to a support pole on the aisle.   At least I was on, with my bike and gear.  But where would the crowds of people sit? My bike was blocking access to two rows of seats. Completely unexpected, the bus left.  I was expecting it to stay in the station until the bus was packed full, but this one left with half the seats empty.  I was now on my way to Polonnaruwa, with my bike inside, in a bus that was half empty.  And then the rain started.  Sometimes everything works.   While on the bus, I talked with the man sitting in the seat ahead of me.  He was heading to Batticaloa with his new wife.  They had been married for just a month, and he was already having second thoughts.  As it so often does, we talked about the political climate in Sri Lanka.  He was also hopeful of the peace process, but seemed to be hedging his bets when he asked me if I could sponsor him in Canada. We arrived in Polonnaruwa around mid morning and I was dropped off in front of the ancient ruins.  Instead of finding a guesthouse, the guesthouse owner found me.  He happened to be riding by when he saw me strapping gear to my bike.  I followed him along a dirt road out to the edge of town.  The guesthouse was close to the rice paddies, and peacefully far from the main road.  With attached bathrooms and mosquito nets in each room, it seemed like a palace compared to the place I had stayed in the previous night.   As I was running low on time,  I got settled quickly, and rode back to the ruins.  I got caught in a downpour, and waited under the eave of a building until it finished.  There was a really informative museum nearby, which was invaluable for introducing the history of the site.   Because these ruins were only 800 years old, they had much more detail work left.  I spent the rest of the day alternating between visiting ancient temples and hiding from the rain with drink sellers and site guards.  One of the guards tried to marry me to his sister and one of the drink touts offered to buy my bike.  Despite the bad weather, I thought these were the most impressive ruins in Sri Lanka.    It was nearing the end of the day.  I had just seen a very impressive set of huge Buddha images carved out solid stone, and was ready to head home.  I got on the bike, and felt the wheel lock just as I started pedalling.  The chain had snapped, and snagged on the derailleur.  The derailleur twisted itself around the spokes, was hopelessly bent out of shape.  This didn't look good.  A passing guard said the same thing, and directed me to a bike mechanic 2 km away.  He said I should hurry to get there, as it would be closing soon.      I rushed as best as I could with an unridable bike, and found the mechanic shop in the middle of nowhere.   They took one look and started working.  First, they bent the derailleur back into shape, and then pounded the chain links together (no chain break at this shop!)  with an metal plate and a hammer and pin.  All things considered, they did a great job, and charged me only 30 R. It was a tense ride back into town.  Would the chain snap again or was it the derailleur getting hooked on the spokes?   I rode slowly and carefully.  After a few kilometres, nothing had snapped or snagged, and I felt a sense of relief, at least for a little while.     After stopping for a brief pre-dinner snack of egg hoppers, I arrived back at the guesthouse.  His wife served up a delicious, yet slightly overpriced vegetarian curry.  There was a full house that night, with a couple of Brits, and three Germans.   I was planning to ride towards Batticaloa, and then cut down towards the hill country.  The owner said this wasn't a good idea, as the roads were not only terrible, but flooded as well.  The late monsoon had flooded the road to the east, and it was questionable whether it would be passable. Change of plans.  I decided to head towards Dambulla in the west, and possibly Kandy, or return early to Negombo.  The breakdown shook my confidence, and I wasn't sure if the bike would last all the way back.  I felt it was better to get closer to civilization, rather than head further into the countryside.  With only a few days left, I didn't want to miss my plane flight to India.  If I missed the flight, I'd miss my train, which would mean missing my flight to Dubai, and my flight to London Well you get the idea.  It would be bad to miss the first leg. 
This part of the country didn't really differ much from the rest of the country.  Lots of farms, low hills, and lakes.  There wasn't much traffic and the clouds kept the temperature cool enough to ride comfortably.  After an hour I felt better about the bike, and the rain hadn't yet arrived. About 20 km from Polonnaruwa, the road cut through a national park   The tended crops transformed to thick jungle, and I started thinking about wild elephants again.  Despite this, I felt an irresistable urge to sneak into the jungle, not only because I could get in the park for free, but also because I felt the call of nature.   I spotted a small trail off the main road, parked the bike, and walked the path to look for a convenient tree.  While standing about, and enjoying the vastness of the jungle, I heard the distinct sound of an automatic weapon going off in the distance.  This was followed by more gunfire, and small explosions. Was there a firefight going on?  It didn't sound like a training exercise, and I wasn't willing to find out if the ceasefire just got broken.  I could walk further into the jungle and find out, or I could just get on the bike and pretend I never heard it.  I remembered that expression about cats and curiosity,  and how it could apply to Curts as well.  Fear won out over stupid curiosity, and I hopped back on the bike.  After a few more kilometers, I was out of the national park.  It wasn't far to the crossroads.  I stopped quickly for some savoury, doughnut-like snacks (whose name I never did learn) and a few bottles of ginger beer.  And then, it was downhill.  The Brits were right!  It was almost effortless to pedal, and the sun came out too.  I was feeling great, and arrived in Dambulla at noon.    I went to a place that was recommended by the guesthouse owner in Polonnaruwa.  After seeing the room, I realized that the two must have been friends.  It was grotty and dark, and badly in need of renovations.  However, the price was right, and they had a restaurant that was recommended by the Lonely Planet.  It was only noon and I was getting hungry.  I ordered some lunch, and waited eagerly. I was clearly in a place that catered to tourists.  There were several small groups of tourists in the restaurant, all of whom were travelling on a higher budget than me.  They were clean, dressed in summer outfits, and sunburnt.    The meal itself was a huge disappointment.  It looked good, but that was about the best that could be said.  As it was spiced for tourists, I found it very bland, and had to ask the waiter for chili powder, or anything that would give it a bit of fire.  I had originally used the knife and fork provided, but went back to eating with my right hand because Sri Lankan food really does taste better when eaten that way.  There is a set of ancient Buddhist caves in Dambulla.  Although I was getting very tired of seeing ancient carved stones, I had nothing better to do that afternoon.  It was a fair hike up a few hundred steps to the caves, and hot in the in afternoon sun.  It was the weekend, and the staircase was crowded with Sri Lankans.  Because they were Sri Lankan tourists, it made the place feel less like a tourist trap, and more like a cultural event.   Inside the caves, there were several statues of Buddha, and countless painted images.  If you are not into Buddhist art, each Buddha looks very similar, and it can be hard to appreciate.  What made the caves special were the Sri Lankans that came.  It was a religious experience for many of them, and I felt like a bit of an intruder.  The sound of dripping water in an otherwise dark, silent cave full of praying people lent an eerie and  otherworldly atmosphere to the experience.     I went back to the guesthouse, and started writing some postcards when the power went out.  The owner said it was a common occurrence, and would be back on within the hour.  It flicked on again in fifteen minutes, lasted all of five minutes, and shut off again.  It came back on, and an hour later, shut off.  I started feeling tired and feverish, and went to my room to rest. By dinner time, I was not feeling any better, and could barely eat.  There was not supposed to be any malaria in Sri Lanka, but I started worrying.  Had I been bitten somewhere in India?  Was it dengue fever or something worse?  Or was it because I was just tired? 
The countryside started getting hillier, and it was still sunny.  The monsoon had finally left!  I might actually be able to dry something!  I had to stop frequently, for rest, ginger snaps, and the occasional king coconut but was really enjoying riding in the sunshine.  The last ten kilometres were along a terribly maintained, and hilly road, but I didn't care.    At the edge of Kegalle, I found a hotel that looked promising.  I asked the price, and the girl said it would be 1275 R for a single.  The manager overheard our conversation, and offered to discount a single room to 600 R, which was more of what I had in mind.  The room was clearly a step above what I was used to, as it had natural, and was really clean and quiet.  More than I wanted to spend, but more quality than I was expecting.  A good trade off. There was nothing to see worth mentioning in Kegalle.  Little more than an oversized truck stop, it didn't have much to entertain the average tourist, or local for that matter.  However, it was the closest town (if you could call it that) to the Pinewawa elephant orphanage.   The orphanage takes orphaned elephants and trains them for useful work.  A bit like a delinquency school for pachyderms.  I rode the 10 km to the orphanage, to arrive at what may have been the greatest concentration of tourist traps in Sri Lanka.  The road to hell is paved with good intentions, and the road to Pinewawa is paved with spice plantations, cold drink shops, and guesthouses.  I suddenly understood why my hotel was so quick to discount my room.  There was no question of missing the orphanage, as all the drink stops and kitsch shops seemed to congregate into a seething mass.   The orphanage was capitalizing on its fame, and souvenirs of just about anything elephant related could be purchased.  It was even possible to buy paper made from the dung of elephants.    This was my kind of souvenir.  I would have bought some except that it was extortionately priced by just about anyone's standards, good taste not withstanding. I bought a tourist ticket (marked up a mere 1000% of what the locals pay) and ran the gauntlet of restaurants and souvenir stores that sprouted from either side of the river road.  By the time I had arrived, the elephants were getting ready to be washed in the river, and a crowd of westerners and Sri Lankans had gathered at the numerous river view restaurants.     While seeing an elephant wasn't high on my list of priorities,  and seeing a bunch of them was only slightly higher,  it was a really enjoyable experience watching the elephants loll about and get washed by the mahouts.  They really are fascinating creatures to watch, as they walk funny and just sway about. With the afternoon spent,  I headed back to Kegalle, ate loads of ice cream, hoppers, and whatever else I could find, and turned in early.  With such a good room, it seemed like a waste not to spend any time in it. 
The congestion had gotten worse in the 45 minutes that it took me to eat breakfast.  After waiting for one of the infrequent breaks in traffic, I headed down the highway, and the traffic mysteriously trickled to nothing a few minutes later.  The sun was shining, it was comfortably cool, and I was heading downhill. Three kilometres later, the enjoyable part of the ride came to an end.  My chain was starting to pop out.  The fix done in Polonnaruwa was wearing out. I tightened up the chain link, and started riding again, only to have it loosen up a few hundred metres later.  I needed to replace the links, or the chain.  No stores had yet opened, and there wasn't a mechanic in sight. I had to pedal slowly, and push the bike when I hit an uphill section.  Sooner or later, I would pass an open store, or find a mechanic.  I found a mechanic first, but he knew little about mountain bikes and cracked the link trying to pound it into place.  It was better to have  a short working chain, than a long broken one, so I removed the link and continued on.  I found a bike store  twenty kilometres later, and got a Taiwanese chain.  The mechanic was too busy at that moment, so I did it myself, and drew a small crowd of spectators.   With only thirty km to go, the traffic got considerably worse, and I had three close calls.  Sri Lankans drive like maniacs, and I was very happy to be at the end of the trip.  The morning meal was weighing me down, and I was fatigued, hot, and thirsty.  Fortunately, there were plenty of people selling coconuts, and I made a small contribution to the livelihoods of several farmer in Sri Lanka.   The tourist ghetto was a bit north of Negombo, so I would need to cut through the centre of town. I rode through the core of Negombo, and I found rambutan!  These are red hairy fruits that are delicious.  The twenty that I bought didn't even last one day.   
  Colombo was a noisy, congested place. Downtown, there were plenty of old colonial style buildings, and dumpy, atmospheric markets.   I walked from the bus station to Galle road, passing several military checkpoints, touts, and traffic jams.  It was good to have nowhere I had to be, and nothing I had to see.      On the promenade at Galle road, it got really hot, I felt feverish again, and had a splitting headache.  I took a nap on the promenade, and spent the rest of the afternoon in a somewhat fruitless attempt to find more souvenirs.    I caught the bus to Negombo, and headed out for something to eat.  On the way, I stopped at the souvenir/gem store owner's shop to let him know I was back, and still alive. We chatted about my trip, and the future of Sri Lanka.  I told him I was selling the bike, and he said that he would buy it if I couldn't find anyone else to sell it to.  At least now, I had a backup plan. 
   My last day.  I had nothing to do except sell the bike, and find some rambutan.  In the morning, I headed to the old market in Negombo.  It was bustling, but I didn't find any rambutan.  There was plenty of fresh fish, but it would be difficult to get them through customs.  I circled the market a few times and then tried at the street corner where the seller was the day before.  No luck.  Whoever was selling rambutan was keeping it a secret.  I headed back to the market and was ready to give up, when one of the merchants found an old woman selling rambutan.  They were tiny, and overripe, but I didn't care.    Somebody was supposed to come at noon to look at the bike, but he didn't show up.  However, the guesthouse owner said he knew somebody who was interested.  He said I could take the bike for the afternoon, and sell it in the evening. Sensing a sting, I told him that I wanted to sell it this afternoon.  He called over his neighbour, who started trying to bargain me down.  I didn't tell them that I had an ace in the hole.  The neighbour figured that he had me, and wouldn't give me a decent price.  He thought he could get it for less, so I called his bluff, and packed the bike and left.   The gem store man and I swapped the bike for souvenirs.  He had made the offer earlier, and probably had a good idea of what might happen.  (To any of my friends who weren't happy with their Sri Lankan gift, you could have gotten a rusty shifter  or cog set!)  Because treated me fairly, I gave him my screwdriver set as well.  I was livid with the guesthouse neighbours, and would have rather given my bike a burial at sea than sell it to them.  When I returned, they seemed genuinely surprised when I said I sold the bike, and still tried to offer me an outrageously low price, despite the fact that I was walking to the guesthouse.  The bike was gone, and now I had a bag of souvenirs to take home. 
This line was to pay the airport departure tax.  Colombo was one of the last spots on the planet that collects the tax at the airport, and only accepted Sri Lankan rupee.  Be warned, should you come this way.  One unsuspecting traveller in the line did not know this, and had to go back outside the security check to get some local currency.  I wonder if he made his flight. Finally, I made it to the cashier, and paid my tax.  Then it was time to stand in the passport control line, followed by the baggage check line, followed by the final passport stamp checkline.  It had taken nearly two hours to jump through all the hoops.  I sat down, exhausted, and looked in my bag for a snack. As I cracked open the last of my rambutan, I heard a voice ask me what I was eating.  I looked up, and saw Jeff, a fellow Canadian.  He had been part of the group of Canadians that I spent Christmas day with back in India.  He was a friend of a friend of a friend (how's that for a tenuous relationship)  and just transiting through Sri Lanka on his way to Bangkok.  He had just arrived, and had a flight out in fifteen minutes.  It is indeed a small world.       After saying goodbye, I went catch my own flight.  Once again, it was time to wait in line.  This time, I had to get my luggage checked, then get my passport and ticket checked and then get my luggage checked again.  After so much security, it seemed almost anticlimactic to just step on the plane.   The flight was uneventful, and short.  Once in Trivandrum, I caught a cab to the train station, and checked for my train.  It was leaving the next day, but I wanted to be sure where to catch it. The schedules posted made no mention of the train number, so I checked with the information office.  The man told me the train left from Ernakalum, 200 km north.  I purchased a ticket north, and hopped the first train I could.  But that's another story. 
Cycling is very common, so it is easy to find bike shops and mechanics throughout the country.  However, having cyclists on the road doesn't necessarily mean that the drivers are any better.  The roads within a 30 km radius of Colombo (the main city) are crowded and very hazardous, as drivers will expect a cyclist (or any vehicle smaller than them) to get off the road if they want to pass. There's lots to see and do in Sri Lanka, and even people not associated with the tourist industry are warm and friendly.  And the food...fiery hot, but really tasty.  I'd go again just for that. 
   We have done several small tours in the past and have always looked forward to having the time to ride across our country.  One day Sandy said, "When are we going to do that ride we've been talking about?"  There's no time like the present, so.... now we have to get in shape!!! We are experienced cycle tourists, and we have most of the equipment we will need but some of it is old and in need of repair or updating. The first thing we needed to do was get a bike that we could ship easily. The Bicycle Outfitter in Los Altos was where we went to test ride new tandems. Our new bike is a Santana Arriva set up with S&S coupling, and all the necessary accessories for long distance loaded touring.    On our last trip we borrowed a friends trailer and really felt that having some of the weight on the trailer made for a much more enjoyable ride. When discussing the difficulty getting a trailer that would fit the extra wide dropouts on our new bike, an acquaintance (who happens to work at Yakima) suggested that we might be able to test out one of their prototypes with the wide spacing. We are looking forward to its completion so we can start getting used to hauling it around on our training rides. Planning and organizing has been great fun.  Hope the trip is equally fun!!!   
   We just picked up our new Yakima Big Tow trailer, and today's inaugural ride went perfectly. The people at Yakima had to develop a new yoke to fit the wider 160mm dropouts on our Santana tandem. We really like the way the trailer looks and the handling behind the bike was as if it wasn't there, but there must have been a flat on the bike 'cause we went a bit slower! All of the gear we want to stow in the trailer fit in the bag with room to spare. Riding around with a trailer sure gets more attention.
