We feel kind of silly when we have to say we've only gone 20 miles and we are back home after a training ride. People expect us to be out on a big trek and we will be home in our own bed tonight.    Show links to this Hide links to this     
   Show links to this Hide links to this      Our route today was relatively flat but we still spent a lot of time in our small chainring. Having the touring mindset helps, slow and steady all the way. When we got to Arcata there were so many people in town for Humboldt state's graduation that we got even more attention than our first ride with the trailer last week. It really is fun having so many people ask about the bike, trailer and all the gear. The children especially love Tigger our leader   
  

After getting to the island we still had 20 miles to reach the campground which made for a bit of a long first day.   
In the morning we had a quick ride north to the ferry terminal so Dick and Heidi could head home, and we continued north toward Anacortes. We enjoyed the islands scenery but the hills were a bit of a challenge. Training, what training? In Oak Harbor we found a bike shop and got info about routes and a new chain to replace the one John had fouled up installing in Seattle. Unfortunately the county maps we bought didn't have the correct names of the roads. Alas, the great directions about missing a wicked hill did us no good. More character building!! Deception pass Campground.......NOISY NAVY FLY BOYS!!!!!! otherwise not so bad.   
It is nice to be off the Island, much flatter terrain this morning. Threatening weather but dry. We stopped in Burlington at the C of C visitors center to find out about laundry and library. While inside the sky opened up and a deluge came down..while we were inside. There was no internet access in town so Karr at the C of C let us use her computer to E-mail our moms. With the threatening weather we decided to stop at the KOA outside of town and get a cabin, do laundry, and soak in the hot tub. A great luxurious night all together.   

  
As we approached the top of Rainy Pass, it started to lightly snow, continuing until we started to descend after Washington Pass. We had never really ridden in snow before so that was fun...but also cold on the descent. We put on lots of layers of clothing for the descent; some other cyclists didn't have enough and could barely control their bikes on the downhill. We stopped at Mazama for some warm coffee, then on to Winthrop for a well deserved day off.   
We visited for a while with a group of recumbent riders who rode over the passes one day, rested a day, then were planning to ride back over again, fully loaded with gear, as a training ride for their upcoming tour.  It was fun chatting with other cyclists.   
The afternoon was hot but we had an incredible tailwind until we stopped. We really made up some miles quickly. Our tent held up to the wind but we have never camped in stronger winds anywhere before. We met fellow EB(eastbound)tourists, Marge and Terry, today at the store in Riverside. They pushed on a bit further tonight to get closer to tomorrows climb.   
As we approached the top we kept hearing thunder and the sky was getting very threatening behind us. We got over the top before the rain started and pulled into a lumber yard and waited out the rain and hail under the plywood shed. We found a library in town and then moseyed out to the fairgrounds for a hot shower and a great nights sleep. We saw Marge and Terry today a couple of times and they camped at the fairgrounds too.   
As we reached the top it started to sprinkle. We hurried down and stayed ahead of it all the way to Colville. We dodged the rain yet one more time. Camped at the fairgrounds in Colville. Very interesting with all the preparations for the upcoming rodeo. The whole campground was full of horse trailers and kids, big and small, on horses.   
We still had plenty of climbing today but nothing like the past few days. We came out at the Pend Oreille River, which was a bit confusing because it runs north. We followed the river south and found a great campground with laundry, showers and soft grass for our tent. Everything we needed.   
We got into Newport about noon and stocked up for the rest of the day at our ever handy Safeway. As we headed out of town we started noticing the Idaho plates and helmetless motorcycle riders. How did we get into Idaho without knowing? How hot is it??!! We pushed through the heat and hills to Mosquito, we mean Round Lake State Park. It was nice except for, did we mention the mosquitoes?   
We rode down a side street and encountered another cycle tourist.  It turned out to be Dave Bowen, who we met through this website prior to our trip.  It was nice to finally meet him face to face. What a coincidence! We stayed at a great (and inexpensive)motel called the K2 Inn right downtown.  We ran into Marge & Terry again, staying at the same place.  We spent the day doing errands, shopping, eating ice cream, and generally goofing off.  It was wonderful to sleep on a REAL BED!   
Oh no! Glacier is closed?! At the campground we heard that Logan Pass in Glacier Nat'l Park will probably be closed until July.  No "Going To The Sun Highway" for us this time. They are having problems with heavy snowfall and avalanches. Maybe next year.... hey, Loren & Greg...we need to talk about next summer!   
   Highway 200 was nice and fairly flat, with light traffic.  It followed the Clark Fork through a beautiful valley bordered by fantastic sheer rock mountains, some still sprinkled with snow. Hooray! We finally found a place that would let us upload our pictures to this website.  Thank you, thank you, Crazy Ernie!
Luxurious night with king size bed, hot spa, tavern and a restaurant.  What more could a touring cyclist want?   
   In Missoula we stopped at the Smoke Jumpers Center and took a tour of their facility.  That made up for missing the one that was closed in Winthrop.
  There were all the services that we could have desired in Missoula. Shoe repair,maps,restaurants, and we even got to go to the REI store and replace a few needed items. We had dinner with Jackie and Dave, they are heading east tomorrow and we will be going to the south before heading east.
  We stopped to take a tour of the Marcus Daly mansion outside Hamilton. Daly was one of the Copper barons and the history was very interesting. Even with the time spent touring we got to camp fairly early and dodged the afternoon thunderstorms again.   
We started dinner early, when the thunder started up. We ended up eating in the tent and we let the rain rinse out the dishes. The hot tub helped ease our muscles and kept us out of the rain too. We are really beginning to love the good old KOA's   
We were a little disappointed at the descent.  We expected a screaming downhill, but it turned out to be a gradual grade and we had to pedal!! About halfway down we stopped at the Big Hole Battlefield Monument where the army engaged the Nez Perce Indians.  The most memorable thing for us was the most tenacious, vicious mosquitoes we ever met. We couldn't take any more stops because the little buggers were everywhere!  They could keep up with us at 12 MPH so we had to go faster to avoid them.  That wasn't always easy on the uphills! Jackson is a tiny town with basically 2 taverns and a hot springs lodge. Another night of soaking in wonderfully hot water!    Show links to this Hide links to this     
   We got a nice descent this time, into Dillon.  This is the first real city we've come to since leaving Missoula, therefore we're using the library's computers, went to the supermarket, and did laundry too.  We went to 7 Peaks internet service on South Montana St to upload our pictures.  It's difficult to find a place that will let us upload our images.   
  
  
It was a nice ride into West Yellowstone skirting a lake with rolling terrain and beautiful scenery.  After taking care of some errands we rode 14 more miles into Yellowstone Park to Madison Junction where we camped.  The roads had good shoulders, traffic was moderate, and we saw a bull moose and a bald eagle nest with a fledgling that was testing his wings before his first flight. Of course, it wouldn't be a national park without RVs and crowds.     
The rest of the day was spent climbing toward our next campground, crossing the Continental Divide twice.  It was slow going, with lots of traffic and barely adequate shoulders. We're starting to see more cycle tourists both east and west bound.   
        
  
  
  
Cody was in the midst of their 4th of July and rodeo celebrations. It was a bit hectic and crowded but everyone was in good spirits and having fun. We missed the parade but we had to work to miss what the horses left on the roads.  We had to hurry out to the campground when the weather started to threaten rain. It never did do anything but sprinkle and we got set up with no problems. We were in the most expensive KOA we've ever seen and also the most crowded, but at least there was room for us and we got free pancakes the next morning.   
We were riding by 7:30 but it was already warm. By 9:00 it was hot by our standards. The most interesting thing about the terrain was the road junk. We added 4 license plates to our collection, pretty good for one 40 mile stretch. The scenery was just rolling hills with nothing but sage brush growing anywhere. Every once in a while there would be an irrigated area but they were few and widely spaced. The Root Beer floats at Greybull were very welcome. Even at noon it was very hot and we spent the rest of the day just trying to stay out of the sun and stay cool. It was too hot to cook so we found a nice air conditioned restaurant to eat at and tried to get to bed early so we could get a very early start for tomorrow's climb. The local fireworks display was visible right from the window of our tent, very pretty but not conducive to a good night's rest.   
The Shell Canyon is very beautiful where the river cut into the mountains. The colors and rock formations were incredible. The biggest problem was that we had to climb up the canyon and it was relentless. Never a break, not even a lessening of the grade, just a steady, sun drenched, 18 miles at 6%, with 6000 feet of elevation gain. We took numerous breaks to rest all the various parts of our bodies that were rebelling. We did it though and are we glad that is over. It was by far the most difficult day of our trip if not our entire cycling lives.     
We went through Ranchester to Sheridan where we spent the evening with Bob,Judy and their family who we met through our tandem club.  We had a fabulous dinner and a relaxing and enjoyable evening getting to know them all better.   
In Buffalo we got a motel room, found an all-night diner so we could get an early start on tomorrow's long hot day.  No cooking breakfast, no packing up camp, just riding at first light. In the middle of the night we were awakened by the biggest and loudest thunderstorm we've ever seen.  It was exhilarating, frightening, and beautiful and it made us very glad we weren't in our tent.   
  
After leaving Moorcroft, we turned north into a moderate wind and started climbing through rolling hills toward Devils Tower.  The wind actually made the heat bearable.  We got glimpses of the Tower from about 12 miles out, and we enjoyed the beautiful red rock canyon as we continued to climb. We found a shady campsite at the KOA which was at the base of Devil's Tower.  Every night at 9:00 (too late for us) they show "Close Encounters of the 3rd Kind" on an outdoor screen.  Our campsite just happened to be the closest one to the movie... thank goodness for earplugs!   
Spearfish is the nicest city we've been in for quite a while.  John made the comment,"This is my favorite city in all of Wyoming!"  Uh, John, this is South Dakota!    Next to the campground was a fantastic Mexican restaurant (The Guadalajara), and the friendly women at the visitor center directed us to their very modern library, a bike shop, and a barbershop.  Everyone was extremely nice and very helpful.
   Deadwood is really into their history (Calamity Jane, Wild Bill Hickok, etc.) but it looked like a tacky version of "Old West Las Vegas" to us.  Upstairs in Miss Kitty's casino we found a Chinese restaurant.  In view of the slot machines, we ate our Kung Pao chicken while listening to the "Lovin Spoonful" and various other oldies.  Weird!!
   It was fun riding over the trestles and we loved those nice cool tunnels!       The total trail is 109 miles and we rode about half of it to Hill City.
   It was too hot, even in an air conditioned car to fully appreciate the natural beauty of it.  It was embarrassing to be so wiped out by the heat that we couldn't really experience it.    Back to the Black Hills where it was (somewhat) cooler.  Mount Rushmore was very interesting and we enjoyed learning about why and how the monument was constructed.    On to Crazy Horse.  Another incredible monument being carved into a mountain.  The story was interesting, but we were even more burned out than we were in the Badlands. We got back into Hill City in time to upload our pictures for the whole last week (it's often difficult to find a place to upload our pictures- libraries usually just let us do text). We didn't ride a single mile, but we were exhausted at the end of the day.
  
  passing the 2000 mile mark in the process.  The day got hotter--another 110 degree day. We killed time in the bizarre coolness of the Wall Drug tourist shops.  What a zoo!  And SO tacky!   
We arrived in Midland by 10:30 and got a tiny motel room to wait out the heat.  We couldn't bear the thought of camping in this heat.  When John loses his appetite, you know things are getting bad!  Another day of 110 degrees!  And no relief in sight!   
  
The weather is cooler today and we are hoping for a bit of a reprieve when we continue tomorrow.   
  Today's ride was much cooler, with an overcast sky all day. The headwind helped keep us cool too, even though it was a bit humid. Instead of grazing cattle, we saw fields of corn and sunflowers and the terrain was pretty flat.  In Gettysburg we were told it's OK to camp at the city park, which also has showers.  Everyone here is super friendly and helpful...and the library is air conditioned.      We had fun tonight watching the local boys play a double header against the team from Pierre. Not the greatest quality baseball but something to do as we waited for the temps and sun to go down. We're still heading north and east, and will probably leave South Dakota in 4 days or so.
We discovered a crack in our rear rim as we came into town and the ladies at the drug store helped us find a bike shop in the next town, Aberdeen. They didn't have 48 hole rim so we contacted Jack Goertz at Tandems Limited in Alabama and he is overnighting a rim to the shop. We think we can ride on the rim so we will head to Aberdeen tomorrow. As it got later in the evening we had to get into our hot tent and try to sleep. Which is worse, heat because the screens are up or bugs because you take down the screens to try to get the nonexistent airflow??!!  We had been told that there was a cold front coming to help ease the temps some. We weren't told it would hit at 2:30 AM and have 60 mph winds. The tent held together fine after we actually put the tent stakes into the ground properly, in the dark, wind and rain. It was a bit scary for us coastal residents, unused to intense thunder storms. At least the lightning wasn't real close and we were mostly worried about the wind. Needless to say sleep was a hard to find comfort during a night of heat, bugs, wind, rain, and thunder.   
Trying to straighten out the crack in the rim seems to have exacerbated the problem and we now have piece of the rim in our tool bag!!! After pushing the bike to the cafe and having a great breakfast, we put out the sign that the cook helped us make and had a ride in about 5 minutes.    Tom was heading to Aberdeen to get building supplies in his truck and helped load our wounded bike into his truck for the 1 hour drive. Thanks Tom... again we find that the people in our wonderful country are friendly, and caring.    After getting to Aberdeen a local resident pointed us to a great bargain motel and we have settled down to await our rim from Alabama (Tuesday). More Tour de France on TV, go Lance go.
Although we didn't ride, we walked about 6 miles in town.  After doing errands, we walked the couple miles to the mall, picked up a few item we needed, and watched a movie.  "Men in Black 2" is pretty silly, but it was a good way to pass some time.

Now in North Dakota, we have gone through 6 states and 3 time zones.   
We passed more corn fields and sunflower fields and had an uneventful ride to Enderlin.  Everywhere we stopped we were approached by people asking about our trip.  At one point we thought we may never be able to leave the grocery store's parking lot! While in the library in Enderlin, we were even interviewed and photographed by the local newspaper, "The Enderlin Independent". The tandem & trailer attract a lot of interest and it's fun sharing our trip with everyone.   
  We rode past more corn and sunflower fields, passing Enderlin's huge sunflower processing plant (the world's largest according to locals).  Along the way we stopped for cold sodas ("pop" out here) at the Knickerbocker Liquor Locker (we love that name!).  The young bartender gave us free pop and good advice about finding our way around Fargo (another city with a lot of road construction). We crossed the Red River into Moorhead, Minnesota, where we found a campground with showers and laundry facilities.
  The view from the cabin was fabulous, with the sun setting into Ice Cracking Lake.   
We headed to Lake Itasca which is the headwaters of the Mississippi River.  We were 7 miles away when we encountered a road closure with construction (we can't blame the ACA for this one!).  There had been no signs warning us about a closure or detour.  Now what?  It was a 20 mile detour so we decided to ride through the 5 miles of the construction zone.  Being Sunday, there was no work being done.  At first the road looked impassable.  We could hardly push the bike through the thick soft sand.  It seemed impossible.  We flagged down a passing car and asked about the road.  The driver said he would unload his car at his home and come back to give us a ride.  He came back and reported that the really bad part was minimal and that most of it was hard packed dirt.  We decided to go for it.  We walked and pushed some, rode some, slid and swerved some, and finally made it to the Mississippi River (which was the size of the creek in our back yard!).    We cruised into Laporte and asked about camping.  The woman in the store said we could pitch our tent behind her laundromat which had bathrooms, sink, tables, benches, and laundry facilities--everything we needed.
  We checked out the national forest campground at Mable Lake, but since it only had pit toilets, no showers, and lots of mosquitoes and poison ivy, we rode on to Remer.  There we found a nice campsite in town.  This town, like most small towns that we've passed through in Minnesota, had no library, but a man we met in a cafe offered the use of his computer.
The Floodwood campground was on the Savannah River, so we got a motel room,  no mosquitoes there.   
Back on the road we had an uneventful ride into Duluth.  We stopped at the library for information.  Before we even entered, we had half a dozen people come up and offer information and help.  It's surprising that the big city seems more friendly than the small towns in Minnesota.   
  When we arrived at the waterfront the 2 masted tall ship Niagara was just coming into the harbor. It was very festive with so many people watching and the ship firing it's cannnons. We had perfect weather to wander around and enjoy the old town and the lakewalk. They have a beautiful harbor and there were tons of people just like us wandering around and enjoying the sights.  We have been looking forward to seeing Duluth ever since we started planning our trip. Duluth came up in many, many different contexts as we talked to people about our plans and it was always portrayed in a very positive manner. We have found it has lived up to our expectations so far.
We had a nice time, but overall we wished we had been on the bicycle heading east.   
Once in Superior we found the paved Osaugie Trail which ran east through town.  When it ended we picked up the Tri Counties Corridor, a packed gravel trail that could take us all the way to Ashland.  The surface was good, but we couldn't make as good time as on the highway, so we rode on Hwy 2, using the trail only to bypass the 8 miles of construction. We spent about an hour under a picnic shelter in Brule while a thunder storm passed through.  we met Jim from Victoria, BC and leapfrogged with him all day along the highway. We were told of a nice campground on the shore of Lake Superior, but when we got there, guess what?! NO TENTS ALLOWED!!!  We had to backtrack through town to find another spot to camp and we shared a site with Jim.  Today was the first day we actually had to ride, make camp, or cook in the rain, and we had to do all three.  After 2 months and 2800 miles we had a little light rain on our parade.   
In Ironwood we met Sandy and Arlyn who hosted us.  We had a nice time getting to know them and talking about bikes and touring.  The comfort of their home was wonderful, especially after our previous wet night in the city park.   
Midway through the day we broke a rear spoke.  The combination of the rough roads and the inexpertly rebuilt wheel took its toll.  We knew the wheel was not perfect, but we had hoped it was good enough.  Not quite.  After some minimal roadside adjustments we rode on. When we arrived at Boyd's, he was as happy to see us as we were to see him.  He thought he may have to rescue us.  With his help, we repaired the wheel then spent an enjoyable evening getting to know him.  Needless to say, these two cyclists slept very well.   
  It seemed like a short day today, only riding 50 miles.  We rode leisurely along our old friend, Bumpy Hwy 2 through Crystal Falls and Florence.     We celebrated our 3000th mile with rootbeer floats and had a relaxing evening working out the kinks from yesterday's ride. 
The highlight of the day was crossing into the eastern time zone.  We pulled into Pioneer Trail Campground on the Escanaba River and found a flat, quiet, bugless site to pitch our tent.  This is one of the best campsites we've had in months.   
  We rolled on another 20 miles and stopped just short of Blaney Park for the night.   
  
  The island was pretty, with interesting historical and geological features, but if you want to enter the sites, get out your wallet!  We enjoyed riding around the island, no cars allowed made the riding pleasant.  By the time we got back to town there were so many people we could hardly move.  We had thought we'd walk around and look at the shops, but with the crowds we fled to the dock where we got an inadequate, overpriced lunch and left. Once in Mackinaw City we realized we needed to get away from the hustle and bustle so we rode down Hwy 23 to Cheboygan State Park.   
We ended the day at Rogers City.  The weather was still and comfortable until we got off the bike and realized it was a warm 90 degrees.   
  We cruised along the back roads for about 20 miles, rejoining Hwy 23 at Alpena.  In Alpena we stopped at the library and at a bike shop to pick up a spare tire.  we didn't realize how hot it was until we got off the bike and the humidity closed in on us.  We were immediately soaking wet. Coming out of the library we saw it had rained a little so we hurried on down the road to the campground before any storms hit.  As it turned out, the storm never did materialize. 
We stopped in Harrisville at a great little cafe for some juice and pastry.  We also got good route advice from a local cyclist.  After Harrisville, we experienced a very strong headwind, the strongest of our entire trip.  We plodded on reaching Tawas with time to spare before the storm hit.      The sky was still pretty clear, but we heard thunder in the distance. Thunder storms and torrential rains are really exciting...from a motel room, not a tent.  We didn't even venture out again, we had pizza delivered to our room! 
  We only got a couple miles down the road and it started to sprinkle and it was obvious that it would intensify. We found a large covered truck parking area behind a business and waited a couple hours until the squall passed. After a few more hours we came to Au Gres and found the library so we are taking advantage of the opportunity to update our journal. When we left the library and headed south the sky ahead was black. We quickly headed into a cafe that had a covered place for the bike and got some lunch and tried to wait out the passing shower...it didn't pass though. Since the circus was in town we decided to get a room (the rain wasn't going away anytime soon) and go see the big top show.   
  
  
  
  At the Ontario Visitor Center we picked up maps and chatted with Jim and Grace, a couple on a motorcycle.  We rode around the waterfront and did some sightseeing and shopping before leaving town.  A couple hours later, in the middle of nowhere, we came to an intersection from the west just as Jim and Grace rolled up from the south!  We chatted some more, they gave us a wonderfully cold bottle of ice water, and then said our goodbyes again.    The town of Wyoming was not marked and we rode right past it.  Realizing our error, we backtracked a few miles into a headwind until we came to the campground. 
We continued on toward London, using the directions that Gosse had given us, including a nice bit along the Thames river through town in Springbank Park.    We got to Barbara and Gosse's home and spent quite a while going over routes and maps to help us get to Niagara falls.
  
We rode toward Lake Ontario then up on the Niagara Escarpment through miles of vineyards.  We were never quite lost, but often confused, as the roads in Ontario are not marked as clearly as we are used to.  They also have little or no shoulders.  After what seemed like days, we finally made it to the N.E.T. Campground near Vineland.  It had lousy facilities and misleading advertising.   
From there we caught the bike path south along the Niagara River.  It was very scenic with the river on one side and beautiful bed & breakfast houses on the other.   
We continued on until we reached the home of Bethany and Chuck in Lockport, where we were treated to their generous hospitality.   
We went to town and got a few needed items for the bike and our other gear. We then had a very relaxing day and another very enjoyable evening with Bethany and Chuck.   
   We had lunch and said goodbye at Medina and then we got onto the tow path and headed to Holley. There was a fantastic camp spot at the dock in Holley that even had beautiful new showers.   
It was nice to sit and chat and have a chance to get acquainted. After dinner Leon got out the maps and helped us choose our routes for the next few days.   
  Leon's directions to get us through Rochester were flawless and we had a great ride in spite of the stiff head wind. We enjoyed the rolling hills through the rural areas with plenty of fruit stands to supplement our lunch (fudge too!!).     We had a nice break and celebratory kiss when we passed what should be our last thousand mile mark, 4000!!!!!! The temps and roads were great so we were able to ignore, or at least tolerate, the wind and enjoy the day. When we checked into the somewhat dilapidated Wolcott hotel we were pleased to find another touring couple there too. We met Mark and Kathy, from Oakland, California, later in the bar and had a great evening sharing stories, pizza, beers and ice cream. 
  
Our first flat...As we were leaving we noticed our trailer tire was flat...our record is blemished! It sprinkled off and on all day but never really rained.  It was a bit chilly so we rode in tights and jackets most of the day.  Quite a change from the intense heat of the prairies! It's starting to smell like fall is in the air.   
We rode through many shady areas along the banks of numerous picturesque lakes. We stopped in a small town called Inlet to use their library.  We barely got settled when in walked Marge and Terry, fellow cycle tourists we rode with in Washington, Idaho, and Montana!  Our paths diverged in mid June and here we are 2 months later seeing them again.  We had a great reunion over lunch.   
Down the road a ways things didn't seem right.  We double checked our map and discovered we had missed a turn...mistake #2.  We backtracked up and down the hills 5 miles to the turnoff, which in all fairness to us, was marked very poorly. OK, we're on the right road, what do we do for dinner?  We stopped at the Adirondack Buffalo Farm and bought some veggies and buffalo stix.   At the end of a tough day the Blue Ridge Falls Campground was very accommodating, with a half price tent site.  It's crowded here because of the Labor Day weekend, but it's home for tonight.   
  
After crossing into Vermont, we rode to Middlebury and met Pat and Mike, for a great afternoon of cycling. We crossed Middlebury Gap, boy are the hills steep in Vermont,  and found a place in Rochester for the night. Then we enjoyed a delightful dinner with Pat and Mike before they had to head home.   
  
It was  beautiful riding along the river north toward North Haverhill before turning east and our big climb of the day.  The good road surface and small amount of traffic made for a nice ride in spite of the hill.  We continued on to Lincoln to be close to the bottom of tomorrow's climb over the Kancamagus Pass.   
We woke to cool overcast skies which made for a comfortable ride up the Kancamagus Hwy over the pass.  It was a 12 mile climb, but only the last couple miles were steepish.  It helped to do the climb in the morning and in cool weather.  After reaching the top we had 25 miles of a beautiful downhill.  We had lunch in Conway then crossed into Maine, over our last state line.   
We made it into Buckfield, another very tiny town, and checked into the Buckfield Inn which was cozy and inexpensive.  We had a relaxing afternoon reading their "Down East" magazines in the garden.   
We continued through Augusta picking up state route 3 which would take us all the way to Bar Harbor.  We pushed on until we came to a campground that left a manageable distance for our last day.     The campground came complete with a friendly cat named Larry that entertained us through the evening.   
  We rolled up to the rail at the waterfront in Bar Harbor and had barely gotten off the bike when we were approached by Alice who we met in Montana on June 26th, 3500 miles ago!     She and her husband Ron are from Utica NY and spend time every summer fishing near Yellowstone.  It was incredible to see them here in Bar Harbor almost 3 months later!  We all were enjoying a beer in a restaurant when up walked another woman who had recognized us from a cafe in Inlet, NY.  She was our waitress there when we had lunch with Marge & Terry, after running into THEM coincidentally!  What a small world!!! We said goodbye to Ron and Alice, got a motel room, and walked back for our celebratory lobster and champagne dinner. It's so nice to be done riding, but it's a bittersweet ending.  It will be hard to rejoin the real world, but we have many fantastic memories to take with us.  The wonderful people who make up this country have made this a trip of a lifetime! 
The coupling system worked perfectly. We had no difficulty shipping the bike at all. The disassembly and reassembly was a breeze. We did purchase 2 of the carrying cases (as suggested by the guys at The Bicycle Outfitter) instead of one and it was very easy to fit the bike and extra gear into them. We had only a couple of mechanical problems. The main one was a rear rim failure. We got a new rim in South Dakota and finished our tour, but we have heard from some others who have had problems with the FIR rims too. We now have Mavic rims, from a set of wheels we previously had built for touring. We had to put the old Mavic rim on our new Hadley rear hub because the drop-out width is greater on our new bike but we just switched to our old front wheel.  The other major failure was the Shimano Flite-Deck computer. By the end of the trip even the clock had quit working. We loved the features on it but it was VERY unreliable. Before we left it had failed once and the new one began to fail within 1 month on the road. We now have 2 Cateyes. The tires were bullet proof. We got about 1800 miles out of a set if we rotated them and we did not have one flat on the bike the whole trip of 4800 miles, repeat, NOT ONE FLAT ON THE BICYCLE!! 


We used a MSR whisperlite international stove and the ease of use, easy maintenance, quiet operation, and being able to use unleaded gasoline made it a great choice. We tried to use white gas as much as possible but occasionally we had to use the local gas station for our fuel. Our tent was a Moss Olympic. Our biggest equipment mistake was trusting a 15 year old tent to still be watertight. We didn't have much problem with rain and when it did rain we never really got wet but the floor and rain fly were porous. We should have put a coat of water proofing on them before we left. The other problem with our tent was that it was a bit of overkill for the conditions. We could have used a lighter tent with better ventilation. Most of the time we needed protection from the bugs not the weather. Sometimes we needed to close up the screens but it was too hot, without the screens it was too buggy. We used home made sleeping bag liners (made from old sheets in our bags. When the weather in the plains turned hot they were a blessing. Many nights the sleeping bags didn't even come out. 

   Then, getting more involved and intimate with my bike, I made cycling part of my weekly routine. I got new friends that were into cycling, and that went places, and they made me itch to discover more of the places to go and itch to discover myself through touring. Then I had to decide what I would do for my holidays. It must have been April or May of this year. I had initially 3 weeks holidays, and I thought I would cycle from Vancouver to San Francisco, solo. Then, after visitting so many cycling related web-sites, I came upon the adventure cycling web-site and in the classified there was this woman looking for a partner to cycle the Pacific Coast. It got me curious, I wanted to know how long it would take her, and what was her plan. So I innocently e-mail Joice, and began this partnership that would makeus plan this trip together. So I changed my holiday time, banked some overtime and trained like crazy to make msure my body would be ready for the journey. In the meantime, Joice and I made contact by e-mail and by phone and talked about all the details  of our trip, and what we each wanted for this trip and see if we were compatible. Joice told me she was into running, and cycling and had been trekking to Nepal and aspired to go climbing in South America in a near future. At 43, she was living life to the fullest, taking a full year off work and enjoying things she loved to do. I had positive vibes from our talks and from our e-mails, and we were both so excited about this trip. Cycling the Pacific Coast represented achieving something big to me. To have a goal, to prepare for it, to do it, to face adversity, and to come out as a winner, that was my piece of cake. I was there for the cycling and to reach my goal.


Joice and I left our place right on time as planned: 0800 sharp. My rear tire was somewhat soft so we stopped at the gas station for air and we had our picture taken. I felt happy and excited to leave but somewhat worried because even just a couple of blocks after leaving, Joice was way behind! Oh-oh! There were warning signals in my head, especially when after the very first hill, I was waiting for her and waiting and she showed up finally walking her bike! I was disappointed of not being able to push it and cycle at my full capacity. I had to stop biking and wait for her many times. I must admit that the way to go to the Tsawassen ferry is not nice: busy industrial road, a bridge to cross, lots of big trucks and not much shoulders at times. That was one of the reason I wanted to push it a bit, because there ws nothing nice about this road. Lots of debris on that road, especially shoes, different kind of shoes, a swivel chair wheel, lots of nails, a reflective hunter vest, and few DOA (district of attorney) animals of all kind. The fresh dead seagull on the way to the ferry was not nice to see. The ferry ride was quite nice in a cycling day, breaking the cycling in 2 parts. You must have seen the face of the booth attendant when we told her where we were heading (San Diego). That was priceless! We decided to take the busy road as the quiet road would leghten the day cycling and took highway 19 to Victoria. Joice and I agreed we'd meet downtown Victoria as she felt bad of being slow and wobbly on her bike. I felt like a caged animal with lots of energy and wanted to be freed. So I was relieved that she didn't mind riding on her own. At the first turn off, I would wait for her, we decided. We were heading for the hostel knowing that we had to get up early the next day for the ferry. Unfortunately the hostel was full so we headed for the closest campground which was 15 km away. Joice and I really enjoyed the Galloping goose cycle path going there.Thetis Lake campground, cheaper than the hostel, was RV land. There were mobile homes too. The owner perched us on top of a steep hill, that we walked up, and found ourselves on a very small campsite, but oh well. Joice was very tired, she had a rough day but yet she impressed me; I thought she would give up.I was tired too because I was trying to catch up on my sleeping hours, recovering from night shift work, and yes, I had a stressful day.   
The ferry ride was nice as we talked to our neighbors and a lot of people were impressed with our trip. We even got a couple that gave us their phone number to use if we were in trouble in Oregon. I had some more work to do on the quilt I was working on and when I had it out, the ladies around asked to see and were impressed with the work. (This was mostly the work of my internet quilting group). Then in the middle of the Georgia Straight, I got a bit sea sick as the ferry was gently rolling from one side to the other. Fortunately the shore got closer and closer and soon enough we were on firm ground. Port Angeles is not so pretty and was into the fog, and Joice and I had few errands to run before taking off for our destination of the day. Groceries, post office and libraries would be a common trend for the rest of my trip. My webmail didn't work when I tried to log on and I was quite disappointed of that. After the internet session, we left for Crescent lake which is quite pretty but on a windy and narrow road. Our guide book was warning us about that section and there was a button to activate a warning sign for motorists that cyclists were on the road. I thought it was a pretty ride and not much traffic was on the road. The sky was threatening to fall off, so I was wanting to push myself and set up camp before the rain. I met up with Danielle and Hilde right by the campsite, at the little store by the lake. The 2 friends were from Belgium and now living in Switzerland , cycling down the coast and travelling very light. They had only one tent and decided they would be camping only if it was not raining. They didn't have a stove either, having one meal a day at the restaurant and the dinner meal would be bread and cheese, or cold cuts. Joice joined me there, maybe 10 or 15 minutes after I arrived. Danielle and Hilde would take a hotel that night while Joice and I set up camp in a desert campsite. The rain started  just about as we pitched our tent, so we dressed up warmly and proceeded to cook our dinner. Joice expressed feeling rushed on this trip, she would like to have more time off the bike, lingering in small towns, talk to the locals, etc...I feel like pushing myself, and get the hell out of Washington State before the whole sky falls on us. I hope that we find a middle ground, I wrote in my journal. I had some bike problems today. (So early in my trip) The problem is that I can't shift gear in the front rings. Oh-oh. I was meaning to try to fix it but the rain got to me and the darkness too. No bike shop in sight for a long time. The other problem was my right grip shift grip was getting quite run down and torn. It is a tough item to replace as I tried to have it replaced but 2 bike shops didn't have the grip anymore.     
We left the campsite late, and started up the hill. I was all geared for the rain, long pants included, booties and oh, all of it! On top of the hill, (3km hill) I was way too hot as the sun was started to peek out, so I changed and told Joice we would meet up at the first cafe we would encounter. I got there and waited and waited, and got cold, and she showed up, wanting a burger. That was after 1 hour cycling and we still had 75 km to go! I told her that we were kind of late in our schedule and that she would be better off to continue on cycling to make it to the next campsite before dark. Poor Joice! She couldn't stand being deprived of a greasy burger and she left. We met up again in Forks, where I offered to dry her sleeping bag in a laundromat while she kept on pedalling. I took on the occasion to dry my tent while the sun was out. At Forks, I got to the library to check my e-mail.  I couldn't access my e-mail for some reason and it was driving me crazy, especially that I didn't write down anybody's e-mail addresses, I had it all set up on the webmail.  Leaving Forks we met up with this cyclist, a Andre Agassi look alike that has been cycling from Vancouver to Baja, then dropped his bike and backpacked the Copper Canyon and cycled back from Baja to Vancouver. Very impressive. He had all his load on his rear rack, including his backpack and a full size guitar!  We still had 50 km to pedal from that point and it was closee to 3 PM.(Remember that this is nearing fall and it gets dark by 7). I told Joice I would meet her at the campsite, and left. The ride was good, a bit long. Scenic. Not much traffic. Got rained on real good, one of those quick showers (Joice didn't get it) then finally made it to the beaches. Wow! The sound, the smell, the sights!!! This is what I came for! Very impressive. I did a bit of a detour and stopped at the very first beach, took a picture and headed towards the campground. At that point, all I could get for gear on my bike was the small ring at the front. Geez! Lots of spinning.Lots of swearing. I was tired too.    I made it to the campsite at 1800 or 1830, and met up with 2 cyclists, a couple from Burnaby, BC, Gael (a guy) and Heather.They are heading to Mexico, maybe Guatemala!!! 4 months of pure bliss!  I set up camp right net to them.And that night Gael helped me fixing my speed changing problem. I was very thankful for that. Joice made it to camp shortly before dark. I was sure glad to see her. I was getting worried. She was starting to mention that she might not carry on, being quite sore in her knees and tired. She wanted her boyfriend Jeff to come and pick her up from Seattle. I felt bad and a bit guilty that she was having such a hard time and did not enjoy herself. I had food ready for her: macaroni in a creamy alfredo sauce with tuna. Yummy! Shortly after eating, we cleaned up, talked openly about what we were feeling and thinking and went to bed. One incident that made me careful for the rest of my trip was when I turned on my little gas stove and I obviously was way to close from it as I got a flame in the face as the gas is quite volatile! I could smell burnt hair shortly after that. Fortunately there were no mirrors in the washrooms. No showers either. 
It was a lonesome ride today as Joice and I agreed to meet at the campsite, at the end of the day. We agreed on a shorter day today to allow her knees to get better. There were open lands, logged fields, and I saw lots of bear scats today. Being alone in such a quiet place with only few cars passing by, I was a bit worried about the bears, so I starting shouting around: "bear scats! bearrrrrrr scaaaaaaatttts!!!" (don't ask me why) I was also looking around in the bushes for movements of black beary faces. Towards the end of my ride, I thought I could see bikes on the horizon, but this would never materialize, until almost my turn off to the campsite, where I saw them for sure, those 2 young guys, Alec and Greg, cycling from Victoria to San Francisco. We talked a bit, learning that they would cycle a bit more than Joice and I today but we thought we would see each other farther down the coast. I set up camp at July Creek State Park, just as the sky fell off on me (once more). Awaiting for Joice, I changed, gathered wood, and made myself a hot drink. An hour later Joice came in, in better spirits than the previous days but with sore knees. She rode with Hilde and Danielle today and really enjoyed that as they have the same pace and style.I was glad that she found people to ride with, as they promised to meet up again tomorrow. I went on the other side of the lake Quineault for laundry, which happened to be a longer ride than expected. I put my cycling shoes in the dryer as they had refused to dry totally. Met up with Danielle who was sharing a hotel room with Hilde very close to the laundromat. I came back to our campsite after dark and Joice was getting worried. I also came back very wet, more than ever as the rain had started again and it was quite heavy. All that for drying my shoes. Dinner was on the table, thanks to Joice,and we ate quickly, before heading back to our respective tent for protection and for the night. It rained really hard all night, and our tent were in a bit of a slope, I was worried that the trench made on the uphill would get clogged and we'd get flooded. Our tent were all muddy already when we called it a night.
Once I cycled past Humtulips, I could see a bit of blue sky! I could then start the process of drying. Impressive. Finally! I had an encounter with a german sheppard. He came to me showing his teeth. I was scared. Really. So here I am, getting my nicest softest voice: "Hi!!! How are you? Good dog" He retreated back home, to my greatest relief. It left me a bit shaky for a while. But quickly forgotten, as I was heading once more towards the beaches and the weather was improving some more! The first beach I hit, I cycled to it and took my tent out for drying. It was one of those long endless beaches, and cars were allowed on it as the sand was quite packed. After repacking everything, I carried on, stopping in this small farm market where I bought for 80 cents of fruits, some grapes and 2 peaches. The lady at the counter told me to take 2 apples extra! I was very grateful for that, watching my cash flow and writing down every penny spent along my journey. I then carried on south until the end of the road and enquired about the ferry we had to take to go on the other side of the jetty, to Westport. We would be 6 cyclists on this ferry, Joice and I, Danielle and Hilde, and Greg and Alec, the 2 young guys.       We met Gael and Heather at Twin Harbor State Park and shared a campsite for 6$ total. That ended to be less than 1$ per person! (Gael got the hiker-biker fee for 6$ and then asked to be transferred to a regular site considering that the campground was not busy, then invited all of us to share his site!) I have to mention that I had my first shower since leaving Canada. You can't imaging how good it felt to get the warm water on my body and to scrub the sweat and dirt. Some neighbors of ours, 2 sites away from us were having a fishing and drinking mission and invited us to warm up and dry our clothes by their fire at night. They were quite the camping gourmets and were cooking all kind of stuff that would make anybody but especially a hungry cyclist salivating. To each of us they pushed a plate of freshly BBQ salmon under our nose, which was very yummy, even if we had full dinner before. We dried our clothes (managed to make a hole on both my newly bought cycling socks) and talked for a while but I excused myself early sensing they were getting quite drunk and obnoxious. The good news is that we've been told that the good weather is on our side!!! 
The road was pretty flat, and quiet on this early morning. I hit a quilt store in the first hour of riding. It made my day! I had to get in of course and saw this beautiful raffle quilt that displayed in one of the magazine. I purchased a ticket and left all the fabric I liked behind and left. One of my knee was hurting, probably an overuse injury. I had been carrying some of Joice's equipment for a few days (to facilitate her rides) and combined with 5 days cycling, I guess it was a lot of pressure on my joints and muscles. I promised to go easy today.  Met up briefly with Gael and Heather who were having lunch in a really prime spot, on the beach. It was really pretty and the bright sunshine was making it easy to appreciate even more the scenery. The rest of the road till Raymond was quite diversified, sometimes in the forest, sometimes along a big muddy bay. The common thread was that it was very quiet, not much traffic and good riding. I waited that I cycled at least 50 km before I stop for lunch. And when I was ready for lunch, there was nowhere to stop! So I went overtime and finally reached this baseball field with a couple of pik nik tables and gladly got off my bike. There were 3 other people having lunch and they invited me to join them. Randy was around 45 yo and his parents that were celebrating their 50th wedding anniversary by traveling across the USA. They offered me sandwiches, drink, snacks, and what not! It was quite overwhelming. I left that lunch spot heavier that when I came, loaded with food that those people gave me. Raymond was nothing to be excited about, it was a saw mill town and also a fishing village. North Bend was next to it and more of a fishing town and I stopped there to read my e-mail, at the library. Now I spent an hour and a half there trying to figure out my webmail and my address book, and was quite embarrassed and uncomfortable by the smell of my feet. I enjoyed getting news from my friends. I met Gael and Heather at the library and left for the campsite which wouldn't be that far. I saw at least 3 dead snakes on the pavement and lots of live and well cows, and found myself mooing at them and waiting to see their reactions. That would be a favorite game of mine all along the coast. I made it first at the campsite and got to celebrate the day with a really good malt beverage, and waited for my friends. Gael and Heather followed and then before dark, tired Joice. I am tired too mind you and am looking forward to my day off in Astoria.  I saw the sunset for the first time of this trip. I was standing there, alone on the edge on a cliff and watching the big plunge in the Pacific and waiting for the nice colors to show up afterwards. That was nice. I was hoping for many more to come!    Danielle and Hilde came quite late, well after the sunset, as one of them forgot her watch at a lunch spot and realized it much later. They turned around and looked for it and were quite delayed by it. We were all glad they were safe. We all were in bed when they had dinner, and they were giggling quite a bit, speaking Dutch and I was wondering what it was all about. Well it happened that they had never seen racoons but heard about their theft habits at night. We had warned them to hang their food like we did that night with ours. Danielle asked me whether the racoon liked bananas, with her coarse Dutch voice. That was funny. The whole campsite started to laugh! I was crying out of laughter, and my stomach was hurting. Laughter is the best medecine...   
I reached Seaview where finally there was a bit of life, and treated myself with some Pepsi. I was hoping to be joined by Gael and Heather, but after 20 minutes, I left again, this time slower. I met them entering Ilwaco, where we stocked up for lunch and headed to the Columbia George lighthouse, Fort Camby State Park. With commanding views of the ocean we shared lunch together and had a picture taken with the lighthouse in the background.    There was a huge visitor center at that park and Gael wanted to spend time learning about the history of  Lewis and Clark so I left them at that point and went my own way. I learned about myself that I didn't really like historical stuff too much, and that I prefered cycle the route all at once, or close rather than linger along the way and make it to camp later. I visited the center, but definitely didn't read all the explanations, as I don't have the patience and the information doesn't register anyways.  The riding towards Oregon was interesting: following the Columbia River, going East towards the bridge that would lead me into a different state and a next step into my cycling trip. There was a tunnel to cross, with a big cyclist-operated "cyclist in tunnel " sign. That was OK. It just makes a lot of noise when there is a car in the tunnel. Shortly after that, I was on the long bridge that led me into Oregon. I had a bit of an emotional moment but not enough not to notice the freshly dead seagull right into the 2 feet wide bike lane on the bridge. I did my best to avoid it.     In Astoria, I went to the visitor center to get my free Oregon Coast cycling map and directions to the bike shop, library and grocery store. I headed then to the Fred Meyer which is kind of a big Cosco to buy groceries for dinner. The first tragedy of the trip happened when I wanted to lock my bike. I had the U-shape of the lock but not the other part! I must have lost it somewhere along the way. I ended up putting my bike inside the store and thought "oh well, if it's just the worst that can happen to me on this trip, I am lucky". I thought I would buy a new lock tomorrow.   I made it to camp by 1800, late considering that the sun sets by 1900 and that Joice, Hilde and Danielle were way slower, stopping often. Waiting for the others to arrive, I pitched my tent, drank my malt drink, wrote an entry in my journal, and then Gael and Heather arrived...with the other piece of my lock, and the cable that I use with it.Wow! It made my day! Gael found it just about 35 km behind as I left Fort Camby. He thought it could be mine and carried it all that way to find out. Yay! Thank you, thank you, thank you!!!! The other good news was that our neighbors who were camping as a group of quiet retired couples went fishing that day and came back with a lot of crab, cooked it and asked if we could please take as much as we wanted because they had way too much... Heather, Gael and I looked at each other in disbelief and felt like it was Christmas. I later on passed again by their campsite on my way to the shower and they gave me 3 of those yummy italian plums, which made me a bit teary as I gratefully accepted them. This was way overwhelming. I did not expect that much generosity from complete strangers. I am so thankful for all these kind gestures that made my day. I waited a long time for Joice that night, but 2 hours after dark, figured out she wouldn't show up that night. Neither Danielle and Hilde even though we promised to meet at the campsite. The campsite happened to be more expensive because of their no-show. I was worried about them, wondering what might have happened disastrous that prevented them not to come. Part of me knew that they were ok, just caught by darkness and a long day cycling. Tomorrow is a day off, I am really thankful for that. I had laundry to take care of, and my bike needed the handle grip repair and a derailleur job, maybe even crash on the beach. 
The morning was a leisurly one, slow rise and shine, no picking up and packing up everything. Nice breakfast with Gael and Heather. I got into the habit of eating the same yummy breakfast and every evening I would make sure I had everything I needed for my morning feast: bagel with peanut butter, a banana and some hot chocolate. After that I headed in town to run my errands. I left my bike in confidence to the bike mechanic and walked to the library for my e-mail, and surprise! Joice was just getting out of there!!! I was so happy to see her alive and well, that was a big relief! We hugged! She told me that Danielle, Hilde and her made it quite late in Astoria last night, and in fact it was dark as they crossed the bridge. They were looking for their way and asked directions to this woman who invited them in her home overnight. Wow, that generosity thing again... Joice and I parted again after I gave her the directions for our campsite and I went on with doing my e-mail thing and came back to my bike which was now fixed and ready to tackle any hill with all its speed gears  I wanted. It cost me 30$ US but oh well... I needed it, I was glad it was done, I will pay it when the bill comes back on my credit card... I then headed back "home" and right before entering Fort Stevens State Park, after shopping for food, I got a flat tire. Well, that was OK because I had Pepsi with me. It was really hot so I sat down, had a sip and got to fix my flat  (a big staple). I was happy to do it. It was almost a convenient time to have a flat, when I'm not that loaded... Returning to camp quite sticky and plain dirty, I got to clean up my very filthy bike and had a shower. Laundry was next on the list and I went to the KOA that was in front of the state park. I didn't have any soap with me and the laundromat or the little store didn't have single load soap so I asked another camper at the laundromat if she would sell me some. She told me I could take it, for free... For dinner we had the 2 boys, Greg and Alec joining us from 2 days ago, and along with Joice made 6 of us. I made Joice a sweet and sour vegetable stir-fry with cashews on a bed of rice with wine-she liked it.
   Seaside came and I went by the beach, had a picture of me taken and headed towards Canon Beach.     Stoping in towns is a bit shorter when I ride on my own. First I don't feel the need to stop as much and there is nobody to share the moment with so I prefer riding.  So still facing strong headwind (lots of white caps on the ocean) I made my way to Canon Beach which is is a cute tourist town just south of Seaside. I took a side trip to Ecola State park. The 3 miles service road was more than hilly. There were steep section to it that I wished there was another smaller gear after my granny gear. But the scenery was really worth it. Only I wished I had company to share the moment with. The winds gusts made me unsteady on my feet and I had to brace myself to walk to the peninsula that would give me tremendous views of the north and south coast. It was georgous! The picture I took, I had to hold the camera using a lot of strenght and had to watch the scarf on my head too... Good thing there was no rain to that storm!      Then I headed to Canon Beach, in its busy touristy street and purchased something for my lunch and for dinner later on. Even though it was pretty, I didn't linger too much as I had more cycling against the wind to do, and few hills to climb. The climb out of Canon beach got quite hairy because of that head wind. The sand would come in a cloud, I had to keep my mouth shut and my eyes too at times as I do not wear protective glasses when cycling and the wind gusts would sometimes push me towards the road, in the traffic. Then I hit the tunnel. There was a cyclist-operated warning signal, thankfully. I waited for the big semi to pass, activated the light and sped through the tunnel, hoping for no cars to pass by. On the opposite way came 2 dirt trucks that made a terrifying noise in the tunnel and then behind them they brought the vacuum wind. I got a bit emotional on my way out, I guess I was a bit scared and nervous in there. I was as well quite surprised to notice how the weather changed on the other side of the tunnel (and the mountain): big low clouds, threatening to burst, and cold enough to wear my windbreaker. I carried on, downhill and then back up again. I was getting tired. I made it to camp by 1530,the way I like . Tired and relieved that I made it safely. The last hill had been quite difficult on top leaving me exposed to the traffic and fighting with all my strenght the fierce wind so I am not pushed off my bike and pushed in the traffic. I made it.  I pitched my tent,unloaded the bike and cycled back in town again to get some camping fuel for the group. It happened that the price of a  gallon was the double of what I normally pay so I left it there. I found myself a library and went reading and sending e-mails. Joice didn't make it to camp till 7:45 that night. I was worried, hungry and perhaps a bit angry. Well, it happened that, right before Seaside, she and a car collided as she was pushed by a gust of wind. Very shaken by the event, she had almost made arrangements to return to Seattle. She left camp late, waiting for Hilde (Danielle was heading to Portland for her return flight) which drives me crazy because daylight is a ressource for cyclists. I am worried when she doesn't come by sunset. I kind of feel responsible for her. Her morale was pretty low that night, and I didn't know what she wanted to do, carry on or go home.. That night I started  contemplating that I might be on my own in a very short time. The last entry on my journal that night was that I really enjoyed myself on this trip.... and Joice, not so much. I have to talk about the "Jurassic Park effect" in some of the campsites in Oregon. In some places when you want to reach the beach like in Nehalem bay, you have to climb a sand dune, say 50 feet high, maybe more. Then you have a really nice ocean view, and a really nice wild beach, nice sand. But if you turn around towards the campsite, you would see a forest, no real high trees but hiding most of the RV's and buildings. I would expect to see a dinosaur's head emerging from a hill or from a bush... I had that thought few times in Oregon. So wild....   
In Tillamook, I stopped to the very touristy cheese factory and bought some cheese curds.(Later on everybody at the campsite would turn their head on the delicacy because of the word curds). I had stopped here last year as well and had seen the displays but hey, who would say no to free cheese tasting???  The quilt museum was the next stop on my list and I admired a very beautiful applique quilt made by a local group. I took a picture and talked with the ladies for a bit, admitting that I missed my quilting and working on my many projects.    After groceries and some e-mail at the library, I headed towards the 3 Capes loop, a very scenic and quiet road off highway 101 that would hug the coast and offer wonderful sceneries. Last year was one of my favorite place! I stopped for blackberries along the way, thinking that I should have done that way earlier on my trip as these were really yummy!  Cape Meares was quite steep, and long (3 miles of fairly steep climbing); I worked hard for that one, singing to change my mind and to stop thinking about my sore thighs. I met up with Hilde on top and Gael and Heather joined in. We cycled to the lighthouse together. It was sure hilly.  On one of the long and fast descent, I lost my handlebar bag as I sped into potholes that I didn't expect and as I forgot to lock it on to the handlebar. Well, I almost ran on it and almost had a pretty bad accident. That taught me a lesson as it really scared me. The rest of the ride was pretty uneventful but I got tired towards the end, and I kept having flashbacks from my last year's trip which disturbed me a bit. Finally in camp, I quickly set up, hopped into a delightful hot shower and put on some warmer clothes. The sunset anounced itself and I ran to the beach to watch it. The sky got all orange and the surf was beautiful.      Cape Lookout is one of my favorite campground on the Oregon Coast but today was very crowded as we were Friday. So lots of people on the beach, some dogs pulling their masters as they wanted to play or to sniff other dogs... It was an interesting sight- lots of action on the beach. Dinner was interesting too as Joice and I didn't share meals anymore as I told her I could not wait for her to show up anymore to have dinner. We agreed in the morning that if we were to arrive at different times  (ie: her coming late) it would be better to plan our own meal. It felt weird, as we were sitting at opposite sides of the table. It felt like I was distancing from her. My thought today was that I had to stop to mother her. She had to take responsibility for herself and her actions. I wonder what she would have to say if I told her that as this was my feeling, maybe she didn't feel that at all. I went to bed early and found my earplugs in the bottom of my bag as we had very noisy and obnoxious neighbors. Typical Friday night in a campsite... 
I started cycling by 10AM which is late for me. I left with Hilde, but she fell behind quickly, having met some Swiss cyclists to talk to. There was a 1000 feet hill to climb right out of the campsite so I warmed up quite quickly! I got sweaty, started to breathe the most effective way for the exercise output and spun my pedals! I was sure glad once I reached the top. I waited for Hilde maybe 10 or 15 minutes but as she was not coming, I left.  Down the hill there were sand dunes on the left and right side of the road, a pretty and different sight. I remember that section from last year. The sand had drifted on parts of the road shoulder, narrowing the road especially if a car had to pass me. A little further down, there were some pastural decors, and I had a chat with the cows. At some point I stopped by a fenced field and all the cows came very close, pushing one another for a better view of the strange person with a scarf and helmet on her head.    I ate cheese curd right in front of them and told them they wouldn't have any. Then for dessert I had some very yummy blackberries. My fingers- and probably my tongue too- got all purple! Cape Kiwanda is another favorite place of mine. Nice stumpy rock not far from the coast and sandy beach. I bought myself some Pepsi and sat on the beach for a while, watching the trucks and the cute surfers getting on and off the beach.Shortly after noon, it was time to go. Soon after that the road was following a river emerging on to the ocean and again there was a lot of action, lots of small boats clustered at the same spot for good fishing and lots of shore fisherman trying their luck. I saw a rather large salmon being caught, which was quite exciting.    Next, I hit a quilt store, to my big surprise as this place was quite rural. It was signed on the road as a tourist attraction so I followed the signs off my way a bit and ended up in a house basement with 2 quilters and lots of bolts of fabric. We chatted for a while, and I got to miss my quilting and fabric handling. They warned me about the upcoming hill right before Lincoln city, and they were very surprised that I was traveling by myself, happily talking about this guy cyclist that had been stopped on the roadside and robbed of his money and valuables. Thanks ladies! The Lincoln city hill was steep, the quilters were right on that. It climbed forever, winding lots and in and out of the sunshine, making it quite hot when the sun was hitting the pavement. I found Hilde again right close to Lincoln city but we parted as I stopped for groceries. We had to prepare for cheese fondue that night!!! Yummy. Hilde left us that night to have a longer day as she had a restricted time to reach San Francisco. I reached camp by 1530. I was the first one to arrive. Pitched the tent and headed for the library. My e-mail was nice to read but I didn't have enough time. I felt kind of homesick. I felt sort of excluded from the group because Joice and I were not sharing dinner anymore. It felt really weird and uncomfortable. The cheese fondue was great! We had 4 different cheeses and some garlic and some wine in it. Then 4 bottles of wine to help the cheese down. Joice and I got a bit happy for a while, giggling a bit. That was fun. We ate quite well. So in general it was a great day, great scenery, great cycling and a great dinner. Tomorrow was another day off-I could have done without but the group decided to have one to have everyone rested at the same time (Greg and Alec needed a day off). My biggest concern about this day off was to find out something to do. Linclon city is not real exciting to me.   
Gael, Heather and me went for laundry (Wow! Nice clean clothes!) and then headed for a renown clam chowder restaurant for lunch (Mo's). I was not craving at all a meal at the restaurant and sure didn't want to spend the money but ended up joining my group. I had a salad and some fries conscious about the greasy food as I didn't want to gain weight on this trip!!!    After a group picture session, we headed back against the wind, stopping  to the library for e-mail. I must have spent 1 and a half hour composing this really nice e-mail for all my friends and family. From day 1 to day 7, the whole Washington State story. I pressed "send", then there was an error message and I tried to get back to find out what I did wrong and .. I lost the whole e-mail. I was so mad, yet there was nothing I could do. I am so unlucky with my e-mails. After being back in camp, I was watching Gael fixing and cleaning his and Heather's bike and he showed me a bit how to true a wheel. He taught himself to build wheels and was quite knowledgeable about the matter. I wanted to check a bit my back wheel,as I knew it was way out of true. So I turned my bike upside down and found out with Gael a huge crack on my rim at a spoke base. The rim needed replacement, and now!!! The next bike shop was 40 km away from here. I hoped I could make it and I hope that I could catch up with my buddies afterwards depending on how fast the bike shop could do the repair and if they had a rim for me. I had a good dinner: Ramen noodles with corn, cheese and broccoli and a glass or 2 of Zinfandel. We all retired early into our tents in prevision of our longer day tomorrow. As for me I wanted to get up earlier just to allow more time for repair or in case I had to hitchhike or anything like that. I was kind of stressed out with the idea of riding with such a big problem.
I made it without any other incidents to Newport by 1100, left my bike in confidence and headed to the library which was only one block away! I took advantage of the free time to stock up in food and had lunch . My bike got ready by 1300 and after giving 85$ in US funds, I had a newly refurbished mean of transportation!!! Right before taking the Newport bridge I found the quilt store Darlene was suggesting me to stop at and indeed, it was well worth the stop! Lots to salivate about and yes, I missed my quilting! I didn't buy anything (good girl) and carried on. I passed Newport bridge and met up with what looked like hard core, big calves, lightweight bikes cyclists. One of them was in a wheelchair. We said hi, and followed each other for quite a while. Tail wind helping I reached and maintained a speed of 36-40 km per hour with and then without the boys as they slowed down. I think that they were impressed with me as I could keep up with them and as I was way heavier loaded than they were. I passed them a few times. It was nice to push myself a bit. They stopped in Yachats-I carried on. The ride was so scenic, and it was so fun!!! I had a blast!. I made it to camp by 4:30 PM. Even with my 2 hours break in Newport, nobody made it before me. I pitched my tent, had a delightful shower, had some soup, went for a walk. Heather and Gael made it by 6PM. That was nice to see them. Greg and Alec came shortly after that and Joice made it before dark. Must have been 7PM. She got a flat tire today and it took her 2 hours-so she says to fix it. She never fixed one before.    Tomorrow will be an easier day. Will stop for e-mail in Florence and we will have chocolate fondue for dessert as a group at night. Yummy!!! 
   I made it to the Lighthouse State Park, but not first as usual: Greg and Alec were all set up. It was pretty cold at camp because of the fog. There was the fog horn making noise a few times per minutes, and it carried on for the whole night too. You kind of tune it out after a while. I felt kind of uncomfortable with Greg and Alec because I found that we didn't have much in common, not much to say. Their motto for this cycling trip (and they insisted that they weren't cyclists) was : the easy way out, which mean they would take the easiest route, the shorter one and rest was important. I didn't make too much effort to keep a conversation with them. Joice really like them. She was always bugging them, arguing and kept saying that they could have been her sons. Whatever. I felt a bit out of the group that night again, kind of rejected, maybe except for the time we shared the chocolate fondue. Actually, nobody had chocolate fondue before so I introduced them to the delight of this yummy dessert!    We fought for the chocolate and shared fruits, the strawberries and bananas being the most popular. I will remember that one. Joice exempted herself from the fondue with the pretext that she had too much chocolate in her panniers to eat even more of it. Whatever. I went to bed early that night after warming up at the little fire that we had going, donation of wood from some fellow campers. 
The rest of the day I would keep thinking about being on my own tonight. Part of me is not bothered by it all. In fact I am yearning for a bit of solitude. Part of me is bothered by the security aspect of being a woman and travelling on my own. During the day, no problem. It's at night. A campsite like the one I left this morning, no problem. I am worried about quiet and remote hiker-biker sites. I phoned my sister in Paris that morning and it was good to talk with her. The line cut right in the middle of our conversation, I think it was her cell phone battery that died. I would have talked to her longer, maybe to get some encouragements from her as I needed it. So I cycled the 106 km today remembering the route John and I did last year; I can't wait to be out of Oregon and see something different and not have that history to think about, and places we went. I fell today. I was in the Seven Devils loop (what's in a name? ) which is a very tiring ride with lots of up and down, some of them quite steep. I was trying to get into the smaller ring and the chain got stuck-again. And I fell, right in the middle of the quiet road as I was going uphill. More fear than hurt, but it sure bruised my ego. A car stopped, and the man lowered his window as I was still sitting on the pavement and enquired whether I was ok. Yes, I am ok. Thanks. Bandon is a real nice funky place. I like it. I arrived there in the afternoon, passing my campsite to spend some time in town, do my e-mail, get groceries and even check out the quilt store. I must have spent an hour in town and returned towards my campsite, where I queued for the check in, taking my place in the traffic behind those monster RV's with satellite dish and BBQ and microwave oven and the jeep behind for town cruising. Well, my transportation was real cheap gas! And I didn't take that much room, and I could eat what I wanted and not gain weight. There. I shared the hiker-biker with a strange character, a cyclist doing only the Oregon Coast, a man that must be in his early 40's and not looking so fit. We talked briefly as I was filling my pot with water for cooking and was sure glad he kept his distances as I wanted to be alone. I had a delightful shower, as usual, cooked myself a good meal (Ramen noodles) and a glass of Zinfandel, and got to eat chocolate and went to bed early after failing at lighting a fire. I remembered being worried about racoons as I had my food with me in the tent, and was hoping not to have any confrontation, which didn't happen.
   I ended up having to backtrack a couple of kilometers for the laundromat. Sorting out my dirty clothes, this lady approached me and asked: "Are you travelling on your own?" I said: "From now on, yes". She replied: "Aren't you scared with all the bad stuff that is happening around?". I had an answer for her: "Well, I don't read the papers, it's way too scary! But really so far on my trip, everybody have been very kind." I really meant it. Then I headed to the library just to see if one e-mail I sent the previous day had been replied. My friend indeed replied and I read:" Knowing you well you must be worried about being on your own". Tears fogged my sight as I exited and left Bandon and I was kind of upset for the next 10 km. Yeah, part of me was worried. The unknown. Will I be ok? What if I don't feel safe? I felt relieved after crying a bit. Later that day, I was better. I was cycling. My element. Getting endorphins. I stopped for blackberries but they were getting rotten so I really had to pick well. I couldn't believe that such a gift from mother nature could be left out there and not used for pies, or jam or whatever.  I took a 10 miles detour to Cape Blanco where there is a lighthouse. It didn't matter today as I had a shorter day so I could afford the detour. Last year when we went, we were fogged in and I wanted to see if I could have views of the cape, and the shoreline this time. The ride there was pretty, passing through fields of hay, country homes and then the state park with glimpses of a very pretty stream meandering throught the land. Patches of fog hung out by the coast but still, here and there I could manage to see a bit of the shore.    Back on the main route, I met up with a tandem in Port Orford, Theresa and Jeff who were leisurly cycling down the coast, no real goal, just where their bike would take them. We chatted for a while and I stayed there a bit longer sipping my Pepsi and looking at the great scenery.    I was getting tired and knew  the last section to my campsite was hilly so I was trying to gain some energy. At the end, I made it just fine to Humbug which wasen't so far away after all neither it was so difficult and set up camp at the hiker-biker site. I remembered that Gael and Heather said they would be at Humbug that night but I came to believe that they would not make it. I met up with Jake from Seattle and Debbie from Vancouver, who cycled together that day but didn't know each other before that. They are quite the seasonned cyclists, as Jake likes to cycle 90 miles a day and Debbie rides 100 km a day. Both are going to San Francisco, and both had a limited time to get there. I was sure glad to meet both of them. I went for another delightful shower and back to the campsite, after I had  hot chocolate came Gael calling my name. I was surprise to see him and he said that they had a campsite in another section.
