I was hesitating to move with them as I really thought I would have more fun with Debbie and Jake but moved anyways, just to be nice. After meeting again everybody I announced that today would be our last night as I wanted to go the distance tomorrow and always. I also added, to explain myself a bit better, that I felt it was time to say goodbye and to go my own way.  We had dinner: for me it was mashed potatoes and pastrami, along with fried onions and pepper. Not so great but oh well. I ate it all. After dinner I went back to my old site to see Jake and Debbie and explain why I played Houddini on them (they were at the beach when I changed site) and I got Debbie's e-mail address so we keep in touch and go cycling together when we would both be back in town. I was hoping to ride with them tomorrow and I figured that I might even meet Jake at the next campsite as I wanted to do 80 miles. 
   We stopped at Gold Beach (name of a town) and had coffee and second breakfast and then we stopped for laundry, also to allow the fog to lift up. After that we headed for Cape Sebastian which look quite steep in my guide book but I managed, slowly but steadily. On top, Jake and I lost Debbie and Jake wanted to see the cape, but oh! That extra uphill was so steep!!! 20% grade. I was on big gears and tried to change to the smallest gear and my chain jammed again and I fell, hurting myself this time, in my crotch and opening my knee-once more. Ouch. I stay sitting for a while till the pain subsides than I lifted my bike and walked up that hill, panting and sweating. Mid-way up, we heard a terrible tire noise and looked down and this truck with a U-Haul trailer lost control and hit the ditch, right where I sat few minutes ago. (It was a good thing I got up). So we turned around and attended to that poor guy. It ended up he was quite shaken but not hurt and the truck's front axel was wrecked.    The rest of the day was tiring and cold. Lots of fog, lots of ups and downs. Jake and I made it to Brookings by  0330 and I decided to stop there for the night, and so did Jake and so did Debbie. After stoping I got really cold, and warmed up only after putting all my layers on and drinking hot soup. Wasn't that ironic that just 2 days ago Brooking was in the middle of a heat wave, climbing as high as 90 degrees? Hard to believe. That night we were 10 cyclists sharing the campsite, and it cost us 1.60$ each!!! That was impressive. I still didn't feel connected to my initial group and was looking forward to leave them behind. Just time to move on. Anyway, Gael and company (including Joice) would have a rest day tomorrow. Joice and I had a hug wishing each other luck before going to bed and promising to write and give news. 
   I was worried that the agricultural check point officer would confiscate my veggies and fruits but it was no problem at all, they waived at us to carry on.  I was really happy to leave Oregon behind as it meant to me leaving memories from last year's trip behind. The way to Crescent city  was very scenic as the cycling route took us in through the back roads, with nice panoramas, some farms, and really nice properties. We got to eat more blackberries! Yummy! We stopped for second breakfast at Crescent City. I had 2 orders of toasts and 3 cups of tea with a lot of sugar in it. (4 teaspoons per cup) (What can I say I am a sweet girl... Then we headed for the hill. "The hill" was long and somewhat steep and marked the beginning of the redwood forests. Large, tall trees surrounded us and thankfully provided some shade while we were climbing. I must have climbed for 30-45 minutes. There was some road work on the uphill section necessitating alternate closure of one way while the other direction would pass by. It got somewhat treturous to ride in between the concrete fence and a logging truck, on a very narrow or no shoulder at all. In general everybody was very careful with me when passing. The scenery of the Redwoods was quite peaceful and quite pretty. But the most spectacular view was on the downhill, joining the coast again. Wow!!! There was a second hill to climb, right after Klamath, and then we got into the Scenic Parkway. Jake waved us goodbye and aimed for Eureka where he had someone inviting him for dinner and overnight. Debbie and I got into our own pace and I stopped at the very touristy "Big tree" where I took a picture.  There were 2 Japanese older men there and once they saw me, asked if they could take a picture of me-an American girl. I didn't mind too much but I am Canadian, I told them. They didn't mind. So I proceeded to stand there by the big tree, with one of them in the picture. The photograph tried to explain with words and gestures to hug and kiss. I said "Well, you're pushing it a bit now" Geez, the nerve! They soon left to my relief and I got my picture taken with my bike in front of the big tree and headed for the campsite.    Debbie was there setting up her tent and I noticed Hilde's tent! She must have gone hiking because she wasen't around. Then there was this Swiss woman cycling for the last 4 months, and smoking a lot too, a not so polite smoker. We took it easy that afternoon and Debbie and I had a really yummy dinner, pastas with carrot and tomato sauce with cheese. It was so good! Debbie hapened to be really good company.  I phoned Darlene confirm my visit tomorrow as she invited me to her home when I would pass by. I met Darlene through the friendship quilt project I started on the internet. We had occasions to get to know each other a bit, through e-mail, but tomorrow, I would get to meet her and see her quilts. I politely asked if Debbie could come too, as she was expecting that Joice would come, and she said yes.  Elk Creek campground is in bear country. Fortunately there were those sturdy metal bear boxes in each campsite, so everything that could smell food, even toothpaste or everything that contained food like clothes I would stash chocolate and gum in would have to go in it. I was very conscious of being bear aware as I knew I would wake up with every little sound in the forest.
   Debbie and I were dressed for winter and enjoyed our warm hands and feet for a while, until the sun warmed the air a bit more. The ride was pretty. We made it to Trinidad for second breakfast (!) by 1030 and enjoyed good pancakes, no guilt!     Trinidad is quite pretty being on a cliff and having a lighthouse providing contrast with the ocean and the green of the trees. We took pictures and I shopped at the quilt store right in front of the restaurant for a present for Darlene.    The next stop was Arcata as Debbie was looking for a bike shop to buy a new front rack as hers broke. In Arcata there was a sort of Woodstock type of gathering, a street fair with people proudly showing their tattoos and piercing. Lots of "weird" young people there, and different stuff to buy: candles, t-shirts, jewellery, etc... We walked our bike for a bit but we had to go because we were expected!  Eureka came and went and for that size of a city it was really weird to see so little people outside for a nice Sunday like that! Well, they were all at the mall! The mall was full. There was nice drafting sessions between Debbie and me in between Arcata and Rio Dell. That was a lot of fun.    After 130+ km we found ourselves being greeted by Darlene in Rio Dell. She was very nice to offer her roof, a shower and laundry, and a cold drink soon after we came! She showed me all her quilts which are really nice. We had dinner (Deb and I were starving)- steak and potatoes- and we chatted for a while. She even offered us to use her computer for e-mail.  I sent everybody an e-mail. Debbie and I ate M&M's and Fig Newton in hiding in the bedroom because we were still hungry after dinner. There was a lot of giggling about it too, I guess because we were feeling guilty of being still hungry. I made a mental note of sending a nice thank you card to Darlene. 
     We ate quite well for breakfast-maybe we ate too much?- as hungry as we were: cereals, muffin, coffee, banana. We got out of Rio Dell and entered Scotia where we stopped for groceries. Scotia is a logging town and the company owns the whole city! I was surprised to be woken up by a siren in the morning, it was actually a wake up call for the employees!  Soon after we entered the "avenue of giants" which pretty much extended all day.    What a spectacle of greenery, tall and big trees, and the Eel river, curvy, offering a beautiful scenery. We stopped for second breakfast, I had an egg and bacon muffin sandwich and 2 toasts and jam that were quite yummy. Gradually it warmed up and the trees left place to a drier environment and we left the avenue of giants for the freeway, and it got so hot! It was hilly which got me in a sweat. That afternoon Deb and I stopped in Garberville, another weird, granola town, and had a cold drink sitting outside. That was our goodbye toast, as Debbie was heading for a longer day and I was heading for a normal one. I was kind of reluctant to say goodbye and face solitude, this time maybe for the rest of my trip. I even considered making the distance to match it up with Debbie but I wasn't sure I could do it. I went to the library to find it closed and went for groceries to find Debbie again!!! I bought myself a bit of wine and some more supply and left for my campsite, which really was not far away. The campsite was really quiet. No cyclists, few RV's, sparse around the park. I asked the host about safety and he said that the ranger was doing rounds at night and that they didn't have any problem for the time he was there. There are food boxes on each campsite to cache our food against the common pest, racoon and skunk. I will not leave my food in my tent tonight, that is for sure. I phoned Bonnie tonight (a friend in Vancouver), just to say hi. We talked for 20 minutes I'd say. I was sure glad to talk with her, not that I was desperate but I needed to share what I was going through with someone. (Okay, I was just a little desperate to talk to someone). Tomorrow I will have to attack the highest peak of the whole Pacific Coast, the Leggett hill, 1894 feet high. It will be interesting. I am a bit worried about the heat. I want to make sure I will have enough energy and enough water. So I ate rice and beans for dinner tonight (Was very yummy). The last comment I have logged that night was that I needed to send a bunch of stuff home, stuff I didn't need anymore, like one of my journal that was getting full, some clothes, some maps. Well let's watch how long it would take me to do that... I saw a lizard near my tent, the first one of how many? It reminded me to zip my tent after and before entering or exiting, as I don't want to sleep with them! Maximum temperature today: 100 Faraneit and the lowest forcasted: 44- yikes. 
The cycling was O.K. A lot of places were quite narrow and the logging trucks were out early. Fortunately all of them were very courteous and gave me lots of room to maneuver. The Leggett hill was nothing to get excited about, really. It's just very long, windy and uphill. Not even that steep! It wasnt't that bad really. Soon and without warning, I started going downhill and having glimpses of the horizon in between the trees. It was difficult to figure out how to dress: I had my reflective jacket to be visible, a tank top underneath for when I'd get hot, but I was sweatty in the uphill and cold in the shade and downhill. I reached the coast, without seeing the ocean, and found myself munching on the blackberries on the roadside. There was another big hill to cycle, and that one got long and quite hot! But I managed. After that I finally emerged by the ocean, and what a spectacle! The next 10 miles were tiring but well worth it: open views of the ocean, the cliffs, and small communities established in peace. I wished someone was with me to share the moment.    Towards the end, I was getting real tired. A german cyclist, older man, passed me and I wasn't of good conversation especially that I could barely understand him. Part of me was scared and I withheld some information, for some reasons: no, I wasen't alone, my friend was ahead, not specifying where I was going to end up tonight, etc... He was much faster than me so he passed me and that was it. Then, more hills and I happened to have low pressure on my rear tire. Oh no!!! Not again! I reinflated twice until it was real obvious that I had a flat tire and ended up changing it, with an attitude. This was less than 1 km away from my campsite but I didn't know it at the time. I must have made it to camp by 1500. I drank a malt beverage quite quickly, to relax after a hard day. Had a shower (another blissful one), went for a walk, ate like a pig, had dinner on top of that, and then went watching the sunset. All by myself. Solitude was great actually. So was the sunset.     
Woke up with an overcast sky. I had slept really well, and woke up past 0730. So this was a "leisurly morning" and I left the campground before 0900.  Arriving in Fort Bragg, the biggest town on the California coast north of San Francisco, everything was still mostly closed as it was not 10:00 quite yet. I spotted a quilt store and another shop that I would have liked to check out. The Safeway was open so I went for groceries and did my shopping for the day. Lots of people asked me on my trip how much my bike weigh fully loaded. I always answered that it depends whether it's before or after groceries. I had thought about that as I was trying to find some room for all the food I had purchased. If the front compartments are full, there is always the top rear rack where I can stack it up and then I look like a real bag lady! Then I was keen to look for the library to do my e-mail, so I tried to look for it on my own then ask someone on the street to direct me to it, and I don't know what it was but I still couldn't find it. It took few people to give me directions to find it and I found it closed. It taught me that I didn't take directions very well, or I didn't listen very well or I was having a bad day to take directions...  So I headed out of town, towards Mendocino, called the "Little New England" of the Pacific Coast. It is a stylish town, with lots of character dream homes, mostly of Victorian style. I was wondering which celebrity lived here, or at least had a summer home. I toured a bit around town, visited a little store full of nice stuff that I would have liked to buy but this was a bike trip and I couldn't buy anything, but something edible...I had a sandwich confectioned just for me and bought some pepsi and went eat lunch in a not so quiet but scenic spot right out of town. I watched the hawks turning and turning in search of their next prey. There were a lot of them.In fact today I probably saw hundred of them unless it was the same and they were following me! The way towards Manchester state park was very scenic, and again lots of up and down and the sun was sometimes more playing peek than playing boo. I made it to camp by 1530 or 1600. Wow, I am 3 days away form San Francisco!!! I met up with Dave at the campsite (which was very quiet). Dave is retired and has been on the road with his wife and dog for the past 5 years in his camper. Wow! They are now waiting on the coast that the temperature gets down a bit in Nevada so they can go visit the children and grandchildren. Dave asked me if I needed anything and I said that I was getting low in salt so he took me to his camper and his wife topped me up in salt and gave me a peach, some V-8 and some Diet Pepsi! It is so hard for me to accept from other people. I said thank you. The weather changed a bit tonight. The wind turned and brought some threatening black clouds. I wonder what tomorrow will be like...         
Ok, I didn't have the best night, I must admit, as in the middle of my sleep I heard a racoon searching my panniers in quest of edible goods. After trying to chase them away from there, I had to get up and relocate my panniers, hang them in trees not so nearby. I got used to the food boxes available in some of the campsites, making it so easy to store the food.. In the morning, I noticed that half my banana was gone!!! (The peel was chewed through) Oh well! The sky was threatening and though there were some patches of blue, the black clouds seemed to take over from the north. I left the campsite by 0830 and started my ride. Point Arena was the first town I hit, and at this hour everything was close. I skipped the detour to the lighthouse as I knew I had a long day ahead. The cows were my company for a while so I played the "moo" game and got some weird look from them and some of them got to moo back to my delight. Then Gualala came and I took a pit stop. It seemed that everybody in town spoke spanish! I found a copy center with a pay internet use and printed my e-mail for reading later. Had a yummy muffin and coffee with a lot of sugar and went to the craft store in the same complex, and bought myself a needlework project to keep my hands busy when time was getting long, especially at night time. This was my first extravagance on this trip. After groceries I hit the road again. It cleared out nicely as the sun was playing hide and seek and I had a nice tailwind. I was going much faster than the previous day, and feeling better too. I reached Fort Ross when I was just about starving. I went in the visitor center, not so interrested in the history of the fort but mostly browsing the books on earthquakes and the San Andreas fault. I chatted a bit with a park ranger and a couple asking about my trip and, cold, went back on the bike. From Fort Ross and on, the vistas started to be just spectacular! The sky became blue on all corners and I was just so happy! I climbed on high, with the ocean  and cliffs on my right side and mountains with very dry grass on my left side. There were cows fields and on few occasions had to cross cattle grills. The views were awesome, and life was good. This was the favorite part of my trip I think. Climbing the hills was effortless and it was so rewarding to see what was around the corner!          Then I hit Jenner, a cute little town marking the end of this section so scenic. Jenner was right by a river which was joining the ocean. I watch the sea lions on an island of sand, playing beach whale. From far they looked like logs but being forewarned by the guide book and looking long enough I could see the "logs" dragging themselves into the sand. Shortly after I reached my campsite and quickly set up my tent. There was nobody at the hiker-biker site and I found some white gas in the food box for my stove! I would top up later but I had to hurry, go into the so delightful shower and in town for laundry. I came back by 1800 to find the hiker-biker site occupied with 2 guys that were touring  locally. I was glad to finally have company but after talking briefly I realized that I was disturbing them so I retreated to my quarters. I had a nice dinner with pasta, tomato sauce, fried onion, garlic, mushroom and cheese. It was quite yummy. This little kitten was around and begging for food, probably very hungry, lost and scared. I felt sorry for the little guy and didn't know what to do, to feed him? To capture him and take him to the park rangers? I feel sorry I didn't do anything. (In general they say not to feed the wildlife). Checking the guide bood I noticed that I was getting quite close from San Francisco and so I had to make plans to avoid disappointment. I went to bed after working on my cross-stitch and  being irritated by the fog horn. 
It was very foggy when I left and the coast stayed foggy till at least 10 or 1030  but I headed inland and got my jacket off as soon as I started climbing. Was there ever a lot of climbing today! That was "very" rolling hills! I got to play the cow game for a while as I was in cow country for half of my day. At some point on highway 1 was signed a detour as the road was completely closed. I thought oh-oh, this is a bad deal. So I went through the backroads. Was it ever so pretty! Hilly, but pretty! I ended up in Tomales, cute little town, almost a ghost town, and found myself sitting with the bees with a coffee and a cream cheese pastry. Yummy! I talked with this woman cyclist and got some recomendations about what to do in San Francisco. Apparently Tomales is a destination chosen by many cyclists training or gone for a ride as I saw many. Past Tomales, I reached the waterfront again, and found myself on the shores of a bay, Tomales Bay, where the great white sharks breed I've been told!    On the other side I could see Point Reye, a giant national park that I wanted to visit. Then I entered Point Reyes Station the little town before entering the national park. I really liked it with its little shops, all on one street. I stopped at the library and managed half an hour of e-mail business and then went for groceries. The nice part was that this grocery store was really geared towards campers as they had a nice section of dehydrated food, and lots of take out too. I bought supply for cheese fondue and chocolate for dessert. I decided I would stay 2 days at Samuel Taylor State Park and I would camp at the hiker-biker campsite overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge the night after. I was glad I had plans for myself around San Francisco. The Samuel Taylor State Park is like an oasis into the desert. As hot as it could be today (was it ever) I climbed a steep and hot hill, then down the hill and once I entered the park, shade sneaked in like magic, and the big Redwood trees took their place like if they were there for a long time. It was very bizarre, but delightful to have a break from the sunshine. Amazing California! I had a wonderful shower after pitching the tent, and planned my days to come, especially tomorrow. I wanted to go back to Point Reyes and visit that park a bit. I was particularily interrested in the San Andreas fault and to see the lighthouse which seemed to be spectacular. The same 2 guys from last night showed up at the campsite, and this time I kind of ignored them a bit, as they had been kind of rude with me yesterday. They seemed to be a bit more friendly today, but still. I retired in the tent early, and with my headlamp and flashlight managed to cross-stitch a bit and then un-stitch as I made a mistake. It was a typical Friday night at the campsite, lots of noise, lots of noisy kids running around, some people listening to the baseball broadcast on the radio. I want my quiet campsite back!!!! "I am so happy that I am doing this trip! It's an awesome trip!" Those were the words I read in my journal entry for that day. So it was....
By 0900 or 0930 I was on the road. My goal today was to reach the Point Reyes Lighthouse. I first stopped at the visitor center, which was absolutely great. I saw a seismograph, reminding me I was standing on the San Andreas fault line and I was in earthquake country. It was pretty quiet on the paper, no earthquake in the last hours... I took a little self guided trail called the earthquake trail, and saw the fault line being demarcated. That was very interesting. By 1030, it was already hot, so hot and the climbing I did didn't help at all. I found out that the lighthouse was 21 miles away, so I was in for more than a Sunday ride. I also had to climb a mountain range before reaching the coast. Oh well, this is what it's all about! I'm doing a bike trip! The first hill up and over the mountain gave me a good sweat, as the heat and lack of wind accompanied me on the uphill. Then I got into farm lands. The trees diseappeared and cattle fields were all over. The historic farms, established in the mid-1800's are named by letters. "G" farm was the first one, all the way to the "A" farm which was the closest to the coast. The farms are still fully functionnal and I must have seen thousands of cows that day. The land is bare. Grass, more than brown. I don't know how the cows eat enough, as there is not much on the ground, really.  I reached Point Reyes Lighthouse with effort as there were not many flat spots and sometimes switch backs to go up a steep hill.The wind was a bit of a problem at the end as I cycled on top of a crest and the strong cross-wind was pushing me onto the road. Fortunately the drivers were all good and passed me when safe and waited otherwise. The lighthouse was down the cliff a bit so I had to go down around 300 steps, equivalent to 30 floors building. The going back up got hard on the thighs after all that cycling but I won't complain about that one.          The way back home I was told would be piece of cake as I would go downhill, but I knew too well that I would fight a head wind. It was challenging all right, for the time I had the headwind. But I stopped close to a farm, watching a bunch of birdwatchers out with their zoom lenses watching... what were they watching??? I couldn't see any birds? Well after asking, I found out they were watching a mama cow that had just given birth to a baby cow! I stopped too and had it all figured out: that fenced section which was rather small had only a few cows, say 5 or 6 and at least 4 of them were very pregnant. 3 of them were in labor and one had just given birth. Wow! A maternity ward for cows! No midwives for cows, but a couple of cheerleaders encouraging the poor cow trying to push and quite a few curious getting quite impatient to see the show. I think it bothered the poor cow. Or else she was getting quite tired and decided to rest for a while. In the meantime, another pregnant cow that had broken her waters was helping the mama cow licking off the little one- very interresting dynamic going on! The other cows not into the show, stayed away from the action and didn't mingle, munching away. When nothing went on for a while, I left and decided that, after all, I was off-duty and I didn't need to time the contractions neither decide whether I should alert the cowboy neither decide to prep for a cesarean section...(I am a maternity nurse in my real life). I headed back to Point Reyes Station and bought groceries and went back up the big hill under hot sun. At the campsite I found 2 new campers at the hiker-biker site. Two older gentlemen probably in their fifties. The first one talked like if he was drunk- I wasen't sure about him. The other one seemed like a real cyclist, having done few cross-countries by bike and having travelled places. We talked for a while and then I made my dinner, real gastronomy for me: chili with red kidney beans and cheese. Yummy! I added some couscous in it and ate the whole pot. I had yogourt for dessert and a rice krispies square too. I would be curious to know how many calories it totalled tonight and for the whole day. I think I eat like a pig, and kind of feel guilty about it. I understand that I need the calories  but... Anyways, I will go to bed now. It's getting "late" (8:30 PM)... 
Yesterday I said I saw thousands of cows... Well today I could say the same for cyclists... Sunday morning is for cyclists. Saying goodbye to the 2 old guys at the the campsite, I headed towards San Francisco, a little puzzled by the guide book that had 2 pages of directions just to get to San Fran!  Will I find my way? I was a bit worried but happy to leave the campground and head south. It felt like I was going uphill the whole day. My legs weren't so fresh from the previous days. I actually asked myself when was my last real day off, and it was 10 days ago.  Soon enough I was "in town". From Fairfax the cycling route takes me into a residential neighbourhood and through the suburbs. There were a lot of cyclists out, and lots of people to say hi to. It was quite early, and Sunday morning, and all those people out working out! I was quite impressed! My favorite place today, even if I count San Francisco was Sausalito where the cycle path takes us right in the heart of a nice yuppy type of place with cafes and shopping (nothing that I could afford) and with a nice view of the Bay. It was sunny, and lots of people out. I would have liked to stop and sit there for a while but didn't feel comfortable as I felt I didn't fit in with my helmet, panniers and chain tattos on my legs. I was planning to set up camp early and go to San Francisco that afternoon so I didn't delay. Out of Sausalito was... uphill, and by chance I found myself at the Marine Headland Visitor Centor where I needed to register for my free campsite. I had a brief look of the Golden Gate Bridge but alas, fogged in. The campsite too was fogged in to my big disappointment because I chose to camp there just for the view it offered on the Golden Gate Bridge. The campsite was really not what I expected. Well it was free, but... there are limits! The only 2 sites were into a valley, almost enclosed. An outhouse laid there, at sight, but the smell that came out of it was the worst: because of the enclosed valley, the odor was coming out and staying within the campground which would bring waves of nausea... I wasen't so happy about that. Then, there was no running water. I knew that already, so I filled up at the visitor center but if I needed more water I would need to go down a steep hill and then back up (worth 1 km). "Only one night here" I promised myself... Tent set up, I geared up to go to town, and briefly waved my neighbors goodbye. They were 2 men, maybe one father and grown son but it was hard to tell, and they made sure to warn me about some very aggressive racoons, a skunk and even a mountain lion that they saw last night. I got the message and went hanging my food in the trees using the clothesline technique, all that at a respectable distance from camp. That done, I slowly made my way to San Francisco... Those hills! My muscles were aching... Before entering town I spent time at the Golden Gate bridge viewpoint, drinking a well deserved Pepsi and hoping that the fog would dissipate a bit more. Lots of tourists here. Riding on the bridge was a bit tricky with all the pedestrians on it and there were wind gusts pushing me on to the side and I had to weave my way around the tourists... Not much time to look around and admire the view. In San Francisco, I randomly rode around but heading towards Fisherman's Wharf. I was too tired to follow indications on my guide book and they were pretty vague anyways. I found myself following another cyclist or following some bike path sign that would be meaningless for me but I was on a bike lane anyways, so who cared?      I eventually made it to Fisherman's Wharf but felt lost, alone and aimless walking on the busy sidewalk and trying to make room for my bike. I bought some grapes to eat and some pop corn as a treat, and headed back to camp..  Crowds weren't my thing, especially after so many days in solitude. The way back was complicated with a strong head wind and the bridge was even worse with the strong gusts trying to push me off my bike. Fortunately there weren't as many pedestrians. Past the bridge I decided to return to camp in a different way, the "scenic" route. Geeez, with that fog, I couldn't see ahead of me for more than 25 feet. The hills were steep- uh.. deadly- tiring and left me out of breath. And when I got to the downhill, it was so steep again that I had a thought for my breaks, hoping they would hold!!! My hands were grabbing them and squeezing them as much as I could and yet was still going down faster than I wished for. What an adventure!  Alone in camp and cold, I made myself some dinner, than dessert and got to wash my dishes- with minimal water- Just the regular evening stuff. I went quickly in my tent that night. My thoughts were to head out of town in the morning, as soon as I could, and go back to the peace of the ocean, and nice campgrounds with shower... My last comment in my journal reads as is: today I was telling this group of older adults about my trip as they asked. I talked about where I was from, where I left and where I was going. I could really see how impressed they were but I could really feel as well how proud I was of myself. I wanted to remember that moment, and to record it somewhere, so I can have easy access to it when  times would get tough.
I eventually fell asleep again to wake up by 0600 with a noise on the back of my tent, like an animal that touched the fly as it was running. (I had ear plugs in) I sat up straight, took off my ear plugs and listened for more noise but it didn't happen again. At 0620, now awake, decided to peek outside to see what the weather was like, and horror! there was a skunk roaming around... Closed the tent and chilled for a while... I didn't know what else to do! Half an hour later, I look again and it's still there. Oh, great! What now???  Then my neighbor got out of his tent to take a pee and I warned him of the skunk. He saw it once I told him and we agreed that we would not piss her off this morning. I found that she was having quite a round back, and sure hoping she would not spray. 15 minutes later, I decided to be brave and came out of my tent. No sightings of the terror, good. I had a peek on my panniers, from a distance and they were still hanging, good. I would have breakfast! When I got brave enough to go get them, to my surprise, the thiefs stole all my pasta, the garlic and my apple! Geeez! My panniers are dirty and I feel cheated. I packed, ate and left. What a start of the day! Leaving Marin Headlands Park, just out of the tunnel and towards Golden Gate Bridge, bad news. Flat tire. I was bummed out with this one. The tube changing went well for this one but I found a big slash on my tire. I put some good old duct tape in the inside but I thought I would need another tire to get me through the rest of my trip. I tried to pass on the west side of the Golden Gate bridge to avoid the walking tourists on the east but on week days, that section is closed and we are being redirected onto the east side. I had to climb another big hill to do so, back to where I was. Finding my way through San Francisco following the book was easier than expected but still sort of slow as I had to read the directions. I ended up in a residential area and stocked up in food at a grocery store. I saw very few people on the streets- I guess that all the missing ones are trying to pay their very expensive mortgage. Reaching the coast again I crossed the Golden Gate park and saw few surfers braving the very foggy, dreary weather and trying their luck with the waves. Only then I could relax a bit, with the sight of the ocean and the sound of the waves crashing.  I was stopping often, tired and muscles aching. My left calf was having enough of all those steep hills. I wished there were some flat spots, just some of the time! Daly City offered me a rest as I posted few post cards and then I found a library. I must have sat there for a full hour and sent out a few e-mails. It felt good to keep in touch with the world and keep my whole trip in perspective after such a rough night. Part of me didn't know what I was doing on the road. I was just bummed out, tired, dirty from the flat tire, and needed a shower, a massage, a haircut, a manicure, a pedicure and also have my eyebrows waxed... Help! It was 1430 when I reach Montara and went to check the hostel, just to see. My destination was a campsite 40 km down the road I guess but I was tired physically and mentally and I needed a rest. So I changed my mind and decided I would treat myself and get a real bed that night. However as the hostel opened its doors by 1630 I had 2 hours to kill in a not so warm overcast day. I headed in a marine park and read my e-mail that I printed, and then I headed for a cafe and ordered a big pot of tea that I sippped slowly with a lot of sugar in it and I read the paper.    Once checked in at the hostel, having listened to all the rules and locked my bike, I jumped in the shower which felt totally incredible. I shaved, shampooed, scrubed... And got to wear my street clothes for the second time in 4 weeks. The shirt is a bit beat without ironing but oh well. I got to do laundry which was overdue and wow! I am sleeping in a real bed tonight. What a delight.      I had a relaxing evening at the hostel. It might be the best location of all the hostels I've seen so far being a lighthouse and on the coast, you can go on the cliffs, and look at the spectacular scenery north, south and west. I went out for the sunset, sitting on the rocks, listening to the waves crashing and watching that big ball of fire falling in the ocean. I felt a bit nostalgic and lonesome but appreciated the solitude like an old buddy.    I had dinner accompanied by few hostellers, this Slovenian girl waiting for her job to start, this guy from Toronto asking about my trip, those 2 UK old guys on a Coast tour, and this young german couple on a car trip. I managed to cross-stitch a bit and then, very early, called it a day. 
It started by 0830: my regular time to leave. I woke up by 0530 in a real bed and never made it back to sleep. But that's ok. I slept well. Had a yummy breakfast, the same old thing, bagels with peanut butter and this time toasted, imagine that! I really enjoyed it. Ana, from Germany and her boyfriend gave me the same brand of peanut butter I have been using, the one with a Crispy Crunch in it as they didn't like it and the 2 old guys offered me a glass of orange juice that I gladly accepted. That was great! I did my chores that the hostel expect you to do in the morning (I swept the kitchen floor) and left. The cycling today was a bit monotonous. Lots and lots of fields of brussel sprouts. Met up with Brian, a  cyclist out for a day ride. We rode together for an hour, talking along the way. I was panting parts of it to keep up with him but that was ok because I like to challenge myself. That was nice to have company. At some point I lost control in the sand- beware of the sand as it makes it very slippery for the bike- and fell... However was that ever a nice fall!!!! Painless. There was a sand dune where I landed so I was really stunned to be unhurt! It's like falling into some powder snow.  The worst I had was some sand into my newly lube chain, but I took out most of it and didn't feel grinding at all. In the same section I saw some "sleeping" deers on the road side, with some blood coming out of their nose...Arrrgh...In the middle of the day I stopped in a pretty spooky corner store. The fruits were all covered with fruit flies, and I was looking for a bag of chips and one bag was opened and half eaten. The shelves were half empty and there were beef jerky left on the counter in the open, uncovered.  I was hungry and there was no other choice of store so I stuck with the safest: a Pepsi and some salty crunchy thing and left. Looking for a snack shop was difficult- brussel sprouts fields all over, the odd pumpkin patch, field all the way to the cliffs and no beach access. So I ate quickly on the road side, watching the cars and the semis passing by.I made it in Santa Cruz in good time and toured the pier and some of the shops.      Edit     | Relation     | Bookmark     | Printable     | Report     | Link     Rating:  (0)       Typical picture of the Santa Cruz Pier... Everything was close when I was there.I looked specifically for a stationnary as I needed to replace my journal that was full. I found this cute journal that would keep my deepest thoughts and who knows would travel with me to some other corner of the earth. Santa Cruz seems to have a lot of young people that don't know what to do with themselves, lots of tattoed and pierced people. I was glad to have my campsite out of town. After grocery shopping I reached the state park following my instinct-and got it right. (The map was not so detailed). I was worried of transcient people invading the hiker-biker as I saw one just out of the campground but it was not the case. To my surprise there were 2 cyclists at the campsite. Henk is a Dutch guy my age cycling from Alaska to Panama, and Ward is someone he met along the way, cycling from San Francisco to Carmel (Monterrey peninsula). They were really nice guys, and we had dinner together with me interrrupting to catch up a glimpse of the sunset. We spent the evening sitting on the pik nik table, laughing lots, writing our journal and post cards and sharing stories. It was quite refreshing to share with other cyclists.      Edit     | Relation     | Bookmark     | Printable     | Report     | Link     Rating:  (0)       South of Santa Cruz...We got harrassed by quite a few young racoons in the learning of being pests and thiefs for us the human kind. I must admit that when they passed very close to where we were, I screamed and stood up on the table... :) How's that for brave?  In the middle of the day I stopped in a pretty spooky corner store. The fruits were all covered with fruit flies, and I was looking for a bag of chips and one bag was opened and half eaten. The shelves were half empty and there were beef jerky left on the counter in the open, uncovered.  I was hungry and there was no other choice of store so I stuck with the safest: a Pepsi and some salty crunchy thing and left. Looking for a snack shop was difficult- brussel sprouts fields all over, the odd pumpkin patch, field all the way to the cliffs and no beach access. So I ate quickly on the road side, watching the cars and the semis passing by. I made it in Santa Cruz in good time and toured the pier and some of the shops.    I looked specifically for a stationnary as I needed to replace my journal that was full. I found this cute journal that would keep my deepest thoughts and who knows would travel with me to some other corner of the earth. Santa Cruz seems to have a lot of young people that don't know what to do with themselves, lots of tattoed and pierced people. I was glad to have my campsite out of town. After grocery shopping I reached the state park following my instinct-and got it right. (The map was not so detailed). I was worried of transcient people invading the hiker-biker as I saw one just out of the campground but it was not the case. To my surprise there were 2 cyclists at the campsite. Henk is a Dutch guy my age cycling from Alaska to Panama, and Ward is someone he met along the way, cycling from San Francisco to Carmel (Monterrey peninsula). They were really nice guys, and we had dinner together with me interrrupting to catch up a glimpse of the sunset. We spent the evening sitting on the pik nik table, laughing lots, writing our journal and post cards and sharing stories. It was quite refreshing to share with other cyclists.    We got harrassed by quite a few young racoons in the learning of being pests and thiefs for us the human kind. I must admit that when they passed very close to where we were, I screamed and stood up on the table... :) How's that for brave? 
I woke up at 0700, slept well. As I opened the tent door I noticed this person sleeping on the pik nik table across, on a blue tarp, and in a sleeping bag. That made me feel uneasy. First I thought about my food and second I was wondering whether my bike was still there. How's that for judgemental? I was being aware of that. Then I thought it could have been Ward, as he told me last night he didn't have a tent but just a thin bivouac. Maybe he got tired to be harrassed by the racoons? Well Ward was sleeping where he set up last night, so I felt uneasy. Yep, there were some homeless in the hiker-biker, exactly what I had been told for the south of California. Then she got up. That was a woman! Oh well I give up guessing what she was doing there, beyond trying to sleep. Today I rode with Henk. We actually got along well and riding at the same pace. He had quite the nice mountain bike with full suspension and disk breaks  and a BOB trailer, one of those thin trailers with one wheel in the back. We talked lots, each about our lives, we laughed, and had a good time. There were lots of fruits and vegetable fields around, brussel sprouts, cauliflower, cabbage, and I saw for the very first time how artichoke grow, and we saw so many strawberry fields! I wanted to stop and sit down and eat strawberries. They were ripe and the smell made my mouth water! Yummy. I had the urge to make strawberry jam... That's the part of me that want a country home, make bread, do canning, and make jam. Most of the route today was off the highway and well marked too for cyclists. Maybe a third of the distance was a separate cycling path which made the cycling care free. Henk and I stopped in a fruit stand for strawberries. They were so yummy! Not the ones you would get in Canada. Those that we ate were freshly picked.I ate them almost all at once. Then we stopped for e-mail in a very spanish town. We wanted to use the computers together but in this strip mall where the library was this lady from an adjacent business came out and warned us of not leaving the bikes alone, for safety reasons. So we took turns. I got mail and it really warmed my heart to read from all my friends and from people that cared about me. As I was waited for I wrote a short note and left for more cycling. The sun decided to show up by that time. Henk and I took some pictures of ourselves when we got near Monterrey and then went looking for Ward at Fisherman Wharf.        We didn't find him there but we decided to have a drink, and relax a bitand had a tour of the pier. Henk was invited at Ward's sister place farther than where I was going, so we carried on until my campsite and we parted with the trust that we'd meet farther down the coast.     Now, I've been told a lot of stories about Vets Memorial Park, about how this was a druggies place and how unsafe it was. So I spent a lot of time looking at the park rules, the map and I asked around if the campsite was safe. The park ranger assured me that it was. Still unsure, I went to the hiker-biker and looked around. There were few tents already there but no occupants as this was the afternoon still. One tent was canvas suggesting hippie like people. I pitched my tent and went in town, going down that big hill that was so hard to climb! First stop, the post office. I mailed myself a parcel including my gore-tex jacket, my cycling rain pants that I didn't use, my journal that was finished and few maps. 5 pounds worth! Second stop, the library. Then I went to Safeway, stocked up and reluctantly went back to camp. Well, there were quite a few cyclists there, 2 guys I met earlier in the day, one in recumbant. One older guy over 70 doing a circle around North America and a young 19 year old guy that learned to bike 2 months ago and now going from San Francisco to San Diego. Another guy was in the campsite, probably not a cyclist but he was playing flute while I was having dinner. Weird. Well, the lesson for me is not making too many assumptions about things. Few words about the 2 men, one in a recumbent. This guy was soooo excentric! Both were family men, doing a short 5 days trip. Mr recumbant doesn't like to travel at all but loves weird bikes. The first day of his bike trip he was wearing jeans. He got quite hot so that night at the campsite he made himself some shorts out of his jeans!!! :)  That night I had my favorite meal: ramen nooddles with carrots and corn and threw in this yummy yellow cheddar cheese... Yummy! Went to bed early. 
   I made it to Big Sur-Pfeiffer State Park by 1700, late for my liking and I met George, a cyclist that Henk met and cycled with for 2 weeks. George is cycling from Wisconsin, went on the Northern Tier to Florence, Oregon then is heading to Los Angeles and hopefully to Florida after that. Wow. We had a nice chat while I had dinner, discussed each other's plans and then darkness came in, so soon... Ryan (the 19 year old guy) is here too and we stood by a little pit fire before retiring into our respective quarters. There were no real spectacular sceneries today because of the clouds. Well it is spectacular but harder to see! I hope to sleep well tonight as tomorrow I will have a long day. 
     George and I met again for a snack shortly before noon and we had a hot dog, believe it or not, my first of the year! A very expensive one too. Oh well, I was hungry. After attacking 2 steep and long hills, the descent got exhilarating and very scenic.    I found myself on a very different terrain, rather flat with some very gentle rolling hills, but it seemed endless!!! I thought there would be only 10-15 km of that to go before the campsite but I think it was more than that. I was tired, I could feel the energy leaving my body. The book said to keep my eyes open for the Hearst Castle which could be seen from far away up in the hills and I could not see it at all and got me discouraged, until I reached the historic part of San Simeon where I bought myself some Pepsi and chips and sat down for a while until I got frozen (wasen't that warm). Then I went to the San Simeon visitor center where I booked a  tour for the next day as well as a ticket for the movie presented. I am actually looking forward to it, it seems promising. Tomorrow is my day off and I absolutely need to do laundry and hope to get on the internet if I can. I had some pasta with tomato sauce dinner again tonight (Debbie's recipe) and George shared his little bottle of wine with me and I shared my banana bread with frosting with him. That was a nice dinner. Then came Ed, that I met earlier today. He had been touring from Ohio (so he says) to the coast then down to San Diego. Then he got everything on his bike stolen when eating at a restaurant (panniers, sleeping bag, tent, everything) and had to buy everything again and headed back towards San Francisco again for a job opportunity but changed his mind again and is now returning to San Diego. He is quite a weird guy, not inspiring confidence to me. He is also quite unpleasant. Overweight, I wonder how he crossed the USA... He had a liter of milk and a bag of chips for dinner. It is not quite 8 PM yet and I am pretty tired, so will go to sleep soon. Good night 
       Wow, how impressive. Surrended by statues, lots of tiles, some white columns reminding me the greek architecture. Stunning. We weren't allowed to take any pictures with flash indoors AND outdoors as we were told that some peope have fell in the pool blinded by the flash- Duh! Then we went to visit one of the many guest house. Tapestry inside, nice carpets and ...wow! Then we went in the castle itself, passing by the main entrance, living room, dining room, game room, movie room. Very impressive architecture, accessories, tiles on the wall. Mr Hearst was a collector. He travelled in all those different countries and purchased those expensive and ancient pieces of art, statues, roof peices, carpets, tapestries, etc... Our last item to see was the indoor pool.     Very stunning. made of blue tiles and gold (24 carats) there was gold on the floor, walls, ceiling, and even the pool bottom. It was a big wow! I really enjoyed my visit. Back to camp, Henk was there!!!! So there was George, Henk and me. We had a nice dinner together, George gave me a piece of chicken. I made myself a vegetable soup with chicken and orzo. To my surprise, the orzo takes a little while to cook, but oh well. I shared some white chocolate and macademia nut cookies for dessert. Tomorrow I get to cycle again! :) I have to cycle with all I ate today. It was way too much! Will go to bed and get my shoes off as they are wet... Good night 
     We carried on and headed towards San Luis Obispo. Again very good cycling. It was inland and it got quite hot. We found the hostel after spending time searching real good but it didn't open till 4:30 PM so we had 2 hours to kill. I still had lots of energy to spend  and went on a tour around town on my own. I found a young woman sitting on a front lawn with a parrot on her shoulder. Red-headed amazon, age 43 years old!!! We chatted for a while, and I remembered my little bird waiting for me back home.(Also an amazon parrot) Back at the hostel, I sat with George and Henk still waiting for the hostel to open and sunbathed a bit. I was amazed at my wonderful cyclist tan, nice brown legs and arms but very white hands where I wear my cycling gloves. I was very proud of them, even if it looked real weird. I am now a real cyclist! They wanted 18$ Us for the hostel, which is not so expensive if you think about it but real luxury for me travelling for 6 weeks. We had yet another nice dinner night; I had some pasta again, same recipe (leftovers) and Henk shared his falafel. That evening I reserved my hostel rooms for the rest of my trip, the last 5 nights. I would also book my return flight back to Vancouver. The countdown is on, and I am not sure I am very pleased abut that.
   After 130 something kilometers I made it to camp, Gaviota State Park. Very windy, small beach and helpless camp host ( I asked him whether there was some racoons around and he didn't know as HE sleeps in a luxurious RV) I am writing those words on the fishing wharf so typical of the Southern California, awaiting for the sunset so I can take a picture. Another cyclist showed up and we got acquainted. I was glad to have some company again tonight. He sounds quite friendly. I more week to go as I booked my flightback home. It will be Los Angeles to Vancouver, so I will have to arrange transportation back to LA.   
   We made it to Santa Barbara's outskirts in good time and spotted a bike shop quickly where I bought a new tube and got a free map of Santa Barbara and the surroundings. After eating a yummy sandwich Sam and I parted (to my relief) and I headed south, then east, looking for the library. I could tell I was going more and more south as people grew oranges and grapefruits in their backyards, the soil is a bit darker orange and the houses are getting a bit more luxurious. Santa Batbara is really friendly for cyclists with special bike lanes and paths all through the city. The Coast path took me through the university campus, right in the middle of it. There was about a thousand bikes parked there. Then I went around the airport and stopped to watch a plane land, passing couple of inches above my helmet and I hit the library. I worked on an e-mail for my friends and my time was up.    I searched for the fabric store, my next stop, and bent my rule and purchased fabric. I don't have a clue what I am gona do with it, but it felt so good to touch and squish it!!! (I know, I am an addict...)     The meandering through Santa Barbara (and the errands) took longer than expected and I ended up in a filthy rich neighbourhood, no store in view and actually more than starving, with no snacks, no M&M in my handlebar bag. My blood sugar was getting low, the bike slower and heavier.It's called bonking in cycling terms. Fortunately I had peanut butter and bagels, which I devoured until I reached a groceery store. This was a lesson to learn. Never run out of M&M's. The rich people houses were not seen from the road as the fences would be too high, or there would be brushes or big trees to hinder the view. The ones I saw were palace overlooking the ocean, well manicured yards with a lot of flower gardens. Big wow. I didn't take much pictures today. I thought that the panoramas were kind of the same all along and I would like some pictures of myself and nobody to take them. I reached the campsite by 1730 after groceries and splurging in a chocolate filled pie (yummy) I was tired at that time and did not expect to cover that much distance today. A swiss couple travelling by tandem was at the hiker-biker and we attempted a conversation but their english was quite restricted. I had cheese fondue for dinner with whiite wine. It was quite yummy! And then Sam showed up and now he announce that he is changing his itinary and wants to go to the border with me. Help!!!! I want my space!!!!! It is 7:45 PM and I am ready for bed... good night 
   The morning of cycling was going quite well until 10:30. I visitted the Channel Island visitor center, and out of there, on a bridge, pfffffft! Flat tire. Rear one. It was a bad day to have a flat tire, knowing that I had a long day. Oh well. I set the timer, changed the flat, and beep: 20 minutes. That is including putting all my stuff back on the rack and fiddling with the tire on the rim. Not bad! I couldn't manage to get enough air in the tire so looked for a gas station, to no avail, until I reached the outskirt of Oxnard. There, this guy in a Honda stopped right ahead of me and asked me where I was going, and where I came from and if I needed anything. I asked for the closest gas station for air, which he gave me directions for. I thanked him for that and headed my way but maybe 1 or 2 minutes after that my tire was totally flat. Angry and frustrated, I started to change the tube with the new spare I bought yesterday and the same guy showed up again with a hand pump (the foot type).I wasen't in a good mood but he happened to be very helpful so I was grateful for his help. He showed me a map of the area and showed me my way. Inflated my tire. Gave me his business card and told me he was working at L.A. Airport and could help me box my bike or find a box for me. Wow. He gave me 2 bananas and one apple and asked me if I had enough water. I couldn't believe that. What a nice person.  With an inflated tire (I like them like that) I left again, south, through Oxnaard, and Port Hueneme and followed the Pacific Coast cycling route signs. Left, right, straight, right, left... The signs weren't always there so I has to wonder whether I was in the right way. I past a naval base, a huge one and a missile test center, and then reached the coast again. It was quite hot, had forgotten to apply sunscreen and wouldn't do it now with greassy hands. The surroundings were just the same, and not the same. Some veggie and strawberry fields, some orange orchards, lemon too, and red pepper... The mountains were quite close to the shore past the naval base. Bare mountains with a bit of brush on it and very little beach, with some surfers apprearing at times when the surf was cooperating. Past that I found a bare campsite by the 101 and by the beach and stopped for a quick bite to eat as my energies were quite low. Malibu came, and stretched and stretched and stretched. The houses, and the castles by the ocean were mostly hidden. All I could see was the fences. I passed the time trying to decide which celebrity would make their home there. I would never find out. I didn't see anybody I knew. The traffic was quite heavy but thankfully the shoulder was quite wide in most places. After 110 km, I was quite tired but I had to remain alert in the traffic as getting closer to Santa Monica, the shoulder narrowed, and narrowed even more, and I had to watch for those cars not so well parked on the shoulder, and I had to watch for the crazy drivers. Fortunately, nothing bad happened and nobody honked at me. I went to the grocery store before entering Santa Monica and then got on the L.A. bike path, right in the middle of the beach, where so many people rollerblade, walk, run and bike all along L.A. I was way too tired to stop and take pictures and was dying to find the hostel, which I did without too many problem. Santa Monica Hostel is a big one. I am on the 4th floor in a 8 bed dorm and on the second level. I got my bike locked in, took all my stuff to my bedroom and had a lovely shower. I got to scrub my chain tattoos, put deodorant and got my street clothes on! After dinner I was meaning to do laundry but there was no soap as the soap dispenser is broken. I got to bed early, with the last thought on my journal for that day: I hope nobody in my dorm snores! 
       Back to the hostel I was exhausted! I went up to my dorm and just lay there. I think I am getting a virus or something. My nose was plugged last night and I have this headache too. My muscles ache.... Hum! I hope it will be better tomorrow. My roommate came with some laundry soap and gave me some so I can do some laundry. And I did. Yay! Clean clothes!!! It was getting quite smelly in my locker. I worked on my needlework while laundry was being processed and went for groceries afterwards. Not much really. Just the little life. I had Ramen noodles, corn, carrots and cheese for dinner. Really wanted to be alone for dinner but this older couple on a circle-the-globe tour invited me to their table and made me conversation. They weren't really listening to what I had to say, even though I was listening and commenting on what they had to say. I was relieved to finish eating and get out of table. I spent a quiet evening in front of the tv, cross-stitching and thinking. Will go to bed early again today. Tomorrow is a cycling day. Go south. Go girl!!! Go to the border... 
     Little action there, just the odd runner or walker. It took me just about an hour to reach the airport. I made a mental note for myself as I would take the same route on Monday to take my plane. I took my first break at Manhattan beach. I stopped and had a yummy apple. Another cyclist stopped and presented himself: John. He was nice. We chatted for a bit as he was waiting for his buddy. He was kind of impressed by my trip and I think he would have like to cycle a bit with me but once his buddy arrived, they turned around. As he is working at the airport, he gave me his phone number for me to phone if I had trouble boxing my bike. So sweet! We waived goodbye, me leaving south, them north, and soon found another library, and stopped for an hour as I was exhausted.    One hour there and when it got time to go, I went, slowly, but surely. I found my way after parallelling the Pacific Coast Highway for a while until someone directed me onto it. The worse stretch was just ahead, which is from Redondo Beach to Seal Beach.Reffineries, rough road, shoulderless road, industrial area, busy, full of semis, highways entrances and exits to deal with, I had it all. And survived to talk about it. In the middle of it, blue sky, and barely 2 clouds in front of me. I could see clearly a cyclist out of the first cloud. And out of the second cloud, it was a heart! That was so weird. It made me smile. It made me happy. It gave me energy. I stopped at Seal Beach for Pepsi and Gatorade and visitted Huntington and Newport Beach (briefly). I felt sorry of not taking so many pictures as I didn't have much inspiration. I tend to take the same pier and beach pictures, boring! At Newport Beach I made a detour to Balboa Island and really liked the place. Little shops waiting for tourists, restaurants, nice atmosphere, really. I took a ferry back to the mainland, for 65 cents. I was a bit sorry not to stop and visit more as it was getting late. Laguna beach was quite pretty too. By that time, rush hour had started and it was time to push a bit. I had a tailwind which was quite nice and there were some rolling hills to keep me occupied. I stopped for groceries before getting in the hostel in San Clemente and bought some goodies. I needed energy, after that long of a day! Ate the rice and bean meal I had in my bags for a few weeks. It was quite yucky. The hostel was not really what I had expected. It was a small house with much less divisions, and for a good hour there was only me there! They were doing some painting job which closed one of the dorm so the room left was co-ed which I wasen't very impressed about. But oh well. I am only here for sleeping... That was why I was only paying 13$ I presume... 
   Then past the camp, the cities started again, one after the other one: Oceanside, where I got some Pepsi, Carlsbad, Leucadia, Encinitas, etc... I got a flat tire just about there, I was tired and took that one personnally. I thought I would not be able to finish this trip if I carried on having flat tires. I wanted to cry. I changed the flat and half a block down the road, I found a bike shop. I almost cried when I told the woman that sold me yet another tube how thankful I was for all the people that helped me or encouraged me along the way. I saw a bird store and stopped and waited for half an hour for it to open so I could go see the parrots inside. I sure could hear a whole array of sounds in there... Then when I came in, they all got silent little angels sitting pretty on their perch! There were nice birds and I had a thought for my own parrot, missing him but also apprehending the greeting as he usually bites when I come back from a trip. Continuing south I met a couple of real nice people that rode with me and that encouraged me and that were impressed by my trip. Yeah, I was just about there! Courage! I saw the beach and had a thought about riding along the shoreline all the way from Vancouver and yet never swim in it!!! Oh well. The ocean was beautiful, the coast georgious as usual and surfers ever present, maybe more today than any other day. After the big hill I had been warned about by day riders, I got tired.     I must say that the hill itself was a piece of cake, really. 1 mile long, the shoulder was wide and the climbing was going well and I had to laugh as I read grafitis on the pavement like "my butt hurts!"  Down that big hill I was in San Diego- so I thought- well maybe the suburbs. It got endless, there were lots of indications to follow and I was so tired! The beaches were very pretty and I don't think I took any picture and felt bad about that. This would have been the day not to be alone. I would have liked company. I took a long break in La Jolla and almost watched an outdoors wedding ceremony but felt out of place and so I carried on. I watched the surfers having fun with the waves. A cop in a 4x4 all terrain thingy drove by me and asked me about my trip and noticed how tired I was and gave me encouragenments. I lost my way in san Diego. I found myself in Point Loma instead of downtown where my hostel was. Then this cop in a car stopped right by me and asked from his driver seat whether I was cycling with panniers and a big load just for fun or I was really touring. I almost started crying. No, I'm not just doing this for fun, I'm trying to finish my trip. Geeez!!!!! Well, he explained that a month ago he was just back from a cross country himself, from Washington to Maine, and he was curious about where I've been. He waived goodbye and said "Congratulations! You did it!" That left me quite stunned. I can't believe it just yet. I made it to San Diego, I don't know how. My brain was in no mode to function, my body was in auto mode. The hostel was soon at my feet and a little later, I was in the shower. Funny enough, I wasen't so hungry. I took a walk to the train station to enquire about the train schedule tomorrow. I came back with groceries and had dinner. An australian woman warned me that there was some bed bugs and fleas in the dorms, so be careful. I didn't care.  All I wanted was to sleep...   
   No time to get emotionnal, but I was a bit, I had to watch my bike, and the cars, and the road, and the traffic lights, and the pedestrians. I ended up in a bus and taxi terminal, and saw the gate, where I could read "Mexico". I got some shivers in my back but tried to remained composed, and asked a lady to take a picture of me.       I didn't think that it would turn out well because she was moving when pressing the button. I made her take another one and she did the same thing. Oh well. I smiled and thanked her profusely. I will remember the moment in my heart. Victory. Relief. Fatigue. Joy. The emotions were buffered a bit by what I had to do next, find the trolley and head back to San Diego, and from there take the train to L.A. , then think about boxing my bike, all that kind of stuff. There were a couple of steps, big ones, to board the trolley and I was very thankful to get some help from someone from the crowd. 2$ to head back in San Diego, that was a bargain. It took me right at the train station, Santa Fe where I purchased my train ticket. Then I had 2 hours to kill, so I thought I'd go cycling in town and take pictures. Wrong!!!After cycling 2 km around the harbor towards the airport, I was so tired!!! I just sat there, watching the anchored sailboats rocking to the rythm of the ocean.      I ate my tortilla chips and just waited, taking a sunbath with a twist (cyclist tan). This guy, older, pulled in and parked his van and started mounting a recumbant bike, and carefully attaching all the parts that go with it. Well, he explained that today was the beginning of his journey from San Diego to New Orleans, the Southern Tier and his wife would drive the van day after day after day... How impressive! He congratulated me for my achievement, a couple of times and still I don't realize what I have done. Awaiting for the train at the station, this older guy insisted to buy me a drink when he learned about the completion of my trip. I was kind of embarrassed but oh well. The train was the type I would walk in with my bike and lock it up in the same car I was in. That was a nice trip. I could see the coast, the one I saw in the last couple of days, the surfers, the sun worshipers, the cyclists... I could say: Hey, I've been there!!!  A nice feeling. 1830 "Home" Santa Monica Hostel. It was a longer bike ride from the train station to the hostel than I thought. Not a piece of cake. But I did it. What a day! The train ride went smoothly. But getting out of the train was hectic as I had to reload my bike and as I had to find my way through L.A, Geez! I just didn't know!  Fortunately it was Sunday, so no rush hour. I started on the infamous Sunset boulevard but wanted to get on the Santa Monica Boulevard which would lead me just couple of blocks away from my hostel. Then this angel dropped from the sky in the form of a cyclist who suggested me a beter way, through Wilshire boulevard. He told me that my hostel was 15 miles away! I didn't expect that. But did I have any choice? I was stressed out because it was getting late, and I had to make it before dark. So I pushed it a bit. Cars were very good with me. It was a busy boulevard. Then I got into Beverly Hills. There was some action on Rodeo Drive, with cameras and a crowd gathering but I didn't stop to watch the commotion. When I got too tired I would sing, "I want it all" from Queen. That ws my trip motto. I got it all. I was so happy! After a fair amound of pedal strokes, I reached Santa Monica Boulevard, and I thought my brain was playing trick on my because there was two of them. I asked a driver at a red light, and he told me that one of them was going in downtown LA, and the other towards the ocean in Santa Monica. The one for me.It would be another 30 minutes of hard riding until I would recognize myself in Santa Monica and found my hostel. The sun was plunging in the ocean at that point too, so it was just about time! Was I ever starving. I checked in, got my bike locked up, took a shower and headed for the restaurant alley. It took me a while to decide but hunger took over and I treated myself with pizza, salad as appetizer and a glass of white zinfandel to celebrate my trip. I still have some pizza for lunch tomorrow which is goood news for me!  Tomorrow I will be home. Sort of. Late on Monday night, or Tuesday morning. I have yet to figure out how to box my bike. It costs me to remove my low riders (front rack) which was so hard to install.  But I have yet to find a box and also the right tools to remove the rack and the pedals. I'm better get early at this... Went to bed at 0930PM, way past my usual bed time :) 


Tomorrow morning, Feb 6, 2003, we leave Chico CA at 9:30am. We get driven to SFO by our good friend Tim in the SuperSonicSubaru. Our flight to Auckland begins with a quick hop from SFO to LA at 3:30 and if all is well we will leave LA at 6:30pm for Auckland. Somehow we will arrive in Auckland after 12 hours of flying and it will magically be 5:50am (you just KNOW that's gonna be UGLY!) on a SATURDAY! We get Saturday and Sunday to get acclimated, and then we will begin the OFFICIAL tour on Monday morning, New Zealand time. So... between now (7:30pm) and tomorrow morning we only have a few things to get done. The S&S coupled tandem (the infamous Flying Bilenky) is packed as are our clothing, camping gear and cooking gear. What still remains: prune a few trees in the yard, one final load of laundry, pack my personal toiletries, fill our carry-on bags with the right selection of food, books and magazines, go to the copy store and copy all our important documents as well as a bunch of pages from the "New Zealand by Bike" book loaned to us by our good friend Jeff Smith, oh and did I mention, close on the refinance on our house??? You think I'm joking but I'm not... Could be a long night. I hope the notary gets here soon!  We will try to give you an update in the next few days before the tour starts, we'll see how hard it is to find an internet cafe...  Keep on checking back!
What Day Is It, Anyway??? Well, we got everything packed, stuffed, tossed or put back, as best we could on Weds night (LATE Weds night!) adn Thurs morning. Friend Tim waited patiently for us to be ready, finally, to leave, helping us to load the Subaru with our 4 bonus-size bags (Mike's gear, Janine's gear, camp gear and the bike) and us... a quick last stop at Peets for coffee and we are off! At 10:45am we are only an hour and 15 minutes late, not too bad (luckily we left some slack in the schedule!). Three hours' uneventful driving to SFO, where the usual level of chaos was going on... about17 government vehicles with assorted lights flashing at one end of the airport (welcoming a big government official from China, rumor has it) and a whole platoon of cop cars (just like on TV!) at the other - apparently tending to a little old lady who 'ran through the security area', luckily flying with UNITED and not American with us! The United check-in line was the longest I've ever seen, which is saying something in the post 9/11 era. An uneventful flight to LA and we start in on a 4 hour layover with the hottest chinese food I've ever been exposed to. I want to eat... but I can't, it hurts too much! Even Mike thinks it's hot. After dinner, we still have 3 more hours, and battle fatigue starts to set in for me (Mike got alot more sleep than I did in the last few nights!) so I resort to the first of several 'caffeine injections' that help me make it through the next 24 hours! Finally it is time to board our plane... a 767 that holds 335 people and there are NO empty seats. Now we are REALLY wishing we had been able to get Business Class! Sorry, none available for 'frequent flyer miles'. So we are stuck in the 'cattle car'... But not complaining, too much!  The flight lasts through 3 meals, 3 movies and 12 hours... and at 6AM we land in Auckland literally moments before sunrise. That was One Long Night! Disappointing that we don't get to see a 'from the air' preview of the land we're going to get to cycle. But we'll get the chance to see New Zealand from the air later, no point in dwelling on it!  Customs, immigration and Ag inspection are never to be taken lightly so we behave ourselves (does anyone NOT think of Midnight Express wihte they're standing in the customs line??) and emerge without incident, and with all the luggage seemingly intact. The Bilenky, in an apparent bid for freedom, has punched a crankarm through the soft-side carry case but all seems to be ok. We arrive at the Manukau Holiday Park (that's Kiwi for Campground) at 8AM. Weather is downright balmy and the scenery is kind of 'sub-tropical'... we'll add some photos to show you, when we figure out how! The day goes by in a sleep-deprived blur but we definitely did do the following: make camp, pitch tent, put together the bike, buy lunch, visit grocery store and two local bike shops, make dinner. I collapse into the tent at 7:30PM to avoid the embarrassment of falling asleep with my face in my dinner! Mike joins me at some point after visiting with old friends from past trips (more on them later!) and we don't emerge until 7am! What a great sleep. 
The roads are pretty quiet on a beautiful Sunday morning as our ride takes us out of town to the south, then east into the hills and out of the traffic altogether. After quite a few rolling hills, we arrive at our destination - Hanua Falls, a local park with a gorgeous waterfall. Very unspoiled, once you leave the parking lot, there are no signs, no paved walkways, no litter... nothing at all made or thrown away by humans. Just nature. Really nice!  After the requisite photo session and gawking, we get back on the bikes and head back for 'home'. We make a loop with a slightly longer route back home. We see alot of cyclists (and cars with mtn bikes) enjoying their Sunday rides. Everyone is pretty friendly, and the cars seem to give us plenty of berth. We hit a dairy (a.k.a mini-mart) and a bakery after we come out of the hills, about 10 miles from camp for lunch (very appreciated after a breakfast of two scones!). The big score is the apple-cream turnover Mike and I split for dessert - divine! And, pretty cheap, too. We are going to eat well on this trip! We hang around the campsite for the rest of the afternoon and evening, reveling in the joy of 'no obligations'... no chores to be done, no tasks more pressing than oiling the chain (Mike) and deciding whether to cook or have Chinese take-out for dinner (Janine). This is a good chance to tell you a bit about NZ campgrounds... We had heard that they are a real step up from what we're used to in the USA, and we weren't mislead. Each campground (or Holiday Park) has a kitchen/common room where you can cook and hang out. This one has 3 stovetops, 4 sinks, 3 refrigerators, 2 big tables and a big 'free bin' wher you can put or take books, magazines, cooking and camping items, spices and food. There's even a TV ;-)  It has really nice, clean showers and bathrooms... plenty of picnic tables, trees for shade, stores nearby too! Wayne says that in NZ the Holiday Parks are where the poor live... not sure about that but it's definitely where you can vacation luxuriously on-the-cheap! Oh, and when it rains, you can upgrade from camping to a 'camp-cabin' for about $5 US... it's a cyclist's heaven! Everyone is super-friendly and helpful too. They think WE have the accents! Kind of funny... We can understand them mostly, when they don't talk too fast. They have alot of slang we're not familiar with, so that can be funny, too.  We wrapped up the day with Wayne's traditional welcome speech outlining the details of daily life on the road, more on that later. Can't wait! We also got our maps, with ther route marked... made it seem really real at last!  Oh, Mike wanted me to mention that the biggest challenge of riding is getting used to being on the WRONG side of the ROAD!!!  It's more than alittle disturbing... especially when descending a narrow twisty road with out a painted cneterline... or negotiating a roundabout, circling clockwise... or makeing a right turn off a busy road into the campground!  All of which we did survive... we only once got back on the road and automatically went to the right side of the road, luckily saved by our new friend Thom's helpful reminder, "Hey, Wrong Side Of The Road!!!" Oops. Thanks Thom! Tomorrow, we have a "Tourist Day" , we will take the bus into downtown Auckland to see the sights. We are actually staying pretty near to the Airport, on the southern outskirts of Auckland. One member of our group is still 'at large', so this day gives them a chance to show up!
