Tomorrow I'll tell you about our travel companions, if I have room (I only have one page per day, maybe that's a good thing?)... Lots more to come!
Downtown Auckland (population 1.2 million) is a beautiful city! Mike and I both agree - we could live here, if we ever were to live in a city. Immaculately clean (even the alleys!), bright and busy. No Peets Coffee (yet!) but we indulge in a cup of Starbucks to get the adventure started. Wander the city on foot a bit (pretty hilly, like SF's pretty little sister), check out the amazing yachts in the harbor (they are HUGE!) including the America's Cup contestants, fantasize about life on board a  boad (Kirk and Pru, we're thinking of YOU!). We manage to accomplish everything except the visits to the museum and aquarium. It's OK though, because we'll be back here two more times before we leave.  This is a good chance to give you a quick overview of the trip - if you want to learn more about it, visit the organizer's website: www.waynesue.com!  We are doing a complete loop around the perimeter of the north island of New Zealand. The trip is divided into three segments: Auckland to Wellington (via the east side of the island), Wellington back to Auckland (via the west side of the island) and then a loop of the 'Northlands', the country north of Auckland, returning to Auckland one final time. The total distance is 2100 miles, in 51 days.  After that, Mike and I have 6 days in which we will fly down to the South Island, rent a CAR (!!!) and act like normal people on vacation!  We are pretty tired by the end of our tourist day but feeling like we are getting to know our travel companions. They are: Wayne and Sue, organizers extraordinaire, John and Sharon from New York (we met John last year on our Death Valley tour with Wayne and Sue), Bob from Washington I THINK, also familiar from the Death Valley tour, Allan from Chico (actually one of my yoga students!), Ed from Washington, Thom from Salt Lake City UT, Dan and June from Canada. Some are doing the whole tour and some only part, and others will be joining us for the third section only! You can find out alot about Wayne and Sue if you go to their website, www.waynesue.com, so I'm not going to give you a ton of details here... suffice it to say that they have lived the life that most of us only dream of. They travel adventurously for a good part of each year (whether its biking, hiking, kayaking or whatever!) and live lightly on the land.  John and Sharon are fellow 'escapees' from the American work ethic... much like Mike and I, they timed out (John first, Sharon second) in the last year or two. They live in New York City and love it there... but life keeps calling to them with adventures from all points of the globe. Are we lucky or what? In our 30's/40's/50's with few encumbrances and the freedom to do whatever we want... excess possessions are highly overrated relative to experiences!  Bob from Washington is a seasoned tourist, having pedalled many miles all over the world. He's the one to watch when scouting out the ideal cafe, vista point or tent-pitching spot! He just has 'that touch'... Allan, my friend/yoga student from Chico is our free-spirit. He's quite a world traveller but this is his first tour by bike. He's an ex-firefighter and is he STRONG! He rides a mountain bike, carrying this enormous backpack thing that weighs about 50 lbs, up hill and down. We don't know how he does it! Back home he's a bit of a 'gym rat' but out here he just has to settle with loading the bags out of the van for an upper body workout! Ed from Washington has done some trips with Wayne and Sue before... His wife had to work this time but apparently she is quite an active type as well (mountain climbing, anyone??). Ed's other hobby besides bike touring is refereeing soccer back at home. We like to tease him about his skinny legs... but it doesn't seem to stop him from climbing those hills! Thom from Salt Lake City is not a mormon (why is that the first question I always have to ask??). He's done a number of tours, too (mostly 1-2 week trips)... but none in the last few years. We think he's trying to make up for those years by piling on a million miles this year!  Finally, Dan and June are veteran riders. June has completed the Brevet training rides up to 300 miles in one day! And Dan has actually completed Paris Brest Paris twice! Now that is a glutton for punishment! They ride the Bike Fridays, folding bikes with small (20 inch?) wheels that each fit in a hard-shell suitcase. Pretty handy! So, that's our crew. We got to visit quite a bit today (every time we turned around we ran into one another... didn't think Auckland was that small!). We accomplished alot, today, too... we have cash for Wayne and Sue, new tires (or tyres, in Kiwi-talk!) for John to replace the ones he left in NY, a full set of maps and smiles on our faces. After dinner I rally and head to the nearest internet access - McCafe at a McDonalds!!! - to enter a few pages into the journal. Back home to bed by 9:30PM. Hope you're enjoying our account!
We quickly leave the city and traffic behind (like, REALLY quickly - 10 minutes!) and find ourselves in gorgeous rolling terrain with hedgerows for fences and every sort of farm animal you can imagine. The country side is very lush (though they are saying that it's been a dry summer), and it's typical to see hughe 10 ft tall fern forests, next to palm trees next to pine trees, next to oak, poplar and birch. The only tree I haven't see here is a crepe myrtle! Dirk Burgon, you would think you had died and gone to heaven if you woke up one morning in New Zealand!  One of the really gorgeous sights was a grove of low-growing trees of some sort, literally covered with morning glories. Spectacular! Completely growing wild, out in the middle of nowhere. It also takes some adjusting to get used to seeing hydrangeas just growing wild as part of the roadside vegetation... it is a wildflower wonderland, and this is the end of summer! I can't imagine what it would be like in the spring... Michelle Watkins, you have to come here! Today we experience first-hand Bob's uncanny ability to 'ferret' out the best of the best good things (Martha Stewart has nothing on him!), when, a good solid 45 minutes into the ride, we go through a round about and make a right turn. Bob pulls up, hops off his bike and zips behind a hedge in the charming little town-let of Clevedon. We all follow, somewhat mystified, and find ourselves at a totally charming little cafe converted from an old house. We take over the back patio for lattes and hot chocolates. It MUST be time for a break, after all that cycling! Mike is totally amazed at this, but he's determined to be a tourist, so he goes along.  We hav lunch oday in a tiny town called Kawakawa (KaWHACKa-wa), where we first spot the ocean. Actually it's still a bay of some sort, and with the tide out we ride past miles of mudflats... but still pretty! And the ocean air is invigorating. The overcast burns off just in time for us to climb the only hill of much consequence for the day, right after lunch, climbing on a full stomach, YEAH! After that we get into a long series of really serious rollers - FUN riding! Words cannot do justice to the scenery... We pass many many small farms, and almost every farm house is a charming cottage with flowers of every sort running rampant. One place has a solid hedge of lavender that is 4 ft tall, 3 ft deep and must be 100 ft long - wow. Almost every house I find myself saying, "that's my fantasy house!" Mike and I have already started joking about selling everything and moving here (don't worry, we won't!).  The whole area reminds me of a warmer Point Reyes, with lots less people. If it were in the US, it would be overrun!   Later in the day, Bob strikes again. On the afternoon segment, there are two stores. One looks like a nice little market, and the other is awful - a Shell gas station with a mini-mart. Mike and I consider stopping at the first (I want to buy some chicken to cook a curry for dinner) but don't, and then sail on past the second. We hear from the rest of the gang that the first market didn't have much of anything in it... Bob, however, stops at the gas station and comes into camp with fresh corn, cauliflower, and a bunch of other really beautiful produce. Who'd have thought?  After Wayne salutes Bob's 'ferreting' ability, we all decide to christen him 'the Ferret' from here on out! The new rule of the road - when Bob stops, we stop! We don't want to miss a thing! We wind up the ride with a surprisingly long (seeming)15km stretch of dead flat road along the water till we arrive at the campground. THis area is apparently quite famous for birdwatching - it is a very big stop for many migratory birds! We don't see much as we cruise through... but we are ready to be done and don't stop.  We arrive at the campgrounds (Holiday Park), rumored to be the nicest campground of the trip. It is unbelievable. Like Disneyland for campers, it is that clean, manicured and cared for. It is an almost new facility and it really does have a hot spring - a backyard-sized pool with temp about 95 degrees F. It even has a huge shade awning over the whole thing! You really have to see it to believe it...  The bathrooms and kitchen have washcloths beside every sink so you can wipe down the sink after you finish - and everyone does! Amazing.  We all have an awesome dinner in the community kitchen (this is a rare place without a restaurant in walking distance). Cooking together really adds a different dimension to the experience... we're already planning to put together a 'potluck' where we each cook a dish and all share! 
Today's ridegoes like this: some more dead flat road next to the bay (kind of like marsh flats, not too pretty) for about 20 or so kms to the big town of Thames and then a spectacular 25 km stretch where the mountains close in on the bay. We just roll up and down, left and right, through the most wonderful "Pirates of the Caribbean" scenery: ocean on the left, far as we can see... sandy/rocky beaches... then big, mysterious trees, some with hanging roots and most with shaggy, mossy bark... and overhead, towering rocky cliffs. The road here and for the rest of the day is two-lande, each about 13 ft wide, and no shoulder. Some of the drivers are very considerate, but others RACE by at great speed, with utter disregard for blind curves and even visible on-coming traffic - nervewracking! But it' hard to remember to be terrified because the scenery is SO spectacular (watch for photos if we can figure out how to put them up here!).  There's a lunch break in this stretch, where we all regroup. We learn that some of the group has already hit a pub for beers, wine etc. I could NOT get on a bike after that! We know there is a pretty big set of hills still to come so Mike and I dine *lite* and then hit the road.  The beautiful rolling coastal road contines after lunch for a few brief miles til we hit the promised hills - two relatively short but quite steep little climbs! The first is about 800 feet, with a spectacular view of the ocean the whole way, and a beautiful, perfect natural harbor. The second, about 600 ft, is more inland and hotter. A few perilous descents (it's still alarming to be descending on the wrong side of the road, especially when a car comes around a corner unexpectedly!) and a few more kms of beautiful rolling terrain and we are here in Coromandel, a quaint, little old tourist town. We have just enough time to eat an ice cream and buy some veggies from a local produce stand and then Wayne arrives in the van and leads us to camp! On our list today is laundry, bike check and journal catchup. Wayne and Sue are leading a 1 hour hike up to a place called Castle Peak which sounds great - but we will probably pass. Mike wants to save his legs for tomorrow, and I feel like I've had enough sun for the day. They're saying we're due for some rain but I see no sign of it...right now the sun is BLAZING! It seems to get hottest, around 3pm each day. The humidity is also quite high but we're getting used to it! 
One of the things Mike and I noticed right away s that most everyone takes articluare care with their stuff here... most things aren't new but they're perfectly maintained. And best of all, we rarely see piles of junk in yards or on roadsides. There is a fair amount of litter along the road but it's small stuff like bottles and cans (Mike wants them to start a better recycling program right away!). We have yet to see a car or even an appliance on the side of the road - or even a dumpsite, for that matter! Today's ride takes us from Coromandel, immediately launching into a 4 mile or so climb, followed by a long series of rollers and one short, steep MONSTER grade - about 1/4 mile, we estimate 18-20% - into the 'lunch' stop where  Wayne and Sue switch. It's a short day and so a bit early for lunch. Mike and I have a quick snack and decide to proceed on - we can see the next hill we face from the stop. This hill turns out to be biggish, inland, hot and humid - but not too steep or hard. It's followed by another series of rollers (see a trend here???) into the town of Whitianga (say: Fid-e-anga). We're ready to eat now, and here we find a nice bakery and a chicken sandwich... and our first meat pie. We choose chicken to be on the safe side but worry needlessly. The meat pie rules!  It's a NZ tradition, they come in all sorts of wild flavors - sausage, mince, steak, pork, you name it). It's a generous serving for one, made fresh at the bakery and kept warm for us! About $1.50 US, it's a food bargain. Alot like a mini- chicken pot pie but with the most delicious flaky fresh pastry. Mmmm! We share a table with a nice guy from Minnesota(!) who has been here 7 times... he comes for the winter every year! He tells us about some more 'can't miss' things that we probably won't be able to squeeze in (THIS time!) but are interesting nonetheless. After lunch we take a ferry about 500 yards across the bay and continue to Hahei Beach, stopping first with the gang for coffee at a little cafe - high prices, mediocre coffee and a 'foofy' art gallery... but good company! And, since we never really started back riding after lunch, we didn't really even have to worry about stopping and starting! Mike and I saddle up and take off on the last stretch. The scenery continues to roll along, beautiful but we're having to work for it as the rollers continue. The campground is at the end of a steep downhill road (good to know that we'll get to enjoy it longer on the way out tomorrow!).  Wayne has already arrived and gotten our campsite... Allan is there too, apparently he just put the hammer down on the first big hill and we never saw him again! Animal! Gotta run, we're getting ready to take a hike along the beach to Cathedral Cove, a purportedly beautiful swim spot. Will tell you how it is, later! 
We made it an early night... today is rumored to be one of the hardest on the trip: not TOO long but LOTS of climbing: 3 major hills (each 2.5 miles or longer) and tons of rollers. Mike and I are a little more serious today: no unnecessary stops!   The terrain is like this: sharp, steep mountain-like hills descending right down to the ocean. Lots of rivers (say, every 5-to-10 miles there's another) and since we're following the coast relatively closely, each river means a big downhill, some rollers and a river crossing, and then eventually (or immediately!) another uphill. Then, just for variety, every once in awhile we keep on going up, way up, as the road cuts around a headland - then through more fields of cows, goats, sheep and flowers before plummeting back to sea level once more. After finishing the first two big climbs, we lunch in the little town of Whangamata (fangamata!) before facing up to the last big climb - and it turns out to be the toughest of the three (at least, our legs think so!). By now (we spent an hour at lunch, eating, buying groceries and visiting) it is the full-on heat of the day and when we get out of the cooling ocean breeze, it is HOT! And VERY humid. The sweat just pours off of us, especially Mike, and we really have to focus on drinking enough water to stay hydrated. We haven't been able to find gatorade, and 'sport' stuff like that seems quite expensive over here so we've started drinking these 'koolaid-like' packets (called sachets!) which mix up to a liter of any fruit-flavored Tang-like beverage you can imagine (Tangerine-mango, raspberry-lime...whatever!). In fact, we have gotten just about the whole group hooked on them! At about 20 cents US a packet - oh, I mean a SACHET! - it's a bargain!  We pick the brand with the most sodium and throw caution to the wind... life on the road is one big adventure.  Back to our climbing... and climbing... and climbing... and we finally reach the top, after countless false summits. Just after we begin a screaming descent, we barely spot the turn-off onto a smaller, quieter side road... beautiful! Goodbye logging trucks! Goodbye RVs! We own the road... for awhile! Some clouds even gather overhead to help give us some relief from the sun's baking (it's amazing how much color we've all gotten - already, after just 7 days!). The terrain is rolling but mostly down as we navigate the last few kms to camp.  When we get there, we find we're the first to arrive. Mike has been cultivating a hankering for some more of hat good NZ ice cream (Tip Top is the local brand, served by the scoop out of every dairy (minimart) we pass!) so we go off exploring. We find the ice cream - 2 huge scoops for $1.20 NZ (one scoop is $1.00, the second one is a no-brainer!) and Mike is happy. Lucky thing, too, since I spent our 'jersey money' on the grocerys at lunch and forgot to restock from the wallet! I had $1.80 left....  Whew! That was close! While we sit and eat, we visit with two young NZ families vacationing at Waihi Beach (each with 3 kids under the age of about 5, what pandemonium!). They want to know all about our trip and tell  us about their visits to the US and bike tours in Europe. Very nice people! The one guy wants to buy our bike after we finish the tour... we have to say no!  The hardest challenge is understanding them, especially when they speak quickly. It's embarrassing, considering that we're supposedly speaking the same language... funny! WE get back to the campsite, pitch tent and shower, cook dinner and eat - there's only one stove in this kitchen and we try to beat the rush. We end up trying the outdoor griddle ($1 for 30 minutes) to make tuna melts - yum! It's probably the richest dinner we've had since we started riding! We spend some time organizing and writing in the journal and then, after a nice romantic valentines day walk along the beach, we call it another successful day in paradise! 
Anyway, we hit the road and it is pretty muhc rollers all day. The route hits the main road, Hwy 2, after a few miles (good news is, there's another way out from the campsite so we don't have to climb the hill we went down yesterday!) and then it's pretty uneventful. It's either big rollers or small rollers... and a persistent strong headwind the entire way - sigh. Payback I guess, for all the tailwind we've had so far! The most noteworthy scenery is this interesting thing we started noticing yesterday. We've been getting into some wie country, somewhat like Napa but all hilly - no friendly vallye to cycle through! So the vinyards are planted up and down the sides of the hills and the view of them is quite beautiful from the roads - sometimes from above and sometimes from below.  Most vinyards seem quite well-established and here's the interesting part: they are all divided up very neatly into these small sections (maybe around 15'x60' to 25'x200'), separated by these spectacular hedges. Some are cypress, poplar, maybe even fir? Anyway, they grow these trees  in a very particular fashion such that they turn into these very solid hedges about 25' tall. They plant them very close together and then prune them quite severely so that they only get about 4' wide, and surround these wonderful old gnarly grapevines. When we see them from above on a hillside, it looks almost like an English maze hedge. It is visually arresting. Dirk, you would LOVE it! I didn't get a picture today, the traffic made us uninterested in stopping, but I am hoping to get another chance.  The closer we get to Tauranga (the 'real' city inland from the 'tourist' city we're staying at) the worse the traffic gets. Wayn had warned us that the navigation woudl be tricky so we are ready with our mantra "follow the signs to Mt Maunganui". That gets us through the freeway interchange, the expressway through town, over the harbor bridge, through a few treacherous roundabouts and into downtown Mt Maunganui where we finally get stumped and hit an "i" information center - 5 blocks from the campground! By the way, this place is amazing! The campground is quite large, and it is PACKED since our arrival coincides with a huge surf tournament (NZ, Australia and South Africa) AND a big triathlon, both tomorrow, but it is immaculately clean and tidy. Right next door is a 'hot pool' place where you can swim from 7am to 10pm in salt water pools heated a variety of temperatures... for $2.50NZ. Some of the pools are even shaded! Also 'next door' is the actual Mt Maunganui, which can be hiked to the summit in about an hour. We're saving that for tomorrow morning when it's cool.  We shower, set up camp and go exploring in town, about 3 blocks walk away. We find an awesome fish-fry take-away place where we just pig out, eating ourselves into a stupor again! Later this evening we plan to hit a movie.
After we hike down, Allan joins me for a quick dip in the ocean, body surfing is the BEST! The water temp is perfect, maybe 72 degrees. A quick shower and I am off to the internet place to catch up. Mike meets me here after watching the surf/lifeguarding contest and selflessly doing the laundry (is he great, girls, or what???) and now... off to dinner!  We need to check a few things on the bike and get organized for we ride tomorrow at dawn. Well... somewhat after dawn. But it sounds so good! Yoga buddies at North Rim - are you practicing???
The first 15 kms float by pretty easily as we tour the rows of fabulous beachhouses that line the coast. Then we get back on Hwy 2 for some more traffic-dodging... yikes! Some of our group (most, actually - all but Allan) take a side road called Old Coach Rd, which adds about 10 kms and a bunch of climbing. But, it got them out of the traffic! Mike and I opt for the more direct route, hoping to save alittle for tomorrow. The road rolls to Te Puke an dfrom there it gets into very flat, somewhat bleak farm country - drier out here and less tropical-looking. We have a slithg headwind again but its not too bad! After about 40 more kms we wander back to the ocean, where the scenery gets alot more tropical and dramatic again (boy are we getting spoiled!) and here we have lunch. Allan comes by and we flag him down to share lunch and the really nice, remote, rustic beach campground. Later we learn that Dan has a little low-speed incident involving the railroad tracks and the very rough gravel road leading into the campground - he is pretty sore for the next few days! Ouch! One more inland stretch where the land gets quite try and we fina a blueberry farm. We stop to check, even though the sign says 'frozen' only... I *love* blueberries! I'm telling the woman there how blueberries are my favorite fruit (no exaggeration!) and she says, "Wait a moment!" and grabs one last basket with a handful of berries from the fridge. "Here you go", she says as she pours the berries into my cupped hands, "These are the last"! Totally wonderful! Mike and I savor them (he says they're BETTER than US blueberries!) before hopping happily on the bike, energized for the last 15kms. The road into Whangatani is dead flat. As we get closer we pass this interesting jungle-gym-like-thing for adults (we took a photo), very cool! No signs, no people...just this big massive 'ropes course on steriods' with a climbing wall suspended in air, as well as tires on ropes, ladders, handholds and you name it. Adventurous! The closer we get to town, the more lush and green the scenery gets. It stays flat as we wander through town and finally find th campground approximately where it was supposed to be! No one's here yet so we decide to go downtown (starting a dangerous precedent, it turns out!), to get lunch and find the 'pro bike shop' located here. We drag Allan with us for more meat pies (steak and onion, and steak and pepper this time - Good!). Don't find the bike shop but we decide it's time to get back to the campground to make camp and shower.  After cleaning up, we head back downtown, on foot this time (it's only about 5 blocks) to exchange currency, grocery shop and search further for the bike shop. A bit of window shopping to round out the day and we are set. I'm predicting this sleepy little backwater town for 'next big thing' status - it is so charming! Ocean on one side of the main street, rocky cliffs straight up at least a couple hundred feet on the other - right in the middle of town - and flower beds and trees everywhere! It's only about 10,000 population but really nice. Probably my favorite city so far. The legend of the town's name (say: fo-ko-tani!) is that a Maori princess named Waikaka, in a boat full of women that was drifting out to sea, picked up the oar that was forbidden to women and paddled them all back to safety, saying "Te whakatane au i au" or, "I will act as a man". They made her a hero and there's even a statue of her downtown... No wonder I like this place!! Then we're off to 'home' to cook dinner (we almost succumbed tot he allure of chinese takeout but it was CLOSED on mondays!). The tiny kitchen is a bit of a madhouse as we all converge but dinner is still fun (Rogan Josh curry with steak, carrots and zuchini - mmm!). After cleanup, we all veg out by the tents where I find a little kitty to visit (turns out almost every camp will have one!)... I miss our little Miss Kitty and hope she is well! How is everything at home, Tim? As the sun starts to set (8pm), we all complain a bit about the cold as we all don jackets for the first time in days... it must be 60 degrees out! Loving it...
We continue on through some pretty awesome marshlands (lots of birds!) and into some pretty farm country. We stay inland pretty much the next 15-20kms then pop out again at the ocean, which is just the most awesome shade of turquoise blue... Mike is amazed by it so we got a photo! We pass the designated lunch stop at Opape Beach and it looks pretty deserted so we keep going until we find a nice spot by the side of the road for snacks. Then, we settle in for the majority of the day's climbing. My stomach is still churning a bit but I'm hanging in there! Mike wants me to tell you ab it about he roads (he probably notices them alot more, being in front!). Petty much all the roads here are 'chipseal' (or dirt!)which I guess is mad eby laying down tar and then throwing abunch of gravel on it. Eventually the cars driving over it packs the gravel into the tar for a relatively decent surface, but we are stuck out on the shourlder where it's either rough or rougher! Mike say NO WAY could you ride 23 tires over here. We've learned to categorize the surface by a couple of factors... how big the pieces of gravel are, and how long ago it was laid down.  Then where it's really hot, on the inside of the turns, the stuff even develops this special washboard effect - particularly fun on a downhill! The only other choice is to ride in the middle of the road! Yikes! Today we have several stretches of new chipseal, seems like always on a downhill. When a car passes, the gravel just FLIES everywhere - watch out! And, it's pretty exciting on a turn when you hit a big clump of gravel! Finally, witht he fenders, something completely new... the tires seem to pick up the gravel and throw it up into the fender where it rattles ferociously! Everytime, I think we've run over a big piece of sheet metal somehow - it makes a terrible noise! Back to our ride in progress: it just gets prettier and prettier as we go... really remote, isolated, undeveloped, beautiful countryside. The east cape is known for being a center of Maori culture and this area is predominantly populated by Maori. They have a very distinct culture of their own and yet seem much better integrated into the mainstream culture than many minorities are, back home in the states.  The last 25 kms or so of our ride is just wild unspoiled coastline - totally wonderful! We arrive in Te Kaha just as the van does, yay! The usual drill - showers, make camp and dinner. No errands to run tonight, no where to go at all, great to just be!
Somehow we miss the lunch stop again... we look for the van at Araoita but it turns out Sue went to get gas and since we don't see her, we just keep going, thinking we have plenty of food and there'll probably be a store ahead somehwere. The road turns inland and we have a series of shortish and not too steep climbs. The scenery is really pretty tropical and it's humid. The only real drawback is that there is alot of roadworkgoing on - at least 5 sections where they're putting down new chipseal (we even get to ride through a spot where they are actually laying it down, what a mess!) and one really exciting 1/4mile stretch uphill where they are completely revamping the road. Bulldozers and rollers and backhoes everywhere. When we arrive they are putting down the bottom layer of really coarse gravel and pretty wet dirt. The flagger waves us on like it's no big deal so we pick our way up the road, dodging the heavy machinery (don't think CalTrans would OK this move!)until, with the end right in sight, we get bogged down in a very muddy stretch and have to bail. We 'switch lanes' and make it through to the next stretch! Eventually we emerge at Hicks Bay (apparently some European first touched land here) where we are pretty desperate for fluids. 80 kms in the hot humidity on 3 bottles between us is not ideal! Luckily we had plenty of food though - that bike rack and pack has REALLY been a blessing. One more good stiff climb (about 600 ft) to a really panoramic vista and a wtisty technical descent to the campground. Yay! This place looks like it was probably pretty nice about 20-30 years ago, but has somehow fallen on harder times. The grass isn't mowed and the flower beds are all dead. The used to feature 'the eastern-most movie theater in NZ' in a little quonset hut but apparently the new owners didn't learn how to operate the vintage film projector! The hut and sign still stand as testimony to better times.  It's a nice quiet evening, we do laundyry and hang it out to dry. There are quite a few cyclists here including a really cool guy from Great Britainn named Kale - 30 years old and he has  been travelling the world for the last 5 years. He has been everywhere, it seems, especially in southeast asia: Australia, NZ (twice!), Thailand, Burma, Cambodia, Vietnam, laos, India, Nepal and lots more I can't even remember! He's been travelling on a mt bike with full suspension, pulling a BOB trailer and he is whip-thin. He tells us he is also a rockclimber and he looks it! Imagine travelling for 5 years! When he needs $$$ or seels a place he like, he finds a job for a few months - the travels on. Wow. He's meeting his parents here today or tomorrow (in a CAR!) and they are going to the south island for a few moths together. They sound pretty adventurous too, he says he gets it from them! What a life! REALLY looks like we'll get some rain tonight.
We're all siting in a little bit of shady lawn when a guy comes out from the building next door with two plates full of 'Rockmelon' slices (cantaloupe in the US) for us! Turns out he's from the local youth mission, and before we're done, he has brought us another plate of melon, 4 melons to take with us and a bag of tangerines as well! They're all fresh, grown in Gisborne (our destination for tomorrow ) and delicious. Yum! And just another example of Kiwi generosity. After lunch we haul ourselves back onto the bike for one more round of climbing. Shortly after, the headwind switches to a tailwind and things begin to look up! There's quite a bit of coimbing but it's separated by rollers that we manager to mostly float through (thanks much, tailwind!). We climb and climb and eventually, after countless false summits, we descend into Te Puia Springs, once a spa resort but now just another charming little town with a beautiful spring-fed lake. A quick stop to rest and recharge, and we are ready to tackle the last little climb. We get our first 'ocean sighting' and we are motivated! We don't resort to the little chainring but we feel sluggish slow... over the summit and it's a 9km screamer into Tokomaru. There isn't much here so we find the campground pretty quickly. It was a hard ride but we feel pretty good! Guess we're getting used to it. A quiet afternoon and we all walk down to a terrific pub on the beach with verandah seating, for dinner. It's about a mile walk each way, just enough to stretch our legs. When we get back, we find our friend Kale has arrived, with parents in tow! They're now off to their trek in the south island - maybe Mike and I will run into them there. A possibility of rain is threatening!
We start the day with a pretty good climb, right out of the gate.  Ouch! We go up and up and then down down donw to a pretty valley which we follow along with the river downhill to our 'lunch' stop at Tolaga Bay, about 35km into the day - alittle early for lunch! We have a tailwind for this stretch so the riding is about as good as it gets!  We have a quick snack and then wander on to Tolaga Bay's main attraction: it's 660 meter wharf built in 1929. Advertised as the longest wharf in the southern Hemisphere, sadly it fell on pretty hard times about 30 years after it was built. Ironically, the materials for the inland roads that replaced it were mostly shipped in via the wharf. It is pretty weather-worn but impressive nonetheless...  we are allowed to ride the bike right out to the end of it for photos! Then, we get back on teh bike for the real meat of the ride... up hill and down. Up hill and down. Roller roller flat, up haill and down. For most of the way we have a pleasant tailwind but we notice that clouds are starting to geater so we stay focused. We pass back and forth with Wayne in the van a few times as we com back to the sea once more... and the wind has cruelly turned on us! A few nasty little hills, fighting the wind and suffering. A great bike ride gone bad... ;-) But we make it.  Mikeand I are feeling better than in the last few days - our legs pretty strong and our butts are getting tough! Gisborne is a city of 40,000 - I'd compare it wht Chico though it seems a bit more touristy. We ride through the main drag on the way to the campsite which we find without incident, whew! Biy the time we get the tent pitched the clouds are REALLY closing in. We have a brief rainstorm and then the wind picks up and it is COLD!! I visit the grocery store for supplies (Pak and Save!) and then we have a quiet dinner. Now, we're all gathered in the kitchen (this time it's Dan and June, Thom, Ed, Bob, Mike and I) because its WAY too cold to be outside! Gee... it must be 55 degrees out!  We'll sleep well tonight with the cool air.
Today's ride is longish, with a big climb (508 meters) smack in the middle. It turns out to become one of those days when we just can't seem to get in sync - with each other (are wecranky because we're one day away from a rest day?), with the bike (ghost shifting is driving Mike nuts!), with the road (the promised 15 km downhill seems more up than down!) or with the weather (it never seems to get warm and we have our most persistent and strongest headwind to battle so far!). WE soldier on and manage to find some highlights in the day anyway...  a fabulous vista at the top of the hill, a steaming hot cocoa a tthe cold lunch stop after the freezing 'anti-descent', a huge flock of beautiful black swans (50 to 100 of them!) in the marsh and a herd of really neat-looking deer hanging out in a pasture. We've heard they have 'venison farms' here but this is the closest we've come to seeing one! The afternoon drags on as we face 40kms of flats with a pretty good headwind. We finally approach town only to face one more nasty littl eclimbi and descent right into town. Mike and I have a mission: to visit "the best bakery in NZ" - Ostlers, it's called. WE don't know when it closes but we're sure it will be soon! We arrive at 2:30 with 30 minutes to spare. We try out 3 more meat pies (scotch, sausage roll and steak and cheese, all great!) and a strudel. At 2:55 I go back for seconds, but alas - too late! Turns out in this town, 3:00 means 2:45, when it comes to closing time! We are glad we made it at all! After our repast, we tour the town (in case you haven't figured it out yet, that's a euphemism for 'getting lost while searching for the campground') for a few minutes and are ultimately able to find the campground without help. Tonights' lodging is another small place - quite a contrast to the rather institutional feel of last night's place - it's kind of like going to visit grandma's house!  It has little curtains under the sinks, plastic flower arrangements on the counters and a bowl of fresh lemons on this huge hardwood worktable set up in the middle of the kitchen. Martha Stewart would love this place! There's even a rug in the women's room, which is also charmingly decorated! The other interesting feature of this little town (population 6000?) is that it boasts 'the second biggest movie screen in NZ' - the biggest is apparently in Auckland. Unfortunately we can't get coordinated with showtimes so we don't go. It's only about 3 blocks from the campground, but... can't do everything! 
Miek and I finally shove off just before 9am, the first to leave camp, for the first time ever! John, Sharon and Ed leave with us but turn off immediately for a visit to the bakery which is surprisingly open on Sunday. We later learn that Wayne is chasing after them all morning, only to find that he was ahead of them the whole time! That's one way to get a focused workout! The day is an ongoing series of precipitous climb, shallow descent followed by shallow climb, thrilling descent. It is pretty neat to see the scenery change from arid to tropical back to arid on the east and west sides of each hill. We have a quiet lunch 'rendezvous' with Sue almost exactly at the half-way point and then tackle what's promised to be the more strenuous climbing in the afternoon.  It doesn't seem too bad, though, as we continue to roll up and down... waiting for the other shoe to drop.. We get to the town of Tutiro with its beautiful lake and famous swan colony and I start to wonder if maybe today won't be too bad, after all! We have a little climb out of the lake and 40 kms to go, and things are looking pretty good... Then suddenly we round a corner and are on a raging descent, going WAY too far down... we come around another corner and look up, up, up to the tiny toy cars on the tiny ribbon of road far above us on the next ridge.  I can't even figure out how we are going to GET there! But get there we do, and bravely we make our way up - thanking our small chainring again.  We stop near the top (but not near enough!) for a photo break before we turn away from the vista for good - wow! We get a nice long descent with only a few narrow, steep places where we really have to brake, and then 20kms or so of flat terrain into the city, passing wineries, vinyards, fruitstands and ocean views - nice! It's pretty dry here, and as we come into town it reminds me somewhat of Santa Cruz CA. Napier is considered a tourist town. It's claim to fame today is it's largely Art Deco architecture. Apparently the downtown was virtually destroyed by an earthquake in the 1930's and it was totally rebuilt in the art deco style. Hopefully tomorrow we will get a chance to see somje of it! Today, though, we are eager to find camp and get off the bike! On our way there, we see a bakery and of course we have to stop and re-fuel.  We get the usual pies and a goodie. It is SO good, in fact, that we decide to get a bag full for the rest of the gang before the bakery closes!  Laden with bakery bounty, we make our way to the campground. Everyone starts to trickle in and the evening turns into a sort of buffet meal, starting with goodies, then progressing to Sue's cheese bread from the morning's bakery stop and Sharon's, John's and Ed's wine from the Crab Farm Winery (a quick stop enroute to camp got them wine AND the story of the name: apparently the original crab place was uplifted 11 ft in the 1930's earthquake, changing it into the perfect location for a winery!)... and ending with tuna salad sandwiches which we all contributed to (think Stone Soup!) because no stores are open!
We got the laundry done and this ends the internet segment of the day... we're off to do some exploring! It's 1:30pm and there's a New Zealand movie called Whale Rider that we might try to catch at 3:45. It was filmed entirely along the coastline we just finished touring so there'll never be a better time to see it!  Later! Janine and Mike PS Many thanks to all who've written a note in the guest book, it's great to hear from you! We'll try to reply when we can but inet time is $$$ so we're trying to keep it to the minimum to do the journal. So even if you don't get a reply, know that we love hearing from you!
By morning, the sky is about half blue and half big grey clouds so we pack raincoats but stay hopeful. We head out at 9am into a pretty stiff headwind as we ride along the headland for 10 or so kms - disillusioning! Eventually, though, we turn inland and head towards North Havelock, a little town with an eerie resemblance to Saratoga in the SF bay area... vEry upscale small town, lots of hrses and lots of cafes. WE stop for a moment and immediately we are engaged in conversation with a very proper looking woman who wants to hear all the details of our trip!  After a little visit with her, we see Allan out of the corner of our eyes, sneaking ahead of us in a move that pretty much sets the pattern for the day... we exchange positions 5 more times before it's over! From North Havelock, we head down a small country road that just rolls along through the most beautiful, easy-riding countryside. WE have a lot ov milage to cover but if it stays like this it won't be bad! WE get alittle distracted as we head how an big hill towards (and past) a little pub, looking at the river we're about to cross and the hill we're going to have to climb up the other side on our left. So distracted, in fact, that we miss the subtly marked right turn we were SUPPOSED to make just before the pub!!! WE fly down the hill, cruise over the (really cool) bridge, and make the climb (fairly short but STEEP!), go down the other side and continue about 10kms until we come to an intersection that is definitely NOT on our route! Doh! We turn around, and almost immediately, run into Allan - again - as it seems he made the same error! The only good things about THIS little detour are: we don't make it ALL the way to the ocean before discovering our mistake, and we have a tailwind on the way back! We have about 25 kms to lunch, once we get back on the route, and it is a powerful stretch of road. We are flying! Downhillish mostly and with a tailwind... and the chipseal even seems smooth today! When we get to lunch we already have 90kms in so we know we are going to have a long day. The scenery after lunch is alittle less pretty... drier and alot less trees. Later in the day we do encounter some really weird red algae in this march/river/pond thing that goes on for close to a kilometer. We took a photo! We did also see our first official 'venison farm', didn't get a photo though. The deer are pretty cute and look pretty happy. Finally, we make it into camp, pretty tired... but alive! We almost rode a century today! This campground is a bit run-down but still charming in its own way. We are really 'out in the boonies'... pretty sure we are the only guests in the campground... but the owners are very friendly! After dinner (Indian masala curry with steak and veggies today!), the clouds really begin to gather... we all end up in the combo kitchen/tv room as th rain starts again. HOpefully it won't last all night or if it does, hopefully we'll be able to sleep through it tonight! 
Today's ride is a shortish one, though there are some hills, gravel road surfaces and rain threats to make it interesting.  The road is bordering on spectacular, scenery is fabulous. Even with dark clouds hovering overhead,  we are so mesmerized by the scenery that we just aren't interested in going all that hard.  Few towns today - the 'town' where we have our lunch break consists of a childcare center which luckily has a little gravel parking lot just big enough for the van!  The morning has most of the hills and a 2km stretch of recently graded gravel (or shingle as they call it here) road which is quite sinky and slidey - alittle scary!  Mike and I have ridden quite a bit of dirt on singles and on this tandem and we both agree this is some of the worst we've encountered on an actual road. The uphill is bad but the downhill is even worse! Everyone escapes the morning but not all arou unscathed... Alan ;manages to get lost again (another 17km mistake) and June has a little-slip-slide and fall on the gravel - but no big injuries, thankfully! The afternoon is a little easier riding than the morning. The road just flows along, even with a bit of a headwind! No big climbs and lots of gentle, rolling, winding and beautiful countryside.  The trees grow so big that they limit the amount of undergrowth prett effectively - whether in 'tree farms' (which are everywhere) or where the trees just grow on their own - underneath the trees it's almost parklike. We're also getting more and more close-up views of the local animal life... a baby pig on the side of the road this morning and a sheep loose on the road in the afternoon! We roll into our accommodations around 3pm. It's a special night tonight as we are staying at a 'backpackers' (like a youth hostel) that's on a working sheep ranch! We get a chance to see sheep close up  (you'll see the photos we took!), getting herded by dogs, getting sheared and hooves trimmed, and baby sheep getting wormed. This place is 22,000 acres, and has 11,000 sheep! Wow! The owner told Alan that the sheep get sheared twice (once per year) and then its 'off to the mutton shop'... except for the few they keep to breed. They told Thom that they have 45 rams to service 4500 females. Sounds like a big job, huh!?!?  They told Mike alittle about herding... apparently there are different dogs with different jobs... one to bark, one to chase and one with the 'evil eye'... no kidding... he just stares at the sheep and intimidates them (not that hard as it turns out!). Another great job! In addition to all this, we actually get REAL ROOMS with REAL BEDS tonight! What a treat not to have to pitch the tent etc! John and Sharon are having a bit of a crisis though, having vowed to see how many nights they can sleep outdoors! We're betting they'll stay in though, especially as it's raining again! Once more, we have all arrived before the heavens open and the rain begins!  In the kitchen (which is awesome, it even has a fireplace!!!), we all make dinner (I make a pot roast!!! and Mike and I eat a TON!) and then hang out. Wayne and Sue give us some highlights of the south island and then the talk turns to their next year's bike tour of the south island... I wanna go already! 
WE've been promised an easy day today. The forecast is for RAIN but we manage to make it through the morning without ever getting really wet. There are alot of clouds loooming but they're holding back. We start the morning with a good stiff climb and then descend into a pretty big valley. The scenery is probably pretty but it's hard to notice with the rain. Lots of rolling hills and beautiful trees, too. After a nice quick road-side lunch break with the van, we tackle the afternoon. and the afternoon mimics the morning... harder at the beginning and easier at the end. This time, though, it's a headwind making us work a bit at first but eventually it turns and gives us a helping hand towards town. As the afternoon progresses, we ride through another beautiful valley and then start a long series of rolling little climbs that we barely feel, with the help of the wind. Then we start down into Masterton. I'ts about a 1-2% downhill with the tailwind... and we're doing 45km/hour pretty much effortlessly!  We cruise on into Masterton and eventually find the campground (we stop to ask directions from a fruitstand and the guy speaks no english at ALL... we take his advice anyway and head in the completely wrong direction - CLASSIC!  Another cyclist gets us on the right road though and soon we find the campground.  This place isn't anything special, but it is a place to pitch the tent, and it's close to town (really close) and it's also located RIGHT next to the annual "Golden Shears" contest of sheep shearing for NZ and Australia, which just happens to be running this weekend. Of course we HAVE to stop in and see some of it... it is amazing how fast they are! Another thing we would not likely see at home in Chico!
It's raining harder as we get ready to leave so we all elect to stop off at the local bakery as we ride out of town. Wayne even gets a photo of Mike and I with our hands in the pastry bin! After coffee (Mike) and an apricot turnover (me_, we finally and tentatively set out. Today is promised to be a second 'relatively easy' day in a row - hard to believe - but it turns out to be pretyt darn fabulous! Even though the rain is looming, we can't help but revel in the glorious tailwind, the slight downhill, dry pavement and the fact that we're still dry!  We are now heavily into wine country. The terain is just gently rolling... pretty dry country but still with lots of trees overhead and lots and lots of cows and sheep in the fields. It's not ALL vinyards! For lunch, we stp in another charming little town going upscale. Martinborough is the first town we've seen with a traditional 'town square'. Apparently it is seeing a 'gentrification' from Wellington folks moving 'out'... there's alot more activity and a sense of affluence that we definitely haven't seen since we got to the east cape. After lunch, we head back out, thinking it can't get better than this morning. Fortunately, we are wrong!  We are headin gout to the coast, riding down a valley between a smallish set of hills immediately on our left and a pretty big range, the Rimutaka Range, in the distance on our right.  We'll be climbing the RImutaka Incline tomorrow so we're alittle curious to see what's in store. Right now, all that looks to be in store is some pretyt nasty weather! The clouds, especially on our right, but also on the left, are just BLACK and we can see the sheets of rain falling in the distance, as we fly along on the back of the wind.  10km before camp, we stop at a really nice little general store - our last retail opportunity for today!  Allan wanders in and we all hang out for an hour or so before the final stretch.  After we arrive in Lake Ferry, we have another frantic tent-pitch, racing the rain (we got rain half-way through pitching the tent yesterday!), which never really does show up. From the comfort of our campchairs, and with the sun glowing somewhat feebly on us, we watch the clouds on the Rimutaka get darker, bigger and increasingly more ominous as the afternoon turns into evening. Better not to think about what comes tomorrow, it'll be here soon enough! 
The wind blew all night and rain squalls came and went - nothing that sounded too serious though! We wake to more clouds and a hopefully somewhat quieter headwind. We take off with a sense that our charmed luck may finally have run out - everyone is carrying a full complement of rain gear! We have a choice of taking the possibly muddy Rimutaka Incline (an old railway-bed trail for bikers and hikers only) or the very busy Hwy 2 into Wellington... we don't have to decide until the lunch stop. Because of the headwind, most of us ride together back towards the Featherston lunch stop (about 45 kms total). Mike and I do our best to shield everyone from the wind, earning lots of appreciation along the way. John even serenades us with an extemporaneous song about the tandem, sung to the tune of Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer! He has a fine voice.  We don't go too fast but we have a godo time and eventually we arrive in Featherston! Wayne, driving the van, has time to do a little research and decides that we will be fine on the Incline trail, so we're pretty excited to see what's in store. The trail turns out to be fabulous, after we get through the first two kms of  singletrack to the actual rail-trail. Mike and I have to walk the tandem, the turns are just too tight and the drop-off too risky, but we see and hear single bikes flying (and screeching to a halt!) behind and in front.  The actual old railroad bed, where it starts raining almost in earnest - a very light rain or heavy mist, enough to get us saturated but also refreshingly cool, is about aa 7% grade.  The path is chunky gravel punctuated by stretches of muddy grass - not the easiest surface so we are pretty surprised at how effortlessly we are able to make our way up. Makes us wonder about the grades on some of the paved roads we have been on - MUCH harder riding than this! The scenery is really spectacular out here - so lush! And, completely uninterrupted by any kind of civilization. The rain is coming down pretty good now so we are getting pretty wet. The rain is pretty warm - wonder if this is what it's like to ride in southeast asia? The mountains seem to encircle us in their folds of every shade of green imaginable, packed with ferns, palms and brush.  The climb is from 70 meters to 380 meters at the summit, with 3 tunnels to go through along the way. The last one is the longest, at 550 meters... dead straight, luckily, so we can see the end. WE've brought our headlights but they turn out to be pretty worthless. We end up walking through all three of the tunnels to the summit. They are slick and wet and spooky-fun! The long one, Mike reminds me, at 550 meters is just shorter than the 650 meter long wharf we cycled out, just days ago. Amazing! We start out riding but after about 20 feet we start to get a pretty good sensation of vertigo... and dismount pretty quick! After the summit, we have a very gradual descent on a perfectly graded gravel path with one more small tunnel - we are even able to ride through this one.  I'm amazed at the workmanship of the tunnels, built in the 1880s. I can't imagine the project it must have been!  As we begin the descent, the weather changes quickly from misty to blazing sunny and HOT! Wayne later tells us this is the hottest day he has ever seen in Wellington, a city known for it's cold, rainy and windy days! The gravel road gives us a 'forever descent' where we don't have to pedal or brake, we just float along. Finally we reach the end, where Wayne is waiting with the van. A quick stop for refreshments and we begin the last leg into town. We hop onto Hwy 2 for one last little climb and then a wild and wooly descent where we are catching up to the cars (there ar alot of cars!) on a marvelously smooth stretch of road. Only John stays with us as we tackle the last 25kms or so of city riding down to the campground.  We're travelling pretty quickly with a slight tailwind and a slight downhill to the ocean so I really have to focus on the navigation. Pretty challenging! We're moving so fast that I have to refold the map almost constantly to stay up. With only a few mis-turns and missed turns, quickly corrected, we arrive at the huge campground. It is warm here! We shower up and are ready to eat... take out chinese tonight, I have no energy left to cook. It was a long day, we didn't get off the bike till 4:30pm! It is a beautiful evening and we are all delighted to be able to sit out in chairs and not get rained on or frozen! We get an astrology lesson from Dan tonight, verifying the Southern Cross, and identifying the 7 sisters (Pleides or Subaru) Saturn, Betelguice (sp?) in Orion and Jupiter. With Mike's binoculars, we can clearly see two moons on Jupiter... cool! Thanks to everyone who wrote us this week, it's great to hear from you! 
My friend Anita wrote in the guestbook (thanks for the note!) that this journal isn't up to the standard of humor set in previous expeditions  I think that might be because I'm no longer traveling by myself, and so in some way the journal is speaking for Mike as well as me?   And, these first few weeks have been a time of learning a new routine and experiencing a new culture, but we are really adjusting! Anyway, I wouldn't want it thought that we aren't having any fun so I'll be looking on the lighter side in the coming days! 
Joining us here is Susan from Cedar Rapids Iowa. She's an ex-sys-admin type, 'semi-retired' like many of us on this trip, and in her 50's. She comes to cycling from a hiking background. She's been to Nepal 3x, including a trek to a Mt Everest base camp at around 17,000 ft. Her highest summit is 22,000 ft (without oxygen) so she's no slouch, but she wastes no time and immediately throws out the gauntlet, challenging Bob for the coveted position of last to arrive in camp each afternoon. She's going to fit in with our group just fine! Last night the weather was so balmy it MAY have lulled us into a false sense of security.  The morning is somewhat cloudy but we decide to leave the rainfly open as we make a bus trip into Wellington. We have two days here, and we've decided to make today our 'out and about' day (internet/journal, sight-seeing, eat out, etc) and tomorrow our 'stay in camp' day.  We have a bit of a hard time finding the bus (it's Sunday so the schedule is a lot less regular - and less predictable - than normal) but eventually we are on our way, arriving in Wellington downtown around 11am. We immediately hit an internet caf where I update the journal and Mike checks mail and pays bills etc. While I'm still typing away, Mike has time to check out the local bike shop and stock up on some new supplies for bike cleaning as well as a serving spoon for our meals  it's the little things like trying to serve dinner with a teaspoon that can make us crazy! After a decent lunch of meat pies from a mega-bakery (definitely not up to the high standard we've become accustomed to!), we explore a bit more on foot then take the tram up the side of a huge, steep hill (and through 3 tunnels) to the botanical gardens at the top. The tram itself is another miracle of engineering, designed to open up a 'suburb' area for further development of Wellington, back at the turn of the century. It is STEEP!!!  We do some exploring in the gardens, including visiting an observatory and getting a southern hemisphere star chart, and enjoying the paths through the gardens - magical! One path in particular has its route marked by these tiles set in the pavement so we can't possibly lose our way. Cool! Wait till you see the photo! Finally, we're pretty exhausted and ready to find the bus home. We run into Wayne and Sue at the bus stop and Bob and Ed are already on the bus when it comes by. Small world!  A quick stop at the grocery store for me (Mike isn't allowed to come to the grocery store anymore, it's just too stressful for both of us!!!) and it's a quick trip back to the campground. Miraculously, Allan is on the next bus so he helps me carry the grocery bags to camp - bless you Allan!  By now the sky is really pretty dark (luckily for us it never did rain today on our open rainfly - that was pushing our luck!) and the wind is seriously blowing. We all retire pretty early and don't wake up till the pitter patter of rain intrudes in the morning! 
The sprinkles of rain that awoke us have whipped themselves up into an absolute frenzy of wind and sheets of rain by 8am. Sue takes the opportunity to fly across the yard and into the kitchen, umbrella in tow, to welcome us to 'the Real Wellington - the windy city!'  Glad we're staying here today! It sounds so great to have a lazy day with no real objective (except maybe to read a book!). By 10 or 11am, the laundry is done and the skies are remarkably clear, so Mike goes out to work on the bike. Not long after, he discovers some really bad new: the rim of our rear wheel has a crack in it (two small ones, actually ) right at one of the spokes (you'll get to see the photo here). We don't know how long ago it happened and we don't know how long it will hold together, but it's certain to fail at some point in the near future.   Normally, the thing to do would be to replace the rim and rebuild the wheel. Because this is a tandem wheel, though, things get complicated. This is an 'industrial strength', 40 spoke wheel, so fixing it is likely to be limited by availability of parts.  So much for our relaxing day!  Wayne lets us use his cell phone and we start calling local bike shops here in Wellington to no avail - we leave tomorrow and there isn't a 40 spoke  26' rim to be found. Next alternative, to buy a complete new wheel in a more standard configuration (about $200-300 NZ) also falls through as no one seems to have such a wheel built up out of components that could take the abuse of a tandem.  So, we regroup. While I've been calling, Mike has been studying the damage with Wayne. Maybe it's not as bad as we think. Maybe we can call ahead to a shop and have them order us a rim, and we can ride on this one for a few more days?  I try that for a while, and finally find a suitable rim at Penny Farthing bike shop back in Auckland, a shop we actually visited when we first arrived in NZ! So. We'll try to baby the rim along (maybe sag on any really intense downhill?) and keep an eye on it  and try to make it to Auckland, 10 riding days away. Mike has marked the ends of the crack with a marker so we can easily see if it grows any, over the next few days. Hopefully it will be fine! Mike has already figured out that this is probably the cause of a few weird phenomena we've been experiencing for awhile - a weird 'chirping' sound from the vicinity of the back wheel, and a most unpleasant thumping sensation when we brake really hard  it's because the sidewalls of the rims - both front AND back - are worn so thin that the weld is now 'raised up' in comparison. Doh!  Both rims are basically shot, but at least it's kind of a relief to know what was causing some of the strange noises! With that resolved (as well as it can be), we decide to go and get dinner (after all, crisis or no, we still have to eat!). Thom and Susan join us for a rather wild 5 block or so ride to the fish and chip place (lots of traffic, round-abouts everywhere and a HUGE wind blowing us all over the road in our street clothes and sneakers!), where we all manage to stuff ourselves again. The fish is pretty good but Mike and I agree that the place in Mt Maunganui was better. Thom gets Kumara chips instead of fries. Kumara is what NZ'rs call Sweet Potatoes!  They are in season, I know, because 'NEW CROP' is plastered all over them in the grocery stores and at the vegetable stands. Anyway, I'm not a big French fry fan but I find Kumara chips to be a big step up! They are a bit sweet, and have a good enough flavor to eat without ketchup, vinegar or lemon just a dusting of salt!  After dinner, Mike and Thom somehow find a way to fit in some ice cream (Thom has developed a reputation for his sweet tooth!) and I discover a new vice - NZ Popsicles!!! They have lots of different brands and flavors here and they are GOOD! The one I had was orange, very refreshing  Sharon and John reported eating a total of 10 in one day before they left us. I don't know if I'll be able to beat that record!!!  I could try, though! The wind is still/again raging and really dark clouds are layering one atop another as we make our way back to camp. As the sun goes down, the sprinkles of doom begin again. We don't actually even fear the rain all that much (it's plenty warm, and the tent so far is staying pretty waterproof) but the wind is literally blowing hard enough to make me wonder if the tent poles might break. I spend much of the night awake or only slightly asleep, using my arm to support the one tent pole that is bearing the brunt of the wind and just happens to be right next to my head! It would be funny if it weren't so aggravating!!!  If the wind is still blowing from the north it is going to be a nasty little ride tomorrow! Bordering on dangerous. The gusts have to be around 30-40mph, really an eye-opening blast. We're hoping for the best  and in the back of all of our minds, if worst comes to worst, there's always the possibility of taking the train for most of tomorrow's route! 
Mike and I do coffee and baked goods with the gang - could this become a habit???  And then we decide to keep on going, even without Wayne. Mike is pretty concerned about the wheel and safety issues, and wants to stay ahead of the van as much as possible in the coming days, just in case of a breakdown, so we'll be able to get a ride if we need one. The road we turn onto as we leave the suburbs turns out to be a fabulous one-lane (not one lane in each direction, one LANE period!), twisty-windy, narrow path through a spectacularly lush tropical green gorge, following a river gently uphill. One (another!) of our definite picks for the top 10 roads in NZ! We got a photo.  We truly ARE on the 'wet and windy' west side of the island now! It is literally like a tropical rainforest - except the temperature is about 70 degrees, and it's windy! Wayne catches up to us at about 45 kms and stages an impromptu lunch stop at the side of the road  marvelous! A quick look at the map and I realize that we are in for a pretty short day - there can't be much more than 30 kms left!  After lunch it turns out there's a quick 2km to the top of the hill we've been climbing all morning (getting steeper all the while), where we steal a quick glance at the ocean (photo), then begin another breathtaking descent back to it! Mike and I are being extra careful, babying the rim along, and the good news is, it seems to be holding together so far! It's a quick trip into Waikanae (Why-can-I) where we get on Hwy 1 - whoa, traffic again! So glad we didn't have to go on this road the whole way! Nice wide shoulder, though, so that helped! WE do have a pretty good crosswind but the road is almost dead flat  16 more kms and a few curves and we're there! If this isn't the easiest day we've had, it's close to it!  Great ride, great day! Our campground today, Byron's Resort, seems either to have delusions of grandeur or is living on past glory (I've nicknamed it 'Byron's Last Resort'!).  Pretty run-down, but it has odd features like a squash court and a ping-pong room and a rusty old swimming pool. Clean and cozy, though, so it's still far and above a US campground! The sky is relatively clear so we're hopeful for tomorrow! For now though, it's Popsicle time! We've already devoured spaghetti with steak, carrots, broccoli, fresh corn on the cob and numerous slices of buttered bread! As if that isn't enough, Allan has found my weakness and has been leading me into sin, tempting me with cheese-flavored rice cakes (they call them crackers here!) - evil man!  Susan also asks me to add that she's proud to report that she survived the first day with only one small 'tip-over'  that might not sound so great except that she also discovered she spent half the day with her front wheel quick release lever unfastened! LUCKILY it was noticed just before the big descent began! Yikes! 
The first stretch is not too inspiring - busy highway, even with a nice shoulder, is still a busy highway!  We turn off and head into the foothills after about 20 kms of trucks speeding past us and a mild but annoying headwind in our faces.  Little do we know that these will turn out to be some of the easiest riding of the day! We soon get into some pretty serious rollers as we head fro the lunch stop - it comes early today in the town of Shannon, 40 kms into the day. We are on this road, a lesser highway with fewer trucks but smaller shoulder, for much of the day.  Wayne and Sue haven't ever ridden this stretch, only driven it. So we have more mystery about the distances and terrain than usual. At lunch, Mike and I both probably eat too much (or too many kinds of things or the wrong combinations) and stay off the bike a little too long. When we get back on the bike we know we are in trouble! The terrain just gets hillier (with a constant slight uphill trend) and the headwind gets windier and soon it feels like we've been out there forever! We haven't, though  'Forever' comes MUCH later in the day, as we're still slogging along. The countryside is pretty but it's hard to appreciate it when we feel we are struggling so much (and my stomach is telling me that I REALLY should have thought before I had tuna AND peanut-butter and jelly at lunch! We manage to drum up a little interest as we pedal up and down through he rolling hills near Palmerston North (distinguishing it from the Palmerston on the South Island, we're later told) as we ride past the beautiful campus of Massey University. Further on, we ride past 'Owlcatraz', an intriguing name! We don't stop, but we learn from Allan that it is an Owl refuge, reclaimed from a prior dumpsite!  Finally, as we are about to give up all hope, we stagger into Ashhurst, the last town before our destination. The last 15 kms or so to here were quite hilly but almost devoid of traffic. We get a coke here and split it  it revives us enough to tackle the last 20 kms - which turn out to be on another one-lane, narrow, winding and even hillier, but really beautiful stretch of road. We escape the headwind here and for whatever the reason it turns out to be the most enjoyable (if not the easiest!) stretch of the day! Today by some good fortune we have no problem finding the campground, a really cute little place with ducks, guinea hens and peacocks running around loose. The office is closed when we arrive, but an older guy walks up and tells us that Wayne is already parked in back (he's still driving, back still hurting!).  I ask the guy if he has a coke for sale in the office and he says 'No, but how do you like ice cream?'  Naturally we tell him that we like ice cream pretty well! He says to go back to the van, he'll meet us there with cones!  Moments later, as we're chatting with way, the guy comes out of a 'caravan' (motor home to us) with two vanilla cones for Mike and I!  He goes back, then comes back with two more, one for himself and one for Wayne. Turns out he's another guest at the park, not the owner at all! He packs a mean scoop, though, I'll say that for him! 
The morning is pretty mild and there's plenty of sun. It's a beautiful day for a pretty back-road ride. Pastoral rolling terrain, NO cars! The countryside starts out flat but just gets hillier and hillier as the day goes on. The morning is a bit of a  grind as it seems a lot more up  than down  no hill is more than a couple of kms (if even that), but they follow one another relentlessly! At the viewpoint for Mt Ruapehu, we get to see a great view of the plateau we're on, with all the carved out river canyon layers cutting deep, dramatic slashing lines in the scenery. Fascinating! It's like a little mini geology lesson on the fly. After, we descend into the river canyon, step by step making our way further and further down. Then it's basically up and up and out the other side to lunch. Hope our photo of the region turns out because it is pretty darn cool! WE go a bit easier on the food at lunch today, and with a shorter break, it seems to help a lot. After lunch, we have a real treat - about 40 kms of really isolated, remote, periodically one-lane road. Really wonderful! We're still climbing a lot but at least now we're also getting some flat/downhill stretches in. Sure helps the kms to fly by, in spite of the headwind!  WE have two biggish climbs in the afternoon (just like in the morning!) - one at the beginning and one at the end of the secondary road. In between the terrain is surprisingly dry but strikingly beautiful. It reminds me somewhat of the badlands in North and South Dakota - really eroded river beds and brown hills. Susan reminds me, though, that the scenery is all much more compact here  and the hills are a lot hillier! We get a nice scenic overlook at the top of the last hill - and we are hoping for a nice downhill into town. But our hopes are dashed as we fight a headwind that's increasingly stronger with each passing km! The last stretch seems interminable! WE see the ribbon of road in front of us for miles, descending ever so slightly, but we aren't able to get any traction!  Finally, finally we get to descend right down into Manganui, a brake-grabber descent with a full complement of traffic. A bit of a let-down in the end but still a relief!  We find a  fast food join tot help us make the last 5kms to camp as we are riding on fumes of energy! Speaking of food, I thought you'd be entertained to hear just what you can eat when you ride for 4-5 hours every day. Here's what we ate today, with an estimated calorie count: Janine:  Breakfast: 3 HB eggs _ 2 slices toast with butter, one with jam + 3 small plums + hot cocoa (900 cal) Lunch: 1 chicken meat pie + 1 can coke (500 cal) During ride: l liter gatorade substitute (400 cal) After ride: 1 toasted cheese, fried egg and tomato sandwich (600 cal) Dinner: 1 huge portion of tuna and macaroni salad (3 cups at least) + a huge portion of steamed carrots with butter + 5 big crackers and half an avocado (900 cal) Grand total: 2900 cal Mike: Breakfast: 4 slices toast with PBJ + coffee (800 cal) Lunch: chicken meat pie + 1 cup dates + 1 can coke (800 cal) During ride: 1 liter gatorade substitute (400 cal)       After ride: 'the works' burger: patty, bacon, ham, fried egg + thick shake (1000 cal) Dinner:  5 cups tuna salad, 3 slices bread with butter Grand total: 4200 cal In case you don't know us we are both of average height and build, tending toward the muscular. We aren't gaining weight but I don't think we're losing much, either!!! 
The campground is another pretty small, city-run site, but this one is immaculately clean. Rows of pots and pans sit on the shelves beside rows of dishes and silverware, cutting boards and utensils, awaiting our use  amazing!  We arrive approximately with Allan after separate 'snack breaks' on the way into town, and sit around for an hour or so before the van arrives and we can get organized. After making camp and showers, Allan and I walk together to the grocery store (Mike is relieved to be again dismissed from this favorite domestic chore!) and back with a full load (our upper body workout!). Allan is getting to be quite the sherpa, carrying my stuff around!  We daringly try a 'short cut' through the park next to the campground (this complex is really huge!) and, though it may be no shorter in actuality, we enjoy discovering a huge garden area with rose garden, cactus garden, English hedge maze, Japanese garden with koi pond and island and bridge  a huge pond with ducks and a great kids play area, a swim center (I ALMOST get my act together for an evening swim!) and tons of playing fields for cricket, lacrosse and rugby. Wow, what a place!  And all this is for a city of 10,000 people! We get 'home' and I immediately start cooking when I discover, much to my chagrin, that the huge slab of beef I bought for tonight's and tomorrow's dinner is MISSING IN ACTION!! With panic in my heart, I get Mike to saddle up the pony for a quick trip back to the store  it MUST be there  and I have no heart for a repeat of the 5 block walk - gardens or no!  We are soon at the grocery store, where my  beef awaits patiently me  another crisis narrowly averted! Speaking of crises, the rear wheel seems to be holding together just fine, not worsening at all, that we can tell! Another great day in paradise! 
Taranaki (or Mt Egmont as it was renamed by white settlers) is one of the 4 mountain peaks in the north island. Unlike the south island which boasts some 'alp-like' terrain, the north island is relatively flat (relatively!!!!).  According to Maori legend, all four mountains once lived together in peace in the center of the island. But Tongariro caught Taranaki fooling around with Pihango, Tongariro's wife, and banished Taranaki. He traveled  to the very edge of the west coast, carving out the Whanganui River in the process, where he sits in isolation to this day. However it got there, Taranaki totally dominates the horizon  as you'll see from the photo!  We're suffering from a pretty poor-sleep night (turns out there's one of those big streetlights right outside of our tent window, DOH!) , but it doesn't even seem to matter  the view is so magnificent!  At first we're riding through farms and fields and the terrain seems almost level (of course we have a tiny bit of a headwind, too). But gradually, gradually the slope begins to pick up as we climb closer and closer to the actual mountain. Once we start the 13 km side trip, it really begins to feel like we are climbing, even though it's still only about a 5% grade. Quite dramatically, the scenery changes from cleared pasture to a 'scenic reserve' where the tropical forest rises up overhead and almost shuts the sun out from overhead. And now we are really climbing. We make it most of the way in the middle chainring but in the last km or two, we realize that we are going to have to surrender and we shift into the little ring. First time we've used it since we started up the western coast from Wellington! We get some good photos, though. And, here I have my first sighting of Treebeard. The Lord of the Rings fans will be familiar with the name .  I can't get a photo because there's too much other background greenery but the likeness is uncanny! We eventually manage to get to the Falls, and then somehow, spend an hour goofing around there (between the falls, the lookout platform and the caf and nature center, it's not hard to do!) before we start back down. We think we have nothing to worry about; after all we should have only 40 kms to go (or less!) on this ride that was originally billed as 78 kms long!  We actually have several options to  get to New Plymouth on the other side of the mountain  more highway to the east, a highway to the west on the coast the whole way, and a small country road that circles the mountain about half-way between the top and the coast, on the west side - this is our recommended route.  We start out; picking the recommended route because we want to have the van behind us in case of any wheel problem. At first, we are FLYING along with the help of a slight tailwind through countryside that just rolls effortlessly along. However we continue to roll and roll along and we don't seem to be getting much closer to the other side!
