After about 30 kms, the end is nowhere in sight, our tailwind has turned on us and the rolling hills are getting steeper and longer. The mileage continues to accumulate, but we still have a long way to go. Uh oh. We approach a town (on the map it's a town, anyway!) of Tumahu, where our hopes of a coke are cruelly dashed Nothing but a crossroads and a meeting hall. And we have 90 kms for the day so far. For sure it's another 30 to go  so we stage our own mini rest-stop and munch on dates and almonds while we contemplate the road ahead. The only bright side: the looming clouds seem to have departed, taking with them the threat of rain and thunderstorm!  Just as we're getting ready to go on, Sue pulls up in the van - Wayne's back must be finally feeling better! We visit with her for a few minutes, refill our water and leave, with Sue's parting words ringing in our ears, 'One last big climb before the descent into New Plymouth!' Oh joy. We set off and start climbing pretty much immediately. The climb is relentless and the humidity is high, not the best conditions for tired legs! Where is that nice cool wind now, we wonder? We do get a little break when we run into a big bunch of cows crossing the road.  One cow runs away from the rest and so we stop and wait while 'old bessie' gets rounded up by the farm hand. I use the opportunity wisely to stock up on wild blackberries though!  We get back on the bike and resume climbing - today is going to beat all for total elevation gain! We're already at 4000 feet and the end is not in sight! After the cow crossing, though, we enter a section where the road is only about 8 ft wide, the banks reach up so high it's like a tunnel (a nice, cool tunnel!) and the road twists and snakes along relentlessly! Luckily for us, the terrain here changes to an up and down rhythm that's pretty forgiving for a tandem. Down to a river, then back up up up and down again to another river  again and again!  At last we are making some decent progress! We are reveling in the scenery and the road and the bike  it is all fabulous! At last we pedal up to the famous Rhododendron Gardens shown on the map, where we stop at the caf for a quick coke and another visit with Sue.  Coupled with a Moro bar (like a Snickers!) it's got to fuel us for the last 20 or so kms to camp  unless we decide to steal the battery-powered chair-things we see sitting temptingly beside the building! But no, that would be cheating!  So it's back on the bike AGAIN (this ride seems eternal!) for a few more climbs, twists, turns, and descents (by my count 8 climbs of any significance - ouch!) before we finally do really begin our 'final descent' into New Plymouth. And it is quite a ride! We FLY! When we get into town (which I think bears a remarkable resemblance to Santa Cruz in CA), we are able to make our way without any big issues or errors to our motor park right where the ocean meets the land. Apparently there is a Striped Marlin fishing tournament going on here so we are sharing the camp with a lot of big FISHING boats! Naturally all of the guys are intrigued! We visit with a few and they seem to think we are as crazy as we think they are  so the world stays in balance! Truly an epic day. 
Most of us (all except Allan and Thom who want to rest, and Mike who's knee isn't really fit for hiking anymore) pile into the van at around 9am and set out for the northern trailhead (with an obligatory stop at a bakery along the way!). The trail turns out to be wonderful. The first third or so is immaculately groomed. It is deeply cut into the mountain (the dirt side walls of the trail rise up to 4ft and much higher in spots), giving it an 'Indiana Jones' kind of feeling, with all the ferns and palms and mossy undergrowth. The trail here is largely stair steps up and up and up with all-too-brief segments of walking in between. Then the trail opens out a bit and we walk up the very ridgeline for a bit, somehow missing a turn in the process, and find ourselves in a 'scrambling' section that's a bit more challenging but lots of fun!  Then, after we discover our 'mistake', we rejoin the main trail for a quick traverse across another ridge through a sandy-slidey section more-or-less above the tree line. Soon we arrive at a hiker's hut (our destination for lunch and our highest point for the day) where we all huddle away from the wind and cold cloud, which has been creeping down the mountain to meet us!  Soon it's time to head downhill. This is where the real torture sets in for me. The trail down is much bigger than the trail up was - almost a freeway, as the photo will show! The first kilometer or so actually has tow cement tracks (for emergency vehicles?) with dirt in the center  and it goes STRAIGHT down the line.  I've never seen anything quite like it!  As we switch onto a more traditional dirt fire-road type trail I am thanking the gods  my quads are going to kill me tomorrow, I know already! And, my toes are starting to get a bit too well acquainted with the front ends of my sneakers! However as we continue to plummet down I quickly realize that the dirt is no more forgiving than the cement was  and it goes on a lot longer! I can't quite believe that we climbed this much! Eventually though the torturous descending does end and we arrive back at the trailhead. What a wonderful alternative to sitting on a bike all day! I vow (not the first time) to work more hiking into my life when we get back home. My legs are pretty tired but I know I'll REALLY pay the price tomorrow and the next day when the soreness has fully set in. Yikes! But, it was worth it  and I'm way too stubborn to take an Advil! After the hike we visit the nature center and of course the caf located within, which is very nice!  After an hour or so, we pry our weary bones out of the chairs and head for the van. A stop at the grocery store on the way home is greatly appreciated by all as it means we don't have to lug our bags further than the van!  Susan and I share a cart and wander wide-eyed through the aisles of Pak and Save, mesmerized by all the choices (NEVER go to the grocery store hungry!). At least we'll be able to give Wayne and Sue some cheap entertainment as we try to figure out how to store all the stuff we bought in our little food bins! Finally we get 'home' and begin to think about dinner (there's a theme here  food!). I have big plans tonight, I'm going to attempt French Toast! Combined, in a daring culinary foray, with fresh corn on the cob that looked so good at the store I HAD to buy it! I don't have room to carry it so we'll just have to eat it!  Everything turns out great (the corn is the best I've had since we got here) and the final score is: Mike: French Toast 9, fresh corn 0; and Janine: French Toast 4 and fresh corn 4. Who's the real winner here? Maybe it's the grocery store! Mike and I take a nice little walk along the beach and enjoy the sunset  he's pretty tired too. It turns out he walked about 6kms into town and back, probably further than we hiked! 
Skies are cloudy but no rain is predicted. Today is another day on Hwy 3 all day - two lanes of fast-paced traffic, very rough chipseal, relatively easy rolling terrain and a slight headwind to make it a bit more challenging. Just another wonderful day on the bike! There are no major cities on our route today. The morning is spent shaking free of much of the New Plymouth traffic. Turns out today is a local 'district' anniversary day or holiday. New Zealanders take their holidays pretty seriously. The have the usual 12 - 15 or so national holidays similar to those of the US, but in addition, each district has it's own set of holidays commemorating founders, wars, whatever  and then even the cities will each have their own set of holidays. On a holiday, all the banks and schools, all government offices and most business will be closed. Mike and I are getting pretty low on NZ currency and I had planned to hit a bank on the way out of town but it looks like that won't be happening after all!  It will be fun to see how long we can stretch our last $30NZ!  We probably won't starve (both because we have about 3 weeks of food stockpiled and because someone's bound to loan us a few $$ if we develop a Popsicle or ice cream crisis!).  We're on our way. The ride to the lunch stop is a gentle, easy ride (or it would be for me if my quads and calves weren't screaming with every pedal rotation!) in spite of the really rough chipseal. Quite uneventful riding under overcast skies, a good thing under the circumstances. We take only a short lunch break in anticipation of the 600 ft, 3km climb that awaits us shortly after. When I get off the bike and try to walk a few steps I realize that my legs are still getting sorer with every hour that passes by. Of course I have no one to blame but myself - and I would do it all again if given the opportunity! Mike says I never learn  I guess he's right! We get on the bike after lunch and somehow make it to the top of the hill (luckily Mike isn't as sore as me!) and start the twisty descent when I feel the most dreaded sensation - a thump, thump, thump from the rear wheel. 'Stop the bike!' I cry, but it turns out to be just a piece of gravel tarred to the tire. Whew! We work our way through a few turns and then, on an inauspiciously rough stretch of road, Mike calls out, 'Stopping - the front fender is falling off!' Turns out it has cracked almost all the way in half, right at the point where the brakes are. We end up taking the whole fender off and strapping it to the rack and pack in back (!). Now we really look like tourists! We waddle through the rest of the ride, carefully  but without further incident, through the town of Mokau and on to our seaside campground.  The beach here has almost pure black sand, it's very dramatic! After a quick dinner (sweet and sour beef - I'll try to cook ANYTHING with beef here, it's so good!), it's movie night, so, gotta go! 
We hide out in the tent till 7am (a record!) and finally get up, pack everything and throw our fate to the rainy winds. This may be the day when our luck rains out  or will we get lucky again?  We all have a quick breakfast and get the low-down on today's ride: mostly flat, we're told, with one hill (short but steep) right after lunch. The morning is on Hwy 3 and the afternoon is mostly all on small secondary roads.   Our destination today is Waitomo Caves, a little 'Adventure Tourist' spot which features an apparently significant set of caves with rivers inside for rafting, openings for rappelling  (or Abseiling as the Brits call it!) up to 100 meters down and all sorts of other 'concocted' adventure action (river tubing, 4WD ATVing, glow-worm watching, you name it!) which can be added in for a price. It ain't cheap; 4 hours run about$100 to $200 NZ, and a full 7-hour day of adventure is up to $350!  Mike and I will probably just hang out or go for a hike  but first we need to get there! We start out in drizzle under gloomy skies. It's pretty warm so we quickly shed our jackets. The scenery is indeed lush and green, and the terrain, at least at first, mild.  We are following a series of rivers upstream so we are climbing but it's very gentle. The river valleys are fairly narrow and very rich in undergrowth. Though it has almost stopped right now, it MUST rain a lot here! We're getting back to that striking mix of palms, ferns, pines an deciduous trees that we remember from our first days out of Auckland. As we get closer to the lunch stop, the terrain gets hillier, with one really nasty climb that has Mike convinced that it must be the 'tough' climb promised for AFTER lunch! I'm not so sure though  The terrain looks like it could get increasingly hilly for quite some time. We're climbing up out of the ferny glens and into more open, spacious fields of grass. Our pace slows with the climbing but eventually we do get to the lunch stop, where after a few short minutes, the rain returns, with a new level of intensity. Darn! We wait for a few more minutes to see if it will let up; but it shows no signs of stopping so we get back into our raincoats and set off  it looks like it COULD clear up later but who knows?  The promised short, steep climb after lunch never seems to materialize as we head up the quiet secondary road  in fact the series of climbs we encounter are neither short nor step but are in fact pretty much continuous!  Each time we think we're to the top, we round another curve and see more  we don't really mind too much because the climb is keeping us warm! So much so, in fact, that we quickly shed our jackets again. Eventually though, after about 15-20 kms of steady climbing, just as the rain starts to fall with a vengeance, we seem to reach some kind of a summit. We manage to get the rain gear back on at just the opportune moment as the skies open, and we begin a brief but technical descent.  Mike has some concern because rainy downhills that require a lot of braking are probably the worst thing we can do for our poor tired wheel rims  but we don't have a lot of choice! With every km that we pedal, it is raining harder now. This is our first real rain-ride on the trip. Big fat hard cold drops are falling through the holes in our helmets and between our jackets and our necks (brrrh!) and the splashes from the road onto our shins reach the proportion of small icy creeks running down into our shoes! We quickly reach that point in the ride that I call the 'saturation point' - we're not going to get much wetter!  The scenery is probably really magnificent here but it's hard to notice. We're focused on staying warm (but not working up a sweat), watching the road and traffic for potential menace (it's actually raining so hard it's tough to see clearly!) and mostly, just on moving forward through the monsoon. After a half hour or so of rolling hills (ideal conditions for rain riding, actually, as there aren't more than a few mild descents and enough quick steep pitches up to keep us warm), we emerge back onto Hwy 3 for the last 15 kms or so on flat busy road with wide shoulders and some of the roughest chipseal we've seen yet! Now our strongest thoughts are, 'I hope we can upgrade to a cabin' and 'I'm sure glad we don't have to ride tomorrow!' It's going to take us awhile to clean ourselves (and the bike) back up after this! I will say this for 'supported' touring - it is wonderful to know that our gear is completely dry at our destination. If it were in panniers, it wouldn't be a question of if it were wet; it would be a question of just how wet it was. Finally, after a few last kms of gentle climbing (and by now my still-sore quad muscles are completely confused by the cold and wet and work), we sight the campground - and we are ready to get off the bike! Like a wonderful dream, cabins, hot showers and warm food await us! The group all rides in on their own power (Wayne went back out to search for anyone who needed a lift but we are all stubborn, I guess!) in varying states of disarray but universally delighted with the cabin option! The cabins actually turn out to be pretty poorly insulated  Mike and Susan (she's sharing with us) both resort to earplugs when we realize we can hear the person in the next room snoring while we're alls still up reading!  I can't stand earplugs but I don't think I'll have much trouble sleeping. This is a real bed here, after all! In all, the best thing about the cabin (besides the watertight roof!) must be the electric light switch, which lets us read until whenever we want to! We stay up till near 10, a record probably! 
It really is a glorious day. We have in mind to take a 25km roundtrip ride to an aviary that's supposed to have the best nocturnal kiwi house in NZ... there's also a nice free hike that apparently goes to a few caves so we may try some of that, too! If we see a grocery store there's a few things we could use. That's about it for our aggressive 'day off' plans!  It's right  when Mike decides to clean the bike th at disaster strikes! While cleaning the rear weheel he notices that the braking survace has some weird crease-like cracks in i, right near the weld. Upon further examination (after he removes the tire) we see an even bigger crack - about 8 inches long! - that goes althe way through the braking surface. I can bend the whole edge of the rim in wiht on e hand! We are done riding on this wheel... Looks like we will have to figure out the best way to get it fixed. My hopes of it holding out for the rest of the tour are dashed! But, we are SO lucky that we made it in yesderday without a blowout. Yikes! We don't even want to think about the roadrash we would get from this rough road surface... and Mike tells me that we actually hit 70 km/hour on one of the brief descents yesterday!!! Needless to say, we don't make it to the Kiwi aviary. We spedn a few hours makig phone calls and considering options , then we go out for a hile an dget some perspective. This hike (largely the only 'free' outdoor attraction here!), which Thom sniffed out, is marked out on a photocopied sheet kept behind the desk at the info/booking centers, where the eyes are assaulted by literally hundreds of fancy 4-color brochures advertising every kind of adventure imaginable!  Lucky for us that we even found out about the hike! The trailhead turns out to be right next to our campground. The trail is described to us as a 3-4 hour return (round trip) and the map shows an out-and back wiht a little loop at the far end.  Not knowing what to expect, we join Wayne and Sue and Bob and set off (Allan, Susan and Ed all decided to go for the 7-hour full adventure package, earlier in the day!). The first part of the trail is full of jungle with some twists, turns and steps (taking a photo I here some gus talking about Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom in  a thick german accent - funny! Then we move into a long stretch that is cow pasture an driver.. uneventful but nice and easy hiking! I'm very conscious of Mike's bad knee and concerned about overdoing it... but at least we don't ahve to worry about riding tomorrow! All of a sudden, on the other side of the river, the bank rise up into a sort of cliff fact that's covered in deep jungle undergrowth, and we begin to feel the coolnes of underground air waftin gtowards us - neat! We start seeing put-ins and take-outs for the rafters around here. We find a little 'hidey-hole'  cave that overlooks the river which is no, somhow, many feedt below us - we're way high up on its bank. This is getting alittle more adventurous! Soon, we find ourselves at a little park-like informaiitno cneterw ith route info and a sign that says "Walk to Underground Tunnel Viewing Platform - 30 minute Return". We're not really sure what that means, but Wayne and Sue are pretty enthusiastic. Mike decides that his knee will hold up if we take the road back to camp (we've been hiking for at least an hour already), so we go for it! We set out on the trail and almost immediately we are in a clool, grotto-like environment with incredibly elaborate pathways, bridges and viewing platforms that let us look down into the depths easily 100-200 feet underground into the caves and rivers below. I hope the photos turn out!   We are all astonished by the 'cool factor' on this FREE walk! WE certainly get our $$$ worth!  And, Mike thought best of all, we start our walkback to camp via the road (which turnsout to be a pretty significant hike in itself) and after about a half hour of hiking, we're surprised by a horn tooting behind us. It's one of the adventure guides, offering us a ride back to the tavern! Without hesitation we all pile in... luxury!  We try to buy our hero a drink but he has to pick up more customers. It would have taken us an hour or so to have walked in! We spend the evening finalizing plans for the next few days... we're going to take the bus to Auckland to ensure that we can get tehwheels fixed in time! WE will miss the last 3 days of riding on the second section, but it can't be helped. 
The riders all set out and we help Sue to pack up the van. It's especially hard not to ride today: beautiful scenery, smooth (relatively) and flat road, no cars, sunshine and tailwind! Sue shuttles us up to the 'lunch break' where she switches with Wayne, who drives us to Hamilton in plenty of time to catch the 12:30 pm bus for Auckland. We're carrying our 2 wheels, a few clothes, sleeping bags, some cooking supplies (just in case) and minimal toiletries. Still it makes an impressive pile of stuff!  We are off on our onw adventure! After we get in to Auckland, we are able to find a bank and exchange $$$ and get a room in a 'Backpackers' (kind of a youth hostel-like, low rent motel) for $60 a night. After we stach our backpacks there, it's a 30 minute walk to the bike shope where we spend some time with the mechanic, Michael (it's pretty complicated, what with our existing hubs (40-spoke) and their in-stock rims ( mostly 32 spoke) and all the related compatibility issues and component choices. Mike and Michael figure it out, and we set off with the hopes that the wheels will be built by the end of the day tomorrow. Worst case, it will be done on Sunday. We end up with one new 40 hole rim for the rear, so the wheel can be rebuilt and one completely new 36 spoke wheel for the front (we'll take the 40 spoke hub home and rebuild it later). We are filled with new hope! With minds at rest, we walk back towards the Backpackers', with a brief stop for dinner. We spend the evening scoping out the area near the Backpackers for bakeries, internet and souveniers. By 8)) we are back in our little shoebox of a room (did I mention the 'ocean view'? Check it out in the photo!). Mike says this is the worst place he's ever stayed in... but I have to admit I've been in quite a few worse places! We finally connect with Sergei and Irena Gulaev, friends of Julia and Peter Lester, and residents here in Auckland. We make plans to meet for lunch on Saturday. Looking forward to it!  Now - it's off to dreamland! 
At the appointed time we call the shop (it's Penny-Farthing Bicycles on Khyber Pass Rd at Symond St in Auckland, they're GREAT, if you're ever in the neighborhood!) and the new wheels are ready! They also have the surprising news that our group is already at the campground in Manukau City, a full day early! As we walk back to the bike shop, we are elated about the wheels but alittle concerned about everyone on the trip - hopefully it is not bad news! We pick up the wheels without further event. Mike is very satisfied with them. As a thank-you, we give Michael a North Rim Adventure Sports t-shirt (that's the bike shop where Mike works!). Wheels in tow, we return to the backpackers... it's too late to cancel our room and it would be complicated to change our plans with Sergei and Irina... plus we are kind of looking forward to 'staying up late' and watching the city night scene for awhile! I haven't been out in a city at night in YEARS! We stay up (and out) pretty late, doing a bit more journal updating at the internet cafe (we've spent so much time there that they are giving us the discount rate!), with a break for dinner... and then, around 10:30 or so, we take a nice walk around the city, watching the night life. It's pretty active here!  It's a big college town, so there are alot of kids and alot of places that are open at night. Even at this early hour, things are hopping! It has been a real (and unexpected) treat, watching the ebb and flow of the city for the last 24 hours.  In the morning, we saw all the workers flooding the streets heading for work, and then watched the streets quiet as the clock rolled past 9am. The streets were packed again, with a different energy, at noon... and then a whole new energy at 5pm.  As the evening progressed, the dinner crowd somehow transitioned into the night crowd as the city metamorphosed before our eyes into a night animal, glittering with lights and mystery. Something we never would have seen on this trip if not for our wheels wearing out! 
Sergei and Irina have graciously agreed to pick us up at the Backpackers at 11am, and later, bring us down to the campground in Manukau City! We're outside, packed and ready, at 11. After a few minutes, we begin to wonder whether they have the right Backpackers (there are probably over 20 different ones in downtown Auckland alone!)? We've told them to look for two people carrying two bicycle wheels - so we should be easy to spot! They soon arrive - it turns out they HAD gone to the wrong place first, but no harm done!  Quickly we are whisked away (in a CAR!) to a lovely oceanside cafe in Mission Bay, a small community on the east side of Auckland - beautiful beach park, charming cafes, restaurants and stores - upscale but with a very warm community feeling. Sergei and Irina used to live here but recently moved to a more conveniently located place with more room for Irina's father who lives with them... but I can tell that their hearts (especially Irina's) are still here! After a nice walk along the beach (complete with windsurfer rental, pony rides and refreshment stands), we hop back into the car and drive to their house for lunch. We have a wonderful visit and get to know each other a bit... it almost feels like we already know them through our friendship with Peter and Julia! Peter and Irina came to NZ from Russia, 5 years ago. They met Peter and Julia because they all were active in a sister-city program between San Jose CA and Ekaterinburg (hope I didn't spell that TOO badly!). Peter ended up teaching Sergei and Irina's son, Sasha at San Jose State University before he retired!  Sergei is a professor of Mathematics and Earth Sciences (I think!) at the university here in Auckland, but his true passions are Astronomy and Physics. Irina is an instructor of opera singing and of violin! They both are very active here in their adopted home.  Peter and Julia, they send you fond greetings! After a delicious lunch of chicken caesar salad and a baked 'meat pie' made of  layered dough, potato slices, chicken meat and dough (I believe this is a Russian dish?) all made by Irina, and a light dessert of watermelon, papaya, tea and cookies, Sergei and Irina deliver us to the campground at Manukau City, where they give us a little 'care package' of cookies and crackers and delicious strawberry tea - what a nice treat! Thank you both!  We haven't seen the last of Sergei and Irina, though,...; they've generously agreeed to let us store the tandem with them while we visit the south island in the first week of April! Peter and Julia, thank you for sharing these dear friends with us! FYI we're (Sergei, Irina, Mike and I) already plotting to bring you two bakc here with us again next year for another visit! So, be prepared!  The rest of the afternoon, and into the evening, is spent uneventfully, visiting and catching up with everyone (thankfully it turns out the group just decided to put in a big mile day (130 hilly kms!) to get to the campground a day early, so we can start the last leg a bit early and use the 'extra rest day' at some more exotic location in the northlands!).  Our friend Sherry Smith arrives tomorrow morning for the northlands segment, can't wait to see her! And Peter and Julia, tha
Mike and I wake up at about the usual time, anyway... It's been raining lightly for most of the night so everything outside is pretty wet. Once I get out of the tent, I'm not getting back in, so it's up before 6am with the time change! Sherrry arrives right on time at 7:30 am, with all her luggage and bike safely retrieved from Qantas' care. She's alittle punchy (I remember THAT feeling!) but still we have a great visit and hang out a bit in the common room while getting her acquainted with the rest of the crew.  She gets her bike put together with out issue (except for Mike bugging her about skinny tires, about not enough gears for teh hills, about having road shoes instead of Mt Bike shoes, about anything else he can thing of - isn't he getting to be the experienced world-bike-traveller?).  Luckily, she can take it (and hand it out!). As mke getst eh wheels all back on the bike and the brake pads replace, the clouds start to break up overhead and it looks like we'll be able to get in a dry ride!  By the time we saddle up, in fact, the day is WARM and still quite humit. We just take a quick spin out to the botanical gardens (the place we raced past on teh VERY first day of our tour) which turns out to be a wonderful place!   With the help of the resident plant expert, we are FINALLY able to identify the legendary Silver Fern (the undersides of teh leaves and the new branches are all silvery-white), the official plant of New Zealand! Cool, see the photo when it gets here!  It grows up to 10m tall, now wonder we didn't find it looking on the ground!  The test ride goes without a hitch (though the new brake pads are screaming!). The bike seems more stable, nice and steady. There's no more thumping when we brake, and no more unexplainable noises! The chirp is finally gone! This afternoon - laundry and groceries. 
Having said that, there are a few things I would say about the riding on the west coast. It was, as promised, wetter - but not by alot. It was also windier - but a fair part of the time was a tailwind, so that at least wasn't too bad! The roads had alot less traffic (and there were quite a few really neat side roads that got us off the beaten track)...  the hills were less steep and shorter.  The scenery was beautiful if a bit less spectacular and the economic situation of most of the cities and towns was more 'middle of the road'... less upscale and trendy than the tourist spots on the Coromandel Peninsula but less poor than alot of the East Cape towns. Seemed to be alot more british influence on the west side as well. The cycling highlight was definitely Mt Taranaki and Dawsons' Falls there. Really great cycling and really fascinating topography - perhaps more memorable than any other part of the trip - with the possible exception of the Rimutaka Grade on the way into Wellington. Anyway, all in all the west side turns out to be a wonderful way to spend two weeks!
We get the day started at a leisurely pace because we want to let the traffic die down before we try to fit all our bikes and ourselves on the train.  Sherry masterminds a really decadent kick-off breakfast of breaded grilled pork chops, eggsa nd yesterday's leftover fried potatoes - fabulous! It's going to be great having someone to cook with! We finally depart Manukau City around 10am. Mike, Sherry and I end up riding to Swanson with Wayne and Sue in the 'SueMobile' (our new name for the van, because their van at home is known as the 'WayneMobile'!) so that there will be more room on the train for the other bikes (and the other paying passengers!). There's no bike storage area, apparently you just bring the bike onto the trian with you. We figure it will be easier to get the tandem on the SueMobile (we've had some recent practice at that!) than onto the train.  It's a short and uneventful ride to the Swanson train station, where we reunite with the rest of the gang and (finally!) start cycling. Mike, Sherry and I start out and it is pretty funny watching (and listening to) Sherry as she gets used to bein gon the left side of the road - though I KNOW we were just the same, 6 short weeks ago!  It's a pleasant enough ride, the first 15 kms or so on narrow hilly side roads and the last 25 on the busier, biger Hwy 16. The highlight of the ride comes when we see some very frisky steer getting herded inot a pasture with sheep and some really pretty deer already in it! We stop for photos and the steer run to us, bucking and kicking away like mad, scattering the deer in the process. Then, when we take their photo, they stampede to the other side of the field, bucking and kicking some more, and even head-butting some of the sheep!  When we finally leave, the sheep are hiding, the steers are still feisty, and the deer  are posing a stand-ins for Rudolph and the rest of Santa's crew at the top of the hill, just in front of the farmhouse! When we reach our destination, the van still hasn't passed us, so we decide to wanderinto Hellensville for a 'sneaky snack'. We find a really charming cafe called Upper Crust (also the name of our favorite bakery at home in Chico!). After sandwiches we try a new bakery treat (one I've never seen before) called, I think, a Plum Fraid - it is divine! The size of a little muffin bottom, it has an unexpected density. It is the consistency and flavor of a really fine, delicate Macaroon, with a sweet/sour wedge of baked plum in the center. Fabulous! Then, it's on to the campground at the Parakai Aquatic Park. "Aquatic Park?" you may ask, and rightly so. the campground isn't anything special but the Aquatic Park is awesome indeed. It has two hot-spring-fed pools...  oh, and did I mention the FREE waterslide??? After we make camp, we head on over for some big fun!  Sherry, Mike, Sue, Tom and I quickly revert to about 7 years old, runing back up to the top as fast as we slide down to the bottom! After we master the basics, we start getting creative - first trying to catch each other in the tube, then forming up into a train and going down the slide together (this is FAST!) and taking turns going first. Finally after our feet are too sore from runing up on the fake-grass carpet and our bodies are covered with a nice assortment of bruises, we take one last 'go for broke' run. Sherry and I go side by side, with Mike behind us, holding one of each of our feet, with Thom as the caboose. We almost do a roll inside the tube, WAY out of control. We shoot out of the tube like a cannon, with appendages flying in an awesome display of carnage. We are laughing so hard my stomach hurts! The joke is probably on us, though, as we have worked harder (and taken more damage) than on any day of riding so far! After all that, we are pretty wasted. We have a great dinner, Mike and I walk to the Dairy for dessert (Sherry crashes - jetlagged still) and then we sit around in the dark at 7pm, trying to figure out what we are going to do till we can go to bed at 9 (that's the minimum embarassment hour)! What a day! I'll drema waterslides tonight!
We quickly shed our jackets as we start to climb.  Wayne is riding with us, at least briefly, depending on how his back holds up. It is 62 ks to lunch, on an not-too-busy highway, rolling pretty much relentlessly up and up and up.  Every so often we catch a panoramic glimpse of bay and slough (hope the photos we took will capture it!) and then we are whooshing down into the trees once more. We have a bit of a headwind today too so that contributes to making it feel just a little bit harder than it seems like it ought to! After a really nice scenic overlook, we descend into Wellesford for a quick lunch just as it begins to sprinkle. Mike takes the opportunity there to grease my pedal which for some reason chose this morning to begin screeching most unpleasantly! After all our wheel problems, we dread to think that we could have more mechanical trouble, but it turns out that the lube-job pretty much seems to fix whatever the problem was. The pedals are pretty old so I'm hoping they'll just hold out till the end of the trip! After lunch, we immediately enter the nerve-wracking zone of Hwy 1, a road which, by clever route design by Wayne, we've been able to avoid pretty much completely thus far. Luckily the rain has let up so we aren't getting too wet, but the cars and trucks are driving past us FAST!!! We just try to get through it as quickly as possible, but not as quickly as we'd like. The terrain is pretty challenging, consisting of more endless rollers into the wind.  After only a few close calls with logging trucks and sheep trucks (the WORST - stinky like you wouldn't believe!) we prepare to get off Hwy 1 - only to have our hopes dashed when we realize that we (that would be ME, I admit it!) have misread the map and we still have 8 kms to go! Eventually though, we do finish that unpleasant stretch and, after powering up on Moro Bars and Coke, Mike, Sherry and I tackle the last stretch: 20 kms of rollers (this time with a tailwind!) to a charming Backpackers (The Old Post Office Guesthouse) where we will spend the night tonight (no tent to pitch! A real bed! Wow!). When we arrive, we find that it really was once a Post Office and is now filled with wonderful gardens from front to back. The owner is out on an errand so we finish the descent into Paparoa, which turns out to be a VERY small town (grocery, dairy, 2 cafes and an antique store) but nice! It's easy to waste an hour here and the time flies by. Soon we saddle back up and SLOWLY make our way back up the hill to our accommodations. We are sharing 4 to a room so it's a bit crowded, but wonderful to sleep in a bed and gardens are a real treat! We finish the night off with popcorn and TV in the 'Library'. A great, big day! 
We have a nice leisurely breakfast today, in anticipation of a short, relatively flat and easy day. With around 60 kms in front of us and no camp to break, we can afford to relax alittle! Eventually though, it's time to get on the bikes and go. Just before we leave, we discover that Sherry's brand of sunscreen is a real mosquito magnet! She and I are both swarmed with mosquitos immediately after applying it... arrgh! A crude but effective motivator to get moving! Around 8 kms out, we have a 'scheduled stop' highly recommended by Wayne and Sue, the Kauri Museum in Maungaturoto (say THAT 5 times fast!), it's supposed to give us some perspective on the native-growth stand of Kauri that we're going to ride through tomorrow - as well as on the way this tree has shaped the lives and economy of the entire Northlands. The Kauri is the second-largest tree in the world (after the Giant Sequoia in California, USA) and it was key in the lives of the Mauri as well as in the early settling of NZ by white man.  Aside from the unique and truly spectacular nature of the tree, it was valued both for lumber and for an amber substance called "Kauri Gum" which would ooze from wounds and then harden over a 6 month period. It was used from about 1860 to 1940 for the production of varnish and linoleum, in addition to being used as a carving medium for art, jewelry  and tourist trinkets. Originally, the Mauri used it for coloring their tattooes, which were used to reflect the individual's status and position within their community. The story of the Kauri is probably a pretty typical tale of human exploitation of resources... with an added twist of conflicting purposes between the gum-diggers and the lumberers. The gum collectors initially just picked pieces of gum off the trees but when that was depleted they figured out that they could cut the tree ('bleed it', it was called) then come back in 6 months and collect the hardened gum. Meanwhile the lumberers were cutting the trees with reckless abandon, in quantities that seem unbelievable to our modern eyes, and with tools that seem shockingly primitive. Conveniently, the bleeding of the trees would eventually kill them, freeing them for use as lumber. As the trees started to become more scarce, some lucky or inquisitive person discovered that there were many Kauri buried in the local swamps and they could be dug up, revealing great lumps of Kauri gum to be had for the taking (and by great I do mean great - some of the carvings in the museum came from discreet pieces that must have been 3 cubic feet in size - amazing!), pumping new life into the Kauri gum industry. Apparently, at some point in the 1950s or so, someone came to their senses and realized that almost all the Kauri of any significant size were gone (these trees can live to be 3000 years old and older), and the government passed laws making it illegal to cut down any living Kauri - or to collect any gum from one. The few native stands of Kauri remaining are considered to be national treasures, and the gum and Kauri lumber both are part of the NZ heritage. All Kauri items made/sold today come from reclaimed Kauri buried in swamps for over 50,000 years.  The museum turns out to be both fascinating and immense. We spend close to 2 hours there, even trying to hurry! There is just a huge amount of stuff, thoughtfully displayed in historical vignettes shoing the felling of trees, operational versions of all the field milling and transporting equipment and devices as well as a reproduction of an actual mill, complete with operating equipment. They also featured displays of bush-clearing (both with oxen teams and the tractor that obsoleted them, equal in power to 115 ox), Kauri gum collecting (off trees in the bush and in swamps), washing, and polishing, and a huge display of Kauri gum art. Finally there was a reproduction of the rooms of a NZ home from the period of about 1900 (parlor, bedrooms, kitchen, dining room, sitting room, library) and even a display of antique dolls! Finally we tear ourselves away and get back to the business at hand. We saddle up and, after a few more rollers we slog through the 40 kms or so of dead-flat river delta land (with a headwind of course!) to Dargaville, another charming tourist town, this one pretty good-sized, for lunch.   After lunch and a quick stop at the grocery store, we head out for the last 15 kms or so to Baylys (say: Baileys!) Beach, a pretty beach community (couldn't be more than 150 houses, one holiday park, one restaurant and one dairy!) set into the side of the hills overlooking the ocean. Since it's a short day, Sherry and I gird up and go for a 'run' on the beach. We're gone for about 45 minutes but probably actually run for less than 20... still, not too bad for my first time running in months and months! Then it's back to camp for showers and dinner... and a walk to the "Funky Fish Cafe" for dessert! Check out the photo of the bathroom, it is, like a few other things we've seen here, "World famous in NZ!"  We even get a nice sunset view of the ocean and beach on teh way back to camp, what a way to end a beautiful day! 
By the time we set out, the sky is already clouding over (how does that happen so quick?), enough so that I grab a jacket to take with me on the bike, just in case. The first 10 km or so is a backtrack of yesterday, fighting a good headwind the whole way. then we are back on Hwy 12, continuing north, enjoying a somewhat more favorable wind. We'll be on this road all day, till we reach tonight's campground in Omapere (O-ma-piri). It's on the left. Hard to go wrong with navigational challenges like this! The next 40 kms flow by, relatively effortlessly. We have a nice cross-tailwind and the traffic is next to non-existent. Scenery is rolling hills of lush green with lots of big trees and lots of underbrush in between. Occasionally we'll get a glimpse of ocean, just to keep our interest. Mike thinks this is easier riding than yesterday's dead-flat 40kms... that was monotonous where this is ever-changing and beautiful. We have a quick lunch at a cafe along the way, saving our 'van stop' for the upcoming Kauri Tree site! Immediately after lunch, the terrain gets quite a bit more challenging as we embark on the first of 3 promised 'decent' climbs! The first two are gradual, the first out in open courntry with lots of cows and sheep to visit along the way, and lots of false summits to throw us off-guard.  Then we have a great descent down into a Preserve Area (kind of like our National Forest) that is just loaded with growth - groundcover, several layers of understory trees of varying heights and finally, above it all, the mighty Kauri stands, guarding their last domain. Most of the trees must be around 5-8 ft in diameter so we know they aren't very old (at least in Kauri terms!). In our enthusiasm to see the trees (and exhilaration from the awesome descent?), we allow Bob to lead us a few kms down a dirt road to a visitor center where there actually aren't any Kauri - oops! But there's a bathroom and a great gift shop and a ranger who visits with us for awhile and helps us identify our favorite morning bird calls... Apparently they are Tui! So, it wasn't a total waste! We make our way back to the road and begin our second climb, 9 kms of winding, gentle ascent through jungle that slowly changes to higher country bush as we begin to wonder wheter we will ever climb our way to the top!  Finally it levels out for a few kms and then we are at the pull-out for Tuma Makuta, the 'lord of all trees' - the largest tree in NZ. It's a few minute's walk through the bush (jungle is what I'd call it!) till we round a corner and there it is - wow! I know our photos won't do it justice, at all... but we tried! Totally amazing... and even more amazing to me is the thought of how much bigger the biggest trees were before they were annihilated. It defies the imagination!  Humorously (to me anyway), near the tree is a small, polite sign asking people to show proper respect for the tree by refraining from playing music, chanting or other ceremonial behaviors... classic NZ! After viewing its majesty for a few mintues, we need to get back on the bike - the cloud cover that's been haunting us on and off all day has returned with a vengeance and it is too cold and damp to sit around!  We head out with Sherry and Wayne for a bit more climbing (not climb number 3, that's still to come!), followed by an awesome technical descent out of the jungle and back into civilization and a great stretch of pretty, relatively flat road befire we tackle the last hill, a short but STEEP climb that tests out our lowest gear for the first time on the trip! We regroup for photos at the top, then careen down the hill to Omapere and the hotel that hosts our campsites. We are onthe beach - a harbor that stretches for miles. Fabulous!
The weather today is alternatign sun, cloud, mist, rain, cloud, sun, repeat on about a 1 hour schedule. We eventually have breakfast (in a comedy of errors, the expensive hotel buffet offering is stingy and extremely limited in variety and the take-away place is about an hour late in opening so we end up cooking in the grim little kitchen and eating on the steps (there's no table... perhaps to motivate campers to use the restaurant???) feeling a bit like refugees as teh garbage man drives up and sends clouds of diesel fumes our way - sometimes things just WON'T go our way! After breakfast, Mike works on the bike and I sit and read some more in the lounge (it really is a most pleasant and inviting room, in a wonderful old hotel building!), just enjoying the refreshing experience of doing nothing! Around noon, we saddle up the bike for a quick ride to the next town, Opononi, just to stretch out our legs - they're pretty tight from yesterday's climbing! It's about 5 km, pretty, rolling scenery along a wide river mouth with a huge sand dune on the other side. In Opononi, we find a great Fish and Chips place that is cooking fresh fish, right off the fishing boat - yum!  After lunch and a quick ride back to camp, I hit the grocery store and then read (more!) till it's time for a hike out to the headlands with Wayne, Sue and Sherry. Spectacular views abound, hope I can get the photos in here. On the way back we run into Allan and Susan - holding hands! Looks like a vacation romance! Another nice and easy dinner from the take-away next door (burgers this time, they're out of fish!) and another evening to kill. We are really noticing the time change... it gets dark now around 7pm, way too early to go to sleep! There's a rumor of a slide show by Wayne and Sue on the South Island, don't want to miss it. Tomorrow - back to the bike!
We're energized from our relaxing day off and ready to go! Under cloudy skies with the threat of rain we set off.  Mike and I are riding alone because Sherry wasn't ready to go and the mosquitos were biting. We have a beautiful stretch of quiet road to cover this morning. We start out along the south side of Hokianga Harbor (an amazingly long body of water), heading 'upstream'. The lush green terrain rolls along and so do we, slowing a bit on the ups and making it up on the downs...  There are a couple of bigger hills to wake up our legs but it's mostly just a pelasant cruise. This is what cycle-touring is all about! About 20 kms into the ride we make a turn and head towards the Rawene ferry, which will take us to the north side of the harbor (we later learn that if you miss the ferry it's about 70 kms further to get around to the north side of the harbor). The ferry runs every hour on the half hour, so of course Mike and I arrive at 9:38, just in time to see the ferry pulling away. It turns out ok, though, as it gives Mike a chance to check out the local cafe. He even has a capuccino - what are we coming to?? I also sneak in a quick visit to The Clendon House (a National Historical Place). It was built in the 1860s by a shipbuilder for his 'beautiful young Maori wife', who had the improbable name of Jane. The house is very cool, filled with the original family possessions. By the time an hour has sped by, most of the gang has arrived - Sue with the van, Bob, Wayne, Ed and Thom - Allan and Susan ride up just at the last minute and decide to have coffee and wait for the next ferry. Oddly enough, Sherry has not appeared! We figure she is just behind Susan because she was taking alot of photos so we don't give it much thought.  The ferry is crowded (after all it's Saturday!) but fast and short. After, we hit the road for an ablolutely fabulous stretch of road. We get a few light showers (almost more of a mist than a rain, actually kind of refreshing!) and one minor climb and then a FAST rolling downhill stretch through a long valley into lunch. More awesome cycling! During lunch, we get to see a real, live cattle drive, right down the main road through the center of town, up close and personal (as you will see from the photos)! It is quite a carnival, with about 75 head of cow (they are BIG!), 4 or 5 dogs, a few guys on horseback, an ATV and a truck. Quite a sight! What we don't see, however, is Sherry! Allan and Susan haven't shown up by the time we leave the lunch stop, but still we are beginning to wonder what might have happened to her - we know she can ride pretty fast when she needs to! As we're riding, we speculate on where she might be... there's not much else we can do! The afternoon is a it more challenging (more uphill, that is!), and our comfortable cloud-cover dissipates, so it gets quite hot! Mike and I are feeling pretty good, though, so we go to work a bit, towards the end of the day. When we get into town we head to the campground but don't see Wayne, so after a drink from the Dairy (Mike's new thing is called a "Wave", it's flavored milk drink that's pretty darn tasty! I like the coffee flavor, personally!), we go back into town to see what's up. We find Wayne heading BACK to the campground so we do a 'speedy shop' at the Pak and Save and buy just enough to make us a hazard on the road, carrying the groceries!  By this time, we've heard that Sherry didn't make the ferry... and that Allan passed her but Susan never did. So we are pretty sure that she missed the turn to the ferry! Most likely, she's looking at that 70km detour I mentioned earlier!  After we set up camp, the speculating really begins. Wondering what to do, we start considering options. We do some calculating and figure out that if she had to do the whole 70 km extra, she would probably arrive by 6pm. We decide that if we don't see her by then, we'll call the police and start to go out and look for her. Worst case scenarios are starting to flip through all of our minds as we each share our 'most ridiculously lost' stories to fill the minutes until at last, right on schedule at 5:40, she arrives. She is in good spirits and has lots of stories... and she's racked up two big titles in one day: Most Kilometers Travelled in One Day - 170km! and biggest detour, surpassing Allan, and Mike and I respectively! All's well that ends well, and another great day! 
We get on the bus at 9am (they come to the campground to pick us up, no extra charge, a nice touch), loaded down with cameras, food, swimsuits, binoculars and high spirits!  It's a short trip of 10 km to our first stop, the Kauri 'museum', which has some fabulous pieces, from small as keychains to complete dining sets that start at $4000NZ. The real showpiece is a truly remarkable spiral staircase cut into a single upright standing Kauri log. I took a photo, hope it turns out! Almost all of us succumb to temptation and buy a piece or two. All of the merchandise here is recovered from nearby swamps where it has been resting ro 45,000 plus years... we even get to see some of the newly-recovered stumps sitting in the lot, waiting to be cleaned and used. Amazing! Then, after our allotted 15 minute visit, it's off to the Gum-Digger World, which turns out to be a charmingly informal (and not at all commercial) 'attraction'. It is a once-abandoned family farm where the the remnants of the by-gone era of gum-digging lie asleep in the fallow fields. Our host, by trade a farmer, discovered this buried treasure in his wife's family 'closet'. A disarmingly low-key guy, he initiated a co-operative effort  with the University of Auckland and several other New Zealand schools, to excavate and restore the site to its original working state.  The University became interested in studying the Kauri buried here for its insight into climatogical (? Climate!) research. The Kauri here (there are 3 layers!) date from 45,000 to 150,000 and possibly more years ago. Because the layers are relatively undisturbed (perhaps the only place that remains so!), they can learn alot about how (and why?) each layer of forest migh have thrived and ultimately died (the Kauri takes 2000 years to come to maturity).  We get to see replicas of Gum-Digger shanties (we took photos), minimal in comfort and security, whether made from grasses, burlap bags or bamboo, and of their work environment where they cleaned, polished and sorted the Kauri gum they found (and lots of samples of various types and quality levels), as well as the actual holes made by the diggers 50-100 years ago, which gave the field a strange resemblance to a booby-trapped mine field!  They dug square holes and round holes... big (20 ft diameter) holes and little (4 ft diameter) holes. All of the holes go down about 8-10 ft through soil that is just a step above the consistency of cement! Those guys were tough. Makes us feel pretty wimpy, just riding our bikes all day! Soon, though, we are herded into our bus and on our way to the Wagener Museum, which is set in an absolutely gorgeous environment (as you will see from the photo). Mike and I skip the museum but really enjoy the views of the bay and the delicious fresh coastal air. After the museum we have a fairly long and, toward the end, exhilarating, ride to Tapotupotu (say THAT 5 times fast!) for lunch, which turns out to be the only disappointment of the day... a wafer-think slice of ham on a rol with a few slivers of lettuce, hardboiled egg and grated cheese, as well as a chocolate chip muffin. We get our choice of a cup of orange drink, instant coffee or tea. Bleah!  Luckily the disappointment is short-lived, as we get over it by jumping into the perfect waves on the perfect beach! There's a pretty strong rip current here so we stay safely near shore... but the wave-jumping is awesome nevertheless!  There are even showers, toilets and changing-rooms... NZ rocks! Soon our allotted 45 minutes is up so we regretfully board the bus for more wild driving. The road into and out of Cape Reinga is incredibly narrow, steep and winding. It is amazing watching the bus drivers whip their vehicles up and down the hills, passing each other with just inches to spare. I am SOO glad there are next to no cars up here, it would be too scary to add them to the mix! Cape Reinga, a windswept point of coastal land, is where the Pacific and Tasman meet. It is considered by the Maori to be a place of great power, and it is easy to see why. The ocean and the sea meet in a churning, boiling, blurring line of chaos, threatening to tear apart anything that strays too close. In Maori culture, Cape Reinga is believed to be the last stopping place for the spirits of the dead, before they make their final voyage to Polynesia (Reinga actually translates as 'the leaping place').  By now our bus driver is really loosening up and he shares a few Maori chants and songs with us as we approach, to help us understand the importance of the place we are approaching. At this point the road has become positively precipitous. Words cannot even convey how spectacular and unspoiled this place is... you just have to come here yourself to experience it!  My only regret is that we have such a short amount of time to spend here. I really wish we could have ridden our bikes and stayed for awhile! Cape Reinga itself is beautiful, and its famous lighthouse quite fun. In our alloted 30 minutes we manage to hike down to the lighthouse and get a photo under the street sign to share with you all, as well as to hike a ways down the other side towards the original lighthouse which was replaced some years ago, and to mail ourselves a postcard (it gets a special Cape Reinga stamp). In a bit of irony, right after Sherry and I photographed each other mailing our postcards, OUR BUSDRIVER walks up with a key and a bag, and empties out the mailbox! This guy does everything!  It's a short trip back out and over to Te Paki Stream where we stop off for some Sand Dune tobogganing. It is WAY out of control. A couple of folks perform some awesome face-plants and other heroic dives, but luckily Mike and I emerge relatively unscathed. We have to agree though, that good as it is, it's not QUITE as good as the waterslides (and it's a heck of a lot more work climbing up those dunes!). After we've had our fill (at least 10 runs!) we get back on board, winded and content, and continue along the Te Paki river bed and on to 90-mile beach. Turns out the river bed and the beach are both such hard-packed sand that, most times, thy are more solid than a gravel road! And, the Department of Conservation monitors the area carefully and only allows tours to go when it's safe (for the environment, that is! Our safety is completely 'at our own risk'!). On the beach, we speed along at 80 km/hr (about 50 mi/hr) but still have time to see a cool island with a tunnel through it (got a photo), wild horses (there's a herd of about 400 here still!) and a brief rainstorm in the distance followed by a terrific rainbow. Eventually we wind up 'home', tired and satisfied! Another full day! But, one day of tour bus is plenty enough for me - I'm ready to get back on the bike! Terrific as it was, I found myself wishing I could have had more time to hike and look and experience the moments in the day... that's what *I* get from bike touring that I just don't seem to get from other forms of travel! 
We wake to sunnny skies - a beautiful morning - but the wind is still coming from the east (unusual for here, they say, and now less than fortunate for us!) as it has for the last week or so. We're looking at a headwind pretty much all day today, on the moderately busy Hwy 10.  On the upside, later in the day we are also going to be passing through some absolutely beautiful beach frontage on a lightly travelled road, and staying at Wayne's favorite campsite in ALL of NZ, north AND south island! The first 20 or so kms are just hard work, grinding away at the flat road, riding right into the wind.  Then, as we approach our lunch stop in Mangonui (a very cute, very LITTLE tiny fishing town!), the hills start to get steeper and more frequent adn the scenery more and more spectacular. Already I can see a resemblance to the terrain we remember from Coromandel Peninsula (also on the east coast) at the very beginning of our trip - we are coming full-circle back to where we began.  The hills are hard but on the other hand they do give us alittle protection from the headwind, a welcome relief! W ahve a long lunch break in Mangonui (we beat the van by about a half-hour, so Mike gets a much-appreciated chance to watch the fishermen casting their lines off the pier - see the photo) and the fishing boats coming in with their hauls. Eventually, though, we realize it is time to set out... and so we are off. The afternoon starts off flat but quickly turns into a long series of fairly easy short inland hills, curving to the left and then to the right. Clouds have set in, and we are no longer riding dead into the wind, making the conditions quite pleasant for cycling.  It seems like we are leaving the more populated and 'touristy' areas further behind with every pedal stroke further away from Hwy 1 - Hooray!  Each town is smaller, older and a bit more charmingly run-down than the last. For the last 15 kms or so, we turn off Hwy 10 onto a really isolated secondary road which starts out with a climb, then a quick descent, steeper climb followed by an even quicker descent and finally a real killer uphill. We are feeling pretty good now that we are out of the wind for awhile and the only sound that competes with our measured breathing as we climb is the overwhelming serenade of the cicadas in the surrounding underbrush. After the last climb and a wonderful descent, we have 3 easy kms, blessedly flat and relatively wind-free, into camp. We weave our way between more hills and suddenly we have arrived in another wonderful little beachside community of maybe 100 houses and our motorcamp - no stores at all.  We camp right on the beach, and we have the place virtually to ourselves. What a wonderful campground! The beach even looks perfect for swimming, which it turns out to be, as you will see from the photo. The water is a bit cold but clear and safe. Sherry and I are even able to put on our goggles and actually do some real swimming!  Before dinner, Sue invites me out for a little walk to the next cove, a secluded little spot where someone has built an absolutely wonderful beach house complete with a koi pond with lilies and a footbridge, and an extensive rock garden with whimsical statues scattered about. To get there, we walk through some natural arches that the waves have carved into the rocky cliffs that line the beach here. The place is just magical, as I hope the photos will show! Mike, Sherry and I have another wonderful dinner, agreed by all to be the best curry dish we've cooked so far!  As always, we all eat way too much. I'm starting to be worried to see what I'm going to weigh when I get back to a scale! I know I haven't lost weight on THIS trip! I know I'm getting stronger (I'm asking Mike for harder gears on hills, more and more often!) but I'm not getting any smaller! Not that I was trying to lose weight, but I really didn't plan on GAINING on the trip, either!  Mike got to the point of being tired of eating in the last few days! Said he knew he needed to eat but he just couldn't take any more snacks. Believe me, this is a FIRST!!! Eating to ride every day can become alot of work, in itself! 
We get off to a fairly late start, but we're not too concerned since it's rumored to be a fairly short (65 km) day. Turns out to be a short but far from easy day, though, as the first 10 kms out of camp are on a road that is both extremely steep (up AND down) and completely torn up, in the process of re-paving. Right after we get back onto pavement, we are confronted by yet another extremely steep hill - our littlest gear is getting quite a workout today! After 17 kms we have logged 1700 ft! That is definitely an all-time climbing record for Mike and I. Hurt me! Actually though, it hurt those with road-bike gearing alot more than it hurt us with our low gears!   After we get through the hilly part, we get back on the main road (Hwy 10) which has less hills, less scenery and alot more (and faster!) traffic, for a seemingly eternal stretch (our good friend Mr Headwind keeping us company!) into the lunch stop at Kerikeri, at 51 kms. Looks like it's going to be more than 65 kms today!  At lunch (at possibly the best bakery we've visited in NZ, Kerikeri Bakery, YUM!), it begins to sprinkle and then to rain pretty good. Back to the van for raingear, lucky for us that the van is nearby! By the time we are finally ready to get on the bike (after a quick pit-stop at the nicest McDonalds - wood-panelled, even the bathrooms!), the rain has, of course, pretty much stopped. Well, better safe than sorry! The last 25 kms alternate hills and headwinds, just so we don't get bored, as we make our way slowly to Paihia, where we are to catch a ferry to Russell. We have lots of time to kil before the van will arrive in camp (this ferry is pedestrian only, the auto ferry is further down the coast), so we all waste some time (and $$$!) in Paihia - it's the local center of tourism and alot more frenetic than our destination of Russell, which is more of a sleepy community. After ice cream and lattes (see the photo if you don't believe me!), wine shopping and souvenier shopping, we finally make our way on board a ferry and head over to Russell. Apparently Russell once was a pretty wild town, but you'd never know it today. After the hubbub and hawksters in Paihia (Motorboating! Sailing! Cruising! Fishing! ATV'ing! Kayaking! Sailing in a bigger boat! Fishing for a bigger fish! Half-day trips! Full-day trips! Weekend-long trips!), the sleepy ambiance of Russell is quite a relief. Our campsite is nice enough (though not too close to the beach - see how spoiled we are getting!), but, it turns out, not too 'sleepy' tonight. There's a school group with 25 or so kids (maybe age 8-12 or so) sharing the campground with us! Pretty funny to watch the interactions between our two groups... but they seem like nice enough kids!   At and after dinner, the topic of conversation is all about what to do with two whole days off - hiking, sailing or fishing seem to be the top possibilities. We all turn in early in preparation for adventure to come.
We get quite a bit of rain (it seems to come in waves that last about 45 minutes) in the morning so we mostly just hunker down in the kitchen/common room which luckily is pretty large and comfortable. Sharing it with 25 wound-up kids isn't quite how we had planned to spend our first day here though! By noon we are all getting a case of cabin-fever and we are ready to escape from our cozy prison. Luckily it clears up into quite a nice afternoon and Mike and I manage to see most of the highlights of Russell including the museum, Department of Conservation (basically a nature center), the Police Station (which is a truly wonderful building as you will see from the photo) and a mission that is supposed to be the second oldest building in New Zealand. Later we walk over to Long Beach (about an hour round trip) and we even squeeze in a bit of shopping, and find time for dinner and dessert out! We have tentative plans for fising and sailing tomorrow if the weather should continue to improve. Otherwise we are doomed, rats trapped on a sinking, rainy ship of despair!
5 inches of rain was forecast and we got at LEAST that much. Standing water everywhere. A couple of tents have collapsed (luckily not ours!) in the raging wind, and ALL the tents are leaking to some degree. It's going to be a long night! And what will tomorrow bring?
Last night was the worst night of our trip! I had thought that the worst of the storm might be overbut it was just hiding out... waiting till we got back in our tent for the night before it unleashed its next salvo. The wind was whipping the trees from side to side and trying its best to turn our tent inside out (and doing a pretty good job of it, too!). The tent was leaking from various points by that time as well. Altogether it added up to a pretty much sleepless night. We occupied ourselves by watching the tent poles flex as the wind would hit them and then SNAP back into position after the wind let up - exciting! In the light of dawn (we are glad to be freed from our watery prison), it looks like it might possibly clear up - for a few minutes. By 7am, though, the wind has picked up and the rain has begun to fall with a vengeance from the darkened skies. Now we know why it is so green here!  The field where we're camped is carrying about an inch or two of standing water, making it impossible to keep our shoes dry, even venturing out on the shortest trip, from the tent to the toilets and showers. More and more of our stuff is getting wet and we are turning into quite a sorry, soggy crew! The main worry of riding today is the wind... it is blowing savagely and our route is on busy Highway 1 for much of the day. The rest of the day is on a narrow, very steep and winding up-and-down-hill sort of road which is subject to flooding, our secondary concern. So, as a group, we make the difficult but safer decision to use the van to shuttle us all to Whangarei rather than cycling. Wayne can only take half of us at a time and we lose the coin-toss, so it's Bob, Ed, Sue and Thom in the first load, and then Mike, Sherry, Susan and I in the second trip. We're basically stranded here in Russell till around 1 or 2pm, when Wayne gets back... so there's a certain sense of poetic justice in the air when the clouds unleash yet another big load of rain on 'the boys' as they are breaking camp and stowing all their stuff! While we are waiting for Wayne Mike and I manage to get our tent down and, using the clothes dryer in the laundry room, we are able to get almost everything pretty much dry. Sherry uses the time to go for a nice long run, but I am lacking in ambition to accompany her! I might have forgotten to mention this earlier, but Allan is leaving the group here (or rather we are leaving him!). He's staying in NZ for another month, looking for work in this area at a farm-stay. Shortly before Wayne arrives, Susan shows up (she and Allan were downtown) to let us know that she's decided to stay in Russell for a few more days and take the bus to Auckland.         "...There's magic in the air..." When Wayne shows up, he's bringing both another rainstorm and some REALLY bad news. The Sue-Mobile is in jeopardy! The alternator seems to be going out, which throws a real wrench in the plans for the next (last!) 3 days of the tour. And of course it is just on the cusp of the weekend which means we can forget any kind of local service till Monday (at least). There are some long faces in the van as we head to Whangarei to deliver the bad news to 'the A group'.  After some speedy consideration of options and possibilities, Wayne and Sue pull together an alternate plan. They will rent the biggest car they can get and, While Wayne nurses the van back to Auckland, Sue will use the car to support us in riding the final few days. If we all reorganize our bags and just bring the minimum with us, we will even have room for our food bins!  We'll make it work out somehow!  While all this is getting arranged, I manage to slip out for a little run. Sue sends me out in search of a trail beside a river just outside our campground, which I find and am delighted with! Filled with tropical foliage, laden with wet remains from the storm (it hasn't rained now for about 2 hours!) the park is a haven for Silverferns (the national plant) and Kauri trees amongst many others! Best of all, I can actually run, pretty consistently, the whole rolling out-and-back trail, for about 40 minutes! A triumph! After, a few of us pile into the rental car (already nicknamed 'the stealth van') and get a ride downtown (and about a mile DOWNHILL!). After a quick stop at Pack and Save, Mike and I begin what turns out to be an interminable search for a place to have dinner. Whangarei is a pretty big town but it is like a ghost-town. Friday night at 6pm and every restaurant is closed. Every store seems to be closed. Weird! After walking and walking, we finally fina a chinese place with good food and unfortunately terrible service. Oh well! Then it's a long walk uphill to camp but we don't get lost, hooray! No bonus miles! Did I mention that today is my birthday??? What a crazy day!
Eventually, we do manage to get all the stuff we need into the car. There's even room for the cooler! It is extra-great to get on the bike today, snatching a ride from the jaws of mechanical disaster, and so we set off with light hearts. Our legs are a bit heavy, though as we haven't been on the bike in 3 whole days! The route through town is made treacherous by a good-sized construction zone where all the street-signs seem to have disappeared. But we muddle through, and with some help from good luck we end up on the right road out of town! The first half of the day is on Hwy 1 but it's relatively pleasant! Not too much traffic (and very few trucks) as it's saturday, a wide shoulder, forgiving rolling terrain, and eventually, even a tailwind! The miles fly by and after 40 kms we are off Hwy 1 for the rest of the day, and onto a network of small side roads that approach and depart the coast - beautiful! Hillier but well worth the extra effort. At the planned lunch stop town, we don't see a store or dairy so we just keep on going. After a brisk climb, we arrive in the next town, Mangawhi Heads, where we find a store and so stop fora break. 60 kms done, abut 35 to go! In quick succession, we see Wayne in the van and Sue in the Stealth Van each go by (we're pretty well hidden off the main road so they don't see us). Then a bit later, as we pause to consider our route, Bob, Sherry, Ed and then Thom all pull up. We're a bit stumped by the map but assisted by a sweet woman who points out the way. On learning that we're Americans, she tells us that her granddaughter is going to be an exchange student in Madison WI and asks if it is a 'safe place'. I reassure her as best I can about the relative safety of Madison and the 'heartland' in general, much to her relief!  Soon (after a 'coffee donut' at the adjacent bakery), we are back on our way for the beautiful 30 kms or so into Wellesford. The scenery here (as in a few other spots in the Northland) looks remarkably similar to Hobbiton from The Lord of the Rings... charming! Our last 8 kms is back on busy Hwy 1, retracing our route (in reverse) from 10 days ago. Today, though, we have sun and no headwind and it is much more pleasant!  We stay in a really charming motel (our first true motel) with amazing gardens of succulents and cacti, annuals, perennials, fruit trees, flowering trees, grasses, shrubs, bushes and ferns, all arranged with paths and garden art and arbors with a whimsy that makes the result simply enchanting.  Inside, each room is actually a suite, with a fully furnished kitchen, including coffee, tea and fresh milk. Sue says this is typical of a NZ motel - we'd be awed just by the fresh towels and complimentary soaps!  Sue herself is up for special honors tonight. Not only did she take care of our stuff today (when we arrived at the motel, Sue was gone but we found all our things delivered into our respective rooms) but she then went on and followed Wayne all the way in to Auckland, to make sure he arrived without further incident. Then she turned around and drove all the way back to Wellesford so she could carry our stuff around for the next (last!) two days of cycling! She arrives just before dinner which we luckily have enough of to feed her and a surprise - her favorite chocolate bar is waiting on her pillow, a small gift of appreciation from her little elves. After two bottles of wine at dinner, we all go outside to tour the motel grounds at sunset. This is just another of the things we would never see at home - an ordinary motel in the middle of an ordinary town, cared for to an immaculate level of loving detail that our American minds just can't get over and our spirits just delight in! We all take alot of photos as we wander around amazed! Primed with wine, we stage an impromptu 'end of trip' party, taking over 'the boys room' (our room has been dubbed 'Mike's harem'!) for the occasion. Everyone finds something to contribute as we try to use up and unload the last of our goodies... Mike brings out a gallon of Tip-Top ice cream (Chocolate Eclair!) that he picked up at the market earlier (the rooms have refrigerators!), Sherry and I pop up the last of my popcorn (using Ed's butter) and Bob pulls out some beers. They even have found a birthday card, candle and wrapped up a gag gift for me! We all share the goodies while watching a movie (yes, the motel even has a satellite!) called 'Cats and Dogs' starring Jeff Goldblum - one of those movies that's so bad it's funny! After alot of laughs and a wonderful evening, we stagger back to our room at the grand late hour of 10:00 - great fun! 
Today's ride is on Hwy 16 till lunch (more 'rewind' of the miles we did, this time from Day 39) from Wellesford to Kauapakapaka. Hillier than we expectit to be, the route just keeps onrolling, with alot of up! Mike isn't having a great day today (in fact eventually he names this the worst-feeling day of the trip!), he says is legs are dead. Wonder why...  maybe it was that wild party last night! We work pretty hard just getting to lunch and then after lunch, with some dread, we separate from the main road to take a more direct and scenic but even MORE hilly route!  The hilly route turns out to be no worse, really, than the busy road was. By now, the worst part is the humidity! We have a tailwind so no breeze at all on the uphills. Just stagnant hot humid air.  On a brighter note, we are travelling through beautiful neighborhoods of upscale country homes, with gorgeous landscaping and well-kept horses grazing in teh fields. At one point, we even ride through a grove of silverferns! My first road-side sighting of one!  We cross Hwy 16 once more to head out to Muriwai Beach, 9 perilous kms down a really busy road... possibly the busiest road we've been on in the entire trip! Almost no shoulder and just *crazy* traffic on a mission to get to and from the beach!  The beach, when we get there, IS worth the trauma. We take a 30 minute self-guided tour around a Gannet colony. The Gannet, as you'll see from our photos, is a striking bird. The signs along the walk give us quite a bit of information about their breeding, habits, and lifecycle. Their first flight is direct from NZ to Australia!! They stay at least 2 years, and then return to NZ. Only 25% make it back alive. Those that do, return to precisely where they were born, where they mate for life. Their flight is unbelievably graceful - their wingspan is probably 4-5 ft - but they are not too coordinated in landing. We see one adult do a total faceplant!   After the Gannet tour, we all jump into the ocean (even Mike!) which is quite rough - lots of surfers and lots of 'warning - undertow, riptides' signs!  We are careful but we have a ball jumping the waves and doing a bit of (very amateur) body surfing. Definitely the roughtest surf we've been in! I could stay for hours but I have to be careful about sunburn! One more fun group dinner and then it's time to call it a day... I can't believe it's so close to being over!
We've found a series of back roads which we can take direct to the train station, making the morning's ride as scenic and traffic-free as possible. We decide to stay together and ride as a group as we don't all have the detailed maps that show the complete route.  We have quite a climb (about 2 km) right out of the gate this morning.
