London-Paris is a fairly short flight, they barely had time to serve us drinks, and again I was on firm ground, a little emotionnal to meet my sister whom I didn't see in a few year. My bike came last and really I was getting worried that it wouldn't come at all but it looked intact, and then I could get out and be greeted by my sis and her partner Mario. We worked on the bike a bit and noticed that the rear tire wouldn't inflate... Would that count for the first flat tire of the trip??? And then we weaved our way through the shuttle then the train that would lead us towards their appartment in the 10th Arrondissement. By that point I was getting tired at times but still wired so we went out for dinner at a mexican restaurant where we got smoked real good by other people's bad habits... That is where my sister told me she was expecting a baby for the end of the year... What a news to learn to start a trip to Europe!!! :-)       
Breakfast in Paris is twice as cool. Mario went to pick up fresh croissants and fresh chocolate bread and we feasted on that along with orange juice and peanut butter toasts with maple butter (at least for me). Well the peanut butter is a north american delicacy and as my sister asked me to bring some. I did and obliged to help her with using the first pot...  Sunday morning in Paris is market day, so she and I went for a stroll along Canal St-Martin amd weaving through the dog shit (yeah, as blunt as that) on the sidewalk we made it to the march de la Bastille in maybe half an hour. There we fought showers on and off, fought the crowd the crowd and found some fruits and vegetables like cherries,nectarines and some savory pastries for our lunch. Lunch... yummy...         After our wonderful meal we decided to head for the bed... for a well deserved nap... OK... My sister is pregnant, and I am on jet lag... Make sense? Then I woke up by 3 and we all went for a nice stroll to the heart of Paris, to discover the Cathedrale Notre-Dame which is absolutely fabulous with its impressive facade and all the details everywhere... I found my chin close to my toes and took a lot of pictures. We would have liked to go up the towers but the line up was already beyond the one hour wait so we decided to carry on. Next in line was a little walk along the Seine river and crossed another bridge, le Pont des Arts and faced le Louvre, where the Mona Lisa smiles somewhere on one of the floors... For today we would walk outside and visit the interior court, viewing the statues and the architecture which is fantastic... No wall is left plain. The most intricate details cover every parts in a way very appealing to the eye, making me wish I was a princess...      We saw the infamous Pyramid in the inside court which doesn't fit much in the picture but oh well then headed towards "les Tuileries" which is some other gardens.           The infamous Champs Elysees came next as we made our way towards the Arc de Triomphe where a ceremony commeemorating the passage of the president Bush took place so we weren't alowed to go even close to it. Very impressive though. By that time we were all tired of all the walking, the negociations of the sidewalks with people, dog shit, strollers and police, and two of us had to pee badly, and so we headed for hot chocolate and bathroom deal at "La brioche doree" and think about what to do next... The plans were for food. When the mood gets low, get food... That is the motto... We settled for pizza, so we headed to a place known by my sister at "La defense" which is a square that is the most futuristic and quite anachronistic whith the idea people have of Paris. The pizza place was closed so we went for thai food at the other end of town. It was quite yummy... I couldn't believe I would be able to eat past 8 PM but I managed without having my stomach screaming to the world that it needed attention.. Careful though for when I will be biking all day... After a good meal like that we headed for the Eiffel tower, which happened to be all lit and majestuous... We had a serious photo session then walked right under it and to the other side to watch the moon rise and the view from a small hill. Really nice wrap up of a wonderful day...        
We made a big backpack full of stuff we could possibly need for the day and this time put on my cycling shoes instead of my sandals (hell with my no sports shoes with nice pants rule) for comfort. Paris is a fashion city and I kind of felt like I could do a bunch of shopping for clothes and other delicacies of a city girl but they don't fit in my panniers so just let it go...  Our stroll took us in the rich neighborhood and we did a bit of window shopping until 12:30 when my sister had an appointment with her doctor. I  was glad to go with her and observe the normal life in Paris. There was much more people in the streets of Paris this time around as it was a working day and I felt a bit dizzy by all the noise of the street, the circulation and the moppeds and motorcycles that were playing stunts on the road just to make it wherever a little faster. I saw one of those moppeds driving in traffic and in the same time talking on the cell phone... As for biking in Paris, I have been strongly discouraged to biking here, but people do. I haven't seen anybody wearing a helmet as of yet, so it sounds that I will be the only one in France let alone in Europe that do but oh well. I will protect my brain.  We went for lunch after fighting the heavy crowd. We went to Le Printemps which is a nice department store and on the sixth floor there is a dining room with a dome roof that is named historical. Apparently the roof has been removed piece by piece during the second World War and put back in 1973. I had quiche and some kind of decadent chocolate mousse with english cream, which i only picked because it was one Euro more with my menu. Quite yummy. Oh-Oh better start biking soon...        Then Marika and I went for the Cathedrale Notre-Dame again to see if we could go up on the towers and have a glimps of the city. There was one hour wait time for that and the groups had priority and could jump queue... So instead we went for the free indoors visit and admired the very impressive stainglass and the painted roofs. I asked my sister if she wanted to confess all her sins to the priest but she declined. As for me I don't have any. :-)    Then we went on the thankfully quieter ile St-Louis to admire the view on the Seine and also stroll on the narrow roads and take a rest. I found some Pepsi for the first time of the trip and toasted my sister... We were quite tired at that point and we decided to take a rest in the park behind the chathedral and sip our drink. Ths sky was very threatening and we knew it would rain sometime tonight.      Marika wa looking for a present and I was looking for some propane-butane for my stove so we strolled around the Latin Quarter and window shopped. The French people have really good taste when it comes to shopping and I was drooling quite heavily. I think I overpaid what I bought however, especially a metal cup that I did buy for 5,5 Eeuros. That is theft! We walked around some ruins that were fenced- I think it was a medieval museum and I noticed this man that was kneeling in the middle of the sidewalk (everybody had to make a detour to avoid him) with this little cardboard sign saying "J'ai faim" (I'm hungry). It is sad to see that people come to that in the  world. That is a universal problem that I will not solve today but it is always disturbing for me to see. It started raining slowly as we were heading towards the metro (subway) then the whole sky fell on us as we had only a small broken umbrella to share. My pants got wet to the knees and the thunder and lightening joined for a son et lumiere party. It has been rainning every day since I am here and started regretting not brining my gore-tex jacket along on my trip.  The evening was quiet and Mario and Marika made a wonderful ostrich meal with a nice little sauce and also mashed potatoes and salad... Thanks guys... Later that evening I prepared my bike for the big odyssee, remembering I came for that, biking  around France, south Germany, Switzerland and Spain... I feel a bit nervous of heading out on my own after hearing the stories of theft by my sister, but it seems to relate more to Paris. I have to be careful with my belongings always keep an eye on the bike. So Am I suposed to take the bike for a pee or pee with my bike??? I will find out and let you know.   
Came back to the appartment with a piece of pizza and a Diet coke and decided to go for a visit of the Opera, the one I took pictures of yesterday from the outside. I negociated my way just fine in the subway by myself and soon was inside the said opera and admired the walls and ceiling architecture and took lots of pictures. I hope that some of them will turn out fine.          I was excited to leave the appartment with my loaded bike and leave for the train station, la gare de l'est. My sister recommended me to walk the bike there but I was itching to cycle and wanted to experience the said nightmare of cycling in Paris. It ended up just fine, but I experienced some problems with the gears on the way and remembered that I had declined Mario's offer to go down on the street and test drive the bike yesterday... Ha! Putting the bike on the train was a bit of a challenge as there is a huge step but someone volunteered to help so I was thankful. My wagon was different from the one I put the bike in so I locked the bike and went in the search of my assigned seat. The French trains are fairly tame, with little closed cubicules accomodating 6 passengers in each one. I sat by the window, and had a look at the surroundings. At first, getting out of Paris was basically a cluster of train tracks criss-crossing but soon enough we were out of there and crossing lands of greens and little villages. I ate my sandwich, wrote my journal and had a little talk with my neighbors... Nothing to write home about. I was glad I changed my mind and didn't cycle from Paris to Strasbourg, because it looked like very ordinary terrain, with not much to cater to the cyclo-tourists... We made it to Strasbourg exactily on time, and again got help to unload the bike and found an elevator to escape the flight of stairs leading to the street level. Something that sounds very obvious in Canada, like having wheeelchair accessible areas like train and subway stations, levelled sidewalks at street crossings and adapted building access is a struggle here in France. I wonder how wheelchair bound people weave their way in here...  The sun was setting, it was getting dark, but I kind of knew where to go, and I clipped my little red flashing light to my clothes before heading out towards the campground. An angel came to rescue me when I got puzzled at an intersection and lead me in the right direction. She was cycling the same way than me so we had a little chat when we could cycle side by side. There was nobody at the campground reception so I sneaked beyond the gate and set up camp under a tree in the dark. Went to brush my teeth and first cultural shock of the French campgrounds, the toilet paper is outside the stalls, so you have to take some before you go, and estimate how much you need right... I will know for next time! This first night camping was quite meaningful to me as it marked the begining of my adventure...
I must have left by 9AM maybe a bit later, delayed for putting my rear panniers upside down and noticing only once I tried to pedal, my feet hitting the outside pockets of the panniers usually on the rear of the bike. A little rusty, I'd say? After paying my dues at the office, I looked for food and found a bakery within 5 minutes, savored a chocolate croissant with a hot chocolate. Little errands ensued and I decided I would bypass Strasbourg for now and visit after my little Alsace tour. I needed a bike shop to adjust the derailleur problem, and as I was getting away from Strasbourg, I was hoping to find something on my way south in a little town. Exiting the town was uneventful, sharing the moderately busy road with other drivers who gave me lots of space to maneuver which allowed me to look around and enjoy the sceneries. My whole day consisted in getting in and out of little towns, some prettier than others but each with quite a distinctive character of Alsace. In between town, vineyards, all the way to the horizon...     Let's talk about the little towns. Most of them had a medieval flair, with cobblestone in the core. Houses had a German influence being so close to the German border, and all of those properties were so well kept that you could tell that it's inhabitants were very proud of them and working hard to preserve them. Churches were of course in the heart of the village, and noticeable form far away. Fountains were also in each of those towns, providing me with fresh and cold water without having to ask anybody to give me some. The fountains themselves were a pride with gargoyles, statues and flowers, something I have never seen in Canada really. Each of them was unique and well located. Of course wine is a main preoccupation for Alsacians along with tourism I presume. Every village has its grower and offer wine tasting and also visits of the winery. You could go from village to village and taste all day if you wanted. It could have been a trip on its own, going from village to village, and buy the best bottles of wine... I was tempted to stop and taste, buy a bottle but just for myself sounded ridiculous, bulky and heavy. After only one glass, I giggle by myself. The bottles of wine can be as cheap as 2.80 Euro and it would be quite normal to buy a 500 ml of Pepsi for 2 Euro... Go figure.      I had a good training for the Alps today as I climbed 2 decent hills, the first one being Mont St-Odile, which is a religious place on top of a hill of 765 m. There is a church up there and the gift shop sells lots of religious gadgets. There was nothing difficult to this climb, just a steady 11 km uphill. I stopped for a 15 min lunch on the way there. I was congratulated for my efforts and one man took a picture of me for the posterity... There was a fair amount of sport cyclists that I met on my way down and I think they were surprised to see a girl riding a loaded bike up there.    The second hill was to visit a castle. Jean-Francois had recommended me to go see for myself, it is called 'le chateau du Haut-Koenigsbourg' and like many castles in Europe they like to make them with a panoramic view to prevent the enemy to sneak in from behind and steal all the princesses. It stands at 755 m and when I arrived up there by 6 or 6:30 PM it was closed for the day... I could have been disappointed but by 6:30 PM, all I wanted was to go down the hill, find my way to a campsite and have a nice warm shower. The one I got was named Camping Pierre de Coubertin  after this guy that revived the Olympic Games (I think) a few years ago... The campsite has hot showers, dishwashing and laundry facilities and sells a few things for the morning, the essentials like 'pain au chocolat' (chocolate bread) and croissants, and the unforgettable baguette. For diner I had some pasta with tomato basil sauce, mushroom, zucchini and emmental cheese. Hot chocolate and GORP for dessert. (Good Old Raisins and Peanuts) That evening I phoned Jean-Francois and happily talked about my experience in Alsace and also about that bike shop I stopped to who's owner didn't want to fix my gears under the pretext that my front rings must be worn out. (I explained that this bike was brand new). How insulting.  In one week we would meet face to face and start biking as a team, and I thought that by that time I would be ready for company.  By 10 PM I got very tired and as it was finally dark, retired in my quarters to sleep before another fabulous day biking...
         The bike happened to ride so much better. The brakes are still not perfect but that was ok by me. I left town using the bike path which goes from town to town without the traffic of the wine route. Ooooohhh, did I ever sweat. I picked one of the steepest way to start with and it got very hot in there, no wind. I found myself surrounded by rows of grapevines, and hills all around, all of them full of the same grapevines.     I was a bit discouraged to see my lack of progress and how slow it was going when I was looking at my map. Would I be in good enough shape to climb the high passes of the Alps? Would I be able to follow Jean-Francois? He has been riding 2500 km this year. Me? I would say less than 1000. I am not sure as I didn't have a computer when I was training on the mountain bike.  Leaving the campsite someone asked to borrow my air pump, and being from the area, he recommended me some routes to do, especially 'La route des cretes' (the Crest Road). So off I go, passed by Kayserberg which is totally fabulous and start my climb towards the 'col du Bonhomme'(949 m). Bonhomme was posted to be 4 km away from where it started to climb more seriously but that was only the little village. I had to climb more, sweat more, climb again all that in a rather busy truck route, you know the 18 wheels type. I managed ok although I would have preferred something more quiet. All the traffic was very considerate to me and I really appreciate that. I phoned my sister from a phone booth in a rest area and it felt good to tell some of my tales so far. Eventually I made it at the Col du Bonhomme and got into a hotel-restaurant in order to refill my water bottles.    There was a lot of motorcyclists parked there and sipping on a drink on the patio and also a few cyclists, but none had panniers on. I had a lot of eyes staring at me as I was handling the bike, and I was aware of that. I think that people were recognizing the effort I made on my way up here. I didn't hang out very much and soon enough I was on my way to the 'Col de la Schlucht'. (1258m)(What's in a name?)... Climb climb climb, and climb more. It was enjoyable, I was in a forest and the air was cool sometimes a little too cool for my short sleeves. The most irritating was the constant buzz of the motorcycles. There must have been 2 to 300 passing me today. I met this cyclist on a high plateau who told me that most of those motorcyclists were German, and they were coming out here for enjoying the speed in the mountains as they didn't have the right to ride that way at home. Sadly maybe 3 or 4 km before the Col de la Schlucht, there was a motorcyclist down in the ditch, and emergency vehicles on the scene. There was not much movement happening, and not much noise either. I didn't stop, and continues with a somber mood. I was greeted at the junction of the pass with applauds from a couple of tourists watching. I was a little embarrassed by the attention, not being used to that. There was also a lot of bikers in leathers showing me the thumb up in admiration. Cyclists were up there as well, again none having panniers like me and mostly men. I decided to head back down the mountain towards Colmar instead of continuing south on the route des Cretes. I wanted to be in Colmar today so I can head back to Strasbourg the next day, and also I had enough of the hills, the cold and the motorcycles. The way down was... cold, exhilarating, and scenic as approaching the end of the descent I was offered a view of the whole valley. It was fabulous! My average speed picked up from 13 to 17 km/hr and soon I was riding in the 27-28 km/hr range on the flat. Ahhhh! This was  more like me! I must have reached the campsite I aimed for in the suburb of Colmar past 18:30. I purchased a beer that I gulped as I pitched the tent and also a 'Coca Light' for celebrations. My body needed the fluid, the bubbles, the caffeine... I had a wonderful pasta meal with pepperoni and tomato sauce in it and had an apple for dessert, hot chocolate for afterwards. Nights were still cool so a hot drink was welcome.
I visited the old part of Colmar with its narrow streets, churches that are so old that even your great grand-ma wouldn't be THAT old, with its roof that's patterned and with the houses that are all different yet matching with one another and making the whole very very charming. I would have like to visit the church yet didn't feel safe leaving the bike alone. Well ha! I took a chance leaving my bike unlocked in front of the Monoprix a large surface grocery store, and also in front of a woman and her child begging and lots of tourists circulating or hanging out. My bike ended up being just fine, and soon after I was on my way out of town, wanting to get away from all the business and traffic. I decided to head back passing through Ribeauville and then head back north towards Strasbourg by the mountains. Good choice, girl...    From the beginning the way up to Ste-Marie-aux-Mines was enchanting and peaceful, but for when the motorcycles would come by. They weren't as numerous as yesterday and it was more pastural as the previous day as well. Someone asked me on top of the pass if the Tour the France had already started looking at me climbing with all my gear. That was really cute... The col de Ribeauville is high of 742 m and left me in a sweat. Lots of tight switchbacks, but the grades were all do-able and I did it easy. There is this feeling of satisfaction and accomplishment when one reaches the top and start gaining speed from the downhill. The way down was spectacular too looking down the valley. It was so lush, smelling so fresh... I loved it!    The second pass I did today, the Col de Fouchy (603 m) was absolutely fantastic. I was greeted by a bunch of motorcyclists resting on top which made me shy a bit, so I stopped for the time of a picture and started my descent towards Fouchy. A little goat said hi and I replied happily and the twists and turns of the road were magnificent, each showing me a different panorama of the valley and the town down there. I had a lot of fun in there, smiling to myself, screaming 'yahoo' to the world... I had a few km of flat to recover and get some blood back into my legs and up we go again... That pass was just a little one, 350 m but it was tiring and also noisy with the motorcyclists. I wanted a cold drink real bad. It was getting late and my goal was to make it to Strasbourg but looking at the map, realized I would get there past 8 PM so I opted for something easier for a vacationing girl and stopped in Obernai, had a beer, relaxed my muscles and cleaned up the first chain tattoes of the trip. I treated myself with a wonderful dinner of pasta, french bread, french cheese and chocolate coated cookies for dessert. The campsite was very quiet that night beside this neighbor of mine screaming 'Putain de merde!' once of twice (not translatable) and beside the crickets. I noticed sunburns behind my shoulders where I haven't been able to reach when applying sunscreen. I made a mental note to try harder. The sun is wicked in here, and when you spend 6 weeks under the element, the exposed skin needs to be protected... I went to bed pleased with my day, aware that those hills were not the Alps but still were a good training prior to them.   
Prior to arriving to Strasbourg there was a U-pick at a strawberry field and got tempted so I parked the bike and out I went picking my strawberries. It made me happy and made me smile... I picked enough for me and not too much for my panniers and carried on. Then I needed to find a grocery store and fast as it was getting past 11 AM on a Saturday, the stores close at noon and everything would be close on Sunday. Fortunately I found something and stocked up in the essentials then headed towards Strasbourg. I didn't have too much trouble to find the infamous and imposing cathedral. Just aim for the middle of town. Once you get up close, follow the tourists. And if you stand right up front, you break your neck trying to look at the top...    There were pedestrians-only streets with lots of junk for us to buy, post card and usual tourist gadgets. It was quite nice, but too many people for my taste. The cathedral was just fabulous to see from all angles. I circled it by bike and sat down on a low wall to eat lunch. In the 20 min I sat there 2 older men came by to beg some food from me. There were lots or beggars on the streets 'working' and this one woman really disturbed me: All dressed of black like muslims do, head covered, she was kneeling on the pavement with her cheek almost touching to ground and looking up to people passing. Unless people have fun doing this and the money is good I wondered how people got to this point in their lives... I wanted to visit the cathedral but unfortunately it is quite risky to leave the bike on its own when the lone cyclist wants to visit a touristy place like the cathedral was. I got around that hurdle by asking another cyclist to watch my bike as he was standing there waiting for his partner to return, and promised not to be too long... (Thank you to that unknown friend for this). The inside of the cathedral was impressive too with the intricate stainglass, I took a few pictures, hoping they will turn out.   Leaving the cathedral behind I walked and biked aimlessly in the 'Petite France' quarter, managed to lose my very precious Alsace-Lorraine Michelin map where I highlighted all my itinary as I went. I also managed to hit a little girl with my front wheel as she was running without looking in the middle of the street. I felt so bad. I was riding slowly when this family come towards me and the children are running one after another. The little girl didn't see me coming but just at the last minute. I applied the brakes but it was too late. The little girl screamed to death and as I braked suddenly I didn't get a chance to get out of my cleats and was hanging on a metal fence by the sidewalk trying to get off the pedals and attempting to reassure the frightened little girl that everything was ok... She had more fright than hurt, fortunately and I apologized profusely to the parents, shaking in my pants. Fortunately the latter were quite understanding that their daughter didn't look around as she was running and also accepted my appologies. I felt so bad... It got me upset for an hour after the incident.          It was shortly after that incident that I noticed the rear rack was wobbly again and the screw was getting lose again. This time it was the opposite side, on the derailleur side. So as I had a spare screw, I changed it but unfortunately the head was too long and impeded on the speed changing. So I had to put the old screw back on, tightening it to the max and making a mental note to check it every day. In the same token my handle bar bag attachment was giving me some grief as well and spent another 15 minutes trying to make it right. After these events, dirty with profuse chain tattoes on the usual leg and still shaken up, I decided I had enough with big cities and to leave town, and by the same token change countries. I had promised to phone Jean-Francois that day and it just happened that I had lots to say... I got a bit of sympathy and felt a bit better from venting it.  I managed to find my way across the Rhine river where on the other side you find yourself in Germany.     There were old custom borders no longer in use and just a very busy boulevard where people drive quite fast. Kehl is very confusing. Especially when you don't have a close-up map and when you don't have a clue what the indications on the road say and when the biker doesn't have a clue where to go! After taking the wrong turn and tuning in circles for a while in Kehl, I stopped in a gas station and asked for directions but the man there didn't speak anything else than German and attempted reluctantly to show me where to go. Welcome to Germany! I felt sorry I could not communicate and when I asked around if someone spoke English or French it felt like begging... After what seemed to be an eternity trying to find my way out of Kehl, I finally followed my own instincts and carried on a little further on the busy road and found just what I needed, a bike path along the Rhine river that was going North and that would take me where I wanted to go, near Karlsruhe.    The bike path was quiet and very scenic, but the paved road became dirt road which slowed me down and I had to fight a head wind that would become increasingly unpleasant. It must have been 4 PM by that time and I had a lot of distance to cover to reach my destination so I was in a hurry. Eventually I gave up the scenery for a parallel paved road and found indications for a bike path for a city I was aiming for which I took. I was then in farmland, everything was lush and beautiful yet different from France and I was enjoying.    Show links to this Hide links to this      Eventually I found the road #36 that was a bit busier but it would take me directly to Baden Baden and beyond and I took that. Martin, a young cyclist of 25 caught up to me and engaged in a conversation in English. I was glad to have some company. Martin was having a 100 km training tonight and didn't mind to slow down for me and also offered some wind protection so we had a little session of drafting after talking for a while. We talked cycling, traveling, work and else. When it got time to part as he was returning home, I knew where I was going but it was getting late! I was still unsure whether I would be able to beat the darkness.  The campsite I was looking that was on my map didn't exist so some kind young soul at a gas station directed me to another one and still had to turn round and round in order to find it. It was advertised at first as a golf course, so I didn't see it at first. When I made it to the campingplatz it was just about dark, 9 PM and it didn't seem to me that the office was open so I went about looking for a place for me to settle. To my big dismay it looked to me like a big resort, and a lot of mobile homes were established. There was also a lake where people did scuba diving and a golf course. Eventually one older man rescued me and lead me to the office where I could register and play my due. The lady at the office wasn't very kind and couldn't care less about me... I wondered whether it was because I didn't speak German. I gave her 12.5 Euro for my little tent and one extra Euro for a token for 3 minutes of hopefully warm water at the shower. All that took a lot of signing and exchange of French and English and German words that went misunderstood by one party or the other. It would have been funny in any other situation but after 130 km and a rather stressful day, all I wanted was to get the film of sweat and dust off my body, pitch my tent, have dinner and go to bed. Mosquitoes were ravenous here and I had to move continuously to avoid being stung. I ate by 10:30 PM, and gastronomy was my emergency ramen noodles with a carrot and cheese. It was dark and here I was sitting outside trying to take hold of  what I had done today... I was glad to rest my head on the pillow...if pillow it was!
So off I go, north, to reach the begining of the tourist route of the Black Forest. Ettlingen was the doorway and I circled a few times in the city to find its center and also to find the said tourist road. I treated myself with lunch in Ettlingen, sitting under shade and eating a donair. It was interesting again to place that order as there was no other way to be understood but to sign and point with the finger, but the waitress and I managed...I enjoyed sipping my Coke writing post cards. Very quiet town on this Sunday, only across the street there was a small bar and a few people were watching the World Cup playing live and were cheering for whatever team.  After lingering a bit I left for the hills, after asking for my way- which always helps... One word regarding bike paths in Germany. They are numerous, they are generally off the road, generally well signed, and if you know where you are going, there is usually a bike path for you! However I got caught a few times taking a bike path and not ending where I wanted to go. So once or twice I just ignored it and took to road. Well! A few drivers made me know I should have taken the said path. I don't know for sure what they said but in english it would probably sound this way: '@#$#@!%?' !!! The off road  bike path I took from Ettlingen to Pfaffenrot (and probably beyond) was away from the road, up the mountain. I was riding in the forest, quietly, crossing bikers and the odd pedestrian once in a while. It was enjoyable especially in the shade but I got some handle bar bag holder problem again today which forced me to stop and to swear a few times.    I had a little stop at the touristy Bad Herrenalb for a diet Coke and a rest. Soon after I was climbing again- I would say a 500 m hill- hard to guess and I enjoyed it. The downhill afterwards was to die for! Brand new pavement, curvy, and so, so cool! I screamed a few 'yahoo!' just because I was so happy!      On my way through Bad Wildbad I had to pass a tunnel-I don't know if I read the sign right saying that bike were allowed or what, but it was kind of spooky... Of one km long, curvy, I had to ride on a narrow sidewalk, climb down to cross a turn off and climb back onto the other side... I had my red flashing light clipped to my shorts and lived to  tell about it... Another yahoo experience (to be alive that is)...    Eventually I made it to my destination, a little town named Enzklosterle, in a quiet campsite by a river. The camping owner lives here with his demented mom that I met in the lobby.  As usual my shower was delightful...There was only this one couple with their 2 children, and the woman came and say hi as I was cooking, offered me a beer and I accepted with many thanks... I was craving one and as I came rather late nothing was open for me to come to camp with one. That was really nice. She dug her english from far away and we exchange a few laugh and some conversation. That was touching. The young children were curious about me, as I was cooking on this weird little stove and I offered them some cheese sticks. My dinner tonight was a cream of potato with potatoes ,carrots and broccoli added, served with cheese and a crusty bun... Yum yum... Hot chocolate for dessert. I am happy to have time to relax tonight, a contrast with last night.
I woke up with an extremely full bladder and it got me out of the tent in a flash. It was kind of sunny, some clouds and somewhat cool... I wonder if it's colder because of the altitude, because I slept with my fleece and long pants on. Usually I end up too hot dressed like that and take off layer in the middle of the night. Not today. I was hungry. My bags were empty so I packed it all up and went down to the village's bakery to see what they got. I found a wonderful pastry with cheese on it and pieces of ham. Then, for dessert, an apple strudel... Yum yum yum. Now I had to burn it off... The cycling was very pleasant. Passing through forests, open spaces, valleys, villages, it was all very enjoyable, without too much traffic.    Past Freudstadt which to me was uninteresting I started on a busy road and then opted for something quieter. Climb climb climb, ended up in a very quiet little village called Odenwald and I refilled my water bottles in a town fountain. I talked to the cows as we were nose to nose and took a few pictures... By then the cycling got a little tough for my liking. I think I am starting to feel tired from my last days riding.          I wanted to see Titisee and sleep there because I liked the name and because I read in the Lonely Planet that is was a nice place to be in. Well I reached St-Georgen with 90 km on the counter and realized there was at least 50 more to Titisee. And more climbing to do. Just out of St-Georgen I received the first drop of rain, which I refused to believe it was what it was until I started to get seriously wet. I had to stop and access my rear panniers (tough thing to do in the middle of the day) to get my jacket out, the booties, then get the map in and take my courage and wing it to find my way and find a place to camp for the night. The map said there was a youth hostel in Triberg so I asked around with the usual sign language, and eventually I learned that the hostel was way, way up there, up the mountain... ha! In the meantime I was cycling in a delightful backcountry road, where the real people live. Mrs Hen crossed right in front of my bike and Mr Rooster said Cocoricooooo!!! The cows looked at me like I was crazy. The children didn't notice me, too busy playing... I should have taken a picture, but it was raining, I was going downhill and I was wondering if I was going in the right direction. Lots of reasons and I will still be disappointed that I didn't frame this one. In Triberg I took a turn like if I was going to Titisee and started climbing and climbing high and steep. Then I saw the sign for the youth hostel. With the rain being rather heavy and more hills in the future for me towards Titisee I decided to go for the hostel. The grade up that hill must have been 15% maybe more. Unbelievable. For the first time in a long time I had to walk my bike. The hill defeated me... I didn't mind so much but I think I was worried about what would come next. Hey, it was still a work out to push the bike!!! There was a bunch of youth at the hostel, like between 10 and 15 years old. It was clear in my mind that I wanted to camp. The rain had stopped. It was much much quieter outside than in. I found the hostel attendants in the kitchen, trying to cater to all the kids, and asked permission to pitch my tent in the backyard, have a shower and use the bathroom. They agreed, all that for nothing so far. The shower was divine, hot and everything and I had a nice salad with german sausage and couscous dinner. The cherries, meant for dessert were eaten pitching the tent. I had a leisurly evening writing and walking around and taking picture. I phoned my friend Michele for her birthday and tried my father but there was no answer.    Short story before I go to bed... I went to the washroom a last time before retiring in my quarters and in order to save power, the lights are tuning on and turning off automatically. I am not sure if there is a movement detector or what, but... Well here I am all organized on the trone reading my map when... it gets completely dark... Oppps... He he! I guess one has only so many seconds to do their business in the washroom then you are expected to be out. Hope it wasn't too much details... Good night!
Triberg... I slept ok but was woken up by a mother nature's 'son et lumiere' (thunderstorm) and a little bit of rain. I fell asleep after the show, closing my tent and putting the head back on to the pillow. In the morning, the sun was back on and my stomach was empty and growling. I braved out shyness and went to the hostel and ask if it was possible to have breakfast. For 3 Euros I had 2 glasses of juice, I bowl of cereal, 3 buns of medium size, cheese, jam. Yum. What a piglet I am, I ate it all. Went back to my tent, packed it all up, and left with anticipation of the big hill that was awaiting my right off the bat. It ended up going ok, even though I was worried I might have to walk it up. I conquered it and started my cycling day. The air was fresh, the shade was good and the views on top of the hill fabulous... One thing about today was the wild flower fields were just fantastic- yellow, purple and white all over. Once in a while there would be villages and once in a while I would stop for refreshments. Now, I knew this would be a long day. The hostel attendant had recommended me the flatter course and the most direct route that would lead me in Switzerland. But I wanted to see Titisee...  So off I go to Titisee. Riding the last section to reach the town was a bit nerve racking as I seemed to be on a highway with not much shoulder. I had my first glimpse off some snow on the mountains which got me in awe. The lake was pretty, the city quite touristy, and I had a lunch of bread, cherries and coke and after dabbing myself of sun screen I left for my next destination, the Swiss border.    Now and then I had the chance to talk to the cows, the goats and the sheep but not much luck for answers. It must have been mid day when I noticed my camera would no longer take pictures. When I turned the camera on, the zoom would expand to the maximum and an error message would appear on the screen. Now this was a very distressing moment for someone like me who's pictures were very meaningful. This meant no pictures at the swiss border, no pictures of the swiss landscape, no pictures of Zurich. I would think and re-think in my head what to do, as I couldn't go on like this, without camera for the rest of my trip, this was just not possible. In the meantime, I passed at the swiss border at 4 PM I'd say. It was a very small one, just one person attending. He made me park my bike aside while he was checking out my passport. 2 minutes after that he returned it to me stamped and I was free to go. The first thing I noticed of Switzerland was the price of the gas compared with the one in Germany. Well it was only later that I understood that with the money change, it would end up being the same... Still it was way more expensive than in Canada. I was glad I didn't need any... Soon enough I emerged up a hill with commanding views of the North of Switzerland... Long plains full of agriculture and viniculture and once in a while, here and there I could see one village with its typical red roof houses and the inevitable church. Still every village had its fountain available for everyone to fill out their water bottles. It had been great for me and sometimes I would stop and refill my bottles, and also wet my bandana and wash my face with it and then place it on my head to cool off... Past the border I didn't want to look at my mini computer as I knew I was beyond 100 km and I knew I had quite a bit to go before Zurich. I was trying to look at the scenery, singing , and thinking 'Zurich'. The little village of Reineau was totally charming. In the middle of a meandering of the Rhine river that I met again after crossing from Strasbourg to Kehl, I had to cross in a beautiful covered bridge and head back up the hill in a quaint little village. It was a popular place for cyclists and I met plenty including one that rode with me for a whileand enquired about my trip. It was in Flaash that I got lost, or maybe the map lost me. There was no indications for the direction I wanted so I was forced to do a detour which I was not so pleased about as I was already at 130 km and not in Zurich yet (ok I had a peek at the computer). Oh well. I managed I guess. Did the detour. Followed the highway without being on it, stopped in Embrach for groceries- they happened to close so I was lucky I got in. I gulped my ice tea bottle like there was no more drinking for 3 days and swallowd all at once a soft cookie filled with apple in the middle. Yum. If I was going the distance today, might as well keep the stomach happy uh? Soon after that I reached Kloten where I would meet Jean-Francois the next day and the sight of it made me really happy almost emotional. I didn't have time to get emotional as I had to remain focused and alert in the traffic to make it alive to the campsite. In Zurich I had to ask many people for directions and finally I was directed to the train station for tourist info regarding my campsite. I thanked the guy who helped me at the visitor center and who brought me the good news that the camping was less than 10 km away and not too difficult to find, then I got other much needed information like where was the nearest internet caf, camera shop and then carried on. Negociating the downtown core in any city is always tricky, but after 160 km on a loaded bike, well... what can I say...I had to fight for my space in between scooters, pedestrians, cars, trucks and trams. I was honked at once for not knowing where to go. Ooops. Then made my way around Limmat Quay and looked at the tremendous views I had across the canal. Beautiful city. I am impressed. I reached the camping by 9, maybe later, after 8h30 on the bike and 172.1 km, my longest distance ever on a bike in one day, with or without load. I was tired but not exhausted.. I pitched my tent by Zurichsee, the lake, and had a delightful but expensive (4 Francs for 6 minutes) shower and had some of my cuisine with was quite yummy. Mind you dinner at 10:30 PM is always good after 172 km... So, this is my story... Sticking to it!
So... First things first, eating. I had a left over of bread and a single sample of Nutella which I really liked. A banana. I took a detour after the bathroom run to buy some yogurt and orange juice. Then I was shown the best place for specialists to have a look at my camera and the lady had a look at it and announced that it was dead. There was no way I could go the rest of my trip without a camera so I looked into replacements and found this second hand Minolta, compact with a zoom. It looked ok with an acceptable price. Done deal. Then I headed to the laundromat. At 5.5 Swiss Francs for a wash and 3.8 Swiss Francs for a drying, you better make sure your clothes is well beyond dirty when you wash. (That was close to 10$ Can. for the whole thing). It was 11:30 when I was out of there and I was wanting to do some internet work but my stomach started making wahing machine noises to make sure I knew it was hungry... "Feed me, feed me!!!" I found some pizza from a sidewalk vendor and I ate it like there was no tomorrow and it tasted just wonderful, greasy and cheesy and all..        Back to my campsite I had a little bit of time to sit down and enjoy the scenery so I did just that and updated my journal, watched the duck doing their duck things and remembered I had some wine left in my pack and also some left over Gouda so I pretended to be a queen on holidays and had a little wine and cheese as I sat there...  I packed it all up at 3 PM and realized that I must have had a hole in my inflatable mattress. It was flat this morning and this afternoon too when I used it as a chair... I guess that if I won't get flat tires, might as well get some flat mattress... That said, I was on the road again, with all my gear, towards Zurich and then Kloten by the airport where I would meet Jean-Francois. On my way there I stopped at the train station to pick up my mail at the internet caf. Still can't edit my text at www.crazyguyonabike.com  (I would later learn it was a cookie problem)(Sorry Neil). Jean-Francois e-mailed me some funny things that made me laugh. There was a small food market going on at the train station, so I bought some nectarines and some cherries and left for Kloten. Meeting Jean-Francois was fun. I was jolted by the ride in (I got lost) and excited to be there and to finally see him in person. He was still in bed as the plane landed in the morning and he was jet lagged but got up and gave me a hand with my packs and examined my bike like a surgeon would when opening a belly trying to find the source of bleeding. My bike passed the test thankfully. We had a good dinner at the hotel's restaurant, some swiss specialty, rostis potatoes, veal in a mushroom sauce, beer. Yum.  Nice finishing touch to a nice day.   
Breakfast was included in the room's price so we went downstairs and were offered a plate of breads and cold cuts and cheese coffee and orange juice. That was worth 18 Swiss Francs, or 18 Canadian dollars. So much for our logger's breakfasts in Canada uh? It is amazing how expensive things are over here. Our supper last night ended up being 110 Swiss Francs, for a very ordinary dinner.  Soon enough we were on the road negociating the morning traffic to make it to Zurich. We had a picture of us taken in front of the hotel marking the start of our trip together.     We had a few things to do in Zurich and then we finally headed out of town, leaving behind the city, the traffic and hustle and bustle. After an hour and a half of cycling my stomach was screaming for food, remnants of my very long day of 172 km.  I remembered being happy of being there, looking around in the fields, the cows, the towns in the horizon, the forests...      A little incident happened when we had to cross a busy road as the bike path was changing side of the road. At first I hit Jean-Francois on his left rear pannier as I didn't think he would stop in the middle of the road and then I heard him give me the ok to cross with a 'go' but it happened to be a 'no!'. That shook him up quite a bit I think. It was a fast day today with good descents and good, fast, flat sections. We made it to Luzern in the middle of the afternoon and we settled for lunch on the side of the lake with a tremendous view over the mountains.           Jean-Francois was hit by a bird's dropping right on the neckline of his white t-shirt. I couldn't stop laughing. After lunch I went investigating for bathrooms when I cam across an aviary, with a very nice citron-crested cockatoo (kind of parrot). It took a while to convince Jean-Francois to come over and see the little surprise I had for him (the bird) but when he saw he found it fun to play with the little beast. The parrot was very interactive, mimicking my laugh or bobbing the head after I did. The people sitting behind must have had a show of us trying to entertain the parrot. That was so cool! I had a belly workout from laughing...    We left Luzern for our campsite which was probably 20 km down the road, in Sarnen.    It got increasingly cloudy and Jean-Francois was getting quite tired with the jet-lag. We got to pitch our tent with the beginning of the thunderstorm and we had dinner under an overhang, sitting on my air mattress. It was with reluctance that we had to face the rain to cover the 500 m to our tents. Arrrgh... Rain is not in my plans so when it comes.... Yuk! Son et lumiere was good though.
   The first stage of today was to get to the foot of Brunigpass and to climb it. It elevates at 1002 meters and is climbed in 2 steps, with a nice flat section with a lake. The views were fabulous.       The climbing, well it had to be done. The route was turning and turning, sort of narrow and the trucks were passing all right. Most were very good. I stopped a few times to take pictures and to take my breath. Jean-Francois was ahead, standing on the bike all the way and climbing steadily. I was trying to follow, but in the same time if I saw something nice to frame I would stop and take a picture. Eventually we reached the pass, took a traditional picture and let ourselves go down.    The pavement was drying, passing through the forests and sometimes we had tremendous views of the surroundings, it was awesome... We ended up having to make a 10 km detour because of rock fall and that happened to be good as it allowed us to see war planes at exercise and landing in the fields, a hidden military base I guess. The planes passed ahead of us a few time and rather low, like in the movies. Eventually we made it through Brienz and started to go along Brienzersee. It was goergious at it was just a begining!!!  We had a stop on a wharf and I splurged in some very expensive Pepsi, and a snack for energy and carried on.    The goal was to reach Interlaken, do the groceries and have a lunch there. I was glad to reach it as I needed energy... We were very fortunate to have good weather and to be able to dry our tent while we ate. On the menu: a small chicken with Dijon mustard and bread... Yum. It was fairly late when we left Interlaken and still had to cover 40 km or so for Bern, our destination. Along Thunersee (or Thun lake) we had fabulous views over the lake, the mountains (I had to imagine them or else have a look at them on post cards as they were hidden behind the clouds) and the little villages full of charms with really nice Swiss chalets with big overhangs and flower boxes at each windows. We rose once at 100 m above the lake level and had a view over Interlaken on one side and Thun at the other end of the lake.      We also passed by a couple of castles that I really would have liked to visit but we were passed the visiting hours and we were in a bind with time, we had a deadline to observe and we were expected at my aunt's place tomorrow. It's always like that with me isn't it, always rushing into things? So we visited the washrooms in Thun and that was just about it. The city looked pretty. Then we headed towards Bern passing by the country side. The road we picked was very hilly. It was only when we got on top of a big hill and looking at the valley that we realized that the road we wanted was the flat one at the bottom...    We made it to the campsite after 8:30 PM, after 115 km sun trying to show up before setting. There was a party going on in the neighborhood and partyers wanted to share their music selection with everybody at a kilometer around, typical Friday night. It was kind of cold that night. The showers were a bit cold too, to my disappointment. I will always repeat it, there is nothing like a warm shower after a long day cycling... We had a free use of an outdoor mini kitchen and we splurged in a pasta dinner at 10:30 PM. Called it a night after that.   
Then we reached Fribourg and stop in the old town for lunch in a tea room. Jean-Francois bought a can of ravioli that he opened and ate like is (cold) yerk... I had some Pringles, a ham croissant that was so-so and a couple of desserts. A Coke. A cup of tea to warm up from the Coke.It was when we got out that the rain started. Awwww... Rain, rain, always the rain...        In Payerne we stopped in a large surface to stock up in groceries. Everything is closed on Sunday so we needed a few things for tomorrow. In the meantime Jean-Francois was checking the bikes and having coffee. The coffee got him going real good on the read as he left like a bullet on an uphill. Soon came Estavayer-le-lac, a fortified medieval city with a lot of character. We went in, thumbling on the cobblestone until the church, took a few picture and left in the direction of Cheyres, little village where my aunt lives with her family. I would have liked to visit around as it was totally charming and the map was indicating a castle there but we didn't see any signs for it and we were expected so we left...    We had to do a little climbing to reach the village which left me with a film of sweat within my rain jacket. The rain was at that time mostly mist and totally inoffensive but still had to cover myself for warmth. My aunt and uncle were out singing for a wedding and we were greeted by my cousin Marie, who is 15.  We were kind of shy with one another because I haven't seen her in quite a while and we don't know each other well. She had become a real teenager, hating school and putting on make up! That evening we were treated like royalty! We had a fabulous dinner of Raclette, Cheyres' wine, boiled potatoes, pickles, little onions, bread. Yum! After dinner Jean-Francois tried his luck with a couple of games of ping pong with my uncle Claude, to no avail. My aunt Brigitte and I went visitting the vineyards and went picking cherries. We must have picked 6 or 7 pounds . We also had a contest of cherry pit spitting and had a good laugh about it.    A little internet session followed and also more cherry splurging (my uncle says that we will be very "regular"). It was good to have a roof over us as it rained overnight...
We were treated to a loggers breakfast this morning. Eggs, bacon, cereals, yogurt, cheese, cherries, maple syrup, coffee, orange juice, you name it. Yummy. We were given 6 packs of swiss chocolate for the road...Thank you Brigitte and Claude! We said good bye, 3 cheek kisses for each my aunt, uncle and niece as the Swiss tradition wants it.      My uncle Claude was to accompany us by bike for a little while. He found our lifestyle quite interesting and healthy and he was impressed with my level of fitness. Passing on a small bike path in the midst of fields of wheat, sugar beet and other cultures, my uncle was explaining what plant was what and that was fun.    Kissing goodbye my uncle at an intersection, and after a fair amount of climbing we stopped in a deserted little village looking for our route and I found the cutest baby goats in a goat nursery by the road. They were adorable. I wanted to get the camera out and in the time of 2 seconds I dropped it on the pavement which messed the electronics up real good. I wanted to cry. This was the second time this trip. This was the second time this trip that my camera broke, and now what?    Eventually we made it to Lausanne, uneventfully beside me ruminating my camera loss. We reached the cathedral that is up a hill and overlooks the city and le Lac Leman and the mountains that should be across the lake but were not. Instead there were big black clouds and they spreaded all the way towards Montreux, just where we were going. We ate half of the 5 pounds of yummy cherries we were given in Cheyres and had a bit of a snack. I took on the opportunity to visit the cathedral. I managed to make the camera work by playing around with the battery door to turn the camera on and off but the zoom was dead. Meawhile Jean-Francois was being entertained by the post card sale lady and her dog.        Leaving the cathedral we went all the way down to Ouchy with its promenade on the lake passing the Olympic Museum and also a castle. It was a few kilometers later that tragedy almost happened as a car advanced on the road trying to turn left on our road and didn't see us cyclists. Jean-Francois and I screamed real loud to the point of being scared of my own voice. If we had not warned the driver of our presence we would have been just a pack of broken bones and squashed cherries. It left me shaken for a little while after that. We carried on with tremendous views of the surroundings including luxurious mansions, vineyards from the edge of the water to high up in the mountains, and on the other side of the lake stunning  mountains announcing for us the end of rolling hills and really soon some serious climbing.    It must have been around Vevey that the sky fell on us. All of a sudden. We had some warnings but I thought the clouds could go away before we made it to Montreux. Well we were out of luck. Mother Nature had an urge and we were to get what we got! We sought refuge under an overhang for the worse of the shower and left when it eased up. Montreux seemed quite nice to me. There were a couple of castles that I would have liked to visit but being all wet, and with little time to spare to make it to the next campsite, there was no way... I was disappointed that I couldn't stop and appreciate the places I was passing by. Stopping in Montreux for energy and pee break, I found a good old Mc Donald for using the washrooms. In a nick of time we were back on the road, soon leaving the Lac Leman behind, and the road got kind of boring, I was wet and probably tired too. I was a bit disappointed not to see the mountains that seemed to elevate quite high as they also seem to get closer and tighter around the road we were taking. I called up on an energy break past St Maurice as I learned in past situations that when I get low in sugar, I get cranky and down and everything gets black. We leaned the bike over a house that was by the sidewalk, ate a couple of nectarines and cherries. Jean-Francois was admiring a cat through a window when we heard a suspicious noise coming off his bike. A spoke broke just like that, on the rear wheel. We had to think what to do. We decided to head to the camping we had just past, that really didn't look like the greatest but oh well. Indeed entering it really looked spooky with its old abandoned campers and mobile homes with blue tarps on them. It fortunately got better further down, and it had to do. We met some cyclists that were camping too but busy with the camping chores, and getting cold we kept to ourselves. The shower really warmed my heart and my feet and I made some soup while Jean-Francois fixed his rear wheel. Fortunately while the rain fell we were sheltered in between 2 rows of sinks with lots of room to do stuff like... Sorting out equipment, drying stuff etc... While Jean-Francois had a shower I got busy at making my couscous dinner, 2 more spokes popped on his rear wheel. A little disconcerting. We had dinner and went to bed, leaving the spoke job for the morning.     
Soon after straddling the bike again, we were on the way up. The Col de La Forclaz (pronounce Fore-Claw) stands at 1527 m. Martigny is at 476 m. 13 km of climbing, not much rest if none in between. We took a break at the first look out offering tremendous view over the mountains and the valley that lead to Italy, following the Rhone river.     Jean-Francois later told me he broke another spoke just before arriving at the lookout. For some reason he didn't tell me. I was climbing at 7 or 8 km an hour. A little farther down the road, I called upon another stop to catch up my breath and had a little pee under a bridge. The views were still awesome, leaving behind vineyards and entering a more forested environment, gradually getting alpine. The mountains were awesome all around. Eventually we started some switchbacks and noticed that the voice was carrying quite far... At least some motorcyclists were thinking so!!! We were slowly going uphill and ahead we heard people trying their voice (Heyyyyyy Hooooooo!) and Jean-Francois answered back to much of their surprise as they couldn't see us yet! We had a good laugh about it in between being out of breath from the climbing. It felt like an achievement when finally there was nothing more to climb and I saw the famous sign announcing we were at the top of the pass. I was proud of myself. We were offered breathtaking views of the snow capped peaks around. We bought some post cards, had a bite to eat, dressed up and went down the hill. It was down that hill that we crossed the French border, not a big deal anymore in the European community as nobody was watching the border or asked us to stop. It was a deal for me, another step into my trip.      The Col des Montets wasn't as impressive but still stands at 1461 m. Once we made it to the top we said: 'That's it?'...     We clicked the camera for souvenirs and headed downhill all the way to Argentiere which is a nice little village catering to the tourists and also the hikers, skiers and climbers. I would have liked to stop but then we were heading to Chamonix for a meal stop and needed a grocery store before everything closed for the day. We couldn't verify that Mont-Blanc was indeed right there, as it was hidden behind thick clouds. The only clue we had that something real big was there was this huge overhanging glacier visible. I was disappointed not to be able to see the infamous mountain. I stopped in a photo shop and changed my Swiss Francs and lost a lot of money on the deal. Then went for groceries while Jean-Francois was checking over the bikes, looking for things for our dinner and also a good snack to eat on the spot as we still had a fair distance to cover before our stop for the day.  Fortunately the way to Sallanches was all downhill, and enjoyable, other than looking for our way trying to bypass the highway. We lost some times around Les Houches as Jean-Francois was trying to remember where to take the overpass and reach the quiet road on the other side of the highway. We asked around and decided to retreat and engage on the highway hoping for safe shoulder and light traffic. I felt fairly comfortable on the said highway,being used to heavily passed roads. Jean-Francois was stressed out. At times we had no shoulder at all and cars were fast, but respectful.  It was a relief to exit and get onto the quiet road, in a forested area. That last section was very enjoyable to me winding down the hill with the views over the surrounding mountains and the valley, losing lots of altitude to finally make it down to the valley in Sallanches. Jean-Francois had it the hard way with yet another spoke to fix, trying to be gentle with his out-of-true wheel and hoping to avoid breaking more spokes. The first camping found in Sallanches we took and it ended up being a really good deal. Jokingly I asked the owner who was registering us that we wanted a pizza and beer with the deal and he said he would see what he could do for us. But first he led us to our lot and opened a little cabin for us for the price of the campsite!!! Toilet, 2 rooms, kitchen, fridge, everything! There was also a table and chairs on the patio and even a clothesline to dry our stuff. I was impressed with the generosity and I think that Jean-Francois was too. Not only that but our host came back with 4 beers that he offered us. I gave him some Euros, overwhelmed by now...       Being in the cabin made our life easier that night with a nice shower, drying everything that was wet, fixing the spoke, and cooking dinner, real gastronomy here... a very yummy pork and cashews sweet and sour stir-fry over a bed of rice. Yummy. Chocolate for dessert. We slept like babies that night in the bunk room. 
We had planned a small day today, thought we'd do one pass, the Col des Saisies and stop in Beaufort. We would change our mind later that morning to a fuller day, adding another Col and take a rest day in Bourg St-Maurice which would place us in a better position for the days to come to attack the next mountains.  We started climbing right at the exit of Sallanches and was there ever lots of traffic! There was some construction with alternate circulation and flag men at both ends. Jean-Francois decided to go ahead of the line up of cars waiting to have the right of way. And seeing no cars coming in the opposite direction decided to go ahead and I followed. Eventually the line-up of cars and dirt trucks caught up with us, and as the road was very narrow with no shoulder, this truck got impatient with me as I was taking my space and he couldn't go and as it was uphill I wasn't very fast and I knew it. I had nowhere to go so I ignored the trucker and kept on pedaling and sweating profusely like I usually do on an uphill. Jean-Francois was ahead as he always is uphill and I was working hard to catch up with him. When it got a little wider the dirt truck passed and  forced me out of the road, that or passing under his rear wheel. I ended up falling in lose dirt. That incident really scared me with the result that I got upset at Jean-Francois for being so much in a hurry. I was shaken for a while trying not to cry in the next few km of pedaling. I found that Jean-Francois didn't want to stop anywhere and the area was beautiful and I felt like I couldn't stop and take pictures because I would be waited for. The road continued to be busy and I was kind of nervous so I called on a break at the next village.      Food takes care of a lot of things... It calms people down, refills the body with much needed reserves and prevents low blood sugar which can make people cranky... Well it helped in my case and in case of doubt, I try to remember to have a bite... So we left for our much longer than planned day and got thankful that we had a good 20 km slightly downhill. It helped me refocus and get my muscles working again. Further down the road we turned off to a 2.5 km climb to our lunch spot at Notre-Dame de Bellecombe, our last rest stop before les Saisies. I had a go at my first Turkish toilet, the kind of 'toilet that has only a hole on the ground and 2 footprints just for that, the feet. The instructions are not posted anywhere but you get it real fast when you gotta go. You get your pants down and you squat. If you are not aiming very well like some women like me do when they are not used with the system you get your legs splashed... and when you flush the toilet make sure that you get out of there real fast because water will come sometime as close to the door to wash everything you may have splashed while doing your business... A very cultural experience... I was quite grossed out.    The col des Saisies was quite a climb but doable. We just had to pace ourselves. We passed through a few little villages and pastures with cows and then some skiing oriented villages. Finally we were on top, and cold with the wind.    All dressed up we didn't lose time and aimed at Beaufort. Beautiful but cold descent, I just had a kick! There was this 18 wheelers that followed us as we were doing 40 or 45 for a while and they got very patient with us until it was safe to pull out in a hairpin turn. Thanks guys...  In Beaufort we took a quick break in front of the public washroom which I refused to get in fear of some the mighty squat style again. So instead I went for groceries and with dinner in mind as we expected to get in town fairly late. The Cormet de Roseland was a bigger challenge, standing at 1968 m (we left Beaufort at 743 m). We had 20 km of tough climbing before the summit with  endless switchbacks, narrow roads and commanding views over the surroundings.     I was huffing and puffing, but also could appreciate the beauty around me, talking moo to the cows and just being in awe of being where I was. Eventually and thankfully we made it at a first pass called Col du Meraillet, and that was right in front of an artificial lake and let us see what was ahead , what was left to climb. It was awesome, we could see some lunar like geography, some grassy steep hills where likely the sheep come but all that in a very quiet peaceful high altitude environment. We had another pause there before attacking the last 8 km before reaching the top.      We got applauded by some hikers watching us while resting which somewhat gave me goose bumps and a little farther down stopped at the sign saying Cormet de Roseland. It was windy and cold and it didn't take long for me to dress up as I felt my finger get cold already from the wind, the sudden stop and sweaty body of mine. Raynaud syndrome sufferers will understand me... We took pictures of each other and then left as it was getting fairly late, maybe getting closer to 7:30 PM. The first little stretch wasn't that steep but I was going slowly, because I had the impression of cycling into a cliff and falling over. Eventually I could see where we were to go and every turn a new vista would surprise my eyes and even though I was frozen to the bones I was loving what I saw... I wish I had taken more pictures but my fingers were like ice blocks...        Jean-Francois broke yet another spoke on the downhill so his ride down was tampered by a rear wheel that was so out of true that when you looked ar it you thought it would get off the bike. It took us an hour to go down the hill, with the twists and turns of the road until we finally reached  Bourg St-Maurice. It must have been 8h30 PM. Another late night. Finding a campsite took us a little while as it wasn't indicated the usual manner on the signs. But we found and pitched the tents at dark. Had a lovely shower in a top notch facility and must have eaten cheese fondue by 10:30 PM...That was good... Another day well spent...
So we walk down, me reluctantly as I thought it would take us like 45 minutes to get there by foot and I would have taken the bike but Jean-Francois had for rule not to use the bike on a day off. We started at the post office, I sent some used maps to my sister for me to pick up on my way home when I'd come back to Paris and I also purchased a phone card and an internet card as some post offices have internet stations. Jean-Francois started with his e-mail and I went on the lookout for a Michelin Alsace map which I have lost in Strasbourg and I wanted it for souvenir of my route.     I also stopped at the photo shop to get one of my rolls finished just to see if I was doing a good job at taking pictures with my new and broken camera. I came back for a little internet session but was disappointed with the connection and Netscape which I am not too familiar with. I didn't do too much. The French people are not so keen with internet cafes!!!  After that, getting close to noon I was past starving and we were getting desperate to find something to eat before everything closed. We audited several places as the surrounding business were putting the key to the door and settled for the bakery and had some pizza, chocolate bread and other delicacies. We ate all that across at a caf-bar, being smoked in by the people beside us. We met some sport-cyclists that we coming from the Cormet de Roseland and we had a little chat about the lovely region they were living in. Coming back toward the campground we parted as Jean-Francois was ready for the bike clean-up and I stopped for grocery shopping in one of the 2 large surface grocery store we encountered on our way. Looking out for iced tea I had the worst bowel cramps ever- and looking real desperately for toilet. Sweating profusely I enquired at the cashier who fortunately directed me to one. I had a bad time- will spare you the details...  It was relief to reach my headquarters and another bathroom, had a nice shower, worked on laundry which was still expensive and laid low all afternoon, writing in my journal, sipping on coke, fighting stomach cramps, and keeping company to Jean-Francois who was doing spring clean-up with all his gear and the bikes. Another spoke repaired on his bike too!    Coming on to 6 PM we left for town for dinner as I was relieved from cooking that night. Jean-Francois had stopped his choice on a nice restaurant, and we made it there for 7 PM after errands and it was still too early for the kitchen... So we settles for 'apperitifs' (Coke for me, beer for him). We treated ourselves to a multi-course dinner with cheese plate before dessert and a Ventoux demi-litre (red wine). It was totally yummy, having ribs for main course.  We headed 'home' by 10 PM full, sort of drunk and tired...   
The climb to Val d'Isere was a steady one, no flat section, from Bourg St-Maurice... At first we passed through little villages but then we were in the wild and increasingly with open views or the mountains around, some hanging glaciers, a valley down low, and quiet tranquility... when the motorcycles were not around... There was construction at a couple of spots explaining the service trucks traffic and once the traffic was being stopped. At first we were told there would be a 15 minutes wait but fortunately after 5 minutes we were allowed to go.      Getting closer to Val d'Isere there were tunnels and avalanche guards to pass, some scarier than others, some oozing with water, other very dark and curvy. That one I had a semi passing me at the same time. I was glad to have my dear clip on red flashing light and we both managed. Traffic is very respectful of us cyclists. It is refreshing to see. By the time we made it to town, in the middle of the afternoon, everything was closed and the city totally deserted. How disconcerting I was looking for yet more food and a cartridge of gas for my stove. No luck. We ate on a bench in front of the bus station and info center that was also closed and I fell asleep afterwards while Jean-Francois fixed yet another broken spoke. He also had time to talk to his sister on the phone before I wake up in a daze and wonder how much time had lapsed... After just about 2 hours break and a stop at the local caf for caffeine we were on our way for the most scenic mountain of the trip I'd say but there was a few that are running up very closely behind, and it is le col de l'Iseran.  The approach to the bottom was easy and scenic climbing up a valley, and the view of the surrounding peaked almost broke my neck. What a spectacle!!!    I wanted to take pictures everywhere! I stopped a couple of time and as Jean-Francois doesn't like to stop when climbing, he left me in the dust, and that was fine by me, I was to freeze the scenery on film, and he could always wait for me...  Soon enough I could not even see him on a higher hairpin and I was all alone, with the constant buzz of the motorcycles, most of them at full speed, some of them careless and reckless.     The climb was tough but rewarding. The snow line appeared, and sometimes the snow banks were higher than me. Apparently they had just officially opened the col to the traffic a few days before we were there. It was very impressive to be there.  Jean-Francois had been waiting for 11 minutes (yeah, he timed it) before I made it on top. He was being entertained by 2 older ladies that were chatty to a fault and congratulated us profusely while we were dressing up and taking a bite before the descent. After a victory picture it was downhill time, which was breathtaking and just fabulous...              Down the valley we encountered some cow traffic as they were returning home after a long day spent chewing grass in the fields. This was another highlight after the col itself as they came toward us in a hurry, wanting to be back home... It was exciting, but also scary to me city girl as some of those big beasts had horns!!!  By that time I was very tired and every little elevation gain felt like a mountain. It was getting late and we were racing for the closing of the store to get some provisions. Fortunately it was all downhill, and I was good at that.  In Lancelebourg we found a few grocery items and some gaz cartridges and we also found out there was a camping in town so we decided to make an early stop here. Beautifully located there was a mountain across the camping offering a spectacular view and the little torrent muffled the noise of the circulation. Of course the other campers looked at us like we were aliens, as to them, holidays meant settling with their trailer, get the patio furniture out and sit there for 2 weeks...   
The cycling was slow for Jean-Francois that morning even though the first 15 km was downhill. Being heavier in gear and also more aerodynamic, I had the advantage downhill. Eventually we made it to St-Michel de Maurienne where we looked for washrooms and found some, Turkish style. They were gross from the outside. I passed. Jean-Francois braved it and the look on his face was precious when he came out of there....  It's at St-Michel de Maurienne that the climb to the Col du Telegraphe and Galibier starts, right after the main traffic light where 4 sports cyclists were standing, one fixing a wheel. That is exactly where, trying to down shift to smaller gear, got my chain off not once but twice! How upsettingand embarrassing. Anyways we got off and started climbing the infamous Col du Telegraphe. It was hot, and a long tough ascent. We were trying to seek refuge in the shade on either side of the road while cycling, most of the time to no avail. Jean-Francois took the lead for a while then I joined him for the end and we summitted together for the time of a drink and a picture. We had planned to go down to Valloire, an alpine style village where we'd have lunch and then attack Galibier, a very respected pass all around the world by the cycling community.      We had lunch in front of a church of Valloire. I was craving Coke, (let alone Pepsi) but nothing was open at this time of day, as usual. It is so frustrating to be in a country where the quality of life of the workers prevails over the comfort of the consumers and tourists...
