Then after a long lunch, and half an hour of looking around we found that one bar that was open and the so long craved Coke and coffee for monsieur. The climb to Galibier started by 4 PM. At first there was a long steady climb, all do-able. Lovely sceneries of the surrounding mountains, then a not so noticeable aproach to the real climb. We stopped before the hairpins at 'Plan Lachat' (1961m) for a little break before the heavy duty climb, leaning the bike against an abandoned house with lots of signs on the windows saying 'maison piegee' on it (tricked house is my best translation). Following was a steep ascent in switchback, unforgivable, unforgettable. But there was stunning views to keep me distracted, the water to drink, the mind to trick, the breathing to pace. All of that made me climb to the summit.I must admit that the last 2 km were really tough with its steeper ascent and endless turns that prevented you to see where was the end...          We met this one sport cyclist on top that looked quite a bit in shape and was gathering paper journal from car tourists to put under his jersey to keep warm for the descent. It was after talking to him a little longer that he admitted that he hitchhiked and got a ride in the last 10 km because it was too tough for him. He was waiting for his buddy that was coming without cheating so they could go down together. We had a summit picture, ate some food, chocolate, fruits, etc..., dressed up for the descent and left. The way down was awesome. I saw a 'Go Lance' writing on the pavement in reference to Lance Armstrong which was really cool. There was lots of writings like that up the popular passes as those were races pathways.         The junction to the Col de Lautaret came and as there was a caf-bar I went in to refill my now empty water bottles and had a long long descent to Chantemerle where we stopped for the night. We found the camping right at the entrance of the city which was handy, and set up camp almost at dusk. The clouds were threatening and we could hear thunder which fortunately never came out way with the dark clouds. As we didn't have food in the panniers for dinner we treated ourselves in a dinner at the campground's restaurant and had a lovely salad and pizza... Yummy...  It didn't take long before I fell asleep that night... 
We started climbing in town for our first col of the day, col d'Izoard. As the heat was  a factor, at the first fountain we stopped to refresh our water bottles and met up with 2 Italian cyclists that greeted us with a 'Bonjourno'  That surprised me and I could only mumble a greeting in French.  The climb was tough and it took 2.5 hours to summit. Lots of people on top including motorcyclists, sport cyclists and tourists. We are lots and noticed the bag of chips I purchased in Briancon all puffed up ready to explode due to the high altitude.        The downhill was awesome once again but I got really cramped hands due to the breaking I had to do. We then had a treat, cycling along the 'Combo de Querras', a canyon with a fairly flat, windy road with carved tunnels with ceilings that could barely accommodate an 18 wheeler . Jean-Francois had a couple of close calls in tunnels because of people in a hurry. By that time my energy was running low and I was getting cranky. Lunch had to happen     Soon after we were in Guillestre and we borrowed a camping ground to have lunch, and use the plumbing system. Another pass was to come, the Col de Vars. I had another try at the Turkish style toilet, and it was very unsuccessful as I splashed my legs while squatting (Can't I aim???). That was our only opportunity to have bathrooms  for a while, and there was no trees around and nowhere to hide.  Guillestre was like an oven I thought as we left for our next ascent. The climb was slow and hot. Did I say hot? I took the time to wet my bandanna at the campsite and to put it on my head as it was cooling but it didn't cool me for long  I was very tired at the summit as we made it again close to 8PM.      The descent was remarkable for a long 300 or 400 m tunnel that was so dark that we couldn't see a thing, even the holes on the pavement. That one was very spooky. Fortunately there was no traffic. The campsite showed up by 9 PM. Dinner was made and ready by 10:45 PM. Chorizo and rice and corn. A white and caramel cat came to keep us company and to lick the plates scented with yummy sausage. Bed by 11:45 with Jean-Francois's promise he would do the dishes first thing in the morning  
   After some more downhill we made it at the junction and turned to climb 'the highest road of Europe.'  Le Col de La Bonette peaks at 2802 m. It is steady climbing from bottom to top. Being a Sunday, motorcycles were out more than ever and we almost witnessed an accident when a motorcyclist attempted to pass us at full speed in a curve and never saw the incoming motorcyclist. They touched slightly without any impact on either of them or us but it was scary. I told Jean-Francois I was here as a cyclotourist and not a nurse.    In the meantime, we kept climbing. There was some some advertising for 'Halte 2000' all along, which was a restaurant-bar at the altitude of 2000 m and would be our midway point, very conveniently and strategically located for a cold bottle of Coke. I was sweating profusely, drinking water like crazy and focused on that bottle of Coke as the reward for all the work. However Halte 2000 never produced. They got out of business I suppose. That almost crushed me. Fortunately there were lots of streams to refresh our water, even though I had some doubts about the safety of drinking it without any treatment. I didn't care that much as the cold water was refreshing on such a hot day. We carried on winding with spectacular views of mountains, rocks, grass and patches of snow. The higher we got the more we could see the black clouds that were threatening on the other side of the mountains, while it kept being sunny on our side. It was when we heard the thunder that we decided it would be wise to seek refuge before the summit. We found some military buildings used in the second world war, but they were all closed and forbidden to the public but a little higher up there was an abandoned house with open windows and door and we waited there for a while, maybe half an hour. Jean-Francois was keen to go as soon as possible and we seemed to disagree as of what to do next. I wanted to wait and let the storm pass by so we could go down on the other side safely. (Breaking on a wet pavement or raining weather is trivial, and more so down like 2000 m)    Eventually we left and climbed to the junction. At this area, tourists and motorcyclists were gathering, looking around. We were still not there. We had to  climb some more, however it was impossible to pass for cars and some motorcycles as there was a snow bank on the road. Once that bypassed, under the disbelief of the crowd we were back on the saddle to reach our objective, the real Col de La Bonette.  There was a rock slide making the last kilometer and a bit quite difficult with the 13-14% incline. That was tough.     I was counting my pedal strokes, and when I reached a count of 20 to 30 I would get my feet off the cleats, get my breathing  under control, get a sip of water and then do it all over again. Around the corner there was an italian family walking down the hill who applauded my efforts and cheering 'Brava! Brava!'. That made me a bit emotional. Eventually I made it to the highest of the road when nothing else was to be climbed, and met up with Jean-Francois who had made conversation with 2 motorcyclists.     We spent time conversing, maybe too long as we were watching the thick clouds on the horizon. We had a bite to eat, took pictures, dressed up for the descent and then left, cautious with some fallen rocks on the pavement at first then the narrow road that we had to share with the rest of the traffic. There were nothing to stop a fall should we catch the shoulder and lose balance or something so most often we would take the middle of the pavement or the safest side even if it meant to ride against the traffic until a car came up.  Needless to say that we had our hands on the breaks constantly to be ready for any  emergency  and also to be able to negociate the hairpin turn at a safe speed.. The road was also fairly bumpy which provided an additional hazard at high speed and inconvenience for our sore butt! I had to stop a couple of times to rest my hands as they got quite cramped. I got increasingly tired and irritable even with the endless straighter descent, probably because of the lack of sugar. I found myself unable to enjoy the scenery which was probably beautiful but for some reason I can't recall anymore   We slept at a municipal camping that night in St-Sauveur-Sur Tinee, very quiet campsite with only 3 parties including us. After pitching the tents and having a shower we headed to town for dinner. It sounded like there was only one decent restaurant in town, in an auberge but at the end it wasn't that great  Jean-Francois got drunk with the wine, which was funny as he was talking endlessly, quite unusual for him. We must have hit the pillows by 11:30 that night, full stomach and happy from a well spent day. 
   We left town by 10:30 which is quite early for us!!! For the first time since leaving Vancouver I checked my messages on my answering machine and all I had was old messages from before my departure,and the usual "Can you come to work?" from staffing clerks desperately looking for nurses. We had a long descent again along the Tinee river which is surrounded by a red rock canyon, sometimes pink and quite pretty. The road was hugging the side of a cliff and we just had to make sure the big trucks saw us as we rode around the corners. We also went through  a few tunnels. The heat was bothering me already and it wasn't noon yet.      We cycled until a junction of a national road (read highway) and as the map we were using dated of 1991 things got revamped in here in the meantime and that got us puzzled. There was a 2 km long tunnel built for the southbound traffic, obviously forbidden to cyclists. The northbound people were using the old 2 way road along the river now made into a one way. We didn't have a choice to go against the traffic for 7 km. This was quite stressful and somewhat dangerous but we managed. To relax a bit, reward ourselves and cool down from the heat we stopped for a Coke and some refreshing water at this very conveniently located bar-hotel-restaurant. It was so hot by now!!! The kind of heat that would prevent you from doing anything physical, crushing type. But I was out of luck...  Next was awaiting us the Georges de la Vesubie, a very gentle climb along a river for 21 km to reach the beginning of the real climb for the col de Turini. That gorge was quite pretty (and also hot). The asphalt had s tarted to melt and stuck to the tires should you inadvertantly roll on the melted spots We tried to keep cool by changing our water as frequently as possible for fresh one in the little villages and it would turn boiling hot in no time again. I would refresh my bandana and put it on my head. It would offer a brief moment of coolness...    Lantosque marked the beginning of the climb and the junction for the col de Turini. We met up a group of 10 unloaded cyclists taking a break. We greeted and started to climb at first gently and then more seriously as we had settled to climb a little bit to the next village for our midday break. One by one the cyclists came and passed us. Jean-Francois started to push it a little bit to follow them, and I stayed in the back. The last cyclist to pass was a little bit of a cheater as he was towing himself on a truck, holding himself from the door chassis (kids, don't try this at home). That made Jean-Francois and me protest a bit and laugh. The beginning of the climb was steep and left me out of breath. It sounded as I wasn't alone as the slowest cyclist of the other group had enough of it and was walking his bike. His ego must have warned him it would get bruised as he saw me threatening to pass so he got back on his bike and went again. We had a nice break at La Bollene-Vesubie sitting in the shade at a bar patio. We had a nicoise salad fixed for us and also ate what was in our food cache. For me it was cheese and bread and fruits. Yum. After that break it was 5 PM and we had yet to climb the last pass until the Riviera. 12 more km to go and 1607 m of altitude. It took us 90 min of hard and hot work, with beautiful sceneries to make me forget about the pain. We caught some shepherd dogs at work gathering the mountain goats under the orders and the calls of the shepherd. That was quite cool to surprise the frightened goats at a hairpin turn waiting for the rest of theirs.     The frustrating part of this climb was the constant buzz of the flies around me which made me swear at them profusely and wave my arms around like someone having hallucinations should you have not guessed I was trying to get rid of the flies circling me. They wouldn't leave me alone, I was hot and sweaty, and cranky and could they please leave me alone??? Making it to the top was quite satisfying. We rewarded ourselves with a cold drink with lots of ice at the little hotel. There was no real views to awe on but we were treated to spectacular sceneries on the descent along the George du Piaon.  One of the highlight was to see this church called Notre-Dame de la Menour perched on top of a hill in the middle of the gorge. I was amazed at how every day on this trip I made new discoveries, sceneries to be impressed about.    We were required to climb a little bit before reaching our campsite for the night which reminded me I had quads indeed. We pitched our tents on a not so optimal ground, kind of clayish and uneven, and had a very cold shower to my biggest disappointment. I made dinner sitting in a real chair and around a table to make some change, around some noisy table hockey players. We had on the menu some pasta with tomato sauce, chorizo and vegetables, some beer and black chocolate leftovers for dessert.    Sleep came easy that night.
This morning I finished packing a little early so went sit down in the camping's restaurant and got the pre-ordered croissants and pains au chocolat, and ordered our usual drinks, which cost more than a full lunch at a local sushi place in Vancouver! I decided that Sospel was the right place to get rid of some of my cold weather clothes, some of which I didn't use at all!   I also sent back to my sister in Paris some maps I no longer needed and the set of photo that I had developed. Total, 2.5 kg!!! Jean-Francois also sent some clothes home for just about the same price than me even though it was overseas! Then we went in town for the usual errands, groceries and snacks. All that took more time than it should have as we lingered in the shade sipping on a cold drink. Noon!  Jean-Francois was reluctant to climb yet another pass (because there was this last one) but I didn't mind really, what the heck I thought! Just another one, a small one after the gigantic ones... My body was used to it by now. It was hot hot hot with the noon sun. To pass time Jean-Francois started telling stories and I worked my belly by laughing at them. We were climbing along a mountain so dry, so hot we could have been in an oven and there wouldn't have been any difference. We could feel the mugginess of the ocean. Finally we made it and loyal to the tradition we took pictures.     Then we were awarded with a long descent that lead us over Menton, barely cooling but enjoyable. I was a bit emotional to see the Mediterranean sea, felt pride of finishing a stage in my trip. The traverse of the Alps was done and over with...    All I wanted was to dip my feet in the water, cool down, celebrate with a Coke. Jean-Francois had other plans, wanting to reach the Italian border and stop there. Fair enough, it was only 3 km away. Following the coast we meandered around tourists, pedestrians, strollers, cars, scooters, you name it and finally stopped in the middle of a 2 ways highway that lead in and out of Italy. There used to be a custom check there but not anymore due to the new European Union I suppose. We took pictures in front of the Italy sign, then looking around wanting to find a nice spot to stop, and finding none, sat right down against the custom building and ate a snack, disappointed of not stopping in a better place than just here watching the cars go by. I wanted to have a taste of the riviera, not just a teaser...     Jean-Francois suggested to stop for lunch in Nice which was 20-30 km away. So off we go. We backtracked towards Menton, and beyond. As I had the map on the bike, and mostly leading the way I decided which turns to take and lead Jean-Francois into a peninsula where lived very rich people. It was only a few km detour and I thought we could have nice views and photo opportunities. After a few turns, Jean-Francois demanded to see the map and told me we couldn't fo all the little detours to make it to our destination. Why being so rushed I thought??? I wanted to enjoy myself. On another hand there was a lack of campsites on this coast and we might have to pay big Euros for a hotel if we didn't make it to destination.      So off we go again this time towards Monaco. Traffic was getting bad. It was hilly. Scooters all over zigzagging around the cars. Fumes from the cars. Noise from the Harleys. Heat. Sweat on my shins, arms, back. Dust from the road. Thirst. Traffic light and pedestrians to watch. So much stimuli beside looking around and get a feel of the place that seemed to have lots to offer.We managed to make it to Monaco all in one piece and in the midst of the traffic, after a scary tunnel and negotiating in-ramp and off-ramp we decided to stop on a sidewalk and take a breather and also have a good look at the map to see if there was a quieter alternative. Not 10 seconds after getting off the saddle this cop came out of nowhere and told us we belonged on the road and could we please get off the sidewalk. Wow! For once someone had it right. And for once I wanted to be off the road!!! The cop relaxed a bit when we asked him question about which road to take and told us that yeah, we were on the quieter road....  We crossed yet another castle that would have deserved some visiting and bypassed a peninsula thanks to Jean-Francois tighter vigilance. It must have been 4PM when we made it to Nice, at least the entrance of Nice, at the port. I imagined Nice with a long beach and a walkway. That's where I wanted to be. Jean-Francois had for idea to stop at the post and have food there. it's what we did.  It occurred to me as I am writing these words after the facts that Jean-Francois took a lot of decisions on this trip some of which would have been different have I been on my own. So... Nice... We stopped in a restaurant and Jean-Francois got enticed in a full meal deal. I had a salade nicoise and got into the bread and cheese we already had. Leaving the restaurant Jean-Francois left his very precious baseball cap behind and we had to return to check out again if he forgot it or if he lost it on the way. It was gone. La promenade des Anglais announced itself, and we cycled right on it on the bike path, meandering between brainless tourists. By then the coastal road had 4 lanes each ways so I was glad to use the bike path. Nice beaches, so I have heard.    The bike path finished eventually and we had to go 'where we belonged' on the road. At first we took the bus and taxi lane which was protected from the other lanes. That was good until it ended , and then we joined the cars, motorcycles and scooters in the party and we started a little speeding session, where we cycled-me leading, Jean-Francois drafting at 28-35 km per hour. That was a lot of fun. Jean-Francois would encourage me, letting me know when he had caught up with me if he lost me from a traffic light or else. Then we arrived in Antibes, a charming town with a lot of character. I would have loved to stay there and shop, visit, swim in the sea. I felt really sorry of leaving behind this pretty dress seen in a window... So we left this time for Cannes. Cannes is known for its film festival,actors and actresses hanging out there but we would see none of that, stopping in a Petit Casino for groceries as it was closing. I bought supply for chocolate fondue and other stuff. We gulped a liter of fruit juice in no time and ate cherries and peaches. And we left again. Bye bye Cannes! Our next destination was a campsite. The sun was getting quite low and we wanted to get as close to St-Raphael as possible, Agay where we knew there would be a camping. We also wanted to settle for 2 nights in a decent city where we could eat in a nice restaurant and also have internet acces if possible. The only problem was it was getting late, sun was falling behind the mountains and Jean-Francois was worried of riding in the dark because of poor visibility and dangers of being hit. I didn't worry as much as I knew I was being seen with the fluorescent lights on my bags, and also from the red flashing light I clip on my clothes. I was a bit irritable by that time from feeling rushed and tired and the bike's gears didn't react upon order as well as I would have liked... The coast got really beautiful past Cannes as we wandered according to the moods of the land. The earth and the rocks got quite red-orange tinged with the sunset accentuating the already deep color. We made it to a bay and down a hill there was a sign for a campsite. I stopped there waiting for Jean-Francois to catch up. I knew we had planned to go farther but it was dark and it just made sense to stop now. It was getting close to 10 PM now! The office was closed, no surprise, but we encountered this very chatty Dutch guy that showed us where to go and gave us a good chat. It was nice but we were hungry and tired... We set up camp close to the bathroom among other campers that seemed quiet. It was after being all organized that we noticed those 3 or 4 guys in front of our site that were getting quite drunk and increasingly noisy and obnoxious. I went for a shower and started to make dinner and awaiting for Jean-Francois to come back from his shower and became increasingly pissed off at those losers that were disturbing everybody else around. After a long day cycling this was most unwelcome... Ear plug night was declared. Vomiting from drinking too much didn't deter the other guys from drinking more but eventually they all went to sleep. Me too. 
I let Jean-Francois rise and shine when he would deem appropriate and went to the office to pay our dues and enquired about the washing machine. Jean-Francois and I started a load before heading out to the little store and restaurant for breakfast. We spent 2 hours there reading the paper, shopping for fruits and lunch, sipping on a hot drink, eating our pastries and looking at the map. At noon time we found our clothes neatly placed back into the plastic bag we had left on the washing machine ready to be laid for drying. I got busy with that and Jean-Francois got ready for yet another spring clean up to the bottom of his panniers, and then worked on the bikes.  By that time we were in an oven and it was hard to do anything. I had for mission to work on my journal and catch up to my procrastination. Eventually the thermarest-chair became a flat mattress and I was horizontal and drowsy but the flies would not leave me alone and it got me real cranky. Did I mention how swollen my feet had gotten? I started noticing maybe a day or 2 ago but today it was bad, the right more than the left. I tried to set up my tent so the feet would be a bit higher than the rest so I could fit in my shoes...  After a small lunch made of pate and bread, salad and ice tea, and after a little nap, I wanted to swim in the sea. I wanted to cool down and also, well not every day would we be here, on the French Riviera with clear and inviting water. Jean-Francois for some reason didn't want to swim, but agreed to come with me, and then we'd pick a restaurant to go to later for dinner. We were in a small cove, the sand was beautiful, the water fairly warm to my Canadian standards but I am a wimp when it comes to dip in the water so it took me a while to soak totally , but it was totally refreshing... As I dressed back up I noticed this old woman going topless to my surprise... Ewww... that's all I have to say.  After the visit at the beach we took a walk along the road to check out the restaurant menus. It was restaurant night and Jean-Francois wanted some French gastronomy. He made his choice, I looked around for photos opportunities as the sun was going down and headed back for a refreshing shower.      The restaurant had a nice patio overlooking the water. Unfortunately all the tables with such views were taken but we settled for something fairly nice in the coolness of the evening and made out order. All the time during dinner we had bold birdies flying and diving close to our table and into a nearby tree. Obviously those brats have learned they could get food out of the patrons. Service was slow and we had a fairly young waitress that was funny with her service manners. Every time she was picking up a dish she would announce for herself 'Allez hop!'  We had a good laugh about that. I splurged in a very yummy lobster bisque and some duck for main course. Dessert was not forgotten and we accompanied all that with a good bottle of wine. We headed back to camp full and slightly drunk for a warm night where I took the fly totally out in order to be able to breathe. 
We had a stopover in St-Raphael and found a decent internet station where we had an hour full of e-mail and web site updating. That was nice. There were 2 girls there speaking English only that left before us and then came back as one was looking for her credit card. I helped her with translation when she asked the owner if by any chance he found it in his store. I felt for her. Plastic in the wallet is extra precious when one is traveling. When you lose it, what do you do??? We were promptly on the bike after that, direction St-Tropez and gladly leaving behind the urban traffic. Well... it was temporary as the tourist traffic was trickling in to the beaches as the day was getting by, motorcyclists and all. However the riding was pleasant, we encountered a few training cyclists and also rode by the water along the bay leading to St-Tropez, and watched the cluster of sailing boats racing away. Eventually St-Tropez and its beach worshiper traffic was there and we got in the look out for a grocery store and a bathroom. I wanted to visit a bit of the town and Jean-Francois wanted to go. I guess it was too early for him to stop for lunch. We managed our business in town and then headed to the old town where I took a few pictures and reached a historical site by the water where a monument marked the historical landing of thousands of soldiers on the 15th of August 1944.        Did I mention the heat yet?  Well it was hot! I was drinking and drinking and my mouth kept feeling dry. Past St-Tropez we got into remote area with just about no services at all, as villas with big gates and large fields was our riding environment. I got kind of desperate for water uintil I found this gas station. Funny enough we had to ask for water as the faucets were kept inside even though the taps were outside. We had to negociate another pass today. The Col de Collebasse stands at 129 m. We still had to sweat for this one and my muscles felt really still and tired. The downhill was much better for me but Jean-Francois broke yet another spoke. By that time I was use to the sound of it, and what it meant. We agreed on stopping for lunch at the next town and we found a corner store to by yet some more groceries and a little corner of concrete with some shade to eat our lunch. I leaned against the wall and sat down but got up real fast as I could smell pee... Grrrrr...      We had lunch and Jean-Francois fixed his spoke mumbling and being irritable. My feet were so swollen I could hardly fit them in my shoes so I laid horizontal on the ground and elevated them for a bit for a little relief. More biking after that and we found a bike path to make our life easier. The riding was nice up and down cliffs and hills to make the riding interesting. After a nectarine break I noticed I lost a screw off one of my cleat as I couldn't put it back on the pedal. Oh-oh! I walked back a hundred meter bent in half looking for the screw but to no avail. I would just have to be careful and check the screws everyday.       At 7:30 PM we reached a grocery store and I begged the security guard to let me in as they were closing. We bought supply for dinner and also a 2 liters of iced tea (room temperature) that we gulped in no time at all. We had more biking to do as there was a campsite sign on the map in La Crau which we eventually reached as the sun was getting low. The locals in La Crau were not sure about the campsite, which is not a good sign. We were finally directed out of town for a few kilometers where we had a 300 m of the bumpiest road I have ever encountered. I was hoping that I would not lose any more screws. At the end of that road on our left side there was a cluster of dirty and somewhat unkept trailers, a kind of a commune with dirty naked children, barking dogs, chicken and roosters, and old cars with flat tied and missing doors. We passed that and entered the campsite, and found no one around. The office was closed. A few trailers here and there but no one to be seen. We found an acceptable site and I inspected the facilities. Everything was very unkept and dirty, dusty and obviously had not been in use for a while. There was no power working and cobwebs everywhere. The bathroom were Turkish style and really dirty so finding a friendly tree was more appealing to me.  I washed using a cloth and hot water that I warmed on the stove and washed my hair under the tap by our campsite. It was dark when I started making dinner and as I was cooking, Jean-Francois was bathing in the buff by the tap until he saw this car coming around the corner with the headlights on. He went in the hiding behind a bush and I had a good laugh! Gastronomy of the day was sweet and sour cashews and vegetable stir-fry over a bed of rice. Something good in the midst of a spooky campsite. 
We headed into town for breakfast. La Crau is not very big but big enough to look for the downtown core. We found the bakery, our first stop and then a coffee shop, where we sat and sipped on coffee and hot chocolate and Coca Light for me watching the people doing their morning business. There were old women with their baskets full of produce, young woman holding a child in their hand, old men walking their dogs. Now, so much to say about the dogs  Usually small pocket things, some with hairdo worse than mops, some with little girl's barrettes on top of their head. Then the inevitable boy driving his scooter like a maniac. All kinds of people       We lingered in that little place until it got real hot then declared it was time to go before it got warmer. Was it ever hot! We first passed through a truck route, nothing so interesting and then a more forested area, starting to gain elevation in the process. Still on busy roads, we had to negociate the road with others, until Roquebrussanne, where we took a left turn in this quietest little road. Boy was it ever hot! There was a short climb in the process of crossing that section of country and I managed to complain about it. Fortunately a nice downhill, almost cooling  followed and we stopped in this lost and dead little village  in the middle of nowhere where we treated ourselves with a popsicle. The owner's husband was watching the World's cup and we were not allowed to go near the freezer to go pick our own frozen treat because we would disturb the man and his very important football match  We took the quiet road again meandering among fields of sweet nothing, surprising lizard in the process, then we hit the vineyards. It was fairly pleasant riding once you get passed the heat. St-Maximin became our lunch spot and Jean-Francois decided on stopping in this quiet park facing the police station. (gendarmerie) I was not so impressed because I didn't have any access to the mandatory Coca Light (diet Coke). I almost fell asleep on the bench even though I was quite uncomfortable and reluctant to leave when it was time to go. (This girl is never happy)    We then headed toward Mont Ste-Victoire, a very cherished mountain by Paul Cezanne, a famous painter that dedicated his whole life comtemplating and painting this famous and unique mountain. The way along the mountain was slow hot and painful. No services were available to cool us down, I was tired and irritable. I just couldn't understand how come this bike was so slow and what the hell was wrong with me for biking so slow. I got so discouraged on my poor progress that I was ready to cry and give up. For some reason I never realized that we were climbing up to 500 m and never clued in that I was so slow because we were indeed climbing  Once we were going down to Aix-en-Provence my mood improved a bit although still tired. I thought Aix should have that something interesting to see. It is a city made in circle and more of a student city than anything else. It was close to 7 PM when we made it there and were racing to find some store to buy food and cold drink. For some reason there weren't any in the big arteries we took so we ventured downtown in the pedestrian only streets. There was a lot of people walking the streets that evening and all towards a gathering spot. We would later learn there was a music festival of some sort that night. We sat down with a 2-liter of iced tea, some chocolate and taboule, our energy food before continuing. We asked some cops the way out of town using the quieter routes and for some reason we must have missed some instructions because we ended up just where we didn't want to be, right on the highway and up a very steep ramp to get on the said highway to boot. By that time I had a bit more energy and I was ok. We were heading towards Rognes, a city that didn't have a camping sign by its name on the map but we took a chance thinking that there might now be a camping as the map was 10 years old. In the meantime the sun was getting low and Jean-Francois was worried about riding in the dark. There were tense moments looking for the right road as we had different opinions as of which road to take and we were trying to make sense of the map, and compare it to the clues of the environment. At the end, I just didn't care. Whatever road we took would be fine with me. Eventually we found the right road and made it to Rognes. It was pitch dark. We asked around for a campsite and were told there wasn't any in here. So we asked for a hotel and we were told again that there wasn't any. We were directed to the church and told to ring the priest, to ask him about the possibilities to camp around. The priest was already in bed and didn't have any answer for us not being from the area. We looked around for a bed and breakfast, asked around and were then directed to this house that was 4 or 5 km out of town. We geared up in our most reflective clothing and flashing light and ventured on a very dark road, seeing nothing but when the cars would pass by. Fortunately they were very good with us leaving lots of space and slowing down when they passed by. We looked for a sign of the B&B and finally found it but the work wasn't all done! We had to bike through a dirt road until a gate where a row of lights lit as we passed the said gate. That made our way to the house easier and made us a bit more hopeful to find a place to stay overnight. By that time (it was 10:20 PM) all I wanted was a place to sleep, regardless of the price. We rang the bell at the door and asked if there was a room available, excusing ourselves profusely for the late intrusion. We were quoted a high price for the last room available (84 Euro) and were shown this very nice room which we took on the spot. (How could we refuse and leave at this time of night after almost 130 km of riding in the heat?)  We took care of the bikes, got the clothes and food upstairs, had a delightful shower in a real bathroom, and I made something to eat. All I wanted was to sleep. The bedroom was something to see, quite nice with a French antique flavor to it. Sleep came easy that night.   
After more packing and bike set up we left this domain and went back on the road, thankfully downhill for the next little while. The next village we stopped for real size croissants as promised and also for fruits and other groceries. I walked briefly into a pottery outdoor market and was impressed with the talent, a lot of pieces caught my attention but I couldn't buy anything at all and I knew it so I passed quickly. A little farther down we were treated with a very nice little town with cobblestone in its downtown core, narrow roads and quaint little stores. Although it was Sunday morning there were a lot of people out there sipping on coffee and also people watching the world cup. There was also a medieval castle nearby which I wanted to see from up close and personal but we didn't have time. The riding towards our first pass of the day was warm but scenic, as we left the villages we got into some rocky, dry and also increasingly hilly relief. We started to climb, gradually on a very pleasant road but in the middle of it Jean-Francois broke yet another spoke! The top was quoted at 499m and we stopped for lots of water. Was it ever hot!!!     The nice descent took us to Apt with is a larger city that would be our lunch spot. There was a market going on in the core area and would be the largest we would encounter. There was a lot of people around, it was hard to find a path for our bike and us but we managed and found a shady corner behind the olive salesman. Jean-Francois was not very happy about his broken spoke and about the low mileage so far today and I sensed he wanted to be left alone so I looked around for grocery items, some cold drinks and I needed a roll of film for my camera. I bought some more cherries, some bread and also stopped at the cheese counter held by 2 brothers that looked alike. They made me taste their cheese until I liked what was under my palate and served me some. I really enjoyed my shopping around in these markets... There were Provencal tablecloths and fabrics to die for, and also all kinds of crafts. Back to the back of the olive counter Jean-Francois finished his repair and we had some lunch in the shade. It was so hot it was hard to bear. We made the decision not to attempt Mont Ventoux today due to the late time and hot weather. It was just not realistic. We settled for the town at the foot of the mountain and we would summit in the morning tomorrow. We treated ourselves to an ice cream at a bar while everybody else but us was watching the world cup on tv.     Eventually it was time to get back on the road and we took a relatively quiet road towards Murs  where I experienced my first lavender fields. I was impressed even if there was no colors yet in the fields. I could imagine for myself what it would be like in August...    The climb to Murs was painful due to the heat. It was really hard to bear and I was drinking at a scary rate. We would later learn it was 39 degrees that day (102 F) with no wind. So arriving to Murs, a lost little town on top of the hill we looked for the fountain which was invaded by wasps but we didn't care really. I would have like to plunge in the water, but as some people were watching I settled for dipping my bandana in and wetting my hair and refreshing my face. There were few old folks selling cherries on the side of the street and we sat down with them for a little conversation and more cherry splurging... We bought another pound or 2 from them and ate the samples they were offering us. We learned that there was a campsite in Sault which was not marked on the map and that would put us in better position to climb Mont Ventoux tomorrow so we settle for this last minute change of direction.     Waving our new friends goodbye we took a turn towards Sault and passing several cherry trees, started climbing slowly and gradually towards the Col de La Ligne. We had the delight of a rabbit crossing in front of us and a lizard sighting, and I also saw a snake that Jean-Francois missed before the pass. The Col de La Ligne is also called "Mur de la Peste" or pest wall, which was a boundary preventing people to cross to prevent pest propagation many years ago.    The downhill was wonderful although the road was not optimal with the bumps to watch and irregularity of the pavement preventing me to go at the speed I wanted. We had a wonderful view over a gorge at some point and went down some more. I missed the turnoff for Sault so we had to ride a few more kilometers to reach Sault and Jean-Francois was not impressed that I made a mistake. He was very tired and mind you so was I. Sault was on top of a hill so our last kilometers were spend going up that hill and Jean-Francois ran out of steam! We stopped at a junction to eat melted chocolate out of the wrapper and I went across the road to see this huge memorial in honor of the soldiers who died for the freedom of everybody.  The campsite was full of mosquitoes and we set up in a zombie mode. I had a delightful shower and we had the visit of a middle age couple that had been cycling in Corsica and now were heading back home. They were interested to chat and I was interested in eating and crash in my bed! We had some pasta and a bit of wine and then headed to bed. 
There was some sort of road race in Sault when we sat down in front of our yummy pastries and coffee, so we watched the people running basically by the tables outside of the bar where we were sitting. I splurged in croissants and pain au chocolat, fruits and fruit juice. Anything to get me up that mountain! Sault happened to be a charming town on top of a hill and had some quaint little shops and some views over lavender fields and the mountain. I enjoyed it.  Eventually it was time to leave, and I got a little nervous thinking we had like 26 km of climbing to do to reach the top. Fortunately we had a little time to warm up as we had to climb down the hill and across a brief valley before climbing. The air was still fresh, the sun was there, and the views awesome. It was a gentle climb to start with and Jean-Francois got ahead leaving me with the flies to deal with. Some cyclists passed us waving us, with nothing on the bike but themselves. Some of them were in their sixties!!! So the climbing was ok to my surprise. Not too much traffic, I would just guess it was still early for the motorcyclists and it was just fine with me. Otherwise the climb was uneventful until Chalet Reynard. Just before that point we encountered some chalets and then a little downhill which took us to the chalet where all the action was in preparation of the car rallye. There was a bunch of fire trucks and inevitable firefighters, some police cars and other volunteers ready to close up the road at noon. They all gasped with the sight of our loaded bikes !!! It was almost funny. We stopped and went in the restaurant and I wanted some bubbly real bad and could not believe my luck... They had some Pepsi!!! It would be my best find of the trip... I bought 2. It was very expensive but I couldn't care less. It tasted really good. We also purchased some post cards, I ate some fruits and other energy food, filled up with water and then after watching so many cyclists climbing the steep uphill off Chalet Reynard, it was our turn. I was a little anxious about this last section that was averaging 8% . The crowd of  the outdoor patio, the firefighters and the rest of them watched us take some speed to climb as I quickly downshifted to the easiest gear... 6 kilometers of hell it was but I have been told that it can be worse than that if the wind gets in the way. Business as usual. Breathe, get into 'the zone' that place where you just spin, and get the bike up there...       Jean-Francois got ahead, and I just pedaled, into my little world, looking around and being impressed I was here. I was glad to 'have to stop' to take pictures, as it allowed to catch up on my breath. There was more traffic than the first leg, motorcycles and all, some more cyclists, some of them that were hauled by truck and were going down, cars. I was panting and my legs were sore. I joined Jean-Francois at the Tom Simpson memorial where we paid our respects to the guy and looked at the views.      Soon enough it was time to attack the last kilometer of the climb, not the easiest. There was a snack bar maybe 400 m before the top and lots of people around there, and I got applauds and encouragements from the tourists but I was panting and very concentrated to keep on pedaling and make it up there. The last u-turn was a notch steeper, and I had to weave my way between a biker that was walking his bike and pedestrians. My lungs were ready to explode! Then there was a gate, and people chatting up there as it was still climbing and I had to tell them to get out of the way so I don't fall or put them in danger. That was when I got applauded and I almost started crying... Few more pedal strokes and there was nothing more to climb, and I just let the bike roll and met up with Jean-Francois, totally out of breath... There we were. We did it. I did it. There were lots of cyclists up there, having climbed their Ventoux. but nobody had 65 pounds of gear on their bike. It was nice to see all those people sharing their love of biking... We must have spent half an hour eating more food, drinking, shopping for post cards and souvenirs and taking pictures. The views were a little bit hindered by the haze but still beautiful.            Well rested, we left and started the long descent on the other side. It was warm but the wind was cooling and lovely on the skin, I just loved it. Rather than short switchbacks, we had long stretches of straight road allowing for high speed... Cool. My top speed reached 68.4 km/hr. I stopped in Malaucene at the foot of Ventoux and waited for Jean-Francois noticing how warmer it was down there, almost unbearable. We stopped at this restaurant where we had cooling drinks and some kind of meal before going again. We hung out a while, waiting for the heat to just go away but it just wouldn't leave. Eventually we had to go, and fortunately we still had 300 m to go down to Avignon, over 40 km. The first section was very pleasant, the one to Carpentras. It was wine country and sceneries were fabulous though there was much traffic. I sang along and it went well. From Carpentras to Avignon was a little tougher, though flat. I am sure my blood sugar crashed, I had to stop, was low in energy, and finding our way was a little trickier to avoid the busy road and still avoid doing extra mileage.  I wanted to see Avignon. I was told it was quite pretty. There was much to see I was told. I mentionned to Jean-Francois that I wanted to see Avignon and that if we were just to pass by, that we might just as well avoid the urban area and cross the Rhone river where it would be quieter. So it was with trust that we would visit that I followed him as he chose the route. But once in town, all of a sudden, what was most important was finding food and get the hell out of town. That was very disappointing to me, leaving me thinking what type of trip I signed up for. We crossed town, and sat down on the sidewalk against a building to gulp some 2 liters of Iced Tea, and eat chocolate pudding. Sitting nearby outside from a small pub was a drunk guy that made a joke to my intention and it was not funny at all. Then we got on the lookout for a bathroom for me and I found one of those public pay bathrooms that are supposedly self cleaning in between uses. Jean-Francois was my guinea pig and I changed my mind when I saw him coming out of it.    So we cycled a little farther down and I was coaxed by the urgency of nature call to ask a restaurant if I could please use their facilities. It's the one thing I really don't like doing, asking to use the bathroom when I am not a patron of the place. But this time I had to go, it was an emergency... So I was ready to ask but the waitress and the waiter were talking together, and I didn't bother after waiting a bit and just went. There. That was that easy...  Getting out of town was very hairy. We were looking for the right bridge to take, and once we had it, could not return. It looked to me like a highway, no shoulder and very fast driving traffic. We got honked at a few times and we had to negociate a few off and on ramps. This was the only option we had to reach our destination, and when you are racing for the sunset and for your dinner, you don't question... We stopped once for a bit of a breather in the middle of a decent hill and had a cold drink and finally reached Remoulins where supposedly we would find a campsite. We had to look for it. I saw this lady walking with a duck in her hands and she didn't looked impressed. I gathered that the duck escaped his yard. I laughed out loud and that made me feel better after the stressful time on the highway. Our campsite of the night was a top notch fully catered campsite, with lovely showers and bathroom. Interrestingly enough those were mixed- not sex segregated.  And also a restaurant. I set up camp, had a shower and rushed to the restaurant before the kitchen closed and had time to gulp a beer while Jean-Francois had his shower (by now you need to wonder whether he has more body parts than anybody else in the world). The evening was very pleasant and the food got down well... I had a salad for entree and a pizza that was yummy. I was really surprised that they didn't accept credit cards and got caught with little money in hands and they accepted that I pay the following morning. The waitress didn't even take my name down, trusting we would be there. 
We only had to cycle a few kilometers before standing in front of this beauty that is the Pont du Gard. Double decked, out of nowhere,  all I could do was stand there and admire. I snapped a few shots and then off we went for our day ride. We agreed that this would be a good day to go the distance which would put us in good position in prevision of a day off in a medium size city that was Millau.          The day was already hot and I kept complaining it was soooo hot. Jean-Francois decided it was not hot at all, trying to trick his mind I guess. We rode with a head wind most of the day, and not the cooling kind. I was sweating from every sweat gland of my body, especially the forearms and the shins. The ride was enjoyable, being in countryside amidst orchards, vineyards and quiet roads. We kept hopping from village to village, most of them dead quiet. We were offered a rolling hill terrain, the type to make you work out to make it on top, and added to the head wind and the crushing heat, did nothing to make us feel strong and full of energy.      In the shade we found a fruit stand and it was a good occasion to sip on a can of iced tea and try some fresh ripe peaches. The village of Arnet was dead otherwise, no one to be seen around. I was hoping to find a store for films for my camera but to no avail. Eventually leaving a friendly stray dog behind we got back on the bike, stopping just a few hundred meter farther down the road in a bar to fill up our water bottles. Water is in short supply here,there are  no water fountains in the villages. However it is a law in France that bars cannot refuse people water even if we don't buy anything. The barmaid gave us ice cubes along with the water which we were thankful for. One rather drunk patron woman could not believe we were headed to Florac, maybe 100 km away from here, and told us it was easier to go by car... I made a mistake of taking the wrong road again which made us take a forced detour and Jean-Francois was rather pissed off by this error. Again I am carrying the map as my handle bar bag is very handy to hold a map right on top so I am the navigator.  I am quite used to making mistakes, it happens to the best of us and I know I am not perfect. We made a stop to Ladignan for lunch just 20 km down the road, where everything was closed in the small town but an empty bar held by a mother and daughter. I gulped a Coke before anything else and we hid inside trying to hide from the sun and keep somewhat cool. Jean-Francois seemed to lack energy by that time, not feeling too well. I waited until the stores reopened and went for groceries, buying some really yummy chips, grapes and more of those yummy cherries. I also phoned my sister from a very hot phone booth (I almost asphyxiated) which was really nice and headed back in the bar. Jean-Francois realized we would not make it to Florac today as it was just to far considering the heat, and there were a couple of passes to 700 m we had to climb prior to Florac. I didn't mind. A shorter day would be fine with me. After all I am on vacations! So we settled for St-Jean-du-Gard. It was hard to get back on the bike after such a long break but it felt like the heat was not so bad after all. And we were treated to a bit of a downhill to start with. There was just about 14 km to cover to Anduze where we stopped and I bought much needed films for my camera and a little farther down the road we had a grocery store to buy supply for our dinner. Another 14 km was separating us from our final destination and a few hills were indicated on the map. The views were nice although the shoulders were narrow and we had to focus on the traffic. There was a river by the side of the road with people swimming and it felt really inviting. On the outskirts of St-Jean-du-Gard we stopped on the foot of a hill and were puzzled as for where to go. There were no campsites posted and it sounded like town was on the left. Jean-Francois didn't want to do another detour today and wanted to make the decisions. I was tired, stressed out and just stepped back, let him decide whatever. All I wanted was a nice shady area to pitch my tent and a nice shower. We ended up being directed up the hill and then down into town. Jean-Francois was pissed off at the guy because turning left would have taken us at the same place and without the complications of the hill. I didn't care by now. The little town was quite pretty. Nice patios for people to sit and enjoy a drink and little boutiques. Sounded like we would have the choice of places to go the next day for breakfast. To our dismay though the campsite was like 4 km away from town, and we had to retrace our steps, but on the other side of the river. The campsite was quiet and held by this young guy that had great dreams for his new business. He was working on the yard planting a tree and showed us around walking us through the sites. He showed us what was available, and showed us imaginary divisions of each sites. I had to laugh. Well we didn't care so this one site in the middle would do just fine. He started talking to us, happy to have someone to be a recipient of a conversation. Then after a while as we were unloading he realized that we were quite tired, stopped in the middle of a phrase, turned his heels and walked away. What a different character! I hope that we didn't insult him. I pitched my tent on an ant nest and as they started climbing my feet and stinging a bit I decided I should step out of their territory and change spot. What followed is well worth forgetting. To this day I am still hurt by what happened. I will just say that I was very upset and puzzled, contemplated packing back up and leave on the spot. Instead I had a shower, biked the 8 km return to town to speak with my sister as she needed to talk to me some more, and came back to camp to make dinner. I was not even hungry but ate in prevision of the day to come as it would be a long one to make up for the distance we didn't cover. Words are not coming up to talk about that evening so maybe I should stop here. 
   We took a while to find  what we needed for breakfast and sat down at a bar for the usual fare of coffee and hot chocolate.  There was a cute cat looking at us from the edge of a roof wanting to come down but not daring to jump, then he got absorbed by the sight of a bird in a nearby tree and it was the first time I saw a cat drooling.  Eventually we left the business of the town behind, and headed up the mountain, on a crest pathway called 'Corniche des Cevennes'. The first mountain pass was rather easy but steady climb in a forested area, quiet and peaceful. It was enjoyable. We went as high as 597 meters and then had a bit of a downhill offering views of the other side of the crest.    Old wavy mountains were all around, offering a panorama not as spectacular as the Alps but still. I was curious to see where it lead. We had a stop at Pompidou, a small village out of nowhere for coffee and a bit of energy food. We watched a small group of Dutch cyclists leave town pushing their bikes up the hill and it looked painful. The hill was rather steep indeed. When it got time to climb that hill I had a fight with the laws of gravity. It must have been one of the steepest hills I have encountered since La Bonette but I climbed it all up and we met up wit the Dutch party just around the corner as they were taking a breather. The climb didn't finish there, there were a few sharp turn, more steep climbing and then we reached a high plateau and the cycling got much more comfortable. And eventually cycled down the crest with a change of valley, in a very spectacular way.      There were tight hairpins to negociate and really nice panoramas to appreciate. Eventually we had to climb a little section again before reaching Florac where we stopped for lunch. A cyclist in training got into a conversation with Jean-Francois which made the cycling a little less painful up the little section and then we found ourself sitting in this caf watching the other patrons watching a World cup match. Florac seems to be a very young city with lots of young families. It was sitting in a valley and there were mountains all around, actually quite a pretty setting. The bar didn't offer food at the time we got in but let us eat our own food while we gulped iced tea and other drinks.  Eventually we had to leave because we had still lots of distance to cover today. We were hoping to reach Millau where we would take a day off tomorrow. A few kms riding lead us to the Gorges du Tarn turn-off, we were offered another dcor different than everything else we saw before. Lush at first, we followed this river entering small villages, sometimes gaining a bit of altitude and leaving the river down lower, sometimes winding through very narrow corridors in between rocky tunnels and rocky walls.    It was just spectacular! The river was a great occasion for canoeing and swimming and at places it was just a big canyon. As for the cycling, most of it was downhill so lots of the time we had a little push in the back from mother nature  It was another hot day and once in a while we would stop for cold drink and for energy. Another of those days where the pavement was found melting at places and sticking to the wheels.       After 143 km we entered Millau and rather easily found a camping near the downtown core, at the foot of a mountain where dozen of parasails launch their attire in the air and swirl in the air endlessly. We took the first campsite we found and set up after gulping  down a celebration beer at the office. That night we treated ourselves to pizza at a neighbouring restaurant. We had poor service and the pizza was burnt but it would do for the night      
   The laundry took a little longer than expected as I chose the longer cycle, and then hung the clothes on the fence as I had left my clothesline behind somewhere. We went to town for part 2 of our breakfast and looking for an internet station mainly. There was also a castle according to the map and I wanted to see. Jean-Francois wanted to check out the menus for good food for our dinner tonight.     The internet session was 2 Euros an hour, an incredible price considering I have paid as high as 10 Euros an hour in other parts of France and in Switzerland. We were given good computers and I managed to talk to my brother live with yahoo messenger. Ahhh, technology! We wandered a bit in the streets of Millau, looked for the castle, didn't find it, or if it was what it was, it wasn't impressive. We looked for restaurants and settled for one that looked good and offered some good menus. I was tired of walking by the time we headed back to our campsite. My legs were protesting as they were not used to the walking anymore.     The afternoon was spent cleaning the bikes for Jean-Francois and attempting to write for me. I had been neglecting my journal for a while which is fairly unusual when I travel as I love keeping track of everything. For some reason, likely because of the company and also because of chronic late arrivals at campsites, darkness and fatigue, it was just not possible to write as much. I had a nice shower to help me cool down and discovered some fungal infection  underneath my feet as I didn't manage to find my flip flops back home and was using the public showers bare feet. My shoes were pretty stinky too, and if I left my socks in my tent at night I was sure that one of those nights I would be found dead asphyxiated. Even the shoes in the vestibule were not acceptable anymore. Something needed to be done  The dinner at the restaurant was quite good, good old French cuisine. The restaurant walls were all stone with dim lighting making a really nice warm atmosphere.  All the tables outside were taken so we had one inside, and we sipped a nice cocktail for apperitif. The food was really good and so was the wine. I forgot how I made it back to camp but obviously did.     
We were given a few kilometer warm up before climbing a decent hill to get out of town. There was a big semi truck traffic and again everybody was very respectful of us. The downhill on the other side was very nice and I remember looking around feeling happy to absorb myself in riding and scanning the horizon for interesting sightseeing.  I was looking forward to make it to St-Affrique, as the name was very inspiring. I was curious to see if there would be huts, maybe some herds of elephants and zebras... None of that. Actually we had to climb another decent hill and the decent stretched all the way into town, and I discovered a happy city that would have deserved some visiting. I refilled my water bottles at the pub as the fountain's water was not potable and we carried on out of town towards our junction. The landscape was slowly changing, very subtly but it was hard to say in which way. A little story about the junction's rest area. This was a nice looking one and offered some rest rooms! We had to jump on the occasion, and have a little rest, and visit the bathrooms... Well outside was better than in, and I changed my mind very fast. The turkish style toilet, despite newer facilities were not maintained at all and it was all so gross... We met a trucker in need of human contacts and had a chat with him for a while. We learnt that the soccer's world cup was not over yet and the final match would be Germany against Bresil.  A little farther down the road we found our lunch spot in Belmont, where a really nice cathedral overrides the skyline. For so much room around with fields and everything, the town was made so tight and small streets and all I couldn't even find my way to the cathedral to check it out. I purchased some supply to take care of the fungus that was growing underneath my feet and just sat down and rested in the shade. We were sitting by a little coffee/smoke shop and were listening to a couple of retired  locals discussing the town's difficulties to attract tourists.     Back on the road again, we were given a hill to deal with and a crest's ride and we managed both just fine despite the heat. The sceneries on the crest were not spectacular but still at least gave me something to do. It felt like a long time to me up there. It was agricultural lands all around, with rolling hills. We took a small detour for the Col de Sie for the picture and had a lovely descent to Lacaune, a medium size town where we stopped and gulped a 2 liter of warm iced tea.       We also bought supplies for dinner that night and took off out of town again. Next was the Foret de Montroucous which offered quiet and peaceful riding in the shade. In that area every little town had their memorial remembering children that never came back from war. It made me reflect on how awful it would be to have a loved one going to war and never see him again.  We ended up in Brassac, after 105 km and with a camping in town. The day was not so young anymore and we still had a fair distance to the next campsite so we opted to stop here to the city campsite. It was the cheapest ever for a whopping 4.80 Euros!  We ate Knorr's noodles for dinner watching a thunderstorm rolling in but fortunately in never came over our tent, just a few drops and that's it. It just cooled us down for the night which was just delightful.   
This morning's cycling took us through some green and lush forest, and through small towns with the same war memorials described yesterday. I really enjoyed myself as it was very quiet and peaceful. The mist provided a mysterious effect to the surrounding and just kept me comfortable on the bike. I was hoping that it would clear out for the visit of Carcassonne.  Cycling through Mazamet marked the end of one stage and announced the beginning of climbing and crossing Montagne Noire. We ate a Snicker each for energy and started a steep ascent just out of town, for a respectable 800 meters elevation gain. I was impressed with myself for maintaining a speed of 10 km an hour for that climb, and I thought I must be getting in good shape after all!     The descent towards Carcassonne was just wonderful, a long, long descent for 10 or 15 kilometers. By that time we entered Carcassonne we had cycled 85 km without a break and I was ready for one! We cycled along the Canal du Midi where lots of houseboats driven by tourists taking their holidays boating around from town to town. I thought it was a pretty romantic way to travel! My first sighting of Carcassonne had me impressed and left me in awe. Mind you I was hungry and the first thing I needed was to put some energy in my body.  We pedalled to the entrance of the Cite and walked the bike inside where we found very narrow streets and a lot of shops catering for the tourists. I was led by Jean-Francois to a central court and then a quieter section where we sat on a bench and then decided to sit down at the restaurant across the little park where we were. I ordered some fries and salad, and Jean-Francois had a full lunch deal, steak and all. I wanted to visit and as Jean-Francois had been here already, he decided to stay put and I promised to come back in half and hour or so. I just wandered in the stores, and also took some pictures, bought a couple of post cards. I enjoyed being there, would have liked to visit the pay section but in the same time was ready to move along. Being with so many people was getting to me after a while and I needed back to the solitude of the road again.            Out of town we cycled through vineyards and followed the Aude river. It was really enjoyable riding but we could see a thunderstorm on the horizon and it was coming our way it seems. Again I missed a turn at some point and we found ourselves on the busier road, which made Jean-Francois furious. It didn't really made our ride longer but we had to deal with heavy traffic instead of the quieter vineyard crossing. Oh well. It allowed me to stop at a fruit stand and buy a kilo of cherries for tonight.    Finding the campsite in Limoux wasn't so easy and we had to ask around, then cross town, and found it a few kilometers away. I would have liked some beer but then it would have meant returning into town and I was not ready to do that. I was very tired and fell asleep while Jean-Francois entertained our neighbors. It happened that this couple and him met in a campsite in Southern France last year! Small world. 
We went in town for the usual fare of croissants and hot drinks, and I managed to drop all the pastries on the floor at the bakery, leaving a mess of crumbles behind, apologizing profusely to the owner. Then we went to sit down in a pedestrian square and sat down to eat and drink. People watching is a great thing to do, especially people and their pets. A lady and her dog under her arm came and talk to us, probably in need of social contacts. The cycling went just fine for me. I was just back into my inner thoughts as I was pedaling away. I left Jean-Francois way behind for some reasons, and when I reached the next big town, I sat down in front of a grocery store waiting for him. By that point I was wondering if it was time to just say goodbye. It sounded like we just didn't have much to say to one another, and I felt some kind of tension installing. When he arrived, the need to get groceries prevailed and all was forgotten for a while. Quillan was crossed and we found some turkish public toilets (I am getting better at aiming now) and then we headed for the hill that would take us beck to the mountains. It was an easy climb for me, the views were great and soon we had our first pass under the belt. Again I found the writings aimed at bike racers on the pavement and had to stop when I saw Lance's name. It got me distracted for a while. Some more climbing led us to the Col de Coudon at 833 meters.         We found a lunch spot in a lost little village called Espezel. Couple of intersections, no one in sight, no access to a prized can of Coke, let alone Pepsi. We sat down at the public fountain and ate there. I had a couscous salad and some bread. The flies and other bugs were ravenous here and it was irritating. A huge horse and it's cavalier came by, and a lost cyclist that didn't talk to us.    We thought we'd stop at the next village for cold or hot drinks. We were riding on the Plateau de Sault, higher elevation with mountains in the horizon. We were indeed in the Pyrenees...     The next village had a little caf and 2 stars hotel where a few young woman were smoking like locomotives. It was getting quite cool at that point and the clouds were rolling in, so after hot chocolate, dressed up and went for more riding, hoping for the best.  We were hit by the rain in Belcaire where we sought refuge first in a bus stop then a tourist information where we waited half an hour or one hour. Thunder was going at it and the rain was heavy at times. Eventually, rain or not we had to go providing that the thunderstorm was done and over with, so we braved it out. At times it was barely raining and the cycling was comfortable. We had some more climbing to do, as the Col des 5 Freres was standing at 1253 meters. It was nice riding. That was probably the only pass I didn't take a picture as I didn't want to stop and freeze to death, and it had started raining some more. The way down was like cycling into a freezer and I felt my extremities stiffening and getting like popsicles. I stopped at Camurac where there was a very inviting caf. The thunder came back and felt it would be better to call it a day. It took a while to make a decision as of what to do but eventually settled for a bed and breakfast or something of that sort and found a 'gite' which is a mountain type hostel primarily aimed at backpackers touring in the Pyrenees. For the modest sum of 10 Euros we were given a bed, a roof and access to the kitchen and the garage for the bikes. Our host made us feel at home at the 'Gite de la Marmite' and I was very thankful to hurry in the shower to thaw my hands and feet... The evening was spent trying to dry the clothes (with no luck), sipping on hot tea, reading a book and just dozing... I was wanting to make baked potatoes as a special treat as we had access to an oven but my cooking tonight was totally disgusting... Jean-Francois was pretty polite to eat it all that night but mind you, it must have been out of hunger!!! 
We ate a really hearty breakfast this morning, Jean-Francois with fried eggs and me with cereals and yogurt and pastries. Yummy! We headed back to the grocery store that morning as we managed to spot a computer in the corner and paid a small fee for half an hour for both of us to check out the mail. Then waving the dog goodbye we left, to climb the first col of the day which was easily summitted.  That was col de Marmare.     Then we headed to the next one which was Col de Chioula standing at 1431 m. That one was nice to reach as it marked a stage for me, the last hill before the serious climb of Andorra. We took a break, I had a bite, dressed up for the descent and a French couple came to talk to us and wish us luck and courage.    The descent was great although very very cold. I got my fingers and toes frozen and it took a while to thaw. Ax-les-Thermes looks like a pretty town. Jean-Francois had a spoke to repair from the descent into town and was very unhappy about that one. I kept busy in the meantime by visiting around, window shopping and phoning my sister for the last time before heading back in Paris. Once the mechanic finished his task on the bike we had something to eat among a group of motor bikers that invaded our bench and then left for another country... What was to come was only uphill to Andorra-La-Vella, passing from 720 m in Ax-les-Thermes to 2407 m at the highest over 35 km. At first it was a gentle climb so I took on the lead and span the wheels. Averaging 12 to 14 km an hour I remember the traffic at first heavy but then as the valley opened up a bit and the traffic didn't seem as heavy or at least noticeable. The cycling was pleasant for me as I felt full of energy and was curious to see what was ahead. The mountains grew closer and higher, and unfortunately the clouds got lower too. We made a stop at L'Hospitalet, a small village that was just at the right place for a lunch break before the steeper grades of the summit. We ate outside, on a bench then went at the bar for coke and coffee and we witnessed the victory of Bresil over Germany at the World cup. We cheered for the end of the tournament as that was the only thing that Europeans had in mind those days!!!    Heading back outside it seemed to be much cooler and dressed up for it. We noticed the clouds getting thicked which got me a bit worried about being noticed by the traffic so I clipped my red flashing light to my clothes and started climbing. We didn't have a clue where we were, where we were going but we got encouragements from the drivers by a thumb up out of the window, a cheery hunk and also someone screamed to me 'T'es la meilleure!' (You're the best) That one was priceless and gave me shivers. This was in a tougher section where the climbing was steeper and we were sure working hard so encouragements were welcome. We reached Pas de la Casa, where a big post was announcing we were in Andorra. This town looked like a shopper's paradise with bargains and neon signs everywhere, lots of traffic and of course big line-up at the border like it would be at the Canada-US border on a long week end. I would have loved to stop for a look around but it was cold, we had yet some more km to go and some more climbing to do. I ran in a store and bought some drinks for the road and we were back on the road.    The last of the uphill section was a bit tough, climbing in hairpin when my muscles were already protesting from the work out. On one turn we notices some mountain peaks as we emerged over the clouds and on the next turn, we saw some gas stations and nowhere else to climb. It was really weird and somewhat disappointing to find a couple of gas stations at 2407 m as it didn't fit there. Imagine the gas truck that needs to bring the fuel on top of the mountain for the delivery... We celebrated the summit with chocolate, and saw that on the other side there were no longer clouds and threat of rain. We were 'home free'...        The descent into Andorra-la-Veilla was cold again and I found myself having to stop a few times just because I didn't have any feelings in my fingers. There was 26 km downhill to reach the capital and I enjoyed every piece of it despite the cold. There were a few Alpine villages along the way that were really nice and also stunning views over the mountains. I was sad we were just passing by. Andorra la Veilla comes more like chaos with the heavy traffic. Jean-Francois knew where to go so I followed but I was a bit worried that the stores close and there wouldn't be anything to eat. We went to the camping he knew and all my worries and fatigue calmed down when I saw they had Pepsi in their little store! I bought 2 cans and some food for dinner. We were shown a little walk in site where many people had their tents pitched. The same cat from last year came to see Jean-Francois to his delight. An Australian travelling on a BMW touring motorcycle came and talk to us, and we had a little chat, found out he was heading for a 18 months trip back home to Australia with his motorbike... How impressive...We were invited to go to the spa in Andorra with a few of them which we declined. I would have liked to go but we were out of time and it was a bit expensive. Next time? 
We packed it up quickly but then we had a long conversations with the Australian guy from last night so we ended up leaving by 11 after a breakfast that was meant at the restaurant but it was closed, so we winged it and I had my usual fare of bread, cheese, jam and fruits. The cycling day began by a long descent down the mountain, to St-Julia and shortly after that we entered Spain. They didn't even want to see my passport at the custom, nothing. So we carried on and snapped a picture at the Spain post. We were still going down and although it was a busy road with lots of big trucks so not so restful. The views were impressive at time. It is hard to believe that you can go down for 40-50 or even 60 km but hey, it happens!        I was totally aware we were in a new country, first with the signs of the road being different, the language spoken, and also we were totally ignored by drivers where in France we would often get a thumb up or a curious eye through the window. Here, we were just nuisance on the road. At least that was my impression. I was better looking at the map better as the roads had all the same number!!! I almost took a turn off that would have taken us up the roller coaster and probably led us in Madrid through the backdoor but fortunately the vigilant eye of Jean-Francois noticed that indeed we had to carry on straight.  The panoramas were stunning, the cities totally different, it was a shock to the eye after a few weeks in France. Mountains were rocky and dry, and beside the first few cities we encountered we got to ride a good distance without any services, just the road, the trucks, some tunnels and 2 loaded bikes.
