We stopped in Organya for Coke, Cheetos and cupcakes. I was glad to stop, my legs didn't feel that fresh today after yesterday's climb for Andorra. The road past that point got wilder, with the wind getting in the party and stunning sceneries.       I was glad to stop for lunch, and found a caf-bar in a city called Oliana. We set up outside to have a look at the bikes and I went in to order. Oh-oh... My Spanish is very basic and I had to ask for assistance in English or French and they found someone after a few minutes. This town is not touristy it felt like we were the only foreigners around. Not only that but standing at the bar waiting I realized I was the only woman in that section, everybody else were men, and I was getting watched too! I didn't know if I was allowed in or what was the scoop. Maybe it was a custom thing for men to have a drink or coffee in the afternoon... I wanted French fries and I got them. And a salad. Oh, and Coke of course. Shortly after cycling out of Oliana we took a turn east towards Cadrona and it was that road that would take us to Barcelona the next day. I was getting well aware that my trip was just about to finish, that this was my next to last day of cycling. I didn't want my trip to end! The road to Cadrona was finally quiet, we had some peace at last. What we didn't know and the map didn't show is we had a col to climb. The Spain Michelin map is has a smaller scale than the France ones therefore not as detailed. It was really a surprise to realize that we climbed to 880 m after a good half hour of climbing.      The views were lovely up there and so was the descent in Solsona where I called another rest. I also wanted to see what a nice Spanish city looked like... This one looked fortified so it looked interesting. We did stop by an inside court, and took a breather. I was tired, and was looking forward to reach the camping some 15 km away. So said the map...         Well the camping was in fact well away from the road and we would have had to ride a dirt road for a few kilometer which wasn't appealing for 2 tired cyclists. So we decided carry on and hope for an unannounced camping in Cadrona. Cadrona came, and we noticed that we had to climb this big hill to reach town. There would be no camping there that was for sure so as the sun was getting quite low and I didn't want to carry on any farther so thought that a hotel would by needed.. I ended up having to push my bike up a narrow steep street looking for a hotel and oddly enough there wasn't any. We asked this one lady that didn't speak much English but just enough to understand hotel and led us a few blocks away to this group of people at a table. The lady spoke to this one man in Spanish and to my understanding the hotel was closed but he was willing to give us a room for 25 Euros for one night only. That was a relief to have found something. We were shown the room, and started to get everything up on the second floor. The mattresses had seen better days, and the shower was so small that even if you placed the curtain well inside you created a lake everywhere on the bathroom floor.  We showered, and went back out for dinner to this restaurant where we had good food with a pitcher of sangria.    
This morning we got up and were thankful of not having to take the tents down. We loaded the bikes and went on the lookout for something to eat for breakfast. We found some bakeries and also fruits off the street- it sounded like a market was being set up on the streets. We ate at the info center bench and Jean-Francois noticed then that he had lost one of his cycling glove. He went back where we came from and found it!  The cycling started today by a nice downhill and following a busy and especially dusty road we got to climb then descend following the moods of the landscape. I kept thinking this was the last official day riding of my trip and I had mixed emotions about it, sadness, relief, pride. I wanted to make this day enjoyable and could not wait to see Barcelona. We had a few tunnels to pass today including this very scary one that was narrow, with big semis passing, very dark and we had maybe one foot in between the side line and the broken pavement. One little mistake, to the left was busy traffic that couldn't care less about the cyclists (a few angry honks) and to the right was soft dirt and then the wall. I survived, and was relieved after that section. Jean-Francois emerged a bit later with a line up of cars kind enough to have slowed down to make him ride through safely.  We took a break and a breather at Olesa de Monserrat which is a suburb of Barcelona and we sat down on a bench in a park. Siesta for both of us gave me a little rest, some good food and off we went again. What cane was really going through cities neighboring Barcelona, and the closer we got, the worse the traffic was. A very nice mountain range got me in awe and stayed in my field of vision for an hour or 2 which was a nice distraction to the cycling, the road, the dust and the traffic. Talking of distraction, there were a few girls that were 'hitchhiking' out of nowhere, dressed 'to impress' and no, we didn't stop to say hi! Eventually after a nice drafting session for Jean-Francois, we made it close to Barcelona trying to decide on which direction to take. It was all very confusing and we were looking for a camping. the closest one happened to be by the airport and that is where we went at first. I had to use my very basic spanish to ask around in this bar where the camping was and we learned it was closed so after buying some cold treats we left for another camping by the ocean. The barman told us it would be around 10 km. I was getting tired and wanting to just be at camp, rest, have a nice shower...  We cycled and cycled, passed some campgrounds but were not the one we were looking for, watched the sun getting lower, got passed by cyclists in serious training, and just when we thought of heading back we saw this camping resort fully serviced with tennis courts, pool store and restaurants. We took it. We were given a spot behind the dump in a corner and on dusty type of dirt in the walk-in area. It was tent city and only a few feet were separating each tents. Not the best but tired like I was thought it would do. I just sat there on my thermarest drinking some beer and watching an ant colony at work, coming down a tree and heading somewhere with a serious purpose. I watched a huge tent with obnoxious people getting installed and also turning on the tv to watch the evening's programs. All I wanted was a bit of peace and quiet and I didn't even get that. Oh well. Gastronomy of the day was some macaroni and tomato sauce with lots of cheese. It would have been a nightmare to clean the pot with all the melted cheese in it but as this was the last cooking day of the trip I allowed Jean-Francois to throw away the pot he reluctantly carried all the way from Zurich. I declared that night an earplugs night and surprisingly enough I managed to fall asleep ok.
The bus ride to town was like any other bus ride except it had been weeks I ever climbed in a bus. Motion sickness was a threat but I kept busy trying to look around and absorb the sights. People watching was also very interesting as the locals were also heading to town for seemingly various reasons.  Once out of the bus, we found ourselves stepping straight into an internet cafe, and as we were in no big rush today we decided to go in and check it out. There must have been 150 terminals with flat screens in there, with a little cafe section where one could buy snacks and coffee. There was another floor with the same amount of computers. To me it was quite the sigt after a drought of many weeks without being abe to have decent internet cafes. We spent an hour in front of the screen typing stories and e-mails to loved ones and to crazyguyonabike. It made me happy but also in need of a nap afterwards... And my stomach was screaming for food, used to the high demand of energy of the last weeks.  Out of the internet cafe we headed towards the port of Barcelona in search of information for the Mallorca ferries that would reunite me with my brother. We walked in streets full of people, and should I say there was lots of stimulation for the senses, after spending weeks in quiet places. Music, people, traffic light and jams, smells of all kinds...  Huge contrast for me. We stopped and admired a cathedral surrounded by hundreds other tourists and visited the insides before heading out towards the water.       I purchased my ticket that would take me to Mallorca, and we decided to treat ourselves to a lunch before walking to the other very famous cathedral of Barcelona. It felt like things were going very fast for me now and soon enough I would be back to work in my day to day rat race life. We chose a nice restaurant and toasted to our trip...    We walked a long way to reach Gaudi's church, too much to my liking. My feet and legs were good for cycling, but then walking was a different game. I wanted to sleep, or eat more. I was on the look out for ice cream... The cathedral was very impressive to see, yet unfortunately in construction, taking away some of the awe of it all. The building had 4 towers that were going quite high in the sky, a neck twisting sightseeing, and the whole thing just looked so weird! At first it just looked like a big pile of mud. But once you get closer, and admire the details, it makes a bit more sense, and then one understands why painters and artists are too often mistaken as crazy people!           The way back got interrupted by my need for popsicles and rest my legs and then another internet session to see if anybody answered my e-mails yet! The bus ride got me motion sick and reflective about rat races that was indeed international as I people watched everybody around me in the bus. Things were starting to sink in for me as I would not have a normal day bike ride anymore on this trip, just family visiting and travel days that would eventually lead me home. There was a sense of relief getting off the bus and walking home even if "home" meant this dusty narrow noisy campground.    I tried to sleep that afternoon to no avail, then splurged in a shower and cold drinks. Tonight was restaurant night and JEan-Francois and I celebrated a month of cycling together, for the better and for worse I guess, and picked a pitcher of white sangria, made with chapagne! That was yummy but it left me quite tipsy I must admit! 
It felt weird for me being the only one to pack up but I got real focused on the task and on thinking about my route, and how I would spend the rest of my day. Breakfast got spent lingering at the camping's little cafe, sipping on hot chocolate and also remembering every day of out trip with Jean-Francois. I really enjoyed doing that as sometimes my memory fails and it made me appreciate the distance I have covered (and the altitude), the places we have seen and how fast a holiday goes when one has fun!  Noon came and for me it was time to leave. Said my goodbyes to Jean-Francois, wish him good and happy road, promised to give some news and I was on the road. I was a little worried of getting lost, like I get when I go on a trip by myself and get worried about whatever that can go wrong. But cycling the 15 km to Barcelona happened to be real fun as I was gently pushed by the wind and  averaged speeds of 32-36 km and hour. That was a blast! Getting into town got scary as I had to negociate highway conditions, on and off ramps and fast traffic but apparently bikes were legitimate on that road... I ended up in town with a relief, stopped at a fruit market for everlasting cherries and other fruits and then headed to the Art Museum that I wanted to see from up close before hitting the ferry terminal. Soon enough I was finding myself climbing a hill and looking at Barcelona from the lookout at the foot of the Art Museum's entrance. I was greeted by this middle age guy that appeared lonely, visiting Barcelona for a few days as his friends were attending an international AIDS conference. He was from Toronto and was proud to try his French on me and also enquired about stuff to do in the area as his days were empty while his friends were busy. He asked where I was heading to and whether he could also go to Mallorca for the day (!) and as he was getting a bit too nosy regarding my wearabouts I decided it was time to go and head towards the ferry terminal.       I had lots of time ahead of me and took a slow bike ride around the port, sat down and ate a full pound of cherries, wrote my journal and had some ice cream, then sat down with lunch and a good book of mine until the boat showed up. The same guy from the Art Museum decided to surprise me and come and say hi at the ferry terminal to my dismay and discomfort. He came to check out the ferry options for himself and fortunately soon enough he left... Boarding the ferry was a bit chaotic as I didn't have any direction as of where to go and what to do. I decided to leave the bike by the stairwell and climbed upstairs to find a nice comfortable spot. Now the Mediterranean sea looks quite harmless from the shore, but at sea, it's a different thing believe me! Gradually the sea got agitated and I found myself rocking with the boat.My stomach was not impressed with its contents and was threatening to send it back...  Let's say that the 3 hours of the fast ferry seemed like an eternity!  Fortunatly Mallorca showed up and the captain indeed had a good map and compass! After being all high on carbon monoxide from not being able to get out before half the cars on the ferry got out, I phoned my brother and we set a meeting point. I have been here on the island in 1996 and remembered a bit where to go but all I had to do was to follow the shore and splurge in sightseeing of docks and elegant sailing boats all along my short ride until my brother met me on his bike! That evening we went for tapas in town which happened to be really nice and then headed to sleep.   
I had coaxed my brother Michel to take me on a bike ride on the island. I wanted to go bike along the hills west coast of Mallorca and hopefully catch some good photo opportunities. We must have left by 10 or something silly like that. It was a bit late as it can get quite hot during the day here. Getting out of town was easy and soon enough we started climbing in the mountains. The surroundings were different from the mainland, drier, more olive trees, rockier. I found myself frustrated that even after 6 weeks of biking some 3500 kilometers with 65 pounds of stuff, my brother was still faster than me even if he didn't bike much anymore. Oh well... Look around Kati, appreciate the scenery, breathe!         We finally got on top of the mountain range and finally had a rolling hill-top of the crest type of terrain. The sea was bluer than blue, amazing contrast with the coast. No picture could be able to show how beautiful this was! We stopped in a village for snack and little rest and continued on the coast. It was a lot of work I should admit, hills were steep and the roller coaster was never ending! Lunch was spent eating a submarine, Mallorca way sitting on an outdoor patio, in the shade, sipping on a soft drink. Michel got tired towards the end, so he says but I don't think it showed in his performance. The last 10 km were a little hairy in the urban Palma, full of traffic and also tourist area but all went well. I was aware that this was the last bike day of my trip. The afternoon would bring me a little quiet time before it was time to go pick up the kids in daycare. I was looking forwatd to that, after seeing them in picture only. Here was Alex, 4, Ana, 2.5 and Marc,1.5 beautiful children. They were shy to me and so I was shy to them.    We headed to the large surface grocery store and daddy put them all 3 in the cart. Oh-my-god what a cultural experience... 3 kids under the age of 5, all wanting this and that, hungry and all... All of a sudden I was a bit dizzy from the extra stimuli...      We headed home after a stop in the washroom for the little lady, and a stop at the mall children ride (they all had to get on the fake horse). We got into a little crisis in the elevator when one of the kids broke the applesauce jar and got spread all over from the elevator to the hallway in the appartment. Ahhhh, the joy of kids! (Can I go back cycling now???)    Dinner was another cultural experience for me, eating with 3 hungry monsters and making the faux-pas of opening the yogourt container for the little lady creating a major crisis as she wanted to open it herself... Oooops. Appologizing didn't work in restoring the peace and one of us got big crocodile tears all over the face...     Baths were following and story reading by daddy and finally the little angels were put to rest and an amazing quietly appartment offered me the time out I needed... 
We had a whole day to enjoy the kids. We decided to go to the beach and then go see the hand gliders at play as my brother is into hand gliding up to his ears. This would be my first car trip in ages, which made me worried a bit with 3 kids in the back and my heavy history of motion sickness. Fortunately the roads were pretty straight to the north end of the island and the kids were really quiet; in fact, all three fell asleep before we made it to the beach.  We were in tourist area and it showed.. Everybody was working on their tan, there was post card alley in the commerce area and also beach items on display. The beach was crowded and after dabbing suntan lotion to everybody we found a spot to lay the towels and kids toys. The water was warm and I ended up taking each kid one at a time for a stroll in the deeper area. That was fun. I was glad to practice my role of auntie for once.  Lunch was spent at... Burger King to the delight of the kids and I am sure they enjoyed every bite of their meal. Then we had a little session on the kids coin rides. As you can see in the pictures they had a lot of fun...        Then to the hand gliding, we climbed a rugged road up a hill for an awesome panorama of the bay and there were 5 or 6 men playing with the wind up in the air. I got to think if I was hand gliding myself and being sick up there, where the vomit would land?... (Sorry that is disgusting! )    We headed back home and got crepes for dinner and then we waved goodbye to the kids as their mother came and pick them up. I wonder if they will remember me? 
The stress at the airport was whether my bike would be ok without any kind of wrapping or not. It was a chance I was taking. We had brought some tools to remove the pedals but things got a little rushed and when I handed out my bike, I left it as is, and they took it! (No wrapping, no turning out the handle bars, no removing the pedals, just deflating the tires.) I didn't pay any supplement for all my bags however they didn't have any plastic bag to put everything together so I was worried the bungee cords would not hold. I found myself hugging my brother goodbye and boarding the plane soon after... Good bye Mallorca! Well wait! It got a bit complicated at the x-ray scanner where they discovered my Swiss Army knife in my carry-on panniers among my kitchen ware. They rewinded the conveyer belt and the officer made a sign to someone else to take me in a search room. In there the man told me to get my knife out. Oh-oh. I remembered now what was going on, that I forgot to switch around some of my equipment before checking in my luggage. Well, I thought fast, and seeing the condition of my grungy pocket knife, I was more than happy to hand it out and get out of trouble, board my plane and everybody would be happy. It didn't turn out his way... The man then told me to keep my knife but not to show it in the plane... Go figure, I guess each airlines has their own safety standards. In the states I would have been in trouble and could have possibly missed my plane for that.  Well that probably means that I don't look like a terrorist, which is a good thing. The connection in Barcelona was quite short, unfortunately, so no time to linger, shop, and walk around looking at the crowd. But that meant that I would make it to Paris on time, and get reunited with my sister afer 6 weeks of biking. Orly was the landing spot this time, and as Mario and Marika were a bit late I had the chance to examine my bike for any in flight injuries or anything at all, but no! All in one piece! I inflated the tires the best I could and loaded the bike when Marika and Mario arrived and complimented me on my tan and my shape. I guess this is what 6 weeks spent outside do to you right?  Mario and I negociated the subway and the RER (regional train) the best we could with the bike and we made it home without back spasms or almost. (Paris is very unfriendly for wheelchair accessible public transportation or girl with a bike having to take the subway instead of riding the crazy roads of Paris, a real nightmare) Soon enough we were back to their appartment with the cats and good company. Afer a little nap we went back around la Seine and splurged at a trendy restaurant for French style pizza and diet coke. Oh, didn't I mention the ice cream too? :-) 
We went in town looking out for little presents for my friends, and walked miles and miles it seemed. Nothing real exciting. Just the last day in town and having a few errands to run.  We headed back home in the afternoon and splurged in a little nap, and then I got on to the task of packing it in.  We waited for Mario to come back from work and went for morrocan cuisine, couscous and merguez sausages. That was quite yummy. However like many places in Paris they think people is like sardines and they sit you so close to one another you have the neighbor's breathe (and smoke) under your nose... So that was it uh, my last day in Paris... the last day of my trip. 
We left for the train station before noon, and it involved walking to a farther train station to avoid stairs. Bought subs at the train station, which we ate on the RER (regional train). The French trains are a cultural experience. There is always musicians, entertainers, beggers coming in your wagon, playing music loud enough and close enough for you to notice real well. Then they pass the hat. I don't like that kind of sollicitation, nor the people that can't help themself and light up a joint or a cigarette in the train while you start coughing.  You can't go anywhere, you have to submit to the smoke. Vancouver is good for that, with the bylaws there are no smoking at all in the restaurants and really soon in all public spaces.  I deflated the tires at the airport, slipped on the plastic bag, removed the pedals, turned the handle bars, put some bubble wrap around the derailleurs and other sensitive spots. The panniers were attached together, the sleeping bag, tent and thermarest was put in an airport plastic bag along with my stinky cycling shoes and other items and sealed with tape. Checking in was no problem at all, the bike was handed in and so we had an hour and a half to kill before the boarding so we went sitting down, and I splurged in a Mc Donald's caramel sunday! We talked about lots of things, a real sister to sister conversation. That was very pleasant. Goodbyes were just goodbyes. This time I knew I would see her soon as she was moving back to Montreal and I would visit in the fall. So I left her to go into the tunnels towards my gate and had to wait what seemed way too much time for the metal detector/search area. That cleared, I reached the gate and noticed that the plane was not there. I didn't think too much of it as my connection in London was of 2 hours so I had time if there would be a little delay in France.  Maybe half an hour after the scheduled departure, the plane arrived, was prepped for the flight, and we boarded. Small plane, geared for short flight. Uncomfortably tight. We left the gate to park on the tarmac. Apparently we were not allowed to leave. We waited there for an hour, believe it or not. It was hot, everybody had a connection to make in London and fuming. I didn't care too much about my connection. I was just tired to wait, and wanted to have more control over my time.     Eventually the plane left Paris and France behind and I found myself running in Heathrow as my plane was scheduled to leave by now. I was told they were waiting for me so I was rushing. I managed to leave behind my helmet at a metal detector control and noticed the loss shortly before boarding. I asked a cabin steward to keep an eye on my belonging and fetched my helmet and boarded the plane that would take me home. I had thoughts for my bike, hoping it would make it all in one piece. I needed it to ride home from the airport. The plane left late too as they were recounting the number of suitcases but eventually we were up in the air. The flight was uneventful but when we passed over Greenland, a lot of people were oohhhhing and ahhhhing. I stood up and had the same feeling when I saw the mountains and icefields down below. I wish I had  taken pictures. It was awesome.  Vancouver finally came and I was glad to stretch and walk in the airport. Custom was a pain in the ass, line-ups again, and of course, I always pick the slowest lane. I waited and waited for my checked in luggages, and after half an hour, after the conveyor belt stopped working, showed up at the British Airways counter and told them all of my luggage was missing. Bike included. I also lost my luggage tickets so it would make it harder for them to trace them. It sort of bothered me that I didn't get to ride home and had to call a cab. But the worse feeling was that my bike was still in England and I was home!  I was exhausted but also excited of being home. It would take a few weeks to put things in perspective.
Riding with partners has been rewarding in some ways, like companionship, looking after one another, pushing one's physical limits and motivations and exchange of services (food for mechanics). However it has some drawbacks, like feeling you can't really do what you want to do. Having to compromise. Putting up with one aonther when time gets rough, or when the conditions are less than perfect for instance.Add to this personnalities. So either you get closer or you distance yourself...  For those of you who are wondering, I haven't had any news from Jean-Francois despite e-mails. Oh well. Each and all of us make some choices in life, and that is ok. I think I have decided to enroll in bike mechanic courses, and will stock up in a few pairs of latex gloves on my next trip. Next trip??? Yeah there will be one. Keep posted.
What I needed was something to get me going.  One day - about 6 months before my 50th birthday, I received just the motivation that I needed - an invitation to join AARP. This invitation, arriving much earlier than I expected it, was a slap in my face, and a motivator - to get me planning my cross-country trip, rather than to pass into another decade with it as a dream. The planning was kept pretty simple. My wife bought me a book about someone else's trip across the country, and I contacted Adventure Cycling, ordering the map set for the Northern Tier route. After some minor adjustments to my 5-year old hybrid bicycle (rather than working on my 20+-year old bike, or buying a new bike), I picked a date to start and made plans for a route that would take me from the Atlantic Ocean in the Boston area as far as Buffalo, NY, where I would join the AC Northern Tier route.  My route parameters were simple: follow a similar line to Buffalo as I had followed in  a trip taken 20 years before; try to intersect with as many friends along the route as possible; and divide the trip into 2 week segments to comply with my office policy to limit consecutive vacation time to two weeks.  Using the AC Northern Tier maps, I estimated that I would require about 6 two-week segments to make the full trip across the USA. Assuming that I could ride two segments each summer, I would take 3 years to finish the trip. For some reason, this all seemed reasonable to me. With tremendous support and encouragement from my wife and children, I started to make my plans more and more firm, aiming for a start date of 3 June 2000 - starting while I was still in my 50th year. This journal follows the general form of my trip.  Each chapter is a two week segment.   

The first day I managed to get a little sunburn - perhaps I did not plan quite as well as I should have?  There are so many little things that can happen on a trip, both good and bad, it is hard to plan for them all. I started my journey at about 10:30AM, dipping my back wheel in the Atlantic Ocean, down at Fisherman's Beach in Swampscott, MA. (My friend Mike Gow called the house about 9:30AM and immediately asked me why I was not on the road already.  He also gave me my mantra for the trip "Why the hell are you doing this!!")  I followed the ocean for a short while and then headed west.  I found out immediately that I was not as ready as I had hoped.  By 35 miles I was tired and ready to stop, but I plugged along to my intended campsite in Bolton.  Most of the riding was in the cities surrounding metropolitan Boston.  By the later afternoon, I had started to get into less populated towns and onto quieter roads.  The roads were generally good, with a few difficult spots (narrow roads, soft/non-existent shoulders, potholes). I rode by a high school graduation ceremony in Maynard, MA.  From a distance I could not tell what it was - a game, a flea market.  As I approached, it ended and I could see graduates coming out of the football stadium still wearing their caps and gowns.  I am sure it was a very significant event to everyone involved, but I could not tell what it was from the outside. I camped at the Crystal Spring Campground in Bolton, which was fine.  Looking in one direction, I saw a quiet stream and trees.  Turning around, I was assaulted by RV campers with kids, TVs and radios.  Apparently, this site is the summer vacation spot for people in the area, rather than renting a cabin in NH or on the Cape.         
This day had a good start - a tough middle - and a good finish.  Being Sunday, I started the day at Mass, there being a church right down the street from the campground.  After Mass, I met an older couple who gave me directions to a local diner, Michael's Bridgeside Diner, in South Lancaster.  The directions and the diner were excellent.  The road was quiet, tree-shaded and downhill.  The diner was a classic, with good food and the proper diner "atmosphere." Leaving the diner, I met a local oil-delivery man, who gave me directions to get back on my main route, Rte 62.  Unfortunately, he did not warn me that Rte 62 was a difficult bicycle route.  When I plotted the route I saw that it went through the town of Princeton and near Mt Wachusett.  What I did not realize was that Princeton was perched about 3/4s of the way up Mt Wachusett.  The hill was unridable for me - not enough lung-power or leg-power.  As the day worn on (and I wore out), I realized that I would not make my campsite in Erving, so I detoured to the town of Athol.  I arrived in Athol as a parade was going through the town, in honor of the visiting Duke of Athol, of Scotland, after whom the town is named.  I skirted the parade and rode right in front of the reviewing stand. I found a motel and finished the day slightly behind schedule and tired.  The weather forecast is for rain over the next two days.
No rain in the morning - so off I went at about 8:30AM.  I followed back roads toward Miller Falls, but became lost and wasted about 7 or 8 miles of biking, and about an hours time, until I got put back on the correct road.  My map was outdated and a segment of the road is now listed as "impassable."  I can imagine how bad it must be, because I rode some dirt roads that required me to walk some steep rutted sections.   To be "impassable," the other areas must be completely destroyed. Once back on ridable roads, the day went fine.  By 1:30 or 2:00, I was at the foot of Greenfield Mountain, which I remembered from my trip in 1977 with PJ.  It was not easy, but I was able to ride it (I had been afraid that the previous hill that required walking were setting the scene for a very difficult and disappointing trip; now it appeared that I might be able to do what I intended).  Once on top of the hill, I rode the plateau toward No Adams.  The rain held off, although it looked threatening for most of the afternoon.  The end of the road included another hill, which was tough enough, but I had forgotten a series of ups and downs before I got to the big downhill into No. Adams.  I always find those ups and downs to be draining, physically and psychologically. The downhill into No. Adams was exciting and I arrived safely at the campsite, Historic Valley Campgrounds.  Dinner was a hamburger at a stand by a baseball field, where a game had just finished.       All downhill from here! 
I started out today, thinking that the storm might stay south of me again today.  I stopped for breakfast and a little drizzle had begun.  Within a half hour it was a steady rain.  I stopped at a laundromat, read for a while and had lunch - rain, rain, rain.  I headed for a motel and called it a day. I treated myself to a nice dinner and watched the US-Ireland game from Foxborough (thanks to Anne giving me the schedule).  It rained throughout the entire game - this was a big storm.
God bless Rte 346 through Ponall, VT. As I started this morning, I stopped to take a picture of Williams College in Williamstown, and mentally prepared to ride over the mountains between me and Schenectady.  While I was stopped I chatted with an older man out walking his dog.  He recommended an alternate route, going north to Rte 346, which would take me around the mountain.  It turned out to be a wonderful route, scenic, lightly traveled and relatively flat.  The upper portion of the ride included birds (hawks and red-wing blackbirds) and flowers to distract me.  I stopped for a snack at a small restaurant outside of Troy and had a pleasant chat with an older woman.  When I resumed my ride, I found that I was already at the city limits of Troy, about 5 or 6 miles better than I had thought - a nice surprise.  As I neared Troy and Schenectady, the road was less friendly to bicycles, but I managed to arrive safely at Tom and Cheryl Della Sala's, where I had a great visit and dinner.   
The day started off overcast, but the storm had passed and I was able to ride on.  I am basically following Rte. 5, along the Erie Canal/Mohawk River.  I kept thinking that I would "push on," but I found I was tired by the time I reached the KOA at Herkimer, and I crashed for the night.  The campground is nice, with a stream running behind my tenting area. I treated myself to a nice meal at a restaurant across the street, and saw a high school awards night being held in one of the function rooms.
The day's ride was tiring again, with the heat and rolling terrain.  If I had the time, I would take a short day or two, but I am trying to keep on schedule.  At least the area is pretty and the road is relatively smooth and traffic free.  I see quite a lot of animal life - a deer standing by the road watching me go by, rabbits and bunnies, and other unknowns rustling in the brush by the road.  I also see a fair amount of roadkill - skunks, raccoons, birds and turtles. I camped at the Green Lakes State Park, which is lovely, and includes a public golf course designed by Bobby Jones, with a clubhouse that serves pretty good pub-style meals.  Unfortunately a school group arrived at the campsite, adding to the noise level.  Then at about 3AM I had to get up and chase a raccoon away from the food on my bike.
Another hot day of rolling hills.  Today I rode through Syracuse, and it took me at least an hour to navigate the city traffic with stop lights and all. My plans were to rendezvous with an old friend, Larry Zimmer and spend the night at his home.  With the rolling hills, headwind and heat, I faded fast.  When I stopped at 2PM for food, I called Larry, and he just asked, "Where are you?  I'll come and get you."  About an hour or so later, I was struggling along, head down, melting in the heat.  I looked up and there was Larry standing by the side of the road, leaning against his car.  He was a beautiful sight to behold!  We loaded my bags into his car and he drove on about 10 miles into Seneca Falls, and I rode in on my bike (having some initial problems because my front wheel was so light).  It was nice to get off my bike. Larry gave me a ride to his home on a hill with a great view of Keuka Lake, one of the Finger lakes - it is a beautiful spot.  He and his wife gave me a great meal, pleasant company and a soft bed - perfect.     
Today was a good day.  Larry gave me a ride to another friend's lakeside cottage (Mike Gow).  There Mike and his wife loaded bikes in their car and drove me back to my stopping point in Seneca Falls.  Mike and I then had a delightful ride to his home in Mendon.  He knew the back country roads and he was a great riding companion. The day ended with rain for the last few miles, but a hot shower cured everything. The Gows have a beautiful home and they are wonderful hosts.  After showers and a beer, we went to visit another friend who had been battling cancer during the past year.  Dinner was a wonderful lasagna - sleep was in another soft bed - this bike touring can be pretty wonderful stuff!!
The riding was good today - a few hills but nothing too bad.  At one point, the wind was at my back, and I was going 18 MPH on a nice flat section of road.   Staying at a nice campground, but the ground is very wet,  When I talked with Anne and with Dawn Northwood, I found it had rained much of the day in Boston and in Buffalo.  I didn't realize how lucky I had been. Anne told me that she had heard from PJ, who was cutting his ride across the USA short because of a fall coming out of the Rockies.  I talked with him and he is OK, but disappointed
It took me about 5 hours to cover 25 miles because of passing rain storms and the usual city delays in Buffalo.  Within the city, I was riding on the sidewalk because the edge of the road did not allow safe travel for cars and bikes.  As I was riding along, a truck went by and splashed water all over me - it was as if an ocean wave had broken over me. At breakfast, I had a nice chat with an older couple who used to ride a tandem together.  At lunch, a local barber stopped and asked if I needed email access.  Evidently he had a computer in his shop down the street.  Nice offer, but I was within an hour of the end of the trip, so I continued on. I had a great visit with the Northwood family in Buffalo, the end of my first trip segment.
The ride was comfortable, but made for a long day, convincing me that I should fly back to Buffalo when I start segment 2.  Looking out the window, it was funny to realize that I reversing the efforts of the past 11 days.  Many times I had looked over the distance to see a passing train, wishing I were on the train.  Now I am on the train, realizing that travel by bicycle has some nice advantages - especially the chance to see the country up close, and the opportunity to meet people along the way. A cute blond meets me at the train station - it is great to be home!
Anne and my daughters, Emily and Hannah saw me to my flight from Hanscom Field to Buffalo, NY.   Met by Dawn Northwood after an "interesting" flight.  Delayed at the beginning to replace the radar, we flew through thunderstorms to arrive in Buffalo.  The radar provided the pilot with the proper view of the weather to avoid it all.  There were a few uncertain moments as the pilot explained several times that we would probably experience pretty serious turbulence, but that the plane was very sturdy and he had flown since the days of the DC-9 and was confident.  His constant reassurance convinced me we were is for a bad ride, but we were lucky and had no bumps at all. Sad news about an old friend.  His leukemia had recurred and he had died over the 4th of July weekend.   
A good day to start my trip.  Unfortunately, as I was packing, I grabbed one of the Adventure Cycle maps for the wrong section of the ride.  Fortunately, Ed had a map of the Buffalo area to get me onto Route 5, which is the main road to follow for a while, joining Rte 62 later on.  All went well until I approached the turn for Rte 62.  When I stopped at a gas station for directions, I met a guy traveling the same route as I am, and he had the correct AC map.  He helped me find my route for the day, and I was on my way - it pays to be lucky! As I was riding along, I noticed a parallel road closer to Lake Erie.  I detoured and found a small park area, where I stopped for a rest.  I chatted with a man and his grandchildren.  Evidently this was their private park and he was surprised that I had found it - but very glad to share it with me.  He also advised that my original stopping place, Dunkirk, NY was only about 10 miles away (at 2PM), and that I could get to a nice campground in Westfield, in about 25 miles.  I took his advice and did push on to Westfield, arriving tired but satisfied. I had a nice visit with a couple in an RV near my campsite, they were headed back to Long Island after a nice vacation. I popped a rivit on my front pannier, but I was able to fix it and re-attach the hook that hold the bag on the bike rack, using little plastic ties. The campground was close to the NY turnpike, so it was a little noisy, making for interupted sleep.     
Conneaut is pronounced "con - ee-ought."  Another nice day for riding.  I passed through parts of NY, PA and OH..  Compared to the MA and NY segment, this segment is flat.  While riding along, I passed some interesting farms - one had a list of everyone in the family who had attended Penn State. Going in the other direction, I started to see groups of riders.  Finally, I yelled over to one group and found they were a van-supported tour going from San Francisco to New Hampshire.  I was envious of their ease of travel. While riding I felt my thigh muscle tighten up - nothing like a muscle pull with 440 miles to go on the trip. Passing into Ohio, the road lost its shoulder - I hope that is not a presage of things to come. Camping in a site by the turnpike again tonight       
A great day, I was able to pickup the missing map at the PO in Ashtabula, OH.  The riding was great and the weather was super. While riding from Mentor to Willowich, I passed about 8 miles of stop-and-go traffic.  I was the fastest moving vehicle in either direction.  For a portion I even had a separate bike lane.  (I found out later that there had been an explosion at a gas plant by the turnpike, causing the turnpike to be closed and shunting all traffic onto side roads like the one I was riding.) I stopped in a motel about 10 miles east of Cleveland.  While it was comfortable, it looked a little seedy and I am afraid I did not sleep well.   
(Vermillion is named after the local red clay, which the Indians used for paint.) The ride today never seemed to get going.  The morning ride was through Cleveland - city riding is always slow for me - and I can feel the bike and equipment jar on each bump in the road.  The towns west of Cleveland are continuous suburbs of Cleveland so there is little "open road' to ride.  I find Ohio to be schizophrenic about bicycles - sometimes providing nice little bike paths and other times forcing you to ride on the sidewalk - with a one inch bump at each intersection - definitely not wheelchair corners. My leg is much better, though.  I bought some Sport Crme and it makes a big difference. During one of my stops, I had a nice talk with two people, at a gas station.  We were talking about distance biking and they said that they often see a portion of an American Lung Society ride - about 500 people riding West to East.  A woman added a comment about her son living in the Boston area (Bridgewater, actually). I did laundry today, and the woman at the laundromat talked about a couple that had stopped to do laundry two days ago - perhaps they were part of the West-to-East group who passed me the other day. Going out of Cleveland heading west, I began to go through some lovely suburban communities, and had some great lakeside views.  At lunchtime, I met a guy who stopped to talk about his plans to ride a century soon (on his own if I understood him correctly).  He currently does triathlons and was excited to talk about a long bike ride.  It was good to see someone else who was excited by my trip - it picked me up. The day has ended very nicely.  I am staying at a campground by Lake Erie.  I went for a swim in the lake earlier and I am now sitting on a rock quay watching the sun go down.   Later in the evening I went into a local bar and watched some baseball and had some interesting talk with the locals, including a young woman who wanted me to stay and chat (which her male companion did not seem to want), and a fellow who wanted to know whether he had made a good deal on a bike he just bought (and planned to ride home later - in the very dark of night, with more than a few beers in him).  I escaped unscathed, and retreated to my tent. Hopefully the next few days will go well - there is the threat of rain and I am leaving the AC route as I head toward Chicago.   
The wind was in my face for much of the day, and I am now in an area that is laid out like a checkerboard, with long, straight, flat roads running East-West and North-South.  Stecker Road runs East-West for about 12 miles - with a headwind the whole way.  Occasionally, the corn fields are high enough to block some wind, but open fields let the wind come right at you and make for tough riding.  Because the road was so long and unchanging, I decided to call home and bring Anne out onto the road.  Fortunately she was home and we had a nice chat, as I rode along.  Now we can say she has been on the road with me! I met another cross biker - Don Cockman, a retired Englishman, who is making his third crossing (first time alone).  We saw each other as we approached, so we both slowed down and had a nice visit for 20 minutes or so.  He is hoping to make Bar Harbor, ME and then bicycle down to Boston, MA for his flight home, by mid-August.  I invited him to visit on his way, as the most likely route he would follow into Boston passes within 1/2 mile of my home.  (He did indeed stop and visit for several days, and we gave him a ride into the airport.) Between Clyde, OH and Fremont, OH there is a bike path that is 6.5 miles long.  It was great (except for the headwind), providing a smooth, paved surface and no traffic - a great break from the road. As I exited the bile path and got back on the road, two rear spokes popped.  Fortunately, the town had a bike shop.  I called, got directions and they took me right in and fixed me up.  Great service. My legs are tired and sore by the end of the day.  I expect the constant stress of 65 to 80 miles per day are tougher than I expected - maybe I will take a short day tomorrow.
(Bryan, OH is the home of Ohio Art - the maker of Etch-a-Sketch.) Today was a nice day, good weather, good roads, and no problems.  I stopped in Grand Rapids, which is a small town on the Maumee River, with a lovely river walk park in its downtown area.  I had a nice chat with two men who were driving through the area, but nothing remarkable.
I reached the 1,000 milestone for my trip today! Finally, a day with very little wind - and what there was, was at my back.  To my surprise, the area of Indiana in which I am riding is similar to New England - with forests and rolling hills.  The forests are not as extensive as the New England forests and the types of trees appear to be different, but there is a similar feel as you ride through the area.  Fortunately, the hills are less steep and not as high as the hills I encountered in New England. My route joined US Rte 20, which concerned me because I know it can be a heavily trafficked road.  Fortunately, I joined the road at a spot where the road had been resurfaced, with a full shoulder in excellent condition! - all the way to La Grange (about 15 or 20 miles).   As I was riding along this new road, I was amazed that there were so many bicycle tire marks on the shoulder area.  There was also an unusual chipped look in the middle of the shoulder lane - between the tire marks.  After about  a half hour, the appearance of several piles of horse poop, and a particularly clear signpost, I finally realized that I was seeing the marks of horse-drawn carriages - I was in an area with a large Amish/Mennonite population. I stayed in a pricey campground - big, but not worth it to an itinerant like me.
I rode about 10 miles this morning before stopping for breakfast in Shipshewana, at a nice Amish restaurant.  Amish/Mennonite carriages are commonplace in Shipshewana, but I felt a little invasive when I considered taking pictures.  As I was riding out of town I decided that they are certainly a special part of the area and I should have at least one picture.  I prepared to photograph the next carriage that approached.  As the carriage approached, the driver, an older woman took out her whip and sped up to get by me - evidently she considered the picture invasive, as well.   I took two shots anyway.  I rode on through Middlebury, which was another beautiful town, with a large Amish/Mennonite influence. The rest of the day was delightful - the wind was at my back for most of the time, the roads were good and the weather was nice for riding.  Using my map and local directions, I was able to pick a nice route (County Route 36 and New Road) which gave me about 30 miles of good riding.  New Road (amusingly enough) even had a section of fresh roadway - so fresh, that I saw the roller finishing one end of it. This has been a great section of my trip. La Porte is a middle sized city that looks a little tired.  I stayed in a non-descript motel and ate at a mediocre family restaurant. I called ahead to make arrangement to meet Walt, my college roommate and host in Chicago.  Plans to meet for a short ride on the last day are still uncertain, even though tomorrow is the last day.   
The final day of riding in this segment was very nice.  The weather and road conditions were fine. As an added treat, the first part of the day involved a 30 mile ride to the Indiana Dunes National Park, a beautiful beach area on the lake.  I had estimated the distance at 50 miles, so I felt great when I was at the Park much sooner than I had expected.  Also, the county roads were good riding.  I only ran into about a 1 mile stretch of dirt/gravel, just before I arrived in the Park area. The second part of the ride was into and through Gary, IN and Chicago, IL, which was pretty typical city riding.  Busy streets - glass on the roadway - and delays because of a flat tire right outside of a steel plant in Gary.  A bit of a silver lining - two people stopped to see if I needed any help.  It was encouraging to see that people still look out for one another.  Fortunately, I successfully located and patched the puncture - so far only two flat tires, and two successful patchings. As it turns out, Walt was not able to ride into Chicago with me, but the ride eventually accessed a nice bikeway by Lake Michigan.  There were several beautiful views of Chicago as the bikeway wended its way along the lake shore.       
I had several days to visit in Chicago and saw quite a bit: riding by the lake, I saw a noontime jazz concert; I went to the Field Museum; saw a baseball game (Cubs at Wrigley Field); swam in Lake Michigan; had dinner with friends; and had a great time with my college roommate and his family. I flew home on July 29 and was glad to be back with my family again.     
Walt and I took a ride around Chicago and then I loaded everything back on the bike and was ready to go   
Walt and Alycia had breakfast with me and saw me on my way.  (Walt was heading off to play golf.)  It took me about 20 minutes to have my first mishap.  On an early Sunday morning I did not expect to see many people around (and I did not).  However, someone swung a door open on a parked car, and hit one of my front panniers, snapping the holding hook off.  I was able to do some roadside repair and was back on the road in 15 or 20 minutes.  It took me about two hours to clear the city and about four hours before I began seeing fields and birds (cardinals) and chipmunks. Outside of Chicago, I got onto the Illinois Prairie Path (a bike path) and the Geneva Spur.  The combined distance was about 20 miles and I was glad that I was able to follow the bike path for so long.   After the bike path, I began to follow Rte 38, which was my original route of choice.  As it turned out, Rte 38 was not a very bikeable road - it was busy and congested.  As a pleasant surprise, Walt was waiting along the side of the road, near where I had joined Rte 38.  He had decided to drive out Rte 38 after his golf match to see if he could catch me.  He had just decided to turn around when he saw me riding along.  It was good fortune because I had just gotten on Rte 38 about a mile earlier, having just come off the bike path.  It was great to see Walt - a boost to the day. At dinner, I overheard the people at the next table talking about riding a Century that day.  I interrupted and asked about possible routes west, and they gave me a suggestion, which required that I buy a local map book, but gave me a much better route to ride than I had planned on my own.  As in the past, local advice is good to get.           
Because I had heard that tomorrow should be rainy, I tried to push a little farther today, and was able to ride a hundred miles and reach the Mississippi River.  This day had everything.  The riding conditions went from great to grit.  Based on the advice of the people the previous evening, I was able to ride on back roads most of the way, but the roads turned to gravel on two occasions, the last including a hill that I had trouble walking up.  After that segment, I rode some rolling hills that took me from 32 miles per hour to 3.2 miles per hour.  Finally, I waved down a UPS truck to see if I had taken any wrong turns.  Knowing from my map that the road could be either Scenic Palisades Road or Scenic Georgetown Road, I asked which road I was on.  He said it is sometimes called both.  However, he did assure me that if I proceeded another couple of miles, I would be in Savanna - very good news.  (By the way, the next street sign I saw said that I was on Scenic Bluff Road - go figure.) Dinner and a bed were welcome tonight - rain is still forecast for tomorrow.   
I found that the Gideon Bible in my room had Psalm 14 and Psalm 53 appearing to be the same Psalm.
The early ride was very nice, once I crossed the Mississippi River, on an open grate bridge with two very narrow lanes, for two-way traffic.  Fortunately, I had an early start and had beat the traffic out of Savanna.  After the bridge, the road was great, the surface was pretty smooth, there was a shoulder and the traffic was not bad.  After a while, it began to get hilly and there were several hills that I had to grind over in my lowest gear, for up to a mile!  There were a couple of hill before I arrived in Dubuque, IA, which seemed like a nice little city on the river.  As I was biking through town, I met a local biker, Mike Hogan, who is a retired phone company worker.  He rode with me out of Dubuque for a few miles and proved to be a pleasant companion.  He said that he usually biked about 4,000 miles a year, but had to be a little careful since he had had a heart attack a couple of years ago, at 55.  Before we went our separate ways, he previewed the route for the next 30 miles or so - pretty, but hilly, and he was right.  He also assured me that I would be able to find a motel in Guttenberg, which was good to know. He was correct about the hills, there were several, but the ride along the river is beautiful in many spots.  One interesting site, although not exactly beautiful, came as I was riding up one hill. I came around a corner and saw a turkey vulture eating a dead rabbit in the middle of the road. I pushed on to Guttenberg and found a nice, inexpensive motel.  Guttenberg is a lovely town on the river.  It is only about 3 blocks deep, but has a nice road along the river, with a lock, which I always love to see.     
While I had foolishly expected Iowa to be flat and full of cornfields, I was learning that the land along the Mississippi is all hills and valleys.  The ride out of Guttenberg was interesting, starting out in fog by the river, I climbed a hill to leave the city, climbing out of the fog into beautiful sunshine.  The hills were hard for me between Guttenberg and Harper's Ferry and on into Lancaster.  In one 5-mile stretch, I had to climb two 1-mile long hills, in my lowest gear, which means I was going about 3.6 miles per hour.  Fortunately the downhills allow me to go fast enough that my average speed stays about 10 miles per hour.  Finally, the steeper hills seemed to be behind me, and I started riding on Rte 26, which had traffic, but also provided a wide shoulder (and seemed to follow a route that avoided the bigger hills).  On this road, I rode out of Iowa and into Minnesota. The route was more forgiving and I was able to spot some bald eagles soaring out over the river.  I saw a few live deer along this part of the route, and I "heard" turkey vultures taking off from trees by the road.  (As near as I can tell, the birds I saw just drop out of the tree they are in and fall through the branches to reach the proper speed to fly.  I could hear them crashing through the branches, and then I would see them fly out of the trees and rise up into the sky.  It was a nice humorous break in the routine.) When I arrived at my planned campsite in LaCrescent, I found that it was set up for RVs, and did not provide warm showers.  Being addicted to a shower at the end of the day, I pushed on into LaCrescent itself, about 10 more miles, and found the Ranch Motel, which was fine, and inexpensive.   I checked email today and did laundry.         
Stopped in Wabasha about 2PM, after about 65 miles.  Sat by the river and had lunch and cooled down.  Trying to call ahead to Lake City for a place to stay at night, I had to use AT&T because I was outside of the NEXTEL network.  Riding on toward Lake City, I stopped at a pretty overview area, to admire the view and to take another break.  While I was taking a picture of a historical marker, I heard screeching behind me and turned in time to see a sparking boat and trailer go by on the other side of the road, coming to a flaming stop about 100 yards down the road.  The trailer was followed by a logging truck that stopped about 200 yards down the road.  In front of me was a pickup truck with some blown tires.  Evidently the logging truck had run into the trailer, which had been attached to the pickup truck.  I was very happy that I had not been on the road when the accident occurred.  I was wary for the rest of my ride that day, which was less than two hours, thank God. Lake City claims to be the birthplace of the water ski.  There was a great campground run by the city, which was a good end to a hot and tiring day.  I was glad to get in some camping - the air was great and I was within hearing distance of the shore - a nice, lulling sound.
Hills again on a long, hot day!!  Why am I doing this trip again? Much of today was lost in a heat/hill-induced haze as I decided to push on to Osceola.  Of interest to me as I was leaving Lake City, I did notice a very large turtle by the side of the road.  On closer inspection, I decided that it had dug a nest in the sand by the road and was laying eggs.  A few hundred yards away was a pond/inlet from which it had come, I assume.  A nice sight and a reminder of how much more you can see when you slow down.  I spotted several lovely towns along the way, particularly Stillwater, MN, which was having a festival weekend.  It looked like a great place and I am sorry that I did not stop for more than a water break.  But, the distance was about 60 miles and I wanted to try to get in some more (which actually meant pushing on for 35 miles into Osceola). I crossed the Mississippi River coming out of Stillwater on a very bicycle unfriendly bridge - a narrow, busy roadway, with a mediocre sidewalk alternative.  As soon as I got off the bridge, I took my first right (following the AC map directions).  This turn put me on County Route E, "E" for "Egad, this hill is vertical!!"  After a difficult 1/4 mile walk up this hill, the route leveled out and was pretty good for a while.  I was getting so tired by the time I ran into another hill that I needed to walk.  After that hill, the road finally settled down and I made it into Osceola for the night. Dinner was good - sleep was better.   
Finally, I have made the turn toward the West - and flatter land.  There was rain in the morning, so I had to delay my start.  The day became hot, the wind was mostly in my face - and it took a long time to get where I wanted to go.  After I decided to go as far as Milaca, I called ahead to make sure that one of the two listed motels would have space for me (there being no campgrounds listed in the area).  The Super 8 Motel said that it was full - no vacancies.  The other motel had an answering machine.  Nervously, I arrived in Milaca and checked at the Super 8.  There was a dog show in town and the motel was indeed full.  I asked about the other motel and was told it was a little place and I got the impression that it was less than a reputable place.  When I arrived at the motel, there was a sign at the desk saying come back a 8PM.  I saw a woman drive up and check herself in (having made previous arrangements) so that I knew the place was open, at least. I went off to dinner, after leaving a note on the check-in desk.  While I was eating, a woman came into the sandwich shop, looked at me and asked if I was the biker looking for a motel room.  I said "Yes" and she said she and her husband ran the place and he was at the motel - and they did have a room (Thank God!). It turned out the motel was fine - clean, quiet, comfortable and inexpensive.  I have no idea why the clerk at the Super 8 was so strange about the place.
Today was full of everything.  The riding was great, cool wind at my back and level roads!  By 12:30PM, I had logged 60 miles - but I had been watching thunderstorms move in, first to the North and then filling from the Southwest.  I caught a little rain coming into Little Falls and saw some large, close lighting bolts.  I pulled into a restaurant for lunch, just as a hail storm broke.  After lunch I headed for a motel in town and settled in to weather the storms.  I did laundry and went to the local library to catch up on email.  While I was in the library, lightning strikes knocked out power two or three times.  Finally there was a break and I was able to take a short tour of the town - the park by the falls was lovely.  Then it was back to my room for a good night's sleep.   
Today was a near perfect day - sun, 70 degrees, wind at my back, and riding companions for a couple of fast-paced hours. While I was having lunch in the RK Cafe, I saw a bike rider come in for a phone call.  We chatted briefly - his name was Jim and he was traveling from Pittsburgh to Seattle with five college friends.  As I wanted to ride enough miles today to make Fargo by tomorrow, I declined an invitation to meet the group at the local park, and we went our separate ways. A few miles outside of town, I stopped for a bathroom break at a local general store.  As luck would have it, when I came out of the store, Jim and his friends were pulling in.  They had seen my bike and stopped to say "hi."  We rode on together toward Battle Creek.  It was a pleasant time - they were very personable riding companions, and they made the time pass quickly, and kept a nice fast pace, for me.  They were all college-age and were traveling on the cheap - staying on town greens or in people's yards/garages/etc.  They were building up a collection of great stories. We separated in Battle Creek where they were taking a break to swim in the lake.  They had explained to me that they tended to ride at a moderately fast rate, but to take long breaks, so their progress was less than they hoped for on some days.  I went on to Amor and stayed at a lovely B&B called "Aloft in the Pines."  It was a nice home on a lake, and I had the place to myself, only overlapping with the proprietress when I arrived, as she and her husband had evening plans and left for work early in the morning.  In the evening, it was great to sit in a screened porch and watch hummingbirds come to feeders in the yard. I had called the Fargo bike shop before I finished the ride today.  They are still ready for me, and I have a good shot at making Fargo tomorrow.   
The final day for this segment of the trip. After a very comfortable sleep at the B&B, I awoke to the sound of rain falling at 7:15AM.  I took my time getting organized and ready to ride again because the forecast was for gradual clearing.  By 9:15 I was ready and the rain had stopped.  Even though it was still overcast, I decided to start the day.  As I rode toward Fargo, the clouds became more distinct and began to show occasional breaks.  Finally, the sun was out and the wind was filling from the east.  This was a day on which I could feel myself riding fast.  At one time I looked down and saw that I was going 22 MPH, a good combination of a flat, straight road, and a good wind at my back. I followed the alternate route suggested by Tom at the bike shop in Fargo.  It turned out to be a very nice route - a great finish to the ride.  As I neared Fargo, the rain clouds began to gather.  I met a biker named Jim, who was headed back into Fargo, and guided me through the local streets.  He was an airline pilot and knew the group at Island Park Cycle.  I rode into Fargo and found the bike shop, the train station and the motel.  The riding portion of another stage is done - now for the trip home.     
Today I dropped my bike at IPC and hung out in Fargo.  I caught the 2AM train to Minneapolis

The two-day travel plans for my return to Boston was too much down time.  I don't think that I will do that again, even if it gets more expensive.
I need to make arrangements for leaving my bike somewhere over the winter.  It is difficult to estimate how far I will be able to ride, allow for weather delays, and still end up in a town that is near an airport and has a bike shop (or some other place to store my bike).   My guiding principal is to plan as best as I can, but rely on a little luck to help it all work out. I have heard back from the Havre Bicycle Center, and they will store my bike for the winter (thank you!).   
After an uneventful flight though Minneapolis, I arrived in Fargo, ND.  There was a big wind/rain storm passing through and I overheard the pilot comment that if we had been five minutes later, we would not have been able to land. I settled into a motel, picked up my bike and prepared for the next two weeks of cycling.   
  
I had a nice chat with the locals at one of the bars.  The people are very friendly, there just are not many of them around. Also, these people are familiar with the bicycle route I am following and have stories about previous cyclists passing through.  Some of the cafes have books to sign, or maps to place a pin in your hometown.   
A quiet day on the road - just me, the hawks, the frogs and the snakes.
The beginning of my ride was great, a light tailwind and cloud cover to keep the temperature down.  I reached Rugby, ND (the geographical center of North America) about 12:30PM.  I stopped for pictures and food and water before heading on to Towner (tow - ner), which was about 25 Miles away.  I considered pushing on to Minot if the tailwind held.  As I left Rugby, I was on a four-lane divided highway.  About two miles down the road, I saw another bike traveler, unfortunately we were on opposite sides of the divided highway, so we merely waved and kept going our separate ways. By Towner, the wind had swung into the South, but was not a problem, so I decided to push for Minot.  As luck would have it, the wind became a lot stronger, so even a crosswind was tiresome.  Then the cloud cover cleared and the sun beat down on me.  While I had plenty of water, the water itself got so hot that it was not refreshing me at all.  I had about 22 miles to the next town (Granville), so I just plodded along.  I saw more tumbleweeds b;ow across the road.  When I arrived in Granville, I found out that the campground did not have showers, so I decided to continue on and make Minot before sundown.  Minot would have motels and showers and beds - a real incentive.  About 10 or 15 miles outside of Minot, the wind swung from the South, into the West (a headwind), and then into the North.  When the wind swung into the North, the temperature dropped about 15 degrees.  I could breathe again, and was able to finish the day's ride with a little more strength.  (I heard later that Minot set a record for the temperature on the date - 104 degrees.) After dinner, I saw the skies lighting up with lightning - very impressive.  It looked like that scene in "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" when the space ship arrives in an approaching thunderstorm.   
Minot has the first library I have seen on the trip, so I have taken advantage of computer access, as well.  I am not sure what access will exist during the rest of my trip.
The land is beautiful, the rolling hills remind me of the way the West was portrayed in the old Westerns.  It makes me want to ride off on a horse.  My experience with horses has always been poor - so this desire is not natural. New Town was created from two separate towns in the 1950s, when they dammed the Missouri River in this area, flooding the two towns.  The town is in the Fort Berthold Reservation and the facilities are not luxurious.  However, the motel was adequate, and gave me a warm place on a night with temperatures in the lower 40s.  If the night temperatures stay low, I think I will be using motels more than camping over the next week.   
"The bear went over the mountain, the bear went over the  mountain, the bear went over the mountain, and what do  you think he saw.   He saw another mountain, he saw another  mountain, he saw another mountain, and what do you think  he did.   The bear went over the mountain, the bear...." It seemed as if I was that bear today. There was nothing to look at except the scenery, which again was lovely.  As I have noticed during my ride in North Dakota, people driving by are very likely to wave as they pass.  I think that they realize that there is no other human contact because there is nothing on the side roads that I am using. I am staying in a very nice motel that provides a computer in the lobby.   Tomorrow I cross into Montana - the mountain time zone.   
I had planned on a short day, taking an easy breakfast and going to church (doesn't hurt to have God on your side).  I thought it would be an easy day, but a combination of the wind and some small hills made it a more difficult ride than I anticipated. I did meet two men who were riding from Bremerton, WA to Devils Lake, ND.  When we met, I had come 30 miles from Williston (their destination for the day), and they had come 50 miles (from Poplar).  I just didn't feel as if I had 50 miles in me, so I decided to cut the day at Culbertson. I stopped at the Culbertson Museum, which gave an interesting (eclectic) view of the area.  Two older women were the curators/guides, and the museum is an odd collection of things from people's attics and barns, mixed with some items people have been collecting for years.  It ranges from historical to hysterical.  It was a very nice break,   
At Wolf Point, I did laundry, and stopped at a Post Office to mail my camping gear home.  The nights are too cold for me to be sleeping comfortably on the ground, and the weight is just an extra burden now. Today, I had an interesting experience.  I was riding on a side road, which is parallel to Route 2 (the main road across northern MT).  I was riding a nice flat road, with the wind at my back, and about 10 miles of clear road ahead.  I was wondering about this lone house by the side of the road, when I heard and quickly saw a pack of about 6 or 7 dogs racing from the house toward the road - and me!  Thank god I was on a flat road with the wind at my back.  By the time I passed the driveway break in the fence (through which poured the dogs), I was going about 20 MPH.  The largest dog, a german shepard, chased me for about a quarter of a mile, but seemed to lose heart when we reached about 24 MPH.  Needless to say, my heart was pumping from the exertion and the fear of being eaten. Wolf Point is on the Fort Peck Indian Reservation, and is a city of some size, for the area.  It is a little run down, but nice enough.  It has a pleasant little park area, with a gazebo, where I sat and read while my laundry was washing.  In front of the gazebo there is a plaque explaining that the gazebo is a reconstruction of one from 1917.  The reconstruction was provided by the son of a couple that settled in the area in 1915, before there were roads, water, electricity, or phones.  The plaque goes on to say that the ranch that they established is still owned by members of the family - and that this couple helped to bring civilization to the area (I can't help but think that some of the reservation Indians might take offense at this plaque, although there were no signs of vandalism.)   
The highlight of the day was lunch at "Bergie's" in Nashua, MT.  The place boasts a soda fountain which has been in the town since 1932.  It was nice to talk to some people, also.
Another beautiful riding day.  The tailwind was strong all day, which allowed me to stop and read the historic markers along the route and to take food breaks, while finishing 75 miles by 3PM. Talking to people today, it is incredible how many people in Montana have relatives in NYC or Wash DC, showing the wide reach of the attacks yesterday.   
Again, the day is beautiful.  Montana weather seems to start each day a little cloudy and cool, with the sun burning through by mid-morning.  I have been very lucky that there is a low pressure area passing south of me and giving me strong winds from the East.  If it had been a high pressure area, I would have fought headwinds.  A couple of times in the past two days, I have ridden back on the road for one thing or another.  When I turned and headed East, the wind would drop my speed by 3 or 4 miles per hour, and cause me to increase my effort.  I am ever thankful for tailwinds.
I dropped my bike at the Havre Bicycle Center and had a nice talk with Roger, the owner.  He is planning a ride of the Southern Tier route, with his son this Fall.  He said he would take good care of the bike and would see me in the summer. My trip home begins tomorrow morning and I hope all goes smoothly.     
The flight home did go well indeed.  I had re-routed to arrive in Providence, RI rather than risk problems/delays at Boston.  Fortunately my family was able to make the connection in Providence and we had a very happy reunion when I arrived.  Glad to be home!
I will try to stop by monthly to make notes on my progress. 6 March 2002 Well, I am still struggling with my training schedule, although I have established an indoor area for an exercycle and NordicTrak ski machine and have been able to start logging in about 90 minutes on weekend days and 45 minutes of several week nights each week.  The weather broke for one Saturday and I was able to ride for about two hours, including a route with some gentle hills. 29 April 2002 I have finally been able to settle into a routine of riding outside.  For the past several weekends, I have been able to ride 30 or 40 miles on Saturday and/or Sunday, and I have begun bicycling a portion of my daily commute, adding about 14 miles each weekday. 28 May 2002 For the past few weeks, I have been commuting to work, roughly 30 miles per day, roundtrip.  I feel that I am in as good or better shape for this portion of the ride as I was for previous portions.  I have two more weeks to get it all together, so I intend to spend my evenings getting all of the information I need into travel format.  This time is the antsy time, when you are mentally getting on your way, before you can actually start - a nerve racking time.
When I checked my bag through to Havre, MT, the agent in Boston commented that this was the first time that she had ever checked anything or anyone to Havre, MT. The flights were fine and everything arrived as planned.  My bike was ready and I am re-loading the bags, ready to start the last part of this journey tomorrow.
Today was a good beginning.  The wind pushed me so that 100 miles felt like 70.  The rain held off for most of the morning, which helped.  Unluckily, I did have to negotiate two muddy sections - as described by a local woman as "6 miles of the worst mud you will ever see, I dont know how you will get by."  Fortunately, one of the muddy sections had an unused side that I could ride - gravel but not too bad.  The next muddy section was completely unrideable and I had to do some off-road riding. The rest of the riding day was wet and cold, but I reached Shelby and a nice motel. Already I have seen several live deer running through fields by the road.  You don't have to go far out of Havre to get into the rural parts of Montana.     
After about an hour of riding, the day settles into a steady rain - a cold, steady rain. I had planned to ride to East Glacier, but in Cut Bank when I stopped for some food and to warm up, I was told by a couple that they had just come from East Glacier, which had no power and was sending all of its guests away.  I called forward to Browning, the town I would reach before East Glacier and I was told they had power and were open for guests. I pushed on. The day was just a wet, cold ride, culminating in a final 5 mile section, during which I rode into an increasing wind along fields covered with about 5 inches of snow.  I found out later that the wind chill factor was about 27 degrees F.  My fingers and toes were well aware of the chilling combination.  (It took me about 10 minutes to warm up enough to sign in at the hotel at the end of the day.) While I was warming up and waiting to register in the hotel, I chatted with fellow guests including a returning local who preferred to refer to me as a crazy whhite guy on a bike - to distinguish me from the locals on the reservation.  The other person I met was a man from California, Dan Potash, who had grown up "back East".  When I said I was from the Boston area, he said he grew up just north of Boston, in a small coastal town called Swampscott, which is the town where I started this journey - talk about your small world!   

Today was a great day.  While it looked a little threatening and many advised that the pass would not be great for a bicycle, I took the advice of some electric power workers and headed along (Boredom comes fast in the town of Browning).
