The ride was great.  I reached Marias Pass before I expected to.  When I thought that I had about 10 miles more to go, a passing trucker gave me a big honk from his horn and a thumbs up sign.  I thought how nice that he was encouraging me.  Around the next bend I saw a small sign that said:  Marias Pass, Continental Divide, Elev 5,280. I had made it! I stopped at a roadside area dedicated to the first white man to floow the pass through this area.  It was a chance to warm up and savor the moment.  There was a woman who pulled in who wanted to take my picture - just to prove there was a crazy guy riding a bike over the Continental Divide, in the snow.  She was kind enough to take a picture with my camera, as well. The rest of the ride was basically downhill, with beautiful scenery.  An added advantage to crossing the Divide was a drastic improvement in the weather - warmer and less snow on the side of the road.           
The ride from West Glacier to Eureka was straight and uneventful.  The town of Whitefish is a nice little place, with a street that still looks like an old western town.  As I passed the local bike shop, I saw two loaded bikes outside.  I stopped to see who was traveling through.  There were two guys inside who were both named Smith and were traveling together from Missoula, MT to Anchorage, AL (Jeff Smith from Kansas; Ralph Smith from Philadelphia, PA.  They told me that they had also experienced similar bad weather, and had even ridden through some snow (for those of you who think I might be crazy - even I have my limits - no riding in the snow - yet).  We chatted for awhile took pictures, and then I was on my way.  It was nice to see other travelers.   
Today was a beautiful day, and my route followed a lake for about 55 miles.  The area is very similar to the Finger Lakes in New York state, I assume because glaciers carved both areas.  While the guide book indicated that the route would be mostly flat, it was rolling hills for the 50-odd miles that ran by the lake.  I did see two osprey sitting by their nest, in a tree by the lake. I am told that the nests are added to each year by the birds and become very heavy, eventually weighing tons.  Later, I saw another osprey fishing for dinner (watching him I almost drove off the road).  Another treat was watching a moose walk across the road about 500 yards in front of me. As I came to the end of the lake, I met a fellow rider, heading in the opposite direction.  We stopped and chatted for a while and I commented that his bike had a lot less equipment than my bike had.  Basically, he was riding with two bags, which were about the size of the smaller two of my four bags.  He explained that he had so much trouble going over Washington Pass that he had shipped most of his equipment an clothing home.  He was down to three sets of riding clothes with some cool weather pants and tops.  He was down to the minimum (or below).  It showed the variety of approaches you see on a trip like this one. The final 15 miles took me from Libby, MT to Troy, MT.  The road was pretty busy and the side of the road was sandy, holding the shattered remains of beer bottles (truly a hazard of the road).  The day had become hot by now, and I was glad to reach the end of the day's ride. I arrived in Troy and had time for a nice dinner and a welcome shower - the simple joys.           
Another beautiful day, and a better route for riding (although I must admit that at least once a day I thoroughly curse the drivers on the road, and/or the route makers at Adventure Cycling). Today I reaped the rewards of riding through the sand/glass coming out of Libby - a flat tire.  Before I fixed the tire, I checked for the cause and found a brown-tinted wedge of glass stuck in the tire.  I pried it out to prevent continuing problems, and then I replaced the tube. Today I saw a number of other people taking tours, all going West to East.  All of them mention the 5 mountain passes that I have to ride in Washington state.  For some reason no one smiles when they mention the passes.  Mostly they just mention that it takes time.  One group did mention that they did not enjoy coming down the 26 mile downside of one of the passes because it was snowing.  (Ah, for the adventures of the open road!) I am in Clark Fork, ID in a very nice little library.  I have about 30 miles to go to get to Sandpoint, my destination for the night.   
Today was an "easy" day.  I did laundry and had a leisurely breakfast to start the day.  As I was getting ready to begin the day's ride, I saw Sandy Dardenelle & John Bracklow, with whom I had exchanged emails.  It was amazing that we ran into each other because neither of us were "on the route" at the time we met.  At first we did not raealize who were had met. Actually we were chatting for a while and they began telling me about a detour I would need to take in about 20 miles.  When I pulled out my map, Sandy asked why my map differed from their map.  I explained that my map was a couple of years old because I had started in June 2000, and was doing the ride in segments.  John looked up and said, "Are you Dave?"  I looked and said, "Are you John and Sandy?"  Proper acknowledgements all around determined we were indeed who we were. We had a nice visit and exchanged road details, happy that we had met, and then my day began. Except for the heat of the day, it was beautiful riding - relatively flat, a slight tail wind, and not much traffic.  I met a group of 5 college-aged riders, who were drying in the sun, after a cooling dip in a local river.  I was tempted to jump in and cool of as well, but realized if I got too comfortable, I would not ride the final 20 miles to Usk.  A few miles outside of Usk, I stopped for a breather.  Hearing a rustling sound in the woods, I looked around and spotted two deer running deeper into the woods. Tonight I stayed in the Hotel Usk, run by a very nice couple.  The man's father had lived in Ipswich, MA as a young boy, which was a nice connection.  Usk is a community center of about 5 buildings, which include a bar and the Usk Hotel, fortunately.  The Usk Mall is hardly a shoppers paradise - although they do buy and sell antlers.     
Today is Father's Day and I was able to speak on the phone with both of my daughters (Emily and Hannah) - so it was a great day! The ride today was very nice.  The first 30 miles were flat and along a river.  There was a steep 5-mile climb that gave me a preview of the climbs I will be doing over the next several days.  The good news is that I made it. While riding today I met a couple who had just retired and were riding across the country.  The woman had injured her knee, so she was driving their van for a while, but she intended to get back on her bike soon.  They were headed to Falmouth, MA - again an easy connection. (Has Rome so faded in its glory that all roads now lead to Boston?) I also met two young women who were crossing the country - doing the entire trail from Anacortes, WA to Bar Harbor, ME.  We talked about the route a little and I learned that they had taken the Curlew alternative route, which I was considering.  They said it was beautiful, but that the climb into Curlew seemed as if it would be very steep going in my direction (because it was a great downhill for them).  I was already leaning toward following the main passes on the assumption that they would be the most consistently graded, for truck traffic.  These comments convinced me.  (We'll see.) Animal spottings for the day:  One black bear, who walked across the road in front of me and was sitting in a field as I went by a few minutes later - he stood up tall, looked at me and ran away (I didn't think that I had become that wild looking on the road). (Don't bother looking for a bear picture - I was happy enough to pass by with as littell fuss as possible.) Several deer at various points on the route Two hawks flying over a field on a detour I followed, because the main road was torn up for repaving.
Another beautiful day.  This day is the first of the days for riding over mountain passes.  I have decided that I will enjoy the trip much better if I plan to ride one pass each day.  Today's pass is Sherman Pass (elevation 5,575 feet).  (I was told that it is the highest pass in Washington state, but have not confirmed this myself.) The ride was long and challenging, but I made it.  I find that riding hills is a combination of legs, gear ratios, the grade of the road and energy level.  My setup is just making it, and as my energy level sinks, the effort is harder.  I am not sure that I could do two passes in a day, if I tried. Again I met a nice couple traveling east.  As usual we chatted for a while and were on our way.  We had a very pleasant visit because I had just ridden through the Pass, which made me feel good, and I was able to tell them they had only a few hundred yards to the Pass, which made them feel very good. I am staying in Republic, which seems like a very nice town.  The Library has computer access, and another group allows travelers access also - a very considerate town.     
Today's ride went well.  The climb through Wauconda Pass (elev. 4,310 feet) was not very difficult.  About 5 miles before I reached the pass, the weather got stormy - strong winds followed by about 10 minutes of hail (instead of rain) followed by strong winds again.  The entire "storm" took about 20 minutes and then it settled down to overcast.  About 30 minutes later, I started to hear thunder rumbling behind me, but I had passed through the storm before it developed fully.  (I heard on the evening weather report that the area I passed through had thunder and lightning for much of the day.  Fortunately, I had avoided it.) Later in the day I had a few brief showers, but nothing serious. I met two young men (late 20s??) who were riding East.  We discussed the route, and they seemed to be taking a perverse pleasure in the mountain passes.  When I told them that they were approaching a mile-long hill that was listed as a 6% grade, they just smiled and said, "Oh yeah, we're used to those."  I envied them their young legs.       
Today's climb was through Loup Loup Pass (elev. 4,020 feet), which was more difficult than I had anticipated.  I met and chatted with a retired woman who was traveling with another couple (each day, two would bike and one would drive their van, with all of the equipment).  She said that she considered Loup Loup Pass to be harder than Washington Pass (which made me feel better).  As we talked, however, she paused and said, "Of course, you will be riding up the other way, which seemed pretty steep."  (So much for "feeling better.") I stopped for lunch in a touristy town called Winthrop (I have noticed a number of town names that are similar to town names around Boston).  The town is designed like an old west town - wooden sidewalks, overhangs over the sidewalks, old-fashioned signs, etc - but everything has the look and smell of new wood.  The effect is pleasing, none the less (perhaps made more pleasant by the fact that it is a lunch break - away from riding time). Tonight, I am staying at the Mazama Ranch Resort - a motel/riding resort, with a very nice Inn and restaurant.  It is very comfortable - a good preparation for  a full day I have planned for tomorrow.     
Today was a good ride.  I combined distance with a pass crossing, but it took a long time.  Today, I crossed Washington Pass (elev.  5,477) and Rainy Pass (elev. 4,855), which is sort of an addendum to Washington Pass.  While Washington Pass had some steep sections, I was able to climb it much faster and more easily than what I had dreaded.  (As is often the case, I worried this task into a bigger effort than it really required.) The downhill run was pretty nice - still beautiful scenery, and not much pedaling for about 15 miles!  This section has been beautiful, the mountains are awe-inspiring and now there are plenty of streams and rivers and cascades coming down the sides of the mountains.  One benefit of the cascades is a bit of natural air conditioning - as you pass the streams and cascades, the air is chilled, providing excellent cooling. Today I saw several deer, as I have on most days.  I even saw a wild rabbit.  I would have ridden by the rabbit completely unaware, except that it moved and made enough noise to attract my attention. Tonight, I am staying at the Clark Cabins motel.  One of their claims to fame is the 150 to 200 domesticated rabbits roaming the grounds.  Today is rabbit day, I guess.                 
After the mountains of the past several days, today has been more ordinary - fairly flat roads and routine scenery (similar to New England roadside scenery).  The miles seemed slower today, perhaps because I am nearing the end of my trip. As I approached Anacortes, I had some anxious moments trying to coordinate a rental car to get to the airport in Seattle.  Finally, everything fell into place nicely and I was able to finish the ride in the official ending location, a small park with access to the water.  I dipped my wheel in the water and had a local visitor take some pictures.  I called home to share the news - and the trip has ended! I had a wonderful dinner at a restaurant called the Nantucket Inn.  I had a full meal, which was well prepared and I ate everything, including a slice of very nice cheesecake.  The restaurant was lovely, there was a cool breeze blowing through the windows on this balmy evening - a great finish! (Note: at one point I had planned to ride a portion of the Olympic Peninsula, but that portion of the ride was just not practical given my timing, the logistics and the issue of traffic.)               
It was great to walk out of the passenger area and see a cluster of familiar faces waving and holding up a welcoming sign - a special thanks to those who were able to join Anne and Hannah: my brother Pete, and the Geraghty family (Tim and Nancy and John and Elizabeth).  Thanks also to the many others who have been so encouraging to me - just another crazy guy on a bike.   
Now that my journey is complete and I have had time to gather my thoughts and complete my journal, I want to take a few minutes to try to wrap it all up. While I was going through the planning and riding of my journey, there were two common questions:  Why are you doing this?  (a variation included: Are you doing this to raise money?); and Do you listen to music on the road? There are many answers to the first question, but primarily, I did this ride as a challenge to see if I could do it.  It was wonderful to see friends along the way and to see the country 'up close and personal,' as they say, but the continuing drive was to ride all the way across the country.   On the variant question, I did not do this ride as a fund-raiser, although many people do a wonderful job combining the effort with fund-raising - just not part of my ride. Because I did a solo ride, many people thought about the loneliness of the ride and wondered if I listened to music on the ride (hence, the second most common question).  Actually, the thought never occurred to me.  During my last segment I did bring along music, which Anne had prepared for me - something both inspirational to get me over the mountains, and whimsical to keep me amused.  I listened to the music on a few evenings and during a few days of riding.  However, I found the music could be distracting and get annoying as I got tired, so I did not make it a regular part of my routine.  For me, lonliness was not a serious problem - there were moments, but not many. Now that I am finished with this trip, almost everyone asks the same question: Where are you going on your next bike trip?  Interestingly, this trip has dominated so much of my time since June 2000, that I do not have any plans for future bike trips, as big as this one.  There are many things that I have pushed to the background.  Now I would like to spend time on those parts of my life.  Hopefully I will still have time for one or two short, local trips on my bike, but nothing extended, for now. The final photos that I include here include a picture of Don Cockman - a friend from the road - and me, with a cake that was prepared to celebrate the completion of my trip.  The second picture is a close-up of the caketop - the wonders of technology, they transferred a photocopy onto the caketop, in frosting. Finally, I want to thank everyone who supported my journey, especially my immediate family, but also my friends, and the people I met along the road, and the people who read this journal and wished me well.  For me this has been a wonderful experience, something that I thought about doing for a very long time, and I am glad that I was able to attempt it, and to complete it.  I hope that each of you is able to experience something as fulfilling in your own life. My best to you all, Dave     
thats the what, and im sure you're curious as to the why, or you wouldn't be here. hopefully, you already know the why, but ill type it up anyhow... about two years ago, while working as a bike messenger in manhatten, i got bronchitis. this kept me out of work for a week. as it was clearing up, i headed out to a bmx video premiere in binghamton new york for a weekend of drunken rowndiness and debauchery. it was a blast to say the least. upon returning to my brooklyn apartment, i found myself with a complete lack of desire to go to work. so i didn't. several months later i found myself with this great job, getting paid to ride my bike around different towns in long island taking pictures of intersections. i was loving it, the pay was great, i saw new towns, got exercise and fresh air. after a while though, i just decided that work isn't for me, no matter what work it is. for some reason, i had a permanent case of 'office space'. i dragged it out, working a few days a month, and selling some of my artwork to help finance my rent. i thought about buying some cheap land out in nevada or alaska and living off the grid for a while. then i thought about riding out to whatever land i purchased. then i thought about just riding around and seeing the country, continent, land mass, world whatever before i settled on one place. then i thought about all the places i ever wanted to go mountain biking, and the fact that this would allow me to ride those places.  so i regrettably told my roommates that i would be leaving them at the end of may, which i did, and doing a pretrip out to colorado, back to massachusetts, then down to the southwest and mexico. the plans were abridged, but within four days, i will be leaving for my southwest/mexico trip, which will be another journal. this one is about my "test" trip, a two week, fully loaded tour up to pedrosfest, to visit friends in new hampshire and back. all distances are approximate based on past experience, maps, and time out there. i dont use a cycling computer. 
2 weeks of travel= $86 lodging= $0 bike repairs= $0(bomber single speeds are pretty worry free) food= $86
bags: blackburn hydrasack backpack w/100oz bladder jandd handlebar bag(three point, mounts on top of stem) jandd large mountain panniers, rear sleeping gear: sleeping bag in outdoor research waterproof compression sack. never taken out. used only as something to sit on around camp. eureka backcountry solo tent*highly reccomended for taller folks travelling alone. thermarest foam sleeping pad coccoon sleeping bag liner, what i used if anything to sleep in. camera:sony dsc-s75128 meg memory stickusb connectorfive batteriesbattery charger all in two ziplock bags, one inside the other. other gear:surveyors compass. came in very handy for approximating distances and making sure i was going the right way.rand mcnally road atlas maps. i cut the pages out of my big road atlass. a couple of roads near my home werent on there, but i knew them so it didn't matter. pocket knife50 ft nylon rope 10 liter dromedary bag msr water filter 1 small led headlamp(lost) vistalight system for night riding(lost one charger) trek handlebar light for backup and night riding on the road 4'x6' tarp 'survival candle' winding camp clothesline(never used) waterproof matches6 ft cable combination lock. used it once or twice. probably never needed it.  'kitchen':spoon/forkcondiments(sea salt, raw sugar, oregano in ziplock bags)asthma herbs(mullein, coltsfoot, both gathered and dried by me)drink mix(crystal light in ziplock bag, makes more by weight than anything else)energy food(honey and finely ground black walnuts(equal parts), mixed together with a little sea salt. very good, very sustaining) bike tools: roll of duct taperoll of electrical tapesurly jethro tool three way allen wrench channel lock pliers random small allen wrenches patch kit high pressure hand pump magura bleed kit(i havent had to touch this set of maguras other than to change the brake pads twice in the 5 years i have had them, but you never know) clothes: 3 ss riding jerseys 2 ls riding jerseys 1 long sleeve liner jersey 2 polyester button down shirts 1 bib bringing less clothes. i had several items that i never used during the two week period. i will also be leaving the sleeping bag at home, and bringing just the liner and a wool blanket. this will save some weight, but mostly space. i can roll up my sleeping pad, then roll that in the wool blanket and it stays put. this way, i only need to unpack one item (aside from the tent) to go to sleep comfortably. i will also be bringing a goretex rain jacket that i have had, as well as the poncho. on this trip i packed all my food in my backpack. next trip i will be using my insulated trunk bag for all food, and brobably camera as well. im having a friend meet me in vegas, at interbike with my big ass messenger bike chain. i dont trust that dinky cable lock out there. he'll be bringing it back to new jersey with him when he leaves.

i eventually made it to bear mountain bridge, but not before snagging the corded tie downs on my new, expensive panniers and snapping one of them. it was a simple fix, but bothersome nonetheless. bear mountain bridge was under construction, so i took the only logical route for non-motorized traffic, the footpath. unfortunately the bear mountain bridge footpath is not even wide enough to easily get my bike w/panniers across. one side or the other was rubbing a part of the bridge the whole way across. i was lucky i suppose, that at this point in my trip, i had my knobby tires strapped to the outside of my panniers, so they worked like bumpers. once across, i am on bike route 9d for quite some time. through cold spring. called my old roommate aaron to let him know i rode through his home town. the pictures below were taken right above cold spring. one is the tunnel with generous shoulder that i rode through, the others are (i think)9w where it is cut into the face of a cliff. i couldn't be sure as there was a hudson river between the cliff and myself. then there is a shot of the mountain right before the tunnel, shrouded in mist.         rode right past the road i was supposed to take, and knew it the whole time. ended up riding all the way up to poughkeepsie, where i stopped at a very helpful bike shop to ask for directions. one of the employees offered to fill up my water bottle and bladder(camelback). on the way to the sink, he decided that the hose would be a better idea. so we walk out behind the shop, he attatches the hose, and i go to work filling my fillables full of what fills such things. i thank him, get back on the bike and take off on the excellent connector route they sent me on. only, 100 ft across the parking lot, i noticed this strange and horrible taste in the water from my camelback. so i tried my bottle as well. it was like a mixture of bug spray and rubber, obviously from the hose we used. oh well, press on. it was a ways before i found a convenient stream to filter water out of, but even in doing so, that wretched taste stayed in the water bladder for three days.   once i connected with 44, it was fairly smooth sailing. steady drizzle the entire way, except for that torrential downpour around 5:30, south of millerton. on the one downhill during the downpour, a car pulled up next to me, the guy rolled down the window and shouted "37mph!!" with a big grin on his face. i responded with an equally large grin and we parted ways. millerton is a neat little town. i sat in the gazebo across from their bike path that didnt head in my direction for about an hour. i just sat there, eating grapes and drying off. finally got up and back on the bike, up the short steep hill, and down the road a little bit, where i spotted an american legion post. im SAL, so i stopped in, changed into dryer clothes, had a few sodas, chatted with the locals, signed the guestbook. i asked if i could camp under thier pavillion, but the man in charge said he didn't know if it was ok by the local law, and didn't show any interest in finding out. so i rode off to route 41, which crosses the appelachian trail twice, and brings me through the northwest corner of connecticut and into massachusetts. i cant remember for the life of me if i camped in ct, or ma, but it was in a grassy area right near a trailhead. i dont think it was the at though, just a connector perhaps. 
      
after the sky seemed to come to grips with itself, after lightning struck thier sattelite dish not four feet from my head, i left and rolled down that wonderful 112 downhill, all the way to route 2. the pictures below are on route 2, part of the mohawk trail of tears, on a bridge overlooking the deerfield river.           as i hoofed the bike up one short but pesky hill a little while later, some rednecks in a truck thought it would be proper and good to yell out "get a car!". being a former bike messenger, my initial reaction was to chase after them on my bike and get up in thier face about it. but the weight of my bike, the fact that i was not in the city, the fact that it was just a dumbass making a dumbass comment, and the fact that i would have to walk all the way back up the hill after futily trying to chase them down made me reconsider and resort to simply letting the bird fly in thier general direction. not the most mature response, but it shows restraint from my typical reaction. this was my only bad motorist occurance. a little while further i came upon a farm stand and got a overloaded pint(+) of absolutely deliscious blueberries, a few husks of corn, and some plums. the people that were running the farm stand were extremely helpful and kind. very enthusiastic about the fact that i was riding up to keene. when i told them where i had come from, the were a little taken back. i dont think they had ever met a bikepacker before. a little ways up route 5 from there, a fella out on his daily ride caught up with me and i rode with him for a while. we chatted about where i was going, the best route to get there, etc. it was a huge help to ride with someone, to have someone to pace myself by. after a while, he took off to continue on his way. he hit some pretty decent speed leaving me, probably holding 23-25mph as he accellerated away as far as i could see. the reason i was headed for keene was to visit with my longtime friend steve and his family, who i hadn't spoken to in years. due solely to losing touch. i for some reason assumed that they would be at the same residence, despite divorce. so i pedalled on, i got into the town of keene right around dark, and knew that the house was still another 45 minute ride to the north edge of town, up a bigass hill. so i called my mom to double check what i knew to be the adress. i didn't have a phone number, so i was going on luck. i eventually got going, and it was pitch dark out. i hoofed up that huge hill, and started rolling down the other side to thier old house on peg shop road. when i pulled into the driveway, just after 9, i was so relieved to just be there. i knocked on the door, and peered inside through the window. childrens toys EVERYWHERE. unless steve had a kid in the last year or two, this was not a good sign. sure enough a stranger opened the door to a greeting of "i guess the petersens dont live anymore, huh?". i felt defeated, and quite embarassed. luckily the owner was friendly and helpful, telling me all he could remember about where the petersens had moved to. i couldnt bring myself to ask the guy if i could camp in his yard, or the woods right next to it, i was too embarassed. i played it off like i had somewhere else to go in town, and rode up to the powerlines at the top of the hill. setting up camp that night was a living hell. the mosquitos in new hampshire have intelligence. they are silent, huge, and efficient. your worst nightmare. by the time i got everything together, got out of my riding clothes and got into my tent, i was pissed off, embarrassed and downhearted. just as i was about to fall asleep, the screech owl in the tree right above me decided to do his thing for a few minutes. i knew what it was, but still jumped every time it screeched. 
   VOILA!, an adress in five minutes. i rode over to the house, great rail trail connecting keene and swanzey i would later discover. luck started looking my way because steve's mom had decided to take her lunch at home and was only going to be there for fifteen minutes. i happened to show up during those fifteen minutes. she was shocked to say the least to see me knocking on her front door. i was welcomed as i had been when they lived on my street, and melanie went off to work while i took a shower and snacked a little. after i was showered, and had checked my email, i rode back to keene without any of my gear. i stopped into the friendly's where lauren was working and gave her a bit of a shock too, when she turned around to see me there. i had a grilled veggie sandwich and chatted with her, when she wasn't waiting on others. 

   i was right about the thunderstorms. i could see them over the next range, this big, black ominous sky, flashing rapidly with lightening. i turned off of route 9 to go say goodbye to lauren at work, but as i was riding north, a woman pulled over next to me, rolled down her window and told me that there were mini tornados touching down in the area, and that i should seek shelter immediately. she offered me a ride into town, but i knew that there was no way we were getting my bike in her little hatchback. i said thank you for the information, and turned around, heading back to the petersens for one more night. after the trip, i found out that the area i would have been camping in was declared a disaster area from the damage caused by the minitwisters, and the heavy rain. THANK YOU TORNADO WARNING LADY!! 
        on route 30, here you can see my tires strapped to the sleeping bag. this is usually not the stup i go with. normally, it would be my sleeping pad and tent strapped to the front rack. i just messed up. it really made no difference though.     further up route thirty, which is a very pleasant ride, if you ever have the chance, i ran into this long, beautiful covered bridge. i'm all about the covered wooden bridges now. the smell of the wood inside, the shelter they offer in a storm, you just cant beat them.           i ended up riding too far up on rt 30. up past newfane before i realized it. so i turned aroudn and headed back, got myself directions to where i was headed. rode through some beautiful terrain connecting rt 30 and rt 100 at mount snow. long push up the mountain in west dover. once on 100, it was an enjoyable, scenic ride down to route 9. i assumed that by riding up 30, and down 100, that i would miss the construction i was warned about on route 9, but it wasn't the case. this didn't make rt 9 unenjoyable though, in fact it was the exact oppositte. when i came upon flagmen/women, the almost all waved me through, making the traffic coming from the other direction wait longer or stop just for me. they all greeted me with a smile and a wave, and got one in return. the parts that werent limited to one lane, were like riding on a really big, wide dirt road. i loved it. before reaching route 8, i turned off on **** rd which connected with it. excellent choice. i saw maybe five cars the entire time. which was good, because when you're pushing your 85lbs of bike and gear up a huge hill, the last thing you want is to be inhaling car exhaust. it was a really nice ride/hike to the top, where i was surprised to find windmills. i didn't think they saw much use on this side of the country. from the top, it was a very long, very high speed downhill almost all the way to route 2 in mass. i stopped and shopped at a stop&shop, then continued on down to the festival site. rolling through the entrance, i was greeted by the first fellow volunteer with "now THATS the way to arrive!". it brought a smile to my face. pedrosfest. where to begin? i dont know, so ill let the pictures speak for themselves for now....
