About the pictures:  In the midst of all the other preparations we brought the digital camera along, but forgot to get it ready.  The memory was almost full and the battery charge was really low when we took it out to take our first pictures.  It was a couple days before we figured out how to get it charged in camp.  Pictures are a little sparse until the third day.  [This is Connie.  What Bob really means is that I forgot to get the camera ready.  We charged the battery in the back of the shower truck...who knew?] I started cycling 3 years ago (at age 50) in desperation when my knees would no longer tolerate running.  For a long time I did just mountain biking.  Then I started riding the MTB to work.  That led to a road bike.  A year ago I got my wife to start mountain biking too.  [Yeah! Fat, old biker chick...that's me!]  We also got a tandem thinking that would be the most enjoyable way to ride together on the road.  [Do you know that you get absolutely no respect when you're on the back of a tandem?  I tell people about our trip and they're all impressed, until I say we rode on a tandem, and then they say "oh" with a knowing look.  Believe me, Bob's in much better biking shape than I am, but there is absolutely no way he could pull us up those hills if I weren't pedaling like mad.  We're what is called a "big team" and it's not because of the size of our quads.] It was my brother-in-law who got me interesting in bike touring.  He told me about Adventure Cycling and I began to look around the net.  I read journals in "Crazy Guy on a Bike" and joined the T@H (tandem@hobbes) and phred (touring) mailing lists.  (Both of these lists are fantastic resources.)  The idea of riding across the country caught my attention.  Since my longest bike ride at that point had been a 22 mile mountain bike ride, this was a considerable leap of imagination on my part.  My wife Connie gave me that "oh, oh, here he goes again" look. She's been humoring my enthusiasms for 30 years now, so she's practiced at being supportive while maintaining a mild skepticism.  [Oh, is that what he calls it?  I thought I was just looking at him like he was your standard male person suffering from testosterone poisoning.  Doesn't every wife look at her husband that way?]  She admitted, though, that it would be interesting if we could actually pull it off. Connie started riding as well about a year ago and liked it.  We've always been involved in physical activities, but lately we hadn't been able to do much. Our bodies were wearing out and we needed to find different activities.  Cycling seems like the perfect sport to turn to. So now with both of us enjoying cycling, Connie was willing to talk about touring.  That's where this tour comes in.  We knew we needed to start slowly.  First we thought we would do a couple of overnight credit card rides.  In May we rode from Palo Alto to Mill Valley, stayed over night, and then rode back the next day.  It was 55 miles each way and we survived, though we were pretty sore.  [Start slowly?  Part of that trip was on a busy freeway (scared me to death riding across the on and off ramps) and part of it was over the Golden Gate Bridge (beautiful!) on San Francisco Bay.  We stayed in a nice hotel, and talked the staff into letting us take our tandem into our room because we were afraid to part with it.  It was so brand new and so pretty -- it's a light to dark blue fade, my favorite color.  With my first long bike ride under my belt, I enjoyed a huge dinner and didn't skimp on anything.  Obviously that put more under my belt, but talk about guilt-free eating!]  We had only done one overnight, but we didn't want to let the summer get away.  The next step was to try a week long tour.  [More like a leap.]  We wanted to do something supported and had lots of time constraints.  Our kids are both in college and we didn't want to be gone while they were home.  The Oregon Bicycle Ride began to look like the best option.  Connie took some persuading though.  She wasn't sure we could do the distance and climbing, but the big one was the heat.  The ride was in Eastern Oregon and temperatures in the 90's could be expected every afternoon.  Bill Martin and Sandy Green answered a lot of questions by email and assured us that if we had done back to back 50 mile days, we could do the ride.  They didn't sugar coat the weather predictions. [But Bob did!  Well not exactly.  He'd say that it might get up into the 90's, and give me that ever-hopeful, "pleeeese be ok with this" look that I can rarely resist.] Connie's biggest worry was the heat.  [I was imagining hot flashes + 100 degree temperatures + riding a tandem thousands of feet of vertical out in the mid-day sun, listening to "are you pedaling?"  Turned out I was too hot to know if I was having hot flashes, but the rest of it came true for sure.]  I promised her that we would start early every day to avoid the heat.  "No later than 8." I told her.  I am not an early to rise person.  I thought getting packed up and out by 8 would be an accomplishment.  Boy was I clueless.  More about that later.  [I can't get Bob out for a ride on any old weekend before 10 am.  Practicing mild skepticism again.] The single thing that clinched the deal was the OBR's sag policy.  They will allow you in and out of the sag wagon whenever you like within reason.  On the sixth day, there was an 8 mile climb, 6 percent, the 3rd long climb of the day.  We figured we had a reservation in the sag wagon for that climb.   So, against her better judgment, we signed up for OBR.  "Now look at the pickle you've gotten us into, Ollie!"
We got the thickest Thermarest available, the Camp Rest LE.  These are heavy but turned out to be worth it.  They worked well. [Better than just the cold, hard ground better.  But we were jealous when we saw other people with real cots and big air mattresses.  When the truck carries all your stuff, go for it.  As newbies, we dutifully restricted ourselves to two bags per person, for all our gear.  Other folks had several bags, folding chairs, tents, and those shade things the well-prepared parents bring to swim meets and soccer matches.] I hate sleeping bags.  I just can't stand having may legs constrained while I sleep.  I have been trying to figure out how I could sleep comfortably.  My idea was to get a rectangular bag and a sleep sack for a sheet.  Until it got too cold, I would crawl into the sleep sack and try to use the bag as a quilt, completely unzipped.  We got identical bags, 45 degree REI.  They weighed about a pound and half each and were reasonably cheap.  The sleepsacks are polyester and very light.  They provide about 4 degrees of insulation according to the label.  This worked great for me.  I never needed to zip up the bag.  The temp reached down into the 40s, I think.  [I, on the other hand, froze to death the first night.  I had to resort to my sweat pants and ski hat.  After that first night I was fine, though.  Maybe the metabolism kicked up a notch.] We got little head mounted LED lights.  I really liked this for reading and dealing with a dark tent.  Connie hardly used hers.  A wide angle light to hang in the tent was barely used.  We also brought along a big flashlight, but that never got used.  [You have got to picture this: pitch dark outside, with a whole campful of dark tents, and ours must look like there's a madman with a flashlight doing calisthenics inside.  Bob's got this headlamp thing on, and can't find anything in the dark.  He's rooting around in all the stuff, swearing none too softly, headlamp flashing in all directions, looking for his pillow, his book, then his glasses (which were in his hand at least once).  He's irritable because he's tired and I'm lying there with my eyes closed (partly from being blinded by the headlamp thing), trying to pretend this isn't as funny as it looks and trying to keep from laughing.  And he doesn't think I can keep my mouth shut!]  I was really worried about hydration.  I have long noticed that a lot of sweating would give me headaches, often migraines.  Despite trying to heavily hydrate myself, the problems would still occur.  I knew that on a 7 day bike trip in the heat,I would be miserable if I couldn't fix this problem.  I decided that what I was missing was electrolytes.  I had tried drinking a bottle of Gatorade along with my Camelback, but that didn't seem to be enough.  I wanted to try adding a lot more electrolytes while drinking.  To do that I had to find some drink that I could mix from powder and could stand to drink all day from my Camelback.  From three LBSs, I got sample size packages of every sport drink and flavor I could find.  After sampling them all and studying their contents, I ended up settling on Green Gatorade, the same thing I had drunk all along.  It tasted by far the best to me and you can buy it in bulk at Costco.  [I too participated in the great electrolytes blind-tasting test.  I knew I would just drink whatever Bob chose, but he wanted me to try them anyway so I wouldn't complain--who me?.  Some of them tasted like sugar-coated, metal tooth fillings.  We settled on a drink in a nice shade of green.]  I would fill my Camelback with 2/3 - 3/4 strength Gatorade every morning and top it up at the rest stops.  I carried one bottle of plain water for when I just needed some plain water to drink.  This worked great for me.  We rode long hills in blistering heat.  I KNOW I wasn't able to replace all the fluid I lost during the day, but I always felt reasonably good at the end of the day. No headaches.  [No problems for me either, but I felt like I would float away from all the liquid I drank.  I love the Camelback so I can take sips frequently to keep my mouth and throat from getting too dry while panting up all those hills.]
We arrived about 3, in plenty of time to check-in.  A lot of tents were up on the grassy area at the fairgrounds, and people and bicycles were everywhere.  We had reserved a hotel room for the first night.  Not having slept on the ground in more than a decade, it seemed like good idea to ease into it.  We also wouldn't have to figure out how to strike the tent and pack up before starting the first day's ride.  It seemed a little sad to leave the site of the excitement when we went off to the hotel.  [Before we left, we had dinner at the fairgrounds and got to know our 150 riding companions.  We had our story all worked out before we arrived.  We'd be among the "older" riders, entitled to an automatic, "no-fault" pass to the back of the pack.  While the age range of the group was 18 to over 80, the median age was probably in the mid-40's.  There were lots of folks our age and older, and most seemed to know each other, to have done the OBR many times before, to be seasoned campers, with fancy bikes, nifty camping gear, and every piece of biker clothing you can imagine.  We decided our "not too bad for old farts" excuse probably wouldn't cut it, and changed our story to "first-time on tour" people.  Bill Martin gave us beginners (20 or so) an orientation after dinner, and we were introduced to "chamois butter" and "bag balm."  I decided to stick with the diaper rash ointment my sister had recommended.  Yup, that's where you put it.]  We thought we were probably the only ones who were wussie enough to be staying in the hotel, but we should have known better.  Parked in front of the room next to ours was a BMW SUV with 2 Lightspeeds on the back and one inside.  Other cars had nice bikes too.  It was clear we were not alone.   We set the alarm clock for 6 am to be bright and early back to the fairgrounds.
At the end of breakfast, we got our stuff together and got ready to ride.  By then it was about 7:30.  Plenty early by my reckoning, but almost everyone had left.  It was clear these people do not have the proper respect for a good nights sleep. There was some trepidation mixed with the excitement of getting started.  The first two days were both about 57 miles.  Just slightly longer that we had ridden before, so we knew we could do it.  But we would also be a hundred miles from our car when we started out on the third day.  That would be the first time we had ridden significant distance 3 days in a row and the day would be the longest we had ridden by 28 miles and the most climbing that we had done on the tandem, by far.  [We'd only had the tandem about three months, and we were still trying to get used to each other--Bob, me and the tandem.] The morning was beautiful and cool when we started at 7:45.  We slogged up a hill on the way out of town.  Tandems do not climb fast!  By the end of the trip, we would not class this as a climb, just a little rise.  [Looking back on it, I realize that other riders were probably wondering if that big team on the blue tandem was really going to make it all the way.  We had to stop at the end of that first little hill to take off a few layers of clothes as we were completely overdressed.  I was meeting lots of riders that day...but only by watching their backsides as they passed us and rode ahead.  Unfortunately in camp that evening I didn't recognize anyone from the front.]  A couple more modest climbs and we came out along the Metolius River gorge.  Everyone pulled over at the first overlook and spent a while ooohhing and ahhing.  It was a great view.    The route rolled along by the gorge and then off into the fields.  After 25 miles or so we see our first rest stop.  The food is great.  M&Ms, Oreos, canteloup, pineapple, Cheeze-its, peanut butter, chips and salsa.  [Aaah, the food!  This was one of the best things about the ride!  The rest stop people had something for everyone.  More guilt-free eating after all those miles.] The route went through Smith Rock State Park.  This is a great rock climbing area.  Right by the park is a little store that sells huckleberry ice cream.  The store didn't open until noon though, so nobody got to try it.  The rest of the route was flat through pleasant farm land.  [The route went through Smith Rock State Park, but we almost didn't.  The first couple of days of the ride had lots of turns, and we thought we'd missed the turn to Smith Rock.  So  we turned around two or three times, searching, and Bob almost dumped us over discovering that the turning radius of the tandem is about the same as a panel truck.]  When we arrived in Prineville, it seemed like all the tents were already set up.  This would be the pattern for the ride.  [We soon discovered that the tent spaces along the fences were very popular, so you could wash out your biking clothes in the shower or in some buckets available for that purpose, and hang them on the fence to dry.  Others used clothespins to attach their clothes to the ribs of their tent.  Since we were late getting to camp, we had no fence and of course no clothespins (not on the packing list) so we just hung our clothes on our folding chairs.  This was also the day of discovering the joys of showering in a shower truck.  I hit the showers at rush hour, and the humidity was suffocating.  I learned better timing the rest of the trip, and the shower truck actually worked great.  They had rows of sinks with mirrors outside the truck for teeth brushing and shaving.]  The afternoon heat was oppressive.  We found a restaurant and discovered how good a beer and nachos supreme could taste after spending a few hours riding a bike in the heat.  The waitress was friendly and we told about the bike and that we were riding to Paul-ee-na in the morning.  She looked blank and then recognition lit up her face.  "Ah, Paul-eye-na.  That's a long way."  So, its "Paul-eye-na" from now on. We also found some sun hats.  We had remembered all the camping gear and bike gear but forgotten that we would be out in the sun during the hours after riding.  We both left great sun hats at home in the closet.  [Now we were the big team with the dorky matching sunhats.] Dinner was spare ribs.  They were incredibly good!  We couldn't believe how good these ribs were, served out of the back of a U-Haul.  [Sitting in the shade of the dining canopy, I discovered large red blotches covering both my thighs and parts of both calves.  The red looked like little bumps, but didn't feel bumpy, and didn't itch or sting.  I always wear SPF45 sun screen everywhere, since I'm a pale, freckled red head, so I knew I wasn't sunburned.   The camp manager gave me some cream to rub on my legs, but the redness spread further that night, before gradually fading over the next few days.  Someone suggested it was heat rash, and another said it was sun poisoning.  I don't know what it was, but it didn't bother me and it went away.]  The first night in the tent went fine, though it was a little hot.  The thick Thermarests gave plenty of cushion and my idea of sleeping in a sleepsack and using the bag as a quilt worked just as I'd hoped.  [I didn't sleep very well flat on my back that first night.  Made it through the night without a trip to the bathroom though, probably because it was so dry in Eastern Oregon!]  So far so good.  The legs were sore, but not too bad.  We set the alarm for 6 am.
Breakfast was at a church a few blocks away. It was great.  By the time we were done, we were at the back of the pack.  Just outside of town, we started the one long climb of the day.  It was several miles of moderate grade.  Looking at a topo map of the route, this day looked like it would be a long dry ride through the high desert.  The ride was unexpectedly beautiful.  The climb in the cool of the morning was lined with small pine trees.  The top of the climb was followed by a short descent and then some rollers followed by a long fast down hill. This was the biggest descent we had tried on the tandem.  It was very unlike the climb.  It dropped off steeply with a lot of curves through a canyon.  We took the curves so slowly that the singles were passing us.   [Alright I confess.  I'm not supposed to use the drag brake without permission of the Captain, but our first big downhill was scary!  I may have just put that little old drag brake on a little bit without him noticing.  I had to let up, though, when the singles overtook us.  Looked suspicious.]  Then the grade let up a little after a couple of miles and we felt safe enough to let the tandem run.  We quickly caught up with the singles and passed them.  What a blast! This is where the tandem is incredibly fun.  On a moderate grade, a tandem just cuts through the air and you feel like you have Sea Biscuit's legs.  A good tandem is rock solid.  The tires hum and the wind is loud in your ears.  There's a real sensation of power and speed.  [Some of that humming was the stoker yelling from behind against the wind, "Boy, are we going fast!"] We had switched over into an adjacent valley.  This valley was only 200-500 yards wide, carpeted with green from the river and irrigation.  The remainder of the ride wound slowly up the river valley for 35 miles and perhaps 400 of net rise. Coming over a small rise, there was a Y in the road.  OBR to the right the sign said.  We were in Paulina.  This was a little different from Prineville.  There were about 10 buildings total, including a two-room school, a church, a store and a dance hall.  We camped on the grass behind the school, a tight fit.  [Since we were just about last to camp, as usual, we had to lug our camping gear and belongings all the way across camp to the far edge.  After two 50+ mile days, my legs felt like rubber.  It was a slow walk across camp.  But it felt so good to stop pedaling!  Sandwiches were available for lunch, and they sure tasted good.  There was a shortage of shade, so that dorky sunhat was a welcome sight.]  It was very hot again as we ambled... No, ambled sounds too fast.  We shuffled down the road to the store.  Ahh, beer!  The pastor of the church was working on an addition.  Someone asked him about his flock and he said he gets between 5 and 32 each week.  The school has two rooms and handles K-8. We missed the excitement in the camp while at the store.  A gust of wind came and the two tents next to ours had gone airborne and blown halfway across the camp.  The eating tent had also blown over.  Last night our own tent had nearly blown over, so we had staked down carefully today. [After a very good dinner we were entertained by a local blues guitarist who was wonderful.  Most of these early birds on the ride go to bed by 9:00 pm, so folks gradually wandered off to their tents.  The music was a great way to end the day.]
The day began with breakfast in the Paulina Dance Hall.  It was the best breakfast of the trip.  Several ranch ladies had gathered from miles around.  One said she got up at 3 am and came from 17 miles away.  They joked about their husbands fending for themselves, stumbling around the kitchen looking for food.  Bacon, sausage, eggs scrambled with a light touch and ohhh, the pancakes.  There had to be lots of butter in these and they were light, too. Last year we spent a few days in late fall in Minnesota and Iowa.  On a whim I had eaten pancakes every day for breakfast, looking for the best ones.  They were all very good.  But these ranch ladies from Paulina made the best pancakes I have ever had.  The real triumph though, the brilliant innovation in mass breakfast feeding were the two crockpots.  The first was filled with hot maple syrup.  The second, though, mmmmmmm, the second was filled with melted butter.  A big ladle of melted butter, followed by a ladle of hot syrup.  This is the way to eat pancakes [and definitely the way to become a "big team."]    The ride out of Paulina was brown and treeless.  The route rose slowly until we rounded a curve and saw a long sweeping climb out to our left and then right up to a saddle.  We could see riders 20 or 30 minutes ahead of us.  It was a nice warm up climb for the day.  A short steep downhill and then another short climb.  What followed was one of those great tandem downhills, long and gradual.  The hills were now covered with trees and we had 7-8 miles 30-40 mph speeds.  Fun!!! [Alright, this is for the ladies.  All you guys who are squeamish about female anatomy, skip this section.  I had never done so many miles day after day as by now on this third day of our ride.  My butt bones were killing me.  When I looked ahead to that climb up to the saddle, I wanted to climb out of my saddle and walk.  Oohh, those aching butt bones--the ones that used to have lots of padding on them, but now that I'm over 50, the padding seems to have dropped, or drooped, so the bones just feel naked.  I was desparate, and of course, Bob can feel me squirming around on the back of the tandem.  In mid-squirm, I realized I could kind of lift up my butt, tilt my pelvis forward, and "sit" with my butt bones blissful up off the saddle.  Ah, sweet relief!  I will survive!] The downhill always ends.  A few miles of very gradual uphill through another river valley brought us to Izee.  At least I think it did.  I missed it.  It apparently consists of one abandoned building, a former school.  Izee is on every map I have seen of Oregon and is uninhabited.  Makes me wonder what is actually behind all those little named dots in the rural west. Just after Izee, the big climb started.  We entered the trees soon after the climb started, which made it pretty and provided occasional shade.  The grade was steady, but it was getting hot. We stopped a few times in the shade.  It felt great when we came over the top and had another of those wonderful tandem descents for 3-4 miles to a rest stop.  It felt great to have competed the big climb and we were ravenous.  Ate like pigs at the rest stop.  The OBR does great rest stops. After the rest stop were miles of lightly rolling road running through the ragged edge between pine forest and meadow, eventually coming out at highway 395.  We don't have much country like this in California.  If you are in pine trees there you almost always are going either up or down.  Ahead of us we could see the Strawberry Mountains.    On 395 a short uphill was harder than it should have been because we were beat by now.  Then the summit and a screaming downhill.  We feel a little more confident on the downhills now, but still use the drag brake a good bit.  [This was the descent when we were chased by the big rig, maybe a tanker truck.  The driver was not really chasing us, and was actually giving us some space, but I was nervous.  We were on a fairly steep descent, with a large drop-off to the side into a canyon, and taking quite a few curves.  Tandem riding is not for the meek, particularly when you are on the back and can't see where you're going or do anything about it. I guess this is one of the reasons people say tandem riding is a test of a relationship. But at least if Bob takes us off a cliff, I can have the satisfaction of knowing it was his fault!]     At the bottom of the steep descent, we're riding along a pleasant little creek.  Funny, the road looks like its slightly downhill, but I can feel we're going uphill.  Wait a second, the creek is flowing in our direction!  We stop  and check on the drag brake.  Turns out it's overheated and stuck on.  When it cools a little, the bike starts behaving and we resume our descent.  It's great to see Canyon City and then John Day.  It's been a long day. We reserved a hotel for the two layover nights in John Day and there it is right on the main street.  We roll right up and check in.  Kinda cool to do that on a bike.  [Later we rode a few blocks over to the campground to check on the activities.  Bob got to discuss overheated drag brakes with the bike mechanics who promised to check out the bike for us.  We talked briefly to a young man who was riding solo from Canada to Mexico, and who happened to find our campground.  He appeared to have really bad second degree burns from the sun, and listening to him, we thought the sun might have done something to his mind also.  But then, solo long distance biking probably attracts some unusual folks.  Dinner didn't look too great, so we opted for a restaurant in town.  Ahh...a soft booth to sit in for my sore butt bones, a cold beer, and food served with metal eating utensils.  I felt pampered.  And then a soft bed to sleep in! On the one hand, I felt like a wimp staying in a hotel with all those other folks still out there camping, but...it was great!  We even had a laundry room so we could wash our clothes.] 
The only time during the trip that anyone ever complained about an aspect of the OBR planning happened today.  Wanting to provide another, shorter optional ride, the staff proposed a 30 mile out and back ride to a lake.  They would meet the riders at the lake with lunch.  It turned out they underestimated the difficulty of the climb to the lake and many riders turned back before reaching the lake.  The staff overreached a little in trying to provide the best experience possible and it didn't turn out well.  This was an aberration in an otherwise smoothly run trip.    The highlight of our day was a visit to the Kam Wah Chung Museum.  This museum is a perfectly preserved building and its original contents.  The building was owned by "Doc" Hay, Chinese herbal doctor, who also operated a store and an opium den.  The contents are exactly as they were in the 1940s when Doc Hay had to move to a nursing home.  For instance, an orange still sits on the kitchen shrine, more than 60 years since it was placed there.  Doc Hay had lived in the building since the 1880s.    (Actually, my day had several highlights.  The museum was great, and the woman who hosted us there was as interesting as the building and its story.  She had been dedicated to preserving the museum for over twenty years, and clearly loved the history of the place immensely.  I also enjoyed our lengthy conversation with a ten year old local boy on his bike outside the museum. He was very curious about our tandem.  After grilling us and inspecting our machine thoroughly, he rode off to the fairgrounds to check out the camp full of OBR folks.  In the big city where we live, a local kid wouldn't likely talk to strangers so freely, nor would they likely take the time to talk to him.  Even the folks in the Dairy Queen who served up my milkshake were friendly.)  Who was John Day? I was wondering where the name of the town, John Day, came from.  Here's an explanation from the National Park Service's web site for the John Day Fossill Beds National monument. John Day Fossil Beds National Monument is named after the river and not the man. Still, how was the river named? John Day was born in Culpeper County, Virginia, about 1770. In 1810 he joined an overland expedition to establish a fur trading post at the mouth of the Columbia River. The party became divided and widely separated. Experiencing hardships, John Day's group dwindled to two people. He and Ramsey Crooks eventually reached the mouth of the Mah-hah River along the Columbia. There, a band of American Indians took everything they had, including their clothes. They were rescued and reached Astoria (Oregon) in 1812. Due to this incident, people traveling along the Columbia River would point out the mouth of the river where John Day was robbed. By the 1850's, the Mah-hah River was referred to and renamed the John Day River. If you name the mouth of a river, you name every stretch of it upstream. It appears John Day never came within 100 miles of Sheep Rock. Looks like John Day was famous mostly for getting robbed and never came near the town of John Day.
   It started with 20 or so miles along the John Day River in a fairly broad valley.  Then the road and river plunged into the narrow Picture Rock Canyon.  This was the first time we had ridden through a narrow canyon like this and it was great fun.      The entrance to the canyon is also the beginning of the John Day fossil beds, one of the best fossil hunting areas in the world.  The Fossil Beds visitor center became an unofficial 3rd rest stop as almost every stopped.  The short movie shown was interesting. Having a little background made the remainder of the ride more interesting. Riding though this valley brings back a memory from my childhood.  We had visited Boise and were returning to California via Oregon.  In a summer deluge we had a flat tire on a road just like this, a cliff on the north side of the road, a river on the south side.  Blind curve behind and ahead.  I helped my Dad change the tire in the rain while my mother and brother stayed dry.  My brother also has a sharp memory of this even though he was at most about seven years old.    [We actually finished in the front 25-30% of the pack today, and so we met and talked to lots of different people at the rest stop, on the road and at camp.  We had the chance to talk to the three-legged tandem team, who were strong riders, very friendly and inspirational for us relative newcomers.  We also got our pick of campsites for once, at the high school in Spray, and made it to the store/bar across the street before all the good beer was gone.  Some folks went to the local swimming hole just down the road in Spray, but we were too lazy.  Finishing earlier meant we were putting up the tent earlier, and the heat was oppressive.]    It was good that the riding was easy today.  The heat was bad by the time we reached Spray.  We moved like molasses as we set up our tent.  I didn't know I could move that slowly.  We mostly just sat in the shade through the afternoon.  [The school principal was very friendly and distributed fliers listing "things to do" and places of business in Spray.  I don't think Spray has a traffic light, but it wasn't short on hospitality.  The school was open for us to use the internet if we wanted, and the gym for basketball.  I don't think anyone made it to the gym, but it was a nice gesture.  I think our group probably at least doubled the population of Spray that day.]  Later we wandered over to the little cafe/bar and found a dozen or so other riders there.  Beer.  Air conditioning.  This was good.  The group went through every beer in the place that wasn't Bud, Miller or Coors.  The proprietors allowed as how they didn't usually have so much call for microbrews. 
   At 7:15 we came to Station House where the first climb started.  We stopped and took off our warm clothes and stated the climb.  It was very pretty, a steady grade on a good tree lined road.  We were in the shade of the mountain for a long time and got occasional shade from the trees when the sun got higher.  It was pleasant, but it was very long, 10 miles and 2000 feet.  At just after 9 am we topped the summit and right there was a very welcome rest stop.  [Another woman rider showed me how she wet down her bandanna with ice water and put it around her neck. That did help in the heat.]    It was 10 miles downhill into Fossil and then it was back to climbing.  It's one of those cruel ironies of cycling that you spend forever climbing and then the descent is over in a flash.  The second climb is only 5 miles and 1100 feet.  It's steeper than the others and it's now much hotter.  The trees disappeared about half way down the last descent.  We reach the second summit at about 11:00.    (Note Connie's really red face. It's a really hot day and we've been doing a really lot of climbing!) The descent from the second climb was very pretty through a narrow winding canyon with scattered pine trees and craggy rocks.  The drag brake acted up again and we stopped and sprayed some water from a bottle on it as the mechanic said we could.  It was like spraying water into a hot frying pan.  It sizzled like crazy and then you could see the cable loosening up.  Freed from unwanted drag, we continued the descent out of the trees and into a wide, bone dry valley.  Coming into Clarno, it was like a moonscape, nothing but rocks and dust.  At Clarno, by a river and just before a bridge was the rest stop, within sight of the Clarno grade.  It was 100 degrees and right next to the rest stop a farmer is burning off the stubble in his field.  I could have sworn that was illegal for the last 20 years.  Just the thing to clear your lungs. At the rest stop, everyone was moving very slowly in the heat.  Others were wading into the water.  Wetting down your clothes from the ice water was popular.  In 2s and 3s, people were mounting their bikes and slowly crossing the bridge to begin the climb.  The sag wagon left with a full load.    Finally it was time to move on.  We climbed onto the tandem and crossed the bridge at about 12:45.  4 mph.  Slow going.  Hot.  Stop and rest.  Hot.  Try riding on the leftside, more breeze maybe.  Slow.  Hot.  Stop and rest.  Passed by a group that was in the river last we saw them.  They stop, we pass.  Hot.  Stop.  "Hey!"  someone yelling from ahead, "Rest stop right around the corner!" The rest stop folks had set up an impromptu rest stop, right at the half way point.  They just set up their tent, put out water and sport drink and connected up a battery driven fan.  Oh, were we thankful.  [Actually I think they saved my life.  Well, maybe not literally, but I really doubt I could have finished the climb up the Clarno Grade without this break.  Just to be able to have some ice water to drink and a little shade to stand around in to cool off helped me regain my sense of humor and positive outlook.  It was really, really HOT!  And I grew up in Tucson, Arizona.  But as another Arizonan on the ride had commented a few miles earlier, "In Arizona, we don't go out and ride during the middle of the day!" That same Arizonan reported later that he had checked the temperature reading on his wrist watch as he climbed the Clarno Grade and it had registered 110 degrees.]  We wet everything down and started out again.  We stopped every mile or even sooner.  [The sag wagon guy was attentive and kept driving up and down the hill, stopping at least three times to check on us.  At the back of the pack, in all that heat, our big team on the tandem probably seemed like prime candidates for heat stroke.  We just kept slowly grinding up the hill.]  Finally we could see the saddle and began to count the turns.  When we crested the summit, there was another U-haul, another impromptu rest stop.  Water, bananas and chairs to sit in. [SHADE!!!]  2-3 more riders trickle in.  I used to run marathons a long time ago and I was recently at the finish of the Big Sur Marathon.  I realized then I really missed the atmosphere and comaraderie that comes from having all experienced the same exhausting, draining effort.  That's one reason I wanted to do this ride.  Here it was, sitting in the shade of the truck, eating bananas and laughing with the release of having made it up the climb.  It was literally all downhill from here.   It was the same air of happy exhaustion in Antelope when we got there.  Rolling slowly into town, we see the one cafe.  Let's go in and get whatever they have that's cold!  We can set up camp later.  [As we stumbled toward the cafe, we met a small group of freshly showered riders leaving the cafe to head back to camp.  They asked if we had finished the whole route, and when we said "yes" one of the men looked at us and said "That's not an easy climb.  Several strong tandem teams had to get a ride from the sag wagon today.  You have my respect for finishing."  Whoa! We felt like real tandem riders now.  Wait, we ARE real tandem riders now!] Sitting at the cafe counter, we order the Marionberry Cobbler.  "With ice cream?"  Of course.  The cobbler was wonderful, marionberries are a lot like blackberries and the scoop of ice cream was huge.  The place was run by an older couple, he at the counter and she in the kitchen.  They were very nice.  They had made 70 cobblers and had only 7 left, 5 after we got ours.  I asked if anyone had turned down the ice cream.  "Nope, not a one."  Right after that, Ted came and ordered a cobbler.  "Ice cream?"  "No, thanks."  Oh well, 69 out of 70 ain't bad. This camp ground was the worst.  We camped around the old school, the one that was closed when the Rajneeshies came to town in the '70's.  Since it was closed the grass had died and the gophers had a field day.  It was tolerable though, at least it wasn't rocky.  [I spent some time sitting under a tree with ice on my knees.  By now, they were starting to get pretty sore by the end of the day.  No one else seemed to need any ice treatments, so maybe I still need some adjustments to fit my bike better.  Dinner in camp looked great - grilled salmon -- but since Bob dislikes salmon, we wandered gingerly back to the cafe and indulged in the best burgers west of the Mississippi - or so they seemed after a day on the Clarno Grade.  When we got back to camp, we found speeches in progress in celebration of the last full day of riding.  Then we had entertainment, a vocalist with a keyboard, set up outside the abandoned school in the middle of nowhere.]  [Bill Martin is a great stand up comedian.  He was the best of the entertainment on the tour.] It felt great knowing we had made it through the most difficult day.    [After six days on the road, the ground was getting softer every night and I had no trouble getting a good night's rest.  For the first time on the trip, I awoke in the middle of the night and had to visit the toilet.  In the high desert at 3 am or so, there was not a sound, nor a breath of wind, nor a flicker of light or movement from our 150 or so campers or anywhere in Antelope.  I picked my way to the toilet by moonlight, feeling like my feet crunching on the gravel road were loud enough to wake the dead.  Looking out over the desolate landscape before crawling back into our tent, I knew I was a long way from my suburban home south of San Francisco.  It was perfect.] 
   [Our final rest stop!  I hated to leave, knowing that I would have no more excuse to eat all those great snack foods.  The trip was all about basics:  heat and cold, sleep and wake, eat and drink, pant and pedal, sweat and more sweat.  I didn't lose any weight on the trip, but I built some endurance and muscle, both physical and mental.  And boy did I get to eat a lot!]  We were happy to be done.  At the finish, lunch and the shower truck were waiting.  It's great to be able to get into the car and head off showered and clean. 
Shimano SPD Sandals - These worked great.  They are very comfortable for touring, especially in the heat.  I prefer to wear socks with them.  I use them with Speedplay Frogs.  Some trimming is necessary, but they work after that. Brook B-17 Saddle - I was worried how my butt would hold up over the week.  I think the Brooks saddle helped a lot. Thermarest Camprest LE - We bought these knowing that we do not sleep well on the ground.  Even with our aged bodies, we slept reasonably well on these. Camp Chairs - Since it was a supported tour, everyone had brought folding chairs. The ones we brought could have been more comfortable.  It's worth getting good ones.  Many people had something that would provide shade by their tent.  This could have been really nice. Sleeping - I used a square sleeping bag (45 degree) and a Cocoon sleep sack that was made of polyester.  I used the sleeping back just as a quilt. I was quite comfortable this way and never got cold. Camera - We had a Canon digital S30.  It works fine, and the pictures look very good to me, but it works much better WHEN YOU TAKE IT OUT AND USE IT.  We wish we had taken many more pictures!  The Canon software for uploading the pictures sucks.  It was very difficult to set up and get started.  Once up and running, the usability was OK. Camelbacks - We both used Camelbacks, mine filled with water and Bob's with gatorade.  I put gatorade in my water bottles on the bike.  I did well keeping myself hydrated in the heat, and the Camelback worked great because I could take sips of water frequently without fumbling with a bottle. Skin Aids - SPF45 sunscreen and lots of it!  Lip balm with sunscreen.  Desitin Creamy Zinc Oxide Diaper Rash Ointment (don't laugh - it worked great!) Clothes  - I wore a Solumbra Cycle Shirt from a company called SunPrecautions on several days (but not the days we took any of the pictures in this journal).  The shirt is for sun-sensitive people, so it covers completely but has lots of air vents to cool you off.  I had been a bit skeptical, but found that it worked great.  With long sleeves and a collar, it kept the sun off me but I didn't feel any hotter than when I wore my short sleeved shirts.
The Oregon Bicycle Ride was great.  We would recommend it to anyone, the relative beginner or the 20 year tourist. (For once I agree.  The OBR was great--great people, great scenery, great roads, great food (especially the Marionberry Cobbler), and a great feeling of accomplishment.  Now if we can just find a ride without hot sun, big hills, and hard ground.... I've heard if you ride from the West Coast to the East Coast, the ground gets softer along the way, right?  I think Bob told me that....)
  Blue Ridge Parkway map   
Elevation gain: dunno.
6 snakes 2 squirrels 1 porcupine 1 raccoon on the verge of bursting open and spewing forth obnoxious gases and the like. On the first day (or 1/2 day) of the ride we immediately detoured off the Skyline Drive (because of the aftermath from hurricane Isabelle http://www.noaanews.noaa.gov/stories/s2072.htm) and took to this nasty high-speed highway from hell.  I started noticing (or trying to avoid hitting) one dead critter after another....so after the 2nd squirrel I kept track and asked Dave to do the same.  The tallly of our combined effort is listed above. The next day (ready for more roadkill counting fun) we entered the Skyline and amazingly I didn't see another dead animal....a few dead insects...but no more big critters!  I begain thinking there's probably more wildlife in the park but no road kill??  Why??  I thought about it some more and it came to me.   SPEED!!!  Cars in the park are driving much slower and therefore able to avoid obstacles (or animals) in the road. Lesson:  Slow down....you'll save some lives! Just a quick note on the ride from West Chester, PA to Front Royal, VA....ever ride 3 hours with a couple nuts who've got the entire sound track to the movie Spinal Tap on tape and memorized?  Note to self: "Bring ear plugs next time I ride anywhere with Dave and Suzie!"       
             Suzi was nice enough to drive Bruce and I to the start of the trip, Front Royal, VA.  A long drive, but entertaining for various reasons.  We got all of our gear in order at the spacious Food Lion (Food Weasel to some - Rob, care to tell us why?) and Bruce and I shoved off at 3:30 pm, a nice lazy time.        The highlight of the day was arriving at the northern entrance of the Skyline Drive to learn that it was closed for most of its length due to storm damage from Hurricane Isabel.  I felt "D'oh!" for about a second, then started laughing.  So, we had to ride the nasty, busy, no shoulder Rt 340, which wasn't a pleasant way to start the trip, but at least it wasn't raining.  Yet. Rain came later, along with the discovery that my rear deraileur shifter didn't survive the trip from SLC to Philly unscathed.  It wasn't shifting right, in fact it was stuck in the big cog.  I messed with it for a couple of minutes when Bruce came over, laid his bike-healer hands on the shifter, and voila - problem fixed.  From now on I'm taking my broken bike parts to Bruce for him to fix.  He still won't tell me what he did to fix the shifter.   
Elevation gain: 5,500'.
Dave's Method:  As the time approached to settle down for the night Dave would begin looking ahead for possible spots (maybe within a 1/2 hour of the end of the ride for that day).  He would make this distinct sound like low mumbling if an area ahead looked promising.  The more potential an area had for 5 star camping the louder and more pronounced the sound he would make.  Click on the link below and select documents and "Dave's Campsite Signal.wav" to hear my version of Dave's call for a good campsite.  http://www.msnusers.com/TourDeuxMoser Here is a description of the places we stayed each night that I was on the tour: 1) Open field next to closed flea market.  A little close to the highway and somewhat boggy with these weird glowing bugs crawling on the ground.  Had a few mice nibbling at my head during the night.  Not bad considering it was getting late and we needed a place....fast! 2) Sloped wooded area down a closed fire road, across a stream, and back up the other side; probably the worst camp spot of my part of the trip since I had to dig out several big rocks (with my bare hands) from my sleeping area and I kept sliding down the hill all night long.  Woke up with a really stiff neck! 3) Grassy area behind (or in front) of a closed restaurant overlooking a valley.  Had running water (no hot) and was protected from the wind and rain.  By far the best "free" spot on the trip.  Hoping we'd wake up to a nice sunrise but got rained on instead. 4) Down a secondary road just off the parkway but not far enough away.  Pretty good level ground but weird rental cars passing by us a couple times.  Couldn't get far enough away from the wood "chipper" that started operating shortly before 7:30 in the morning. 5) This one doesn't really count because I "forced" Dave to camp in a paid campsite just outside of Roanoke, VA.  Even after volunteering to pay for the site Dave was still looking around for that perfect "free" site within the state park.  I guess it's hard to go back once you've commited to going "free".  Not much better than day 3...no hot water and a gravel box to sleep on.         
   Once we got on the Skyline Drive, the climbing didn't stop.  I didn't expect it to be a flat ride, in fact I know that total climbing on the 470-mile Blue Ridge Parkway (BuRP) is 48,000', but it's always a shock to climb hills while towing a boat anchor (BOB trailer).  My knees hurt, but that's to be expected.      Skyline Drive is something that every touring cyclist should experience.  35 mph max, no commercial traffic, views abound, smooth surface.  It's so lovely that I can barely even stand it.  The leaves are just starting to change, so I've got that going for me as well.  The trees show quite a bit of damage from Isabel - lots of tree branches stripped bare. When we got to Swift Run Gap, MP 66, it was decision time.  Continue on the closed road, or drop off the parkway and ride busy roads that parallel the Skyline Drive, the whole time dreaming what it'd be like to be riding on the Skyline Drive.  As the "Road Closed" sign didn't say, "This Means You", we continued on the Skyline Drive and loved every second of it.  While on the closed portion we really didn't have any auto traffic, and could ride in whichever lane we pleased. Bruce joined me for the first week of the tour last year, and here he is again for the first week of this trip.  He and I make a good match - we ride at about the same pace and we've been friends for almost ten years.     
Elevation gain: 4,077'.
I wanted to write to let Dave (and everyone else) know why his trailer is so heavy.  Please click on the link below and download the list of items that Dave sent to me prior to starting the trip.  http://www.msnusers.com/TourDeuxMoser Dave....this is why your beast is so heavy.  Reduce and reuse! It was actually somewhat amusing that I even volunteered a few times to ride the hog up some of those steep inclines.  Dave and I have the same pedals so it was easy to take turns on the "other" bike.  It took me only two days of saying "I'll ride the hog" that I got smart and kept my mouth shut and on my ass on my bike.  Plus I could only ride that thing up hill....down hill scared me to death! Day 3 was an incredible experience because we got to ride a stretch of the Skyline without any cars!  Beats single file on a busy highway.  It pretty cold up on the ride and for the next several days unseasonably cool weather was on it's way.  The highlight of this segment of the ride was stopping off at the SkyLand Rest Area and getting a big cup of coffee and a sweet cinnamon roll....lowlight was going back outside again and freezing my ass off changing into my long sleeve shirt and vest.               
  See, if you leave the Parkway to go to a town, you're going to drop at least 1,000' of elevation gain.  Sure, it's a fun downhill, but then you have to turn right around and ride up the hill after stuffing your face at the grocery store.  Best to stay on the Parkway and eat mac'n'cheese than drop off of it and have a better selection of food.        The BuRP is kind of like the Skyline Drive, it follows the crest of the Appalachian Mountains, but there are some differences.  The BuRP feels sort of abandoned, like a thing that people just don't do anymore for entertainment.  Maybe back in the 40's or 50's it was the thing to do, but now it's kinda deserted.  That's fine - close it to auto traffic!  Hikers and bicyclists only! We camped beside a restaurant that closed due to lack of business.  Actually, tonight's campsite was great: level ground, a view, a restroom with running water nearby.  Cheap thrills on a bike tour.    As an appetizer, Bruce at a whole can of salmon.  I had a little bit, but it just didn't taste right to me.  I was impressed by how much salmon Bruce ate - I think it was nearly a pound of salmon.  Pass.    The weather has been cool, partly cloudy, with rain off and on.  Clothing is a challenge - put on the fleece for the downhill, take it off for the uphill, short finger or long finger gloves?, etc. Bruce and I are riding the Skyline Drive and the BuRP without the only book written specifically for bike touring along these roads.  Yes, I own this book, but some big jerk didn't return it to me before Bruce and I shoved off.  Hey big jerk, you know who you are, I'm charging you $0.50 for each day that I ride without that book. On that note, Cheers!     
Elevation gain: 4,200'.
   The ride was somewhat short but very scenic off the BRP and down to Buena Vista.  The best part was watching Dave try to negotiate the ~2,000 feet elevation loss and all those hairpin turns with his BOB all going about 40mph!  T'was a good thing we weren't across the center line when that dump truck was coming the other direction, half-way into our side of the road.      Show links to this Hide links to this      We did indeed stuff our "pie" holes in Buena Vista....I got so excited with all the food that I bought more than I could fit on my bike so I had to get "creative with the corn."  The checkout lady made a comment about the type/amount of food I had saying that "she would have to have a big glass of water to get any of it down."  Hmmm....  I had no choice (because of the lack of room) but to eat several things before we starting riding again...including an entire box of powdered donuts!  Boy was it hard to ride for awhile but my stomach loosened up.   
       In Buena Vista we stuffed our faces with cottage cheese, yogurt, a whole box of Krispy Kreme powdered mini-donuts (I made Bruce laugh when he had a whole mouth full of donuts and powder flew everywhere - I think some even came out his nose, it was classic), Doritos, etc.  After that we were feeling a bit sluggish while battling traffic along Rt 510, but we both made it to James River unscathed.      James River is the lowest point along the Burp at 649'.  From there it climbs to 3,950', the highest point along the BuRP in Virginia, in 14 miles.  Even though we were energized by the box of donuts, we didn't climb all 3,300' as we had already climbed 3,000' by the start of the climb.  We climbed 1,200' to save the remaining 2,100' for the next morning. A funny moment: at the James River Visitor's Center I asked the lady at the info desk if there was a phone that we could use at the VC.  She responded by writing the VC's phone # on my map.  Bruce and I looked at each other, baffled.  I asked her again, and she said no, then went back to reading her book.  OK.
Elevation gain: 5,117'. I probably won't get a chance to update the website for a while as I'll be riding along a stretch of the BuRP with minimal services.  In fact, my next stop here in Roanoke is to head to the Food Weasel to buy four days worth of food.  Well, that'll be fun to carry! Also, check out "The Route" page for a link to the Blue Ridge Parkway map, if yer interested.
   As fate would have it I ended up having a potentially trip ending break on my bike.  The wind had really kicked up that night and just before dusk a big gust of wind blew my bike over...ironically I was sitting close enough to reach out and grab it but instead I just watched it go down to a loud crunching sound.  At first I thought my sunglasses broke but upon further inspection the bike had landed smack dab on my front shifter permanently forcing it into the "little ring."  See entry for Dave for a song about my little ring!          Not sure how this came about in our conversations but Dave was somewhat infatuated with the ingredients from a canned meat product from Armour called "Potted Meat Food Product."  So to push it one step further I decided to buy some and eat it in front of him....I told him "tastes like chicken!"  I said I was going to make a poem about the ingredients but instead I'll just list them below in order of appearence on the label (for those that are really interested here's a web site that has everything you wanted to know about the subject and more http://www.shipbrook.com/jeff/potted.html).  My ingredients differ slightly in that mine had more "real" chicken. - Mechanically Separated Chicken - Beef Tripe - Partially Defatted Cooked Beef Fatty Tissue - Beef Hearts - Water - Partially Defatted Cooked Pork Fatty Tissue - Salt - Sodium Erythorbate and Sodium Nitrite   
       The BuRP near Roanoke isn't quite as pleasant as the rest - it passes right near the town, it's busy, and there's more trash alongside the road.  Basically, it's just like any other two-lane blacktop in the U.S. Right before reaching camp, I had myself a little ol' accident.  Bruce and I were just riding along on a flat stretch of road, nice and slow, when all of a sudden the rig veered off the road and onto the grass.  I suspect The Pig is responsible for the move.  So, instead of stopping on the grass (I still don't know why I didn't just do that), I tried to steer back onto the road but the front wheel didn't want to get up and over the 2" lip of the road.  The bike and The Pig fell down onto the pavement and I kinda ran off the bike.  It was kinda funny - the bike stopped and I ran ahead of it for a few steps, shaking my fist at it.  I wasn't hurt, the bike is fine, but it still wasn't pretty.  A D'oh! moment.      At camp Bruce ate a whole can of Potted Meat Food Product.  I couldn't watch him do it, in fact I had to stand away from him while it was happening.  I think he was intrigued by the combination of mechanically separated chicken and partially defatted cooked pork fatty tissue.  Regardless, this is what he had to say after he polished off the can: "I figure, what the hell, you're gonna die of something someday, it might as well be a potted meat product."
