Elevation gain: 3,500'. In downtown Roanoke Bruce turned right to go to the airport to get a rental car for the quick drive back to Philly, and Dave turned left to shower at the YMCA (he doesn't shower much), update the website, and buy four day's worth of food.  After that, Dave headed out of town, got back on the BuRP the hard way (the road out of Roanoke didn't exactly intersect with the BuRP, it went under it, so there was a portage involved), and continued southwest on his merry way, where he'll stop referring to himself in the third person.
   Dave was curious about the bivy sack the whole trip so we ended up trading for the night...Dave in the bivy and me in the tent.  The next morning I asked Dave how the sack treated him and he said "never again!"  I guess it was a little too cramped and claustrophobic.  I actually stayed warmer in the sack than the tent just becuase there is less air to heat between your body and the outside....unlike a tent!  Sorry Dave.  The only bummer with a bivy sack would be if you had to hang out in there for extended periods of time like in the rain.    I really regret that I couldn't have continued on with Dave and I'll say it again...I will go back and finish the BRP!  It was an amazing ride (for the short time I participated) and one that I'd recommend in a heart beat to any biking enthusiast looking for some fun and adventure!
So, Bruce has left me again, the second time in two years, to finish the rest of the Tour by myself.  I'm sure it'll take a couple of days to adjust to riding solo.  I think I can manage, although I'd rather have him along, broken front shifter and all.      Today was the $20 bill day.  I went to the YMCA to shower.  Showers are $1, I offered the lady at the front desk a $20, expecting $19 in change, and she let me have the shower for free - she didn't want to break the bill.  OK.  Then, on the way out of town, I filled up the stove fuel bottle with $0.07 of unleaded.  Again, I offered the $20 bill, and the gas station attendant let me have the gas for free.  I wonder how much other stuff I can get for free by offering a $20 bill?  Stay tuned! During the major climb of the day (1,400') I was joined by a road biker out for a ride.  Even though he was on a superlight bike and could've easily gone twice my pace, he slowed down to my pace and we chatted until the top of the climb.  There, he turned around to head back to Roanoke and I continued on my way along the BuRP.  Riding with him definitely made the climb seem shorter.      Tonight I'm camped in the middle of a big grassy field, just the kind of spot that Bruce was looking for the last night of his ride.     
Elevation gain: 6,322'. Ouch. As today is a Saturday, the BuRP was busier than usual, which means there was a car every two minutes instead of every five minutes.  Lots of rich white couples tearing around in big, new SUVs.  I stopped at Mabry Mill for lunch, and it was swarming with people.  After this one guy saw that I was bicycling, he told me with a straight face that yup, it's gonna rain all day.  It was 1:30 pm, and it hadn't rained a drop.  I asked him when it was going to let up, and he said by tomorrow morning.  Thank goodness!            As I was just riding along (JRA) today, a chipmunk darted out from the side of the road and ran right underneath me.  I don't know if he ran between my front wheel and my rear wheel, or my rear wheel and The PIg's tire, but it was one of those, and it was crazy.  I didn't even have time to react, which was probably a good thing. Tonight I'm staying at the BuRP Hostel.  It's run by a 82-year old guy named Alex, and like most hostels, it's definitely unique.  I stayed at the hostel for two reasons: to meet and talk to other travelers, and to read through the guestbook which was sure to have entries from other bike tourers.  Well, no one else was there except a retired German guy named Detlev that arrived late and left early, and Alex doesn't keep a guestbook because, as he says, "What would I do with it?  Too much stuff!"  However, the views from the common room of the hostel are superb, all forest, good sunset and sunrise (I saw 'em both!).    It's rainy country - Alex said that it's already rained 47" here since the beginning of the year, already exceeding the annual 46" average.  Yikes.
Elevation Gain: 5,210'. Last night I didn't sleep so well.  Detlev wasn't snoring or anything like that, but it was just so quiet in the hostel, with no window to crack!  As David St. Hubbins has said (and probably read): "The hush was almost deafening!" Alex, the hostel owner, came up to the hostel (it's the second story of his two-story house, he and his wife live on the first floor) to say hi.  He sat down and asked, "So, what's happening in the world today?", which lead to a really stupid, long discussion about, well, everything that's happening in the world today.  We touched on politics, economics, agriculture, world trade, corporate downsizing, and the whole thing left me feeling like I wanted to just get on my bike and ride, which I did.    This morning my legs weren't feeling 100% after yesterday's big day, and the sunrise was so nice, and the common room was so pleasant, and I was listening to Weekend Edition on NPR, that I didn't start riding until 10 am.  A nice, lazy Sunday morning. During the ride I stopped at the Northwest Trading Post, and was amazed at the density of schnick-schnocks and bric-a-brac in that place.  It was almost suffocating.      I'm looking forward to buying food from a grocery store tomorrow - it's been a few days since I've seen one of those, and I'm getting a bit tired of eating just pasta, Pop Tarts, oatmeal, and - dare I say it - Snickers!  Oh, the horror!  I want yogurt!  Bananas!  Perishable items! At camp I was shocked to turn on the radio and hear the Cubs playing.  The Cubs - in October!?!  I don't follow baseball much, but after living in the Chicagoland area for a while during high school, I know that the Cubs playing in the playoffs is a big deal.     
   The ride: Continued southwest on the BuRP from The Lump (MP 264) to Linville Falls (MP 316), with a minor detour to Blowing Rock for groceries. Elevation gain: 5,370'.      After a few days on the road without a grocery store, today's lunch never tasted so good.  I ate a pound of cottage cheese at the Food Lion in Blowing Rock, among other things.    The leaves are gettin' really good, lots of color.  Near Grandfather Mountain (MP 302), they were spectacular.        Found a great campsite at Linville Falls, in the picnic area.  It's right by the Linville River, so I'll have that babbling at me all night.  The best part: the floor of the tent is level tonight.  No more sliding downhill.    Blue Ridge Parkway Fact-of-the-Day: The Blue Ridge Mountains are four times older than the Alps.
Elevation gain: 6,245'. Oof. That's a bunch over only 40 miles.            During today's ride I saw a little orange salamander crossing the road.  He was so cute - only about 2" long and he was taking his sweet time getting across the road.  It was moving so slow that I thought it was plastic until, of course, I saw it move.    Tonight I'm camped at about 5,000', near the base of the climb to Mt. Mitchell.  The site is great - it's about 1/2 mile off the BuRP, level grassy ground, trees all around, all that.  It's really foggy here.  Smoky mountains, indeed.      Stopped in Little Switzerland for lunch today - how could I not?  The grocery store has basically two things for sale: candy bars and wine.  The other funny thing about that town is that none of the buildings look Swiss.  Hmm. Math Quiz of the Day: If my descending speed is five times my climbing speed (in road miles per hour) and my average speed for the day is 11 mph, what are my descending and climbing speeds?  Assume that my starting and ending elevations for the day are the same, the road distance climbing equals the distance descending, and that I'm only either climbing at a constant speed or descending at a constant speed all day.  The first one to post the correct answer in the Guestbook receives, uh, a prize!  Good luck.
Elevation gain: 1,910' plus all the hills that I rode in Asheville. It was nice climbing up Mt. Mitchell without The Pig in tow.  It went really quick, and was one of the easier climbs of the trip.  Couldn't see a darn thing from the top, though, as the fog had a firm grip on the hills.          Rode into Asheville, and that's when the D'oh!s began: 1. I planned on today being sort of a rest day, with most of the riding downhill, but when I saw the hills around Asheville, D'oh! 2. First thing, take a shower (I don't shower much).  I went to the YMCA only to find out that they don't offer showers.  But the YWCA does, on the other side of town.  D'oh! 3. After doing a load of laundry in the washer at a laundromat, I turned around to find that all of the dryers were in use.  D'oh! 4. I went to UNCA to update the website at the computer lab, but the lab was closed since it's fall break.  D'oh! 5. Riding around UNCA, I had a nasty case of chain suck when shifting to the largest cog.  The chain wedged itself between the cassette and the spokes.  D'oh!  That hasn't happened to me on that bike on probably five years.  Of course I blamed the new rear shifter that I had just installed that day. 6. Went to the Asheville library to update the website, only to find out that (1) it's $2 for non-residents (D'oh!), and (2) it's a 45-min. wait (D'oh!). 7. When I was unlocking my bike at the library to leave Asheville and its many D'oh!s, I noticed something funny with my spokes on my rear wheel.  Not good.  One of the spokes tore its eyelet out of the rim when I had chain suck earlier in the day.  The spoke didn't break, but the rim was in bad need of replacement.  D'oh!  So, I called up the same bike shop that I was at earlier in the day.  They were about to close, but the mechanic there (Ben) said he'd stay late and replace the rim for me.  Very cool, but on the ride to the bike shop I was wondering what type of rim he'd have for me - the one I had was stouter than a typical rim, for towing the trailer.  Well, he had a downhill mountain bike rim that worked great. The scary thing about the rim that blew up is that at each of the drive side eyelets, there was a small crack in the rim running along the length of the rim.  It's a good thing that the rim decided to blow up in Asheville, with its seven bike shops, instead of, say, Little Switzerland or B.F.E., Tennessee.      Ben finished replacing and truing the rim at about 7 pm, and asked where I was staying for the night.  I hadn't really thought of it, I was more worried about the rim, but he offered his couch for me to crash on at his place.  Southern hospitality at its finest.  As a thank-you for staying late to replace the rim, we went out to eat at a great restaurant.  Then we drank a few beers and watched "American Movie" with his roommate.  For some reason, I liked that movie way better this time than the first time I saw it.    So, the day ended on a great note.  Asheville is a cool town, reminds me a lot of Portland, OR with its rain, good beers, and hills.  I even admire it's D'oh!s now.
The Ride: Left Asheville through the Biltmore Forest, a great road with big houses to gawk at and hardly any traffic, then hooked back up with the BuRP.  Rode that through Mt. Pisgah to camp (at 5,500'). Elevation gain: 5,245'. During the ride I talked to three other bike tourers who were headed north.  Each had a BOB trailer.  One guy had a Surly Karate Monkey bike, a mountain bike with 29" wheels.  It was funny seeing that setup because that's basically the bike that Ben (yesterday's bike mechanic) said he'd want to ride on a bike tour.      At Mt. Pisgah, the top of a major climb, I had a tough time warming up.  It was fine when I was on the bike and working, but when I stopped, all that sweat started drying and cooling me off, a bit too much.  It was fine when I got back on the bike and started riding again.    On the way to Mt. Pisgah I saw a big, red crawdad crossing the road.  At 3,300' elevation.  Only in North Carolina.    At camp I had an appetizer of kippered snacks and crackers.  Ben's roommate, who was our waiter at the restaurant last night, gave me a whole Ziploc bag full of crackers, so I put those to good use.  Found a good site for camp as well - in a beautiful red spruce tree forest, right off the BuRP.    Tonight at camp, I was listening to the radio and heard a guy talking about trans fats and how he thinks they're linked to hyperactivity.  Does that mean that if I eat more Fritos Corn Chips, I'll be more active and be able to ride farther each day?  Well, only one way to find out! The mileposts along the BuRP are triangular concrete posts.  The one for milepost 420 was missing, which was sort of frustrating because I knew the top of a steep climb was at milepost 420.2, so I kept looking for 420 and was confused when I started going downhill without seeing it.  Then I remembered the hippie, crunchy, stoner town that I just left (Asheville), and it all made sense as to why the milepost marker was missing.
Elevation gain: 1,235'. Today's ride was mostly downhill.  Last night I was camped at 5,500', I had a few rolling hills to the highest point of the BuRP (6,047'), then it was C.F.A. all the way to Waynesville.  It didn't rain as hard today as it did yesterday, but it still rained a little.  Mostly it was just foggy, really foggy.          Leaving the quiet, pleasant, scenic BuRP for busy, four-lane divided Rt 23/74 was shocking.  Lots of trucks, fast traffic, wow. In Waynesville I'm staying with my Aunt Juanita and Uncle Joe.  When I got there, at about 11:30 am (nice and early), it was all business with laundry, showering, updating the website, drying out my stuff from the previous night's all-night rain, etc.  Then the four grandkids showed up (Teri and Carl's kids), some with friends, and they kept me busy until dinner playing rollerblade soccer, talking, etc.  After dinner the kids left for friend's houses, and we grownups sat around and watched the Cubs, talked some more, that kind of thing.  It was great to see the whole gang again, especially outside of a big hairy family gathering.          Before dinner I was working on my bike, greasing the chain, checking the brakes, etc. when I noticed something goofy with the rear cassette - the big cog wasn't spinning round, it was more elliptical.  Turns out that the chain suck I had in Asheville bent the big cog in back, so now it's not exactly round.  Should be ok (famous last words?), as I shouldn't have to use that gear much between here and Chicago as it's the lowest gear on the cassette.
Elevation Gain: 5,464'. Despite the Weather Channel's nasty, rainy forecast for the day, I didn't get rained on.  The fog was thick in spots, but I managed to dodge the rain, which is always a good thing. The last six miles of the BuRP were the best of the whole 469-mile road.  Why?  Well: 1. It was just the right grade for me to maintain a coasting speed of 35 mph without using the brakes. 2. The curves weren't too tight, but it was curvy enough to keep the scenery changing and the riding interesting, bordering on challenging. 3. The colors, oh the leaf colors.  Thinking back, I don't know how I managed to keep my eyes on the road. 4. It was the last six miles of the big, long, hilly BuRP, so it felt good to be near the end. 5. Hardly any traffic, even though it was a Saturday.  I think the weather forecast kept the crowds away. 6. No rain, no fog, no wind, dry road, about 65 deg. F.              So, that's why.  Contrast that with the nasty ride through GSMNP.  I've never seen so much traffic, and it was a twisty uphill (granny gear) road with no shoulder.  I found out later that most of the traffic was due to the Tennessee - Georgia football game (Hubba Ho! Shanks Akimbo!) in Knoxvile that was starting about an hour after I hit all that traffic.  D'oh! At around 3:30, after almost being run off the road by an RV, I decided to find camp and finish the climb to the pass the next day, which should hopefully be less busy.   
       The Ride:  Continued northwest on Rt 441 to the top of the road at Newfound Gap (5,048'), then descended into Tennessee, turned west onto Little River Road, northwest on Rt 73 for a bit to Townsend, then hopped on Rt 321 west through Walland and Maryville to Friendsville. Elevation gain: 3,000'. The descent from Newfound Gap was a hair-raiser.  40 mph easy, leaves falling, wet and twisty roads, all that.  Little River Road was a pleasant, scenic ride if you don't count the people yelling and honking at me.  Here's what I don't understand:  if you're in a hurry, why drive along a twisty 30 mph road when there's another parallel road that'll get you there much faster?  And why yell and honk at a bicyclist that's going 22 mph (it was slightly downhill, following a river)?  I noticed that most of the people that were honking or yelling had plates from out of state, or had either a "God Bless America" or "United We Stand" bumper sticker / window decal.      Found a great campsite, in an open field, no traffic noise, with a great view of Ft. Loudoun Lake.  It was nice and relaxing reading my book and watching boat traffic on the lake.   
The Ride: Continued west on Rt 321 through Lenoir City, then turned north on Rt 95 to Oakridge, then west on Rt 62 through Oliver Springs and Coalfield to Wartburg.    Today I rode over the Charles Deadrick "Pete" Johnson memorial bridge, so I've got that going for me. Lots of bramble and run down houses along the ride today.  I heard a wild pig snorting in the bramble, which added to the creepy viney feel. Wartburg is a great little town, I like the vibe.  Found a great campsite, right next to a run down barn.  I've got a tin roof over my head, which might come in handy with the forecasted rain for tonight.      Show links to this Hide links to this     
Thanks, Suzi, for the apples.  I ate one at the post office and packed the rest - they just might make it to camp! The Ride:  Rode north on Rt 27 out of Wartburg through Sunbright to Elgin, where I turned west on Rt 52.  Rode that through Rugby and Allardt to Rt 127, which I took north through Pall Mall, Static, and into Kentucky to Albany. Rain is the word of the day.  The first 25 miles or so were pleasant, no rain but overcast skies, and then all hell broke loose.  I had to seek shelter inside a barn near the road for about 1-1/2 hours because (a) it was dangerous to ride with all the truck traffic and heavy rain, and (b) the rain was stinging my face.  My face is on fire, indeed!  If the rain let up at all, the wind picked up, and it was a headwind.    Today was just plain difficult, both physically and mentally.  After I left the barn and started riding again, my calf muscles were cramping up from sitting still for so long.  Not good.  Also, from today on, I'll be getting my daily mileages from MapQuest as my computer blew up in all the rain.  D'oh! But, after all that tough riding, the day ended on a great note.  I found a great place to camp inside a barn with some tobacco drying, my camp stuff stayed dry inside The Pig, the burritos tasted particularly good after such a tough day, and the sunset was just plain spectacular.         
The Ride:  From Albany I rode west on lovely quiet roads (1590, 1351, 449, 61, 953, 214, 100) to Tompkinsville, where I hooked up with Rt 63 and rode that northwest into Glasgow.    Had my first flat of the Tour today.  I was all ready to go at 8 am when I saw that the front tire was flat - D'oh!  Oh well, I was due. The highlight of the day was taking a ferry across the Cumberland River.  Didn't know it was there until I almost rode right into the river.  Two guys drive the ferry back and forth across the 50 ft. wide river all day.    As I was tooling along at about 15 mph, just minding my own business, a black cat jumped out of the bramble alongside the road and crossed in front of my path - it missed my front wheel by about a foot.  Good thing I'm not superstitious.  Or am I? One of the many differences between cows and horses: when a horse is eating grass and hears me riding by, he looks up but keeps chewing, like it's no big deal - I'm just a bike.  When a cow hears me, it looks up but stops chewing, looking all stupid with gobs of grass sticking out of its mouth.  Duh. There is just not much daylight at this time of year.  When I finally left Glasgow to look for camp, it was only about 45 minutes until sunset.  I found a spot, behind a church way outside of town, and hustled to set up the tent and make dinner before it was pitch black.  Then, of course, I heard the Cubs lose on the radio.  D'oh!  The curse continues?       
The Ride:  Continued north on Rt 90 to Cave City, where I headed into Mammoth Cave National Park via Rt 70 and 255.  From there I exited the park on Green River Ferry Road (RT 1352) and continued west on Rts 1827 and 728 until Rt 259.  I took Rt 259 north through Bee Spring, Anneta, Meredith, and Leitchfield to Rt 737, which I took northwest.  I hooked back up with Rt 259 for a bit and then went nothwest on Rt 105 to camp. I spent some time at the visitor's center at Mammoth Cave, but didn't go on an organized tour because (1) I've seen the caves before, apparently, but only have a hazy memory of the trip, so uh ... (2) steep admission price (3) each tour was about 2 hours long, and with daylight in such short supply, that's a lot, and most importantly (4) it was SUCH a beautiful day for riding that I couldn't spend even part of it underground.  Now, if it were raining, I probably would've taken multiple tours of the cave.    Got to ride another ferry today, this one across the Green River.  The ferry operator told me a funny story about a bicycle tourer whose chain broke right when he pedaled off the ferry.  Funny because it wasn't me, I suppose.      Had a couple big, black, barking, snarling dogs orbiting me for about 30 scary seconds today.  They stopped not because of my screams and shouts, but because they were far down the road and didn't want to have to walk too far back home.  Yikes. The forecast is for rain tonight, so I'm glad I found the campsite that I did - a nice grassy meadow without any trees above me to drip rain water on me even after the rain stops.  And, the best part, it's down a gravel road with a chain across it. At camp I listened to the Red Sox get beat by the Yankees.  Oh joy, what a surprise, the Yankees are in the World Series.  Boy, that'll be exciting and different. Here you go (you asked for it): Math Quiz-of-the-Day:  If my power output drops from 150 watts at the start of the day to 75 watts at the 100th mile of the day in proportion to the square of the distance, and my speed drops linearly from 16 mph at the start of the day to 12 mph at mile 100, how many regular-sized Snickers bars do I need to eat to ride 80 miles in a day?  Assume the following: - The rate of change of power output with respect to distance at mile 100 is zero.- My piehole-to-pedal efficiency is 25% (the remaining 75% is spent yelling at pursuing dogs, thinking about math quizzes, oohing and aahing at leaves of color, etc).- My only food/fuel input is Snickers bars. The first one to post the correct answer in the Guestbook wins a prize, if they want it, of course.  Round your answer off to the nearest tenth of a Snickers bar - yes, it's possible to eat only part of a Snickers bar, but that doesn't happen too often.  Good luck!   
The Ride:  Continued north on Rt 105 from McQuady to Rt 60, which I took west to Hawesville.  There I crossed the big bridge over the Ohio River into Indiana, and got my kicks on Rt 66 into Tell City, where I refueled.  After having a great conversation with a local couple at the grocery store in Tell City, I headed east on Rt 37 for a bit, then took Rt 145 north through Bristow, Sassafras, Birdseye and Riceville to Patoka Lake.          Today's hills were steeper than any I've ridden so far on the tour.  On about five of them (by the way, none of these were over a 1/4 mile long, so it wasn't that bad) I was switchbacking in the lowest gear, and on one doozy, the final climb to Birdseye, I was out of the saddle in the lowest gear.  Yikes.  So much for looking forward to Indiana's flat roads.  I have a feeling that they'll flatten out quite nicely further north.    Tonight's campsite is great - I've got a nice view of the lake, but I had to work for it.  I couldn't get around the Keep Out No Trespassing Private Property gate (pesky gates!), so I had to portage the bike and The Pig over the gate.  As I was swinging my trailing leg over the gate, my foot got caught on a wire and I went down.  Oof!  Not too hard, but the wire did draw a little blood on my ankle.       
The Ride:  Rode north from Patoka Lake on Rt 145 through French Lick to Prospect, where I turned east on Rt 150.  I passed through Abydel then hit Paoli, where I turned north on Rt 37 and rode that through Orleans, Mitchell, Tarry Park and Bedford to Bloomington.        Orleans proudly declares, via a roadside sign, that it's the home of the Indiana State Soils Champions for a few years in the 90's.  Wow! I got to Bloomington at around 3 pm, rode around the campus for a bit, then rode around town with a stop at a bike shop that has the coolest air pump I've ever seen.  This weekend is the Hilly Hundred bike ride - 50 miles on both Saturday and Sunday.  It's not a race, more of a RAGBRAI-style ride.  A guy at the bike shop suggested that I stay in town the next day and ride it.  My twisted line of thinking: "Hmm, maybe I should take a day off of the tour and do the ride.  My legs could use a rest!"  Duh.    Bloomington is a great town.  Although, the weather may have influenced the experience - it was one of those clear, crisp, cool fall afternoons.  Lots of people were walking around, the trees were all colorful on campus, and the shops near campus were lively.
The Ride:  Rode NW out of Bloomington on Rt 46 through Ellettsville, Spencer, Vandalia, and Bowling Green to Rt 59, which I took north through Ashboro, Brazil, Mansfield and Bellmore.  At Rt 236 I turned west through Guion and Marshall, then turned right on Rt 41 to Turkey Run SP. Today was a cloudless, windless, 65 deg. F day.  Doesn't get much better than that for bike touring. After Bowling Green, the hills finally eased up and cornfields became the typical scenery.  Quite a difference from last year, though - last year the cornstalks were green (July / August), now they're all brown.      Ladybugs abounded today.  After cicadas, they have to be the clumsiest flyers I've ever seen.  I'd see them in the air in front of me as I was riding and I'd have no idea if I was going to hit one or not until the last second - very erratic flying.  Also, I learned that it's tough to get by breathing through just my nose while riding since I had to keep my mouth closed or else a ladybug would be sure to fly in.    Found a flat, grassy, open spot for camp tonight, a good site.   
Today was all about the wind.  I woke up and it was windy, but I couldn't tell which direction it was blowing as it was kinda swirly at camp.  So, I rode to the library in Attica to plan out the next few days of riding - I was planning on riding generally west then north to get to St. Charles, to avoid the mess around Chicago as much as I could.  That's when I learned that the wind would be 25 mph out of the southwest today, and 25 mph out of the northwest tomorrow.  Seeing as how I really don't enjoy riding into a headwind, I decided to ride as far north as I could today, taking advantage of the tailwind, then have the last two days be unavoidably into the headwind but not too far of a distance. After I left the library, it was just stupid fast for most of the rest of the day.  The only time I wasn't riding at least 20 mph was when I had to ride northwest for a bit between Atkinson and Earl Park - that's when I had a crosswind from hell.  I was leaning way left to counter the wind, to maintain a straight line, but when a truck would pass it was always a bit dicey (the road was a four-lane divided highway). When a truck would pass, even if they got over into the left lane after seeing my hand signals (I was looking in my rear view mirror a lot) the effect was huge - the wind would cut out when they were passing me and I'd veer left since I was already leaning way left into the wind, then I'd straighten out just in time for them to finish passing, when the wind would come back and I'd get blown to the right. I'm sure it looked funny from behind.  A couple of times, when I saw that a truck wasn't going to get over into the left lane, I'd have to stop and stand with both feet on the ground and hunch over just to stay upright in the strong gusts of wind.  Yikes. Now, that crosswind only happened for a 12-mile stretch - the other 110 miles was spent perma-smile flying down the road with a strong tailwind.  You know you've got a strong tailwind when you're pedaling easy in your second-to-highest gear, you spit off to the side - and your spit takes the lead! It was an unseasonably hot day - the high temperature was 85 deg F.  I drank all three liters of water in my CamelBak and had to fill up along the way with some nasty sulfury water from a gas station that I really didn't want to drink, but had to in order to stay somewhat hydrated.  And, the Snickers in my black rear pack melted - imagine that, on a 85 deg sunny day!    When I finally reached Schererville, the sun was about to set and I still needed to get food for dinner.  I sped to the grocery store, checked my messages really quick (no, Stinky Pants, I still haven't had a chance to get through ALL of yours, but I'm sure you'll enjoy knowing that I was running out of time to get to camp and said "D'oh!" when I heard that I had eight messages), grabbed some food, and rode west down Rt 30 from the big nasty intersection of Rt 30 and Rt 41, wondering what kind of camp I'd find for the night. Well, I found a great spot.  I camped in a grove of trees right next to some cornfields.  The sun hadn't quite set yet and I had the tent set up and the stove going - ok, good, I can eat then go to sleep.  Right when I started cooking dinner I saw a guy round a corner on his ATV and look at me.  I waved hi, he rode over, I asked him if it's ok if I camp here, he said no, and I thought, wow, now what?  It was his uncle's property that I was camped on, but when he learned that I wasn't planning on camping there for two weeks, that I was on a bike tour, and that I wasn't going to shoot him, he said it was ok.  We introduced ourselves (his name's David, and his friend Rob (Ron?) showed up later), then we talked for about an hour about this and that, mostly about either bike touring or bow hunting for deer (the arrows are so sharp that they usually go right through the deer!), which David does on the 100 acres that his uncle owns.  It was weird to be camped on this beautiful 100-acre land, with deer and geese everywhere, and it's located right next to the big, nasty intersection of Rts 30 and 41.
The Ride:  Continued west on Rt 30 through Dyer into Illinois, where I turned west on the Sauk Trail Road.  I rode that through Sauk Village and South Chicago Heights to Park Forest, where I joined the Old Plank Road Trail, a rail trail, and rode that west through Frankfort to New Lenox.        In New Lenox I'm staying with my cousin Cathy.  She has a shower at her big fancy house, and as I hadn't showered since Kentucky (I don't shower much), you can best believe that I showered at her place.   Today was a short easy ride - the trees alongside the rail trail blocked most of the wind, so it was relatively easy cruising.  It was fun hanging out with Cathy and her daughter Elizabeth for the afternoon.  Elizabeth wants to be a butterfly fairy princess for Halloween (she's three), but when she learned that her friend Megan, who is four, is going to be a cheerleader for Halloween, Elizabeth declared that she wants to be a butterfly fairy princess cheerleader instead.  Ok, so a wand in one hand, a pom pom in the other ...    After eating dinner (Elizabeth loves to slurp spaghetti, and she declares that she's good at it), Cathy and I hung out, talked, and watched the World Series.  A nice lazy day, which was a welcome change.
   Show links to this Hide links to this      The Ride:  Rode west on Laraway from New Lenox to Rt 52, which I took northwest for a bit to Briggs Road.  Rode that north through Joliet and Lockport to Rt 7, which I took west over the Des Plaines River to Rt 53.  I rode dumptruck-hell-Rt 53 north for far too long, through Romeoville, to Bolingbrook where I turned left on Lily Cache Road to Rt 19.  I rode Rt 19 north through Naperville, across the East-West Tollway (Rt 88 on maps), west on Warrenville Rd to Warrenville, then north on Winfield Rd to Central DuPage Hospital in Winfield, where I checked myself in for carbon monoxide poisoning from all the trucks. No, no, at CDH I met my Mom (she works there) and my brother Dan (he met us there), and they joined me for the last 11 or so miles along the Illinois Prairie Path rail trail through West Chicago to St. Charles, the end of this tour.  We left the hospital at around 1 pm, stopped for lunch at a great mexican restaurant in West Chicago, then chatted while riding the last miles along the rail trail to St. Chuck.          Dan's bike was in need of some repair before the ride, so we spent about a half hour or so pumping up his tires and adjusting his brakes right in front of the main entrance to the hospital - it was kinda funny.  It was a beautiful day for a ride, bright sunshine and 60 deg F, and it was great riding with them for the last miles into St. Charles.   
As a side note, I weighed the bike and trailer in St. Charles.  The fully-loaded trailer weighs 50 lbs, and the bike weighs 55 lbs.  Yikes.  I knew that I don't travel light, but I didn't know the rig weighed that much. In SLC I get to sort through the 332 photos and short movies that I took along the tour.  Aren't digital cameras great?  If you're interested (and you should be, 'cause there are some great photos, like the one of Bruce eating his potted meat food product), check back in a few weeks to look at the photos.
Important side note: I don't make empty (albeit drunken) promises.   That said, the days since that night last October crept ever closer, even as my roommate's devotion to the trip quietly faltered at nearly the same pace.  However, the looming reality (or unreality) of this trip finally asserted itself.  About two weeks ago, my roommate admitted she had neither the time or money to be gone six months, much less the physical preparation to spend all that time on a bicycle.   Fine.  Myself?  Nervous, excited, unprepared... green.  But I can not imagine NOT taking this trip... 
I've modified it (and am still modifying it): with  Nimbus Armadillo Tires - 700x28c, pedals with toe clips and straps,  Jandd expedition rear rack,  Jandd Mountain Panniers,  3 water bottle racks,  Jandd Touring Handlebar Pack II. CLOTHING:  2 pairs riding shorts (tights w/ chamois),  1 pair touring shorts w/ built in liner,  1 ss wool jersey (expensive, better be worth it),  1 pair regular shorts,  1 pair pants for dressing up,  1 collared shirt for dressing up,  4 pairs wool socks,  1 Cannondale windbreaker,  1 biking jacket,  Specialized Rockhopper bike shoes,  sandals,  2 pairs underwear (boxers and tighty-whities, so you know),  sunglasses,  cap w/ bill,  wool sweater. STUFF: compass.   oh, and sunscreen,  toiletries,  travel towel,  Eureka Zeus 2-person tent,  Moonstone sleeping bag,  jack-knifing bike tool,  needle nose pliers (thanks Galloway's Mom),  swiss army card (like the knife, but the parts come out of a blue credit card size card!) frame pump (like that sits squeezed btw seat tube and headset), helmet, journal (thanks Eva!), passport (and copies), traveler's checks (and receipts), behind-the-shirt hidden wallet, insect repellent (w/ deet), aloe vera (for sensitive skin), all purpose citronella soap (cleans hands, hair, clothing, dishes...but i haven't tried it yet), carabiner watch (thanks Whitney), first aid kit (thanks Mom!  for the diarrhea medication!)wooden clothespins (several),cell phone (that takes pictures, hopefully for this site)      Show links to this Hide links to this     
 Sunday September 14, 2003--  Training-- Thirty-five mile ride today with Dad.  From here to Southaven, MS and back. Monday September 15, 2003 -- Training--  Twenty mile solo ride.  [Central(E) to Highland, Southern(W) to Cooper, Cooper(S) to S Pkway, S Pkwy(W) to 3rd, 3rd(N) to Union, Union(W) to Front, Front(N) to Auction, Auction(N) to Harbortown, Harbortown(N) to 2nd, 2nd(S) to Chelsea, Chelsea(E) to Evergreen, Evergreen(S) to Belvedere, home] Tuesday September 16, 2003 --Training--  Twenty mile solo ride.  [Central(E) to Ellsworth, Ellsworth(S) to Southern, Southern (W) to Cooper, Cooper(N) to Peabody, Peabody(W) to Mclean, McLean(N) to N Pkwy, N Pkwy(W) to 2nd, 2nd(S) to Vance, Vance(E) to Peabody, home]   Tuesday September 16, 2003 --Journal-- : Also today... tried to figure out about crossing the border on land (after taking the Greyhound) as opposed to flying.  Flying is easier, and you're allowed to bring more.  Also, Mom is willing to donate some of her frequent flyer miles to the cause.  Probably, that's how I'll go. At least, before you're totally whipped, you can fire back up just by finding your efficiency again.  But it was dark... and I hit some bumps. Friday September 19, 2003--Training--30KM/18MI SOLO, with panniers(w.p.) [Peabody(W) to Vance, Vance(W) to Main, Main(S) to S Pkwy (indirectly), S Pkwy(E) to Willett, Willett(N) to Madison, Madison(E) to Avalon, Avalon(N) to N Pkwy, N Pkwy(W) to Second St, Second(S) to Vance, Vance(E) to Peabody, home]Friday September 19, 2003 --Journal--An amazing ride just as the sun was going down.  Spent the entire day, from the moment I woke up until I got ready to ride at six pm, reading "The Da Vinci Code," a fascinating book... transfixed me the entire day.  Then I suppose that made me more thoughtful as I was out riding.  As I rode downtown and headed back the first time, I was aware for the first time of fall weather-- and felt reminded of college in Chicago.  At the same time though, something in the sky and the early evening reminded me of Peru.  And something about Memphis, specifically the South Memphis I was riding through, is down and out--the boarded up buildings, the burned out houses, the decaying porches-- yet at the same time invigorating-- kids riding bikes, people cooking out on their stoop, an empty but well kept park with green grass as the sun goes down, the smell of much cotton candy being spun at the Mid-South Fair not too far away... but far enough that it must be a lot of cotton candy if you can smell it from here...  and it's Friday night!  People come out on the weekends here like they don't really do on weekdays.  Of course, the biker, racing by it all, you feel removed.  But uplifted nonetheless.  And I felt even more tantalized, almost disbelieving of the awesome trip I'm about to take.  !! Over beers...mmm... Monday September 22, 2003 (LITTLE CYCLING TODAY)--Journal--Some boring things today that didn't really fill the entire day... (These days before I leave, not working, offer almost too much time) but things that had to be done.  Ordered new copies of credit cards.  Don't get stuck in a foreign country with a scratched, stripped credit card as your only form of payment (from experience)!  Purchased a cell phone and calling plan (may come in handy... but hopefully not due to emergency)  Significantly, I did a drive train session with supreme bike dude Bobby at the Peddler bike shop tonight.  With instruction, I took apart the entire drive train - removing the chain, chain rings, cassette, crank arms, even bottom bracket - and cleaned everything.  Then put everything back, relubing the chain, putting locktite on threads and noting the direction of the threads on all bolts.  We went over basic maintenance that can be done on the road to avoid having to take everything apart very often (since a drive train overhaul cannot be done on the road). A good trail b/c traffic is mostly very low, and you get to cycle on some surprisingly country roads for so close to such an urban area.  Actually, you're still in Memphis on much of the trail, which is even more surprising.  At least, I was surprised. Then this morning I thought it'd be cool to put a few bumperstickers over the tape.  Maybe some representatively Memphis stickers. Thursday September 25, 2003 --Training-- 30KM/18MI SOLORode my bike without a lot of gear and the speed was exhilarating.  Also, for the first time (and this sounds really cheesy ((and probably should since I was stoned)) I was biking back from someone's house last night and really felt like the bike was an extension of my legs.  Like I was running down the street at 20mph.  I think biking probably does have to be the most productive use of the human body's potential for movement (to quote an educational bike video).  Did a training session last night at the Peddler, truing wheels, replacing spokes... not so much fun.  But vital to understand.  Then the tube under the front tire I put back on the rim blew out. So who knows if I get that far, what I'll do... maybe fly to South America, keep on biking to Panama City and then fly home...? Tuesday September 30, 2003 --Training-- 35MI SOLOCentral(E) to Goodlett, Goodlett(N) to Tuckahoe, Tuckahoe (E) to Shady Grove, Shady Grove (E) to Humphreys (Wolf River Pkwy), Wolf River Pkwy(E) to Germantown Rd. Thursday October 2, 2003 --Journal--Boxed the bike today at the Peddler (thanks to Bobby and a free box and packing materials).  I do hope I'll remember how to put the bike back together in Mexico.   Sunday October 5, 2003 --Journal--I leave... tomorrow!  After a year of planning -- and the leisurely month I've spent at home since I quit working -- I leave at 6:50AM tomorrow morning for Monterrey.  People ask me if I'm nervous, and I don't know what to say.  It's not that I am or I'm not.  It's that I've stopped looking at the trip in the "macro" -- the furthest I'm thinking right now is getting my bike put back together tomorrow in a hotel room in Monterrey.  I need to get there (to Monterrey), then find a cab that will fit the bike box, then find a hotel, then assemble the bike... then whatever comes next.  Including how exactly I'll get to my first destination.
 
 
The past two days in Monterrey were cool.  I began by putting my bike back together when I got in on Monday.  My hotel, though very nice and very expensive, was in a "dangerous" part of town.  Lots of "homosexuales," my taxi driver explained.  I didn't have any confrontations, however.   My two favorite moments in Monterrey were both last night.  I was wandering around downtown and the Barrio Antiguo last night when I heard amplified classical piano music echoing loudly across the plaza.  And this is a sprawling, green, statue-covered plaza that covers many city blocks.  I followed the sound to the Palacio del Gobierno del Estado de Nuevo Leon.  The Palace was beautiful, brilliantly lit, and the music, it turns out, was being played over a sound system from inside.  There was a small room with a man inside, whose sole job I guess was to choose the music.  I sat outside for a while on the steps, listening, checking out the Monterrey skyline, checking out the many, many couples PDA-ing on benches all around the plaza.  If only there were such a place in Memphis.  If only couples in the United States did that.  If only I had a girlfriend!    The second awesome moment came just as I was ready to turn in for the night at my new hotel after walking all over downtown.  I was staying in the Barrio Antiguo.  Just as I approached the corner of my hotel I heard live music - latin music this time.  Drums, like several drummers, trumpet, keyboard, guitar, etc.  There was no sign over the door, but just then people walked past me and right inside.  I followed them in.  Inside was a packed club with only men inside.  The band was playing at floor level in the corner of the room.  And they were rocking out!  It was refreshing to wander into what sort of felt like a Mexican Wild Bill's (Memphis blues bar) after wandering past countless trendy, more commercial bars in the area.  It turns out that this club only has music one night a month, and that it is a member's only club.  I never figured out if I was really allowed to be there or not, but the patrons were very friendly.  The Argentinian band jammed out, and a couple of people who had brought instruments joined the band for a song.  Mostly young, the group had come to Monterrey out of the dire economics of Argentina.  They gave me their cd, so if I can hold onto it the whole trip, maybe I can listen to it when I get home.  Maybe book them at next year's festival, Judy? Tomorrow, hopefully, towards Zacatecas.  Two hundred thirty five miles across high desert plains.  If I push it, over two days, get there by the weekend.  Again, I question my choice of route... PS. My camera won't transmit pictures over email from Mexico.  So much for that idea.  Also, I did cover my bicycle with black electrical tape and stickers a couple of nights ago.  So at least now it sticks out like a sore thumb.  Or wait, is that a good thing?   
I woke up yesterday feeling guilty about taking another night for free in a lavish hotel.  Also, I didn't really feel like I knew what to do with myself.  I'm still a little too intimidated to do much walking around by myself.  I ate at McDonald's next to the hotel twice while I was in Saltillo - for dinner and breakfast.  Now that's embarrassing.  But it was so good. So, today I chill out and let my legs rest over a few Corona's.  This is a very pleasant small mountain town.  And it's bright and hot, and there's guitar music playing over the plaza in front of the iglesia.  And tonight, Amorres Perros is on television!  You're thinking, he's watching a lot of television...  But I might have to camp tomorrow, so I'll take it as it comes.  Then again, I may take the bus tomorrow, depending on how I feel.   Zacatecas is the next big town that I really want to see.  I'll probably spend a few days there.  I should get there tomorrow (if I give up and take the bus) or the next day.  After that, I should be entering a much more inhabited area.  I'll get to visit a lot of small towns up in the Central Highlands: Guanajuato, San Miguel Allende, San Luis Potosi... perhaps meeting a few tourists along the way?  I certainly wouldn't mind the contact.  At all.
Zacatecas is beautiful.  Very much like Cusco in Peru.  I'm sure I'll have more to say of it in the next few days, since I plan to stay here a while.           
I left Zacatecas and headed for Aguascalientes, an unexciting destination, according to what I'd read.  Anyways, I get very far, like fifty five miles, within about three hours.  On the left side of the highway I see this sort of exotic looking cabana with an adjacent beautifully kept garden.  A sign like would be on a restaurant or hotel advertises "Villa Santana."  I did the indecisive thing and drove by it and back and by it again a couple of times.  I finally decided it looked too friendly and potentially ripe for camping to pass it up, so I walked up the driveway.  After much dog barking, three guys came out from behind the house.  I explained my situation and that I thought maybe I could camp and they invited me in.  We sat behind the house for a couple of hours, drinking tequila with fresca.  The namesake of the bar was Sergio Santana, incidentally a first cousin of Carlos Santana, of "Black Magic Woman" fame.  There were three other guys.  One of them was Salome, a ranchero who tended to Sergio's property.  The other two were Felix and Eloy, who co-operate a "massage" business, providing "massages" by "chicas de Sonora, Chihuahua and Guadalajara" for seven hundred pesos an hour.  They were trying to arrange a party for eighty men (and paid professionals) in Sergio's palapa in the upcoming weekend.  I just so happened to get to sit at the table and listen to their conversation at length over cheap tequila.  Finally, we dropped off Sergio at his place, and I ditched the camping idea in favor of staying at Eloy's place for free in Aguascalientes.  There begins a very bizarre detour in my bicycle adventure.  I spent the night, uneventfully.  The next day we set out - Eloy, his girlfriend Carmen and Salome - for some sightseeing.  We took in a tour guide's explanation of some fairly impressive murals in a gov't building.  We took in the major church.  Eloy bought me a rosary.  We dined tapas-style over several beers and snapped a couple of pictures.  Like variations on the theme "fried," with a few beers.  Very nice.  At home, the streak continues with dinner and more drinking, tequila of course.  Eventually, I pass out on the couch.   The next morning, Eloy walks in the living room with two severe black eyes.  The story goes, after I fell asleep, Eloy thought Carmen was drinking too much, so he said so.  Salome, who apparently had definitely been drinking too much, defended Carmen.  He and Eloy got into a fight.  Carmen fled the apartment before Salome battered Eloy severely before leaving himself.   When I woke up, Carmen and Salome were gone, and I was very confused.  How had I slept through the whole thing, and how had what was good gone so bad?  Felix explained that you never let a ranchero drink too much.  Sort of like pouring water on a gremlin, or so I related.  I spent the day with Felix and Eloy.  We went to pick up cash after a "massage."  We had lunch in some empty political campaign offices where we met some girls, who were looking for employment.  We took them to be shown to the manager of a restaurant.  We took one of them to a house and waited the allotted hour for her to complete her work.   All in all, it was a safe, but very bizarre, very out-of-a-movie detour.  I left the next morning while Eloy was asleep.   
  

Downtown, and all throughout and underneath the town, run a series of tunnels.  Occasionally, the tunnels open up from above and you can see houses hanging on the edge and trees growing on the walls.  Guanajuato has a law forbidding any new building be built within city limits, so imagine a perfectly preserved colonial hillside mining town with its defining architecture dating from the early 1800's and earlier.  If you can take all that in...   Last night after settling in, I watched Casablanca (in English) on a screen outdoors at the foot of the steep steps to the university.  Then beers with a few girls I met as the crowd was dispersing.  Until the end of the month Guanajuato celebrates the Cervantino festival, a major Mexican and international tourist event with theatre, dance and music performances from all over the world.  I should be here about a week, so I'll probably take in some of the performances, many of which are free.  Also, take in a few more beers, relax and meet some more folks.  More to come... Here's a link about the Cervantino festival: http://www.festivalcervantino.gob.mx       
The way it goes is they actually surrounded me while I was sitting on a bench and started chatting me up.  One of them took my glasses and asked for ten pesos.  I didn't have it - at least I didn't think he'd make me change - and I was so surprised/angry/humiliated I just told them to go away.  But next time I'll just beat somebody up.  This just happened about an hour ago... A couple of links:  http://digestive.niddk.nih.gov/ddiseases/pubs/diarrhea/index.htm http://cdl.library.cornell.edu/moa/browse.author/m.122.html

Links of interest: http://www.inside-mexico.com/featuredead.htm     
While confused about how to get to Tzintzunzan, we met Vicky, with whom we shared a cab.  When we arrived to this small village, the "party" had definitely already started.  American rock music playing out the open windows of pickup trucks as young locals tailgated alongside the highway.  The irrelevant, drunken SuperBowl side to an otherwise traditional celebration was definitely in effect.   There was a lit dance stage and risers.  We sat and watched the dance of the Viejitos (Little Old Men), accompanied by live, poorly amplified Purepecha music (the Purepechas are the indigenous people in Michoacan, this state).  The men were dressed all in white, wore smiling pink masks, carried wooden canes and topped it all with sombreros that dangled colored streamers.  To the festive sounds of the native Purepecha music, they circled and tapped and doffed their hats around the stage.  We sat and watched until the risers made a cracking sound and everyone got off.   We first saw the lights in the cemetery from high above, from the grounds of the ruins the town is best known for.  When we reached the bottom, the cemetery grounds were crowded.  It was like Christmas Eve meets Fourth of July meets major sporting event.  Even more families jammed around single plots.  Children roaming the grounds looking to clean or re-paint sepulchres for money.  Adult vendors hawking pink cotton candy from six foot poles leaned on their shoulder.  Tourists with cameras on tripods.  Candles amidst flowers amidst framed photographs amidst bananas and apples and chocolate and sugared skeleton candies.  As I stumbled down a muddy section in the dark, a female voice called out "Armando!" definitely in my direction.  It was Vicky from the taxi.  I spent the next four hours of wet candlelit cold with Vicky and her daughters, huddled around Vicky's husband's grave, stoking the fire they'd made, enjoying hot fruit punch.  I got to participate!  I wasn't just a meandering photo-tourist politely asking to reap the multitudinous coffee table book photo-ops (and a fantastic Dia de Muertos coffee table book could have been produced).  But that's in a way exactly why I didn't bring a real camera, why I had a simple disposable jammed in the single pocket of my Camelbak.  Around four am, I accepted the offer I'd initially refused to spend the rest of the night in Vicky's house.  I thought I wanted to watch the sun come up, but I found my stamina lacking.  The next morning, Vicky woke me up and paid my taxi to Quiroga, from which I took a bus back to Morelia.  And this was an awesome Day of the Dead.
The volcano was incredible.  As if it could have been any other way.  It is the youngest, or one of the youngest, volcanoes in the world - and the only volcano for humans to have witnessed being created (in 1943).  It destroyed two villages, Paricutin and San Juan.  The volcano took the village directly beneath its name.  San Juan was entirely destroyed, but for the church that was partially covered by lava.  It's a striking site to come upon.  Then, we got to run down the side of it.  Sort of feels like running on the moon if you jump while coming down, because your feet come down "weightlessly" into soft volcanic ash.  You really had to be there... Due in part to the open sore the horseback riding left on my behind, but mainly to the incredible vistas, this was an unforgettable experience.
I didn't know then when or if I'd be back, or whether I'd still be a crazy guy on a bike.  And, as it turns out, I will be merely a fairly average guy on a bus.  Sigh...  Too many variables.  Solo bike touring is very hard (or so I felt).  Though I do think I was almost over the hump.  After crying on the side of the road in Guanajuato because one of my bags fell off - and I was going to miss the early bus to Morelia from Guanajuato! - something clicked.  Some realization of the right - and THE WRONG - ways to experience a bicycle tour.  Then the next day I had a seizure.  Add to this crazy, open-ended, educational biking adventure the possibility of another seizure, and you've got even me convinced.  I'll shelve the biking adventure, for a while.   Thanks for following my trip!  Going out of the country on a bicycle - and letting everyone know about it - is a great excuse to get in touch with EVERYONE you know.  Though it does make the moment of giving up that trip only a month in a little more embarrassing.  My de-bicycled trip starts next Wednesday in Mexico City.  Again, I'll stay until the rest of the money or the travelin' spirit is gone - or until the next seizure.  If I find another journal website, I may continue my travel log.  If so, I'll be certain to let all you vicarious travel groupies know the address.  Thanks again for all the attention!    -Drew (you should still email me often at click to show email)
In Fall/Winter 2002/2003 as I was contemplating my next touring adventure, Alaska came to mind. I wanted to do a self-contained tour in a beautifully exotic place. We'd visited Alaska in late Spring 2000. I had a 'feel' for the terrain and the road conditions from that trip. Also, the 2000 visit had whetted my appetite to see more of this huge and wild state. I would not have had the nerve to do this trip had I not been to Alaska previously. To avoid the worst of the Alaska bug problem, I scheduled the trip for late May-early June. I would have liked to have toured for longer than two weeks but my employer frowns on anything longer than that. I anticipated temperatures for this time of year to be anywhere between 20 and 80 F. It wasn't far off this mark. I decided to start my ride in Valdez and to take the Richardson Highway to Fairbanks. From Fairbanks, I had the option of catching the Alaska Railroad back to Anchorage if pressed for time. This indeed happened and I took the train from Fairbanks to Denali National Park where I camped two nights. I concluded the trip by taking the train from Denali N. P. back to Anchorage. Getting to Valdez involved a day of travel on the Alaska Railroad (Anchorage to Whittier) and on the Alaska Marine Highway (Whittier to Valdez).    I flew from Greensboro, NC to Anchorage with plane changes in Chicago and Denver. I was fearful of the airlines misplacing my baggage with three flight segments so I shipped everything by UPS to the Anchorage Hampton Inn. 'Everything' consisted of three boxes: bike, BOB trailer, and BOB trailer bag. While touring, I kept family and friends up to date by email using a Pocketmail device. The daily accounts in this travel journal were the daily email postings I had sent during the tour with minor editing. 
Judy Colwell's trip with Adventure Cycling Association in 1995 was a good primer on Alaska touring. Ed Noonan reports on a 1996 trip from Alaska to Florida. Janet North offers an excellent overview of what Alaska touring is like. Susan Walker and her daughter Jessica celebrate their 60 th and 30 th birthdays while touring the 49 th state. Books that I had read or consulted included: The Milepost Alaska, James A. Michener  Lonely Planet Alaska, Jim Dufresne (I carried this with me)  Delorme's Alaska Atlas and Gazetteer (I cut out the maps I needed for the trip)  Coming into the Country, John McPhee  Against the Wind, Marty Basch What else did I do? I cycled up and down the mountains around home as much as time allowed.
I arrived around 8:30 pm to warm (relatively) sunny skies. My bicycle and gear were at the Hampton Inn waiting for me. I had shipped it up UPS for fear of something getting lost if I had checked it as baggage (three flights to get here with changes in Chicago and Denver). I assembled my bike this evening in my motel room. Tomorrow morning I'll reassemble my BOB trailer and repack for hitting the road. Tomorrow is another travel day (well, mostly a non-bicycle travel day) as I take the train and ferry to Valdez. I'll cycle to the train depot, about 3 miles from the motel. Weather's looking nice. Regards,  Roger in Anchorage
There wasn't much cycling today as it was a day in transit. I left the Hampton Inn at around 8 am and biked to the train station in about half an hour. Got my bike and trailer loaded  onto the train with the help of a baggage handler and the conductor. The conductor said, "Don't tell them inside you have a bike or they'll charge you extra." I confessed that I'd already paid the extra fee but thanked him for his help and advice. The weather was overcast, but visibility was good. At one point, ram Dall sheep were fairly close to the RR track so the train stopped so everyone could have a look. Where else but Alaska! Got to Whittier a little after noon and offloaded my gear. The ferry terminal was just across the way from the train drop point (no depot in Whittier). Headed there and checked in, locked up my bike, and had lunch at the Swiftwater Cafe (Halibut, cole slaw, and a few beers). The weather in Whittier was getting real nice--I believe it must have been the nicest day ever in this town that gets 176 inches of rain and 22 feet of snow every year. The word "weird" comes to mind with Whittier. It was built during WWII to serve as an ice-free port for Anchorage. But it's cut off from Anchorage by mountains and glaciers. Until recently, the only access was by rail through a tunnel or by ship via Prince William Sound (now motor vehicles alternate through the tunnel with the trains). Now it's home to a few hundred residents, most of whom live in the same WWII vintage apartment building. Whittier nestles at the foot of a glacier which spills cold air down on the town winter and summer. Someone said, "If God wanted to give the earth an enema, Whittier is where He'd insert the hose." What with earthquakes and all, I think I'd live somewhere else. However, this day was beautiful in Whittier.     The ferry ride started out great but soon overcast skies and rain in the Prince William Sound chased all but the hardiest inside. Saw some Steller's sea lion colonies. The ferry--the M/V Bartlett--took a route close to Columbia glacier and a sea strewn with hull thumping ice burgs. Kept looking around for Leonardo Di Caprio. I arrived in Valdez around 9:30, rode to the Eagle's Rest campground and set up camp in a light drizzle--not too cold, high 50's. Went to sleep following a nip of brandy. Roger in Valdez 
I woke up early in Valdez; thank goodness for the Totem Inn restaurant that opens at 5 am. I ordered a short stack special which was two pancakes and two eggs (over easy). The waitress served my order; I didn't say anything but the eggs were a little too firm. As I was preparing to devour this assembly, the waitress came back with two more eggs: "The cook thought those other eggs were too firm," she said. Well, I knew it was going to be a long climb up to Thompson Pass so eagerly I dug into my expanded breakfast. Valdez is at the head of a long fiord. The town is surrounded by snow capped peaks and is very attractive. The morning was partly cloudy and offered hopes of a nice day. I broke camp and headed out at 8. The Richardson Highway begins in Valdez and I would be following this same highway all the way to Fairbanks (it's hard to get lost in Alaska if you're on a paved road). A bike path paralleled the highway for the first several miles out of town. At first, the road was level and pleasant.  About 10 or 15 miles out of Valdez, the road runs through Keystone Canyon, a real dramatic section with high rock walls and misty waterfalls. I stopped in the canyon to adjust my trailer load. I had strapped both the bear resistant food canister and the tent on top of the trailer bag, parallel with the length of the trailer. The load was not balancing correctly so I re-secured the food container laterally across the trailer and held it in place with some creative strapping and bungee cording. This arrangement felt better and was the loading method I'd use for the rest of the trip. On the ferry yesterday, I'd met a couple from Anchorage who expressed interest in my plans and route. "Have you ever been to Valdez?" he asked. "No," I replied. "Ah . . . , there's a long hill after you leave town," he cautioned. Thompson Pass--I'd read about it. Gradually the climb began, gently at first, then in earnest. And it climbed, and climbed, and climbed. It took hours to get near the top and then I had a flat tire. On the good side, the weather was splendid and the scenery awesome. I finally peaked over Thompson Pass, a little shy of 3000 feet (this place is the snowiest in Alaska and there was still a considerable amount along the roadside).      Then, DOWNHILL! I had about 30 miles yet to go to my intended campground, and it wasn't all downhill, unfortunately. And it rained off and on. I used the last of my water so stopped to filter some from a stream; from now on I'll be drinking glacial runoff and snow melt. Got to the campground only to find it closed and posted, "No Overnight Camping." At this point I was really tired. So, I went a few more miles and stealth camped in the woods. Set up camp in a light rain and was too tired to fix dinner so, with my bear spray handy, I crashed to bed at 7. Roger, somewhere in Alaska. 
Slept well in my stealth campsite in spite of a visit from my old nemesis: leg cramps. Woke up thinking a grizzly bear was gnawing on my thigh. And here's a problem: How do you deal with a cramped up leg in a cramped up tent? With a rash of intense massage, stretching, and cursing, I relieved the cramping and returned to blissful sleep. Woke up early (I'd fallen asleep around 7), had a peanut butter burrito, broke camp, and was on the road by 6. This day was spectacular. The weather was not only nice, it boosted my peddling with a tail wind all day long (thus my average speed was so high). I stopped at the Copper Center Roadhouse for a late breakfast. They feature pancakes made from a 100-year old sourdough starter; which of course I had.    I stopped at the Dry Creek Campground about 4 miles from Glennallen. Arrived around noon, set up camp, and rode into Glennallen to do a laundry. I wanted to wash everything and was hoping there was a restroom in the laundry mat so I could change into my rain gear and wash the clothes I was wearing. No restroom. I stripped off as much as modesty permitted and pranced around in cycling shorts and rain jacket while the washer and dryer did their thing. Must have been a big thrill for the laundry ladies of Glennallen. Back at the campground I cooked dinner over my handy-dandy wood-burning Sierra Zip stove; fuel this evening was twigs and pine cones. This has been a very pleasant day of cycling. Turned in early. Regards, Roger near Glennallen. 
Left the campground near Glennallen at about 7:30 this morning. Another nice day for cycling: nice weather and a tail wind, although not as strong as yesterday's.    Today I was planning to ride to Paxson and stay at a lodge there (three days, no shower--you understand). About twenty miles short of Paxson, I stopped at the Meiers Lake Roadhouse for a late lunch. Also late lunching there were two ladies from Washington, DC. They were staying at a lodge in Paxson and reported the only place to eat there was the Paxson Inn and then advised not to. In fact, they'd driven the twenty miles to Meiers Lake to avoid eating in Paxson. On the spot, I booked at room at the Meiers Lake Roadhouse. Nice place, a mixture of old classic Alaska with modern conveniences. Room is new and clean. The shower sure felt good. I washed out those few items of clothing that modesty prevented me from washing yesterday. Today was a lesson in local variations in climate. I was riding through terrain equal in elevation to the Thompson Pass and nearly 200 miles further north. But unlike the Pass, today's terrain was below the tree line and there was no snow in the vicinity. Amazing difference. A few weeks prior to taking this trip, I was having breakfast with my two work companions, Mitch and Steve, in a Perkins Restaurant in Orlando. Spying the tray of jellies and jams, I pocketed several thinking they'd be handy on this trip. Mitch, observing this action, attempted to turn me in to the Perkins Jelly and Jam Security Guard but I managed to escape the restaurant before getting handcuffed. I am using a hard plastic, bear proof container to store my food items. Before leaving for Alaska, this container was packed very full of stuff. Well, when I opened my stash up here, everything was sticky. Investigation proved the culprit to be a leaking packet of Perkins orange marmalade. The result has been that everything I've eaten from my food stash has had a certain flair: gorp a l'orange, peanut butter burrito a l'orange, cous cous a l'orange. . .well, you get the picture. I hope to get everything wiped off and destickified this evening at the Roadhouse. There must be a valuable lesson here. With a sunburned face, Roger at the Meiers Lake Roadhouse 
Had a nice stack of pancakes for breakfast at the Meiers Lake Roadhouse. Rule 1 when road tripping in Alaska: never pass up a stack of pancakes. As I was assembling my kit, I found a flat tire on the bike. There was a fine steel wire in the tire that probably caused the problem but I couldn't find the leak in the tube (must be a slow leak) so I just put on a new tube. Left around 7:30.    About 3-4 mile north of the Roadhouse, three grizzly bears (mother and cubs, no doubt) started to cross the road about 50 yards ahead of me. Not wanting to discuss who had the right of way, I braked to a stop. The cubs crossed and headed into the brush; momma bear paused, turned, and looked straight at me. I THINK I heard her say, "Hey kids, here's our meal on wheels." Not wanting to become bear breakfast, I waved my arms which in bearspeak means something akin to: "I am an unthreatening and thoroughly tasteless human." Satisfied with that, momma followed her two cubs into the brush to saunter on--or set an ambush. Well, no ambush and I survive, remaining potential bear meal rather than the less desirable alternative. Today I rode through the Alaska Range. Isabel Pass was considerably easier than Thompson Pass. The climb was shorter and a gentler grade--didn't even have to use my lowest gear.    But, it became payback time for those tailwind days. Once up to Isabel Pass, it was strong headwinds. Isabel Pass is near the headwaters of the Delta River: this valley forms a funnel for wind and it was all directed at me. How windy was it, you ask? It was so windy, I had to peddle downhill. It was so windy, I couldn't whistle. It was so windy, I had to blow my nose down wind. Etc. It was a nice ride in spite of it with great weather and more magnificent scenery. There was something unexpected I observed while peddling beside the Delta River. I had to climb hills in order to cross streams feeding into the Delta. These side streams have carried huge amounts of glacial debris down from the ice fields and have built alluvial fans like those I've seen in Death Valley. So, the streams are running down on top of this mass of till and the road has to climb up to cross them. Riding away from these streams was fast and fun but climbing up to them was, ah, glacial. ("Oh, how could he have stooped so low?") This evening I am at the Donnelly Creek Campground, it's virtually empty. There's been a chattering red squirrel to keep me company. Also two large birds (larger than bluejays, smaller than crows) keep hanging around. I understand they prefer peanuts to almonds. This area is supposed to be within the grazing range of the Alaskan bison herd but I have yet to see any. I'm now about 130 miles from Fairbanks. I could do this in two days but I think I'll extend it to three and drop my pace a bit. After sixty or seventy miles pulling my load, all I want to do is eat and sleep. There are some towns up ahead and a slower pace will allow some time to explore. We'll see how it goes. I'm ready to trade in my front wheel for a pizza. Getting stronger every day, Roger along the Delta River. 
Set out from Donnelly Creek Campground arond 7:30. There was some hill climbing until I passed a geologic feature called Donnelly's Dome. After that, it was downhill or dead flat. All in all, a leisurely day.    I stopped in Delta Junction for lunch and a few grocery items. My final destination was only another six miles to Big Delta (actually much smaller than Delta Junction). I'm semi-stealth camping at the Big Delta Historical Park. The only "camping" here is a parking lot for the motorhomers to overnight in. I've just set up my tent near some picnic tables at the edge of the woods on the banks of the Tanana River.      This park is set up around Rika's Roadhouse (now a museum of sorts rather than a functioning roadhouse). Historically, this spot is significant for being at a transportation/communications hub in the old days. It's at the confluence of two major rivers (Delta and Tanana) and it's where the Richardson Highway (which I have been on since I started this ride) and the Alaska Highway (formerly Alcan Hwy) cross the Tanana River. Formerly, a ferry operated at this spot. The park caters to the tourist crowd as there have been several bus loads of people in and out since I've been here. There are some fowl at the park including a peacock whose yelping calls I hear from time to time. Camping, I have observed, has a rhythm about it, much like breathing. In the morning, it resembles an inhale as all my gear gets placed into organizational bags (like alveoli) which then get placed into the larger packing bags. All of that is secured to trailer or bike and the breath is held for the day. Then in the evening, everything is exhaled out of the bags and scattered about for the temporary convenience of this camper. This park has a restaurant where I ate dinner (a very interesting reindeer sausage sandwich). Unfortunately, they don't open until 9 in the morning so I'll likely be gone before I can sample their pancakes. I purchased one of their specialty pastries called a bear claw to eat in the morning. Relaxing with the peacock, Roger at Rika's Roadhouse 
First, let me advocate that should you ever find yourself near Rika's Roadhouse, do not skip the bear claw pastry. A great breakfast treat. Well, this day was so splendid for cycling, I rode to North Pole. This little community capitalizes on its name by offering all sorts of Christmas theme things all year round. This afternoon here, the temperature at the local bank was 78 degrees yet there was Santa Claus hanging on to the proverbial barber-striped north pole offering boundless Christmas goodies. Apparently, North Pole, Alaska survives on its name (and a lot of consumers from nearby Eielson Air Force Base).  Today's ride was a cyclist's dream. There were some hills this morning but all afternoon was flat as an Alaskan sourdough pancake with frequent views of the Tanana River and the Alaska Range beyond. For the first since being here, I rode in tee shirt and shorts.    When I arrived in North Pole, I checked into the Beaver Lake Resort Motel for the night. My room has a FULL kitchen and a wonderful shower (well OK, any shower at this point would rate as wonderful). Also, there is a laundry facility on premises and a restaurant that serves pizza within walking distance. Truly a touring cyclist's dream come true. I've sorted out my schedule for the next few days. Tomorrow I will cycle through Fairbanks to Ester (about 7 miles the other side) to camp there in order to go to the show at the Malamute Saloon tomorrow evening. Then on Sunday, I'll tool around Fairbanks checking things out. Monday, I've booked train passage to Denali National Park. What happens there will depend on availability of campground sites, etc.  According to my trusty GPS, sunrise where I now am is a little before 4 am with sunset around 11:30; I'll have to trust the GPS because so far I have been awake for neither. Of course, it never gets dark. I packed a flashlight but so far it's been only ballast. The other evening I awoke around 12:30 and began thinking about the next day's stop and campsites. I reached for Lonely Planet's Alaska guide, which I am carrying, and had no trouble reading, without flashlight, in the tent. Warm in sunny Alaska, Roger at North Pole 
I left that little bit of paradise at the Beaver Lake Resort Motel at about 8 am after breakfasting on my leftover pizza from last night. It was a 15 mile ride to Fairbanks where my first stop was the visitors center. I picked up a bikeways map so I could traverse the city with minimal problems with automobile traffic. My next stop was the bike shop to pick up a patch kit and an inner tube. My gear stirred up much interest at the shop from customers and shop people alike. I was headed west to Ester to camp at the Ester Gold Camp and took a somewhat circuitous route in order to stop at the large animal research station. There was a tour scheduled for later in the day so I proceeded to Ester (about 5 miles further) and set up camp. That accomplished, I returned to the research center and got to see musk oxen, caribou and reindeer up close. Musk oxen are some of the most awkward looking animals I have seen but they are amazing to watch--they play, butt each other and cavort around, apparently, just to have fun. They are an animal that looks like it enjoys life.    Returning to Ester, I took a nap (aah) and then a shower (aaahh). Ester Gold Camp is a funky little tourist trap that went from being a gold mine to becoming a gold mine. The roads are dirt and dusty, all the buildings are authentically original--it's very unpretentious yet offers some neat things to do and see. There's a hotel/restaurant and nearby bunk houses and shower houses that date back to the '30's. For entertainment there is the "photosymphony" which is a panoramic slide show of the aurora borealis set to symphonic music. And of course the "world famous" Malemute Saloon with it's presentation of humorous skits, music, and reading of Robert Service poetry.  One little musical ditty was about a drunken Scotsman who fell asleep beside the road. Two curious and mischievous ladies spot him and wonder what Scotsmen wear under their kilts. They peek and having satisfied their curiosity, one of the ladies pulls a blue ribbon from her hair to leave with the Scot. Presently, the Scotsman awakes and needs to relieve himself. Off he goes behind a tree and lifts up his kilt. Noting the unexpected accouterment, the Scot exclaims, "I don't know where ya bin, laddy, but ya won first prize." A good time was had by all. Roger at the Ester Gold Camp 
Count today as a rest day. It rained last night at the Ester Gold Camp and continued to rain into the morning. I just relaxed in the dry, warmth of my tent until the rain let up. Then I went over to the camp office for a breakfast of coffee and muffin (this was included with the camp site!) and gradually assembled my gear. Headed out of Ester back to Fairbanks at about 9.    I checked in at my campsite in Fairbanks (Rivers Edge Campground) about an hour later. This is a full service campground accommodating RV's, tents and  offering cabins. It has a classy restaurant, gift shop, showers, laundry, etc. My tent site is right on the Chena River and very pleasant, if not completely private (I'm no longer in the wilderness but in a city). It's significantly cooler today--low 50's. It must have been a cold front that moved through here last night. No shorts and tee today! As I was setting up camp, a man and his two young daughters came over to chat. They'd driven up from Texas, seen cyclists on the road and wanted to know how it was possible to travel that way.
