So, I got to do what every touring cyclist loves to do: talk about bicycle touring!  After setting up camp, I rode to the museum at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. Though small, the exhibits were well done and informative. Real interesting gold display. After that, I traversed Fairbanks's bike paths exploring the town a bit. Then I headed back to the campground for the always satisfying shower. Read a bit before heading to Chena's, the campground's restaurant for a dinner of grilled salmon. I met a couple of touring cyclists at the campground this evening. They 're German. They are touring the world and will be cycling for several years. I'll need an early start in the morning to catch the train to Denali. Check in is at 7:15 so I anticipate heading out of the campground by 6:30. The weather has recovered during the day and this evening is nearly cloudless. I hope it will be a clear day for tomorrow's scenic train ride. Your intrepid traveler, Roger on the Chena 
Rode to the train depot in Fairbanks with a stop at McD's for breakfast. A letdown from Alaskan sourdough pancakes, but convenient. The train left Fairbanks at 8:15 and arrived in Denali around noon. The train was clean, modern and comfortable. The car had a dome section for great views. This was a nice way to travel. At the Denali station, I got my bike and gear all back together and headed for the Park visitors center. I arranged to get a camp site for two nights at Sanctuary River Campground which is 22 miles into the Park and about 10 miles further in then where we camped here three years ago with the rented motorhome. The guy who sold me the campground ticket didn't know the Park rules and tried to tell me I couldn't ride a bicycle into the Park, that I'd have to take the bus in. He finally checked with a supervisor and I was all set to go. The ride in was a lot of uphill, as my average speed suggests. The last 10 miles were gravel which is also the road surface further into the Park.    There is one other couple here at the campground--they took the bus in and are here for several days doing day hikes. They are from Chicago. The campground has a food locker (for bear protection), a port-o-potty but no water (the dummy at the visitor center told me there was), so I'm glad I have my filter. Had New Orleans style dirty rice and a bottle of cabernet for dinner--Ah, wilderness! Yours back in the wilds, Roger in Denali 
This morning began clear and crisp. I bundled up and set out from camp to explore the Park. Access to the Park is fairly restrictive. Visitors must travel on school bus style park vehicles or hike or bike. Campers can sign up for the camper bus and travel from site to site that way. On a bicycle, the only restriction is that you must stay on the road. Well, this is no restriction at all. The road is primarily hard packed gravel and a very suitable surface for my touring bike. A mountain bike would be ideally suited for this road. I rode in about 23 miles from my campsite to Polychrome Pass (this makes a total of about 46 miles into the park). I saw the great one, Mount McKinley. Although I'd seen it several times on the trip three years ago, it was still an awe inspiring sight.    Saw lots of caribou grazing on the tundra vegetation. As I was climbing the last curve to Polychrome Pass, two Dall sheep rams came onto the road about 50 feet in front of me. I looked at them and their horns which come out, curve down and terminate in points. I looked down at my handle bars which come out, curve down and terminate in points. I'm thinking, "Are these guys at all territorial? Will they think my Trek is some sort of robo-ram?" I didn't want to get much closer. At that moment, a park bus approached from behind me. I pulled in behind the bus. A mini-van with two photographers came in behind me. So, now we had a motley parade slowly progressing up Polychrome Pass: two Dall rams setting the pace, a bus full of excited and camera clicking tourists, a cyclist, and a mini-van. After about a quarter mile of this, the rams decided to abandon the road. As I passed the rams (I was at this point perhaps 15-20 feet from them) one gave me a sheepy eye-to-eye look. I gave him a bear tooth smile and kept real close to the bus.    All of this, as I mentioned, occurred at Polychrome Pass. All of the park is postcard scenery but this pass is a postcard's postcard. I ate lunch (I'd packed a peanut butter burrito) at the pass and then headed back to my camp site at Sanctuary River. It was virtually all down hill back to camp; a fun ride, a Tour DeNali. I was the only cyclist on the road this day (at least I didn't see or hear of any others). Cycling is a great way to see this park, much more up close and personal than the park bus service. Saw no bears. Ramming right along, Roger in Denali National Park 
Cold this morning--frost on everything and thin ice on the still waters.    Packed everything up and bundled up for the ride out of the park. The sky was pristine and I knew I'd be stripping off clothes quickly as the sun rose and I started peddling uphill (the ride out of the park was mostly downhill but there were a few uphill sections early on). I was rewarded on this clear morning with several views of Mt. McKinley. It was distant, cloud-like; a ghostly presence, peeking over the Alaska Range.  Also, some caribou were feeding along the road so I got to see them real close (20 or 30 feet). As I was coming down an incline, there was a bus stopped heading into the park. If there's a stopped bus, there's wildlife nearby. I could not see anything and was concerned there might be a bear near the road. I stopped to ask the driver what people were watching. "Dall sheep up on the mountain," he replied. Well, I'd seen Dall sheep so was about to go on when the bus driver asked about my trailer. He apparently had cycled some in the park and was researching options to carry equipment. After a vigorous downhill run, I stopped at the visitors center and made train reservations for tomorrow back to Anchorage. That meant spending the night in the tourist community of Denali Park (all it is is hotels, cabins, RV parks, shops, restaurants, etc. to handle the park visitors and park overflow). I'm staying at the Sourdough Cabins. I very much needed to do a laundry; since Sourdough Cabins lacks this facility, I went to the hotel next door. After loading my things in the washing machine, I sat outside the laundry room working on email messages. A man stops by, intrigued with my Pocketmail device. I explained to him what I was doing and that as I was cycling this device was a lot easier to carry and use than a laptop computer. He commented that he'd seen a cyclist in the park this morning who had talked to the driver of his bus about the wildlife they were watching. I asked, "Was the cyclist pulling a trailer with an American flag?" He said yes and I said that was I. As I think about that, I likely saw and waved to hundreds of bus riders over the last three days, some of whom I observed taking my picture. I guess I've become an anonymous celebrity of sorts. Sourdough Cabins are on the Nenana River. (For a little perspective, the Chena, on which I camped in Fairbanks, flows into the Tanana near Fairbanks. The Tanana joins the Nenana which then flows on to the Yukon River.) Here, the Nenana forms a canyon. I strolled down to the river and watched a slew of rafters bouncing through the rapids. There's a huge assortment of rocks in the river bed--granite, basalt, schiss, quartz, conglomerate. It's like the Nenana is the bottom of the glacial funnel and all the debris drops here. I didn't see any gold nuggets peeking out of the sand. Had a great pizza for dinner. I am taking the train to Anchorage tomorrow. Weather is GREAT! Your showered and rested traveler, Roger on the Nenana. 
Today was an all day train ride to Anchorage. I arrived at the Denali train depot about 11 to get my ticket and check in. I hear behind me, "Hey Roger!" It was the couple from Chicago with whom I camped at Sanctuary River. They decided to break camp a day early, head to Anchorage, rent a car and drive to Seward. The train ride was 8 hours, but better than an 8-hour flight. Train seats have lots of room, you can move around and you can eat/drink whenever (and pretty much whatever) you want.    On a train ride like this, you can't help but noticing that there is a lot of wilderness up here.  We arrived around in Anchorage around 8 pm. Here I was, back at the same train station I'd started out from on my way to Valdez. Seems like months ago. I rode to the motel where I had made reservations. This is "John's Motel & RV Park." It looks quite the dump from the outside but the room is quite clean and nice. There's even a TV that gets multiple channels, a telephone and a refrigerator. And this is the least expensive placed I've stayed and it's in Anchorage! John, himself, checked me in. Tomorrow is going to be a busy day of errands, boxing the bike, shipping the bike, etc. As today will be the last of my cycling days (and not much of one at that), I plan to terminate my trip reports with this note. I'll write a summary/epilogue on the plane ride back home and fill you in on anything exciting that happens Friday and Saturday. Yours having completed the circle, Roger in Anchorage 
On Saturday, my flight was scheduled for 8:40 pm, so Saturday morning I checked out of John's Motel, and drove south out of Anchorage, down the Kenai penninsula to Seward, a nice little town at the head of a fjord called Resurrection Bay. Alaska continues to amaze me with its vast beauty and utter wildness. There are two philosophies of bicycle touring. Some tour to primarily get somewhere and sightseeing only as it presents itself. Others mainly sightsee, using a bicycle as their mode of transportation. I think this tour consisted of two phases. The first, getting to Fairbanks, held traveling primary and sightseeing secondary. Once I hit Fairbanks, sightseeing became primary with travel secondary. The second phase included my excursion into Denali National Park. Combining the ferry and train with cycling allowed a very flexible schedule and allowed me to do and see things that I could not have otherwise fit into a two week schedule. Animals I saw were: Steller's sea lions, bald eagles, marmots, foxes, grizzly bears, moose, caribou, Dall sheep, beaver, porcupine. Many were up close because I was on a bicycle. Alaska's a great place to tour on a bicycle. I only had two flats and both were while on paved roads. I did ride considerable distances (mostly within Denali National Park) on gravel but had no problems with this (except for dust, my bike got pretty dirty). I would have been happy to continue on. I didn't feel exhausted (on the contrary, I was just getting warmed up!). From the time I uncrated my bike until I boxed it back up, I rode 562 miles. Some of those miles were tough, some were easy; all were spectacular as new vistas and experiences opened before me. Camping went well although I ate in restaurants as often as possible. I had been worried about packing too little or too much stuff. It worked out about right. A few things I never used and a few things I wished I had. I enjoyed keeping this journal, sharing my experiences and getting notes from those follow my adventure. So, what's the next big adventure? I think I'll stick closer to home. The logistics of getting stuff (and myself) to and from Alaska absorbed a lot of time and added complications. Starting a bicycle touring trip from the end of my own driveway is considerably simpler. Killin' time between flights, Roger in Chicago
  Basics:      Specifics:  Camping  Eating  Rack Pack  Handlebar Bag/fanny Pack  On Bike  Clothing  Off Bike First Aid Kit  Miscellaneous 
   We knew things we were getting serious when it rained for the weekly ride just before the big weekend- Larry picked us up in his 4x4 and shouted us brekky at a great little cafe on the Esplanade- with the explanation that we really needed the planning time!! This guy really was going after all!! Steve had no back rack and the rear suspension system ruled out a conventional rack- he manufactured one from some aluminium lying round after being told by a bike shop it couldn't be done (trust an Aussie!!). Steve had a pair of ancient panniers picked up from a garage sale- tad small but material tough as boot leather and a very useful item. Larry had no rack either and simply opted for a back pack. I took all my panniers and tried to pick up some of the surplus. This was a credit card trip (my first) which minimised gear. Larry was looking for a good night meal (weren't we all??) and also a mixed grill brekky. Wow!! I initially tried to book into the Theebine pub but all beds were taken by macadamia-picking backpackers. So it was a few more k's south to Gunalda pub for the night- dearer- but they looked after us pretty well. (When we finally got to Theebine it turned out the nut picking had finished and we could have stopped there anyway!!) The extra distance put a little more pressure on us but we survived! Hit the Road Jack...er Larry Steve and Dave...   
It was rather amusing that because country police stations are now only open limited hours I found the front door locked  and had to ring the station on my mobile phone (standing literally only a few feet away) to tell the duty officer what we were doing. Larry suddenly realised we were about to depart civilization and rushed around to the local cafe to stock up on Rocky Road bars and cans of Coke (his thoughtfulness was greatly appreciated!!) We rode down the Bruce Highway for the first few k's to the Bauple turn-off. The shoulders are pretty wide here and there was no great drama. We'd hardly turned for Bauple when the worms made their presence felt.    From memory it was only a few more pleasant k's along tree-lined roads before we reached Bauple. Our destination here was the Museum. Walkers Band played here during the opening ceremony by the Queensland Governor Major General Peter Arnison in 2001 and I wanted to check it out more thoroughly. It is set in a long narrow island in the middle of the road between the traffic lanes with beautiful parklands, old machinery and BBQs and picnic tables. This road originally was the main highway passing through the town.    Show links to this Hide links to this        It seems hard to believe looking how small the town is now that there was once a busy sugar mill processing cane from a wide area. There was a series of cane tram tracks for transporting the cane from the farms to the mill and one of the old locos is now in the Museum grounds. We found one of the cuttings for one track as we rode south out of town. There was also a branch line to the Queensland Railways at Gundiah which was used to bring in cane from other areas and take bagged sugar out. all of this can be seen at the Museum.    The Museum folk looked after us wonderfully well even sharing a cuppa with us. We realised though we would have to finally make a move and we set off south thorugh a stand of tall pines heading for the highway. Here we clipped on our tail-lights and rode straight across the highway and headed down the Bauple-Woologa road as far as the Paterson turn-off. Sight of the century was watching Larry riding the double-line in the centre of the road on the crest of one hill. Seems he has been dying to do that ever since he was a kid. Then going downhill he threw his legs over the handlebars and let out a hari-raising "Whoopee"". Very therapeutic for all of us!!  Finally we turned left at the Gundiah-Theebine crossroads and headed south for Paterson. Seems hard to believe that some railway sidings which gave their name to districts have disappeared to the point where you can't even find a couple of old stumps to mark their existence. Lunch was eaten beside the road near Paterson, and then on to Kanyan and Theebine.      If only buildings could talk! I have a feeling this pub could certainly tell some yarns!! In its heyday it had a reputation. Thankfully little has been done to the pub over the years and so it is pretty original. The current owners are working hard to restore it to its heritage splendour. Below is the coloured glass window behind the main inside staircase.     Many of these country pubs now are making a comeback catering to busloads of tourists and Theebine often has a dining room full of locals for dinner on the weekend.      The run from Theebine to Gunalda was fairly uneventful apart from a couple of doozy hills that certainly knocked the stuffing out of us coming at the end of the day. One hill I noticed cramps starting to set in so I hastily skolled some sports drink. Interesting to ride over a new major rail cutting on the edge of town- the former railway yards in town (along with station and residences and other buildings) all disappeared when the line was straightened and all minor railway  stations were closed.    We were well-looked after at Gunalda pub- sumptuous buffet dinner for only a few of us- they certainly knew how to cook. The Gunalda pub is very old although it has had major renovations over the years. Somewhere along the line I realised there was no centre hallway- the bedrooms opened straight on to the verandah. I've seen many shearers quarter like that before but never a pub. Speaks of the times (not long ago) in the country when you never locked a house- never needed to- and often couldn't lock many houses. It was a cold night but I slept with the bedroom french doors open so I could hear the trains pass through the edge of town. I drew the short straw for the double bed in a room on my own- might have been mistaken but thought I heard muttered comments about snoring. The lies some people spread!! 
   As we wended our way north again I felt a deviation to Dickabram Bridge on the Mary River at Miva was in order. Neville and I had passed through here in reverse direction on our earlier trip through here  (see http://www.crazyguyonabike.com/doc/Broweena2003 ). While we were enjoying an early smokoh a bellow of diesel engines climbing a grade at Sexton behind Miva made us sit up- instantly we knew it was something far bigger than a semi and I quickly grabbed Steve's digital camera and bolted for the bridge. Sure enough before long came this double header train with an incredibly long string of cattle wagons.          As we headed north we bypassed the detours to Theebine and Kanyan and headed straight for Paterson. There is quite a climb behind Theebine with beautful views of the mountains to the west and to the east we could see Theebine township and the two-storey pub in the distance.    Show links to this Hide links to this      Back to the point where we turned off the Bauple-Woolooga Rd to head south the day before. Now we were heading north for Gundiah and Tiaro again. Last trip Neville and I had ridden out to the Mary River at Gundiah but we were pushing for time now so I gave it a miss and we headed straight for the pub. Larry stunned the publican by asking for tea and toasted sandwiches- first time ever apparently- but he produced same in style and we had high lunch on the pub verandah. At one point we were entertained by the antics of a carload of guys who had spent the previous night investigating the inside of a large number of bottles of grog out at some obscure campsite. It seems they were in town for some of the "hair of the dog that bit them"!!      The trip back to Tiaro was fairly uneventful apart from one last mongrel hill not far from town. We were all still in pretty reasonable shape- and Larry was even quite chirpy. No telling these suited businessman- more to them than meets the eye. We were pushing the bikes about halfway up this hill when a Scotsman rockets past- he was much older than us, in athletic gear and still riding like the clappers. "Och what be wrrrrong with you lads- I be much older than you and I still be riding!!" Yeah whatever!! We admired his physical condition but I could never ride like that- no matter how much I rode!! Nice to dream about I suppose!     
This was my first credit card trip and I enjoyed it. Because it was winter I still seemed to carry too much stuff- mainly clothing (I hate being cold and it sends my asthma haywire). I found credit card touring is great for the change of pace- someone else does the cooking etc- edmittedly for many people now such a holiday is the norm. However for me from a single income family I couldn't justify it on a regular basis- particularly when it is only me (and not the two of us) getting the benefit (unless peace and quiet for the spouse is regarded as a benefit- maybe there's a thought!!).  One interesting discovery- credit card touring is much more affordable if you head for the out of the way places- Theebine pub for example the three of us could have doshed down for the night in their three-bed room at $25Au for the room for the night- $8 a night each. Motels vary from $50-$80 a night for a room. Pub meals are often cheap too- $6-$10 Au- and in these quiet country pubs you often get well looked-after. So in future as I plan trips I will consider cheap accomodation in pubs as a possible alternative. Perhaps the economic approach would be to self-cater through the day- ensuring appropriate food for riding and economy- and buy a night meal and bed. Steve's garage-sale panniers and home-made rack worked well. Larry's "garage sale clunker" was a tad low in gearing for cruising but rode well and never hesitated. I had borrowed the bike earlier and wrecked the original saddle- the replacement gel seat made it much more comfortable to ride. However a rear rack at least is a must- Larry found the backpack uncomfortable over any distance. There are a couple of places here where I am sure we can pick one up second-hand easily. I was using home-made panniers in the front for the second time and apart from a tendency to slip they performed well. The slipping was rectified by changing how I tied them on. My daughter-i-l made them from a couple of old fishing bags and I found they needed to be kept pretty well full to keep them in shape and out of the spokes. Perhaps I need to put a stiffener in the back. Just putting this journal together has made me quite nostalgic- I think I'll ride the area again before too long- and sample Theebine pub's hospitality!!
http://www.users.bigpond.com/museduca/murray%20to%20mtns%20rail/murtomountains%20rail%20trail.html I've always enjoyed bike-riding as a kid- very occasionally in adult years- somewhere over the last few years I became interestd in the concept of touring- particularly encouraged by websites such as Ken Kifer's. 2002 and the M to M Trail was the spark that ignited the flame. Christmas 2002 saw me succumb to a fit of shoppers fever as the Christmas music rose to a crescendo and I rushed off to our local bike shop to put an Avanti Discovery crossbike complete with racks and panniers on lay-by. A thoughtful tax cheque from Mr Howard shortly after saw my Avanti home and me on the road.  I was planning a three day ride at Easter near Brisbane- but I needed something shorter locally to test everything out while having a good time in the process. Where we live at the seaside we are almost out on a peninsula- there are a couple of local rides to nearby beaches around 40 to 70 K return but nothing of an overnight nature. To ride anywhere else means going on busy highways back to the hinterland. So my short ride would entail a car ferry to the start point. I found Peter Gordon's site http://homepage.powerup.com.au/~gordonp/ a great inspiration- he has created these rides around South-East Queensland which use mostly secondary roads to dodge the traffic and find places of interest. So I pored over endless maps of the Wide Bay region vectoring in factors such as length of ride, possible camp spots, points of interest etc. The ride I finally created is shown here.    The Brooweena-Woologa Rd is comparatively remote but scenically very attractive with hills either side of the road (plus we discovered some crossing the road!!) The short stretch on the Bauple-Woolooga Rd is narrow and hilly and does carry quite a deal of traffic as it is a shortcut between the Bruce and Wide Bay Highways. The Theebine area is easy riding and minimal traffic- past Gundiah heading to Tiaro the hills pick up. The last stretch Mungar to Maryborough is very hilly. I decided to take pot luck on a camping spot along a creek somewhere (since discovered this is called "stealth camping")- the final outcome of this was quite funny. Next question- who to ride with?? Tried a few mates but they broke out in a cold sweat and hot flushes just thinking about it. Finally conned Neville a long-suffering mate and fellow muso who was half-used to my crazy ideas. He has a Repco (I think??) bike about 10 years old which still rides very well- it had a rear rack which Nev supplemented with a backpack. We were both busy with work right up to the last-minute so planning was minimal- I offered to bring shared gear such as cooking gear, tent and the like and Nev his personal gear and some nibblies.  Hit the Road Jack... 
We picked up Nev bright and early and headed off for Brooweena. I wasn't impressed when I realised we had a fairly stiff hill within sight of the car- wouldn't look good if we walked it no matter how steep. I remember looking forward to the trip with anticipation mixed with apprehension. Great time ahead- what if we have a breakdown?? We would be out of mobile range for most of the time (geographically most of Australia is out of mobile range!)and farms were pretty scattered along the first part of the trip.    My fears were groundless. It took around four hours to cover those 44 k's- almost all bitumen road, and including a lunch break by the side of the road. Traffic was minimal so we had a peaceful meal. It seemed to me that even with downhill and uphill the land seemed to gradually fall towards Woolooga. Some of the downs were spectacular for us little ducks- 50 k's with laden bikes rocketing downhill with a tiny single lane bridge at the bottom and no side rails. Little scope to swerve off at the last minute. From memory we arrived on the Bauple-Woolooga Rd somewhere after 1pm. At this point we turned towards Bauple. This stretch of the road required vigilance- it is hilly, sometimes single lane and always narrow, and cars seemed to materialise from either direction out of nowhere. When we reached the Miva turn we took a breather on a gravel heap and sucked out the last Mars bars out of their packets. By this time of day it was pretty hot.  While taking a rest we saw a spectacular error of judgement- could have been nasty. The visibility is poor here and the two side roads- Miva and Glen Echo have "give way" signs. A van roared up the Miva turn and shot straight across the main road down the Glen Echo turn without even slowing. Not many seconds after a car doing 100 ks'hr came down the main road towards us. A few seconds earlier and it would have collected the van- and thrown it straight onto us.      After the bustle of the Bauple-Woolooga Rd we appreciated the quiet gravel Miva Rd. As we came down the hill into Miva township we stopped to chat with one of the locals and gain a picture of the area. Miva now is just a few houses and a CWA hall- hard to believe once there was a very busy general store, butcher, cream carrier and garage, and railway station (on the Kingaroy Branch Line). Just after Miva is the historic Dickabram Bridge and picnic area on the Mary River where we stopped for a cuppa and a breather. The bridge was built in the 1880's with a steel centre span and timber spans either side. As I remember it is one of only two combined road/rail bridges left in Queensland. Up until the 1970's a gatekeeper lived in a Railway House on the far side of the bridge and they used to open the road gates onto the bridge every time a car wanted to drive over. When rail traffic dropped and the gatekeeper was removed the Railway fitted a timber kerb to the bridge which separated the road from the rail. On a later ride we were fortunate enough to see a train crossing this bridge. (See        By now the afternoon was well advanced, we felt like baked potatoes and we were hanging out for a cold drink. As we left Dickabram for Theebine pub I noticed a long low cloud mass to the south- storms well away from us I thought. The riding here is comparatively flat and quite enjoyable. Eventually the two-storey historic Theebine pub and surrounding township hove into view and we parked the bikes along the front paling fence and staggered in for well-earned cold drink.     The current lessees have only owned the pub for a short time and are doing wonders to restore it to its former glory. Fortunately it has never really been altered much over the years so it is pretty well original and loaded with character. The Kingaroy branch line turns off the main Northern railway line here. I have heard riotous stories about the Theebine pub from folks riding the Kingaroy line- travelling from the south they had to wait at Theebine for the Kingaroy train to arrive from Maryborough. Nev and I would liked to have lingered longer but we needed to find a camp spot so we stepped outside to push off. When we reached the bikes I looked up- and gasped. The storm which recently was down on the horizon was now right overhead and ugly. Find somewhere to stop and find it fast- certainly nothing outdoors now!! In hindsight- why didn't we just stop at the pub? We've since discovered their accomodation is very cheap!! We headed for Kanyan and pedalled for all we worth. Somewhere down the road Neville called out "Car behind- I can see the lights"   Brief pause  "Hang on the lights have moved to one side!!" Suddenly the north-bound Sunlander passenger train roared past- oops!!  At Kanyan we spotted an old farm shed- hmmm- pretty bleak- passed it up. Around another corner and there was the familiar cream shed found at so many farm front gates where in past years the cans of cream were placed for the carter to pick up. Beggars couldn't be choosers- Nev was still shy but I could hear the storm rumbling and banging right overhead. We turned in and headed up the track to a very amused farmer. Twin brothers lived on this farm and they were most hospitable. I discovered I had worked at the same school as one of the farmer's wives once- although on different days. The other brother was a bachelor with his own house and a very palatial back patio complete with comfy furniture and hot and cold shower. Nev and I accepted his offer with alacrity. We had barely wheeled the bikes in under the patio when all hell broke loose overhead. The storm swung around and came back several times in the course of the night. However we were snug as bugs in a rug. A good hot shower, leisurely tea and a pile of books. What an evening. When our host had realised we were interested in the history of the area (including the Miva store where he had worked for many years) he dug out all his local history books (and a spare pair of specs for Nev- I always have an old pair of reading glasses in my panniers). We sprawled out in the comfy arm chairs and read to the music of the rain on the roof. I slept well for the night on my Thermarest self-inflating mattress I bought at Wangaratta in 2002. Neville only had one of those thin foam mats and in the early hours I heard him drag the armchairs together for a makeshift bed. Whatever works!! 
  Morning looked ominous with heavy cloud but within an hour or so of sunrise the cloud had burned away and it was another glorious day. We had nearly finished packing when our genial host surfaced- so we chatted some more before pushing off.       As we came towards Patterson the hills started to appear again- however they still weren't too bad. Before long we had reached the major crossroads on the Bauple-Woolooga Rd and a couple of kilometres across was the the one-teacher Gundiah State School with Bauple Mtn in the background. I have fond memories of teaching music here one hour a week for about 6 months in 2000. In front of Gundiah State School is the local Sports Ground- the old timber Theebine Railway Station was moved here as a clubhouse some years ago.       While teaching at Gundiah I used to drive sometimes down to the bridge on the Mary River- not far- only a few k's so I suggested we ride down there and check it out. I had forgotten the three steep hills in those few kilometres!! However it is a very pretty area and it has been a popular camping spot for many years- not too sure about now looking at the "no camping" sign on the gate. By the time we mastered those hills- twice!!- a quick trip to the Gundiah pub was in order. When the publican sensed our interest in the pub he brought out a folder of pics and newspaper clippings which held our interest for an hour or more. The original pub at Gootchie (which I think would have been a Cobb and Co coach stop) was shifted up to Gundiah when the railway was built from Maryborough to Gympie in the 1880's. This original pub seemed to be in the Railway yards and doubled as refreshment rooms. Later after it burnt the pub was rebuilt in its present spot just off the yards.    Tiaro on the Bruce Highway was only a few k's up the road with only a couple of really nasty hills near town. Neville I think never pushed his bike up any hill- rode every one to the top and then did doughnuts at the top waiting for me to catch up. El Slacko- never mind I got there! Interesting riding into Tiaro from the southern end- the Bruce Highway veers off to the east but the Gundiah Road points straight up the main street. Seems the original highway to the south actually passed to the west of Mt Bauple straight through Gundiah, Patterson, Theebine and Gunalda. Later rebuilds saw the highway built on the eastern side of Mt Bauple and bypassing all the towns. Tiaro is one of the few towns with the Bruce Highway still passing through- very busy- cyclists beware. We cooked a good pasta lunch in the park and rang home to our pick-up agency.  "Tiaro already?? Well you can ride yourselves into Maryborough then!!"   "Uh huh!!" Nothing like encouragement!!    Mungar here we come. The Mary River runs behinds Tiaro and there was a very steep run to the bottom (easy on the brakes) and then across a bridge with no side rails (quite a novel sensation). The first part of this ride was flat and easy. By Antigua Hall the hills were picking up again and we had a breather on the landing of the Hall. We'd bought a map of Tiaro Shire at the Information Centre and I was looking for a track to the steel Railway Bridge on the Mary River at Antigua but no luck.  Mungar township we did a quick lap of honour to check out the town. Like so many of these towns as the shop, pub and various other businesses closed the towns really dwindled. Mungar still has a fairly large State School (I taught music here at the same time as at Gundiah- and thoroughly enjoyed it) and the Monto branch line leaves the main northern railway in the railway yards here.  Mungar to Maryborough has some doozy hills and we were really starting to feel the pinch. However Nev is never one to complain and I always seem to keep chundering on. When I taught at Mungar I remember one visiting teacher who used to come out from Maryborough on his racing treddly and I remember passing him on the way back into town many times- he seemed to eat those hills. Admittedly he was ex-PE and very fit!! One interesting sight on the way in was Yerra Hall- built in the 1880's in prosperous times when there was a local sugar mill and the railway was going through- I think it is the only country hall I have seen in Queensland made of brick. Finally Maryborough West Railway Station and the Biggenden road hove into view- we had beaten the last hill and more or less completed a circuit (we had been dropped off about 40k's down this road the previous day). The rest was history- coasted into town and felt quite good about weekend out!! 
Equipment wise I based my gear on my Victoria trip and we seemed to have everything. Second morning in Vic I rememember rummaging around on my hands and knees in my tiny tent almost having panic attacks lost in this welter of gear everywhere. So I spent an hour grouping everything together and using a set pattern loading the packs. Haven't had a wobbly since.  Packing order roughly is one rear pannier- sleeping bag, mess kit, tin billy other rear pannier- mainly food grouped in several plastic shopping bags-            easy to find- just grab the right bag one front pannier- clothes and first aid kit in large pencil case other front pannier- skivvy, flannel jacket, spray jacket etc plus various sundries scattered around the pockets rear rack bag- heavy stuff- tent, fly, gas stove and cylinder, padlock and chain, pump, nibblies in pocket nearest saddle Stove needs to have windshield made- takes forever to boil and wastes much gas when wind blowing. Also gradually getting into habit of measuring exact amout of water needed into billy- again saves time and gas. Trip successful?? In my opinion definitely- and had a ball.
     Why am I doing this? I have always had a streak of wanderlust. Some of my fondest memories of my misspent years are of my hitch-hiking trips across the US, a summer spent climbing in Yosemite, campfires in the Rocky Mountains, etc. Lately, the need to recapture the spirit has grown in me. (I know what you thinking... Mid-life crisis (note to self: burn the AARP card)). So why am I taking a 13 year old kid with me? Hey, someone has to carry all the gear. Besides, It will be good to have someone responsible along with me. I will try to update this journal as often as possible from the road, so please comeback and check it out.

Note: Washington doesn't have a bottle law and the shoulders are loaded with broken glass. I had forgotten what a benefit NY's bottle law has been for cyclists.         
    
  
    
      
    

  
Honeyman has some dunes that are supposed tobe a lot of fun, but we got into camp too late to enjoy them. The idea of more climbing wasn't all that interesting anyways. The girls from last night were already at the campsite as were 2 non-biker guys, and another non-biker with a dog. I say 'non-biker' instead of 'hiker' because it was not clear to me that any of the non-bikers were not just taking advantage of the system and either hitchhiked or parked nearby and walked into the park. At dusk another biker showed up on a mountain bike pulling a Bob (BeastOfBurden) trailer. His name was Mike McCann (www.MikeLikeBike.com) and Cal and I quickly became friends with him. The girls, Mike, Cal, and I stayed up till midnight shooting the breeze. After 11:00 a transient couple appeared at the hiker/biker site with their 3! dogs. Didn't sleep well with the ensuing cacophony. The pre-dawn coughing fit by one of the smokers didn't help either. The transients moved out a little after dawn.     



                

  
          
    
    
Camp was interesting this evening. When we registered we were told there was a family squatting in the Hiker/Biker area and a ranger would be along to move them out. Thomas and Sarah, a young couple from Portland heading to SF, were already there, Bill, a single guy who was the only coastal rider we could keep apace with, and Max from last night. Free Showers! (Especially since there were no showers last night.) The squatters walked thru the campsite a few times but when the ranger came they were nowhere to be found.  Ramin and fruit for dinner. At bedtime Sarah's sleeping bag came up missing.  I had been on the picnic table. Under the assumption that the squatters had a  hand it the bags disappearance we searched the surronding trees and brush  thinking that maybe they had just chucked it to be retreived at a later time,  but no luck. Made sure to lock the bikes together before we went to sleep.  Max talked on his cell phone for about an hour arranging transportation in  SF (I could have killed him.)     
 
At last we reached the Golden Gate Bridge. The first half was in sunlight and the second was shrouded in fog. We stopped partway oveer so Cal could spit off the bridge. I have to admit this was pretty interesting. A good gob would drop 30 or 40 feet and then would get caught by the wind coming under the bridge and would take off horizontally. There must be someplace over in Oakland that is covered with spit. Cal was annoyed by all the tourists on  rented bikes but we got behind a maintenance vehicle which plowed through all  the gawkers. In the Parking lot on the other side of the bridge, I gave Cal  a congratulatory kiss, but this disgusted him. Rode thru quiet residential  areas in SF out to the coast, watched some surfers, climbed a big but easy  hill over Daly City, and dropped down Pacifica. We got directions from one of  the many people who have stopped and asked Cal about his trip. Ate a pizza,  and rode toward my brother's house. I missed a subtle turn off and ended up  climbing a very big hard hill. Had to ask directions from a lady in her yard  and she said " oh no, you have to go all the way back down the hill...".  Drat. Back tracked and got to my brother's street. After 1100 miles of never  having to surrender my pride and push the bike up a hill, I was defeated by  the last 100 yards. How ignominious. Cal, however, made it up (but with no  whistling). Finito.
Another good reason was Peter Gordon's superb website http://homepage.powerup.com.au/~gordonp/ which comprehensively details all sorts of tours through South-East Queensland. My trip was an amalgam of about three of Peter's varied to suit my tastes and time. http://homepage.powerup.com.au/~gordonp/Ipswich/Harrisville/desc.html http://homepage.powerup.com.au/~gordonp/Ipswich/Century/desc.html http://homepage.powerup.com.au/~gordonp/Ipswich/Boonah/desc.html This trip was also significant for me because it represented my first solo trip on my own bike and was a test of the ideas and gear I had accumulated to date. I had ridden a weekend a couple of weeks earlier with a mate (see "RIDING MY OWN BACKYARD- Brooweena to Tiaro the Long Way") and this Ipswich ride took my abilities and stamina another step forward. Forward ho.....   
Quite a novel experience for me riding through the One Mile in Ipswich and out through Churchill past the old saleyards (and what was the start of the Fassifern Valley Railway before it was pulled up!) Finally reached the Boonah Road proper- and it really was "head down and tail up"- headwinds for most of the day!! Traffic on the early part of the road was busy but bearable. Still can't quantify my feelings that day- third long ride so no great problem but I think it was still all very new for me. First break was at Peak Crossing store. Finally reached Boonah early afternoon- 44K's. Been hearing about Boonah for thirty years from in-laws so did "lap of honour" around town. Checked out the great little Information Centre and then headed for Kalbar. Fascinated by Kalbar- whole town seems to be strung out along either side of one road. Then off to Harrisville. Discovered going through this stretch one vital principle- if a map shows minor roads with major roads some distance away either side- you can bet your bottom dollar there are mountains in the middle, the major roads are skirting them and the minor road goes straight over the top!! Some doozy hills on the way to Harrisville.          Harrisville is particularly important in the in-law saga. Grandfather (paternal side) lived there for many years along with other rellies from both sides of the in-laws. Somewhere between the wars grandfather found some brass band instruments stashed away in the Harrisville Hall and formed up the Warril View Band of a dozen or so players- grandfather on bass and my father-in-law on cornet being two of the players. They played at all sorts of functions including a wedding once and the Warril View Show (I think it was called). My wife and two of her brothers were born in the little cottage hospital there. Much of the farm business including livestock sales were transacted there and even today one cousin-in-law still grows lucerne on an irrigation block on the edge of town. By the time I rode out of Harrisville the light was waning but I knew I was nearly at my destination. It was only a few k's to Warril View (on the main Ipswich-Warwick Highway) and then a few more k's to Trevor and Myra's farm- and my long-suffering better half!! After 83 klicks a hot shower went down very well- and Myra even had Voltaren for a dicky knee!! Bed never felt so good but I was pleased with my progress to date.   
  Regardless of what I have done the previous day I seem to rise early- must be the ADD- the body can't stand still- and today my hyperactivity was rewarded with a beautiful (if rather drought-stricken) picture postcard landscape looking back towards Cunninghams Gap and the Fassifern Valley. I pushed off early knowing this would be a fairly long day also, and I was riding through new territory so I needed time to make (and correct!) a few mistakes. I was encouraged with a steep hill straight off the farm over Cunningham's Lookout. I passed the T-junction leading to Coleyville where my wife grew up- before I left we had spotted one of the cousins driving back towards Harrisville so I didn't turn to Coleyville but kept on for Rosewood. Discovered later he merely went to the shop at Warril View and had in fact then gone back home and waited for me. Oops! The 27 K run to Rosewood was uneventful- I loved the long downhill run into town. Rosewood fascinated me. On the way through town I passed the school where my better half and her brothers used to come once a week in late primary school for manual arts and domestic science- their transport a truck covered in at the back and fitted with forms- ala 1950's school bus.     The locals mustn't have seen anyone in bike shorts before- they seemed rather stunned when I asked where there might be a barby to cook lunch. They were probably even more stunned later as I departed the main street- after locking the bike I had chucked the keys down my bike pants (well I had no pockets)- time to unlock again I couldn't find the keys- and there is a definite limit to how much you can scratch around inside your bikepants in a busy country main street and remain respectable- and free. I finally dragged my rack bag off the bike and sat down to rummage through it (finally deciding that was where I must have put the keys- short term memory loss!!). As I sat down I noticed a marked lump in the leg of my shorts just above the elasticised hem. Ahhh- they had slid down and almost out!! Ooops!!    Rosewood to Marburg was certainly cardio-style exercise. The climb to Tallegalla was little short of horrendous but the views from the top rewarded the effort (so did the run down the other side to Marburg). In that short distance there were some interesting sights. A flight of F-111's from Amberley Air Force Base thundered overhead. There are several open cut coal-mines up this road; and also the Rosewood Railway Museum (unfortunately not open when I passed through).  http://www.arhs-qld.org.au/rosewood/rosewood.htm A spur railway line ran from Rosewood to Marburg for many years (I am sure I can remember seeing the Marburg rail motor times up on the board at Central Station when I was a kid) and the line was also used to haul coal out from the mines. After the line closed the Rosewood Railway Museum took over a large portion of the line and they run steam trains and railmotors on it. As I climbed to Tallegalla Lookout I could see one station below- think it was Cabanda.    Marburg I have driven past countless times on the bypass- and never checked it out. A fascinating little place. The historic main intersection in town sports - a grand old pub (1881), a 1911 General Store (now a fascinating collection of bric-a-bric) and a similar-age community centre. Further up the main drag (formerly the through Toowoomba Rd) a plaque marks the spot where the local hospital stood. After Marburg I lost my bearings (sort of- well according to Peter Gordon's directions anyhow). I realised in hindsight I should have taken the road under the highway. Oh well. I headed for Minden- via the main highway! Oh hell!! Head down, tail up- lowest gear possible and ride like the wind hugging the guard rail. Minden was only over the hill and I was soon off the highway heading for Tarampa and Atkinsons Dam. This stretch was fairly flat and I quite enjoyed it. Again the sun was lowering but I was confident I would make it in time. Within a few miles of Atkinson's Dam one knee started playing up (I had chalked up 140 k's on a loaded bike with some heavy hills in two days- not too bad for this unfit duck). So out with the Voltaren- a couple of doses got me enough relief to reach the Dam. Atkinson's Dam is a small earth-wall dam built in the 60's for local irrigation. It has a large picnic area and was a popular skiing and fishing spot- until the drought. Now it is a small puddle. The campsite was reasonable- good price and store; but basic BBQ and no picnic table or light. Later in the evening however I cadged a folding chair and table so that helped. I camped near of pen of goats and found their company quite enjoyable!! 
  Fortuntely the goats slept well and so did I. I packed fairly quickly and headed off for Coominya. Somewhere around here I experienced a couple of interesting reactions from people on two wheels plus. Can't remember the exact place of the first but I do remember a semi-trailer approaching and hunkering down waiting for him to pass. Much of the road around here is pretty narrow two lane made interesting with quite a few trucks because of the small crop farming. The truck finally passed me but before I could relax a brief toot behind me warned me I had another semi waiting sitting square behind me (hadn't heard him)- he had been waiting for the first truck before overtaking me. His consideration placed him high on my list of "good blokes". The second occurred on my to Coominya next morning. Again I was waiting for an approaching car to pass and I knew this time I had a car right behind me. The bitumen was narrow, edges were very rough and while hugging the edge I wasn't going into the gravel for anybody. On these back farm roads you couldn't drive fast if you wanted to!! When the car behind was finally able to overtake me I found it full of young guys who abused the hell out of me for getting in their way. Also noticed a youngster in with them- good role modelling- nothing like perpetuating arrogance across the generations!! I'd heard of Coominya for years in connection with grape growing- folks used to come and fill their buckets when the season ended- but it seems now all the vineyards are gone. Also very disappointing to find the famous Bellevue Homestead being sold by the National Trust and no longer open for tours. However the old railway station was a sight to behold. The Brisbane Valley Railway apparently never formally closed in late 1970's- just ceased operations- so there was never a formal winding up of assets. There are railway stations and even whole railway yards left pretty much as staff walked out of them (apart from interior fittings). I had never seen such a small station before but have since realised these were the norm for small branch lines. The Coominya Station seems to have been refurbished as a Community Centre.    Lowood Railway Station is similar except that it sits in the middle of quite a busy CBD. I found this small station- almost like a dolls house- quite a novelty amongst all the shops. This station has been converted into a clubhouse for a service club. As I was there the local Council was busy pulling up some of the old Railway yards to extend the CBD car park.         If the Rosewood folks found a guy in bike shorts looking for a BBQ a trifle disconcerting- some of the Lowood folks were downright rude in their stares and comments (at least the guys working on the car park). Seems no-one ever rides a push-bike long-distance through here. Here again I found the "be suspicious of the road in the middle" idea came into play (see day 1). I had no intention of using the Brisbane Valley Highway to ride into Ipswich and there was another road in the middle- of course I would take that.  Asked a local about it- "Errr it's a bit hilly!"  "No probs- I've ridden plenty of hills!!" The local knew more than I did. To go through Glamorganvale I had this helluva climb over a range- two or three peaks in fact- and it took forty five minutes to push the bike up walking (in fact I was getting chest cramps towards the end from sheer muscular effort) but when I got to the top- the view was spectacular. If only I had known I would have eaten my lunch up here instead of in town!!    It took about forty-five seconds to rocket down the far side to the Glamorganvale Pub and as I staggered into the bar one of the locals said "Ah you finally got here!!" Seems he had passed me one stage as I was pushing. Also discovered the road beside the pub went to Marburg- the one I had missed the previous day!! Oh well file for future reference! I had a good half-hour chatting in the pub but realised I needed to push on. The road I took from here finally came out on the Brisbane Valley Highway near the new prison and I realised I had been right- no-one would want a leisurely ride very far on the this road.  Blacksoil on the Warrego Highway came all too soon and as it was approaching peak hour in Ipswich I took the chickens way out and phoned my sister-in-law for a pick-up!! I'd had a great ride and came back with plenty more experience, some good pics and some very good memories.   
It was interesting- crossed at least parts of three valley systems- Fassifern, Lockyer and Brisbane Valleys. I checked out parts of four railway systems- three defunct (Fassifern Valley, Marburg Branch, Brisbane Valley Railway)and the main Western Line to Charleville through Toowoomba. I enjoyed the unknown aspect- even if I did deviate from Peter Gordon's maps and found myself on the main Warrego Highway. Somehow I seem to have this organisational fetish where by the time I leave on a trip I have the whole thing mapped out day by day night by night which instantly creates pressure. Perhaps these Christmas hols I need to go off for a few days letting it all hang out (well not quite literally!) - follow my nose and see what happens. As always stupidity cost me money (goes with ADD- had 52 years experience there!!)- had to replace tyre and tube after burning them with exhaust; and when sister-in-law picked me I left my helmet sitting on a brick wall beside where we pulled up. Duhhh! Bike performed well and my loading seemed satisfactory. I put my heaviest gear to the rear because my front rack is light and so are the panniers so I usually put clothing and the like in the front. Also my first aid kit which is in a large pencil case. Rear pannier one side mainly food; other rear sleeping bag, billy and mess kit. Heaviest stuff in rack bag on top- tent, fly, gas stove and canister, security locks and chains. Nibblies I put in a pocket on rack bag straight behind the saddle. Debating getting a handlebar bag- don't like bumbag around my waist with wallet, mobilephone etc. However curious to know if that would affect steering. The ride has whet my appetite for more places in the area visited. There are heaps of good rides around Boonah and Moogerah Dam- discovered later an old pub at Rosevale (not far from Warril View) which could possibly be worked into a trip for accomodation. You could spend an entire hols pottering around the dams, mountains and camp areas here. Brisbane Valley well worth a visit- although would need to follow Peter Gordon's routes which would keep you on back roads off the Brisbane Valley Highway- I would call that murderous. Also found an interesting spot behind Laidley- Centenary Park which is a Council camp area and seems there would be quite a deal to see here in a short distance. It is beside the Little Liverpool Range and a mate who knows the area warned me it is hilly- adds to the interest! 

So, I have to say I am feeling totally out of place with my hybrid bike. Everyone there had road bikes. But I really *like* my hybrid. So off we went. I don't know the names of all the roads we took.  Andrejs told me it was a 22 mile ride all together, averaging about 13mph. I actually made it up all of the hills this time, instead of having to walk my bike up, like I had to a couple times last week. I had quite the workout trying to keep up with the people who showed up, and I kept up pretty well until maybe the last 5 miles. But Andrejs and Dan were very good about coming back to check on me. Thanks guys :) I felt really spent by that point. It was a lot of fun riding with a group, and Andrejs gave me some pointers about riding behind people to lessen wind resistance. It really does make a huge difference. There were a couple times where I pulled out to pass someone (those times when I wasn't the last person), but the effort of going into the wind was too much for me, and I would end right back behind them again. There was one point where I was preparing to turn left, and there was a car coming up behind me, and a car coming from the opposite direction, and I totally panicked. Not wanting to run into a car or get run over by one, I veered off the shoulder of the road right into this huge ditch filled with muck and dirty water. ACK! The car behind me went right on by, but the woman coming from the other direction stopped and asked me if I was alright. I told her I was fine, just my pride was damaged. Oh, and my shoes and socks were soaked. Oh well. That occurred about a mile away from our return point. I was glad we were almost done, because I was starting to get cold and I was exhausted. But all in all it was a wonderful ride, and I'm looking forward to next Thursday. 
Here's my public service announcement: Use your sunscreen. I'm only 27 and I had skin cancer removed this past January!! I poured about half a bottle of sunscreen on me yesterday, and surprisingly I didn't get burnt at all, even though I was out for 3.5 hours. Usually it takes me about 15 minutes to burn to a crisp. The joys of being fair-skinned..... 
I mentioned that I had all the necessary equipment to fix a flat tire, but had no idea how to do it, while another group member whipped out a few sheets of paper entitled, "How To Fix A Flat," but professed that she didn't have any equipment. We decided that between the two of us, we could probably figure it out. After a successful transplant operation was performed, we headed right on Taughannock Park Rd. and up to rt. 96. We crossed and headed up Rabbit Run Rd. This was a very peaceful, scenic portion of road. There seemed to be a lot of dogs outside last night determined to rip the tires off these strange, two-wheeled creatured that dared to invade their territory. Luckily, they were all rudely contained by their ties and runs.    At then end of Rabbit Run, we turned south onto Podunk Rd. By that time, we'd broken up into two groups. Surprising myself, I managed to stay with the lead group. We looked to our left and noticed a mass of very dark and very angry clouds making their way down the lake. We kept going and stopped at the intersection of Podunk and Perry City. Andrejs had told us to turn left, but he hadn't said which left... or we hadn't heard. So, as he caught up to us, someone said, "Do you mean this left?" To which he replied, "No, I meant the last left. But let's go up Iradell Rd. Let's do something...... heroic." The rest of us looked at each other skeptically and told him that we really could turn around and go back to the last left. It wasn't that far!!! Andrejs just smiled and continued on. Okay, so there was a pretty good size hill on Iradell, but it really wasn't all that horrible. After I reached the top of the hill I caught my second wind. The rest of the ride seemed pretty easy, as it was mostly downhill. Those few flat miles along Dubois Rd. on the way back always crush me, though. A few of the other riders also concurred with me on this. We arrived back at the meeting point at approximately 7:40pm and went our separate ways. All in all, another beautiful ride, and my most enjoyable one yet, I think. 
We took off in our usual direction, down DuBois Rd., where we were met by another biker, waiting for us at the end of his driveway! I don't know if we were going slower than usual, or if I'm just getting stronger, because it seemed like we were going at a really leisurely pace down DuBois Rd., turned left on Kraft, and went up this killer short, but very steep, hill, which I'm getting much better at with each ride. Took a quick right onto Willow creek. We sped down Willow creek, as most of that is at a slight decline, took a left onto Gorge Rd and started up a fairly challenging hill. We went down some more back roads until we came out in Trumansburg, where Not My Dad's ice cream stand is located. Sarah and I were ready to stop and put in an order! But we continued on, across 96 and into "farmland." I not quite sure what the roads are we took out there. I'm looking at Mapquest right now, and I still can't quite figure it out! Oh well.... I know we went by a big dairy farm and upset all the cows. They were all standing there peacefully chewing their cuds, minding their own business, and then we rowdy bikers came along and sent them all into a mini-stampede away from the road. Then there was a really tough little jack russell from the same farm that ran along side the road barking at us. I think he was protecting his cows. :)    The ride was pretty uneventful, but it was very pleasant. We came up to the top of one fairly long hill, and Andrejs encouraged us to stop and look back, to see what we'd accomplished. The view was amazing, and it was really great to know that you can climb a hill like that. About 2/3 of the way through the ride, I realized my foul mood had been completely replaced by a much better feeling of exhileration. It's amazing what some fresh air, exercise, and good company can do for your spirits! 
So, I arrived at the supermarket in Moravia, after a late start, thanks to the ATM machine at the P&C on Hancock St. that ate my debit card this morning. (No, I didn't get it back.) I arrived and there was only one person there, so I was worried that they had already left!! But no, we waited a few more minutes, and a whole gaggle of FLCC'ers came round the corner of the market. So I waited 'til most of them passed and fell into line. We went up a gradual ascent out of town. I think you go maybe 5 or 10 miles, and then you can see Owasco lake for most of the ride. It was very calm today, silver and shimmery, and smooth as glass, almost. Perfect for water skiing, although a bit cold still, I'm sure! The eastern side of the lake has really great terrain. It's very rolly, so we were constantly going up and down little hills. It makes for very fun riding. There isn't too much traffic on Rockefeller road until about 5 miles from the intersection with 38A, so I was able to get a lot of talking done with Dan, heh. We discussed everything from our Romanian roots, to bikes & components, to our kids. Along the tops of some of the hills, we looked down on Owasco lake and kicked ourselves for not having brought our cameras along with us. I have an idea to someday perhaps write book, or something, with photographs of the area. Although, I know someone's already done one of the FingerLakes area, so it'd have to be something more unique. Anyway, I just can't express with words how absolutely beautiful this area is during the summer. It almost makes putting up with winters like this past one worth it.  Dan and I eventually turned onto 38... A? I think it is, and caught a straggler who thought he had made a wrong turn somewhere. So, he rode on with us a bit, until we came across a group of FLCC'ers who were helping repair a flat tire. After a harsh reminder of sudden braking techniques (translation, I was going a lot faster than I thought I was and almost flew over my handlebars), we stopped and offered assistance. Or should I say, we stood around and mused at the old joke of "How many FLCC'ers does it take to change a flat tire?" since there were 6 of us there, and only 2 people were actually fixing the tire! After that was fixed, we continued on our way and met up with the rest of the members at the little mini-mart on the traffic circle in Auburn. We started back down the lake towards Moravia. Although the terrain is not as fun on this side, the scenery is better, in my opinion. It's very flat for about 5 miles, and then there's a long, gradual hill that lasts a couple miles, and then of course the really cool descent on the other side where one can build up quite a bit of speed. There are quite a few little waterfalls along this side of the lake. There probably are on the other side as well, they just can't be seen from that road. We caught up to a few more FLCC'ers closer to Moravia... one woman who was having trouble with her chain and shifting, and a few more guys further down the road. We came back into Moravia and parted ways at the market. I'm looking forward to next Sunday, and hoping the sun will come out to play with us again!
Sarah F. and I headed up to Geneva to go for a ride. I'd found a map online for an "easy" ride for us. It was taken from "20 Bicycle Tours in the Finger Lakes" by Mark Roth and Sally Walters, and the url is located here: http://www.interlakes.com/flp/flptourbike/flptourbike04.html Well, the terrain itself was fairly easy, but the map was really horrible!!! I hope the map in the book is better than this one, because if it's not I certainly wouldn't waste my money on it. We never did find the starting point for the ride. We rode around Geneva trying to find South Main Street. We couldn't find it. So we stopped in at a Subway fast food shop, showed the guy behind the counter the map, and said, "Can you tell us how to get to ANY of these streets??" So he directed us towards the nearest one, and finally, almost an hour later, we were on our way. We decided to take a slightly different, shorter route than was on the map because we got off to such a late start. So that was fine.... we went down County Rt. 4 instead of going up to Phelps as the map directs. The road had a decent shoulder, and traffic was fairly light. Then we turned left onto Seneca Castle road, which is one of the roads on the "official" ride. That was a quiet little road with lots of farms. This road and the next one both had no shoulders, but they were fairly straight roads (no blind corners) and very lightly traveled by cars. Next we were supposed to turn down Ferguson Rd. Well..... they'd recently dumped a blanket of gravel about 5" thick on that road, so that wasn't happening. So we continued on down Seneca Castle road until we hit Rt. 5&20. How the heck we ended up there, I'll never know. Last I knew, we were heading due west, which meant we never should've hit it.  Oh well. We turned left on 5&20, because it looked like the next road we wanted to take, Old Mill Rd., was down further, and it was! Woohoo! So then we turned down that road, where my bike was practically engulfed by a pot hole the size of the Barringer Crater. You have to be really careful when riding in the shade of trees because it's very good at disguising pot holes, I learned. Luckily I was able to ride right through it, though, with a very surprised choice explicative, while Sarah almost fell over laughing at me. Payback for me laughing at her when she was learning the clipless pedals last week, I guess. :) So we continued down this road, keeping an eye out for Charleton Rd, which we were supposed to turn on next. Guess what? Never saw it! We eventually ended up on Rt 425. Like Co. Rt. 4, that had a nice wide shoulder and wasn't too busy with traffic. We couldn't find that Lake to Lake Rd. that's shown towards the bottom of the map, so we just stayed on 425, hoping to see Hastings Rd, which of course we never found, until we got back into Geneva. We had to ride maybe a mile of 5&20 through Geneva, and that was hairy. Tons of traffic and no shoulder whatsover.  But the drivers were *really* nice and moved into the other lane to pass us whenever they could. No one honked at us or tried to mow us over, so that was good. All in all, we ended up riding 27 miles, so 10 miles shorter than the original route. So despite getting lost and having no clue where we were going half the time, it was a really nice ride! If we had more concise directions it would've been excellent. As I said, hopefully the book that this map came from has a cue sheet or something to go along with the map!
"What do you wanna do?" "I don't know, what do you wanna do?" heh. We thought meandering over to upper Robert Treman park would be the thing to do, so we headed up (and up and up) Hayt's Rd. I put my new road bike to the test; those granny gears work really well. I'm quite impressed with the bike. It's much lighter and faster, though a lot more squirrely than my hybrid is. I suspect as I get used to it that will go away, though. In the meantime, don't ride right next to me. :)  We turned left onto Sheffield Rd. and continued until Bostwick. We flew down into a little dip, climbed the hill on the other side, and turned left onto Van Dorn Rd. That was a really pretty little road, and the views of the hills surrounding us were beautiful. We reached 327 and headed down into Robert Treman. It was very quiet last night. There were very few people there besides us. Despite the heat of the past week, the rains (downpours?) from last week have the creeks running high and fast. This is my favorite state park out of any of them in the area. I went to check out the waterfall behind the old mill, which was running fiercely. We all loitered around for a about ten minutes, deciding where we would go next. We eventually continued on 327 back into Enfield, crossed rt 79 and headed back towards the "usual" Thursday night stomping grounds. We rode up Halseyville Rd, and the view down into the valley on the left was really cool. The humidity and haze made it look as though there was a light fog cloaking the valley. Brendan parted ways with us at Iradell Rd., as he lives on a road somewhere off that, and next Charles and I turned right onto Swamp College Rd, leaving John and Mark(?) who continued on to Trumansburg. I was feeling pretty spent by that point due to a too vigorous workout the day before, so I didn't think I had it in me to go the extra miles. The roads were so quiet up there last night. I think the heat was keeping everyone inside, though Charles and I both noted how we weren't getting too overheated, since we were creating a pretty good wind on our own. The lack of a headwind last night was REALLY NICE!!!! I think it's the first time I've been out since I started riding 2 months ago that I haven't had to fight the wind. What a welcome change, along with warm, dry weather. Okay, HOT weather, and only dry in the sense that it wasn't raining, but I'm not complaining!!! We ended up back at our cars, where I mentally congratulated myself for completing my second ride using clipless pedals without falling over and making a fool out of myself. Yay!!! LOL, you watch, now I'm going to fall next time I'm out, just for writing that. I'm going to give my body some time to recover, and then I'll be raring to go for the Sunday ride. The weather looks favorable so far.....
So I slowed down into a comfortable pace, and began to enjoy the scenery. But not too much.... as I knew that road bike's tires would not be quite as forgiving as my hybrid's tires if I happened to run over broken glass because I wasn't paying attention.   Ann S. was waiting for me just across rt 79. She'd noticed that I'd been dropped.  Then she told me not to worry about dropping her, since she was really slow and was fully equipped for emergencies. LOL, another girlscout like me! We rode within eyeshot of each other for a while. We rode down White church road together, which has some really cool views of the valley that is between that and Coddington Rd. I had two interesting dog experiences, the first of which was along this road. I heard a vehicle coming up behind me, and just continued on as normal. It started to pass me, and a huge canine let out this deep, bellowing "WOOF!!" which just about gave me a heart attack! LOL, I mean, you just don't expect cars to bark at you! So Anne and I traveled together down 96B to just outside of Candor, where we took Gridleyville Crossing road over to rt. 96 instead of going into the small town to stop at the convenience store. We stopped for a snack and a stretch right before we turned from Gridleyville onto 96.    I continued down 96 and turned left onto Straits corners rd., and started up a long, gradual incline. Most of the other riders must have went on into Candor and stopped at the convenience store, because as I neared to top of the hill, a bunch of them started to pass me... again.  :)   We were almost at the top when I saw a large-ish dog standing in the middle of the road. But since a bunch other cyclists had just passed the dog without incident, at least as far as I could tell, I just kept going. As I neared it, I called out "Hi puppy!" to the dog. He was a cute dog.   Uh oh, here comes cute dog right at me. Uh oh, is that cute dog growling at me? Yep, definitely growling, with some snarling in there. SLIME! SLIME! Dog's wet nose is on my calf!!  AAAAHHH!!! Okay, what did my _Cycling for Dummies_ book say about dog encounters? Go as fast as you can? Not happening, since I'm still going up a hill, ummmm...... oh yeah! I deepened my voice and yelled out a stern "NO!" and cute-turned-territorial doggie went back into his yard. Phew. Compared to that, the rest of the ride was pretty much without incident.  Well, except for falling a couple times. I caught up with about 4 other riders where Halsey Valley rd. intersected with 96. We went up Crumtown rd, which has 4 pretty good hills on it. Going up the first hill, my chain gone caught when I tried to downshift, and splat, went Brenda on the pavement. Not too much of a problem. My seat got knocked out of whack, so it took me a few minutes to fix that. Started going again, and I was spent. Just totally bonked. Man it was hot today, and the sun was pretty intense on top of it. I started up the third big hill, and about halfway up I knew I couldn't do it. So I tried to get off, but somehow managed to get tangled up with the clips and splatted a second time. This time I landed in gravel, so I did quite a bit of damage. I'm sitting there on the side of the road, debating on whether or not to go to my mother's house, which was about a mile away off on Peter Rd., or whether to tough it out and keep going. I looked down at my knee and I had blood running down my leg. Didn't even care. Yeah, whatever. LOL! I had some bandages in my bag, but my skin was so sweaty and dirty I knew they wouldn't even stick. Oh, what's that? I just sucked the last of my water out of my Camelbak. ARGH! So, I walked the rest of the way up the hill, and decided to just keep going. I was so tired by this point, when I came to the last hill, I didn't even bother trying to ride up it. I just got off my bike and walked it up. Another girl passed me, and at the top she pulled over, apparently having trouble with *her* chain. I came up to her and we talked for a couple minutes, and she was out of water too. She was afraid of passing out, and I said, yeah, I'm pretty dehydrated, too. We were right next to a house with a bunch of people out front, so we decided to ask them if they'd mind letting us refill out water bottles. They were happy to help us out, let us use their bathroom, and a woman gave me a washcloth to clean my scrapes out. They were so nice. :) We got down to 96B, and I just couldn't bear the thought of having to climb any more hills to get back to East Hill Plaza, so I told the girl I was just going to keep going down 96B into town and home. I figured Icould get my husband to take me to get my car later. So I did that. By the time I got to the intersection of Aurora St. and State St., my whole body was shaking. But I was soooooooo happy to be home! WOOHOO!!!! I was pretty happy when I saw that I'd shaved off a half hour from the 60 mile ride I did a month ago! I finished it in 5 hours, including stops, whereas the Tioga county ride took me 5.5 hours, maybe a bit longer. So I was pretty psyched by that. PLUS, the Tioga county route was flat, and this one had tons of hills on it. So I think I did really well. :) Anyway, I got home and passed out on the couch for about half an hour, but other than that, I feel pretty good! The wonders of ibuprofen....
As per the norm, we headed off north, this time going up into Trumansburg and turning left once we entered town. We headed out a couple side roads until we ended up on route 227, and followed that out a ways. Nice, peaceful, quiet... and just like last week's right, there was a thick haze from the heat and humidity hanging in the air, giving everything a foggy appearance. I find it quite beautiful, myself. We went through lots of rolling farmland, went through Perry City, and finally headed back to the meeting point via Iradell Rd. Andrejs, Charles and I started up a gradual, long incline, chatting away. "God, Andrejs, doesn't this hill EVER end?" I demanded about a mile into it. Charles responded cheerfully, "Oh, it ends, and we coast downhill for a while, and then we go up another!" I just shook my head and groaned, wondering why am I doing this again? Oh yes, there it is, as we crest the top of the hill and the world: it's that breathtaking panoramic view we indulge upon once we finally pedalled up that last huge wall of hill, panting and gasping for air, yet feeling as though our entire bodies have been purged of all toxins. And the wonderful rush of excitement as "WOOHOO, I did it!" rages through my mind once again.    As we neared our end point, we rode past a huge meadow where four or five deer were grazing. They saw us coming, and decided that racing us from afar seemed like a fun idea. They all began running through the meadow parallel to us, white tails flipped up, gracefully bounding through the tall grasses. What a perfect end to a perfect ride..... 
Off we went! After settling into our own individual paces, I started out riding with Anne Shapiro, and two other people I'd met earlier that morning, another Anne, and Owen, for about the first quarter of the ride. I really enjoyed East River Rd. It had a beautiful view of a deep valley off in the distance, all green and lush looking. We almost missed a couple of turns, but luckily I had burned the names of some of the roads into my memory, so when I saw the road signs, a little voice would say, "Hey! I think I'm supposed to turn!!" Going down Taylor Valley Rd., we caught up to Alex, Jack, Andrejs and Charles. The Flat Tire Demon had decided to pay Alex a visit, so they were helping him out with that. I stopped briefly, but figured that they were stronger riders than I, so I went on ahead with Owen and Anne, figuring they'd catch up. Charles and Andrejs also decided the same thing.
