From that point on, I rode with Andrejs and Charles for a good bit of the ride.  This part of the route involved a lot of gently rolling hills. There wasn't anything too strenuous, and I was feeling quite hopeful for the remainder of the ride. At the end of Taylor Valley, turning onto rt. 26, we all stopped for a short break. Apparently my body decided I wasn't torturing it enough on this ride, so as I came to a stop, I unclipped my right foot, but somehow ended up leaning over to my left and landed on the pavement.  UGH NOT AGAIN!!!! Ya know? One of these days, I WILL get the hang of this! So I had to fight with my bike a bit to get my left foot unclipped so I could get up. I got up and surveyed the damage, which wasn't too bad. Just a small cut across my ankle from the derailleur, right next to the lovely gash that I received from a fall a couple weeks ago. Okay, so back on the horse, or something like that. By that time, Jack and Alex had caught up to us. We started up route 26 and fell into a haphazard paceline. I've never really ridden in a paceline, so Andrejs yelled at me to notice the reduction in wind around my head, and I definitely noticed it. He said it would work wonderfully until we hit the hill coming up, because he'd never been in a paceline that could overcome gravity *grin*. We started up the hill, and I came out at the top feeling pretty strong, thinking, "Oh, well if *that's* as bad as it gets, them I'm all set." Little did I know the pain that lay ahead.... We came down the other side and I saw Alex pull off to the side. Apparently he's such good company that the flat tire demon decided to pay him yet another visit. I stopped for a few minutes, but realized that he, Jack, and Charles were all much stronger riders than I, and that if I didn't get started again I'd get left behind. So I started off and met up with a guy in a maroon shirt I hadn't previously seen, Andrejs, Owen, and the two Annes again in Willet. Charles showed up soon afterward, as Don and Alex had the flat tire just about changed. We began a steady ascent up rt. 221 at this point, where Andrejs foreboded that this was the beginning of the climbing. I really need to get a cyclometer with an altitude reader.... About halfway up the first hill, Alex and Don came charging past us. I did pretty well going up these hills. I reached what I  hought was the top, but looking ahead I realized it just flattened and then started going up again. So I made it to the top of that, still feeling good, when I noticed that it was just flattening before going up yet again! Grrrrr!! Andrejs passed me at this point, and I said to him, "I hope this is the last 'bump'!" He replied "I'm not going to say ANYthing!" Which I knew was just bad. Bad, bad, bad. I got to the "top" of that hill and saw that AGAIN it had flattened and was going up, although this one was not as steep as the last couple, so I panted out, "Oh, that wasn't so bad, " to Andrejs as we crested. He just kinda smiled, and soon I saw why. We flew down the other side of that hill, when I noticed the mother of all hills looming ahead, seeming to go straight up. As I reached the bottom of the hill, I thought to myself, "Oh, it can't be *that* bad! They always look bad when you're coming off another hill. It won't be so bad once I start up it." And then I reached it and looked up, and I was right... it wasn't so bad, IT WAS WORSE!  ARRRRGH!! So I shifted down into my lowest gear, but even so, amazingly I managed to pass a couple other people. Of course, by the time I reached the top of this hill, I was spent. Andrejs passed me towards the top where it flattened out, as I was trying to catch my breath. He stopped a bit further down the road, and so I stopped. I just kinda slid off the seat and planted my feet on the ground, my whole body shaking like crazy. Someday I will learn to pace myself. Probably after I pass out from overexhertion one of these days. I finally got my breathe back, and we started down the hill into Marathon. Andrejs warned me that it was a steep descent, but I didn't find it too bad. We stopped at a Mobile station and met up with the rest of the FLCC'ers. We stopped for about 15 minutes, where I loaded up on more Gatorade and ate another power bar. I think my stomach is finally beginning to tolerate Gatorade, as it didn't make me too nauseous this time.   Andrejs told the group that we (he and I) were planning on just taking rt 11 back to Cortland, shaving off 5 miles and more climbing from the ride. We picked up a couple people this way, Dana and David, the same David I'd met last Sunday. Although I didn't realize it at first, because he and Owen both had similar bright red jerseys on, and my confused brain thought that they were the same person until I saw them riding side by side. Huh, what? Duh. LOL!!! So it was a 10 mile ride up to Cortland, straight into an unrelenting headwind. I'd noticed it as a crosswind on the top of some of the hills when we were heading west to Marathon. A couple times I thought it was going to knock me right over, and I found just how strong it was trying to ride right into it. We had a small group: Owen, Anne, Guy in Maroon, David, Andrejs, Dana, and me. We pretty much tried to stay together and form a paceline into the wind. Finally we arrived back into Cortland around 1:15pm, finishing our 50 mile trip in about 4 hours, including stops. I am totally psyched that I was able to keep up with a group of strong riders. That feels like even more of an accomplishment than "just" riding 50 miles.
I turned onto 327 and then turned off onto Trumbulls Corners Rd, beginning a long steady ascent. This was truly a beautiful road, going through a thick, dark, green forest, with some nice streams going under and along side the road to provide distraction from the climb. As I neared the end of the climb and could see the end in sight, I consulted my heart rate monitor, which had me in the 180's. I recalled Andrejs telling me there were no "memorable" climbs on this ride. "Memorable!  This isn't memorable?" I thought to myself. "It'll be memorable when they find my 27 year old body in the ditch, dead from premature heart failure!!!" But alas, finally I reached the top of the hill and turned into a nice flat, finally catching up to a small group who was waiting around for us slow people a couple miles later. I am truly convinced that Andrejs was a shepherd in a former life. :) We continued on once we had everyone, and headed out on Protts Hill road, which also had some wonderful views of Connecticut Hill and the surrounding hills. True to Andrejs' word, there weren't really any memorable climbs in this ride. There was, however, a memorable *descent*, and it was at the end of Protts Hill. I started riding down it, saw that it literally turned into a sheer drop, pulled over and got off my bike. And began to walk it DOWNhill! Now THERE is a first.   I mentally thanked Gary Weidberg for recommending mountain biking shoes instead of road shoes as I gingerly made my way down this hill. It was REALLY slippery! Everyone was down the hill, and so we took off down 13, and back up Trumbull's corners rd, over to Sebring, and back out onto 13. Andrejs and I decided to burn a little rubber out on 13, and we tore our way down the highway until the next turn, onto CR 14 in Alpine Jct.   Just before we turned from CR 14 onto CR 15/Church St., there was yet another breathtaking view of the surrounding hills and green countryside.    We stopped at the convenience store in Odessa for about a half hour, and watched some of the goings-on of the locality. These little towns sure do have a lot of personality, that's for sure. Having gone to school in Spencer Van Etten, I'm pretty familiar with little towns like this. I'm sure they were just as intrigued by us as we were of them, heh. After our break, we remounted and embarked on our last 27 miles. The long break didn't do me any favors, and my legs felt like pure lead as we started. On top of it, the Winnie the Pooh song my son has been listening to constantly began replaying over and over again in my head at this point. I trailed behind the lead group for a while, but in doing so, I was treated to a really cool scene. When the group turned onto CR 6, the road that goes around Cayuta Lake, they were up on a ridge. It looked as though they were riding a tightrope, and only the sky was in the background. So it provided a really cool image, of these riders on their bikes, silhouetted against the blue backdrop. Really neat :)   (Oh yeah, the sky cleared up and it turned into a beautiful day about an hour after we started). CR 6 is another really beautiful road that goes through forest, and then farmland. We reached a "minor inconvenience" (hill) as Andrejs put it, and worked our way up that. We stopped at the top, and Charles said this was his favorite view of the entire ride. It was a really nice view, a grand vista of a valley with some houses and a farm, plus really pretty mustard plants along the side of the road, and some other blue flowers I don't know the name of... We came back through Mecklenberg and then Perry City, and decided to turn off of Perry City Rd. in favor of some other roads that would take us around the ridge rather than over it.   We crossed 96 and were in the homestretch. At this time, my bike decided the ride had just been far too mundane and it was time for some theatrics. As we went up this short, steep incline just before Gorge Rd., I didn't shift down far enough soon enough. I got toward the middle of the hill and tried to shift to the smallest gear, and the chain fell off! Ugh! Not having any momentum at all, without any time to even think of unclipping, I went down. So there I am, lying on the pavement, unable get my shoes unclipped, mentally screaming "AUGH! A CAR'S GONNA COME AND I'M GONNA DIE!!!"   I looked up and sure enough, there's a car coming to a stop behind me! Oh, HOW EMBARRASSING! I mean, bad enough when you fall in front of other cyclists who understand the whole concept of clipless pedals, but I can only imagine what was going through this couple's head as they saw me struggling to get away from my bike. So this woman came bolting out of the passenger side of the car crying, "ARE YOU OKAY??!!" as I'm floundering around like a fish out of water. FINALLY my right shoe unclipped and just like that, the left one came out, too. I got up, and assured her, "Really, I'm fine. This is just a normal day for me. See, look, I'm not even bleeding!" LOL!!!!! After getting the chain straightened out and spouting off a bit to no one in particular, I got back on the bike and continued on back to my car. I imagine that there has probably never been another person in the history of clipless pedals that's fallen as much as I have! "They" said, Oh yeah, after a couple of first timer falls, you'll be fine!! Yeah, right, whatever. You obviously don't know who you're dealing with, here!! ~wry grin~ Until I do some really serious damage to myself, I'm going to keep at these things. A few scrapes, bruises.... ahh, it's just like being a kid again! Anyway, another nice long ride, which all in all, was very beautiful. The weather was great. Another Sunday well spent, in my opinion! 
There was a time, and it wasn't that long ago, maybe a month or so.... when I thought riding 30 miles on a weeknight would be an act of total and utter insanity. I mean, that's a ride best left for weekends, when one has all the time in the world to finish, and one is not racing darkfall home. As I rode the Thurs. night easy ride last night, we reached T-burg and pondered about whether or not we would go 20 or 30 miles that night. I found myself mentally rooting for the 30 mile journey, and feeling like major disappointment would be experienced if we chose to do the 20 mile route. So... does that mean I'm insane now? Come now, what is 30 miles, anyway? It only took us a couple hours to complete, and yeah, it was getting fairly dark when by the time we reached our cars.... but insanity? No, I'm thinking *progress.*  Progress in my climbing skills--I'm able to go up hills in larger gears than I could just a month ago, progress in speed--my average speed has been steadily improving, progressing endurance--I'm not dog-tired after riding 30 miles anymore, progress in that I haven't fallen/crashed in over two weeks now!!! .... But not necessarily insanity. Except for the fact that I'm actually beginning to *like* hills. What? I didn't just write that, did I? Definitely nuts.... I've been climbing hills all week, which is why I strongly suggested we *not* take Iradell or Perry City Rd. last night, and took it upon myself to lead the group on a route around the ridge instead. Was it cheating? Yeah, probably, but there are plenty of hills around here to climb if you were really feeling deprived. :) Anyway, our ride last night was really wonderful. It was a bit muggy starting out, but by the time we were 5 or so miles away from the end, it was getting a bit chilly. We had a good group starting out, 8 people, and then picked up another rider on Dubois Rd, and from out of nowhere, Charles came charging through like a train gone wild on Gorge Rd. We went on a little jaunt through the side streets of T-burg, as we missed our turn onto 227 and had to backtrack a bit. We headed our Searsburg Rd. to Stillwell Rd., came back 227 towards Perry City, and stopped at the intersection to decide which way to go next. I was not in favor of Iradell at all, was on the fence about Perry City, but was much more incensed to use my powers of persuasion to convince people to go over Waterburg and a few other roads in order to avoid the ridge. It really wasn't that difficult to persuade people. :) We took a few roads here and there that Andrejs had shown me and a few others on the ride back from Odessa a few weeks ago, hoping I would remember all the turns.   And I did remember the turns, so at least I didn't lead an entire group of people astray. It's one thing when you get lost on your own, but a whole 'nother story when you've got a bunch of people following you. heh!      We made it back just as it was getting dark, what with the overcast skies and all. I guess it's time to invest in a tail light... does the spending $$ EVER STOP??!!! Rhetorical question, I know. We saw a herd of deer in one field, made some wild guesses at the types of plants growing in the fields. "What do you think that is over there?" "Umm....... crops?!" as Kerry responded. Had a run in with some sort of field mower/hayer/tractor/something or other the size of a small house. That was kinda interesting. No ornery dog encounters (the word must've traveled that I am fully prepared to deal with them now), but there was a little fuzzy black kitten standing along the side of the road that was really cute! I would've like to have stopped and taken it home, but the cat I already have probably wouldn't appreciate that much. All in all, another fun ride! 
My first picture was of an inquisitive, friendly horse that was curiously peering at us from behind a tree as a group of 6 of us stopped briefly to refuel. I never realized how many horse farms are in the area until I started biking! We continued down some rural roads west of Seneca lake, many of which provided some really great views of the lake.  Although not very blue because of the cloudy, hazy skies, it almost looked like glass, it was so calm. Sometime along the way, we realized that we weren't on a road that was on the cue sheet or the map.  Obviously we'd missed a turn or taken a turn that we weren't supposed to! But it was all good, since someone had a map of the area, and we were able to hook back up with the route on the cue sheet. We began seeing quite a few Amish people in horse drawn carriages and riding bikes as well. We went down Ridge Rd, where there was a huge hill we sped down; I topped out at 43mph and about scared myself to death. :) It was fun though.... roller coaster, anyone? There were a bunch of kids and some adults riding their bikes around here in a leisurely fashion, and they seemed quite surprised when we came blazing through. Of course, on the other side of the descent, there was a huge hill, like a wall. I tried using the momentum from going down the hill to get up the other side, but I downshifted a little too enthusiastically and dropped my chain and jammed it up. Lucky for me, I was able to get unclipped both feet safely on the ground before my body met pavement. The chain was jammed up pretty good, and it took me a good three or four minutes to get it all straightened out. Ack, then I had to take off in the middle of this monster hill! But I made it without another incident. Finally, we were getting close to Geneva and preparing for our rest stop. We stopped at the lakefront park for food for about a half hour before heading on our way. I think I could've laid down and taken a nap at that point.... it was a very tempting idea! We were a little over halfway through our ride and ready to finish though. We were in the middle of the hottest part of the day, and the heat was getting intense.  We headed up rt 96A and turned off onto East Lake road near the psychiatric center. This road took us down the eastern side of Seneca lake, but the views from this side weren't as grand as from the other side. Or, maybe at this point I was just getting too tired to enjoy the scenery. I swear, this road, although the cue sheet SAYS it was only 7.6 miles long, it seemed to take an *eternity* to ride, and the group was setting a pace that was just too much for me. My head felt like it was going to explode, and my stomach was complaining quite a bit as well. So I slowed down and decided, hey, if I get left behind, oh well.  I've got the cue sheet & map, I'm all set. But Carl slowed down and kept me company, which I truly appreciated. Toward the southern end of East Lake rd., it goes through Sampson state park. Since most of the road was blocked to car traffic, it was peaceful, and SHADY, which was a welcome relief. We regrouped at this point and 6 of us rode together. The roads were a bit rough, but this section of the ride was quite nice. After getting off this road, we took a few other county roads. Around mile 60 or so, it started raining. Lightly for a while, but then it came down fairly hard for a few minutes, and then it was over. It was actually kind of nice and cooling, and I actually wished it would rain a bit more. After the shower, it became muggy and oppressive, and again, my head began to throb. Soon my right leg began to join in on the chorus of complaints and threatened to start cramping up in various places, so Carl and I stopped for a few minutes. I downed a Gu gel, yech, that was pretty nasty! But it seemed to do the trick, as suddenly the world, which had been a bit fuzzy and faded, became brightly lit in technicolor!  Alright, 20 more miles, NO PROBLEM! But it was a bit of a problem. I had run out of all fluids, and my left hand was so numb I couldn't shift my gears anymore. ACK! I thought there was something wrong with my derailleur, but we stopped and Carl was able to shift it without any difficulty whatsoever. Now if that isn't embarrassing, I don't know what is. So, he shifted it into the big gear for me, and finally we found a convenience store where we could get more water/gatorade, and the last 10 miles were a piece of cake. We stopped at Hector Falls where I did the tourist thing and took more pics, and came down the hill of rt. 414 and made it back to the Wal-mart parking lot. Phew. 82.5 miles later, and here I am! Yay! I did it! 
When we got to the turn-off for Sheldrake, Carl decided to take the loop, and I decided to follow Charles and keep going straight up rt 89.  I rode maybe a half mile behind him for the next few miles, and we met up with some of the riders from the main group coming out of the loop down into Sheldrake back onto rt 89. There were really nice views of Cayuga Lake from rt 89, and the shoulder of the road was in good condition and quite wide, so it was good riding. I'm not as nervous about riding with traffic as when I first started back in May, so the cars going by didn't bother me too much. At one point, I was following Charles, about 20 feet behind him, perhaps, and I noticed him swerve, and then saw why. There was a thick plastic lid from a cooler sitting in the middle of the shoulder. I missed it by millimeters, I think, while visions of hitting that thing and going flying at 20-some mph flicked through my head. Other than that, the ride as a whole was fairly uneventful. The pretty parts along this section were going through Varick and another little town, where 89 goes right along the shore of the lake. I could see people out on their docks fishing and swimming and just basically having a good time. I lost Charles again, and turned off 89 down the road which led up to Cayuga State Park at the northern tip of Cayuga Lake. This was a nice quite little road that went right along the lake again, with a view of the railroad bridges going across the tip of the lake.   I finally rolled into Cayuga State Park, and pretty much the rest of the group was there already. They'd been there about 20 minutes. We quickly took off again, after about a 10 minute rest for me. Charles, Chris, and a couple others decided to go up through Montezuma Refuge to get their extra miles in and make the ride a full century.  At first, I thought of going with them, since I was still feeling pretty good. After a couple miles, though, I realized I wasn't going to be able to keep up with them, and I really didn't want to hold them back.  So when they turned left at the intersection of rts 89 and 5&20, I headed right, going directly for rt 90. I was headed south, back home!  I was halfway through my ride! I was still feeling pretty good by this point, about 40 miles into the ride. I stopped for a moment in the middle of a hill, as I thought I saw some road markings indicating a turn. I was about to get my cue sheet out, when I heard this whoosh coming up behind me. I looked up and saw the main group of riders coming, passing, gone! "Oh, okay, I guess I AM heading in the right direction," I said to myself. So I remounted and took off.   A few more miles down the road, around mile 50 or so, I started to tire. The heat was beginning to bother me quite a bit. I began to feel like a 4 cylinder engine running on 3 cylinders, faltering and sputtering. I pulled over for a short break, and another rider pulled up next to me.  I asked him if he had any idea how far Union Springs was, but he wasn't sure. I never got his name, but learned that he was a grad student in engineering at Cornell. We rode together for a while, finally getting to Union Springs. Yay! Food!! So, we stopped for about 20 minutes and watched a few more smaller groups of riders pass by. We took off again, but unfortunately, the food didn't seem to refuel me very much. The grad student went on ahead, and by now I was feeling like I was running 2 cylinders! I turned off rt 90 onto Lake road just south of Aurora. This was another nice little road, right along the lake and shady, providing relief from the relentless sun. I came up upon Long Point State Park, and stopped there for water (maybe this should be called the NY State Park day-tour). However, they had big signs up on the mirrors stating that the water was only for washing, please do not drink. Oh MAN! That SUCKS! So, I hosed the dirt and grime and bugs off myself and headed back on the road. The road curved and turned into a fairly steep upward climb. I just looked at it and said to myself, "Yeah, I don't THINK so! And why can't this damn sun go behind a cloud?!!! Puh-LEAZE RAIN or SOMETHING!!!" I rode up it a bit, but when it got to the steepest incline, I got off my bike and walked it up the rest of the way. I crested the hill and saw a rider in a red jersey with a camelbak. "Hmmm....... that looks like Carl!" He had stopped underneath a tree for shade, so I caught up to him, and it was, indeed, Carl. After another short break, we started off again. Augh, by this point, I was just in agony. My feet were alternating between numb and hurting, and my saddle, well, I'm not getting back on my bike for a few days, let's put it that way. Luckily I'd remembered my gloves this time, so my hands weren't numb, and I wasn't having trouble shifting this time.  Carl and I decided that instead of remaining on rt 90 when it cornered by the Triangle restaurant, we were going to go straight. I'm sure this is where all my milage got cut down, as my ride only turned out to be 86 miles instead of 92, but at that point, I didn't care. I just wanted to finish the ride. We came up to the intersection of this road with rt 34B maybe 3 or 4 miles later and stopped. Soon, Charles and the two Chris's came through and stopped with us. Riding with a group of people provided me with some desparately needed motivation. We came down into Lansing, and I knew that big climb was ahead of us near the high school. I told them I was walking it, and Chris O. said, "Oh, you can do it. Just get into that lowest gear and spin!" And so I did. And so I made it up the hill. And from there, it was all downhill, as I had decided to take rt 34 down the hill back into town. None of that Cayuga Heights and extra miles junk for me. I just want to be home! I finally walked through my door and literally collapsed on the floor, sweating bucket, in my living room with a fan blowing down on me. My husband just shook his head and smiled at me.  "Fun ride, huh?" he asked. "Yeah, I guess so. I'm probably NOT going on the 100 mile ride next Sunday though." I responded, which resulted in another head shake on his part.
So, since I'd been off the bike for two weeks, I decided to take the 40 mile route option rather than the 65 mile route.  I met the group up in Dryden at the Post Office, and there was a fairly small group of people, maybe 15 riders.  The couple was back on their tandem bike again.  That thing is awesome looking.  A very nice cannondale, beautiful!  I stayed with the group for about 3 or 4 miles before falling behind.  I wasn't expecting to keep up with anyone, though, so that wasn't disappointing.  Having just begun a new job, I haven't had much time to myself lately, so I was looking forward to 40 people-free, conversation-free miles. As it was though, Charles as usual feels compelled to wait around for me and accompany me on these rides.  I don't mind, as he usually stays back just enough so I have him within eyesight, but then I feel bad because I don't think he's getting the ride that he would like to do.  Oh well.   The first half of the ride was fairly easy.  It was also mainly along state highways, so there was a wide, comfortable shoulder for most of the ride.  And although it was a state highway, there wasn't much traffic at all.  There was a long, gradual ascent up a hill just outside of Marathon, and then of course a nice downhill going into the little town.  I was actually speeding for the first time in my life on a bike.  That gave me some sort of cheap thrill, as I was going 35 in a 30 mph zone. heh.  We reached a little gas station/convenience store in Marathon and stopped for some something to eat & drink.  The wind was starting to pick up by this point, so we were all riding in a long paceline.  I was doing really well, keeping up with everyone, but we just kept going up and up and up and finally I couldn't take it anymore!!  I slowed down, but FINALLY we reached the top of the hill and started going down.  Yay, FINALLY!  At the bottom of the hill, we turned left and started up yet another steep incline.  This one did me in, and I lost everyone again.  Even Charles pulled way ahead of me and out of eyesight.   This stretch was 7 miles along route 215 into Virgil.  It seemed to me that it was taking FOR-EV-ER!!!  So I pulled over and consulted my cue sheet to make sure I was headed in the right direction and hadn't missed a turn.  Well, I looked at the wrong line on the cue sheet, thinking I was on a different road, which I was only supposed to follow for about a mile.  So I thought I'd missed a turn.  So, I turned around and pedalled a couple hundred feet, but wasn't really wanting to backtrack, so I thought hard about where the road I was on went, and remembered that it came out right in Dryden.  So, cool!  So I went to turn around AGAIN, and here came splat #1 on the pavement.  Right in front of a huge line of cars, no less.  I got up and had two nice cuts across my left knee, and some mild road rash up my left arm below my elbow. Oh well.   So I started back on my way, and got about a half mile down the road, when I see two other bikers coming from the opposite direction.  It looked like Charles and I couldn't tell who the other person was.  But right at that moment, a bee flew inside my helmet and was angrily buzzing where it was caught.  I completely freaked out and the only thing I could think to do was get that helmet off!  So, I don't even think I applied the brakes, I just crashed into the very grassy ditch, disentangled myself, and got that helmet off before I got stung!  So, that was pretty stupid, but effective, as the bee flew off on it's merry way and I was left unstung.  I saw Charles and Chris waiting on the other side of the road waiting for a break in traffic to cross the road, and saw the concern in their faces.  So I yelled that I was fine, which I was.  The grass provided a nice, soft landing, and thank goodness I was wearing gloves, or my left hand would be all torn up.  As it is, I just have some scrapes in my pinky.   Anyway, so it turned out that I was heading in the proper direction, and I stayed with them for the remainder of the ride.  About this time something deep inside my right knee began screaming bloody murder.  I don't know if I'd been pushing the previous hills in too big of a gear, or if I did something during one of my falls, but I was forced to take it easy for the last few miles.  As we got outside of Dryden, we separated, since I had to go back to my car, and they were heading back to Ithaca.  I meandered around the outskirts of Dryden for a while, not quite sure where I was going, stopped and asked for directions, and finally made it back to my car.  I was not exhausted, but my knee was aching pretty good.  It feels fine now, a couple days later, so I don't think I did anything horrendous to it.  I should be fine for tomorrow night's easy, slow club ride. 
As he was changing it, Andrejs checked my front tire and thought that felt a bit soft, too. Kerri asked me if I'd pumped them up before I left, and I said no. "Oh, well when was the last time you pumped them up?" I kinda looked at her with this confused expression and responded that I hadn't pumped them up since I got the bike! She looked like she was going to choke! Andrejs was like, "You've *never* pumped your tires up???" Ummm....... okay, at this point I know there's OBVIOUSLY something wrong with the fact that I'm not pumping my tires up on a regular basis. So lesson learned: I should pump air into my tires on a very regular basis. I've read a few books on bicycle maintanence, and for the life of me, I can't recall any of them mentioning this little tidbit. Sheesh, they must think I'm a complete moron! I always wondered why I saw this one woman pumping her tires up before she took off on EVERY sunday ride. I was thinking "damn, she must have some bad tires; why not replace them?" Oh well..... now I know! Anyway, we set off on our ride. We got about 23 miles in, averaged about 14.5mph, which was good. They decided to take Iradell Road on the way back, my absolute faaavorite (heavy on the sarcasm there). I was getting closer to The Mother of All Hills, and thinking, "oh, you know, this really doesn't look that bad anymore." I'm halfway up it, thinking, "MMmmm, okay, it is still pretty challenging." I'm almost at the top, thinking, "HOLY MOTHER OF GOD I'M GONNA DIE! What the hell was I thinking back there, 'this isn't so bad'-- MY ASS! *GASP**PANT**SPUTTER*" But the nice thing about Iradell is that you go up this hill that's about a half mile long, if that, and then you get this nice two or three mile descent on the other side of it. It is *well* worth the effort. We crossed 96 and looked back to see a gorgeous pink and orange sunset illuminating the western sky. It was a great ride. When we got back to the parking area, Andrejs suggested that next week we meet at Cass park and go up Bostwick Rd. I thought Charles was going to choke on his water. He looked at Andrejs with this expression that clearly said, "You've got to be kidding me." and said, "What?" And Andrejs had this expression on his face in response to Charles's that said "C'mon you pansy. I'm not proposing Mt. Everest here," and said, "Yeah, Bostwick. I think we should do that next week." And I'm thinking to myself, "I'm game, cuz I wanna know if I can do it. Do I have what it takes? I think I do. I need to prove it to myself." In the end, we decided to wait until later in the season, when the nights were short and we didn't have a lot of time to ride. Because Bostwick in only maybe two miles long, but it's two miles of about 8% grade the entire way up. It ought to be interesting. :)
Already the leaves were falling and lightly coated the black pavement.  After a couple miles of climbing, the road went into gentle rollers for the remaining 10 miles or so.  It went through thick, damp forests, and goldenrod blanketed the fields and hills that were scattered in between the forest.  It was very pretty, contrasting with the brilliant red of the Sumac trees interspersed throughout.  I can't wait until the leaves reach their peak to do some of these rides.  I love the colors of fall:  deep purples, bright reds, golden yellows.  Toward the end of the road, down towards the town of Chemung and 17C, the road got *really* rough.   Up 'til that point, I'd been riding with Andrejs, who was taking it easy after doing a bunch of hill climbing the day before.  Me, I have no excuse.  I'm just slow.  :)  Toward the end of Wyncoop, we picked up Charles, who was sitting along side the road.  He had lost the lead cyclists, was unsure of which direction he was supposed to go next. Discomfort aside, we turned east onto 17C and rode down through Chemung.  Shortly after leaving Chemung, we turned right onto this narrow road that eventually turned into a recreational pathway that ran along the Sesquahanna River for a mile or so.  That was absolutely gorgeous!   So that ended and spit us out on an overpass that went over rt 17 and back to 17C.  We headed through Waverly, and decided to cut the road a bit short and make it a little easier (ie. less hilly) and took rt. 34 north.   We hooked back up with the pre-determined route from there.  Route 34 was good; they'd just repaved a good portion of it, so it was nice and smooth.  A lot of traffic though, and I don't particulary enjoy inhaling car/truck exhaust.  We reached the end of Dean Creek rd, which was one of the roads that the map showed, and headed up (and up and up and up) that road.  It was a much more gradual climb than it would've been if we'd followed our original route.  By that time, it was 11:30 and the sun was getting pretty hot.     We got to the top of the hill, and took a break.  Pretty soon, the lead group of cyclists came huffing up the hill.  They were quite shocked to see us, and rightly so.  We made some jokes about blowing by them so fast that they hadn't even seen us.  I trapped Dan, who I hadn't seen in a couple months,  with conversation, and pretty much rode the remaining 5 or 6 miles with him.  The rest of the group plowed on ahead and had their bikes all loaded into their cars by the time Dan and I pulled in.  It was such a gorgeous day.  I really hope the 50 mile ride next weekend is as nice! 
The air was still fairly cool as I loaded my bike onto the rack on my car and started out on the 30 minute drive over to Watkins Glen.  Thankfully, the irritating Slow Driver whom I always seem to get stuck behind when I'm running late was nowhere in sight!  I pulled into the marina parking lot a few minutes before 11am, and saw several other people unloading bikes and putting on cycling gear.  There were the Big Horn Velo women, and a few other people who sometimes join the Velos, plus Andrejs and myself from the FLCC.  I put on my own accessories and soon afterward, we embarked on our 50 mile journey.   We started up the long, steep 1.5 mile climb out of Watkins Glen.  I felt like I did much better this time than when we came up this hill for the Seneca Lake ride last month.  Perhaps it's just because I was with a group that was going my speed, and I wasn't passed by 15 other people and left in the dust.  Andrejs, Amy, and I reached the top of the climb and waited about 5 minutes for the rest of the group.  We couldn't see them coming at all, so we decided to keep going.  We would stop in Dundee and wait for them to catch up at that point.  The beginning of this ride was familiar.  The first 3 or 4 roads we took were the same roads that we'd taken on the Seneca Lake ride. After about six miles, we began turning west, however, and departed from the northern-bound Seneca Lake route.   We went along some rolling hillsides for a couple miles before starting down a long, nearly 2 mile descent.  It was great fun going down, but as Amy commented, it was not going to be quite as much fun on the way back up it.  I decided not to think about it until the time came.  We turned onto another rural road, and then came to 14A, which led into Dundee.  We followed that for about 5 miles, and that again, was mostly downhill.  We reached a gas station in the center of the little town, and waited for the rest of the group to show up. We ended up waiting nearly half an hour.  We ate some food, drank some fluids.  Andrejs and I talked about riding the trail along the "Grand Canyon of the East" down in PA.  I've heard a lot about this place, and I'm quite curious about it.  We decided to maybe organize a ride next month for that.  Then we wondered who was doing the full century ride, and gee, where was Charles?  We would've thought he'd be riding today.  The other riders pulled in, and Andrejs, Amy, and I decided to head out again.  I was getting cold. The sun had ducked behind a cloud when we arrived, it seemed, and hadn't come back out.  We were just about to take off when who should arrive, but Charles!  He said he'd started out at the normal noon take-off time, and he was the only one there.  I was flabbergasted, for lack of a better word.  "Wait a minute.  You started out a full 45 minutes after we did, and 15 miles later you've already caught up to us?"   Andrejs and Amy quickly pointed out that we'd been sitting here for almost half an hour, so we really weren't that far ahead of him.     The four of us started out again, and my legs felt like leaden weights.  Augh, it had taken me 10 out of the 15 miles we'd just ridden to warm up, and now it was going to take me another 10 miles to warm up again.   We headed out 14A again and turned off onto Chubb Hollow.  We received a full taste of Amish life in central NY along this road.  We passed at least 3 horse drawn carriages and at least 4 groups of young Amish men riding bicycles going in the opposite direction.   We pedaled a few more miles, and began to turn back towards Watkins Glen.  We went along a short section of rt 414 past a vineyard, and the smell of grapes was absolutely divine.  We came off the highway and went to the opposite extreme, where we had to do a little rough riding into a gulley on a dirt road.  The section of dirt road was only about a quarter of a mile long, so that wasn't too bad.  All too soon, it seemed, we were back at the top of the hill coming out of Watkins Glen.  "Check your brakes!" Charles joked as we began the quick descent back into town.  We flew down the hill, dodging some nasty potholes in the road, and before we knew it, we were back at the marina.  Somehow, we'd only ended up with 43 miles on our odometers.  Amy was determined to reach 50 miles, so I rode down to Montour Falls with her, and then around a few blocks in town to get the full 50 miles in.  Around 3:45pm, we had our bikes packed up and we headed home.  I had decided not to hang around for two more hours and enjoy the steak dinner to follow, but even so, it was an enjoyable ride.
Anyway, so I frantically ran to a local sporting goods store to buy a long sleeve dri-fit t-shirt, warmer socks, and a fleece head band thingy to keep my ears warm before heading home to load my bike on the car.  Seriously, wasn't it just last week that I was at the Bike Rack telling Gary, "Those gloves are too warm.  That jacket's too heavy.  I don't need those yet."  Should've gotten them!  I got to the store, and the wind practically ripped the door off its hinges as I cracked it open.  "Ugh," I thought.  "Am I seriously thinking of going riding tonight?  Maybe the wind isn't as bad on the *other* side of the lake."  No, I'm not demented or anything.  So, I bought my goods in a hurry, nicely brushing off the sales clerk who was trying to flirt with me, and maniacally drove home.  As I flitted around the house pulling my long tights on, my new shirt, socks, etc., my husband came home.   I wondered at him if anyone else would show up for the ride, and he replied that there probably would be, since there were all kinds of crazy people out there.  Hmm... thanks Honey.   So I again, maniacally drove up to the meeting place, conveniently ignoring the temperature gauge as I passed the bank.  I was afraid if I actually saw how cold it was, I would turn around and go back home.  I got to the parking lot and sat in the car for a few minutes, prolonging my comfort in my heated car.  I had passed Andrejs hoofing it up the hill, so I knew at least he would be there.  In a couple minutes, another car pulled in, and a guy named Jason asked me if this was the meeting spot for the Easy Ride.  "Yup," I replied, and he parked his car.  We both started unloading our bikes and worried to each other about the lack of clothing we were wearing.  He at least had a thick pullover on under his windbreaker.  Soon Andrejs reached us, and then Charles arrived.  We set off pretty quickly soon thereafter.   It didn't take me too long to warm up.  We have to climb a hill shortly after starting out, so that warmed me up.  The going wasn't too bad.  The air was very crisp....  very.  But it was pleasant.  I really love fall.  There's nothing better than being outside during the fall.  The colors are awesome, and they are even more awesome when they're illuminated by the setting sun.    And the clouds in the sky made for a truly magnificent sight.  They were these HUGE, thunderhead-type clouds, but white with streaks of gray instead of all gray or black.  But they were really high and voluminous, and the sun was setting in the opposite hemisphere of the sky, which made these clouds all pink and orange with streaks of gray throughout.  Beautiful!  Gorgeous!    I think by this point, we'd gone about halfway or maybe 2/3 of the way through our ride.  The sun had set.  The air was getting even colder, and it was getting fairly dark.  I can't tell you how many deer we saw last night.  It seemed every road we turned onto, a group of 8+ deer would run across the road, scattering.  We saw them out in the fields, too.  They would see us and their little white flag tails would raise to alert the others as they bounded away.   Coming down Iradell Road and across 96, back to DuBois road was an interesting experience.  It was almost completely dark by that point.  But the skies were clearing up, and a few early stars were shining, and the half-moon illuminated the landscape fairly well.  My night-time vision is still fairly sharp, so I wasn't having too much trouble seeing, even though I don't have a head light (I've decided that's my next investment, along with thicker gloves and some sort of foot protection).  I think all four of us were pretty chilled to the bone, so we weren't talking.  We were concentrated on wandering down the darkened roads without running into any huge potholes and getting back to our cars.  I did look up long enough to watch the moon for a bit.  Okay, now I can understand the attraction of night riding.  It's very peaceful and solitary.  All I could hear was the sound of the bikes' tires rolling along the pavement.  I saw Andrejs up ahead, and noticed plumes of steam coming out of his mouth when he exhaled.  "Just how cold out here is it?" I wondered to myself.   We got back to our cars, hands and feet thoroughly frozen.  My legs weren't faring too much better, but still, I felt invigorated.  This isn't enough to deter me from riding; I just need warmer clothing!!  Anyway, looking back at yesterday's weather forecast, I see that the temp was about 40 degrees (F) when we started out, and about 35 degrees when we ended our ride.  Brrrrrrrrrrrr!!!!   Warmer clothes, definitely. 
So, we all met at 10am.  We actually didn't get started until about 10:20, as one of the ladies discovered a flat tire when she arrived.  Better to find it then than while riding!  Unfortunately for me, none of the people I normally ride with showed up, so I prepared for doing the 40 mile trip alone.  There's no way in hell I could keep up with the group that did show up.  Kind of a bummer, but it was such a beautiful day....  who cared?  I stayed with the group for about 3 miles before getting dropped on the rolling hills on Ellis Hollow Rd.  I had decided to bring my Canon EOS with me that day to get some nice shots.  I keep writing about all these rides, but never get any photos to go with them.  I felt confident enough that I wouldn't be falling over that I could finally take my camera with me.   This route is quite familiar to me, as it's a variation of the White Church-Coddington route that Sarah F. and I used to do on Tuesday nights.  I got to the top of the hill just before Ellis Hollow descends down to 79, and stopped to admire the view.  I took a couple photos before continuing on.   I got to the intersection of 79 and had to wait for a few minutes because there was a ton of traffic.  I shook my head in exasperation as some idiot turning onto the road I was waiting on decided to cut the corner short and turn into the oncoming lane rather than going AROUND me and turning into the correct lane.  What the hell is wrong with people?  It's like they see a bike and instantaneously transform into Idiot Driver.  That's just as bad as the morons who pull up beside me on the left to make a left hand turn, when *I'M* trying to make a left hand turn, and am signalling my intentions.  Um, DUH!  Gee, don't take a few extra seconds to wait now!!  Idiots!  Anyway, I traveled the short distance down 79 to the right hand turn onto Boiceyville rd, which connected to Valley rd.  I stopped here to consult with my cue sheet and chat with the horses who live on the farm at that intersection.  I reaffirmed my directions and continued west/south on Valley rd, and then took a left onto Old 76 Road.  This road was 2.5 miles of long, gradual incline.  I shifted down into my granny gear and just spun away at a slow, comfortable pace.  I like this road despite the climbing because of the cliffs on the left side, and the cool stream meandering along the right hand side of the road.  I stopped and took a couple photos of the stream.  It looked awesome with all the orange and yellow fallen leaves blanketing the stream bed.   I got back on the bike and kept going.  About a quarter of a mile later I saw two dogs standing in the road.  Ugh, I groaned to myself.  I braced myself for a few seconds of yelling at the dogs, but they seemed more interested in the car that had pulled into the driveway behind me than in me.  Phew.  Kept pedaling, pedaling, oh, I think this might be the top of the hill!  I thought to myself.  I reached the top and saw that it began climbing once again after a short flat distance.  Grrrr.  I *hate* these trick hills!  Finally I reached the turnoff onto South/Honeypot Rd, which was yet again, MORE CLIMBING!  Wheeee!   Spinning in my big gear, I reached to top of that ascent about a half mile later and FINALLY a downhill!  I cruised down the hill and saw my fellow FLCC'ers congregating in the valley.  Two bikes were laid down flat, strongly resembling horses that had to be shot due to broken legs.  I pulled up and two of the riders were fixing a flat tire on one of the "dead" bikes.  So I stopped and waited with the group until they got the tube changed.  We climbed up another short hill, and ahhhh, finally a reward!  A long descent down!  I cruised down the hill averaging between 34-38mph the entire way.  And of course, with the downhills, there must be the ups, once again.  I was already behind, as usual, but got completely dropped again on these climbs up yet more hills.  I didn't mind too much though, as I was seeing some awesome views and wanted to stop for more photos.  If I'd been with the group, I wouldn't have been so willing to stop and take pictures.  Since I was already dropped, who cares if I stop?  I got to the top of yet another long hill, that had some fairly steep parts to it.  Again, more breath taking views.  And yay, another long descent on the other side, all the way into Candor!  I got to the bottom of the hill, which spit me out on 96B and the convenience store, where the rest of the FLCC'ers were resting.   At this point, the group split into two factions:  those of us who were content with the original 40 mile route, and those that wanted to extend it into a 60+ mile route.  I was, of course, a member of the former.  :)  There were 7 of us, and even though I was really pushing myself, I managed to keep up with them for the second half of the ride home.  The downside to this was that I felt like I couldn't stop to take photos because I didn't want to hold them up, so I didn't get any more pictures for the ride.  The rest of the way back was fairly easy.  There weren't any long, gradual inclines, or even any steep inclines, aside from two stretches that were only about a quarter of a mile in length each.  There were just a lot of rolling hills.  When we were sailing down Brooktondale road, again, we broke into two more groups-a group that felt they needed to do more climbing and headed up Besemer and Snyder Hills, and myself and two other guys who felt we'd done enough climbing for the day.   I ended the ride feeling as though I'd just gotten my second wind!  I averaged 15mph, so that was pretty good for me.  I was thinking maybe I should've gone on that 60+ mile route.....   Oh well, there will be many more rides to come.  Not this season, but next....
